title: Many Happy Returns
description: MY grandfather, who grew up in what was once Prussia, got his first taste of the American West from Karl May, a 19th-century German author who wrote about the prairie with uncanny vividness considering that he had never seen it.

title: THE WORLD HAS NEVER BEEN QUITE THE SAME
description: Drew Middleton's article ''The World Has Never Been Quite the Same'' (Sept. 3) brought back memories of the early days of the war. I had arrived in England in early August, a Czechoslovak refugee, and the start of the war was almost a relief, an event that we knew had to come.

title: 1929 Aviation Feat Commemorated
description: SIXTY years ago, an aviation legend climbed aboard an airplane, placed a canvas hood over its cockpit, took off, circled and landed without ever having seen the ground.

title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER
description: MILE ZERO By Thomas Sanchez. 349 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about airline safety included incorrect figures from the National Transportation Safety Board. In 1979, 354 people were killed in accidents involving large commercial jet flights flown by United States airlines. This year 277 have been killed.

title: BUT NOAH WAS NOT A NICE MAN
description: A HISTORY OF THE WORLD IN 10 1/2 CHAPTERS By Julian Barnes. 309 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: In Search of An Ancient Mediterranean
description: DESPITE HAVING SPENT MORE THAN TWO decades living and traveling along its shores, I often had the sense that I had never really seen the Mediterranean - at least not as I had envisioned it after my horizons (not to mention my expectations) had been lifted by the lyricism of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Andre Gide, Norman Douglas and Lawrence Durrell. Whether I visited Spain's Costa del Sol or a Greek island, the French Riviera or the ruins at Carthage, the roads were clogged with cars, the beaches seemed a solid rump- and bosom-scape of tanning bodies, and the sea was iridescent with oil slicks and dead fish. So when my wife recently suggested that we take a hiking trip through Cinque Terre, a section of Liguria in northern Italy, I agreed to go, but harbored no high hopes.

title: Wine; VINO FINO
description: POOR MICHAEL Broadbent. He bit off, as they say, rather more than he could chew. Mr. Broadbent, if you didn't know, is the urbane wine director of Christie, Manson & Woods International, the London auction house better known simply as Christie's. The job requires an immense knowledge of wine, of course, and Mr. Broadbent has demonstrated his considerable erudition in countless public appearances, hundreds of articles and some excellent books.

title: A Cross Between Buckminster Fuller And Buck Rogers
description: Paolo Soleri is a frustrating figure to put your finger on: the parts of him do not quite fit together. Architect, scientist, visionary, philosopher and engineer, Soleri is truly successful only as a visionary. His architecture hovers between the magical and the totalitarian; it is late Frank Lloyd Wright blown up to gargantuan scale. His scientific ideas are a cross between Buckminster Fuller and Buck Rogers; his philosophical musings read like Khalil Gibran rewritten by Gertrude Stein, and his engineering designs, which pretend to a noble purity, are in fact quite complex and romantic.

title: A Bid to Reap Profits From a Trimmer Pig
description: Consider the pig. It has a public relations problem. That erstwhile tub of lard apparently has 50 percent less fat than it did 20 years ago but few consumers know it.

title: THE TRUE SPICE OF SICHUAN
description: Even with my Cantonese ancestral and culinary roots, I have always had a passion for the fiery foods of Sichuan. A year or so ago, in the markets, restaurants and food stalls of the region, I finally tasted the real thing (not Taiwan- or Hong Kong-influenced or, even worse, Americanized - the foods with the * next to the menu listing). I found a food flavored with freshly ground dried chilies and Sichuan peppercorns, lightly roasted in the wok and freshly ground. The revelation was the subtle, haunting flavor of the Sichuan peppercorn, which loses its pungency and aroma by the time it is exported. It left me with a longing to find this spice in its purest form.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Posting on Sept. 17 on the renovation of a building at 555 Broadway contained several inaccuracies. The cost of the project, between Prince and Spring Streets in SoHo, will exceed $12 million when it is completed by the end of the year. The Vrej Baghoomian art gallery has taken 12,000 square feet on the second floor.

title: Man to Appeal Ruling on McKinney Estate
description: The man who claims to have been the late Congressman Stewart McKinney's lover for five years plans to appeal a probate court ruling that essentially denies his claims to the estate.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: 'A Jeffersonian Compact'; The Statement by the President and Governors
description: AT the end of the education conference last week at the University of Virginia, President Bush and the country's governors issued what they called ''a Jeffersonian compact to enlighten our children and the children of generations to come.'' Declaring that ''the time for rhetoric is past,'' they issued this statement.

title: The Graying of America's Countryside
description: WHEN Helen Augelli retired as the principal's secretary at Newtown, Conn., High School in 1986, she and her husband, Joseph, moved to Kitty Hawk on the North Carolina Outer Banks. They had summered there for years, bought a building lot a few years ago, and when the time came, moved into their beach house to stay.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Realty Giants Expanding in Westchester
description: LEAD: LARGE real estate companies are expanding and reorganizing their operations in Westchester County, a move they say will bring better service to their customers.

title: >Answering The Mail
description: Q. My screened porch has a concrete slab floor. For years, I have been painting this floor with an acrylic concrete deck paint, and in April the paint bubbles and lifts in large sections. I scrape these areas and then repaint the floor, but the bubbling and separating grow worse each year. Is there a way to correct this?

title: The Great Theater That Is Munich
description: WHEN I GET TO MUNICH, THIS IS WHAT I do. I check into the Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten - if I can afford it, which is not every year -and I take a room overlooking a quiet side street from which I can see the unmistakable upper bulge of the rebuilt opera house (which in Munich is called the National Theater). That bulge is to me what the Eiffel Tower is to the visitor to Paris - the unmistakable, indispensable profile that serves as both compass and landmark. Unlike the Eiffel Tower, however, it carries a secret message. For the enthusiast it is, in fact, a bulge that signals the imminence of some of the most exalted of human pleasures.

title: Chinese Specialties Served at the Grill
description: A HUGE grill manned by two or three chefs and the barbecue meals it produces are the cornerstone of Khan's Mongolian Garden in Stamford, and the grill is what sets this newcomer apart from other Chinese restaurants in the area.

title: Victor Gaetan Weds Eleanor Kennelly
description: Eleanor Bride Kennelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Kennelly of Hartford, was married yesterday to Victor Alexandre Gaetan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ion Gaetan of Ploesti, Rumania. The Rev. John Gigrich officiated at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington.

title: Jury Duty: Hard Time
description: A recent cartoon in the Wall Street Journal summed up jury duty (About Long Island: They Also Serve Who May Only Wait'' Sept. 3) when it showed the foreman reading, ''We find the defendant guilty and recommend he be sentenced to jury duty.'' Marjorie Fener Hempstead

title: Elizabeth Mason, Executive, Weds
description: Mary Elizabeth Mason, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stayton Mason Jr. of Roslyn Estates, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert John Hay Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hay of Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Lawrence Costello performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I.

title: The Battle Is Joined Against the Mighty Flea
description: THEY were everywhere. On the floor. The furniture. The cat. Me. The futility of battling an army of nearly microscopic, indefatigable creatures called fleas has left me confident that roaches won't be the lone survivors of a nuclear disaster.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: No. Certainly he's not always a model player. But the Mets would miss his power. So a hasty trade when his value is down would be a serious mistake. I wouldn't want a whole team of Darryls. But one is certainly a good thing. MARC I. WHINSTON Flushing, Queens

title: Top Dogs Aplenty, But Few Top Hats
description: The only top hat seen at the Metropolitan Opera's opening Monday was worn by David McDermott, an artist. The opera was ''Aida,'' and Michel Orloff, a descendant of Ismail Pasha, who commissioned the opera in l870, attended. Later, at the Waldorf-Astoria, Saul Steinberg rang the dinner bell at a dance honoring Carolyne Roehm and Henry Kravis for their philanthropy. The party benefited the Burden Center for the Aging. On Tuesday at Macy's, the Bide-a-Wee Home Association invited pet lovers to attend a coronation of Mario Buatta as the King of Canines, a step up for the designer known as the Prince of Chintz. The same evening, paintings of dogs and horses by Bernard de Claviere opened at the Habsburg, Feldman Gallery celebrating the 60th anniversary of Seeing Eye Inc. On Wednesday, back at the Waldorf, 1,000 guests at ''Cabaret '89'' helped raise a million dollars for the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Life Style: Sunday Outing; In a Temple Setting, Tibetan Artifacts
description: The Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art, on Lighthouse Hill on Staten Island, aims for authenticity. To arrive at the museum, visitors who use public transportation must take a 10-minute walk uphill, the traditional path to arrive at a Buddhist monastery. The humility of the climb is intentional.

title: Fallback Scheme
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Copland: 'Appalachian Spring' Suite, 'Short Symphony' and Other Works Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Deutsche Grammophon 427 335; CD and cassette. Copland originally wrote ''Appalachian Spring'' for 13 instruments, all that could fit in the pit for the 1944 premiere of the Martha Graham ballet - a version he suppressed once the suite for full orchestra caught on. With his concise and rhythmically exciting ''Short Symphony'' (1933) he did something of the reverse; since it proved too difficult for many orchestras, he made a sextet setting, which we are likelier to encounter. Here are variants on both originals - the ''Spring'' Suite in a chamber orchestration (the 13 instruments plus extra strings), the symphony in a chamber orchestra reduction devised by Dennis Russell Davies - along with chamber orchestra renditions of ''Quiet City'' and ''Three Latin American Sketches.'' Orpheus plays with verve if not an especially original point of view. In DG's recording, close and striking, the ''Short Symphony'' is a real grabber. - Mark Swed Richard Strauss: 'Aus Italien,' Four Orchestral Songs Felicity Lott, soprano (Songs); Scottish National Orchestra conducted by Neeme Jarvi. Chandos 8744; all three formats. Like Mendelssohn and Berlioz before and Elgar after him, Richard Strauss knew how to capture his glowing youthful Italian impressions in music. The designation ''Symphonic Fantasy'' fits the early ''Aus Italien'' (1886) well. Those who tend to dismiss it as a ''travelogue'' because of its symphonic elaboration of the familiar ''Funiculi, Funicula'' in the final movement are bound to overlook the subtleties and splendid colors of the preceding three - particularly the third movement (''On the Shores of Sorrento''), which points ahead to later Strauss. The performance, apparently the first on CD, is vigorously led by Neeme Jarvi and, save for a tremulous oboe solo, well played. The songs - ''Winterweihe,'' ''Mein Auge,'' ''Der Rosenband'' and ''Befreit,'' rapturous utterances in radiant orchestral settings - are faultlessly sung by Felicity Lott. - George Jellinek 'New Music Series,' Vol. 1: Works by Korde, Lippe, Mabry, Risset, Rubin, Scelsi and Xenakis Robert Black, double bass; Walter van Hawe, alto recorder; Mel Cuthbertson, tuba; Holy Cross Chamber Players conducted by Toshimasa Francis Wada. Neuma CD 450-71; CD only. Neuma, a label based in Acton, Mass., offers seven recent works in a sampler reminiscent of the new-music collections the major labels offered in the 1960's; indeed, a 60's avant-garde esthetic pervades the disk. Most enjoyable are two electronic pieces. Jean-Claude Risset's ''Contours,'' a tactile and sometimes spacily atmospheric work, is a study in thematic transformation; and Anna Rubin's ''Crying the Laughing and Golden'' uses the sound of laughter and whispering to create an evocative, intensely emotional soundscape. Interesting too are the glittering, variegated ''Chamber Piece'' by Shirish Korde, and Drake Mabry's ''12.5.83,'' a fleet virtuosic essay for alto recorder. - Allan Kozinn Mendelssohn: Concertos in D minor: for Violin and Strings; for Violin, Piano and Strings Gidon Kremer, violin; Martha Argerich, piano; Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Deutsche Grammophon 427 338; CD and cassette. It's in just this sort of peripheral repertory, which requires first-rate performances to make it at all effective, that we've too often had to settle for well-meant mediocrity. Nothing of the sort here, as two supreme virtuosos, admirably supported by the conductorless Orpheus ensemble, throw their formidable artistic weight into impetuous, committed and compelling performances of two seldom-heard works Mendelssohn composed at ages 13 and 14. Even given such high-powered treatment, the Violin Concerto of 1822 cannot rival its famous E minor counterpart of 1844 in formal concision or lyrical refinement, but both youthful works emerge here as strong, vibrant creations, fully worthy of broader exposure in such top-flight performances. - James R. Oestreich Davis: 'The Silents: Musical Scores for Classic Silent Films' London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Carl Davis. Virgin Classics 7 90785; CD and cassette. This music is the sort that makes the snobs shout ''derivative.'' Let them shout. They'll take nothing away from Carl Davis's gifts as a composer of memorable Hollywood music in the grand old tradition - eclectic but always expressive of the dramatic situation and handled with consummate flair. Sometimes Mr. Davis adapts existing music - Gottschalk tunes and traditional Chinese melodies for ''Broken Blossoms,'' hunks of ''Scheherazade'' for ''The Thief of Baghdad.'' But such original material as ''The Eagle of Destiny'' for ''Napoleon,'' the Garbo theme for ''Flesh and the Devil'' and the nightmarish Prokofievian cyclone music in ''The Wind'' stand securely on their own. The London Philharmonic plays well, and Virgin offers good sound. - Barrymore L. Scherer POP/JAZZ Jefferson Airplane: 'Jefferson Airplane' Epic 45271; all three formats. Reunited after 17 years, the Jefferson Airplane still sounds like a collection of quarrelsome bohemians with eccentric interests. ''Summer of Love,'' Marty Balin's eulogy to the hippie dream, is the likeliest hit. Paul Kantner's ''Planes'' exalts the Freudian implications of air travel. Grace Slick's ''Panda'' pleads for the salvation of the species from extinction, and her ''Common Market Madrigal'' compares erotic love with European tourism. The portentous political anthem ''Solidarity'' lists Bertolt Brecht as one of its collaborators, and the mystical ''Wheel'' proclaims, ''From the heart of the volcano the future is born.'' With all its windy blather and quirkiness, the album sounds too fresh to seem a cynical cashing-in on nostalgia. - Stephen Holden Archie Brownlee and the Five Blind Boys of Mississippi: 'You Done What the Doctor Couldn't Do' Gospel Jubilee RF-1402 (Down Home Records, 10341 San Pablo Ave., El Cerrito, Calif. 94530); LP only. The best tracks on this anthology, taken from 1948 through 1959, achieve the forward motion of a hurtling train, the deep intensity of the best art. Archie Brownlee, one of hard gospel's most influential singers, had a voice that could balloon at the end of a phrase, turn from velvet to crushed rock on a syllable. The group, which began at the Piney Woods School for blind children in Mississippi, cushions Mr. Brownlee's expeditions into passion with purring, organlike chords, occasionally backed by guitar and drums. But it's Mr. Brownlee's voice, gashing through the accompaniment, signifying a man caught up in the passion of belief, that makes these numbers work. - Peter Watrous 'Siya Hamba: 1950's South African Country and Small Town Sounds' Original Music OMA 111 (R. D. 1, Box 190, Lasher Road, Tivoli, N. Y. 12583); LP only. While recent commercial recordings from South Africa have lately been reaching the United States, ''Siya Hamba'' is a find - a glimpse into the urban and rural music of the 1950's. The urban music on side two shows how South Africans assimilated big-band pop and jump-blues; the music uses suave, jazzy harmony choruses behind powerful lead singers whose melodies still have traditional shapes. But the rural music on side one, recorded in the countryside, is the revelation. Using imported instruments like harmonica, concertina, autoharp or guitar in place of previous generations' traditional instruments, the music is raw, rhythmic and utterly joyous, with shouting, laughing audiences to prove it. - Jon Pareles Rhonda Clark: 'Between Friends' Tabu; all three formats. Ms. Clark has a pinched, tight voice that can get nasty, painted with touches of Dinah Washington or Esther Phillips's nasal tone. This is good, as her sound introduces a touch of reality into tunes heavy with ethereal synthesizer colors and distant, thumping bass lines. Recorded at Flyte Tyme Studios in Minneapolis and partially produced by Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis (the movers behind Janet Jackson, among others), Ms. Clark's debut album has the producer's special sound, clean, full of puffs of music and overdubbed voices. When she improvises, screaming through the breaks in the production on ''The Way You Are,'' it's obvious she's something special. - P. W.

title: Counted At Last
description: MY daughter would be proud of me. In my advanced middle age, I finally attended my first rally. And I stood up and was counted.

title: Windham Isn't Bowles
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Malloy, Student, Weds
description: Nancy Ann Malloy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Malloy of St. Louis and John's Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Andrew Axilrod, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Axilrod of New York. The Rev. Walter Modrys and the Rev. Paul G. Sheridan officiated at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: DATA BANK: Oct. 1, 1989
Something Basic Is Wrong in America
description: A serious look at the composition of the United States-Japan bilateral trade imbalance shows that the United States is becoming highly dependent on Japanese high-tech industrial products.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
U.S. Leaders: No Vision, All Expediency
description: LEAD: There was a time when American leaders were judged not by today's polls but by their vision for the future. In the public and private sectors, success was determined not by the speed with which one achieved it, but by the sturdiness of the foundation on which it was built. Those days are gone. Time after time, President Bush chooses the smooth waters of political expediency over the stormy seas of real issues and difficult choices.

title: Drug Agency Ends Its Investigation of Pilot
description: A newspaper reported today that Federal drug investigators have found no evidence of drug smuggling or gun running by a Washington lawyer whose small plane crashed into the Atlantic after an 800-mile flight with him unconscious at the controls.

title: POSTINGS: Where the Trains Run; 18 Duplex Condos in Midwood
description: The site, at Avenue I and East 16th Street in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, is not promising. On one side, the Q and D trains of the IND subway line go rattling by. A hundred feet away, the Long Island Rail Road runs four freight trains a night.

title: Lest Anybody Forget
description: To the Editor:

title: Episcopalians Compromise on Women's Role
description: The danger of a split in the Episcopal Church over the ordination of women as priests and bishops has receded after a compromise statement was unanimously adopted by the church's House of Bishops Thursday.

title: PROTESTS GO ON IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Scores of black and mixed-race families picnicked and swam at a white beach near Cape Town today, ignoring police officers who told them that they were breaking the law.

title: NONFICTION
description: WHITE BEARS AND OTHER UNWANTED THOUGHTS: Suppression, Obsession, and the Psychology of Mental Control. By Daniel M. Wegner. (Viking, $18.95.) Try - try as hard as you can - not to think about a white bear, says Daniel M. Wegner, a professor of psychology at Trinity University in San Antonio, at the start of his book, ''White Bears and Other Unwanted Thoughts.'' He is betting that you will be unable to do it. Try as you might, he proposes, the thought of a white bear will push its way into your head just because you're trying not to think of it. This, in a nutshell, is what Mr. Wegner's book is about. He argues that trying to distract yourself is only useful if the distraction is compelling in itself, and that we cannot disbelieve an idea unless we have another idea to put in its place. I found Mr. Wegner's theses interesting, but his execution boring. Mr. Wegner repeats himself a bit too much to sustain attention, and in particular he slips in the white bear story so often that it seems almost a nervous tic. I became particularly impatient when he dwelled at length on concepts that seem self-evident. For example, he writes in a chapter on self-distraction that people can become absorbed in ''things that provide good exercise for their abilities.'' Then he goes on for three long paragraphs, expounding on this idea. His second paragraph on the subject starts by saying: ''The good tennis player who takes on someone of equal ability, for example, will usually become absorbed with the game. The child who has just learned to cut paper dolls, too, may well become engaged in the experience. Many people find this kind of engagement in their work - if it is a proper challenge for them. Even washing dishes can be absorbing and interesting if you find it to be a challenge that just matches your abilities.'' I'd rather think about a white bear.

title: Coping in an Italian Castle
description: IT is called Castello di Polgeto, it's near Umbertide in Umbria and we rented its only ground-floor apartment. With it came our own cherry tree in full fruit, our own owl and cuckoo, our own private garden with two elegant cypresses flanked by a low stone wall. On one side of the garden stood a small stone barn where the previous owner had wintered his lemon trees; behind us rose a hollow 70-foot tower connected to a wing of the castle by the tower bridge under which we parked our car. Immediately below us on differing levels were other small walled gardens, one with a fountain, another a carp pool, the lowest the pretty castle swimming pool. Beyond this medieval privacy lay the intensely green swaying Umbrian landscape of farms, hayfields, olive groves and vineyards stopped abruptly by Monte Acuto's 2,500 feet.

title: Two Parties Agree to Endorse One Slate of Judicial Candidates
description: VOTERS in the county will face no significant judicial choices in the next three general elections, in the wake of decisions made by the two major political parties.

title: Bronx Man Beaten in Attack That Police Call Race-Related
description: A Hispanic man was severely injured as he was chased and beaten by a group of whites in the Belmont section of the Bronx early yesterday in what the police said was a racially motivated assault.

title: Hang On To the Old One
description: To the Editor:

title: Righetti Will Be a Starter Next Season
description: Dave Righetti's days as a Yankee relief pitcher are over. Next season, he will be a starter again.

title: Linda Buchanan Has a Wedding
description: Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Linda Vincent Buchanan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Buchanan of Madison, to David Coyne Flanagan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Flanagan of Norwich, N.Y. The Rev. Karen Murphy performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John Carroll, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
EXPLORING THE WORLD OF FOOD AND DRINK;
SUMMER'S SWEET RECAPTURED
description: LEAD: As a child in Virginia, I thought all food tasted delicious. After growing up I didn't think food tasted the same, so it has been my lifelong effort to try and recapture those good flavors of the past. Trying out old dishes, I remembered a wonderful dessert my mother used to make, called roly-poly.

title: How Velazquez Seizes The Truth That Is Art
description: I recall a trip uptown to the Hispanic Society prompted by Manet's ''Dead Christ and the Angels'' in the Met. I was a college student who could not believe that an old-fashioned painting could be at the same time so loose and so beautiful. But it was. Passages of Christ's body were painted with angular, creamy brushstrokes that appeared to be lifting off the canvas. This separation made me see that in Manet's hands, paint was alive and purposeful before it was used to form an illusion. It seemed such a natural way of saying (something I'm sure I wanted to hear then) that paint dictates painting. I had to see more of the source of Manet's method - Velazquez, the 17th-century Spaniard he called the painter of painters.

title: New Season's Theme is International
description: WITH Strindberg, Shakespeare and Shaw at Yale Rep, Buchner, Moliere and Wilde at Hartford Stage and Feydeau at the Long Wharf, the new theater season has the makings of an international playwrights festival.

title: THE WORLD HAS NEVER BEEN QUITE THE SAME
description: Anglomania is fine, but only up to a point. This is particularly true when you are a military-affairs columnist.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: For 33 years two countries have dominated the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl, now sponsored by Japan's NEC Corporation. Italy and the United States have won every event, 22 in all, since France won in 1956 in Paris.

title: A Doctor for Struggling Economies
description: If Hollywood were casting it, Jeffrey Sachs might be the Indiana Jones of economics.

title: At One Regatta, Friendly Rivalry
description: It wasn't until two weeks ago that the Italian team competing this weekend in the International Yacht Club Challenge learned it would be coming to New York.

title: San Francisco's Real Mission
description: EACH TIME AMERICA SEALS ME IN A laminate of deadlines and Dow Jones averages, bills due and bills payable, I journey to a place where urgencies fade, colors brighten and all claims on reality begin to look relative. Just a stroll down the hill - though, like a good Californian, I usually drive - leads me out of my silent, wind-scoured, chillingly pretty neighborhood into a raucous, mouldering, charmingly unscrubbed caldron. Suddenly, the sidewalks are bordered with azure tiles and doused with the perfume of rotting mangoes; the streets are serenaded by thumping basso laments broadcast from souped-up Chevys; the advertisements appeal to a dozen loyalties and languages. Black-shawled Guatemalan women ply the restaurants, peddling red carnations, followed by packs of Vietnamese urchins toting bags of fresh-picked garlics; each available clapboard wall bursts with murals of naked Aztec deities and painted jungles; every sight conspires to defeat grayness and to sabotage the straight-and-narrow. Where thousands have sought asylum before me, I am a refugee in reverse - fleeing the benefits of the Promised Land for the immigrant hothouse and global miscellany that is San Francisco's Mission District.

title: 'A History of the World in 10 1/2 Chapters'
description: Post-modernist in conception but accessibly straightforward in execution, Julian Barnes's fifth book is neither the novel it is presented as being nor the breezy pop-history of the world its title suggests. Influenced to varying degrees by such 20th-century presences as the inevitable Borges, Calvino and Nabokov, as well as by Roland Barthes and perhaps Michel Tournier among others, ''A History of the World in 10 1/2 Chapters'' is most usefully described as a gathering of prose pieces, some fiction, others rather like essays.

title: Lisa McCloskey Weds in Capital
description: Lisa Siobhan McCloskey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James McCloskey of Chevy Chase, Md., and George Joseph Brodmerkel 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Brodmerkel Jr. of Pittsburgh, were married yesterday at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington. The Rev. Percival D'Silva officiated at the Roman Catholic ceremony. Andre Taylor McCloskey was her sister's maid of honor. William Nadel was the best man.

title: For Peter Hall, the Curtain Keeps Rising
description: It was 1955, and Peter Hall, the 24-year-old son of an East Anglian railway clerk, was sitting in his office one morning at the Arts Theater in London when the telephone rang.

title: oalition Disbands After Primary
description: LEAD: LESS than a month after engineering the stunning defeat of two Suffolk County officials they regarded as their greatest enemies, an Island-wide coalition of Long Island developers, businessmen and labor leaders has quietly disbanded.

title: About Men; How I Spent My Summer Vacation
description: THIS IS WHAT IS FAC-ing me, for 18 years a confirmed city boy, as I drive a rented car from the Louisville airport to the small (population 800) Kentucky town where I grew up: a summer with my widowed mother, who lives alone in a house that once supported parents, four daughters, four sons, three dogs, a flock of Rhode Island Reds, a one-acre garden, 200 quail that my father brought home from the Rolling Fork Fish & Game Club as an experiment in re-establishing the birds in neighboring fields.

title: Army Marches Over Harvard
description: Army demonstrated clearly today why Ivy League schools no longer want any part of the Cadets on a football field.

title: Lawrence: Keepers Of the Flame
description: OUTSIDE THE LOBBY DOOR OF THE HOTEL LA FONDA DE Taos hangs a wooden sign: ''D. H. Lawrence, Author: Lady Chatterley's Lover. This is The Only Showing of the D. H. Lawrence Controversial Paintings since his Exhibition Was Permanently Banned by Scotland Yard, When his show Opened at the Warren Galleries, London, in 1929.''

title: Woman Scorned?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accountants Play for Laughs
description: Martin Edelstein, a New York accountant whose cheeky biography states that he co-edited ''Tax Planning for the Little People'' with Leona Helmsley, has a gripe. ''How come we never see movies where John Wayne is the head of the tax department?'' he protested. ''Or what about Conan the Certified Public Accountant or Friday the 15th?''

title: Griffith's 'Intolerance,' Given the Blush of Youth
description: Imagine an elephant as big as a brownstone, rearing back, straight up, on its hind legs. Place the pachyderm atop a column twice as high again. The column is on an arch, flanked by scores of stairs. Multiply by six, surround with stenciled walls taller than Times Square billboards, throw in a few more oversize elephants, sundry 10-foot lions and 5,000 antlike humans on a movie set.

title: J. W. Kirby Wed To Miss McCabe
description: Karen Lyden McCabe, a government securities marketing representative at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, and Jefferson Walker Kirby, an associate in the corporate finance department at the Bankers Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Starke S. Dillard, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert W. Ihloff. Mrs. Kirby, 24 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. McCabe of Westport, Conn. She is a graduate of Lafayette College, as is her husband. Her father is the president of the Onyx Corporation, a management consulting concern in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Film Festival; A Trip Into the Middle Ages, and a View of Langston Hughes
description: Both Meredith Monk's ''Book of Days'' and Isaac Julien's ''Looking for Langston'' are strong-minded films that juxtapose the past and the present; that is all they have in common. ''Book of Days,'' which transports its audience into the Middle Ages, has visual grace and a good deal of artistic success. ''Looking for Langston'' exhibits plenty of hubris in its approach to Langston Hughes and the Harlem Renaissance, but has the depth and style of an artsy television commercial. The films will be shown at Alice Tully Hall at 9 o'clock tonight as part of the New York Film Festival.

title: Seize The Moment
description: Secretary of State Baker is a political craftsman of uncommon toughness and skill, as the Democrats have learned to their regret. In his new role he may prefer the statesman's aura. But he has a chance now at a diplomatic prize that requires his political instincts.

title: A World of Pottery in Vermont
description: FINE handcrafts, especially pottery, have become a major attraction for visitors to southern Vermont. Whether the basic plan is to camp out under the summer stars, gaze at the fall foliage, or zoom down a sugar-white ski slope, more and more Vermont vacationers are visiting some of the region's many craft centers and artisans' studios, seeking something to take home that will not merely be a reminder of the trip but also a work of art.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ''. . . WHERE LOVE BEGINS.'' By Helga Sandburg. (Donald I. Fine, $20.95.) Carl Sandburg, biographer of Lincoln, champion of free verse and the rougher side of American life, was a complicated man. He also led a long and, in many ways, public life, so it should be a pleasure to read a biography recounting his private side written by one of his daughters, herself a poet, novelist and writer of children's books.

title: Morris Fox, Pharmacist, 102
description: Morris N. Fox, founder of the company that makes Smith Brothers cough drops, died Wednesday. He was 102 years old.

title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs
description: Crack, which has been devastating entire inner-city neighborhoods, has begun to claim significant numbers of middle- and upper-class addicts, experts have found.

title: Soviet Plant, U.S. Managers
description: LEAD: It is the last thing anyone would expect to see in the office of Charles W. Missler, a former Air Force captain and 30-year veteran of the defense and computer industries. But right next to the Stars and Stripes stands the flag of the Soviet Union, with hammer and sickle on a field of red.

title: How Much Does New Jersey Really Like Republicans?
description: ON a recent visit to New Jersey, President Bush portrayed the race for governor as a referendum not only on eight years of Republican leadership in Trenton, but on the national party's values and policies in the 1980's. Calling the New Jersey election ''crucial,'' Mr. Bush said, ''This election will decide whether New Jersey continues to have the kind of leadership which balances a sound economy and sound ecology, and whether its leadership says 'no' to higher taxes and 'yes' to extending the prosperity of the last eight years.''

title: WHAT A CHILD IS GIVEN
description: Unfortunately, the laws concerning secrecy in adoption records have not kept pace with findings in medicine and psychology. Only two states -Alaska and Kansas - give adult adoptees access to their birth records on demand, and the vast majority of other states have ''sealed records'' laws that effectively prevent reunions between adoptees and their birth families. I recently photographed an adult adoptee inside the Bureau of Vital Records in Manhattan, accompanied by her adoptive mother and her birth mother; despite the presence of all three parties, the bureau refused to allow this young woman to see her own birth certificate.

title: ANSWERS TO THE QUIZ ON PAGE 106
description: 1-L: Vienna. The headdress, in the Ethnological Museum, was acquired by Cortez and passed into Hapsburg hands, probably through Charles V.

title: THE FALL OF A FAMILY
description: THE GEORGICS By Claude Simon. Translated by Beryl and John Fletcher. 322 pp. New York: Riverrun Press. $29.95.

title: Selling Yourself on Madison Ave.
description: One day last March, Marc Eisenoff walked into the office of Ira Madris, deputy creative director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide advertising, to ask for a raise. The 39- year-old senior art director spotted one of the agency's executive recruiters. For a split second, he thought that might be standard procedure - but she wasn't smiling. He struggled with an overwhelming urge to turn and run. Then he was dismissed.

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Cuisine and a Sushi Bar Too
description: LEAD: PEONY, a five-month-old Oriental restaurant conveniently situated near the Somerset County Courthouse in Somerville, is an attractive upscale restaurant whose entrance is guarded by a large pair of ornamental Chinese dogs.

title: Japan's Market Is Closed Drum Tight
description: Just over a decade ago, the company I work for decided to enter the Japanese market with a high-tech amorphous metal alloy we had developed in our New Jersey laboratories. Determined to avoid the pitfalls that had doomed the efforts of so many other foreign companies on Japanese soil, we named a Japanese-born and educated executive who worked for Allied-Signal Inc. in the United States to head the effort in Tokyo. Fluent in the language and schooled in the nuances of doing business in Japan, he seemed an excellent choice to help us establish a Japanese beachhead. He also had the advantage of a joint venture with a Japanese business group, and a long-term commitment from Allied-Signal.

title: Stagflation for Female Engineers
description: When Andrea Robertson began studying electrical engineering five years ago at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, she was usually the only woman in the lecture halls.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TRIBUTE TO THOREAU

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A PLACE IN MIND. By Sydney Lea. (Scribners, $17.95.) The poet and essayist Sydney Lea's first novel is no material for a mini-series. Most of the action takes place, as the title suggests, in its hero's mind - or at his camp in the Maine woods. Brant Healey, a professor from Boston, avoids his roots whenever possible and retreats to McLean, a town whose name is shared by its river and its leading residents.

title: GOODBYE NEWARK: ROTH REMEMBERS HIS BEGINNINGS
description: Philip Roth's ''Goodbye, Columbus,'' published in 1959 as the title novella in a collection of stories, has turned out to be an enduring commentary on postwar America and, more specifically, the Jews who were part of it. ''Goodbye, Columbus'' won the author the National Book Award at the age of 26. Mr. Roth wrote this preface for the 30th anniversary edition of the book, published this month by Houghton Mifflin.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Strawberry's lack of maturity and lackadaisical play both on defense and offense make him expendable. He definitely should be traded to the American League for a number of quality players, while he still has value. By trading him, it may help him to grow up and also help the Mets, by showing that even big name stars can be traded. FRANK C. QUINN Port Washington, L.I.

title: The Sophisticated Traveler/Magazine Part 2
description: In the Middle Ages, pilgrims traveled for months in the quest for sacred places. Today's travelers go on different quests - the search for a radiant English landscape, a princely Indian capital, a perfect Pacific beach - and the best part is often the journey itself.

title: Africa Airports: Cautionary Tale
description: The day after a French airliner broke up over the desert of southern Niger, killing all 171 people on board, I arrived at the airport in Niamey, the capital of Niger, for my flight to Abidjan.

title: VICTORIES OF THE SPIRIT
description: We were delighted to see the magnificent pictures of the senior olympics in your magazine but were disappointed that you did not mention Washington University and its unique role in Olympic history.

title: Italy's Vin Santo: A Sip of Hospitality
description: IN Tuscany and neighboring Umbria, vin santo is the wine of hospitality. Whatever the time of day, a guest is offered a small glass of the amber dessert wine. ''It's the wine of hospitality, the wine of friendship and of courtesy,'' explains Giacomo Tachis, winemaker for the 650-year-old Tuscan firm Antinori. At one time, every family in the Tuscan countryside made some vin santo and had a prized barrel or two squirreled away in the attic. Chianti they made for sale, but vin santo was strictly for family use.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
For Trenton, a Proposal To Revitalize Its Downtown
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH downtown Trenton has been on the mend for five years, beyond the shiny new government and business office towers it remains a hodgepodge of parking lots, discount stores and time-worn buildings.

title: In 1990's, What Price Scarce Labor?
description: Workers in the 1990's will have one advantage they have lacked for nearly 25 years: scarcity. This shortage will have profound implications for both managers and employees into the 21st century, economists and labor experts say.

title: On Language; Country Matters
description: THE WHOLE COUN-try has gone >country.

title: Miss Wettlaufer, A Teacher, Weds
description: Jennifer Scott Wettlaufer, a daughter of Mrs. David Southam Innes Ker of Dundas, Ontario, and Conrad Penn Wettlaufer of Buffalo, was married last evening to Michael Kent Sednaoui, a son of Mrs. Michael C. Sednaoui of Washington and New Haven, Vt., and the late Mr. Sednaoui. The Rev. John Smiley officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Buffalo.

title:
MUSIC;
Buckley, Why On Earth? . . .
description: LEAD: Buckley: What made you decide to play a concerto with the Phoenix Symphony Orchestra? BUCKLEY: That's easy - I was invited. The interesting question is, what made the Phoenix Symphony Orchestra decide to invite me?

title: Candidate Is Ruled Off Ballot; Only Buffalo Mayor Remains
description: In a ruling that could leave Mayor James D. Griffin of Buffalo unopposed in his bid for a fourth term, a state judge last week invalidated the independent candidacy of a former chief city judge who was the runner-up to Mr. Griffin in the Democratic primary.

title: Paul Mavis Wed To Victoria Boies
description: Victoria Anne Boies, a daughter of Elaine Boies of Staten Island and the late Dr. Jack Jay Boies, was married yesterday to Paul Anthony Mavis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Nestor Mavis of Cedarhurst, L.I. The Rev. John H. Walsted performed the Protestant ceremony in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: L'AFFAIRE TOUVIER: OPENING OLD WOUNDS
description: YOU COULD CALL IT A WAR game. Let's say you were a young Frenchman during the Occupation and you chose the losing side, the wrong side, the German side. Let's say you were tried in absentia and sentenced to death as a war criminal.

title: Freelance Exchange Encourages Ideas
description: In reference to the recent articles ''Homeworkers warned of Fraudulent Schemes'' and ''More On L.I. Are Working at Home, (Aug. 27) in which myself and my organization, the Long Island Freelance Exchange, were mentioned, I would like to advise you of a few errors and exclusions regarding the organization's services and locations.

title: The Quest for a Pacific Beach
description: UNDER SOME COCONUT PALMS NEAR THE entrance to Manuel Antonio Park, a woman sells juice. Little capital investment has gone into this business: a booth, a glass juice squeezer for oranges, a machete to cut coconuts constitute the operation. The woman twists and presses the oranges for me with wholehearted vigor. I hope her hands are clean, because I really want this juice.

title:
INVESTING;
Alliant's New Alliance
description: LEAD: The Alliant Computer Systems Corporation, weak and vulnerable, may have a big brother watching out for it. The Intel Corporation is negotiating a joint technology and licensing agreement with Alliant, and might invest as much as $3 million in its new partner.

title: Drunken Drivers Hear From Victims
description: DRUNKEN drivers are listening to survivors of the tragedies that such drivers cause, through a new program for first offenders called the Victim Impact Panel.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Sept. 23 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $535,000 11 Fifth Avenue (8th St.) (Brevoort) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,350-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, manned elevator, dining alcove, terrace, Washington Square Park view; maintenance $1,099, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn Weigner Real Estate) TriBeCa $425,000 55 Hudson Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; high ceilings, large master bedroom; maintenance $1,700, 55% tax-deductible (Broker: Meisel Real Estate) Upper East Side $645,000 30 East 85th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,250-sq.-ft. condo in a 3-yr.-old building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, manned elevator, terrace; common charge $710, taxes $900 (Broker: S. W. Bird & Company) Upper East Side $525,000 4 East 70th Street 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 850-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, den, fireplace; maintenance $1,230, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Upper West Side $185,000 175 West 92d Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, windowed kitchen; maintenance $427, 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) BRONX Pelham Parkway Area $150,000 2936 Cruger Avenue 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; 1-car garage, 41- by 68-ft. irregular lot; taxes $953 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) Riverdale $141,000 57-75 Mosholu Avenue (Fieldstone Plaza) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,050-sq.-ft. postwar condo; dining ell, large closets, hardwood floors; common charge $217, taxes $1,560 (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) BROOKLYN Carroll Gardens $410,000 323 President Street 4-family, 4-story brownstone; 1 bedroom, 1 bath, dining area, den in each unit; full cellar, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Harborview Realty) Park Slope $650,000 7 Plaza Street 5-bedroom, 4-bath, single-family, 4-story, attached brownstone; dining room, large kitchen, den, 800-sq.-ft. of professional space on the first floor, 18- by 96-ft. lot; taxes $3,500 (Broker: A. J. Clark) Prospect Heights $120,000 135 Eastern Parkway 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, parquet floors; maintenance $375, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: John P. Barry Real Estate) QUEENS Elmhurst $170,000 81-09 41st Avenue (Elmhurst Terrace) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,860-sq.-ft. condo in a 2-yr.-old building; dining area, terrace, hardwood floors; common charge $209, includes parking space; 100% tax-abated (Broker: Century 21/Elms) Forest Hills $446,000 71-55 Ingram Street 2-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached, center-hall colonial; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, powder room, 2-car garage, c/a, 60- by 100-ft. lot.; taxes $2,700 (Broker: Terrace Realty) STATEN ISLAND Bay Terrace $137,000 74 Nancy Court (Evergreen Park) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,380-sq.-ft. postwar condo in a 1-yr.-old building; dining area, 2 skylights, finished loft; common charge $130, 100% tax-abated (Broker: Schlott Realtors) St. George $132,500 55 Hendricks Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached Victorian; dining room, large kitchen, full basement; 33- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $350 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: Indian Police Kill 5 Protesters
description: The police fired on crowds protesting the arrest of a separatist leader in northern Jammu-Kashmir state, killing at least 5 and wounding 75, officials said. The authorities imposed a curfew and sent soldiers in Anantnag, where three people were killed by police gunfire on Friday, a Government spokesman said. Protesters set fire to official jeeps and threw homemade bombs at Government buildings, he said.

title: The Many Aspects of Hospice Care
description: Stephanie Johns missed the basic point underlying hospice care in her letter.

title: JOE COLLEGE
description: PATERNO: BY THE BOOK By Joe Paterno with Bernard Asbell. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Fashion; Pants for Weekends or Whatever
description: Pants, pants and more pants. That's what designers on both sides of the Atlantic overwhelmingly suggested for fall. They showed them for day, for evening, for weekends and for work. They showed them with tailored jackets, with oversize tunic sweaters and with simple white cotton shirts.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Thin Legs, Fat Bats

title: Working Warily With Japan
description: INSIDE the Austin, Tex., laboratories of Sematech, the research consortium struggling to restore American manufacturing skills in memory chips, the Japanese are distinctly unwelcome. The clean rooms where chips are fabricated are closed to most foreigners. When Sematech needed a Nikon repairman to keep a vital piece of equipment running, he was walled off from the rest of the lab.

title: Ileana Cotrubas to End Her Singing Career
description: The Rumanian soprano Ileana Cotrubas announced her retirement today during a rehearsal at the Royal Opera House. She said her recital here on Thursday would be her farewell appearance in Britain.

title: 'Liberal Democracy' Almost Defines Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Policeman Slain in Santiago
description: Gunmen thought to be leftist extremists ambushed a national police van answering a bogus call for help in San Miguel, a working-class district of Santiago, late Friday, killing a police corporal and wounding a patrolman, the authorities said. Youths had erected burning street barricades nearby, apparently as a distraction.

title: Here Comes Supersquirrel
description: SQUIRRELS are not among my favorite creatures. Actually, they're listed high on my rodent list. Besides, I'm afraid of them. This fear is strongly rooted in my childhood, when my parents took me to the Bronx Zoo and a squirrel, aggressive little thing, chased me. No, I have no need for squirrels.

title: Santiago's Golden Legend
description: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA HAS BEEN A lodestar for visitors for more than a thousand years. The world's first guidebook was written in 1130 by Aimeri Picaud, a French monk, to give information to travelers on their way there. In the early Middle Ages, between 500,000 and 2 million people came each year. They came, however, not for the sun or the architecture, but to visit the sacred relics of the body of St. James.

title: Cambodia Expects Resurgence of Khmer Rouge
description: While Vietnamese officers who have returned from Cambodia routinely assert that the Phnom Penh army is now good enough to stand on its own, they also volunteer nearly uniform respect for the guerrilla tactics and skill of the Khmer Rouge, the main military force opposing Prime Minister Hun Sen.

title: Farm Belt Gambling On an Oil
description: Farming is always a gamble, but this year Richard Rice and his son Michael are putting down a bigger wager than usual. They are using about 130 of their 1,000 acres to plant a crop that most American farmers have never produced.

title: VATICAN AND EAST LOWERING BARRIERS AT A RAPID TEMPO
description: At a dramatic pace that would have been unthinkable only a year ago, the Vatican and the Eastern bloc have begun to forge fundamental changes in their relationship, easing mutual suspicions and lowering diplomatic barriers that had been intact for decades.

title: No Headline
description: THE ADVENTURES OF GOODNIGHT & LOVING By Leslie Thomas. 510 pp. Los Angeles: Price Stern Sloan. $15.95.

title: Kings and Blackhawks Geared to Test Flames' Depth and the Red Wings' Grit
description: SMYTHE DIVISION

title: A B&B's Appeal Beyond Lodging
description: AN establishment in New London now offers A&A along with B&B - that is, art and antiques as well as bed and breakfast.

title: IN THE HOSPITAL, WAITING FOR A SAVIOR
description: DIRTY WORK By Larry Brown. 236 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill.

title: Nancy D. Burns, Scientist, Marries
description: Nancy Dayton Burns, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Robert P. Burns of Branford, Conn., and Christian N. Kafoglis, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Z. Kafoglis of Bowling Green, Ky., were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Branford by an uncle of the bride, the Rev. Edward J. Burns.

title: After a Half-Century, The Class of '39 Returns to Rye
description: AN even 100 we were, the Rye High School Class of 1939, an easy number for statisticians. Now, at the 50th anniversary of that event, at least 57 percent of our class is still alive and accounted for. That's 57 people. Twenty-four percent are known to have died; the rest are listed as ''not found.'' The known dead include several killed during World War II, one of them at Iwo Jima. More than 80 percent of our class went on to higher education despite the fact that we were children during the Depression. The percentage of grandparents is high. Some never married, some are widowed: the normal cross-section.

title: Republic Airport Has Growth Pains
description: LEAD: HAVING dropped plans for a third runway and lowered predictions for future airport use, officials at Republic Airport in East Farmingdale thought they had answered neighbors' complaints about noise and a proposed expansion plan.

title: Tolstoy's Little Universe
description: THE SERFS ARE GONE FROM YASNAYA POLYANA, BUT birches still sway on this serene piece of Russia that was universe enough for the riotous creativity of Leo Tolstoy. Here, on his aristocratic family's estate, the writer and moral reformer was born, and here he alternately despaired and then took heart from fallible humanity, reworking its lessons and language into art.

title: Best Player Not Necessarily the M.V.P.
description: The name of Kevin Mitchell is pratically engraved on the 1989 National League most valuable player award. Why not? Mitchell has been the best all-round hitter in baseball this season and he has helped power the San Francisco Giants to a division championship.

title: Editors' Notes
description: An article on page 8 of the Arts and Leisure section today about a new production of a Martha Graham work describes Mikhail Baryshnikov as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater through the 1990 season.

title: Paraguay's Progress
description: Last year, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, dictator of Paraguay for 35 years, paid a rare visit to the United Nations. When Paraguayan exiles attempted a peaceful protest, they were set upon by pro-Stroessner goons.

title: For U.S. Coins, a Great Day Is About to Dawn; Eliminate All Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Wagner Routs Alfred, 35-19
description: Ray Benevenuti threw three touchdown passes and Greg Harris scored twice as undefeated Wagner routed Alfred, 35-19, yesterday on Staten Island.

title: Notre Dame Sails Past Purdue, 40-7
description: Anthony Johnson rushed for two touchdowns and Tony Rice passed for a career-high 270 yards, leading top-ranked Notre Dame to a 40-7 defeat of Purdue today. The victory was the 16th in succession for Notre Dame.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newport, Vt.;
Lake Access Stalls Project
description: LEAD: CONCERN over public access to state waters has stalled development of a project planned by two local developers, Chester Greenwood and James Mulkin, on the shores of Lake Memphremagog, a 20-mile-long waterway that stretches 15 miles into Canada.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Plainfield, Mass.;
Once a Dairy, Now a Resort
description: LEAD: A ROLLING 560-acre property with a central cluster of former dairy buildings has been redeveloped as a mixed-use country resort, Cummington Farm Village.

title: MAN OF LA BOCA
description: LEAD: THE GEOGRAPHY OF DESIRE By Robert Boswell. 310 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/SCIENCE
description: LEAD: MAMMAL By Steve Parker. Illustrated. 64 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title:
DINING OUT;
Gallic Flavor in Old Hastings Haunt
description: LEAD: RESTORATION of one dining room and the addition of another have given Buffet de la Gare much-needed elbow room without sacrificing the pubby feel of the place. The tin ceilings and walls and molded plaster, now freshly painted, once provided the backdrop for generations of Anaconda factory workers who hoisted their payday brews in the heyday of industrial Hastings.

title: Village Needs a New Firehouse but Cannot Settle on a Site
description: WITH a thriving business district, good schools, stately Victorian homes and regular commuter train service to Manhattan, the Village of Ridgewood has everything a successful bedroom community can offer. Everything but a new firehouse.

title: Glittering Icons
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last week about the fragrance industry misidentified the company that introduced Fahrenheit perfume. It is Christian Dior.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Doing Time

title: Sports of The Times
description: LEAD: The year before, the Chicago Cubs had finished last in the National League East. But now, the day before the Cubs would open their 1988 spring training workouts, their new manager, Don Zimmer, and his coaches were meeting with Jim Frey, the new general manager. With a straight face Frey pointed to the names of the pitchers, catchers, infielders and outfielders on the big board in

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: VIRTUOSI OPENER

title: A Monastery Stay: Expect the Austere
description: NESTLED in the Sabine hills 30 miles north of Rome, the Imperial Abbey at Farfa was the most important monastery of the Carolingian period in Italy. Writers of the time said it had no equal for its situation, the splendor of its artisans and its importance politically. Because it had Charlemagne as its protector and owned vast territories in central Italy, Farfa was considered one of the most powerful Benedictine abbeys in Europe and one of the most famous buildings of the Middle Ages. Today it is not only possible to tour Farfa but also to stay in one of 40 rooms once occupied by monks in a special wing of the abbey set aside for guests.

title: The Battle Lines Are Drawn At an Old Dirt Road
description: ALONG the Mianus Road, a half-mile stretch of country road in Bedford, there are no utility lines, driveways or mailboxes. Except for several drainage pipes added under the dirt road many years ago and a guiderail installed by the town in the last year, the road has not changed since it was dug by hand in the 19th century.

title: Introducing a 'Recycling Superhero'
description: LEAD: RECYCLUS is landing! To be more precise, an actor playing a character conceived by a public-relations consultant specializing in environmental issues is arriving at the County Center in White Plains on Thursday.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Headliners column last Sunday referred incorrectly in some copies to the year in which Bernhard H. Goetz shot four teen-agers on a subway train. It was 1984, not 1974.

title: Miami Struggles; Quarterback Hurt
description: Miami lost its starting quarterback with a fractured knuckle but rallied behind his substitute and a field-goal kicker today to beat Michigan State, 26-20, and raise its record to 4-0.

title: An Opera Rivalry Rivals Civic Rivalry
description: Those longtime California competitors, San Francisco and Los Angeles, are now engaged in an operatic rivalry that may wind up benefiting both cities. For decades, the San Francisco Opera perched alone on top of its roost as the West Coast's only opera company of national distinction. But today there is a flock of opera companies there that has attracted widespread attention, from Seattle through San Francisco to San Jose, Los Angeles, Costa Mesa, Long Beach and San Diego.

title: Stephen P. King, Architect, 44
description: Stephen P. King, an architect, died of cancer Friday at his home n East Hampton, L.I. He was 44 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Echoes of a Princely Past in a Many Layered City
description: NEVER WAS THERE A CITY THAT LIVED more in the present than does Delhi today. To arrive at the Indira Gandhi International Airport, and drive from there into New Delhi, is to be struck at once by its unfinished appearance. Huge public housing estates in unpainted concrete rise out of the gravelly red soil where cattle still linger, as if no one had informed them that the past was over, fini. Tumbledown tombs and mosques, dating back three, four, five centuries, wear gaudy signs pointing to three-, four- and five-star hotels in New Delhi.

title: Pre-deb Set Learns How Not To Slurp
description: The tony crowd clustered on the corner banquette in the Hotel Pierre's classy cafe chatted idly about class schedules and the latest Freddy Krueger film, while waiters served steaming bowls of double beef consomme with julienned vegetables.

title: Regional Approach to Garbage Is Gaining
description: LEAD: THE first regional plan to address the garbage crisis in New Jersey could be completed by the end of this year, say officials involved in negotiating a pact between Warren and Somerset Counties. This action has already generated further interest in an approach to solid-waste planning that has been widely discussed in the state for the last year.

title: Soviets Set to Mix, Mingle and Play
description: The National Hockey League, after two decades of wistful glances toward the progeny of the Soviet Union's hockey program, is about to embark on a lesson in wish fulfillment.

title: Treacy Moran Is Married
description: The marriage of Treacy Barbara Moran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Farley Moran of Madison, N.J., to Carl Watson Badenhausen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Badenhausen of New Vernon, N.J., took place yesterday at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon. Msgr. John Corr performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. The bride, a 28-year-old graduate of Tufts University, is the associate sales promotion manager for Doubleday & Company in New York. Mr. Badenhausen, 29, a graduate of Boston University, is the founder and president of Morris Computer Forms in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: WHAT A CHILD IS GIVEN
description: Deborah Franklin's article raises some interesting questions. She cites numerous instances in which there is evidence that heredity dictates the traits of individuals - including quite minor traits - but she reports that on such fundamental issues as a person's ''niceness'' or the tendency to ''criminality'' heredity does not seem very important. This would seem to call into question many of her subtler findings. WILLIAM E. STONEMAN Belmont, Mass.

title: FOR ONE THING, IT'S NOT BLUE
description: DANUBE By Claudio Magris. Translated by Patrick Creagh. 416 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: Q and A
description: Maintenance Deduction

title: Rail Support
description: To the Editor:

title: In Europe, East Prevails Upon West
description: NEARLY 50 years after the Western democracies lost Eastern Europe to Communism, they are beginning to see how they can help Poland and Hungary find a way back. What they lack, diplomats here say, is an overall strategy for the effort, one that will probably require leadership from the United States.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GOD'S EQUAL. By Alain Absire. Translated by Jon Rothschild. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $21.95.) Alain Absire's eighth novel, the winner of France's Prix Femina, is a work of compelling psychological drama. Rendered with a stark, fluid lyricism by its translator, Jon Rothschild, ''God's Equal'' takes the form of a penitential chronicle prepared by an aged, dying monk in 11th-century Normandy to expiate a hidden sin committed in his youth.

title: Alabama Beats Vanderbilt
description: An Alabama cornerback, John Mangum, halted a frantic Vanderbilt rally with a pass interception at the 16-yard line today as the 13th-ranked Crimson Tide held off the Commodores, 20-14, in a Southeastern Conference matchup.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BRIGHTEN THE CORNER WHERE YOU ARE. By Fred Chappell. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) In the prologue to Fred Chappell's new novel, a boy named Jess recalls the icy North Carolina morning when his father yanked the moon from its place in the windowpane and slapped it into a milk bucket for safekeeping. Jess tells this story quietly, almost reverently, heaping on the metaphors and similes until we squirm in our seats and wonder just what we're being asked to swallow.

title: U.S. Is Seeking to Increase Military Ties With Singapore
description: The Bush Administration has offered to step up military cooperation with Singapore, Defense Department officials report.

title: Iain Bruce Wed To Linda Lewis
description: Linda Ellen Lewis, the daughter of Richard Forest Lewis of Norwich, Conn., and the late Frances Lewis, was married yesterday to Iain Hay Bruce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald M. Bruce of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Harold Donald Smith performed the ceremony at the Park Congregational Church in Norwich.

title: Q and A
description: Soccer Cup

title: FROM VLADIMIR, WITH STYLE
description: LEAD: VLADIMIR NABOKOV Selected Letters, 1940-1977. Edited by Dmitri Nabokov and Matthew J. Bruccoli. Illustrated. 582 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: Social Events
description: Party in Prospect Park

title: Exiled King's Body Returned
description: Thousands of people turned out in Yugoslavia's southern republic of Montenegro today for the return of the remains of their last king, who died in exile in Italy in 1921. It was the first time a Communist country allowed the return of the remains of a former royal ruler. The remains of the King, Nikola Petrovic, the Queen, Milena, and their two daughters, Vjera and Ksenija, were carried to the ancient Montenegrin capital of Cetinje, 125 miles south of Belgrade, for reburial.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: EVERY day just before dusk, Charlotte and Charles Harrison head outdoors to do their evening chores. Mrs. Harrison first checks on the ducks, resting by a small artificial pond, and then /he goose, looking a little lonesome in the middle of the yard. Her husband, meanwhile, goes over to where their two sheep are standing, plucks them up with one hand, tucks them under his arm and heads for the garage, where the sheep will spend the night leaning against the lawn mower.

title: >Answering The Mail
description: Q. My screened porch has a concrete slab floor. For years, I have been painting this floor with an acrylic concrete deck paint, and in April the paint bubbles and lifts in large sections. I scrape these areas and then repaint the floor, but the bubbling and separating grow worse each year. Is there a way to correct this?

title: READERS RESPOND TO ARTICLE ON TUTORING A CHILD AT HOME
description: 'Trivial' Orders? Whose Definition?

title: Shortwave Makes News
description: The Canadian sociologist Marshall McLuhan used to speak of a ''global village'' as the likely result of the electronic age.

title: Burly Penguins and Fluid Canadiens Already Seem Poised for Run to Top
description: PATRICK DIVISION

title: Pavarotti Withdraws From Met 'Gioconda'
description: Luciano Pavarotti has canceled his series of performances in ''La Gioconda'' at the Metropolitan Opera in January because he must undergo treatment for sciatic nerve inflammation, the company has announced. The tenor Nicola Martinucci will replace him in the first two performances, on Jan. 15 and 19.

title: New Hours at Met Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced that it will discontinue Tuesday evening hours and will stay open until 8:45 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays, starting this week.

title: O'Rourke and Brodksy Meet in First Debate
description: THE campaign for County Executive began its final and most crucial phase last week with the first confrontation - a debate in Mount Vernon - between the two-term Republican incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and his Democratic challenger, Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky.

title: Lie-Detector Tests in a New Guise
description: LEAD: When a Congressional ban on the use of lie detectors by most private employers was on the horizon a year ago, a Miami bank substituted a new employee-screening program. Prospective job applicants at Sun Bank were told they had to take a written ''honesty test,'' a urinalysis and a thorough background check before they would be hired.

title: The Emelin Incentive To Its Subscribers
description: THE bluegrass and variety series have begun at Mamaroneck's Emelin Theater, but five other music cycles are waiting in the wings, with subscriptions still available. That is important to know, because the Emelin has fewer than 300 seats, which sell out quickly for the more popular events.

title: For the Homeless, Public Spaces Are Growing Smaller
description: IN recent years, New York City officials have done little to stop thousands of homeless people from staying in the city's bus and rail terminals, some subway stations and parks. But lately, as the number of homeless people and the number of complaints about them have continued to rise, the officials seem to have taken a tougher approach. They have adopted codes of conduct in public spaces and erected barriers closing off areas frequented by the homeless.

title: 'The Jeffs' Mine a Traditional Vein
description: LEAD: SO far as Jeff Warner and Jeff Davis are concerned, there is something about traditional music that is riveting, even though they have been performing it for decades.

title: Correction
description: The Personal Finance column last week misstated the rule that determines when the wages of children employed by their parents become subject to Social Security tax. Because of recent changes in the law, the tax applies to children 18 years of age or older, not to younger children.

title: Retailers Find Shoplifting a Growing Burden
description: A WELL-DRESSED customer entered a White Plains clothing store recently. Julian DiDonato, who owns the store, Dakota Dry Goods Ltd. on Mamaroneck Avenue, recalled that they exchanged a friendly word or two. It wasn't until after the customer left, Mr. DiDonato said, that he noticed a pair of deerskin gloves, valued at $59, were missing.

title: British Soldier, 20, Charged With Security Leak in Ulster
description: A 20-year-old British soldier was charged today with leaking confidential photographs, names and addresses of suspects on security files in Northern Ireland. The soldier, Shaun Cunliffe, a member of the Air Defense Regiment of the Royal Artillery, was freed on bail after a hearing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Posting on Sept. 10 gave an incorrect time for the start of condominium sales at the Coronado, at Broadway and West 70th Street. Sales are currently under way.

title: FICTION
description: THE CURRENT CLIMATE. By Bruce Jay Friedman. (Morgan Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly Press, $18.95.) In his novel ''About Harry Towns,'' which was published 15 years ago, Bruce Jay Friedman presented a disturbing portrait of a hedonistic Manhattan playboy. The life of Harry Towns, a moderately successful screenwriter in his 40's, degenerates through episodes of drug abuse, disease-spreading sex and finally the molestation of his girlfriend's daughter. Filtered through Harry's myopic point of view, the novel offers occasionally harrowing glimpses into the temptations and excesses possible in a newly liberated age. ''The Current Climate,'' which takes Harry's life story both forward and back, offers less. The novel is neither realistic enough to be engaging as a story nor absurd enough to work as satire. Harry, now 58, has mellowed some but not much. Though he has a new wife and daughter and lives in a placid Long Island suburb, he remains addicted to indulgent Manhattan weekends of sex and drugs. Not as firmly rooted in a palpable time or place, and more prone to stereotype and contrived plot devices, these escapades lack the tension, and the relevance, of those in ''About Harry Towns.'' Mr. Friedman's writing, rife with choppy sentences and coarse language, is at times well suited to the simplistic mind of his protagonist, but such a voice is hardly sustainable over the course of a novel. To his credit, Mr. Friedman does try to step back and observe Harry and his environs in a more detached, sardonic manner than he did in the earlier novel. The intended humor occasionally works, but Mr. Friedman's look at the movie business and the rest of Harry's world lacks incisiveness. It remains inconsequential and flat. CRAIG BLOOM

title: Fashion; In Fitting Room, a Little More Equality
description: For many women, finding the perfect dress or outfit is only half the battle. Then, it must be altered.

title: Lawyer Married To Ms. Hamilton
description: Jeanmarie Hamilton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Hamilton of Fair Haven, N.J., and Richard Allen Drucker, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Drucker, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Edward O. Miller officiated.

title: Rose Seeks Some Help
description: After being banished from baseball amid allegations that he violated major league rules by betting on baseball, including making wagers on his own team, Pete Rose has concluded that he has a problem and has sought professional help.

title: For Philippine Rebels, Strength Exceeds Strife
description: Three assassinations attributed to guerrillas this week have enhanced the Communist rebellion's image of strength even as it is being dogged from within by serious political and logistical problems.

title: Abortion Focus Shifting to Teen-Agers
description: LEAD: THE issue of teen-age pregnancy could become an important facet of an ongoing debate to restrict abortion rights in Connecticut, where more than half of pregnant teen-agers under the age of 19 have abortions.

title: Small Business Is Overwhelmed By Health Costs
description: Millions of small American businesses that provide health coverage for their employees have been staggered in recent months by insurance rate increases of 20 percent to more than 100 percent.

title: Budget Beds: An Inside Look At New Motels
description: THE last two times I was on the road for research, I started gathering information on new types of inexpensive accommodations along the highway or near the airport. Three of four of the places explored were parts of chains, so you could reasonably expect to find the same thing each time.

title: In Brazilian Race, a Communist Stands Out
description: Flipping through Brazilian television channels one recent evening, viewers had the choice of a comedy, ''Cockroach Cabaret,'' an action show, ''Tank Commando,'' or a one-hour interview with Roberto Freire, one of 28 minor-party candidates for President.

title: South Africa Disbands Special Police in Namibia
description: South Africa disbanded its police counterinsurgency force in Namibia today in response to pressure from the United Nations and complaints of intimidation from civilians in the territory.

title: Linda Veith Wed To Bruce Glover
description: Linda Susan Veith, a daughter of Karen Veith and Dr. Charles J. Veith, both of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Bruce William Glover, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Thomas Glover of Rowayton, Conn. The ceremony at the Lower Brandywine Presbyterian Church in Centerville, Del., was performed by the Rev. Dr. Roy Martin and the Rev. Edie Fenimore.

title: >Answering The Mail
description: Q. My screened porch has a concrete slab floor. For years, I have been painting this floor with an acrylic concrete deck paint, and in April the paint bubbles and lifts in large sections. I scrape these areas and then repaint the floor, but the bubbling and separating grow worse each year. Is there a way to correct this?

title: Miss Golier Weds Timothy Wright
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J., Susan Christine Golier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Golier of Montvale, N.J., was married yesterday to Timothy Lee Wright, a son of Joan M. Wright of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and the late David K. Wright. Msgr. John McDermott officiated.

title: 20 Questions
description: The world is full of unexpected things, or at any rate of things where you'd never expect them. Match the following artifacts with the places where they may be found. Note that any question may have more than one answer; conversely, any answer may fit more than one question. Any score is passing. rr 1. The great feathered headdress thought to have belonged to Montezuma.

title: A Cotswolds Journey: Back Into Time
description: THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF GLOUCESTER-shire is stone country - Cotswold stone, oolitic limestone. What lies beneath the soil is reflected above in the golden glow of cottages, churches, manor houses, the dry stone walls that snake up the hillsides. There is no building material to match this limestone: it reflects and absorbs light in a way that perfectly matches the shifting, changing moods of the countryside. A wall or spire can burn apricot on a summer evening, fade to a dying cream in the dusk or drain of color to match the grays of a winter morning. It is sedimentary rock, full of fossils - brachiopods and ammonites and the strange black teeth of fish. The old quarries - some of them still in use -litter the landscape; from them came the stones that built Oxford and Bath, with names that sound like the names of dance steps - Coral Rag and Cornbrash and Forest Marble.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's hard for a politician to vote against a tax cut.'' Newt Gingrich, of Georgia, House Republican whip.

title: New Orleans Resists High-End Condos
description: JEROME GOLDMAN, a local developer and marine architect, had always dreamed of a home with a view of the Mississippi River. When a downtown site on the river became available in 1984, he decided to build a 14-story condominium there so he could enjoy a panoramic view of the city and the waterway from his penthouse.

title: GOOD SCHOLAR, GOOD FRENCHMAN
description: MARC BLOCH A Life in History. By Carole Fink. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $29.95.
