title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: In 1986, Strawberry helped the Mets to a championship, and in 1988 he was robbed of the MVP. Leave Darryl alone and allow him to be the respected star he would be in any other city. Are we allowing history to repeat itself by giving away another franchise player and future Hall of Famer? KEVEN P. JACKSON Flushing, Queens

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Why not? They have traded all the other players who might have made the Mets great again. People like Hubie Brooks, Wally Backman, Mookie Wilson, Len Dykstra, Roger McDowell, Rick Aguilera, David West. And on and on. So why trade Strawberry and let him hit .350 with somebody else?

title: Recycling Recipe: Easy as Pie
description: WOE be unto anyone who dares to drop a banana peel into my trash container. ''That goes into our kitchen garbage pot!'' I scold. ''Right, I forgot,'' comes the remiss reply, and the banana peel is duly dropped into the covered half-gallon container that sits sentry next to the kitchen sink. We call it the KGP.

title: Cast in Bronze, the Keys To an Ancient Culture
description: Prehistoric bronze objects - powerful images of great technological refinement made in ancient Sardinia - are compelling relics of the little-known nuraghic culture. The people who made them derive their name from nuraghi, the truncated stone towers that rose on the Mediterranean island between the 15th and 6th centuries B. C. A selection of these rare bronzes, made from the ninth to the sixth centuries, is now on view at the Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street. The exhibition, the first of such metalwork in this country, remains through Oct. 28. The entire contents of the Merrin show, ''Sardinian Bronzes,'' would easily fit in an orange crate - so small are the 32 richly detailed, highly expressive depictions of warriors, priests, women, animals, ships and buildings. They range from less than two inches tall to about a foot high or wide.

title: Falsely Shouting Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Reunion at the Bruce Museum
description: THE works of Leonard Ochtman (1854-1934), his wife, Mina Fonda (1862-1924), their daughter, Dorothy (1892-1971), and their son, Leonard Jr. (1894-1976), are all at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich. It is a reunion for a family that appeared together for the first time in the 1912 inaugural show of the Greenwich Society of Artists, which was also held at the Bruce.

title: Nancy O'Brien Is Wed in New Jersey
description: Nancy Theresa O'Brien, a daughter of Raymond V. O'Brien Jr. of Colts Neck, N.J., and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and the late Theresa Sweeney O'Brien, was married yesterday to Scott Harold Meisenzahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Meisenzahl of Rochester. The Rev. James J. Fischer officiated at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/SCIENCE
description: LEAD: EXPLORING THE PAST Ancient Egypt By George Hart. Illustrated by Stephen Biesty. San Diego: Gulliver Books/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. 64 pp. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Joyful Dancing in '42d Street'
description: WHEN the curtain slowly ascends on ''42d Street'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse, an all-out blast of tap dancing is under way. Here, indeed, are ''those dancing feet'' that the title song invites us to ''come and meet,'' and all at once, one is overtaken by the rush that only a real live musical can produce.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's truly amazing, but no longer surprising, the questions asked, and the comments made, by comparative strangers at social gatherings. You've just bought a new apartment - how much did you pay for it, and what's the maintenance? You're getting a divorce - they've just gone through one and regale you with more personal details than you ever want to hear. You're a friend of Mr. X? Of course, they don't believe it, but they've heard that he beats his wife.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 17 about fall lectures gave an incorrect date for a talk by Daniel Robbins at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase about the museum's collection. It is Oct. 29, not Oct. 20.

title: Colleges Increase Remedial Efforts for Marginal Students
description: LEAD: IN recounting a story about a student from an affluent home in the Five Towns who was having trouble in high school, Barbara Shulman, a counselor at Adelphi University, remembers that his parents sent him to a private school to complete his studies.

title: Legacy of Innuendo Splits a State Anew
description: Some of the suspicion and mistrust that pervaded the social turbulence here in the 1960's are being replayed 25 years later in a court fight over a defunct state agency that spied on and harassed participants in the civil rights movement.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: No. Since I'm a Chicago native, any detriment to your team makes it easier for my team to win the division. MARK J. KASPER New York

title: PASTIMES: Sunday Menu; Corn (and Tomatoes) In an All-Season Salad
description: A salad with tomatoes and corn is obviously best in summer or early fall. But it can be made when the tomato and corn seasons are just a memory.

title: The Fallout From the Font Wars
description: The Font Wars, as the competition among industry leaders is known, went ballistic last week at the Seybold Computer Publishing Conference here, and the outcome will fundamentally change the way software looks on computer screens and the way documents look when they are printed or sent to other computers.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Chicken Salad and Catastrophic Care
description: In a famous scene from the movie ''Five Easy Pieces,'' Jack Nicholson is told he cannot get a side order of toast in a restaurant. He comes up with a hostile and imaginative solution.

title: Advantages of a Hand Scraper
description: BEFORE sandpaper became popular, woodworkers, especially cabinetmakers, relied on a simple tool called a hand scraper for smoothing wood prior to applying finish.

title: MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.
description: David Burnham's article ''The Abuse of Power: Misuse of the I.R.S.'' (Sept. 3) was timely. As head of an organization working to establish the first AIDS thrift shop, I wrote in frustration to my Representative and Senator, asking to have the Internal Revenue Service agent removed from our case only the week before your article was published.

title: Valdez Vows
description: To the Editor:

title: If Your Line Is Cellular, Give a Ring
description: After Shayna Felts, a computer-science and engineering major, graduated last spring from Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., she did not have to look hard for a job. Ms. Felts, 22 years old, was recruited by Bell Laboratories, the research and development arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to write software for high-level computers.

title: Goodbye Newark: Roth Remembers His Beginnings
description: Philip Roth's "Goodbye, Columbus," published in 1959 as the title novella in a collection of stories, has turned out to be an enduring commentary on postwar America and, more specifically, the Jews who were part of it. "Goodbye, Columbus" won the author the National Book Award at the age of 26. Roth wrote this preface for the 30th anniversary edition of the book, published this month by Houghton Mifflin.

title: Canal Project Sets Off U.S.-Mexico Clash Over Water for Border Regions
description: An American Government plan to renovate a California canal has locked the United States and Mexico in a major dispute over the use of water from the Colorado River.

title: Developer Is Host Of Meeting on Jay Site
description: A LITTLE more than a decade ago, the developer Diane G. Millstein purchased a 23-acre site in Rye overlooking Long Island Sound and began drawing up a plan for a series of houses. Last week, several of the key participants in the lengthy dispute that ensued accepted her invitation to meet in her Mamaroneck home and discuss a resolution.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Condom Olympics Seek to Encourage Safe Sex Practices
description: Organizers of last Sunday's Condom Olympics at the University of Wisconsin say their event may not have had the spectacle of Seoul but their goals were just as noble.

title: Three-Day Fair to Open
description: DOZENS of craft artists in 31 states have been polishing, stitching or waiting for their kilns to cool in the last-minute preparations before they pack up for the trek to New Jersey this week. Despite the prospect of a long, rigorous drive with a van full of fragile glass, comic ceramic pots, jewelry or handmade clothing, nearly 1,000 people applied to show their work at the 13th annual Morristown CraftMarket. Only 150 were selected by a jury of seven craft professionals.

title: Giuliani Sets Out on Tricky Task of Attacking Dinkins
description: The quivering anger of Rudolph W. Giuliani as he defended his criticism of David N. Dinkins last week made painfully clear the predicament he faces: How to raise enough doubts about his rival for the New York City mayoralty to beat him without being accused of beating up on him.

title: From New Arrivals to Shifts in Rules, a Season of Change
description: The arrival of several Soviet players is only one of many personnel shifts in the National Hockey League as it opens its 73d season this week. None are as dramatic as Wayne Gretzky's move last season from Edmonton to Los Angeles, but a few teams won't seem the same with familiar faces in different places.

title: A POTENT BREW IN PONAPE
description: One of my more exotic gastronomic quests occurred in 1978, during a trip with a photographer friend through the Micronesian Islands in the Western Pacific. Along the way, we stopped in Ponape, a 129-square-mile volcanic island famous for its rugged beauty and for the ancient ruins of Nan Madol, man-made islets believed to have had both religious and defensive significance.

title: Tracy L. Seretean Plans to Be Wed To Glenn I. Levin
description: Mrs. Farol Seretean of Washington and Martin B. Seretean of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracy Lynn Seretean, to Glenn I. Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Levin of Ardsley, N.Y. The wedding is to be this month.

title: Rogina Haase, an Engineer, Marries
description: Rogina Louisa Haase, a daughter of Dr. Mary Louise Mallery Haase of West Winfield, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Benjamin Jeffries, the son of Benjamin Eustis Jeffries of Chelsea, Mass., and the late Philippa Roosevelt Jeffries of Boston. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Rhys Williams, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, at the Arlington Street Church in Boston.

title: A Poet's Safe Haven In Amherst
description: THE RUSTY BRICK, CENTER-ENTRANCE FEDERAL HOUSE that Emily Dickinson lived in most of her life is registered with the United States Department of the Interior as ''The Dickinson Homestead.'' It is planted on a small rise directly across Main Street from Valley Bicycle and the Black Sheep Farm Kitchen, in the town of Amherst, Mass. Even if you don't know Emily Dickinson's poetry well, a visit to this house more than satisfies the kind of gnawing curiosity most of us have about the way the great, the admirable, the divinely inspired, conduct their daily lives.

title: Dissident Parishioners End Bridgeport Protest
description: Dissident parishioners of a predominantly Polish church here say they have decided to end their protest after 41 weeks of demonstrations at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: Music That Rouses or Soothes - in Small Doses
description: Like pharmacists, composers peddle stimulus on the one hand, narcosis on the other. Two 20th-century miniaturists represent these two poles. One rouses our minds, the other invites them to dream.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about thefts of statues from parks in Buenos Aires described the poet Antonio Machado incorrectly. He was Spanish, not Argentine.

title: Where Washington And Moscow Line Up On Arms Control
description: AFTER the summer doldrums, the arms control process has received a shot of adrenaline, helping the Bush Administration counter Democratic accusations that it is taking a timid approach in its dealings with Moscow.

title: STRANGE CREATURES AMONG US
description: LEAD: A CAT IS WATCHING A Look at the Way Cats See Us. By Roger A. Caras. Illustrated. 238 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Another Colombian Crop Takes Off: Flowers
description: In the high Andean plains here, Reynaldo Garcia Navas lives in a world bounded by Thanksgiving, Valentine's Day and Secretary's Day.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Grymes Hill
description: WHEN David and Marjorie Hack moved to Staten Island's Grymes Hill in 1979, they couldn't afford anything better than a $65,000 handyman special on the fringe of the decaying, high-crime Stapleton neighborhood. Now, 10 years and $150,000 later, the 1910 eight-bedroom Victorian is almost completely restored and is valued by brokers at about $420,000.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Joyce Anisman-Saltman; 'There Is Humor in Everything'
description: THERE is little else that will make a person feel as good as will a good laugh, says Joyce Anisman-Saltman, a professor who lectures on the importance of humor.

title:
INVESTING;
Can Cray's Stock Come Back?
description: LEAD: Just a few years ago, Wall Street saw Cray Research Inc. as a cutting-edge enterprise, on the forefront of technology. The stock soared. Now, as smaller competitors bite into its profits, Cray has spun off some of its most advanced research and development. And the stock has collapsed.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Sally Skeele and George Post Jr. Marry
description: Sarah Hayden Skeele, the daughter of Ruth Richardson Skeele of White Plains and Robert Billington Skeele of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to George Browne Post Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Post of Norwalk, Conn., and Isleboro, Me. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speere Jr. officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan.

title: EAST GERMANS GET PERMISSION TO QUIT PRAGUE FOR WEST
description: With their hopes for freedom suddenly granted, several thousand East German refugees were allowed to leave the West German Embassy here tonight and were being transported to West Germany.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT A. ROTHMAN;
Helping Jews Find Meaning in Religion
description: LEAD: FRIDAY NIGHT marked the beginning of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish new year - 5750 on the Jewish calendar. The 10-day period from the start of Rosh ha-Shanah until Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, is a period of reflection for Jews.

title: Review/ Dance; An Updated Version of the Narcissus Myth
description: Dance 2000, the Felice Lesser Dance Theater, is certainly ambitious. It uses ballet as its basic technique, yet remains open to other stylistic influences. Felice Lesser favors serious themes in her choreography, and she sets her troupe dancing to contemporary music.

title: Sights to Behold Along the Palisades
description: LEAD: WORK crews are busy with the fall cleanup and reseeding of wildflowers along the Palisades Interstate Parkway. Wildflowers blossomed all summer, and now vestiges of red gaillardia, yellow black-eyed daisies and purple beach peas provide observant motorists with flashes of color along the parkway's median and shoulders.

title: OBRYCKI'S: PARADISE ENOW
description: Baltimoreans are a real nice bunch of guys, but they have this thing about their old part of town. Imagine a compulsion to take all visitors to New York through Corona for their dose of urban quaintness. Nevertheless, the children of the Chesapeake like nothing better than to stroll through this engulfing blockade of row houses, with their multicolored faux brick facing and three-step stoops, beaming as if they were Roosevelt showing off Campobello. Notwithstanding civic pride, it's still disorienting to find a place on earth where native son John Waters's taste is the norm.

title: Year in Rome T>urns Composer's Requiem Into a Celebration
description: SHE is back from paradise, with an Italian wardrobe and a new appreciation of the ''air kiss.'' Michelle Ekizian's year at the American Academy in Rome is over, and she has now begun to assess its influences.

title: Expectations Confront Reality
description: The time: late July. The place: the local 10-plex. The weather: horrid. The line: unbelievably long. Every kid from miles around has been brought to the movies this afternoon, and most of the buzz is about ''Batman.'' They've been hearing about it for weeks; they all want to see it, and most of them aren't going to get in. With the line snaking down into the parking lot and the 2 P.M. show about to start, all but the hardiest are beginning to peel off to the other nine theaters. Some are heading for ''Dead Poets Society,'' some for ''Ghostbusters II,'' some for ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.''

title: Sculptures That Test the Idea of Opposites
description: ''MATERIAL FORMS'' is a show by 10 sculptors at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts here. The brochure says that it ''explores the tensions created between surface and volume, natural and man-made materials, abstraction and representation, ancient and modern civilization.''

title: The Taxpayer's Turn to Win a Few
description: The number of rounds in which the taxpayer emerges the victor after battling the Internal Revenue Service are precious few, but lately the Government has been taking it on the chin. In a variety of court cases that provide lessons for average taxpayers, individuals have prevailed. They have won disputes over deductions of home office expenses and personal computer purchases and they were awarded legal fees for litigation that arose because of heavy-handed I.R.S. action. What follows is a rundown of these rulings. Home Office. The call in this case was a split decision that favored the taxpayer, a transportation expert who operated his own consulting business from 1976 on. In April 1984 he was hired by the Department of Energy as a consultant, and spent half his time at his home office and the rest either in the field or at the department. In September of that year he was hired as a full-time employee by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Alaska Oil Fund's Dividend Is Second Largest
description: This year, when thousands of people in Alaska felt the effects of the nation's largest oil spill, the state's residents will receive their second largest annual check from Alaska's oil wealth savings account.

title: Jennifer Tanner and Richard Taylor Are Married
description: Jennifer Harris Tanner, the daughter of Evelyn Schmidt Tanner of New York and Marvin Allen Tanner of Coplay, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Zachary Holbrook Taylor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Lee Taylor Jr. of Easton, Md. The Rev. Donald Etherton officiated at the Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Easton.

title: Stella Madrid Takes Matron
description: Stella Madrid stamped herself as the nation's leading 2-year-old filly with an easy victory in the $136,200 Matron Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park, and Adjudicating scored a narrower and less meaningful victory in the $114,600 Cowdin for 2-year-old colts.

title: WHEN RUINS WERE THE RAGE
description: THE SEARCH FOR THE PICTURESQUE Landscape Aesthetics and Tourism in Britain, 1760-1800. By Malcolm Andrews. Illustrated. 269 pp. Calif.: Stanford University Press. $49.50.

title: Mary Sue Howley to Wed
description: Mrs. Peter D. Howley of Bronxville, N.Y., has announced October wedding plans for her daughter Mary Sue Howley and Paul Gerard Dwyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Dwyer of New York. Ms. Howley, 27 years old, is the marketing associate in the incentive department at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. Mr. Dwyer, 29, is a foreign-currency broker at Harlow Meyer Savage in New York.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE sky was thickish and threatening, spitting at intervals. Chances were the weather had suppressed the hordes of Sunday shoppers in Chester, but who wanted to gamble? We took the short cut to avoid traffic, a winding dirt road, older than the nation, trickier than a chased fox.

title: Help the East Look Ahead
description: Immediate concerns are about the ability of reformers in the East to weather the transformations made possible by the internal crises in Poland and Hungary, already peeking over the horizon in Czechoslovakia and East Germany. No one can doubt that it's in the West's interest to help, even if how and how much have to be figured out.

title: A Chilling Evening Down on the Farm
description: AS surely as B follows A, evil transpires in plays set in isolated houses in remote rural regions. Peter Colley's play, ''I'll Be Back Before Midnight,'' currently at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is set in such a farmhouse.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 1, 1989
description: *4*BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Aug. 89 July 89 Aug. 88 New York 3,946 3,656 4,156 New Jersey 3,580 2,164 4,412 Connecticut 1,244 1,040 1,692 *4*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.35 10.36 10.69 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.88 8.87 8.18 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.14 10.15 10.49 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.61 8.63 8.11 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.25 10.26 10.66 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.74 8.73 8.44 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 10.68 10.73 11.22 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 9.02 9.05 8.42 *4*Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 8.18 8.07 8.07 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.81 9.81 9.00 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title:
The View From: Girl Scout Troop 1943;
As Scouting Makes a Comeback, Badges Reflect a New Era
description: LEAD: JANET BELL, the 37-year-old leader of Girl Scout Troop 1943 here, was recalling her own Scouting days, ''selling cookies, marching in the Memorial Day Parade and going on an overnight with 32 other girls.''

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Bogota; War on Drugs, for Real, With Casualties
description: HOW can I describe what a journalist in Colombia thinks and feels in these times? How can I explain the fear, the rage, the frustration that engulf journalists every time they sit down in front of their computer screens to perform the professional ritual of commenting on a situation that floods Colombians every day with surreal brutality?

title: Roberta Peters Bringing Arias, and Berlin, to the County Center
description: LEAD: WHEN Roberta Peters performs with the Boston Pops Esplanade orchestra at the County Center in White Plains on Saturday night, her program will be ''half arias, half Irving Berlin,'' she said. Miss Peters - the opera star, actress, Scarsdale legend and community volunteer - called the late composer ''one of popular music's greatest geniuses.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Overcoming the 'NIMBY' Attitude
description: LEAD: THOSE disarmingly simple acronyms, ''lulu'' and ''nimby,'' have repeatedly arisen in recent years. The ''locally unwanted land uses'' and ''not in my backyard'' syndromes refer, of course, to those land uses or facilities that are generally conceded as necessary, but that no one wants in his community.

title: Jamming on the Other Side of Midnight
description: In a television studio in lower midtown Manhattan, where episodes of ''The Phil Silvers Show'' once originated, ''Night Music'' (formerly called ''Sunday Night'') is taping the first show of its second season, scheduled to air tonight in the New York area on Channel 4 at 12:30 A.M. It is 10 o'clock at night, but the host, David Sanborn, tailored in his trademark black and gray, wears sunglasses during rehearsal. He looks like the kind of man that the show's single sponsor, Michelob, has built its advertising campaign around - the coolest night owl in the city, the guy who wows the barflies simply by putting his lips on his saxophone.

title: A Village Seeks Its Identity Through the U.S. Postal Service
description: WITH more than 300 employees, the Harris Graphics Company is the largest employer in the village of Pawcatuck, but its corporate letterhead lists its address as Rhode Island, because Pawcatuck, a village in Stonington, has no post office.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/SCIENCE
description: WHALES By Seymour Simon. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $14.95. (Ages 5-8) THE SIX BRIDGES OF HUMPHREY THE WHALE By Toni Knapp. Illustrated by Craig McFarland Brown. Unpaged. Colorado Springs, Colo. The Rockrimmon Press. $15.95. (Ages 9 to 13) CAN THE WHALES BE SAVED? By Philip Whitfield. Illustrated. 96 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Congress Courts the Dangers Of Living for the Moment
description: THE legislative behemoth that Congress will be wrestling with for the next month or so is artfully described as a deficit reduction package, and in the narrowest sense that description is correct.

title: Cutting Capital Gains Tax: New York Boon and Burden
description: A boon to the wealthiest New Yorkers and a burden on local governments already struggling with severely diminished Federal support was one scenario sketched by executives and public officials last week as they assessed the possible effect in New York City if the capital gains tax rate is reduced.

title: IMAGINARY PEOPLE IN A REAL WAR
description: TO ASMARA By Thomas Keneally. 290 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

title: Biotechnology Creates a Jersey Job Culture
description: LEAD: America's medicine cabinets have long been stocked with products made in New Jersey. The tradition continues today; its 173 pharmaceutical and other health products companies make New Jersey the leading state in this manufacturing field for the third year in a row.

title: Laurie Anderson Sings the Body Electronic
description: Seated at her kitchen table in her downtown Manhattan loft overlooking the Hudson River, with a mug of coffee and a pack of Marlboros, Laurie Anderson, famous for her multimedia cyber-punk performances complete with filtered voices and electronic violin, tells a story of hang-gliding in Rio last July, a pair of wings looming over her head, a perfect view of the local pollution below:

title: Developer's Empire Keeps Growing
description: WITH more than 94,000 apartments in his company's portfolio, Samuel J. LeFrak, 71 years old, is among the nation's largest landlords. The Lefrak Organization is the principal developer of the massive Newport complex, an office, residential, shopping and marina complex that is the largest development along the Hudson River in New Jersey.

title: Chris Meade and Michael Motta: Personal Trainers
description: Chris Meade and Michael Motta could be called stylists, but they do not work with fabric, paint or precious metals. Their creations involve muscle and strength, power and agility. Mr. Meade, 33 years old, and Mr. Motta, 37, are personal exercise trainers to some of the most visible, fit bodies around.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: My mailbag has been filled to the brim of late, perhaps because everyone's pictures from summer vacation were not what everyone hoped they would be. A few of the questions asked have a potentially wide audience, so here goes.

title: Russia's Reborn Splendor
description: WANTON destruction, in wartime, was once a frequent German amusement. In 1871, for instance, the palace of St.-Cloud, outside Paris, was shelled for the sheer fun of it. And during World War II, Hitler's army, as it whiled away the siege of Leningrad, destroyed the imperial palaces just outside the city. In this case, however, the Nazis were less thorough than the Kaiser. Although these splendid buildings were very severely damaged, enough remained of them to make restoration a difficult but not impossible task; and nowhere was the work carried out more thoroughly or more successfully than at Pavlovsk.

title: WHAT A CHILD IS GIVEN
description: I was encouraged by Deborah Franklin's article ''What a Child Is Given'' (Sept. 3). My adoptive mother suffers from bipolar illness, and I spent much of my early childhood wondering if I, too, would suffer from it. I know now that my concern about ''contracting'' her illness was unnecessary, but the emotional scars of growing up in an unstable family remain.

title: Campus Life: Harvard; Campus Rent Rise Affects Businesses Run by Students
description: For student organizations, rental space at Harvard has always been hard to come by. Now, it's more costly as well, as Harvard raises rental fees for the first time in a decade, in some cases. The largest group affected is Harvard Student Agencies, a student-run corporation that provides jobs for hundreds of undergraduates, writing and publishing the popular ''Let's Go'' series of travel books.

title: Pamela S. Snyder Marries in Darien
description: Pamela Spotswood Snyder, a daughter of John A. Snyder of Darien, Conn., and the late Sue Davis Snyder, was married yesterday to Earle Kirkpatrick Borman 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Borman Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Frederick T. Bender, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's father.

title: No Misha
description: When somebody else tried to call the tune, Mikhail Baryshnikov decided to walk instead of dance. Last week, nine months before his planned resignation as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, Mr. Baryshnikov abruptly quit. Angered by the company management's removal of one of his staff members, as well as by a dispute over the troupe's finances, the dancer said through a spokesman that he was ''not taking orders from anyone, especially unfair ones.'' Indeed, he added, that was the reason he defected from the Soviet Union in 1974. For its part, the A.B.T. board criticized Mr. Baryshnikov's increasing involvement in extracurricular dance and film projects and commercial ventures.

title: Change Sought in Custody Laws
description: LEAD: ASSERTING that the majority of child-custody cases are decided in favor of the mother, advocates of fathers' rights are seeking to make the awarding of child custody in New Jersey more equitable. But several bills before the Legislature that address the problem illustrate the legal and emotional complexity of the issue.

title: Marchers in Minsk Demand Further Chernobyl Cleanup
description: Thousands of Byelorussians, denouncing local leaders, marched through the center of Minsk today to demand further measures to clean up the aftermath of the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Kite Leads U.S. Into Title Match: Tom Kite converted mistakes by Christy O'Connor of Ireland into a playoff victory that sent the United States into the championship match in the Dunhill Cup tournament yesterday at St. Andrews, Scotland. O'Connor put his ball into a stream on the first extra hole of the decisive match. The Americans' 2-1 triumph over Ireland, the defender, advanced the three-man American team into today's 36-hole final against Japan, a 2-1 upset winner over England. Mark Calcavecchia clinched his victory with a 25-foot putt on the final hole for a 69-71 decision over Philip Walton. Ronan Rafferty defeated Curtis Strange, 71-72, before Kite's decisive match. (AP) Britton Leads by 4 Shots: Bill Britton, looking for his first victory in nine seasons on the PGA Tour, shot a nine-under-par 63 yesterday to take a four-stroke lead after three rounds of the Centel Classic in Tallahassee, Fla. Britton was at 16-under 200 after 54 holes, within range of Jeff Sluman's tournament record of 269, after shooting nine birdies in a bogey-free round over the 7,098-yard Killearn Country Club course. Ronnie Black had a 70 and was second at 204.(AP) Daniel Leads Bradley by 3: Beth Daniel fired a 5-under-par 67 to take a three-stroke lead over Pat Bradley after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. San Jose Classic yesterday. Daniel, who has won three tournaments in the last two months, enters today's final round at 12-under-par 132, five shots better than the previous course record of 137, set by Sandra Haynie in 1982. Daniel began the day with a one-stroke lead over Bradley, who shot a 69 yesterday. The 54-hole tournament at the Almaden Golf and Country Club is the final Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament of the year in the United States, with two more scheduled in Japan.(AP) Charles Retains Lead: Bob Charles shot a two-under-par 70 yesterday to retain a one-shot lead over Butch Baird after two rounds of the Space Coast Senior Classic in Melbourne, Fla. Charles had four birdies and two bogeys as the field battled stiff winds and thick rough at the Suntree Country Club. He was at eight-under-par 136 after 36 holes. Baird, who shot a 70, came to the final hole tied with Charles but took a bogey and dropped one shot back. Baird started with three birdies in the first four holes, but stumbled to a double-bogey at the par-5 11th.(AP) Tennis Lendl and Sanchez in Final: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia reached the final of the Passing Shot men's tournament with a 6-3, 6-3 victory yesterday over Jaimie Yzaga of Peru. Lendl will meet Emilio Sanchez of Spain, seeded No. 2, in the final today. Sanchez beat Jean-Philippe Fleurian of France, 6-7, 6-4, 6-1, in the other semifinal. (AP) Perez-Roldan Makes Comeback: Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, the last seeded player left in the tournament, came back to reach the final of the Championships of Sicily yesterday in Palermo. Perez-Roldan, seeded seventh, lost the first set by 4-6 to Pavel Vojtisek of West Germany but won the next two, 6-4, 6-1, to reach today's final against Paolo Cane of Italy. Cane reached the final of the clay-court tournament by defeating eighth-seeded Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia, 6-4, 6-3. (AP) Soccer Chelsea and Arsenal in 0-0 Tie: The Chelsea goalie, Dave Beasant, saved a penalty kick by David Rocastle to preserve a scoreless tie yesterday against Arsenal in the English Soccer League. The tie prevented both teams from catching idle Liverpool atop the First Division.(AP) Dog Show Poodle Takes Best in Show: Ch. Ale Kai Ambitious, a black standard poodle owned by Mary and Dr. Samuel Peacock and Wendell Sammet, her breeder, was gaited by Sammet to the best-in-show prize yesterday at the 51st annual fixture of the Suffolk County Kennel Club. The show was held on the campus of Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. It was the fourth top award for the days. She won Friday at the Brookhaven Kennel Club show in Middle Island, L.I.

title: STREETSCAPES: Millburn Pumping Station; A Rundown 'Abbey' Gets New Life as Condominiums
description: RIDERS on the Long Island Rail Road could mistake it for an ancient, war-damaged abbey. There is a huge hole in its roof and its Romanesque-style tower and walls have gaping holes, with moss and small trees growing all over the structure.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: It is always risky to copy a previous game without subjecting it to your own independent study, even if it is the moves of the world champion you are following. This becomes truer than true if your present opponent happened to be the champion's opponent in the earlier game.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Fort Meade, Md.;
A New Image In the Making
description: LEAD: ALMOST hidden behind a row of fast-food restaurants, bars, video and car-parts stores, a tattoo parlor, a used-car lot and a trailer park along the highway facing the 9,000-acre Fort George G. Meade are the beginnings of a new residential community that may help change the character of the area.

title: Martha W. Miller Becomes a Bride
description: Martha Waite Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Huntington Miller of Wilmington, Del., and Lee, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Hart Bolling 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bolling Jr. of Greenville, Del., and Nantucket, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Lockhart at the First Congregational Church of Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Good Luck, Shane
description: May Cindy Soehner with the mighty attitude My Son Can Do Absolutely Nothing Wrong While Everyone Else Can Do Absolutely Nothing Right be blessed with stupendous good luck so that Shane can turn out a happy and productive member of society.

title: Virgil Thomson, Composer, Critic and Collaborator With Stein, Dies at 92
description: Virgil Thomson, whose homespun, subtly sophisticated compositions and witty but trenchant criticism made him a central figure in American intellectual life for 55 years, died early yesterday in his suite at the Chelsea Hotel in Manhattan. He was 92 years old, and his health had been in decline for several months.

title: Irving Berlin's America: The Melody Lingers On
description: LEAD: Perhaps no other American Composer of popular music was quite so vocal about his love of everything American as Irving Berlin, who died Sept. 22. Lacking the highbrow musical education of, say, Gershwin, Rodgers or Porter, Berlin drew from a bank of melodies that seemed to encompass all of American culture and at the same time included enough of his Russian Jewish roots to add spice when needed.

title: THE THEOLOGY OF THE BOMB
description: THE MEANING OF THE NUCLEAR REVOLUTION Statecraft and the Prospect of Armageddon. By Robert Jervis. 266 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $21.95.

title: ART VIEW
description: Every museum director dreams of the exemplary acquisition - the one that will appear to have found its way to the museum with a beautiful inevitability. Almost never, of course, does it happen like that. But that is how it can look in retrospect, just as when we have watched a golfer hole out in one we forget that, before the little white ball nestled down at the bottom of the hole, luck, wind, weather and a supreme degree of nervous concentration all had a part to play.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD: CIVIL-WAR RE-ENACTMENT

title: Backing for Valvano
description: Although North Carolina State admitted basketball players who were academically unqualified, the basketball coach, Jim Valvano, was not to blame and should not resign. That is the view, anyway, of Bruce Poulton, whose resignation as the university's chancellor took effect yesterday.

title: How to Give Student-Athletes a Better Chance for an Education
description: To the Editor:

title: The Many Aspects Of Hospice Care
description: For whatever reasons, Stephanie Johns's letter to the New Jersey editor on Aug. 20 is a bitter and angry attack on the ''freestanding'' hospice. As a volunteer for the Center for Hope Hospice in Roselle, I would like to offer comments that might have a salutary result for her.

title: A Drive to Improve Products and Compete With the Price of Chicken
description: Three developments could profoundly reduce production costs and, in turn, consumer prices for pork:

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Downtown Brooklyn; Metrotech's Start Signals a Neighborhood Comeback
description: AFTER years of delays, the steel frame now rising for the first building in Metrotech, a $1 billion office and academic complex in Brooklyn, is just one sign that the ambitious plan of city officials and private developers to remake downtown Brooklyn is finally under way.

title: Hugo Shows How to Save Lives While Much Is Lost
description: IT will be months if not years before this coastal city and much of the rest of the Carolinas can put Hurricane Hugo's ravages behind them. But some lessons of the nation's most costly storm ever are already becoming clear. Some are comforting. Some are not.

title: Rachel Bramson Weds B. S. Giese
description: Rachel Bramson, a daughter of Leon Bramson of Chevy Chase, Md., and Mary Van der Tuin of Southfield, Mich., was married yesterday to Benjamin Sherwood Giese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Graham Giese of North Truro, Mass. Annamarie Pluhar, a justice of the peace, assisted by the Rev. Francis A. Hubbard, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Celebrating the Pleasures of Verse
description: LEAD: Literary scholars, and even poets themselves, have often proclaimed poetry passe. Some say people are too driven toward immediate gratification to enjoy the contemplative pleasures of verse. Ohters have blamed poets for writing in styles too comples and self-reflective. Yet, a dedicated group of 200 amateur but active poets has been celebrating the contemplative pleasures of verse for the last 15 years.

title: Supreme Court Rich In Cases of 'What If?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Won Over But Worn Down
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
It's Time for a Firm Hand With Weeds
description: LEAD: THIS is a good time of the year to minimize weed problems. The most obvious step is to prevent weeds from going to seed. If that has already happened, collect and destroy the stalks.

title: F.D.A. Questions Use of Grain in 3 Cereals
description: The Food and Drug Administration says it has serious concerns about how much of a grain is used in three new breakfast cereals and about the manufacturers' claims that the cereals can help lower cholesterol.

title: Film Festival; Uncommon Places In Avant-Garde Trilogy
description: When the three film makers represented in the New York Film Festival's ''Avant-Garde Visions'' program took questions after the press screening, the first one was, ''Do your titles mean anything?'' Whether this question was mischievously philistine or just inarticulate, the panel's moderator repeated it in a delicately rephrased form: ''Would you talk about the meaning of your titles?''

title: Lyme Disease Center Adopts Off-Season Hours
description: LEAD: THE Lyme Disease Diagnostic Center at the County Medical Center in Valhalla scaled back its hours last week but it will remain open yearlong. The center, which has evaluated more than 3,000 people since opening June 12, was to close Sept. 1.

title: Lincoln E. Frank And Molly O'Neil Wed on Fishers I.
description: Margaret Thomas O'Neil and Lincoln Elliot Frank were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y. Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, an Episcopal priest, officiated. Alice Cary Brown attended the bride. The best man was E. Scott Mead.

title: Voice of American Drawing New Critics
description: Bruce S. Gelb, the new director of the United States Information Agency, says he heard ''no complaints about the Voice of America, not one at all,'' when he met Soviet officials in Moscow this month.

title: NASA Names 5 Shuttle Crews
description: The space agency Friday named astronaut crews for five shuttle missions. Those named included Dr. Mae C. Jemison, the first black woman selected for space flight.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Star Wars: Vote on a complicated amendment to a military spending bill for the 1990 fiscal year that would restore $300 million in spending on the anti-missile program. A ''no'' vote would hold the spending at roughly $3.7 billion. Rejected 66 to 34, Sept. 26. 2. Star Wars: Tactical vote on an amendment to the 1990 military spending bill that would raise the money spent on ''Star Wars'' programs to $4.3 billion.

title: Colette: Home Of the Heart
description: BENEATH THE STANDARD FRENCH ROAD SIGN FOR ST.-Sauveur-en-Puisaye, in Burgundy, another larger one proclaims with elaborate flourish that this is ''Colette's Country.'' In the village itself, crude hand-lettered wooden arrows point the way to the house where she was born. Dun-colored signs identify every street but one - there, on fresh royal-blue enamel (blue was her favorite color), a sharp white replica of her signature marks the ''Rue Colette.'' On the house itself, a large rose-marble plaque announces quite simply that ''Here, Colette was born.'' When it was unveiled in 1925, Colette said she appreciated more ''the discretion of a text which evades the exact date of my birth'' than the plaque itself.

title: Conspiring to Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Festival; Video Era in Hungary, In 'The Documentator'
description: Free enterprise's new appeal to some of the Communist-bloc countries is examined with bitterness and occasional wit in ''The Documentator,'' a 215-minute Hungarian film that takes advantage of other aspects of the same political thaw it satirizes.

title: R. J. Lyman Wed To Ms. Schnurr
description: Leslie Anne Schnurr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Schnurr of New York and Sheffield, Mass., and Richard Jeffrey Lyman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bardwell Lyman Jr. of Wayland, Mass., and Sweden, Me., were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church in Sheffield. The Rev. Frederick Heberle, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Peter J. Gomes, an American Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Ankara, at the U.N., Will Press Bulgaria on Turks
description: Turkey's Foreign Minister asserted in an interview this week that Bulgarian officials must restore the ''usurped'' rights of people of Turkish origin living in Bulgaria. He said his Government would call on the General Assembly to give political support to the Bulgarian Turks.

title: MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.
description: The tax code, like other American products, should become obsolete every five years. Planned obsolescence would force the writers of the tax code to be concise. A lawmaker, pressed for time, might write a few pithy pages but would not have the patience to amend a 2,000-page fossil. DUWASKY SNOW New Haven

title: MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.
description: Show us any business with 123,000 employees that does not have a few bad apples within its ranks. Yet, after 35 years as a tax practitioner, I have found the I.R.S. personnel to be helpful and to be trying only to do their best to get their job done.

title: Waging Protest Against the Machines of War
description: DRESSED all in black, her cropped gray hair hidden under a black bathing cap, Kathleen Boylan stepped into the water. It was 3 A.M. on the Thames River near New London, Conn. All was quiet except for the occasional lapping of waves and the sound of Mrs. Boylan struggling to shed her shoes.

title: PASTIMES: Sunday Dinner; Dining, Paris to Beijing, And All in Manhattan
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Alcala

title: Campus Life: Boston U.; Legislator Seeks Dormitory Status For Apartments
description: A city legislator's proposal that would force some landlords to register their buildings as private dormitories and could eventually lead to the use of resident advisers to help curb student rowdyism in off-campus housing has met with opposition from students in this high-density college town.

title: A Dirty War
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Rallies to Stun Clemson
description: Just a week ago, after watching a rout of his Duke squad, Coach Steve Spurrier pronounced his team's chances of victory in the coming game against Clemson as one in a million. Today, that most improbable triumph came to pass, as the Blue Devils defeated the previously unbeaten Tigers, 21-17.

title: Decoy Maker's Art Is Putting Life, and a Little Smile, Into Wood
description: LEAD: UNLIKE the ducks he carves fluidly from cedar planks, Harry Vinuckson Shourds 2d has a solitary streak, a penchant for independence and introspection that has served him well as an artist and a student of nature.

title: Miss Fraser Wed To Bruce Gregory In East Hampton
description: Jennifer Nicoll Fraser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Goodall Fraser of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Bruce Webster Gregory, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Gill Trexler Gregory of Dallas, Virginia Beach, Va., and Northeast Harbor, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Francis D. Creamer and the Rev. Harold E. Barrett officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: Living At Home: Love's Duties
description: I don't think Erika Goodman in writing ''What Am I Doing at Home?'' (Opinion, Sept. 3); really understands not only her parents but what her own responsibilities are. If she does, she certainly doesn't express herself very well. I know if I were living with her, I wouldn't be too happy with her attitudes.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Brentwood $120,000 49 Gates Avenue 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old high ranch; dining room, den, half acre; taxes $3,300. Hicksville $160,000 81 Woodbine Drive North 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement with workroom; taxes $2,100. Islip Terrace $140,000 904 Connetquot Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old high ranch; dining room, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,200. North Massapequa $200,000 6 Mohawk Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; den, finished basement, above-ground pool, cabana; taxes $4,700. Roslyn $439,990 8 Ursula Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; new eat-in kitchen, den w/fireplace, office; taxes $5,000. Sayville $113,000 50 Rollstone Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 100-year-old farmhouse; eat-in kitchen, porch, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. OTHER AREAS West Orange, N.J. $228,500 4 Bromley Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 37-year-old split level; family room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,180. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $490,000 299 Elm Road 5-bedroom, 3 full- and 2 half-bath, 59-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, family room, w/b stove, deck, 0.62 acre; taxes $6,564. Chester, Conn. $208,000 69 Wig Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 89-year-old colonial; period features, large deck, 2 acres; taxes $1,321

title: Sony Expands Into Hollywood
description: Sony is buying into Hollywood. Columbia Pictures accepted a $3.4 billion offer from the Japanese electronics giant. Columbia produces several successful television series but its movie division has lagged. The biggest attraction for Sony executives, led by the president, Norio Ohga, apparently was the 2,700 films in Columbia's library. The movies will provide the ''software'' for video devices that Sony makes, including its new Video Walkman. Sony was already a significant part of the American entertainment industry, having acquired CBS Records last year. Coca-Cola owns 49 percent of Columbia, and an analyst estimated that Coke's profit before tax would be $1.5 billion. *

title: A Humbling Account
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Leaning to Florio, New Jersey Polls Show
description: Three new polls on the race for Governor of New Jersey indicate that voters who have made up their minds or are leaning toward a candidate now favor the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, over his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, by substantial margins.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $490,000 299 Elm Road 5-bedroom, 3 full- and 2 half-bath, 59-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, family room, w/b stove, deck, 0.62 acre; taxes $6,564. Chappaqua, N.Y. $1.2 million 300 Millwood Road 6-bedroom, 6-bath, 77-year-old colonial; library, pub room, studio, sauna, service wing, pool, 3-car garage, 3 acres; taxes $13,920. South Salem, N.Y. $380,000 Spring Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 174-year-old farmhouse; w/b stove, study, music room, fireplace, greenhouse, barn/3-car garage, 2.2 acres; taxes $4,953. Old Saybrook, Conn. $187,000 134 Bokum Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; whirlpool bath, private setting, 2 acres; taxes $1,228. Chester, Conn. $208,000 69 Wig Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 89-year-old colonial; period features, large deck, 2 acres; taxes $1,321. Mansfield, Conn. $175,000 24 Summit Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old raised ranch; fireplace in family room, 2.5 acres; taxes $1,831. OTHER AREAS Belmar, N.J. $347,000 307 Seventh Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. Hicksville, L.I. $160,000 81 Woodbine Drive North 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement workroom; taxes $2,100. Islip Terrace, L.I. $140,000 904 Connetquot Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old high ranch; deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,200.

title: Trademarks for Special Cuts To Give Them Brand Pizazz
description: A well-done chunk of meat with solid bone on one side and a hefty strip of fat on the other, the fried pork chop was once the perfect foil for Jello salad with marshmallows.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA
description: AS BROADWAY CUTS UP through the Upper West Side of Manhattan and into Washington Heights, it gradually turns into a giant Caribbean bazaar. The avenue abounds with bodegas, farmacias, unisex beauty salons, bargain clothing outlets, restaurants serving pollo and platanos, and travel agencies offering bargains to the Dominican Republic. Women squeeze mangoes, children lick flavored ices, men play hard at dominoes, all to the accompaniment of a hundred different radios blaring salsa music. Long a magnet for immigrants, Washington Heights today is home to large colonies of Irish, Jews and, most numerous of all, Dominicans. As the ever-present crowds make their way up and down the street, the Heights seems a living embodiment of the American Dream - a vibrant, energetic urban melting pot.

title: Campus life: Illinois; Stadium Fire May Be Part of Vandals' Attacks
description: Vandals set fire to the football field at Memorial Stadium, hours after the Fighting Illini defeated Utah State University 41-2 in the team's first home game, the authorities said.

title: Questing; Adventures And Visions
description: When pilgrims of the Middle Ages saw the spires of the great Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela, they knew that their adventure was at an end. The goals may be different for today's pilgrims - although Santiago still holds rich rewards - but the pleasure of the traveler's quest remains. The past rises from the present: houses and landscapes, informed by imagination, are populated by poets and princes, saints and charlatans.

title: Review/ Pop; Philip Morris Superband Plays It Light
description: New York City appears to be blessedly in the middle of a big-band revival. The recent appearances of several repertory orchestras and regular engagements by the orchestras of Buck Clayton, Mel Lewis and Illinois Jacquet have all served to raise the standards for big bands. As a result, the Philip Morris Superband, which gave a concert at Town Hall on Sept. 23, suffered by comparison.

title: Appealing Guest Lists Highlight Season
description: THE Jorgensen Auditorium at the University of Connecticut in Storrs today opens an impressive - and international - fall season that will include appearances by the Canadian Brass, the Moscow Virtuosi, the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande and the Vienna Choir Boys. Two orchestras, the New Haven and the Hartford, will begin their seasons this week, and also have appealing guest lists.

title: A Cabaret Tribute to Billie Holiday
description: FOUR months before she died of cirrhosis and heart failure, a ruin at the age of 44, Billie Holiday was relegated to singing in a seedy bar in South Philadelphia.

title: WASHINGTON MEMOIRS: BOMBSHELL OR BUST
description: ''As far as I was concerned, Donald Regan's crack addiction, wife beating and cruelty to animals were his own business, but when I discovered that he held the rank of colonel in the Soviet K.G.B., I put my foot down and said, 'Ronnie, this man has to go.' ''

title: Christine Chang, Designer, Weds
description: Christine Chih Chuan Chang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yuan Chang of New York, was married yesterday to William Shriver Hanway, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. William Hanway of Hypoluxo, Fla. The Rev. Susan Harris officiated at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Surgery for Jacoby
description: The commissioner of the Southwest Conference, Fred Jacoby, received a heart transplant Friday night and was listed in critical condition yesterday at St. Paul Medical Center in Dallas. The 61-year-old Jacoby, who became commissioner in 1982, suffered congestive heart failure in April and entered the hospital's intensive care unit Aug. 27.(AP)

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep planting, especially evergreens, new perennials and shrubs. If the new lawn is at least three inches tall, start mowing; last call to seed bare patches in the established lawn; cover with twigs or burlap to keep birds and rodents from scratching at the seed. Odd Perennial

title: Review/ Music; The Composer as Instrumentalist
description: Bernadette Speach, a pianist, and Jeffrey Schanzer, a guitarist, are also composers who draw on a healthy variety of musical influences. They perform and compose both individually and collaboratively, and on Saturday evening they offered a few of their recent works at Roulette.

title: 5 Facing U.S. Charges In Dallas Race Attacks
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted five men linked to racist skinhead groups in connection with vandalism at a Jewish temple and attacks on black and Hispanic people.

title: Chicago Journal; A New Process Is Used In a Ritual of Cleansing
description: Right now, it's just a small corner of the market, but Howard Skolnik thinks he could be on to something a lot bigger. This week he unveiled a process for making what he thinks is the first kosher steel shipping drum.

title: The Last of Fernando
description: A pet bull named Fernando wandered from a pasture and trapped five people in a convenience store for 45 minutes Wednesday, until a veterinarian shot him with a tranquilizer dart. No one was injured in the episode, but it prompted Ishmael Gomberoff, Fernando's owner, to make plans for his sale next week.

title: For Once, Something Good Happens to the Nice Guy
description: Before the taping of the first episode of ''The Famous Teddy Z,'' a new and much-praised CBS sitcom that takes an amused look at life in a Hollywood talent agency, Hugh Wilson went out and asked the live audience if they knew what an agent was. The crowd got a little testy. ''Of course we know what an agent is,'' said one guest. ''Don't you think we read People?''

title: FOR WOMEN GOLFERS, LIFE IN THE ROUGH
description: AS THE SKY GROWS PASTEL OVER THE FAIRWAYS, A GROUP OF EX-cited corporate executives at the Beaconsfield Golf Club, outside Montreal, are busily draining their highballs. Each of them, all men, has paid more than $1,000 to buy a round of golf with a Ladies' Professional Golf Association touring pro. And now, as names are being drawn from a basket to determine the next day's matchups, the men are cheering wildly. ''You got a good one,'' cries someone to the threesome that will play with Laurie Rinker. ''She's got nice legs!''

title: No Compromise
description: It took an act of Congress to end an act of defiance. Last week, 25 months after going to jail in the District of Columbia for defying a court order and a few days after fast action by Congress, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, a plastic surgeon, went free. She was imprisoned for civil contempt in 1987 after refusing to reveal the whereabouts of her daughter, Hilary, now 7, for court-ordered visits with Dr. Morgan's former husband, Dr. Eric A. Foretich. Dr. Morgan contended that Dr. Foretich sexually abused the girl. He has denied the accusations. As the case drew national attention, Congress passed a bill limiting to 12 months the time that a person can be jailed on civil contempt charges. While her release did not resolve the custody dispute, Dr. Morgan said she was ''happy and very grateful.''

title: Fond Memories of the 'King of Swing'
description: WHEN Loren Schoenberg was growing up, musical groups like the Beatles and the Grateful Dead were the voices of his generation. But he longed for the sound of another time, made popular by big-band greats like Benny Goodman. For Mr. Schoenberg, an opportunity to work with the renowned ''King of Swing'' was a dream come true.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: After the Hurricane
description: HURRICANE HUGO battered the Caribbean two weeks ago, just as island resorts and hotels were readying for their high season. And for some, it will not be business as usual for a long time.

title: Hutchins at Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: For U.S. Coins, a Great Day Is About to Dawn
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Who Left Baby Is Pregnant Again
description: A woman who gave birth in a jetliner restroom in July 1988 and left the infant in a wastebasket will not go to jail until December because she is expecting another baby in mid-October.

title: Mary Sullivan and Peter Fisher Wed
description: Mary Susan Sullivan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Sullivan of Summit, N.J., and Peter Ryerson Fisher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger D. Fisher of Cambridge, Mass., were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. The Rev. James C. Martin officiated.

title: How to DeadenA Live Concert
description: Assuming that music has been around nearly as long as people have been talking, then recordings, which first became available soon after Thomas Edison figured out his wax cylinder in 1877, have been around for just a short blip on the long graph of mankind. But in that short time, recordings, and the technology that allows them to exist, have radically changed music. They've had an enormous impact on the presentation of live music, rearranging the rules of performance, the function of live music and what an audience expects from the show.

title: Christa M. Carey, Broker, Is to Wed
description: January wedding plans have been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Carey Jr. of Duncan, Okla., for their daughter Christa Marie Carey and Richard Wolfe Dunn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Dunn of Boston.

title: Hearing Set on Aged, Disabled Poor
description: A CONGRESSIONAL hearing in Central Islip this week will throw a national spotlight on an innovative Suffolk County program that can better enable localities to shoulder the burden of their growing population of the elderly and disabled poor.

title: Handke's Afternoon
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese Legislators Hold Talks in Saudi Arabia
description: Lebanese legislators who have survived more than 14 years of civil war gathered here today for peace talks intended to overcome differences over the deployment of Syrian forces and Muslim demands for greater political power.

title: Editors' Notes
description: A front-page article in The Times Book Review today discusses the publicity fanfare that has heralded political memoirs, including Nancy Reagan's forthcoming book, ''My Turn.''

title: Academia: Safety Net Or Threat?
description: Trying to identify musical trends in a crazy-quilt culture can be frustrating. Even as the prophets of serious pop proclaim the dawn of a new age of democratic art, equally earnest thinkers for whom pop may be no more than a sound made by a very small gun examine the evidence and see Western music being homogenized and trivialized beyond hope by the new levelers. Since history never moves in only one direction at a time, both camps of seers may be right, if that is any consolation.

title: Suspect Found Hanged in Jail
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man who had been arrested on burglary charges committed suicide in his cell at the 48th Precinct station house in the Bronx early yesterday by hanging himself with his sweatshirt, the police said. The body of the man, Robert Cribb, of 345 Dupont Street in the Greenpoint section, was found by a police officer at 12:47 A.M. during a routine check, which was made of the 20 cells every 15 minutes, the police said. Mr. Cribb, who had been jailed since 5 A.M. Friday, was alone and could not be seen by the guard at his station and the other prisoners, said Capt. Terrence J. Tunnock, commander of the precinct.

title: Alternatives to Bankruptcy
description: ''Personal Bankruptcy Filings Rise on L.I.'' (Sept. 10) was informative and helpful. However, I would like to correct the impression that there are no nonprofits on Long Island to assist people with financial counseling.

title: Richard and Robert Rathe: Exhibit Designers
description: At cocktail parties, the Rathe brothers draw blank stares when they try to explain just what it is that Rathe Productions Inc. produces.

title: Dana Nungesser Marries
description: Dana Ashcraft Nungesser and Eric Richard Macy, vice presidents at the New York investment firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, were married yesterday at the Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J. The Revs. Alfred M. Niese Jr. and David B. Earnest performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Macy, 30 years old, is the daughter of Dr. John Vliet Nungesser of Mendham, N.J., and Avis Ashcraft Nungesser of Park Falls, Wis. Mr. Macy, 30, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Richard Macy of Moraga, Calif.

title: The Fallout of Autumn
description: HERE they come, floating so merrily and drifting so gracefully down into my yard. I marvel at the colors, but only for the moment, for I know each leaf will soon fade and lie in the shadow of another and another and another.

title: Pitt Ties West Virginia, 31-31
description: A 42-yard field goal on the game's last play capped a 22-point rally for Pitt tonight and enabled the Panthers to tie West Virginia, 31-31. Ed Frazier kicked the field goal and the Mountaineers were undone after leading, 31-9, at the end of the third quarter.

title: Fight Baseball's TV Fadeout
description: For 37 years, the ''Game of the Week'' has been Saturday's national Main Street, a televised grandstand linking baseball to provinces hundreds of miles from the nearest big league city. It is network television's longest-running sports program; indeed, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company, it is the most popular April-August weekly sports series of the 1980's.

title: Hurricane Left Grievous Wounds To Land and Spirit of Puerto Rico
description: In most parts of Puerto Rico that were ripped apart by Hurricane Hugo, children rush out now to greet the helicopters that fly in with aid. But not on Culebra.

title: For U.S. Coins, a Great Day Is About to Dawn; Handfuls of Puzzles
description: To the Editor:

title: No Kidding
description: So there was this Jew, this Italian and this black guy, and none of them was laughing last week. The comedian Jackie Mason, who joined Rudolph Giuliani's mayoral campaign a few weeks ago to inject a note of humor and help attract Jewish support, was roundly panned last week for tossing off a flurry of racially tinged one-liners aimed at the Democratic candidate, David N. Dinkins, who is black. In an interview with The Village Voice, Mr. Mason said, among other things, ''There is a sick Jewish problem of voting for a black man no matter how unfit he is for the job.'' Mr. Dinkins said he was sure that Mr. Giuliani would not condone Mr. Mason's remarks. Mr. Giuliani promptly disassociated Mr. Mason from his campaign. The comedian later apologized. ''I learned a lesson in the last few days,'' Mr. Mason said. ''What's funny on the stage can be insensitive when it's said off the stage and in the world of politics.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YIDDISH THEATER

title: Sun Finally Shines on the Blue Jays
description: To Dome or not to Dome? That was the question for the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday.

title: Dinosaur Show Not for All
description: Does Estelle Stanecky still have to be told by someone else that if she stands on a windowsill of the Empire State Building she's likely to fall? (''Dinosaur Display Can Be Scary,'' Letter, Sept.17.) Or has she now -- having put away childish things -- learned it for herself?

title: TWO SEEKERS IN THE SOUK
description: During dinner at the Nile Hilton, in Cairo, a chatty captain recommended we try what he called feteer, a kind of filled pancake sold at snack shops throughout the city. The best one, he added, was to be found in the bazaar, somewhere near the big mosque.

title: Sexist as a Matter of Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamie Jett Wed In New Mexico
description: Jamie Denise Jett and C. Carter Walker 3d, 1987 graduates of the Rhode Island School of Design, were married yesterday in Las Cruces, N.M. The Rev. James Galbraith performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Fashion: On the Street; Pants Suits, Soft And Voluminous
description: Those who yearn to be in the fashion forefront ought to keep an eye on the soft pants suits emerging from the workrooms of a few precedent-setting designers. The term avant-garde could aptly be applied to the prototypes shown here.

title: Historical Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pulaski Day Parade, Fifth Avenue between 26th and 52d Streets will be closed today from noon to 4 P.M.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Meal Memorializes AIDS Victim
description: AN unusual new cookbook out this month is donating part of its profits to providing meals for people with AIDS. ''The Open Hand Cookbook'' (Pocket Books, $18.95) is a compilation of menus donated by 60 California chefs. Edited by Robert C. Schneider, a chef associated with several California restaurants (among them the Hayes Street Grill and the Pier 23 Cafe in San Francisco), the focus is on nourishing meals chefs cook for friends.

title: Glitter and Gleam: A Show of Glass in New London
description: THE glitter of glass objects and the history of glassmaking are the focus of an exhibit at the Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London. Entitled ''All That Glitters Is . . . Glass,'' the exhibit does indeed glitter and gleam, with special lighting on some items like an 1820 English candelabrum with facets and drops.

title: POSTINGS: 190 Units in Greenburgh; Ponds as Centerpieces
description: A 190-unit Georgian colonial-style development will go up over the next two years on a former public school playing field on Stadium Road near Route 100A in the Town of Greenburgh, N.Y. The project, called Pondside, will include 94 two- and three-bedroom town houses and 96 one- and two-bedroom condominium units around two manmade ponds. Do H. Chung & Partners of Stamford, Conn., and Ginsburg & Ginsburg Architects, a unit of Ginsburg Development Corporation of Hawthorne, are the architects.

title:
MUSIC;
State Opera Joins Columbus Parades
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH opera productions often contain scenes of pageantry and spectacle befitting a parade, opera companies are not often invited to participate in real-life parades. This week, members of the New Jersey State Opera chorus and its conductor, Alfredo Silipigni, will make their parade debut.

title: It's Over for Yogi
description: Yogi Berra's announcement that he's about to hang up his uniform for the last time calls for the usual statistical rundown.

title: Keeping the Ambulance Rolling in North Salem
description: LEAD: IN the quieter moments of the North Salem Harvest Festival, between the grape-stomping and pie-eating contests, children walked away from the crowd at the local winery grounds to inspect the new North Salem Volunteer Ambulance Corps ambulance.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the effect of divorce upon children omitted the title of a book and the name of Dr. Judith S. Wallerstein's co-author. The book is ''Second Chances'' (Ticknor & Fields, New York, 1989). The co-author is Sandra Blakeslee, a contributor to The New York Times.

title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala
description: Farmers cultivating the lush volcanic mountains above this isolated city have in the last two years become one of the hemisphere's largest producers of opium poppies, from which heroin is made.

title: T.G.M.F. (Thank God, More Fridays)
description: There's no compelling reason for the week to have seven days. Different cultures have different lengths of the week, ranging from four days in the Bantu and Ibo tribes in Africa to eight days in ancient Rome.

title: Final Go-Rounds For Old Carousel
description: CAROUSEL lovers can take a last spin on the turn-of-the-century Flying Horses at a Middlebury amusement park for free today and next Sunday.

title: Mubarak Repeats Offer to Meet With Shamir
description: The Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, made a rare telephone call to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Friday night and repeated a conditional offer to meet with the Israeli leader, an official said today.

title:
FOCUS: Evictions;
Running Drug Dealers Out of Public Housing
description: LEAD: SINCE 1988, when the Federal Public Housing Drug Elimination Act authorized the eviction of tenants involved in illegal drug activity, this city of 110,000 people, like other cities across the country, has been using it as a major weapon in a war against drugs.

title: Retirement Thins State Worker Ranks
description: NEARLY one-fourth of the seasoned investigators in the western district of the state police will not be showing up for roll-call after today. At Western Connecticut State University in Danbury some ''mega-classes'' are being taught because so many professors will not be returning tomorrow.

title: MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.
description: David Burnham focused on I.R.S. abuses that occurred prior to 1976, the year in which sweeping revisions were made to Section 6103 of the Internal Revenue Code. The provision as it reads today carries stiff penalties (5 years' imprisonment and a fine of up to $5,000 for each offense) for abuse of the information gathered by the Internal Revenue Service. Changes in the ''disclosure'' provisions of the code were made following revelations during the Watergate investi-gation of abuses of the I.R.S. and its information-gathering systems by the Nixon Administration. SCOTT P. BORSACK New York, N.Y.

title: Noodle Kugel Inspires 'Home Style' Poetry
description: LEAD: LIKE William Carlos Williams, Sonia Usatch has a dual interest in verse and medicine. The East Patchogue resident is a medical secretary, not a doctor, as was Williams. But, then, Williams never wrote an ode to a salami.

title: In Monology, to Play It Right Do It Yourself
description: Ten years ago, no one in television would have dreamed of scouting out jarring forums of New York downtown theater for material that could play in Peoria. Yet this November, HBO will feature Reno, one of downtown's most promising monologuists, performing at P.S. (Performance Space) 122, a former public school on the Lower East Side that's becoming a breeding ground for cable specials.

title: Victory for Neighbors of Ohio A-Plant as Lawsuit Is Settled
description: Upholding a central contention of the plaintiffs, a Federal district judge has approved a $78 million settlement in a lawsuit against the Government by neighbors of a uranium processing plant.

title: Outdoors; Waterfowl Season Opens This Month
description: New York State's waterfowling seasons get under way this month, and they and the daily bag limits are much the same as last year.

title: Reassessment Is Never Painless
description: Civic Action Council's Property Tax Committee watches with sympathy the looming specter of reassessment in the City of Long Beach (Sept. 19, ''In Long Beach, Revaluation Brings Specter of Higher Taxes'').

title: 'The Dying Animal'
description: I knew her eight years ago. She was in my class. I dont teach full-time anymore, strictly speaking dont teach literature at allfor years now just the one class, a big senior seminar in critical writing called Practical Criticism. I attract a lot of female students. For two reasons. Because its a subject with an alluring combination of intellectual glamour and journalistic glamour and because theyve heard me on NPR reviewing books or seen me on Thirteen talking about culture. Over the past fifteen years, being cultural critic on the television program has made me fairly well known locally, and theyre attracted to my class because of that. In the beginning, I didnt realize that talking on TV once a week for ten minutes could be so impressive as it turns out to be to these students. But they are helplessly drawn to celebrity, however inconsiderable mine may be.

title: Miss DeBerardine Weds
description: Veronica Ann DeBerardine and Bruce Cameron Bennett, associates in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, were married yesterday in Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. Frank Del Prete performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Gabriel.

title: Soviets Seek Proper Word For Property
description: The Soviet Legislature is to digress from the gloomy, down-to-earth business of next year's budget on Monday to consider what may be the ultimate issue: who owns the Soviet Union?

title: VICTORIES OF THE SPIRIT
description: Congratulations on your photographic feature ''Victories of the Spirit'' (Photographs by Mary Ellen Mark, Aug. 27).

title: How's Old Burt Reynolds? Doing Fine, Thank You
description: It comes to few men to be as successful in films as Burt Reynolds has been. For five consecutive years, a record bested only by Shirley Temple, he parlayed an easygoing insouciance, a riverboat gambler's charm and a genial bonhomie into a run as the world's No. 1 box-office draw. ''I am a part of film history, and that pleases me no end,'' he says quietly. ''It's like the Heisman Trophy; you die with that, it's as good an introduction as you get. They can say, 'His career went downhill after that; he made bad films.' It doesn't matter.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Montauk Yacht Club Conversion Proposed
description: LEAD: A MANHATTAN development group called Montauk Development Associates has proposed converting the Montauk Yacht Club on Star Island in Lake Montauk - with its 107 hotel rooms and about 230 boat slips - into a condominium resort.

title:
GARDENING;
It's Time for a Firm Hand With Weeds
description: LEAD: THIS is a good time of the year to minimize weed problems. The most obvious step is to prevent weeds from going to seed. If that has already happened, collect and destroy the stalks.

title: 18 Hurt in Cleveland Crash
description: A tractor-trailer loaded with steel coils hit the rear end of a disabled tourist bus today, and the police said 18 people had been hurt. The victims were carried to various hospitals, and there was no word on the severity of their injuries.

title: Tamara Weiss Marries Gary A. Stuber
description: Tamara Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Weiss of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday at her parents' home at Gay Head on Martha's Vineyard to Gary A.
