Stuber, a son of Audrey Stuber of Copake Falls, N.Y., and the late Alfred Stuber Jr. The ceremony was performed by Luther Tackmash Madison, a Wampanoag Indian medicine man; William Sloane Coffin; the bride's father, and Betty Ann Bryant, a justice of the peace in Chilmark, Mass.

title: A Rock Singer Returns, With a Difference
description: Having spent most of the 1980's delving into musical territory outside the pop-rock mainstream, Linda Ronstadt returns to contemporary pop with a strong new album, ''Cry Like a Rainstorm - Howl Like the Wind'' (Elektra 96082; all three formats).

title: Frans Hals: Unabashed Painter of Portraits
description: If there is a time for everything, the time for Frans Hals came in the middle of the 19th century, some 200 years after he died. Hals had spent more than five decades as a portraitist in his adopted city of Haarlem, a position not without significance but hardly one that qualified him as eminent. Painters of grand historical and religious scenes were considered artists of ambition; portraiture was an altogether more lowly endeavor.

title: Vietnam Goes Home, Still Casting an Eye Over All of Indochina
description: AT the final farewell ceremony for Vietnamese soldiers here last week, the General Secretary of the People's Revolutionary Party of Cambodia, Heng Samrin, was the centerpiece of a typical socialist-style tableau of Politburo leaders and distinguished guests.

title: Power From Space Is Pollution Free
description: Most of the discussion about preserving the ecology of our planet has focused on Earth-based solutions. These have been aimed at protecting the environment and providing energy to meet the demands of the planet's expanding population. In the near- to mid-term, these are important and valuable steps. But in the long term, a key to humanity's continued evolution will be the penetration of space and the economic and scientific exploitation of the solar system's inexhaustible resources and unique physical characteristics.

title: Dr. Duchesneau Weds Dr. Michelle Paris
description: Duchesneau, a resident in pediatrics at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, and Dr. Joseph Michael Lally Jr., a resident in ophthalmology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Piscataway, were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Timothy F. Hourihan officiated. The bride, 28 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Duchesneau of Maplewood, N.J. Dr. Lally, 29, is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lally of Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Miss Brown Wed To John DeClue
description: Elizabeth Grace Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Brown of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Martin DeClue, a son of Marjorie M. DeClue and Albert S. DeClue, both of Bainbridge, N.Y. The Rev. Edward J. Dougherty officiated at Our Lady of Princeton Roman Catholic Church.

title: Owner and Skipper of Tanker Fined for Spill
description: The owner of a tanker that spilled 300,000 gallons of heating oil off Newport when it ran aground in June has been fined $500,000 and its captain has been fined $30,500.

title: New York Area Aids Islands After Hurricane
description: Donations and supplies from people in the New York metropolitan area to help the victims of Hurricane Hugo in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands have amounted to at least $7 million since the storm devastated parts of the Caribbean less than two weeks ago, and the relief effort is continuing.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Darryl has proven to be a liability in the field, lazy on the bases, and a poor hitter in both his average and his power when men are on base. Would the Mets be sacrificing home runs by trading Darryl? Probably. But more importantly, would the Mets be a better team with a player in right field who batted, played hard everyday, and who hit better than .260 for a career? I think the obvious answer is yes. GREGORY JAMES Jersey City, N.J.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: When a Government office sends Government mail through a Government Postal Service, who pays?

title: Campus Life: Virginia; Vacating Rooms In Dawn Searches For a Bush Visit
description: Arthurian romances were on Kathy Lavezzo's mind until Federal agents with German shepherds came to her classroom door at the University of Virginia.

title: NONFICTION
description: NEW YORK. By Djuna Barnes. Edited by Alyce Barry. (Sun & Moon Press, Cloth $24.95, Paper $12.95.) To Djuna Barnes, author of the novels ''Ryder'' and ''Nightwood,'' New York could never be discovered in its demographics or statistics. ''The real Bronx has nothing to do with facts,'' she wrote, ''as the real Greenwich Village has nothing to do with facts, as no real good woman has anything to do with facts.'' Barnes's youthful journalism, written between 1913 and 1919 for such newspapers as The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, makes no claim to objectivity, which she called ''newspaper fiction.'' In search of adventure and subjects, she enters gorilla cages, volunteers to be rescued by firemen and, more painfully, undergoes force-feeding, to see if she had ''as much nerve as [ her ] English sisters,'' the feminists subjected to such treatment by British authorities. To the modernists the city was a site of dislocation, and Barnes traveled the length of New York to experience its unsettling effects. A favorite location was Coney Island, and the Coney Island of Barnes's mind was a frontier of novel behaviors set in a futuristic landscape of thrilling, giant machines that epitomized a changing society. In fact, Barnes's Coney Island became a trope for the danger and promise of the city itself. Her social commentary is vivid and idiosyncratic, marked by unusual images, empathy, irony and a complex class consciousness. What is fascinating about these essays, edited by Alyce Barry, a freelance editor, is their unique language and insights, which exist in tandem with some of the conventional wisdom of the day. Barnes's writing exemplifies an American avant-garde that was not ahead of its time on all counts, but was, rather, thoroughly of it, reveling and struggling in it.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A CHINESE SUMMER. By Mark Illis. (Viking, $16.95.) Without going anywhere at all, Simon Hare finds himself in a foreign country. It's still his native England, but after his sweetheart, Helen, moves out, it seems to him a China with isolating walls and inscrutable, teeming masses. His is a crisis of youth and loss, and some serious self-pity.

title:
GARDENING;
It's Time for a Firm Hand With Weeds
description: LEAD: THIS is a good time of the year to minimize weed problems. The most obvious step is to prevent weeds from going to seed. If that has already happened, collect and destroy the stalks.

title: CRY, THE BELOVED CITY
description: JERUSALEM City of Mirrors. By Amos Elon. 286 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: Hungary Refuses to Sign East Bloc Statement
description: Hungary refused to sign a final statement at a meeting of Communist officials from 12 countries, saying the document made false accusations against West Germany, a report by the Hungarian state press agency said.

title: Review/Music; Quartet Opens Shostakovich Project
description: Dmitri Shostakovich was 32 years old and had five symphonies behind him when he completed his first string quartet, in 1938. At his death in 1975, the symphonies and quartets had reached parity - 15 each. The cycles complement each other, with the symphonies standing as his more public pronouncements and the quartets as records of his private turmoil.

title: Margaret Tsang Wed to Eugene Miao
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Margaret Elizabeth Tsang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew W. Tsang of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Eugene Anthony Miao, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ling Miao of Palos Verdes, Calif. The Rev. Leo Gorman officiated.

title: Prospects
description: Seeking the Dollar's Level

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PICASSO: Creator and Destroyer, by Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington. (Avon, $4.95.) Considering how badly he treated his lovers, Picasso's painting ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon,'' with its twisted, tormented women, might have been a family portrait. Last year our reviewer, James R. Mellow, called this biography ''a lively and tendentious book.'' TWO AGAINST ONE, by Frederick Barthelme. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) During a surprise birthday visit from his estranged wife, Elise, Edward learns how much he truly loathes her. ''In its determination to pare away the layers of irony, casual self-deception and bravado that obscure the reality of modern marriage, 'Two Against One' is intermittently shocking and admirably brave,'' Francine Prose said in The Book Review last year. ''Unlike novels in which heroes with marital troubles still manage to have a rollicking good time, 'Two Against One' is so suffused with loneliness and angst that some sections . . . are almost unbearably painful to read.'' THE LIFE OF LANGSTON HUGHES. Volume II: 1941-1967. I Dream a World, by Arnold Rampersad. (Oxford University, $12.95) When the second volume of this biography of the poet laureate of black America was published last year, our reviewer, Rita Dove, praised ''the penetrating characterization and elegant analysis. . . . By tackling the thorny issues of race and politics whenever they impinged on Hughes's public and private ambitions, the author focuses an entire century through the lens of one exemplary life.'' THE CAPTAIN AND THE ENEMY, by Graham Greene. (Penguin, $7.95.) In the jungles of Central America, the narrator of this novel seeks the true identity of the mysterious stranger who, once long ago, spirited him away from a boarding school, claiming that he had won him in a backgammon game. Last year our reviewer, Brian Moore, said that ''in this short, skillful book we enter those disparate worlds Mr. Greene has made his own - the England of 'Brighton Rock' and 'The Ministry of Fear,' and the exotic Central American territories in which his restless talent has so often roamed.'' NOWHERE TO GO: The Tragic Odyssey of the Homeless Mentally Ill, by E. Fuller Torrey. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $8.95). Because of the country's failure to empty its asylums, E. Fuller Torrey writes, there are now more mentally ill people on the streets than in hospitals. At the same time, he says, psychiatrists concentrate on treating the ''worried well,'' who can afford to pay their bills. Last year our reviewer, Tamar Lewin, said she was unpersuaded by Dr. Fuller's argument for a return to involuntary commitment and forced treatment. But she said the book was ''an urgent call'' to make community mental health centers ''fulfill their original purpose.'' THE SILENCE IN THE GARDEN, by William Trevor. (Penguin, $7.95.) With the building of a bridge to the mainland, a wealthy Irish family finds the splendid isolation of its island kingdom invaded by the sordid realities of life. ''Mr. Trevor demonstrates the same sort of intimate knowledge of a place that Joyce displayed in 'Dubliners' and 'Ulysses,' '' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. HYPOCHONDRIA: Woeful Imaginings, by Susan Baur. (University of California, $9.95.) A psychologist tries to figure out why so many people make themselves sick by imagining that they are ill. ''The author's horrific case histories are relentlessly entertaining, and her interpretations ring true,'' Mike Oppenheim said here last year. THE MASKS OF ROME, by Caroline Llewellyn. (Ivy, $3.95.) A young Canadian art expert is the target of a murder plot after she uncovers a forgery. Last year our reviewer, Anne Whitehouse, called this first novel ''an adventure novel in the style of Daphne du Maurier and Mary Stewart.'' BROKEN ALLIANCE: The Turbulent Times Between Blacks and Jews in America, by Jonathan Kaufman. (Mentor/New American Library, $4.95.) During the civil rights movement, many blacks and Jews were united in what seemed a common cause. Interviewing people from both groups, a Boston Globe reporter asks why the alliance fell apart. ''The book's tone is that of a good novel in which human complexity tempers conflict,'' Shelby Steele said here last year. SILENCE IN HANOVER CLOSE, by Anne Perry. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) Inspector Thomas Pitt and his wife are joined by her recently widowed sister, who poses as a maid to solve a Victorian high society murder. Last year our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, said ''the period detail in these stories always comes decorously draped around the solid bones of a good, gory crime.'' A HISTORY OF THEIR OWN: Women in Europe From Prehistory to the Present. Volume Two, by Bonnie S. Anderson and Judith P. Zinsser. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $12.95.) Two historians show that history looks very different when seen through the eyes of the women who lived it instead of the men. ''For a book that presents the big picture, this one is remarkably readable,'' Lynn Hunt said here last year. ''The young women, and young men, who read this history will find scores of examples to emulate.'' HEAVEN'S PRISONERS, by James Lee Burke. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) When a plane crashes in the bayou, a New Orleans ex-detective finds a secret survivor and clues to an underworld of drugs. ''There is a pronounced streak of poetry in Mr. Burke's prose,'' Newgate Callendar said last year in The Book Review. ''He has the knack of combining action with reflection.''

title: The People's Republic at 40, at Odds With the People
description: THE People's Republic of China prepared to mark its 40th anniversary today with splendid dragon dances and fireworks, but with little joy.

title: Words of Beauty And Terror Inform A Graham Classic
description: Martha Graham was sure of one thing about her new version of ''American Document,'' a dance she originally choreographed in 1938: ''I know some people - some of the old birds - may hate it,'' she said. ''They'll hate it simply because it's different and not the 'American Document' they saw before. Others may like it, though.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: San Diego
description: Not everyone in this conservative military town approves, but San Diego this fall hosts what is billed as the largest festival of Soviet art and culture ever brought to the United States. The Soviet events represent a kind of reverse glasnost, part of Mayor Maureen O'Connor's efforts to show that San Diego is more than just a warm quiet place by the ocean for retired naval captains to tend their gardens of hibiscus and oleander.

title: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF AN ANGELHEADED HIPSTER
description: GINSBERG A Biography. By Barry Miles. Illustrated. 588 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Suzanne E. Hyer, A Lawyer, Weds
description: At Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Amherst, N.Y., Suzanne E. Hyer, a partner in the New York law firm of Hinckley & Silbert, was married yesterday to Joseph F. Savona, a partner in Dockery, Savona & Scully, a law firm in New York. Msgr. Francis T. Sorci and the Rev. Peter Pastore, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Works in Progress; Egging Them On
description: SEA TURTLES ARE LARGELY mysterious creatures. Because they are pelagic, meaning they live their entire lives in the open ocean, most of what we know about them comes from observing the females, who periodically visit beaches, mainly in warm-water regions, to lay eggs. There are no estimates as to the extant population, but it is evident, from the numbers of turtles that become casualties in the course of commercial fishing and the loss of their egg-laying habitat to beach development, that they are a dwindling breed. Five of the six species are endangered.

title: Correction
description: A report on Sept. 17 about the wedding of Allison D. Barrall misidentified her father, Dr. John H. Barrall. He is an assistant professor at the Brown University medical school.

title: 1940's Baseball Hit a Chord
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sun Setting on Pakistan's Horse-Drawn Tonga
description: On the streets of Rudyard Kipling's town, now choked by traffic and blanketed in exhaust, there is scant space and little time left for the tonga.

title: Lost? Here's Mr. Directions.
description: I SOMETIMES think that people must think that my name is Rand McNally. It seems that a day doesn't go by when some motorist doesn't pull up to me when I'm walking and asks me directions.

title: In Ethiopia, Unlikely Warriors Against AIDS
description: In a tin-roofed, shanty-like classroom where primary school students usually struggle to learn math, a smartly dressed prostitute posed her problem to a nurse conducting a seminar on AIDS.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: LEAD: GRASS by Sheri S. Tepper (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95) is a splendid achievement, one of the most satisfying science fiction novels I have read in years. With a nod toward Frank Herbert's ''Dune'' and Brian Aldiss's ''Helliconia,'' Ms. Tepper has conceived a fascinating planet covered with grasses of many colors, shapes and textures, a world of long, long seasons inhabited by creatures whose complex ecological interactions are appropriately confusing to outsiders.

title: French Premier Faces Strikes and Left's Fire
description: It looks as if it might be a long hot autumn for France's Socialist Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, as he hears rumblings on his left over his efforts to hold down social spending and salaries for Government workers.

title: Zina Glazebrook: Window Display Designer
description: As a child, Zina Glazebrook used to get together with a friend and move all the furniture around. ''It used to make my mother nuts a bit,'' recalled Ms. Glazebrook, who was born in Philadelphia, grew up in Bedford, N.Y., and is 39 years old. ''But for me I guess it was the genesis of what I'm doing now.''

title: Michael Caine Turns Homicidal
description: It is a character that Michael Caine seems born to play. Sinister yet seductive, immoral yet irresistible, he conceals his madness with a coating of charm. When a beautiful young co-worker, played by Elizabeth McGovern, discovers that he may have committed a horrible crime, he quickly and effortlessly puts his powers to work. He moves close to her, then gives her a coolly suggestive smile. ''Don't look so worried,'' he whispers reassuringly, and in a second, her fears are calmed. Despite her better instincts, she finds herself longing for him.

title: Ms. Jack Weds A. H. Rowan 3d
description: The nondenominational First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Claudia Badger Jack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Kress Jack of Greenwich, and Archibald Hamilton Rowan 3d, the son of Mrs. Theodore W. O'Connell Jr. of New York and Greenwich and the late Mr. Rowan Jr. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester officiated.

title: Cards' Back Is Out
description: The Phoenix Cardinals placed the running back, Stump Mitchell, on the National Football League's injured-reserve list yesterday and activated the rookie defensive back Marcus Turner off their developmental squad. Mitchell, the franchise's No. 2 career rusher and its leader in combined yardage with 11,988, suffered a severe knee injury in last Sunday's 35-7 loss to the Giants. The 30-year-old Mitchell, a nine-year pro, underwent reconstructive surgery for torn ligaments and cartilage in his left knee Tuesday and is out for the rest of the season. He said he might attempt a comeback next year.(AP)

title: Pork That is Pinker and Purer Appeals to the Japanese
description: The Japanese don't like the pale, watery pink color Americans seem to prefer in pork. They like their meat to be deeper in color.

title: Pamela Polcini, Designer, Weds
description: Pamela Grace Polcini and Dr. Carl Dietrich Reimers 3d were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. John Andrew and the Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin. The bride is a daughter of Paula Polcini of Yonkers and the late Damon P. Polcini. Her husband is the son of the Rev. Carl D. Reimers Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and New York, and Mrs. John N. Irwin 2d of New Canaan, Conn. and New York.

title: THE GLORY THAT WAS GREECE'S
description: Beginning in 1801, when Greece was still part of the Ottoman Empire, the British Ambassador to Constantinople, the seventh Earl of Elgin, acquired from Turkish authorities much of the sculptural ornament of the Parthenon in Athens. Known as the Elgin Marbles, the sculptures are generally recognized as the most sublime expression of the Classical Greek style of the fifth century B.C. and are among the prized exhibits of the British Museum. They also remain an intrinsic part of the Parthenon, the great temple of Athena that has become an icon not only of Greek nationhood but of Western civilization. Since the removal, there have been passionate calls for their return to Greece by the Greek Government and others. Christopher Hitchens's IMPERIAL SPOILS: The Curious Case of the Elgin Marbles (Hill & Wang, $19.95) is both a history of the controversy and a plea for the return of the sculptures. A number of Lord Elgin's contemporaries - from Lord Byron to members of Parliament - opposed the acquisition on much the same grounds advanced by restitutionists today: that Turks had no right to allow Greek treasures to be carried off, that Lord Elgin overstepped even the authority given him by the Turks, that archeological remains are best appreciated in situ. Despite the title, Mr. Hitchens, a columnist for The Nation, treats the acquisition more as an ill-considered use of influence than as imperialistic looting, and he views any eventual return as an act of generosity. His account, full of colorful characters and written with wit, is entertaining as well as provocative.

title: Fan Travels Heartbreak Lane
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bridgeport Zoo Adding Rain Forest
description: LEAD: THE trill of songbirds, squawk of macaws, roar of cougars and intermittent croaks of a dozen species of toads will soon greet visitors to the new rain forest exhibit at the Beardsley Zoological Gardens in Bridgeport.

title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow
description: Eric Griffin, who lost a chance to make the 1988 United States Olympic team because of a positive test for marijuana, stood tonight as the world amateur boxing champion at 106 pounds.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Breaking In,'' which will close the New York Film Festival, gives an incorrect date. The film will be shown on Oct. 9, not tomorrow.

title: Liftoff for Armchair Travelers
description: In the course of his new 12-part PBS series, ''Travels,'' which begins tomorrow night at 8, John Heminway devotes an hour to ''Yesterday's Travelers,'' notably Lowell Thomas, James Fitzpatrick and Osa Martin Johnson, who introduced a generation of homebound moviegoers in the 1930's and 40's to faraway places and exotic peoples. The homage raises the question of whether what public television needs these days is another travel series. After several seasons of National Geographic journeys and other venturesome shows, what can ''Travels'' bring us that is special?

title: Julia Tualavera Plans to Marry
description: Julia Talavera and Robert McKay Pflieger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ely Pflieger of Washington, plan to be married this month. The announcement was made by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Edwin Flye Stetson 2d of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Meriden Loses Claim to Fame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: London Isn't Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFESSIONS OF A SMARTYBOOTS
description: FOR LOVE & MONEY A Writing Life, 1969-1989. By Jonathan Raban. 344 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row.

title: POSTINGS: Grant's Farm; History Subdivided
description: A part of what was once Ulysses S. Grant Jr.'s Westchester County farm has been subdivided and offered for sale to anyone who wants a piece of history along with the privacy that 10 or 15 acres can provide.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These new addicts are business executives and house painters and doctors and receptionists. And if you met them on the street or at the Little League game, you wouldn't have a clue they're smoking their brains out on crack back home in the basement.'' - Dr. Arnold M. Washton. [ 1:2. ]

title: John Walker, 64, Episcopal Bishop in Washington
description: The Rev. John Thomas Walker, the first black Episcopal bishop of Washington and a staunch crusader against racial discrimination at home and abroad, died of heart failure at Georgetown University Hospital yesterday. He was 64 years old. Bishop Walker had undergone triple bypass surgery Friday, the Episcopal Diocese of Washington said.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
In Plant World, Latin Isn't Dead
description: LEAD: Latin binomials of plants often sound strange to the uninitiated, but take heart. For one thing, you do not need to learn the whole language with its attendant grammar, tenses, declensions and parts of speech. All you need to know is a vocabulary, a partial one at that.

title: Chef's Signatures in Huntington Village
description: LAST year, East Northport's Peter's Inn headed my list of exciting food finds. This neighborhood bar-turned-gourmet restaurant was a diamond in the rough. Its sparkle emanated from the unexpectedly innovative dishes created by the chef, Bruce Grasley.

title: Review/Theater; A Private Eye, a Piano And the Usual Suspects
description: Charlie Peters's new little comedy, ''Hollywood Scheherazade,'' is an innocent piece of nonsense. Utterly innocent. It is over soon enough, in little more than an hour, but it could have made its points and won all its laughs in a quarter of that time.

title: Poland's Censors Beginning to Fade
description: Poland's censor, still officially ensconced in the Government bureaucracy, reached for his scissors 2,528 times last year, and 80 percent of his snipping was done in 20 mostly non-Communist, church-related newspapers.

title: At Home in Tuscany
description: IT all seemed very Italian, renting a house in Tuscany with my husband, our two sons and my mother, all five of us piling in and out of the car wherever we went. The two women collecting money for the use of the public toilets at Pisa's Campo dei Miracoli thought it was terrific. They laughed when my husband kept shelling out coins as we straggled in, one by one.

title: Urgent Need Seen To Protect Beaches Of South Carolina
description: Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. says South Carolina urgently needs to build 65 miles of protective sand dunes before mid-October to prevent high tides from doing further damage to a coastline already devastated by Hurricane Hugo.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: The 19th-century American fascination with wealth fostered an American art form - the trompe l'oeil painting of paper money.

title: Rules Needn't Destroy Individuality
description: How sad that Cindy E. Soehner has chosen to home tutor her 8-year-old son, Shane, rather than send him to school.

title: Shoreham Story: Unbridled Greed
description: Every time we think we have seen the most bizarre event yet in the Lilco-Shoreham story, another one arrives to surpass it. One of the most curious is the disclosure that hundreds of thousands of dollars were paid out to Lilco's chairman, William Catacosinos, as a reward for negotiating the deal with Governor Cuomo.

title: Some Bases Not Covered
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: DIANE DORAN;
Saving Fossey's Gorillas in the Mist
description: LEAD: SOMETIME later this month, Diane Doran, a 34-year-old primate researcher, will leave her home in Northport for the east-central-African republic of Rwanda, where she will become director of the Karisoke Research Center.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MAJESTIC. By Whitley Strieber. (Putnam, $18.95.) Whitley Strieber has a story to tell. He also has a message to deliver, but sometimes his objectives collide. In his new novel, ''Majestic,'' he combines fictitious confessions and military documents with genuine newspaper reports to depict a reputed encounter with alien beings near New Mexico's Roswell Army Air Field in 1947.

title: Christina Dockstader Weds
description: At the Princeton University Chapel, Christina Dare Dockstader, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tod Allen Dockstader of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Randy Eugene Kinard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Eugene Kinard of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Sue Anne Steffey Morrow, a Methodist minister, officiated. Mrs. Kinard, an actress, and Mr. Kinard, a bond salesman for J. P. Morgan Securities in New York, are both 27 years old and graduates of Princeton. The bridegroom has an M.B.A. from New York University.

title: A Dirty War
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Stakes Strike Looms for Hospitals
description: Pinning its fortunes to a sharp escalation of a long-simmering contract dispute, the state's largest hospital workers union is preparing for a high-stakes strike Wednesday against most of the New York City area's private hospitals and nursing homes.

title: Sailing Fiji's Far Waters
description: SUNLIGHT COMES THROUGH THE HATCH OF the crew compartment in this 50-foot sailboat - now at anchor in Suva, Fiji - and wakes me at dawn. I've taken the lower berth, 24 inches across at its widest point. Through the hull, a few inches from my ear, I hear snapping shrimp crackle softly like popcorn as they graze along the bottom of the sea. The shrouds hum in the early breeze.

title: TALKING: 'Gazundering'; Soft Market Puts Sellers On the Spot
description: WHEN the housing market is weak, sellers are sometimes forced to accept less for a home than the price stipulated in the sales contract. Brokers and lawyers say buyers are increasingly chipping away, between the signing of the contract and the closing, in an effort to get the seller to lower the agreed-upon price.

title: Toon Is Finding Injuries Are Part of Job
description: When Al Toon has a pain, Joe Walton suffers.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIBERTY IN EXPANSION 1760-1850. By Oscar and Lilian Handlin. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row. $25.95.) In ''Liberty in Expansion 1760-1850,'' the second in a projected four-volume series on the evolution of freedom in the United States, the historians Oscar and Lilian Handlin focus on the development of the republic from its inception to the eve of the Civil War.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Absolutely not. Trading away Strawberry would become a blunder similar to the exportation of Nolan Ryan and Tom Seaver. Darryl is the premier left-handed power hitter in the National League. He has been plagued by injuries all season which have resulted in a drop of his statistics. RICHARD S. BEATUS Woodmere, L.I.

title: Towns Resist Selection As Sites for Sewage
description: LEAD: TWO communities are fighting against being chosen as the site for a $50 million Nassau County sewage-sludge drying plant. The county must build the plant because ocean sludge dumping will be stopped by the end of 1991.

title: A 'New Dylan' Crosses Paths With the Old
description: During the 1970'S, when one singer-songwriter after another was touted as ''the new Bob Dylan,'' the promiscuous announcement of so many imminent successors to one of the most influential rock artists of the 60's eventually became a joke. It wasn't until 1981 that the automatic comparison of every up-and-coming troubadour with Mr. Dylan was finally ridiculed to death by the critic Greil Marcus with his list of 57 ''new Dylans'' in ''The Book of Rock Lists.'' Capping the joke was the fact that Mr. Dylan's own name appeared on the list five different times, in recognition of the stylistic and religious contortions his music and point of view had undergone.

title:
ART;
Graphic Art's Glory Days in New Rochelle
description: LEAD: THE adage about birds of a feather flocking together applies resoundingly to the cultural life of New Rochelle - home since the last century to a legion of prominent artists, especially illustrators. The dean of them all, Norman Rockwell, lived here in the 1920's and 30's.

title: Design; AS TIME GOES BY
description: MANHATTAN BROWN-stones that have remained single-family houses are a rarity these days, especially those that have retained their original layouts and intricate architectural details. The rooms in this 1860's house were remodeled, but nearly 80 years ago during the Edwardian era. In the intervening years, they have been lovingly preserved and purposely decorated to reflect the spirit of the place. ''The Edwardians sensitively revived 18th-century styles,'' says Mark Hampton, the New York designer who decorated the house. ''When I began the project, I felt as though I was viewing the 18th century twice removed -through the eyes of the Edwardians.''

title: Wistful Visit By a Welcome Season: Sweet, Fleeting Indian Summer
description: OCTOBER has within it a time, a smell and a feeling of its own. The contrast between the deep greens of early September and the polychromatic botanical display of mid-Autumn jars the eye.

title: Despite Ban, Chilean Army Gets 15 U.S. Copters
description: The Chilean Army has taken delivery on 15 helicopters bought from a United States manufacturer, but American officials say the transaction does not represent a lifting of the ban on military sales to Chile.

title: Heidi C. Kesseler Weds Executive
description: Heidi Christine Kesseler and John P. Langton 2d were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: BLACKMAILING BILLY ROSE
description: THE BELLAROSA CONNECTION By Saul Bellow. 102 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: TUNIS: A RAGOUT WITH A SECRET
description: Sometimes a dish is so haunting you can't get it out of your mind.

title: Tish Barroll Wed To J. B. Frederick
description: Letitia Humphreys Barroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Barroll of Baltimore, was married yesterday to James Bradley Frederick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Frederick of New Britain, Conn. The Rev. David H. LaMotte officiated at St. Christopher's By-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Gibson Island, Md.

title: 'Class War' Pitch Now Fails, Democrats Find in Tax Defeat
description: The Democratic defeat on the capital gains tax in the House of Representatives this week is raising new questions on Capitol Hill about the party's message, the strength of its leadership and its ability to hold the line against a popular President.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Back to China: A 10-Day Tour For $1,339

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Devils have signed two goaltenders, Craig Billington and Ronald Melanson, and assigned them to the team's Utica farm club in the American Hockey League. . . . Janet Evans, the swimmer who won three gold medals at the 1988 Olympics, was named the Women's Sports Foundation Amateur Athlete of the Year. . . . Ivan Lendl, a five-time champion, has become the first player to qualify for the Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden Nov. 28-Dec. 3. . . . Andy Walker resigned as the men's basketball coach at Niagara University. . . . Leroy Irvin, the Los Angeles Rams' cornerback, has been activated after completing a 30-day suspension for substance abuse. (AP)

title: ROASTING THE ACADEMICS
description: AN APPETITE FOR POETRY By Frank Kermode. 242 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.

title: Baur's Passes Help As Lafayette Wins
description: Frank Baur silenced most of his doubters today with his first pass of the day as he rifled a 53-yard line-drive between two defenders to Dave Baird for a touchdown 50 seconds into the game, as Lafayette beat Columbia, 52-14.

title: Mets' Most Ominous Day: It Ran Gamut of Season
description: Maybe it began on the day in March when they gathered for the annual team photograph in spring training and Darryl Strawberry threw a punch at Keith Hernandez, and then huffed out of camp for a day of sulking on the sidelines.

title: A Youngster's Efforts On Behalf of the Police
description: THE Bristol police department is now two bullet-proof vests richer because of the efforts of a 4-foot 9-inch, 87-pound resident who said he was concerned about police officers being shot in the line of duty.

title: The Midwest Tries to Slow The Flow of Eastern Trash
description: EACH week, the trucks roll westward and southward from New Jersey, New York and, to a lesser extent, Connecticut, filled to overflowing with one of the East Coast's rising new exports. It is garbage, tons and tons of unsorted household refuse and miscellaneous municipal waste, stuffed into semi-trailers and headed for landfills in western Pennsylvania and elsewhere.

title: Review/ Theater; Absurdist Double Bill
description: Although Robert Pinget's reputation as an experimental novelist - as a leader of the nouveau roman movement in France - is secure, his role as a playwright is more problematic. These problems are not resolved by the Ubu Repertory Theater production of two Pinget one-acts, ''Abel and Bela'' and ''Architruc.''

title: Paying Attention To the Schools Is a National Mission Now
description: MANY educators and state officials feared that President Bush's ''edu-cation summit'' last week at the University of Virginia would be little more than an extended photo opportunity for the man who has vowed to be ''the education President.'' But afterward, there was growing agreement among the experts that something more substantive had occurred.

title: The Wisdom of the Tooth Fairy
description: >WHILE back, my son lost a tooth, and I lost my temper. Actually, it happened the other way around. First, I lost my temper, and then the tooth came out.

title: POSTINGS: Photo Exhibition Opens; Land-Use Debate
description: A sweeping land-use change, the Lower Density Contextual Zoning Amendment, has prompted heated controversy since it was adopted by New York City's Board of Estimate in June. Requiring new residential construction to be compatible with existing housing, it will affect half the city's residential land.

title: No Headline
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-27 East Germans left Bonn's embassy in Prague, where they had been camping, and boarded buses on their departure to West Germany. Page 1 Ankara, at the U.N., will press Bulgaria on Turks 19 Vatican ties with the Soviet bloc have begun to fundamentally change, with an easing of mutual suspicions and a lowering of diplomatic barriers that had been intact for decades. 1 Anglican head prays with the Pope in Rome 4 Who owns the Soviet Union? That debate is to begin tomorrow as the nation's parliament takes up a law defining the notion of property. 15 Soviet dissidents begin to find the Voice of America boring 18 Poland's censors start to fade 18 President Mubarak of Egypt called Prime Minister Shamir and repeated a conditional offer to meet with the Israeli leader, officials said. 6 Lebanese legislators hold talks in Saudi Arabia 5 A stepped-up civil war in Cambodia appears inevitable to more people a week after Vietnam's withdrawal. For many, the main question is what does the Khmer Rouge want. 22 Cambodian guerrillas claim capture of three towns 23 Guatemala is a major drug source for South American cocaine headed to America and Europe. The change has occurred in the last two years, with a boom in local poppy growing. 24 Chilean Army gets U.S. copters 27 Communist runs in Brazil 26 Colombia flower exports surge 25 A plan to renovate a California canal has locked the U.S. and Mexico in a major dispute over the use of water from the Colorado River. 3 Philippine rebels show strife has not reduced their strength 13 South Africa disbands Koevoet, the special Namibia police 8 In Ethiopia, ex-prostitutes used as warriors against AIDS 10 French premier faces strikes and the left's fire 14 NATIONAL/28-35 Crack has moved to the middle class, despite reports that drug use has declined among the affluent. The largely invisible use appears to be exacting large economic costs. 1 Hurricane damage in Puerto Rico is far worse than was thought. On one island, electricity is still two months away; Puerto Rico unemployment has risen to 70 percent. 1 New York area aids islands 33 Increases in health insurance rates in recent months of 20 percent to more than 100 percent have staggered millions of small businesses that provide health coverage to employees. 1 Doubts over the Democrats' strategy have been raised this week after a defeat on a capital-gains tax cut. Some wonder whether appeals based on economic class can still succeed. 1 The new weapon against cholesterol and saturated fats is said to be the oil canola, which is made from the rape plant. American farmers hope the oil brings benefits to them, too. 28 F.D.A. questions use of grain in three cereals 28 A $78 million settlement of a lawsuit against the Government by neighbors of a uranium plant in Fernald, Ohio, was backed by a Federal judge. 28 Owner and skipper of tanker fined for Newport spill 29 Alaska fund pays big dividend 34 A clash of the 60's is being replayed in Mississippi, where a debate is boiling about disclosure of information kept by a state agency that harassed the civil rights movement. 28 Episcopalians reach compromise over female bishops 31 Chicago journal: A new process in a ritual of cleansing 28 REGIONAL/36-41 Can Rudolph Giuliani play tough? His recent defense of his criticism of David Dinkins made one thing clear: He must raise doubts about his rival without seeming to attack him. 40 New polls in the New Jersey race for governor show that voters making up their minds heavily favor the Democrat, James Florio. 38 Radon in New Jersey said to pose a grave risk 41 Hospital workers plan to strike Wednesday against most of New York City's private hospitals and nursing homes, in a high-stakes push to resolve a contract dispute. 38 A capital gains tax cut's effect on New York City appears to be unclear. While it may help the securities industry, city officials worry the cut would reduce Federal aid. 36 Bronx man beaten in attack that police call race-related 36

title: It's Over Now That It's Over
description: Yogi Berra has been a player, coach and manager for 45 years. As a player, he won three most valuable player awards. As a manager, he won pennants in each league. Last week he announced his retirement and today in Cincinnati, he will end his career, finishing it as a coach with the Houston Astros. Next season, he will have an unspecified job in the Astros' front office.

title:
GARDENING;
It's Time for a Firm Hand With Weeds
description: LEAD: THIS is a good time of the year to minimize weed problems. The most obvious step is to prevent weeds from going to seed. If that has already happened, collect and destroy the stalks.

title: Buffaloes Score 45 For Ex-Teammate
description: Fifth-ranked Colorado honored the memory of a fallen teammate today, then defeated Washington, 45-28, scoring the most points allowed a visitor at Husky Stadium in 60 years.

title:
ART;
Likeness: A Subjective Concept
description: LEAD: THE current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, ''Personae,'' interprets the question of likeness through the works of 22 portrait painters and sculptors.

title: Saberhagen (23-6) Has Top E.R.A. (2.16) of Year
description: Bret Saberhagen set a club record today with his 23d victory and clinched the American League earned run average title as the Kansas City Royals beat the Oakland Athletics, 6-1.

title: It's Toronto in the American League East
description: In each corner of the clubhouse, there were Blue Jays with their heads buried in towels. Now and again, a head would emerge, eyes ringed red and burning. There were, though, no tears, for the only hurt the 1989 season produced was the wonderful sting of champagne.

title: How to Fill The Retirement Void
description: MANY people make elaborate plans in advance for their retirement. I did not. And when it was forced on me last fall at age 65, I was totally unprepared. But I felt it shouldn't be a problem.

title: More Stern Charges
description: A week after publishing an athlete's claim that he supplied illicit human growth hormones to Florence Griffith Joyner six months before she turned in a stunning series of performances at the 1988 Olympics, the West German magazine Stern has published what it described as a secret East German report suggesting that Griffith Joyner's thighs expanded two inches in the year before the Olympics.

title: WHAT DO YOU EXPECT FOR $2.25 MILLION?
description: Diane K. Shah must be congratulated. She has managed to convey, in her article ''What Do You Expect for $2.25 Million?'' (Sept. 10), much of what is wrong with our society.

title: Elitist View
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: MINGUS/MINGUS: Two Memoirs. By Janet Coleman and Al Young. (Creative Arts Book Company, $14.95.) Charles Mingus was one of the more tempestuous talents of jazz: a bassist, bandleader, composer and dynamo of creativity who never let up. Two of his friends wrote this recollection of his life and times. We should all have such friends. Mingus, whose outsized appetites and volatile temperament were as celebrated as his music, died in Mexico of the effects of Lou Gehrig's disease in 1979, at the age of 56. The writers Janet Coleman and Al Young had then known him for almost 20 years. They were young, idealistic English majors at the University of Michigan, habitues of the beatnik scene, when they met Mingus in the late 1950's. ''Mingus/Mingus'' is their story of the man and the musician and also a story of their own awakening in pre-Kennedy America - a time when, they make clear, jazz did not have the mainstream acclaim it enjoys today. The book examines Mingus in his creative fits and starts and is unabashed in its celebration of him. There are mixed tenses, anecdotes that wind their way haphazardly into others and disjointed leaps from memory to memory - and so what? While ''Mingus/ Mingus'' may have its narrative bumps and sharp curves, it rushes forward with the energy of a stand-up monologue and serves as a faithful mirror of one of modern music's more difficult personalities. ''Mingus/Mingus'' is a breezy but heartfelt tribute to an irascible talent, a collection as passionate and unruly as its subject. Until that definitive Mingus biography comes along, these remembrances - funny, respectful and revealing - will serve nicely.

title: Anna Quindlen Will Write a Times Column
description: Anna Quindlen, former reporter, editor and columnist for The New York Times, will begin a new column on the paper's Op-Ed page in January. Her appointment was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times.

title: THE PLEASURES OF PLONK
description: Finding fine wines really isn't all that difficult. It can cost plenty, but it can be done. A 1945 Petrus? Or a 1934 Le Musigny, Comte de Vogue? Or a magnum of '28 Krug? Just say the word; Christie's or Sotheby's or your favorite wine shop will probably be able to track it down.

title: N.C.A.A. Aims to Keep Out of Politics
description: When Theodore Roosevelt summoned representatives of Harvard, Princeton and Yale to the White House in October 1906, he told them in no uncertain terms that the Federal Government would not hesitate to impose its own solution for ending the mounting violence in college football. He offered two options: clean up the sport or have it abolished.

title: Life Styles; At a Tribute to Films, Stars From Two Coasts
description: It was Lights! Camera! Action! at the National Building Museum here on Tuesday night as actors, producers, directors and writers joined President and Mrs. Bush and a number of political leaders in a celebration of the 25th anniversary of the American Film Institute.

title: Food; CAMPFIRE CACHET
description: THE SMELL OF a wood fire on a crisp fall day has a certain allure to a certain set of people, those susceptible to the imagined romance of snuggling indoors near the flames on a chilly night. Since much of my childhood was endured in a house that relied on wood fires for both cooking and heating, the mystique has always mystified me. Songwriters never mention it, but smoke also gets in your hair and your clothes. And there was certainly nothing romantic about walking into St. Cecilia's on a cold Sunday morning and having the entire congregation turn around to take a collective condescending sniff.

title: Anita A. Wager, Banker, Marries
description: Anita Andrews Wager, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Wager of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to George O. Richardson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Robert Brown officiated at the Smithfield United Church, assisted by the Rev. Martin Wager, a Lutheran minister who is an uncle of the bride. Mrs. Richardson, 28 years old, graduated from the University of Delaware and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. She is an associate in the merchant banking division of Paine Webber in New York. Her father is the associate director of the audit staff of the USX Corporation in Pittsburgh.

title: RADON IN JERSEY CALLED GRAVE RISK
description: Radon gas has become the most serious environmental health threat in New Jersey, state environmental officials said today, causing more cancer cases than exposure to hazardous waste sites, drinking-water contaminants or food with pesticides.

title: Homeless Need Aid From Commuters
description: AS a member of the vast army of commuters that passes through Grand Central Terminal twice a day, I am pained by the seemingly hopeless plight of the homeless and by my inability to be of help.

title: TV'S ARSENIO HALL: LATE-NIGHT COOL
description: ON A BRIGHT MID-SUMMER Wednesday, on the south side of Sunset Boulevard, off La Cienega, Arsenio Hall, the latest prince in the late-night realm where Johnny Carson is king, got a towering present: a billboard with a picture of him sprawled like a diva on a couch, smiling the smile of a Cheshire cat. The massive panel, a gift from his studio for the success of his nationally syndicated talk and variety program, carried a simple, almost understated legend: ''The Arsenio Hall Show: Late Night Cool.''

title: Japan's Giant Banks on the March photos of Yuko Oana and John McGillicuddy after the CIT deal (NYT/Vic DeLucia);
description: Dai-Ichi Kangyo, the world's largest bank, isn't trying to catch the fancy of millions of American consumers, as Toyota and Sony have. It will settle for a close relationship with 10,000 or so corporate treasurers.

title: Suzanne Millard Weds R. K. Stanners
description: Suzanne Marie Millard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. Millard of Southport, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn., to Robert Kevin Stanners, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stanners of Stuart, Fla., and Old Saybrook, Conn. Msgr. Carl Hinrichsen officiated.

title: >Answering The Mail
description: Q. My screened porch has a concrete slab floor. For years, I have been painting this floor with an acrylic concrete deck paint, and in April the paint bubbles and lifts in large sections. I scrape these areas and then repaint the floor, but the bubbling and separating grow worse each year. Is there a way to correct this?

title: Parcells Likes Brainy Types
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants has always liked the size (6 feet 5 inches and 290 pounds) and drive-blocking ability of Damian Johnson, his starting offensive right guard. But most of all, he likes his brain.

title: WHAT DO YOU EXPECT FOR $2.25 MILLION?
description: I am thrilled to learn there is no shortage of people who are able to pay $2 million to $10 million for a house in Beverly Hills. To think - on my modest income, I am in the same tax bracket they are!

title: Not-So-Happy Fiscal New Year
description: No ball descended from the top of the Washington Monument at midnight last night to celebrate the new fiscal year. There was nothing to celebrate. The budget deficit in the old year had grown -again. The new year's budget is a sham. And problems are piling up for future years. Despite much talk about the urgency of deficit reduction, President Bush and Congress are joined in an unspoken conspiracy to procrastinate.

title: The Airlines Industry Is a High Flyer
description: When America West Airlines, a midsize carrier based in Phoenix, sent recruiters to schools that train mechanics, it often ran into a problem. ''An outfit like Delta Airlines would come in a day ahead of us and hire the entire class,'' said Leroy Paulson, vice president for technical services.

title: Anglican Head Prays With the Pope in Rome
description: Making his first official visit to the Vatican, the Archbishop of Canterbury prayed alongside Pope John Paul II today as the two spiritual leaders discussed future reunification of the Roman Catholic and Anglican churches.

title: Tax-and-Spend Democrats Never Learn
description: People like to say the only certainties in life are death and taxes. Medical science is making headway against death, and Democrats in Congress appear to be working hard to retain the certainty of the second.

title: INSIDE
description: Marxist Pillar Trembles

title: THE WORLD HAS NEVER BEEN QUITE THE SAME
description: Drew Middleton's Francophobia mars an otherwise entertaining account of his 1939-40 experiences. An article explaining the reasons for his Francophobia would be most welcome. (A surly waiter? An unhappy love affair, perhaps?) J.S. CARTER New York, N.Y.

title: 'Question Authority'? Learn First
description: According to Cindy E. Soehner, her son, Shane, is ''the kind of child who keeps teachers on their toes.'' From her description, he is also the kind of child who can't stop talking long enough to listen and learn, who demands his way, who doesn't recognize authority, and, when he doesn't get his way, he is ''an underachiever, a discipline problem, and an unhappy little boy.''

title: The Many Aspects of Hospice Care
description: Without offering excuses for why a particular hospice program proved inadequate to serve the writer's needs, I must respond to Stephanie Johns's statements: ''Hospice care is akin to no care at all'' and hospice care at home is of no benefit for the women...''who have to care for the terminally ill.''

title: Anne Wise Weds Jonathan Bailey
description: Anne Seymour Wise, a student at the Temple University Medical School, and Jonathan Arthur Bailey, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, graduates of Wesleyan University, were married yesterday at the Friends Meeting House in Westtown, Pa. The Rev. Fred S. Enman, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Let Nicaragua Vote Without Our Intervention; Marines Didn't Do It
description: To the Editor:

title: World Stock Markets Gained in 3d Quarter
description: With few exceptions and little variation, stock markets around the world posted strong gains in the third quarter.

title: FOR FLORIO AND COURTER, CRUCIAL TV BATTLE TURNS NASTY
description: When the candidates for governor of New Jersey began their television advertising two weeks ago, their commercials differed sharply in tone and tenor.

description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. GENERAL COMMITTEE - 9:15 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: South Africans Permit Protests in Homelands
description: Anti-apartheid leaders joined traditional chiefs today to challenge South Africa's black-homeland policies at the funeral of a Xhosa chief here in one of the black homelands, Transkei.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Quietly, McGriff Makes His Mark
description: The bags of mail are stuffed into an adjacent locker, a season's worth of unanswered correspondence. Fred McGriff, the notoriously quiet first baseman for the Blue Jays, apparently eschews other forms of communication, as well.

title: B.A.T. Loses British Plea
description: B.A.T. Industries has lost an appeal against a decision by British regulatory authorities to give Sir James Goldsmith more time to pursue his hostile takeover bid for the British tobacco-based conglomerate.

title: More Suspects Are Arrested In Seizure of 20 Tons of Drugs
description: Federal agents have arrested three more people in the biggest drug case on record in this country.

title: GLEN RIDGE BOARD IS EXONERATED
description: The Glen Ridge Board of Education acted properly in its handling of a sexual attack on a special-education student, according to a report by a retired judge.

title: Beating Called Bias-Related
description: A man was beaten in the East Village on Saturday morning by three men who yelled anti-homosexual slurs, the police said. The victim, Roger Justice, 32 years old, was attacked from behind with a baseball bat and a pool cue as he walked in front of 440 East 13th Street at 10 A.M., said a police spokesman, Sgt. Peter Berry. As the three men struck him, they yelled, ''Faggot!'' Sergeant Berry said. Mr. Justice was taken to Beth Israel Medical Center, where he was treated for bruises and cuts and released.

title: Black Fraternities Thrive, Often on Adversity
description: Black fraternities and sororities, long criticized by other blacks as divisive and elitist, are attracting record numbers of young people, particularly on many predominantly white campuses shaken by racial tension.

title: The Generic Drug Scandal
description: These are bad times for generic drug makers and their regulators. Three officials of the Food and Drug Administration have pleaded guilty to receiving bribes, and two generic drug companies have admitted to providing false data. Now, after a new scandal involving defective generic drugs for epilepsy, Representative John Dingell says he's lost confidence in the industry's integrity and the F.D.A.'s ability to ensure safe drugs.

title: Man Dies and Two Are Hurt In Fire in a Brooklyn House
description: One man was killed and two other persons were injured last night when a fire of undetermined origin destroyed a three-story dwelling at 559 Lafayette Avenue between Bedford and Nostrand Avenues in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: AIDS Drug Is Seen as Ineffective
description: An unapproved drug popular in underground efforts to fight the AIDS virus since it showed promise in the laboratory is apparently ineffective in the body, a medical journal report says.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 23 about a New York State Health Department panel's action on a complaint against two doctors at New York Hospital in the death of an 18-year-old woman was bylined incorrectly in some editions. It was by Donatella Lorch.

title: Psychiatric Workers Strike in Connecticut
description: More than 70 psychiatric workers at Natchaug Hospital went on strike yesterday in a dispute over wages and work conditions, a hospital official said.

title: Review/Ballet; A Century of Passions, Posters, Toe Shoes and a Wedding Bouquet
description: The passion that Russians feel for ballet is embodied in ''100 Years of Russian Ballet, 1830-1930'' an exhibition from Leningrad that is rich in revelations about the sometimes uneasy history of the Soviet Union's most celebrated art form.

title: INSIDE
description: Nicaragua Voters Register International observers were in place as registration began for Nicaragua's February vote. Page A10. Tax Debate Doesn't Add Up In the debate on cutting the capital gains tax rate, both sides buttressed their positions with misleading statistics. News Analysis, page D1. Price War in Japan New long-distance services are offering rarely seen discounts in a nation of traditionally high prices. Page D1. What Ward Leaves Behind New York's Police Commissioner made progress but was swamped by the crack epidemic. Page B1. The Matchups The A's, the Blue Jays, the Cubs and the Giants: comparing the playoff teams. SportsMonday, page C6.

title: Georgia Woman and Child Die As Tornado Hits Trailer Park
description: A woman and a toddler were killed and 12 people were injured when a tornado destroyed a trailer park and a church in a 10-mile rampage in southern Georgia today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESST: Television; The Networks' 'Opportunity' in Sony Deal
description: A BAD joke in Hollywood last week suggested that Columbia television had started pitching a series to the networks based on the film ''Tora, Tora, Tora.'' That film tells the story of the Pearl Harbor attack from the Japanese point of view.

title: Tax Watch; Family Business In a Legal Tangle
description: FEW provisions of the sweeping overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years have prompted as many anguished protests from tax professionals as Section 2036(c), colloquially known as the antifreeze provision. It is intended to prevent affluent families from escaping gift and estate taxes by using techniques known as estate freezes to transfer family-owned businesses to a younger generation.

title: Cure for Hit-And-Run Politics
description: A seamy piece of campaign literature circulated during last month's primary race for Brooklyn District Attorney attempted to link the former special prosecutor Charles Hynes to homosexual groups. Assemblyman Daniel Feldman, who lost the contest to Mr. Hynes, denies authorizing the leaflet, which was signed by ''Friends of Dan Feldman.'' Whatever the truth turns out to be, the episode points to a need for changing New York State law.

title: No Ordinary Tailgating
description: Bill Brennan, a Stamford, Conn., real estate executive, recalls being caught in a traffic jam on the Bear Mountain Bridge while heading for an Army game at West Point in 1970. ''While we sat in our car on the bridge, I looked down at the Hudson River and said to my friend, Dick Merritt, 'Look, Dick, there's no traffic down there,' '' Brennan said. Merritt got the message and said to Brennan, ''Next year let's go by boat.''

title: Aid to Eastern Europe: Almost an Afterthought
description: A group of Hungarians, Hungarian-Americans and others gathered for dinner one night last week, with Foreign Minister Gyula Horn, who had traveled from Budapest to the United States to speak at the United Nations and to meet with senior officials in Washington, as the guest of honor.

title: Issue of Syrian Troops Clouds Talks on Lebanon
description: Lebanese lawmakers clashed today over the presence of Syrian troops in their country and the Lebanese Christian military leader demanded a timetable for their withdrawal before agreeing to peace.

title: Australia Arrests Protesters
description: The police arrested more than 200 people today while breaking up the latest in a series of antinuclear protests at an Australian-American military intelligence-gathering base. Officers said 217 of the 500 protesters were arrested in the base's outer security zone, bringing the arrest total in five days of the protests to 490. The demonstrators consider the base, situated about 350 miles northwest of Adelaide, capital of the state of South Australia, a likely target in a superpower nuclear confrontation.

title: Two Teams With Something to Prove
description: Now that the Toronto Blue Jays have drawn the short straw, this is what awaits them in the American League playoff that begins Tuesday: perhaps a deeper, better, more focused Oakland Athletics team than the one that ravaged Boston in last season's championship series.

title: Tina Weis Weds Charles R. Grant
description: Christine Anne Weis, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Joseph F. Weis Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Charles Robert Grant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grant of Sydney, Australia. The Rev. David Donovan officiated at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church in Brookline, Mass.

title: G. A. Hirsch Wed To Shay Scrivner
description: Shay Yandell Scrivner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morley Nelson of Boise, Idaho, was married in New York yesterday to George Aaron Hirsch, the publisher of Runner's World magazine. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Exxon Cleanup Looked Like a Mini D-Day
description: To the Editor:

title: More Must Be Done on International Parental Child Abduction
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Flood Swamps Charleston: Help
description: The response to this region's appeal for hurricane assistance is overwhelming the network of warehouses, public buildings, schools and churches that distribute food and other material.

title: Giants Reach 4-0 Mark
description: All that talk that the Giants need defensive turnovers to win is a myth they helped create. What they need is good defense when it counts. They got enough of that today, kept Herschel Walker from doing too much damage and scored a methodical 30-13 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Browns Finally Defeat Broncos
description: The Cleveland Browns had been through all of this against Denver before. A last-minute drive. A critical fumble in the closing seconds.

title: 3 Sentenced In Bid Fraud
description: A former Navy procurement official was sentenced Friday to six months in a halfway house for giving confidential information on Pentagon contracts to a military consultant.

title: Tired Businessmen Get Chance to Play
description: THOMAS MEEHAN is a project manager for the architectural firm of Robert Dwight Nostrand in Farmingdale, L.I. He sits in rush-hour traffic just as everybody else does, puts in his eight-hour day, and daydreams the way others do on his way home to Seaford, L.I.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Mike Walsh has been named chairman of Ogilvy & Mather/London.

title: WARD YEARS: LEAVING A MARK ON POLICE
description: He intimidated people. He was short on tact, impatient with failure and determined to leave his mark on the largest police department in the country.

title: Pizza Delivery Car Hits and Kills a Man
description: A 71-year-old man was killed early yesterday when he was struck by a pizza delivery car, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Menem's Pardons And Purges
description: LEAD: When Argentina's President, Carlos Saul Menem, was in the U.S. last week for the United Nations General Assembly meeting, he easily deflected questions about his plan to pardon military officers still facing trials for their grotesque crimes during the ''dirty war'' of the late 1970's. His purpose, President

title: JUDGE UPSETS RULE REQUIRING MINORITY CONSTRUCTION HIRING
description: A judge has struck down a regulation that Mayor Edward I. Koch imposed in 1980 to require contractors to hire ''economically disadvantaged'' trainees for construction projects that are built and financed by New York City.

title: Give the Chancellor the Help He Needs
description: As Dade County Superintendent of Schools, Joseph Fernandez once dismissed an elementary school principal on the spot when he found the school in disarray. But as Schools Chancellor in New York City, Mr. Fernandez could not do that because state law gives principals lifetime tenure in their school building.

title: More East Germans Sneak Into Embassy in Prague
description: Several hundred East Germans sneaked past the Czechoslovak police today to gain sanctuary at the West German Embassy here, a day after thousands of their countrymen were allowed to leave the compound for West Germany.

title: H.U.D. Ties of 2 Bush Nominees Raise Roadblocks
description: The disclosure of widespread mismanagement and political favoritism at the Department of Housing and Urban Development has placed roadblocks in the Senate confirmation process for two of President Bush's nominees who had ties to the agency.

title: What's In, What's Not
description: Asking sportswriters and broadcasters what sports should be in the Olympics is like asking letter carriers what letters they should carry.

title: Sports of The Times; Mookie Wilson Is Still a Free Agent
description: MOOKIE WILSON didn't like the sting of alcohol on his eyes three years ago, and he didn't like it again Saturday. He did, however, love what it represented.

title: Let Nicaragua Vote Without Our Intervention
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues for this week is confined to today's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Rise in Rates Seen as Temporary
description: Credit market analysts say that long-term interest rates, which have tested the upper limits of a 7.75 to 8.25 percent range recently, could move higher still in coming weeks.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 1, 1989: MONDAY Carolina Fght Corp Central VT Pub Svc Corp Dean Foods Co Nevada Pwr Co Oxford Inds Inc Sierra Pac Res United Indl Corp Xerox Corp TUESDAY CBI Inds Inc Central ILL Pub Svc Co Pacific Enterprises WEDNESDAY Houston Inds Inc Hunt Mfg Co Murphy Oil Corp Rite Aid Corp Southwestern Energy Co THURSDAY American Wtr Wks Inc Freeport-McMoran Corp General Pub Utils Corp Grace WR & Co Orange & Rockland Utils Sun Inc FRIDAY Equitable Res Inc Travelers Corp US West Inc

title: Dissension on McLaren Team
description: For all its domination of the Formula One championship series the last few years, the McLaren team has been split this year by dissent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Levine, Huntley Moves
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, a unit of Grey Advertising, restructured its creative department last week, promoting Terry Bonaccolta, Jim Brandhorst, Jim Dragoumis and Jane Pack to executive vice presidents and management directors. Each will be responsible for a major agency function.

title: Fraud Cost Up at Ferranti
description: Ferranti International P.L.C., the British electronics company, said on Friday that a fraud involving phantom contracts at a United States subsidiary would cost it $:185 million ($299 million), far more than it had estimated.

title: Norman F. Smith, Administrative Judge, 64
description: Judge Norman F. Smith, an administrative law judge who was a leading advocate of abortion rights, died of cancer Friday in Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse. He was 64 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: STEAM BLASTS MAY BE RISING AS MAINS AGE
description: When an underground steam pipe exploded with a thunderous roar in the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan Aug. 19, killing three people, injuring 24 and coating much of the area with asbestos-contaminated mud, New York City officials assumed they were dealing with a phenomenon that happened once in a blue moon.

title: ISRAEL ASKING U.S. FOR AID ON HOUSING FOR SOVIET EMIGRES
description: Israel has asked the United States for $400 million in loan guarantees to finance the construction of housing for Soviet Jewish emigres, and Israeli officials said some of the housing would probably be built in the West Bank.

title: 'Today' Official Goes to 'Channel One'
description: A senior executive of the ''Today'' show has been named executive producer of ''Channel One,'' an advertiser-supported daily news program that is to be presented in junior and senior high schools beginning in March 1990.

title: Review/Television; The Way a Battered Wife Finally Made Herself Heard
description: There are certain kinds of television movies that give certain television actresses their big break. One was ''The Burning Bed,'' which enabled Farrah Fawcett to prove conclusively that she was capable of something more than ''Charlie's Angels.'' She played a battered wife in a story based on fact. Another is ''A Cry for Help: The Tracey Thurman Story,'' tonight at 9 on NBC.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 21 about promotions in the Soviet Communist Party leadership misstated the birthplace of Yuri D. Maslyukov, who was named a full member of the Politburo. It is Leninabad, in Tadzhikistan.

title: 'People's China' Celebrates, but Without the People
description: The People's Republic of China celebrated its 40th anniversary today with colorful dances and fireworks, along with such stiff security that ordinary Chinese could not get within a mile of the birthday party in Tiananmen Square for ''People's China.''

title: Rams Edge 49ers On Late Field Goal
description: For the Los Angeles Rams, it was a day where so much went right only to fade and become tarnished. Then, in the waning minutes, the Rams' fortunes turned golden for good.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arizona Commerce Bank, Tucson, named John Reardon senior vice president for marketing.

title: Legal Services, White House Wimps
description: Ronald Reagan was relentlessly hostile to the Legal Services Corporation, which Congress created to provide lawyers for the poor. The Bush Administration, though apparently not bent on the program's destruction, is letting itself be pushed around by the same narrow-minded obstructionists who helped set poverty law policy during the Reagan years. They have persuaded the White House not to designate Caldwell Butler, a moderate Republican from Roanoke, Va., as its choice for chairman of the corporation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Firms Change Names
description: Several New York public relations firms have changed names and venues. Porter/Novelli, a public relations subsidiary of the Omnicom Group, has acquired Jay DeBow & Partners, a small New York public relations firm. Terms were not disclosed. The Betsy Nolan Group has changed its name to the Nolan/Lehr Group, after its vice president, Donald Lehr, agreed to buy a controlling interest in the firm. And Daniel J. Edelman Public Relations Worldwide has moved its New York headquarters to 1500 Broadway in Times Square.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Arnell Accounts
description: Arnell/Bickford Marketing announced $2 million worth of new business on Friday. From Bausch & Lomb Inc., for which it already handles designer eyewear lines, the agency received Levi's sunglasses. And Fendi, the Italian apparel and accessories company, hired the agency to create advertising for the store it is opening in midtown Manhattan. In addition, Arnell/Bickford will be in charge of creating displays for the store's 11 windows, changing them every 10 weeks.

title: Karin G. Greene, Designer, Marries
description: Karin Goodwin Greene, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Greene Jr. of Zionsville, Pa., and Peter Gerard McCann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. McCann of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., were married yesterday at the Gideon F. Egner Memorial Chapel at Muhlenberg College in Allentown, Pa. The Rev. John Mraz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the bride's uncle the Rev. Walter G. Hed, a Lutheran minister.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Tuesday about the Japanese film ''Black Rain'' at the New York Film Festival gave an incorrect date for the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. It was Aug. 6, not June 6, 1945.

title: More Than 6,000 East Germans Swell Tide of Emigres to the West
description: From early this morning, packed East German trains pulled into this border junction town at three-hour intervals, disgorging exhausted East Germans whose departure had been allowed only the day before through an extraordinary face-saving arrangement reportedly approved by Erich Honecker, the East German leader.

title:
METRO DATELINES;
Suspect Is Arrested In a Random Killing
description: LEAD: A 23-year-old man was arrested yesterday for last week's killing of a Bronx man who was shot when he went to his bedroom window, the police said.

title: Review/Music; Trio Plays Standards With Veneer
description: The pianist Steve Kuhn, who played through Sunday night at the Village Vanguard, presents a simple, conventional image to an audience. He uses a traditional trio - in this case featuring Eddie Gomez on bass and Al Foster on drums - and he plays standards. The music is broken up into obvious, clean-cut solos and Mr. Kuhn, for the most part, sticks to straight-ahead, swinging 4/4 time.

title: Market Place; Continued Appeal Of Equity Funds
description: SEPTEMBER was not the best month for the stock market, but mutual fund sponsors say they kept taking in cash from the public for their equity funds. But ''junk bond'' funds, the most popular category of funds for much of the past year, may have had more than a billion dollars flow out.

title: Personal Vendetta Is Seen as the Motive For Bombing of Van
description: A Federal inquiry into the bombing of a van driven by the wife of a Navy captain has shifted the suspected motive from terrorism to a possible personal vendetta, it was reported today.

title: Insurers With a Niche Favored by an Acquirer
description: David J. Stone, a practitioner of the management buyout, thinks the insurance industry offers opportunities to acquire companies for prices that are not outlandish, and his company, DJS/Inverness, is on the lookout for insurance companies that have a niche in their industry.

title: Potent Form of Heroin Surfaces in California
description: An extremely potent form of heroin has surfaced here, causing dozens of overdoses, one of them fatal, and overwhelming hospitals.

title: BENSONHURST ON STAGE: PLOT IS SADLY FAMILIAR, THE PLAYWRIGHT SAYS
description: There were times when he was growing up in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Frank Pugliese said, when he felt afraid - afraid of the angry young men who hung out at street corners and candy shops getting drunk and picking fights, and afraid that he might become one of them.

title: Juvenile Book Publishing Becomes the Goose That Lays the Golden Egg
description: Parents and educators often despair that youngsters cannot or will not read, but the younger set is the apple of the book publishing industry's eye. William Morrow & Company, owned by the Hearst Corporation, announced the week before last that it was adding a fourth division to its existing children's book publishing program. And just since last year, at least nine other publishers have added either divisions or lines of children's books.

title: Strong Arms Behind the Bashing Elbows
description: LEAD: A YEAR ago, when the Oakland Athletics were elbow-bashing their way to a pennant, their pitching was the best in the American League. But alongside their prodigious hitting, it was sometimes undervalued. This year, with important injuries to Jose Canseco and Mark McGwire, to the team's shortstop, Walter Weiss, and to the top reliever, Dennis Eckersley, there has been less attention to the thudding of forearms and more to the way the A's play baseball and, particularly, to the way in which their pitching has consistently sustained them.

title: Walter O'Meara, 92, Author and Executive
description: Walter O'Meara, a former New York advertising executive and author of 16 books, died of heart disease Friday at his home in Cohassett, Mass. He was 92 years old.

title: Books of The Times; A Book Catalogue as Reference and Revolution
