description: The Reader's Catalogue An Annotated Selection of More than 40,000 of the Best Books in Print in 208 Categories Edited by Geoffrey O'Brien, with Stephen Wasserstein and Helen Morris Illustrated. 1,382 pages. Jason Epstein, publisher. Distributed by Random House. Paper, $24.95.

title: Dunston In Full Stride
description: WHEN all those strangers came to watch in the spring of 1982, leaning on the outside of the chain-link fence where the baseball team at Thomas Jefferson High School played, there was little doubt about the abilities of the 18-year-old they had come to see.

title: Jets Sputter And Colts Rally, 17-10
description: The Jets brimmed with confidence today. The offense, fresh from a 40-point performance against Miami, was primed for another good outing against a questionable Colt defense; the defense, despite allowing 33 points last week, vowed to pressure the Colt's stand-in quarterback, Jack Trudeau, and stop the Indianapolis running attack.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Israel is seeking $400 million from the United States to finance construction of housing for Soviet Jewish emigres. Israeli officials said some of the housing would probably go up in the West Bank. Page A1

title: The Sony Deal Aside, Japan Not Rushing to Buy Up U.S.
description: These are heady days for American practitioners of the takeover game here. There is the $3.4 billion takeover of Columbia Pictures by the Sony Corporation. And a number of big corporate breakups in the United States have sent investment bankers skittering all over town trying to peddle multibillion-dollar companies.

title: Remembering The Woman Who Danced With Bananas
description: When the restaurant Chez Josephine celebrates its third anniversary with a private party tonight, it will honor another anniversary as well. It was 64 years ago today that Josephine Baker, an entertainer from St. Louis, opened in Paris at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in ''La Revue Negre'' and took the town by storm.

title: McKinsey May Buy Consultants
description: In a sign of the growing importance of information technology and systems-related expertise in general management consulting, McKinsey & Company is seeking to buy the Information Consulting Group, which was created last year by several high-ranking executives from Arthur Andersen and other top accounting firms.

title: Charlotte Journal; PTL Trial: Even The Devil Showed Up
description: Kenneth Huff was parading around the granite Federal Courthouse here as usual, hollering at the top of his lungs, ''The District Court in Charlotte, North Carolina, is crucifying Christ through Jim Bakker,'' when some onlookers began derisively howling like stray dogs.

title: Fourth 'Quality' Sunday Paper Enters in Britain
description: Are enough British readers of the three established ''quality'' Sunday newspapers so dissatisfied with what they get in The Observer, The Sunday Times and The Sunday Telegraph that they will try something new?

title: Club Sweetens Stroke
description: A new technique for weighting a golf club iron is designed to compensate for off-center hits. Subtle changes occur in the contour of the club head if it strikes a ball outside the sweet spot, its optimal striking surface. Wilson Sporting Goods Company of River Grove, Ill., recently introduced its Ultra, an iron made to minimize the microscopic twisting that comes from an imperfect stroke.

title: Campaign Matters; Mason's Jokes, Jackson's Photo, Giuliani's Woes
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign demonstrated last week the pitfalls of racial politics. The campaign's apparent failure to capitalize on race represents what for a politician of any color is the ultimate ineptitude.

title: Danger of Political Surrogates Is Seen in Mason Controversy
description: Who would have thought two weeks ago that a borscht belt comedian would become a major issue in the New York mayoral race? Probably no one.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ernst & Young Won by Grey
description: Grey Advertising last week became a beneficiary of the consolidation of the accounting industry, winning the advertising business of the newly merged Ernst & Young. The account was reported in the trade press to be worth $2.5 million, but James A. Taylor, the national director of marketing for Ernst & Young, said a budget had not yet been set.

title: Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Senna Wins Spanish Grand Prix: Ayrton Senna of Brazil drove a slick race in his McLaren-Honda to win the Spanish Grand Prix yesterday, keeping alive his hopes of recapturing the Formula One crown. Senna completed 72 laps of the 2.62-mile Jerez de la Frontera circuit in 1 hour 47 minutes 48.264 seconds. Gerhard Berger of Austria, who trailed Senna from the start, brought his scarlet Ferrari home in second place, 27.051 seconds behind the Brazilian. Alain Prost, Senna's French teammate and main rival for the world drivers' title, was third, 53.788 seconds behind the winner.(AP) Tennis Lendl Overpowers Sanchez: Ivan Lendl powered his way to his 81st Grand Prix victory yesterday, beating Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 6-2, in the Passing Shot clay-court tournament in Bordeaux, France.(AP) Gilbert Triumphs: Third-seeded Brad Gilbert defeated unseeded Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 7-5, 6-2, last night to win the $425,000 Volvo tournament in San Francisco.(AP) Golf Calcavecchia Wins for United States: Mark Calcavecchia won the only afternoon match that mattered yesterday to lift the United States to a 3 1/2-2 1/2 victory over Japan in the final round of the Dunhill Cup in St. Andrews, Scotland. Calcavecchia secured the Americans' first title in the five-year history of this medal-match play event. England beat Ireland, 2-1, in the match for third place.(AP) Britton Wins First PGA Event: Bill Britton won his first PGA Tour tournament yesterday without having to lift a club, as the final round of the $750,000 Centel Classic in Tallahassee, Fla., was rained out. Britton took a four-stroke lead with a nine-under-par 63 Saturday and finished 54 holes with a 16-under 200.(AP) Milestone for Daniel: Beth Daniel scored a one-stroke victory over Pat Bradley yesterday in the Konica San Jose Classic in California. Daniel's victory, the fourth in her last six tournaments, earned her $48,750 and pushed her over the $2 million mark for her career. Daniel shot a one-over-par 73 yesterday for 205.(AP) Charles Wins With a 67: Bob Charles shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to close out a front-running victory in the Space Coast Senior PGA Tour Classic in Melbourne, Fla. His 54-hole total of 13-under 203 was six shots ahead of the runner-up, Butch Baird.(AP) N.H.L. Rangers 3, Blues 2: John Ogrodnick scored two goals as the Rangers defeated the St. Louis Blues last night in Oakland, Calif., in their final exhibition game. The Rangers completed their pre-season schedule with a 6-4 record.(AP) Islanders 4, Bruins 3: Tom Fitzgerald scored with 2:51 remaining to give the Islanders a victory over the Boston Bruins last night in Portland, Maine as the Islanders finished their exhibition schedule with a 5-3-1 mark.(AP) Yachting Belgians Take Yacht Club Challenge: A Belgian sailing team overcame a gear breakdown in New York Harbor yesterday to win the International Yacht Club challenge with 13 points. Second was a crew from the Raritan Yacht Club of New Jersey, with 12.5.

title: Irene D. Sann Is Married
description: Irene D. Sann and Hervey M. Johnson, professors of law at Pace University in White Plains, were married yesterday at the Lumberton, N.C., home of the bridegroom's mother, Mary Patterson Johnson. The Rev. Samuel B. Shumate, a Presbyterian minister, officiated. Mrs. Johnson is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Deaville of Schiller Park, Ill. Mr. Johnson is a son also of the late James Evans Johnson. The bride has a daughter, Jessica Gabrielle Sann, from her previous marriage, which ended in divorce.

title: A.O. Dahlberg, 91, Economist and Inventor
description: Arthur O. Dahlberg, an economist and the inventor of the Parker fountain pen, died early Saturday morning at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. A resident of Scarsdale, N.Y., he was 91 years old.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Help for Hugo Victims
description: LEAD: Football is one of South Carolina's sporting passions. Thus it was perhaps inevitable that, while discussing ways to acquire immediate aid for constituents affected by Hurricane Hugo's devastation, Senator Strom Thurmond hit upon the idea of enlisting college football spectators as donors of needed food and money.

title: Colombians, Weary of the Strain, Are Losing Heart in the Drug War
description: After enduring six weeks of bombings and shootings, many Colombians are tiring of the drug war and suggesting that the Government abandon its campaign against powerful cocaine traffickers.

title: Why Subsidize Gridlock?
description: A growing crush of commuter traffic threatens the economic vitality and air quality of the nation's cities. Yet present Federal tax policy actively encourages people to drive to work. Legislation now pending in the Senate could help erode this perverse tax bias.

title: Some Enchanted 'Saigon'
description: Seems not so long ago that I produced an NBC radio broadcast from Mary Martin's dressing room after the London opening of ''South Pacific.'' That smash hit was an American artistic export based on stories growing out of the American victory in World War II; some enchanted evening.

title: Court Rules Accountant Can Solicit Clients
description: A West Palm Beach accountant won a victory on Thursday when a Circuit Court judge agreed with him that Florida laws that prevent accountants in the state from soliciting business without an invitation or quoting audit fees to prospective clients were unconstitutional and ruled that the bans be lifted.

title: The Quest for a Commissioner
description: On Oct. 10 in Dallas, the National Football League's 28 owners will again gather in hopes of electing a new commissioner after a seven-month effort filled with of hitches and surprises.

title: Childhood Is Not Safe, Congress Study Warns
description: More children than ever are living in the streets or in families shattered by divorce, drugs or poverty, a Congressional study has reported.

title: Britain Delay Sale of Stock
description: The British Government said on Friday that it would postpone its sale of stock in the electricity industry for up to six months because of the complexity of its plans.

title: Founder Quits At Carlson
description: Curt Carlson on Friday turned over control of one of the nation's largest privately held companies to his son-in-law. Mr. Carlson began the travel, restaurant and hotel operation more than 50 years ago from a trading stamp business.

title: School Football; Coach's Son Makes A Name for Himself
description: Once there was a quarterback at East Islip High School with the name Norman Julius Esiason. He became more famous at the University of Maryland and then with the Cincinnati Bengals under the nickname Boomer, which he got because of the way he kicked inside his mother before he was born.

title: Stocks Post Solid Gain in Quarter
description: Over the last three months, the stock market showed surprising strength and resilience, advancing on takeover activity and on encouraging economic data, despite an unstable ''junk bond'' market and expectations of lower corporate profits.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Review/Theater; No Chance at Bat, In Baseball and in Life
description: It is the premise of Tom Ziegler's ''Home Games'' (which opened last night at the Hudson Guild Theater) that behind Yogi Berra and Elston Howard, the 1955 New York Yankees had a third, reserve catcher, a bush leaguer named Tony Tucker, who spent exactly one year in the majors. Actually that year, Howard was generally in the outfield and the Yankees had another backup catcher, Charlie Silvera, who was not - by any stretch of the imagination - the basis for Tucker.

title: Review/Television; Tracing the Art of the West, Starting in Greece, in 9 Parts
description: Nothing less than 2,500 years of Western art is the subject of ''Art of the Western World,'' a nine-part series that begins tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 and at 10 o'clock on Channels 21, 49 and 50. This big American-British-Austrian-Spanish production is as rewarding a survey course as television has given us, filled with images and ideas that linger after each hour ends and may even send people out to museums.

title: Boy in Coma After Falling Down Airshaft
description: A 12-year-old Brooklyn boy was in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital last night after a four-story fall down an airshaft Saturday afternoon.

title: John Walker, 64, Episcopal Bishop in Washington
description: The Rev. John Thomas Walker, the first black Episcopal bishop of Washington and a staunch crusader against racial discrimination at home and abroad, died of heart failure at Georgetown University Hospital on Saturday. He was 64 years old.

title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial
description: With the growth of crack addiction in the middle class, treatment specialists have discovered that affluent addicts are more likely to deny their problem at first, and more able to hide addiction's devastating costs.

title: Mohasco Chief Mixes Furniture and Buyouts
description: Seeking a chief executive who knows the furniture business and can operate in a leveraged buyout environment, the Mohasco Corporation found its man in Robert W. Hatch.

title: FIREFIGHTER IS KILLED BY AN F.B.I. AGENT
description: An F.B.I. agent shot and killed an off-duty New York City firefighter yesterday morning after the firefighter apparently threatened another F.B.I. agent with an AK-47 assault rifle, the authorities said.

title: HIGH COURT FACING FIGHT ON ABORTION, PRIVACY AND DEATH
description: With echoes of recent decisions still reverberating through the legal and political system, the Supreme Court returns Monday to a docket that all but guarantees a replay of the divisive constitutional struggles that defined its last term.

title: Rights for Gay Couples in Denmark
description: In what gay rights advocates hailed as the first unions of their kind in the world, six homosexual couples were legally joined today in ''registered partnerships'' that gave them most rights of married heterosexuals, but not the right to adopt or obtain joint custody of a child.

title: Charles Rostov, 74, Retired Import Executive
description: Charles I. Rostov, retired president and chief executive officer of the Trans-Ocean Import Company, a home furnishings importer in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Friday in Budapest, where he was traveling. He was 74 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: China Culture Official Remains in Favor
description: To the Editor:

title: Churchill Understood Afternoon Naps
description: To the Editor:

title: Scoutmaster Is Held In Sodomizing of Boy
description: A 31-year-old scoutmaster has been charged with sodomy after he was caught having sex with a 13-year-old boy in a Manhattan parking lot, the police said yesterday.

title: Waking Up to Joy of Morning Bicycling
description: THE Century Road Club is looking for a few brave women and some older men too, equally brave. The club is a bicycle organization almost a century old that stages races in Central Park on Saturday mornings for the fun of it, and there are some membership openings.

title: AN EARLIER JACKIE MASON RACIAL SLUR AGAINST DINKINS IS DISCLOSED
description: Jackie Mason and his use of racially sensitive language continues to trouble the mayoral campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani almost a week after the comedian was forced to withdraw from the campaign for making harsh remarks about blacks and Jews in a newspaper.

title: Most-Wanted Fugitive Caught in Pennsylvania
description: The F.B.I. captured one of its ten most wanted fugitives today when a television viewer's tip led to the arrest of a New York City man wanted on murder charges.

title: Jamaica Handicap To Domasca Dan
description: Domasca Dan struck a blow for the quality of Canadian racing yesterday by coming in from Toronto to score a three-length victory over Garemma and Is It True in the $118,200 Jamaica Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Europe Takes On Auto Pollution
description: With environmental concerns rising and the influence of the European Community growing, the nations of Western Europe have begun to take united action to curb air pollution from automobiles.

title: Review/Opera; Hei-Kyung Hong and Richard Leech in 'Boheme'
description: On March 5, 1938, Kirsten Flagstad sang Brunnhilde in ''Die Walkure'' at the Metropolitan Opera after an Isolde the night before. Caruso sometimes sang three days running, and Eleanor Steber once did ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' and ''Otello'' on the same Saturday. So let us not make too much of the fact that Hei-Kyung Hong had to sing Mimi in the first ''La Boheme'' of the season at 1:30 P.M. on Saturday after finishing ''Gianni Schicchi'' around midnight on Friday. In the event, she had a steeper challenge than fatigue to overcome. But the main thing is that she did well.

title: James Kaufman Weds Amy Bach
description: Amy Elizabeth Bach, a daughter of Linda J. Bach and Richard J. Bach, both of New Rochelle, N.Y., and James Lobach Kaufman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Kaufman of New Rochelle and New York, were married yesterday at the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow in North Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. David Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Capital Gains: Politics and Poor Data
description: In the debate last week before the House of Representatives voted to lower the capital gains tax rate, both sides buttressed their positions with misleading statistics.

title: When News Must Pay Its Way, Expect Trivia
description: For as long as there has been television journalism there has been the TV journalist's predicament, that of doing serious work in a medium that most wants merely to amuse. But the news divisions at last seem to have found an answer to their abiding dilemma: In a universe that values entertainers more than it values journalists, the journalists are becoming entertainers.

title: Bridge
description: The final day of play in the recent NEC Bermuda Bowl world championship in Perth, Australia, featured wild oscillations. Brazil began with a lead of 54 imps and built it to 140. The Americans surged back, almost canceling the Brazilian gains but leaving the South American champions with the title.

title: A Price War In Japan on Foreign Calls
description: One of the most expensive services in Japan, the land of $70 watermelons, $150 cab rides and camera gear that costs twice as much as in New York, is making international telephone calls. But this weekend, a price war broke out.

title: Question Box
description: Twice a Met

title: College Football; 'Unbelievable' Pitt Rallies From a 31-9 Deficit for a Tie
description: After three periods, West Virginia had the game in hand, 31-9. But the fourth period belonged to Pitt, 22 points to none. So the game ended in an unlikely 31-31 tie on Ed Frazier's 42-yard field goal on the final play Saturday night in Morgantown.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies McKinsey is seeking the Information Consulting Group, which was created last year by several executives from Arthur Andersen and other accounting firms. The move is a sign of the growing importance of information technology and systems-related expertise in general management consulting. [ Page D1. ] Florida laws that prohibit accountants from soliciting business were ruled unconstitutional in a suit brought by a West Palm Beach accountant. [ D2. ] The Economy Public officials are not dealing with the capital gains issue as a question of tax policy and its consequences, but rather as one of political principle - and they are using misleading statistics in the process. News Analysis. [ D1. ] The Senate majority leader predicted he could marshal enough votes to block passage of the House's plan to reduce the capital gains tax rate. [ D7. ] Few Wall Street executives and real estate developers think the capital gains reduction, if passed by the Senate, will have any significant impact on their business or on stock prices. [ D7. ] The stock market showed surprising strength and resilience over the last three months, advancing on takeover activity and encouraging economic data, despite an unstable ''junk bond'' market and expectations of lower corporate profits. [ D1. ] International Competitive international telephone service has come to Japan. After four years of preparation, two new competitors for a longtime Government-approved monopoly tossed switches that connected them to every telephone in Japan. Instantly, telephoning the U.S. became, in some cases, 20 percent cheaper than calling from the U.S. to Japan. [ D1. ] Investment bankers say the Japanese are more discerning in their American acquisitions. Deals like Sony-Columbia Pictures are growing rarer, they say. [ D1. ] The stock markets of Japan, the U.S. and Britain grew by about 10 percent in dollar terms for the third quarter. Stocks in Austria, Hong Kong and New Zealand shone, while share prices in Finland sagged. [ D8. ] The Media Business So far the only parties aggressively ringing alarm bells over Sony's entrance into American television are the three networks, which see a lobbying opportunity. Television. [ D10. ] The Hartford Courant is trying to offer hometown coverage -and attract hometown advertising - in 82 towns from Long Island Sound to the Massachusetts border. [ D10. ] The Sunday Correspondent is Britain's first new national Sunday paper at the serious end of the market since The Sunday Telegraph was started in 1961. In many areas around London, the first issue on Sept. 17 was a sellout. [ D10. ] Since last year, at least 10 publishers have added either divisions or lines of children's books. [ D10. ] Marketers should build better bridges to their customers and each other if they want to survive the 1990's, FCB/Leber Katz says. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D11. ] Today's Columns A tax provision intended to prevent affluent families from escaping gift and estate taxes has prompted many anguished protests from tax professionals. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Investors are more bullish on stocks, but the fund managers who invest the money seem to be having a harder time finding values. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] Long-term interest rates could continue to rise in coming weeks, analysts say. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Clues and Adornment: The Score of 'Intolerance'
description: When Peter Williamson, the film curator at the Museum of Modern Art, got a grant to restore the original version of D. W. Griffith's ''Intolerance,'' he wondered whether the musical score might be any help. He looked around to find out who had done work on music for silent films and put in a call to Gillian B. Anderson, a musicologist and conductor on the staff of the Library of Congress.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketers Get a Guide For the 1990's
description: A New York advertising agency known for its analyses of consumer trends says marketers had better build bridges to their customers and between each other if they want to survive the 1990's.

title: Packers Rally to Defeat Falcons, 23-21
description: Chris Jacke, a rookie, kicked a 22-yard field goal with 1 minute 42 seconds left, capping a 17-point fourth-quarter rally today as the Green Bay Packers beat the Atlanta Falcons, 23-21.

title: Manila Journal; In Death, Marcos Is Pitied and His Return Is Urged
description: In recent months of relative normalcy, thousands of Filipinos have come each day to gawk and wander in the remarkably opulent halls of the Malacanang Palace where Ferdinand E. Marcos ruled for 20 years before his ouster in 1986.

title: A Battle of Wits In 2 Windy Parks
description: THEY are two teams with creative and formidable offenses and with creative and formidable managers who freely call pitchouts, squeeze bunts and the hit-and-run. And when they open the National League playoff Wednesday night at Wrigley Field, Don Zimmer of the Chicago Cubs and Roger Craig of the San Francisco Giants will open a war of wits for the pennant in two of the oldest, coldest and windiest ball parks in baseball.

title: More Hometown Turf for Hartford Courant
description: The Hartford Courant, long the voice of Connecticut's capital city, is now trying to offer hometown coverage - and attract hometown advertising - in 82 towns from Long Island Sound to the Massachusetts border.

title: In Nicaragua, the Election Observers Are Coming!
description: As national voter registration began today, Nicaraguans got their first look at what will be a huge international effort to preserve peace and supervise free elections in their war-battered country.

title: Retracing Hurricane's Path, Jackson Gives Words of Hope
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson swept from South Carolina to the eastern end of the Caribbean over the last four days, backtracking on Hurricane Hugo's path and rekindling his formidable popularity among the poor blacks who were the majority of the storm's victims.

title: Senator Predicts Defeat for Tax Bill
description: In unusually blunt language, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, predicted today that he could marshal enough votes to block passage of the House-approved reduction in the capital gains tax rate.

title: Let Nicaragua Vote Without Our Intervention; In Guatemala, Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Rapist Hangs Himself in Cell At Maximum-Security Prison
description: An inmate imprisoned for raping a 5-year-old girl and running her over with his car hanged himself in his cell at the Clinton Correctional Facility, state prison officials said over the weekend.

title: Manuel Clouthier, Who Sought Mexican Presidency, Dies in Crash
description: Manuel Clouthier, the candidate of the right-of-center National Action Party in the 1988 presidential election, was killed today in an automobile accident in northern Mexico, the highway police reported. He was 55 years old.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Outdoors: Faraway Rivers With Strange-Sounding Names
description: LEAD: ''SEPTEMBER has a touch of the year's death in it,'' said the English fisherman, hunter and naturalist Roderick Haig-Brown. Now, as trout season comes to a close, one begins to dream about where to fish one last time before rods, reels and flies are reluctantly pushed into a corner until spring opens the rivers once more.

title: ARGENTINES HONOR A WARLORD OF OLD
description: In a probable prelude to the granting of presidential pardons to military officers for rebellion and political crimes, the remains of the most famous of Argentina's 19th-century provincial warlords were buried in his homeland today.

title: Yanks End Dim Year Dimly
description: As the Yankees' dismal season ended yesterday, their off-season planning had already begun.

title: Review/Music; From Gospel to Cabaret
description: So severe is the dearth of distinctive male cabaret singers in New York nowadays that the emergence of a talent as promising as the young baritone Steven Davis is an encouraging sign for the genre.

title: Mexican Leader in the U.S. for Talks
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico left for Washington today on his first official visit to the United States, intent on testing Bush Administration pledges to help restore his country's economy while avoiding entanglement in the American Government's new drug control strategy.

title: China Calls TV Tale Subversive
description: Television programming has been blamed for many things, but China is perhaps the first country to accuse a program of helping sow the seeds of a counterrevolutionary rebellion.

title: Head of Indiana Klan Is Held With Gun and Club in Auto
description: The leader of the Indiana Ku Klux Klan was arrested on weapons charges after he was stopped for traffic violations near Poughkeepsie, the police said today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending Aug. Purchasing Managers Index Sept. Tuesday New-Home Sales Aug. Factory Orders Aug. Wednesday New-Car Sales Sept. Thursday None Friday Unemployment Sept. Consumer Credit Aug.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Roger and Me'' on Wednesday listed the credits incompletely in some copies. The editors were Wendey Stanzler and Jennifer Beman.

title: Mets' Final Victory Proves Bittersweet
description: The Mets closed today with a 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates and a sweep of their final four-game series, and they ended a season of turmoil by taking second place in the National League East, one year after they had won 100 games and the division championship.

title: Review/Opera; 'Il Trittico' Substitutes
description: No one who saw Teresa Stratas in her first-night performance of ''Il Trittico'' last Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera could have been entirely surprised that she canceled the second one Friday night. The soprano had played Puccini's three one-act operas with manic intensity, and sometimes seemed to be getting through on sheer nerves. It was an extraordinary performance, but it was understandable that she might need extra time to recover her energies. Three singers took her place Friday night.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What has happened shows that we are in a historical period of change, which cannot be reversed and will continue. I hope that the East German leadership realizes this and will not isolate itself by refusing to change. Gorbachev is coming and I hope he will convince East Germany that reform lies in its best interests, that reform means more, not less, stability.'' -Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany. [ A8:3. ]

title: Only Light Effect Expected On Stocks and Real Estate
description: Although many Wall Street executives and real estate developers welcomed the House of Representatives' vote on Thursday to cut the capital gains tax rate, few thought the reduction, if passed by the Senate, would have any significant impact on their business or on stock prices.

title: Lake Champlain in Rapid Decline, Experts Say
description: Lake Champlain is declining more rapidly than scientists had realized and is in desperate need of Federal assistance to slow the process, experts said here today at a symposium.

title: How to Help the Disabled Pay Their Own Way; Facilities at Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Kangaroos Sets Merger
description: Jumping-Jacks Shoes Inc. reached a preliminary agreement last week to merge with Kangaroos U.S.A. Inc., a privately held shoe company. The agreement calls for Jumping-Jacks shareholders to own a 20 percent equity stake in the combined operations, with the rest being owned by Kangaroos shareholders. Third parties would also buy up to a million Jumping-Jacks shares from current shareholders for $2.35 a share.

title: Nations Agree to Extension Of Coffee Pact for 2 Years
description: A two-year extension of the International Coffee Agreement has received the necessary backing of importing and exporting nations, allowing it to take effect without new provisions for price supports, officials said today.

title: Commtron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Two AIDS Cases Traced to Oral Sex
description: The city's Health Department says it has documented two cases in which men have become infected with the AIDS virus through oral sex.

title: Chess
description: What is the difference between a detective story and a gambit? One is a whodunit, and the other a who's going to do it. Each one thrives on suspense.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS U.S. Gains Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert each won a singles match today to lead the United States, the top-seeded team, past Greece in the first round of the Federation Cup in Tokyo. Evert, who recently retired from Grand Slam competition, needed only 43 minutes to beat Christina Papadaki, 6-0, 6-1. Navratilova, ranked second in the world, beat Angeliki Kanellopoulou, ranked 74th, by 6-3, 6-1. In yesterday's opening-round matches, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, the French Open champion, defeated Nathalie Tauziat, 6-4, 6-2, as second-seeded Spain beat France. Sanchez Vicario, ranked fifth in the world, pulled away after the first set was tied at 3-3. Conchita Martinez of Spain struggled nearly three hours before beating Isabelle Demongeot, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4. In other matches, fourth-seeded Bulgaria defeated South Korea, the Netherlands defeated Yugoslavia, Argentina defeated the Philippines and the Soviet Union defeated Switzerland. (AP) Becker Advances: Boris Becker of West Germany defeated Thomas Muster of Austria, 7-5, 6-1, yesterday to advance in the Stuttgart Classic in West Germany. Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated Alberto Mancini of Argentina, 7-5, 7-5, and Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany edged Henri Leconte of France, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1.(AP)

title: British Laborites Abandon Arms Stance
description: The British Labor Party voted today to abandon a commitment to unilateral nuclear disarmament that its leader, Neil Kinnock, blamed for keeping the party out of power for the last 10 years.

title: Harold R. Fatzer Retired Judge, 79
description: Harold R. Fatzer, former Chief Justice of the Kansas Supreme Court shot himself to death at his home on Saturday. He was 79 years old.

title: Ecumenical Bible in Current English
description: The Revised English Bible, described by a former Archbishop of Canterbury as the ''first truly ecumenical Bible,'' has been published by Oxford and Cambridge University Presses.

title: CSX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $26,000,000, or 25 cents a share, for the latest 9 months and $189,000,000, or $1.21 a share, for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest third quarter included a $34 million, or 33 cents a share, after-tax gain largely because of the sale of Rockresorts and related properties to VMS Realty Partners. c-Included $6 million, or 4 cents a share, in earnings from the company's discontinued energy segment.

title: Talking Business with Sikes of the F.C.C.; Communication Challenges Seen
description: Alfred C. Sikes was sworn in as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission in August, succeeding Dennis R. Patrick, a Reagan appointee who was a champion of deregulation. Mr. Sikes, who is 49 years old, had been administrator of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, the communications policy arm of the Commerce Department, since 1986.

title: Former Reagan Aide for H.U.D. Denies Pushing Housing Projects
description: A former White House aide in the Reagan Administration insisted today that he had not directed the Department of Housing and Urban Development to provide assistance to housing projects that were politically desirable.

title: Immucor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Stinkbird Takes a Resemblance Another Step
description: A South American jungle bird nicknamed the stinkbird has a digestive system similar to a cow's, ornithologists in Venuzuela have discovered.

title: Confusion on Quinn
description: Although Bob Quinn denied again that he was leaving the Yankees, a source familiar with the situation said yesterday that the general manager was intending to step down at the end of the month to accept a position with another club.

title: Salvadoran Leader, at U.N., Says He'll Propose Cease-Fire to Rebels
description: President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador gave his personal backing today to peace negotiations with rebel forces arranged in Mexico City last month.

title: Leona B. Hill, Advertising Executive, 79
description: Leona Bowman Hill, an advertising executive and founder of The Fashion Newsletter, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHINA WARNS U. S. ON INTERFERENCE
description: The Chinese Foreign Minister said yesterday that his country's relations with the United States were ''at a crossroads.'' He said relations could improve if America accepted the premise that China has a different political system that should not be criticized.

title: Violinist Placed on Probation
description: A violinist who has won international acclaim was placed on three years probation today on drug charges. The violinist, Eugene Fodor, pleaded guilty to breaking and entering but not guilty to the drug charges. The 39-year-old New York City violinist pleaded guilty to breaking into a Martha's Vineyard motel room, where he was found July 27 with 20 grams of cocaine and a hypodermic needle with a small amount of heroin.

title: For Spring, a Soft, Romantic Turn
description: The first spring styles emerging from Seventh Avenue design rooms have a soft, gentle air with a new fit that makes them kinder to the body. ''Romantic'' is the umbrella word that designers use when explaining their approach to the new season.

title: Michael Anthony Jewelers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $17,000 for the quarter and a loss of $267,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after losses of $212,000 for the quarter and $231,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. Sales for both fiscal 1988 periods were reclassified.

title: Steinberg Inc. reports earnings for Year to July 29
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $4,027,000, or 19 cents a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $4,099,000. Fiscal 1989 had a 52-week period, compared with 53 weeks for fiscal 1988. The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: Pope and Runcie See Snag to Reunion
description: Pope John Paul II and the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, the Archbishop of Canterbury, ended four days of talks today, pledging to reunite their long-divided churches.

title: .251 Hitter Talking Baseball
description: What with all the horrors that cross his desk on any given day, the President of the United States is not terribly disturbed by talk of young people staying up late to watch World Series games.

title: Jean Grambs, Teacher And Author, 70, Dies
description: Jean Grambs, a professor of human development at the College of Education at the University of Maryland at College Park until her retirement last year, died after suffering a heart attack Saturday at her home in College Park. She was 70 years old.

title: Japanese Get Music Stake
description: A Japanese media group will pay about $150 million to buy a stake of just over 25 percent in the London-based Virgin Music Group, the world's sixth-largest record company, Virgin's managing director, Ken Berry, said today.

title: Review/Television; A Tour of the 'Hidden City' Underground
description: ''Hidden City'' takes us uptown, downtown and, mostly, undertown in an exploration of the methods and machines that make possible the improbable, keeping New York running. The opening hour of the new season of ''Nova'' at 8 o'clock tonight on Channels 13 and 49 and at 9 on Channel 21, shows how seven million people get their electricity and water and get rid of their trash and sewage.

title: Bensonhurst Slaying Suspect Is Injured in Brooklyn Prison
description: Joseph Fama, the 18-year-old white youth accused of shooting a black teen-ager to death in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, suffered a slight injury under the right eye, apparently at the hands of a guard at the Brooklyn House of Detention last week, authorities said yesterday.

title: A New Chapter in the Life of Story
description: Story, the literary magazine that helped to discover such writers as William Saroyan, Truman Capote, J. D. Salinger and Carson McCullers in the 1930's and 40's, will be reborn this month, two decades after its demise.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES STRICT NEW LIMITS ON CAR POLLUTION
description: A House subcommittee voted unanimously today to tighten automobile tailpipe emission controls, establishing national pollution standards as strict as California's.

title: Southern Hospitality Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Wisconsin Toy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included $500,000 of pretax non- recurring consulting income relating to an inventory liquidation of a major toy maker.

title: Cray Cutting Its Computer Work Force
description: Citing advances in manufacturing technology and the switch to a more advanced supercomputer model, Cray Research Inc., said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 400 of its assembly workers, about 7 percent of its 5,400 workers worldwide.

title: No Need for the Execution Express
description: When Justice William Rehnquist suggested several years ago that death penalty cases be put on a faster track than other criminal appeals, the idea seemed ghoulish and commanded only his vote on the Supreme Court. But as Chief Justice, he insisted on appointing a committee of judges to study execution delays.

title: Prices of Land Higher in Japan
description: The cost of land rose nationwide in Japan, the National Land Agency reported today, but prices in Tokyo's residential areas fell for the first time since the Government began keeping records in 1975.

title: Hudson General reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $10,042,000. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,129,000. The company said results from continuing operations for the latest year included a previously announced charge of about $3,200,000 in connection with the sale of the balance of the company's aircraft spare parts inventory.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Thursday about fines paid by two banks to the Federal Reserve Board for improper recording of deposits reversed the amounts. The National Bank of Greece paid a $125,000 fine.

title: Polymeric Resources Corp. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The increase in latest year's net income and share earnings was due primarily to the implementation of FASB 96 of about $153,000, or $1.46 a share.

title: Oakland Journal; 'Subway Series' Where Car Is King?
description: In the control room of the Bay Area Rapid Transit system here, red and green lights blink and flicker, marking the progress of 45 trains moving whisper-soft along 71.5 miles of track.

title: Hipotronics Inc. reports earnings for 13wk to Sept 2
Earnings Increase At the WCRS Group
description: The WCRS Group P.L.C. said yesterday that its earnings more than doubled from the previous fiscal year. The British advertising and marketing conglomerate reported pretax profits of $:38.1 million, or about $61.3 million. Its earnings per share increased by 28 percent, to 29.91 pence, or 48 cents.

title: U.S. Securities Prices Are Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in slow trading yesterday.

title: Salute to Orioles
description: The city of Baltimore gave the Orioles a parade through a rainy downtown yesterday and then about 1,200 fans gathered at the Inner Harbor's Festival Hall to salute the team.

title: Is Coaxing Mr. Shamir Enough?
description: The Bush Administration appears to be prodding Israel toward a dialogue with Palestinians by careful private squeezing and minimum public pressure. That policy probably won't bring Prime Minister Shamir and his Likud coalition to the table. But given Likud's central role in any negotiations, gentle persuasion is a sensible first step.

title: New Fight in Old West: Farmers vs. Condo City
description: The gentrification of the American West, promoted by some people as the best economic hope for the future of many communities that have fallen on hard times, is meeting stiff resistance in this alpine valley on the western side of the Teton Range.

title: Stock Link By Nintendo
description: Fidelity Investments, a Boston-based private investment mangement company, and the Nintendo Company of Japan, the world's largest video game manufacturer, said yesterday that they would team up to develop, produce and market a home trading system for financial services.

title: Drug-Cartel Aide, Arrested, Is Now in a Colombian Jail
description: An associate of the leaders of the Medellin cartel, one of Colombia's two main cocaine trafficking organizations, was jailed here today after being captured over the weekend in Ecuador.

title: Clarus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest 9 months was due mainly to higher interest charges on increased working capital and one-time costs related to management changes. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: By Design; Illusions of Youth
description: There is a good reason so many heads of gray hair become blond. Or why hair styles that stop at the chin line are better than those that fall to the shoulder. These two are just a few of the illusionary tricks that trim time off a woman's age.

title: Soviet Envoy Tells U.S. of Mental Hospital Reform
description: In an unusual move, a senior Soviet Embassy official appeared before a Congressional committee today and said Moscow had created a new independent commission to insure that mental hospitals would not be used to incarcerate political prisoners.

title: Drug Figure's Mother Offers Plea
description: The mother of a major drug figure, Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, pleaded guilty yesterday to a reduced Federal charge that could enable her to avoid a prison term.

title: Our Deposit Insurance Would Startle New Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the annual animal blessing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine misidentified the presiding minister. He was the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., Episcopal Bishop of New York, not Bishop James Parks Morton, Dean of the cathedral.

title: Dr. Mary Paduano, 43, Professor of Nursing
description: Dr. Mary Ann Paduano, professor of nursing at the Lienhard School of Nursing at Pace University, died Sunday after a long illness at Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. She was 43 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: How a Hormone Limits Appetite Is Discovered
description: RESEARCHERS have identified how a hormone triggers the brain to tell the body when to stop eating, and they have discovered two chemicals that block the hormone's action.

title: Groups to Consider Proposals to N.C.A.A.
description: With three months remaining before the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention, the N.C.A.A.'s Presidents' Commission will meet in Kansas City beginning today to approve legislation it will propose to the convention.

title: Dean Foods Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Leader Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $97,517, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $126,152, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary credit of $43,211, or 1 cent a share, for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Robert Felheim, 85, Ex-Brokerage Partner
description: Robert J. Felheim, a retired partner of Neuberger & Berman, a brokerage and money-management concern, died Friday at New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Singer Island, Fla.

title: Review/Comedy; Hope, Burns and a Chair With an Ashtray
description: So the other day this reporter calls up George Burns. And she asks him if it's true he chases girls, that he drinks four or five martinis a day, that he smokes 15 or 20 cigars. ''Yes,'' he says. ''What does your doctor say?'' she asks. ''My doctor's dead.'' George Burns, thank goodness, is very much alive.

title: Market Place; The Minuses of Prime-Plus Funds
description: A new investment product that has attracted billions of dollars from investors has sparked a widening controversy and has even prompted an investigation by the securities industry.

title: Ford Prices Raised 4.9%
description: The Ford Motor Company's 1990 model cars will cost an average of 4.9 percent more than comparably equipped 1989 vehicles, the company announced. Ford said nearly half of the increase came because of Government-required passive safety devices like driver-side air bags or automatic seat belts. The General Motors Corporation has announced a 3.4 percent average price increase, and the Chrysler Corporation, which will announce its prices within two weeks, has estimated its increase will be about 5 percent. Both companies said their price increases were also affected by new Government regulations requiring additional safety systems.

title: Henderson in the No. 1 Spot Gives Athletics Their Gusto
description: He swung a bat and then sat down, and in the moment that it took Rickey Henderson to look into the sky this afternoon, a crowd had gathered. But he did not flinch; attention almost seems to soothe him.

title: Forcible Conversion Is Alien to Buddhism
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pioneer In Portables Issues Update
description: THE portable computer arena has been especially busy in recent months, with introductions of machines ranging from the one-pound Poqet and Atari computers to the 17-pound Apple Macintosh Portable. Last week the Tandy Corporation of Fort Worth, Tex., whose classic Model 100 started the whole lightweight portable industry several years ago, unveiled its next-generation machine, the 1100 FD.

title: No Charges in Striker's Death
description: No criminal charges will be filed in the death of a striking Nynex worker who was injured while picketing, the Westchester County District Attorney said today. The District Attorney, Carl Vergari, said a county grand jury concluded that there was ''no chargeable criminal conduct'' in the death. Edward Horgan, 34 years old, of Valley Cottage in Rockland County, died after he jumped on a car on Aug. 14 that was driven by Tricia McNamara of Katonah, an 18-year-old summer worker at the New York Telephone Company, Mr. Vergari said. Mr. Horgan rolled off the car and hit his head, Mr. Vergari said.

title: Walsh an Adept Fill-In, But Cowboys Still Fail
description: When Jerry Jones, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, spent more than $15 million signing Troy Aikman and Steve Walsh, he explained the high cost of the two rookie quarterbacks this way: ''This may be my first year in the National Football League, but I do know that quarterbacks are a premium. You never have enough good ones. This stabilizes our future.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 31 about ''Days of Rage,'' a documentary about the uprisings in the Israeli-occupied territories, referred incorrectly to financial backing of The Journal of Palestine Studies. In a letter to The Times, Philip Mattar, executive director of the Institute for Palestine Studies, said the journal is underwritten solely by the institute and by Kuwait University, receiving no money from the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, acquired six Airbus Industries jets and options for six more, giving its American Airlines unit firm orders for 248 jets with options for 302 more.

title: Texas Court Rules Rich-Poor Gap In State School Spending Is Illegal
description: The Texas Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the state's system for financing public schools is unconstitutional because of ''glaring disparities'' between what rich and poor school districts spend on education.

title: Steel-Import Curb Voted
description: The House of Representatives today approved President Bush's request for a two-and-a-half-year extension of arrangments with other steel-producing nations to restrict their exports to the United States to help the recovery of the domestic steel industry.

title: Presbyterian Hospital in Union Pact
description: In a departure from negotiations involving most of the New York City area's private hospitals, the Presbyterian Hospital reached a tentative agreement yesterday with a union representing its health-care workers.

title: How to Help the Disabled Pay Their Own Way; Protects Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: McNeil Apologizes to Coach for Sitting Down
description: Freeman McNeil says he has learned that a football player should not stop to feel sorry for someone he has injured.

title: Panama Opposition Figures Are Arrested and Questioned
description: Ricardo Arias Calderon, a prominent opposition leader, and eight companions were detained over the weekend for 20 hours and questioned about their efforts to deprive the Government of funds, the Panamanian military announced today.

title: Marriott Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
description: Marriott said that the latest third quarter net is after a pre-tax gain of $15 million from the sale of the London Marriott Hotel. Year-ago third quarter net if after a pre-tax gain of $4 million from the sale of a hotel.

title: Head of Trustees Resigns at SUNY
description: The chairman of the board of trustees of the State University of New York said yesterday that he was resigning after 11 years because it was time for someone with ''new ideas.''

title: Checkrobot Inc. reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included a loss from unconsolidated affiliate of $184,400.

title: Cara Operations Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 17
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Foul Weather Hinders Storm Cleanup Efforts
description: Rain, floods and a tornado dealt new blows today to people trying to rebuild towns devastated by Hurricane Hugo.

title: The Proper Time to Tell Doctors What Will Be Expected of Them
description: SEVERAL leaders in medical education and health care say the risks and responsibilities of becoming a physician should be explained clearly to students before they enter medical school, not during training as is now customary.

title: Q&A
description: Billiards Q. Is the Earth really as smooth as a billiard ball? A. ''On average, certainly yes,'' said John O'Keefe of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md.

title: New Drug Treatment For Colon Cancer
description: A drug used to deworm farm animals combined with a common cancer drug has been found to save the lives of patients with an advanced type of colon cancer, the National Cancer Institute announced today.

title: Parcells Offers Praise for Giants' Attitude
description: With a fourth of the season gone and the Giants' record now at four victories and no defeats, Bill Parcells made a team assessment today that balanced promise and caution.

title: Safety Isn't a Luxury Item
description: If you've never heard of ABS - the acronym for antilock braking system - then, like the vast majority of consumers, you probably have less than $20,000 to spend on a new car.

title: 14 U.S. Athletes Selected for Tests
description: Fourteen American track and field athletes have been selected at random for the start this week of a new program of drug testing by The Athletics Congress.

title: Careers; Shortage Of Ph.D.'s on Campus Seen
description: EDWARD T. LEWIS, 55 years old, a college president, and a poet by avocation, says that after years of overabundance there is a shortage of Ph.D's. ''We are beginning to see it now in the humanities, along with the usual shortages in engineering, mathematics, computer science and, to a lesser degree, in other sciences,'' he said last week.

title: Kellogg Expects Lower Earnings
description: The Kellogg Company said it expects its third-quarter earnings to be lower than in the corresponding period last year because of increasing competition for ready-to-eat oat bran cereal. The announcement caused a sharp fall today in the company's stock, which lost $2.25 to close at $71.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. The company earned $145.7 million, or $1.18 a share, in the third quarter a year ago.

title: Gains Seen By Chairman Of Northwest
description: Alfred A. Checchi, who led the buyout team that won control of NWA Inc., left no doubt today that he would be involved in managing the company on a continuing basis and that he was in for the long term.

title: To Get His Museum, Opening in '92
description: More than 700 paintings by Andy Warhol, as well as drawings, prints, photographs, sculptures, films and videotapes, will form the core collection of a museum devoted entirely to the artist's work, to open in 1992 in his hometown, Pittsburgh.

title: Raleigh, N.C., Paper Closing
description: The Raleigh Times, the evening sister paper in North Carolina's capital to the morning News and Observer, is ceasing publication on Nov. 30 after 110 years.

title: Risk to Fetus Ruled as Barring Women From Jobs
description: If a factory job poses a potential risk to an unborn child, an employer may bar all fertile women from those jobs even if they are not pregnant or say they have no intention of getting pregnant, the Federal appeals court here has ruled.

title: Epsilon Data Management Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Music; D'Leon's Energy and Salsa
description: The band leader and bassist Oscar D'Leon brought his large orchestra into S.O.B.'s on Friday night for a typically exciting set. Mr. D'Leon is one of salsa's most energetic entertainers, and by mixing tightly and cleverly arranged material with his own nonstop dancing and fooling around, he packed the dance floor.

title: Trade Group Names Officers
description: The Association of National Advertisers chose new officers for the coming year. John E. Ruhaak, the vice president of advertising and promotion at United Airlines, was elected chairman. He succeeds Joseph J. Doherty, a vice president at the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation.

title: Let Manila Use Its Aid For Police, Quayle Says
description: Vice President Dan Quayle said today that the Bush Administration was considering asking Congress to let the Philippines use some of its American aid to build up its internal security.

title: Conquering the Wishbone Behind a Small Force
description: People hear about this elusive little Air Force Academy quarterback named Dee Dowis, whose statistics have turned him into a Heisman Trophy candidate, and the same questions always arise.

title: People
description: * David Johnson and Rich Martel have been named senior vice presidents of BBDO New York.

title: IN A DIZZYING DAY, 2,500 MORE SEEK REFUGE IN PRAGUE
description: More than 2,500 East Germans sought refuge today in the West German Embassy here, hoping to join more than 6,000 other East Germans who were allowed to travel from Czechoslovakia to West Germany over the weekend. The East Berlin Government demanded that Bonn not allow the latest refugees to remain in the embassy.

title: Conservative Picked for Kenya
description: President Bush today announced his intention to nominate a conservative journalist, Smith Hempstone Jr., to be Ambassador to Kenya. Mr. Hempstone, 60 years old, a former executive editor of The Washington Times, wrote a syndicated column for that newspaper until his retirement a month ago. In the 1960's, he worked as a foreign correspondent in Africa and Latin America for The Chicago Daily News.

title: Sana Journal; With A Dagger in Its Belt, Yemen Is a State of Mind
description: A Yemeni magazine editor pointed at the handle of the curved dagger thrust into his woven silk waistband and explained its origin by way of a gesture depicting the single horn of a rhinoceros.

title: New Data Scheme's Potential and Pitfalls
description: THIS could be the start of something big.

title: Mark IV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1.2 million, or 12 cents a share, for both periods; the 6 months also included a loss of $900,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1 million for the quarter and $1.4 million for the 6 months. The company said it restated figures for the year-ago quarter and 6 months. The company said the loss from discontinued operations included the results of operations of Alston, Conrac Elektron and the video monitor business of SCD for both year-ago periods, and the 3-month period ended May 31 as well as Blackstone for the 3 months ended May 31. The extraordinary credit represented gains realized on open market purchases of certain of the company's subordinated debentures, net of taxes.

title: Univar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Governor of Puerto Rico Denies Promising a Contract to Wedtech
description: Rafael Hernandez-Colon, the Governor of Puerto Rico, yesterday contradicted the Federal Government's main witness against Representative Robert Garcia. He said he had ''absolutely not'' promised an island government contract to officials of the Wedtech Corporation after Mr. Garcia ushered them into the Governor's residence in San Juan in 1985.

title: Bergen Brunswig reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a loss of $124,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain on sale of discontinued operations of $1,999,000, or 9 cents a share. Share earnings for all periods are adjusted for the 25 percent stock dividend in July 1989.

title: Blaming Others for Collapse of PTL, Bakker Completes Testimony
description: Jim Bakker finished a day and a half of testimony at his fraud and conspiracy trial today by blaming his fellow evangelist Jerry Falwell, who took over the Bakker ministry, for its collapse.

title: Washington at Work; An Image Polisher Leaves Nevada Neon to Sharpen a 'Beige' White House
description: He is a friend of Wayne Newton. His clients have included Frank Sinatra and Donald Trump. He wears well-cut Italian suits, Hermes ties, Bally loafers and a $3,000 Bertolucci watch. He drives a Mercedes sedan with a cellular phone.

title: International Dairy Queen reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
PVC Container Corp. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a $330,000, or 5 cents a share, adjustment due to a reduction in the company's deferred income tax liability complying with the requirements of FASB No. 96.

title: On Horse Racing; Facts and Bits to Boggle the Mind
description: Here's a frightening thought: Imagine the clutter you would see if you looked inside a horseplayer's memory.

title: Working-Class Families Losing Middle-Class Dreams
description: Gilbert and Debra Matthews enter every penny of his subway motorman's salary on the giant lined sketch pad that serves as their budget, only to find they keep coming up short.

title: Houghton Mifflin Will Buy Gollancz, British Publisher
description: The Houghton Mifflin Company, one of the few remaining independent American book publishers, announced yesterday that it intends to purchase Victor Gollancz, a 60-year-old privately held British publishing house. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Community Psychiatric reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,032,000, or 6 cents a share, and $8,422,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also included taxable gain of $1,629,000 from the sale of real property. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,202,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,185,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: McAdoo Steals Show
description: Some 13,000 fans of Messaggero Roma of the Italian basketball league jammed the Palaeur Arena in Rome on Sunday night to greet two young players from the United States, Danny Ferry and Brian Shaw, who were expected to make a triumphant home-court debut.

title: Visa Applicants Deluge Embassy in Moscow
description: People lined up for blocks outside the American Embassy here today and snapped up more than 30,000 visa applications as new emigration rules went into effect.

title: Becker Milk Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rite Aid Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
U.S. Cites New York In Sludge Dumping
description: A Federal complaint has been issued against New York City for spilling sewage sludge into the East River. The complaint, seeking $100,000 in civil penalties, was announced yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency, which said the city dumped 328,000 gallons of sludge into the river on Sept 22.

title: How to Help the Disabled Pay Their Own Way; Ingenuity Will Prevail
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev Calls for a Strike Ban, Saying Economy Is Near Collapse
description: Warning that political unrest has brought the Soviet economy to the brink of collapse, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for a 15-month ban on strikes and proposed other emergency powers to halt disruptions in industry and transport.

title: Cott Beverages reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Acklands Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MBIA Buying All of Stock In Bond Investors Guaranty
description: Reflecting narrowing profit margins in the municipal bond insurance business, MBIA Inc., the industry's largest company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy all the common stock in the Bond Investors Guaranty Insurance Company, the fourth largest, for $275 million in cash.

title: Mubarak Sees Bush and Cautions Israel on Rejecting Egyptian Plan
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met President Bush today and said afterward that the Israeli Government would make ''a grave mistake'' if it failed to open discussions with Palestinians based on his latest suggestions.

title: Sun Coast Plastics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said figures included the results of Plastics Manufacturing Co. since its acquisition in January 1988.

title: Amos Peaslee Jr., 66, a Mayor and Lawyer
description: Amos J. Peaslee Jr., a lawyer and the Mayor of East Greenwich, N.J., died Friday at his home in Clarksboro, N.J. He was 66 years old and had suffered a heart attack in April that left him in a coma.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Purchased the contract of John Davis, pitcher, from Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. Placed Jerry Hairston, designated hitter, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Named Larry Haney pitching coach. Reassigned Tony Muser, hitting coach, to minor league instructor and scout. TEXAS (AL) - Announced they will not exercise the contract option for Charlie Hough, pitcher, for the 1990 season. Announced Cecilio Guante and Paul Wilmet, pitchers, and Thad Bosley, outfielder, have refused being assigned outright to Oklahoma City of the American Association and will become free agents. CINCINNATI (NL) - Assigned Scotti Madison, infielder, outright to Nashville of the American Association. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Purchased the contract of Mike York, pitcher, from Harrisburg of the Eastern League. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Reassigned Johnny Lewis, hitting coach, to their minor league system. BASKETBALL SANTA BARBARA (CBA) - Signed Brian Vaughns, forward. FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Activated Maurice Douglass, defensive back. Waived George Streeter, safety. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Waived Jim Gallery, place-kicker. Signed Jim Breech, place-kicker. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Waived Mark Cannon, center. Activated Mike Ariey, offensive tackle, from the reserve nonfootball-injury list. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Announced that O'Brien Alston, linebacker, will miss the rest of the season with a knee injury. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Waived Dwayne Jiles, linebacker. Activated Ron Solt, offensive lineman, from the reserve nonfootball-injury list.

title: Man Held in Crashes And Machete Attack
description: A 39-year-old attacked a woman with a machete yesterday and hit two pedestrians with his car before slamming into a police station house, the police said. The police said the man, Sergio Vega of 1535 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, was drugged, apparently on cocaine.

title: Zenith To Sell PC Subsidiary
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that it would sell its computer business to Groupe Bull, France's largest computer manufacturer, for about $635 million.

title: KEY RATES
Coelho to Join Banking Firm
description: Tony Coelho, the former United States Representative from California who resigned in June amid accusations of financial impropriety, said today that he was becoming a partner at Wertheim Schroder & Company, an investment banking firm.

title: Higher Benefits for Some Veterans Backed
description: The House of Representatives approved a 4.9 percent cost-of-living increase in benefits today for some 2.5 million disabled veterans and their survivors.

title: The Wartime Spirit
description: The Bush-Bennett ''war on drugs'' is not only underfinanced and misdirected toward predictably ineffective law enforcement rather than needed treatment. Like any other war, it's sure to produce a dangerous wartime mentality that ''anything goes'' in pursuit of victory.

title: Savings Agency Allocates $8 Billion for 5 Institutions
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created by Congress to clean up the savings and loan industry, set aside almost $8 billion on Friday for five severely troubled savings institutions under its control, its officials said today.

title: Memorial for Giamatti
description: Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the president of Yale University, heads the list of speakers at a memorial service Friday honoring A. Bartlett Giamatti, the former president of Yale who was the commissioner of baseball when he died of a heart attack Sept. 1 at the age of 51.

title: Review/Recital; Norwegian Seeks Extremes For the Cello
description: Truls Mork, a cellist from Norway, seems drawn to music that allows him to move between the expressive extremes to which his instrument is best suited. In the Grieg Sonata (Op. 36), for instance - the high point of his Saturday evening program at Weill Recital Hall - Mr. Mork and his pianist, Juhani Lagerspetz, played with unbridled energy. Yet for the central Andante Molto Tranquilo, they set the fireworks aside and gave a finely balanced, sweetly lyrical performance that made the movement an island of reflectivness in a tumultuous sea.

title: Huynh Tan Phat, Vietcong Aide And Hanoi Official, Is Dead at 76
description: Huynh Tan Phat, a leader of the Vietcong during the Indochina war and later a senior official in the Hanoi Government, died Saturday in Ho Chi Minh City. He was 76 years old.

title: Sifting Through What Little the Battles Have Left
description: Two years after the end of the First World War, on the former battlefields of France, there is still grim business at hand. And business it is: as the nightmare of war recedes, it has been replaced by bustling, impromptu forms of industry that call for their own curious brand of sang-froid. Those who have undertaken, quite literally, to sift through the rubble do so with patience, fussiness, occasional opportunism, gallows humor and most of the same bureaucratic instincts they might bring to other, less catastrophe-laden lines of work. It is the only way of bringing the horror to heel.

title: Divi Hotels N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: PMG Financial reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $225,000 from discontinued operations. The company recently changed its name from Peter Miller Apparel Group Inc. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Offstage Gains on Debt; As Bush Faces Harsh Criticism by Bankers, Some Countries Are Earnestly Negotiating
description: While President Bush and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have worked publicly in recent days to rebut criticism of the Administration's strategy for reducing third world debt, offstage developments demonstrate that important progress on debt is indeed being made. In meetings at the

title: Columbia Pictures Entertainent Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $4,629,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,875,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months. The company said the extraordinary credits in both the year-ago periods were due to the utilization of net operating loss carryforward.

title: Video Superstores reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: L.A. Gear Inc. reports earnings for Sales
description: All share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 25.

title: Eleanor Brown-Sheve, Medical Director, 64
description: Eleanor Upton Brown-Shev, medical director for disability at A.T.&T. Communications Systems, died of a heart attack Sept. 16 while on a tour in Vienna. She was 64 years old and had residences in Chatham, Mass., and Sausalito, Calif.

title: Scottish & York Holdings Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $620,000, or 4 cents a share, from a special tax credit for the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Children at Risk Must Be Saved Very Young
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Help the Disabled Pay Their Own Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Quality Food Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $890,000. The extraordinary item represented the early repayment of the company's 13 3/8 percent senior subordinated notes due 1996, in the principal amount of $10 million. The after- tax charge consisted of an early redemption premium and the write-off of unamoritzed debt issuance costs and discounts related to the redemption, which will occur on Oct. 10.

title: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Rises 20.90
description: Stocks reversed an early downtrend yesterday to register a solid and broad advance, but trading was slow.

title: Rotech Medical Corp. reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued and disposed operations of $995,693.

title: Rubicon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Satellite Information Systems Co. reports earnings for Year to June 30
Commonwealth Mortgage of America L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Addenda
description: * McDermott Kilsby & Co. has moved to 104 Fifth Avenue.

title: California Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Braniff Starts Some Flights
description: With a $49 one-way fare to attract passengers, Braniff Inc. resumed about 20 percent of its 256 daily flights. The carrier was virtually shut last week as it filed its second bankruptcy reorganization in seven years.

title: Fund Shortage For Eurotunnel
description: Directors of the effort to build a tunnel under the English Channel said today that they would have to raise more money because of a 40 percent increase in the estimated cost of linking Britain and France by rail in 1993.

title: A Big Gamble From Zenith On High-Definition TV
description: In deciding to sell its personal computer business, the Zenith Electronics Corporation is cashing in one of its most valuable chips to bet on the risky new technology of high-definition television, analysts said.

title: Court Refuses to Hear Occupational Safety Appeal
description: The Supreme Court, turning down an appeal in one of the most closely watched business cases on its docket, refused today to intervene in an Illinois prosecution of a Chicago manufacturer accused of exposing employees to toxic chemicals.

title: Andean Culture Found to Be As Old as the Greaty Pyramids
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS working in Peru have unearthed stunning evidence that monumental architecture, complex societies and planned developments first appeared and flowered in the New World between 5,000 and 3,500 years ago - roughly the same period when the great pyramids were built in Egypt and the Sumerian city-states reached their zenith in Mesopotamia.

title: A Modest Proposal For Presidential Visits
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav Inflation Soars
description: Yugoslavia's annual inflation rate increased to 1,181 percent in September. The Bureau of Statistics said inflation had increased by a monthly record of 287.2 percentage points, compared with 893.8 percent in August. In September 1988, the inflation rate was 217 percent.

title: Italian Areas Giving Giuliani a Strong Push
description: The line of march for the Columbus Day parade up Fifth Avenue this Friday appears to be the reverse of where New York City's mayoral candidates stand with Italian-American voters.

title: PATTERNS
description: Banker's Gray for Spring

title: Tokyo Chief Asks a Reappraisal
description: In his first major policy speech as Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu sounded today much like Japan's critics, declaring that the time had come to lower domestic prices, halt a growing disparity between rich and poor, and stop ''concentrating single-mindedly on economic efficiency.''

title: Johnson Is Certain Mets Will Dismiss Him
description: Davey Johnson was back home in Florida yesterday, convinced that he was about to be dismissed as manager of the Mets and replaced by Bud Harrelson, and agitated that the management of the Mets had left him dangling in public with two years remaining on his contract.

title: From Vacant Lots to Safe Havens for Children
description: In city neighborhoods where fearful children have grown accustomed to playing on rooftops, five new playgrounds have sprouted like tiny islands of green in a desolate gray sea.

title: Biology of Brain May Hold Key For Gamblers
description: THE psychological forces that propel so many chronic gamblers to ruin marriages, lose jobs and even turn to crime may spring from a biological need for risk and excitement, a new study has found.

title: Those High-Flying Orioles
description: On April 29, 1988, after the Baltimore Orioles lost their 21st straight game en route to the worst record in baseball, we offered three words of comfort: Remember the Mets. In 1969, a mere two years after finishing last for the sixth straight time, the Mets won their division, the pennant and the World Series.

title: Non-Socialists Forming Government in Norway
description: Three moderate non-Socialist political parties agreed today to form a coalition government. But with fewer seats in Parliament than the Socialist Labor Party, which they would replace, their prospects for maintaining power are widely viewed here as doubtful.

title: Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for 12mo to Aug 31
Autoclave Engineers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $554,000. The company said share earnings and shares outstanding used to compute share earnings have been adjusted to give effect to the 10 percent stock dividend issued on Sept. 15, 1989.

title: Stake in Harley Held by Group
description: Malcolm I. Glazer, a Rochester businessman, and members of his family, disclosed that they had acquired a 6.24 percent stake in Harley-Davidson Inc. and might seek control of the Milwaukee-based motorcycle manufacturer.

title: The World of an Addict in Moscow
