description: Georgi Gavrilov's ''Confession: a Chronicle of Alienation'' is a cool, memorably level-headed documentary feature about a young Moscow drug addict named Lesha, who is very sad, lost, gallant and Russian.

title: Construction Spending Up For August
description: The Government said today that construction spending had made its biggest monthly advance of the year in August. The gain was in Government and nonresidential building, while single-family housing continued to sag.

title: The Turmoil On Madison Ave.; A special report.; Shifts in Marketing Strategy Jolting Advertising Industry
description: After five years of stagnation, the American advertising industry is facing a dim and uncertain future.

title: Auto Insurance Rate Rises Halted
description: The California insurance commissioner today barred automobile insurers from raising their rates for six months while the state grapples with how to put into effect a rate-cutting initiative approved by voters last year.

title: Bridge
description: Defenders occasionally have the opportunity for the dunce-or-hero play. In the diagramed example from the NEC Venice Trophy contest in Perth, Australia, last month it was a dunce-or-heroine option, since it was the world women's team championship.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Don't Fiddle With the Fed; It's the Politicians Who Need Discipline
description: The Federal Reserve System's independence constantly frustrates idealistic populists, economic monetarists and Presidents uncomfortable with the ambiguity of its powers.

title: INSIDE
description: Rulings on Safety In the Workplace The Supreme Court declined to block prosecution of a company accused of endangering workers. Page A17.

title: Witold Rowicki, 75, Polish Conductor, Dies
description: Witold Rowicki, who founded the Warsaw National Philharmonic Orchestra and was its conductor for nearly 25 years, died on Sunday, the official Polish press agency reported today. He was 75 years old.

title: Jaco Electronics reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $571,000, or 39 cents a share.

title: Acting S.E.C. Chairman
description: President Bush today named Edward H. Fleischman, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1986, to be acting head of the panel. Mr. Fleischman, 57 years old, a former New York lawyer, will head the S.E.C. while the Senate considers the President's appointment of Richard C. Breeden, a White House aide, as permanent chairman. The previous chairman, David S. Ruder, left last week to return to teaching at Northwestern University's law school.

title: Riser Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After an extraordinary non-recurring charge of $5,706,000 for settlement of litigation and associated legal fees for the quarter and year. The company began operations on June 9, 1988.

title: High Court's Support Asked On Yonkers Housing Fines
description: In a case that may determine how much power Federal courts have to enforce desegregation orders, the Bush Administration asked the Supreme Court today to uphold personal fines imposed by a Federal judge last year against four city councilmen from Yonkers.

title: Simon Gluckman, 81, Accountant, Is Dead
description: Simon Gluckman, an accountant and an executive, died of cardiac arrest Friday at Benedectine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., and Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Campaign Trail; The Cardinal Disapproves Of 'Evasion'
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, is protesting vigorously that he has no favorites in this year's mayoral race. He even refused to make joint appearances with his good friend and co-author, Mayor Edward I. Koch, during the Democratic primary campaign.

title: Lure of 300th Victory Keeps Ryan Pitching
description: An opportunity to achieve 300 career pitching victories by picking up just 11 more triumphs in 1990 will lure Nolan Ryan back into a Texas Ranger uniform next season. This season, the 42-year-old Ryan ran his career strikeout total over the 5,000 mark and became the oldest man to strike out 300 batters in a season.

title: Cal-Star Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Slowdown Is Found Continuing
description: The National Association of Purchasing Managers' index of economic activity showed a continuing slowing in the manufacturing sector in September.

title: H.R.A. Chief Resigns Post After 3 Years
description: William J. Grinker announced his resignation yesterday from the New York City Human Resources Administration after three tumultuous years in charge of the agency responsible for serving the city's most troubled and most vulnerable citizens.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Anchor President Quitting In Wake of Reorganization
description: The Anchor Savings Bank said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, William G. Schneider Jr., had notified the bank that he was resigning, Mr. Schneider, 48, told the bank that a management reorganization in July reduced his duties and, as a result, became an ''event of termination'' under his contract.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Augustus A. Busch Jr., brewer and owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, referred incorrectly to one of his marriages. At the death of his first wife, the former Marie Church, in 1930, the couple were still married; they did not divorce.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anthony M. Franco Inc., Detroit, a public relations firm, named Claire K. Coleman senior vice president in its New York office.

title: Devils Choose Nilsson In the Waiver Draft
description: The Devils selected Kent Nilsson, the Swedish center, in today's National Hockey League waiver draft.

title: Oldsmobile Offers Free Plane Tickets
description: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation said it was offering buyers of 1989 or 1990 Cutlass Supremes two free round-trip tickets on Delta Air Lines to anywhere in the continental United States or to Bermuda or Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Phone Debentures Are Priced at Par
description: The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia offered $100 million of debentures yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 8 3/8 percent debentures, which have a final maturity date of Oct. 1, 2029, carry a ''put,'' at par, or $100, on Oct. 1, 1999.

title: Boston Bank Is Projecting Large Loss
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it would report a loss of about $125 million for the third quarter after raising its reserves by $370 million to cover problem real estate loans and difficulties it had with a large loan to a heavily indebted company.

title: Victoria Creations Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
Firefighter Believed He Was Watched
description: The off-duty New York City firefighter who was shot and killed Sunday morning by a Federal agent apparently believed he was being investigated by the F.B.I., the authorities said yesterday.

title: ICI Plant to Make Safer Refrigerant
description: ICI Americas Inc., a subsidiary of the British chemical giant Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., said it would build a plant in Louisiana to make an environmentally safer alternative to ozone-depleting chloroflourocarbons. Chloroflourocarbons are used as the cooling agent in refrigerators and air-conditioners and in producing plastic foams and pharmaceuticals. Scientists say that the chlorine in CFC's destroys the upper atmosphere's ozone layer and leads to an increase in dangerous ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth.

title: Being Nice or Rotten in Writing
description: You might not think in first meeting Cynthia Ozick that savage literary thrusts and volcanic flows of shrewd observation could emerge from the pen - or, as she has put it, from ''the wet substance, ink or blood'' - of this gentle figure of a Jewish mother.

title: Farmer Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1988 results included assets write-off of $3.2 million as a result of an accounting change.

title: I.B.M. Vice President Heads Rolm Venture
description: The Rolm Company officially began operations yesterday as a joint venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and Siemens A.G. of West Germany, with H. Mitchell Watson Jr. at the helm.

title: Books of The Times; World War II Los Angeles, as a Boy Sees It
description: The Year of the Zinc Penny By Rick DeMarinis 174 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: Nevada Goldfields reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $191,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said the 1989 loss included a non-recurring writedown of $8.2 million and depreciation, depletion and amortization of $7.6 million. The comnpany said the writedown came from a reassessment of the Kingston ore reserves in Nevada and the Empire project investment in Colorado.

title: U.S. Cool to Housing Soviet Emigres in West Bank
description: The Bush Administration said today that while it wanted to help Israel with the cost of resettling Soviet Jewish emigres, it did not want to do anything to encourage or subsidize the construction of housing in the West Bank.

title: Lockheed Expecting Loss of $35 Million
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it would take a charge of about $165 million against third-quarter earnings because of cost overruns on two aircraft-development contracts. The charge will result in a loss of about $35 million in the quarter, the company said.

title: Refusal to Arbitrate Leaves City Opera Talks Stalled
description: Negotiations in the strike by the New York City Opera's musicians remained at a standstill yesterday, despite a proposal by the company's chief negotiator that the dispute be submitted to binding arbitration.

title: Amplicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,350,000, or 20 cents a share. The company said results for the latest fiscal periods are not comparable to like periods a year-ago because of a new method of accounting for leases and selling expenses mandated by the Financial Accounting Standards Board. The amount of the decrease in earnings for the year ended June 30, 1989 attributable to new accounting principles is about $1,183,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: Ameron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Reaching Individual Consumers
description: Giving voice to a contemporary trend in advertising, the chairman of the largest American-owned ad agency told marketing executives today that the most important factor affecting their businesses was ''a mass movement to individuality.''

title: Bears (4-0) Put Crunch On Eagles
description: More than 10 months later, for too much of a cool, clear night, the Philadelphia Eagles were still in a fog at Soldier Field.

title: Motorola to Cut 2,500 Workers
description: Motorola Inc. said it would reduce its 105,000-employee work force by 2,500, or 2.4 percent, and take a pretax charge of about $43 million in the third quarter to cover the cost of the voluntary severance program. The company said the cut of salaried employees would be made mostly from its United States operations and would be effective immediately.

title: Apogee Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Included a $1 million charge relate to the sales of a unit for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: A Divorce Settlement Forces Out Founder
description: As part of a divorce settlement, George E. Johnson, chairman and founder of the Johnson Products Company, resigned yesterday and transferred control of the company to his former wife, Joan B. Johnson, the company's board announced. Their son, Eric G. Johnson, was named chief executive.

title: Beirut's Truce: Anxiety Takes Terror's Place
description: After the shells and the rockets, it is uncertainty that is causing agony for most Lebanese.

title: Volcanoes Seen on Triton
description: A CLOSE examination of Voyager 2 photography has revealed the first direct evidence of active volcanoes on Neptune's moon Triton, scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory announced yesterday.

title: Our Towns; Camaraderie Changes a Y Into a Home
description: When the evenings begin to grow chilly it is time for Mrs. K to pick up a pack of turkey wings at the market and cook a pot of soup. Then all the women boarding at the Y.W.C.A. are invited to come down the hall with their bowls to 202.

title: 2 Unions Suing Texas Air
description: The Air Line Pilots Association and the International Association of Machinists have filed a lawsuit against the Texas Air Corporation, its Eastern and Continental Airlines subsidiaries, two corporate officers and its largest shareholder.

title: Girl's Mother Doubted Assault Report, Study Says
description: School officials delayed informing the police of reports of a sexual assault against a retarded 17-year-old by a group of athletes because her parents declined to file a criminal complaint, a Board of Education report said today.

title: Xicor Inc. reports earnings for 12wk to Sept 10
USX Is Planning to Sell Texas Oil Unit Reserves
description: The USX Corporation, the giant steel and energy company, said yesterday that it planned to sell the reserves of its Texas Oil and Gas Corporation subsidiary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The economy is sinking further each month. If we do not stop this process, there will be no Soviet power. It will be the end of perestroika.'' -Leonid I. Abalkin, a Deputy Prime Minister of the Soviet Union. [ A1:1. ]

title: Mideast Peace: Bridge vs. Wedge
description: Strange how in the Middle East making peace looks so similar to waging political war.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Agrees to Rule on Use of Political Patronage
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether political patronage in hiring, promotion and transfers of government employees is constitutional.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Zenith Electronics is leaving the computer business. In a surprising announcement, the company said it would sell the division to Groupe Bull for about $635 million in an attempt to concentrate on its consumer electronics. [ Page D1. ] Zenith is cashing in one of its most valuable chips to bet on the risky new technology of high-definition television, analysts said. [ D7. ] USX plans to sell the reserves of its Texas Oil and Gas subsidiary, which has failed to earn a consistent profit in recent years. [ D1. ] The new chairman of Northwest Airlines left no doubt that he would be involved in managing the company on a continuing basis and he predicted gains for the carrier. [ D1. ] Bank of Boston will report a $125 million loss for the third quarter after raising its reserves by $370 million to cover problem real estate loans in New England. [ D4. ] Cray Research plans to lay off about 400 of its assembly workers, or a little more than 7 percent of its work force. [ D4. ] Lockheed expects to take a charge of about $165 million against third-quarter earnings. [ D4. ] ECONOMY A House subcommittee voted unanimously to tighten automobile tailpipe emission controls, establishing national pollution standards as strict as California's. [ A1. ] An employer may bar all fertile women from factory jobs that pose a potential health risk to an unborn child, a Federal Appeals Court in Chicago has ruled. [ A16. ] The Supreme Court refused to intervene in an Illinois prosecution of Chicago Magnet Wire on charges of exposing employees to toxic chemicals. [ A17. ] Resolution Trust set aside almost $8 billion for five troubled savings institutions under its control, officials said. [ D11. ] California's insurance commissioner barred auto insurers from raising rates for six months while the state determines how to implement the rate-cutting initiative approved last year. [ D3. ] The nation's purchasing managers reported a continuing slowing in the manufacturing sector in their September report. The group's index rose to 46 percent, from 45.2 percent in August. [ D1. ] Construction spending made its biggest monthly advance of the year in August. The gain was in Government and nonresidential building, while single-family housing continued to sag. [ D5. ] While President Bush and Treasury Secretary Brady have worked publicly in recent days to rebut criticism of their strategy for reducing third world debt, offstage developments demonstrate that important progress is being made. News Analysis. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stock prices reversed an early downtrend and registered a solid advance. The Dow climbed 20.90 points, to 2,713.72. [ D8. ] Treasury note and bond prices were narrowly mixed in slow trading, as market participants shrugged off the September survey of the nation's purchasing managers. [ D16. ] The dollar rose in quiet trading, resisting continued selling by central banks. [ D17. ] An extension of the International Coffee Agreement received the necessary backing of importing and exporting nations, allowing it to take effect without new provisions for price supports. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A new type of mutual fund is under investigation. The funds have attracted billions of dollars from investors. Market Place. [ D1. ] New challenges in regulating the communications industries have been created by improved technology and globalization. Talking Business with Alfred Sikes of the F.C.C. [ D2. ] The most important factor affecting marketing executives is ''a mass movement to individuality,'' the chairman of Young & Rubicam says. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D2. ]

title: Peace for Peace
description: Every year about this time a particularly unpleasant piece of nastiness takes place at the United Nations, a ritual of hatred and hypocrisy.

title: Groupe Beaugarte reports earnings for Year to May 21
description: The company said its decision to abandon a restaurant project in Montreal resulted in a loss of $133,026 in the latest year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Acid Rain and Fertilization Linked to Greenhouse Effect
description: NITROGEN deposited in the soil by acid rain and as agricultural fertilizer may be promoting an atmospheric buildup of methane gas, a major contributor to the greenhouse effect, a new study suggests.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
Stock Fraud Indictment
description: A man believe to have helped to mastermind one of the biggest international stock frauds was indicted today in Geneva, the Swiss news agency, ATS, reported.

title: Heavy Reading
description: The weight of medical knowledge is increasing, but not as fast as it once was, a new study has found.

title: Stanley S. Joseloff, 82, Advertising Executive
description: Stanley S. Joseloff, a radio and advertising executive, died of leukemia Sunday in Yale-New Haven Hospital in New Haven. He was 82 years old and lived in Branford, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 25 about a rally of 10,000 Ukrainians in Kiev mistranslated the banner shown. It called, in Ukrainian and Yiddish, for official restoration of ethnic and regional languages.

title: Designing a Plane for the Leap of Space (and Back)
description: SCIENTISTS and engineers are making rapid progress in developing technologies needed to build a 17,000-mile-an-hour ''space plane'' that could escape earth's gravity and circle the globe in 90 minutes. In an unusual cooperative effort directed by the Defense Department and NASA, scientists and engineers from leading aerospace companies are beginning to overcome daunting problems like finding exotic materials that can withstand temperatures of 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit, designing engines that can gulp oxygen from the thin air of the upper atmosphere and predicting how the unusual atmospheric chemistry that occurs in hypersonic flight will affect the plane's performance.

title: Prof. William N. Fairbank, 72, Physicist and Pioneer in Quarks
description: William M. Fairbank, whose work in low-temperature superconductivity for more than three decades involved some of the most difficult and subtle experiments in physics, died of a heart attack Saturday while jogging in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: Safety-Kleen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
Tranzonic Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $701,500, or 19 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in tax accounting. Year-ago 6-month results included a gain of $606,000, or 17 cents a share, as the result of a change in accounting estimate.

title: Marcus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 17
Books of The Times; Art and Money Tug-of-War For 'Huxley in Hollywood'
description: Huxley in Hollywood By David King Dunaway Illustrated. 458 pages. A Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $24.95.

title: Arbor Drugs reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: U.S. Officer Quits Hyundai
description: Hyundai Motor America, which is struggling to find the right strategy after its initial success dimmed, said yesterday that Greg Warner, its senior American executive, had resigned effective Friday.

title: Florio Runs With Method to His Meekness
description: Representative James J. Florio, a candidate once derided as stiff if not robotic, is campaigning for governor these days with the fluid ease and growing self-confidence of a man who feels he is finally in synch with his times.

title: Marjorie C. Vietor
description: Marjorie C. Vietor, an organizer of the Red Cross Blood Donor Service in Manhattan in World War II, died in her sleep on Sept. 21 at Lawrence (Mass.) General Hospital. She was 97 years old and moved in 1984 to Needham, Mass., from Woodbury, Conn., where she had lived for many years.

title: New York, in Move to Bar AIDS, Puts New Limits on Sperm Banks
description: Trying to guard against any transmission of the AIDS virus through sperm banks, the New York State Health Department has drawn up new rules requiring donors to undergo at least two AIDS tests before their sperm is used.

title: Union and Hospitals Bargain in New York
description: Negotiators for many private hospitals in New York City and the union representing 50,000 hospital workers bargained into the early morning hours to avert a strike, but remained far apart at 1 A.M. Several hospitals facing serious fiscal problems reached separate agreements with the union. Articles, page B1 and B2.

title: Teleprobe Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: His Father's Invention
description: To The Living Section:

title: Kaufman & Broad Sells Paris Complex
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation sold a planned Paris office complex to a Japanese investor group for $600 million. The buyer is a group of international investors led by Kowa Real Estate, a subsidiary of the Industrial Bank of Japan.

title: U.S. Created Coup Conditions, Panamanian Asserts at U.N.
description: The President of the Panamanian Government, who is loyal to General Manuel Antonio Noriega, blamed the United States today for creating conditions that led to the coup attempt in his country.

title: How the Cubs and the Giants Line Up
description: Catchers(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 7Joe Girardi (.248, 1, 14) Became the starting catcher when Damon Berryhill developed a sore arm. Berryhill is still hurt, Girardi is still catching. Strong arm, caught 20 of 55 base-stealers. 1Rick Wrona (.283, 2, 14) Delivered key hits, as did Girardi. Especially good on blocking pitches in dirt. Infielders(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 17Mark Grace 1b (.314, 13, 79) Made the top 10 in the National League in hitting for the second time in two years. Fine contact hitter with some power. Made only 17 errors as a rookie last season, only 6 this year. 23Ryne Sandberg 2b (.290, 30, 76) All-Star veteran closed the season with a record of 90 errorless games. Also a dangerous hitter. His 30 home runs were the most in 10 years for a second baseman in the big leagues. 11Luis Salazar 3b (.282, 9, 34) Arrived Aug. 31 in a trade from San Diego and immediately replaced the slumping Vance Law at third. Versatile athlete can play several positions. He hit over .300 for the Cubs and delivered three game-winning hits. 12Shawon Dunston ss (.278, 9, 60) Enjoyed the best season of his career. Cut errors down, learned to accept walks and not hack wildly. Best arm in the big leagues for an infielder. Outfielders(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 15Dwight Smith lf (.324, 9, 52) Arrived from the minor leagues on May 1 and stayed. Got his big chance when all three regular outfielders were injured. 20Jerome Walton cf (.293, 5, 46) Outruns infield hits and is also a good bunter and two-out hitter. Had a 30-game hitting streak during the season. 8Andre Dawson rf (.252, 21, 77) In his 14th season, five times an All-Star, the Hawk leads the way despite his bad knees. Bats either fourth or fifth with devastating power, and still has a rifle arm. Starting Pitchers(record, e.r.a.) 31Greg Maddux rh (19-12, 2.95) A 23-year-old star who made an impact last year when he won 15 games and lost 3 before the All-Star break. He will start the opening game. 36Mike Bielecki rh (18-7, 3.14) Discarded by Pittsburgh in spring training of 1988 and was traded to the Cubs for a minor league pitcher. Before this season, he had won 12 games in parts of 5 seasons. 40Rick Sutcliffe rh (16-11, 3.66) If his shoulder behaves, he will start the third game. Remains prime veteran with post-season credentials from the 1984 playoff, the year he won the Cy Young Award. 44Steve Wilson lh (6-4, 4.20, 2) Cubs are going with a three-man rotation, but he will start if Sutcliffe can't. Leaped to the big leagues from the Class AA level in a trade with Texas last winter. Relievers(record, e.r.a., saves) 28Mitch Williams lh (4-4, 2.76, 36) The Wild One who came in the Texas deal and immediately became a legend, striking out Mike Schmidt with the bases loaded on opening day. He is as advertised: a hard-throwing, flamboyant stopper. 50Les Lancaster rh (4-2, 1.36, 8) Works as a setup man for Williams or as a stopper. Generally more consistent and stable than Williams. 45Paul Assenmacher lh (3-4, 3.99) Arrived in late August in a trade from Atlanta and became valuable as a setup man for both Lancaster and Williams. 21Scott Sanderson rh (11-9, 3.94) Limited after back surgery last year. Most likely a middle reliever. Beat Giants twice as a starter this year. 39Paul Kilgus lh (6-10, 4.39, 2) Used as both a spot starter and in middle relief. Gives up hits, but survives. Reserves(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 2Vance Law 3b (.235, 7, 42) Experienced infielder who opened the season at third base but lost his everyday job to Salazar in August. He will be used as a right-handed pinch-hitter. 15Domingo Ramos if (.263, 1, 19) A fine pinch-hitter from the right side who delivered key hits all season. Also one of the best bunters on the team. 19Curtis Wilkerson if (.244, 1, 10) The fourth man in the Texas trade. He filled the need for a utility infielder. 10Lloyd McClendon of (.286, 12, 40) Came out of the farm system in May when all three starting outfielders were injured and hit a three-run homer in his first time at bat. 33Mitch Webster of (.257, 3, 19) He was the opening-day starter in left field, then strained his left leg on May 1 and never got the job back. He can play all three outfield spots, and can run and switch-hit. 25Marvell Wynne of (.243, 7, 39) A left-handed hitter who arrived in August from the Padres. Manager 4Don Zimmer At 58 years old, reaching new heights in a career that began as an infielder with the Dodgers. Like his friend, Roger Craig, he was one of the original Mets of 1962. Bold tactician who will squeeze a run home or put runners in motion with the bases loaded. San Francisco Giants Catchers(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 16Terry Kennedy (.239, 5, 34) Slow but experienced 10-year veteran of four clubs who played against the Cubs for the Padres in the 1984 playoff. A left-handed hitter who may start every game. 17Kirt Manwaring (.210, 0, 18) A right-handed batter and backup catcher with a reputation as an outstanding thrower (caught 41 percent of runners trying to steal). Infielders(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 22Will Clark 1b (.333, 23, 111) Rivaled Tony Gwynn for the batting title and finished in the highest brackets in hitting, r.b.i.'s and fielding. 6Robby Thompson 2b (.241, 13, 50) Made no errors in the first 50 games this year and only eight all season. He is also a versatile hitter who led the league in triples and stole 12 bases in 14 attempts. 9Matt Williams 3b (.202, 18, 50) Strikes out and hits home runs with great frequency. 23Jose Uribe ss (.221, 1, 30) Not much of a hitter, but tremendous in the field with range and a fine arm. Led the league in chances and double plays at shortstop. Hurt his shoulder on Sept. 23 and has played only once since. Outfielders(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 7Kevin Mitchell lf (.291, 47, 125 ) Played in the 1986 World Series for the Mets. Set a record for intentional walks for a right-handed hitter, led major leagues in home runs and runs batted in and is the ranking candidate for the most valuable player award in the National League. 2Brett Butler cf (.283, 4, 36) The catalyst in the Giants' attack. Missed only seven games, hits for a high average, stole 73 bases in the last two years and scored more than 200 runs. Covers center field with dash. 21Candy Maldonado rf (.217, 9, 41) A veteran of seven seasons with the Dodgers and the Giants, but he lapsed noticeably this year after opening as the regular right fielder. Now he platoons with Pat Sheridan. 25Pat Sheridan rf (.205, 3, 14) This is his debut season in the National League, and he's not hitting. Starting Pitchers(record, e.r.a.) 50Scott Garrelts rh (14-5, 2.28) He was a top reliever who became a top starter this season. Uses a split-fingered fastball that was taught and promoted by his manager. League bats only .212 against him. He will start the first game. 48Rick Reuschel rh (17-8, 2.94) Big Daddy got off to a flying start, went 6 and 0 in May with an 0.84 earned-run mark. Disabled in August by a groin injury, but came back to shine. 31Don Robinson rh (12-11, 3.43) Durable and experienced, a veteran of 12 years with the Pirates and the Giants. A former relief ace who now starts regularly. Strained his right knee, status questionable. 29Mike LaCoss rh (10-10, 3.17) Another of the team's senior citizens (32), pitched for Cincinnati, Houston and Kansas City before joining the Giants as a free agent in 1986. He was the bullpen stopper until Steve Bedrosian arrived in June. Relievers(record, e.r.a., saves) 40Steve Bedrosian rh (3-7, 2.87, 23) Throws heat and had a record of distinction with Atlanta and Philadelphia (Cy Young Award winner). He was traded to San Francisco on June 18 and saved 17 games since then. 49Jeff Brantley rh (7-1, 4.07) Serves as a setup man for Bedrosian. 37Kelly Downs rh (4-8, 4.79) Led the staff in shutouts for the last two years, but has been hurt most of this year since he injured his shoulder May 2. May get a start in this series. 14Atlee Hammaker lh (6-6, 3.76) Former starter, now a relief pitcher, has playoff experience. Injured several times this season and has worked only once recently. 28Bob Knepper lh (7-2, 5.13) Released by Houston on Aug. 5. Giants use him as a spot starter and in long relief. 32Craig Lefferts lh (2-4, 2.69, 20) Recorded the most saves for a season in his career. Pitched in the 1984 playoff against the Cubs. Reserves(average, home runs, r.b.i.) 19Bob Brenly c (.182, 0, 3) Started the year in Toronto, but was released in August and was signed by his former team. A backup catcher and a right-handed pinch-hitter. 30Donnell Nixon of (.265, 1, 15) Right-handed hitter who fills in sometimes for Mitchell in left field and for Butler in center, and for everybody in right. He can also run (10 for 13 stealing). 10Ken Oberkfell if (.269, 2, 17) Traded from Pittsburgh on May 10 after a long career as an infielder and left-handed hitter. Led the league with 18 pinch hits in 47 times at bat. 1Ernest Riles if (.278, 7, 40) Starts sometimes at third base and has some power. Manager 38Roger Craig At 59 years old, one of the game's successes after a career that began in 1955 as a pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Father of the split-fingered fastball, a longtime friend and colleague of Don Zimmer. Raises horses on his ranch outside San Diego.

title: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Up
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were generally higher in the week that ended yesterday.

title: Stock of Ferranti Plunges
description: Already reeling from an apparent fraud at its United States unit that has cost almost $300 million, the British military contractor Ferranti today lost about a third of its market value when its shares resumed trading on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Less Prenatal Care Urged For Most Healthy Women
description: In a major shift in policy, a Federal panel of experts has recommended that less prenatal care be provided to the 1.6 million pregnant women whose fetuses are at no apparent risk of health problems and that more be given to women whose fetuses are at risk.

title: New York Acquisition By McCaw
description: Opening a new front in its battle for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Metromedia Inc.'s stake in the New York cellular market for $1.9 billion.

title: Lehndorff Canadian Properies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: With Every Course, an Opinion
description: AS might be expected, Andy Rooney, the curmudgeon whose commentaries on CBS News's ''60 Minutes'' assail everything from manners to mufflers, has strong opinions on food and dining. At a recent dinner in a restaurant near his weekend home in upstate New York, he served forth more than a few of them, including these:

title: A's Maintain Their Poise And Take Lead Over Jays
description: In the late afternoons, when he would sit at his locker and dream aloud, Rickey Henderson would talk about the thing he wanted most in his career. He could see himself right there, smack in the middle of the post-season at Yankee Stadium, and the mere thought would sometimes make him smile.

title: Flow General Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,750,000 for the quarter and $16,586,000 for the year. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $1,200,000, or 12 cents a share, and $4,320,000, or 48 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest periods results are restated.

title: Historic Shift Seen in School Finance
description: The ruling by the Texas Supreme Court Monday that the state's system for financing public schools is unconstitutional because of ''glaring disparities'' between rich and poor school districts shows not only that the struggle over school financing is being reheated but also that the terms of the struggle are changing.

title: CML Group Inc reports earnings for 12mo to July 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $16,937,000, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $9,426,000. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $3,208,000, or 50 cents a share.

title: Grower's Commute: Scardsdale to France
description: WHEN Stephen Schecter looks out over his vineyards here, he recalls his childhood in Queens, shakes his head in disbelief and says, ''When my father talked about red or white, he meant horseradish.''

title: Gingrich Asks Caution In an Inquiry on Frank
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, the second-ranking Republican in the House, said today that the House needs to proceed cautiously as it investigates the questions of judgment and personal behavior that are raised by the case of Representative Barney Frank.

title: Tridont Health Care reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss included a charge for unusual items of $26.1 million. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Shelly Associates Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Real Estate; In Midtown South, Space Eases a Bit
description: THE effects of New York City's glut of office space and the economic slowdown may be catching up with the midtown south office district.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketers Study Start Of a Network
description: A new television network, created and programmed by the nation's largest marketing companies, is one of several ideas marketers are studying to combat rising network television costs and declining audience shares, a top advertising executive said today.

title: Two Flyers Are Back
description: The Philadelphia Flyers reacquired Pete Peeters, a goaltender, and Keith Acton, a forward, from the Winnipeg Jets yesterday, only five days after they had been traded to Winnipeg for future considerations.

title: Bundling Campaign Money: Giuliani Is the Big Beneficiary
description: Thirty-two intermediaries representing the last vestiges of big money in the New York City mayoral election have funneled $685,000 into Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign in the last four months, making him the biggest single beneficiary of a process known as bundling.

title: Reviews/Dance; Gina Gibney's 'In Pieces' at Choreospace
description: Stage setting and choreography were inseparably united in Gina Gibney's ''In the Village,'' one of the works that formed part of ''In Pieces,'' the program she offered Friday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace.

title: David Geiger, Engineer, 54, Dies
description: David H. Geiger, an engineer who invented an air-supported fabric roof system used for almost half the domed stadiums in the world, died, apparently of cardiac arrest, Sunday at the Lotte Hotel in Seoul, South Korea, where he was traveling on business. He was 54 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Photon Technology Intl reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for all periods adjusted to reflect the sale of the company's German subsidiary, which was sold late last year as part of the company's restructuring program to improve its overall financial condition.

title: Review/Theater; Kelly McGillis Stars In 'Twelfth Night'
description: Though there are movie stars who regard classic roles as a careerlong mission instead of a one-shot summer vacation - Kevin Kline and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio among them -New York audiences have lately seen too many Hollywood visitors treat Shakespeare like a cheap tart. These are the stars who milk the Bard for all the self-serving publicity he's worth during rehearsal, then turn their backs on him by self-indulgently goofing their way through his plays in performance. The audience, asked to bask in the empty glow of celebrity rather than the deep illumination of Shakespeare, goes home with the gloomy feeling of having been had.

title: Moose Call Of Canada Angers Hunters
description: Here in far northern Maine, where the United States-Canada border cuts a straight line through the privately owned forest and areas are numbered, not named, a rite of fall that pits Americans against Canadians will soon begin.

title: 114 'Right Names' Attract 1,000
description: EVERYONE with signing privileges at Mortimer's was there. So were others who would dearly love to lunch at a window table in Glenn Bernbaum's exclusive Upper East Side bistro. Well, that can be arranged, as Mr. Bernbaum was telling a woman whose name means nothing to the gossip columnists: ''Give me $25,000 for the AIDS Care Center and you'll get a good table, I assure you. The name sticks in one's mind.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airgas Inc., Radnor, Pa., a maker of gases, completed the sale of its Jackson Products Inc. unit to Jackson Acquisition Corp. for $70 million.

title: Sikes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: During the first 6 months of this fiscal year, the company said it made capital expenditures of about $16,743,000, most of which were for the Florida plant renovation and modernization and were funded from both operating revenue and bank borrowings.

title: 5 Million Pounds of Butter Melted in Warehouse Blaze
description: Firefighters sloshed through five inches of melted butter Monday in battling a warehouse fire that burned out of control for nearly 21 hours.

title: A House Plan to Raise S.E.C. Budget
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission may be allowed to raise fees and increase its budget if a little-noticed provision in the House of Representative's budget reconciliation bill becomes law.

title: Graziano Recuperating
description: Rocky Graziano, former world middleweight champion, was reported in stable condition and resting comfortably yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan after collapsing at his home on Sunday.(AP)

title: International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
William F. Turner, 53, an Interior Designer
description: William F. Turner, an interior designer and a management consultant, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 53 years old. Mr. Turner died of pneumonia, Kenneth L. Wyse, a former business associate, said.

title: Out Of the Suitcase
description: I saw Tip O'Neill come out of a suitcase the other night. That's right: the large man who used to be Speaker of the House of Representatives. Out of a suitcase. Sure it was on television. You don't think a man that big is going to pop out of a suitcase live, right in your own living room, do you?

title: Minority Hiring by Yale Is Criticized in Study
description: Yale lags behind leading colleges and universities in recruiting and retaining minority professors and has to respond swiftly and boldly to avoid an intolerable situation, a university committee has urged.

title: INSIDE
description: Choice for Rockefeller U. Dr. David Baltimore, a Nobel laureate who has figured in a controversy over possible scientific fraud, has been offered the presidency of Rockefeller University. Page A18. A's Top Blue Jays in Opener Oakland used strong hitting, pitching and base-running to win the first game of the American League playoffs from Toronto, 7-3. Page D25.

title: Rebels Assail Salvadoran's Cease-Fire Plan
description: Leaders of El Salvador's leftist guerrilla movement today dismissed the cease-fire proposal made by President Alfredo Cristiani at the United Nations General Assembly on Monday as an insincere political maneuver intended to supplant the negotiations recently begun between the two sides.

title: Crazy Eddie to Liquidate, Ending Move to Reorganize
description: The saga of Crazy Eddie Inc., the consumer electronics retailer known for its boisterous advertising, appears to have ended today.

title: Frankly Nice to China
description: China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, told the United Nations that relations with the U.S. were ''at a crossroads,'' but could improve if America stopped criticizing China.

title: Spy's Wife Appeals to Israel To Ask Bush to Free Couple
description: Anne Pollard, whose husband was convicted of spying for Israel and is serving a life sentence in an American prison, has asked Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to intervene with President Bush on the American couple's behalf.

title: SCI Television In Loan Default
description: SCI Television Inc. said yesterday that as expected it had defaulted on a $153 million principal payment that it owes a group of bank lenders, led by the Bankers Trust Company, and would also have to skip interest payments due Oct. 15 on two ''junk bond'' issues.

title: Taxes and Environment Affect a New Jersey Race
description: The 19th Assembly District, once the home of giant industries along the Raritan River that provided work for generations of immigrants, has become a prime battleground in the State Assembly races this year.

title: New Savings Board Chief
description: Daniel P. Kearney, a Boston mortgage finance specialist, was named president and chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation Oversight Board, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady announced today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Trump Shuttle Introduces Ads
description: The Trump Shuttle introduced its advertising campaign yesterday and Donald J. Trump was nowhere to be seen.

title: F.D.A. Approves a Backup Therapy for Severe Schizophrenia
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a drug treatment for severe schizophrenia today but said that because it has serious side effects it should be used only on patients who fail to respond to conventional therapy.

title: Four Hospitals Break Ranks And Set Pacts
description: With a strike deadline hours away, four New York City area hospitals, including Beth Israel Medical Center, broke ranks with industry negotiators and reached separate union agreements late last night, officials involved in the negotiations said.

title: Bulls Sign King, Their Top Choice
description: Stacey King, a No. 1 draft choice who is expected to provide more inside scoring and rebounding to complement Michael Jordan's outside play, signed a contract with the Chicago Bulls yesterday. No terms were disclosed. King is the first of the top six choices drafted last spring to come to terms.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Rise
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in lethargic trading yesterday, helped by a rise in the dollar in overseas markets. The move in the dollar prompted some overseas buying, but dealers in New York said most domestic customers showed little interest once trading shifted to the United States.

title: Mack Sentenced
description: Kevin Mack, a Cleveland Browns running back who was selected for the National Football League Pro Bowl in 1985 and 1987, was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison after pleading guilty to having used cocaine. Judge Richard McMonagle, of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court in Cleveland, sentenced Mack to the Mansfield Reformatory, a Cuyahoga County assistant prosecutor, Frank Gasper, said.

title: Boat Hits Pipeline in Gulf; 3 Are Killed and 7 Missing
description: A 160-foot fishing boat struck a gas pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico, setting off an explosion that killed three people and injured at least four, the Coast Guard said. At least seven people were missing. ''It was just a boom and big ball of fire went up into the air about 300 feet,'' said Allen Willett, a helicopter pilot who takes drilling crews to rigs.

title: Senate Unit Approves I.R.A. Plan
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved early today a Democratic plan that would restore tax deductions for contributions to individual retirement accounts for all taxpayers, after a Republican measure to reduce the capital gains tax rate for individual and corporate taxpayers lost on a tie vote.

title: Sampling Rheingau's Rieslings
description: Fourteen members of the Association of Charta Estates, an organization spearheading the new emphasis on dry rieslings by West German winegrowers, came to New York last month to offer a glimpse of their 1988 rieslings, a highly rated vintage.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Cheshire, Conn.
description: LEAD: WHEN Marla Novia dresses for work, she puts on a vibrant green fruit-appliqued apron over a colorful dress, a ceramic apple pin (sans one bite) and cherry red shoes. Before leaving her home in Cheshire, Conn., she stuffs yogurt, carrots, Cheerios and peanut butter into her bag. She then heads for a school to teach young children about good healthy snacks as the Snack

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Talking, and Tasting, Wine

title: Help the Horses
description: Mayor Koch has a chance - his last - to go down in history as the Mayor who liberated New York City's carriage horses. He can do that by signing a measure that has already passed the City Council by a vote of 31 to 3. It would protect carriage horses from having to work when it is very hot, very cold, very humid or for more than eight hours at a stretch.

title: Economic Scene; Airline Leverage: Who Loses?
description: CAUGHT off guard by the airline industry's frenzied financial restructuring, Washington is scrambling to put on the brakes. Last week Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner succeeded in putting pressure on Northwest Airlines to rewrite its leveraged buyout agreement with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, halving KLM's equity stake and denying the foreign carrier a place on its board.

title: President of Bergdorf Is Leaving for Gucci Job
description: Dawn Mello, the president and the creative force at Bergdorf Goodman, will leave on Oct. 15 to join Gucci, where she will direct the worldwide corporate image and product development activities of the 60-store specialty leather and accessories concern, with offices in both Milan, Italy, and in New York.

title: Sun Microsystems Sees Gain
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it expected a small operating profit in the quarter that ended last Saturday.

title: Braniff Resumess Some of Its Flights
description: With a $49 one-way fare to attract passengers, Braniff Inc. resumed about 20 percent of its 256 daily flights. The carrier was virtually shut last week as it filed its second bankruptcy reorganization in seven years.

title: Alfin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $163,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: U.S. KNEW OF PLOT
description: Dissident Panamanian officers tried to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today but failed when troops loyal to the Panamanian leader recaptured a central military headquarters the rebels had seized.

title: Pancontinental Oil reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Gillette Challenge to the Disposables
description: Razor makers have always scratched their chins over what men want. Do they want platinum chromium coatings on their blades? Razors that open like missile silos? Or maybe blades in high-tech injector cartridges?

title: Reviews/Dance; Faces of Japan, Starting at Creation
description: What the program said would happen Thursday night was one thing. What actually did happen at the City Center Theater was something else entirely.

title: Reverse Half-Windsor . . .
description: To The Living Section:

title: Europe Reaches TV Compromise; U.S. Officials Fear Protectionism
description: After months of debate, the European Community adopted a compromise plan of nonbinding rules today that urge European television stations to devote a majority of their air time to shows made in Europe.

title: Whom Do the Giants Look Up To? Clark.
description: LEAD: One afternoon in Los Angeles last week, while the San Francisco Giants were clutching before clinching their second divisional title in three seasons, Will Clark, the team's All-Star first baseman, walked into the clubhouse wearing a thigh-to-mid-calf knee brace. Several days earlier he had damaged his knee in a home-plate collision with Mike Scioscia, the Dodgers' bone-is-stronger-than-stone catcher, and his availability, crucial to the team at the most critical part of the season, had become doubtful.

title: Avantek Inc reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 9
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,605,000.

title: Joseph W. Allen, Engineer, 96
description: Joseph William Allen, an electrical engineer, inventor and pioneer in the field of aviation engineering, died Monday at the Morristown (N.J.) Medical Center of injuries sustained in a recent fall at his home in Whippany, N.J. He was 96 years old.

title: C.I.A. to Avoid Secret Role in Nicaragua Vote
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Bush Administration has for the first time stated that the Central Intelligence Agency will not engage in any secret activities to influence the outcome of the Nicaraguan elections scheduled for February, members of Congress and Administration officials said today.

title: Godollo Journal; How to Disarm Hungary (Hamburgers? Tennis?)
description: A large American flag covered a window by the entrance to the House of Culture in this college town 20 miles northeast of Budapest. Pinned to it was a photograph of a boyish-looking man with a bow tie, whose smile has become familiar throughout Hungary.

title: Overwork Led to Spill, Tanker Captain Says
description: The captain whose tanker spilled 289,000 gallons of oil off Newport in June said today that he had gone 36 hours with little sleep, had no lookout and was overworked and distracted at the time of the accident.

title: MEXICAN-U.S. PACT REACHED ON TRADE AND INVESTMENTS
description: In the latest sign of closer ties between the United States and Mexico, Presidents Bush and Carlos Salinas de Gortari signed an agreement today intended to enlarge trade and investment between the two nations.

title: Ex-Kidder Executive Joins Japanese Firm
description: Nine months after internal upheaval at Kidder, Peabody & Company resulted in his departure from the firm, Max C. Chapman Jr. will head another American securities operation, Nomura Holding America Inc., a division of Nomura Securities International.

title: Lazare Kaplan International reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $279,000, or 9 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $30,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year-earlier period. The company said the extraordinary item represents utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Graphic Scanning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $586,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $3,164,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,726,000 and $20,849,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said fourth quarter results included $3.3 million in restructuring charges and asset writedowns and a $1.7 million charge for litigation expenses. Its loss on the disposal of Graphnet Inc., reflected in the third quarter, resulted in a charge of $1.5 million, net of tax benefit, in fiscal 1989. In the fourth quarter last year, the company sold its radio paging properties in five midwestern markets for $20.5 million and realized a gain of $16.4 million. In addition, the company said, it recorded a $23.1 million charge to reflect an impairment in the carrying value of its investment in Graphnet.

title: Poland Orders Investigation Into Crimes of 40's and 50's
description: Poland's new Government ordered an investigation today into crimes committed during the era of hard-line Communist rule in the 1940's and 1950's.

title: Harold W. Conroy, 82, A Corporate Lawyer
description: Harold William Conroy, a lawyer specializing in corporate law, died of a disease of the cartilage on Saturday at his home in Southhold, L.I. He was 82 years old.

title: Devils' High Hopes Are Dotted With New Faces
description: The Devils have been guilty in the past of overrating their personnel and aiming too high, but this year the high expectations may be justified.

title: Senators in a Rush to Declare A Bigger War Against Drugs
description: In a boisterous Senate session, Republican as well as Democratic senators came forward tonight with a host of amendments to remold President Bush's anti-drug strategy into a bigger, bolder plan.

title: Palestinian Militants Urge Wider Revolt
description: The underground leadership of the Palestinian revolt in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip sought today to broaden the protest, calling for a five-day general strike and ''rebellion'' in the streets.

title: Custom Shop Knot
description: To The Living Section:

title: Eastern Environmental Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings for the latest quarter and year-ago quarter were not available. The company also said the decrease in net income was a result of a 7.6 percent increase in cost of sales due to increases in labor costs and an increase in depreciation expense. Net income was also affected by a $1.5 million increase in general and administrative expenses due to increases in advertising and estimating labor expenses.

title: Docugraphix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said there was no revenue in the year-ago period.

title: Aztar Sweetens 'Junk' Offer To Attract Wary Investors
description: Two weeks after the sharpest sell-off in its short history, the ''junk bond'' market continues to show signs of skittishness. Yesterday, investment bankers for the Aztar Corporation, the successor company to the Ramada Corporation, postponed and restructured the company's $400 million offering of new securities.

title: Minority Students Walk Out Over a Teacher's Remarks
description: Hundreds of black and Hispanic students, incensed by a history teacher's remark that they deemed racist, walked out of classes in a Brooklyn high school yesterday morning, smashing display cabinets and forcing the school to close early, the police and school officials said.

title: About New York; Lessons of Life, At the Wet End Of a Fishing Line
description: Sunday morning was one of those rare occasions when time stands still and the world doesn't seem like such a bad place after all. Golden sun, a gentle breeze and birds heading south for no obvious reason. A day to go fishing.

title: 'Everything's on Hold' for 1199 Clerk
description: Tina Sasser, a single mother of two, earns $17,000 a year as an admitting clerk at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. She joined the last strike, five years ago, and she is prepared to walk out again. But as the deadline loomed, she found it hard to think about anything but her bills.

title: Polls Find U.S. and Pennsylvania Share Divisions About Abortion
description: In Pennsylvania, where legislators introduced a package of sweeping anti-abortion measures yesterday, people are as deeply divided over the abortion issue as are other Americans.

title: The Larger Issues Behind the CBS News Case
description: Behind The New York Post's recent charges that CBS News broadcast misrepresented films of the war in Afghanistan are larger questions about the methods and ethical standards of television news and the vulnerability of news broadcasts - and news viewers - to having drama passed off as reality.

title: MGM Grand Expands Plans for Hotel-Park
description: Expanding on earlier plans, MGM Grand Inc. said today that it would spend nearly $700 million to build a movie theme park and 5,000-room hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Foyt Hurt Seriously
description: A. J. Foyt, a four-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, was listed in serious condition with neck pain at Charlotte Memorial Hospital in Concord, N.C., yesterday after he crashed into a wall at Charlotte Motor Speedway during a practice session for the Nascar All-Pro Auto Parts 500 Sunday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Phoenix American Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Film Festival; 'Yaaba' Explores Humans and Frailties
description: The utter simplicity of ''Yaaba,'' set against flat, barren plains in an African village made of mud and straw and acted by a barefoot, nonprofessional cast, bespeaks great sophistication. The director Idrissa Ouedraogo, of Burkina Faso (formerly Upper Volta) shapes this spare and resonant drama with perfect control. ''Yaaba'' is without extraneous details. It is also without specific reference to time, place or the larger world beyond this isolated community. Nothing obscures the mythic, universal aspects of Mr. Ouedraogo's story.

title: Script Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Are There Limits to What a Necktie Symbolizes and Celebrates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Ordinary Extraordinary Lifts A's
description: A slide to break up a double play. A well-timed bunt. Aggressive base-running and not merely stolen bases. A pitcher finding his rhythm in the middle of a game.

title: Marcos Followers Win A Hearing Over Burial
description: The Philippine Supreme Court agreed today to hear a request to overturn a Government ban on the return of the body of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos for burial here.

title: Julian Miller, 85, Ex-Actuary and a Hiker
description: Julian Miller, a retired actuary who became an environmentalist, died of cancer Thursday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Teaneck.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: RECENT articles and studies have raised concerns over whether the use of plastic wrap and commercial plastic containers in the microwave oven pose safety problems. Although the risk has not been determined, cooks can use several techniques at home to avoid problems altogether.

title: Your Car Is Calling
description: Urban Americans often arm their cars with piercing alarms that go off when a thief intrudes. In New York the alarms seem to blare mostly in the middle of the night, and it's not clear that they discourage perpetrators nearly as much as they disturb the peace.

title: Jetborne International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Modern Guitarist Feels Tug of Past
description: ''The commercialization of the early-instruments movement has led to the most incredibly exaggerated claims for what early instruments are, and what they do,'' the guitarist David Starobin said the other day. ''Basically, they're instruments. They respond to the player, and you have good early-instrument performances and bad ones, just like with modern instruments. I'm not really interested in creating aural facsimiles of what happened in the 19th century, and I'm not sure that those kinds of re-creations have much value. What I value more is the way this music is perceived from today's vantage point.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Roger Rowe has been named senior vice president and associate creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

title: U.S. Tells East Germany: Reform or Lose Citizens
description: The Bush Administration publicly called on East Germany today to undertake political and economic reforms as a way to halt the flood of its citizens to the West.

title: INDIAN'S LIBEL CASE NEARING DECISION
description: After two weeks of complicated, cryptic and sometimes obscure testimony, a jury here is preparing to decide whether the journalist Seymour M. Hersh libeled a former Prime Minister of India, Morarji Desai, when he described him as a paid informer for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: British-United Plan Stirs Antitrust Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: LIMITED BAN VOTED ON SOVIET STRIKES
description: The Soviet legislature today approved an immediate ban on strikes in important industries, and took the first steps toward approval of a more sweeping and permanent law regulating labor disputes.

title: Title Matchup in March
description: Julio Cesar Chavez of Mexico will meet Meldrick Taylor, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist, on March 17 in a title matchup of two undefeated fighters. The fight, for Chavez's World Boxing Council superlightweight crown and Taylor's International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title, will be at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel. Chavez, 27 years old, is 64-0 with 51 knockouts. Taylor, 23, is 22-0-1 with 12.(AP)

title: More and More, Kindergarten Means a Full Day
description: Responding to the needs of working parents and to increased evidence that 5-year-old children can handle a longer school day, schools all over the country are switching from half-day to full-day kindergarten.

title: Giuliani's Wife Walks a Delicate Line in His Campaign
description: When Rudolph W. Giuliani announced his candidacy for mayor last spring, his wife, Donna Hanover, had more than just the typical political spouse's concerns. As a co-anchor for WPIX-TV news in New York City, she had to promise to take no role in the campaign to keep her job.

title: Altai Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,000, for the quarter and income of $119,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and gains on sale of assets of $18,000, or 1 cent a share, and $1,247,000, or 60 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $65,000, or 3 cents a share, and $280,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Let Japan Be Japan
description: LEAD: Why can't the U.S just let Japan be Japan?

title: Nobel Prize Winner Asked to Head Rockefeller U.
description: Dr. David Baltimore, a Nobel laureate who has figured in a dispute over questions of possible fraud in a research paper that he helped write, has been offered the presidency of Rockefeller University, the university said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Tracy-Locke Inc., a part of the Omnicom Group, has signed an associate agreement with Ornelas & Associates, a Hispanic advertising brand marketing agency in Dallas.

title: Unocal to Cut Its Operations
description: The Unocal Corporation said today that it planned to withdraw from several regions of Washington and Oregon, where it operates 233 Unocal 76 service stations.

title: Japan Acts On Apple And Canon
description: In a rare crackdown on high prices, Government investigators here searched the offices of Apple Computer Japan and a unit of Canon Inc. today, seeking evidence that importers selling Macintosh computers at deep discounts are being driven out of the market.

title: Howell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Four Seasons Is Designated A Landmark
description: The Seagram Building on Park Avenue and the Four Seasons restaurant within it -which have long been seen as pinnacles of the cool, sleek, International style of architecture that dominated American cities after World War II - became official New York City landmarks yesterday.

title: This Country Needs a Chancellor of the Exchequer; Back to Silver and Gold
description: To the Editor:

title: The Persels Reverse
description: To The Living Section:

title: Struggle Within the Military Appears to Be a Major Cause
description: A bitter power struggle between rebellious junior officers and older members of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's inner circle appears to have been a major catalyst in the fighting that erupted in Panama yesterday, experts on Panamanian military affairs say.

title: Montpelier, Vt.
description: BUTTERNUTS played an important role in Harry Morse Sr.'s boyhood. ''Trying to crack 'em is how I learned to use cuss words,'' said Mr. Morse, a retired dairy farmer who, with his sons, runs Morse Farms, a produce stand and gift shop on Montpelier's outskirts.

title: Gypsy Protesters Driven From a Nazi Camp
description: Gypsies who had occupied a former concentration camp for a month to dramatize their campaign to remain in West Germany were driven out by the police this week in an action that highlighted a troubling aspect of West Germany's immigration policies.

title: Lessons
description: President Bush may or may not be able to create a ''kinder, gentler'' nation, but he has already created a kinder, gentler Federal education policy.

title: Meret Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $44,875 for the quarter and $147,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $59,167 for the quarter and $1,619,109 for the year.

title: McGillion Named Top Police Deputy
description: Alice T. McGillion, the New York City Police Department's chief spokeswoman, was named yesterday to the No. 2 police post, first deputy commissioner, making her the highest-ranking woman ever in the department.

title: There Can Be a Clean Air Bill
description: Poll after poll has shown that Americans want cleaner air and will pay for it. Year after year, a Congress paralyzed by sloth and industry pressure has refused to grant that wish. On Monday, however, a House subcommittee agreed to stringent new controls on automobile pollution. That agreement doesn't end the legislative struggle. But given the subcommittee's history of strife, it's a giant step forward - and a fine example of political maturity for the rest of Congress.

title: This Country Needs a Chancellor of the Exchequer
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Gains Break - Wrong!
description: Last Thursday the House approved a two-year cut in the tax rate on capital gains - increases in the value of stocks, bonds and real estate - to less than 20 percent. The decision was wrong. Profoundly wrong. It's now up to the Senate to preserve some semblance of conscience and reason, and reverse the House vote.

title: Deans and Presidents Fear Education Takes 2d Place
description: A survey of college and university presidents and deans has found that 86 percent of those polled believe that the financial rewards of intercollegiate athletics are interfering with the educational mission of schools in the United States. The survey was done by U.S. News and World Report magazine.

title: Deloitte Affiliate Rejects Merger
description: The British affiliate of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells said it had refused to join the accounting firm's planned merger with Touche Ross. The International Accounting Bulletin reported that the Deloitte affiliate would instead join Coopers & Lybrand, a union that would create the largest accounting practice in Britain.

title: Correction Officials Fined Over Abortions
description: A senior official of New York City's Department of Correction has resigned and four others have been penalized in an investigation into charges that the department had told pregnant correction officers to have abortions or resign.

title: Custody Case Heard in Egypt
description: An American woman was told today that she would have to wait another month before an Egyptian court would rule on the disputed custody of her two children. The court met in closed session to hear competing pleas from Barbara Mezo, who lives in Brooklyn, and her Egyptian mother-in-law for custody of 7-year-old Mohammed and 4-year-old Leila. Ms. Mezo says her estranged husband, Abdel Aziz Mohammed el-Mergawi, who is Egyptian, smuggled the children out of the United States despite a New York court order granting the mother custody.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Bionaire Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company was formerly called Biotech Electronics Ltd. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Little Independence For Baltic Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Shellfish Harvesting Is Prohibited On Coast Damaged by Hurricane
description: Shellfish harvesting off South Carolina was banned today, and warnings were issued against swimming in ocean water and rivers choked with untreated sewage because of Hurricane Hugo.

title: Details Given On Columbia
description: Peter Guber and Jon Peters, the co-chairmen of the Guber Peters Entertainment Company, would each receive an annual salary of $2.75 million plus bonuses and equity if they are hired by the Sony Corporation to run Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. Sony has agreed to acquire

title: Macyro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Drexel Consolidation
description: In response to a dropoff in the number of the firm's employees, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has decided to consolidate its New York operations into its main headquarters on Broad Street, the firm said yesterday. Drexel currently occupies 1.5 million square feet of office space in four downtown locations in New York, of which 400,000 will be vacated in a year and a half. The firm reached an agreement earlier this week with Olympia & York, the real estate company, under which it would continue to lease the Broad Street offices through 2004. The old lease would have ended in 1993. Under the terms of the new lease, Drexel will occupy 700,000 square feet at the Broad Street office.

title: Unpredictable Series For Giants and Cubs
description: The scoreboard atop the center-field bleachers at Wrigley Field, filled all summer with the names of cities and inning-by-inning results, was a green blank except for two teams beneath the word NATIONAL: San Fran and Cubs.

title: REFUGEES IN PRAGUE TO LEAVE FOR WEST
description: In an attempt to stop an exodus of its citizens that had turned chaotic, East Germany said Tuesday that it would allow refugees already in Czechoslovakia to head west. Then it closed its borders.

title: Austin, Tex.
description: IN Texas, where many believe that if you can't drive up to or through something, it isn't worth the effort in the first place, an Austin company has come up with one more reason to keep the seat belts fastened.

title: Brady's Debt Plan: Dead in the Water
description: LEAD: Hooray for Lewis Preston! J. P. Morgan & Company's chairman has finally stated what many suspect: The so-called Brady plan is contradictory and unworkable. Mr. Preston has brought the Treasury back to earth by reminding us that, political considerations aside, banks must account for losses like other companies.

title: U.S. Had Indications Coup Would Be Attempted
description: American officials said today that the United States had some advance warning of the coup attempt in Panama, but they maintained that the Bush Administration had provided no direct assistance to the rebels.

title: Mets Say Farewell to Carter and Hernandez and to an Era
description: The Mets closed one era and two careers yesterday when they said farewell to their 35-year-old co-captains, Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez, and sent them into the free-agent market with thanks and blessings.

title: 'The Great One'
description: To The Living Section:

title: United Merchants & Manufacurers Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,264,000, or 25 cents a share, from the extinguishment of debt. c-Included income prior to sale from discontinued operations of $2,806,000; gain on sale of discontinued operations of $23,751,000, and an extraordinary gain of $517,000, or 6 cents a share, from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Boeing Machinists Reject Wage Package
description: Perhaps no company in America has been so successful in surviving the manufacturing downturn of the 1980's as the Boeing Company, but its current prosperity has made it a prime target for organized labor's attempts to make up for years of stagnant wages and other concessions.

title: ENFORCEMENT LAX, U.S. AUDITORS SAY
description: The internal inspectors of three Federal agencies told Congress today about serious weaknesses in the agencies' enforcement of Federal law.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE provenance of the Italian cooking term ''alla Francese,'' or in the French style, has never been clear. Some have postulated that a French chef who worked in Italy was responsible for the term, or perhaps the technique in question seemed typically French rather than Italian.

title: Japan Gets Import Plea
description: A group of Southeast Asian countries today urged Japan to buy more of their products, dismantle trade barriers and spread technological expertise around the region. The Association of South East Asian Nations, which consists of Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Brunei and Indonesia, said Tokyo had an important role in insuring political stability in the region, but it also had to fulfill its promise to help poorer countries develop.

title: Bellwether Exploration Co reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the increases in earnings and reserves are primarily due to the acquisition of Winchester Energy Inc. on Feb. 15, 1989, and the acquisition of working interests in the N.W. Panther Reef Field, Calhoun County, Tex., on March 29, 1989.

title: A Cheaper Road to Solar Power: It's Done With Mirrors
description: For years the quest for economical solar power has centered on photovoltaic cells that turn sunlight directly into electricity. The cost of the cells is so high, however, that their use has been limited.

title: Xplor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: PTL FRAUD CASE GOES TO THE JURY
description: Jim Bakker was described by prosecutors as a con man and by his defense lawyers as a victim of Government interference today at his trial on conspiracy and fraud charges.

title: House Bars Deletion of Broadcast Fairness Rule From Budget Bill
description: The House today kept alive a move to require broadcasters to air opposing views on controversial issues.

title: Are There Limits to What a Necktie Symbolizes and Celebrates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Authorities Deserve Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow at Record 2,754.56 After Advancing 40.84
description: The stock market climbed to another historic high yesterday as investors focused on the underlying strength of several blue-chip issues, a firm bond market and a strong United States dollar.

title: Hospitals See Services Continuing
description: Private hospitals in New York City said yesterday that services would not be greatly affected in the event of a strike today by members of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Workers union.

title: Kemp Seeks Broad Changes To Curb Abuses in Housing
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp today announced a series of proposals to ''clear the decks'' at his scandal-ridden department by eliminating virtually all discretionary spending in Federal housing programs.

title: New-Home Sales Slip 0.4% After Surge in July
description: New-home sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in August but remained above 750,000 for the second consecutive month, as buyers took advantage of lower interest rates, the Government reported today.

title: A Trove Of Recipes Is Stolen
description: LEAD: A burglar broke into Lindsey Shere's house here recently and stole a large leather handbag containing Ms. Shere's credit cards, cash, checkbook and hundreds of unpublished recipes for some of the country's most acclaimed desserts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; R. J. Reynolds Settles
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company agreed yesterday not to misrepresent the results of a study linking smoking and heart disease in the tobacco company's future advertisements, settling a false advertising claim brought by the Federal Trade Commission. The F.T.C. said a Reynolds ad falsely contended that the study had proved smoking was not as hazardous as commonly believed.
