The company said the ad ''constituted an exercise of free speech,'' but added that there was no point in continuing the dispute. Reynolds acknowledged no violation of the law in the settlement.

title: Harley Maintains It's Not for Sale
description: Harley-Davidson Inc., the Milwaukee motorcycle company, said it is not for sale. Harley's announcement came a day after Malcolm I. Glazer, a Rochester businessman, disclosed he had acquired a 6.24 percent stake in the company for more than $17 million and indicated that he might seek control of the company.

title: Assembling A Charity Event, Piece by Piece
description: GLENN BERNBAUM, owner of Mortimer's Restaurant, gave a party last night. He had 75th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues cleared, put up six contiguous tents and charged 1,000 guests $250 each to sip donated champagne and nibble chili con carne in pastry shells. He called his party Fete de Famille IV. Everybody went. Nearly $750,000 was raised for the AIDS Care Center at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Factory Orders Advanced 2.9% in August
description: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods rose 2.9 percent in August, the Government said today. But analysts said a one-month increase from automobile orders belied weakness in the industrial sector.

title: House Passes Compromise On Federal Arts Financing
description: The House today approved restrictions on Federal aid for ''obscene'' art, a compromise that replaced even stricter limitations favored by Senator Jesse Helms.

title: Market Place; Banking 'Frenzy' Seizes California
description: STOCKS of independent California banks that have previously gone without much notice are being bid up. The recent acquisition of four banks anticipates a shift in California state law that will allow banks in other states to enter California banking, beginning Jan. 1, 1991, either through acquisition or by opening offices, if that bank's home state has a reciprocal law.

title: Shell Is First Black Coach in N.F.L. Since 20's
description: Art Shell, an outstanding offensive tackle for 15 years who was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame two months ago, yesterday became the first black head coach in the National Football League since the league began to gain recognition more than 60 years ago.

title: June Guicharnaud, 67, Translator and Editor
description: June Guicharnaud, a translator and editor, died of cancer on Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: First Federal of Alabama reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: From Tinker To Pafko To Sandberg
description: rrThe day the sky fell was June 15, 1951. I remember as though it were yesterday.

title: Hinderliter Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 21 about journalists who spoke before a special House panel on news coverage of Congress misidentified Tom Oliphant of The Boston Globe. He is a columnist, not a correspondent.

title: McMillan Reflects Jets' Frustration
description: Erik McMillan punctuated the end of a bad day at the office for the Jets by angrily flinging his helmet today.

title: White House Sees 'New Thinking' by Pretoria
description: The Bush Administration said today that economic sanctions had helped stimulate ''new thinking'' in South Africa's white power structure and urged Pretoria to begin to dismantle apartheid swiftly.

title: Florida Bars Licenses To Reduce Dropout Toll
description: Florida has joined the growing list of states that withhold driver's licenses from high school dropouts.

title: Once Again, A Survivor; Ruthlessness Keeps Noriega in Command
description: Over the last two years, two American Administrations have elevated the leader of Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to the top of the list of world figures they wanted to see removed from action. Only Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya came as close to getting under Washington's political skin.

title: Year's Best Honored
description: Steffi Graf of West Germany, who won the tennis grand slam in 1988, and Janet Evans, who won three Olympic gold medals in swimming for the United States that year, were honored last night in Manhattan as Sportswomen of the Year for 1988 by the Women's Sports Foundation. Graf was named Professional Sportswoman of the Year. Evans was chosen as the outstanding amateur.

title: Hospital Staffing Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Still No Decision on Johnson
description: Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, said yesterday that he had almost reached a decision on Davey Johnson's future as manager.

title: ...And Another Windsor
description: To The Living Section:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Colorado Is Top Team in Times's Ranking
description: In its first ranking of college football teams this season, The New York Times's computer has put Colorado on top.

title: Tyco Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
William Hurt and Ex-Dancer Were Never Married, a Judge Rules
description: Sandra Jennings was never the common-law wife of William Hurt and is not entitled to a share of the actor's income, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Pacers Add a Guard
description: Looking for a quick guard, the Indiana Pacers yesterday signed the 6-foot Rickey Green, an 11-year veteran who spent most of his career with the Utah Jazz. Green, 35 years old, was taken from Utah in the 1988 expansion draft by the Charlotte Hornets. He was waived by Charlotte in February, and played the rest of the season with the Milwaukee Bucks. He has a career average of 10 points and 5.9 assists a game(AP)

title: Abie Nathan Jailed for Meeting Arafat
description: A magistrates' court here sentenced Abie Nathan, one of Israel's best-known peace campaigners, to six months in prison today for meeting with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Compumat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included pretax charges related to the formerly proposed acquisition of the company of $90,000 for the quarter and $99,000 for the 9 months.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Loses Key Player
description: Hugo Perez, the star midfielder of the United States national soccer team, tore a groin muscle in a match last Friday and will miss this Sunday's World Cup qualifying match in Guatemala. Perez, 25 years old, was born in El Salvador and is considered the top American player.

title: At Begetarian Meal, Wine and Curiosity
description: THE future of wine is in food. This is not the ranting of some dedicated teetotaler but the opinion of Jim Fetzer, president of Fetzer Vineyards in Redwood Valley, Calif.

title: Tucker Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the 1989 loss is primarily attributable to the $1,501,000 provision for loan losses recorded by the Tucker State Bank of Jacksonville. The latest second quarter results also included a one-time gain of $445,506 recorded on the sale of the portfolio of mortgage servicing rights by Tucker Bros. Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Tucker State Bank of Jacksonville.

title: Book Notes
description: Big-Money Deals

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Killin' Time'

title: FCA International reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest year's loss included a $1.4 million write-down of investment in Continental Bank of Canada shares. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sony's Columbia Deal Is Criticized in Japan
description: For more than a decade, the Sony Corporation has prided itself on being the most internationalized of Japan's businesses, and perhaps the most adept at the politics of running one of America's most widely known consumer electronics company from a Tokyo headquarters.

title: Breakup Plan For N.T.T.
description: A Government report said breaking up the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation would provide a more competitive and efficient telephone industry in Japan. N.T.T., which had been state-owned, became a private company in 1985.

title: The Jensen
description: To The Living Section:

title: Don't Gamble on Jersey Politics
description: When New Jersey embarked in 1978 on the dubious course of using casino gambling to spur urban redevelopment, it wisely erected a legal wall between the gaming industry and politics. Now the casino king Donald Trump calls for tearing down the barrier. He couldn't be more wrong.

title: Arthur J. Keeffe, 86, a Law Professor, Dies
description: Arthur J. Keeffe, a law professor and columnist on legal matters, died of congestive heart failure Monday while recuperating from surgery at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 86 years old and lived in Washington.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Rebels attempted a coup in Panama but failed when troops loyal to General Noriega recaptured a central military headquarters that the rebels had seized. Page A1

title: S.E.C. Shuns Role In B.A.T. Takeover
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has concluded that the commission had no power to regulate Sir James Goldsmith's bid for B.A.T. Industries, Richard Breeden, the candidate for S.E.C. chairman, said. Mr. Breeden's outlined the staff's position in a 108-page response to questions from the Senate Banking Committee, which is considering his nomination. In August, David S. Ruder, the previous chairman of the S.E.C., said the staff was examining the $21 billion bid for B.A.T. by Hoylake Investments, which is controlled by Sir James.

title: Deals
description: Hockey

title: Official Named At Ann Taylor
description: Gerald H. Blum has been named to the new posts of vice chairman and director of marketing and merchandise direction of Ann Taylor, the fashion chain of 144 stores, effective Feb. 1, 1990. Mr. Blum will report directly to Joseph E. Brooks, chairman and chief executive of Ann Taylor.

title: Tell Us How Much Charter Reform Will Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Evert Helps Defeat Greece: Chris Evert, playing in her last Federation Cup, needed only 43 minutes yesterday to help the United States beat Greece, 3-0, in the first round of the women's tournament in Tokyo. Evert, 34 years old, who announced last month that she was retiring from major tournaments, beat Christina Papadaki, 6-0, 6-1. Martina Navratilova, No. 2 in the world, beat Angeliki Kanellopoulou, ranked 74th, 6-3, 6-1. Steffi Graf, the world's No. 1 player, helped West Germany beat (AP) Berger Loses: Third-seeded Jay Berger of the United States was defeated by Omar Camporese of Italy, 6-1, 6-3, in a first-round upset at the Swiss indoor tournament yesterday in Basel. Berger, ranked 12th in the world, was booed after losing to the unseeded Camporese, ranked 54th.(AP) BASEBALL Parrish Extends Homer Lead: Larry Parrish, a former major leaguer, increased his league-leading home run total to 41 with a two-run shot yesterday, but his team, the Yakult Swallows, lost to the Hanshin Tigers, 6-5 in a Central League game in Tokyo. (AP)

title: Bristol-Squibb Merger Is Set
description: Shareholders of the Bristol-Myers Company and the Squibb Corporation approved their companies' $11.5 billion merger, creating the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company. The merger takes effect

title: Stuart Hall Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included charges of $602,721 for an inventory writedown to reflect declining paper prices and an increase in the company's bad debt reserve to reflect anticipated losses related to the filing of two customers for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Best Products Co., Richmond, a discount retail company, named Stewart M. Kasen president and chief operating officer.

title: Rangers Won't Keep Dionne
description: Marcel Dionne, having just completed morning practice, took off his skates, showered, talked with reporters and headed for his car. He switched on the radio and heard that the Mets had declined to offer contracts to Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez.

title: Acclaim Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sudler & Hennessey Provides Hospice Spots
description: Sudler & Hennessey, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, has decided that the best way to face death is matter of factly. That is the tone of a campaign developed by the agency as a pro bono project for the National Hospice Organization. The organization is a nationwide association of hospices, which provide services to terminally ill patients.

title: French Weapons Trade
description: The French Defense Ministry said Monday that the value of export orders booked by French weapons manufacturers had increased by 30 percent last year, to $6 billion. The ministry said 53 percent of the orders were for aeronautical equipment, 36 percent for land-based equipment and 11 percent for naval equipment. France's biggest customers were the Middle East and North Africa, which accounted for 55 percent of the orders. North America and Western Europe accounted for 24 percent, and South America, 14 percent.

title: Cholesterol Matters, But How Much?
description: ''MY friends are saying: 'Oh, thank heavens. I don't have to worry about that any more.' ''

title: SOVIET AIM UPHELD BY SHEVARDNADZE
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze ended his annual trip to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday and flew off to visit Nicaragua. And he left Americans to ponder a history lesson.

title: The Reverse Windsor
description: To The Living Section:

title: Heekin Can Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $1,445,000, or 44 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,442,000, or 44 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Detroit's Mayor Settles Suit Over Paternity of 6-Year-Old
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young has agreed to pay $11,700 a year and create a $150,000 education trust for a 6-year-old boy to settle a paternity suit.

title: Intervoice Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Leaving Behind a Land of Shortages, but Also Friends and Relatives
description: A 30-year-old worker in a heating plant near Leipzig said his rickety Trabant automobile, carrying his wife and two children, crept across the border from East Germany to Czechoslovakia at 3:45 P.M. today, one of the last before East Berlin closed itself off from the last country to which its citizens could travel with relative freedom.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The economy is flat on its back. You cannot get screws or nails. There are no bananas, and when there are, they're the ones the monkeys wouldn't eat.'' - A 32-year-old construction worker fleeing East Germany. [ A12:2. ]

title: A.T.&T.-Pyramid Computer Venture
description: The Pyramid Technology Corporation, a minicomputer manufacturer based in Mountain View, Calif., entered a strategic partnership agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to develop a new generation of high-performance computer systems.

title: Route to Tyson-Holyfield Is Still Not Clear
description: By the timetable of Don King, Mike Tyson's promoter, a Tyson-Evander Holyfield match will not happen until late 1990 or early 1991.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Willis M. Tate, 77, Ex-President of S.M.U.
description: Willis M. Tate, who was president of Southern Methodist University for nearly 20 years, died Sunday, apparently from a heart attack, while on a trip to Colorado. He was 77 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: ICN Biomedicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $80,000, or 1 cent a share, and $439,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $259,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $506,000, or 5 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said extraordinary items for all periods reflect gains from the earlier extinguishment of debt.

title: Magellan Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary tax benefit of $88,956 realized from utilization of the carryforwards of prior-year losses. The company changed its fiscal year-end from April 30 to June 30 effective May 1, 1988.

title: Hillenbrand Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect the adoption of FAS No. 94, though there was no impact on net income or earnings per share.

title: Berenice Abbott: Still Feisty and Eager at 91
description: Berenice Abbott, the dean of American photographers and one who has always inveighed against visual prettification, lives in a lovely house nestled beside a tree-lined lake in this remote swath of central Maine, But Miss Abbott, who is 91 years old, shrugs off any suggestion of contradiction between the picture-postcard setting of her present life and her feisty days in the 1920's and 30's. In those decades she made memorable portraits of people who set the pace of artistic and literary life in Paris, and unforgettable photographs of New York, from its regal skyscrapers to its mundane curbsides.

title: Intermetrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Colombian High Court Upholds Extradition of Drug Ring Suspects
description: The Supreme Court upheld today the legality of President Virgilio Barco Vargas's decree allowing extradition of suspected drug traffickers to the United States, giving support to his campaign against the cocaine cartels.

title: Armstrong Suitors Request Meeting
description: The Belzberg family of Canada, which is considering a hostile takeover of Armstrong World Industries, has asked the company's board for a special stockholder meeting. Lancaster-based Armstrong, which manufactures interior furnishings, said it was examining the request.

title: DVI Financial Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
At Last, an Honest Work Station Race
description: Comparisons of the speed of the fastest computer work stations have frequently relied on inflated claims and even a bit of trickery.

title: Ex-Biaggi Aide Is U.S. Witness In Garcia Trial
description: Bernard G. Ehrlich, who was convicted of racketeering with former Representative Mario Biaggi in the Wedtech scandal, testified yesterday that Representative Robert Garcia told him in 1985 that he admired the way Mr. Biaggi had become wealthy.

title: Dynamics Research Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 9
Bridge
description: Good players who want to become even better will have a rare opportunity later this month. One of the country's top player-theorists, Marty Bergen, will give a free lecture at 6 P.M. at the Manhattan Club, 23 West 73rd Street. His subject will be competitive bidding, on which he has written extensively.

title: Ramsay Health Care reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $41,000 and $1,387,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $665,000, or 5 cents a share, and $1,411,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss The extraordinary credits resulted from a reduction in state and federal income taxes arising from net operating loss carryforward.

title: Dotronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: American List Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included final income from discontinued operations of $46,829, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter, which included a loss of $23,500 on operations and a gain on disposal of operations of $70,329; the 6 months included final income from discontinued operations of $24,583, or 1 cent a share, which included loss of $45,746 on operations and a gain on disposal of operations of $70,329.

title: Stolen Cartoon Art Is Found In an Office on Park Avenue
description: Westchester County officials have recovered 44 more pieces of cartoon art that were stolen from the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye, an assistant district attorney said today.

title: East and West Converge in Hong Kong Orchestra
description: When a local music producer released a recording of Brahms's ''Hungarian Dances'' by the symphony orchestra that is based in this city, he marketed it as the work of a fictitious group, the Sinfonia Hungarica, because, he said, ''the international world didn't want to know about Hungarian dances made by the Hong Kong Philharmonic.''

title: Greyhound Plans More Cuts in Fares
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. said yesterday that it would cut bus fares for the third time this year in an attempt to woo back travelers disgruntled by rising air fares and weary of driving.

title: Advisers Whoop Their Approval of New Museum
description: In a preview tour of the new Children's Museum of Manhattan, several members of an advisory committee kicked bottle caps around an empty gallery, peeled back the brown paper covering the wall-to-wall carpet and chased each other around a cluster of their colleagues being interviewed for television.

title: Linear Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Boston to Pay 1,500 Families To Settle Housing Bias Case
description: The city has agreed to pay about 1,500 families up to $3,000 each to settle a housing discrimination suit.

title: Plan to Let Builder Buy Part of 61st St. Is Blocked
description: Facing almost certain rejection by the New York City Planning Commission, the developers of a proposed luxury apartment tower on Amsterdam Avenue yesterday withdrew their request to buy part of West 61st Street to gain extra development rights for their skyscraper.

title: Panel Backs S.E.C. Choice
description: Richard C. Breeden, President Bush's nominee to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, was unanimously recommended today by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee.

title: Funds Win in Stocks, Not Bonds
description: The three best-performing mutual funds in the third quarter benefited from owning big blocks of airline stocks involved in takeovers and substantial stakes in Fannie Mae, Nike and a handful of Japanese insurance companies, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: Lillian Vernon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Milton Goldman, Vice President Of Theatrical Agency, Dies at 75
description: Milton Goldman, a prominent theatrical agent, died of heart failure in his sleep yesterday in Manhattan in his Sutton Place home. He was 75 years old.

title: U S West To Acquire Bond Insurer
description: U S West Inc., the regional Bell telephone company serving the Rocky Mountain states, announced plans yesterday to more than double its investments in financial services businesses by acquiring Financial Security Assurance Holdings Ltd., the largest insurer of corporate bonds.

title: The Cubs, a Tavern, A Goat and the Hex
description: As Sam Sianis sat in his place of work, a white cloth apron tied around his waist as he spoke near the counter where cheeseburgers were being served, his easy smile suggested that he is too kind a man to inform a giddy city that its baseball team is doomed.

title: Solitron Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforward credits of $209,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $437,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net income The latest quarter's net included insurance recoveries of $712,000, offset by litigation expenses of $270,000 and severance expenses of $211,000.

title: Israel Foreign Debt Dips
description: Israel's foreign debts totaled $24.1 billion at the end of June, down $900 million from the March figure, a Bank of Israel spokesman said today. He said 90 percent of the decrease was because of repayments by the Government and private sector, while the rest was a result of the dollar's rise in the second quarter. Israel's net foreign liabilities - gross foreign debts less foreign-based assets - totaled $17 billion at the end of June, a drop of $1.7 billion in the first six months of the year. Foreign debt has been dropping since 1987 and the decrease has accelerated in recent months.

title: Review/Dance; Graham Reinvents Her 'American Document'
description: The truths the Founding Fathers held self-evident were anything but that in 1938 when European Fascism claimed the future for itself - and Martha Graham was impelled to create ''American Document,'' an experimental work that used the Declaration of Independence and the Emancipation Proclamation among its spoken texts.

title: STRAINED U.S. TIES REPORTED IN CHINA
description: A secret analysis prepared for the Chinese leadership says that China's relationship with the United States has deteriorated sharply and will continue to be rocked by new conflicts, but that President Bush is quietly trying to limit the damage.

title: Farm Co-op Income Up
description: The Agriculture Department said today that the net income of farm cooperatives last year rose to nearly $1.7 billion, continuing a rebound from the sharp declines of the mid-1980's. Combined business volume of cooperatives in 1988 was reported at $66.3 billion, up 10.3 percent from $60.2 billion in 1987. The record was $73 billion in 1984. The $1.7 billion for net income was up 13 percent from $1.5 billion in 1987 and was almost two-and-a-half times the 1986 level of $688 million. Last year's net income was exceeded only by $1.9 billion in 1980 and $1.8 billion in 1976.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: IN design and home furnishings, Philadelphia has been thought of as a conservative city, notable mostly for past achievements in cabinetmaking. But now there is a new Philadelphia story. Fueled by the energy and enthusiasm of a new generation of entrepreneurs, this city has become an exciting place to shop for contemporary home furnishings as well as antiques.

title: Mason Takes Stock After the Storm
description: ''When it first started, I thought, 'Maybe I could get wiped out, here.' I thought it could definitely end my career.''

title: DCNY Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Many Elderly Fear Loss of Program That Helps Pays Cost of Long Illness
description: As the House voted to kill a program intended to protect the elderly from ruinous medical bills, residents of several retirement homes here continued to express the fears that inspired the plan in the first place.

title: MAYNARD JACKSON WINS IN ATLANTA
description: Maynard H. Jackson rode through downtown Atlanta Tuesday in an Election Day motorcade that resembled an inaugural procession more than a last-minute campaign appearance.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21

title: Crate & Barrel's Foray Into Furniture
description: For more than two decades, Crate & Barrel has built a dedicated following as a stylish but inexpensive merchandiser of glassware, kitchen utensils and accessories suitable for finishing a young adult's first real apartment. Patrons affectionately spoof the company's European-style products by giving a French pronunciation to its name: krah-TAY & bar-ELL.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST storm and screen doors are equipped with mechanisms to assure automatic closing and to protect the door from opening too wide or being blown open by wind. Although these door closers seldom break, they need regular lubrication to keep operating smoothly and occasional adjustment to compensate for internal wear. A common problem, caused both by inadequate maintenance and improper installation, is that the brackets loosen from the door or door frame.

title: Dean Chamberlin, 82, Ex-Time Inc. Executive
description: Dean Chamberlin, a retired Time Inc. executive, died of cancer on Tuesday in a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Cuomo Says Drug Unit Encouraged Fraud
description: The agency that administers drug abuse programs in New York has been so eager to expand treatment in the state that it has spent money haphazardly and encouraged fraud, a report released today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office said.

title: Yields Post Modest Rise
description: Yields of money market mutual funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report rose modestly during the week ended yesterday.

title: U.S. CONSIDERED AID TO PANAMA REBELS
description: The White House considered military support for the Panamanian uprising but ruled it out because it was uneasy with the rebel leadership, fearful of a trap and uncertain whether Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had been captured, Administration officials said today.

title: Short Brothers To Bombardier
description: The British Government signed over the state-owned aircraft and guided missile maker Short Brothers P.L.C. to Bombardier, a Canadian company. Bombardier, which makes subway rolling stock and small passenger jets, paid $:30 million, or $48 million, for Short Brothers. The Government gave the Montreal company $:780 million, or $1.25 billion, to assist in the takeover.

title: Europe to Aid Disney Park
description: In a bid to reap some of the profits from Europe's growing leisure business, the European Community's financing arm said today that it was backing the huge EuroDisneyland theme park near Paris.

title: Classics of Heating and Cooking
description: ''STOVE Mania,'' David Erickson calls his passion. After buying an 1876 wood-burning parlor stove for himself 12 years ago, the 38-year-old Mr. Erickson became so enraptured that he left his job as a teacher in Boston and set up Erickson's Antique Stoves in a Victorian railroad depot in Littleton, Mass. To date, he has restored 2,500 and sold 1,200.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Columbus Day parade, Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.

title: Two Arab Guerrillas Slain by Israeli Patrol
description: Two Palestinian guerrillas were shot and killed late Tuesday night by Israeli soldiers on a routine patrol in the self-declared Israeli security zone just a few hundred feet from the northern border, an Israeli Army spokesman said today.

title:
Currents;
Model of Haute Couture That's Decidedly French
description: LEAD: ''MOST model apartments are so hideous,'' the interior designer Robert Metzger said, ''because the building's owners don't want to spend money.'' Mr. Metzger, who says at least $300,000 is needed for a two-bedroom model, has just finished one in a new building at 279 Central Park West (88th Street) in

title: Drug Inquiry Continues
description: Senior officials of The Athletics Congress voted yesterday to invesitgate any accusations of drug use in track and field in the United States that occurred within the previous six years.

title: Mine Workers Request Ties With A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: The United Mine Workers of America, which broke ranks with labor's umbrella organizations more than four decades ago, today requested affiliation with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Audiovox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Longest Trial Nears a Close
description: Prosecution and defense attorneys rested their cases today in the McMartin preschool molestation trial, which, now in its third year, is the longest criminal proceeding in American history. Closing arguments are to begin next week, and Judge William Pounders of Superior Court said he expected the case to go to the jury by Nov. 1. The defendants are Raymond Buckey, 31 years old, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 62, charged with sexually molesting 11 children at the family-owned McMartin school.

title: Parent & Child
description: A FRIEND recently recalled how, when she was 11 years old, her parents told her she would spend the sixth grade in a class for gifted children instead of continuing at her old elementary school. They expected their daughter, who had always been at the top of her class and who was generally bored with her schoolwork, to be elated. Instead, she sobbed for hours.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Sanwa Bank California, to Sacks/ Fuller Advertising, Los Angeles, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Koch Mulls Professorship At N.Y.U.
description: In the first inkling of what his life might be like after he leaves office in January, Mayor Edward I. Koch is discussing with New York University the possibility of becoming a professor.

title: A City Built for Rock 'n' Roll
description: ''Most architects design a building and then leave it,'' said the London architect Mark Fisher. ''We take a barren jock-style stadium and transform it into a fantasy environment.''

title: Account of Plot: Close Call for Noriega
description: Conspirators who tried to overthrow Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega on Tuesday planned to trap him in his office and turn him over to United States authorities, a businessman with close ties to the Panamanian armed forces said today.

title: Personal Health
description: Every day 20 million Americans take pills to lower their blood pressure. And if some physicians had their way, most of the remaining 38 million Americans who have high blood pressure would be similarly medicated, taking one or more pills every day for the rest of their lives to ward off strokes, heart attacks and kidney disease.

title: Campaign Trail; Police Union Puts Off Mayoral Endorsement
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association put off endorsing a mayoral candidate yesterday, prolonging the battle between David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani for the blessing of the city's most influential law-enforcement union.

title: Schools in Need of Help, Parents Say
description: As they waited for their children this afternoon outside 80-year old Public School 33, most parents praised the school but expressed their approval of New Jersey's taking control of this city's school system.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Administration will regulate international money transfers by U.S. banks, the Treasury said, in an attempt to curb the laundering of drug profits. The Government will open a financial crimes center next month in Virginia to supply information on money laundering to several Federal agencies. [ Page A1. ] Republicans threatened to bring the Senate to a halt if Democrats invoke parliamentary rules to prevent a vote on a capital-gains tax cut. Late Tuesday, the Finance Committee defeated a Republican plan for a permanent cut in the capital gains tax rate while approving hundreds of millions of dollars in incentives to benefit cattle breeders, farmers, oil well drillers, petrochemical companies and tuxedo rental companies, among others. [ A1. ] The F.D.I.C.'s chairman confirmed that the $50 billion allocated to liquidate and sell off ailing savings associations may not be enough. In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, L. William Seidman raised the question of whether the Administration would have to seek a second bailout package. D1. ] Domestic vehicle sales rose 8.7 percent in late September. The 1989 model year appears to be the fifth-best on record. [ D5. ] Transportation Secretary Skinner said it would be more effective to review airline takeovers in advance, as would be required by proposed legislation, than retroactively. [ D6. ] INTERNATIONAL Canada's Government said it would cut passenger train service by more than 50 percent, sparking bitter protests. [ D1. ] West Germany's central bank is expected to raise two important interest rates by at least one-half of a percentage point. [ D9. ] COMPANIES U S West will buy Financial Security Assurance, the largest insurer of corporate bonds. The move will more than double the telephone company's investments in financial service businesses. [ D1. ] About 57,000 Boeing machinists went on strike, virtually shutting down production of $80 billion worth of aircraft. [ A26. ] Greyhound Lines will cut bus fares by 5 to 20 percent in a move to win back travelers disgruntled by rising air fares. [ D5. ] Bulova will offer watch faces with miniature paintings by Norman Rockwell, van Gogh and other masters. The company hopes to make watches that ''reflect people's life style and culture.'' [ D1. ] Varity said it would pay $70 million less for K-H, formerly Fruehauf, than the $650 million it had agreed to spend in May. [ D5. ] Institut Merieux will apparently win control of Connaught Biosciences. Ciba-Geigy and Chiron bowed out of the bidding. [ D5. ] MARKETS A surge in I.B.M. shares pushed the Dow Jones industrials to another record. The average rose 16.53 points, to 2,771.09. [ D10. ] The best-performing mutual funds in the third quarter benefited from holdings of airline stocks and Japanese insurance companies, Lipper Analytical reported. The worst performers suffered from weakness in ''junk bonds'' and rising interest rates. [ D1. ] The dollar was mixed against leading currencies in fairly quiet trading, as traders anticipated a rise in German rates. [ D17. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched lower in slow trading. [ D19. ] Yields of money market mutual funds rose modestly in the week that ended yesterday. [ D8. ] World coffee prices sank to 14-year lows amid deepening pessimism about the prospects for price-support measures. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Independent money managers slightly outperformed the overall stock market in the last 12 months, but trailed the market for the first three quarters, a new report says. Market Place. [ D10. ] New owners of Texas banks have created big-budget ad campaigns and innovative sales promotions in an attempt to introduce themselves to customers. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
E. J. Osmanczyk, Journalist, 76
description: Edmund Jan Osmanczyk, a Polish journalist, independent legislator and compiler of encyclopedias on international affairs, died Tuesday in Warsaw, where he lived. He was 76 years old and had been suffering from heart disease.

title: Review/Ballet; Gregory and Bujones Are Guests in 'Giselle'
description: Guest artists - Cynthia Gregory, Fernando Bujones, Leslie Carothers and Marin Boieru - brought special excitement to the production of ''Giselle'' that Connecticut Ballet Theater danced tonight at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College here. At the same time, they fitted harmoniously into the action. That is how it should be, for ''Giselle'' - one of the greatest ballets of the 19th century - is in many ways a work about communities.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Music; Ruhrworks, a Mixed Series Of Works From Germany
description: Goethe House and the Ruhr Cultural Foundation are presenting Ruhrworks, a series that will run through January, focusing on what appears to be a thriving arts world in West Germany's industrial region. The festival includes music, dance, art and photography exhibitions, films and lectures, with events set in performing spaces, libraries and churches all over New York City.

title: Jewish Figure in Belgium Is Killed; Police Investigate Political Motive
description: The leader of Belgium's principal Jewish organization was shot Tuesday in a hospital parking lot and died early today. The police said they were investigating whether it was an anti-Semitic or political act.

title: Calendar: Gardens and Other Fall Sights
description: Nine Days of Flowers, Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, L.I.; 516-922-9207 (weekends, 516-922-9201).

title: GREATER U.N. ROLE URGED BY SOVIETS
description: The Soviet Union outlined a set of proposals today that are intended to give the United Nations a greater role in preventing conflicts, including the creation of a chain of ''war risk reduction centers'' around the world.

title: Mining Trash Heap for Answers to Riddles
description: A team of archeologists, microbiolgists and chemists has begun mining the riches of the vast Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, and for them it is the little things of life that count:

title: Senate Debates Bill Outlawing Flag Burning
description: The Senate tonight stopped just short of passing a statute outlawing flag burning, legislation that many Democrats hoped would defuse the drive for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag.

title: Fine-Tuning Treatment for High Blood Pressure
description: Physicians treating high blood pressure say there is now such an abundance of effective medications that they can often fine-tune the choice of drug to the particular health needs of a patient.

title: Books of The Times; A Self-Portrait of Nabokov, From His Letters
description: Vladimir Nabokov Selected Letters, 1940-1977 Edited by Dmitri Nabokov and Matthew J. Bruccoli Illustrated. 582 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: Reeling Lions to Be Fed to Quakers
description: There is no light at the end of any tunnel for Columbia.

title: California Journal; U.S.A.'s Culinary Rule: Hot Dogs Yes, Dogs No
description: Few issues so profoundly divide the multifarious cultural and religious groups that have multiplied on the West Coast in recent years as the relative gastronomic merits of the world's fauna.

title: Bucks Hire Lee Rose
description: Lee Rose, who was an assistant coach with the Nets last season, yesterday was named director of player personnel for the Milwaukee Bucks. The 52-year-old Rose, who also spent two years as an assistant with San Antonio and 19 years as a college head coach, will replace Bob Zuffelato, who left the Bucks to become an assistant with the Minnesota Timberwolves. (AP)

title: Skinner Backs Preview Of Airline Takeovers
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that it would be more effective for his department to review airline takeovers in advance, as would be required by proposed legislation, than retroactively, as it did recently in the case of Northwest Airlines.

title: CBS News Head Denies Fakery Charges
description: Responding to allegations that CBS broadcast faked combat films during the war in Afghanistan in the mid-1980's, David W. Burke, the president of CBS News, said yesterday that the charges ''are simply not true.''

title: Egypt Reportedly Lists 12 Palestinians for Talks
description: Egypt, backed by the P.L.O., has put forward the names of 12 Palestinians to sit at the negotiating table in peace talks between Palestinians and Israelis, Palestinians here said today.

title: Jury Suggests Death Penalty For the 'Night Stalker' Killer
description: A Superior Court jury recommended today that Richard Ramirez, a 29-year-old drifter convicted last month as the ''Night Stalker'' responsible for at least 13 murders, be sentenced to the gas chamber.

title: Drug Boss Tells Of Giving Order To Kill 'My Girl'
description: Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, an admitted major drug dealer, testified at his secret pleading last week that he had ordered his former girlfriend killed because she stole money from him and then ''spent it on a dude,'' according to court papers unsealed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The ranking of Division I college soccer teams of Sports Pages yesterday was incorrect. The teams listed were those of the Soccer America poll, not those of the Intercollegiate Soccer Association of America. The correct poll appears today on page B26.

title: New Conran's President To Lead U.S. Expansion
description: Conran's, a home-furnishings chain, is planning an expansion in the United States over three years with an altered name, Conran's Habitat, and a new president, Ray Brunner.

title: Presidents Want to Curb Pressures
description: In a move designed to reduce time demands on college athletes, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Presidents' Commission today decided to recommend a measure that would all but eliminate spring practice in football, shorten the basketball season by a month and reduce the number of basketball games by three.

title: The Exodus, the Bloc, the Ripple Effect
description: As thousands of East Germans boarded trains tonight for their passage to the West, there were growing signs that the continuing exodus from East Germany was severely shaking the Governments in Prague as well as East Berlin.

title: Microsoft Expects Higher Revenues
description: The Microsoft Corporation said it expects to report revenues of about $235 million for the quarter ended Sept. 30, an increase of about 34 percent above the $176 million it reported for the comparable period a year ago. The company said it would release complete earnings information on Oct. 17. Frank Gaudette, Microsoft's senior vice president and chief financial officer, attributed the positive showing to strong sales across all product groups.

title: From Tiffany, Jewels of a Different Kind
description: Walking into the Renwick Gallery right now is like walking into a rainbow: a visitor is enveloped in the glowing colors of a lush exhibition of the masterworks of Louis Comfort Tiffany, which opened Friday. Many of the 65 objects on display, including windows, lamps, glassware and jewelry, come from private collections and have never before been on public view.

title: Campaign Matters; Talk of Slurs Enters 'Air War' In New Jersey
description: Question: What evidence do prosecutors and political opponents have to prove that Representative James F. Florio, the Democrat running for governor, is linked to the Mafia? Answer: None. Question: Then are Republicans trying to smear a candidate as mob-tainted because he has an Italian last name?

title: Graham Chapman, 48, Comedy Troupe Founder
description: Graham Chapman, a Cambridge-educated physician who decided to specialize in comedy and who helped to found Monty Python's Flying Circus, died of throat cancer yesterday at a hospital near his home in England. He was 48 years old.

title: Racial Tensions in New York Blamed for School Disruption
description: A student disturbance at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn on Tuesday was an isolated incident, provoked by what students believed was a white teacher's racist remarks and fueled by a perception that their complaints about the teacher were being ignored, students and staff members said yesterday.

title: Siliconix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary gain of $256,000, or 2 cents a share, on repurchase and early retirement of convertible subordinated debentures, and a gain of $409,000, or 3 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior years of adoption of SFAS No. 96, ''accounting for income taxes.''

title: Photocomm Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter net income was break-even.

title: Oil and Gas Outlook Mixed
description: At least a third of the leading oil and gas companies plan to spend more on exploration and production this year, but most forecast a drop in prices and activity in 1990, an industry report said Tuesday.

title: Private Adoptions Aided By Expanding Network
description: Couples who circumvent public and private agencies to adopt a baby independently have become part of an increasingly self-protective institution with its own advocacy groups, its own protocol and its own lawyers.

title: Student Seized With Gun at High School in Bronx
description: A student at Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx was arrested yesterday after menacing two school officials with a loaded .357-magnum revolver in the school's hallways, the police said.

title: Bundesbank Is Expected to Raise Rates Today
description: Economists and foreign currency dealers here are predicting West Germany's central bank will raise its key interest rates by at least one-half of a percentage point on Thursday. Such a move would follow concerted efforts by the Group of Seven industrial nations to hold the dollar at its current levels or force it lower.

title: 10-Year Notes By Finance Group
description: TransAmerica Finance Group Inc. yesterday offered $100 million worth of 10-year notes.

title: A's Arms and Legs Win Again
description: The headache that belonged to Jose Canseco when the morning broke now belongs to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Navy Punishes Four for Iowa's Deficiencies
description: The Navy said today that mild punishment had been administered to the captain of the battleship Iowa, two of his subordinate officers and a master chief petty officer for training and safety deficiencies uncovered in the investigation of the gun turret explosion that took 47 lives.

title: Physicians Don't Welcome New York State Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Helen of Troy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Glamis Gold Ltd reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income Revenue represents revenue from gold production.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Review/Theater; Cocteau Repertory in Wilde's 'Earnest'
description: There are few more enjoyable evenings in the theater than to accompany those Oscar Wilde dandies John Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff as they pursue, both in town and the country, love and earnestness. In ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' which is being presented by the Jean Cocteau Repertory company, Wilde uses his epigrams like a rapier, slashing his way through Mayfair drawing rooms and Hertfordshire gardens and leaving the cloak of hypocrisy that covered Victorian manners in tatters of laughter.

title: Students Clash With Police; Zimbabwe University Closes
description: Zimbabwe's only university was closed today after thousands of students protesting the arrests of two student leaders clashed with hundreds of riot policemen.

title: LEBANESE MUSLIMS ASSAIL SAUDI TALKS
description: Vowing to continue fighting, a coalition of Muslim and Druse Lebanese militias today strongly criticized the Arab League's efforts to mediate a peaceful settlement to the 14-year Lebanese civil war.

title: New Jersey Seizes School District In Jersey City, Citing Total Failure
description: New Jersey seized control of Jersey City's troubled public schools today, saying ''total educational failure'' in the state's second-largest city had deprived its 28,000 students of their constitutional right to a ''thorough and efficient education.''

title: Shift in Fight On Air Rules
description: The Congressional compromise reached this week on automobile emissions is one of the most significant indications of how far American industry has been forced to retreat from unbending opposition to tougher Federal clean air laws.

title: Henderson's Sparks Help Burn the Jays
description: In the second game, as in the first, the little things won for the powerful Oakland Athletics. But this time they stemmed almost entirely from the person of Rickey Henderson.

title: Trains To Be Cut In Canada
description: The Canadian Government said today that it would cut passenger train service by more than 50 percent nationwide, touching off bitter protests in a country that was stitched together by railroads in the 19th century and where trains and the people who ride them are the stuff of national folklore.

title: Dionne Won't Retire
description: Marcel Dionne, the veteran center who was told Tuesday that he would not play for the Rangers this season, has no plans to retire and intends to collect his $595,000 salary for the final year of his contract, his agent said yesterday.

title: Audit at H.U.D. Finds Other Grant Problems
description: A draft audit at the Department of Housing and Urban Development has identified yet another low-income Federal housing program that was marred by mismanagement and potential favoritism involving politically well-connected consultants and developers.

title: How Other Countries Handle Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidated Fibres Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $2,396,000, or $1.21 a share. The company said the extraordinary credit represents the dividend from the company's Canadian paper processing unit prior to the company's contribution of the unit to a joint venture, U.S. Recycling Industries, on April 1, 1988. The company also said revenues for fiscal 1989 did not include any direct paper activity and the revenues for fiscal 1988 included direct paper activity for 9 months.

title: Fuentes In a TV Film, On Life And Himself
description: With his don't-bother-me sunglasses and flowing white scarf, looking like a high roller in a Fellini film, the Mexican author and critic Carlos Fuentes thrusts and parries his way through ''The Journey of Carlos Fuentes: Crossing Borders,'' to be shown nationally tonight on many public-television stations. (In New York City, the hourlong program will be broadcast at 10 P.M. Sunday on Channel 13 and at 9 P.M. on Oct. 13 on Channel 31 The targets of this verbal swordplay shift frequently as the documentary moves from Mexico to Washington to Nicaragua. They include Mr. Fuentes's views on literary critics (''I love having critics for breakfast. I've been having them for 30 years in Mexico, just eating them like chicken and then throwing their bones away. They have not survived. I have!''), politicians and his interviewers, two San Francisco film makers unafraid to challenge their subject on the merits of his writing or of his left-wing political affiliations.

title: Varity to Pay $70 Million Less for K-H
description: The Varity Corporation said today that it would pay $70 million less for the K-H Corporation, an auto parts maker in Detroit, than the $650 million it had agreed to spend last May.

title: Gooden Undergoes Further Tests
description: Dwight Gooden acknowledged last night that he had undergone an extra medical scan last week to determine the nature of a mass of tissue in his right shoulder, near the torn muscle that disabled him for 10 weeks this season. But the scan showed no tumor in the area, and the Mets' surgeon, Dr. James C. Parkes, predicted that the star right-hander would be ''100 percent ready to pitch long before spring training.''

title: Mets Talk with Johnson
description: The Mets said today that Frank Cashen had finally reached Davey Johnson by telephone and opened a dialogue that would decide whether Johnson returned as manager next year. They denied again in the strongest terms that the decision had been made.

title: East-Bloc Is Said to Cut Managua Aid
description: Two weeks after the State Department asserted that the Soviet bloc had increased arms shipments to Nicaragua, American intelligence officials have concluded that shipments have instead declined by about 20 percent this year, Administration officials said today.

title: Dennis McGee Is Dead; Cajun Fiddler Was 96
description: Dennis McGee, a fiddler who performed on some of the earliest recordings of Cajun music, died on Tuesday. He was 96 years old and lived in Eunice.

title: Conversion Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,098,538 from tax-loss carryforwards for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the results for the latest 9 months and year-earlier 9 months included gains on the sale from an equity position in a power production facility of $3,390,022 and $2,584,796, respectively.

title: G.O.P. Senators Threaten Fight Over Gains Tax
description: Senate Republicans threatened today to bring the Senate to a halt if Democrats invoked parliamentary rules to prevent the full Senate from voting on a proposal to reduce the capital gains tax rate.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aerospace Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a research and engineering company on military space systems, was awarded a $415.3 million increase in a Defense Department contract for engineering and technical support for the Air Force and other agencies in the 1990 fiscal year.

title: Market Place; Money Managers Keeping Pace
description: THE nation's independent money managers slightly outperformed the overall stock market over the last 12 months, but trailed the market just a bit for the first three quarters of this year, according to statistics released yesterday.

title: U.S. SUES 4 CITIES ON TOXIC WASTES
description: The Justice Department today filed lawsuits against Detroit, Phoenix, San Antonio and El Paso, charging failure to control industrial discharges of toxic wastes into their sewage treatment systems.

title: Cadence to Buy Gateway Design
description: Cadence Design Systems Inc. agreed to buy the Gateway Design Automation Corporation of Lowell, Mass., for stock valued at more than $72 million. Cadence, a growing supplier of software for the design of integrated circuits, reported sales of $67.1 million last year.

title: Baltics Report
description: This weekend the congress of the Latvian Popular Front will meet to assert its intent to bring about a fully independent nation. No more veiled talk about ''economic sovereignty'' or confederation with the Soviet Union - the magic word is independence, the state of nationhood stolen from the Latvians 50 years ago in a pact between Stalin and Hitler.

title: Athens Journal; The Papandreou Affair: Did He Stoop to Snoop?
description: In a nation that thrives on intrigue, the stories now seeping out of the Secret Service headquarters here are being consumed as avidly as honey cakes at a Greek wedding.

title: SAILOR CONVICTED ON SPYING CHARGES
description: A sailor stationed aboard a United States aircraft carrier in Japan has been sentenced to 35 years in prison for spying, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: Meggett Performance Spurs Giants' Success
description: The Giants will carry a 4-0 record and a two-game division lead into their game Sunday against the Eagles in Philadelphia. One unexpected reason for that early-season success is Dave Meggett, an undersized, small-college rookie who keeps finding new ways to help the Giants win.

title: A Grand (Slam) Opening for Clark and Giants
description: The San Francisco Giants brought the act to 75-year-old Wrigley Field and shattered the Chicago Cubs tonight, 11-3, to win the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant. And most of the shattering was done by the power tandem of Will Clark and Kevin Mitchell.

title: Overlooked Natives Amid the Exotica
description: A COUPLE of years ago a friend in the nursery business sent me several perennials - two daisies and an aster - he had just imported from West Germany and wished to test for winter-hardiness in various regions of the United States. These three not only got through the winter splendidly but also proved to be indispensable for the late-season garden.

title: The New York City Election, 1989: CAMPAIGN OBSERVATIONS; Tough Politics or Race Baiting?
description: The political rhetoric emanating from Rudolph Giuliani's mayoral campaign has become so dissonant and contentious that it calls for sorting out. Right after the primary election, Mr. Giuliani began to focus attention on David Dinkins's ties to Jesse Jackson. That brought the issue of race to the center of this campaign, and raised questions about whether Mr. Giuliani had decided to pander to racial fears and prejudice.

title: White House Adds $200 Million to Polish Aid Plan
description: Under pressure from Democratic lawmakers to respond more aggressively to the changes in Eastern Europe, the White House announced today that President Bush would ask Congress for an additional $200 million in economic aid for Poland.

title: Businesses Are Urged to Work With Schools
description: Top personnel executives, educators and New York City officials agreed yesterday that businesses must work more closely with public schools and expand their own training programs to cope with an acute and worsening shortage of qualified workers.

title: For 'Ferryshaw,' Fast Break Into Italian Sports Culture
description: It is half an hour before the opening tipoff, and the leather-lung crowd at the Palaeur is already in a lather, screaming for victory, blood and heaven knows what else at unchartable decibel levels.

title: Canadian Rock, at 4 Billion Years, Is Called Oldest
description: Researchers have unearthed the oldest rocks ever discovered, chunks of granite in remote northern Canada that are nearly four billion years old, the National Science Foundation announced today.

title: Horace G. Alexander, A Quaker Writer, 100
description: Horace G. Alexander, a teacher and writer who headed the British Quaker relief effort in India, died Saturday of a gastrointestinal illness at Crosslands, a Quaker retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 100 years old.

title: Gervin Wants to Return
description: After pleading no contest to a driving while intoxicated charge, George Gervin, the former San Antonio Spurs star, says he hoped to make a National Basketball Association comeback this year. Gervin was sentenced to 45 days in jail Tuesday. But County Court-at-Law Judge Tony Ferro placed him on probation for one year, meaning Gervin will not have to serve jail time. ''I intend to play with the N.B.A. somewhere this year,'' Gervin told The San Antonio Express-News yesterday.(AP)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you're going to risk American lives, it's the President's view that you do so on your own timetable. You do so based on your own plans, at a time of maximum opportunity and advantage. You don't do so on the basis of someone else's plans and in response to rapidly changing circumstances.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [ A14:4. ]

title:
Currents;
Small Ideas for Big Vision
description: LEAD: AFTER World War II, many architects spent their days dreaming up compact-house designs the public could actually afford. Some very good ones were even built.

title: As the Army Chief, Pinochet Won't Retreat
description: The tears that Gen. Augusto Pinochet shed at a recent ceremony served as a powerful reminder of the uncertain future facing the man who has reigned over Chile bigger than life for 16 years.

title: Washington at Work; After Gaining a Hard-Won Stature, D'Amato Battles to Keep Hold of It
description: This was supposed to have been the year that Alfonse M. D'Amato transformed himself from an ugly duckling into a swan.

title: Bulova Seeking to Take The Watch Beyond Time
description: The Bulova Corporation has a new face, indeed a variety of new faces -15 original one-inch-square geometric designs by Victor Vasarely, the French painter who is known as the father of ''Op Art.''

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Thomson Medical Ends Tie to Laurence, Charles
description: LEAD: The Thompson Medical Company yesterday pulled the remainder of its business away from Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson. The company split the accounts - consisting of eight pharmaceutical brands - between Grey Advertising and Saatchi & Saatchi. The products include Aspercreme and Sportscreme, both analgesics, and Cortizone-5, an ointment.

title: U.N. REFUGEE CHIEF CHIDED BY ENVOYS
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is under fire from senior associates and diplomats who deal with the agency.

title: South Carolina Begins Rebuilding Storm-Swept Beach Dunes
description: With the highest tides in a decade threatening coastal communities already flooded by Hurricane Hugo, South Carolina began scraping beaches with bulldozers today to rebuild 65 miles of protective sand dunes washed away by the storm.

title: Banponce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sharedata Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The prior year results included an extraordinary gain of $339,275, or 9 cents a share.

title: Concern Sets Repayment
description: RW Technology Inc. has agreed to repay more than 600 investors who the Securities and Exchange Commission says were defrauded when the company sold stock at inflated prices.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Farmers Group Inc., Los Angeles, a unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., named William H. Braddock executive vice president and H. J. Browning senior vice president and chief information officer.

title: Goldsmith Loses Round
description: The investor Sir James Goldsmith lost another round today in his attempt to block state regulators from reviewing his $21.1 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries, the British parent of the insurer Farmers Group Inc. and several United States retailers. Federal District Judge John A. Nordberg refused to block the Illinois insurance director's review of the hostile bid, a Farmers spokesman, Jeffrey Beyer, said. Insurance regulators in nine states are reviewing the bid. Federal judges in California, Idaho, Kansas, Texas and Washington have denied similar requests by Sir James's company, Hoylake Investments Ltd.

title: Strike Averted As Hospitals Reach Accord
description: After a night of frenzied bargaining, negotiators for most of the New York City area's private hospitals reached a contract agreement yesterday, narrowly averting a strike by thousands of their workers.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Post to Outsider At Pacific Enterprises
description: LEAD: Pacific Enterprises, the parent of the Southern California Gas Company and the Thrifty drugstore chain, has appointed its first chairman who is not a member of the Miller family, which founded the company 103 years ago.

title: U.S., IN DRUG DRIVE, TO REGULATE SHIFT OF FUNDS ABROAD
description: In an attempt to halt the extensive laundering of drug profits earned illegally in this country and sent abroad, the Bush Administration has decided to regulate international money transfers by American banks, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 26 about a debate between candidates for governor of New Jersey misstated the site in some copies. It was Monmouth College.

title: Philadelphia Electric Sells $175 Million Bond Offering
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday offered $175 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bid.

title: Wolf Financial Group reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $160,000, or 2 cents a share, from utilization of capital loss carryforward. c-Net loss Wolf Financial said the 1989 results reflected a full year of activities at 11 additional brokerage offices acquired in May 1988. TR

title: Use Force Against Noriega
description: For nearly two years, the United States has been locked into confrontation with Gen. Manuel Noriega. Panama's dictator was indicted by two U.S. grand juries and dismissed by Panama's President in early 1988. He is intensely unpopular in Panama, where his party lost the recent elections 3 to 1, and throughout Latin America, where his drug trafficking and human rights abuses have left him isolated and condemned by the region's democracies.

title: Michael Choukas, 87, a Propaganda Expert
description: Michael Eugene Choukas, an expert on the uses of propaganda who taught sociology at Dartmouth College for 30 years, died Monday at the Hanover Terrace Health Care Facility in New Hampshire. He was 87 years old and lived in Portsmouth, N.H.

title: Shuttle Date Is Confirmed
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today confirmed Oct. 12 as the launching date for the space shuttle Atlantis, which is scheduled to carry aloft a nuclear-powered probe for man's closest look at Jupiter. Federal District Judge Oliver Gasch will hear arguments in Washington next Tuesday on a legal challenge in which a coalition of anti-nuclear groups has asked to postpone the flight until the risks associated with launching the probe are made clear.

title: Dow Up 16.53, to New Peak, Paced by I.B.M.
description: Led by the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to yet another historic high.

title: Cheyenne Software reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed its revenue increases to the acquisition and merger in March of Gates/FA Distributing and F.A. Computer Technologies Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's speech in New York on Monday night misidentified the group he addressed.

title:
Currents;
Recalling A Future Yet to Come
description: LEAD: NOW that the 1964 New York World's Fair is celebrating its 25th anniversary, it may begin to elicit some of the nostalgia usually reserved for the 1939 fair. More likely, ''Laissez Fair,'' as the 1964 event has been nicknamed, will remain unloved, based on a new compendium of essays and photographs, ''Remembering the Future, the New York World's Fair from 1939 to 1964''

title: Dylan Thomas's Light
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Thrifts Bailout Law Has Regulatory Teeth
description: To the Editor:

title: Arnold Ehrlich, 66, Editor of Magazines
description: Arnold Ehrlich, deputy editor of Town & Country magazine and a former editor in chief of Publishers Weekly, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Death Toll Spurring Spanish Draft Resistance
description: When the grim figures are announced each year, the Spanish Defense Ministry invariably tries to blame bad driving and personal problems for the large number of young Spaniards who die or commit suicide while doing military service.

title: Enzon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the fourth quarter profit to income derived from a new product development and marketing agreement with Sterling Drug Inc. The company said interest and other income, primarily from the agreement with Sterling Drug, totaled $2.8 million for the year.

title: B-1 Makes Desperate Touchdown After Part of Landing Gear Fails
description: A B-1 bomber made an emergency landing at Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert today after an increasingly desperate 12-hour flight in which the crew struggled unsuccessfully to lower the landing gear in the plane's nose.

title: An Unloved Loner and How He Is Used, in 'Mr. Hire'
description: When the body of a young woman is found lying in a thicket in a Paris suburb, murdered, it appears, by a holdup man who panicked, the police inspector first checks out Mr. Hire (Michel Blanc), mostly because nobody likes him.

title: Article 844289 -- No Title
description: Low fares offered by Braniff are helping the carrier to fill a slowly rising percentage of the seats available on the limited service offered since its bankruptcy filing Friday, the company said.

title: I. Magnin Addition
description: R. H. Macy & Company said it plans to convert seven Bullock's Wilshire specialty stores into I. Magnin stores next February. The two chains have been operating under the same divisional management since their acquisition last year. The larger Bullock's department store chain is not affected by the change. The company also said it would convert the current I. Magnin Los Angeles store on Wilshire Boulevard into an office building for Bullock's regional personnel.

title: Selling Assets For Air Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: News Media Misapply Poll Results
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated part of a consent agreement between the Department of Transportation and Wings Holdings, the new owner of Northwest Airlines. Under its terms, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines will retain a seat on Northwest's board, not relinquish it. But that director must abstain from decisions involving ''sensitive competitive and international aviation matters.''

title: Player Gets Asylum
description: Aleksandr Mogilny, who defected from the Soviet Union's national team to join the Buffalo Sabres last May, has been granted political asylum in the United States. The approval of his asylum petition by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service means he will now be able to apply for a visa to travel in Canada. While the petition was pending, Mogilny was not able to travel outside the United States and missed several exhibition games in Canadian cities. He is expected to have his visa for Canada in time to play in Buffalo's first regular-season road game on Saturday in Montreal. (AP)

title: I.R.A. Kills Man, Calling Him A Protestant Militia Trooper
description: Two gunmen fatally wounded a man several yards from a primary school in north Belfast today, and the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Rebuilding Begins For Youthful Islanders
description: In five years, the Islanders dropped from the elite of the National Hockey League to the third-best team in a three-team market.

title: Ford Is Recalling 70,000 Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company has recalled about 70,000 1988 Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable and Lincoln Continental cars to repair a potential power-steering problem. Ford announced the recall Tuesday, saying it would replace a power-steering pump pulley on cars with 3.8-liter engines. The pulleys could come off, causing a loss of power steering, the company said.

title: Boeing Strike Halts Work on $80 Billion in Planes
description: The people who weld, rivet and fasten together airplanes for the Boeing Company, the maker of nearly 60 percent of the world's commercial jets, went on strike today, virtually shutting down production of $80 billion worth of aircraft.

title: Pacific Telecom
description: Anchorage voters rejected a bid by Pacific Telecom Inc. to buy the largest city-owned telephone utility in the United States, unofficial municipal election results showed. Pacific Telecom Inc., a unit of Pacificorp, offered $412 million for Anchorage Telephone Utility, which serves business and residential customers in Alaska's largest city. An unusually heavy voter turnout Tuesday, because of the telephone measure, swamped municipal polling stations. The municipal clerk's office said the voting overload caused a shortage of ballots and delays in counting them.

title:
Currents;
The World According To Walton
description: LEAD: TONY WALTON'S set designs distill the essence of a place through realistic fragments and stylized imagery. His extensive design work for films, television and theater over 30 years is on view at the American Museum of the Moving Image, at 35th Avenue and 36th Street in Astoria, Queens, in the exhibit ''Tony Walton: Designing for Stage and Screen.

title: Mortgage Bonds At Jersey Utility
description: The Atlantic City Electric Company offered $135 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds at competitive bid.

title: The Editorial Notebook; America's Japan Problem
description: Akio Morita, co-founder of the consumer electronics giant Sony, is widely known in the United States. He is admired as an astoundingly successful entrepreneur, and he represents the perseverance and ingenuity with which Japan has re-created its industrial vigor. As a mark of that strength, his company last week made a $3.4 billion offer for Columbia Pictures.

title: Man Guilty in Accident That Killed Officer
description: A Brooklyn man was found guilty of criminally negligent homicide yesterday in the fatal shooting of a police officer by a sergeant last year.

title: Lebanese Hijacker Given a 30-Year Sentence
description: A Lebanese hijacker who was lured into American custody two years ago was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for the seizure of a Jordanian airliner in Beirut with two Americans aboard.

title: Review/Television; A Brooklyn Neighborhood Conquered by Crack
description: Tonight at 11:30, Channel 2 gets closer to the drug scene than many viewers may find comfortable. Mike Taibbi, the reporter, spent weeks in a neighborhood in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, which had 3,200 arrests in a recent 90-day period. Smoking crack and shooting heroin are apparently the main activities for many residents. They call it a ''24 and 7'' life: 24 hours a day, 7 days a week of using drugs and getting the money for more.

title: High Plains Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Iona Appliances reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: The Savimbi Smear
description: If you can't win a political argument on the merits, attack your opponent as a Communist. It is an old Washington tactic. But I have not seen it used as crudely in years as it has just been by Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah.

title: Critic's Notebook; Richard Chamberlain Returns to His Stethoscope
description: The world of medicine is understandably experiencing anxiety palpitations these days. Soaring costs, malpractice suits, often frustrating efforts to cope with such crises as AIDS, drug addiction and increasingly indigent patients: the headlines are not comforting. Significant public protests are spreading to Government agencies and pharmaceutical companies.

title: East Germans Line Emigre Routes, Some in Hope of Their Own Exit
description: Thousands of East Germans flocked to stations and junctions along the railroad line taking their compatriots from Prague to West Germany today in hopes of sneaking aboard. Conditions became so hectic that the police had to clear the Dresden terminal by force and the doors of trains were sealed from the outside to block them.

title: Sensible Restraint on Panama
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military strongman for the last six years, had his closest call yet on Tuesday. While rival elements of his Panamanian Defense Forces shot it out, more than 10,000 U.S. military personnel stood minutes away, on full alert, but apparently ordered to stay out of the fight.

title: Physicians Don't Welcome New York State Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; The Prism Saxophone Quartet, With 2 Composers
description: The saxophone has been with us for nearly 150 years, and there have been ensembles of saxophonists for nearly all that time. Yet, the repertory for saxophone quartet is surprisingly small, a problem many of today's ensembles sidestep by transcribing works written for other instruments.

title: Testing Time for 2 Devils
description: Of all the buildings in the National Hockey League, the Spectrum in Philadelphia has been the most hostile place for Soviet hockey players.

title: Hampton Has Surgery
description: Dan Hampton, a Chicago Bears defensive tackle, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday and will be out for at least six weeks. The Bears placed Hampton on the injured reserve list. (AP)

title: As Hospital Agreement Is Reached, A Strong Union and Leader Emerge
description: The contract agreement with the hospital workers' union is as much a political victory for the union and its young president, Dennis Rivera, as it is a triumph at the bargaining table.

title: INSIDE
description: Hospital Strike Averted In New York City Area After a night of frenzied bargaining, negotiators for 44 private hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City area and their employees reached agreement on a three-year contract, narrowly averting a strike by thousands of workers.
