Page B1. Machinists Strike Boeing About 57,000 workers for the biggest manufacturer of commercial jets walked out over pay, halting work on $80 billion worth of planes. Page A26. Bush Plans More Polish Aid Under pressure from Democratic lawmakers to respond more aggressively to changes in Eastern Europe, the White House said President Bush would ask for $200 million more in economic aid for Poland. Page A11. Canada to Cut Rail Service Attacking one of the nation's most dear traditions, Ottawa will reduce passenger train service by more than 50 percent. Among the casualties will be the transcontinental train through the Rocky Mountains. Page D1. Clark Slams Cubs; A's Win Will Clark hit a grand slam and drove in 6 runs, a playoff record, to lead San Francisco to an 11-3 opening-game victory. In the American League playoff, Oakland beat Toronto, 6-3, to take a two-games-to-none lead in the four-of-seven series. Page B23.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova Bounces Back: Martina Navratilova lost the first three games but bounced back to beat Tine Scheuer-Larsen of Denmark, 7-5, 6-3, yesterday and clinch a quarterfinal berth for the top-seeded United States in the Federation Cup women's tournament in Tokyo. The American team swept past Denmark, 3-0. Earlier, Chris Evert disposed of Karin Ptaszek, 6-1, 6-1, and after the singles, Navratilova teamed with Zina Garrison for a doubles victory over Scheuer-Larsen and Henriette Kjaer Nielsen, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) SOCCER Columbia Upsets Adelphi: Chris and Nick Ziadie teamed for two goals midway through the second half to lead Columbia to a 4-2 upset victory over Adelphi yesterday at Garden City, L.I. Adelphi, the top-ranked school in the New York region, is now 6-2-2. Columbia, fourth-ranked in the region, improved to 5-1.

title: Youth Bitter Over Ban On Driving by Dropouts
description: A teen-age father who is fighting a state law that bars high-school dropouts from driving before age 18 says such laws are probably a good idea, but there must be room for exceptions.

title: I.B.M. Head Is Optimistic
description: The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, John F. Akers, said today that the recent forecasts of lower-than-expected third-quarter profits at the computer company did not reflect doubts about its long-term growth.

title: A Connaught Victor Is Seen
description: Institut Merieux S.A. of France emerged today as the apparent victor in a takeover battle for the Canadian biotechnology concern Connaught Biosciences Inc. after a rival team - Ciba-Geigy Ltd. and the Chiron Corporation -bowed out of the bidding.

title: When Work Means Bring the Kids
description: It is 10 P.M. and the lights are low. The toys, the high chairs, the diapers, the bottles, the crayons and the face paint have been stored for the night. Danny Ross, 3 years old, Ryan Moulton, 5, and Ryan's brother Jake, 3, are relaxing on canvas cots watching ''Sesame Street'' on videotape. Kristyna Jaquin, 2, is sound asleep beside them.

title: Review/Dance; Noh and Kyogen Specialties By Companies From Tokyo
description: Two companies from Tokyo offered a sampling of classic Japanese theater on Tuesday night at the Lila Acheson Wallace Theater of the Japan Society. The Kita Noh Theater, which traces itself back to a theater school founded in the 16th century, appeared in two examples of the refined theatrical form called Noh. Between them on the program came the Nomura Kyogen in one of the comic interludes known as kyogen.

title: Joel S. Mitchell, 90, Ex-Corporation Chief
description: Joel Stephenson Mitchell, the former chief executive of Standard Brands Inc., died Monday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Bridge-Crossing and Other Explorations
description: New York City's history and future, its buildings and its parks will be celebrated in a series of tours, exhibitions and lectures in the five boroughs this month.

title: CALIFORNIA WINS SEX BIAS PAY CASE
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the State of California had not deliberately underpaid thousands of women in state jobs held predominantly by women. The ruling dealt an apparently decisive blow to the largest lawsuit concerning this issue in the country.

title: Planning Renovation? Better Keep It Simple
description: PART of the pleasure of owning a home is the freedom to do it over. But given today's soft residential real-estate market, anyone contemplating a home-improvement project - and an eventual sale - had best proceed with caution. With housing prices soft, what buyers are looking for now is ''the architectural equivalent of the basic black dress: adaptable, subtle and always correct,'' said Frederick Peters, an executive vice president with Albert Ashforth & Company in Manhattan.

title: Q&A
description: Adjusting a Drain Stopper Q.The ''pop up'' stopper in our bathtub drain barely opens, so water drains very slowly when the lever is flipped to the ''drain'' position. With my fingers, I can lift the stopper about 1/4 inch. What adjustment can I make to make the stopper open higher and thus provide a larger opening? A.First, take out the ''pop up'' lift linkage by removing the two screws that hold in place the control lever (which is moved to open or close the drain) and its plate near the top of the tub. Pull the plate and its attached linkage out of the tub wall. There will be a rod or threaded yoke or bar connected to a coil spring at the bottom. You may have to wiggle this around a bit to get it out.

title: Blood Cells Linked to Smokers' Lung Illness
description: Doctors have found that tiny cells called neutrophils tend to collect in the lungs of active smokers, and are then free to slowly destroy the lungs.

title: HOUSE ACTS TO KILL '88 MEDICARE PLAN OF EXTRA BENEFITS
description: Barely a year after Congress enacted expanded health benefits for older Americans, the House of Representatives voted today to repeal the program and the taxes and premiums that pay for it.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of an Associated Press picture in Business Day on Tuesday about the sale of the Zenith Electronics Corporation's computer business to Groupe Bull misidentified a Bull executive. He was Michel Bloch, executive vice president for strategy and planning, not Francis Lorentz, the chairman.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Texas Banks In Consumer Campaigns
description: LEAD: IN the good old days in Texas, when the banking business and big-money commercial lending were virtually synonymous, the common man and his common checking account attracted little attention and few advertising dollars.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
Clark Earns Admiration From Beaten Opposition
description: Mark Grace, Chicgo's first baseman, spoke admiringly of the hitting exhibition San Francisco's first baseman displayed tonight. ''It was his night tonight,'' Grace said. Grace's manager chose to disagree. ''He didn't have a night,'' Don Zimmer said. ''He had a week.''

title: Seidman Admission On Bailout
description: A top Federal regulator confirmed today what private economists had been saying for some time: The $50 billion that Congress approved in August to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan associations over three years could be inadequate to cover the losses at the institutions.

title: Physicians Don't Welcome New York State Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Voter Registration Climbing for Mayoral Election
description: The number of registered voters in New York City is at its highest in at least 10 years, and the figure is likely to grow in the next week, the final registration period before the Nov. 7 mayoral election.

title: Elizabeth Murrell-Fax, A Social Worker, 66
description: Elizabeth V. Murrell-Fax, a social worker and former director of the Forest Neighborhood House in the South Bronx, died of cancer Tuesday in La Guardia Hospital in Queens. She was 78 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Peugeot Talks Canceled
description: Efforts to settle a month-old strike at France's biggest car maker, Peugeot, suffered a setback today when workers refused to end a sit-in at their plant and the management canceled talks. Union sources said the strikers voted, 434 to 283, against ending the 10-day occupation of a foundry at the company's Mulhouse plant in eastern France. Peugeot's chairman, Jacques Calvet, under Government pressure to negotiate an end to the company's worst strike in five years, had made evacuation of the foundry a precondition for opening pay talks with the workers.

title: The Silver And Black Head Coach
description: Ken Stabler had suddenly been leveled by one of the Browns' pass-rushers. John Madden hurried onto the field in Cleveland that day in 1977 to check the health of his quarterback, and then the Oakland Raiders' coach began hollering angrily at the perpetrator. After a few words, the Browns' pass-rusher took a few ominous steps toward Madden until Art Shell, the Raiders' huge All-Pro offensive tackle, spoke up.

title: Close to Home
description: ''THERE is an Arts and Crafts carpet to die for, and the most fantastic quilt I've ever seen. You've got to go.''

title: Vehicle Sales Rose 8.7% in Late September
description: Late-September sales of North American-made cars and light trucks rose 8.7 percent, the companies reported today, but for the 12-month model year ended Sept. 30, domestic and overseas auto makers reported a 1.9 percent drop in the daily selling rate. Dealers sold 48,669 vehicles a day in the 1989 model year, compared with 49,603 a year earlier.

title: Rescuing Businesses Is Now a Big Business
description: Frank J. Zolfo is in a business that booms when others do not. The head of an accounting firm devoted to troubled businesses and their investors, he has thrived on the explosion in demand for services like his own.

title: Second Death Sentence Voted in Connecticut
description: For only the second time since the early 70's, a Connecticut jury has voted to send a man to death row. But defense lawyers said the circumstances of the verdict, announced Tuesday night in Waterbury, were as unusual as the ruling itself and would form the basis of an appeal.

title: Getting Old-World Look Without Going There
description: LEAD: MANY Americans want traditional furniture and upholstery to be brand new, but not brazenly so. Now they don't have to search abroad for faded kilim upholstery and floral-print fabrics, or to find soft, down-filled contours in reproduction antique sofas and chairs.

title: Amstar Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $42,268,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $9,160,000.

title: Secretariat, Racing Legend And Fans' Favorite, Is Dead
description: The flags in the infield at Belmont Park were flying at full staff yesterday because tradition says not to lower them for the death of a horse. One fan, who spoke for many, disagreed.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Bush Is Pressing for Angolan Cease-Fire
description: President Bush tried today to revive a faltering cease-fire in Angola as the Administration stepped up its efforts to bring about direct negotiations between the Angolan Government and rebel forces armed by the United States.

title: Bridge
description: The bridge players of Australia, and particularly those in Perth, can look back with pleasure and pride on the world team championships last month. The Bermuda Bowl and the Venice Trophy were successfully staged, thanks to an army of volunteers working behind the scenes. Heading the organizing team were Keith McNeil and John Scudder, president and secretary of the Australian Bridge Federation, and Joe Greenfield, the Perth convener.

title: Pop Radio Corp reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Mucho Slingage By the Pool
description: LEAD: Your average California skater dude doesn't talk like Joe Neckbone in Jersey, but old Joe might want to dial into our style. It's not like some fully bent tongue from hell or anything. This column should help bridge the lingo gap in modern America.

title: Tyson Gets Extension
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, will be allowed to perform a community-service sentence for speeding after the original 60-day deadline date. Judge Stephen Safranko agreed yesterday in Albany to let Tyson conduct three youth clinics on Monday, two days after the deadline set Aug. 7 by the judge. Tyson was sentenced to conduct the clinics and to pay a $300 fine that day after pleading guilty to two separate speeding incidents. (AP)

title: Lottery Redone to Aid Weak Teams
description: The National Basketball Association's board of governors, meeting in Manhattan yesterday, unanimously adopted an adjustment to the draft lottery that will give teams with the worst records a better chance of getting one of the three top choices.

title: Plumbing Old Furniture's Secret Places
description: LEAD: Secret drawers or compartments for the purpose of concealing papers and valuables unfailingly intrigue the collector.

title: Milton M. Rosenbloom, Copyright Lawyer, 82
description: Milton M. Rosenbloom, a copyright lawyer, died of a heart attack Monday at the Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 82 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Less AIDS From Blood Transfusions
description: The odds of getting an AIDS infection from a typical blood transfusion were just 1 in 28,000 two years ago, and the risk is dropping by more than 30 percent a year as fewer AIDS carriers donate blood, a study says.

title: Gates/FA Distributing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Treasuries Inch Down in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched lower in slow, featureless trading yesterday.

title: Mexico Will Press Drug War, But Without Any U.S. Troops
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico told a joint session of Congress today that his nation intends ''to eradicate drug trafficking at its very roots.''

title: Freight Access Program for New York City Remains Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Festival; Postwar 'Sadness' In Taiwan
description: The most dramatic and affecting moment in Hou Hsiao-hsien's ''City of Sadness'' has the calm of a still photograph. The camera lingers on a young Taiwanese named Lin Wen-ching as he stares from a prison window toward the place where his cellmates -also political prisoners of the Nationalist Chinese - have just been taken. Deaf and unable to speak since childhood, Wen-ching cannot hear the off-camera gunshots that signal their execution, but his face carries a look of devastating knowledge and incomparable grief - for his country's future in the aftermath of World War II, and for his own.

title: Jackson to Be Host of a Weekly TV Program
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson announced yesterday that he plans to be the host of a weekly television program beginning next fall.

title: A's Phillips: Clear Head, Dirty Uniform
description: In one corner of the clubhouse, far from where Rickey Henderson and Carney Lansford were addressing masses of microphones, Tony Phillips stood in front of his locker trying to explain what it is he does for the Oakland Athletics. But his uniform said it better.

title: Retail Sales Up, but Durables Lag
description: The nation's biggest retailers yesterday reported generally strong sales in September, but the lag in big-ticket, household durable goods continued to hurt results, particularly at Sears, Roebuck & Company and Montgomery Ward & Company.

title: Crash Puts New Focus On Cockpit Experience
description: The crash of a USAir 737 at La Guardia Airport last month has sharpened Federal and industry scrutiny of pairing relatively inexperienced pilots in the same cockpit. Also receiving more attention is the customary taking of turns at the controls.

title: Banks Warned on Mexico
description: A senior Treasury official said today that if the debt agreement between Mexico and its commercial banks did not work out, it would have to be renegotiated and the banks would have to settle for less advantageous terms.

title: Man in the News; Prophet of the Middle Way
description: A fundamental tenet of Buddhism is that the path to salvation runs between the extremes of self-denial and self-indulgence. Therein lies a hint of the path by which the Dalai Lama, spiritual and temporal leader of Tibetan Buddhists, eventually hopes to return from exile.

title: Easy Goer Closing In on a 3-Year-Old Season Worthy of Secretariat
description: Even as the racing world mourns the death of Secretariat, it will turn its attention tomorrow to the colt who is on the verge of completing the most impressive 3-year-old campaign since Secretariat's 1973 Triple Crown season.

title: Officials Split Over Options
description: Senior officials of the nation's four options exchanges squared off today in testimony to a House finance subcommittee over a plan to allow options to be traded on more than one exchange.

title: Modular Housing With a Difference
description: Factory-built modular construction normally allows a home to be produced more quickly and at a lower cost than one constructed on the site, but a major drawback has been the difficulty of incorporating custom changes requested by buyers, especially for higher-priced new houses.

title: Books of The Times; A V.S. Pritchett Collection of Characters
description: A Careless Widow and Other Stories By V. S. Pritchett 164 pages. Random House. $16.95.

title: President to Undergo Surgery To Remove Cyst on a Finger
description: The White House said today that President Bush would undergo a minor operation Friday to remove a cyst from the middle finger of his right hand.

title: Sports People: PRO BASKETBALL; Hornets and Heat Sign Their Top Picks
description: J.R. Reid, the Charlotte Hornets' first-round draft pick, has been signed to a multiyear contract. The announcement yesterday came only hours before the Miami Heat signed its No. 1 draft choice, Glen Rice, the forward who led Michigan to the national championship last season.

title: How to Slow the East German Exodus
description: East Germans keep heading west. And Bush Administration officials now say they would like the flow of refugees to slow, but that it's up to East Germany to do so by reforming itself economically and politically. Preferring East Germans to stay home sounds harsh, but it's sound policy. And only a country worth living in, not a socialist workhouse, will keep them there.

title: U.S. Cautions Europe On Protectionist Moves
description: The Bush Administration warned today that it might have to re-examine its support for European Community efforts to forge a single market by the end of 1992 if Europeans continued taking actions that discriminated against the United States. Officials cited a recent television directive calling for majority European content in programming and policies that favor European computer chips.

title: SENATORS SEEKING TO SALVAGE PART OF MEDICARE LAW
description: One day after the House voted to repeal the program of expanded health insurance benefits for older Americans, Senate leaders today made a last-ditch effort to salvage part of it.

title: Auctions
description: Newman's Cars

title: Review/Film; Outlaws Looting and Living for Illegal Passions
description: ''Drugstore Cowboy,'' Gus Van Sant Jr.'s glum, absorbing film about a clan of heroin addicts who travel around the Pacific Northwest Looting pharmacies of their supplies the way Bonnie and Clyde cleaned out banks, gives Matt Dillon the role of his career.

title: Unity For Germany, Not Reunification
description: LEAD: Europe is undergoing a profound change that is affecting the international order. And as the impact of this departure from the postwar system dawns upon Western elites, the German problem is re-emerging as one of the crucial unsolved questions of our time.

title: Remembrances of Championship Season
description: LEAD: When Dave Parker, the 38-year-old designated hitter for the Oakland Athletics, belted a home run into the right-field bleachers in the second game of the American League Championship Series Wednesday night, the ball sailed over a huge, well-appointed banner with a target and his nickname, Cobra, emblazoned on it.

title: Group Lowers Offer for American Medical
description: The investor group set to acquire American Medical International Inc. for about $2 billion, plus $1.4 billion in assumed debt, canceled its agreement today and submitted a new proposal worth at least $260 million less in cash.

title: Court Upholds a Ban On Animal Sacrifices
description: A Federal district judge today upheld Hialeah's prohibition on animal sacrifices, saying the Constitution protects only a religion's beliefs, not its practices.

title: Raiders and Jets Just Aren't What They Used to Be
description: The Jets' woeful running game, which is averaging 3.7 yards a carry, will finally meet its defensive equal Monday night when the Raiders come into Giants Stadium with a new head coach who, unfortunately for Los Angeles, doesn't play defense.

title: Review/Guitar; David Starobin in Works By Sor, Spohr and Giuliani
description: An interesting, if narrow, account of Western culture could be written through the history of its musical instruments. As populations grew, as technologies developed, as economic forces had their impact, old instruments evolved to meet new social needs. That was popularly and reverently known as progress. The period-instrument movement, which has been gaining strength and expanding its influence in recent years, is dedicated instead to the quixotic proposition that bigger and newer are not always better. Changes, while historically inevitable, do not necessarily represent an improvement in esthetic values.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball BALTIMORE (AL) - Announced that Frank Robinson, manager, had agreed to return for the 1990 season. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Announced that Steve Braun, minor league hitting coach, had been promoted to the major league club for 1990 and that Rich Hacker, Dave Ricketts, Jim Riggleman, Mike Roarke and Red Schoendienst, coaches, would be invited back for 1990. Placed Rod Booker, infielder, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Hockey ISLANDERS (NHL) - Signed David Chyzowski, left wing, to a multiyear contract. Announced the retirement of Brad Dalgarno, right wing. RANGERS (NHL) - Traded Michel Petit, defenseman, to the Quebec Nordiques for Randy Moller, defenseman. College PITTSBURGH - Announced that Steve Maslek, basketball center, would pass up his final season of eligibility.

title: BUSH AIDES ADMIT A U.S. ROLE IN COUP, AND BAD HANDLING
description: Senior Administration officials said today that the American military had played a greater role in the Panamanian uprising than it had previously acknowledged.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: From Africa and Asia

title: Dinkins's Front-Runner Plan: Try to Avoid Overexposure
description: Nearly midway between the primary and the general election, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral nominee, has largely adopted the classic campaign stance of a front-runner -carefully avoiding overexposure while doing whatever he can to help his Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, self-destruct.

title: Marina Woroniecka Viets, War Hero, 61
description: Marina Woroniecka Viets, who won the Polish Army's highest military decoration as a 17-year-old in the Warsaw uprising in World War II, died of lymphoma Sept. 25 at Loudoun Memorial Hospital in Leesburg, Va. She was 61 years old and lived in Middleburg, Va.

title: Metro Datelines; Workers Strike At Nursing Home
description: More than 300 members of the hospital workers' union staged a wildcat strike yesterday at a nursing home in Washington Heights.

title: At the Movies
description: Pfeiffer as Export

title: Bush's Report Card
description: Most state governors approved of their ''summit conference'' with President Bush because it focused attention on the nation's troubled education system, and because Washington and the states agreed to set national performance standards - to be measured by a sort of ''report card'' on every state and the Federal Government.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday PARADING FOR COLUMBUS

title: FLAG-BURNING BAN IS VOTED BY SENATE
description: The Senate today approved legislation intended to outlaw flag burning and other forms of flag defacement, setting the stage for a battle later this month over a proposed constitutional amendment to accomplish the same purpose.

title: The Tax Follies, Cont'd.
description: Nothing was too slippery for the Senate Finance Committee as it struggled to polish off the fiscal 1990 tax bill this week. Industrious committee members dredged up a little favor for the tuxedo-rental business, a great big one for grain interests and so many others that literally no one knew what they'd done when they finally finished at 2:15 Thursday morning. The bill heads now for hasty, uninformed votes by the full Senate. It should throw the package out.

title: Icahn Increases Stake in USX to 13.06%
description: Carl C. Icahn has increased his stake in the USX Corporation and plans to acquire more of its stock, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Columbus Day Holiday
description: Columbus Day will be observed on Monday, but the Columbus Day parade in Manhattan will be held today. Because of the parade, Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Streets will be closed from 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Here are holiday schedules for Monday. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office at 33d St. and Eighth Ave. open. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed, local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Expects Indictment For 1981 Deal With Jamaica
description: The Young & Rubicam advertising agency said late yesterday that it would soon be indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that it participated in bribing Jamaican officials to obtain the Jamaica Tourist Board's advertising account in 1981. The agency, based in New York, said several of its employees might be indicted as well.

title: PARTY IN HUNGARY SEEKING TO REBUILD
description: As the Communist Party gathers its shrinking forces for a Congress opening Friday, the party's chief of ideology propaganda said the leadership's expectations were modest.

title: Florida Court Rules Against Abortion Curbs
description: In a case that advocates of abortion rights hope could serve as a model elsewhere in the nation, the Florida Supreme Court yesterday relied on its state Constitution to strike down a law restricting abortions.

title: Prices of Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in fairly active trading yesterday, pushed higher by a jump in the dollar, which rose despite a bigger-than-anticipated increase in European interest rates.

title: Peru Police Kill 2 Guerrillas
description: The police killed two suspected Maoist guerrillas in Lima today after one of them tossed a grenade at a passing police car, the authorities said. A man and woman were painting slogans favoring Shining Path guerrillas when the man threw the grenade, the police said. The police also said a bomb exploded beneath a car on Wednesday in the northern city of Trujillo.

title: Topics of The Times; A Touchdown Combination
description: For some years there have been black assistant coaches in the National Football League with the potential to be head coaches. But there hasn't been an owner with the courage to give one a shot at the top job. Now Al Davis, the general manager and principal owner of the Oakland Raiders, has made Art Shell his head coach and the first black head coach in the modern history of the league.

title: What's Next After Mex And Kid?
description: They were never Redford and Newman, sharing a hideaway and a lady friend and a quip and a final hail of Bolivian bullets, the way Butch and Sundance did.

title: Estonia Suspends Part of Disputed Vote Law
description: The Estonian legislature voted today to suspend a clause in its new election law requiring that voters in local elections fulfill a residency requirement.

title: Federal Investigation Begins Into Fishing Boat Explosion
description: A team of Federal investigators today began work to determine the cause of an explosion touched off when a fishing boat struck a submerged pipeline.

title: B. Altman Sale Is Accelerated
description: The L. J. Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in the United States, said yesterday that it would accelerate the sale of its seven B. Altman department stores because of its inability to provide financing to revamp and modernize the stores. The 114-year-old B. Altman &

title: Review/Art; An In-Depth Exhibition Of a Japanese Master
description: ''The Paintings of Jakuchu, Master Artist of Japan'' at the Asia Society is the first major American retrospective devoted to a single Japanese master. This is the kind of show that a number of American institutions involved with theme, group or masterpiece shows of Asian art are now committed to doing.

title: Biin Seeks Buyer For Technology
description: Biin, a venture between the Intel Corporation and Siemens A.G. of West Germany, said it was seeking a buyer for its computer technology. Formed in June 1988, Biin was developing a computer that would use multiple processors for highly specialized applications, where the possibility of system failures must be minimized.

title: Sports People: AUTO RACING; Injured Foyt Improving
description: A. J. Foyt's condition was upgraded to good yesterday and he was moved from the intensive care unit to a private room at Charlotte Memorial Hospital in North Carolina.

title: Dinkins Raises Triple What Giuliani Does in Campaign Funds
description: Continuing to outstrip his opponent in raising funds, David N. Dinkins collected three times as much as Rudolph W. Giuliani in the latest filing period, according to financial reports released yesterday by the candidates.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL; Robinson Staying
description: Frank Robinson, the leading candidate for American League manager of the year, has agreed to return as the Baltimore Orioles' manager in 1990. His coaching staff has also been asked back. Robinson's relationship with the players apparently had much to do with the decision. The Evening Sun, the Baltimore newspaper, yesterday quoted Barbara Robinson, the manager's wife, as having said: ''He wouldn't leave those guys. He loves those guys more than breathing. He can't think of anything but those guys.''

title: British Steel Move
description: British Steel P.L.C. said it would acquire the family-owned C. Walker & Sons Ltd. for $:330 million, or about $529 million. Walker, which processes steel, is British Steel's largest customer. The company has 3,400 employees at more than 50 locations in Britain and Ireland. For British Steel, it would be the first significant acquisition since its shares were sold to the public in 1988.

title: 150,000 Israelis in Petition Ask U.S. to Free Anne Pollard
description: Nearly 150,000 Israelis petitioned President Bush today to free the wife of Jonathan Pollard, the convicted spy, from prison on humanitarian grounds.

title: Review/Art; 31 Years of Color and Shape In a Kenneth Noland Show
description: There was a time in the 1960's when it seemed that the whole of painting would go Kenneth Noland's way. What more did we need than those limpid, weightless and perfectly sprung constructions? There seemed at that time to be no emotional need that could not be satisfied by the chevron, the diamond, the irregularly shaped canvas and, as of 1967, the long, narrow, horizontal striped images that stretched out forever.

title: Dining Out Guide: Lincoln Center Area
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Andiamo! ** (Nov. 18, 1988), 1991 Broadway, near 67th Street (362-3315) - Andiamo!, two blocks north of Lincoln Center, is set in a lofty space with striking, large abstract paintings and constructions. Pastas are an engaging way to start. Recommended are crab meat tortelli in carrot butter, and angel hair pasta with seafood. For entrees, diners can choose nicely seared shell steak or lamb chops with balsamic-vinegar sauce. Seafood entrees include grilled Canadian salmon with tomato and basil and seared loin of tuna with tomato, garlic and red wine. A la carte prices are $6 to $10 for appetizers, $18 to $21 for entrees. Table d'hote, $28 to $31 from 5:30 to 7 P.M.. Lunch noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday, 4:30 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Cafe Luxembourg ** (Aug. 5, 1988), 200 West 70th Street (873-7411) - Distinguished in the Lincoln Center area for consistently appealing fare and lively atmosphere, Cafe Luxembourg has a stylish dining room outfitted in tile, terrazzo and brasserie-style furnishings. The French-American menu offers appetizers of duck terrine with pickled vegetables and Wellfleet oysters served warm with a shallot-red bell pepper vinaigrette. Current entree choices include roast chicken with garlic mashed potatoes; grilled red snapper with ratatouille, and roast duck with spaghetti squash and sauteed pears. . Appetizers are $6.75 to $11.50, entrees $17 to $28. Pre-theater prix fixe, $32.50 from 5:30 to 6:30 P.M. Open 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Monday to Thursday, until 1:30 A.M. Friday and Saturday; Sunday brunch, 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., dinner 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. La Boite en Bois * (Jan. 13, 1989), 75 West 68th Street (874-2705) - Traditional French cooking at moderate prices is the draw at this tiny bistro. Appetizers to recommend here are leeks vinaigrette, and smoked salmon and trout mousse. Roast duck with Armagnac; salmon cooked in parchment paper with a creamy mustard sauce, and poussin grand-mere are examples of the entrees. Red snapper, an occasional special, is sauteed with fresh tarragon. Appetizers are $4.75 to $7.50, entrees $16 to $19. Pre-theater prix fixe at $24.75 from 5:30 to 6:45 P.M. Open 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. Monday to Thurday, until midnight Friday and Saturday, 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Sfuzzi * (Dec. 30, 1988), 58 West 65th Street (873-3700) - This informal Italian restaurant has a trompe l'oeil ancient Rome setting with high-tech electronics and steel-and-rubber dining chairs. The menu, however, is a conventional mix of pizzas, pastas and grilled entrees. Some of the pizzas make good starters to split; one combines spicy sausage, fontina cheese and roasted peppers. Main courses include grilled chicken with goat cheese and spinach and fettuccine with asparagus, mushrooms and arugula. At lunch, appetizers are $4.50 to $7, entrees $12.50 to $18; at dinner, appetizers are $5.50 to $9, entrees $14 to $26. Lunch is 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner is 5 to 11:30 P.M. daily. Brunch 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Shun Lee * (Jan. 16, 1987), 43 West 65th Street (595-8895) - Shun Lee is a stylish and comfortable place to have a Chinese meal near Lincoln Center. The best of the starters are Beijing pan-fried dumplings, nicely seared and filled with seasoned pork, and crispy shrimp balls. The entree list is large and offers dishes from most of the regional Chinese cuisines. Among those recommended are lemon chicken and salmon with black pepper. At lunch, appetizers are $5.25 to $9.50, entrees $12.50 to $17.95; at dinner, appetizers are $4.25 to $13.95, entrees $9.95 to $21.50. Open noon to midnight daily. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: Flames Top Wings 10-7
description: The Soviet star Sergei Makarov scored a goal in his National Hockey League debut and Jiri Hrdina and Joe Nieuwendyk each scored twice as the Calgary Flames opened defense of the Stanley Cup by hanging on for a 10-7 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight Makarov, part of the first influx of Soviets into the N.H.L., also had two assists as the Flames, who won the Stanley Cup last spring with tight defense, reverted to a wide-open style of play.

title: American Air Gets Trump Bid Of $7.5 Billion
description: Donald J. Trump yesterday offered to buy the nation's largest airline, American Airlines, with a $7.5 billion offer for the AMR Corporation, its owner.

title: On Radio, Beethoven Isn't About to Roll Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; At a Show Featuring Prints, The Subject Is Ambition
description: ''Projects and Portfolios,'' the Brooklyn Museum's 25th National Print Exhibition, which opens today, is not like most other surveys. It does not present a dizzying number of unrelated works by as many artists. It does not merely celebrate the momentarily chic, nor does it lack a point of view.

title: Van Is Hope for Bronx 'Throwaways'
description: The young prostitutes rush to the van like children gathering around an ice cream truck on a hot day. ''Hey, man,'' they call. ''Where are the condoms? Give me some condoms.'' The van belongs to Project Street Beat, a program of Planned Parenthood of New York City, and the teen-agers it attracts work the harshest streets of the South Bronx, in decaying neighborhoods rife with drug abuse, unwanted pregnancy and AIDS.

title: Review/Art; The Pottery of George Ohr At American Craft Museum
description: The times have almost caught up with George Ohr, the turn-of-the-century American potter who always knew that he was a genius and that the pots he produced were unprecedented as both art and craft. The exhibition of 91 examples of Ohr's work that has just opened at the American Craft Museum could be larger and more complete. Ohr's achievement merits more than one floor of this small museum; it certainly deserves better company than the display of umbrellas that fills the museum lobby.

title: Above All, Boeing Wants to Slow Wage Increases
description: Because it is struggling to fill a huge backlog of orders for commercial airliners, the Boeing Company did not want a strike and was surprised when production workers rejected management's wage proposals and walked out, company executives said yesterday.

title: Pope Urges Ukrainian Church Legalization
description: Two months before his first meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Pope John Paul II urged the Soviet authorities today to grant immediate legal status to the long-suppressed Ukrainian Catholic Church.

title: ISRAELIS POSTPONE PEACE PLAN MOVE
description: Israel's divided inner Cabinet postponed a decision today on Egypt's proposal for direct Palestinian-Israeli negotiations intended to unlock stalemated Middle East peace efforts.

title: Non-OPEC Oil Talks
description: Officials of oil-producing nations that do not belong to OPEC began a two-day meeting today, and delegates said the matter of export cuts was not on the official agenda.

title: Mabel Staupers, 99, Leader for Nurses, Dies
description: Mabel K. Staupers, a nurse who spent her career encouraging black women in the health-care profession, died of pneumonia Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 99 years old.

title: Hostage Shot in Classroom
description: A 15-year-old boy armed with a shotgun and a handgun took a high school drama class hostage today and shot one student in the face before being talked into surrendering, the police said. The wounded student was in fair condition. The youth, armed with a 12-gauge shotgun and a semiautomatic handgun, entered the class of 35 students at Loara High School, 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles, and shot the youth, then ordered the teacher out of the room, Lieut. Marc Hedgpeth said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dallas Publisher Takes Fight to Washington
description: LEAD: The owner and publisher of The Dallas Times Herald, John Buzzetta, is determined to regain the right to publish ''Doonesbury,'' ''Dear Abby'' and other syndicated features that he lost last month to his competitor, The Dallas Morning News.

title: Growth in Ireland Seen
description: Ireland is expected to have sustained economic growth in the next five years with inflation less than 4 percent, according to a survey of 13 leading economists published today. The poll of the economists from leading banks and stockbroking firms forecasts that gross national product will grow by 4.9 percent in 1989, 4 percent in 1990 and 3.5 percent from 1991 to 1993. The Government estimate for 1989's G.N.P. growth is 4.5 percent. The economists, whose findings were published in the magazine Finance, forecast buoyant consumer spending, low inflation and tax cuts in the next budget in January.

title: Conference Chiefs Back Shorter Athletic Schedules
description: Most college conference commissioners said this afternoon that they agreed with the spirit of the dramatic legislation proposed by a National Collegiate Athletic Association panel, legislation intended to reduce the time pressures faced by college athletes.

title: Topics of The Times; Millions, Still Unregistered
description: The Board of Elections reports that the number of registered voters in New York City is now at its highest in a decade. But that still leaves at least two million New Yorkers eligible to vote but not registered.

title: Harry A. LaBurt, 91, Ex-Chief of Creedmoor
description: Harry A. LaBurt, a doctor and former director of Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens for 26 years, died on Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after being struck by a car. He was 91 years old and lived in Bellerose, Queens.

title: Review/Theater; Laurie Anderson, All Alone in America
description: In Laurie Anderson's performance piece ''Empty Places,'' the song that goes the furthest in distilling its mood and summing up its themes is a witty new ballad called ''Hiawatha.''

title: White House to Study Handling of Panama Crisis
description: The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, today ordered a review of the Administration's reaction to the attempted coup in Panama in the aftermath of what senior White House officials acknowledge was an ineffective response to the attempted overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ''We did not do it perfectly,'' one of the highest officials at the White House said. '' ''This is really our first crisis. We learned a lot. We could have done better.''

title: Peter R. Lessler, 41, Lawyer and Executive
description: Peter Rodney Lessler, a lawyer and senior vice president for planning and acquisitions at Dun & Bradstreet, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Goldsmith Plans New B.A.T. Offer
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, said he intended to make a new bid for B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. once his Hoylake Investments Ltd. received approval from insurance commissioners in nine states. Hoylake's $21 billion bid was allowed to lapse by the British Takeover Panel, partly because of regulatory delays involving the Farmers Group, B.A.T.'s American insurance unit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; N.A.S.D. Hires Messner Vetere
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers awarded its advertising account yesterday to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer. The N.A.S.D., a self-regulatory organization for the securities industry, is best known for running Nasdaq, the computerized trading system for the over-the-counter market. It had never retained an agency but created its own advertising, said Ron Berger, a partner at Messner Vetere.

title: Restaurants
description: When the Hong Kong-based Peninsula Hotel chain took over the Hotel Maxim's de Paris on Fifth Avenue at 55th Street last year, it inherited a somewhat prissy Old World French dining room called Adrienne that, despite its quality food, never really caught on among New Yorkers. Diners in New York City still need compelling reasons to enter a hotel restaurant for a meal, especially one without a separate street entrance.

title: Turgeon and Terreri Lead Devils to Opening Victory
description: The Devils came up with such an inspiring performance in their season opener tonight at the Spectrum that it overshadowed the National Hockey League debuts of New Jersey's two Soviet defensemen, Vyacheslav Fetisov and Sergei Starikov.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air and Water Technologies Inc. said it would acquire Falcon Associates Inc., an asbestos abatement company, in a $25 million stock swap.

title: Economic Scene; Dollar Anxiety At White House
description: THE Bush Administration, concerned about the rising dollar, appears to have ended its ''benign neglect'' for the time being and is working with other governments to push the currency down.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: Dorothy D. Giannone and Thomas K. Handy have been named senior vice presidents of Young & Rubicam/ New York.

title: U.S. Announces Grants for Trials of AIDS Drugs
description: The Federal Government announced its first grants yesterday for community trials of experimental AIDS drugs: $9 million for 18 projects in 14 cities.

title: Wendolin J. Nauss Jr., Lawyer, 69
description: Wendolin John Nauss Jr., a lawyer in Manhattan for 40 years and a partner in the firm of Seward & Kissel, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Dinkins's Road to City Hall Goes by California
description: David N. Dinkins has campaigned in the last two weeks in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the Fordham neighborhood of the Bronx and New Dorp, Staten Island. Within the next two weeks, his quest for City Hall will take him to Beverly Hills, Georgetown and the Loop.

title: Weirton Steel Sells Notes Due in 1999
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation, which was bought by its employees a few years ago, is offering $300 million in senior notes due 1999 through Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Audit Bureau Examines Coupons in Magazines
description: Reflecting concern about the possibility of coupon fraud, the Audit Bureau of Circulations said this week that it would begin studying the coupon-handling practices of magazines. In a pilot project, TV Guide will be the first magazine to submit to the examination, which checks the printing, storage, handling and distribution of coupons. TV Guide had requested the examination at the urging of its advertisers.

title: Nursing Home Fire Kills at Least 11 in Norfolk
description: A fire broke out in a 160-bed nursing home Thursday night, killing at least 11 people and sending dozens to hospitals, the authorities said.

title: New Faces and a New Attitude for Nets
description: If the Nets do not improve this season, it will not be because they were afraid to make changes.

title: Freight Access Program for New York city Remains Essential; Switch to Night Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Koop to Be Featured In NBC Health Specials
description: The entertainment division of NBC has commissioned five hourlong health specials from MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, the network announced yesterday. The series, which is to feature Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General of the United States, will address such issues as AIDS, the escalating cost of health care, and care for the elderly, the network said.

title: Bach's Mass
description: The German Bach specialist Helmuth Rilling will conduct the New York Philharmonic in a performance of Bach's Mass in B minor this afternoon at 2 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The choir will be Mr. Rilling's own Gachinger Kantorei, a resident ensemble at his International Bach Academy in Stuttgart. The soloists are Sylvia McNair, a soprano; Marjana Lipovsek, mezzo-soprano; Howard Crook, a tenor and Mark Pedrotti, a bass. The concert will be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $10 to $40. Information: 580-8700.

title: Safe! Mets Decide to Let Johnson Keep His Job
description: The Mets put an end to weeks of speculation and indecision tonight when they announced that Davey Johnson would return as manager next year.

title: Petit Sent To Quebec
description: The Rangers, in what they called General Manager Neil Smith's first trade of significant magnitude, yesterday sent Michel Petit to the Nordiques for Randy Moller.

title: KEY RATES
Numbers Anyone?
description: How important is the use of numbers in everyday life? The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art counts the ways with the free exhibition ''Numbers,'' which will run through Oct. 26 at the college's Arthur A. Houghton Jr. Gallery and Lubalim Study Center, Third Avenue and Seventh Street. The exhibition includes computer programs, videotapes and graphics to explain such topics as the theory of ''chaos,'' the existence of ''hostile'' and ''interesting numbers,'' and the interpretation of numerology in the Bible and Grimm fairy tales. Weekend hours are noon to 7 P.M. today and noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow. Information: 353-4155.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a memorial service for A. Bartlett Giamatti misidentified Dr. Leon E. Rosenberg, one of the people scheduled to speak. He is the dean of the Yale School of Medicine. The service is scheduled for 4 P.M. today at Woolsey Hall on the Yale campus.

title: Washington Talk; The Monument to '88 Lives in Politics of '89
description: A year ago, many politicians and analysts said the 1988 Presidential campaign would have little to do with governing, little to do with the issues and problems that would shape the years that followed. To the Democrats' despair and the Republicans' delight, they were wrong. If you seek the monument of the 1988 campaign, look around.

title: Sysco Offers $330 Million In Liquid Yield Option Notes
description: The Sysco Corporation, which is engaged in food distribution and service systems, yesterday priced $330 million in liquid yield option notes due 2004 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Bakker Is Convicted on All Counts; First Felon Among TV Evangelists
description: Jim Bakker, who built a multimillion-dollar religious empire on an image of wholesome values and religious faith, was convicted today on all 24 fraud and conspiracy counts he faced in Federal court here.

title: Angolan Rebel to Return to Cease-Fire Talks
description: The Angolan rebel leader bowed to American pressure today and said he was prepared to return to cease-fire talks under the mediation of President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire.

title: Corrections
description: The calendar of cultural events in the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday listed an incorrect date for the performance of ''The Incredible Merlin Magic Show'' at the West Orange High School. The performance will be on Oct. 14, not tomorrow.

title: Bache Draws A Censure From S.E.C.
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. was censured yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for numerous violations of securities laws governing accounting procedures and operational controls.

title: 14 Tons of Cocaine Are Seized in Texas and at Sea
description: More than 14 tons of cocaine were seized Wednesday in two raids, one on a house near the Mexican border and the other on a Panamanian vessel at sea, Federal narcotics agents said.

title: Coming Soon: His Own Story
description: The autobiography of the Dalai Lama, who won the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday, will be published simultaneously in the United States and Britain next year. Its tentative title is ''Freedom in Exile: The Autobiography of the Dalai Lama.''

title: Hudson Valley Festivals With a Backdrop by Nature
description: The fall festival season arrives this weekend in and around the Hudson Valley with a series of country fairs featuring apples, pumpkins, cider, antiques, country cooking and music, with the scenery showing the first signs of autumnal colors.

title: In New York, Topsy-Turvy Justice
description: In Supreme Court in Brooklyn, a defendant was recently convicted of first-degree assault for having intentionally and horribly disfigured a man by dousing him with gasoline and setting him on fire. At the same time, in an adjacent courtroom, two young men were convicted of first-degree robbery for having stolen money at knifepoint from a cab driver, whom they left shaken but unhurt. The robbery defendants each faced a sentence potentially 10 years greater than the defendant in the assault case.

title: Brighter Ways to Dress Up the Leg
description: Small shops selling an array of quirky as well as conventional hosiery have been moving leg wear from the obscurity of the lingerie department to the neon-lighted prominence of storefront windows.

title: South Africa Has Changed Little in 130 Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Some of Noriega's Top Advisers Are Seen Among Coup's Plotters
description: Among the rebellious officers who took part in the violent coup attempt against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega were some of his close advisers, including two officers directly responsible for protecting the Panamanian leader from such a betrayal, diplomats and officials here said today.

title: Dalai Lama Wins the Nobel Peace Prize
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled religious and political leader of Tibet, was named the 1989 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize today in recognition of his nonviolent campaign over nearly 40 years to end China's domination of his homeland.

title: Market Place; Some Pessimism About Dividends
description: IN this long-lasting bull market, hundreds of companies have either raised their payouts or initiated special dividends, or both. But now, Arnold Kaufman, editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook, an investment advisory newsletter, says the dividend boom has begun what might be a long decline.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Tough-Talking Boss Revived AMR
description: Robert L. Crandall, a hard-driving boss who took over a money-losing American Airlines in 1980 and turned it into a highly profitable and highly regarded line, wants to run his own show and would not be happy working for someone else, analysts say.

title: Review/Music; Congo's Beat Lifts a Crowd To Its Feet and the Floor
description: Loketo, one of the premier soukous groups now based in Paris, came to S.O.B.'s on Wednesday night and did what it does best: packed the dance floor.

title: Youth in Central Park Rampage to Aid Prosecutors
description: One of the teen-agers involved in a wilding rampage in Central Park last April has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and possibly testify against six other youths in the case.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Three Tied for Lead: Lanny Wadkins posted an early eight-under-par 62 yesterday and then watched Mark Wiebe and Tom Sieckmann match it in the first round of the Texas Open at the Oak Hills Country Club in San Antonio. The trio, all seeking their first title of 1989, held a one-shot lead over Dan Forsman. Paul Azinger was another stroke back at 64 with Steve Pate and Dan Pooley.(AP) TENNIS Spain in Federation Cup Semifinals: Two 17-year-olds led Spain to its first appearance in the semifinals of the Federation Cup in Tokyo yesterday, but the Maleeva sisters of Bulgaria wilted under a hot sun and that allowed Australia to advance. Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Conchita Martinez turned around Spain's loss to the Soviet Union in last year's Federation Cup by winning their singles matches. The Soviet team won its doubles match, but that only cut the victory margin to 2-1.

title: Repellant May Not Combat Lyme Disease
description: Precautions like insect repellant ''may not be practical'' to protect people against tick-borne Lyme disease, Federal health officials said today.

title: England a Honda Headquarters Site
description: The Honda Motor Company of Japan will set up its European headquarters in Reading in southern England, the auto maker said. The wholly owned Honda Motor Europe will start operating next April. The headquarters operation will create 100 jobs, and it will control production, sales, services, marketing, distribution and management in Europe.

title: Ex-Senator and a Nixon Cabinet Member Asked Help From H.U.D.
description: Documents released today by the Department of Housing and Urban Development add to the list of prominent Republicans known to have sought help from former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce and other senior H.U.D. officials.

title: Review/Dance; Graham on the Mystery of Existence
description: Martha Graham, speaking of her work, has said she does not want to be understood but to be felt. Her dances, in fact, are at their best when they are at their most mysterious.

title: Air Market Rule Change Is Proposed
description: In a significant policy change meant to spur competition in world aviation, the Transportation Department today proposed to open additional American cities to foreign airlines.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL; Video Firm Sues Pitino
description: Rick Pitino, the University of Kentucky's new basketball coach, has been sued by Dick Regan Productions, which has charged the former Knick coach with breach of contract regarding video and television production agreements. The $5 million suit was filed in New York State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We kept looking for something from the defense and couldn't find anything. The only thing I believed about his testimony was that when he started out, he was earnest.'' - Ricky Hills, foreman of the jury that convicted Jim Bakker. [ A1:4. ]

title: Workers Purchase LTV Bar Division
description: Employees of the steel-bar division of the LTV Steel Corporation voted to buy the division in the largest employee buyout by members of the United Steelworkers of America. The new company will be called Republic Engineered Steels. LTV Steel is part of the LTV Corporation, the Dallas-based steel and energy company that has been in bankruptcy since in 1986.

title: Soviet Purchases
description: The Soviet Union has bought 100,000 metric tons of soybean meal and an additional 200,000 tons of corn for delivery in 1989-90, under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The meal and corn were in addition to an order for 2 million tons of corn announced Tuesday.

title: Judge Refuses to Block Shoreham Agreement
description: A judge refused today to block a pact to tear down the Shoreham, L.I., nuclear power plant.

title: Kansas City Paper Merger
description: The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times, journalistic institutions in Missouri for more than a century, will merge sometime next year into a single morning newspaper to be called The Kansas City Star, the papers' publisher announced yesterday.

title: Review/Film; 'Old Gringo,' Fuentes Tale, Stars Peck, Fonda and Smits
description: Harriet Winslow: a prim, sexually repressed schoolteacher fleeing the deprivations of her past. Tomas Arroyo: a handsome, smoldering young general in Pancho Villa's revolutionary Mexican army. The old gringo: an American writer, renowned for his crusading journalism and scathing wit, who has elected to cut all ties with his home and family. In Carlos Fuentes's novel ''The Old Gringo,'' these three principals have been brought to Mexico by the long arm of fate, the magnetic pull of destiny and by various other forces that the film version, directed by Luis Puenzo (''The Official Story''), does not begin to understand.

title: Our Towns; Making Toasts To a Victory Over Garbage
description: It was a pleasant event at the Penfield Beach Pavilion, the kind some like to call casually elegant. There were a hundred guests or so, and the afternoon sun glinted on the sand and the water outside and streamed in through the ceiling-high windows. There was crab and cold roast beef and breast of turkey and bottles of chardonnay on the long buffet. And after lunch there was quiet conversation, mostly about garbage.

title: Brooks Bros. Chief to Retire
description: Brooks Brothers, the New York-based apparel retailer, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Frank T. Reilly, would retire at the end of the year.

title: BMW Price Cuts
description: BMW of North America Inc. said it would lower its 1990 car prices on certain American models by as much as 9.3 percent. The company said it was lowering the price of its 1990 model 735i to $49,000, from $54,000 in 1989. The smallest price decrease, 4.9 percent, will be on the 535i model, which will sell in 1990 for $41,500. BMW said the prices of its 3-series model would not change. The move follows plans by Audi of America Inc. and Volkswagen of America Inc. to cut prices on some 1990 models.

title: Metro Datelines; Witness in Mob Trial Found Slain in Bronx
description: A prosecution witness who testified against three reputed mobsters in the killing of a New York City police detective - and then recanted -was found shot dead in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Law Schools Seeking to Limit Students' Part-Time Work
description: Using letters and moral persuasion, law school deans in the nation's largest metropolitan areas are urging law firms to discourage students from spending too much time in part-time jobs at their firms.

title: Islanders Give Chase But Minnesota Wins
description: Trailing by four goals early in the third period, the Islanders rallied but lost, 6-5, to the Minnesota North Stars tonight at the Metropolitan Sports Center in the season opener for both teams.

title: Rams Not Too Excited About Their 4-0 Start
description: You get the feeling here - once again - that the Los Angeles Rams are going places, big places. Last Sunday they topped the glitzy San Francisco 49ers at Candlestick Park, 13-12, in the final seconds, championship-caliber fashion. The Rams now have a dangerous passing attack to complement their longtime running ways. They are 4-0 and one of only three teams still undefeated.

title: Jubilant East Germans Cross to West in Sealed Trains
description: Some 8,000 weary but jubilant East Germans, who had besieged the West German Embassy in Prague since Monday, arrived here aboard sealed trains today after being officially expelled from their homeland.

title: Dr. Robert Tuby, 82, Orthopedic Surgeon
description: Dr. Robert Tuby, a retired orthopedic surgeon, died of a heart attack Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Sports People: BOXING; Good Works by Tyson
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, left his training camp in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday for Albany to perform court-ordered community service stemming from speeding violations earlier this year, Don King, the fighter's promoter, said. Tyson has been training for several weeks for his Nov. 18 title defense against Razor Ruddock in Edmonton, Alberta. He had hoped to postpone the community service until after the bout, but King said that on Wednesday, Tyson's lawyer, Bob Hirth, advised Tyson that the delay had been turned down by the court.

title: Review/Film; Tom Selleck as a Police Pawn, in 'Innocent Man'
description: Really, it's no less likely than waking up to find oneself metamorphosed into a giant cockroach. Jimmie Rainwood (Tom Selleck), a nice, solid citizen with a chirpy wife (Laila Robins) and an airline job, is minding his own business one day when he chances to take a shower. Moments later, he is drying his hair when the police burst in, mistake the hair dryer for a gun, shoot Jimmie, discover their mistake and then arrest him on a trumped-up drug charge. Next thing he knows, he's serving a six-year sentence in a California state prison.

title: For Children
description: For Children Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES,'' an opera by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays through Nov. 18, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 666-1716. ''ROCKET AND FRIENDS,'' a show by the Puppet Company, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays through Nov. 12, at 31 Union Square West, Loft 2B. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: 741-1646. ''CAPTAIN DAN AND CONRAD,'' a show of magic and puppetry, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a musical presented by the Theater Workshop, 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow and 1 P.M. Sunday, at the Fantasy Playhouse, 317 Merrick Road, Lynbrook, L.I. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: (516) 599-1982. ''LEAF CREATURES,'' a program with Leif Belvason, who will show children how to create creatures from leaves, seeds and pine needles, 1 P.M. tomorrow, at the Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, near 79th Street, in Central Park. Reservations: 772-0210. ''CINDERELLA,'' a show by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the West 72d Street Studios, 131 West 72d Street. Tickets: $4. Reservations required: 874-3297.

title: Child Dies as Mother Forces 2 to Plunge
description: A 32-year-old Queens woman whose home life had been unraveling herded her five children into her clothes-strewn bedroom yesterday and forced two of them out the window of the 10th-floor apartment before rescuers burst in, officials said. The woman's 7-year-old daughter died after plunging to the ground, and a 3-year-old son was critically injured.

title: Private Space Rocket Is Destroyed in Blastoff
description: The nation's efforts to develop a private space launching industry suffered a setback today when the first commercially designed and financed rocket failed at blastoff and burst into flames.

title: Sandstrom a Key Man in Rangers' Blueprint
description: In the hours before a game, Tomas Sandstrom can be found in the basement of Madison Square Garden, his stick laying across a work table. With a gas torch, a saw and a bit of imagination, Sandstrom will labor over the stick for half an hour, subtly shaping it to his specifications.

title: POOR MANAGEMENT CITED AT A-PLANT
description: The Energy Department said yesterday that bad management had contributed heavily to the extensive environmental problems at its Rocky Flats plant, an aging complex near Denver that makes plutonium triggers for nuclear bombs.

title: Colombian Vote Due on Drug Extraditions
description: The Government announced today that it would let the voters decide if suspected drug traffickers wanted in the United States should be extradited.

title: Metro Datelines; 4 Bodies Found in Vacant Lots
description: The bodies of four Hispanic men who were bludgeoned to death have been found since July 31 inside bags in vacant lots in Queens, the police said yesterday. Investigators said they were baffled by the killings and had identified only one of the victims.

title: On Radio, Beethoven Isn't About to Roll Over; Ratings Are, in Fact, Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Gramercy Park's Refugees Long for Home
description: For the last five weeks, Esther W. Levin and her cat, Amor, have been guests at the Gramercy Park Hotel, courtesy of Consolidated Edison. The utility pays for the room, for food, even for the new pink robe Mrs. Levin wears as she waits for someone to tell her she can go home.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Faces and Le Cirque

title: OPEC-Europe Talks
description: OPEC and the European Community took the first step today toward closer cooperation between the oil-producing nations and their European consumers. Subroto, Secretary General of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, met with officials of the trading bloc in the first high-level contact. The two sides agreed to set up a working group to discuss possible areas of cooperation, particularly on environmental issues.

title: JUDGES CHALLENGE REHNQUIST'S ROLE ON DEATH PENALTY
description: Fourteen of the country's most senior Federal judges have written a highly unusual letter that challenges Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's authority as a spokesman for the Federal judiciary on the death penalty.

title: Metro Datelines; Cook Faces Charges In Woman's Death
description: A short-order cook accused of dismembering his roommate's body and boiling it was indicted yesterday on murder charges.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Jeff Harnar Evening Of Comden and Green
description: Early in ''Carried Away,'' his breathlessly paced evening of songs with lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, Jeff Harnar observes that throughout their long-running collaboration, the team kept writing songs for their favorite character, New York City. These remarks introduce ''Lonely Town,'' a memorable ballad with music by Leonard Bernstein that has one of Comden and Green's finest lyrics. Here, for once, the perennially playful team showed that they could write a lyric of probing melancholy. And Mr. Harnar, whose strong, open-hearted singing recalls Larry Kert in ''West Side Story,'' realizes all of its stirring poignancy.

title: Knicks Stable as Training Camp Starts
description: For the first time in many years, the Knicks had an uneventful off season and will have all their players under contract and ready to go today when they open their first training camp under Stu Jackson at the State University in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Europe Lifts Key Rates, But the Dollar Still Rises
description: In a coordinated effort to weaken the buoyant dollar, the West Germans and other European countries increased key interest rates today, but the dollar closed higher anyway.

title: Lodestar Discloses ADC Capital Plan
description: The Lodestar Group disclosed that it had proposed a recapitalization plan to ADC Telecommunications Inc. that would have given its shareholders a special dividend of $16 a share in cash and $2 in senior subordinated debt. Lodestar valued its plan at $22 to $24 a share, or about $316 million, because ADC holders would have retained their stakes in the recapitalized company.

title: Scandals Bring Hard Times For Nation's TV Evangelists
description: The ethical and financial problems of the nation's television evangelists have cost them contributions and followers.

title: Secret to Success: Retire Will Clark
description: If the Chicago Cubs viewed their six-run outburst in the first inning tonight as a positive sign, it was nothing compared with the good omen they encountered in the fifth inning: They actually retired Will Clark.

title: Penny Stock Fraud Case
description: Three men, including the owner and president of the Monarch Funding Corporation of New York, have been charged with racketeering in connection with a penny stock fraud scheme that law-enforcement officials say cost customers around the world more than $10 million.

title: St. Croix: Insult on Injury
description: LEAD: In the early 60's, Herman Wouk wrote a delightful book, ''Don't Stop the Carnival.'' It was a story about the wonderful, fun-loving people on the fictitious Caribbean island of Amerigo. Many, including myself, feel he was writing about St. Croix.

title: Film Festival; 'Sweetie,' a Wry Comedy By New Australian Director
description: After directing only four shorts, Jane Campion, a 34-year-old New Zealand-born director, makes a spectacular feature-film debut with ''Sweetie,'' a movie quite unlike any other you're likely to see until the next Campion comes along. Among other things, it's a love (and hate) story about two sisters who, put together, might make one presentable personality.

title: A Deal Offered on Tax Bill
description: Senate Republicans said tonight that they might be willing to strike a deal with Democrats to keep certain spending and tax measures, including their proposed reduction in the capital gains tax rate, out of a pending deficit reduction package.

title: National Education Is Expecting Loss
description: The National Education Corporation said it expected to report a loss in the third quarter of about $6 million. The education training company, based in Irvine, Calif., attributed the expected loss to disappointing revenues at its Applied Learning division, a computer training concern. The company said its fourth-quarter revenues at Applied Learning would be significantly below last year's.

title: Sports People: MARATHON; New York City Entrant
description: Pat Petersen, the top American finisher in the event in 1984 and 1985, has entered this year's New York City Marathon, which will be held Nov. 5. Petersen was seventh in the London Marathon last April in 2 hours 10 minutes 4 seconds, the best time by an American since 1983.

title: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Up 2.47
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose modestly to yet another high.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Management Association, a management training organization, said its board had named Dr. Thomas R. Horton chairman and chief executive, and David Fagiano president.

title: Sports People: PRO FOOTBALL; Surgery Idles a Saint
description: Reuben Mayes, the tailback for the Saints who twice was selected for the Pro Bowl, will have surgery next week on his right Achilles' tendon and will be out the rest of the season, the club announced yesterday in New Orleans. Mayes first felt pain in the heel July 25, the day after he ran a long run in training camp in La Crosse, Wis. He has not been in any practice since then. The same surgery was done on his left Achilles' tendon after the 1986 season. (AP)

title: New Chief Takes over Schools for Jersey City
description: In her first remarks Wednesday as the state's new Superintendent of the Jersey City school system, Elena J. Scambio complained about ''filthy'' walls at central headquarters.

title: Antiques at the Armory
description: More than 110 dealers will display paintings, rugs, toys, jewelry, quilts, linen and other items at the New York Armory Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street. Hours are noon to 6 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $7. Information: 861-3358.

title: Nairobi Journal; In a Land of the Censor, a Bold Magazine Endures
description: After the second issue of Gitobu Imanyara's monthly magazine appeared on the newsstands, with a bold title about human rights and a chilling graphic of barbed wire splashed across the cover, some friends in the security forces got in touch with the editor. Not a good idea, they warned. Dangerous copy, they said. ''I said I would try and find out what was dangerous in the magazine,'' Mr. Imanyara recalled, only slightly facetiously. ''But no one quite knew.'' In the meantime, the security people ferreted out the printer, who happened to be Asian, and told him he would be expelled from Kenya if he handled any more issues.

title: Cedric Thompson, Episcopal Deacon, 62
description: The Rev. Cedric Fitz-Oswald Thompson, a Perpetual Deacon in the Espicopal Diocese of Newark and the assistant at Christ Church in East Orange, N.J., died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Orange, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: Soviets Said to Double Cambodia Aid
description: The Soviet Union has sharply increased its military aid to the Cambodian Government in Phnom Penh this year, roughly doubling deliveries of arms and ammunition over 1988 levels, Asian diplomats and Cambodian rebel leaders say.

title: Record on Borrowing Can Help Trump's Bid
description: Donald J. Trump brings a strong staff and a solid record of repaying bank debts to his $7.1 billion bid for the AMR Corporation, but he suffers from an image as a corporate raider who may not be seriously interested in completing a transaction.

title: Paterno Is Rolling Up His Sleeves and Cuffs
description: Penn State had its first losing record in more than half a century came last year and it bothered Joe Paterno, the university's revered coach, as much as any rabid alumnus.

title: Protesters Seize Embassy in San Salvador
description: Twenty relatives of political prisoners and ''disappeared'' people stormed the Costa Rican Embassy and seized 19 hostages today to protest against the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador.

title: House Endorses Tax Credits And Grants for Child Care
description: The House today endorsed a greatly expanded government role in assisting parents with child care.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL; Polonia Request Denied
description: A request by Luis Polonia, the Yankee outfielder, to be transferred from the Milwaukee House of Correction to the Dane County Jail in Madison, Wis., has been denied because of overcrowding, Franklin Lotter, superintendent of the House of Correction, said yesterday in Milwaukee.

title: Early Retirements Hurt University in Connecticut
description: In the English department at Central Connecticut State University, there is an air of quiet desperation: no secretaries remain to type a syllabus or organize a professor's life.

title: For Boeing Strikers, Walkout Is Welcome Respite
description: Across the street from the cavernous building where the Boeing Company builds 747 jets is an old cafe called the Overtime Inn.

title: Courter Gets A New Look At Jersey And Himself
description: Whether riding shotgun in the front seat of his Mercury Grand Marquis, sprinting through the air in a rented helicopter, or just listening to his opponent's latest attack against him, Representative Jim Courter says he is learning new things about New Jersey, about politics and about himself.

title: New York State To Aid Children Of Drug Addicts
description: New York State would shift responsibility for treating the growing number of children born to drug-addicted parents from the Family Court system to the State Health Department under a bill being drafted in Albany.

title: Human Resources, Still Reeling
description: William Grinker, head of New York City's Human Resources Administration, once called his post ''the toughest job that one could imagine.'' Now he is resigning after three years in that job.
