While he deserves credit for a few successes, his agency remains swamped by the waves of social problems generated by the housing shortage, crack, AIDS and growing poverty.

title: Sour German Birthday; Humiliation of Exodus to WEst Overwhelms East Berlin's Celebration of First 40 Years
description: If it was not that his compatriots were fleeing his land through every crack they could find or create, the 40th anniversary of East Germany might have been a crowning moment for Erich Honecker.

title: Celebrating Victoriana In Its Gingerbread Kingdom
description: THE joke about this very commercialized but still charming seaside resort is that it has more Victorian structures than there were actual Victorians. Victoriana is a veritable industry here; it's alive and spreading in houses, hotels, bed and breakfasts, guest houses, churches, restaurants and even the Cape May Point Lighthouse that stands between the Atlantic Ocean and Delaware Bay at the very tip of the peninsula.

title: LAW: At the Bar; In defense of ambulance chasing: Will more competition keep lawyers' fees down?
description: No stereotype of lawyers is more common or more unflattering than that of pin-striped locusts descending on tragedies in quest of clients long before the smoke has cleared or the black box has been found.

title: Abortion Protester Jailed After Objecting to Fine
description: The leader of an anti-abortion group was jailed today after refusing to pay a $1,000 fine imposed for his part in a protest during the Democratic National Convention.

title: The Drug Boat
description: Mario Cuomo is a good man to talk to for a fresh supply of an essential weapon in the war against drugs - stubbornness.

title: Victor Feingold, Lawyer, 77
description: Victor Feingold, a lawyer who was general counsel to the Distillery, Wine and Allied Workers International Union, died Monday while recuperating from heart surgery at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Massachusetts Speaker Holds Off Insurance Ban
description: The Massachusetts House voted Wednesday to delay for a year the key provision of the state's universal health insurance law after turning back an attempt to repeal it.

title: Dora Friedman, 77, an Aide in Government
description: Dora Zucker Friedman, an aide to government officeholders and an advocate for West Side tenant groups, died in her sleep, apparently of natural causes, Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

title: Eagles Struggling But Giants Are Wary
description: The Giants are 4-0 and lead their division by two games. The Eagles are 2-2 and are playing erratically and have many key injuries.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: Arts & Entertainment Network, to McCaffrey & McCall, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Two on Staten Island Killed In Collision of Bus and Car
description: Two people were killed when a New York City Transit Authority bus and a car collided yesterday afternoon and rolled up onto a sidewalk in Staten Island, the police said.

title: Lowyd Ballantyne, 65, A Plastic Surgeon, Dies
description: Dr. Lowyd W. R. Ballantyne Jr., a retired plastic surgeon, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 65 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Cubs Rebound Early and Often to Even the Series
description: They used to call the Cubs a lot of things when Rick Reuschel pitched here, many of them uncomplimentary. But those are distant if unpleasant memories now, at the end of a season that will be remembered here for the achievements of the Boys of Zimmer.

title: Article 184489 -- No Title
description: Citing fierce competition abroad and rising concerns about food safety and the environment at home, a prestigious scientific group yesterday proposed a $500 million increase in Federal funds for agricultural research.

title: News Summary
description: The role of the U.S. military in the Panamanian uprising was greater than what the Administration has been acknowledging, the White House said, also indicating that the Administration performed badly. Page A1 Conspirators in the attempted coup included some of Gen. Noriega's close advisers, said diplomats. Among their ranks were two officers responsible for protecting the general. A10 Noriega calling for a crackdown and the rooting out of traitors A10 White House to study handling of crisis A11 News analysis: Erich Honecker, the leader of East Germany, has little to celebrate as his country marks its 40th anniversay today. The recent exodus of many residents is a searing indictment of his Government. A1 Some 8,000 jubiliant East Germans arrived in West Germany aboard trains after being officially expelled. As they left, thousands rioted in East Germany. A8 Moscow has raised its military aid to the Cambodian Government in Phnom Penh this year, roughly doubling deliveries of arms and ammunition over 1988 levels, Asian diplomats said. A3 The Dalai Lama won the Nobel Prize for Peace for his nonviolent campaign over 40 years to end China's domination over Tibet. A6 Man in the news: The Dalai Lama, 54-year-old Tenzin Gyatso, preaches a path of moderation in his political and religious life as leader of Tibetan Buddhists. A6 An Israeli decision on Egypt's plan for direct Palestinian-Israeli talks was postponed. But officials said that Prime Minister Shamir is interested in a United States compromise proposal. A3 U.S. cautions Europe on protectionism D2 Angola rebel to return to cease-fire talks A5 National A12-24, B6 A group of judges wrote lawmakers, asking them to seek the opinions of other Federal judges, in addition to Chief Justice Rehnquist, when new limits on appeals by death row inmates are considered. A1 Senate leaders tried to save parts of the Medicare law that the House voted to repeal, as the Administration also mounted a belated effort to head off an outright repeal. A1 An offer by Donald Trump was made for AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, the nation's leading airline. Analysts said the company was likely to reject the bid. A1 A plan to open more U.S. cities to foreign airlines was announced by the Transportation Department. The proposed change is meant to increase competition in world aviation. D1 An investigation of airline practices, including the pairing of inexperienced pilots and the customary taking of turns at the controls, is being pursued by the F.A.A. after the crash of a USAir 737 last month. B6 A setback to the space industry occured when the nation's first commericially financed rocket failed at blastoff. It was hoped that the rocket would help turn space transportation into a viable industry. A21 Boeing's willingness to face a strike rather than come to a quick agreement with its 58,000 striking workers reflects a management decision to favor longterm strategy over immediate production needs. A12 For strikers, walkout is welcome respite A12 Washington Talk: National politics this year has largely been shaped by issues and strategies from the 1988 Presidential campaign: taxes, patriotism, and the use of rough rhetoric. A12 A law to ban flag-burning was passed in the Senate by a vote of 91 to 9. Its passage sets the stage for a battle over proposing a constitutional amendment to accomplish the same purpose. A13 Jim Bakker was found guilty of all 24 fraud and conspiracy counts he faced. The highly publicized trial hinged on the government's contention that Mr. Bakker bilked his followers out of $158 million. A1 A law requiring parental consent for an abortion was struck down by the Florida Supreme Court. Abortion rights advocates hope the case will serve as a model elsewhere in the nation. A15 G.M. announced a joint venture with Chrysler D1 A compromise is likely on tax proposals D1 Regional B1-5 In the New York City mayoral race, David Dinkins has adopted the stance of a front-runner. He is avoiding overexposure while trying to help his rival, Rudolph Giuliani, self-destruct. A1 The funds raised by David Dinkins were three times as much as those collected by Rudolph Giuliani in the latest filing period, according to financial reports from the candidates. B1 Dinkins goes to California B4 The race for New Jersey Governor has been an education for Jim Courter, the Republican candidate. He says he has learned new things about the state's diversity, public speaking and what it is like to be the target of a negative campaign. B1 People who were evacuated from their Manhattan apartments because of an abestos-spreading steam pipe explosion on Aug. 19 are anxiously waiting to return. Their days are filled with inconveniences. B1 A teen-ager involved in the rampage in Central Park last April has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors and possibly testify against six others youths in the case. B3 A mother forced two of her children out of a window of their 10th-floor apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, officials said. One died and the other was critically injured. B3 Van is hope for Bronx ''throwaways'' B3 Early retirements hurt university in Connecticut B2

title: Cover-Up and Privacy in Nixon vs. ABC
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $429.3 million, to $348.94 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker; Cape May: Easy City to Tour, With Bird Watching Close By
description: Cape May is a New Jersey shore town, but one that is a cut different from most others. It is at the state's southeastern tip, which is actually south of the Mason-Dixon Line. Nevertheless, its charm is not in its Southern ties, but in its Victorian ones - its fidelity to the buildings and parks that have given the place its distinctive look. All this will be a matter of public disclosure during Victorian Week, which starts today and will keep many doors open through Oct. 15.

title: TV Weekend; A Love Affair and a Complication on ABC
description: As a made-for-television movie, ''I Love You Perfect'' has the virtue of not being entirely predictable. In fact, for long stretches, it is downright puzzling. That's one way, apparently, of grabbing a viewer's attention, which is what ABC will be attempting this Sunday night at 9 o'clock.

title: Law Firms Tighten Belt on Recruiting Students
description: Law students who are packing suitcases for job interviews at firms around the country are likely to find only an interview, not an all-expenses-paid vacation. Troubled by the escalating costs of recruitment, law firms are putting limits on accommodations and expenses for prospective associates.

title: Johnson and Lewis Meet in a New Venue
description: Ben Johnson and Carl Lewis faced each other today for the first time in more than a year, this time in the unlikely setting of a committee hearing room on Capitol Hill.

title: Futures Bill Is Introduced
description: Vowing to reform the nation's futures markets ''once and for all,'' the chairman and ranking minority member of the Senate Agriculture Committee introduced legislation today intended to strengthen Federal regulation of the markets.

title: On Stage
description: A Pinter Double Bill

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Democracy in Chile May Prove Elusive
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop/Jazz; New York as Grand Ole Opry Country
description: COUNTRY music, which all too frequently skirts New York while making its way around the rest of America, is invading Manhattan for more than three weeks, starting tonight.

title: First Executive Stake Is Sought
description: Rosewood Financial Partners said it had filed for Federal antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the First Executive Corporation to 49.9 percent from 9.95 percent. Rosewood is controlled by the Caroline Hunt trust, benefiting members of the Hunt family of Texas. First Executive is a Los Angeles-based life insurance comapny.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Passes a Flag Bill The Senate approved legislation to outlaw desecration of the American flag, setting the stage for a battle later this month over a proposed constitutional amendment to accomplish the same purpose. Page A13. A Boost for Foreign Airlines In a reversal of policy, the Transportation Department proposed rules that would allow foreign companies to fly into many cities in the United States, so long as they do not compete with existing service. Page D1. Abortion Law Struck Down The Florida Supreme Court struck down a law requiring parental consent for an abortion, saying it violated the ''right to be let alone'' guaranteed by the state Constitution. Page A15. Cubs Get Even Chicago scored six runs in the first inning and went on to beat San Francisco, 9-5, evening the National League playoff series at 1-1. Page D19.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Indian Shenhai

title: Report Says Soviet Cuts Would Delay Attack
description: Moscow will be incapable of a surprise attack on the West by 1991 if it makes the cuts in conventional forces promised by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the International Institute for Strategic Studies said today.

title: Panama Opposition Figures Seized in Crackdown
description: Armed men attacked opposition party headquarters tonight hours after Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega called for a crackdown on his opponents and urged Government employees to root out traitors in their ranks.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: Today WHOLE LIFE EXPO FOR BODY, MIND AND SPIRIT, Penta Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. Workshops, books and tapes. Today, noon to 10 P.M.; tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Daily admission, $17; a three-day pass is $33. Information; 481-8700. CRAFTS SHOW, 42d Street, along Bryant Park, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. Today, 10 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. Leather goods, jewelry and pottery. Information: 752-8475. BROADWAY FLEA MARKET, SHUBERT ALLEY, between 44th and 45th Streets, west of Broadway; sponsored by Broadway Cares. Theatrical memorabilia. Today, 10 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and 4:15 to 7 P.M; proceeds are to benefit organizations helping AIDS victims. Information: 974-7500. Tomorrow STONEWALL FESTIVAL, Washington Place, from Washington Square East to Broadway; sponsored by Stonewall Democratic Club. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Crafts, antiques and food. Information: 751-4932. WASHINGTON SQUARE COLUMBUS DAY FESTIVAL, Washington Square South, from Macdougal Street to La Guardia Place; sponsored by the New Frontier Democratic Club of Greenwich Village. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. More than 150 artisans and dealers. Food and entertainment. Information: 764-6330. AUTUMN CRAFTS FESTIVAL, Columbus Avenue, from 77th to 81st Streets; sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance. Glass, ceramics, leather goods, toys and jewelry. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Also Oct. 14 and 15. Information: 866-2239. Sunday TIBETAN HARVEST FESTIVAL, Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art, 338 Lighthouse Avenue, in Richmondtown, S.I. Clothing, crafts, food and entertainment. Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. Information: (718) 987-3478.

title: 3-Year Talks Pay Off For Chief of Pyramid
description: Shortly after joining the Pyramid Technology Corporation as chairman, president and chief executive three years ago, Richard H. Lussier began conversations with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company about possible collaborations. This week, the two companies said they would jointly develop a new series of minicomputer systems.

title: G.M. Sets Chrysler Venture
description: In a move that underscores a long-term change in the auto industry, the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that for the first time it would establish a joint venture with its smaller competitor, the Chrysler Corporation, to make manual transmissions and other components.

title: Metro Datelines; Suspect Convicted In Officer's Slaying
description: An accused drug dealer was convicted yesterday of murdering a housing officer who was shot to death when he walked into the middle of a dispute while searching for a missing child.

title: Your Money; No Consolation After a Disaster
description: In the weeks after a disaster like Hurricane Hugo, thousands of people discover that their insurance is not all it should be or all that they thought it was. But those consoled by the thought that they can, at least, deduct losses on their tax returns are likely to be in for further unpleasant surprises, warns Janice M. Johnson, a tax partner with BDO Seidman in New York.

title: Bonds Soar on Signs of Weaker Economy
description: Prices of Treasury and corporate securities soared and yields fell yesterday as the Government's latest employment data indicated a further weakening of the economy. Unemployment rose by one-tenth of 1 percent, to 5.2 percent of the labor force in September, and there was a decline in factory jobs in a broad range of industries.

title: With Puck Bouncing Their Way, Rangers Win Season Opener
description: When it was over tonight, the Rangers, in near unanimous humility, smiled and talked about luck and what it was like to enjoy some after all. They had beaten the Jets, 4-1, to open the season, and their locker room was full of quiet laughter.

title: Trump Has Some Wall St. Believers
description: Although Donald J. Trump arouses considerable skepticism among Wall Street stock traders, a minority is starting to take seriously his offer to buy the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, for $7.5 billion in cash.

title: AMR Likely to Rely on Stake for Workers
description: The AMR Corporation's most likely response to a $7.5 billion takeover bid by Donald J. Trump would be to move about a fifth of its stock into an employee stock ownership plan, investment bankers and lawyers said yesterday.

title: When the Mowing Stops
description: To be sure that your power mower starts trouble-free next spring, store it properly this fall. The Briggs & Stratton Corporation in Milwaukee, makers of engines for outdoor equipment, advises taking these five steps:

title: Bridge
description: There are times in bidding when good becomes bad, and vice versa. An example of the latter occurs when a player who has passed originally has a fit with the opening bidder. A jump shift in a new suit normally conveys that message: a player should not jump simply because his hand was almost worth an opening.

title: Five Exchanges Weighing Move To Jersey City
description: The five commodity exchanges in New York, outgrowing their space in the World Trade Center, are considering moving to Jersey City and are talking to municipal officials on both sides of the Hudson River to see which could provide a better package of tax breaks and other inducements.

title: Henderson Catalytic Even as the A's Lose
description: The Toronto Blue Jays finally found a way tonight to live with Rickey Henderson: outscore him.

title: Why the Vatican Kept Silent on Nazi Atrocities; The Failure to Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Phony Reform for Congressional Mail
description: Roused by the ethics scandal that drove House Speaker Jim Wright from office, Congressional leaders of both parties vowed ethics and campaign reforms. But the House failed an important test last week when it reneged on a pledge to impose stringent curbs on lawmakers' free mailing privileges.

title: Lawyer Tries To Thwart Bush Cousin
description: Judge John M. Walker Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan is perhaps best known for his most recent role: the cool-headed handling of Leona Helmsley's tax-fraud trial last summer. But he is also President Bush's first cousin, and the President's nominee to fill one of the 13 judgeships on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the Manhattan court that is often called the second most important court in the country.

title: Large Centers For Addicts To Be Urged
description: A panel appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to draft New York State's anti-drug strategy will propose creating treatment ''campuses'' to provide care for more than 1,000 addicts each, officials said yesterday.

title: Ms. Suitt Is Wed To Michael E. Yip
description: Halley E. Suitt, an account executive for Mead Data Central, a New York computer data-base service, was married yesterday to Michael E. Yip, the production manager at Lear Levin Productions, a television commercial concern in New York, at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Vance Pollay officiated. Ms. Suitt, who is 33 years old and will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Suitt of Greenwich, Conn. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College, she received an M.F.A. degree in creative writing from Columbia University. Her father retired as chairman of Constellation Film Productions in Greenwich.

title: How Senators Voted on Three Medicare Benefit Measures
description: The Senate took three votes today on changes in the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, which has been under attack by many elderly citizens over a surtax that helps pay for expanded health insurance benefits for the 33 million beneficiaries. Following are the roll-call tallies by which the Senate concluded it wanted to save only some of the new benefits and kill the surtax. Retaining Most Benefits

title: Louisiana Lawyers Move to Revive Invalidated Law Banning Abortions
description: Louisiana lawyers went to Federal court here today to try to revive an old Louisiana law banning all abortions.

title: Holiday On Monday
description: Columbus Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office at 33d St. and Eighth Ave. open. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed, local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: 1. These jubilant East Germans reached their destination after a circuitous journey from Prague. What detour did they take and why was it necessary?

title: U.N. Condemns Israel's Tactics in Arab Revolt
description: The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to condemn Israel for its repression of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

title: Easy Goer Tries for 5th
description: Easy Goer will try for his fifth successive Grade I stakes victory, and make his final start of the year in New York, in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup today at Belmont Park.

title: Tiresome News Dept.
description: Enough is enough in this Deep Throat business. A few days ago a rumor spread like fire through a straw rick that Deep Throat, world's most famous news source, was none other than Alexander Haig.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Thursday about university presidents asking for limitations on college sports misidentified the co-sponsor of a bill that would require all colleges to disclose graduation rates for athletes. Representative Ed Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, was the co-sponsor with Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Patents; Teeth in a Puncher Shaped Like Molars
description: Simple inventions are not always simple. Witness Robert G. Merrick's Personal Punch, a finger-sized device that punches holes in calling cards so they can be put on a Rolodex.

title: Harsud Journal; Water, Water Everywhere? Many Now Say 'No!'
description: Here in the remote Narmada River valley, in hamlets that most Indians have never heard of, a new and growing national environmental movement has drawn its battle line against large-scale development in India.

title: Koch Urges Diplomat To Defect From China
description: Closing out the dozen years in which he guided New York City's independent and home-brewed foreign policy, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday issued one of those communiques for which his tenure was renowned.

title: Two Personal Essays
description: The personal essay is a dangerous form, prone to banality or overreaching. Fred Marx's ''Dreams From China'' and Ralph Arlyck's ''Current Events,'' the first-person films that will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 6:30, show traces of both problems. They are extremely sincere but slight films, not cogent enough to deal with the huge subjects they tackle, and not formally innovative enough to make up for that lack of substance.

title: GORBACHEV LENDS HONECKER A HAND
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived in East Berlin today to offer the East German Communists a measured show of solidarity and to declare that Moscow would not interfere in East Germany's problems.

title: C.F.T.C. Bars Restitution Bid
description: Federal futures regulators voted down a proposal today that would have allowed them to force dishonest brokers and traders to pay restitution to the customers they had cheated.

title: Miss Donahue Wed to C. R. C. Kingzett
description: Madeleine Anne Donahue, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Donahue of New York, Litchfield, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Christopher Richard Colin Kingzett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kingzett of London and Cirencester, Gloucestershire, England. The Rev. Richard Foley officiated at the Farm Street Roman Catholic Church in London.

title: Computer Virus Cure May Be Worse Than Disease
description: Ever since a rogue program created by a graduate student jammed a nationwide computer network last year, the rapid spread of such disruptive software, known as viruses, has caused growing alarm among computer users. Now, to fight fire with fire, some companies, individuals and even a Government research laboratory are crafting a new breed of what have been called anti-viruses to hunt down intruders.

title: CYST IS REMOVED FROM BUSH'S HAND
description: In an operation that the White House termed ''entirely successful,'' President Bush underwent a 25-minute procedure this afternoon to remove a cyst from the middle finger of his right hand.

title: 16,000 Detained in Peru
description: The police detained about 16,000 people in a search this week for a television executive kidnapped by gunmen thought to be leftist guerrillas, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry said today. All but 4,000 were released after questioning, the spokesman said. The executive, Hector Delgado Parker, who is a former adviser to President Alan Garcia, was abducted on Wednesday. The police said pamphlets from the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement were found at the site.

title: Iowa Farmers Are Unearthing Clues to Jetliner's Fatal Crash
description: Farmers harvesting their crops are turning up pieces of a jetliner's metal that could help investigators determine what caused a United Airlines DC-10 to crash at Sioux City in July. General Electric has paid $4,700 to five farmers whose harvests turned up such parts.

title: Review/Theater; David and Bathsheba Retold From Different Viewpoint
description: Lounging in a bathrobe and speaking conversationally, the actress Mary Shultz recalls the story of David and Bathsheba. She tells it as her own story, as the victim of a king who seduced her and had her husband killed. As she explains in David Greenspan's ''II Samuel ll, Etc.'' (at Home for Contemporary Theater and Art), she was a woman completely without choice. If Bathsheba did not accede to David's offensive demands, she would have been stoned to death by the people.

title: 80 Arrested in a Los Angeles AIDS Protest
description: Police wearing surgical masks and rubber gloves today arrested 80 demonstrators who blocked the entrance to a Federal office building to protest AIDS drug policies.

title: Lord Einstein Paying WPP $7 Million
description: Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, an advertising agency founded by American executives rebelling against their British parent company, the WPP Group P.L.C., agreed yesterday to pay $7 million to WPP.

title: Patents; Creating New Tomatoes In Test Tube Procedure
description: In their pursuit of better tomatoes, researchers at the DNA Plant Technology Corporation in Cinnaminson, N.J., have patented a method for breeding them.

title: Bulgarian Change Barely Plods Along
description: Although it may be the Soviet Union's most faithful ally in Eastern Europe, Bulgaria has fallen out of its familiar lockstep with Moscow on the question of democratic change for its nine million people.

title: Indian Oboe Music
description: Ustad Bismillah Khan will perform music for the shenhai, an Indian oboe, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, at 8 o'clock tonight. Tickets are $15 to $40. Information: 206-1050.

title: 2 Swiss With Red Cross Are Abducted in Lebanon
description: Two Swiss serving with the International Committee of the Red Cross were kidnapped today by gunmen in the southern port city of Sidon, the police said.

title: Can't Someone Reduce The Mad Din of Sirens?
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Self-Cleaning Hot Tub
description: Murray Altman, owner of a Jacuzzi manufacturing company in Sylmar, Calif., has patented a self-cleaning hot tub. The tub contains a perforated tube that can spray water down the sides. Controlled by a microprocessor, which starts a cleaning cycle after the tub has been drained, the tube first sprays cold water for 30 seconds, then sprays water containing a mixture of detergent, disinfectant and anti-spotting agents for 75 seconds. Mr. Altman's company, Thermasol Ltd. sells the tub for $3,595 under the name Merlin 20001.

title: Jackson Expecting 'Top Echelon' Knick Season
description: After a spirited two-hour workout by the Knicks today, Stu Jackson's first workout as a head coach, the National Basketball Association's youngest coach was asked the obvious question:

title: Perils After Hurricane Strikes Are Stressed in Federal Study
description: Downed power lines after a hurricane are more likely to kill than the fierce winds and sea surges from such storms, according to a Federal study of Hurricane Hugo's thrust across Puerto Rico last month.

title: Good Game, but You Can't Watch
description: There will be no bowl games or live network television appearances this season for Oklahoma and Oklahoma State, two Big Eight Conference powerhouses put on probation last winter by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for numerous recruiting violations.

title: The Hospital Pact Sets No Pattern
description: The new contract settlement negotiated between New York City hospitals and the hospital workers' union is costly to the industry, but fair to the workers. It provides 7.5 percent increases in each of the first two years and 5 percent in the third, with a $500 cash bonus to each worker in 1991. That's a generous wage package, so generous that the leaders of the city's municipal unions will inevitably try to use it as the model for their negotiations with City Hall next year.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5 Israel rejected an Egyptian proposal to convene preliminary Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo as a way of breaking the deadlock on peace efforts. Labor Party officials criticized the rejection. Page 1 The U.S. called Israel's rejection of talks with Palestinians only a temporary setback. Washington officials said they are moving ahead with efforts to organize such a dialogue. 4 Two Swiss with Red Cross are abducted in Lebanon 4 U.N. condemns Israel's tactics in quelling the Arab uprising 4 Hungary's Communists must change, and seek ''a synthesis to be created from the coming together of social democratic and Communist traditions, values and practices,'' a top party leader said. 1 Bulgaria plans to liberalize slowly, officials say. Although they are Moscow's most faithful ally in the Eastern Europe, Bulgarians say the Soviet Union is reshaping itself at an unsafely quick speed. 5 In East Berlin, President Gorbachev demonstrated a measured solidarity with East German Communists, and he declared that Moscow would not interfere with the leadership's problems. 5 Poland details economic change 2 A Panamanian leader took refuge in the Vatican diplomatic mission on Thursday after soldiers ransacked the opposition leader's offices and briefly detained him, diplomats said. 3 Bush, under fire, defends role in Panama crisis 3 Harsud journal: Water, water everywhere? 4 National 6-9, 24 The Senate refused to repeal a law that expands the health benefits for 33 million Medicare beneficiaries. It then voted unanimously to scale back the plan significantly and eliminate the surtax that finances it. 1 Senate roll-call 8 Senators appear to be nearing a deal that would give President Bush the permanent reduction in the capital gains tax that he promised in the 1988 campaign. 1 Factory jobs dropped sharply in September as the nation's unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported. 1 Bonds soar on signs of weaker economy 31 Dow up 11.96 on job data 34 Women's campaign for pay equity is sputtering in the courts but flourishing at the bargaining table. The trend is bringing major pay upgrades to many jobs traditionally held by women. 1 To stop a spread of computer viruses from disrupting computer systems, some programmers are crafting a breed of ''anti-viruses'' to hunt down intruders. Some question the wisdom of these high-tech vigilantes. 1 Smoke suffocated nine old people in Norfolk, Va., after a discarded match or cigarette ignited a rubber mattress in a nursing home, the city's Fire Chief said. 6 Dick Thornburgh flew to Honolulu with five aides last August aboard an otherwise empty 727. The trip occured two months after the Justice Department limited travel. 7 Cyst is removed from President's finger 7 A civil rights panel rebuked its chief, William Barclay Allen, for deciding to appear at a symposium on homosexuality sponsored by an evangelical church group. 6 Louisiana hopes to ban all abortions under an old law that was invalidated by Roe v. Wade. State lawyers went to court to revive the law, which had been seen as one of the nation's harshest. 9 Plutonium escaped into an air duct at one point in the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, and there was enough of it to cause an accidental nuclear reaction, a study said. 6 Downed power lines are more deadly after a hurricane than the fierce winds and sea surges of the hurricane itself, according to a study of Hurricane Hugo in Puerto Rico. 7 Young & Rubicam was indicted along with two of its executives. The agency is charged with using almost $1 million to bribe Jamaican officials to obtain the Jamaica Tourist Board's advertising account in 1981. 31 U.S. journalist cleared in libel suit by former Indian leader 24 Iowa farmers are unearthing clues to jetliner's fatal crash 6 American Airlines company likely to rely on workers' stake 31 Harsh setbacks are forcing new retail owners to sell 31 Regional 25-28 New drug treatment ''campuses'' that would care for more than 1,000 addicts each are expected to be proposed by a state panel. The centers would be situated on state or Federal land. 25 Alcohol is still popular among youths in the suburbs, while crack and other hard drugs have not really penetrated middle-class areas, experts say. But anti-drinking campaigns may be making some progress. 25 A Federal judge is being attacked by Alan Dershowitz, a Harvard law professor. Mr. Dershowitz wants to prevent John Walker, who is President Bush's cousin, from moving up to the Appeals Court in Manhattan. 25 Many potential voters for Giuliani in New York City's mayoral race live in the Douglaston and Little Neck sections of Queens, where registered Democrats have been known to vote Republican. 25 Rudolph Giuliani borrowed $200,000 from the Republican state committee to pay for television commercials, according to his financial report. 27 Candidates parade for Columbus, and stump for votes 27 Five exchanges may leave New York for Jersey City. Seeking more space, the commodity exchanges are talking to city officials on both sides of the Hudson River to see which could provide better inducements. 27 New Jersey is to free 173 suspects from the overcrowded Essex County Jail under a Federal judge's novel order to use taxpayers' funds as bail money. 26 Coal mine strikers in Greenwich? Miners from western Virginia have been marching on downtown Greenwich Avenue to shame a Connecticut-based company. But they do not seem to have had much success. 26 A plan to restrict horse-drawn carriages is vetoed by Koch 28

title: John Daniel Cronin, Broker, 86
description: John Daniel Cronin, a former partner of Eastman Dillon Union Securities in Manhattan, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Blue Jays Rally Against Henderson and A's
description: Stalled in their drive for a first pennant, the Toronto Blue Jays began to put their fortunes into reverse tonight with a come-from-behind 7-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics that was achieved in their trademark manner, with the top on.

title: Suspect in Deaths of Elderly
description: Olian Small, 36 years old, has been charged with attempting a murder last April by tying a knot in the oxygen tube of Helen Ada Potter, an 81-year-old patient at a nursing home where he worked. She died four days later, the authorities said, and Mr. Small was arrested Wednesday evening after he was indicted. The death was not directly attributed to Mr. Small. He is said to have endangered other patients by not giving them medication.

title: Wolf Camp Is 3 Short
description: When the Minnesota Timberwolves, a new franchise in the National Basketball Association, opened training camp in Bloomington, Minn., yesterday, their three selections in the expansion draft - the team's probable starting front court - failed to appear because of contract disputes.

title: Ralph Henderson, 90, Reader's Digest Editor
description: Ralph Ernest Henderson, the creator and first editor in chief of The Reader's Digest Condensed Books, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y., and South Kent, Conn.

title: Colombia Justice Aide Backs Drug Extradition
description: Colombia's new Justice Minister was quoted today as saying that he favors the extradition of drug-trafficking suspects to the United States.

title: Child Is Killed in Car Accident
description: A 15-month-old Brooklyn boy died last night from injuries suffered when his father backed over him with the family car, the police said. The child, Joseph Mandel, was apparently playing in the driveway of his home at 736 East Third Street in the Borough Park section. His father, Samson, did not see him as he was backing his 1977 Pontiac station wagon out of the driveway, a police spokesman, Sgt. Maurice Howard, said. Joseph's death was considered accidental, the police said.

title: Giuliani Reports $200,000 Loan From the G.O.P.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has borrowed $200,000 from the Republican State Committee to pay for television commercials, according to his latest financial report filed yesterday with the city Campaign Finance Board.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday on the success of the Oakland Athletics this season omitted one of the teams on which four pitchers won at least 20 games each in the same season. The Chicago White Sox accomplished it in 1920.

title: U.S. and States Trade Shots In Battle Over Air-Fare Ads
description: The Federal Government may soon approve airline advertising practices that many state officials and consumer advocates say are deceptive or misleading.

title: Questions Are Raised About Thornburgh's Travels
description: Two months after Justice Department budget officials limited official travel to conventions, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and five aides flew to a Bar Association convention in Honolulu in August aboard an otherwise empty Government Boeing 727.

title: Conscience and Law in Yonkers
description: Four members of the Yonkers City Council voted last year to defy the city's agreement to obey a court order remedying 40 years of deliberate housing segregation. They were heavily fined, and have now approached the United States Supreme Court with the argument that a Federal court may not order them to vote a certain way ''at the price of their conscience.''

title: Greenwich Politely Bored at Miners
description: Downtown Greenwich Avenue lies not far from the brambly back-country and the estates that have made this town famous. Like Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills or Worth Avenue in Palm Beach, it's a pricey promenade of boutiques and bistros, where shoppers can walk their Bichons and snack on brioche.

title: Poland Details Economic Change
description: Poland's new Government announced detailed plans today to convert the country to a market economy, warning of tight money, bankruptcy and unemployment along the way but promising to soften the pain with unemployment benefits.

title: ISRAELIS REJECT CAIRO'S PROPOSAL ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: The Israeli Government today rejected an Egyptian proposal to convene preliminary Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo as a way of breaking the deadlock in stalled efforts toward peace.

title: Defendant Acquitted of Rape; 'She Asked for It,' Juror Says
description: Members of a jury here say they acquitted a man of rape because the woman's clothing suggested she had ''asked for it.''

title: Biggio Convicted
description: Craig Biggio, the rookie starting catcher for the Houston Astros, was convicted in Houston yesterday of driving while intoxicated. He was placed on two years' probation, fined $350 and ordered to perform 50 hours of community service. (AP)

title: U.S. Sees Israeli Stance as Temporary
description: Administration officials said today that they view the Israeli Cabinet's rejection of an Egyptian invitation for talks with Palestinians in Cairo as a temporary setback and are moving ahead with efforts to organize such a dialogue.

title: Patents; Alternator Said to Offer More Power
description: At one time, the automobile alternator did not have to do much more than generate electricity for the starter motor and the lights. Then came air-conditioning, 100-watt stereo systems and power for everything, even antennas. Ten years ago, alternators rarely generated more than 50 amperes of current.

title: Cashen's Vote on Manager Decisive
description: The Mets acknowledged yesterday that Davey Johnson had kept his job as manager of the team on a split vote that embroiled senior officials of the club. But they said the deciding vote had been cast by Frank Cashen, the general manager, after he consulted the owners and informed Johnson that ''some things have to change.''

title: Panama Fiasco: The Helms Version
description: Following is an adaptation of a statement made Thursday night in the Senate by Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Many of the assertions below are disputed by the White House.

title: Kevin Albin Wed To Bette Chabot
description: Elizabeth A. Chabot, the advertising manager at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, and Kevin P. Albin, the president of Albin Adventures, a New York video concern, were married yesterday in Toledo, Spain. The Rev. Honorato Ibanes officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of San Juan de los Reyes.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Traffic Safety
description: Busy parents with busy children too often live life on a treadmill. The children need to be transported between home and school and after-school programs in a seemingly never-ending cycle of daily activities that often compete with the parents' own obligations.

title: Frederic de Hoffmann, 65, Dies; Physicist and Salk Institute Chief
description: Frederic de Hoffmann, a nuclear physicist who worked on the Manhattan Project, helped develop the hydrogen bomb and later directed the Salk Institute for Biological Studies for 18 years, died of complications of AIDS Wednesday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 65 years old.

title: Plan to Restrict Carriage Horses Vetoed by Koch
description: A law barring horse-drawn carriages from most of midtown Manhattan was vetoed yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch, who said the legislation ''goes too far.''

title: INSURING CONDOS N HURRICAN ZONES
description: Owners of condominium units in the Southeast and the Caribbean were among those hit hard by Hurricane Hugo. The total damage to insured property came to a record $4.5 billion, and the storm's devastation holds an important insurance lesson for condominium owners in coastal areas.

title: Medicare Winners, and Losers
description: Congress's decision to drastically cut back on valuable benefits of the 1988 catastrophic-health insurance program generated cheers from the well-to-do elderly who opposed the law. They didn't want to pay the surtax that finances it. But curtailing the program also means that millions will lose. In the wake of the defeat, those losers deserve attention.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Flavor of Dried Herbs
description: With the arrival of autumn, the herb garden begins to lose life, and many cooks rely on dried herbs from now until spring. The flavor of some dried herbs is more intense, so they should be substituted in smaller quantities. Other dried herbs lose much of their character. Basil, chervil, coriander leaves and parsley are much better fresh than dried. Bay leaves, on the other hand, should be used only when dried. Buy freshly dried herbs that look green in the bottle. And replace them regularly, even when the bottle is not finished. Here is a guide to how much of a dried herb to use to equal the flavor of a teaspoon of the fresh herb. $ Herb Dried equivalent for 1 teaspoon fresh Chives 1 teaspoon (freeze-dried) Dill 1 teaspoon Marjoram, oregano 1/2 teaspoon Mint 1 teaspoon Rosemary 1/2 teaspoon Sage 1/2 teaspoon Tarragon 1 teaspoon Thyme 1/2 teaspoon

title: Borrowing Rate Up 6% For August
description: Americans took out $3.48 billion more in consumer debt than they retired in August, the Government reported today.

title: Dawson Struggling, but Keeps Swinging
description: Before the second game of the National League pennant playoff with the San Francisco Giants, someone asked Andre Dawson if it was correct that he was the father figure to the younger players in the Chicago Cubs' clubhouse.

title: Plane Crash Kills 4 Aboard
description: A single-engine plane, buffeted by turbulent air, crashed short of the runway at Palm Springs Regional Airport Thursday evening, killing all four people on board. The identities of the victims were not made known. The Federal Aviation Administration and the Riverside County coroner are investigating.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: 1. East Germans who had taken refuge in Prague were required to return to East Germany before going on to West Germany. The device enabled East Berlin to contend that the refugees had first come home, as it had repeatedly demanded of them.

title: 3Com Stock Purchase Seen
description: The 3Com Corporation said today that Digital Communications Associates Inc. intends to purchase 3Com common stock valued in excess of $15 million, but less than 15 percent of the company's outstanding shares.

title: Parading for Columbus, And Stumping for Votes
description: Candidates for Mayor of New York joined the Columbus Day parade up Fifth Avenue yesterday, vying for votes from Italian-Americans and other spectators at a celebration that fell this year neither on the official holiday nor on the anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America, but in the middle of a working day.

title: About New York; Restoring Some Magic To Brooklyn
description: Will Morton 8th blew into town from Colorado about three weeks ago to give Brooklyn back a piece of its own lost magic. He came to restore the carousel in Prospect Park.

title: Sony Donates $3 Million
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan has donated $3 million to the University of Illinois to endow a research and teaching position in electrical and computer engineering. The grant is Sony's largest single gift to a American academic institution. The position is to be named in honor of John Bardeen, an Illinois faculty member. Mr. Bardeen, who worked on the development of the transistor and the theory of superconductivity, won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1956 and 1972.

title: Patricia K. Kirlin, A Reporter, Weds
description: Patricia K. Kirlin, a reporter and researcher at Time magazine in New York, was married yesterday in Exton, Pa., to Robert A. Santella Jr., a financial planner at the Price Waterhouse accounting firm in New York. The Rev. James Flynn officiated at St. Mary's Chapel of SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Santella, 24 years old, is the daughter of the late Sgt. Maj. and Mrs. Edward Kirlin of Brookhaven, Pa. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, as did her husband, and received an M.S. degree in journalism from Columbia University. Her father retired as a command sergeant major in the United States Army.

title: Devils Are Changing for Lemieux
description: Despite the success the Devils had with the 20 players they used in Philadelphia on opening night, look for changes in the lineup for the home opener Saturday night.

title: Dow Up 11.96, to 2,785.52, on Job Data
description: Buoyed by an unexpected increase in unemployment for September and a sharp decline in factory jobs, blue-chip stocks rose to another record yesterday.

title: Arnold Shaw, 80; Wrote Many Books On Popular Music
description: Arnold Shaw, a writer about popular music and the founder of the Popular Music Research Center at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, died of cancer on Sept. 26 at his home in Las Vegas. He was 80 years old.

title: Pay Equity for Women's Jobs Finds Success Outside Courts
description: The campaign for pay equity for women, considered innovative legal theory 10 years ago, is sputtering in court but flourishing at the bargaining table, bringing multimillion-dollar pay upgrades for many jobs.

title: 'Mighty Casey' Opera
description: The American Chamber Opera Company will present ''The Mighty Casey,'' an opera by William Schuman based on the poem by E. L. Thayer, at 8 o'clock tonight at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. The fully staged production is to be conducted by Douglas Anderson. Tickets are $15. Information: 781-0857.

title: Resilient Dollar Up Slightly Despite Efforts to Rein It In
description: The dollar rose slightly yesterday, despite efforts once again by the United States and its economic allies to rein the currency in.

title: Books of The Times; Inside Japan, but Always an Outsider
description: Japan In the Land of the Brokenhearted By Michael Shapiro 245 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: Civil Rights Panel Rebukes Its Chairman
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission today rebuked its chairman for deciding to appear at a symposium on homosexuality sponsored by an evangelical Christian group.

title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers
description: While cocaine has dominated public concern about drug use, alcohol remains the drug of choice among suburban teen-agers, like those in Westchester County.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE EDGES UP TO 5.2%
description: Factory employment took its biggest drop in nearly seven years in September as the nation's unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: To Be Young and in China: A Colloquy
description: The poem seemed to express an individual yearning, a personal agony only tenuously related to the pro-democracy slogans recently heard in China. But Wuer Kaixi, the 21-year-old exiled student leader who read his short verse at a public meeting in lower Manhattan on Wednesday night, said it reflected the inner life of the student uprising, its wellsprings in alienation and thwarted idealism. The verse goes: I pour my heart out to the white cloud, I, the homeless wanderer. O, float back to my native land And drop the tears I shed for my mother.

title: Fed Left Rates Unchanged At August Policy Meeting
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged in late August, after a period earlier in the summer when they were nudging rates lower, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Michael Williams, 74, Cardiologist in Harlem
description: Dr. Michael D. Williams, a cardiologist who practiced in Harlem for more than 40 years, died of complications of heart disease yesterday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Panama Opposition Chief in Refuge in Vatican Mission
description: The leader of Panama's democratic opposition has taken refuge in the Vatican diplomatic mission here, diplomats and supporters said today.

title: Judgments of Barney Frank Are Premature
description: To the Editor:

title: Plutonium Hazard Found at Nuclear Arms Plant
description: Enough plutonium to cause an accidental nuclear reaction escaped unnoticed into an air duct at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, according to an independent study of the plant released yesterday. The report said such a reaction could have occurred under certain circumstances.

title: No Decision Made on New York Income Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Detectors, No Sprinklers The nursing home fire that killed nine people in Norfolk, Va., was started by a cigarette or match that ignited a foam mattress, the fire chief said.

title: The Genius Factor in The Playoffs
description: Geniuses in baseball lead short, bumpy lives. Take Don Zimmer, the manager of the Cubs. One day he is acclaimed the Einstein of the Diamond, the next day he is hailed as one of the seven or eight dumbest people on the face of the earth, and the following day, why, back to genius status again. It's the kind of uneasy existence that can drive a good man to chewing tobacco, which Zimmer does.

title: F.T.C. Clears Ford On Jaguar Stake
description: The Ford Motor Company has received clearance from the United States Federal Trade Commission to buy up to 15 percent of Jaguar P.L.C., a spokesman for Ford's British unit said. Jaguar shares closed $1 higher today, at $11.77, on London's Stock Exchange. Volume was a heavy 13 million shares. It was not immediately clear whether Ford had purchased any Jaguar shares today. It previously owned about 1 percent of the British luxury auto maker.

title: Judge Orders Crowded Jail to Release 173 Suspects
description: Authorities began freeing 173 criminal suspects from the overcrowded Essex County Jail today under a Federal judge's novel order using taxpayers' funds as bail money.

title: U.S. Journalist Cleared of Libel Charge by Indian
description: A jury in Chicago ruled yesterday that Seymour M. Hersh, the investigative journalist, did not libel former Prime Minister Morarji Desai of India when he described him as a paid informer for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Why the Vatican Kept Silent on Nazi Atrocities
description: To the Editor:

title: McNeil, Calming Down, Says He Will Be Ready
description: It has rarely happened before in professional football or any other big league sport: a player accidentally injures another and is so despondent that he is unable to continue in the game.

title: Duke Is Looking Smart in Football, Too
description: The winning tradition dates to another generation. In a region where college sports are an abiding passion, the team often plays before a half-empty home stadium. Any on-field success is overshadowed by the accomplishments and popularity of the school's basketball squad. This year, the program is budgeted to lose $1.8 million.

title: CAMPAIGN STOP: Douglaston-Little Neck, Queens; Amid a Sea of Democrats, Hope for Giuliani
description: The Douglaston and Little Neck sections of Queens look and sound more like New England villages than New York City neighborhoods.

title: SENATE TRIMS BACK MEDICARE ADDITION AND KILLS SURTAX
description: Spurning the lead of the House, the Senate tonight voted against repealing a program providing expanded health benefits to 33 million Medicare beneficiaries. It then voted unanimously to scale back the plan significantly and eliminate the surtax that finances it.

title: Two Burmese Hijack Plane, Then Surrender
description: Two Burmese students who hijacked an airliner to dramatize human rights abuses in their homeland surrendered to the Thai security forces Saturday after a nine-hour standoff.

title: Protesters End Takeover Of Embassy in San Salvador
description: Leftist protesters ended a takeover of the Costa Rican Embassy today, releasing the 12 hostages they had held for a day to protest the rightist Government of President Alfredo Cristiani.

title: Deal May Bring Permanent Cut In the Gains Tax
description: With the blessing of President Bush, the Senate tonight worked toward a deal that may well give Mr. Bush the permanent reduction in the capital gains tax that he promised in the 1988 campaign.

title: The Harsh Lessons of Retailing
description: Nine store chains, including some of the most glittering names in American retailing, have been put up for sale in recent months in what is proving to be a powerful lesson on what can happen when companies with high expectations enter a volatile industry on the verge of a slowdown.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Banister Continental Ltd., Edmonton, Alberta, a pipeline, civil, marine and industrial construction company, said a joint venture in which its Foundation Co. of Canada Ltd. unit has a 45 percent interest had won a $100 million (Canadian) contract from Marathon Realty Co. for the construction of a waterfront project in Vancouver, British Columbia. Cana Construction Co. has a 55 percent stake in the project.

title: Miss Landshof Marries John J. Fath
description: N. Elizabeth Landshof and John J. Fath were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daniel Brady, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: LaRouche Conviction Challenged in Appeal
description: The tax and mail fraud conspiracy conviction of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. was challenged today in a Federal appellate court as resulting from a rush prosecution that violated his right to due process.

title: Big Wilson Dies at 65; Ex-NBC Disk Jockey
description: Malcolm John Wilson Jr., a radio personality known as Big Wilson, died after a heart attack Thursday at a hotel in Selma, N.C. He had observed his 65th birthday this week and was touring the country with his wife, Jody.

title: MGM/UA Awaits Deposit by Qintex
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company said the Qintex Group of Australia, which has agreed to acquire MGM/UA for $1.45 billion, was late delivering a $50 million deposit. The announcement creates new uncertainty about Qintex's ability to raise money for the deal. According to the purchase agreement, MGM/UA, a motion picture producer and distributor, was supposed to receive a nonrefundable $50 million letter of credit from Qintex on Sept. 15, but the money has not arrived.

title: Irving Newman, 74, a Hat Manufacturer
description: Irving Newman, a retired hat manufacturer who served as a neighborhood aide to three New York City mayors, died of a heart attack Thursday at Edward White Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Tampa, Fla.

title: Boeing and McDonnell Get Taiwan Jet Order
description: Evergreen Airways, a new international carrier based in Taiwan, has signed deals with two American jet manufacturers to buy as many as 26 jets worth more than $3.2 billion, the manufacturers said today.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Foyt Leaves Hospital
description: A. J. Foyt, the 54-year-old driver who bruised his neck and chest Tuesday when he crashed into a wall during a stock-car practice session at Charlotte (N.C.) Motor Speedway, was released from Charlotte Memorial Hospital yesterday and left for his home in Houston.

title: Dinkins's '86 Letter to Pierce Helped Save Housing Funds
description: A 1986 letter from Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan to Samuel R. Pierce, then the Federal Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, helped New York City retain $8 million in Federal housing money that it might otherwise have lost.

title: Review/Music; Helmuth Rilling's Philharmonic Debut
description: Bach's Mass in B minor is one of Western music's peaks - some would say the highest. It is also a mountain of contradictions and anomalies. Except at the beginning, it is not in B minor but mostly in D major. It was composed, not as one work, but as four separate ones, each with its own title page. Although its author was a lifelong, unwavering Lutheran, it is a mass that is true in all but a couple of minor instances to the Roman Catholic liturgy. Although arguably the greatest mass ever written, it is too long and too difficult to have been meant for practical church use. A fair suspicion is that Bach never expected to have the work performed as a whole, intending it as a craftsman's summation of what he could do in the ancient idiom.

title: Frederick Wiseman's 'Near Death'
description: ''Your lungs are about as bad as they can get,'' the nurse explains to the 83-year-old man. ''Your lungs aren't going to get better, and so the act of putting you on the machine is almost a futile effort.'' In a long conversation, the nurse lets this patient know what his options are and tries to determine his wishes, as kindly as possible but with the suggestion that she has done this many times before. ''I want to help you, but I only want to help you in the manner in which you want to be helped,'' she says. ''I don't want to keep you alive unless you like living.''

title: In Budapest, a Toast to Marx's Death
description: LEAD: In trying to rally support, a bloodless revolution, like the one in Hungary, suffers from a terrible handicap. Reforms announced with the regularity of mail delivery do not explode with the same impact as Molotov cocktails. Barriers against the free flow of ideas, when tumbled, do not crash as forcefully upon Washington's consciousness as collapsing barricades.

title: Bush, Under Fire, Defends Role in Panama Crisis
description: President Bush today defended his decision not to allow American military forces to bolster a coup attempt in Panama on Tuesday against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ''I think the record will show that there was never a chance to have him handed over to us,'' the President said of the Panamanian leader.

title: KEY RATES
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS U.S. Gains Semifinals: The top-seeded United States team will meet Czechoslovakia and Spain will face Australia today in the semifinals of the Federation Cup tournament in Tokyo. The United States beat eighth-seeded Austria, 3-0, and No. 3 Czechoslovakia defeated fifth-seeded West Germany, 2-1, yesterday in the quarterfinals.(AP) Woodforde Upsets Jelen: Third-seeded Eric Jelen of West Germany was upset by Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Queensland Open in Brisbane, Australia.(AP) GOLF Rizzo Leads by One: Patti Rizzo fired a five-under par 67 yesterday and took a one-stroke lead over Ayako Okamoto of Japan after two rounds of the Takara Invitational tournament in Gamou, Japan.(AP) Azinger Shoots a 62: Paul Azinger shot an eight-under-par 62 yesterday for a three-shot lead over Donnie Hammond midway through the Texas Open in San Antonio.(AP) Player Takes Lead: Gary Player played the front side in six-under-par 29 yesterday at the RJR Championship in Clemmons, N.C., and wound up with a 65 for a two-stroke first-round advantage in the Senior PGA event.(AP) HARNESS RACING Peace Corps Wins Kentucky Futurity: Peace Corps won the Kentucky Futurity at the Red Mile yesterday, the third race in trotting's triple crown. Driven by John Campbell, she won the third heat in 1:54 2/5, eclipsing Mack Lobell's stakes record of 1:55 set in 1987 and equaled last year by Huggie Hanover.(AP) HOCKEY Capitals 5, Flyers 3: Dale Hunter and Mike Ridley scored midway through the second period to give Washington a season-opening victory in Landover, Md.

title: Jane Austen's Siblings
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Home Blaze in Which 9 Died Is Believed Due to a Careless Smoker (Associated Press)
description: A fire that killed 9 people at a nursing home here and sent nearly 100 to the hospital was caused by a discarded match or cigarette that ignited a rubber mattress, Norfolk's Fire Chief said today.

title: Key Hungarian Communist Urges More Open Party and Ties to West
description: One of the four top leaders of the Hungarian Communist Party told his comrades at a party congress today that they had to change their basic orientation.

title: Ashland Pays Iran
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said it had paid the National Iranian Oil Company $325 million and would charge the payment against results for the year ended Sept. 30. The payment was made under an agreement announced last month that settled all disputes and litigation between the two companies, Ashland said. The Iranian company had been seeking $768 million because an Ashland unit had refused to pay for crude oil in 1979.

title: Review/Television; Walter Cronkite Narrates 'Can't Afford to Grow Old'
description: ''Can't Afford to Grow Old'' gets at the heart of a heartbreaking reality. Elderly people, afflicted with Alzheimer's disease or the effects of strokes or other lingering disabilities, must exhaust their life's savings as well as the energies and emotions of their husbands, wives and children before the Government offers help -and then only in the form of a bed in a nursing home.

title: Walker Rejects Vikings
description: Now that Kevin Mack, their chief running back, has been sentenced to six months in jail after pleading guilty to a drug-abuse charge, the Cleveland Browns are in the market for a quality runner. They would take someone like Herschel Walker of the Dallas Cowboys, the All-Pro whom they admit to having made inquiries about.

title: We Need Many More Computer Scientists
description: To the Editor:

title: An Elegy to Balanchine, The Choreographer of Lives
description: ''Dancing for Mr. B: Six Balanchine Ballerinas'' is as graceful, taut and fiercely controlled as the dancers who are its subjects. In the opening scene, Darci Kistler - at 25 years of age the youngest of them - recalls that as an adolescent she read that Balanchine selected a perfume for each of his dancers. ''I thought it was wonderful that there was a man who cared that much,'' she says, setting the tone for Anne Belle's and Deborah Dickson's documentary. This is not a study of the great choreographer and the guiding spirit behind the New York City Ballet, but a portrait of women who feel privileged to have been shaped by him.

title: Robert Ashmore, 85, Former Congressman
description: Robert T. Ashmore, a former member of the House of Representatives from South Carolina, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital in Greenville, S.C., where he lived. He had undergone open heart surgery last summer and was suffering from pneumonia and kidney failure. He was 85 years old.

title: Soviets Buy More Corn
description: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 400,000 metric tons of American corn to the Soviet Union for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The corn sale was the third this week to the Soviet Union. It has orders totaling 2.6 million tons of corn and 100,000 tons of soybean meal.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Florida Supreme Court decision striking down an abortion law incorrectly reported that the teen-ager who was the subject of the case had obtained her father's permission to have an abortion.

title: Ad Agency Indicted in Bribe Case
description: In the first criminal indictment of an advertising agency under Federal racketeering laws, Young & Rubicam was charged yesterday with bribing Jamaican officials with almost $1 million to obtain the Jamaica Tourist Board's advertising account in 1981.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It cannot be Communist, and it cannot be simply a social democratic party. We should seek a synthesis to be created from the coming together of social democratic and Communist traditions, values and practices.'' - Rezso Nyers, president of the Hungarian Communist Party. [ 1:3. ]

title: Fignon Drug Results
description: Laurent Fignon, the French cyclist who won the 1983 and 1984 Tour de France races, tested positive for a banned stimulant after a race in the Netherlands, the French Federation of Cycling said yesterday.

title: Kemp Promises Action to House Homeless
description: On the eve of a planned march of tens of thousands of people demonstrating for decent and affordable housing, the Bush Administration promised today ''to win this war against poverty, homelessness and despair.''

title: Deficit Expected By Daisy Systems
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, a maker of computer-aided engineering systems, said it would report an operating loss for the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30, as revenues fell substantially below the third quarter's $44.9 million. The company said, ''These results, together with the absence of additional financing, have caused a significant liquidity problem.''

title: Beethoven Series Opens Wednesday at 92d St. Y
description: The violinist Young Uck Kim and the pianist Peter Serkin will perform the complete Beethoven violin sonatas on three consecutive Wednesday evenings starting next week at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Federal Negotiator Joins City Opera Strike Talks
description: Negotiations continued yesterday in an effort to break the deadlock between the New York City Opera and its orchestra, which struck the company on Sept. 13.

title:
TOMORROW'S NEW YORK; The Next Mayor - An Occasional Series;
The Race Issue Won't Die in November
description: LEAD: As the heat rises in the mayoral campaign, Rudolph Giuliani should remember one thing:

title: The Town That Determination Is Building Again
description: FALL in Bantam is not the same this year. People here have put aside such customary pursuits as apple gathering and leaf peeping as they continue to rebuild from the wreckage of a tornado in July. Residents still have leaves to rake, but they also have piles of downed trees and uprooted stumps to clear.

title: Put Limits on Death Compensation
description: Much has been written recently about the adverse impact on American industry and society of skyrocketing verdicts (and settlements in fear of such verdicts) for personal injuries and deaths in tort cases.

title: Bulk for Benefits
description: To The Editor:

title: Correction
description: The Prospects column on Sept. 24 about the Ford Motor Company's proposed acquisition of a stake in Jaguar referred incorrectly to a comment from Charles M. MacDonald, an executive of the Jaguar Clubs of North America, on the status of Jaguar's racing team. He said Jaguar sponsors two racing teams, one in the United States and another in Europe.

title: Bastille Opera Manager
description: Georges-Francois Hirsch, the general director of the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in Paris, has been named general administrator of the Opera Bastille, the administrative council of the opera has announced. Mr. Hirsch, whose nomination was proposed by Pierre Berge, the council's president, is to take over the post immediately, but will remain as head of the Champ-Elysees theater until the end of the 1989-90 season.

title: Running as a G.O.P. Crime Buster: Can Giuliani Match Dewey?
description: The Republican candidate, a celebrated prosecutor, faced a daunting task. There were 563,000 registered Democrats in New York City and only 122,000 enrolled Republicans. He had never run for elective office before, and many wondered whether he could make the transition from intense courtroom pyrotechnics to the more relaxed glad-handing of the campaign trail.

title: Terri Siegel Marries
description: Last evening in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza in New York, Terri Aileen Siegel, the daughter of Marilyn Siegel of Long Beach, L.I., and Irving Siegel of Kings Point, L.I., was married to Dr. Jed Craig Kaminetsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kaminetsky of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Morris Friedman officiated. Mrs. Kaminetsky is an associate at the New York law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon. The bridegroom is a chief resident in urologic surgery at New York University Medical Center.

title: Brand-Name Bargains for Columbus Day
description: The Columbus Day sales that are under way signal the traditional start of the fall merchandise markdowns. This year, some experts say, a shake-up in the retailing business may give shoppers new opportunities to save money, especially on clothing.

title: The End of Pegasus
description: Television has provided the world with many remarkable images over the years, but none more beautiful than that of a horse named Secretariat winning the Belmont Stakes.

title: Software Backlash
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE AMONG THE DEMI-CELEBS
description: SMILE, HONEY By Anabel Donald. 256 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT
description: REAL FARM: Encounters With Perception. By Patricia Tichenor Westfall. (New Chapter Press, $14.95.) ''Real Farm'' is the affecting and frequently humorous memoir of an urbane college professor who fell in love with life on an Iowa farm, while simultaneously falling out of love with her husband, a doctoral student at the University of Iowa to whom she gives the pseudonym Mark in this volume. A cramped housing market led the couple to buy a 20-acre farm, which immediately evoked their enthusiasm for all things agrarian. Gardens were planted. Chickens, goats and two quarreling geese were brought on board. The book provides many amusing vignettes of city folk adapting to farm life. Yet there is a somber tone to all this. The reader is uncomfortably aware that this marriage is ill fated. Initially, the challenges of the farm united the couple; then, inevitably, accentuated their differences. Patricia Tichenor Westfall, a self-proclaimed pragmatist, labels her husband an impractical idealist. The reader, caught up in the battle, may pity Mark not only for his bumbling zealotry (he spent many hours digging deep, useless holes in the garden), but also for his being so severely reduced in dimension. In due course the couple separated, and Ms. Westfall, alone on the farm, became adept in the mysteries of plumbing and the felling of trees, leaving herself a few hours now and then to contemplate the nature of time and the symbolism of dreams. Ultimately Ms. Westfall, broke and unable to obtain a loan, was forced to sell the farm. But her experiences, described so vividly in this entertaining little book, gave her an enduring knowledge of her own strengths and limitations.

title: First Lessons
description: THE first weeks of school have come and gone for our 6-year-old daughter, weeks full of the kinds of experiences that shower down upon us as parents like shards of glass from a seemingly once-perfect globe. ''The boys wouldn't listen to the teacher again.'' ''Some boys climbed up on the desks and threw papers and books on the floor.'' ''The teacher punished the whole class for what some bad boys did.'' ''On the bus a boy pulled my hair and I did my best not to cry.''

title: Inquiry Intensifies on H.U.D.
description: LEAD: AS Jack Kemp, Housing and Urban Development Secretary, announced reforms last week to end political favoritism in Federal housing programs, accusations about abuses of such programs on Long Island continued to resound.

title: Of Cats and Frogs And Lessons
description: I was truly impressed with Maggie McCool's pro-animal position until I read of her 16 cats (''A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned,'' Aug. 27). The photograph of her with one of her cats showed no evidence of a bell or other device that would warn prey of a cat's presence. Apparently, Ms. McCool's animal advocacy extends only to creatures she favors, e.g., frogs, but not to those whose deaths she may not notice.

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: IT WAS A PERFECT PLACE FOR AN EPIPHANY. THE SCENE WAS near St. Brygida's Church in Gdansk, the spiritual home of Poland's Solidarity movement. The date was May 25, 1989, the occasion the annual Corpus Christi procession. Among those leading the 25,000 marchers were Lech Walesa and Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the Polish-born American woman who inherited much of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune.

title: Trimming the Fat From School Costs
description: Right on, Mr. Gerber! (''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education,'' Opinion, Sept. 24). I am a founder of the East Northport-Northport School Tax Watch and believe he hit the target. Our district still has 10 schools and half the students of a decade ago. We have one superintendent and three assistant supers. We have just given the teachers' union approximately an 8 percent increase for the next three years. The average salary is around $40,000 and it costs about $11,000 to educate each student.

title: Warrior Comeback
description: Five times he was a National Basketball Association All-Star and once he was voted the league's comeback player of the year. Now Marques Johnson is attempting another comeback that he hopes will lead to a starting role, if not an All-Star one, with the Golden State Warriors. The 6-foot-7-inch Johnson, an unrestricted free agent, signed a one-year contract with the Warriors yesterday.

title: Furniture With Artistic Stature
description: LEAD: SPICING the home furnishings scene is a trend toward collecting art that is utilitarian. In ''Decorative Concepts,'' an exhibition on view through Nov. 19 at the Elements Gallery in Greenwich, 19 artists, working in a broad range of mediums, create objects that elevate home furnishings to the status of art.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Prepare Tender Bulbs for Storage
description: LEAD: WHILE it is usually best to wait until frost to dig tender bulbs, tubers and corms for winter storage, it can be done at any time after the tops have begun to dry. It is important that they be properly prepared for storage, if they are to survive the winter in good condition.

title: Close, But No Marriage
description: Sandra Jennings said that she and William Hurt (below, second from right) were married ''in the eyes of God,'' but the law looks at things differently.
