A Manhattan Civil Court judge ruled last week that the weeks Ms. Jennings spent living with the actor while he was filming ''The Big Chill'' (below) in South Carolina seven years ago did not constitute a legal marriage. Ms. Jennings's lawyer, Richard Golub, argued that Mr. Hurt and his client were common-law spouses under a South Carolina law. That would have entitled Ms. Jennings to a share of the actor's income. But Judge Jacqueline Silberman said they had not presented themselves as married and had not generally been viewed as such. The ruling did not affect Mr. Hurt's support payments - $65,000 a year - for the couple's 6-year-old son. Mr. Golub vowed to appeal, saying, ''Let five judges who are all men decide, not one woman who is impressed by a movie star.''

title: THE SHRINK ON THE COUCH
description: Barbara Hey has some uneducated theories about psychotherapy (''The Shrink on the Couch,'' April 16). First of all, a good therapy depends as much on the patient as it does on the therapist. A brilliant therapist cannot ''cure'' a resistant patient, and a patient who wants to be cured more than anything else could probably do so with a less-than-brilliant therapist. Secondly, any good therapist will always answer questions honestly. If the question is a request for self-disclosure, the therapist is duty-bound to make sure his or her response will not affect the patient in a negative way. Thirdly, Freud did many things that Freudians now say are wrong to do, but it is the present-day Freudians who made up many of the rules, not Freud himself. JACQUELINE FLEISCHER Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: On the Street; Briefcases: Post-Punk To High Tech
description: The briefcase, once a symbol of staid, business-as-usual efficiency, has been lightened up considerably for the computer generation. It now comes with such distinctive decorative touches as high-tech metal strips and clasps, telephone-receiver handles and dials on the flaps, the sort of latch closings normally used on seagoing vessels, even mail slots on the side.

title: A Jazzman's Fountain of Youth
description: In the family of jazz, parents have insulted children nearly as often as embraced them. For every Coleman Hawkins playing sideman to Thelonious Monk, there was Louis Armstrong denouncing be-bop as ''Chinese music.'' For every Duke Ellington recording duets with John Coltrane, there was Roy Eldridge branding Ornette Coleman a fake. Even in the last decade's increased collaborations between modernists and more traditional stylists, time travel has proceeded mostly in only one direction, with the contemporary generation reaching back.

title: THE MAN WHO MADE NEWS
description: BENNETT'S NEW YORK HERALD AND THE RISE OF THE POPULAR PRESS By James L. Crouthamel. 202 pp. Syracuse, N.Y.: Syracuse University Press. $27.95.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
The War Against the Moths
description: LEAD: MY philosophy about getting my house ready for winter is twofold: A. If I postpone it long enough, maybe I'll move. B. If God meant us to put our outdoor furniture away, would He have invented six-inch snowfalls to cover everything?

title: Democrats Claim Success in Drug Policy
description: With the Senate's approval of an ambitious anti-drug bill, Democratic leaders say they succeeded in defining significant differences with President Bush in the war against drugs.

title: THE A.C.L.U.'S POLICIES
description: The A.C.L.U. supports restrictions against the production of child pornography. However, it opposes legal strictures against the distribution of child pornography. An analogy might be that it is illegal to produce cocaine, but if law enforcement is evaded at the production stage, it should be perfectly legal to sell cocaine.

title: Ogrodnick Shines in Revival
description: It is tough to forget the past when everything you do requires you to explain it all over again. So for John Ogrodnick, every success brings another encounter with past failures.

title: Its Foliage Beckoning, Rockefeller Park Is Ready for Crowds
description: LEAD: WORKMEN laying underground electric and telephone lines last week from Sleepy Hollow Road to the site of a planned visitors' center at the Upper Rockefeller State Park Preserve had only to look up to know that big change was in the air.

title: TAKING OFF THE WHITE GLOVES
description: Why did it take the overseas arrival of Elle to send publisher S. I. Newhouse Jr. racing up and down the halls at Vogue, tearing apart the magazine (''Taking Off the White Gloves,'' by Gigi Mahon, Sept. 10)? A leisurely stroll in the offices of his own striking and unusual foreign editions might have inspired Mr. Newhouse to encourage a bold, new American Vogue, long before the 1985 ''surprise attack'' of Elle. A. BRODY New Brunswick N.J.

title: Labs for Kenilworth; Enlarging the Medicine Chest
description: New Jersey has long considered itself the ''medicine chest to the nation'' because of the large number of pharmaceutical companies based there. Schering-Plough Corporation, with headquarters in Madison, is one of them, and the expansion of its research facility in Kenilworth will no doubt help the state hold the title.

title: Miss Donahue, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: At the Church of Our Savior in New York, Mary Lee Donahue, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Floyd Joseph Donahue of Westfield and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to William Herron Trousdale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer B. Trousdale of St. Paul. Msgr. Thomas A. Kleissler performed the Roman Catholic ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Frank McNulty. Mrs. Trousdale, 28 years old, is an associate at the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells. She graduated from Northwestern University. She and her husband, a graduate of Georgetown University, both received law degrees from Georgetown.

title: Penn State Hands Rutgers Its First Loss
description: The heart of this year's Penn State team is its defense, which shut down Rutgers today at Giants Stadium and helped the Nittany Lions win, 17-0, before a crowd of 52,688.

title: Mutilating the World
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hospital Workers Are The Envy of Labor Now
description: WITH a sophisticated strategy that even its opponents agree was carried out to near perfection, New York City's major health-care workers' union gained a victory last week that many experts say provides the nation's labor movement with a badly needed ray of hope.

title: Henderson Steals Show With 2 Homers
description: Rickey Henderson did not steal a base today. There was little need.

title: On the Road, Radio Echoes The Landscape
description: One of the pleasures of driving long distances through America - a pleasure that this bus- and subway-bound New Yorker gets to experience all too infrequently - is the rediscovery of popular music on the car radio.

title: Baseball Helps U.S. Look Back
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Karen I. Eaton Is Married to Robert A. Raidt Jr.
description: Karen I. Eaton, a daughter of John P. Eaton of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Dorothy P. Eaton, was married yesterday to Robert A. Raidt Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raidt of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. James Bergin performed the ceremony at St. Peter the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Amagansett, L.I.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; An Off-Key Tremor in Darien's Even Tenor
description: THE even tenor of life in Darien - a community known for its low profile, high incomes and relative freedom from commercial development - has been fractured for months by disputes over two pieces of property, one marked for low-income housing, the other a movie theater expansion, and by other indicators of change.

title: REFERENCE
description: THE NORTON/GROVE CONCISE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MUSIC. Edited by Stanley Sadie with Alison Latham. (Norton, $40.) Concise here really means concise. Information from the 20 volumes of ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'' has been abstracted into bare-bones, succinct entries for this big one-volume reference book. Naturally there can be none of the detailed musicology that has gone into the parent volumes. But for those needing a handy book in order to look up something about music quickly without keeping an entire library on the shelves, ''The Norton/Grove Concise Encyclopedia of Music'' will take care of the situation. It is also a lovely printing job: good paper, legible type, intelligent layout. There are diagrams, drawings, tables and a few musical examples (see, for instance, the entries on intervals, key signature and note values). Leafing through the pages one can also find such unexpected entries as lindy, Minute Waltz - ''so called because it can be played (too fast) in one minute'' - and Kool Jazz Festival. The musical terms are given tersely, without frills: ''Diminished seventh chord. A chord consisting of three superimposed minor 3rds (e.g. B-D-F-A flat).'' The major composers each get three or four columns, in which their lives and works are boiled down in virtuoso examples of condensation. There are also abbreviated lists of their works, including dates of composition. The latest musicological findings are of course incorporated. In the Mozart listing there is none of the old sentimental nonsense about his poverty. ''He always earned, by musicians' standards, a good income, and had a carriage and servants; through lavish spending and poor management he suffered times of financial difficulty and had to borrow.'' The book has been scrupulously proofread. In the first edition of a volume of this scope, minor mistakes and typographical errors are bound to creep in. The editor, Stanley Sadie, a former critic for The Times of London, begs all readers who encounter errors to write in so that they can be eliminated from future editions. O.K. Here's one. Under the listing of Xaver Scharwenka, a piano concerto in A flat minor is mentioned. Aside from the fact that there is no such key as A flat minor, the concerto is in B flat minor (and correctly listed as such in ''New Grove'').

title: Jonathan Marvel Weds Quina Fonseca
description: Quina Fonseca, a daughter of Elizabeth K. Fonseca of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Venice and of Gonzalo Fonseca of New York and Seravezza, Italy, was married yesterday to Jonathan Jova Marvel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Marvel of San Juan, P.R., and Bear Island, Me. The Rev. Thomas Pike, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the East Hampton home of the bride's grandmother Alice M. Kaplan.

title: A TV Gamble Hedges Its Bets
description: Rick Kaplan, the executive producer of ''Prime Time Live,'' the highly conspicuous new ABC News program starring Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer, has been wearing a soft cast on his right arm to protect a chronically sore elbow. He did not injure the arm trying to pat himself on the back. Though confident about the long-term future of his program, which has been given a two-year commitment from the network, and proud of most of its work so far, Mr. Kaplan acknowledged that ''Prime Time Live'' is going through a ''frustrating time.''

title:
GARDENING;
How to Prepare Tender Bulbs for Storage
description: LEAD: WHILE it is usually best to wait until frost to dig tender bulbs, tubers and corms for winter storage, it can be done at any time after the tops have begun to dry. It is important that they be properly prepared for storage, if they are to survive the winter in good condition.

title: Iran Hangs 31 Traffickers
description: Iran hanged 31 people for drug smuggling today in a continuing crackdown that has sent over 800 traffickers to the gallows this year, the Teheran radio said. Ten of them, including a woman, were executed at Qasr prison in Teheran for distributing opium and heroin and for possessing firearms.

title: Men's Transitional Coats: Light, Warm and Stylish
description: Blustery, unpredictable fall weather calls for a transition coat, something between an overcoat and a raincoat. Such a garment should take a man from a rainy train platform in the morning to a sunny lunchtime walk to a chill, dark evening after working late. Preferably, of course, in style.

title: Arts and Crafts Born of an Antimachine Ethic
description: What is a Morris chair? Which came first - the spindle-back designs of Gustav Stickley or those of Frank Lloyd Wright? How affordable were Arts and Crafts furnishings originally?

title: REFERENCE
description: THE JOYS OF YINGLISH. By Leo Rosten. (McGraw-Hill, $29.95.) Your strict lexicographer may question whether there is a real need for ''The Joys of Yinglish,'' the newest opus - one is tempted to say eppes - from the prolific Leo Rosten. Mr. Rosten's earlier lexicons, ''The Joys of Yiddish'' and ''Hooray for Yiddish,'' covered Mom-and-Pop Yiddish. This new one concentrates on pop Yiddish, the curious, perhaps even overwhelming, influence the language of the eastern European Jews has exerted on the modern version of the language of the Anglo-Saxons. Need-shmeed, it is a wonderful book. Mr. Rosten, who includes entries from his previous books, not only attests to words and usages that have entered the language (English, that is), but makes recommendations for those he thinks should be admitted. This is no cockamamie collection thrown together by a shlump, but a serious reference work by a maven. Serious? You should have a lifetime so serious. Each entry is accompanied by either an explanation or an illustrative joke (the jokes outnumber the exegeses), and even the ones you know come across lightly and brightly. This reviewer began making notes on passages that were particularly striking, but gave it up when he found he was copying the whole book. Among the expressions that have struck Mr. Rosten's eye and ear are ''Alice Island'' (the one the immigrants arrived at); ''bite your tongue''; farpatshket (''all messed up''); ''excuse the expression''; and, of course, oy. Mr. Rosten is a disarmingly amiable writer, a scholarly polemicist for his thesis. One wonders how English ever expressed itself before Yiddish arrived at the gates. As Will Shakespeare might have observed, ''Now you tell me?'' As you can see, ''The Joys of Yinglish'' is good merchandise. After all, McGraw-Hill is no schlock house. So, enough already.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; Troubled Dorm Offers Support For Minorities
description: The University of Massachusetts at Amherst, a focal point for racial unrest in recent years, has turned a residence hall with a history of bias incidents into a place with a support system for minority students.

title: Thousands March on Washington In Protest Against Homelessness
description: Tens of thousands of people marched on the Capitol today to protest the shortage of decent, affordable housing.

title: Of Cats and Frogs and Lessons
description: Huzzahs to Maggie McCool for not losing her ''cool'' about repercussions on her distaste of brutifying biology.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A knee injury will keep Boris Becker out of this week's Australian Indoor championships. . . . Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion; Mark Calcavecchia, the British Open champion, and Nick Faldo, the Masters champion, have all entered next month's Australian Open golf tournament . . . Mike McCallum's defense of his World Boxing Association middleweight championship against Michael Watson of Britain has been moved up from Dec. 9 to Nov. 29 and will be held in London instead of Manchester, England.(AP)

title: Miss Brittingham Weds L. C. Davis
description: Paget Brittingham, the daughter of Mrs. Richard A. Nielsen of Greenville, Del., and Baird C. Brittingham of Trappe, Md., was married yesterday to Lewis Caldwell Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Hornor Davis 3d of Charleston and White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville.

title: The Tax Breaks America Couldn't Give Up
description: THE brief experiment in tax reform seems to be coming to an end. The three-year-old law, the dream of generations of academic experts, has fallen victim to political reality - a new President who wants to use the tax code to meet economic and social goals, powerful interests that lobby for favorable tax treatment and Americans' pervasive conviction that they are overtaxed.

title: THE MAN-WOMAN THING
description: LIGHT By Seymour Epstein. 282 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: Thruway to Use Drug Patrols in Westchester
description: In a move intended partly to stem the growing flow of drugs to upstate New York, the state police are about to begin a program to apprehend drug-impaired drivers along the Westchester County stretches of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway system.

title: Record of 'Thin Blue Line' Conviction Stands
description: A judge has denied Randall Dale Adams's request to expunge the records of his conviction in a 1977 murder case.

title: Renewing the Ritual of Making Cider
description: LEAD: THE rumble of 30 bushels of apples tumbling down a chute is met by the roar of a mill that grinds them to the consistency of applesauce. Shouting to be heard above the din, Robert Best told a visitor that the ground fruit would be sent spurting through a hand-held plastic hose onto cloth-lined racks.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Food by Phone

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE STATUE WITHIN: An Autobiography, by Francois Jacob. Translated by Franklin Philip. (Basic Books, $10.95.) In helping to discover how cells turn their genes on and off, generating the proper proteins, Francois Jacob learned that science was a ''constant dialogue between imagination and experiment that allowed one to form an increasingly fine-grained conception of what is called reality.'' Last year our reviewer, Peter Brooks, said that ''Mr. Jacob has written an autobiography that is not only literate but positively literary, shot through with reminiscences of classical French authors, skillfully plotted and elegantly written.'' THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED: Book Three of the Vampire Chronicles, by Anne Rice. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The mother vampire of them all awakens from a 6,000-year-old sleep with a plan to bring peace on earth by killing most of the men. Last year our reviewer, Eric Kraft, said Anne Rice is such a good writer that he wishes she would write about something other than bloodsuckers. ''She has a masterly way with language, works on a broad canvas, has a vast range of knowledge, brings exotic settings vividly to life and is wonderfully clever, but these gifts are wasted on vampires. May she find subjects worthy of her talents before these dead guys suck her dry.'' For people who are perfectly happy that Ms. Rice and a bewildering number of other authors have devoted themselves to this genre, Penguin has published THE PENGUIN BOOK OF VAMPIRE STORIES ($8.95). Edited by Alan Ryan, it includes 32 stories and annotated listings of vampire novels and movies. JUDAH P. BENJAMIN: The Jewish Confederate, by Eli N. Evans. (Free Press/Macmillan, $12.95.) Serving Jefferson Davis as Attorney General, Secretary of War and Secretary of State, Judah P. Benjamin has been called the Confederate Kissinger. Last year our reviewer, Arthur Hertzberg, said this fact-filled biography ''retells the story of Benjamin's career very well, and it tries hard to bring the private man to life.'' S., by John Updike. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) A woman named Sarah flees her upper-middle-class life in Boston and takes over a commune in Arizona. ''Mr. Updike is predictably dazzling in his mimicry of an intelligent, witty, articulate woman with the fullest possible storehouse of gripes and perceptions about the role of women in contemporary America,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ISRAEL'S FATEFUL HOUR, by Yehoshafat Harkabi. Translated by Lenn Schramm. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) A former intelligence adviser to several Prime Ministers argues that unless Israel gets out of the occupied territories and negotiates with the Palestine Liberation Organization, the country may destroy itself from within. The author's ''clearsightedness and toughness place him among Israel's pre-eminent soldier-scholars,'' David K. Shipler said here last year. ''This is very strong stuff, and the author delivers his verdicts in icy, merciless language.'' THE BIRTH DEARTH, by Ben J. Wattenberg. (Pharos, $11.95.) A senior fellow of the American Enterprise Institute worries that people like himself - civilized Westerners - are not having enough babies. ''There is something compelling about the rock-hard demographic facts that provide the basis of his speculation,'' Tamar Jacoby said here last year. But he has ''stretched and teased his genuinely unsettling message almost beyond what it can bear.'' SCENES FROM THE HOMEFRONT, by Sara Vogan. (Bantam, $7.95.) In one of these short stories a woman waiting for her husband to return from Central America falls in love with a Japanese crane she discovers in the backyard. ''If you love the National Geographic or Natural History magazine or the wildlife shows on PBS, you'll be entranced at how Ms. Vogan uses the intricacies of the natural world to bolster, inform, explore and create an external validation for the lives of her characters,'' Molly Peacock said here in 1987. STALAG LUFT III: The Secret Story, by Arthur A. Durand. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) An Air Force colonel pieces together the facts about daily life in the German prisoner-of-war camp that provided the inspiration for the movie ''The Great Escape.'' The story is ''ably detailed in graphic and gracious prose in this first-class book,'' David Murray said here last year. TWILIGHT, by Elie Wiesel. Translated by Marion Wiesel. (Warner, $9.95.) On a visit to a mental hospital in upstate New York, a Holocaust survivor and student of the kabbala finds madmen who are also prophets. Last year our reviewer, Stanley Moss, said, ''We accept Mr. Wiesel as Prospero the magician, even if at times he reminds us of a Jewish Polonius, because when his imagination really takes flight, and he takes on the role of a Jewish Ariel, we celebrate.'' CHILD STAR: An Autobiography, by Shirley Temple Black. (Warner, $5.95.) The actress who began her career at age 3 and retired at 22 tells her life story. Last year The Times's Aljean Harmetz said ''the book is candid, clear-eyed, a social history of Hollywood between the Depression and World War II, with an M-G-M producer, Arthur Freed, exposing himself to the 12-year-old Shirley at the same time his boss, L. B. Mayer, was pulling her mother down on his white couch.'' WESTERN SWING, by Tim Sandlin. (Ivy, $3.95.) A pulp novelist's search for transcendence is causing problems between him and his wife, a country-and-western singer named Lana Sue. ''Mr. Sandlin's twangy pedal-steel prose may not haunt you, but it certainly keeps your toe tapping,'' Margo Kaufman said here last year.

title: Taylor Adds Thoughtfulness to List of Football Skills
description: He may be the most gifted player in the history of pro football: big, fast, intense, incredibly quick, incredibly explosive. He may be the best outside linebacker ever, and his pass-rushing skills have redefined the position.

title: Ribbon Speakers Have The Virtue of Clarity
description: Perhaps it is the ultimately fantastic notion of an inanimate object making music. Perhaps it is the challenge of constructing a device that imitates all musical instruments and any human voice. At any rate, there is something about loudspeakers that stirs the engineering mind and results in a perennial parade of novel and frequently offbeat designs.

title: Mary N. Tobias Marries
description: Mary Norwood Tobias, an interior designer in New York, and Richard Edward Miller, a vice president in Philadelpia of Goldman, Sachs & Company, were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Church in Columbia, S.C. The Rev. Mark P. Geary, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated. The bride, 32 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lanty Mimnaugh Tobias of Columbia. Mr. Miller, 32, is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Albert Miller of Waterbury, Conn.

title: Food; Apple Polishing
description: BLACK GILLIFLOWER, WHITE WINTER PEARMAIN, Esopus Spitzenburg, St. Edmund's Pippin . . . the names of these old apples trip off my tongue with pleasure. Now affectionately called antique apples, many of the varieties that were grown before the Civil War are being revived. Alas, they are not as beautiful as their names; the fruit is small, irregular - all right, it must be said - just plain quirky. In fact, their eccentric appearance and short storage life almost led to their demise. But because of their sprightly flavors and almost winy bouquet, pomophiles are eagerly seeking these distinct fruits at roadside stands and farmers' markets. ''Gravensteins?'' they whisper almost reverently. ''Or do you happen to have any Kandil Sinaps?''

title: Correction
description: Articles on pages 5 and 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today about George Abbott's new musical ''Frankie'' misstate Mr. Abbott's age.

title: Subtle Ways to Eat Your Cake and Have It Too
description: Commodities or not commodities - this is one of the big contemporary art questions of the moment. When does art that sets out to satirize the commercial side of art making cross the line and become just another pretty collectible? More and more often, it seems. What does it mean when artists who intend to be subversive turn out irresistible objects, seeming to embrace or otherwise take advantage of the very thing they would criticize?

title: Stiff Soccer Test
description: The United States soccer team, two victories and a tie from qualifying for a World Cup tournament for the first time, faces a key test in Guatemala today without two Latin American-born stars. Missing will be Hugo Perez, a Salvadoran-born midfielder and forward who is out with a torn groin muscle, and Tab Ramos, a native of Uruguay who will be serving an automatic one-game suspension for committing two major penalties in the team's previous game, a 1-0 victory over El Salvador.

title: Suited for Promotion
description: Dressing for success in the New York City Police Department doesn't necessarily require the familiar blue.

title: Pope in Korea After Greeting Soviets From the Air
description: Pope John Paul II began a journey across East Asia today after making the first papal flight over the Soviet Union and sending greetings from the air to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Foul-Smelling Landfill in Harrison brings Recrimination, but Not Removal
description: AS trees in the rest of Westchester begin to display their fall colors, the trees on Kenilworth Lane here remain leafless, their stark limbs an eerie black. The swimming pools and tennis courts once shaded by the trees are empty, and the gardens under them sprout shriveled zucchini and brown string beans.

title: First Things First
description: To the Editor:

title: Glen Cove Law Would Bar Gatherings of Illegal Aliens
description: UNTIL last month, Albert Mejia was one of more than 100 men, mostly undocumented Salvadoran refugees, who congregated every morning in front of Carmen's Deli in Glen Cove, waiting there for the landscaping trucks to come by and hoping to get a job for the day.

title: China Deplores Peace Award to Dalai Lama
description: China expressed ''utmost regret and indignation'' today over the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Dalai Lama, saying the exiled Tibetan leader was working to undermine national unity.

title: UP FROM THE UNDERGROUND IN POLAND
description: LEAD: America's bootleggers and moonshiners lost their raison d'etre when prohibition was repealed. A similar fate may await Poland's underground publishers (bookleggers and moonprinters?) as censorship loosens its grip.

title: A Whirl of Parties To Save a Museum And Honor Artists
description: Monday and Tuesday were busy nights last week in New York City. At Jean-Claude Baker's restaurant, Chez Josephine, on West 42d Street, a dinner on Monday honored Evelyn Anderson, thought to be the last living original cast member of ''La Revue Negre,'' which began Josephine Baker's career in Paris 64 years ago. Mr. Baker is working on a biography of his adoptive mother.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CONTEMPORARY BALLET

title: Unfinished Business With Canada
description: Nine months after the United States-Canada free-trade agreement began chipping away at tariffs and trade barriers, trade relations between the world's two busiest trading partners have slipped once again to their accustomed place on the policy makers' back burner.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Prepare Tender Bulbs for Storage
description: LEAD: WHILE it is usually best to wait until frost to dig tender bulbs, tubers and corms for winter storage, it can be done at any time after the tops have begun to dry. It is important that they be properly prepared for storage, if they are to survive the winter in good condition.

title: Friendship Can Be Earned at the Expense of Miss Manners
description: YESTERDAY, while going through a stack of outdated newspapers, I ran across an etiquette column in which Miss Manners castigated insensitive clods who would drop in unannounced, likening them to boorish know-nothings, unversed in the subtleties of proper social behavior.

title: Museum Is Named for Ansel Adams
description: Ansel Adams, who died in 1984 at the age of 82, is still an inspiration for the Friends of Photography, the group of artists and scholars he helped establish 22 years ago in Carmel, Calif.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Soil Law Leads to New Project Designs
description: LEAD: AT construction sites throughout the state developers are putting up a maze of plastic-sheet silt fencing and working around huge trees, dense scrubland and streams to protect as much of the land as possible from ecological damage.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Functional Embrace

title: Michigan Warms Up To Top Wisconsin, 24-0
description: Michigan's offense, scoreless in the first half, got touchdowns on its first two possessions in the third quarter today and the Wolverines beat Wisconsin, 24-0, in their Big Ten Conference opener.

title: Protesters Call for More Help For Homeless Who Have AIDS
description: Demonstrators staged a ''die-in'' in front of the White House today, lying prone on the street while chanting and waving signs calling for more Federal help to provide housing for people with AIDS.

title: Connecticut's Governor Suffers From Taxes
description: PORTENTS of a volatile 1990 race for governor are appearing across Connecticut as unhappy residents and would-be candidates assess the implications of record tax increases and a state deficit that has suddenly become a surplus. Recent opinion polls showing

title: A Chance to Hear the Stockholm Arts Trio
description: ALONG with its exhibitions, gallery talks and other community offerings, the Hudson River Museum has been presenting chamber concerts in Yonkers for nearly a quarter of a century. Next Sunday's 3 P.M. recital not only opens the 24th season but also introduces the Stockholm Arts Trio in what will be the ensemble's only appearance in the New York City area during its 10-state American tour.

title: Columbus 'Buff' Is Preparing for 1992
description: LEAD: JOSEPH M. LAUFER plans to spend Columbus Day - both the official observance tomorrow and the traditional holiday on Thursday - being interviewed by radio stations around the country, setting the record straight about the explorer credited with discovering America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23, 32

title: Washington Keeps Battling
description: Even though the George Washington Trojans are the defending Public Schools Athletic League B Division champions, they have had to scratch just to stay alive.

title: A Pointillist Painting
description: A FRIEND'S WIFE RE-cently persuaded him to buy a memory book, one that would help counteract his lifelong absent-mindedness. The next day, going in to the office, he left it on the train.

title: A Sympathy Card on East Germany's Birthday
description: THE Berlin Wall can play curious tricks on the eyes, and the sight of Mikhail S. Gorbachev soothingly professing solidarity with his East German comrades sometimes seemed an Eastern replay of President Bush's effort last spring to give a public hug to Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Mr. Bush had just patched up a falling-out with Bonn over short-range nuclear missiles, and soon he was on a Rhine barge chugging beer with Mr. Kohl and proclaiming the big, beaming Chancellor a partner in leadership.

title: Army Stunned by Duke
description: Clarkston Hines caught three touchdown passes and Randy Cuthbert ran for 147 yards and two more scores today as Duke held off Army by 35-29.

title: Favorite for Olympic Job Once Had It
description: A panel of United States Olympic Committee officials will interview the last of six finalists for the job of executive director tomorrow. The leading candidate is a man who had the job two years ago and quit after 17 days.

title: When Verdi Spoke, Everyone Listened
description: On Friday, Nov. 13, 1868, Gioacchino Rossini died at his home in Paris at the age of 76. Four days later, Giuseppe Verdi, a sincere admirer if not a close personal friend of the great Italian composer, wrote his own publisher, Tito Ricordi: ''In order to honor the memory of Rossini I should like the most outstanding composers of Italy to write a requiem which shall be performed on the anniversary of his death. . . . It shall prove how much we all revere this man whose loss the whole world mourns.''

title: Pace Loses to St. John's
description: Scott Scesney completed 20 of 31 passes for 326 yards and three touchdowns as undefeated St. John's held off Pace, 28-21, in the Liberty Conference game yesterday at Finnerty Field, Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Review/Dance; Janis Brenner Explores Isolation and Dependency
description: Janis Brenner's dancing is simultaneously taut and supple. That unusual mix was also characteristic of the four fine dancers who performed with Miss Brenner on Thursday at the Whitney Museum at Equitable Center. And it made for expressive performing, full of detail, that was reminiscent of the dancing of Murray Louis. But the five new and recent pieces and excerpts suffered from the same combination of qualities in the choreography, which often seemed trapped in some midground between freewheeling motion and rooted emotional intensity.

title: John B. Layton, 60's Chief of Capital Police
description: John B. Layton, police chief of Washington in a turbulent five years of strained race relations and rising crime in the 1960's, died of a pulmonary embolism Thursday at Washington Adventist Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Bush Gets Bill on Timber Sales
description: The Senate sent to President Bush today legislation that would allow sales of timber from Federal forests in the Northwest while protecting the habitat of the spotted owl.

title: Rose Palermo Marries
description: Rose Claire Palermo and Antonio DaSilva Castro, both lawyers, were married yesterday by the Rev. John Clermont, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The bride, 31 years old, is an associate at the firm of Shea & Gould in New York. She is a daughter of Rose Palermo of Freehold, N.J., and the late Vincent Palermo. She will retain her name. Her husband, 32, a Bronx County assistant district attorney, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio B. de Castro of New Bedford, Mass.

title: BRIDGE
description: Those around the world, who value the traditions of the game are mourning the demise of the world's oldest bridge periodical, Bridge International. The English publishers have announced that, for financial reasons, the current issue will be the last.

title: When the Rent's Late, but Culture Beckons, Ingenuity Saves the Day
description: Robin D. Chaplik concedes that she is a cheap date. Her idea of a good time is hearing the New York Philharmonic at 9 o'clock on a Thursday morning. Or, after ushering people to their seats, slipping into the back of a theater to see a hit play.

title: Miss Labine Wed in Massachusetts
description: Sherry Beth Labine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Labine of Wilbraham, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Gerard Donovan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donovan of Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Dr. Paul W. Zeckhausen, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the Protestant ceremony at the Wilbraham United Congregational and Methodist Church.

title: Debit Cards Spur Spending But Are Still Scarce
description: What do the Napa County Jail in northern California, Coca-Cola's headquarters in Atlanta and the United States Mint in Denver all have in common?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BINGO BROWN AND THE LANGUAGE OF LOVE By Betsy Byars. Drawings by Cathy Bobak. 132 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Brigid Flanigan, Developer, Weds
description: Brigid Snow Flanigan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Flanigan of Purchase, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. David James Lezak, the son of Sidney and Dr. Muriel Lezak of Portland, Ore. The Rev. Richard Valantasis, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Perlman Heads Lineup of Orchestral Openings
description: THIS will be another week of beginnings, with the Eastern Connecticut Symphony Orchestra opening its season on Thursday and Orchestra New England and the Greater Bridgeport, Greenwich and Waterbury Symphonies opening theirs on Saturday.

title: SHOE MERCHANTS
description: Sam and Libby Edelman fell in love at a 1979 shoe fair. He was there as a salesman for his father's business, she as footwear fashion editor for Seventeen magazine. Now they own Sam & Libby California, which offers a popular line of leather flats.

title: Douglas Bateson And Miss Johnson Exchange Vows
description: Marcia Belle Johnson, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and Douglas Farrar Bateson, a vice president of J. P. Morgan Securities, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell officiated, assisted by the Rev. Brenda Husson.

title: There's a Small Hotel; London: Coziness and quirks
description: NOBODY comes for the weather. But for years, London has lured visitors with its sights, its shopping, its theaters, its ambiance - and its attractive prices. You can still pick up a pair of prime orchestra tickets for shows like ''Shirley Valentine'' and ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' for less than $50. Finding a nice, moderately priced hotel is the big challenge.

title: Do Not Shush Voice of the Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; This Hot Dog's Smothered in Onions, Too
description: The rules were different when Ernie Whitt broke into baseball in 1972, or at least that's the way it seems to him today.

title: Killings by New York Police Drop, Bucking Trend
description: Police killings of citizens in New York City dropped sharply under Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, bucking a national trend, a survey has found.

title: There's a Small Hotel; Paris: Comfort and good coffee
description: CHOOSING a hotel in Paris is like choosing a restaurant: there are a great many options. One of the great charms of Paris is the abundance of hotels, of every size and price category. There are generally one or two hotels on every block, as much a part of the scenery as the charcuterie, or the boulangerie, or the corner bistro.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: I feel that Bart Giamatti was and is this year's m.v.p. This is not based on his untimely and tragic death, but rather on what he wished to address while he was alive: the integrity of the game and, in part, society. He addressed the question of gambling in baseball, and indirectly all that ills society, with honesty, fairness and open-mindedness. DANIEL F. DIVIRGILIO Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Parents Versus Intolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Prepare Tender Bulbs for Storage
description: LEAD: WHILE it is usually best to wait until frost to dig tender bulbs, tubers and corms for winter storage, it can be done at any time after the tops have begun to dry. It is important that they be properly prepared for storage, if they are to survive the winter in good condition.

title: Casualties Of a Truce In Angola
description: Just before dawn a couple of weeks ago, peasants in this languid town in Angola's central highlands were awakened by singing and chanting. Then, without warning, the shooting began.

title: Rating Coverage Of the Open
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ethical Questions Dominate in Campaign For New County Board
description: LEAD: ALL 17 members of the County Board of Legislators are seeking re-election to another term in November, as questions about political ethics dominate races involving two of the Board's most influential members.

title: Miss Eplett Wed To Sean E. Reilly
description: Jennifer Marie Eplett, a daughter of Mary Jane Coughlin Eplett of Lexington, Mass., and Dr. James Douglas Eplett of Nashua, N.H., was wed yesterday to Sean Eugene Reilly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Patrick Reilly of Baton Rouge, La. Msgr. John Keilty and the Rev. Margaret Gunness, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Bradford P. Foley Weds Miss Imhoff
description: Jennifer Marley Imhoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest F. Imhoff of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Bradford Perkins Foley, the son of Polly Sears Foley of Woodstock, Vt., and Robert Perkins Foley of Newport, R.I. The Rev. David Malone officiated at the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: Special Today: The Good Health Magazine/ Magazine Part 2
description: America's farmers are growing safer foods, using toxin-free sprays and other new techniques. By Susan Gilbert.

title: Talking; Reserve Funds; Getting The Best Return
description: OFFICERS of cooperative corporations, condominiums and homeowner associations are feeling increasing pressure to become more knowledgeable about investing their reserve funds. The funds are ballooning while the need to tap them becomes increasingly unpredictable as structures age.

title: WHAT DID THE EMPEROR DO AND WHEN DID HE DO IT?
description: LEAD: HIROHITO Behind the Myth. By Edward Behr. Illustrated. 437 pp. New York: Villard Books. $22.50.

title: Home Alone And Disabled
description: I HAD JUST RETURNED FROM A business trip to see three prospective clients. My consulting company was growing, and I was preoccupied with acquiring more office space. On the way to a meeting with the manager of my building, my knees began to feel weak and the simple act of walking suddenly required concentration. By the time I returned to my desk an hour later, I could not walk a straight line. I had to aim carefully for the chair to sit down.

title: Finding an Authenic Irish Harp
description: IN Ireland the harp is better known as an icon than as a musical instrument. The earliest surviving Irish harp, a 14th-century instrument displayed in the Trinity College Library in Dublin, is depicted on every coin minted in the republic - and even appears on bottles of Guinness stout.

title: Children Who Set Fires Prompt a Conference
description: EVERY three weeks, on average, firemen in some Westchester community are called to extinquish a blaze caused by children. While about half of those fires result from the curiosity of children playing with matches, psychologists say the other half are the work of young arsonists, bent on deliberate, intentional and repeated destruction.

title: Doctorow vs. Brandeis: 2 Winners
description: College alumni magazines rarely make news, except to notify former classmates of one another's whereabouts. But when administrators at Brandeis University offered to print E. L. Doctorow's address to the graduating class of 1989 in the Brandeis Review - and then awkwardly reneged over the summer - they touched off a tempest.

title: Charleston Looks To Spring Recovery
description: CHARLESTON, one of America's most beautiful cities, is battered and bruised after Hurricane Hugo, but the historic district and nearby resorts are already making plans for the spring tourist season. It will take that long, historic preservationists, merchants and city officials say, before the 300-year-old city will be able to accommodate the usual number of visitors who regard Charleston as proof that architectural and arboreal beauty aren't restricted to Europe.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Ski Areas Get Spas
description: LEAD: THE wisdom of diversifying ski resorts to generate more year-round business was illustrated during what some in the Northeast called the non-winter of '89, when snow was in short supply and the addition of sports and fitness centers at or near the resorts helped soften the blow. This winter, there will be two new

title: Miss Galvin Wed To R. S. Smith Jr.
description: Jeanne M. Galvin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Galvin of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Richard S. Smith Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Joseph Nagle officiated at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills.

title: Millions of Dollars in Errors Found in Indian Fund
description: An audit has uncovered widespread Government mismanagement of an Indian trust fund, including an unexplained disappearance of $17 million because of sloppy bookkeeping, officials said Friday.

title: The Heat Is On; Fuel-Saving Pointers
description: During the heating season, which began last week and runs through May 31, New York City requires that indoor temperatures in multifamily buildings always be at least 55 degrees and that when outside temperatures drop below 55, indoor readings must be at least 68 between 6 A.M. and 10 P.M.

title: SAY IT WITH SIGNS
description: SEEING VOICES A Journey Into the World of the Deaf. By Oliver Sacks. Illustrated. 180 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $15.95.

title: At Center of Drama in Manila, Marcos's Body
description: The uncertainty surrounding the disposition of the body of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos lingers, awaiting the outcome of a Supreme Court ruling here.

title: Porter's 'Kate' Revived in darien
description: FOR decades, musical comedy aficionados among us have been waiting for a first-class revival of ''Kiss Me, Kate.'' Now that the Darien Dinner Theater is having its way with the 1948 classic of Cole Porter and Bella and Samuel Spewack, with a little help from William Shakespeare, we're still waiting.

title: Is There Life After 'M*A*S*H'?
description: LARRY GELBART IS SIT-ting in a Manhattan rehearsal studio, watching some actors run through a scene from his new play, ''Mastergate,'' and he's laughing.

title: Donna A. DeBernardo Weds John Marino Jr.
description: Donna A. DeBernardo, the Staten Island regional representative for Governor Mario M. Cuomo, was married yesterday to John A. Marino Jr., the chairman of the New York State Democratic Party. The Rev. Rocco Famiglietti performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Richmondtown, S.I.

title: Anne Bogart Changes Course At Trinity Rep
description: On a recent autumn night, Anne Bogart sat on the stage of the Trinity Repertory Company, facing a small but lively audience. Ms. Bogart had just assumed the theater's artistic directorship and was conducting her first post-performance discussion - a conversation about that night's production of ''No Plays, No Poetry,'' her drama based on the theoretical writings of the German playwright Bertolt Brecht.

title: Claire Townsend Wed to Engineer
description: Claire T. Townsend, the daughter of Mrs. Harold P. Salembier of Oyster Bay, L.I., and New York, and Charles C. Townsend of Germantown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edward V. Bacher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Bacher of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Where the Season Shines Brightest; 'Miss Saigon' is hottest London ticket
description: IN London, a new play by David Hare and a stage adaptation by Anthony Burgess of his novel ''A Clockwork Orange,'' along with Brecht, Wilde and lashings of Shakespeare. In Paris, Peter Brook's production of a satiric fantasy about a Messianic visit to South Africa, plus Moliere galore. In Berlin, Molnar set to music, and the world premiere of a play by the late Thomas Bernhard. In Milan . . . but the European airwaves are in danger of getting clogged with the hubbub of theaters announcing their '89-'90 seasons.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Greeks to Vote Again as Rules Seem to Change
description: After being battered by scandals, electioneering and parliamentary inquiries, Greeks are wearily preparing for new elections, wondering whether the past year of turmoil has changed the country's traditional political rules.

title: In the West, The Verdict on Soviet Psychiatry Is Still Out
description: DURING the last two years, the Soviet Union has carried out changes in the practice of psychiatry, hoping to persuade the World Psychiatric Association to allow it to rejoin the organization. It left the group in 1983 to avoid almost certain expulsion because of charges that political and religious dissidents were being confined in mental hospitals. In January 1988, institutionalized patients were granted new rights of appeal and a number of ''special'' forensic psychiatric hospitals were transferred from the Interior Ministry, which is dominated by the K.G.B., to the Ministry of Health. The Soviets, who deny that psychiatry was ever systematically misused to punish and imprison dissidents, allowed a group of American psychiatrists, lawyers and Federal officials to visit mental hospitals in February and March and interview patients believed to be dissidents.

title: Penn Has to Rally to Beat Columbia
description: With the weight of 49 losses in Columbia's last 51 games resting on its shoulders, the Lions' defense lined up for a fourth-down play yesterday with the ball inches from its goal line and less than two minutes remaining in the game. If Columbia could hold, it would mean a victory over Penn, an Ivy League co-champion last year.

title: AIDS Is Spreading in Teen-Agers, A New Trend Alarming to Experts
description: Alarmed by new data showing that the AIDS virus is rapidly spreading among some groups of teen-agers, experts are calling for an expanded national effort against the epidemic.

title: WHAT THE BUTLER SAW
description: THE REMAINS OF THE DAY By Kazuo Ishiguro. tr,br1245 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: Ruben Sierra doesn't walk enough. What else can you say about a man who led the American League in runs batted in (119), total bases (344) and slugging percentage (.541) while finishing third in runs scored (101), eighth in doubles (35), first in triples (14), sixth in homers (29) and tenth in average (.304)?

title: The Saving Grace of Chicken Livers
description: THERE are two ways to buy chicken livers. The expedient method is to purchase the necessary quantity from the butcher or supermarket. The other way is to collect them from the whole chickens you buy, freezing them until you have enough for a recipe.

title: Keen-Witted Geese: Can They Read, Too?
description: Dave Pelland's engaging piece on geese and their ''smarts'' (''There's No Way to Outwit the Geese,'' Opinion page, Sept. 3) reminded me of my experience when I lived in Fort Collins, Colo., some years ago.

title: For Yankees, Less Is More
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Review/Pop; Twangy Laments by Oslin
description: In one of her best recent songs, ''Didn't Expect It to Go Down This Way,'' the country singer and songwriter K. T. Oslin laments being overworked, overweight, undesired and alone. ''I knew life would be hard, but I didn't know how hard,'' she declares. ''How in the world did I end up lonely?''

title: About Cars; BMW Cuts Back On Price of Luxury
description: Conventional wisdom has it that luxury cars are bulletproof.

title: Ad Doldrums
description: To the Editor:

title: FASHION DESIGNER
description: ''When designers start out, they tend to work too hard to make a statement,'' Randy Kemper said. ''I tend to go for clothes that look elegant and sleek and have as few seams as they need to make them work.''

title: Kate L. Phypers Weds R. C. Heidt
description: Katharine Lockwood Phypers, a daughter of Janet Thatcher Phypers and Dean Pinney Phypers, both of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Clark Heidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Heidt of West Simsbury, Conn.

title: WARHOL FACES THE BIG SCREEN INSTEAD OF THE SILKSCREEN
description: Documentaries thrive on public television, but they rarely entice audiences to movie theaters.

title: Rising Heroin Use and Addict Deaths Alarm Italy, Where Drug Is Legal
description: Calm as if on a coffee break, two young couples sat down on a bench in the Piazza della Repubblica and started shooting heroin into their arms.

title: SELLING TRUE GRIT
description: THERE ARE MANY PEOPLE in Robert Comstock, and all of them want out. Right this minute.

title: Princeton Architect Cited for 'Dominance' in Field
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Michael Graves, who won two awards at the New Jersey Society of Architects' annual competition this year, failed to carry away the top prize, he was singled out along with the Princeton University School of Architecture, where he has taught for 25 years, as a pervading influence on all the entries.

title: Old Things, Old Friends
description: IT is happening all the time, the breaking up and closing of the parental home. For everyone it is a painful experience. And for me, it certainly was that. But it also brought about a change in the way I see myself.

title: Sarah D. Schmidt Weds Executive
description: Sarah Denise Schmidt, the daughter of Mrs. Jack G. Schmidt of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Mr. Schmidt, was married yesterday to George Austen 3d, the son of Dr. Austen Jr. of Lynchburg, Va., and the late Langhorne Watts Austen. The Rev. Ronald George Abrams officiated at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: Maplewood Video: Death by Garbage
description: LEAD: MAPLEWOOD is a tidy suburban town with rambling, well-kept houses and immaculately manicured lawns. Twice a week, its residents bundle up discarded plastic containers, plastic foam cups, disposable diapers and other household refuse into plastic garbage bags and leave them to be trucked away to a landfill, hundreds of miles out of state.

title: HOME OWNERSHIP FOUND TO DECLINE
description: Home ownership declined in the 1980's for the first time since World War II, Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today, citing high prices and high interest rates.

title: GIVING PERESTROIKA A CHANCE
description: OUT OF THE COLD New Thinking for American Foreign and Defense Policy in the 21st Century . By Robert S. McNamara. 223 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Flames Surge Past Islanders
description: Paul Ranheim, Joey Mullen and Gary Roberts scored goals in a 2-minute-16-second span late in the third period to break open a close game tonight as the Calgary Flames kept the Islanders winless at the Olympic Saddledome with a 6-3 victory.

title: A Dollar Coin May Lift Patrons' Purchasing Power
description: Representatives of the vending industry have recently found themselves vigorously lobbying Congress to pass a measure that would mint a new dollar coin. ''It's really vending that's carrying this thing,'' said James C. Benfi, but can give change only in coins, not currency.

title: Hers; Who Said Ignorance Is Bliss?
description: MY LIFE AS A freelance radio reporter from Paris began when I was 51, so it's no wonder that my fellow female journalists are all 20 or 30 years younger than I am. What disconcerts me about this age difference is not, for instance, the fact that the French cabinet ministers who try to seduce them during interviews are younger and more virile than the shambling old fonctionnaires who make the occasional pass at me. It's the fact that these young people know ''nuttin' from nuttin', '' to quote from ''Duffy's Tavern,'' a 1940's radio program that, as usual, none of them has ever heard of.

title: Puerto Rico's 'Watergate' Is Filmed
description: Scene one: Day, interior. The prosecutor taps his pen nervously on his files during a Senate hearing. His language may be American legalese, but his pen taps a 6/8 Latin beat.

title: Southern Cal Prevails Over Washington, 24-16
description: Todd Marinovich threw for one touchdown and ran for another today to lead Southern California to a 24-16 victory over slumping Washington in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: 12-Year-Olds Given the Director's Chair
description: LEAD: LON SEIDMAN of Westbrook used to dream about being a surgeon. But now, he wants to have his own television show. ''It's more interesting,'' said Lon, who is 12 years old, ''and you don't have to cut people open.''

title: STAMPS
description: In the days before income taxes - yes, there was such a time - the United States Government raised money through a wide range of excise taxes and collected the money by selling revenue stamps. Just as postage stamps show payment for a government service, so revenue stamps show payment for a tax.

title: Friday the 13th: A Virus Is Lurking
description: A potentially potent computer virus, known variously as Datacrime or the Columbus Day Virus, is programmed to activate itself Thursday in a large number of computer systems in North America, computer security experts say.

title: The Dalai Lama Has Ideas for Neuroscience
description: FOR the Dalai Lama, the Nobel Peace Prize, which he won last week, might be taken as a tribute to his longstanding assurance that between even the most polar extremes there is common ground. As the exiled religious and political leader of Chinese-dominated Tibet, he has sought a political middle way, an autonomous state within Beijing's orbit.

title: Despite Wet Year, Harvest Pleases Wine Growers
description: THE 1989 grape harvest is under way on the North and South Forks and in Nassau County, and the aroma of fermentation drenches the air around wineries as the must from chardonnay, merlot and other grapes churns and froths in stainless-steel tanks and oak barrels.

title: Community Training
description: It may not be a busman's holiday, but for Mike Tyson, it's going to be hard to tell where training camp leaves off and community service begins. Tyson, who is preparing to take on the Canadian champion, Razor Ruddock, moved his training camp temporarily from Las Vegas, Nev., to Albany, where he was sentenced to perform community service after pleading guilty to speeding in two incidents last summer.

title: Sarah S. Spurdle Plans to Marry David R. Stack
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spurdle Jr. of New York and Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Stuart Spurdle to David Rorick Stack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Stack Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Q&A
description: London Christmas Question: We will be in London Dec. 24, 25 and 26 this year. We have heard that historical sites and stores are closed. Please advise as to what do at that time. - P. W. G., Baldwin Harbor, L.I. Answer: Most stores, museums and historical sites are closed Dec. 25 and 26, Boxing Day. In London, especially on Christmas, the streets are deserted, as families celebrate privately. Transportation is on a much-reduced schedule and taxis are scarce.

title: Shari Perlstein Wed to Roger Barzun
description: Shari J. Perlstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Perlstein of Aberdeen, N.J., was married last evening to Roger M. Barzun, a son of the cultural critic and historian Jacques M. Barzun of New York and the late Mariana Lowell Barzun. Rabbi A. Allen Block officiated at Publican's on the Pier at the South Street Seaport in New York.

title: On Panama: Luck and Incompetence
description: The United States turns out to be fortunate indeed that President Bush decided against strong U.S. military intervention in Tuesday's Panamanian coup attempt. But the way he reached that decision now looks like a model of incompetence.

title: Jeannine E. Davis Marries
description: Jeannine E. Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald M. Davis of Burr Ridge, Ill., was married yesterday in Nantucket, Mass., to Richard B. Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Harris of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Douglas Tompkins officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Reaching Out To the Disabled
description: I am writing in response to Robert McDonald's article, ''Giving Special Workers a Chance'' (Opinion page, Sept. 3). Robert worked as a summer residential counselor at our agency, the Kennedy Center of Bridgeport. Student employees and volunteers have proved to be an invaluable resource to organizations like ours that serve adults with disabilities.

title: Congress Passes Bill Curbing Art Financing
description: The Senate approved and sent to President Bush today a bill that calls for denying Federal money for art deemed obscene, the first time Congress has placed a limitation on arts grants because of content.

title: Pamela A. Block Is Wed To John Bentley Works
description: Pamela Anne Block and John Bentley Works were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert Kaye at St. Gregory's Episcopal Church in Boca Raton, Fla. The bride, 26 years old, is the daughter of Dorothy Block of Boca Raton and the late Alan J. Block. Her husband, 24, is a son of Edwin Works of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Barbara L. Works.

title: Joe, 35, 5'11'', SWM, seeks trvl prtnr; share
description: EARLIER this year, the Practical Traveler discussed some ways to circumvent the distasteful single supplement, the extra charge a traveler must often pay to occupy a room alone at a hotel or on a tour.

title: Reward for Tarpley
description: A week after being promoted from sixth man to starter, Roy Tarpley has gotten a contract worthy of his new status with the Dallas Mavericks. Tarpley, who had two years to go on a contract scheduled to pay him $560,000 this season and $660,000 the next, signed a three-year extension that will bring him a bit more, an average of $2.6 million a year for the last three years, The Dallas Morning News reported. The $9 million total for the five years makes Tarpley the highest-paid player in the franchise's history.(AP)

title: Bush and Panama: Chance Lost, Perhaps to Hesitancy
description: A senior European diplomat, preparing to leave Washington for another capital, had this to say last week about President Bush's performance in the realm of foreign policy during his first eight months in office: ''He's been reasonably deft, and he's been extremely lucky.'' After the failed coup in

title: ALONE IN GDANSK
description: A LIFE OF SOLITUDE Stanislawa Przybyszewska: A Biographical Study With Letters. By Jadwiga Kosicka and Daniel Gerould. Illustrated. 247 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $32.95. Paper, $12.95.

title: Forest Project Called Peril to New Jersey
description: Two members of Congress from New Jersey and a water delivery expert warned today that the proposed development of 19,000 acres of Sterling Forest in southeastern Orange County could imperil the drinking water for two million residents of northern New Jersey and make them more vulnerable to floods.

title: A KILLING IN MAINE
description: Your article failed to point out that in discharging a firearm within 100 yards of a residential dwelling (i.e., my neighbor's house), the killer of my wife was in violation of Maine hunting regulations. The implication in your article was that the man was sufficiently distant because he was more than 300 feet from my house. KEVIN M. WOOD Davenport, Iowa

title:
ART;
Reflecting Haiti's Duality
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the beginnings of Haitian painting date back less than 50 years, the art of that island nation has become justly celebrated for its exuberant response to the character of Haitian culture, which reflects the sometimes complementary, sometimes conflicting adaptations of African and European customs.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 31 in the Arts and Leisure section today about the ''Mystery!'' television series gives an incorrect day for the program's new season on Channel 13. It will be seen on Thursdays starting this week, not Saturdays.

title: Economic Forces That Knock Down The Oldest Forests
description: ONE hundred years ago, John Muir, the pioneer naturalist, rhapsodized about the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest and warned that the carpet of greenery stretching from the Cascade Mountains to the Pacific Ocean might one day shrink to a few small patches.

title: Review/Dance; Triple Bill by Graham Company
description: Martha Graham's superb dancers are back in New York. But even they, with their expected power, can surprise, which they did with their exceptionally strong performances in every work on the third program in the Graham Dance Company's current season.

title: Israeli Brutality, Press Timidity
description: LEAD: In November 1987, I was in a bookstore here in Tel Aviv and saw a poster put out in the early 80's by an Israeli protest group. It showed a photograph of an Israeli soldier beating a Palestinian, and said in Hebrew, ''Don't say you didn't know.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Meaning of Yom Kippur Rides on the Winds of a Hurricane
description: LEAD: A METAL can caromed across Seawall Boulevard. I swerved the car while listening to an emegency hurricane update. What timing, I muttered. It was four days before Yom Kippur and I had yet to complete my sermons for the day of atonement.

title: Noriega's Party Proposes Laws to Punish Dissent
description: The political party controlled by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has proposed a sweeping set of 16 laws aimed at identifying and punishing Panamanians who do not actively support his military rule.

title: FROM BEOWULF TO TOM WOLFE
description: LEAD: THE READER'S CATALOG An Annotated Selection of More Than 40,000 of the Best Books in Print in 208 Categories. Edited by Geoffrey O'Brien with Stephen Wasserstein and Helen Morris. Illustrated. 1,382 pp. New York: Jason Epstein/Random House. Paper, $24.95.

title: Alexander Mauro, 68; Invented a Pacemaker
description: Alexander Mauro, a professor of biophysics at Rockefeller University, died of cancer Friday at New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE SKY IS MELTING
description: THE END OF NATURE By Bill McKibben. 226 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95

title: Polly Runyon Is Married
description: Mary Gilbert Runyon, the fund-raising coordinator for the Performing Arts Research Center of the New York Public Library, was married yesterday to Thomas Henry Wittrock, an architect at the New York firm of Cooper, Robertson & Partners. The Rev. Heather Morrison, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Keene Valley, N.Y. Mrs. Wittrock, who is known as Polly, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Runyon of Fair Haven, N.J., and Keene Valley. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Wittrock of Pleasanton, Calif.

title: Party Chief in the Ukraine Offers a Lighter Touch
description: The new chief of the Communist Party in the Ukraine has offered to curb the official harassment of his republic's growing nationalist movement and to begin a period of cooperation, provided the nationalists do not advocate secession from the Soviet Union.

title: Versatile Chicken Dish Has a Role for the Season's Apples
description: Apple- and ginger-flavored chicken with noodles is a dish of great versatility.

title: In the War on Drugs, Planes Are a Big Enemy
description: CAUGHT up in the war on drugs, Federal and private groups have recently proposed several measures to help disable the smuggler's preferred mode of transport: the small plane.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The family room in our house is directly above the basement. In warm weather, this room has a musty odor, especially when the humidity is high. We use a dehumidifier and ventilate the room, but it has not helped much. We had the carpet shampooed, and this relieved the problem temporarily. How can we get rid of the odor?

title: DATA UPDATE
CHINA FEARS STRIFE DURING HARD TIMES
description: China has entered a period of severe economic austerity and budget shortages that Government officials and foreign economists say may create new political dissatisfaction and uncertainties at a time when the Communist Party is trying to rally support.

title: How New York City Is Trying to Keep Its Numbers High
description: FEARING the loss of millions of dollars and of incalculable political power as the result of another undercount in the Federal census, New York City officials have begun mapping the demographic terrain over which they will have to travel to insure that the most invisible and reluctant New Yorkers are enumerated next year.
