title: Apple Circus Goes Western
description: The Big Apple Circus celebrates the Wild West, from Oct. 26 to Jan 7 in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. The show includes feats on the trapeze and on horseback, calf-roping, gun-slinging and whip-cracking. Tickets are $40 to $10. Information: 391-0767.

title: Program Offers Jobs to Youths
description: LEAD: YOUNG people thought to be at risk of dropping out of high school will be offered part-time jobs with the county under a new program that is to begin later this month.

title: Mental Training Urged for All
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Buetti Weds Andrew Levinson
description: Karen Marie Buetti and Andrew Robert Levinson were married last evening at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., by Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan. The bride is a daughter of Marie Buetti of Bay Shore, L.I., and Robert E. Buetti of Boca Raton, Fla. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Levinson of New York and Sagaponack, L.I.

title: THE GUIDE
description: BORIS ARONSON

title: A KILLING IN MAINE
description: James Howard Kunstler's article ''A Killing in Maine'' (Sept. 10) was sad and chilling. Mr. Kunstler focused largely on the sociological aspects and the very unusual legal process of this case; however, there were important and interesting questions about the dynamics of the shooting itself that were not fully explained.

title: Readings and Interviews In 92d Street Y Series
description: ''Geographies: Writing of Place,'' a four-part series of readings and interviews sponsored by the 92d Street Y, begins on Tuesday at 6 P.M., with the writer Jan Morris as guest at the Hunter College Playhouse, East 68th street between Lexington and Park Avenue. Ms. Morris - whose books include ''Manhattan '45,'' ''Conundrum,'' the ''Pax Britannica'' trilogy and ''The World of Venice''- will read from her works at 8:30 P.M. Admission to each event is $8.

title: Tainted Hand Of Criticism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The family room in our house is directly above the basement. In warm weather, this room has a musty odor, especially when the humidity is high. We use a dehumidifier and ventilate the room, but it has not helped much. We had the carpet shampooed, and this relieved the problem temporarily. How can we get rid of the odor?

title: H. C. Cushing 5th, Media Specialist, Weds Ms. Hawk
description: Laura Elsa Hawk and Harry Cooke Cushing 5th were married yesterday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Thomas Powell Fowler Milbank of New York and William McKinley Hawk Jr. of Fort Collins, Colo. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. Cushing 4th of Rome and New York and Ruth Swift Dunbar Cushing of Greenwich, Conn.

title: 'Touched by an Angel': Other Views
description: I was shocked and dismayed by a patronizing Opinion page piece, ''Touched by an Angel,'' on Aug. 27.

title: Alison Schroeder Becomes a Bride
description: Alison M. Schroeder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Schroeder of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert T. Bedenkop, a son of Ila J. Bedenkop of Cincinnati and Barry T. Bedenkop of Syracuse. Msgr. James Connolly officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph.

title: Former Indian Leader To Press Libel Action
description: Former Prime Minister Moraji Desai will continue pursuing legal action against the author of a book that says Mr. Desai was a paid informer for the Central Intelligence Agency, his son said today.

title:
MUSIC;
Concerts With Something Extra
description: LEAD: THE 1989-90 concert season, which is just under way, shows vigorous and imaginative programming and strong efforts by many musical organizations to educate their audiences in a variety of ways.

title: Tracy Lee Weds Graduate Student
description: Tracy Helen Lee, the daughter of Marjorie Tracy Lee of Washington and San Francisco, and Robert E. Lee 4th of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday in Washington to William Townsend Crittenberger, a son of the late Col. Dale Jackson Crittenberger, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Crittenberger. Msgr. John J. Murphy officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Merging the Tastes of Two Continents
description: TO call a restaurant American Bistro might sound contradictory. Yet this charming new restaurant in Kings Park is appropriately named. American ingredients are highlighted, while food styles, preparation and sauces are rooted in Europe. Bordelais, Cumberland and Champagne sauces, as well as Calvados apple compote, share the menu with Nantucket sea scallops, Long Island duck breast, New England lobster, North and South Fork terrine and Virginia bay scallops.

title: Familiarity Breeds Mayhem
description: I HAVE been living about a dozen years on Long Island and almost every day when I read the papers somebody is murdered by somebody else, a friend, a neighbor, often a close relative.

title: Campus Life: New Hampshire; Can Whistles Help to Prevent Campus Rape?
description: Issuing so-called rape whistles to all women at the University of New Hampshire is among the strategies being considered by school officials in the wake of two sexual attacks on campus since the fall term began last month. Rape-awareness strategies using whistles are already in place at Harvard and the College of William and Mary in Virginia.

title: From Blue Jeans to French Fries, Vendors Diversify
description: The drive for convenience may soon make microwave dinners, videotapes and french fries standard fare in vending machines. The developments stem from the desire of several new companies to cash in on the vending craze. And to keep sales from growing stale, several existing companies have moved upscale.

title: Heavy Metal's Not-So-Obscure Objects of Desire
description: Commercial hard-rock musicians, almost to a man, are interested in thighs. Firm thighs, hot thighs, sweet thighs - any kind of thighs, really, just as long as there is an adjective involved, and it scans right.

title: Afghanistan Waits for East-West Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Bitter Fame'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Course Planned for Stamford Marathon
description: LEAD: The Stamford Marathon, now in its fourth year, has a new race director, a new cable television deal and a new road course that extends partly into a neighboring town, Greenwich, a new partner.

title: Shirley S. Sagawa Weds G. A. Baer
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., Shirley Sachi Sagawa, a counsel to the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee in Washington, was married yesterday to Gregory Arthur Baer, an associate at the Washington law firm of Williams & Connolly. The Rev. Geoffrey M. St. J. Hoare officiated.

title: Exploring the New-Look Louvre
description: IT started out as a fortress in the 14th century; then, when the times became less dangerous, it was converted into a palace; finally, with the fall of the monarchy, it became a museum, the first of its kind in Europe. Now, at the behest of a President with a passion for building, it is going through yet another series of radical changes: enlarged, reorganized, with a new entrance pavilion, it has become in many ways a new museum.

title: Even Gorbachev's Friends Want a Little Order
description: WHEN the Soviet parliament decided last week to ban strikes in key industries, it was just a modest display of what liberal commentators here call ''the strong hand syndrome'' - the yearning for something to control the disorders Mikhail S. Gorbachev has loosed in the land. More draconian proposals are in store, as the country sweats out the unnerving side effects of a little liberty. Among the ideas already in the air: a price freeze, wage controls, rationing of consumer goods, new Government emergency powers, and even anointing Mr. Gorbachev as a full-fledged temporary dictator.

title: Parks Are Becoming Dumping Grounds
description: AS landfills reach capacity and dumping costs soar, parks and forests in New Jersey are increasingly becoming the retiring grounds of old refrigerators, tires and other solid wastes, officials say.

title: Sandra Guerra Marries
description: Sandra Guerra, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfredo E. Guerra Jr. of San Antonio, was married yesterday to Gilbert Andrew Garcia, a son of Roland Garcia and Anne Marie Garcia, both of Corpus Christi, Tex. Msgr. William C. Kinlough officiated at Most Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church in Corpus Christi. The bride, 26 years old, will keep her name. She is an assistant district attorney in Manhattan. The bridegroom, also 26, is a vice president in mortgage sales at Salomon Brothers in New York. Both are graduates of Yale University.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: Although Will Clark will be the player of the 90's, his fellow Giant slugger, Kevin Mitchell, was the player of 1989.

title: Reviews/Theater; 'Wonderful Town' Revived In Slightly Updated Version
description: Has New York ever been so innocent a place as the grimy but effervescent city depicted in the 1953 musical ''Wonderful Town''? That question pertains crucially to the Equity Library Theater's revival of the show, in which the director Adrienne Weiss has unwisely cast members of the ensemble as homeless people and punks in the street scenes. The insertion of contemporary references confuses the mood without adding any ironic resonance.

title: Revival in Darien of ''Kiss Me, Kate''
description: FOR decades, musical-comedy aficionados have waited for a first-class revival of ''Kiss Me, Kate.'' The Darien Dinner Theater is having its way with the 1948 classic of Cole Porter and Bella and Samuel Spewack, with a little help from Shakespeare, but we're still waiting.

title: FICTION
description: SNAKEWALK. By Charles Wheeler. (Harmony, $18.95.) When Patrick Todd is blinded in a boating accident, he takes his changed status in stride. He enrolls in a school for the blind and finds the physical adaptations surprisingly easy; warned that it might take two years to become proficient in Braille, he masters it in two weeks. First-time novelist Charles Wheeler (who was also blinded in a boating accident) has created in Patrick Todd an intriguing, if annoying, character. The somber tones sometimes associated with writing about a disability are completely absent here, and Patrick's irreverence is refreshing. Blind people, for example, are referred to as ''blinks''; sighted people are either ''regulars'' or ''eyeballs.'' Patrick's biggest difficulty is not his lack of sight but dealing with those eyeballs who specialize in condescension. His new friendships with other blind people also have built-in problems, however, which he faces only when he falls in love. ''She's blind, man,'' he tells himself, ''be honest with yourself and say it. You don't want to spend the rest of your life with a blind woman.'' Unfortunately, like all the characters in ''Snakewalk'' except for its narrator, that blind woman is a cipher. And Patrick Todd is mostly interested in Patrick Todd's pleasures. His decision to go to college is an unexplained move that doesn't square with his constant desire to practice mobility in the direction of the bar. Those bar scenes don't help spruce up the plot, but they're among the book's many hilarious interludes. ''Snakewalk'' is exceptional in its nonvisual use of language, its unexpected imagery (a bathroom, for example, is ''loud with disinfectant''). Charles Wheeler makes a good case for Patrick's argument that six months of blindness should be mandatory for sighted people, so they ''can get a good look at themselves.''

title: Monetary Awards Can Soothe the Pain
description: A wrongful death case under New York law is treated differently from a similar case under Connecticut law and from the way cases are treated in other states.

title: Holiday On Tomorrow
description: Columbus Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office at 33d St. and Eighth Ave. open. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed, local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Champion Race Horse, Cherished Friend
description: Secretariat'S death on Wednesday marked the end of a wonderful dream I have been privileged to live. In my eyes, he was the finest thoroughbred performer of the last 50 years and he certainly provided me with a unique experience.

title:
ART;
African Sculpture's 'Moral Obligations'
description: LEAD: NONE of the world's art is less art for art's sake than African art. Every piece has a precise ritual purpose or deep symbolic meaning. Yet until the beginning of this century and Cubism, which was inspired in part by the rigorous angularity of African art, Western eyes couldn't even see beyond the superficial fact that facets of an

title: Oppressed Woman, Your Name in Opera Is Legion
description: I may be the last person alive to have realized it, but isn't it remarkable that opera is so heavily populated by oppressed, manipulated and otherwise pitiable women? This revelation came to me with blinding force the other evening as I sat transfixed by Teresa Stratas's hair-raising performance in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Suor Angelica.'' I now know how St. Paul must have felt when he was struck from his horse by a bolt from above on the way to Damascus. Opera-going for me can never be the same. Women as perpetual, archetypal, dramatically necessary victims - why has nobody mentioned the possibility to me before?

title: Compromise Plan to Move Newsstands Off Curbs
description: After a year and a half of negotiations, representatives of the newsstand business and the newspaper industry announced last week their general support for proposed regulations that would govern the size, location and operation of sidewalk newsstands in New York City.

title: Forget What You've Heard: Risotto Isn't Hard to Make
description: No matter what you may have read about risotto, it is no more difficult to make than a dish that includes pasta. And it certainly does not take any more time.

title: FLEEING DEATH AND TENNIS
description: NECTAR AT NOON By Sheila Cudahy. 151 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: Pitching Problems Dim Giants' Hopes
description: Uncertainty concerning Rick Reuschel and Don Robinson cast a shadow over the Giants' hopes even before they were to resume play tonight in the National League playoff against the Cubs.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: ON Oct. 23, 1935, Dutch Schultz and three members of his mob were gunned down in the back room of a restaurant. It was one of the bloodiest killings in gangster history, second in body count only to the St. Valentine's Day Massacre in Al Capone's Chicago. (The statistics on this sort of thing are a bit obscure, and it may be that drug smugglers have since set a new record.) In television shows and movies, the Schultz killing is depicted as happening in New York City.

title: In White Plains, Two Visions Clash
description: LEAD: AFTER a decade of development in which a flattened urban-renewal wasteland turned into a gleaming and prospering regional center, election debates in White Plains focus largely on how much more development the city can absorb.

title: CONGRESS IS FACING MEDICARE CONFLICT
description: The House and the Senate face a daunting task of reconciling drastically different approaches to curtailing expanded health benefits to the 33 million Medicare beneficiaries.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Moving Up and Out, Rather Than Away
description: LEAD: WHILE many Long Islanders wait, hoping to sell their homes so they can move to bigger ones, others have found an alternative: They are remodeling.

title: Works In Progress; Outfoxing the Viewer
description: ''THE MORE I DO THIS KIND OF work, the more it feels like making a film,'' Sandy Skoglund says. ''A film in one frame.'' The kind of work she's talking about - ''it's been sort of codified as 'tableau photography,' '' she says - draws on elements of sculpture and photography. But indeed, as the detail at the right, from ''A Breeze at Work'' (1987) illustrates, Skoglund's surreal images suggest three dimensions and movement.

title: Incoherent Ravings
description: To the Editor:

title: CHESS
description: Is there a formula for winning against the world's greatest chess computer, Deep Thought?

title: International Kosher Cuisine in Baltimore
description: Sunday is the eve of Yom Kippur, the beginning of the traditional day of fasting and holiest day of the Jewish year. After the fasting, there is the break fast, a hearty family meal.

title: In a New Haven Garage, Neon Art Glows
description: ''THIS garage is the inside of my brain,'' said Mundy Hepburn, gliding his arm through the air. Standing in the bed of a Chevy pickup, his frame backlighted by one of his neon sculptures, ''The Wave,'' he described with reverence the ''mystical beauty'' of neon.

title: Diana Schwab and Marc T. Kennedy, Financial Analyst, Wed in Maryland
description: Diana Bliss Schwab, a daughter of Mrs. Julian S. Stein Jr. of Union Bridge, Md., and Oquossoc, Me., and Walter P. B. Schwab of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday at the Iron Horse Farm in Union Bridge to Marc Tyson Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Tyson Kennedy of Pittsburgh. Judge Lawrence Shipley of the Carroll County Circuit Court in Westminster, Md., officiated.

title: An Allowance For Wit and Human Foible
description: Four days ago the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden unceremoniously passed its 15th anniversary. The circular building, resembling a giant doughnut, has always seemed an oddity amid the neo-Classical and Modernist boxes lining Washington's National Mall. But whatever might be said against the architect Gordon Bunshaft's design - and curators struggling to hang paintings on curved walls have had things to say over the years - his conception underscored one essential characteristic of the museum. Joseph H. Hirshhorn's collection of several thousand modern paintings and sculptures was at least as eccentric as the structure that housed it.

title: 'Touched by an Angel': Different Views
description: I did not find ''Touched by an Angel'' touching in the least. In fact, I found it very disturbing. According to the author, after a short visit with her family, Angel is transformed from a ''street-wise kid with no understanding of our family's values or rules'' into ''just another boy'' - just one ''of our own kids.''

title: Review/Jazz; Judy Carmichael and Piano
description: Judy Carmichael's gradual shift from clubs to concert halls as settings for her jazz piano performances has led her to expand what once were merely announcements of her selections to explanations of style, composers and performers.

title: The Venerable Atheneum Braces for That Show
description: LEAD: THE touring exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe that created a Congressional uproar was booked by the Wadsworth Atheneum last winter, long before the controversy surrounding it began this summer. The show will arrive at the Atheneum on Oct. 21, and the museum's director, Patrick McCaughey, says ''it's time to tighten the safety belts.

title: Constance Pierce Weds R. S Fowler
description: Constance Catherine Pierce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Pierce of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Saxton Fowler, a son of Robert A. Fowler of Houston and Mrs. Samuel A. Bowman of New York. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Mahon at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Review/Music; Puppets And More, From Java
description: Every culture has its puppets (in our case, they're muppets), and in some of those cultures puppet plays achieve the status of high art. Often, like Shakespeare's plays and Mozart's operas, they mix noble legend and raucous low comedy in blissful equilibrium.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
YESTERDAY'S TOMMORROWS
description: LEAD: Poised on the brink of wars that changed thiscountry, the 1939 and 1964 New York World's Fairs, held on the same site in Flushing Meadows Park in New York City, encapsulate eras that now seem exotically remote from the present as well as each other. REMEMBERING THE FUTURE: The New York World's Fair From 1939 to 1964 (Rizzoli, Paper, $25), a fascinating collection of lavishly illustrated essays by such scholars as Morris Dickstein and Robert Rosenblum, serves as the catalogue for an exhibit (through Dec.

title: Hit the Free Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiting Till Next Year
description: With the season finished for New York Mets players, it was up to Mets management to serve up one final cliffhanger last week. It began with a lot of front-office grumbling about the team's disappointing second-place finish this year, and soon the whole world just knew Davey Johnson was finished as manager. Newscasters said it, sportswriters wrote it and Mr. Johnson himself was thoroughly convinced of it. ''They're not bringing me back,'' he said. For days, the Mets owners and executives admitted only that they were ''agonizing'' over a decision. Finally, on Thursday, a terse statement came from the top: Mr. Johnson would be returning next year. The Mets manager had no comment.

title: Newcomers Mix With the Famous In Weisman Collection
description: TO be on the mailing list of the Frederick R. Weisman Art Foundation is, naturally, to be aware of its activities, which include traveling shows like that now at the Neuberger Museum, on the State University of New York campus here. More surprising, it means also to be apprised by newsletter of what's new at Mid-Atlantic Toyota Distributors Inc. - the millionth vehicle sold, the Employee of the Month and so forth.

title: Princeton Routs Brown
description: Judd Garrett rushed for 209 yards and scored three touchdowns today as Princeton routed Brown, 38-15, handing the Bruins a school-record 13th loss in a row.

title: A Lifelong Democrat Packs His Bags
description: LEAD: After a lifelong affiliation with the Democratic Party and its ideals, I am packing. And I am not alone.

title: A Bit of Old Athens on the Susquehanna
description: The PennsyLvania State Capitol is a flamboyant Italian Renaissance extravaganza, a building that gloriously mixes City Beautiful splendor with robber-baron vulgarity. Finished in 1906 and designed by Joseph Huston, it is one of the triumphs of civic architecture anywhere in America, with a 272-foot-high dome modeled after the dome of St. Peter's in Rome and two immense, sumptuously decorated legislative chambers. The building's richness came in part as a reaction to an earlier capitol building by Henry Ives Cobb, started in 1898, that legislators and the governor found so plain that they never allowed it to be finished, ordering work to a halt while they initiated an architectural competition for a grander building to be erected over and around it. Huston, the new architect, ended up spending $13 million as opposed to Cobb's $550,000, but that pleased state officials no more than Cobb's modesty had: the high cost of the building put the architect in the middle of a violent storm of controversy, and he was eventually jailed on charges of mishandling the job.

title: FIGHTING AIDS ALL THE WAY
description: AS A HEART MONITOR BEEPED AT MY side and an automatic blood-pressure machine quietly inflated and deflated, the nurse started the infusion. Doctors and more nurses hovered nearby. The drug dripping into my vein was dideoxyinosine, or DDI. Thus, on July 22 of this year, I became one of about 100 people in the United States to receive what was being described in the press as a ''promising'' new AIDS drug. But at that moment I knew the doctors and nurses at the National Institutes of Health were thinking not about how promising the drug was, but about seizures. Several people who had received intravenous infusions of the drug had experienced them, and, while the doctors felt it was unlikely the seizures had been caused by the drug, they were still nervous - and prepared.

title: TAKING GLEE IN HIS WAYWARD PAST
description: COLLECTED POEMS, 1937-1971 By John Berryman. Edited by Charles Thornbury. 348 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: Retirees With Green Thumbs and More
description: LEAD: KATHARINE M. STEVENSON objects to posing for photographs in front of a flower bed. ''People think we're just pansy planters,'' she explained.

title: University of Virginia President Will Resign
description: The president of the University of Virginia will resign next year to take a new post as director of a center for the protection of freedom of expression.

title: TAKING OFF THE WHITE GLOVES
description: Anyone who compares the quirky first issue of Vanity Fair - which included the Garcia Marquez novella ''Chronicle of a Death Foretold'' - with the glossy vapidity now on the newsstand can only mourn the loss of a potentially great magazine. What happened to that first vision?

title: Players Cashing In Before Playoffs End
description: Last winter, Scott Sanderson was convinced the Chicago Cubs were certain he would not make the team this year.

title: JUST TWO WOMEN
description: Jean Hey writes that her mother found in her servant Nancy ''a friend more than a servant.'' Why is it, then, that when Nancy had no one with whom to spend Christmas, she was allowed to serve her mistress's Christmas dinner? Why, instead, didn't she sit with her ''friend'' and partake of the meal? Friend, indeed.

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Flag Desecration: Vote to kill an amendment to a bill outlawing desecration of the flag that would have banned only public acts against the flag. Approved 53 to 47, Oct. 5. 2. Flag Desecration: Vote on final passage of a bill that would make it a crime subject to a penalty of one-year in prison and a $1,000 fine to mutilate, deface, burn or physically defile any United States flag. Approved 91 to 9, Oct. 5. 3. Drugs: Vote to kill an amendment to an anti-drug bill that would have applied only to aircraft flying over water, and would have given authorities permission to fire on a suspect aircraft only if drug activities were observed and if the plane refused to reply to successive warnings. title: New Sanctums, Faces and Perils For 'Mystery!'
description: Armchair detectives will spot some dramatic changes when PBS-TV's ''Mystery!'' begins its 10th season this week (Thursday on WNYC-TV, Channel 31; Saturday on WNET-TV, Channel 13).

title: Try Drug Legalization On Experimental Scale
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Efficiency Into the Organization
description: WHO among us has not been haunted by the loss of a critical piece of mail? Who has not floundered hopelessly in a sea of paper?

title: IN SHORT
description: BAD INTENTIONS: The Mike Tyson Story. By Peter Heller (NAL Books, $18.95.) A biography of Mike Tyson should offer some insight into the heavyweight champion's effectively brutal behavior in the ring and puzzlingly erratic behavior outside it. It should, at least, provide some entertainment, as the tabloid headlines of the past couple of years are stitched into a juicy narrative. Unfortunately, ''Bad Intentions'' disappoints on both counts. The author, Peter Heller, a television sports producer, gives us 20 and 30 pages at a time of intricate background material - perhaps too intricate for all but boxing historians. Of Mr. Tyson's early days, we learn that he was called ''fairy boy'' in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn because of his soft, lisping voice and that he lovingly raised pigeons on a rooftop - shades of ''On the Waterfront.'' The most revealing episodes involve Cus D'Amato, who took Mike Tyson out of reform school, put him up in his house and taught him to box. Perhaps fearful that he would lose a future champion, D'Amato (who died in 1985) did not hold Mr. Tyson to house rules on discipline, letting him drop out of school before he was thrown out and getting legal custody. On the entertainment side, Mr. Heller gives us the whole delightful cast of characters: Mr. Tyson's former managers Bill Cayton and Jimmy Jacobs, who put together a successful and lucrative game plan for the fighter's career; Mr. Tyson's former wife, Robin Givens, and her mother, who while Mr. Tyson was at Jimmy Jacobs's funeral were at the fighter's brokerage house counting his money; the boxing promoter Don King, whispering in Robin's and Mike's ears to steal him away from Bill Cayton; even Donald Trump, out as usual to get his name in the papers (at their first meeting, Mr. Trump introduced himself and the fighter offered an expletive and walked away). But Mr. Heller's writing is awkward - ''but when it comes down to brass tacks, King plays hardball when cornered'' is a fair sample - and the story does not get the melodramatic spin that it needs to be as amusing as it has been on the 5 o'clock news.

title: Fashion Preview; MILAN: A NEW SEASON
description: THE ITALIANS ARE THE FIRST TO SHOW ready-to-wear collections for 1990, and this weekend spring comes to Milan. As usual, the Milanese are expert at tailoring. But they have given up their crispness in favor of a new fluidity. ''You have to risk,'' says Giorgio Armani. ''It's a feminine collection, for the sophisticated woman who likes to have fun with clothes.'' As for lengths, some are above the knee and some below. ''Long'' is often interpreted in wide-legged pants silhouette. At Fendi, Karl Lagerfeld skirts the issue with hems that rise in front and dip in back. And an underlying influence in many of the collections is decidedly ethnic, both Eastern and African.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 17 about Seoul misidentified a building on the grounds of the 14th-century Kyongbok Palace. It was the Korean National Folklore Museum, which was built in 1972, not the palace itself.

title: Where the Season Shines Brightest; Cezanne, Dali, Giulio Romano
description: FALL is in many ways the best time to go to Europe for major exhibitions. Unmotivated visitors are fewer. The hotels are less full, likewise, though it is a good idea to watch out for the trade fairs, conventions and other municipal promotions that begin in late September.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Hotel Rates Cut in Israel After Dispute

title: Yes, More Money for Air Travel
description: Most problems can't be solved just by throwing money at them, but some can't be addressed any other way. James B. Busey, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, correctly insists the nation's overloaded air traffic control system is one of those that needs money - at least twice as much for capital improvements each year as is currently being spent. But that requires a commitment to tax and spend, almost an impossibility in Washington these days.

title: Miss Spitler Wed To B. G. Arpajian
description: Anne Marie Spitler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee W. Spitler of Brick, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Brian George Arpajian, the son of Kurken G. Arpajian of Philadelphia and Helga M. Reiber of Lake Oswego, Ore. The Rev. Robert Verrigni performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: JUST TWO WOMEN
description: As an Amerian sociologist who studied in South Africa and practiced medicine there for 15 years, I can bear witness to the veracity of Jean Hey's observations in her article ''Just Two Women'' (Hers, Sept. 10). Interpersonal tolerance generally does overshadow the ''stench of South Africa's oppressive politics.''

title: Florida State Runs Over Syracuse
description: Terrell Buckley returned a punt 70 yards for a touchdown and LeRoy Butler scored on an 88-yard interception return three minutes later today as Florida State ended Syracuse's home winning streak at 16 games with a 41-10 victory.

title:
The View From: Interstate 684's Backyards;
It's Not the Sea at the Door, but There's a Roar Just the Same
description: LEAD: MARY O'REILLY used to tell her children that the sound they heard was waves breaking on the shore. Then they got old enough to realize that their home on Maryland Avenue here wasn't anywhere near a beach - and that the steady, rhythmic roar was actually coming from the cars and trucks on Interstate 684, which is practically in their back yard.

title: Hypocrisy Is Not Free
description: Watching TV pictures of East Germans being shoved out of the U.S. Embassy in East Berlin while they flocked into the West German Embassy in Prague, a young American here was distressed.

title: Loose or Broken Banisters
description: Bannisters, or staircase posts and railings, are as much a safety feature as they are a decorative element. This makes repairing loose or broken bannisters important, but also somewhat complicated, because fasteners are usually hidden.

title: An Off-Duty Officer Is Shot in a Fight in the Bronx
description: A police officer was critically wounded yesterday in an early-morning fight in the South Bronx with a man who, the police said, wrestled the officer's service revolver from him, shot him in the forehead and fled.

title: Raiders Piece Their 'Family' Back Together
description: It is Wednesday afternoon and the Los Angeles Raiders are strolling in bunches onto the field at their training facility nestled in a neighborhood full of well-kept homes and loyal, curious well-wishers.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: AMERICA ON THE CHEAP;
Who's Bankrolling the Buyout Artist?
description: LEAD: Sometimes one does not know whether to laugh or rail at the gullibility of Congress, and the hypocrisy of Wall Street.

title: Pamela Johnson Weds S. P. Davis
description: Pamela Joan Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larrabee MacMillan Johnson of New York and Rockport, Me., was married yesterday to Police Capt. Stephen Paul Davis, a son of Justine Davis of New York and the late John Joseph Davis. The Rev. Ferdinando D. Berardi performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: There's a Small Hotel; Rome: Charm and efficiency
description: THE hotel scene in Rome used to be simple. If you wanted luxury and pampering, you paid a lot of money and, in most cases, you got them; if charm and atmosphere counted more than recapturing abroad all the comforts of home, you could find that too (and at a price that was affordable), and if you just wanted a clean place to spend a night, which you never expected to come back to again, that too was an uncomplicated affair.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I'm sure the President is not going to be willing to submit to all that extraneous material in the deficit package just to get capital gains.'' Senator John H. Chaffee, Republican of Rhode Island.

title: COMMUNIST PARTY IN HUNGARY VOTES FOR RADICAL SHIFT
description: The Hungarian Communist Party voted today to transform itself into a socialist party and said it would strive to bridge the gulf between doctrinaire Marxism and European democratic socialism.

title: Sarah Copeman Weds Robert Gould
description: Sarah Caroline Copeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Copeman of Tarvin, Cheshire, England, was married yesterday to Robert Rose Gould, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Gould 3d of Suffern, N.Y., and Prouts Neck, Me. The Rev. Alan Backhouse officiated at St. Andrew's Anglican Church in Tarvin.

title: A Trump Target: American Airlines
description: Donald J. Trump offered $7.5 billion for AMR, the parent of American Airlines. The company is expected to reject the $120-a-share bid. It was not clear whether Mr. Trump would pursue a hostile takeover against AMR's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, one of the most fiercely independent executives in the airline business. AMR's stock rose $20.75 following the offer, to close the week at $103.75. *

title: THE GRAND OVERVIEW, WITH PICTURES
description: LEAD: LITERATURE IN AMERICA An Illustrated History. By Peter Conn. Illustrated. 587 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $29.95.

title: REFERENCE
description: THE FOSSIL BOOK: A Record of Prehistoric Life. By Carroll Lane Fenton and Mildred Adams Fenton. Revised and expanded by Patricia Vickers Rich, Thomas Hewitt Rich and Mildred Adams Fenton. (Doubleday, $40.) ''Many a paleontologist has lived a long and useful life without seeing fossil flagellates, ciliates, or even radiolarians,'' write the authors of ''The Fossil Book.'' And not only paleontologists. But for anyone who would like to see them and find out what they are, this book is a good place to do it. Other creatures are covered, as well. Squids, for instance, had a tough start; they ''made slow progress for millions of years, and then became the most abundant of cephalopods.'' And good for them, I say. The tiny, toothy jaws of extinct worms (I didn't even know worms had jaws) are abundant fossils in some rocks. And giant, nasty birds once hunted and ate small horses on the plains of North America. In fact, ''The Fossil Book'' ranges with admirable thoroughness and clarity over all 3.5 billion years of living things and the remains they left. It describes what fossils are, how they are formed, found and studied. First published in 1958, the book has been reissued with some new sections. The volume contains many photographs and illustrations; among its attractions are numerous black-and-white drawings of invertebrates that are endlessly intriguing (I recommend the brachiopods). Some of the drawings of vertebrates, like the dinosaurs, are less exciting. The lithe, energetic dinosaurs of recent paleontological theory and speculation are not here, although the text does take note of current research and controversies. The book has been revised - by the retired geologist Mildred Adams Fenton; Patricia Vickers Rich, a lecturer in palentology at Monash University in Australia; and Thomas Hewitt Rich, curator of vertebrate palentology at the Museum of Victoria in Australia - for the nonscientist, albeit one who is willing to confront the lophophores, pedicles and condyles that always creep into this sort of discussion. Technical language, however, occurs mostly in discussions of particular animals and is made clear in the text and drawings. (There is also a glossary.) Furthermore, the book is not without drama and pathos, as befits a book on which death weighs so heavily. I found particularly poignant the fate of certain lungfish called Gnathorhiza, from the Permian. These are fish that left the water and spent the dry season in burrows. And that is where their fossils were found, 250 million years later, still waiting for the rains.

title: Elizabeth H. DetwilerMarries A. W. Regan
description: Elizabeth Harper Detwiler, a daughter of Helen P. Detwiler of Metamora, Mich., and Peter M. Detwiler of New York and Bedminster, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew William Regan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Regan of New York and Dublin. Canon John T. Morrow officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Connecticut Q&A: James A. Schlueter 'Smoking Is a Form of Suicide'
description: MOST cigarette smokers quit on their own, but a third of them seek help from programs like the Stop Smoking Clinic at the Institute for Better Health in New Haven. James A. Schlueter, the executive director of the institute, a nonprofit health information service, says the best programs combine several approaches with follow-up support for struggling ex-smokers.

title: Yiddish Film Pioneer Recalls Early Days
description: LEAD: A BIT part in the first talking movie, ''The Jazz Singer'' starring Al Jolson, propelled Joseph Green into a career as the so-called father of the golden age of Yiddish films.

title: Katherine Holihan Weds
description: Katherine Margaret Holihan, a daughter of Margaret Katherine Holihan of Piermont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph Aloysius Burke, a son of Mary Helen Burke of Buffalo and the late Howard Vincent Burke. The Rev. Robert Saccoman officiated at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Burke, 24 years old, is a program assistant in higher education at the Charles A. Dana Foundation in New York. The bridegroom, 28, is an associate at the New York law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine.

title: Let's Just Pick Up And Leave
description: ''TENNESSEE. How about Tennessee, hon? We can buy a nice house there for about half of what it costs here.''

title: Campus Life: Oglethorpe; Proposed Sale Of Greek Row Upsets Students
description: Squarely in the path of a real-estate development juggernaut, Oglethorpe University has put 15 acres of property, including the school's Greek row, up for sale - and at least a few students are upset about it.

title: Folk Art Reflects the Russian Soul
description: LEAD: THE Russian soul, or at least that part of it reflected in folk art, will be on view starting Saturday in Glen Cove.

title: Swedish Dance Tries To Reclaim Its International Standing
description: We haven't heard much about dance in Sweden since 1982, when a dancer in that country's foremost experimental troupe, the Cullberg Ballet, bared her breasts onstage in front of some other visitors at the Brooklyn Academy of Music - the King and Queen of Sweden.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MANHATTAN ON THE ROCKS. By Michael Musto. (Holt, $18.95.) Michael Musto is a talented writer. His weekly column in The Village Voice is sassy, sarcastic and sometimes sincere, especially when he's investigating the politics of AIDS in Manhattan. As a gossip columnist, he delivers the dish while maintaining a conscience.

title: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: GOOD GRIEF: The Story of Charles M. Schulz. By Rheta Grimsley Johnson. (Pharos Books, $17.95.) Grief has been very, very good to the cartoonist Charles M. Schulz. ''Peanuts,'' his comic-strip chronicle of the prepubescent angst of Charlie Brown and others, is syndicated to more than 2,000 newspapers and read by 90 million people daily.

title: October's Two New Golden Hitters
description: When the leaves turn golden, some hitters do too. Reggie Jackson, Mickey Mantle and Babe Ruth always understood that baseball in October is different. The stage is bigger. The audience is bigger. And for better or for worse, the microscope is bigger.

title: Berenice Abbott's New York
description: In the 20's an Ohio woman named Berenice Abbott was living in Paris and photographing the famous. Everybody came to Miss Abbott's studio - James Joyce, Nora Barnacle Joyce, Andre Gide, Jean Cocteau - and it is partly through her images that we know them. But in 1929 she came back to the United States and ''There it was, for better or for worse'': New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl Wins Final: Ivan Lendl overcame problems with his first serve yesterday and defeated Miroslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 4-6, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, to win the Stuttgart tournament in West Germany. The match took 3 hours 14 minutes. Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, broke Mecir twice to win the first set, then started missing his first serves. Mecir took advantage to break Lendl in the first game of the second set and held serve to win. The third set was nearly a repeat of the second, with Lendl struggling and Mecir changing speed and playing steadily to win again. But in the fourth set, Lendl's serve and returns started hitting the mark.(AP) Courier Upsets Gomez: Unseeded Jim Courier of the United upset Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday and advanced to the final of the Swiss Indoors tournament in Basel, Switzerland. In today's final, Courier, 19, will face top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, who beat Jimmy Connors by 6-1, 7-5 in the other semifinal. It will be the first Grand Prix final for Courier. (AP) Federation Cup Play Postponed: The semifinals of the Federation Cup between the United States and Czechoslovakia, and Spain and Australia, were postponed because of rain yesterday in Tokyo. The matches are scheduled to be played today, with the final tomorrow.(AP) Golf Hammond in Front: Donnie Hammond fired a five-under-par 65 yesterday and grabbed a two-shot lead after the rain-delayed third round of the Texas Open in San Antonio. Hammond, who last won at the 1986 Bob Hope Classic, parred the final hole for a 54-hole total of 16-under-par 194 at the short Oak Hills Country Club course. Paul Azinger, Bob Lohy and Duffy Waldorf all trailed by two strokes. The round was delayed nearly three hours by an early-morning downpour.(AP) Okamoto Takes Lead: Ayako Okamoto shot a one-under-par 71 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the Takara Invitational tournament in Gamou, Japan. Okamoto had three birdies and two bogeys on the 7,622-yard par-72 Gamou Golf Course. She was at 210, six under par. Patti Rizzo, the second-round leader, and Aiko Takasu were next at 211.(AP) McBee Moves Ahead: Rives McBee finished with a chip-in birdie to take a one-stroke lead over Gary Player yesterday after the second round of the RJR championship in Clemmons, N.C. McBee, a rookie on the PGA Senior Tour, managed a three-under-par 67 despite a double bogey on the 17th hole.(AP) Boxing Molina Captures Title: Juan (John-John) Molina of Puerto Rico won the International Boxing Federation junior-lightweight championship yesterday when the referee declared Tony Lopez of Sacramento, Calif., defenseless in the 10th round. The ruling sparked shouts and a shower of beer cups from the angry crowd in Sacramento. Molina was ahead on the cards of all three judges: 90-81, 89-83 and 89-82. Molina's record is 20-2. Lopez is 33-2.(AP)

title: Having No Sense of Direction Is Neither Here Nor There
description: I HAVE a terrible sense of direction. Having lived in Westchester County now for nearly 13 years I go by rote to most of my accustomed destinations: the supermarkets, library, mall, even to New York City. I have, I suppose, more or less memorized my way to these places, but this accomplishment was slow and painstaking in coming.

title: WHAT LOLA GOT
description: KISS IN THE HOTEL JOSEPH CONRAD And Other Stories. By Howard Norman. 158 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: Diverse Indian Specialties in Stamford
description: MEERA, Stamford's latest Indian restaurant, is another winning newcomer. Its look is as cool as its cuisine is hot, and the diverse menu is demystified by careful translations and by a friendly, expeditious Indian staff adroit in English.

title: The Girls of Summer
description: HER last night in the major leagues, Mindy Rashbaum saw less action than the ice cream man.

title: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: DUNKIRK: The Complete Story of the First Step in the Defeat of Hitler. By Norman Gelb. (Morrow, $22.95.) The story of Dunkirk is a story of how sluggish armies found themselves outfought while daring troops cut through to victory. In May 1940, Hitler's army slipped around the Maginot Line, slashed between French and British forces, drove toward Paris while French commanders shuffled and fumbled.

title: Historical Acreage Facing Subdivision
description: LEAD: THE sweep and beauty of the land compares only with its historical significance, 11 acres kept intact for 340 years by the descendants of Lion Gardiner, who built a house there for stays off Gardiners Island.

title:
ART;
A Poet's Homage to the City
description: LEAD: THERE is a celebratory quality in the work of the Soviet emigre painter Henry Khudyakov that has remained consistent since he first began to make art, shortly after arriving in New York in 1974.

title: A KILLING IN MAINE
description: Ironically, on the day your article appeared, more than 3,000 gun enthusiasts attended the 12th annual Bangor Gun Show. Meanwhile, as hunting season begins, many of us in the Bangor, Me., area will be especially cautious as we venture outdoors near our homes, lest we, too, be mistaken for an animal by some overzealous hunter. HOWARD P. SEGAL Orono, Me.

title: Climbing High To Fitness
description: PEOPLE ALWAYS ASK ME HOW I can do these crazy things - climbing mountains,'' says Dr. Donald B. Levy, 40, an internist and an instructor at Harvard Medical School. ''But it's not really crazy. Lots of people walk for exercise. I'm just a walker who walks uphill.''

title: Even 1-3 Teams Get Excited on Monday
description: The Jets and the Raiders, two powerful symbols of the genre, tomorrow play their final Monday night game of the 1980's, a sports decade often described as cynical and avaricious.

title: Maryann Mangan Becomes Bride Of C. C. Palermo
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville, N.Y., Maryann Mangan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Mangan of Bronxville, was married yesterday to Christopher Coyne Palermo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Palermo of Rochester.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Aimee R. Clark Weds Engineer
description: Aimee Ruthanna Clark and Matthew Charles Peterson were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y., in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacLennan, a Presbyterian minister. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Merrell Mays Clark of Scarsdale and Mr. and Mrs. Charles O. Peterson of Montpelier, Vt.

title: Lebanese Peace Talks Stall Over Syrians
description: A peace conference in the Saudi city of Taif was deadlocked today over a timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

title: Olive Branch in the Ukraine
description: The Ukraine's new Communist chief has offered to curb harassment of nationalists, provided that they do not advocate secession. Page 18.

title: Turning to the U.S., Again, for Peace Ideas On the Middle East
description: AS Arabs and Israelis have traded talk of peace in recent months, United States diplomacy has seemed to move in the wings, half-player, half-prompter, offering a phrase here, a word there, sometimes a whole chunk of the script. Now, inexorably, a reluctant Washington is being beckoned on stage.

title: The Arts Endowment: Still in Trouble
description: THE struggle in Congress over how much control it should have over the National Endowment for the Arts seems as unlikely to reach a quick resolution as a Wagnerian opera. Although the endowment appears to have avoided being saddled with the Helms amendment, which would have prohibited the financing of ''obscene or indecent'' art as well as that which ''denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion,'' the debate over publicly financed art has just begun.

title: Picture a Home With Flat-Screen TV
description: Most corporations are quite secretive about their long-term research so that, when the time is ripe, they can spring a surprise on their competitors. In a notable exception to this rule, Matsushita of Osaka - the giant company that makes consumer products under the name Panasonic - recently staged an exhibit in Japan that offered a peek at what the company has in store for the future.

title: The Joy of Starvation
description: RECENTLY - IN THE space of a few days, it seemed to me - apples, grapes and all manner of produce grown by means of photosynthesis, as well as all meats derived (directly or indirectly) from animals, have been declared unsafe. It was while I was reeling from this news that I changed my position on censorship. Muzzle the health press! That's what I said to myself. Of course, I say this sort of thing all the time. But usually I shush myself, the way I do when I have a really grotesque thought, like ''What's so bad about Donald Trump, anyway?'' or ''Let's have roast pork tonight. With gravy!''

title: Review/Jazz; Grappelli at Carnegie Hall, Still Seeking New Options
description: Stephane Grappelli's concert at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was an odd mixture of the beautiful - Mr. Grappelli's violin playing is still an example of an unfettered imagination at work - and the badly planned and thoroughly banal. Mr. Grappelli also played with a flat-footed group, including the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, put together by Roger Kellaway; the grouphad the jazz sensibility of a brick wall and the marketing sensiblity of Madison Avenue. It buried Mr. Grappelli's personality, which probably wasn't the point.

title: Powerful Tale of Struggle
description: SHEILA is the generic name for domestic workers in South Africa, and Thursday is their traditional day off. On that day, the women come together for songs and prayer - and for the healing of the spirit.

title: New York's Ships
description: ''New York-Built Ships,'' an exhibition on the history of shipbuilding in Manhattan, will be on view through Jan. 2 at the South Street Seaport Museum, 213 Water Street. Models, carvings, paintings, photographs and other items from various museum collections are included in the show, which focuses on the city's prominence as an international shipbuilding center in the first half of the 19th century. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $5 ($4 for the elderly; $3 for students and $2 for children). Information: 669-9424.

title: A Failed Coup: The Bush Team and Noriega  A special report.; Panama Crisis: Disarray Hindered White House
description: At 9 A.M. Monday, President Bush gathered his senior advisers in the Oval Office to decide whether to throw the might of 12,000 American soldiers behind a little-known Panamanian major who hoped to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: INSIDE
description: Senators Cite Progress In Tax Discussions Republicans and Democrats in the Senate report progress in bargaining over a date to vote on reduction of the capital gains tax. Both sides were seeking tactical advantages and avoiding a filibuster. Page 28. Strength Despite Scandal By some measures, religious broadcasting is more powerful now than before Jim Bakker's resignation from the PTL Ministry. Page 24. Broad Pardon in Argentina President Carlos Saul Menem pardoned those involved in the 1970's ''dirty war'' and those charged in coup attempts of the 1980's. Page 12. New Limits on Art Money Congress sent to President Bush a bill that would deny Federal money for art that is deemed obscene. Page 27. A's and Giants Win Oakland edged Toronto, 6-5, to move within a victory of its second straight American League pennant. The Giants beat the Cubs. Section 8.

title: Beauty; UPS AND DOWNS
description: MISS AMERICA CONTESTANTS wear them with bathing suits. Playboy Playmates wear them with little else. The Rockettes kick up a storm in them. And Barbie's slender plastic feet are permanently poised to be slipped into them. They, of course, are high heels: instruments of torture, symbols of sexuality and fodder for fetishists.

title: Directing 101: George Abbott on What Works
description: George Abbott believes a director wastes his time in rehearsal when he talks endlessly to an actor about who his mother was, what did she want, what does he want and why it has led him up to this moment when he asks for the salt. Instead he prefers that the director get on with it and tell the actor, ''C'mon, Johnny, just pass the salt.'' And for the last 60 years no one has known how to get Johnny on and off an American stage better than George Abbott.

title: Christina Fiore Becomes Bride Of an Executive
description: Christina Barbara Fiore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fiore of New York and Point Lookout, L.I., and Philip Van Munching, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching Jr. of Darien, Conn., were married yesterday by the Rev. Eugene J. Prior at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Ms. Braun Weds A Fellow Lawyer
description: Tracey Elizabeth Braun and Christopher Clark McIsaac were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass., in a ceremony performed by the Rev. James Martin. The bride is the daughter of Howard William Braun of St. Michael's, Md., and Mrs. Richard Roberts Spillman of Berwyn, Pa. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Scott McIsaac of Rochester.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: With apologies to Pedro Guerrero, can a New Yorker not but imagine one of their outfielders with around 50 home runs and 130 runs batted in! National League most valuable player: Kevin Mitchell.

title: TV's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Season Shines Brightest; Opera from Paris to Bologna
description: FOR an American music lover, the main problem with planning trips abroad specifically for musical purposes is a dearth of reliable, sophisticated information. Getting tickets can be a problem, too, of course, although - apart from nearly impossible-to-get-into festivals -that's sometimes solvable through a friendly travel agent or a local concierge or an imploring letter to the organizations in question, which sometimes hold seats aside for foreign visitors.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: The most valuable offensive players were clearly Kevin Mitchell and Ruben Sierra. If one puts enough weight on defensive play and team leadership, one might well opt instead for Ryne Sandberg and Robin Yount. It might be noted that Sandberg's r.b.i. total is about what Howard Johnson's would have been if he had batted second all year. WILLIAM BAKER Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Chilean Volleyball Player Shares Culture and Skill
description: LEAD: WHEN the volleyball players at Fairfield High School learned an exchange student from Santiago, Chile, would be joining the Lady Mustangs, there was a feeling of anxiety and uncertainty.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
Hackensack
description: LEAD: THE corridors of the high school in Hackensack resound with chatter in many languages, and the students come from families representing nearly every rung on the socioeconomic ladder.

title:
INVESTING;
The Case for Convertibles
description: LEAD: As the stock market has surged this year, convertibles, too, have scored gains well into the double digits. Their promise of high current income and a portion of the stock market's advances merits attention from investors who hold only stocks and bonds. But convertibles can be tricky to evaluate and about as vulnerable as stocks to a market crash.

title: 'Cage Aux Folles': The Gender Trap
description: ''LA CAGE AUX FOLLES,'' a spun-sugar confection of romance served up with just a dollop of reality, is the season's opener at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: DATA BANK: Oct. 8, 1989
Commercial Property: Prairie Growth; In Sioux Falls, Commerce Blooms Like Wildflowers
description: AT first glance, the modern office buildings and an expanding mammoth retail center set amid grazing cattle and cornfields that edge this prairie city seem inappropriate investments for such a setting.

title: Nicole Falconer Weds Michael Pisani
description: Nicole Claire Falconer and Michael B. Pisani were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., by Msgr. John Corr. The bride, 24 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Warren E. Falconer of Convent Station, N.J. The bridegroom, also 24, is a son of Mrs. David S. Bonsal and B. Michael Pisani, both of Short Hills, N.J.

title: ed>Rings of Time
description: THE treasure, an old filigreed wedding band set with three small diamonds, lay lightly in my hand. It had been wrapped up in cloth inside a manila envelope in the bottom of my dresser drawer when I came across it quite by accident while searching for some papers.

title:
INVESTING;
Liz Claiborne Recovers
description: LEAD: Liz Claiborne Inc. is back. Long known for its strong growth, the women's apparel manufacturer suffered its first annual earnings decline last year. Now the company is again reporting record earnings. Barbara L. Kahn, an analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, recommends the stock for the best of reasons: ''a tremendous increase in gross margins.

title: For Women, A New Age Of Choices
description: I AM among the missing. Many people would like to find me and ask some questions about where I have been for more than 20 years. You see, I am a registered nurse who stopped working in that profession when I was 26 years old.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport ... $153,000 357 Second Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; basement, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. Carle Place ... $158,500 217 Raff Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,500. Elmont ... $157,000 271 Norfield Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,200. Farmingdale ... $175,000 1 Fourth Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. Glen Cove ... $245,000 51 Willits Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Searingtown ... $690,000 24 Crest Hollow Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; den, library, maid's room, basement, c/a; taxes $10,000. OTHER AREAS Cheshire, Conn. ... $208,000 567 Woodpond Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old raised ranch; large closets, w/w carpeting, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,047. Pleasantville, N.Y. ... $577,000 115 Deerfield Lane North 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; fireplace, family room, 2-car garage, 0.92 acre; taxes $9,411. Toms River, N.J. ... $98,000 542 Cornell Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 19-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, full basement, new furnace; taxes $1,300.

title: Will Decreased Use of Chemicals Leave Farmers Better Off?
description: To the Editor:

title: A LOVE AFFAIR WITH WALKING
description: I was enjoying Harrison E. Salisbury's ''A Love Affair With Walking'' (April 16) until I came upon his derisive comments on Los Angeles, a place he says ''no one of right mind'' would consider walking in. I invite Mr. Salisbury to walk among the hipsters who crowd Melrose Avenue, the Orthodox Jews who patronize the kosher shops on Fairfax Avenue and the culturally minded standing in line for the latest exhibit at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Hungry? Try strolling through the farmers' market. And if Mr. Salisbury is really up to it, he can walk among those on their way to work in offices on Wilshire Boulevard. Jane Galbraith Los Angeles.

title: Protest Is Held at Site Of Rights Chief's Talk
description: Gay rights protesters held a demonstration today at a hotel where a conservative church group was running a symposium in which speakers warned that homosexuals are a threat to American culture.

title: Why Mets Lost: Let Us Count
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Children From India Are Said To Be Used in Camel Races
description: The Indian authorities say they have uncovered child-smuggling gangs that send children as young as 5 years old to Persian Gulf countries to be used as human sirens in camel races.

title: WHOLESOMELY SHRILL
description: LEAD: CREATING AMERICA George Horace Lorimer and The Saturday Evening Post. By Jan Cohn. Illustrated. 326 pp. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press. $24.95.

title: The Great Home-Fitness Craze
description: LEAD: A NEW ROWING MACHINE is much more than a method for getting exercise. Its sleek lines seem to embody fitness and radiate health. In time, however, this gleaming image gives way to reality. A rowing machine, or any other home-exercise device, doesn't confer fitness by osmosis. You have to work hard at it.

title: America Tackles The Pesticide Crisis
description: JIM KNUTZON IS SITTING IN THE restaurant of the Hilton Hotel in Pleas-anton, Calif., near Oakland, solemnly regarding the plate of swordfish smothered in sauteed vegetables just set before him. With his head bowed, he delivers what might be construed as a modern-day meditation. Knutzon, a former pesticide salesman who now advises farmers on pesticide alternatives, expresses the hope that people across America will soon be able to sit down to meals that are free of toxic pesticide residues. This said, he begins to eat.

title: How the Japanese Saw the Arrival of the West
description: IN a way, Lincoln Kirstein was anticipating camp when he began collecting Japanese prints in the 1930's. Not for him the Utamaros and Hiroshiges favored by connoisseurs; his rebellious spirit was attracted to the woodcuts turned out for popular consumption on cheap paper in colors that, after the introduction of aniline dyes, seem tawdry - even today.

title: Lisa Klein Weds Michael O. Boldt
description: Lisa K. Klein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Klein of Washington Depot, Conn., and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael O. Boldt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien Boldt of Englewood, N.J.

title: Sustaining Sales by Improving Convenience
description: Taken a good look at your favorite vending machine lately?

title: REFERENCE
description: TOTAL BASEBALL. Edited by John Thorn and Pete Palmer with David Reuther. (Warner, $49.95.) Baseball is the game of numbers. Its order and its complexities have invited, even demanded, statistics for more than a century. ''Total Baseball'' is one of the best baseball statistics books ever. It uses the traditional statistics, accumulated though painstaking research (Ty Cobb had 4,190 hits, not 4,191), as well as new ones: the so-called sabermetrics popularized by Bill James and by John Thorn and Pete Palmer in their book, ''The Hidden Game of Baseball,'' to rate players of different eras by adjustments that reflect how the game has changed. Their computer base goes back into the last century, and using the Thorn-Palmer scheme of Linear Weights (best defined in the book, not in a short review) they determine that the best single season by a pitcher was Silver King's in 1888 with the St. Louis Browns, when he had 45 wins, 21 losses and a 1.64 e.r.a. Similarly, their numbers maintain that the 10 all-time best careers ever were those of Babe Ruth, Ty Cobb, Hank Aaron,Ted Williams, Willie Mays, Nap Lajoie, Walter Johnson, Cy Young, Tris Speaker and Mike Schmidt. Pick your statistic, traditional or newfangled, and look at the records of 13,000 players. Don't be put off by the 2,294 pages; the first 678 are essays, mostly forgettable. The numbers start on page 679.

title: THE A.C.L.U.'S POLICIES
description: There are many things wrong with the American Civil Liberties Union, and Jeffrey T. Leeds has pointed to some of them, as well as to what is right about its policies (''The A.C.L.U. - Impeccable Judgments or Tainted Policies?'' Sept. 10). But its chief weakness, as I see it, is its insistence that a general principle, whether it deals with free speech or due process, should be applied to all cases - without regard for the consequences. Thus, the A.C.L.U. is willing ''to vindicate a convicted criminal's rights of due process, even if it means setting a killer free.''

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Make a Comeback
description: AFTER an erratic six-month decline that brought mortgage rates down more than a percentage point since last spring, much of the nation is experiencing a minirevival of demand for home loans, most of it in plain vanilla fixed-rate financing.

title: Susan Gilbert Marries Stuart Lovejoy
description: Susan Gilbert, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Gilbert Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Dataw Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Stuart Simmons Lovejoy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stuart Lovejoy of Sewickley, Pa. The Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo officiated at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I.

title: Joan M. Cheever Weds D. C. Quinn
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Mission San Jose in San Antonio, Joan McKinney Cheever, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Cheever Jr. of San Antonio, was married yesterday to Dennis Christopher Quinn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Quinn of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. William J. Collins officiated.

title: Annette Linde Marries Stephen Weatherhead
description: Annette Linde and Stephen Wayne Weatherhead, graduates of the Syracuse University School of Architecture, were married yesterday in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Richard R. McKeon Jr. officiated at Zion Episcopal Church.

title: Playoff's Sorcerer and Star
description: To the Oakland Athletics, who brought him to the big leagues in 1979, Rickey Henderson was a rare mixture of speed and strength, a man who stole 100 bases in his first full season and 130 two years later.

title: CRIME
description: In their relentless quest for a decent apartment in Manhattan, New Yorkers sometimes resort to UNORTHODOX PRACTICES (Pocket Books, Paper, $3.50), an apt title for this hilarious first mystery by Marissa Piesman, co-author of ''The Yuppie Handbook'' and, more to the point, a practicing real estate attorney. Nina Fischman, the Legal Aid housing lawyer who makes her snooping debut here, suspects foul play when two elderly clients die unexpectedly, leaving vacant prime apartments with absolutely no trace of cockroaches. The sinister significance of this unheard-of situation is also not lost on Nina's mother, Ida, a shrewd Upper West Sider whose profound grasp of real estate issues should be an inspiration to us all.

title: Miss Richards, Teacher, Weds
description: Elizabeth Glazier Richards, an English teacher at the Brearley School, was married yesterday to Mitchell Ira Francis, a mathematics teacher at the Horace Mann School. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr., an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, and Rabbi Abraham Weisman officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: The Power of Concentration
description: FRESH WINDS FROM CANADA tore at the psychologist's face, bringing tears to his eyes, as he strolled along Lake Michigan with the Chicago skyline back over his shoulders and talked about that most prized of human experiences - pure enjoyment. Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi is a man obsessed by happiness. For more than two decades, most recently as a professor of psychology and education at the University of Chicago, he has been trying to identify with some scientific exactness what people mean when they say they are enjoying themselves, how they achieve that enjoyment and how the successful ones manage to keep themselves from falling out of it. More precisely, Csikszentmihalyi (pronounced Chick-SENT-me-hi) finds himself focusing on one aspect of human experience that he calls flow.

title: When the Untouchables Are Retouched
description: They're the movies' equivalent of national historic places: 25 classic American films of cultural or esthetic significance to be preserved in trust as part of a National Film Registry overseen by the Librarian of Congress. The films - 50 more titles will be added to the list over the next two years - were chosen last month by the Librarian and the National Preservation Board, comprising representatives of the film industry and related endeavors. With its choices made, the registry is now wrestling with the big question confronting most things designated historic. How do you protect the original?

title: I Need Some Repairs
description: MY person is in need of mending along with my house and car. We're running neck and neck, falling apart simultaneously. My old Buick-friend is no more. It has spluttered, squeaked and coughed its way to its dotage; it has hiccupped, wheezed and sometimes purred its way to decrepitude. For a car 26 years old it is over the hill in spades. Copious tears have splashed the patched upholstery. The mortifying offenses of time had manifested themselves into a frankly fraying state. The jig was up.

title: Moscow No Big Potato
description: To the Editor:

title: Broader Membership Is Giving Teachers' Union New Influence
description: LEAD: IN the last decade, the state's largest teachers' union has moved to broaden its membership, and today more than one-quarter of its members are cafeteria workers, bus drivers, secretaries, teaching aides, computer technicians and school security guards. School officials say the broadening of the union's membership could have far-reaching implications for public education in New

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Working Girl 1988. CBS/Fox Home Video. $89.98. 1 hour, 53 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Offering its heroine one of the best opportunities for wish fulfillment this side of ''Cinderella,'' Mike Nichols's film ''derives a lot of its charm from the performance of Melanie Griffith, the baby-voiced bombshell who gives Tess an unbeatable mixture of street smarts, business sense and sex appeal.'' Sigourney Weaver and Joan Cusack offer memorable performances, but Harrison Ford plays a kind of all-purpose generic male. ''Enjoyable even when it isn't credible, which is most of the time,'' this film, like its heroine, ''has a genius for getting by on pure charm.'' (Janet Maslin) Major League 1989. Paramount Home Video. No list price. LD, $24.95. 1:47. CC. R. Though cast close to type, Tom Berenger, Charlie Sheen, Corbin Bernsen and Bob Uecker give quirky performances in David Ward's loopy film about movie baseball, which is ''even goofier than baseball as we know it.'' Until the last half-hour, when it goes soft and ''heads for that never-never land of movie baseball, where the obligatory big game and the slow-motion shot of the last play are waiting,'' this spoof is ''wonderfully unpretentious, uningratiating and uninspiring.'' (Caryn James) The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie 1969. CBS/Fox. $79.98. 1:56. CC. PG. Based on a novel by Muriel Spark and a play by Jay Presson Allen, this tale of an unconventional Scottish schoolteacher teetering between a basic common sense and a delicate paranoia, makes ''a very decent movie, but it will probably be underrated because it must seem smaller than the big, extraordinary performance that Maggie Smith gives.'' The director, Ronald Neame, has cast the movie superbly, with Robert Stephens, Pamela Franklin and others. (Vincent Canby) The Choirboys 1977. MCA Home Video. $79.95. 2:00. R. Based more or less on a best-selling novel by Joseph Wambaugh, which came alive with ''a forlorn truth,'' Robert Aldrich's movie ''is cheap and nasty without having any redeeming vulgarity and absolutely no conviction of truth.'' Charles Durning, Perry King, Tim McIntire, Randy Quaid and Burt Young turn in intermittently entertaining performances as Los Angeles cops of assorted eccentricities needing to unwind. ''A stylistic and narrative mess.'' (Canby) Bedtime Story 1964. MCA. $59.95. 1:39. Not rated. Marlon Brando is ''full of surprises,'' a critic wrote at the time. Departing from his usual style, Brando plays ''a ring-a-ding comedy character'' - ''a low-down conniver, a sweet-talking, free-wheeling fraud,'' the counterpart of Steve Martin's role in last year's remake of the film, ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels.'' David Niven creates the role of the suave con man, later portrayed by Michael Caine, and Shirley Jones gives a ''sweet'' performance. ''Mark this one down as good, crisp fun.'' A Summer Story 1988. Media Home Entertainment. $79.95. 1:37. PG-13. Adapted by Penelope Mortimer from a John Galsworthy story and directed by Piers Haggard, this is ''a relentlessly pretty film'' that's no more tough-minded than its lead character. ''It could be described as pure hokum if the characters spoke that way, but they don't.'' The stars, Imogen Stubbs, James Wilby and Susannah York, don't so much act as glow. The ending is calculated to require four hankies. (Maslin) Let's Dance 1950. Paramount. $14.95. 1:52. Not rated. The title is appropriate to this Fred Astaire vehicle, according to a contemporary critic, and when the star ''turns his legs to dancing, the new musical . . . whirls as gracefully as a fast spinning top. But when Mr. Astaire steps back into the role of actor and the story takes over, the momentum slackens noticeably and [ the film ] becomes a wobbly entertainment.'' An incompatible partner, Betty Hutton ''runs rampant.''

title: Mara Dolan Wed To Daniel O'Day
description: Mara Grace Dolan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Dolan of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Daniel Patrick O'Day, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Day of Wilton, Conn. The ceremony was performed at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Michael G. Pierce, assisted by the Revs. Bradley Beaupre and Thomas Murphy.

title: Breaking the Sound Barrier
description: TO THOSE WHO HAVE TROUBLE hearing a doorbell ring or a baby cry, the computer has become as significant as the hearing aid itself.

title: CAMERA
description: The man behind the counter at the one-hour photo lab handed me my batch of prints and then offered a word of advice: ''Don't use 400-speed film for the desert. Save it for when the light is low.''

title: Jeanette P. Joyce, A Nurse, Marries
description: Jeanette P. Joyce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher J. Joyce of Dumont, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert A. Cancellieri, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Cancellieri of Riverside, N.J. The Rev. Michael Riester officiated at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church on Long Beach Island, N.J.

title: Sports Medicine Caring for Performers
description: LEAD: OUT of desperation, Murry Sidlin, the former conductor of the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, sought treatment for a sore shoulder at the Yale Medical School Sports Medicine Center.

title: Time for Straight Talk
description: This is the time of year, the High Holy Days, when Jews are supposed to look into themselves, reflect on what has been and commit themselves to what should be. In 1989 it should be a time also for honest thinking about the future of Israel.

title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications
description: When Mia Dillon, wearing a voluminous dress, makes her first entrance in ''The Aunts,'' it is immediately clear to everyone in the theater that her character is supposed to be pregnant - to everyone, that is, except the other characters on stage. For unexplained reasons, the young woman's two aunts are oblivious to her condition.

title: Into the Woods: Junk Cars and Old Stoves
description: A HIKER in the woods accustomed to rounding a corner and coming upon a deer or other wild animal is just as likely these days to confront a rusting Ford or a rotting La-Z-Boy.
