Across the state, many of the remaining unspoiled areas are fast becoming spoiled by the illegal dumping of automobiles, tire, furniture and major appliances.

title: Israeli Preschool Project is Adopted
description: LEAD: THE Yonkers school district is instituting a program developed in Israel that trains disadvantaged parents to teach their preschool children some of the skills the children will need to succeed in school.

title: Legendary Lunch
description: I LOVE eating out - especially out of the country. My husband, Bert, and I have had our most memorable meals in faraway places: Thanksgiving dinner in an Army mess hall in South Korea, a traditional Sabbath among the Jews of Marrakesh, a 12-course Chinese banquet on the Yangtze River, and a herring and aquavit party on a smiling summer night in the Swedish archipelago.

title: Searching for Incentives To Entice Polluters
description: As Congress last week discussed the renewal of the Clean Air Act, it wrestled with expanded use of an unusual concept in pollution control: letting industries buy and sell the right to emit pollutants, with companies deciding among themselves how to share the work that the Government wants done. Under President Bush's proposal, this flexibility would extend to automobiles. The law would specify the number of ''alternative fuel'' cars but would not say what fuel or precisely which companies would make them or the fuels.

title: Damage Control for The Holidays
description: THE IDEA OF HEALTH-ful holiday food is something of an oxymoron. Holidays, after all, are times of feasting, and feasting connotes an embarrassment of food -plates piled high with succulent meats, larded puddings and wedges of buttery pie. These are, of course, precisely the kinds of foods that we should eat only in moderation. So what to do with the holidays?

title: Protection Weighed for Bluefish Stocks
description: LEAD: IT would not seem that an animal as ferocious and seemingly abundant as the bluefish would require special protection.

title: Sharon L. Bullock Becomes a Bride
description: Sharon Laure Bullock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford J. Bullock of Buffalo, Minn., was married yesterday to Joshua D. Libresco, the son of Dr. Emile Libresco of Greens Farms, Conn., and the late Iris Adams Libresco. The Rev. Timothy Power officiated at the Pax Christi Roman Catholic Church in Eden Prairie, Minn.

title: Graduating From the Kitchen Floor
description: ONCE upon a time there was an ordinary housewife who had three children. She liked the wife part and the mother part must have been pretty good since she had two babies and then adopted a third one.

title: Queens Girl, 10, Is Shot in Head By Stray Bullet
description: There was a crimson bloodstain the size of a quarter yesterday on the asphalt in front of the Friendly bodega near the Redfern Houses in Far Rockaway, Queens. An orange police tape twisted in the sea breeze, and teen-age boys whispered about the shooting Friday night of a young girl caught in the path of a bullet fired by a youth as he argued with other youths over a game of dice.

title: Afghanistan Waits for East-West Compromise; Badly Needed Peace
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Authentic Japanese Cuisine by the River
description: LEAD: WITH the impressive new Chinzan-So restaurant, authentic Japanese cuisine has arrived on the banks of the Hudson - and so have authentic Tokyo prices. The much-publicized $7.5 million building, which juts out into the river across from upper Manhattan, is the flagship in the United States of a group of Japanese restaurants.

title: All Some People Really Want to Know Is in Shorter Books
description: SAUL BELLOW'S new novel, ''The Bellarosa Connection,'' began arriving in bookstores in recent weeks.

title: Families of Tragedy and Passion On Brazilian Bill at Repertorio Espanol
description: LEAD: On Friday, Repertorio Espanol begins a double bill in Spanish -with synopses in English - by the controversial Brazilian writer Nelson Rodrigues. The one-act plays, ''Family Album'' and ''All Nakedness Will Be Punished,'' to be performed this month at Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, are being directed by the iconoclastic Antunes Filho under the collective title, ''Nelson 2 Rodrigues.

title: For the Automobile's Sake, An 1855 House Faces Razing
description: ITS shutters hang at odd angles, and many of the windows are broken. A wraparound front porch, once the hallmark of Victorian splendor, is now weatherworn and buckled. But for James R. Croucher, 58 years old, the battered house brings back visions of a time when neighbors knew neighbors and farm life revolved around the rising and setting sun.

title: COINS
description: Where does the $ sign come from?

title: FICTION
description: HERE ARE YOU DYING TONIGHT? By Michel Deon. Translated by Julian Evans. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) The death of the protagonist in too many modern novels leaves the reader merely eager to move on to the next book, but by the time Stanislas Beren departs from Michel Deon's ''Where Are You Dying Tonight?'' we have learned (and come to admire) so much about him that his end provokes real regret. In this highly literate novel, the French author's first work to be published in English, a young man of unknown origins arrives at a ''rather snobbish lycee'' in Paris, is taken up and ''civilized'' by a fellow student's well-to-do family and eventually becomes a celebrated novelist. The story, which begins in 1925 and ends in 1977, is a delicious merging of narrative passages with excerpts from Stanislas' writings (footnotes included) and flashbacks to the events of his life that inspired those writings, not to mention numerous references to actual books, poems, paintings and people. Stanislas marries his best friend's aunt Felicite, with whom for nearly 40 years he enjoys a perfectly complicitous understanding and mutual respect, although he has many liaisons and a couple of great loves along the way. The novel's citations of authors from Rimbaud to Maugham, descriptive phrases about paintings by artists from Giorgione to Picasso and mentions of real people from the period in which the book takes place are not only fun but also make one want to follow the Berens' trail through London and Paris to the art museums and trattorias of Venice. And the felicitous translation by Julian Evans never stumbles.

title: Pact Will Not Bankrupt Hospitals, Officials Say
description: New York City's troubled private hospitals will not, as hospital representatives predict, be driven into bankruptcy by last week's $250 million settlement with their union workers, financial analysts, state and union officials say.

title: Review/Music; A Concert in Celebration Of Rochberg's Electicism
description: Even in the program notes for a concert of his music, George Rochberg is likely to be discussed more for what he represents than for what he is. Mr. Rochberg is known, to the extent he is known at all, as the apostate serialist, the composer who decided he loved old music with its melodies and intelligible harmonies and would jolly well write that way whether it was in line with progress and current thinking or not.

title: Streetscapes: 17th Street Off Union Square; 10 Houses With Collective Charm
description: IT is hard to pinpoint exactly what is special about the old houses on the south side of East 17th Street between Union Square and Irving Place. The individual buildings are not outstanding and most are a bit neglected, even shabby.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: J. MICHAEL GALVIN;
Watching Out for the Health of Hospitals
description: LEAD: A HOSPITAL stay during his senior year at the University of Scranton convinced J. Michael Galvin to abandon his plans to pursue a career in communications and to study hospital administration instead. Mr. Galvin, the current chairman of the Princeton-based New Jersey Hospital Association, has never regretted the switch.

title: Anne Simmons Nimick Married to Carl L. Neilson
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Anne Simmons Nimick, the daughter of Anne Corkran Nimick of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to Carl Lundquist Neilson, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Jack D. Neilson of Parkersburg, W.Va. The Rev. Mark Andrus officiated.

title: America's Health: An Assessment
description: YOU WON'T BELIEVE WHAT'S HAP-pened to Americans since you took leave of this world some 30 years ago. We've become a bunch of health nuts. And sometimes I wonder whether serious scientists and even health columnists like your beloved daughter don't deserve a bit of the credit - or is it the blame?

title: Senators See Some Progress On Cut in Capital Gains Tax
description: White House negotiators and the Senate Republican leadership bargained with Senate Democrats today, seeking a firm date for a vote that could give President Bush a permanent cut in the capital gains tax.

title: Plans for Ecology Center Outlined
description: FOR a quarter of a century, Robert Boyle has been fighting a dump. Last week, the president of the Hudson River Fishermen's Association predicted that his old foe would become the ''Harvard of dumps'' as part of a new educational and research center proposed for the Hudson River site.

title: Trouble Finding Things? Tips on How to Organize
description: TAKE a look around you. Are you an ''Everything Out''? Are papers strewn about your desk haphazardly, each related to a different project, each demanding immediate attention, and each destined to end up somewhere other than where you will eventually look for it?

title: Police and Protesters Clash Amid East Berlin Festivity
description: East Berlin ended its 40th anniversary celebrations tonight with clashes between demonstrators demanding change and police troops.

title: Outdoors; Coalition Fights Dam to Save Salmon
description: Resistance to the hydroelectric dam known as the Basin Mills project, on the Penobscot River in Maine, continues to gain momentum.

title: Dr. Watkis Marries
description: Dr. Patricia Ann Watkis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clinton J. Watkis of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Charles Dale May, a son of Clevon May and Maereatha May of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Jeremiah Wright, at the Concord Baptist Church of Christ in Brooklyn. The bride, who will retain her name, is a radiologist in Great Lakes, Ill. Mr. May is an engineering manager at Timplex Inc., a telecommunications company in Schaumburg, Ill.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Sunday about the composer and critic Virgil Thomson misidentified a performer whose repertory was dismissed by Mr. Thomson as ''silk-underwear music.''

title: Venture Capital Loses Its Vigor
description: An air of serenity pervades 3000 Sand Hill Road, a campus-like cluster of office buildings that is the venture capital business's equivalent of Wall Street. More than 20 venture firms in plush offices here plot their next investments in Silicon Valley, a few miles to the south, hoping to pick the next Apple Computer or Genentech. At lunch, their partners congregate at the Sundeck, an airy restaurant in the center of the complex that serves ''venture burgers'' and puts pencils on the tables so customers can scribble the details of their deals on the placemats.

title: MUCH ADO ABOUT MACHU PICCHU
description: LEAD: PORTRAIT OF AN EXPLORER Hiram Bingham, Discoverer of Machu Picchu. By Alfred M. Bingham. Illustrated. 381 pp. Ames: Iowa State University Press. $29.95.

title: Families Learn to Save Their History
description: Sushan Chin gave life-saving lessons at the McBurney Y.M.C.A. yesterday.

title: Heeeere's Jesse
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson may have found the ideal interim occupation for a once and future Presidential candidate -being host of a television talk show. Mr. Jackson, who sought the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984 and 1988 and is considered likely to run again in 1992, said last week that the debut of his hourlong weekly show, ''Voices of America With Jesse Jackson,'' was planned for fall 1990. He said the syndicated program will ''make room for those voices that make up the real America'' and that being a TV host will not affect his political plans. Unless, perhaps, he gets beaten in the ratings wars by Oprah, Geraldo or Donahue.

title: Teresa Duncan Weds Harry Cox Jr.
description: At the Shiloh Baptist Church in Plainfield, N.J., Teresa Maria Duncan, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John T. Duncan of Dayton, Ohio, was married yesterday to Harry L. Cox Jr., a son of Dorothy Cox of San Francisco and Mr. Cox of Mountain View, Calif. The Rev. Jerry W. Henry officiated.

title: Turning the Living Room Into an Intimate Concert Hall
description: AN unusual music organization in the county has begun its eighth season of fall concerts. This group does not advertise and receives virtually no municipal aid, yet the total for its audiences this year is expected to be more than 1,500, and its concerts sell out quickly.

title: Where Humans Have Edge on Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Little York Draws Big Talent
description: When Janet Hayes Walker decided to form a small theater company on Manhattan's Upper East Side in 1969, the venture seemed as unlikely as Mickey Rooney and Judy Garland staging a full-scale production in somebody's barn. Like the plucky teen-agers portrayed by that pair in numerous musicals, Mrs. Walker had plenty of drive and imagination but limited behind-the-scenes experience and even less cash.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CHAMBER MUSIC CONCERT

title: Charlene Kulick Marries
description: Charlene Kulick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kulick of Dupont, Pa., and Andrew Jay Pal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pal of New York, were married yesterday at St. Juliana's Church in Rock Lake, Pa. The Rev. Bernard Shepulski performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. Mrs. Pal, 26 years old, is a litigation associate in the Washington office of the Chicago law firm of Kirkland & Ellis. Mr. Pal, also 26, is an associate at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: IT'S A BEAR MARKET FOR STOCK ANALYSTS
description: A few months ago, David Musket gave up a promising career as a securities analyst at the Wall Street powerhouse of Goldman, Sachs & Company to try his hand at the risky business of managing other people's money.

title: 200 Military Officers Are Pardoned in Argentina
description: President Carlos Saul Menem today pardoned more than 200 military officers accused of human rights abuses and aiding military rebellions, saying the move was essential for national reconciliation.

title: Minister Found Slain In Manhattan Home
description: An 83-year-old Pentecostal minister was found stabbed to death in his Upper West Side apartment yesterday afternoon and the police have charged his roommate in the slaying.

title: Dinner With Bunny
description: To the Editor:

title: Off on Jaunts for Fun and Knowledge
description: LEAD: ''WEAR comfortable shoes and take a camera'' is the advice of the Westchester organizations and institutions that are sponsoring trips to many different locales during the coming months.

title: Mood and Mist in Portugal
description: ROBERT SOUTHEY, the early-19th-century Poet Laureate of England, was forever haunted by a memory of his youth. ''If I had Aladdin's lamp, the genius should transport me, my household and my books to Cintra. . . . Cintra, the most blessed spot in the habitable globe, will almost bring tears to my eyes.''

title: Correction
description: The review of Paul West's novel ''Lord Byron's Doctor'' on Sept. 3 misstated the relationship of two members of Byron's circle. A reader has written to point out that Claire Clairmont and Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley were stepsisters, not half-sisters.

title: Rethinking the Convenience Store
description: For convenience stores, these should be the golden years. First, supermarkets all but killed off corner groceries. Then the supermarkets themselves consolidated into sprawling, remote megastores. The convenience store chains, the field wide open, eagerly expanded across the nation.

title: Comfortable Bistros and a Handsom Indian Spot
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: NEW FIGHTS OVER SPOILING YOUR BABY
description: Marie Winn's article ''New Fights Over Spoiling Your Baby'' (April 16) states the widely held misconception that infants are only able to communicate by screaming. Numerous scientific observations document what sensitive parents and professionals can easily observe: babies have a rich and eloquent vocabulary of expression, gesture and gaze. Failure of parents to tune in to this capacity of their babies, and neglect of professionals to help parents learn the simple skills needed, can make for a distressing communication gap between parents and their babies.

title: UNNECESSARY SURGERY
description: As I read James Barron's article ''Unnecessary Surgery'' (April 16), I wondered whether my initial reaction qualified me for a Hostile Persons Award from Daniel Goleman, author of ''Agreeableness vs. Anger,'' appearing in the same issue. The problem is far more complex than Mr. Barron allows. Neither medical nor surgical management is an exact science. Some potential for over- (or under-) treatment is therefore implicit in an equation that is usually presented to the patient in terms of a risk-benefit ratio.

title: Greg Taylor, No. 16, Auburn wide receiver, has the ball knocked from his grasp by Chris Tolbert of Kentucky in the first half. (AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL: SOUTH; Virginia Tech Upsets West Virginia
description: The freshman Mickey Thomas kicked four field goals today and Virginia Tech upset West Virginia, 12-10, as the Mountaineers lost their first regular-season game since 1987.

title: Order on the Field
description: Things seem to have gotten a bit unruly in European soccer recently, and now the sport's governing body, the Union of European Football Associations, has taken steps to restore order.

title: History, Foliage and Manhattan Views
description: The roar of American artillery hurling cannonballs at passing British warships 213 years ago has been replaced by the hum of traffic emptying off the George Washington Bridge into New Jersey. But the Fort Lee Historic Park makes every effort to erase two centuries of technology and transport the visitor back to the late 1770's.

title: Campus Life: Tufts; Policy Suspended Amid Controversy Over Free Speech
description: Citing widespread disagreement on campus, Tufts University last week suspended indefinitely a new policy that many students said interfered with their right to free speech.

title: Adrienne Brodeur to Marry Next Year
description: Mrs. Henry Hornblower 2d of Boston and Paul Brodeur of North Truro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adrienne Willets Brodeur, and Bartlett Christmas Brewster, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Brewster of Plymouth, Mass. The wedding is to be next summer.

title: OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
description: Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, is a scenic place. Every summer, Canadian tourists descend by the thousands to camp along its beaches and hike its winding trails. There are souvenir shops everywhere, and the gifts they carry - tartan tams, bright plaid ties, bagpiper key chains -proudly advertise the island's Scottish ancestry.

title: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: HISTORY AND HOPE: Essays on History and the English Civil War. By C. V. Wedgwood. (Dutton, $25.) C. V. Wedgwood believes in the individual. She believes in the individual historian, who is artist and scientist, and she believes history is the acts and beliefs of individuals, common and uncommon.

title: PLAYING DICE WITH MEDICINE
description: In her article ''Playing Dice With Medicine'' (April 16), Linda J. Heller notes that millions of Americans ''fail to take their medicine properly or don't take it at all.'' She gives several reasons for this and I would like to add another: the hierarchical relationship between many doctors and patients. The terms ''doctor's order'' and ''patient compliance'' identify the physician as the active and the patient as the passive partner in their relationship. When physicians' attitudes toward their patients change enough to replace the concept of doctor's order with that of a ''contract'' negotiated between patient and physician, a major obstacle to the execution of that contract will be gone. THOMAS F. PLAUT, M.D. Amherst, Mass.

title: Louise M. Quick, A Lawyer, Is Wed To L. B. Spann Jr.
description: Louise Mabel Quick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Roland Quick of Morristown, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Lewis Brown Spann Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Spann of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Revs. Thomas Sheffield and George White in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church in Morristown.

title: A KILLING IN MAINE
description: My mother, too, was shot by a deer hunter - while clearing brush outside her house in Kent, Conn., in 1976. That particular Nimrod left her to bleed to death in her backyard, then fled to his lawyer's office. She managed to crawl to a phone - and help. She, too, was an ''outsider'' and was told that criminal prosecution was impossible. And as in Mrs. Wood's case, the final result was an out-of-court civil settlement for medical expenses, paid from the hunter's homeowner's policy. Unlike Mrs. Wood, my mother survived - at no small cost in rehabilitation, career losses and partial disablement.

title: Tanker Captain Wins Relocation of Trial
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the tanker that caused the worst oil spill in the nation's history, has won state prosecutors' agreement to have his trial moved out of the south Alaskan port city of Valdez.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: TRAPPED IN THEIR WORLDS
description: LEAD: PRIVATE TERROR/PUBLIC LIFE Psychosis and the Politics of Community. By James M. Glass. 253 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $29.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
REFERENCE
description: LEAD: THE HEART OF ROCK & SOUL: The 1001 Greatest Singles Ever Made. By Dave Marsh. (Plume/New American Library, Paper $14.95.) Rock critics are a hopelessly conceited and anal bunch: they make lists the way other people make breakfast: lists of the year's best and worst records, the month's most fabulous singles and album - some critics even do it weekly.

title: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE MEN WHO LOVED EVELYN COTTON. By Frank Ronan. (Pantheon, $17.95.) Lovers - bruising, affectionate, selfish, obsessed - traipse through Evelyn Cotton's life at a rate alarming only to the narrator of this savory first novel by Frank Ronan, a young Irish writer knowing enough to lay bare the complexities of desire.

title: Soviets Urge Stronger Role for World Court
description: In what it calls a move to strengthen international law, the Soviet Union has called for a treaty that would oblige signing countries to submit drawn-out disputes to the International Court of Justice in The Hague for binding arbitration.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JOHN MONTAGUE MASSENGALE;
A Call for the Traditional Neighborhood
description: LEAD: IT used to be that towns developed near a railroad station, and most of the people who lived in the town lived within walking distance of stores, schools, jobs and mass transit. Once the car was invented and mass-produced, all that began to change. The result is that today people live miles away from many of their destinations.

title: To D'Amato, Sunday on the Boardwalk Is Politics as Usual
description: LEAD: ''FRANNIE, I walked the boardwalk twice yesterday and I never saw you,'' Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said to Francis T. Purcell, the former Nassau County Executive, on the boardwalk in Long Beach last Sunday.

title: Sideline Worker Honored
description: Bernie Sherman, an end on DeWitt Clinton's unbeaten, untied, unscored upon football team of 1932, worked his 500th consecutive game with the sideline marker chains yesterday at the Governors' homecoming in the Bronx. The milestone was marked by honoring the 75-year-old Sherman during halftime of the game with Curtis and giving him the game ball after Clinton's 16-6 victory, its fourth without a loss this season.

title: A Helping Hand on Reverse Mortgages
description: A pilot program run by the Federal Housing Administration that could spur the use of reverse mortgages is just now getting under way around the country.

title: THE BLOOD OF A GENIUS
description: FEDERICO GARCIA LORCA A Life. By Ian Gibson. Illustrated. 551 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $29.95.

title: Scandals Aside, TV Preachers Thrive
description: While Jim Bakker ponders the possiblity of prison, Mother Mary Angelica sits at Our Lady of the Angels monastery in Birmingham, Ala., planning to broadcast to the world.

title: REALITY TRIP IN AFRICA
description: MAASAI DAYSBy Cheryl Bentsen. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: BRAWLING OVER HARRODS
description: SOME PEOPLE LOVE IT, OTHERS HATE IT, BUT FEW would dispute that Harrods is the world's most famous department store. Its size, its style, its history and mystique combine to place Harrods in a class apart. By night, the hulking Edwardian emporium, with its terra cotta exterior illuminated by 11,000 lights, resembles some giant ocean liner beached, oddly but proudly, in the midst of London's Knightsbridge district. By day, Harrods teems with life, offering to the 50,000 customers who pass through its doors daily roughly 20 acres of selling space, spread over five floors and 300 departments that include everything from $400,000 necklaces to 50-cent handkerchiefs.

title: A Completist Turns His Piano Talent To a Piano Legend
description: Gunnar Johansen is not one of the headliners, but he is a highly respected pianist whose lack of public appearance has been a matter of choice. In 1939 he was named artist-in-residence at the University of Wisconsin, the first musician in any American university to be so honored. He settled in. In his home he installed a battery of the most up-to-date recording equipment, and instead of giving concerts he made a series of records that has put most of his contemporaries to shame.

title: Patricia Ragusa Is Wed
description: Patricia Arnell Ragusa, an actress, and Michael Harrison, the general director of the Baltimore Opera, were married yesterday in Baltimore at Old St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Jesse L. A. Parker. The bride, 38 years old, is the daughter of Bernard T. Ragusa of Marrero, La., and the late Gladys Ragusa. She attended Loyola University. Mr. Harrison, 43, is the son of Helen Harrison Smith of Augusta, Ga., and the late Oscar T. Smith. He graduated from Vanderbilt University.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's dreadful and it's going to be devastating.'' - Dr. Gary R. Strokash, on AIDS among teen-agers. [ 1:1. ]

title:
Focus: Time Shares;
Correcting Abuses in the Resale Market
description: LEAD: TO try to resolve some of the problems besetting time-share resales, Florida put into effect last Sunday the first law in the country putting resale agents under the direct authority of a state agency.

title: George Bellinger Weds Ms. Prestwidge
description: Barbara E. Prestwidge and George M. Bellinger were married yesterday at the First Baptist Church in Stratford, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. W. O. Johnson, a Baptist minister, and the Rev. Sandra A. Wilson, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of the late Gladys T. Prestwidge of Baltimore. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Eugene Bellinger 3d of New York.

title: A KILLING IN MAINE
description: It does not take a lot of imagination nor is it cynical to suggest that if the geography and sex roles were reversed (i.e. a female deer hunter from outside Maine who hunted near the home of a native male and shot him), an indictment would have resulted. In all likelihood, she would have been perceived as trespassing (rather than hunting) and inept with a gun. Had the male victim also been the father of two young children, the incident would have been perceived in terms of the senseless taking of a father's life. I doubt that the same shoppers would rush to pat her on the back and tell her it wasn't her fault, the man had two white mittens on and wasn't wearing orange.

title: Q&A
description: High Reserve Fund

title: Ms. MacFadyen Is Married in Maine
description: Camilla MacFadyen and Montgomery M. Lewis Jr. were married yesterday in Small Point, Me. The Rev. John Ineson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Small Point Baptist Church.

title: Trimming the Fat From School Costs
description: As a parent of three school-age children, I read with trepidation Irving Gerber's Opinion article. Too often I've heard the when-I-was-young-I-walked-five-miles-to-school-and-sat-in-a-class-of-45 refrain as a response to our requests for better student services and smaller class sizes. While districts may be top-heavy with administrators, budget cuts go right to the children.

title: Of Cats and Frogs and Lessons
description: The excellent article ''A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned'' revealed the problems faced by a student who objects to using animals as classroom tools. Sadly, the academic status quo often penalizes those who show the most sensitivity and insight. Rather than teaching respect for all creatures, classroom dissection and vivisection desensitize students to animal suffering. Those who, like Maggie McCool, oppose harming or killing healthy animals are currently in the minority, but their number is growing.

title: A Prize Winner for Peace
description: Millions of tourists visit Washington each year and leave without a trace. But one visitor from Berkeley, Calif. may soon realize her dream of a multi-million dollar garden dedicated to the pursuit of peace.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Drawing Up A Master Plan
description: LEAD: AFTER years of rapid growth without strong land-use controls, this shore community is involved in a state-directed process to shape its development. The population, now 24,000, is up 30 percent since 1980; it grew at double the average state rate between 1980 and 1985.

title: Figure in Biggest U.S. Drug Haul Tells Prosecutor of Ring's Scope
description: A man identified as the manager of the Los Angeles warehouse where the Government made the largest cocaine seizure on record has told drug agents that 60 tons of cocaine passed through the warehouse in the last year, a prosecutor said Friday.

title: Bette Davis, a Queen of Hollywood, Dies at 81
description: Bette Davis, who won two Academy Awards and cut a swath through Hollywood trailing cigarette smoke and delivering drop-dead barbs, died of breast cancer Friday night at the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France. She was 81 years old and lived in West Hollywood, Calif.

title: Katarina Mesarovich Weds
description: Katarina Mihajlo Mesarovich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mihajlo Mesarovich of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Donald Robert Mullen Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullen of River Edge, N.J. The Rev. Lisa Ward performed the ceremony at the All Souls Unitarian Church in New York. Mrs. Mullen, 30 years old, is a freelance food stylist in New York. Mr. Mullen, 31, is a senior vice president in the high-yield bond department at Drexel Burnham Lambert in Beverly Hills, Calif. Both are graduates of Yale University.

title: Bradley Clements Wed to J. S. Moore
description: Deborah Bradley Clements, a daughter of Dr. Rex S. Clements Jr. of New Hope, Pa., and Mrs. John C. Bennett Jr. of Wyndmoor, Pa., was married yesterday to Jonathan Scott Moore, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Moore of New York and Sergeantsville, N.J. Judge Kenneth C. MacKenzie of Superior Court in Morristown, N.J., performed the ceremony at Round Hill Farm, the bridegroom's parent's home in Sergeantsville.

title: Dead Photographer a Cause Celebre for Kenya
description: In the stone courthouse here, an inquest into the death of an English photographer at a popular game reserve has Kenyans riveted much the way a celebrated murder trial captivated the country nearly 50 years ago.

title: Kansas City Journal Civic Pride (And Pain) In a Hub Of Midwest
description: All things considered, this was not exactly a banner week for Kansas City spirits. People were just beginning to deal with the bankruptcy filing by Braniff, the city's main provider of air service, when they learned that they would soon also lose their venerable evening newspaper.

title: Sally J. Schwartz Wed to a Lawyer
description: Sally Jean Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Schwartz of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Llewellyn McDermott, the son of E. Harriet McDermott of Pittsburgh and the late H. Bruce McDermott. Justice Harold Baer Jr. of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Pegasus Suite at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

title:
DINING OUT;
Variety Offered at Mamaroneck Bistro
description: LEAD: IN its youth, the American Bistro was a restaurant to travel to.

title:
IN SHORT;
REFERENCE
description: LEAD: WE THE PEOPLE: An Atlas of America's Ethnic Diversity. By James Paul Allen and Eugene James Turner. (Macmillan, $125.) When Nathan Glazer and I set out to write a book on the ethnic groups of New York City 36 years ago, we had little to go on beyond the evidence of our senses. Yes, there were a lot of different sorts of people in the city, but just how many was hard to say.

title: Easy Goer Surges To Win Gold Cup
description: For a moment, the Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday looked as if it was going to be a real horse race. Easy Goer had cruised to the lead round the stretch turn, but Cryptoclearance was making a stirring bid and drawing alongside the leader at the top of the stretch.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
New Homes for Healthy Elderly
description: LEAD: FOR three years, Russell and Constance Bishop, retired and in their 70's, wanted to sell their 11-room house but could find no other place. Then, this summer, they sold it and moved into the Northampton area's first retirement community, which on completion next March will comprise 77 single-story

title: Great Care Taken In Education Plan
description: The recent article ''Plan to Revamp Special Education Draws Criticism'' provided valuable information to parents of educationally handicapped pupils and special-education professionals. The article presented a balance of the different points of view expressed by a variety of people.

title: Prospects
description: Zenith's Computer Logoff

title: On Language; Talk of the Town
description: IN 1928, WHEN THE IVO-ry Soap slogan ''It Floats'' was being drilled into the American consciousness, The New Yorker magazine ran a cartoon by Gluyas Williams of a bunch of harried executives and hair-pulling copywriters running around a pool; it was captioned ''The day a cake of soap sank at Procter & Gamble's.''

title: Martin Knorr, 83, Ex-Queens State Senator
description: Martin J. Knorr, a Republican-Conservative who served in the New York State Senate for 23 years, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at his daughter's home in Long Beach, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Little Neck, L.I.

title: Nancy Jane Lavin Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Carson Lavin of Needham and Duxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Jane Lavin to Daniel Austin Scheerer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Durand Scheerer Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I. They are to be married this month.

title: Memory Repair
description: THE 68-YEAR-OLD CON-gressman was frantic. Long proud of his ability to remember the names, the children's names and even the birthdays of important constituents, he now made embarrassing mistakes. His memory clearly wasn't what it used to be. Devastated, he sought help at a memory clinic near Washington. Could these memory lapses be reversed? Was his career in jeopardy. God forbid, was he in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease?

title: For Salvation Army, A Century in Yonkers
description: LEAD: MENTION Salvation Army and people think of ''red tripod kettles at Christmas and brass bands,'' said Maj. Ronald G. Freiert of the Yonkers Citadel Corps. But the Yonkers chapter - which celebrates its 100th anniversary this fall - does much more than make music and collect cash during the holiday season.

title: Pseudo-Macho Nonsense
description: To the Editor:

title: GIFT-WRAP DESIGNER
description: Anne-Stuart Hamilton thinks of herself as a dresser of gifts.

title: The Cancer War: A Major Advance
description: IN SEPTEMBER OF 1984 DR. RON-ald H. Spiro told Robert A. Pfeiffer that he had a large tumor at the base of his tongue, right next to the vocal cords in his larynx, that had already spread to some lymph nodes in his neck. The standard treatment for such tumors was an extensive operation that involved removing the entire larynx, or voice box. Even with a total laryngectomy, his chance of being cured was less than 20 percent. Pfeiffer, who had spent 30 years as a broadcast journalist for CBS and the United Nations, accepted the news of the tumor as a challenge to be overcome, but the talk of laryngectomy terrified him. ''I thought, Oh, my God, they're going to take away my precious instrument, my voice. It was like saying you're going to amputate the fingers of a violinist. My first reaction was: Don't take out the larynx under any circumstances.''

title: LIKUD SEES THREAT TO COALITION RULE
description: The Likud party accused its Labor coalition partner today of seeking to bring down the Israeli Government over Egypt's newest Middle East peace proposal.

title: Starting Early on Plans to Desegregate Schools
description: LEAD: AS the state trial nears on imbalances between minority enrollments in city and suburban schools, several communities are working to improve the ratios in their districts.

title: Rejoice! It's Independents' Day
description: Alternative commercial cinema lives. Among other things, the box-office success of Steven Soderbergh's independently produced ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' is proof that there is vibrant life outside of the Hollywood establishment.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CALIFORNIA GOLD. By John Jakes. (Random House, $19.95.) James Macklin Chance, the hero of John Jakes's new historical novel, is a dynamic force, lurching around the California landscape, fighting his demons until his tall tale is told. Driven by his father's failed California dream, young Mack sets out from an Appalachian coal mine and lands eventually on Nob Hill, becoming a maverick real estate and business tycoon who sets out to challenge the San Francisco establishment.

title: Social Events
description: Under a Tent on Park Ave.

title: 6 Payment-Free Months; Hard Sell for a Soft Market
description: Say you've built a development that people like and can afford, but because the market is soft and they are having trouble selling their current homes, they can't afford to buy one of yours. What can you do? A Rockland County developer believes he has solved the problem: He is offering to meet a buyer's mortgage payments - up to $2,000 a month for half a year - once that buyer moves in.

title: Speculation Is Not Gambling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Long Way For Leahy
description: Charley Winner was the head coach, Joe Namath was the quarterback, Buddy Ryan ran the linebackers and a Briton named Bobby Howfield was the injured place-kicker when a soccer player named Pat Leahy joined the Jets in 1974.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Chances are that there has never been a survey on this subject, and this oversight could be for a number of reasons. The principal one might be that the answers would be ''Who cares?'' It is perfectly true that this is not something that will change the world. In point of fact, most people have never even thought about it. But it is also one of those niggling things in life that evoke a certain amount of thought once the subject has been introduced.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: Bulb planting begins as catalogue orders start to arrive; if the bulbs cannot be put in the ground for several days, store in a cool, dry place so they do not start to sprout in warm temperatures. If the lawn is becoming covered with leaves, begin raking, but also keep mowing; use rakings to make the first layer of the new compost pile. Indoors, do not neglect house plants; pull off yellow leaves that often occur when tropical plants, summered outdoors, adjust to their new life indoors. Keep Going

title: Perspectives: New Walk-Ups in Queens; Striving for Style in a Transitional Zone
description: THERE is a corner of the Jamaica Estates section of Queens that is something of a laboratory of housing change. It is along Highland Avenue, within walking distance of the 169th Street subway station on Hillside Avenue, a busy commercial thoroughfare. Since the 1920's, a range of housing types, from detached single-family houses to midrise elevator buildings, has been developed in the neighborhood.

title: Panel Discussion; Preservation And Growth
description: With the mayoral election, changes in the new York City charter and a wave of commercial development under way in Manhattan, many experts are questioning whether the city has struck a proper balance beetween economic development, construction and historic preservation. Do architects, builders and neighborhood advocates share a vision of the urban environment? Are they working together for the city's betterment?

title: Campus Life; What Students Think: Racism Is a Big Issue
description: Incidenls like a mock slave auction at the University of Wisconsin at Madison and the broadcast of racial slurs on a University of Michigan radio station have made race relations a top issue on college campuses nationwide, interviews with about 300 students at 20 universities show.

title:
DANCE;
An Aging Heartland's Pulse
description: LEAD: The Ruhr region, West Germany's aged and atrophied industrial heartland, would seem an inhospitable environment for modern dance. The rhythm of life can be dully constant, like the heavy, monotonous thumping of a drop forge in one of the area's myriad steel mills.

title: Under the Pyramid, Foie Gras and Frites
description: AMONG the amenities under the Louvre's new pyramid is an oasis, a place of calm and repose, of good food and fine wines. Called Le Grand Louvre, it is the flagship of the underground restaurant complex that has been installed in the museum's new entrance area.

title: Scarlett O'Hara: Miss or Miz?
description: To the Editor:

title: Forgotten Harvest
description: It is harvest time for squirrels in the city, and the other morning one of them was out foraging acorns in Washington Square Park. With an acorn in its jaws, it dug a little hole in the turf, pushed the acorn in, patted dirt over it and then brushed some grass over the spot as if to conceal it. It did the same with the second acorn and was working on a third when a pair of poodles came along and chased it up a tree.

title: Persuading Savimbi To Return to the Table
description: JONAS SAVIMBI, who has fought the Angolan Government for 14 years, pulled out of peace talks three weeks ago, saying the mediator, President Mobutu Sese Seko of neighboring Zaire, was ''not neutral.'' But after a visit to the White House, where the rebel leader came under gentle pressure from President Bush, Mr. Savimbi said last week that he was eager to return to the bargaining table.

title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH
description: Six months after the Department of Education began requiring college students receiving financial aid to sign oaths that the money would not be used to buy drugs, many university officials say they have no plans to enforce compliance with the oath.

title: R. T. Wheeler Weds Susan Schneider
description: At the First United Methodist Church of Orange, Calif., Susan Lee Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Schneider of Phoenix, was married yesterday to Raymond T. Wheeler, the son of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Raymond D. Wheeler of Dolgeville, N.Y. The Rev. Lee Truman officiated.

title: Not Just Another Remarkably Beautiful Face
description: Michelle Pfeiffer, with the pale blue eyes that pierce with love or rage or humor as easily as they are wounded, hovers on the brink of the big breakthrough. Given the right role in the right film, Ms. Pfeiffer, who also happens to be a blithe comedienne, will soon become a star in her own right.

title: Devils Manage A Tie
description: The coaches and front-office personnel of the Devils wore red carnations tonight for the team's eighth opener in New Jersey. The Devils were, in effect, half-wilted at the end.

title: Births and Immigration Squeeze California Classroom Space
description: School districts in California are facing a classroom shortage because the student population is growing more rapidly than expected and the state cannot meet the demand for new schools.

title: Nancy Rees Wed to Thomas Wall 4th
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Williams Rees and Thomas R. Wall 4th. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. G. Rees of Watch Hill, R.I., and New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wall 3d of Warwick, Bermuda.

title: London
description: Visitors to London this fall will be forgiven if they feel a bit confused about what year this is. The place looks contemporary enough, with its sleekly gentrified buildings, smartly dressed young people, streets lined with Range Rovers and controversial new glass and metal telephone booths, which have uprooted many of the beloved red boxes of yore. Yet there's nostalgia in the air. Last month marked the 50th anniversary of Britain's entry into World War II, and everywhere there are reminders of London's finest hour.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The family room in our house is directly above the basement. In warm weather, this room has a musty odor, especially when the humidity is high. We use a dehumidifier and ventilate the room, but it has not helped much. We had the carpet shampooed, and this relieved the problem temporarily. How can we get rid of the odor?

title: Is Political Humor Politic?
description: Do we need political humor? I usually answer that question with the smart-alecky response, ''I certainly do - I have bills to pay.'' The humorist Tom Lehrer gave up his practice years ago with the proclamation that political satire died the moment Henry Kissinger received the Nobel Peace Prize, and my endeavors as a satirist are often threatened by the verbatim statements of public figures. For example, during the Irangate investigations a reporter asked President Reagan if William Casey, the director of the C.I.A., had carried on covert operations without the President knowing about it. President Reagan's exact response was, ''Not to my knowledge.'' During the pay wars in Congress last January, I quoted an unnamed Senator as saying, ''If we in the Congress must maintain a higher standard of morality without a higher salary, where is the incentive? If we must spend all day long being ethical, how can we do our jobs?'' The quote was pure invention, but inasmuch as it was completely believable no one questioned it. The quote was also deemed acceptable by my audience because Congress itself, unlike the Presidency, is one of those safe objects of ridicule in this country, along with New York City, the Postal Service, potholes and Geraldo Rivera.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The family room in our house is directly above the basement. In warm weather, this room has a musty odor, especially when the humidity is high. We use a dehumidifier and ventilate the room, but it has not helped much. We had the carpet shampooed, and this relieved the problem temporarily. How can we get rid of the odor?

title: The Baby Bomb
description: SINCE HER DAUGHTER, CARMEN, was born, Jasmine Gazzarato of Royal Oak, Mich., says she has taken on three jobs. She works full time developing training programs for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, takes care of her daughter and caters to her husband, Melvin Winkler.

title: Catalogue Companies Should Not Sell Names
description: For Patrick J. O'Connor's information (''No Innocent Victims of Direct Mail,'' letters, Aug. 20) I wrote over two months ago to the Direct Marketing Association to ask that my and my husband's names be removed from mailing lists.

title: For Airline Industry and Public, Tars Signal a Major Change
description: Takeover fever has gripped the airline industry, bringing major changes in ownership, giving employees new power and attracting outsiders with new visions of how carriers should be run.

title: A 3d Hero As Giants Edge Cubs
description: It was not Kevin Mitchell who delivered the Giants to their moment of triumph tonight. It was not Will Clark.

title: The Time Lag Between Freezer and Microwave
description: THOMAS WOLFE said, speaking of writers, that there were putter-inners and taker-outers. I am, like Wolfe, a putter-inner, and our freezer would resemble one of Wolfe's overstuffed novels if my wife, like a Maxwell Perkins, were not a taker-outer.

title: Dorian M. Wiggin Wed To James P. Maguire Jr.
description: The marriage of Dorian Margaret Wiggin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Mitchell Wiggin 3d of Short Hills, N.J., to James Patrick Maguire Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maguire of Short Hills, took place there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Charles A. Cesaretti performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. James Driscoll, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: A 'Tough Cookie' Makes Nets Debut
description: Last season, for the first time in 32 years, Bill Fitch did not coach basketball. He played golf. He traveled. He read books. He spent more time with his friends.

title: Students Punished Over Prank
description: One University of Mississippi student was expelled and four others were suspended Friday for their involvement in a fraternity prank. The incident occurred Sept. 18, when a Beta Theta Pi member and a pledge were stripped, blindfolded, painted with racial slurs and dropped off at Rust College, a predominantly black school about 25 miles to the north. All the students involved in the prank were white. Those disciplined Friday were not identified, and their roles in the incident not disclosed.

title: MORE THAN DADDY'S LITTLE EDITOR
description: SARA COLERIDGE, A VICTORIAN DAUGHTER Her Life and Essays. By Bradford Keyes Mudge. Illustrated. 287 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $30.

title: A Global Sailor Turns Inward
description: It has been two years since Tania Aebi, a New York City teen-ager, sailed around the world in a 26-foot sailboat, alone except during an 80-mile stretch off American Samoa when she took an acquaintance onboard.

title: The Panama Jinx; What Should Washington Do About Noriega?
description: AFTER Washington stops arguing about the extent to which President Bush fumbled last week's attempt by Panamanian troops to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Administration will have to think about where American policy goes from here.

title: CLOBBERING HER EX
description: AFTER YOU'VE GONE By Alice Adams. 229 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Japan and the War: Debate on Censors Is Renewed
description: A court decision this week upholding the Government's right to censor history textbooks has revived the long-running debate over Japan's willingness to teach all aspects of the nation's role in World War II.

title: Afghanistan Waits for East-West Compromise; Back Up Our Rhetoric
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Itinerants Add To Giants' Stability
description: Circumstances forced the San Francisco Giants to rebuild and rearrange their team while the 1989 season was in progress, and four of the principal figures in that adaptability played the prominent roles in tonight's 6-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Bush Aide and Senator Clash Over Failed Coup in Panama
description: In an extraordinary public disagreement over intelligence policy, President Bush's national security adviser and the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee clashed sharply today over whether President Bush has been handcuffed by Senate restrictions on covert action in Panama.

title: We Can Act on Coming Faculty Shortage Now; Business Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Moisen and John d'Arbeloff Wed
description: Virginia Susan Moisen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler J. Moisen of Boston and Newport, R.I., was married yesterday to John Alexander d'Arbeloff, a son of Sybil d'Arbeloff of Cambridge and Rockport, Mass., and the late Dimitri V. d'Arbeloff. Msgr. Oscar Ferland performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the nondenominational Chapel by the Sea at the Newport Naval Base.

title: Azerbaijan Rail Strike Is Reported After Ban
description: Azerbaijani railroad crews defied a national ban on transport strikes today and again stemmed the flow of desperately needed supplies to Armenia, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, said. There were conflicting reports on how much food, fuel and building supplies were reaching the Armenian republic.

title: Abbado Will Succeed Karajan At the Berlin Philharmonic
description: Claudio Abbado, the 56-year-old Italian who is music director of the Vienna State Opera, was elected yesterday as chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, succeeding the late Herbert von Karajan. Mr. Abbado accepted the post by telephone, although details of his contract have yet to be negotiated.

title: Houston and Ware Hit Stride
description: The popularity polls of college football embrace statistical excesses and therefore the stock of Miami went up Saturday while Notre Dame's went down. Regarding Heisman Trophy candidates, perceptions of Houston's Andre Ware grew larger while the mystique of West Virginia's Major Harris diminished.

title: INSIDE
description: Immunity in H.U.D. Inquiry? The leader of a Congressional investigation into housing programs says immunity from prosecution may be considered for two aides of former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., but not for Mr. Pierce. Page A12. A Debate on Export Curbs The Bush Administration is under pressure from European allies and American companies to allow the export of sophisticated machine tools to Communist countries. Page D1. Acquiring a van Gogh Details of the elaborate deal by which the Museum of Modern Art acquired a portrait by Vincent van Gogh have now emerged. Page C13.

title: Accounting Unit Delays New Tax-Benefit Rule
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board announced on Friday that for the third time it would extend the date by which companies should adopt its new rules on how income tax expense is reported to shareholders.

title: Aboard Treadmill To Better Fitness
description: A treadmill has been designed to absorb the impact of running with use of a suspension system in its foot bed. The machine will be available in January.

title: Prisons Aren't Nursing Homes
description: On June 7, 1973, a 50-year-old homeless man named Quenton Brown walked into a bread store in Louisiana and, at gunpoint, stole $100 and a 15 cent pie. He then crawled under a nearby house where he remained until the police arrived. After his arrest, the state found that Mr. Brown had an I.Q. of 51 - the intelligence of a three and one-half year old child. After a one day trial, Mr. Brown was given a 30-year sentence without chance of parole. Now 66 years old, Mr. Brown has been at Angola State Penitentiary for 16 years.

title: Eagles Rally Over Giants
description: In a game of delirious, delicious knocks where little came easy, the New York Giants jumped on the Philadelphia Eagles early here today. The Giants led by 10-0 early in the second quarter, by 13-7 at halftime and by 16-7 early in the fourth quarter.

title: Retreat in Congress; The Catastrophic-Care Debacle - A special report.; How the New Medicare Law Fell on Hard Times in a Hurry
description: With the benefit of hindsight, legislators and policy makers in both parties now agree that the seeds of disaster for the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act were sown well before it became law barely a year ago.

title: Breaking Card Barriers
description: For someone trying to crack a $365 million market, Lud Denny is taking a curious route. The market is for sports trading cards, and while baseball, according to Denny's own figures, accounted for $350 million of the retail total last year, his company has zeroed in on a segment that accounted for only $10 million.

title: Hungary's Extraordinary Change Draws Critics of Varying Ideologies
description: A day after the Hungarian Communist Party changed its name to the Socialist Party and rejected orthodox Marxism, leaders contended today with criticism from members who thought it had not gone far enough as well as from die-hards who thought it had gone too far.

title: Mexico's Baja Wines In Bid for U.S. Market
description: If the wines of California can become world-renowned and gain respect, then the wines of Baja California should be able to do the same. If Mexican beer can be made to appeal to the American palate, the same should be true of Mexican wine.

title: Review/Television; The Travails of Cambodia As Seen by Prince Sihanouk
description: The recent withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia and the threat of the return of the infamous Khmer Rouge lend immediacy to ''Cambodia: The Prince and the Prophecy,'' a political history of that much beset land. This first of two ''Intercom'' programs, at 10 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, takes us from legends of the ancient empire of the kings of Angkor up to the only too real events of the 1970's. Next week, ''Cambodia Kampuchea'' reports on the horrors inflicted by Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge, its defeat by the Vietnamese, who instituted their own tough occupation, and the jeopardy in which the country now finds itself.

title: Shorter Workweek a Volatile Issue for Germans
description: A hallmark of West German labor negotiations in the 1980's has been a drive by the nation's powerful trade unions to reduce the workweek to 35 hours, from the current average of 38.7, without cutting pay. With many labor contracts in important industries expiring early next year, the debate has flared anew.

title: Immunomedics President Named After Year's Search
description: After a yearlong search, Immunomedics Inc. has chosen Russell C. McLauchlan as president. Mr. McLauchlan, 41, was previously vice president and general manager of Lederle Laboratories, a division of the American Cyanamid Company. He has also served as managing director of Cyanamid of Great Britain Ltd.

title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled
description: To the Editor:

title: Henrik K. Carlsen, 75, A Heroic Sea Captain
description: Henrik Kurt Carlsen, a sea captain who gained international attention in 1952 for staying stubbornly aboard his crippled freighter for seven days as she slowly sank, died Saturday at his home in Woodbridge. He was 75 years old.

title: We Can Act on Coming Faculty Shortage Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Seen Delaying Lower Rates
description: Credit market analysts predict that the Federal Reserve Board will not move quickly to lower interest rates, despite fresh signs of economic weakness.

title: We Can Act on Coming Faculty Shortage Now; Pool of Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dynasty That Wouldn't Look Ahead
description: JOSE CANSECO'S artillery shot into the hands of an opera singer in the fifth deck of the Skydome brought friends and foes to the top step of the dugout on Saturday. But the Oakland Athletics have been stunned by a more dramatic home run than Canseco's. Now they are back to where they were a year ago, before hobbling Kirk Gibson swung Wonder Boy, or whatever it is he calls his bat.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 9, 1989: MONDAY Phillips Pet Co PS Group Inc TUESDAY Diversified Energs Minn Procter & Gamble Co Lomas Finl Corp Puget Sound Pwr & Lt Co WEDNESDAY AAA Corp Hillenbrand Inds Inc Bard CR Inc Melville Corp Burlington Res Inc Shelby Williams Inds Caterpillar Inc Super Valu Stores Inc CBS Inc Tokheim Corp Dayton Hudson Corp Woolworth Corp Hartmarx Corp THURSDAY Ashland Coal Inc Ford Mtr Co Del Birmingham Stl Corp HI Shear Inds Colgate Palmolive Co James Riv Corp Va Eastern Utils Assoc Wisconsin Pub Svc Corp FRIDAY Federal Signal Corp SATURDAY Unum Corp

title: Most Markets Open
description: Currency and Government securities markets will be closed today in observance of the Columbus Day holiday. The commodity, stock and corporate bond markets will be open.

title: Impact of Harcourt Deal
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. released a statement on Friday describing the financial impact of its agreement last week to sell Sea World amusement parks to the Anheuser-Busch Companies for $1.1 billion. Harcourt said that it would gain $550 million from the sale and that the proceeds would allow it to reduce interest costs on its debt by $115 million a year. The company also said its publishing and insurance businesses would provide enough cash flow to service its debt obligations ''for the foreseeable future.'' Harcourt said it would take an unspecified $130 million charge to earnings in the third quarter.

title: 3 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week includes the weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, which will be tomorrow because of the holiday today, and Wednesday's auction of new seven-year notes.

title: The Man With No Plan
description: The greatest palindrome - a sentence spelled the same backward - was created in the Teddy Roosevelt era: ''A man, a plan, a Canal - Panama!''

title: Group to Fight Alcohol Ban
description: An advertising industry group plans to continue to fight an amendment to the Senate antidrug bill that would restrict advertising for alcoholic beverages on college campuses, even though the sweeping language of the legislation had already been narrowed. The bill was passed by the Senate last Thursday. The Association of National

title: L. Yaseen, Realty Expert, 77, Dies
description: Leonard C. Yaseen, a real-estate executive who specialized in relocating factories and offices, died of a heart attack early yesterday at the Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: More Covered By Recycling In New York
description: With New York City's recycling law in effect since July 14, the Sanitation Department reports that more than 600,000 households in the five boroughs are now engaged in the curbside recycling program, in which the department picks up newspapers, magazines and corrugated cardboard.

title: 'Good Strong Quads' Bring Biathlon Victory
description: RUSS JONES has given on-the-job-training a new meaning. Jones, a letter carrier who has walked the same 10-mile route in Camden, N.J., for the last nine years, has accomplished more on his beat than just delivering the mail on time.

title: Cargo Boom Causes Plane Shortage
description: Sharp growth in cargo shipments by air is producing a shortage of freighter aircraft around the world. Companies with freight to ship are having trouble finding planes on short notice, and freight rates have begun to rise.

title: People
description: * Tony Gomes has been promoted to associate creative director of Deutsch.

title: Latvians Seek Freedom And Fret for Gorbachev
description: As the largest political alliance in Latvia met today to demand independence for this reluctant Soviet republic, Yuris Dobelis reckoned the timetable this way: If the Soviet Union continues on the course set by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Latvia will be a free nation within five years. If he is replaced by hard-liners, ''no one can predict.''

title: Rangers Beat Hawks
description: The advantage was enormous, the exploitation of it extraordinary. And so when Al Secord's match penalty was over early in the third period, so was the game.

title: Question Box
description: Mack vs. McGraw Q. Did the two legendary baseball managers Connie Mack of the Philadelphia Athletics and John McGraw of the New York Giants ever oppose each other in the World Series? A. It happened three times in the 30 years from 1901-30 that Mack and McGraw were managerial contemporaries with their respective American and National League teams, but those three occurrences all took place in the first 13 years. The score was Mack 2, McGraw 1 in Series victories, and Mack 9, McGraw 7 in game victories, but the first time they met, the score was always 0 for one of the teams. That was in 1905, when the Giants beat the Athletics in five games, winning four by shutout and being blanked by the A's in the other game. Christy Mathewson pitched three of the Giant shutouts, Joe McGinnity had the other one, and Chief Bender pitched the shutout against the Giants.

title: Louisiana Changes Course And Accepts Tax Increase
description: Reversing at least part of the message they sent in a spring election, Louisiana voters on Saturday overwhelmingly approved a gasoline tax increase intended to finance a costly building program and breathe life into the state's dismal economy.

title: When the Money Really Would Stop
description: With Congressional leaders and Administration officials failing again over the weekend to work out a way to allow budget legislation to be enacted this week, prospects grew that across-the-board spending reductions in Government programs would automatically go into effect on Oct. 16.

title: The Emigres' Voices
description: For East Germans now in the West, individual tales testify to difficult times and personal dramas emerged from the chorus of cheers. Page A6.

title: Indians' Education Criticized
description: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos criticized the Government's educational programs for American Indians today, referring to them as having a history of ''crossed purposes and unfulfilled hopes.''

title: Opponents of Queens Park Development Get Federal Money
description: A dispute over a Government plan to let private developers build profit-making attractions in a Queens park has spurred a drive for public financing to upgrade Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: New Fund Form For Campaigns Is Turned Down
description: New York State's Board of Elections has turned down a proposal to change campaign disclosure forms in a way that proponents said would have made it harder for contributors to evade the state's campaign finance laws.

title: Dazzling, Daring A's Win Crown
description: They can exhibit the strut of a group that knows its business, but they also possess the willingness to attend to the details that can close a deal.

title: 100 Lbs. of Marijuana Found
description: More than 100 pounds of marijuana estimated to be worth at least $25,000 was found today during a raid on a house here, Onondaga County Sheriff's deputies said. The two-story private house at 866 West Genesee Street. contained 71 fully grown plants in pots under time-controlled lights in the basement and 121 smaller 3-foot plants growing in an upstairs room, the police said. The tenant of the house was not found in the 10 A.M. raid.

title: Monica Driscoll, Biologist, Is Married
description: Monica Anne Driscoll, a National Institutes of Health Research Fellow in biological sciences at Columbia University, was married yesterday to Stephen Thomas Buzbee, an architect in the New York firm of Thanhauser & Esterson. The Rev. John Hedger, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Deer Isle (Me.) Congregational Church.

title: SECURITY FORCES STORM PROTESTERS IN EAST GERMANY
description: Protesters clashed with the police and security forces today in cities throughout East Germany as the Communist Government's efforts to celebrate its 40th anniversary ignited rallies and demonstrations urging changes in the country's hard-line system.

title: Review/Television; Channel 2 Enlists Rivers And Rivera in Ratings War
description: When in doubt, go with highly recognizable faces, especially if they belong to personalities with an undeniable talent for self-promotion. Let's talk about Joan Rivers and Geraldo Rivera.

title: Ise Journal; An Ancient Shrine Is Testing a Modern Emperor
description: Inspired by religious faith, reverence for tradition and simple curiosity, millions of tourists and worshipers go out of their way every year to visit this sacred and historic spot in a densely forested and hilly coastal area of central Japan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Martinez to Face Evert: Conchita Martinez, the 17-year-old who helped Spain reach the final of the Federation Cup tournament in Tokyo, will face Chris Evert today in the showdown between the top-seeded United States and second-seeded Spain for the women's version of the Davis Cup. The French Open champion, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, will face Martina Navratilova, the world's second-ranked woman player. If neither team can win both singles matches, one doubles match will decide the championship. In the Americans' semifinal victory yesterday over Czechoslovakia, Evert defeated Jana Novotna, 6-2, 6-3. Navratilova beat Helena Sukova, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4. For Spain, Sanchez Vicario defeated Anne Minter of Australia, 6-1, 4-6, 6-2, and Martinez trounced Elizabeth Smylie, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) Courier Upsets Edberg: Unseeded Jim Courier of the United States upset top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 7-6, 2-6, 3-6, 6-0, 7-5, yesterday to capture the Swiss Indoors tournament in Basel, Switzerland. Courier, 19 years old, of Dade City, Fla., won $72,200 in his first Grand Prix final.(AP) Kroon Beats Woodforde: Niclas Kroon of Sweden won the first Grand Prix title of his career when he defeated Mark Woodforde of Australia, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the final of the Queensland Open tournament in Brisbane, Australia. Kroon, ranked 127th in the world, won $30,000, the biggest check of his career.(AP) Victory for Agassi: Second-seeded Andre Agassi made short work of Brad Gilbert yesterday to win the Prudential-Bache Securities Classic in Orlando, Fla. The singles title was Agassi's first in 14 months. Agassi needed only 57 minutes to rout the top-seeded Gilbert, 6-2, 6-1, and earn $59,500. (AP) GOLF Player Takes RJR Title: Gary Player took advantage of Rives McBee's late putting lapse and scrambled to a one-stroke victory yesterday in the RJR Championship at Clemmons, N.C., the richest event on the PGA Senior Tour. Player had a one-over-par 71 for a 54-hole total of three-under-par 207 over the Tanglewood Park course. The triumph was worth $202,500. McBee, a rookie on the Senior Tour, finished with a 73. (AP) Hammond Wins Texas Open: Donnie Hammond completed a blitz of the Oak Hills Country Club course yesterday with a six-under-par 64 for a seven-shot victory in the Texas Open in San Antonio. Hammond won his second PGA title by slashing a course-record 22 strokes off par for a 72-hole score of 258. Paul Azinger, the runner-up, shot a 69 for a 72-hole total of 265.(AP) BOXING Baek Retains Title: Baek In Chul of South Korea knocked out Ron Essett of the United States in the 11th round of a scheduled 12-round bout in Seoul, South Korea, yesterday to retain his World Boxing Association super middleweight title. The referee stopped the fight 29 seconds into the 11th round when the American challenger went down after taking a devastating right, followed by combination punches to the face. The fight was Baek's first defense of the title he wrested from Fulgencio Obelmeijias of Venezuela with an 11th-round knockout in Yochon, South Korea, on May 28. Baek's record is 46-2. Essett's record is 20-3.(AP) HORSE SHOW Patton Tops Field of 33: Beezie Patton of Cazenovia, N.Y., topped a field of 33 entries yesterday in the Clifton Springs Hospital Grand Prix at the Rochester International show. Patton won the Grand Prix aboard Elliot Ness with the fastest fault-free time, 25.696 seconds. She also finished in second place, fault-free, in 28.515 seconds aboard Vancouver.

title: CORE CURRICULUMS IN COLLEGE URGED
description: Asserting that too many college students graduate with limited exposure to the ''basic landmarks of history and thought,'' the National Endowment for the Humanities urged colleges today to bolster required undergraduate studies.

title: Company To Go Private
description: The First Constitution Financial Corporation has agreed to be taken private by a group of New York investors at a price of $25 a share, or a total of $275 million.

title: Marsha Rich Weds Steven Camerino
description: Marsha A. Rich and Steven V. Camerino, both graduates of Dartmouth College, were married yesterday in Woodstock, N.H., at the Moosilauke Ravine Lodge of the Dartmouth Outing Club. Peter B. Rotch, a lawyer and a New Hampshire justice of the peace, performed the civil ceremony.

title: Florida Football Coach Quits
description: Galen Hall resigned as football coach at the University of Florida today amid charges that he made unauthorized payments to a player and to his assistant coaches in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, the university's interim president said.

title: U.S. Fails to Gain in World Cup Bid
description: The United States missed a chance to improve its World Cup qualifying hopes today when it had to settle for a scoreless tie with Guatemala.

title: Sending Mr. Savimbi a Message
description: President Bush did well to push the Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi back to the negotiating table. But it remains to be seen whether Mr. Savimbi is prepared to bargain on the basis of the African-sponsored framework for settling Angola's 14-year civil war. He needs to understand that continued U.S. help will be politically impossible if he misses this chance to negotiate.

title: Unesco Didn't Approve Censorship Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmer's Apples Aren't Pretty, and She Likes Them That Way
description: For Amy Hepworth, a fruit grower here, a shiny red apple without a single blemish is a sign of an unhealthy agriculture.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-7, A18 East German protesters clashed with the police in cities throughout the nation. The Government celebration of its 40th anniversary of Communism has prompted rallies and demonstrations urging reform. Page A1 Emigres tell why life in East Germany proved intolerable A6 In a dispute over intelligence policy, the national security adviser and the Senate intelligence chief argued about whether President Bush has been handcuffed by restrictions. A1 General Noriega ''exploded in rage'' after the coup attempt and ordered the immediate execution of several rebel officers, including a friend who led the coup, diplomats said. A7 Latvia's largest political group met to demand independence, a free market and multi-party democracy. But it also called for a transition period during which Latvia would remain within the Soviet federation. A2 Many Hungarian Communists criticized their party for changing its name to the Socialist Party. They said the party had not yet defined its new identity. A1 Export of advanced machine tools to Communist countries is being advocated by Western Europe, particularly West Germany, as well as U.S. makers of machine tools. D1 Yugoslavia's Premier wants aid from the U.S. to revive his nation's crippled economy, but he ruled out accepting the kind of liberalization going on in Hungary and Poland. He is due in Washington today. A18 Argentina's pardon of officers accused of ruthlessly repressing dissent has left victims of the military crackdown bitterly angry. A3 El Salvador accepts plan for evacuation of wounded rebels A3 The Pope prayed for Korean unity on a vast plaza in Seoul, saying North and South Korea are ''symbolic of a world divided and not yet able to become one in peace and justice.'' A3 Ise journal: an ancient shrine tests a modern Emperor A4 National A8-13 The seeds of a Medicare disaster were sown even before Congress enacted ''catastrophic coverage'' in 1988, legislators and policy makers now say. They blame Democratic largesse and a Republican demand that the program pay for itself. A1 News analysis: A budget deadlock may lead to across-the-board spending cuts starting automatically on Oct. 16. Many of the current budget problems began with the move to cut the capital gains tax. A11 Immunity for two ex-H.U.D. aides is to likely to be considered in Congress as a way of obtaining their testimony, but a lawmaker ruled out immunity for former Secretary Pierce. A12 St. Croix looters are being arrested by the F.B.I. three weeks after Hurricane Hugo devastated the area. Federal Agents say they have confirmed reports that some police officers took part in the looting. A1 Illegal aliens can still find work in the United States, despite the Government's effort to turn the workplace into the front line of the battle against illegal immigration. A1 Soviet emigres are being recruited by the F.B.I. for information on K.G.B. operations. The F.B.I. has begun running advertisements in a Russian-language newspaper in New York City. A1 A gap between the life expectancies of black and whites is continuing to grow, health experts say. Most of it is due to behavior patterns rather than to conditions like heart disease. A8 Colleges should add requirements to core undergraduate studies, the National Endowment for the Humanities said. It cited a survey showing that many college seniors do not know when the Civil War occurred. A11 The auto legend Shoichiro Honda is to take his place next to Henry Ford and Karl Benz in the Automotive Hall of Fame in Detroit. It is an honor some say is long overdue. A8 Louisiana backed a tax increase on gasoline that is intended to finance a building program and breathe life into the state economy. Voters had rejected the measure in April. A8 Young & Rubicam's indictment has raised this question on Madison Avenue: Must American advertising agencies adjust their ethics as they expand their operations around the world? D1 How MTV has rocked television commercials D6 'Junk bond' inquiry by S.E.C. is seen D1 Cargo boom causes plane shortage D1 Regional B1-4 Three Jewish students were attacked outside a fraternity party near the campus of Brooklyn College by as many as 15 men, who shouted ethnic slurs, the police said. B1 Rudolph Giuliani courted votes from Hispanic New Yorkers, campaigning in East Harlem, while David Dinkins was in California over the weekend for private and public fund-raising events.
