B1 Campaign matters: Running with the ghost of La Guardia B1 Board turns down change in campaign disclosure forms B3 New Jersey's legislative races have at times mirrored the race for governor. But while pollution is a big issue in the 11th Assembly District, high property taxes are becoming one too. B2 The sale of large public airports to private interests is being considered by communities to save money and improve service. Albany County in New York may sell its airport, and officials in Peoria, Ill., and Los Angeles are talking about similar deals. B1 A drive to upgrade Federal parks in the New York City region has risen along with opposition against a plan to let developers build profit-making attractions in a Queens park. B3 A fruit grower farms with few chemicals B3

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Independence Is Goal For Head of LTV Unit
description: LEAD: The plan to make the LTV Steel Company's Flat Rolled and Bar Company an independent entity moved a step closer last week when 65 percent of the unit's main labor union, the United Steelworkers of America, approved an employee stock ownership plan.

title: Susan Warms Dryfoos, Author, Wed To Daniel Mayer Selznick, a Producer
description: Susan Warms Dryfoos and Daniel Mayer Selznick were married yesterday at the home of the bride's grandmother Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger in Stamford, Conn. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Andrew Heiskell of New York and Darien, Conn., and the late Orvil E. Dryfoos. Mr. Selznick is a son of Irene Mayer Selznick of New York and the late David O. Selznick of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the noon ceremony.

title: Laurie Anderson Ill
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music canceled yesterday's afternoon and evening performances of the performance artist Laurie Anderson's ''Empty Places'' because she was under doctor's orders to rest. Ms. Anderson became ill during Saturday's show, a spokesman for the academy said, and was told by her doctor to rest for at least 48 hours. She is to resume her performances at 8 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets for yesterday's shows may be exchanged by calling the academy's ticket services office, 718-636-4100.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Babcock Industries, Fairfield, Conn., an industrial and consumer-products manufacturer, said Dennis F. Flint had been named deputy group chief executive of its parent company, FKI Babcock P.L.C., Halifax, England.

title: Business and the Law; A Judicial Attack On Ethics Filings
description: BREAKING legal ground, a Federal court has decided that a law firm could avoid a conflict of interest charge by ousting a partner.

title: Humphrey Carries Broncos
description: Bobby Humphrey, rushing for 102 yards in the first start of his pro career, scored a tackle-breaking touchdown with 1 minute 3 seconds left as the sluggish Denver Broncos beat the San Diego Chargers, 16-10, today.

title: Topics of The Times; Dueling Umbrellas
description: New York City's relentless rains have provided abundant opportunities for observing umbrella styles.

title: Power Is Out, and So Are Jays
description: In the ninth inning of the fifth game of the playoff for the American League pennant, in his final time at bat in 1989, George Bell hit a home run. It was too little and too late, and it was a parting shot that symbolized the downfall of the Toronto Blue Jays and the success of the Oakland Athletics.

title: Bears' First Loss Is to Buccaneers
description: After sliding up and down the scale of improvement for a month, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers reached the top today.

title: President Quits At Ann Taylor
description: Michele Fortune, president of the Ann Taylor stores, has resigned from the retail fashion chain, the company announced on Friday.

title: Yugoslav Chief to See Bush and Seek His Support
description: Prime Minister Ante Markovic is to arrive in Washington on Monday to ask President Bush's support for the economic program that he hopes will pull Yugoslavia out of its long crisis of hyperinflation, high unemployment, a steadily declining standard of living and a crippling foreign debt.

title: Albany Gets Private Offer To Purchase Its Airport
description: While virtually every American airport served by scheduled airliners is publicly owned, Albany County is considering an unusual offer by a private group to buy its 61-year-old airport.

title: A Debate On Controls Of Exports
description: Faced with calls for increased economic cooperation with Poland and Hungary, the Bush Administration is under growing pressure from its European allies, led by West Germany, to allow the export of sophisticated machine tools to Communist countries.

title: Abortions Will Be Moot Soon
description: Typically, technological development creates political debates: nuclear power, radioactive waste, genetic engineering and environmental pollution, for example. In one exceptional case, however, technology may end a debate. The issue is abortion, and the technological development is the French abortion pill.

title: Williams Helps Giant Barrage To Continue
description: Even when the night had ended, Matt Williams could not completely reconstruct the single electric moment in the fifth inning when he stood at the plate and kept fouling off pitches, one after another.

title: 'Custodian' Fees Are Set By Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has adopted a policy to charge retail investors for holding their securities.

title: Karen Anderson Weds a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Karen Anderson to Stephen Michael Ouellette took place yesterday at the Eastern Point Yacht Club in Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. James McCloy, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: How the Modern Got the van Gogh
description: The 1888-89 portrait of Joseph Roulin by Vincent van Gogh, which is one of the most spectacular additions to the Museum of Modern Art in many years, was paid for by the museum through an elaborate deal that involved the sale of seven paintings from its permanent collection.

title: Crash in Canada Kills 12
description: A tractor-trailer hauling logs skidded and crashed into a wagon taking people on a hayride today, residents said. At least 12 people were reported killed and 45 injured. As many as 50 people were on the outing, part of a reunion held each Canadian Thanksgiving weekend by the Leger and McGraw families.

title: Campaign Matters; On Running With the Ghost Of La Guardia
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani declared his candidacy for mayor last May in an Upper East Side Republican club that he identified as the site where Fiorello H. La Guardia began his successful mayoral campaign 56 years before.

title: The Russians Are Still Coming
description: We live in an age of image-building - an age in which it is increasingly difficult to distinguish appearance from reality. Soviet leaders have taken full advantage of this situation in conducting foreign policy. They say one thing, and do another. Since most people cannot determine where the truth lies, they believe noble intentions.

title: An Early Favorite in Not-Just-Hockey Country
description: THIRTY years ago, when the Minneapolis Lakers were opening their final season in the Twin Cities, Harvey Ratner and Marv Wolfenson were young businessmen who had bought a 3 percent share of the struggling franchise for $1,500.

title: Critic's Notebook; Christine Lahti as an Angry Heidi in 'Chronicles'
description: Christine Lahti has stepped into the role of Heidi Holland, the art historian from whom stand-up comics could take a lesson. When she begins her witty lecture at the top of Wendy Wasserstein's lavishly awarded play ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' at the Plymouth Theater, Ms. Lahti, who took over the role last month, wastes no time in banishing all traces of her predecessor Joan Allen's fawnlike, reactive presence.

title: Outdoors: How You, Too, Can Begin Surf-Casting 200 Yards
description: EVERY veteran surf fisherman has watched screaming terns diving over a school of surface-feeding bluefish that are just beyond his own casting range. That can be accepted with some degree of equanimity, except when the fellow beside you, who has no trouble reaching out another 40 or 50 yards, is fast to a fish on every other toss.

title: Expansion Fever Rages in Orlando
description: LEAD: ON the day that single-game tickets for the Orlando Magic went on sale earlier this week, 800 fans stood in line for hours under a broiling Florida sun to have first crack at the remaining seats. Thousands of others jammed telephone lines trying to buy tickets by phone.

title: William J. Fischer, Auctioneer, 91
description: William J. Fischer, a New York auctioneer of furnishings, decorations and art, died yesterday in a nursing home in Burbank, Calif. He was 91 years and lived in Manhattan until he moved to California 18 months ago.

title: Rumors of Saatchi Bid
description: The stock of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. rose several points last Friday on the London and New York stock exchanges amid rumors that the British advertising company might be a takeover target. Fueled by speculation that an American asset-management company might make a bid for Saatchi, and that a Swiss employment agency was interested in buying some of its consulting operations, Saatchi's stock was the third-most actively traded issue in the London market. In London, Saatchi's stock jumped 33 pence, or 53 cents, to $:3.33, or $5.33, on volume of 6.98 million shares.

title: Market Place; Funds Cautious On Hong Kong
description: SIR PIERS JACOBS, Hong Kong's financial secretary, is out ''beating the drum'' for the bustling market at China's door.

title: To Find Out About Soviets, F.B.I. Turns to Advertising
description: In a novel approach to the second-oldest profession, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has turned to advertising to recruit potential Soviet counterintelligence assets and beckon would-be defectors.

title: Review/Dance; Graham Explores Her Early Repertory
description: ''Steps in the Street'' is another important revival from Martha Graham's so-called lost repertory of the 1930's and her company performed the work on Friday night with formidable success for the first time in more than 40 years. As usual, anyone interested in the development of a great artist cannot afford to miss it.

title: 3 Weeks After Storm, St. Croix Still Needs Troops
description: The 1,100 Army troops sent to restore civil order after Hurricane Hugo devastated St. Croix three weeks ago are still needed to insure the peace, local officials acknowledge.

title: Nursing Home Fire Alarm Is Under Scrutiny
description: The authorities say there is evidence that an automatic fire alarm system may not have worked when a fire started last week at a nursing home, killing nine people.

title: Dai-Ichi Mostly Buying Expertise
description: In the last few weeks, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank has committed nearly $1.5 billion to expanding in the United States, the largest investment made in the country by a Japanese bank. But the most important aspect of the splashy acquisitions had nothing to do with their impressive financial bulk; it was the expertise Dai-Ichi Kangyo received.

title: Business Near Victory on Worker Benefits
description: Led by an army of inflamed small-business owners, the nation's 3.5 million employers are on the verge of a sweeping legislative triumph that would free them of what are widely acknowledged as overly burdensome regulations governing health-insurance and other employee benefits.

title: McMillan Ready for a Change
description: Half an hour after practice on Saturday, Erik McMillan stood outside the Jets' training rooms and attempted to put the events of the last few days in perspective.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Music; Quartet's Romantic Offering
description: The chamber music world had its version of a baby boom in the late 1960's, when forming an ensemble seemed almost as glamorous an endeavor as pursuing a solo career. Many groups that were spawned then have remained together, and they are now into their third decades.

title: Inflation Drops In Argentina
description: Argentina's inflation rate, which in July reached a record 196.6 percent, fell below 10 percent in September for the first time in seven months. It was the second consecutive monthly drop in the inflation rate.

title: 7 Die in Bogota Blast; Police Seek Drug Link
description: Seven passengers were killed and eight wounded today in a bus bombing here, and the police were trying to determine whether it was linked to the war of cocaine traffickers against the Government.

title: Pope, at Huge Mass in Seoul, Prays for a Reunified Korea
description: On a vast plaza designed to be turned into a military airfield should North and South Korea go to war again, Pope John Paul II prayed today for the reunification of a people torn by seemingly implacable hatred.

title: El Salvador Accepts Plan for Evacuation Of Wounded Rebels
description: After a tense seven-week standoff that included a church occupation, an embassy takeover and diplomatic maneuvering, the Government of El Salvador has acceded to rebel demands that wounded and disabled guerrillas be evacuated abroad for medical treatment.

title: Noriega Reportedly Orders Executions of Coup Figures
description: Moments after putting down a violent coup attempt last Tuesday, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega exploded in rage against his captured opponents and ordered the immediate execution of several rebel officers, including a close friend who was the coup leader, diplomats here said today.

title: Where Iron Doses of Stamina Count
description: WHAT does it take to prepare for one of the most arduous sporting contests on earth? It depends on where you set your sights. You may want to win, or you may only hope to finish.

title: Federal Industries
description: Federal Industries Consumer Group said on Friday that it would pay $54 million (Canadian) in cash for W. H. Smith Canada Ltd., a unit of W. H. Smith Group P.L.C. of Britain. Federal Industries will pay 86.5 percent of the cash to W. H. Smith Group and the rest to three Canadian institutional investors.

title: 2 Held in Cutting Up of Car in Fatal Accident
description: A 15-year-old girl was killed in a hit-and-run accident early Saturday morning as she was trying to cross a street in front of a discotheque for teen-agers near East Farmingdale, L.I., the Suffolk County police said.

title: Little Progress in Budget Talks
description: Senate Democratic and Republican leaders made little progress today in their efforts to strike a deal that would strip various tax and spending measures from a $13 billion deficit reduction package and provide a separate vote on reducing the capital gains tax.

title: Wilson to Test Market
description: Mookie Wilson, who opened the season sitting on the bench with the Mets, ended it today as the regular left fielder for the Toronto Blue Jays. He expressed his gratitude to the Blue Jays for giving him a showcase for the last two months, but said he was going to consider all his options as a free agent before deciding where to play next season.

title: Schools Have a Role In Combating Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Analyst of Publishing Companies Who's Done a Thing or Two
description: Even if there were such a thing as a typical Wall Street investment banker, Ivan Obolensky, the senior vice president of research for Josephthal & Company, would not be it. That is, not unless the typical investment banker was also the London-born son of a Russian prince and a grandson of John Jacob Astor, who is said to have been the wealthiest man in America when he went down with the Titanic.

title: Police Detectives' Chief Announces Retirement
description: After 35 years in the New York City Police Department, Robert Colangelo, the Chief of Detectives, announced yesterday that he would retire just before Election Day, Nov. 7.

title: Amoco-Saudi Venture
description: The Amoco Corporation, the Chicago-based oil company, signed a letter of intent to study the idea of building a petrochemical plant with Saudi Arabia that would produce up to 400,000 metric tons annually of a chemical used in making polyester. It would cover expected demand into the late 1990's, said James Fligg, an Amoco representative. The plant would be a joint venture with Saudi Chemical Investments Ltd. and private Saudi investors.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Retail sales Sept. Automobile sales Early Sept. Producer prices Sept.

title: College Coaches Cool to Plan for Shorter Athletic Schedules
description: Some of the country's leading college basketball and football coaches feel that a proposal to shorten the basketball season and cut spring football practice by 10 days was a well intentioned but misguided attempt by college presidents to reorder priorities in intercollegiate athletics.

title: Fixed Mortgages Down
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.10 percent last week, down from 10.16 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.72 percent last week, up from 8.70 percent the week before, Freddie Mac said.

title: Policeman Dies in Hospital After Being Shot by Student
description: A 24-year-old police officer shot in the head early Saturday morning during what the police said was a fight with his girlfriend's former boyfriend died later the same day at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, the City Medical Examiner's office said.

title: Sale Price Arouses Wonder Over Deal in South Carolina
description: THE recent sale of three small daily newspapers in South Carolina has left many in the newspaper industry scratching their heads in wonder at the huge prices papers generally command, despite industrywide problems like fierce competition and soft advertising.

title: Katherine Reed, Executive, Weds
description: Katherine Fuller Reed, an assistant vice president for marketing for Citicorp/Citibank, and Kenneth Franklin Hall, the general counsel of Citicorp's Mid-Atlantic Banking Group, both in Washington, were married yesterday in Scarborough, N.Y. The Rev. D. Williams McClurken performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the expense of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's travel misstated the point at which the Federal Bureau of Investigation advised the Justice Department that Mr. Thornburgh should avoid commercial jets because of security and communications concerns. That advice was given months ago, not Friday.

title: Film Festival; 'Breaking In,' Crime Primer, Features Burt Reynolds
description: The 27th New York Film Festival rolls effortlessly to its conclusion tonight with the 9 o'clock showing of Bill Forsyth's halcyon new comedy, ''Breaking In,'' at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Supporters Elude Giuliani As He Courts Hispanic Vote
description: The Rudolph W. Giuliani mayoral campaign spent much of yesterday courting the Hispanic vote from East Harlem to the canyons of Fifth Avenue. It was not an easy day. What the campaign had promised would be an endorsement from the ''oldest Latino club'' in New York City turned into a confusing non-endorsement.

title: Growing Gap in Life Expectancies Of Blacks and Whites Is Emerging
description: After narrowing for decades, the gap in life expectancy between blacks and whites has grown for three years in a row, Federal health experts say, and most of the disparity is due to patterns of behavior.

title: Three Military Airmen Killed When Jet Crashes in Atlantic
description: Three Navy airmen were killed on Saturday when they ejected from a military jet that apparently malfunctioned shortly after it took off from an aircraft carrier in the Atlantic Ocean, the Navy said today.

title: Tales Emigres Tell: Why Life in East Germany Proved Finally Intolerable
description: The thousands of people who have left East Germany in recent weeks have seized opportunities for escape as they arose, first through Hungary and then through Czechoslovakia. Seen from afar, their flight seemed to be a mass exodus. But in this West German border city, as the tired travelers disembarked, individual voices testified to often difficult choices; personal dramas emerged from the chorus of cheers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The President has said he wants him out, and I can't believe that between the will of the people of Panama, and the will of the people of the United States, we can't achieve that. If you want odds, I'd say 8-to-5 that he probably will be out.'' -John H. Sununu, the White House Chief of Staff, speaking about Gen. ManuelAntonio Noriega of Panama. [ A7:1. ]

title: Accounts
description: * Cookie-Crisp, a children's cereal made by the Ralston Purina Co., to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Bridge
description: Most of the jungles of the world greet intruders with a plague of mosquitoes. The bridge jungles of Australia are inhabited by a pesky creature called a Moscito, which caused a lot of trouble during the recent world championships in Perth.

title: 3 Jewish Students Beaten by Men Yelling Ethnic Slurs in Brooklyn
description: Three Jewish students were attacked outside a fraternity party near the campus of Brooklyn College early yesterday by as many as 20 white men who shouted ethnic slurs at them and beat them with ''fists, feet and beer bottles,'' the police said.

title: Pardon of Argentine Officers Angers Critics of the Military
description: The decision by President Carlos Saul Menem to pardon military officers accused of ruthlessly repressing dissent has left victims of the crackdown bitterly angry.

title: Immunity Is Seen as Possible for 2 Top H.U.D. Figures, but Not Pierce
description: The lawmaker who has led the primary Congressional investigation of political abuses in Federal housing programs says he expects that Congress will soon consider granting immunity to two top aides to former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., although not to Mr. Pierce.

title: The Democrats - Late and Lame
description: The Democratic Party is in trouble. The floundering over capital gains taxes has raised serious questions about the quality of the party's leadership, the coherence of its message and the condition of its soul. The Democrats aren't wholly to blame for their troubles. But the signs of decay are worrisome - not just for the party but the country.

title: Opera Musicians Reject Pact
description: The orchestra of the New York City Opera, which has been on strike since Sept. 13, voted 56 to 4 on Saturday to reject the company's latest proposal. The vote was tabulated yesterday. The rejection increases the possibility of a cancellation of the rest of the company's season, scheduled to run until Nov. 19. Martin J. Oppenheimer, vice chairman of the City Opera board and its chief labor negotiator, said yesterday that the company's ''key players'' would meet tomorrow morning. The City Opera had given the orchestra until yesterday to agree to a settlement, after which it said it would cancel the rest of the season.

title: Colts Crush Bills, 37-14
description: Eric Dickerson ran for two touchdowns, and the Indianapolis defense converted six Buffalo turnovers into 23 points today as the Colts won, 37-14, for a share of the American Football Conference Eastern Division lead.

title: Replica of Half Moon to Sail Hudson River
description: Nearly four centuries after the explorer Henry Hudson sailed up the river that bears his name, a replica of his ship, the Half Moon, will sail down the river.

title: Swing Into Perfection
description: Before you get out your credit card and dial Rich Ohly's 800 number to order one of his Perfect Swing Trainers for $600, ask yourself one question:

title: How MTV Has Rocked Television Commercials
description: MTV, the cable television rock-music network, is having a profound influence on the way products are advertised on television, advertising professionals say.

title: At 3, The Independent Is a Solid Success in Britain
description: When the lofty notion of a daily newspaper founded by journalists and dedicated to political independence and high professional standards was first presented to him, Stephen Glover gave it ''about a 5 percent chance of success.''

title: Don't Touch That Dial
description: Don't adjust your television sets tonight. That is Jets green and not Giants blue coming at you live on ''Monday Night Football,'' courtesy of a California-based company called Flying Colors, which was hired by the Jets to alter the look of Giants Stadium for Jets home games.

title: W. T. Eveleth 3d Weds Miss Litten
description: The wedding of Barbara Anne Litten, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack D. Litten of Bethany, Conn., and William Tappan Eveleth 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eveleth 2d of Chazy, N.Y., took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church on the Green in New Haven. The Rev. Andrew E. Fiddler performed the ceremony.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Indictment of Y. & R. Raises Questions of Ethics Abroad
description: LEAD: Young & Rubicam's indictment on charges that it bribed Jamaican officials to obtain the nation's tourism advertising account reads like a Graham Greene novel: a tale of money laundering, shell corporations and corrupt politicians conspiring under the Caribbean sun.

title: Soviet Corn Purchases
description: Private exporting companies have sold the Soviet Union an additional 1.1 million metric tons of United States corn, with a potential value of nearly $100 million, for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The corn sale was the fourth of last week to the Soviet Union, with orders now totaling 3.7 million tons of corn and 100,000 tons of soybean meal. The seventh year of the agreement begins today. United States grain sales to Moscow in 1988-89 were a record of more than 21.7 million tons, including more than 16.3 million tons of corn and nearly 5.4 million tons of wheat.

title: Holidays Today
description: Columbus Day and Yom Kippur are observed today. Here are the schedules for the holidays. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office at 33d St. and Eighth Ave. open. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed, local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery service only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Topics of The Times; The Charter Needs Justice
description: One way or another, New Yorkers will vote Nov. 7 on a referendum to amend their City Charter. One way is better than the other, though: the way that allows New York City voters to know, before Election Day, what the United States Justice Department thinks about the charter proposal.

title: Kansas Journal; The Land Wherein 'Wizard' Is A Humbug
description: Don't bother looking for Toto T-shirts in Kansas.

title: JOBS BEING FILLED BY ILLEGAL ALIENS DESPITE SANCTIONS
description: Despite the Government's effort to turn the workplace into the front line in the battle against illegal immigration, most illegal aliens are able to find jobs in the United States.

title: Rising Taxes Are Issue In Jersey Shore District
description: The green lawns of many homes in the 11th Assembly District along the Jersey Shore are festooned these days with ''for sale'' signs.

title: Benefits of Soviet Entry Into Tariff System
description: To the Editor:

title: Turf Classic Won By Yankee Affair
description: Yankee Affair and Sewickley repeated recent Grade I victories by winning major stakes races at Belmont Park yesterday to make strong cases for themselves as divisional champions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the Senate's refusal to back repeal of the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act described the Senate's measure incorrectly in some copies. Unlike the House's, it deals only with Medicare. It is not part of the deficit-reduction bill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT The Bush Administration is under growing pressure from West Germany and other European allies, as well as American manufacturers, to allow the export of sophisticated machine tools to Communist countries. [ Page D1. ] West Germany's unions are pushing to reduce the workweek to 35 hours, from the current average of 38.7, without cutting the salaries of workers. [ D8. ] The wines of Baja California hope to follow Mexico's beer in appealing to the American palate. Both large vintners and boutique wineries are involved. [ D8. ] COMPANIES Dai-Ichi Kangyo, the world's largest bank, has sought as its most precious commodity not money but knowledge of new U.S. markets and new business methods. [ D1. ] Companies with freight to ship are having trouble finding airplanes on short notice, and freight rates have begun to rise. Air-freight carriers seeking more capacity have placed new orders with aircraft manufacturers. But the manufacturers could be slow to respond. [ D1. ] Goldman, Sachs will charge retail investors for holding their securities, in a move intended to compensate the firm for the cost of ''custodian services.'' [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY The nation's employers are on the verge of a sweeping legislative triumph that would free them of what are widely acknowledged to be overly burdensome regulations governing health insurance and other employee benefits. [ D1. ] From a practical standpoint, the across-the-board spending reductions in Government programs that would automatically go into effect this week would make little difference. News Analysis. [ A11. ] The Financial Accounting Standards Board will extend the date by which companies should adopt its new rules on how income tax expense is reported to shareholders. [ D2. ] The S.E.C. is examining the ''junk bond'' market, seeking more information about the nature of the $200 billion dealer market, particularly since the market's steep decline in September, people close to the investigation said. [ D1. ] MEDIA BUSINESS Young & Rubicam's indictment on charges that it bribed Jamaican officials to obtain the nation's tourism advertising account raises ethical questions. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ] The sale of three small South Carolina dailies has left many in the newspaper industry scratching their heads in wonder at the huge prices papers generally command. Press. [ D6. ] The Independent is regarded as a model of a successful newspaper start-up, as the British paper marks its third birthday. [ D6. ] MTV is having a profound influence on the way products are advertised on television. [ D6. ] Ivan Obolensky, an investment banker, is often sought as an expert on publishing mergers. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A Federal court has decided that a law firm can avoid a conflict-of-interest accusation by ousting a partner. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Hong Kong's financial secretary is ''beating the drum'' for the bustling market at China's door. But the turmoil in China has dampened the enthusiasm of foreign investors. Market Place. [ D4. ] The Federal Reserve Board is not likely to move quickly to lower interest rates, despite fresh signs of economic weakness, analysts predict. Credit Markets. [ D5. ]

title: 'Junk Bond' Inquiry by S.E.C. Seen
description: The recent turbulence in the ''junk bond'' market has spurred a new inquiry into this high-risk market by the Securities and Exchange Commission, people close to the investigation said last week.

title: Books of The Times; A Man of Letters and the Pull of Visual Arts
description: Just Looking Essays on Art By John Updike Illustrated. 210 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Detroit Is Honoring Honda, the Man and the Car
description: Soichiro Honda, the automobile maker whose company first had the audacity to use American workers to build Japanese cars, will soon take his place in the Automotive Hall of Fame, an honor that some say is long overdue.

title: President's Cyst Found to Be Noncancerous
description: A cyst removed from the middle finger of President Bush's right hand was not cancerous, a spokesman said today.

title: 2 Fund-Raising Groups Form to Aid Hispanic Organizations
description: For the first time in the New York region, hundreds of Hispanic social service or cultural groups that have competed for dollars, often with scant success, will have two new fund-raising organizations to help them.

title: Test Flights Start Today Over Adirondack Park
description: The Air Force announced today that it would begin low-level flights over northern New York and Adirondack Park Tuesday.

title: American Bank of Connecticut reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Careers; Swiss M.B.A. Program Is Getting Ready for '92
description: GONE are the abbreviations I.M.I., which stood for International Management Institute, and Imede, as the International Management Development Institute was known. The Swiss schools, which were among Europe's best-known graduate business programs, have merged to form I.M.D., the International Institute for Management Development.

title: Ex-Quintus Executive in High Intergraph Job
description: The Intergraph Corporation, a software company in Huntsville, Ala., announced yesterday that James W. Meadlock, the company's president and chairman, had been promoted to the new position of chief executive.

title: Fans Drink Up Early Because of Beer Policy
description: John Destefano gazed into his cup of beer as if his tickets for tonight's game between the Jets and the Los Angeles Raiders had sunk to the bottom of it.

title: Argentina Pardons Its Demons
description: Argentina's tentative democracy was dealt a cruel, if expected, blow Saturday by President Carlos Saul Menem, in the form of a blanket pardon for accused military officers and suspected leftist terrorists. His action promises temporary gains, but it undermines Argentina's integrity.

title: G.M. May Buy Stake In Jaguar
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it might buy a minority interest in Jaguar P.L.C. and was discussing manufacturing and marketing joint ventures with the British auto maker.

title: Strangely, Chile Race Seems Normal
description: On a recent Saturday, the presidential candidate Hernan Buchi, wearing red running shorts and jersey, jogged for two and a half miles along a sun-drenched beach-front avenue in the Pacific coast resort town of Vina del Mar.

title: At Long Last, Glamour Comes to Ellen Barkin
description: ''Suddenly, I've been perceived differently by the powers that be,'' said the film actress Ellen Barkin. ''I'm perceived as this glamorous, sexy, leading lady. No, they see me as the sex goddess! It's amazing to me.''

title: Dow Jones Earnings Off 10% As Advertising Falls Again
description: Dow Jones & Company reported yesterday that its net income dropped 10 percent in the third quarter, a result of further declines in newspaper advertising and of start-up costs for foreign services at Telerate Inc., an electronic information service that it controls.

title: On Horse Racing; Gold Cup Upstaged By OTB
description: rrMaybe the Belmont Special train that left Penn Station Saturday morning is still stuck in a tunnel somewhere. Maybe 15,000 people all got the day wrong and thought that the Jockey Club Gold Cup was next Saturday. Or maybe the meters on the turnstiles counted only every second customer.

title: Darnell Takes Over
description: Gary Darnell took over the Florida football program yesterday and said he was confident about his ability to lead the Gators out of troubled times.

title: Soviet Legislature Approves Law Providing Limited Right to Strike
description: The Soviet legislature approved a law tonight that grants workers the legal right to strike, but severely restricts the conditions under which they may do so.

title: Q&A
description: Highest Temperature Q. Is there a maximum temperature that corresponds to absolute zero? A.''There is no maximum temperature, because there is no limit to the amount of energy you can put into anything,'' said David Goodstein, vice provost and professor of physics and applied physics at the California Institute of Technology, Pasadena.

title: Ocilla Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Tourist Trade Increases 19%
description: Foreign visitors to the United States spent $20 billion in the first half of the year, 19 percent more than in the corresponding period of 1988, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Threat to Plankton
description: SOLAR radiation penetrating the ozone hole over Antarctica may be damaging the base of the food chain that sustains virtually all wildlife in the region.

title: Winning Is Craig's 'Happiest Feeling'
description: Roger Craig rarely displays deep emotion, and even tends to mumble a little bit when his thoughts outrace his words in certain tense situations.

title: Seattle Journal; The Art Of Burying A Century Alive
description: In trying to package the present for future generations, officials at the Washington State Centennial Commission have discovered that history isn't what it used to be.

title: Japan Questions Ban on Sending Military Abroad
description: The Government has reopened one of the most politically charged questions in Japan's halting moves toward taking a bigger role in international politics: Can the Japanese military be sent abroad, even on non-military missions?

title: No More Likud Excuses
description: The Likud leadership never seems to run out of ways to avoid talks with Palestinians. Last week's split decision by the Israeli Cabinet to reject an Egyptian initiative for getting such talks under way is the latest example of this ingenuity.

title: Review/Television; How Koop Surprised Friends and Foes
description: ''The Controversial Dr. Koop'' recounts the high spots of Dr. C. Everett Koop's surprising eight years as Surgeon General. He surprised both the liberals who opposed the confirmation of a man whom they dismissed as an anti-abortion zealot and the conservatives who expected him to follow the line set by the Reagan Administration.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Electro Rent Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Deals
description: Basketball

title: KEY RATES
INSIDE
description: New Hungarian Party Chief Hungary's newly named Socialist Party, which as the Communist Party decided to turn away from orthodox Marxism, elected Rezso Nyers its President. But he faced demands for more change. Page A10. Land Battle in West Western states have come to regret a deal in which they accepted vast tracts from the Federal Government decades ago, and Utah wants to sell off about 82,000 acres. Page A24. The Long Way to Jupiter In a roundabout trek, the Galileo probe being carried into space on Thursday will loop around Earth and Venus, using their gravity to accelerate. Science Times, page C1. Scrutiny of Federal Reserve In taking up two bills that would curb the central bank's independence, the House will take its first hard look at the institution in years. Page D1.

title: Anderson Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Amex and Philadelphia Markets End Talks
description: Negotiations about a possible merger of operations by the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange have broken off, and officials from the exchanges said yesterday that no agreement was likely to be reached.

title: Clark Drives Giants Past Cubs and to Pennant
description: In the moments that followed the celebration, when it was finally certain that there would be a World Series between teams no farther apart than the bridge that runs between them, there was still a picture of Will Clark.

title: Indiana Man Is Guilty Of Planting 13 Bombs
description: A Federal jury convicted a man today on 29 charges in connection with the planting of 13 bombs in nearby Salem, a plot prosecutors said was rooted in his lifelong rivalry with a state legislator.

title: From Milan, a Soft and Shimmery Spring
description: Italian fashion exploded over the weekend, as established manufacturers and newcomers alike tried to stage their spring shows before the start of Yom Kippur. The spate of presentations around the city, in lofts and workrooms that could hold an audience of up to 1,000 as well as at the Milan Fair, made it perfectly clear that the slick, hard-edged Italian look had turned soft and gentle in the face of spring.

title: Studies Trace Syphilis From New World to Old
description: Researchers who reviewed studies of skeletal remains have concluded that syphilis was carried from the New World to Europe after Christopher Columbus's voyages.

title: Business and Health; Hospitals Suing On Medicaid Lag
description: TIGHT-FISTED Medicaid policies are costing the nation's hospitals billions of dollars each year in lost or delayed payments, health-care experts and hospital industry spokesmen say.

title: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,583,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Calton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Digital Communications Asociates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giuliani Offers Strategy to Help City's Homeless
description: In the first of what his campaign promised would be a flurry of policy statements over the next week, Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday released an 11-page plan for ending homelessness.

title: Chess
description: After the first three games of the semifinal world championship candidates matches in London, the former titleholder, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, led his countryman Artur Yusupov, 2-1, and Jan Timman of the Netherlands led Jonathan Speelman of Britain, 2-1.

title: Groups Protest Use of Plutonium on Galileo
description: THE nearly 50 pounds of plutonium that will produce electricity on the Galileo probe make this space shuttle launching the most disputed ever.

title: Dead 'War Hero' Unmasked: A Life of Lies to Hide Failures
description: Nancy Fife never doubted that her husband was scarred in mind and body by his Viet Cong captors and was a war hero. nearly 20 years ago, her sneakers seemed to drive her husband, Robert, berserk. He told her that his captors wore sneakers when they came to his cage to beat him and urinate on him and that the enemy soldier he strangled to escape was wearing sneakers.

title: Skolniks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income and the year included an extraordinary credit of $287,500, or 16 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Share data for the fourth fiscal quarter and year ended July 29 gives effect to the company's initial public offering of 800,000 units, consisting of one share of common stock and one common stock purchase warrant, in April 1988.

title: MGM/UA Talks Continue
description: Representatives of the MGM/UA Communications Company and Qintex Group of Australia continued discussions today to get Qintex's stalled $1.5 billion takeover bid for MGM/UA back on track.

title: Dinkins Ties To Clubhouse Under Attack
description: For a decade before his election as Manhattan Borough President in 1985, David N. Dinkins was City Clerk, keeper of city records. It was a post he received on the recommendation of the Democratic county leader in Manhattan after years of loyal service as a district leader.

title: By Design; Work Boots, for Play
description: They're the latest steps in the sturdy-footwear fashion movement. With high-tops that end above the ankle, snug lace-up fronts and thick block heels, this season's new boots qualify as members of the comfort class. The ones with rounded toes and thickish ripple rubber soles certainly do.

title: Giuliani Adds Longtime G.O.P. Adviser to His Inner Cricle
description: A month before the Nov. 7 election, Rudolph W. Giuliani has added an adviser to his inner circle, to help overcome the political missteps that have plagued his mayoral campaign and to compensate for a shortage of money for television advertising.

title: U.S. Asserts Soviet Advisers Are Fighting in Afghanistan
description: Despite Moscow's assertion that all Soviet troops have been withdrawn from Afghanistan, the Bush Administration says Soviet military advisers are still there, firing Scud missiles on Afghan guerrillas.

title: What an Actress!
description: ''What a dump!'' . . . ''I'd love to kiss ya, but I just washed my hair'' . . . ''Fasten your seat belts; it's going to be a bumpy night.'' They are three of the most memorable bits of dialogue in American film - primarily because they were delivered by one of the most memorable of American film stars.

title: Sewage Dump Site Teems With Sea Life
description: SCIENTISTS have found a seabed teeming with tiny plants and animals, as richly populated as a tropical rain forest, at the very spot in the ocean where New York and New Jersey have been dumping their sewage sludge for more than two years.

title: First American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter included a $24.4 million provision for loan losses.

title: Heart-Disease Prevention Begins in Childhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Planters Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metro Datelines; Child, 2, Is Killed When Struck by Bus
description: A bus struck and killed a 2-year-old boy yesterday after he apparently broke away from a teen-ager watching him and ran in front of the vehicle, the Paterson police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Roger Rowe has been named senior vice president and associate creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of Westcott Leaves TV Company
description: LEAD: Westcott Communications Inc., the owner of the Automotive Satellite and Law Enforcement Television Networks, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Michael Irwin Smartt, had left the company to pursue other interests. It is expected that Mr. Smartt will resign as a director as well.

title: Double Hull the Valdez
description: To the Editor:

title: Wickes to Sell Car Parts Unit
description: The Wickes Companies said it had agreed to sell A.P.S. Inc., a distributor of automotive parts, for $200 million to a company organized by the management-buyout firm of Clayton & Dubilier Inc.

title: Mugabe Urged to Reopen College
description: The closing of the University of Zimbabwe by the Government last week has led to a chorus of outrage here, and President Robert Mugabe's Government has responded to the dismay with further measures to stifle dissent.

title: Oklahoma Gas Find Splits Drillers
description: Wildcatters and pipeline companies are struggling over how to exploit a 1987 Arco discovery of a major natural-gas field far below the rugged terrain of southeastern Oklahoma.

title: Consider the Racism In the Term 'Hispanic'
description: To the Editor:

title: Joint Venture To Acquire ICI Drug Unit
description: Merck & Company and Johnson & Johnson announced an agreement yesterday to buy the over-the-counter drug business of ICI America Inc., a unit of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain, in a deal they valued at $450 million.

title: Girl Who Received New Liver as Infant Has a Splenectomy
description: Jamie Fiske, who as an infant received a liver transplant after her father had appealed for a donor, underwent surgery today to remove her spleen. She is 7 years old.

title: Clues to Ethnic Attack Sought in Party
description: Detectives are investigating the possibility that a group of youths who attacked three Jewish students near Brooklyn College, severely beating two of them while shouting anti-Semitic slurs, may have been at the same fraternity party shortly before the incident, officials said yesterday.

title: Magna International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year results included a $30.3 million provision related to a reorganization and rationalization program. The latest periods also included gains on the sale of real estate of $36,165,000 for the quarter and $63,765,000 for the year, compared with $314,000 and $7,580,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Gains on the sale of subsidiaries' shares were included in the latest quarter of $4.7 million and the year totaled $8.7 million. The 1988 year had a similar gain of $7.9 million. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Music; Milwaukee Symphony Tests Carnegie Hall
description: The Milwaukee Symphony was on the stage of Carnegie Hall Saturday night, but these visitors from the Midwest seemed almost bit players in the larger drama of Carnegie Hall's acoustics. The plot has arrived at Act III, Scene 1 - from the celebrated sound of this historical space, to the much criticized acoustical changes that accompanied a major renovation several years ago, and now to August's further modifications, which have included absorbent material applied above and behind the playing area and at the back of the hall. The Milwaukee's appearance gave these latest emendations their first major public test.

title: United Vermont Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rig Count Down by 18
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States dropped by 18 last week, to 960, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. It was the first decline in six weeks, but the count remained above the 914 rigs working at this time last year.

title: Shell Makes a Successful Debut As Jets Are Quick to Cooperate
description: The Jets, plagued for the second successive game by erratic secondary play and no offense to speak of, made Art Shell's head-coaching debut a success tonight by dropping a 14-7 decision to the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: LOUISIANA VOTERS DEFEAT COURT PLAN
description: A plan designed to elect more black judges in Louisiana was defeated by the voters Saturday, in part because of voter concern over a clause that would have protected the jobs of predominantly white incumbents, analysts said.

title: Bush to Veto U.N. That Includes Abortion
description: President Bush has informed Congressional leaders that he will veto a foreign aid bill that includes renewed support for the United Nations Population Fund, a group that has been criticized by anti-abortion groups.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Scientists have confirmed that an unidentified flying object recently landed in a park in the Russian city of Voronezh.

title: Disney Stock Rise
description: Shares of the Walt Disney Company soared $6.75, to close at $134.625 a share in New York Stock Exchange trading, more than double the price a year ago. A Disney spokesman declined to comment, but analysts attributed the jump to heavy demand in Europe for newly issued shares of Euro Disneyland, the theme park Disney is developing outside Paris.

title: Price Soars For Black Pearls
description: Heavy Japanese buying sent the price of black pearls soaring at weekend auctions in Tahiti, dealers said today.

title: Midway to Buy Dornier Planes
description: Midway Airlines Inc., a midsize carrier that is expanding rapidly, announced that it had agreed to purchase 33 twin-engine turboprop airplanes for $244 million from the West German manufacturer Dornier Deutsche Aerospace G.m.b.H.

title: Dispute on New President Shatters The Tranquility at Rockefeller U.
description: For decades, Rockefeller University in New York City has been a citadel of basic research in biology and medicine: a place where professor-researchers outnumber students and the ''poetry of science'' (as one of the four Nobel laureates on the faculty puts it) holds sway.

title: Review/Theater; 'Frankie,' the Frankenstein Tale Set to Music
description: Before settling into marital bliss, Dr. Victor Stanford has decided to devote himself to an ambitious scientific experiment. Embracing his fiancee, he sings to her of his dream of becoming famous: ''I'll be cited in schools with Hippocrates and Darwin.'' If by Darwin he means ''survival of the fittest,'' the doctor is out of luck - as is the show in which he appears, ''Frankie,'' George Abbott's modern musical version of ''Frankenstein.'' For the York Theater Company, the new musical is a steep comedown after its revivals of ''Sweeney Todd'' and other shows by Stephen Sondheim.

title: Metro Datelines; Son and Father Plead In Drag-Race Killing
description: A 23-year-old man accused of hitting and killing a teen-age girl while drag-racing appeared in court yesterday to answer, along with his father, charges of cutting up the car and hiding the pieces.

title: Dow Gains 5.89, to 2,791.41, on Low Volume
description: Stocks ended moderately higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average set its fifth record in a row after moving in a narrow range throughout the day.

title: Dow Jones & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said net income for the first three quarters of 1989 included an after-tax gain of $164,149,000, or $1.63 a share, from the January sale of Dow Jones' holdings in Continental Cablevision Inc. The company recorded after-tax gains of $68,034,000, or 71 cents a share, in the like period, largely from the sale of a book-publishing subsidiary.

title: Village Super Market reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
An Old Land Deal Nettles the West
description: Nearly a century after the West was won and tamed, the Western states have come to regret a deal in which they accepted millions of acres of land from Washington in tiny plots like islands in an ocean of Federal territory.

title: 'Covert' Means Fiasco
description: Once again, in misguided zeal to rearrange another nation's affairs, the U.S. Government has demonstrated all that's wrong with ''covert operations,'' and why they have no useful place in the policies of a democratic nation.

title: Rev. John Lord, 87; Was Methodist Bishop
description: The Rev. Dr. John Wesley Lord, a retired bishop of the United Methodist Church who was active in the civil rights movement and in the racial integration of his church, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at Huggins Hospital in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 87 years old and lived in Wolfeboro and Lakeland, Fla.

title: Ecology & Environment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue represented gross revenues.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS U.S. Takes Federation Cup: Chris Evert, 34 years old, and Martina Navratilova, 32, handled two 17-year-olds yesterday to lead the United States past Spain in the final of the Federation Cup in Tokyo. ''You will win this tournament in a few years, but this time it was won by over-30's,'' Evert told the Spanish teen-agers, Conchita Martinez and Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, at the award ceremony. Evert used her classic ground-stroke game to beat Martinez, 6-3, 6-2. Then Navratilova, blitzed by the blistering serve returns of the French Open champion, Sanchez Vicario, in the first set, bounced back for a 0-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory. That clinched the cup, but Pam Shriver and Zina Garrison completed a 3-0 sweep, beating Martinez and Sanchez Vicario, 7-5, 6-1, in doubles. (AP) Zivojinovic Advances in Australia: Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, the Australian Indoor defending champion and seeded fifth, beat a qualifier, Darren Patten, 5-7, 6-2, 6-4, in a first-round match in Sydney yesterday. Richard Fromberg of Australia, ranked 160th, upset the sixth-seeded Eric Jelen of West Germany, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2. (AP) CROSS-COUNTRY Columbia Takes Championship: Columbia, led by the third- and fourth-place finishes of Greg Yahn (25 minutes 42 seconds) and Mark Lindrud (25:45), won the Metropolitan Intercollegiate championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday with 48 points. Carlos Martin of Fairleigh Dickinson was the gold medalist in 25:20.7 for the five-mile race. Devon Martin of Columbia was the women's individual winner in 17:49 for 3.1 miles. The Fordham women took team honors with 29 points. HORSE RACING Capades Wins the Athenia at Belmont: Poma Stable's Capades, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., took the lead after entering the stretch and won by 1 1/2 lengths in the $90,800 Athenia Handicap for fillies and mares, 3 years and older, at Belmont Park yesterday. Miss Unnameable finished second, and Key Flyer was third. Capades won in stakes-record time of 2:13 1/5 for a mile and three-eighths on the Inner Turf course. Capades earned $54,480 and paid $5.20 for $2 to win. (AP)

title: Bond International Gold Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Heat Signs Douglas
description: Sherman Douglas, the Miami Heat's second-round draft choice, signed a two-year contract yesterday after having missed the team's summer camp and the first three days of fall practice. The 6-foot guard from Syracuse, taken 28th over all in the June draft, will be paid an estimated $275,000 a season.(AP)

title: 2d California Desert Quake
description: The second minor earthquake in the Southern California desert in three days was felt in the remote San Jacinto mountain range Sunday, but no damage or injuries were reported. The midmorning quake measured 3.0 on the Richter scale of ground motion and was centered 23 miles south of Palm Springs, said Robert Finn, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena.

title: Snacking Said to Cut Heart Risk
description: SNACKING throughout the day instead of eating three full meals, can lower cholesterol and reduce the chance of heart disease, a study has found.

title: Metro Datelines; Man, 31, Is Slain By Shotgun Blast
description: A 31-year-old Queens man was shot and killed yesterday by an unidentified gunman as the victim's grandmother watched in horror, the police said.

title: Gene-Altering Process for Animals Is Patented
description: DNX Inc., a tiny, privately held biotechnology company in Princeton, N.J., said today that it had obtained approval for a patent on a fundamental process for creating genetically engineered animals.

title: Change in Medicare Law to Be Costly
description: The moves by Congress to dismantle expanded health benefits for older Americans would shift most of their medical costs back to the patients, to taxpayer-supported programs and, to a lesser extent, to private employers, health care experts and insurance industry spokesmen say.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said operating results for this year's first quarter were negatively impacted by losses incurred by Hi-Shear's Defense Systems' operation in Reno, Nev. This operation incurred a pretax loss of about $1.4 million in the first quarter due primarily to unabsorbed manufacturing and engineering overhead as well as a lower than anticipated level of shipments.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Curtice-Burns Foods Inc., to W. B. Doner, Baltimore, for the potato chip brands Hiland and Old Vienna, with an undisclosed budget.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Danaher Corp., Washington, a maker of automotive parts and tires, sold its minority interest in Mohawk Rubber Co., Akron, Ohio, to an affiliate of Japan's Yokohama Rubber Co. for $45 million.

title: Sonoco Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After equity in earnings of affiliates of $1,238,000 for the quarter and $3,934,000 for the 9 months. c-After equity in earnings of affiliates of $337,000 for the quarter and $973,000 for the 9 months.

title: When Will Albany Act Against Hate?
description: Another hate crime in New York City - this time the victims were three Jewish college students - rightly stirs shock and outrage. It is also cause for frustration.

title: St. Croix Has No History of Racial Unrest
description: To the Editor:

title: Software for OS/2
description: THE Microsoft Corporation is firing a barrage of newly updated products for International Business Machines PC's and compatible computers. Among them is Microsoft Excel for OS/2 with Presentation Manager, which is being released today, the first major spreadsheet application for the operating system that is the designated successor to DOS.

title: Color Systems Techology reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,094,000 representing purchase of film library by General Electric pension trust after loan default. c-Included a loss of $7,282,000 for writedown of equipment and property and a loss of $4,112,000 for revaluation of film library after decline in domestic syndication market. The company said it is continuing negotiations with General Electric pension trust to restructure Color Systems' remaining $12,578,000 debt.

title: Talcon L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest 9 months' net included a net gain of about $833,000 resulting from the sale of a partnership interest. There is no income per unit allocable to the unitholders of the partnership, since substantially all the net income or loss of the partnership is allocable to the general partner and the holder of Talcon's class A limited partnership interests. Shares outstanding are in units.

title: N.H. Thrift Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Interco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $77,210,000, or $1.91 a share, for the quarter and $87,061,000, or $2.16 a share, for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $16,192,000, or 43 cents a share, for the quarter and $23,125,000, or 61 cents a share, for the 6 months. The latest periods' income from continuing operations included net gains of $69.7 million and $70.1 million from the sale of assets in the second quarter and year-to-date respectively. The latest periods' share earnings reflected after preferred dividend requirements of $20.7 million, or 51 cents a share, for the second quarter and $41.3 million, or $1.02 a share, for the year-to-date. Both year-ago periods were restated.

title: Iraqi Warning On Oil Exports
description: Iraq has sharply increased its oil-export capacity, but a top Iraqi oil official said his country would increase its shipments only if OPEC agreements collapse, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today. Ramzi Salman, head of the

title: The Young Captive
description: That winter two men of Asia came to India, each on a pilgrimage. One was a captive and the other his captor.

title: Hazards in Arms Cuts, NATO Chief Warns
description: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization warned Western allies today that it was ''wrong and dangerous'' for them to take independent steps toward disarmament in response to the process of change in the Soviet bloc.

title: Bingo Buses Attacked at Indian Reservation
description: Buses carrying bingo players were stoned and shot at during weekend violence at the St. Regis Indian Reservation, where residents are feuding over the legalization of casino gambling. One woman was hurt. The woman, Janet Langley, of Ottawa, Canada, was injured by the rock throwing and treated for cuts at a hospital, officials said.

title: HONG KONG FEELS RANCOR OF CHINA
description: Angry over Hong Kong's decision not to send back a top Chinese swimmer who sought political asylum here, China has retaliated by refusing to accept the routine return of 70 Chinese who immigrated illegally to Hong Kong.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Warwick Baker & Fiore has moved its offices to 100 Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan.

title: Tyson Trains in Albany As Part of His Sentence
description: As part of his sentence for speeding in the Albany area twice last summer, Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, sparred for a half-hour and signed autographs yesterday morning at a boxing clinic at St. Joseph's Youth Center in downtown Albany. In the afternoon, he took part in drug-related talks at the nearby Arbor Hill Community Center. Tyson is in training for a title defense against Donovan (Razor) Ruddock on Nov. 18 in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: Sensing Silent Cues Emerges As Key Skill
description: UNPOPULARITY, poor grades and a host of other problems that afflict schoolchildren may derive from an inability to read the nonverbal messages of teachers and peers, new findings show.

title: Washington Talk; Instincts to Be Cautious With Panama Prevail
description: Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, spoke Sunday about ''the fog of war'' as one element that had sorely complicated the Bush Administration's reaction to the attempted coup last week in Panama.

title: Amserve Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago share earnings has been restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend declared in November 1988.

title: Reviews/Music; Elton John, Still Colorful And Popular
description: It seems like only yesterday, but it was actually 19 years ago that Elton John scored his first major hit with ''Your Song.'' Every year since then, the singer and pianist has had at least one moderate hit and more often than not he has had two or three.

title: U.S.-Soviet-Chinese Teams Will Jointly Attempt Everest
description: Teams from China, the Soviet Union and the United States will attempt to scale Mount Everest together next year to draw attention to international cooperation and problems of the environment.

title: Gasoline Prices Flatten
description: Abundant oil supplies and volume discounts to sellers virtually halted a rise in retail gasoline prices that had been running contrary to seasonal trends, an industry analyst said Sunday. The biweekly Lundberg Survey of 12,000 gasoline stations nationwide showed the average price, including taxes, for all grades of gasoline was $109.56 cents a gallon - up only 13-hundredths of a cent per gallon from two weeks earlier. At self-service stations, the latest Lundberg Survey shows regular leaded at 96.87 cents a gallon, regular unleaded at 98.49 cents and premium unleaded at $1.16. At full-service pumps, regular unleaded was $1.26 a gallon, regular unleaded was $1.27 and premium unleaded was $1.40.

title: Jackpot Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $423,000, or 8 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The share earnings were adjusted for the 5 percent stock dividend distributed on Aug. 4, 1989.

title: Review/Dance; A Look at Words and Music By a West German Troupe
description: It was as if a time capsule had been unearthed and opened on Friday night when Else Klink's Eurythmeum Stuttgart performed at the Triplex Theater of the Borough of Manhattan Community College. A company of 13 dancers and 6 musicians offered a solemn, reverent look at eurythmics, a system of translating musical and spoken rhythms into physical movement, derived from Francois Delsarte's theories of gesture, and developed and elaborated by Emile Jaques-Dalcroze and Rudolf Steiner early in the 20th century.

title: Ax Plays Beethoven and Schoenberg
description: Emanuel Ax played the best of Arnold Schoenberg's piano music and a rousing selection of Beethoven's most animated, Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y. It was an exhilarating recital and something of a surprise even to a listener who has always admired Mr. Ax. Here, more than I can recall from other occasions, he seemed to have something close to the ideal combination of qualities for the material at hand. Above all, he played like one thoroughly stimulated by the scores, who wants nothing more than to show the rest of us the splendid qualities he has found in them.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
Valdez Cost To Exxon
description: The chairman of the Exxon Corporation, Lawrence G. Rawl, said he did not expect many more expenses associated with the Exxon Valdez oil spill in March.

title: International Microcomputer Software reports earnings for Year to June 30
Miller (Herman) Inc(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-After an accounting adjustment gain of $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share, representing adoption of SFAS No. 96 in first quarter of last fiscal year.

title: VTN Corp reports earnings for Year to May 31
EAST GERMANS LET LARGEST PROTEST PROCEED IN PEACE
description: Tens of thousands of East Germans marched peacefully through Leipzig this evening in the largest of a wave of demonstrations for change that has swept East Germany in recent days.

title: Devtek Corp reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dravecky Hurt Again
description: Dave Dravecky, who battled back from cancer only to break his arm while pitching, injured the arm in the post-game celebration on the field today after San Francisco won the National League pennant.

title: Alpha Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
A Road Map for Genes
description: An international effort to map the genes of a wide variety of plants and animals, from slime molds to human beings, advanced significantly this week when scientists settled on a common method of identifying the genetic markers distributed on chromosomes.

title: Science Watch; Smog on Pluto
description: The latest observations of distant Pluto, the only known planet yet to be visited by spacecraft, reveal what appear to be smoggy hazes in the thin atmosphere over the polar ice caps. The phenomenon reminds scientists of atmospheric patterns seen over the poles of Mars and in the Los Angeles basin.

title: Consolidated Papers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Recharting War on Smog; States Like California Are Taking the Lead Over Washington in Pollution-Control Law
description: Civics textbooks say that Federal law is made in Washington and then applied around the country, but when it comes to clean air, a different pattern has emerged.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Commissioner Voting May Face a Standstill
description: There is strong sentiment among the 28 National Football League owners convening in Dallas today that too much polarization remains among them for one of four candidates to gain the 19 votes needed to become the league's next commissioner.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts to repeal the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act referred incorrectly to the surtax that helps provide the benefits. Generally, those of the elderly with incomes of more than $15,000, not $35,000 - calculated by their income tax liability - pay the surtax. Those with incomes above $35,000 pay the maximum surtax, $800.

title: Play With a Full Deck
description: CRIBBAGE and gin rummy, two of the most popular card games, are hard to simulate on a computer. How do you imitate that elusive quality, card sense, in a box of transistors? The Software Toolworks of Chatsworth, Calif., has done it in spades with Cribbage King-Gin King, a new program for I.B.M.-compatible computers.

title: Ryder Expects Loss in Quarter
description: Ryder System Inc. will record a $57 million after-tax charge in the third quarter, resulting in a loss for the quarter, the transportation and aircraft services company said today.

title: Galileo's Itinerary: To Jupiter With an Assist From Venus
description: The Galileo space probe is to be launched Thursday on a looping, circuitous waltz across the heavens during which it will change planetary partners three times and make fleeting passes by other bodies on its journey to Jupiter.

title: Pardoned Argentine Officers Out of Jail
description: More than a hundred military men and accused leftist subversives were freed today as a result of pardons extended by President Carlos Saul Menem in a gamble to win the loyalty of the Argentine armed forces to political democracy.

title: Foundation Seeks Self-Sufficiency for Puerto Rico
description: With help from foundations and United States corporations, a new style of philanthropy is taking root here and scattering seeds through the Caribbean.

title: Tunnel Needs $2.4 Billion
description: Eurotunnel, the company digging a rail tunnel between Britain and France, may need up to $:1.5 billion, or $2.4 billion, in new financing to finish the project, its co-chairman said today.

title: Thomson McKinnon Asset Management reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Evans Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Included credits for income taxes of $1,283,000 and $2,744,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a credit for income taxes of $911,000 for the quarter and the 6 months included a credit for income taxes of $2,463,000 and a pretax gain of $531,000, or 6 cents a share, for the first quarter ended May 28, 1988.

title: Greenspan's Soviet Visit
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, began talks today with Soviet officials on how the United States might help the Soviet Union out of its economic difficulties.

title: Developers Rushing Into Europe
description: With tight regulation keeping office vacancy rates in Europe below 3 percent, North American developers are rushing to get a foothold in this profitable market before 1992, when trade barriers fall.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Thursday misstated the size of a Defense Department contract awarded to the Aerospace Corporation of El Segundo, Calif. It was for $415.3 million.

title: Scotty's Inc reports earnings for Year to July 1
description: b-Included pre-tax charges of $10.5 million related to restructuring and impending merger with an affiliate of the GIB Group. c-After an after-tax gain of $6,353,000 from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.

title: Wordstar International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included $1,059,000 writeoff for an investment in a MacIntosh product acquired from Challenger software.

title: Spearhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
New Jersey Rebutted on Its Car Insurance Losses
description: The insurance industry, blamed by New Jersey's Insurance Commissioner for nearly $1 billion in losses by the state's Joint Underwriting Association on policies issued to car drivers, has reviewed the studies on which the Commissioner based his charge and come up with far different conclusions.

title: Valley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Thermwood Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Boston and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: Telerate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sheriff's Indictment Angers Oklahomans
description: The Sheriff here and a police officer who is the Sheriff's son-in-law in-law are accused of plotting to kidnap a man they thought was a drug dealer, bring him across state lines and torture him to make him talk.

title: Lesotho King Tries to Set Up Talks by South Africa Rivals
description: The King of Lesotho, a tiny African kingdom entirely surrounded by South Africa, said today that he was trying to bring together leaders from all sectors of South African society with the cooperation of the South African Government to discuss the nation's political future after apartheid is abolished.

title: Hewlett-Packard's New Work Station
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company plans to introduce a computer work station Tuesday that features the Intel Corporation's i486 microprocessor and a circuit design called Extended Industry Standard Architecture, or E.I.S.A. The design, adopted last year by a group of competitors of the International Business Machines Corporation, is intended to increase the performance of I.B.M.-compatible computers and to compete with I.B.M.'s Micro Channel design.

title: Pistons' Johnson Hurt
description: Vinnie Johnson, the Detroit Pistons' guard, tripped over John Salley, a teammate, in a practice on Friday at the University of Windsor (Ontario) and will be sidelined for 10 to 14 days with a broken rib.(AP)

title: Bridge
description: Half a century ago only 21 players had earned the rank of life master, which then required, and still does, 300 master points. And in 1940 there were only three additions to the rank. They would have been astonished to know how that number would grow: there are now 40,729, and of these, 79 are Grand Life Masters, having earned 10,000 points and won at least one major national title.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Holiday Closings
description: Most domestic markets for Treasury bills, notes and bonds were closed yesterday in observance of the Columbus Day holiday. But commodity, stock and corporate bond markets were open. In Canada, all financial markets were closed for a national holiday.

title: Silk, Silk, Silk Intl reports earnings for Year to June 30
Scat Hovercraft Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Daugherty Injured
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers said last night that Brad Daugherty, their center, would the miss the first two or three weeks of the regular season with a slow-healing foot problem. His recuperation from surgery six weeks ago to correct a nerve swelling between the toes has been slower than expected.(AP)

title: Pope, on Delicate Ground, Visits Indonesia
description: Pope John Paul II brought a message of Roman Catholic kinship and loyalty to Indonesia today as he began a diplomatically delicate visit to the world's most populous Muslim country.

title: Books of The Times; Past Traced to the Present In a Family's Intricate Story
description: The Other Side By Mary Gordon 386 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Telco Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Sports of The Times; Why the Cubs Didn't Win This Time
description: It's enough to make an 18-game winner tell the manager, ''I feel great'' when he knows his control has deserted him. And it did. After having walked Candy Maldonado and Brett Butler with two out in the eighth inning, that's what Mike Bielecki told Don Zimmer, but then he walked Robby Thompson on four pitches before Will Clark's two-run single off Mitch Williams decided the 3-2 victory over the Cubs that earned the Giants the National League pennant.

title: CHILD CARE BILLS NEAR COMPLETION
description: Federal legislation that vastly expands the Federal Government's role in providing child care assistance is nearing completion in Congress, and supporters predict they will overcome remaining obstacles, including the threat of a Presidential veto.
