title: New Mayor Should Continue Housing Program That Is Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Slot Machines for Soviets
description: A small Swedish company has signed a deal to sell 25,000 slot machines to the Soviet Union, the national news agency reported last week. The company, Bonik A.B., almost went bankrupt after Swedish authorities banned gambling slot machines 10 years ago. The news agency said Bonik was buying existing machines from across Sweden and adapting the coin slots for rubles before transporting them by truck to various towns in the Soviet Union.

title: Little Chance Seen for Bills That Would Put Rein on Fed
description: This month, Congress plans to take its first close look in years at how the Federal Reserve makes economic policy. Two competing measures introduced by House Democrats, one supported and the other strongly opposed by the Fed, would in totally different ways assert political influence over the powerful, secretive institution.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wildman Consolidates At Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: The rosy glow at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss these days comes from the agency's newest account, Frederick Wildman & Sons, an importer of wines and spirits.

title: Notre Dame Slips a Bit And Loses Some Esteem
description: While several undefeated, highly rated college teams - Miami, Colorado, Nebraska and Houston - were adding to their prestige by thrashing their opponents by more than 45 points Saturday, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame lost some esteem by having to struggle to defeat unranked Stanford, 27-17.

title: Lower Bid Accepted By American Medical
description: American Medical International Inc. said today that it had agreed to a revised acquisition offer from an investor group but left open the possibility that it would seek another bidder for the company.

title: Bank of New Hampshire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
As Europe Unites, Dangers Mount
description: LEAD: Every so often an observer on a distant planet could note events on Earth that foreshadow historical change. This happened with the October revolution. It happened when Hitler's stormtroopers marched by torchlight to celebrate their seizure of power. And it is happening again, symbolized for all time by the flood of refugees from a recalcitrant East

title: Guardian Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings reflected a 3-for- 2 stock split effective May 1989.

title: Kleinert's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $224,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and $191,000, or 13 cent a share, for the 9 months, both from tax loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

title: Toxic Levels For an Aquifer Worry E.P.A.
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation, a chemical manufacturer with a legacy of pollution cases at its sites here and in Rhode Island and upstate New York, has created an underground lake of contamination next to the Toms River that Federal officials say will require 30 years to remove.

title: Peoples Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Tass Bulletin: Knobby Aliens Were Here
description: Everyone seems to be coming to the Soviet Union these days: entrepreneurs in search of joint ventures, actors looking for stage sets, heavy metal musicians, arm wrestlers, even aliens.

title: Budapest Encore: Old Socialist Elected
description: The newly named Hungarian Socialist Party, which as the Communist Party over the weekend abandoned hard-line Marxist dogma, today elected Rezso Nyers, a once and present Socialist, as its President.

title: Genetic Tests 'Inconclusive' In Jogger Rape
description: Laboratory tests on genetic evidence that prosecutors hoped would link six young defendants to the rape and attempted murder of a Central Park jogger appear inconclusive, law-enforcement officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Centel Agreement
description: The Centel Corporation said it agreed to buy the cellular telephone franchises serving Aiken, S.C., and Augusta, Ga., from the Pond Branch Telephone Company for undisclosed terms. It said the deal was subject to the approval of minority shareholders and state and Federal regulators. Centel serves 41 markets and is the 10th-largest cellular company.

title: Heart-Disease Prevention Begins in Childhood; Eating American
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuji's Deal in Canada
description: Fuji Heavy Industries said today that it would buy the Canadian sales company for its Subaru cars, Subaru Auto Canada Inc. of Richmond, British Columbia, for more than $25 million (Canadian). After acquiring the sales concern, which is owned by a Canadian businessman, Fuji will change the name to Subaru Canada Inc. and move the headquarters to Toronto. Sales of Fuji's Subaru cars in Canada fell to around 7,700 in 1988 from nearly 10,000 several years ago.

title: Bogota Blast Called Accident
description: The explosion that tore through a Bogota bus and killed seven people on Sunday was apparently accidental and not the work of drug traffickers at war with the Colombian Government, the police said today. Initial police reports said the bus appeared to have been hit by a firebomb.

title: Summit Bid By Venezuela
description: Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, is calling for a special summit meeting of rich and poor countries to tackle the crippling debt and other economic problems of South American nations.

title: Market Place; Icahn's Attempt to Pressure USX
description: When Carl C. Icahn recently lifted his stake in the USX Corporation to 14 percent, the investor ignited a flurry of speculation on Wall Street about just what he can make the giant steel and energy concern do.

title: Baldwin Securities Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year revenue included securities gains of $414,000. The year-ago revenue was a negative figure of $5,033,000 and included securities losses of $7,229,000. The company said the loss for 1988 was attributable to provisions made for possible losses on non-performing loans of its finance subsidiary.

title: Review/Dance; Jazz Versions Of Tales From Japan
description: As a child, Midori Kashiwagi trained in traditional Japanese dance but went on to become a jazz dancer, establishing what is said to be the first jazz dance studio in Japan. In her New York debut, in a Saturday matinee at Gould Hall, Miss Kashiwagi presented two pieces that fused traditional and jazz dance. A curious exercise, it made for a pleasant enough afternoon of dance. But neither form shed much light on the other or, mixed, was much more than the sum of its parts.

title: Coptic Pope's Visit Cheers Faithful
description: When they say ''Pope'' at the Roman Catholic school where Michael Muraghy is in the fifth grade, they of course mean Pope John Paul II. But the other day, Michael, 10 years old, and hundreds of other Coptic Orthodox Christians had a chance to meet their own Pope - Shenouda III - at a Brooklyn Church.

title: Patterns
description: Rumors of Money

title: Norex America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $11,150,000, or $2.54 a share, for the quarter and $13,026,000, or $2.96 a share, for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $960,000 for the quarter and $4,165,000 for the year. Norex's earnings included the sale of its cruise business, Bermuda Star Line, in May, after that operation had returned to profitability, and continuing operations through the end of the fiscal year. The company's latest year income from discontinued operations included $1,091,000 from operations of the cruise business prior to its sale, and an $11,935,000 gain on disposal of the assets. Revenue for both latest periods included revenue from continuing operations and from discontinued operations. Revenue for the year-ago quarter represented revenue from discontinued operations, and revenue for the prior year included revenue from continuing operations and discontinued operations. The company, was formerly Bermuda Star Line Inc., but trading as Norex America Inc.

title: Ithaca College Pupil Charged With Killing Cornell Student
description: A 19-year-old Ithaca College student was held on $20,000 bail today in the death of a Cornell University junior, the authorities said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bus to Stores By American Express
description: TO advertisers and retailers, the distance to the consumer often seems to represent a yawning gulf. So, now and then, they make aggressive moves to bridge that gulf by bringing the shopper to stores that sell the advertised products.

title: A New Pro Tour
description: Ben Hogan said yesterday in Fort Worth that his company had decided to spend $15 million over the next three years for a proving-ground professional tour because he feels he owes an obligation to the game.

title: Carolian Systems Internaional reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Seething Giants Ready To Get Over Defeat
description: If Coach Bill Parcells had chosen yesterday to mull over the myriad of reasons why his Giants crumbled and lost by 21-19 to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, there would have been enough to ponder until he turned blue.

title: Cover Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Christian Protest Alters Cancer Society Plan
description: The American Cancer Society canceled plans to hold a lavish medieval festival on Friday, which will bethe 13th, after loud protests from fundamentalist Christians opposing the day's evil implications.

title: Unfinished Business Is Main Label for A's
description: ''If you care about the label,'' Tony La Russa was saying, ''you can't be a great team unless you're world champions.''

title: Metro Datelines; General Dynamics Is Denied Immunity
description: A state judge has ruled that the General Dynamics Corporation cannot block a lawsuit filed against it by Norden Systems by claiming immunity from legal action under the nation's national security laws.

title: Heart-Disease Prevention Begins in Childhood; Where's the Evidence?
description: To the Editor:

title: GTech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Included a gain of $974,000, or 10 cents a share, from a cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting principle relating to income taxes.

title: Met Gains a Major Photography Collection
description: Thanks to some strategic matchmaking and the largest corporate gift it has ever received for acquisition purposes, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is on the way to building a major photography collection.

title: Oranjemund Journal; Swapo and De Beers: Are They Engaged to Wed?
description: In 1908 a railway laborer cleaning the tracks of sand found a small diamond glittering in the desert sunshine. The laborer, Zacharias Lewala, obediently turned it over to his supervisor, August Stauch, who had told his crew to watch for ''shiny stones.''

title: Kansas City Tries to Revive School, but the Cost Is Criticized
description: There are skeptics aplenty, but an enthusiastic staff and other supporters are convinced that a forbidding old monolith of a high school in a grim inner-city section here will be transformed into one of the most promising arenas of academic and athletic achievement in the nation.

title: New Chain Store Splits Hamlet in Adirondacks
description: A new gasoline station and convenience store in this picturesque Adirondack hamlet is to many longtime residents a welcome addition, offering gas at reasonable prices and another spot to meet the neighbors. But to Baird Edmonds and two other residents, it is an architectural outrage, the equivalent of visual pollution.

title: USX Sells Stakes In South Africa
description: The USX Corporation said it had sold all of its equity interests in South African companies, but it withheld the identity of the buyers and the sale price. Shareholders had submitted a resolution earlier this year that USX sell its holdings in the racially segregated nation. They withdrew after management said sale negotiations were under way.

title: Chrysler Revises Cash-Back Offer
description: The Chrysler Corporation revised the cash-back incentives for its 1990 models. It raised the incentive on the Dodge Daytona from the $500 offered on 1988-89 models to $750 on 1990 models. Incentives on the Daytona ES and the LeBaron convertible Premium GT and GTC were increased $250, to $1,000.

title: For Top U.S. Science Students, a Soviet Magazine
description: A SOVIET magazine that helped America's student team win top honors in this year's international Physics Olympiad will soon be distributed to top high school science students throughout the United States.

title: Islanders Pour It On
description: The Islanders scored four times within five minutes in the third period today and rallied to beat the Vancouver Canucks, 5-2.

title: Divided Iranians Seem Unable To Settle on Firm Policy Course
description: Four months after the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran seems unable to settle on a clear course in its domestic and foreign policies.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AON Corp., Chicago, an insurance holding company, named Paul R. Davies chairman of its AON Reinsurance Agency subsidiary. Gene Taylor was named vice chairman of the division, and Stephen L. Lunsford was made senior executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Iran Expects Mitsui Money
description: Mitsui & Company of Japan will pay Iran about $1 billion in compensation for canceling a joint petrochemical complex, the Iranian press agency I.R.N.A. said today.

title: U.S. Securities Prices Climb in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in very light holiday trading yesterday, furthering an advance that began on Friday after weaker-than-expected September employment data were released.

title: Elderly, Affluent - and Selfish
description: LEAD: Young Americans are a generous lot. Despite all the talk about selfish Yuppies and a coming ''war between the generations,'' the majority of Americans under 35, according to the polls, support more generous benefits for the current elderly. The young stoically pay their ever higher Social Security taxes because they believe the old are generally needy or at least deserving.

title: 2 Doctors Share Nobel Prize for Work With Cancer Genes
description: THE Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded yesterday to Dr. J. Michael Bishop and Dr. Harold E. Varmus, cancer researchers at the University of California Medical School in San Francisco. The two scientists discovered a collection of normal genes that can cause cancer when they go awry.

title: Review/Dance; Penitence and Temptation In a Martha Graham Work
description: Martha Graham's choreography was at its best on Saturday night at the City Center Theater (131 West 55th Street) when it was most crisp. The Martha Graham Dance Company gave the season's first performance of ''El Penitente,'' a terse choreographic sketch from 1940 that depicts a performance by three strolling players in the American Southwest.

title: Review/Television; 'Roseanne' and 'Chicken Soup'
description: If Rudolph W. Giuliani fails to become the Mayor of New York City, he might be able to scold Jackie Mason. But if Mr. Mason's ABC series ''Chicken Soup'' goes down the drain, as seems increasingly likely, the comic can hardly point an accusing finger at the politician. Poorly conceived and charmlessly executed, ''Chicken Soup'' is getting cold very much on its own.

title: Maryat Lee, Playwright, 66
description: Maryat Lee, a playwright and producer for community theaters, died of heart disease on Sept. 18 at home in Lewisburg, W. Va. She was 66 years old.

title: First National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said financial information for 1989 and 1988 has been restated for the April 12, 1989 acquisition of Peoples Bank of Forsyth County and the June 30, 1989 acquisition of Pickens County Bancshares, both of which have been accounted for as poolings of interests. The company also said the two acquisitions diluted third quarter and 9 months results by 4 cents and 10 cents per share, respectively.

title: USAir Stock Rises Sharply, But a Profit Slump Is Seen
description: Stock in the USAir Group, owner of the nation's seventh-largest airline, rose sharply yesterday after a published report that its largest shareholder, the money manager Michael H. Steinhardt, wanted the company to increase its share price and might consider a hostile bid.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD ON INDIAN FISHING
description: A band of Chippewa Indians has agreed to curtail its spearfishing and other treaty rights in exchange for a multimillion-dollar aid package.

title: Our Towns; Students Paying For Their Teams At a Free School
description: When the school year began at Amityville High School this fall, Patty Scheffer and Gretchen Lottman, both l7 years old and both seniors, looked forward to another year on the girls tennis team, Patty in singles and Gretchen playing doubles.

title: Oce-van der Grinten NV reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results are in U.S. currency and were converted from Dutch florins at Dfl 2.2072 equals U.S. $ 1.00.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Treats Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $141,351. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $201,565. d-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Penny Lernoux, 49, a Reporter
description: Penny Lernoux, an author and investigative reporter who specialized in Central and South American affairs, died of lung cancer Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 49 years old and lived in Bogota, Columbia.

title: Ira Hirschmann Is Dead at 88; Executive and Leading Nazi Foe
description: Ira Hirschmann, a business executive, pioneer in radio broadcasts of classical music and political associate of Fiorello H. La Guardia, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: La Jolla Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax loss carryforward of $317,000 from the merger with the Bank of Del Mar.

title: New Toyota Luxury Car
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a high-performance luxury car today that it calls its new flagship automobile. The Celsior features a 4,000-cubic-centimeter, eight-cylinder engine with 260 horsepower.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS American Upset in Australia: Johan Anderson of Australia upset seventh-seeded Richard Matuszewski of the United States, 6-2, 6-2, in a first-round match at the Australian Indoor championships yesterday in Sydney. In other matches at the Sydney Entertainment Centre, Christian Saceanu of West Germany defeated Simon Youl of Australia, 6-2, 6-4; Niclas Kroon of Sweden beat fourth-seeded John Fitzgerald, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, and No. 3-seeded Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany beat Todd Woodbridge of Australia, 6-1, 6-4. Second-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and top-seeded Ivan Lendl will play first-round matches today. (AP) Connors Advances: Jimmy Connors breezed past Johan Carlsson of Sweden, 6-0, 6-1, yesterday to advance in the $255,000 Toulouse Grand Prix tournament in France. Connors, the defending champion, is seeded second after John McEnroe, who will begin play today. Two French players eliminated seeded players yesterday: Fabrice Santoro downed sixth-seeded Omar Camporese of Italy, 6-2, 2-6, 6-3, and Jerome Potier beat eighth-seeded Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-4, 6-1. (AP) Easy Victory for Sabatini: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, ranked third in the world, easily defeated Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday in the second round of a $250,000 tournament in Filderstadt, West Germany. Sylvia Hanika of West Germany beat Lori McNeil, 6-2, 4-6, 7-6. (AP) JUDO First Golds Awarded at Belgrade: Naoya Ogawa of Japan and Fenglian Gao of China won gold medals yesterday at the world championships in Yugoslavia. Ogawa overwhelmed Garcia Moreno of Cuba with a body lock move 2 minutes 31 seconds into the final of the men's over-95-kilo category. Gao beat Regina Sigmund of West Germany in the women's over-72-kilo division. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins 5, Jets 1: Playing at home, Pittsburgh overcame a third consecutive game without a goal by the league scoring champion, Mario Lemieux, to win for the first time this season. John Cullen and Bob Errey had goals 19 seconds apart in the first period and the former Winnipeg defenseman Jim Kyte scored twice as the Penguins raised their record to 1-1-1. Winnipeg is 1-2-0. Kyte and Randy Gilhen, obtained from Winnipeg last June, combined for three goals. Lemieux got his sixth assist on Errey's goal. (AP)

title: Bridge
description: Perceptive readers will detect something apparently wrong with the diagram: East has made the opening lead, which on every other day of the year comes from the West side. East has of course led out of turn, a situation that regularly creates confusion.

title: Phoenix Cardinals Sign Ex-Giant McConkey
description: The Phoenix Cardinals placed the defensive tackle Shawn Knight on the injured-reserve list yesterday and signed the free-agent wide receiver, Phil McConkey, to replace the ailing Roy Green.

title: Worker Survives 12-Story Fall
description: A worker installing lights in a medical building fell 12 stories and survived today, his plunge broken by an atrium's glass ceiling and by a man sitting near a second-story railing. The 24-year-old worker, Troy Livingston, was later described as being in ''very critical condition'' at St. Luke's Lutheran Hospital, suffering from various fractures and internal injuries. The man on whom he fell was knocked unconscious but was not seriously injured.

title: Ban on Ivory Trading Is Opposed
description: A proposed worldwide ban on ivory trading to save Africa's remaining elephants from poaching, widely thought to be the foregone conclusion of an international meeting here, is being vigorously opposed by some southern African nations.

title: I.B.M. Introduces New Laser Printer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new I.B.M. laser printer that can produce up to 10 pages of text a minute as well as high-quality graphics. The company said that the printer turned out documents 25 percent faster and used less desk space than previous models.

title: Police and Protesters Clash On National Day in Taiwan
description: Police officers swinging riot sticks charged thousands of protesters who threw rocks and fired slingshots today to demand freedom for political prisoners on Taiwan's National Day.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Minors' Abortions: Our Own Decision
description: LEAD: ''Mom? Dad? Is it O.K. with you if I get an abortion?''The Florida

title: Boston Restaurants Breaking Tradition: A Lighter Chowder
description: LEAD: People in the Boston area take their chowder, or ''chowdah'' as they say, seriously. Food wars have been fought and customers have been lost and won over which restaurant makes the best chowder.

title: McCaw Bid For Lin Sweetened
description: Continuing its bid to dominate the cellular telephone industry, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. sweetened its tender offer yesterday for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, which owns valuable cellular franchises in several large cities.

title: Age Groups Differ on Rating Colleges
description: Adults are not as impressed with how well colleges and universities are performing as younger Americans are, according to a recent Gallup Poll. The poll also found that most minority students feel they do not have equal access to college because of their race.

title: A Haven for Rambo, Lady and Friends
description: LONG before Rambo was a muscle-bound hero, he was an apple.

title: Annie And Friend Are Chosen
description: Eleven-year-old Danielle Findley of Lee's Summit, Mo., can stick out her chin and grin today: she was chosen yesterday from among almost 400 young girls to play the role of Annie in the new musical ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge.''

title: Iberia to Purchase 8 Airbus A340 Jets
description: Iberia Air Lines of Spain has agreed to purchase eight Airbus A340 commercial jets with an option to buy four others, the European consortium Airbus Industrie said. Iberia said the deal was worth $700 million.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Abortion Foes Lose Plea for Hearing on Their Racketeering Law Penalties
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court's ruling that found a group of abortion protesters liable under the Federal racketeering law for damages to a Philadelphia abortion clinic they tried to drive out of business.

title: Sale of Nuggets Falls Through
description: The much heralded sale of the Denver Nuggets to two black businessmen has fallen through.

title: Flames' 4-Goal 2d Period Disorganizes Devils
description: The first regular-season confrontation between National Hockey League teams with Soviet players went the way of the Calgary Flames, the defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: What It Means to Be a Serious Cook: Forget the Ingredients. Study the Knife.
description: I HAD always taken slicing for granted, like walking or eating. I'd always thought that anyone who ever confronted a knife and a cucumber would know what to do.

title: With Phones Everywhere, Everyone Is Talking More
description: Americans tell pollsters that they do not have enough time to cook, clean, see their children or just relax. But they are spending an ever-growing part of their day on the telephone.

title: Nuclear Plant's Transformer Catches Fire in N. Carolina
description: A fire broke out in a transformer at the Shearon Harris Nuclear Plant on Monday night but was confined to a section separated by concrete from the reactor and posed no threat to the public, the plant owner said today.

title: 2 Concerns Weigh Rescue of Ferranti
description: Two of Europe's biggest military electronics contractors, Thomson-CSF of France and British Aerospace P.L.C., said they were considering a bid to rescue Britain's Ferranti International Signal P.L.C. Thomson-CSF and British Aerospace, in a statement released in Paris and London, said an offer would aim to uphold Ferranti's position as a principal supplier of British military equipment. Ferranti said last month that it had been the victim of fraud involving nonexistent contracts that would cause it to write off $:185 million ($300 million). The company said the fraud involved contracts of its United States subsidiary, ISC Technologies, based in Lancaster, Pa., which it bought in 1987.

title: J.P. Morgan Unit Wins Lead In Savannah Electric Offer
description: J.P. Morgan Securities Inc., the investment banking subsidiary of J.P. Morgan & Company, became the first bank securities subsidiary to act as sole lead manager on a corporate underwriting yesterday, when it won a $30 million issue at competitive bid.

title: Volvo Talking With Renault
description: Volvo A.B. said it is holding discussions with France's Renault, although it would not confirm published reports that the auto makers were in the final stage of negotiating a merger or joint venture. The business magazine

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about the Soviet reaction to Poland's new Government misstated a remark by Fyodor M. Burlatsky, a Soviet newspaper commentator and member of the Supreme Soviet. As Mr. Burlatsky has since pointed out, he said the clash of forces from the right and the left could lead to the danger of a military government in the Soviet Union similar to the one installed in Poland in 1981, not to a military government in Poland now.

title: Water-Main Break Spews Asbestos Into 8th Ave.
description: A water main burst at the intersection of Eighth Avenue and West 43d Street yesterday, sending asbestos-laden mud gurgling up the avenue and cascading down onto the IND subway tracks below, officials said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Hanna-Barbera Head To Mix Old With New
description: LEAD: As a child, David Kirschner says, he was a dreamer.

title: Kean Accused of 'Conspiracy' in a Toll Increase
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean participated in an ''unspoken conspiracy'' that allowed the New Jersey Highway Authority to raise tolls on the Garden State Parkway, a special bipartisan State Senate committee said today.

title: Sihanouk, the Key to Cambodian Peace
description: With the Cambodian problem moving from the conference table to the battlefield, many in the U.S. are questioning the wisdom of Washington's support of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the non-Communist resistance. These critics are wrong: Prince Sihanouk, a Cambodian patriot, is the only Cambodian leader who can bring about national reconciliation.

title: How New York Prisons Deal With AIDS Inside Their Walls
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; When Show Business Meets College Sports
description: Tonight's edition of ''The Other Side of the News'' brings us coaches, college presidents, sports writers and others acquainted with what Eamon Kelly, the president of Tulane University, who ended the men's basketball program in 1985 after a point-shaving scandal, calls the systemic mess of intercollegiate sports.

title: Bank of Japan Increases Rate
description: The Bank of Japan said today that it had raised its discount rate to 3.75 percent, from 3.25 percent. Finance Minister Ryutaro

title: Savoring the World According to Julia
description: THE voice that launched several million cooks warbled through the big, quiet kitchen. ''I am 6 feet 1 and 3/4 inches tall,'' Julia Child said to a reporter who had called on the telephone.

title: High Court to Consider Medical Device Patent
description: The Supreme Court, which rarely examines Federal patent law, agreed today to decide a patent issue of considerable importance to the growing medical technology industry.

title: Deal to Buy MGM/UA Collapses
description: An Australian entertainment company's deal to acquire the MGM/UA Communications Company collapsed today amid recriminations and legal action, opening the possibility that Rupert Murdoch might make another bid for the film and television studio.

title: Atalanta Stake Cut
description: An investment group led by the Atalanta Sosnoff Capital Corporation, a New York money management concern controlled by Martin T. Sosnoff, has lowered its stake in America West Airlines Inc. to the equivalent of 6.2 percent from 8.4 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Atalanta Sosnoff gave no reason for the sale.

title: On American Ice at Last
description: There's an Oldsmobile, this year's vintage, in the driveway of a suburban New Jersey condominium so new that the air around it remains tinged by the smell of sawdust. On the front step is a bright-hued coleus, a standard welcome-to-the-neighborhood gift. In the foyer, a vigilant gray poodle is pacing, uncertain whether to receive guests who speak English instead of his accustomed Russian with a wag of his tail or a worried growl.

title: California Alliance Proposes Vote On Broad Environmental Measure
description: In a move that has as much to do with California politics as the environment, an alliance of politicians and environmentalists today offered a ballot measure that they called the broadest effort ever mounted to protect air, food and water against chemical contamination.

title: Ecolab Revamping May Be Discussed
description: Southeastern Asset Management Inc., a Memphis-based investment advisory concern that holds a 12.1 percent stake in Ecolab Inc., said it had been approached by third parties interested in discussing a possible revamping of the St. Paul-based cleaning and maintenance company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Southeastern Asset said it ''may engage in such discussions with third parties.''

title: Review/Jazz; Pat Metheny's Serious Side
description: In 1976, the arrival of the guitarist Pat Metheny's first album, ''Bright-Size Life,'' announced a new way of looking at the jazz guitar. Mr. Metheny, mixing jazz with an abstraction of country music, reimagined the American musical landscape, producing an intimate synthesis that blossomed with possibilities. Since then, things have gone downhill, and his concert at the Beacon Theater on Saturday night, the third of four, showed why.

title: RICO and Abortion Protesters
description: The Supreme Court let stand a ruling that anti-abortion protesters are liable under racketeering law for damage to a clinic. Page A23.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 Panama's coup leaders were divided over what to do with General Noriega when he was a prisoner, the Pentagon said in a move to head off criticism from rebels in Miami. Page A1 Panama captain buried amid execution reports A10 Two pardoned Argentines return A5 South Africa will free Walter Sisulu and six other leaders of the banned African National Congress, but will not immediately release Nelson Mandela, President de Klerk said. A1 Some southern African nations oppose ban on ivory trading A8 News analysis: East German events are cooling as protests and anniversary celebrations recede. Now divisions are appearing within the Communist Party over reform. A1 What's in a name? Just ask Hungary's redesignated Socialists A9 Nationalists will end an embargo in Azerbaijan that has deprived neighboring Armenia of fuel and supplies for two months. A potentially dangerous impasse is apparently ended. A6 U.F.O. landing is fact, not fantasy, Russians insist A6 The next Chinese leader was picked by the Communist Party. It said Jiang Zemin would be the ''core'' of a third generation of leaders, thereby succeeding Deng Xiaoping. A3 Indonesia moving toward a more private economy A13 An Egyptian-Israeli meeting in Washington is being sought by Secretary Baker to pave the way for Israeli-Palestinian talks. A3 Beit Sahur journal: A tax war develops on the West Bank A4 A French researcher was overlooked in the awarding of this year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, French scientists say. But Americans say he played only a minor role A8 Bush to attend Latin drug talks A10 U.N. shuns drug fight A12 National A14-28 Florida will not pass abortion limits sought by the Governor, top legislators said as they opened a special session on abortion and demonstrators marched on Tallahassee. A1 Supreme Court roundup: Abortion foes lose plea for hearing A23 Court to consider the scope of a generic drug law D2 A bidding war of bigger tax breaks broke out in the Senate as sponsors of competing proposals for a cut in the capital gains tax sought the 60 votes needed to overcome parliamentary obstacles. A1 New oil drilling would be banned off the California coast, some pesticides would be phased out and carbon dioxide emissions would be cut by 40 percent under a ballot measure proposed in California. A1 More companies to phase out ozone-destroying chemicals A27 The Bay Area has a chance to crow to New York and Los Angeles as San Francisco and Oakland become the homes of the World Series. A1 A plea to block a shuttle launching Thursday that is to carry nuclear-powered cargo was rejected by a judge. NASA delayed the launching because of an engine problem. A18 Jury to decide fault in '87 jet crash in Detroit A17 Child care may become more costly under a change in the Federal tax law. The change is meant to cut back the practice of paying child-care providers off the books. A14 Chicago parents vied for votes on the eve of an election to chose who will run the third-largest and newly decentralized school system. A18 Charleston will not suffer damage over the long run because of Hurricane Hugo's foray into South Carolina, Mayor Joseph Riley said. A21 Four aliens found dead in fumigated truck trailer A14 Man guilty of planting 13 bombs in Indiana city A16 Blown fuse blamed for slow response in Norfolk, Va., fire A21 Pentagon softens stand on control of Stars and Stripes A20 MGM/UA deal collapses D1 Regional B1-5, B24 New York City tax revenue lagged well behind expectations in the last three months and, in some cases, dropped sharply from the same period last year, officials say. B1 Governor Cuomo is being chided by critics for urging ''spending discipline'' in his New York State budget but complaining bitterly when President Bush uses a similar theme. B3 Giuliani ties strong city economy to helping the poor B4 Is Rudolph Giuliani a Reaganite? The Dinkins campaign says that Mr. Giuliani's work for the Reagan Administration amounts to an endorsement of many of its policies. The Giuliani campaign disputes that view. B1 Mayoral camps meeting today on debate plan B4 Finance law evens the odds in New Jersey governor race B1 A helicopter crashed in New Jersey, killing five people, including three top executives of Donald Trump's three casinos in Atlantic City. B1 Hospitals shouldn't rely on New York for any ''big bailouts'' and instead should take steps on their own to reduce costs, the New York State Health Commissioner said. B24 A housing manager was transferred after he warned officials in the New York City Housing Authority of suspected corruption, the Department of Investigation said. B5 Suspect is identified in beating of Jewish students B3 Water-main break spews asbestos into 8th Avenue B3

title: They Aren't Fleeing Hungary
description: Why are thousands of East Germans taking to the streets and thousands more running from home? Why are Hungarians doing neither? The explanation has less to do with economics than with everything else.

title: Holy Cross Has Reasons to Respect Army Team
description: For a college with a lesser football reputation, playing a game at West Point can be an intimidating, awesome event. That is a concern of Mark Duffner, the Holy Cross coach whose unbeaten team on Saturday will take on the Army.

title: A Woman Obtains A Restraining Order To Protect Embryos
description: A Louisville woman obtained a restraining order today to prevent her estranged husband, an endocrinologist whose specialty is in vitro fertilization, from destroying the couple's six fertilized eggs.

title: Europe Seeks New Steel Deal
description: The 12-nation European Community hopes to reach a new deal soon with the Bush Administration on the trade bloc's steel shipments to the United States, an official of the community said today.

title: New York Judge Backs Limit on Intern Hours
description: A state judge today rejected a challenge to New York State's new rules increasing hospital supervision of medical interns and cutting their long work hours.

title: A Welcome Shift on Child Care
description: ''A witches' brew'' is what Representative Thomas Downey calls the upcoming Senate-House conference on Federal support for child care. He's not far off the mark. There are conflicts not only between the House and Senate but within the House itself, which endorsed a legislative package last week that is roughly parallel to the Senate's Act for Better Child Care Services. Even so, it's possible the brew can produce a palatable child care bill before the end of the year.

title: Wanted: A Jet to Catch Passes From O'Brien
description: Ken O'Brien has become a quarterback in search of a receiver: one of his own, not the other team's.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper fell sharply yesterday, to their lowest levels since mid-August.

title: U.F.O. Landing Is Fact, Not Fantasy, the Russians Insist
description: It is not a joke, nor a hoax, nor a sign of mental instability, nor an attempt to drum up local tourism by drawing the curious, the Soviet press agency Tass insisted today in discussions of what it called an extraterrestrial visit to southern Russia.

title: Dorothy McConnell, 90, Editor and Author
description: Dorothy McConnell, an editor, author and former chief executive of the Women's Division of the Methodist Church, died Friday at her home in Lucasville, Ohio. She had moved to Ohio from Manhattan last year and recently celebrated her 90th birthday.

title: Food Notes
description: 'Light' Ice Creams

title: Accounts
description: * Bassett-Walker, a maker of fleece wear, to the Martin Agency, Richmond, with a budget of $3.5 million to $5 million.

title: Glaxo's Search: Son of Zantac
description: Ernest Mario, the new chief executive of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., is obsessed with avoiding a problem that has plagued other drug companies: having a highly successful drug, but not having others to succeed it one day.

title: Praise for Little League
description: President Bush, a former Little League coach, joined the celebration yesterday for the team from Trumbull, Conn., that won the Little League World Series in August, the first United States team in six years to take the title.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FETA, the tart, salty white cheese associated with Greek cuisine, can add a lively, sharp edge to all kinds of dishes.

title: For Fendi, Lagerfeld Offers A Perky Twist for Spring
description: The mannequins moved gracefully along the winding runways Fendi set up in a tent Monday night at the Palazzo Barozzi for about 1,000 people. They moved in a continuous line, crisscrossing the audience so everyone could have a first-rate view.

title: MCI Sues A.T.&T. Over Ads
description: The MCI Communications Corporation filed suit today in Federal District Court in Washington, accusing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of false and deceptive advertising in connection with a campaign claiming better quality and service.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Albert Fisher Group P.L.C., London, a diversified food supplier, named Keith Brackpool chief executive of its North American operations.

title: Jury to Decide Fault in '87 Jet Crash in Detroit
description: Jury selection has begun in the liability trial in a 1987 Northwest Airlines crash that killed 156 people, with lawyers prepared to battle over who is to blame for the accident.

title:
EDUCATION;
College Recruiters and Counselors Share Some Tips From the Trenches
description: LEAD: After William Fitzsimmons, dean of admissions at Harvard, finished speaking to the Independent Educational Consultants Association last week, he opened the floor to questions.

title: Governor Nominates 6 Candidates For the SUNY Board of Trustees
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo nominated six people today to the State University board of trustees, including the chairwoman of the state chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., Hazel N. Dukes.

title: Apples After Alar: Old Favorites Wane
description: OCTOBER'S colors dazzle, from the multihued leaves to the hedgerows of goldenrod and fields of fat orange pumpkins. And stacked high in farm stands and greenmarkets are apples in deep and mottled reds, purples, yellows and golds.

title: With Bay Area Series, Sun Rises in the West
description: Thanks to two World Series-bound baseball teams, the Bay Area finally has a chance to even old scores.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Exercised the option on the contract of Bret Saberhagen, pitcher, for 1990. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Named Scott Proefrock assistant of baseball operations. BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Released Anthony Taylor and Keith Wilson, guards. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Waived Jarvis Basnight, forward. FOOTBALL PHOENIX (NFL) - Signed Phil McConkey, wide receiver. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Suspended Dave Manson, Chicago defenseman, for three games for pushing the linesman Ron Asselstine in a game with the Rangers on Oct. 8. MONTREAL (NHL) - Called up Martin Desjardins, center, from Sherbrooke of the American Hockey League. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Named Matt Keator New England area scout. Signed Jack Evans, assistant director of scouting, and Pat Ginnell, Ken Williamson and John Paris, Jr., scouts.

title: Most Bank Yields Decline, Anticipating Drop in Rates
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly down for the week ended yesterday.

title: Older (and Better) Vintages of Alsace
description: Wine growers in the Alsace region of France call riesling the king of grapes and gewurztraminer the queen. The reason for their respect was shown at three unusual tastings that centered on older vintages in New York last month.

title: JUDGE REJECTS BAN ON NASA LAUNCHING
description: A Federal district judge this evening denied a motion by environmentalists to delay the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis on Thursday because of concerns over a nuclear power supply.

title: Sallie Mae Prices $500 Million Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced $500 million of short-term floating-rate notes in its regular monthly issue.

title: House Ethics Panel Criticized Over Speed of Gingrich Inquiry
description: The Congressman who filed an ethics complaint against the House Republican whip, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said today that the House ethics committee was unnecessarily delaying a decision on his request that it investigate Mr. Gingrich's financial dealings.

title: Reaganism Now Liability For Giuliani
description: When Ronald Reagan became President in 1981, Rudolph W. Giuliani went to Washington as a top official in the Justice Department and vigorously pursued the new administration's policies.

title: Giuliani Ties Racial Harmony to Strong Economy
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday the poor ''will suffer the most'' without a strong city economy, as his mayoral campaign continued its strategy of making a policy statement each day.

title: European Jobless Data
description: The unemployment rate in the 12-nation European Community stood at 9.2 percent in August, unchanged from July, the European Community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said today. In the eight-month period between January and August, the rate fell to 9.2 percent from 10.1 percent. Eurostat did not give a figure for the total number of unemployed in August because the Netherlands had not yet sent its data.

title: Walker's Deal Up to Him
description: The Dallas Cowboys had an open ''fire sale'' on Herschel Walker today. Walker's agents, Peter Johnson and Ralph Cindrich, were considering a restructuring of the running back's $1 million-a-year contract as part of the price for Walker leaving the Cowboys.

title: Greenspan View of Russians
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that Soviet economists appear to be unconcerned with ideology as they deal with their country's economic problems. He said that Soviet economists are ''willing to reach beyond the usual confines of what economic policy makers are willing to do.''

title: Topics of The Times; Leapin' Lizards!
description: The Postal Service has taken heavy flak for mislabeling its new 25-cent dinosaur stamp, a drawing of a pair of dinosaurs captioned ''Brontosaurus.'' Furious purists point out that the ''brontosaurus'' is now properly called ''apatosaurus.'' They accuse the stamp's authors of fostering scientific illiteracy, and want the stamps recalled. The Postal Service, unmoved, has printed 100 million and is promoting them with T-shirts and a tie-in with the children's dinosaur movie ''The Land Before Time.''

title: Curbs Listed On Textiles
description: The United States and Canada have increased restrictions on imports of textiles and clothes in the last three years, according to a report submitted today to a world trade body.

title: N.F.L. Is Taking Its Time Selecting a Commissioner
description: The 28 National Football League owners, after nearly 10 hours of work and four ballots today, were unable to elect a new commissioner here tonight and adjourned until Wednesday morning.

title: Four Aliens Found Dead in Texas In Fumigated Trailer on a Train
description: Four men believed to be illegal aliens were found dead here this morning in a truck trailer in which a cargo of flour had been fumigated with a toxic pesticide.

title: Chile's Top Communist Back From Soviet Exile
description: The former Communist Party leader of Chile, Luis Corvalan, returned today after 13 years of exile in the Soviet Union and quickly declared support for the opposition's presidential candidate.

title: Taxing Social Security Benefits Is a Con Game; Elderly Singled Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Hiring Seen Gaining
description: The Sony Corporation appeared to clear a hurdle today in its plan to install two top Hollywood producers as co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., the studio Sony is acquiring for $3.4 billion.

title: Beit Sahur Journal; In a Tax War, Even the Olivewood Dove Is Seized
description: To press the Palestinian uprising, the people of this town have refused for months to pay their taxes. In response, Israel has begun to confiscate their goods. The raids, Aysa Hanna Khier says, have produced some incongruities.

title: U.S. Acting On Guinness Extradition
description: Justice Department officials said yesterday that extradition proceedings had begun against a Washington lawyer who has been linked in Britain to a secret $100 million investment three years ago in an arbitrage company run by Ivan F. Boesky.

title: A Speedier Way to Move a Ship's Cargo
description: Ships that transport thousands of small packages of delicate and perishable goods are finding a gentler and faster method of loading and unloading cargo on the Houston Ship Channel at a new operation that is the first of its kind in the United States.

title: Howe: Never Mind
description: With Wayne Gretzky on the verge of breaking Gordie Howe's National Hockey League career scoring record, there were reports the past two days that the 61-year-old Howe, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, was planning to come out of retirement for one game after Jan. 1 in order to push his career into the 1990's, For Howe, who began his N.H.L. career with the Detroit Red Wings in 1946 and who retired in 1980 while playing for the Hartford Whalers, that would be the sixth decade in which he has played in the N.H.L.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., a maker of paper products and glassware, said its Paper Corp. of America unit had acquired Inter-City Paper Co., Minneapolis, and its Roll Source Inc. unit. Terms were not disclosed.

title: El Diario of Los Angeles
description: Lack of cash has shut down one of the city's three Spanish-language dailies, the newspaper's lawyer said today. ''The paper was undercapitalized, and they ran out of money,'' Jose Mariano Castillo said of El Diario de Los Angeles, which ended publication after Saturday's issue. Mr. Castillo said El Diario's owners, Inmobiliaria America Latina Inc., hoped to revive the newspaper, which was begun in May 1987 and had been losing about $80,000 a month. Mr. Castillo said 24 people lost their jobs when the newspaper ceased publication. Another 26 were laid off in June when the paper moved to reduce operating costs.

title: Dredging Up War Relics From Frigid Alaskan Waters
description: An obscure chapter of World War II history is emerging from beneath the cold, clear waters off the Aleutian Islands, where divers using sonar have made a survey of Japanese wrecks.

title: Books of The Times; Inside Jokes From the Knights Templar to Snoopy
description: Foucault's Pendulum By Umberto Eco Translated by William Weaver. Illustrated. 641 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: Review/Art; Fresh Insights Into Dali, in European Show
description: Given the nature of Salvador Dali's output in recent years, the last thing on earth that this critic wanted to do was to go halfway across Europe to see a mammoth exhibition - more than 300 works, it was said - by the Spanish Surrealist. But then the word went round that in all kinds of unexpected ways this was a show that had to be seen. People had gone crazy about it in Stuttgart, West Germany, where it had been on view at the Staatsgalerie from May through July. They went crazy about it in Zurich, too, where it opened in August at the Kunsthaus and where it can be seen through Oct. 22. The word was that Dali would be seen as no one had seen him before. It was perfectly true.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Monday misstated the circumstances of Michele Fortune's departure from the Ann Taylor stores, where she had been president. The company said last week that Ms. Fortune had left, not that she had resigned. Ms. Fortune was not available for comment last week but said yesterday: ''I did not resign. I was terminated without cause.'' The company declined to comment on Ms. Fortune's remarks.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Republic to End Rail Embargo of Armenia Nationalists in Azerbaijan agreed to end a rail embargo that deprived neighboring Armenia of supplies, ending a threat that Moscow would take control of the railroad. Page A6. New York Tax Revenue Off Revenue from some of New York City's most important taxes are lagging behind expectations, raising concern about the need to cut back services or raise taxes. Page B1. Casino Officials Die in Crash Five people, including three top executives of Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casinos, were killed when their helicopter crashed on the median of the Garden State Parkway. Page B1. Shuttle: Gain and a Setback The Atlantis launching set for tomorrow was backed by a judge, who rejected arguments about the nuclear-powered cargo. But an engine problem postponed the flight. Page A18.

title: Finance Law Evens Odds in Jersey Contest
description: With less than a month to go before the Nov. 7 election, the candidates for governor have reached or are close to reaching the limit on campaign contributions set by New Jersey's public-financing law.

title: Deputy Creative Head Resigns From Ogilvy
description: Ogilvy & Mather's New York office lost another senior creative executive yesterday with the resignation of Jay Jasper as deputy creative head. Mr. Jasper, 52 years old, left for Young & Rubicam's San Francisco office, where he will become executive vice president and creative director.

title: Copter Crash Kills 3 Aides Of Trump
description: Five people, including three high-level executives of Donald J. Trump's three casinos in Atlantic City, were killed yesterday when their helicopter crashed in pine woodlands on the Garden State Parkway near Forked River, N.J.

title: Jogger Trial Judge Bans Lawyers From Disclosing Evidence
description: The state judge hearing the Central Park rape case yesterday barred prosecutors and defense lawyers from discussing any evidence with the press.

title: BREAKS ARE ADDED IN TAX-CUT PLANS
description: Supporters of a lower tax on capital gains are waging a bidding war in the Senate, offering ever more generous tax breaks in an effort to find the 60 votes they need to overcome parliamentary obstacles.

title: Second Bombing in 2 Days at High School
description: The high school here was shaken by a bomb explosion today for the second time in two days, and bomb threats have been received by at least four other high schools in central Indiana.

title: Group W to Represent Cable Sports Networks
description: Seeking to capitalize on the fragmentation of media outlets, Group W has started a venture to represent six regional cable sports networks to national advertisers. The company has retained Earle Palmer Brown/New York to promote the effort with a trade advertising campaign.

title: Communist Chief Is Named Deng's Heir Apparent
description: The Communist Party declared today that General Secretary Jiang Zemin would serve as the ''core'' of the third generation of Chinese leaders and thereby succeed Deng Xiaoping as China's paramount leader.

title: The Mayoral Debate That Matters
description: Just about every front-runner ducks debates, so it comes as no surprise that David Dinkins is reluctant to debate Rudolph Giuliani one-on-one. He obviously prefers including Ronald Lauder, the Conservative Party's choice, and Henry Hewes, the Right to Life candidate. New Yorkers should certainly hear all four. Yet as Mr. Dinkins knows, the contest is between him and Mr. Giuliani, and that's the debate that counts.

title: Frenchman Says Nobel Panel Overlooked His Contribution
description: In an international dispute over this year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, leading French scientists are contending that a French researcher was overlooked, while Americans say he played only a subordinate role in the research.

title: City Opera Delays Decision On Cancellation
description: In response to requests from other unions affected by the strike of the New York City Opera orchestra, the company announced yesterday that it was postponing by 48 hours its final decision on whether to cancel the remainder of its fall season, which is scheduled to run until Nov. 19.

title: German Morning After; The Signs Are Mixed on Whether Reforms Are Closer in East in the Wake of Protests
description: As the wave of street protests that swept East Germany on its 40th anniversary seems to recede, the question left behind is whether democratic change is any closer.

title: Azerbaijanis Agree to End Rail Embargo of Armenia
description: Azerbaijani nationalists agreed tonight to end a rail embargo that has deprived neighboring Armenia of fuel and other supplies for two months, apparently ending a potentially dangerous political impasse.

title: About New York; Puckish Fans Face Off at Bar In Bilious Rivalry
description: Time for a sports column. Maybe one beginning: ''Hey, Mr. Steinbrenner, great news about your slacker, Rickey Henderson, winning the M.V.P. award for Oakland in the American League Championship Series. (Boss!)''

title: Wine Talk
description: THE fortress that dominates this remote hill town south of Siena looks as impregnable as it must have been in the 15th century, but it has not been able to fend off modern times.

title: Grace Liotta, 86, Dies; A Community Leader
description: Grace Bellezza Liotta, a community leader in Brooklyn for almost 50 years, died Monday at Woodhull Hospital. She was 86 years old and had suffered a stroke months ago.

title: Vital New York Taxes Lag, and Economy Is Blamed
description: Revenue from several of New York City's most important taxes lagged well behind expectations in the last three months and, in some cases, dropped sharply from the same period last year, budget officials say.

title: Middlebury College's President to Bow Out
description: Saying he feels like ''a free man,'' Olin C. Robison has announced he will resign as president of Middlebury College, effective next summer, ending a 15-year tenure as leader of the liberal arts school.

title: Tax-Law Shift May Affect How the Baby Sitter Is Paid
description: A little-noticed change in Federal tax law may curb the widespread but illegal practice of paying child-care providers off the books. At the same time, child-care experts say, it may drive up the price of care by adding in the cost of taxes and Social Security.

title: Pilots Approve Funds at UAL
description: About 90 percent of the 6,240 pilots at United Airlines voted yesterday to put up $200 million in equity as part of a deal to buy the UAL Corporation, United's parent, for $300 a share.

title: Panamanian Captain Buried Amid Reports of Executions
description: An army captain who the Government said had been jailed for complicity in the failed coup against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega last week was buried today as unconfirmed reports continued to circulate of reprisal executions and torture.

title: Good/Bad News
description: There is a tremendous sense of urgency in Poland now. The survival question for democratic transformation is just the opposite from the beginning of the decade when Solidarity was born.

title: ABC Near No. 1 As 2 Shows Set Rating Records
description: ''Roseanne'' and the season premiere of ''The Wonder Years'' both had their highest ratings ever last week, helping to bring ABC within eight-tenths of a point of first-place NBC in the prime-time ratings. NBC squeaked by with an average prime-time rating of 15.2, winning the week for the 68th time. ABC's prime-time average rating was 14.4; CBS's was 12.4.

title: Man Guilty of Planting 13 Bombs in Indiana City
description: A Federal District Court jury has convicted a man on charges of planting 13 bombs around a small city in southern Indiana in a plot that prosecutors say stemmed from a lifelong rivalry with a state legislator.

title: Economic Scene; A Gold Standard For the Kremlin?
description: THE folks who persuaded Ronald Reagan that deficits do not matter have an idea or two for the Kremlin. Surprisingly, perhaps, Mikhail Gorbachev's economic advisers are giving these ideas a respectful hearing: They were reportedly even discussed at last month's mini-summit meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyo. More surprising still, they might prove part of the solution to the Soviet Union's desperate economic problems.

title: Indonesia Moving Quietly Toward a More Private Economy
description: In the last few years, there has been a quiet but undisputed economic revolution in Indonesia, which is moving away from the traditional economy - planned, dominated and often owned by the state - toward more deregulation and private enterprise.

title: Anthony Gaubis, Securities Analyst, 87
description: Anthony Gaubis, a securities analyst and investment adviser, died Sunday at John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. He was 87 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: New Digital Software Links Various Products
description: In a move intended to link its computers with those of its competitors, the Digital Equipment Corporation introduced a second generation of computing applications today that would enable office professionals to work together electronically.

title: Chicago on Brink of New School System
description: On the eve of the election that will put parents in charge of the nation's third-largest school system, Veronica Kyle stood outside her son's South Side elementary school, flagging down constituents as they dropped off their children.

title: Lessons
description: Like most colleges, the University of Southern California has a computer that sends out ''personalized'' recruiting letters to prospective freshmen.

title: Top Runners for Event
description: Margaret Groos, winner of the 1988 United States Olympic women's marathon trials, and Zoya Ivanova, the biggest winner among Soviet marathoners, have entered the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5.

title: Taxing Social Security Benefits Is a Con Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Blown Fuse Delayed Norfolk Firefighters. A City Official Says
description: A blown fuse in an alarm system delayed the response of firefighters to a nursing home fire that killed 11 people, a city official said Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will be the media capital of the world for a couple of weeks. Everyone will see that we're just as regular as the rest of the country. We get excited, we cheer madly and we wear funny costumes just like they do in New York, Chicago or Boston.'' - Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco. [ A1:3. ]

title: Let's Have No More Language Bigotry; Views of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: War as Abomination, And a Debate on Evil
description: The last time Paul Fussell wrote about war, it was World War I, and his book, ''The Great War and Modern Memory,'' won two major book awards and became something of a classic. Mr. Fussell has now returned to the subject of war, this time World War II, and the critical response has, he admits, taken him by surprise with its intensity and, at times, its ferocity.

title: Saatchi's Future Cloudier; Big Holder Weighs Options
description: The future of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company became cloudier yesterday when its largest shareholder said it had been contacted by other parties interested in an overhaul of the world's largest marketing communications company.

title: 2 Generations of Fans Enjoy Rolling Stones' Live Legacy
description: Officer Donald Thomas of the New York City Transit Police, a man usually stationed far below ground in the subways of Manhattan, pulled a plum assignment yesterday. Above him, the sun was shining. Behind him, Mick Jagger was warbling ''Angie.''

title: Data General Sets Move and Layoffs
description: The Data General Corporation, a Westboro-based computer maker, said it would sell its plant in Portsmouth, N.H., and move manufacturing operations to a larger plant in Apex, N.C., in the next year. The company said it would eliminate 2,200 of 14,200 jobs and that more than 700 people would be affected immediately. The company will take a charge of about $80 million against results for the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30 to consolidate operations.

title: Unisys Picks President For Its Healthcare Unit
description: The Unisys Corporation announced yesterday that it had named David M. Pomerance, a 44-year-old entrepreneur, as president of its Unisys Healthcare Systems unit. Mr. Pomerance joined Unisys earlier this year as vice president and general manager of the division.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY Supporters of a lower capital gains tax are bidding for votes in the Senate, offering ever more generous packages of tax breaks. The latest offering would cut capital gains taxes for individual taxpayers and corporations. It would also provide tax breaks for small high-risk businesses and would restore the deductibility of individual retirement account contributions. [ Page A1. ] The Supreme Court will examine the scope of a patent law exemption for generic drug makers. It agreed to hear an appeal by Eli Lilly on whether the special protection extended beyond generic drugs to products like food additives and medical devices. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Qintex's deal to acquire MGM/UA collapsed in amid accusations and legal action, reopening the possibility of Rupert Murdoch making a bid for the film and television studio. [ D1. ] Members of the Air Line Pilots Association voted to continue paying strike benefits to Eastern Airlines pilots, making it likely that the seven-month strike against Eastern will continue. [ D1. ] McCaw Cellular Communications sweetened its tender offer for Lin Broadcasting to $125 a share. [ D1. ] P.&G.'s chairman and chief will step down on Jan. 2, nearly three years before mandatory retirement. In a surprise, the head of international operations was named the successor. [ D1. ] Extradition proceedings have begun against a Washington lawyer who has been linked by British authorities to a secret $100 million investment in a company run by Ivan F. Boesky. [ D5. ] MCI Communications sued A.T.&T., accusing it of making false and deceptive advertising claims. [ D4. ] McDonnell Douglas will introduce versions of its short- to medium-range commercial airliners next year that will be powered by traditional jet engines rather than a new engine technology. [ D4. ] Volvo is holding discussions with Renault. But Volvo did not confirm reports that the auto makers were in the final stage of negotiating a merger or joint venture. [ D4. ] Digital Equipment has a new second generation of computing applications that would enable office professionals to work together electronically on machines made by different companies. [ D16. ] Telerate said a special panel of its directors had rejected as inadequate Dow Jones's $576 million offer. [ D22. ] MARKETS Stocks fell moderately as some futures-related trading ended a six-day surge that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average to a gain of nearly 100 points. The Dow fell 6.08, to 2,785.33. [ D8. ] The dollar rose sharply, passing the 1.90 mark level again and breaching 144 yen. The pound also fell sharply. [ D15. ] Copper futures rose to new contract highs before plunging later. [ D15. ] Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading. [ D19. ] Yields on C.D.'s and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down. [ D6. ] TECHNOLOGY A new class of specialized computers is becoming the next area of opportunity in the computer business, and a host of new companies are staking their claims to it. [ D7. ] Wharfside conveyor belts can unload a ship of small packages of delicate and perishable goods more gently and more quickly than conventional methods. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A gold standard for the ruble is being suggested to the Kremlin by American supply-siders. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Sun Electric is making progress in the growing field of automotive emissions controls. Market Place. [ D8. ] Saatchi & Saatchi's future is clouded, after its largest shareholder said it had been contacted by other parties interested in an overhaul of the company. Randall Rothenberg: Advertsing. [ D1. ]

title: WEFA Fills Operating Post
description: William A. Mundell, 29 years old, yesterday was named chief operating officer of WEFA Inc., an economic research and management consulting group formed in 1988 through the merger of Wharton Econometrics and Chase Econometrics.

title: Police Identify A Suspect, 18, In Beating Jews
description: Investigators have identified an 18-year-old Brooklyn man as a suspect in the beating of three Jewish students near Brooklyn College early Sunday by a gang that shouted anti-Semitic slurs, the police said yesterday.

title: A Rivalry Mild No More In First Series By the Bay
description: After two rapid playoffs that took only five games apiece to decide the pennants, the major leagues cleared the stage yesterday for their main event - the first ''Subway Series'' in 33 years, the second straight Series in California and the first ever to be played entirely in the San Francisco Bay area.

title: W.B.A. Sets Deadline For Tyson-Holyfield
description: The World Boxing Association has put Mike Tyson on notice that if he beats Donovan (Razor) Ruddock on Nov. 18, he must fight Evander Holyfield within 120 days.

title: Aide at Pentagon Backtracks On Changing Military Paper
description: A Pentagon spokesman said Monday that the armed services newspaper Stars and Stripes, accused of censorship in recent years, would be run in the future by civilians instead of military officers. The remark apparently took a Pentagon-appointed ombudsman by surprise, and today the spokesman said such a decision would not be made until the ombudsman, who is studying the newspaper, submits his report.

title: 2 Pardoned Argentines Return
description: Two former leftist guerrilla leaders accused of murder and other crimes in the 1970's returned to Argentina today after receiving presidential pardons and said they regretted ''the errors committed in the past.''

title: Hospitals Urged Not to Count On a 'Big Bailout'
description: The New York State Health Commissioner told administrators of the state's financially ailing hospitals today that they should not count on the state for ''any big bailouts'' and instead should act to reduce costs.

title: Florida Grandfather Charged Under a New Child-Gun Law
description: A man whose 8-year-old granddaughter shot herself in the thumb may be the first person charged under a new Florida law intended to keep loaded guns out of children's hands, the authorities said today.

title: Pilots to Continue Strike Benefits at Eastern
description: The Air Line Pilots Association announced yesterday that its membership had voted to continue paying strike benefits to Eastern Airlines pilots, making it likely that the seven-month strike against Eastern will continue for weeks, or even months.

title: Court Rules Agency Can Bar Funds for Abortion Backers
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the right of the Agency for International Development to deny financial aid to private groups supporting abortions in foreign countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Dow Jones & Company misstated the performance of the company's business publications in the third quarter of the year. That division of the company reported a slight gain in operating income compared with the third quarter of 1988, not a sharp drop. The article also misstated the quarter in which Dow Jones reported one-time gains; those gains were in the third quarter of last year, not the current year.

title: Manson Is Suspended
description: Dave Manson, a defenseman for the Blackhawks, was suspended on Monday by the N.H.L. for three games for demeaning an official during a game against the Rangers on Sunday in Chicago. After Chris Nilan of New York poked Alain Chevrier, the Chicago goalie, in the mask with his stick in the third period, Manson rushed toward Nilan and pushed aside Ron Asselstine, a linesman.

title: U.S. SAYS LEADERS OF PANAMA REVOLT WERE IN DISARRAY
description: To head off expected criticism from Panamanian rebels who have just arrived in Miami, the Pentagon sought today to portray the leaders of the failed coup as hopelessly divided over what to do with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega when he was in their custody.

title: What's in a Name? Just Ask the Hungarians
description: Attila Agh, until last weekend a leading ''reform Communist,'' was asked today what party members should be called now that their organization has become the Socialist Party. ''Radical Socialists,'' he replied. For the first time in a Communist country, a ruling party has formally abandoned Communism.

title: The Pop Life
description: Ronstadt's Dreams

title: Storm-Delayed Election Puts Mayor in Runoff
description: Mayor Sue Myrick today swamped her opponent in a Republican primary that was delayed two weeks by Hurricane Hugo. Ms. Myrick's victory sets the stage for a Nov. 7 battle with Craig Madans, a Democrat, to lead North Carolina's largest city.

title: Soybean Meal to Soviets
description: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 150,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal to the Soviet Union for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. The latest sales increased the purchases of United States soybean meal by Moscow to 250,000 tons for 1989-90. Since the new delivery year began on Oct. 1, the Soviet Union has also bought 3.7 million tons of corn under the agreement.

title: McDonnell Douglas Bypasses New Engine
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it would introduce versions of its short- to medium-range commercial airliners next year that will be powered by traditional jet engines rather than a new technology the company has been considering.

title: Paula M. Gilpatric, 55 A Real-Estate Broker
description: Paula Melhado Gilpatric, a real-estate broker, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 55 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M.

title: A Serious Rivalry Now
description: In nine exhibition games last spring, Oakland beat San Francisco eight times. But the World Series is another ball game. Page D29.

title: Eating Well
description: NUTRITION information is like mercury: it slips through your fingers whenever you try to capture it. First the experts tell you to lower your cholesterol; then others question that wisdom. Next they say polyunsaturated fat should be substituted for saturated fat; then they change their minds. Use monounsaturated fat instead, they say, and it is all right to eat a little saturated fat.

title: A's Prowess Leaves Giants Unawed
description: They would have to deal with the subject soon enough, so Monday seemed like the right time. Even in the midst of their playoff celebration, the San Francisco Giants could not avoid talk about the Oakland Athletics, the team from across the bay and now their World Series opponent.

title: Texas Sheriff Goes on Trial In a Kidnapping Conspiracy
description: About 20 people wearing blue ribbons stood outside court in support of two law-enforcement officers today as the officers went on trial on charges of plotting to kidnap and torture a suspected drug dealer.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: A standard criticism of the public school system is that, as a monopoly, it treats its customers - parents and their children - as captives. The remedy? Competition, a growing number of educators and politicians say. Letting parents choose their children's schools. This was one of President Bush's key proposals at the recent education summit.

title: Mary A. Rice, 78, Dies; Fashion Show Producer
description: Mary Alice Rice, a retired producer of fashion shows and former showgirl, died Monday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N,J., after a long illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Summit.

title: More Companies to Phase Out Peril to Ozone
description: More large companies have agreed to eliminate ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons and halon in their worldwide operations, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: G.E. Curbs Lifted
description: The General Electric Company's aerospace operations in Syracuse resumed shipping products to the Navy and Air Force after Defense Department officials determined that the company had corrected serious procedural and quality control problems. Sanctions were imposed in February because the company was found to be mixing production on contracts for both the United States military and foreign governments, whose specifications were less stringent.

title: Servers Spurring an Evolution in Computing
description: A new class of specialized computers is becoming the next area of opportunity in the computer business, and a host of new companies are staking their claims to it.

title: KEY RATES
K Mart Plans Expansion
description: The K Mart Corporation outlined a $1.3 billion expansion plan today intended to double sales and profits at the second-largest United States retailer and burnish its image.

title: Ex-Giant Fan Hopes to Beat Them
description: Long before there were any Oakland Athletics or a Bay Area Rapid Transit, Dave Stewart was a San Francisco Giants fan. And that was plenty good for a young man from the hard-times section of Oakland.

title: People
description: * Katherine Chiles has been promoted to senior vice president, management director of the integrated communications group of FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: Veryfine Picks Mullen Agency
description: Veryfine Products Inc., turned its back on Manhattan yesterday, awarding its $10 million account to Mullen Inc., a small agency that is its neighbor in Massachusetts.
