title: Hong Kong Leader Tries to Tone Down Criticism of Beijing
description: With Hong Kong's relationship to China growing steadily worse, the colony's governor gave an important policy address today and carefully avoided provoking Beijing.

title: New Spark For Classic Cigarette Lighters
description: REPAIRING old Ronsons, Dunhills, Duponts and Zippos is a dying art. Many cigarette lighter companies have gone out of business, and some who are still around do not fix old models, encouraging customers to buy new ones instead. Luckily, there are a few independent repair shops that specialize in the task.

description: SCREWS can be troublesome to use if they are not selected and installed correctly. Here is a guide for choosing wood screws, the kind most often needed around the house, and basic instructions for installing them neatly and effectively.

Malpractice Costs Cut Ranks of Obstetricians
description: The Institute of Medicine said today that a two-year study found that frequent malpractice lawsuits and sharply rising insurance premiums are leading some doctors to stop delivering babies, leaving poor women with only limited obstetrical care.

title: Furor Over Panama: It's Helms vs. White House
description: As the debate over Panama policy continues in the capital, President Bush and his aides still seem puzzled over how to manage their basic political problem: a fierce disagreement between the White House and Senator Jesse Helms. Mr. Helms, a North

Student Loan Marketing Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Utility Refund Bill Loses
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today defeated a bill that could have been worth an average of $223 per household for customers of power, gas and telephone companies.

title: Photo Control Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
80 Youths Slain in Sri Lanka; Officials Suspect Vigilantes
description: The bound bodies of 80 Sinhalese youths, all with gunshot wounds and some burned, were found along a southern road today, the authorities said.

title: American Medical May Get New Bids
description: American Medical International Inc., whose directors have accepted a $1.79 billion offer for the hospital concern, said it had been approached by two parties who have indicated that they might make higher bids for the Beverly Hills, Calif., company.

title: Champions of Choice
description: When the Supreme Court upheld Missouri's restrictions on abortion this summer, the right-to-life movement cheered a major victory. Right-to-lifers saw the decision as the first step toward abolishing any legally protected right to end a pregnancy. Events this week in Florida and in Washington suggest that the cheering was premature.

title: New England Bank Discussing Sale
description: The Bank of New England Corporation, said it would discuss selling part of its leasing business to the Bank of Tokyo. The bank said it had agreed to negotiate for a short period with the Bank of Tokyo.

title: Federal Express Sets Offering
description: The Federal Express Corporation is offering $100 million in sinking fund debentures due 2019 through Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Town & Country reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income Figures for the latest quarter and 6 months included results of L.G. Balfour Co., acquired on Nov. 4, 1988, and Feature Enterprises Inc., acquired on Dec. 6, 1988.

title: Reviews/Music; Perle's 'Windows of Order' Has Premiere
description: When a new musical score is introduced to an audience, the accompanying pieces on the program are generally chosen without much concern for historical context. The audience is seldom encouraged to hear connections between the new piece and anything composed before it. The Juilliard String Quartet's program on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard Theater may or may not have been so casually planned, but it managed to set off interesting resonances.

title: Rangers Fend Off the Flames in Home Opener
description: The game may, by season's end, prove to have been of limited value and consequence. But for a night - an evening of unequivocal accomplishment and rarely equaled applause for the Rangers - it was a small treasure.

title: Bio-Logic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Talman Home Federal S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brenco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Natural But More Durable
description: IN the early 80's, Michele Oka Doner lived in a house in Michigan with three fireplaces. ''When I was lazy and sitting in front of one of the fireplaces, I used wood branches instead of iron fire tools to poke the fire,'' said Ms. Doner, a sculptor and furniture designer in Manhattan.

title: Negotiations Break Off In City Opera Strike
description: A last-minute negotiating session between the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra broke off Tuesday night without hint of a resolution of their differences, both sides reported yesterday. No new bargaining sessions are scheduled.

title: Microcom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Police Halt Protest in Taiwan
description: About 2,000 police officers drove demonstrators away from a jail with clubs and water cannons early today and at least 28 people were reported injured. The protesters demanded the release of a dissident publisher. Demonstrations outside the Tucheng jail in a Taipei suburb began on Tuesday, Taiwan's National Day, when 10,000 people gathered to demand the immediate release of the publisher, Hsu Hsin Liang..

title: Delay of at Least 5 Days Seen for Shuttle Mission
description: Technicians began removing a faulty engine control unit from the space shuttle Atlantis today as officials predicted that the craft would be launched no earlier than next Tuesday.

title: USLife Income Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income represented net assets; per share, assets per share. First quarter Sept. 30 net investment income was $1,214,357, or 23 cents a share, compared with $1,229,091, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. In the latest quarter, net realized losses totaled $519,055, compared with year-ago net realized gains of $83,950, or 2 cents a share. At Sept. 30, unrealized losses on investments were $815,142, or 10 cents a share, compared with $121,001, or 3 cents a share a year earlier.

title: Plasti-Line Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
N.F.L. Hits Gridlock, Calls for Adjournment
description: The National Football League owners adjourned their meeting here tonight, unable to elect a new commissioner after nearly 20 hours of debate over the past two days. The owners will meet again Oct. 24-25 in Cleveland in another attempt to name a successor to Pete Rozelle.

title: JRM Holdings Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said its latest year included a loss from discontinued operations of $549,574, compared with a loss of $236,630 from discontinued operations for previous year.

title: Q&A
description: Cedar vs. Vinyl Q.Our house was built in 1950 and is in a rural setting. We are considering replacing the cedar shingles on the exterior with vinyl siding because we have been told that vinyl offers better insulation and protection from insects, and that it requires very little maintenance. We are reluctant, however, to replace the shingles because they seem to suit the house. The wood is beginning to rot in a few places and we are concerned that the shingles will not adequately protect the house in the future. What suggestions can you offer? A.Vinyl siding does not offer any additional insulation, although it may offer added resistance to infiltration of cold air. And, of course, vinyl requires little or no maintenance. Shingles do not protect the house; they are mainly cosmetic. The building paper or felt under the shingles, and the sheathing under this, are what protect the house from weather.

title: Turner System Debt Securities
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. yesterday priced $750 million in debt securities and $550 million in debentures through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter and $200 million in liquid yield option notes through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.

title: United Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3.7 million for the quarter and $1.7 million for the 9 months.

title: Two Nations Pledge to Clean Up Great Lakes
description: William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and Canadian health officials said today that the Great Lakes are facing ''a critical situation'' as a result of toxic contamination and the destruction of wildlife habitat.

title: Norwegian Wins Nobel For His Work in Economics
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded today to an obscure Norwegian professor whose pioneering work in methods for testing economic theories helped pave the way for modern economic forecasting.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Designers Worry About Self-Image
description: IN an era in which stylish mass-produced images are more pervasive than ever, the people responsible for them - art directors, illustrators, typographers and other graphic designers - are doing some soul-searching about their own self-image.

title: Stricter Rules Urged for Cruise Ships
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, pressing a campaign to more closely regulate cruise ships, today called for extensive changes in safety standards aboard vessels operating from United States ports.

title: Walton Sends O'Brien To Bench
description: Kyle Mackey, whose National Football League career consists of three starts in strike games and one incomplete pass two Sundays ago, today became the Jets' quarterback as Coach Joe Walton sent a stunned Ken O'Brien to the bench.

title: Football's Headless Horsemen
description: rrAmong football's the most enduring nicknames in sports is The Four Horsemen of Notre Dame. But with the National Football League still without a new commissioner, its 28 club owners deserve to be dubbed The Headless Horsemen.

title: New Baseball League Likely to Wait Until 1991
description: Founders and owners of teams in a proposed new baseball league met in New York yesterday and apparently decided to begin play in 1991. The owners also decided to soon begin signing players to future contracts.

title: Los Angeles Times Design
description: In the most radical redesign in its recent history, The Los Angeles Times appeared today with a new format intended to make the paper more accessible to readers.

title: The Ruckus at Rockefeller
description: Rockefeller University, in New York City, is in turmoil. The board of trustees has offered the presidency to David Baltimore of M.I.T. Some faculty members are concerned about his handling of a disputed scientific experiment that is still being investigated by the National Institutes of Health and a House subcommittee headed by Representative John Dingell. But some facts are already plain.

title: CalFed Plans Sale Of Insurance Unit
description: CalFed Inc. agreed to sell its British property-casualty insurance business to an affiliate of John Head & Partners, a New York merchant banking firm, for about $100 million. The sale of the Anglo American Insurance Company is part of CalFed's strategy to sell its less profitable operations. CalFed has already sold a number of insurance businesses and its $125 million credit-card portfolio.

title: Right and Wrong on Student Ignorance
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities reports appalling ignorance among college students about ''basic landmarks of history and thought.'' A survey of 700 college seniors conducted in the spring found that 25 percent did not know that Christopher Columbus came to America before 1500. And more than 40 percent did not know when the Civil War was fought.

title: U.N. Unable to Verify Abuses by Swapo
description: United Nations investigators said today that they had been unable to verify accusations that Namibian guerrillas imprisoned, tortured and killed hundreds from their own ranks between 1977 and 1989.

title: Nugget Suitors, Set Back, Are Remaining in Pursuit
description: Although Sidney Schlenker, the owner of the Denver Nuggets, said Tuesday that he had called off the proposed sale of his team to two investors who would have become the first black owners of a major sports franchise, there were indications yesterday that the transaction might still be alive.

title: Teacher Accused of Past Anti-Semitism Quits Dinkins Camp
description: A black community organizer has withdrawn from David N. Dinkins's New York City mayoral campaign after the Anti-Defamation League of the B'nai B'rith called on him to disavow anti-Semitic comments and articles attributed to him 20 years ago.

title: Blushing John Is Favored
description: Blushing John, the Pimlico Special and Hollywood Gold Cup winner, was made the even-money morning-line favorite as a field of eight was drawn yesterday for the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup tomorrow night at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: U.S. Issues Sag on Supply Fears
description: Treasury note and bond prices sagged in lackluster trading yesterday as worries about placing a flood of forthcoming new issues prompted dealers to sell securities.

title: Mister Donut Bids
description: The International Multifoods Corp. said that it had been approached about selling its Mister Donut franchising business and that it was soliciting other offers for the chain. Mister Donut, the second-largest doughnut chain in North America after Dunkin' Donuts Inc., has 573 shops. Its estimated sales for this year are $156 million.

title: EAST GERMANS CALL FOR SELF-SCRUTINY ON REFUGEE EXODUS
description: After an unusually long session, the ruling East German Politburo said today that there was a need ''to discuss all basic questions of our society'' and to learn the reasons that sent nearly 50,000 East Germans fleeing to the West.

title: A Sculpture of Shadows and a Roof With a View
description: TWELVE vignettes by New York designers will be on view at the Great American Salvage Company, which sells architectural antiques at 34 Cooper Square (near Third Avenue and Sixth Street).

title: Coca-Cola Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the results included a non-recurring, after-tax gain of about $36 million, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of the company's bottled water business in the third quarter.

title: Kemp Suggests Pierce Testify And Adds, 'I Think He Will'
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp suggested today that his predecessor, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., should break his silence and testify before Congress about allegations of political favoritism that Mr. Kemp said had ''tragically'' stained Mr. Pierce's reputation.

title: Spurs Sign Elliott To 5-Year Contract
description: Saying he was ''excited to get it over with,'' Sean Elliott, San Antonio's first-round draft pick in June, signed a five-year contract, reportedly worth $9 million, with the Spurs yesterday. Elliott, the No. 3 draft choice in the National Basketball Association, has made publicity appearances and attended team meetings, but the 6-foot-8-inch forward from the University of Arizona has yet to work out with the team.(AP)

title: Sounds Around Town
description: New Cabaret Artist

title: Self-Defense Is Argued In Brooklyn Bias Case
description: The lawyer for a Brooklyn teen-ager accused of being the instigator of an assault on two Jewish students told a judge yesterday that his client had ''fought back'' after he had been attacked by the students.

title: Records Show Unexplained Payments by Dinkins Campaign
description: David N. Dinkins's campaign has failed to provide adequate documentation for a number of expenses, including three payments totaling $9,500 for a ''get out the vote'' drive led by a community organizer, Robert (Sonny) Carson, New York City campaign finance records show.

title: A Gain for Bid to Put Pros on Olympic Team
description: The first administrative step toward the inclusion of National Basketball Association players on the 1992 United States Olympic team was taken today when the league joined the organization that oversees the national program in the sport.

title: A's Drills Have Air Of Spring
description: On the fourth day between the end of the American League playoff and the start of the World Series, the Oakland Athletics spent another afternoon as if it were spring training in Arizona.

description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. promoted Norma J. Arnold and Steven W. Alesio to senior vice presidents.

title: Dr. Philip G. Colin, 86, Chemical Engineer
description: Dr. Philip G. Colin, a chemical engineer who developed industrial processes for many drugs, died of a heart attack on Oct. 5 at his home in San Diego. He was 86 years old.

title: Mr. de Klerk Earns an Indulgence
description: South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, took two strides this week in pursuit of his ''mandate for change.'' By releasing eight prominent political prisoners and holding ''talks about talks'' with three black leaders of the anti-apartheid movement, he seemed to signal that he was serious about negotiating an end to whites-only rule and finding a formula for enfranchising blacks.

title: 6th Indicted in Hawkins Death
description: A sixth white defendant, Charles Stressler, was indicted yesterday for murder in connection with what the police have described as the racially motivated slaying of a black teen-ager on Aug. 23 in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. The victim, Yusuf K. Hawkins, 16 years old, was fatally shot after he and some friends went to the largely white neighborhood to look at a used car that was for sale. Mr. Stressler's lawyer, Michael A. Santangelo, said his client was ''not guilty of murdering anyone.''

title: IMC Fertilizer Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Zenith Introduces 4 New Computers
description: Zenith Data Systems, the soon-to-be-sold computer division of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, introduced four new personal computers, including the first battery-powered laptop model based on the powerful Intel 80386SX microprocessor. Zenith, the world's largest seller of battery-powered laptop computers, said the new Supersport SX laptop could operate for more than three hours on the battery before it needed recharging.

title: Breeders' Cup Candidates Making Their Moves
description: Easy Goer and Sunday Silence will not race again before their showdown for Horse-of-the-Year honors in the Breeders' Cup Classic at Gulfstream on Nov. 4.

title: Frederick Bush 3d, 85, Former Oil Executive
description: Frederick A. Bush 3d, an oil executive and consultant, died Monday of leukemia at the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center in Greenwich, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: FOREIGN SERVICE TO HIRE THE BLIND
description: In a policy reversal, the State Department announced today that blind people may serve as Foreign Service officers.

title: 7-Year Fannie Mae Offering Is Priced With 8.474% Yield
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association took advantage of lower interest rates yesterday and priced a $900 million debenture issue in a nonscheduled offering through its regular selling group.

title: Silicon Graphics To Buy Back Stock
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. agreed to repurchase 2,360,000 common shares held by the Control Data Corporation. The shares will be bought for $22.60 each, below the recent market price, for a total of $53.3 million. The transaction will cut Control Data's holdings in Silicon Graphics to 702,750 shares, or just under 5 percent of the outstanding stock.

How, and Why, the Dalai Lama Won the Peace Prize
description: People close to the Nobel Peace Prize selection process say that the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader, gained the advantage over other candidates, including President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, largely because of the brutal suppression of the democracy movement in China and the international outrage that followed.

title: With Bird Walking Normally, Celtics Prepare to Walk Tall
description: When the Boston Celtics' two-hour practice ended this morning, Larry Bird still wanted more work. So he did some extra running on the sidelines with a teammate, Ed Pinckney.

title: Mellon Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $29 million on the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss and the quarter reflected a one-time restructuring expense incurred in connection with Mellon's asset disposition and equity capitalization program announced in July 1988 and completed in June 1989.

title: Confident Vanbiesbrouck Is Rolling
description: Sergei Makarov, perhaps the premier right wing in the world, was in alone against John Vanbiesbrouck. Less than a minute remained in the game, less than a stride separated Makarov from the puck, and so Terry Crisp thought it something less than a preposterous notion to assume a goal would be scored.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Beck Advances in Match Play: Chip Beck trounced Aki Ohmachi of Japan, 8 and 6, yesterday to advance to the second round of the world match-play championship at Virginia Water, England. Beck was the only one of three Americans to win opening-day matches of 36 holes over the 6,945-yard, par-72 Wentworth Golf Club course. Scott Hoch, runner-up to Nick Faldo in the Masters, was eliminated by Jose-Maria Olazabal of Spain, 4 and 2. And Mike Reid lost to Ronan Rafferty of Northern Ireland, 3 and 2. (AP) TENNIS Shriver Upset in Moscow: Pam Shriver's struggles continued yesterday when she was upset by Julie Halard of France in the second round of the first professional tennis tournament held in the Soviet Union. Shriver, seeded No. 1, hasn't won a singles title all year and lost, 6-2, 3-6, 6-0, in the $100,000 event in Moscow. In another match, Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, seeded second, rolled over Natalie Herreman of France, 6-1, 6-3.(AP) Lendl Hits 14 Aces to Advance: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, slammed 14 aces en route to a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Leif Shiras of the United States in the second round of the Australian indoor championships yesterday in Sydney.(AP) McEnroe and Connors Have Tough Victories: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors struggled yesterday but advanced to the quarterfinals of the Toulouse Grand Prix tournament in France. Connors, seeded second, beat Udo Riglewski of West Germany, 2-6, 6-2, 7-6. McEnroe, seeded first, beat Ramesh Krishnan of India, 7-6, 6-3. (AP) HOCKEY Flyers 4, Nordiques 2: Rick Tocchet scored a power-play goal in a three-goal first period in Philadelphia as the Flyers beat Quebec last night. (AP) Red Wings 5, Jets 4: Rick Zombo, a defenseman, assisted on one goal and scored another in a 12-second span last night as Detroit rode a four-goal second period to victory over Winnipeg in Detroit's home opener.(AP) North Stars 3, Blues 0: Mike Modano, a rookie, scored his fourth goal in four games and Jon Casey made 24 saves for his second career shutout as Minnesota remained unbeaten by defeating visiting St. Louis.(AP) Blackhawks 9, Maple Leafs 6: Denis Savard's second goal of the game on a breakaway broke a 5-5 third-period tie and Doug Wilson had two goals and two assists, lifting Chicago to a wild victory over visiting Toronto. Savard's effort overshadowed Wendel Clark's third career hat trick and a goal and three assists from Gary Leeman for the Maple Leafs.(AP)

title: Ross Reid, 72, Lawyer and Executive, Dies
description: Ross Reid, a lawyer and business executive, died on Monday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Msgr. Arthur F. Bukowski, Educator, 83
description: Msgr. Arthur Francis Bukowski, president of Aquinas College here for 32 years, died Tuesday of heart disease. He was 83 years old.

title: Not Everybody Wants to Sign a Living Will; Rights of New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
J. Rupert Picott Dies; Teacher Advocate, 77
description: J. Rupert Picott, an educator and early civil rights leader, died of prostate cancer Wednesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 77 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Katharine Graham Writing Her Memoirs
description: Katharine Graham, chairman and chief executive officer of The Washington Post, is writing her memoirs, which will be published by Alfred A. Knopf Inc. The announcement was made yesterday by Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Random House Inc., of which Knopf is an imprint.

title: Luby's Cafeterias Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Courter AIDS Proposal Faulted; He Would Bar Infected Teachers
description: Representative Jim Courter, the Republican candidate for governor, found himself under criticism today for his proposal in the gubernatorial debate on Wednesday to remove teachers and children infected with the AIDS virus from contact with uninfected children in the classroom.

title: A Blend Of Rhythms, Urban And Exotic
description: Tonight's bill of Zahar and Carbon, two of the downtown scene's best bands, is a typical evening at the Knitting Factory, the sort of night that makes out-of-town music fans think, if momentarily, about moving to New York. It's typical not just because of the level of musicianship, but because of the emphasis on rhythm -on the joy, pleasure and sheer grinding noise of it. Neither band is big on melodies: textures, and their relationship to the almighty cathartic groove, are what both bands are about. But this emphasis on rhythm reflects the always growing influence of ethnic music among experimentalists - the continued looking away from Europe for source material. And it also represents what the wrangling experimentalists are doing with pop music, where rhythm plays a supreme role.

title: Wolverine World Wide Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
British Aerospace
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had bought 5.72 million shares of Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., raising its holding in the troubled British military-electronics company to 1.7 percent. On Tuesday, British Aerospace and Thomson-CSF of France said they were working on a possible rescue of Ferranti and considering the possibility of making a bid. Ferranti is seeking partners after discovering contract frauds that the company said would cost it $:185 million, or about $287.5 million.

title: NBC Sought MGM/UA Deal Stake
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had expressed an interest in becoming an equity investor in an Australian entertainment concern's proposed buyout of the MGM/UA Communications Company.

title: California Changes Phone-Rate Structure
description: In a move watched closely by regulators in other states, the California Public Utilities Commission today approved a different way of setting rates for the state's two largest local telephone companies. The change is intended to provide freer competition in the marketplace.

title: Fastenal Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Senior Service Names A New Chief Executive
description: The Senior Service Corporation, a young company that provides publishing services, home health care products and day-care centers for older Americans, has named Donald L. Luke as president and chief executive.

title: John Hanson Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Restaurants
description: The Meridien hotel chain pioneered the consulting-celebrity-chef strategy in the early 1980's, winging in three-star French chefs like Alain Chapel, Paul Bocuse and Jacques Maximin to oversee its kitchens around the United States. At Maurice in New York's Hotel Parker Meridien, the imported luminary was Alain Senderens of Lucas-Carton in Paris, followed early this year by Marc Haeberlin of the renowned Auberge de l'Ill in Alsace. As a public-relations strategy, the tactic has succeeded; on a culinary level, though, the results have been mixed.

title: Barrett Bows Out
description: J. Patrick Barrett, who failed to get any backing from National Football League owners this week in the voting for commissioner, withdrew his name yesterday from the list of four being considered for the job. Barrett, chairman of the New York State Republican Committee, said it was apparent that the process of selecting a successor to Pete Rozelle would be a protracted one and that he could not keep his life ''on hold'' any longer.(AP)

title: NBD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed June 30.

title: 'Mistake in Judgment' by Garcia Is Conceded
description: In his final remarks to the jury in the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia, the chief defense lawyer conceded yesterday that Mr. Garcia ''made a mistake in judgment'' by borrowing $20,000 from a Wedtech executive and then trying to conceal the loan.

title: Inspectors Tripping Up Truck Drivers
description: Bill Lemasters was driving a tractor-trailer south on Van Emburgh Avenue, a narrow country road used by truckers to avoid a weigh station and congestion on nearby Route 17, when he was stopped by township police officers.

title: Leslie S. Pearl, Executive, 87
description: Leslie S. Pearl, a retired advertising executive, died Tuesday after a long illness at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He ws 87 years old and also lived in Blue Hill, Me.

title: Guerrilla Fighting in Sahara
description: Polisario guerrillas killed 190 Moroccans and wounded 150 in fighting on Wednesday in the Western Sahara, a Polisario military communique issued in Algiers said today. The guerrillas, who are fighting Morocco for independence of Western Sahara, captured six Moroccan bases and observation posts in the Hauza region in the northern Sahara, it added.

title: Lockheed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $1 million from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $177 million, or $2.99 a share, for the quarter and $187 million, or $3.10 a share, for the 9 months. The loss in the latest third quarter reflected charges in that period against earnings of $165 million, which the company disclosed last week.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 American officials in Panama will get new guidelines on how to communicate effectively with coup plotters, the White House said. The move amounts to an invitation to overthrow General Noriega. Page A1 Panamanian tells of goal of rebels A8 A power shift in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan occurred last month when a nationalist movement gained its legalization and a constitutional right to defy federal authority in an agreement with the Communist Party. A1 Call for dialogue raises doubts in East Germany A6 Hardline Hungarian Communists announced that they were forming a Communist Party in rejection of the governing party's decision to convert to democratic socialism. A6 Lebanon's warring religious factions appeared to be close to an agreement that would give Muslims a significantly greater role in the country's national affairs. A1 Teheran journal: The return of fashion A4 The contents of the universe are distinguished by no more than three fundamental types of matter, scientists have found. The discovery has far-reaching implications for physics, astronomy and cosmology. A1 Nobel Prizes were awarded in chemistry and physics to four Americans and one West German. Their work involved cellular chemistry, an atomic clock and the isolation of atoms and subatomic particles. A10 How, and why, the Dalai Lama won the Nobel Peace Prize A10 The Swede convicted of the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme was ordered released after an appeals court overturned his conviction. The court found the evidence against him was inadequate. A3 The Pope's Mass ended in a melee in East Timor as anti-Government demonstrators brawled with police officers. In the Mass, the Pope admonished Indonesia to respect human rights in the province. A3 Pinball scandal erupts in Japan A12 Saatchi to get new chief D1 State Dept., in reversal, to hire blind Foreign Service officers A9 Upbeat end to U.N. talks A8 National A14-21 The practice and costs of medicine could go through a fundamental change under a measure that is heading for final Congressional approval. It involves the alteration of Medicare's payment system. A1 The political balance on abortion has shifted, advocates on both sides agree, following actions in Congress and the Florida Legislature this week against abortion restrictions. A1 Rape and incest: just 1% of all abortions A17 Democrats seem to have the votes to block a capital gains tax cut in the deficit-reduction package under consideration in the Senate. But Republicans say they will pursue other ways of getting a vote on the cut. A1 Bill to ban flag desecration passes House A18 Chief Justice again urges Senate action on death penalty plan A21 Jack Kemp issued a harsh critique of the Housing Department under his predecessor, Samuel Pierce, and suggested that Mr. Pierce testify before Congress about allegations of political favoritism. A18 The ex-chief of staff of the panel that regulates the nuclear industry said that he kept secret for seven months charges of safety problems at a plant. He is the President's choice to head a weapons complex. A17 Part of a Federal clean-air measure would not be good for California, officials there said. The clause they fear would pre-empt state control of off-road pollution sources like bulldozers and lawn mowers. A19 South Pole ozone at lowest level, experts say A19 Washington at Work: Mstislav Rostropovich, the dynamic and politically astute conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra, is helping the nation's capital become its cultural center. A16 A book by an ex-civil rights leader about his life has been criticized by civil rights leaders and black officials, while also resurrecting old rifts among the followers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King. A14 Bishops urge chastity to curb spread of AIDS A14 Engine crack existed before jet crash, investigators say A17 AMR offer reported D1 Ex-Congressman to head Amex D1 Middlesex journal: Gold bugs are biting A14 Regional B1-5 New York City's homicides for the first seven months of this year -1,019 - are just below last year's record pace, the police said. Between Wednesday night and dawn yesterday, 11 people were slain. A1 A plan to test correction officers in New York City's prisons for drug use was narrowly upheld by a New York appeals court. B1 Fatal accidents involving trucks have been reduced in Bergen Country, N.J., under a program that pays overtime to the local police to inspect trucks. The program is being expanded to nine other counties. B4 Rudolph Giuliani's style while campaigning on the streets has become more relaxed and self-assured, even during lonely times in unsympathetic territory. B1 Bush praises Giuliani B2 Woody Allen praises Dinkins, defends Mason B2 Records show unexplained payments by Dinkins campaign B2 Courter attacked on proposal to ban AIDS virus in school B4 A Brooklyn teen-ager ''fought back'' in self-defense against several Jewish college students, and was not an instigator of the attack, his lawyer said. The judge in the case set bail at $50,000. B3 F.B.I. admits bid to disrupt lawyer group B1 Lawyer concedes Garcia made a ''mistake in judgment'' B1 Commission proposes 11.5% rise in cab fares B3 B3

title: How to Get Those Bright Colors on Film
description: Photographing the spectacular colors of autumn requires no secret techniques, only a modicum of knowledge about cameras and films. Even a simple camera that does all the focusing and exposure calculations for you is sufficient, provided its idea of the perfect picture coincides with yours. And off-the-shelf amateur films are fully capable of rendering all the bright hues and subtle shades of fall, although some do it better than others.

title: National Community Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Art; Work Produced or Shown In Era of French Revolution
description: New York this year has done very well by the bicentennial of the French Revolution. At the New York Public Library and, later, at the Pierpont Morgan Library, there was much to enjoy and coincidentally much to learn. And now there has opened at Colnaghi an exhibition called ''1789: French Art During the Revolution'' that functions as an ideal pendant to those earlier manifestations.

title: Portsmouth Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter results included securities gain, after taxes, of about $2,240,000, or 56 cents per share. The year-ago 9 months' per share earnings and shares outstanding were not available because the company went public in February 1988.

title: Teleflex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Victory Is Upheld
description: The British Boxing Board of Control, meeting in London yesterday, ruled that Tony Wilson could keep his victory over Steve McCarthy on his record, even though Wilson's mother landed the winning blows with her high-heeled shoe in a light-heavyweight bout in Southampton, England, Sept. 21.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS CLOSER CONTACTS IN A PANAMA COUP
description: The White House plans to issue specific guidelines to American military, intelligence and diplomatic officials in Panama so they can provide clearer and more rapid communication with potential coup plotters, a senior official said today.

title: Oilers Look for Luck On the Road to Chicago
description: Here go the Houston Oilers on the road again. And when the Oilers leave the Astrodome, they usually finish bone dry.

title: C-Cor Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Palme Conviction Upset; Drifter Is Freed
description: A seven-member Swedish appeals court today unanimously overturned the conviction of the 42-year-old drifter and drug addict who had been found guilty of the 1986 murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme, and ordered him to be released immediately.

title: When Sewell Replaced Ray Chapman
description: rrOn the eve of the World Series, Joe Sewell vividly remembers the first one he ever saw, 69 years ago. He remembers it so well because he played in it. Joe Sewell is the last living member of the 1920 Cleveland Indians team, which beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in seven games in the Series. And it is a curious slice of history that in the fifth game he actually assisted in the only unassisted triple play in a World Series game.

title: Laclede Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in October 1988.

title: Celanese Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Burlington Resources Inc., Seattle, said it would seek buyers for the real estate properties held by its Glacier Park Co. subsidiary, which it said are worth about $450 million.

title: An Ungrand Total
description: Among other significant recent events in Poland, the population of its prisons has fallen from about 116,000 in April 1986 to about 58,000 on July 31, 1989. It seems worth noting that:

title: Electrosound Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $142,000, or 5 cents a share and also included is a gain of $418,000 on sale of commercial duplicating equipment manufacturing operations. c-Net loss and reflects pro-rata share of losses of compact disc joint venture of $1,779,000.

title: No Tolerance for Hate
description: Hateful words like ''shvartzer'' and ''nigger'' and ''kike'' are still unacceptable and objectionable to most New Yorkers. But recent reminders that such ugliness has its adherents reinforces a troubling reality about New York: Though blessed with a rich ethnicity, the city is also threatened by deep ethnic and racial animosities. The way New Yorkers think, and sometimes talk, about each other is becoming the dirty subterranean theme of the political season. It demands urgent attention by those who would be mayor of a great, diverse city.

title: Louisiana Begins to Slip Its Legal Ties to France
description: LEAD: Louisiana, the only state whose laws are rooted in the Napoleonic Code, has begun distancing itself from its French legal heritage, led by those who believe the Code's anachronisms are impeding the state's ability to compete economically with other states.

title: Huzzahs for Armani's Soft and Slithery Collection
description: Fashion is moving in a softer, gentler direction, and Giorgio Armani has reached the finish line first. Skipping all the intermediary steps, he threw away shoulder pads, all kinds of inner construction and extraneous details like collars and made clothes that slither over the body in gossamer fabrics. It was a quantum leap for a major tailor, and it will have a radical effect on how women dress.

title: Undaunted, Giuliani Swims Upstream
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani smiled stiffly at a subway stop in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn the other day, his arms folded across his waist, waiting for someone to shake his hand. Deep in the liberal Democratic turf of David N. Dinkins, the Republican mayoral nominee was standing more or less alone.

title: Edward G. Schumacher, Merchant Mariner, 66
description: Edward G. Schumacher, a former merchant seaman who helped win veteran status for merchant mariners who served in World War II, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Dale City, Va. He was 66 years old.

title: Willamette Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Editor Resigns Post at U.S. News
description: Roger Rosenblatt, the editor of U.S. News and World Report for the last 14 months who has continued an active writing career, resigned yesterday. In his letter of resignation to the chairman and editor in chief, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, who had wanted him to take a more active management role, he cited commuting difficulties.

title: Molex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Weekend; Those Eccentric and Lovable English
description: The 19th season of ''Masterpiece Theater'' begins Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 with a 90-minute drama entitled ''And a Nightingale Sang.'' With mini-series scarce in Britain these days, especially those of the lavish ''Jewel in the Crown'' variety, shorter productions will be presented more frequently on this prestigious imports showcase.

title: Top NATO Civilian Sees Role For Both Alliances in 1990's
description: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today that he believed the Western alliance and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact would continue to exist for at least a decade more because they could both be useful in a time of dramatic change.

title: Woody Allen Supports Dinkins . . . and Mason
description: Woody Allen came last night to praise David N. Dinkins at a chic fund raiser but ended up galling him by saying that Jackie Mason was ''just joking'' when he made charged remarks about blacks and Jews in the New York City mayoral campaign.

title: U.S.-Soviet Drug Plan
description: Officials of the United States and Soviet Olympic Committees today completed the fine-tuning of their bilateral agreeement to test each other's athletes for drugs, and said testing would start in 1990.

title: Glatfelter (P.H.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canter Retiring After 43 Years
description: Stanley D. Canter, whose prolific career included stints as an agency executive and marketing consultant, announced his retirement yesterday after 43 years in the advertising business. Mr. Canter, 65 years old, is president of Canter, Achenbaum, Associates, a consulting firm he co-founded with Alvin Achenbaum 16 years ago.

title: Hon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $356,000, or 2 cents a share and $1,082,000, or 6 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 9 months results are restated to reflect the sale of the company's prime-mover subsidiary on Dec. 6, 1988.

title: Giants Face Redskins: Physical, Not Fancy
description: The Giants will play the Washington Redskins on Sunday in Giants Stadium, and if you've seen one of their games you've seen them all.

title: ALC Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included writeoffs of $12.3 million for equipment upgrades and business and management restructuring.

title: Review/Film; Huppert as an Abortionist, in Chabrol's 'Story of Women'
description: Isabelle Huppert has an uncanny ability to convey self-interest on the screen, a quality rendered even steelier by the utter indifference with which it is displayed. Pale and fine-boned though she is, Ms. Huppert never looks frail. The same strength of will that can transform her from a mousy, nondescript figure into a vibrant beauty is apparent in the blatant single-mindedness with which some of Ms. Huppert's most memorable characters command what they need. Ruthless pragmatists, they lead wholly unexamined lives, and they stop at nothing.

title: Economic Scene; Another Autumn Of Fiscal Discord
description: WITH the new fiscal year 1990 under way, and the United States operating without a Federal budget, economic battles are raging in Washington from Capitol Hill to the White House to Constitution Avenue.

title: G.E.'s Profits Up 16% On 7% Revenue Rise
description: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 16 percent increase in earnings for the third quarter, based on improvements in its financial services, plastics, locomotive and electrical generating equipment operations.

title: Susan P. Riley, Doctor, Is Wed
description: Dr. Susan Patricia Riley and Thomas James Fleming Jr. were married yesterday by Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in his chambers in New York. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Riley of Eltingville, S.I. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fleming of New York and Westbrook, Conn.

title: Jets Make the Big Switch At Right Time for Mackey
description: Despite the snickering at what appears to be Joe Walton's folly, this may be the right time for the Jets' new quarterback, Kyle Mackey, to make his debut as a starter in a nonstrike game.

title: Aristech Chemical Gets Takeover Bid
description: The Aristech Chemical Corporation said it had received a takeover offer of $25 a share, or a total of about $842 million. It said the Huntsman Holdings Corporation had proposed that its affiliate, the Banstar Corporation, acquire Aristech in a friendly transaction. Aristech said its board would make a response ''at the appropriate time.'' Aristech's shares dropped 62.5 cents today, to $17.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Deadly Night: New York Murders Keep Pace
description: A Baptist minister, a doorman walking home and a printer who planned to be married on Saturday were among 11 people slain in New York City during the 12 hours between sundown Wednesday and the following dawn. The police said it was one of the bloodiest nights the city has seen this year.

title:
About Real Estate;
More Development on Palisades Site
description: LEAD: It has been 18 years since the Palisades Amusement Park in New Jersey closed after its purchase by the Centex Corporation of Dallas, but redevelopment of the 38-acre site atop the Palisades is still going on.

title: Bank of New York Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The Bank of New York said it made a special addition of $600 million to its loan loss allowance in this year's third quarter. The special addition of $600 million also reflected the latest 9 months' earnings.

title: New York City Opera Cancels Rest of Season
description: The New York City Opera, shut down by a musicians' strike since Sept. 13, yesterday canceled the remaining 40 performances of its fall season at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center. The entire fall season, scheduled to run through Nov. 19, comprised 70 performances.

title: Six in Seoul Briefly Occupy The U.S. Envoy's Residence
description: Six intruders armed with firebombs and tear gas briefly occupied part of the residence of the United States Ambassador early today before the police removed them.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Genlyte Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are pro-forma.

title: Corrections
description: On Sept. 23 the obituary of Irving Berlin misstated the number of Academy Awards he won. As a letter from a reader has pointed out, his only Oscar was for the song ''White Christmas'' from the 1942 film ''Holiday Inn.'' The song ''Cheek to Cheek'' from the 1935 film ''Top Hat'' was nominated for an Oscar, but did not win.

title: Walgreen Executive To Head Operations
description: L. Daniel Jorndt, who joined the Walgreen Company out of college as a pharmacist, has been named to succeed Fred F. Canning as president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest drugstore chain. Mr. Canning, who is to retire on Feb. 1, 1990, will remain on Walgreen's board.

title: Majors Dismisses Cobb
description: Reggie Cobb of undefeated Tennessee, the top rusher in the Southeastern Conference, was permanently dismissed from the team yesterday by Coach Johnny Majors for a violation of team rules. Majors did not say what the violation was.

title: Crestar Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures were restated to reflect the merger with Colonial American Bankshares in May 1989.

title: Market Place; A New Concern Over Asset Sales
description: THE ''junk bond'' market, which has been reeling in recent weeks, was dominated by selling pressure again yesterday and it is likely to get worse before it improves, according to Robert M. Steinberg, the head of risk arbitrage at Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Engine Disk Was Cracked Before Jet Took Off, Officials Say
description: The large metal disk that broke away from the tail engine of a United Airlines jet over Iowa soon before the plane crashed at Sioux City last July was cracked before the aircraft took off, Federal safety investigators said today.

title: Valley Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ex-Congressman to Head Amex
description: In a surprise move outside Wall Street's inner circle, the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had chosen as its new chairman a former Democratic Representative from Oklahoma, James R. Jones.

title: Alexander's Inc reports earnings for 12wks to July 29
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,416,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $1,741,000, or 35 cents a share. The latest year's earnings included a gain of $25,100,000 related to the sale of leases and property of three of its stores. The company said the extraordinary loss in the 1989 year was related to the cumulative effect of changes in accounting to systems development costs. The company also said the extraordinary credit in the year-ago full-year was related to the effect of changes in accounting for income taxes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday incorrectly characterized the Israeli Labor Party. It is a partner in the coalition Government, not an opposition party.

title: 5 Win the Nobel Prizes in Chemistry and Physics
description: The Nobel Prizes in Chemistry and Physics were awarded yesterday to four Americans and one West German.

title: Potlatch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Melee Erupts as Pope Speaks in East Timor
description: Praying on a barren plain said to have been a killing field for Government troops, Pope John Paul II admonished Indonesia today to respect human rights in the disputed province of East Timor, where he said ''many innocent people have died.''

title: Fuel and Heating Oil Spilled in Antarctica
description: About 50,000 gallons of jet fuel, gasoline and heating oil leaked onto the ice near the main United States base in Antarctica, the National Science Foundation said today.

title: O'Sullivan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sidewalk Obstacle Course
description: East Side, West Side, forget the light fantastic - just walking on the sidewalks of New York can be like threading through a slalom because of construction equipment and jury-rigged scaffolding.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company of Pittsburgh yesterday priced $150 million in sinking fund debentures, due in 2019, through competitive bidding won by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: General Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oneok Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a loss of $1.57 a share from writedowns. Per share results for the year ended Aug. 31, 1988, also included a $1.03-a-share gain from an accounting change.

title: Perkins Signs
description: The Dallas Mavericks have signed Sam Perkins to a one-year contract, which will pay the forward $975,000 this season. Team officials said they had sought a three-year deal, but Perkins, who averaged 15 points and 8.8 rebounds last season, agreed to the one-year deal because he wants to become an unrestricted free agent at the end of the season.(AP)

title: Rubbermaid Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge equaled to 6 cents a share reflecting write-off of certain intangible costs associated with previous acquisitions.

title: Europe Agrees To Steel Limits
description: European Community negotiators have agreed to a compromise with the United States over limits on European steel exports, a community spokesman said today.

title: Citizens & Southern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Northern Telecom Technological Gain
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said it had developed a fiber-optic technology that would quadruple its current capacity. The telecommunications concern, owned by BCE Inc., said the new high-speed transmission and switching technology would vastly increase the capacity of current copper-wire systems. The technology will allow the transmission of all communications via a telephone line, including videotex, cable television, computer data and X-rays and person-to-person video telecommunications.

title: Jackie Mason's Remarks Are as Inaccurate as They Are Dangerous; A Place for Amateurs
description: To the Editor:

title: Altera Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the selection of a new executive director for the United States Olympic Committee misstated the action taken. Harvey Schiller was recommended for the post by a search committee, but the final selection will be made by the Olympic Committee's executive board.

title: BALL PARKS FIGURES
description: OAKLAND COLISEUM Built: 1966 Seating capacity: 48,219 on three tiers. Outfield distances: Left-field foul line: 330 ft. Left-field power alley: 375 ft. Center field: 400 ft. Right-field power alley: 375 ft. Right-field foul line: 330 ft. Outfield walls: Plywood covered with canvas 8 feet high. Field: Grass that is not quite as high as Candlestick's. Weather: Much less wind than at Candlestick but a heavy atmosphere. The ball does not carry well at night. Home dugout and bullpen: Third-base side. Unusual field feature: Because of the oval shape of the multipurpose stadium, the field has one of the largest foul areas in the major leagues, which is bad news for hitters. Scoreboard: Old-fashioned type in which numbers and names are posted by hand. There is, however, a giant television for replays, notices and advertising. Fun: In a fantasy broadcasting booth, you can broadcast an inning of the game and take home your tape. Also, you can try a pitching machine that measures the speed of your throws, or get your photo taken alongside life-size cutouts of the team's stars. The giant replay screen features dot racing - dots of different colors move around a track and fans bet one another on which dot is going to win. Food: Very big on sausages - bratwurst, kielbasa, Louisiana hots, Polish and English bangers. They also have super nachos, with an inordinate amount of condiment fixings, and a large selection of beer. One cafeteria-type restaurant. Access: BART, the subway system, has a station right at the Coliseum. For those who drive, a major freeway runs right alongside with an entrance and exit serving the Coliseum. Luxury boxes: On press-box level along both foul lines. Boxes seat about a dozen and have a bar and television screen in the back. CANDLESTICK PARK Built: 1960 Seating capacity: 60,000 on two main tiers with a mezzanine between. Outfield distances: Left-field foul line: 355 ft. Left-field power alley: 365 ft. Center field: 400 ft. Right-field power alley: 365 ft. Right-field foul line: 355 ft. Outfield walls: Wire fence 9 feet high. Field: Grass that is particularly high and soft. Weather: Although the wind is not so strong as it is during midsummer, it swirls unpredictably. Flags only a few feet apart can fly in opposite directions. Home dugout and bullpen: First-base side. Unusual field feature: Behind the Giants' bullpen there is a little shed in which the relief pitchers can stay warm. It has a door that faces home plate. This season, a ball hit fair bounded into the open door, which Craig Lefferts then closed, leaving his own teammate in right field bewildered and searching for the ball. The play was a grounds-rule double. No shed for the visiting team; also no access to clubhouses from visiting bullpen or dugout. Scoreboard: Modern, electronic with Jumbotron - a hugh television screen for information and replays. Fun: You can have a videotape made of yourself hitting a home run to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers. Also, you can try a pitching machine that measures the speed of your throws, or get your photo taken alongside life-size cutouts of the team's stars. Between innings, the scoreboard shows the names of three songs, and fans vote by applause and shouts which one they want played. Food: Cuisine features health foods like trail mix and vegetarian hot dogs along with regular hot dogs and Polish sausages. Beverages include Anchor Steam beer and wine. There is an upscale Stadium Club restaurant and a cafeteria. Access: Very poor for cars because of a hill blocking one side and water blocking the other. No train or subway or trolley or bus routes go to the ball park or to any place close enough to walk from. Public transportation includes special city buses that run from set locations and a few from the suburbs. Luxury boxes: Less luxurious than most luxury boxes are, but have been rebuilt in the last three or four years more to suit the football customers than the baseball customers. They have about 12 seats and a bar area with a television set in the back.

title: Ford Plans To Establish A New Unit
description: In a move that would keep its tax bill from rising by millions of dollars, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would establish a separate subsidiary for the Associates Corporation, the finance company that Ford expects to acquire later this year.

title: Agreement Eases Way For Connaught Takeover
description: Lawyers told an Ontario Supreme Court hearing today that an important obstacle to the takeover of a leading Canadian vaccine producer by a French company had been tentatively removed, The $943.5 million (Canadian), or $803 million (United States), acquisition of Connaught Biosciences Inc. by Institut Merieux S.A. of France would be one of the largest foreign takeovers of a Canadian company not involved in natural resources or real estate. Canadian nationalists and the nation's scientific community had objected to the offer.

title: President Quits at Squibb
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that Jan Leschly, president of the Squibb Corporation, had resigned to pursue opportunities outside the company.

title: Books of The Times; La Baker, the 20th Century's Empress Josephine
description: Jazz Cleopatra Josephine Baker in Her Time By Phyllis Rose 321 pages. Doubleday. $22.50.

title: Soviet Sale By Olivetti
description: Ing. C. Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy, which shipped high-technology machine tools to the Soviet Union, said today that the sale had been approved by Italian authorities.

title: First Illinois Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its earnings do not include results of Mercury Finance Co., which was spun off in a stock distribution to First Illinois shareholders in April 1989.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Sci-Fi Specialist

title: Rowan Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hayes-Dana Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $384,000, or 2 cents a share and $1,152,000, or 8 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company noted that, for 1988, $7 million of third-quarter sales and $23 million of 9-month sales related to a company that is no longer owned by Hayes-Dana. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cowboys Trade Walker To Vikings
description: Herschel Walker sauntered into the Dallas Cowboys' locker room at approximately 6:15 this morning, packed his gear and scurried to the airport for a flight to Minneapolis. Walker, the 1982 Heisman Trophy winner as a junior at Georgia and one of pro football's outstanding backs, had just been traded to the Minnesota Vikings for five players and a bushel of draft choices.

title: No Forced Conversions
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Good Health' Walk And Fitness Event
description: A four-mile ''Good Health'' walk from midtown to lower Manhattan will start a health and fitness event on Sunday sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation and The New York Times Company. The walk will begin at 1 P.M. at The New York Times Building, 229 West 43d Street, and will wind down Broadway to Battery Park, where a health festival will feature food, entertainment, sports clinics, competitions and prizes; the fair will continue until 4:30 P.M.

title: Exhibitions Are Planned On Titian And 1492 Art
description: The National Gallery of Art today announced two exhibitions to dramatize the cultural ties between the United States and Italy: a retrospective of the work of Titian and a celebration of the quincentenary of Columbus's first voyage to America.

title: People
description: * Rick Flata has been named senior vice president and media director of Hill, Holliday, Connors & Cosmopulos/New York.

title: Foliage Tours On the Farm-Stand Route
description: IF anything could add to the splendors of a visit to the countryside this weekend to see the changing colors of the fall foliage, it must be returning home laden down with bags of farm fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: Panel Proposes To Raise Fares In Taxis 11.5%
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday recommended raising New York taxicab fares an average of 11.5 percent next year and replacing the night surcharge with one for the rush hours in hopes of encouraging additional cabdrivers to work in the peak hours.

title: Houston's Ware: All Work At Play
description: On Sundays, when the Houston Oilers are playing at home, the Astrodome is the House of Pain. On Saturdays, it's the Ware-house, the home of the University of Houston Cougars.

title: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A law professor with a beef takes the judge to task and the case to the public.
description: For a variety of reasons judges, particularly those holding exalted appellate posts, enjoy a kind of immunity from criticism from lawyers. Whenever the bar rates the bench, it does it in the way the Zagat Guide rates restaurants: through anonymous surveys.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the six teen-agers accused of the rape of a jogger in Central Park misattributed assertions about the role of one defendant, Steven Lopez. It was a co-defendant, Kevin Richardson, who told the authorities that Mr. Lopez had held the jogger down and struck her with a pipe. Mr. Lopez has made no such admission to the authorities.

title: Syrian MIG Pilot's Feat Worries the Israelis
description: The Israeli military formally opened an investigation today to determine how a Syrian MIG-23 fighter-bomber pilot managed to fly his plane unhindered deep into Israel on Wednesday, land at a private airstrip, request asylum and wait 20 minutes before he saw or heard from anyone in the Israeli Air Force.

title: Budapest Hard-Liners Form Party to Toe the Old Line
description: A group of hard-line Communists announced today that they were forming a Communist Party in rejection of the governing party's announcement that it was converting to democratic socialism.

title: On Stage
description: U.S.-Soviet Student Exchange

title: Reviews/Music; San Francisco Symphony Plays Beethoven's 'Eroica'
description: There is a feeling abroad that pieces like Beethoven's ''Eroica'' symphony, which the San Francisco Symphony brought to Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening, are all but played out - that they have been interpreted so much, played so often, heard so repeatedly that somehow they just don't work any more. This speculation follows from the fact that lots of musicians and critics find themselves a little bored at a lot of performances of the canonic classics by artists and organizations that should be expected to do them well.

title: Rights Leaders Denouncing New Book by Ex-King Aide
description: A new book by a former top lieutenant of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is generating bitter denunciations from civil rights leaders and black officials and resurrecting old divisions among the followers of Dr. King.

title: Dining Out Guide: Three-Star Sampler
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. The date of original publication is listed. Prices are current. Huberts (July 15, 1988), 575 Park Avenue (entrance on 63d Street), 826-5911 - Soft-edged and Japanese-inspired, the dining room at Huberts is designed for comfort and conversation. The owners' fondness for Japanese esthetics and cuisine is evident in some of the dishes, like the starter of bright shrimp salad embellished with daikon and cucumber. Main courses include include breast of duck salad; Saudi clove chicken (chicken sauteed with fragrant spices); and rack of lamb with tomato-cucumber-mint salad. Lunch is a four-course tasting menu at $34 or a la carte (appetizers $6 to $11, entrees $12 to $18). Dinner is a $45 tasting menu or a la carte (appetizers $8 to $16, entrees $19 to $28). Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner, 6 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Le Perigord (June 16, 1989), 405 East 52d Street (755-6244) - The 25-year-old Perigord offers classic French cooking, opulent but light and herb-infused; its service staff is among the best in New York. In the dining room, soft lighting and bursts of fresh flowers surround patrons with elegance. Recommended appetizers include a salmon and onion tart and tartar of fresh salmon. Pasta with smoked salmon and shrimp is another example of the chef's talent. For main courses, consider skate with aioli and red cabbage; salmon steak with clams and spinach, and roast duck with seasonal fruits. Lunch is prix fixe at $28 (with some supplements); dinner $48. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday. The Sign of the Dove (March 27, 1987), 1110 Third Avenue, at 65th Street (861-8080) - The food is as seductive as the setting at Sign of the Dove, where brilliant flower arrangements decorate the dining rooms. The menu offers (as starters) a casserole of poached oysters and lobster and homemade beet ravioli accompanied by chanterelles and red-onion marmalade. Something for every taste can be found among the entrees, which include carmelized bass with leeks and baby artichokes; veal medallions with morels, and grilled duck with Middle Eastern spices and potato galette. Appetizers are $6 to $10, entrees $16 to $22. Four-course dinner prix fixe is $60. Sunday brunch appetizers are $6 to $14, entrees $18 to $24. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday; dinner: 6 to 9:30 P.M. (prix fixe) and 9:30 to 11:30 P.M. (a la carte) Sunday to Friday; 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. Saturday (prix fixe only). Sunday brunch 11:30 A.M. to 2:15 P.M. Union Square Cafe (May 12, 1989), 21 East 16th Street (243-4020) - Union Square Cafe has acquired a well-deserved reputation as a paragon among international bistros. The chef is offering a menu of mostly northern Italian dishes in the restaurant's three dining areas. An excellent way to start is with pasta; bombolotti tossed with fennel sausage, Cognac and cream, for example. Main course standouts include roast chicken with polenta, grilled veal chop with vegetable torte, and smoked Black Angus shell steak. Appetizers are $5.50 to $8.50 at lunch, $5.95 to $8.95 at dinner. Entrees are $8.95 to $17.50 at lunch, $16.95 to $23 at dinner. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Saturday; dinner: 6 to 10:45 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11:45 P.M. Friday and Saturday. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: A.T.&T. Details Unix Licensing
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced the terms for licensing the Release 4.0 version of its Unix computer operating system, which is scheduled to be released later this year.

title: 2 Bankers Cited In Iraqi Case
description: Two senior officers at the Atlanta branch of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, were accused yesterday of fraud and racketeering in connection with the issuance of more than $2 billion of loan agreements and letters of credit, primarily to banks and Government agencies in Iraq.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't advocate leaving the Soviet Union. Our position is that if the conditions are right, we can live in the Soviet Union.'' - Nadzhaf Nadzhafov, a director of the Azerbaijani Popular Front. [ A6:4. ]

title: REHNQUIST RENEWS REQUEST TO SENATE
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, passing up a chance to defuse criticism from fellow Federal judges over his handling of a death penalty proposal, urged Congress today to act as quickly as possible on the proposal for speeding Federal court review of death sentences.

title: Apple Harvest Festival With Crafts Lessons
description: Pumpkin decorating, cider pressing, pony rides and lessons in making corn-husk dolls are among the activities that will be offered at the Apple Harvest Festival at the New Pond Farm Education Center in West Redding, Conn., tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Both year-ago periods' nets and share earnings were restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS No. 96, which is an accounting change for income taxes. Latest 9-month results included a restructuring charge of $261.5 million that was offset by a gain of $266.1 million from sales of businesses and joint ventures.

title: INB Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SWEEPING CHANGE IN MEDICARE FEES NEARS FINAL STEP
description: A measure that could lead to fundamental changes in the practice and costs of medicine is heading for the Senate floor and final Congressional approval in the next few days.

title: Upbeat Ending to U.N. Talks
description: Members of the 44th United Nations General Assembly ended their annual exchange of views on world problems today.

title: Westinghouse Credit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Third-quarter results last year included a $14.3 million ater-tax benefit from the sale of the company's fixed asset lending division.

title: Analysts International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for the effect of a 5-for-4 stock split in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 14, 1989.

title: AMR Offer To Pilots Is Reported
description: The chairman of the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, has held talks with the company's pilots' union to consider a buyout in which the company's unions would be offered a large stake, a person on Wall Street familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Rise
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited reports this morning on the economy and inflation.

title: Review/Film; The Dismay Among Filipinos
description: ''Fight for Us,'' opening today at the Paris Theater, is as much a political gesture as it is a political film. Produced by French interests in the Philippines, the movie is the outraged response of its director, Lino Brocka, one of the most popular and successful Philippine film makers, to the human-rights abuses that are reported to be continuing in his country.

title: Chemical Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Chemical said it had recorded about a $600 million special addition to its loan loss allowance related to countries engaged in debt rescheduling and about $300 million of provisions at its Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. unit. Chemical said its year-ago third quarter net income included several non-recurring gains, including a $53.8 million pre-tax gain from settlement of a portion of its pension obligations and a $31.5 million net pre-tax gain from the divestment of certain non- strategic businesses.

title: The Finalists Are Named In National Book Awards
description: A first novel, ''The Joy Luck Club,'' by Amy Tan, is among the five finalists for the 1989 National Book Award in fiction, as is ''Billy Bathgate,'' a novel by E. L. Doctorow, who is a previous winner. The five books nominated for the nonfiction prize are on such public policy issues as the American civil rights movement and the Middle East conflict.

title: Affiliated Publications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $26,884,000. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $37,219,000 and $89,201,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Coca-Cola Net Up 20.9% in Quarter
description: Helped by strong overseas sales of soft drinks, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that third-quarter profits surged 20.9 percent, to $356 million, or $1.03 a share. Sales rose 8 percent, to $2.3 billion.

title: Elcor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,131,000, or 16 cents a share.

title: KEY RATES
Exxon Capital
description: The Exxon Capital Corporation is offering $200 million in noncallable capital notes, due in 1994, through Salomon Brothers Inc. The 8 1/4 percent notes are priced at 99.75 to yield 8.312 percent, or about 37 basis points more than the Treasury's five-year note. The notes are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.& P.

title: Washington at Work; Maestro as Political Symbol: The Americanization of Mstislav Rostropovich
description: As Mstislav Rostropovich tiptoed through a news conference with the Soviet Ambassador earlier this year to announce the National Symphony Orchestra's plans to tour the Soviet Union, some of his musicians were struck by how he balanced his evident excitement and the diplomatic euphemism fashioned for the event.

title: Heritage Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ross F. Nigrelli, 85, an Expert On Disease of Sea Life, Is Dead
description: Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli, a marine biologist and world-renowned expert on diseases of aquatic creatures, died of complications of a stroke on Oct. 4 at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in East Quogue, L.I.

title: TV: Selling Off Credibility
description: The local news ends on Channel 2 in New York. Dan Rather's CBS Evening News show scrolls up - together an hour of highly professional news broadcasting, as usual.

title: Lance Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Hancock Team in Race
description: The John Hancock Running and Fitness Clinic staff, which includes eight of the finest marathon runners in the world, will compete in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5 and will also conduct the first Hancock Running and Fitness clinics in New York next month.

title: Gramm-Rudman? Let the Ax Fall
description: Now that the House has passed the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989, the deficit reduction bill designed to avoid automatic spending cuts under Gramm-Rudman, I have some advice for the members of the Senate, where the debate has stalled. If you think that the Federal budget deficit should be reduced, the surest way to accomplish that goal is to shelve this legislation and allow the Gramm-Rudman spending cuts to go into effect next Monday.

title: Review/Film; Alley and Travolta in 'Look Who's Talking'
description: Amy Heckerling, who wrote and directed ''Look Who's Talking,'' says her own daughter was the inspiration for the film, a comedy in which a small baby's thoughts are heard on the soundtrack.

title: Jackie Mason's Remarks Are as Inaccurate as They Are Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighborhood Gangs Line Up for the Series
description: The last time two gangs from the same neighborhood tangled in the World Series, Roger Craig was pitching for one of them. Now the manager of the San Francisco Giants, Craig was overshadowed in the 1956 Series by his teammates in the Brooklyn Dodgers' lineup and his opponents in the Yankees' lineup. Nine of the players in that World Series are in the Hall of Fame, fellows named Robinson, Reese, Campanella, Snider, Drysdale, Berra, Ford, Mantle, Slaughter.

title: Our Towns; Gadgets to Fight What Goes Bump In Your Night
description: Melanie Franklin and her husband, Antony Lee, conceived of a security supermarket about two years ago when they were living in an apartment in New York City.

title: Giants Call on Riles For New Hitting Role
description: With Kevin Mitchell back at practice and his one-day excursion home to San Diego being accepted as a ''failure of communication,'' attention at the San Francisco Giants' workout today shifted to the self-effacing but important Ernest Riles.

title: Bank of New York and Chemical Post Big Losses
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Bank of New York Company announced large third-quarter losses yesterday as they greatly increased the reserves set aside to cover possible losses on loans to third world countries and to domestic businesses.

title: Foul Play By Eckersley?
description: A videotape that the Toronto Blue Jays claim shows Dennis Eckers trying to hide something in his trousers in Sunday's playoff game has been sent to the American League president and to the commissioner's office, said General Manager Pat Gillick of Toronto.

title: G.M.'s Van Output
