description: The General Motors Corporation said it would move the production of its full-size vans to Flint, Mich., from plants in Lordstown, Ohio, and Scarborough, Ontario. G.M. and union officials said the move would be completed in late 1991. The shift will affect about 2,500 workers at the Lordstown plant, which employs a total of 11,500. The Scarborough plant employs about 2,700 people, and G.M. said it was looking for a vehicle to produce there. G.M.'s Truck and Bus Group plant in Flint employs 4,700 workers.

title: Review/Art; William Tucker Explores The Shapes of Prehistory
description: If the formlessness and scatological shapes and textures of William Tucker's new sculptures put you off at first (''dinosaur droppings,'' one visitor called them), give them a chance. The 10 pieces of shifting, rocky matter at the David McKee Gallery in Manhattan and four larger, more boulderlike blocks at the gallery's Brooklyn exhibition space are among the most evocative and ambitious works Mr. Tucker has done.

title: Dow Falls By 13.52, To 2,759.84
description: Stocks fell for the third session in a row yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 13.52 points, to 2,759.84.

title: Lawrence Goossen, 46, Producer and Manager
description: Lawrence Goossen, a co-producer of plays and a company manager, died of AIDS on Monday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 46 years old.

title: Saatchi Is Getting a New Chief
description: Maurice Saatchi, the co-founder of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, said yesterday that he would relinquish the position of chief executive in favor of a 43-year-old French executive barely known in the advertising business.

title: Review/Theater; Feydeau's 'Flea in Her Ear,' at Long Wharf
description: John Tillinger's production of ''A Flea in Her Ear,'' which is opening the 25th season at the Long Wharf Theater, is performed with split-second synchronicity. The mechanics of the farce never show as the actors and audience are swept away by the sport of the chase - the slammed doors, the revolving beds, the frazzled looks and the mistaken identities that confuse an irate husband with a drunken hotel porter.

title: Barfield Signs 3-Year Pact
description: Jesse Barfield, who hit 18 home runs and cut down 16 runners as a Yankee outfielder this past season and then became a free agent, signed a three-year contract with the team yesterday in Tampa, Fla. No financial terms were announced.

title: Bill to Cut Capital Gains Tax Appears Thwarted, for Now
description: Senators of both parties said today that the Democratic leadership had the votes to keep a capital gains tax cut out of the deficit-reduction package that came to the Senate floor today.

title: Lincoln Failure Inquiry Is Set
description: The House Banking Committee voted today to subpoena Charles H. Keating Jr., a Phoenix millionaire, to testify about his insolvent savings institution, which is expected to require the Government's largest savings bailout ever. The panel also subpoenaed L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; M. Danny Wall, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision; William Crawford, California's savings and loan commissioner, and other officials. Hearings are scheduled to start next week.

title: Seaway Food Town reports earnings for Year to Aug 27
description: b-Included cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes of $1,085,000 and an after-tax effect of $5,170,000 attributable to a reversion of pension assets. Year-ago share earnings were reed to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend payable on Nov. 4, record Oct. 25.

title: Farmer Gets $110,000 Check
description: Janice Sorenson, the farmer who found the fan disk suspected of causing the DC-10 crash in Sioux City, Iowa, in July, received a $116,000 reward check yesterday from the engine's manufacturer, the General Electric Company.

title: Filing Discloses Dispute Over Sale of Sheller-Globe
description: It was just a few phrases buried in an otherwise dull financial document. But it hinted at a smoldering dispute among some of the savviest financial executives on Wall Street and in the corporate world. The targets of the mud being thrown include United Technologies; Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, and Knoll International Holdings.

title: Boise Cascade Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
South Pole Ozone Is at Lowest Level, Researchers Report
description: The ozone in the stratosphere over the South Pole has equalled the lowest level that scientists have measured, space agency scientists reported today.

title: Rival Scientists Decide Universe Is Composed of 3 Types of Matter
description: Using two giant particle accelerators, one in Europe and the other in California, rival teams of scientists have established beyond reasonable doubt that the universe contains no more than three fundamental types of matter.

title: Stephen Hartigan, 86; Led Jail Guard Union
description: Stephen C. Hartigan, a retired correction officer and former president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in the City Island section of the Bronx.

title: Fur Vault reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
Central Jersey Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 470 money market mutual funds increased by $899.9 million, to $349.89 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased by $21.3 million, to $83.14 billion. The assets of the 233 general-purpose funds were up by $436.7 million, to $114 billion. The 96 broker-dealer funds increased by $484.5 million, to $152.75 billion, the institute said.

title: Louis Levine, 78, Dies; Manufacturer of Coats
description: Louis Levine, a retired manufacturer of women's coats and suits, died of colon and bladder cancer on Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Morton International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harlyn Products reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said after the end of the fiscal year, it acquired George Hoffman Jewelry Manufacturing Inc., a Beverly Hills-based manufacturer and marketer of diamond jewelry.

title: Divi Hotels N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pinball Scandal Erupts in Japan
description: Both of Japan's biggest political parties found themselves enmeshed in new accusations of influence-peddling today after disclosures that one of Japan's most shadowy entertainment industries - its ubiquitous pinball parlors - contributed roughly $1 million to key politicians.

title: Senate Interferes in Azerbaijan's Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: First of America Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Film; Pfeiffer and 2 Bridges Brothers in 'The Fabulous Baker Boys'
description: Long after midnight, New Year's Eve: a moment that ''The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' the slow, teasing, rapturously moody romance written and directed by Steve Kloves, has been waiting for. Every waiter and busboy and reveler has left the hotel nightclub, but the balloons and the confetti remain. On each empty table, a little lamp casts a deep, warm glow. And on the stage, at the piano, the beautiful singer and the handsome, world-weary pianist are still reeling from the version of ''Makin' Whoopee'' they performed earlier in the evening. Alone at last, with the time finally right, they're ready to add a new verse.

title: Teheran Journal; Islamic Street Scene: Add a Whisper of Lipstick
description: Militancy, once a trademark of this capital city, appears increasingly associated with poor taste.

title: Review/Dance; Fairy Tales and Horror From Tanztheater Reinhild Hoffmann
description: Grim. That might be just about the right word for ''Machandel,'' and not because Reinhild Hoffmann's highly uneven dance-theater piece from West Germany is based on the Brothers Grimm.

title: Reviews/Music; A Voice of the Windy City
description: Patricia Barber, a pianist and singer who has been packing them in for five years at a tiny room in Chicago appropriately called the Gold Star Sardine Bar, made her New York debut Tuesday evening at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, where she is appearing through Oct. 28.

title: Call for Dialogue Raises Doubts in East Germany
description: Diplomats and opposition leaders in East Germany reacted with caution and some skepticism today to a statement by the Politburo calling for discussion of national problems while making it clear that Communism was not negotiable.

title: Middlesex Journal; Gold Bugs Are Biting In a River in Vermont
description: Robert Newhall, all 6 feet 6 inches of him, is standing calf-deep in the Mad River, his huge frame folded in half as he swirls a pan underwater.

title: Public Service Fellowships
description: A fellowship program will be established at the Harvard Law School for students choosing careers in public service.

title: INSIDE
description: 5 Win Nobel Prizes In Chemistry and Physics Thomas R. Cech of the University of Colorado and Sidney Altman of Yale won the chemistry prize. The physics prize went to Norman F. Ramsey of Harvard, Hans G. Dehmelt of the University of Washington and Wolfgang Paul of West Germany. Page A10. A Surprise on Wall St. The American Stock Exchange chose as its new chairman James R. Jones, a former Democratic Congressman from Oklahoma. Page D1. City Opera Cancels Season The strikebound New York City Opera canceled its fall season, and the spring series is in peril. Page C29.

title: Not Everybody Wants to Sign a Living Will
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Senate Democratic leaders said they had enough votes to keep a capital gains tax cut out of the deficit-reduction package under consideration. Republicans conceded that they could not muster the 60 votes needed to add the tax cut to the deficit legislation, but they made it clear they would try to attach the capital gains reduction to other legislation, perhaps by the end of the month. [ Page A1. ] Regulators in California will set local telephone rates for Pacific Bell and GTE based on price caps, rather than the cost of telephone service, under a plan adopted after two years of study. Other states are expected to copy the plan. [ D1. ] COMPANIES AMR's chairman has had talks with American Airlines' pilots about a possible buyout in which unions would be offered a large stake, a Wall Street source said. Such a buyout would be similar to one being completed at United Airlines. American has received an unsolicited $7.54 billion offer from Donald J. Trump. [ D1. ] ''Possible misrepresentations'' were made in the sale of Sheller-Globe, United Technologies said in a tender offer document. The dispute could result in a lowering of the purchase price. [ D1. ] NBC had expressed interest in becoming an equity investor in Qintex's proposed buyout of MGM/UA. A $1.5 billion deal for MGM/ UA fell through on Tuesday. [ D1. ] Chemical Banking and Bank of New York announced large losses for the third quarter as they increased their loan-loss reserves. Chemical said it would sell $500 million of new stock. [ D2. ] General Electric said its earnings rose 16 percent in the third quarter, based on improvements in operations including financial services, plastics and electrical generating equipment. Earnings from broadcasting, including NBC, were flat. [ D2. ] Coca-Cola's profits surged 20.9 percent on strong foreign sales. [ D2. ] Ford said it would establish a separate subsidiary for a finance company that it expects to acquire this year. The move will keep Ford's tax bill from rising by millions of dollars. [ D4. ] An obstacle to the takeover of Connaught may have been removed, lawyers told an Ontario court. [ D20. ] Northwest Airlines has ordered and taken options for 90 Boeing jetliners worth $5.2 billion. [ D4. ] A.T.&T. announced terms for licensing the Release 4.0 version of its Unix computer operating system. [ D4. ] Roger Rosenblatt resigned as editor of U.S. News and World Report after 14 months in the job. [ D6. ] MARKETS The American Stock Exchange's new chairman will be James R. Jones, the former Democratic Representative from Oklahoma. Many on Wall Street were surprised by the appointment. [ D1. ] Stocks fell for a third straight day. The Dow Jones industrials declined 13.52, to 2,759.84, amid some profit taking. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury issues rose. Trading was light as dealers awaited reports due today on producer prices and retail sales. [ D12. ] The dollar fell in subdued dealings. Gold prices rose. [ D13. ] Prices of frozen pork belly futures soared amid supply concerns raised by a plan to make shipments to Poland. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Saatchi & Saatchi's co-founder will relinquish the chief executive's job. Maurice Saatchi will be replaced by Robert Louis-Dreyfus, a French executive barely known in advertising, at the top of the world's largest ad company. Analysts and executives were unsure whether the changes meant that Charles and Maurice Saatchi were surrendering control. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ] Nobody wants a meat-ax approach to deficit cutting, but it may take a miracle to avoid it. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The troubled ''junk bond'' market is likely to get worse before it improves, a prominent arbitrager, Robert M. Steinberg, told money managers, as holders of the bonds become increasingly suspicious of deals financed by asset sales. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Review/Art; The Reinvented Americana Of Robert Gober's Mind
description: Robert Gober's eccentric made-from-scratch objects constitute a kind of revised Americana. They honor the humbler crafts while raising troubling questions about the culture that values them. These questions are deeply personal, for almost all of Mr. Gober's objects allude to the body, often to its most private functions. In the past, the artist has fabricated abstracted fixtureless sinks that were clearly not for cleansing, cribs whose slatted sides crossed where the baby should be and leaning playpens that did not suggest happy childhoods.

title: Say Yes to the Landmarks Compromise
description: New York's Charter Revision Commission, dragged into the protracted battle between the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission and religious institutions, managed to extricate itself with an ambiguous compromise. That compromise goes to the public as a separate question in November's referendum. It won't resolve the eternal conflict between preservationists and religious institutions. But New Yorkers can support it with confidence that it's not likely to do harm and might do some good.

title: Peoples Heritage Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Wachovia CorpN) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid Sept. 1.

title: Rape and Incest: Just 1% of All Abortions
description: For all the symbolic importance of the House of Representatives' move to restore the Federal financing of abortions for poor women when the pregnancy resulted from incest or rape, the practical effect would likely be very limited.

title: Carol B. Ohmann, 60, A Writer and Professor
description: Dr. Carol Burke Ohmann, a writer and professor of English at Wesleyan University, died Oct. 3 at her summer home in Hawley, Mass. She was 60 years old and lived in Middletown, Conn. The cause of death was suicide, said her husband, Richard.

title: Bill to Ban Flag Desecration Passes House Easily
description: The House of Representatives gave final approval today to legislation that outlaws flag desecration, and Congressional leaders began maneuvering for a greater battle next week over a constitutional amendment to protect the flag.

title: Auctions
description: An Heir's Collection

title: Review/Film; 'Crimes and Misdemeanors,' New From Woody Allen
description: Judah Rosenthal (Martin Landau), a successful Manhattan ophthalmologist, and his best friend, Ben (Sam Waterston), a rabbi, are discussing what one of them describes as ''a small infidelity'' when they suddenly are confronting the meaning of existence.

title: Henderson the Run King
description: The child who became the man of perpetual motion grew up not far from the stage that will serve as a backdrop for the opening games of the 86th World Series. The reminders of Rickey Henderson's youth are scattered all across north Oakland, not so much in the places he played as in the minds of those who watched him.

title: A.O. Smith reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $3,567,000 due to one-time costs associated with a lawsuit against a former subsidiary. c-Net income

title: Diner's Journal
description: Panevino

title: Barnett Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Up Thoughts for a Down Day
description: People who regard 13 as unlucky - triskaidekaphobes - are especially unnerved by Friday the 13th. There is always at least one a year, often two and occasionally, 28 times since 1800, three. Today is the second and last for 1989, and time to shed some light in this dark corner of the calendar.

title: Eldorado Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sale of Stamps for $1 Million Sets Record for a U.S. Issue
description: A block of four United States stamps, the ''Inverted Jenny'' on which the plane in the center is upside down, was sold for $1 million last night, the highest price ever paid for an American philatelic item, a spokeswoman for Christie's auction house said.

title: Review/Theater; Casualties of Officialdom: Language and Truth
description: How do you write a truthful play in which everyone is a liar? Set it on Capitol Hill, of course. In ''Mastergate,'' Larry Gelbart's excoriating satire of the Iran-contra hearings, the witnesses before a Congressional committee aspire only to be ''steadfastly evasive and selectively honest,'' and they don't even succeed at that. They speak in nonsensical double talk and official bureaucratese redolent of such past Gelbart writings as Sid Caesar's shtick and television's ''M*A*S*H.'' As Maj. Manley Battle - a lunatic amalgam of Oliver North, Alexander Haig and Joseph Heller's Major Major - says, ''I prefer to call a spade by its code word.''

title: Raytheon Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Travelers, St. Paul Settle Texas Suit
description: Two large insurance companies, sued in an antitrust case, have agreed to testify for the state and pay $500,000 in legal costs each, Attorney General Jim Mattox said. The Travelers Insurance Company and the St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company also agreed to cease certain activities in the settlement agreement.

title: A-PLANT NOMINEE ADMITS MISTAKES
description: The former chief of staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission acknowledged today that for seven months he delayed an inquiry into allegations of drug use and safety problems at the Nine Mile Point nuclear plant in upstate New York, even though he believed they were probably true.

title: Lebanese Factions Seem to Be Moving Toward Agreement
description: Lebanon's warring religious factions appeared early today to be close to an agreement that would give Muslims a significantly greater role in national affairs.

title: Ford to Sell Its Steel Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had signed a memorandum of understanding to sell its Rouge Steel Company to an investor group.

title: Manila Moves To Cut Its Debt
description: The Philippine Government offered Wednesday to buy back some of its commercial bank loans at half price in a bid to reduce its $29 billion foreign debt. The central bank governor, Jose Fernandez, said Manila was prepared to buy $1.3 billion of the $7.2 billion in medium- and long-term bank debt at 50 cents on the dollar, or a total cost of $650 million.

title: Space Shuttle Team Rushes to Complete Repairs to Computer
description: Technicians perched on a platform worked round the clock today to remove a faulty engine computer and get the space shuttle Atlantis and its Galileo space probe prepared for launching next Tuesday.

title: AmSouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Philips Shipping TV Sets to Japan
description: In a reversal of an electronics trend, the Philips Consumer Electronics Company began shipping American-made television sets to Japan. Philips plans to export 1,500 sets to Japan this year, ''with significantly increasing exports projected for the 1990's,'' the company said.

title: Bush, at Dinner for Giuliani, Praises 'America's Greatest Crime Fighter'
description: President Bush praised Rudolph W. Giuliani last night as ''America's greatest crime fighter'' and said a Mayor Giuliani ''will have a friend in the Oval Office.''

title: Californians Say Clean Air Pact Will Backfire
description: California officials today denounced the new Congressional agreement to extend California's stringent automobile-emission standards to the rest of the country and called it a bad bargain for the state.

title: United Stationers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Nationalists in Azerbaijan Win Big Concessions From Party Chief
description: The Communist Party chief of Azerbaijan bought peace with his Soviet republic's defiant nationalists - and the end of a rail embargo against neighboring Armenia this week - by signing a remarkable pact with an unofficial political group.

title: Altman Deal To Financo
description: The L. J. Hooker Company, the Australian developer that owns the B. Altman and Bonwit Teller department, named Financo Inc., the New York-based merger-and-acquisition consultant, as its financial adviser yesterday in the accelerated attempt to sell B. Altman & Company.

title: New Children's Museum Joins 2 Old Favorites
description: BEFORE there were children's museums, children went to school to learn, to the playground to play and to museums to be bored.

title: Society for Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest 9 months' figures included a gain on the sale of credit card receivables and accounts, and a loss from the accelerated amortization of goodwill. The net effect of the two items was a gain of $14.5 million, or $1.22 per share.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY CANADA COMES SOUTH

title: Development Fears Prompt Rally
description: Voicing fears that a fast-food restaurant would destroy their neighborhood, about 100 people gathered on a sidewalk on the Upper East Side last night, waving placards that proclaimed, ''Save Our Services'' and ''Fast Food Clogs Arteries.''

title: Southnet Venture
description: The Southnet Corporation and Fone America Inc., two long-distance telephone companies, agreed to form a joint venture. Southnet, based in Tampa, and Fone America, a Nevada company, plan to consolidate and share switching centers, data-processing services, network facilities and billing services. Terms of the agreement are expected to be completed soon, the companies said. The two have customers in different geographic regions.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Fred Hersch

title: Bairnco reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,430,000 for the quarter and $9,033,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and included income of $41,000 for the quarter and a loss of $31,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations; the 9 months also included income of $6,199,000, or 59 cents a share, from a spun-off operation. The latest quarter and 9 months included an after tax charge of $5,024,000 related to a change in the inventory reserve policy and losses on several major open jobs.

title: Jail Guard Drug Testing Upheld, 3- 2
description: A plan to randomly test more than 10,000 correction officers in New York City's prisons for drug use was narrowly upheld yesterday by a New York appeals court.

title: PANAMANIAN TELLS OF GOAL OF REBELS
description: A Panamanian sergeant whose commander was slain leading an abortive coup against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that while the uprising seemed well planned, he and other lower-ranking officers had been informed of it less than an hour before it began.

title: Lockheed Reports Loss
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it lost $32 million in the third quarter after taking a $165 million charge to cover cost overruns on several development contracts. The loss was $3 million less than the company predicted last week, when it disclosed the write-off.

title: Analogic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Edward P. Moore, 81, A Retired Consultant
description: Edward P. Moore, a management consultant for many years before his retirement in 1977, died Tuesday at his home in Darien, Conn., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: House Votes to Widen Oversight of C.I.A.
description: The House of Representatives voted today to give lawmakers broad access to the Central Intelligence Agency's most private analyses of its own failings.

title: Florida Progress reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Stryker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and average shares outstanding have been adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split effective May 19.

title: Accounts
description: * Jones Dairy Farm, a meat-products manufacturer, to Frankenberry, Laughlin & Constable, Milwaukee, with a budget of $2 million.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''JUST-SO STORIES,'' a puppet show based on tales by Rudyard Kipling, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''PETER AND THE WOLF,'' a show by the Hudson Vagabond Puppets, set to music by Prokofiev, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I. Tickets: $6.50. Reservations: (516) 922-0061. ''STORIES FROM AROUND THE WORLD,'' a program with David Gonzalez, a storyteller who will offer legends and tall tales, 1:30 and 3 P.M. tomorrow, at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, Crown Heights. Admission: $2. Information: (718) 735-4400. APPLE FESTIVAL, a fair with fiddle music, fresh cider, face painting, contests, games, apples and apple pies, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the Kissam House and Barn, 434 Park Avenue, Huntington, L.I. Sponsored by the Huntington Historical Society. Admission: children, 75 cents; adults, $2., includes a tour of the Kissam House (circa 1795). Information: (516) 427-7045. ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES,'' an opera by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays through Nov. 18, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 666-1716. ''ROCKET AND FRIENDS,'' a show by the Puppet Company, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays through Nov. 12, at 31 Union Square West, Loft 2B. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: 741-1646. ''THE SLEEPING BEAUTY,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic show with audience participation, with Brian McGovern and Imam, 2 P.M. Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Information: 924-1472. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' a magic, music and comedy show for young children, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sundays, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''WEAVING WONDERS,'' a program with a tale about magical weaving and instructions for using yarns and other materials to weave, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Dairy in Central Park, near 64th Street. Reservations required: 397-3165. ''CINDERELLA,'' a show by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the West 72d Street Studios, 131 West 72d Street. Tickets: $4. Reservations required: 874-3297. NEW CANAAN (CONN.) NATURE CENTER, a 40-acre site, with trails open from sunrise to sunset and exhibition buildings and greenhouses, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. Sundays, at Oenoke Ridge. Free. Information: (203) 966-9577.

title: Northwest Sets Deal For 90 Boeing Planes
description: Northwest Airlines said today that it had placed orders and taken options for 90 jetliners worth from the Boeing Company worth $5.2 billion.

title: Green Tree Acceptance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $39,637,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: F.B.I. Admits Bid to Disrupt Lawyers Guild
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday acknowledged a broad effort to disrupt and investigate the National Lawyers Guild for decades, although Government officials decided as far back as 1958 that they could not prove charges that the organization was subversive.

title: Bishops Shift Earlier Stance on AIDS
description: In a sequel to an unusual public debate among Roman Catholic leaders, a committee of bishops issued a statement yesterday strongly rejecting the use of condoms to prevent the spread of AIDS and urging society to support an ideal of chastity for adolescents.

title: Nellcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
An Altered Political Climate Suddenly Surrounds Abortion
description: Victories for abortion rights supporters this week in the Florida Legislature and the House of Representatives, plus gains in electoral campaigns in New Jersey and Virginia, have shaken their opponents and emboldened Democratic politicians to challenge President Bush and the Republicans to defend their opposition to abortion.

title: Mosinee Paper Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Knicks Open With Nuggets
description: With more plays for Patrick Ewing, a more controlled up-tempo game and emphasis on halfcourt defense rather than the press, the Knicks open an eight-game exhibition schedule Friday against the Denver Nuggets at Madison Square Garden.

title: As Gorbachev's Troops Pull Out. . .
description: Mikhail Gorbachev startled the world last December when, in a speech to the United Nations, he promised to withdraw a significant part of Soviet forces in Eastern Europe. These would be unilateral withdrawals and reductions; no price was extracted from the West for them. Mr. Gorbachev gave himself two years to complete them - by December 1990.

title: First Chicago Reports Loss
description: Following the example of other leading United States banks, the First Chicago Corporation reported a third-quarter loss today after increasing its reserves for shaky third world loans by $200 million.

title: Review/Film; 'Halloween 5' And Sinister Rustlings
description: ''I prayed that he would be in hell, but in my heart I knew that hell would not have him!'' laments Dr. Loomis (Donald Pleasence) the disfigured psychiatrist and veteran of three installments of the ''Halloween'' horror series early in episode 5. Once again, Loomis is in pursuit of Michael Myers, the seemingly indestructible killer of teen-agers, who materializes in Haddonville, Ill., on Halloween night to cut another splattery swath.

title: TAKEOVER STOCKS HIT HARD
description: A late wave of selling swept the stock market yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, to 2,569.26. In terms of points, the decline was the second largest in history, exceeded only by the 508-point plunge of Oct. 19, 1987, but the decline in percentage terms was not nearly so bad. It ranked as the 12th worst.

title: Gaston Agrees to Pact For 1 Year at Toronto
description: Cito Gaston, who took over as manager of the Toronto Blue Jays 36 games into the season and turned a 12-24 team into the winner of the American League Eastern Division title, agreed to a one-year contract yesterday.

title: Review/Rock; Just What the Tie-Dyed Crowd Wanted
description: Grateful Dead concerts are as iffy as blind dates, but the band had a good night tonight, the second concert of a five-night stand at the Brendan Byrne Arena. In two sets that added up to about two-and-a-half hours of music, the Dead concentrated on songs rather than its famous free-form jamming.

title: All of the Hype Aside, It's Time to Play Ball
description: After nearly a week of talk that has more closely resembled the annual hype before the Super Bowl, World Series LXXXVI begins Saturday with the Oakland Athletics and the San Francisco Giants playing for the championship of the Bay Area. And of baseball, too.

title: Eat and Be Wary, Governor
description: Gov. Bill Clements was among several diners who witnessed an armed robbery at a restaurant Thursday night in which one man was shot. The lone robber apparently did not recognize Mr. Clements, who was seated at a counter eating a hamburger, without his bodyguards. A customer who tried to stop the gunman in the restaurant's parking lot was shot in the leg. The Governor's spokesman, Mike Toomey, said Mr. Clements left the restaurant before giving the police a statement.

title: President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following is the transcript of President Bush's news conference here today as provided by the Federal News Service: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Books of The Times; Emma Goldman, Queen of Causes
description: Emma Goldman in Exile From the Russian Revolution to the Spanish Civil War By Alice Wexler Illustrated. 301 pages. Beacon Press. $24.95.

title: THE DOW'S WORST DAYS
description: Following are the 15 largest one-day percentage declines for the Dow Jones industrial average since Oct. 1, 1928, when the average was increased to 30 stocks. Yesterday was the 12th worst day.

title: Police Almost Released 3 Suspects in Park Rape
description: A New York City police officer testified yesterday that the police were about to release five youths who had been arrested after reports of marauding in Central Park last April, but changed their minds when they learned that a jogger had been beaten and raped in the park.

title: Your Money; Many Advised To Review Wills
description: With the overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years, many people have rearranged trust funds and shifted assets but failed to update their wills or or have new ones written.

title: Review/Music; Ozawa Leads Mahler Ninth
description: Mahler's progress from his Fourth Symphony to his Ninth tells us that life teaches much but not always what we want to know. The two works are joined by a number of similarities - the delicate employment of elephantine orchestral resources, for one, also the persistent references to the land: horns call from the hills beyond, naive folk songs are sung, Landler danced with the lightest of feet.

title: Unselfish Knicks Finally Get Message
description: Selfishness, the players' failure to give up the ball, was one of the biggest complaints about the Knicks last season, and Stu Jackson witnessed that fault repeatedly as an assistant coach under Rick Pitino.

title: Early October Auto Sales Down by 12.6%
description: Sales of American-built cars fell 12.6 percent in early October after two months of steep discounts by auto makers seeking to clear year-end inventories of 1989 models.

title: Seoul Vows More for U.S. Troop Costs
description: President Roh Tae Woo says that South Korea will increase its share of the cost of stationing American military forces here as it grows stronger economically, but that a cutback of those forces should not be considered now.

title: Steps to Control the Slide Yield Unintended Effects
description: As the markets raced out of control yesterday, a series of emergency actions was initiated at the major stock, futures and options exchanges in an effort to limit price declines.

title: Medigap Policies: Fine for Now
description: The Senate and the House of Representatives have moved to repeal all or part of the Federal program of expanded health insurance for older Americans. A new measure to replace the 1988 Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act has still to be shaped by a Congressional conference committee, but there seems to be little doubt at this point that most of the benefits will end shortly, along with the income-tax surtax that was to pay for them.

title: Eckersley Not an Issue
description: Bobby Brown, the president of the American League, said today that the Dennis Eckersley emery-board issue is not an issue with him.

title: Joe Foy, Baseball Player, 46
description: Joe Foy, a third baseman with the 1967 American League champion Boston Red Sox and later a member of the Mets, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in New York. He was 46 years old.

title: Patents; Mask May Improve Laser Eye Surgery
description: Summit Technology Inc., a small manufacturer of laser systems in Watertown, Mass., has developed a mask the size of a contact lens that the company believes could make eye surgery easier and more reliable.

title: Air Midwest Bid Is Made by Mesa
description: Air Midwest, a Wichita-based regional air services company, said Mesa Airlines Inc. of Farmington, N.M., was proposing to acquire all of Midwest's shares outstanding. Mesa sent a letter proposing a combination of cash and Mesa stock for the purchase of Air Midwest. Mesa's stock fell $1 today, to $6.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Air Midwest rose 50 cents, to $5.25, in over-the counter trading. Air Midwest has almost 2.9 million common shares outstanding.

title: Review/Theater; Gorky's 'Summerfolk' in Providence
description: It is clear from her debut as artistic director of the Trinity Repertory Company that Anne Bogart is not satisfied with halfway measures. Her unorthodox production of Gorky's ''Summerfolk,'' which opened Wednesday night, is an ambitious attempt to reinvent the play as a radical and relevant comedy about the complacency and ennui of the new Russian bourgeoisie. In pursuit of her bold concept, she loses sight of the specific humanity of Gorky's characters and she obscures the heartline of the play itself.

title: A Glimpse of Peace in Lebanon
description: Against odds and expectations, what seems like a serious peace plan for Lebanon is being tacked together by aging politicians meeting in the Saudi Arabian resort town of Taif. Arab League mediators have diligently promoted marathon talks among the surviving members of the Lebanese Parliament, elected in 1972. The 62 deputies are said to be near agreement on a new national charter that would give more power to Lebanon's non-Christian majority and provide for a pullback of 40,000 Syrian occupying troops.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Syrian Pilot's Escape to Israel Was a 'Very Difficult Mission'
description: The Syrian fighter pilot who defected to Israel in a Soviet jet fighter on Wednesday said today that his flight was ''a very difficult mission'' since he flew at about 800 miles an hour and was only about 100 to 150 feet off the ground.

title: Population Bomb Keeps Ticking; China's Policy Decried
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcott & Andrews to Close Its Stores
description: After failing to win creditors' support for a 90-day financing agreement, Alcott & Andrews, the retail chain that specializes in career apparel for women, said it would go out of business.

title: Elephant Man Disease Not Neurofibromatosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Talk Evokes 1960
description: David N. Dinkins assembled more than 1,000 leaders of Jewish congregations and community groups at breakfast Thursday to repeat - this time ''as candidly and as plainly as I can'' -a message that has underscored much of his campaign for mayor of New York City.

title: Takeover Troubles Give Wall St. a Jolt
description: A financing failure helped set off the drop in stock prices.

title: New York's Dangerous Insurance Policy
description: New York's State Insurance Fund, founded 75 years ago by a socially inventive, farsighted Legislature, now writes 45 percent of all workers' compensation insurance in the state. To mark its anniversary, the fund recently sent its policyholders a handsome financial statement complete with a message of congratulation from Gov. Mario Cuomo.

title: Moncrief Retires
description: Sidney Moncrief, an All-Star in the National Basketball Association five times who was dropped by the Milwaukee Bucks this summer because of knee problems, said yesterday he was retiring to become a broadcaster for the Dallas Mavericks.

title: S.E.C. Chief Quiet on Drop
description: Two days after being sworn in as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Richard C. Breeden spent this afternoon in his office and refused to discuss today's market drop with reporters. A spokeswoman for the

The move reverses a 1977 decision, confounding development plans. 29 About New York: In Chelsea, 81 years of love, survival and art 27

title: Jersey Takes Over Failing Schools
description: Citing ''total educational failure,'' the state of New Jersey assumed full responsibility for all 37 schools in Jersey City - the first state takeover of a local school district in memory. Coming on the heels of a summit meeting where the nation's governors promised improvements in education, the move demonstrates just how far some states will have to go to meet that obligation.

title: British Inflation Rises
description: Retail prices in Britain rose by the steepest amount in five months in September, bringing the annual inflation rate to 7.6 percent, the Government reported today. The Government said the rise of seven-tenths of a percent in the retail price index for September was the highest monthly increase since April's 1.8 percent. Forecasters had expected a rise of four-tenths of a percent.

title: Bail Ordered for Ex-Agent in Jail for Spying
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Richard W. Miller is not likely to flee and ordered a judge to set bail for the former Federal agent whose conviction for espionage in 1986 was overturned this year.

title: Bridge
description: An opening no-trump bid with a hand containing a singleton is frowned on by theory and avoided in practice by all but a few eccentrics. But an overcall of one no-trump is another matter, as on the diagramed deal reported by David Berah from a rubber bridge game at the Cavendish Club.

title: Yugoslav Premier Seeks U.S. Aid
description: Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia met with President Bush today, seeking United States assistance in making economic and political changes opposed by hard-liners in the Communist Party.

title: The Voronezh Visitors
description: Tass, the Soviet press agency, has reported the landing of an extraterrestrial vehicle in the Russian city of Voronezh. The creatures who emerged were nine feet tall, with little knobby heads and three eyes. They had a small robot in tow and went for a ''short promenade about the park,'' Tass reports.

title: Workers Replace Computer In Shuttle and Begin Checks
description: Technicians replaced a defective computer in the space shuttle Atlantis today as they worked toward a launching scheduled for Tuesday.

title: HONECKER ADMITS NEED FOR CHANGE
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, met today with leaders of normally pliant minority parties and spoke of the need to change economic and social policies, East German reports said.

title: Mayor Gaynor Survived Assassination Attempt
description: To the Editor:

title: School Forfeits More Than Game
description: Two school board members have resigned and seven athletes have quit an all-white private school's football team after it forfeited a game with a school that has a black player.

title: A Killing in Brooklyn: Was Bias the Motive?
description: Paul Trotman, a 19-year-old Brooklyn man, was mourned at his funeral yesterday as another victim of New York City's racial and ethnic violence.

title: Janice M. Baker Weds C. G. Benedetto
description: Janice M. Baker, a daughter of Jack Baker of Central Square, N.Y., and the late Janet M. Baker, was married yesterday to Christopher G. Benedetto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Benedetto of Huntington Bay, L.I. The Rev. James Morrison, a Baptist minister, and the Rev. David Baehr, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the First Baptist Church in Central Square.

title: Japanese Make a U.S.-Style Movie, In English, Aiming for Global Appeal
description: While Japanese companies are buying up Hollywood studios and financing American producers, a group of Japanese businessmen is hoping to invigorate Japan's sluggish film industry by grafting American rhythms and plot structure onto a Japanese movie.

title: Review/Dance; 2 Dancers Take Next Step
description: Martha Graham has invited several of her dancers to create works for the Martha Graham Dance Company's current season at City Center (131 West 55th Street), through Oct. 22. On Wednesday night, Thea Nerissa Barnes and Lyndon Branaugh presented dances that suggested these neophyte choreographers have learned from the committed, professional atmosphere of this major American modern dance company.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: President Hints at a Compromise Over Federal Funds for Abortion
description: President Bush encouraged White House aides and Republican Congressional leaders today to continue negotiations to avoid a confrontation over Federal financing for abortions for victims of rape and incest.

title: Hofstra Upsets Wagner
description: The Flying Dutchmen of Hofstra took off against Wagner tonight and upset the Seahawks, 42-24. Wagner had been undefeated after five games and was ranked first among the East's 87 Division III teams.

title: Jane Pauley Is Expected to Leave 'Today' Show
description: NBC is expected to announce early next week that Jane Pauley, the co-anchor of ''Today,'' will leave the program to become part of a new weekly prime-time news program or series of programs next summer.

title: Treasuries Climb on Stock Proceeds
description: A ''flight to quality'' sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields plunging yesterday. Dealers said the demand for all Treasury securities surged as stock prices began tumbling in the last 45 minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. But a sharp decline in the dollar tended to take the edge off the price advances.

title: Toronto Journal; Will They Always Get Their Man, Hats or No?
description: Along with the moose and the maple leaf, the scarlet-jacketed Mountie in his light-brown ranger hat has been a Canadian totem. Now, guardians of the country's traditions are being asked to accept a new image within the force that tamed the Canadian west: the Mountie in a turban.

title: Favored A's Are Eager to 'Get It Done'
description: The Oakland Athletics are still being chased by the failure of 1988. They say it is a forgotten part of their past, that last year has no bearing on this year, that there are no dark clouds hanging over them. But the clouds are there, seen or unseen.

title: Gallant Suspended
description: Gerard Gallant of the Detroit Red Wings has been suspended for five games by the National Hockey League for deliberately attempting to injure Garth Butcher, a defenseman for Vancouver, while going out of his way to retaliate in a game last Saturday. The Red Wings said they would not appeal.(AP)

title: SENATE APPROVES $14 BILLION PLAN TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: The Senate approved a $14 billion plan to reduce the deficit tonight, stripping from it hundreds of extraneous measures including child care assistance and Medicare changes, and putting off a battle over cutting the capital gains tax.

title: New York's New School Chief Visits City and Faults System
description: Joseph A. Fernandez visited New York yesterday to start setting up shop as the new schools chancellor, and he immediately offered some blunt challenges to the city's way of running its schools.

title: Chinese Vice Premier Meets Gandhi and Sees Warm Ties
description: The highest-ranking Chinese leader to visit India in nearly 30 years met with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today and declared that a new era of friendship had begun between the two Asian giants.

title: Labor Secretary Gets 2 Sides To Meet in Long Coal Strike
description: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced today that the leaders of both sides in the Pittston coal strike had agreed to meet with her on Saturday in the first face-to-face negotiations since the walkout began six months ago.

title: Sharp Rise of Private Guard Jobs
description: Walk into a store, and a security guard looks you over. Try to enter the lobby of an apartment building and a doorman blocks the way. Arrive for an appointment at a company office and a receptionist politely but firmly checks to see if the appointment really exists.

title: Peterson to Yankees
description: The Yankees yesterday named Harding (Pete) Peterson, a former executive vice president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, vice president and general manager after Bob Quinn resigned, as expected. Quinn accepted a similar position with the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Walker Feels at Home After Viking Workout
description: It was like a return to his pro football glory days for Herschel Walker today. Here he was, just one day into his Minnesota Vikings career, and he felt comfortable in an offense for the first time this season.

title: Ex-Reagan Aide Won Grant After Brief Talk With Pierce
description: A top fund-raiser for former President Ronald Reagan disclosed today that he won $28 million in assistance for a housing project in Texas after a brief meeting with former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. The Congressional testimony of Gerald Carmen, who left Mr. Reagan's 1980 transition team to head the General Services Administration, offered another example of what lawmakers have described as a pattern of political favoritism at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the Reagan years.

title: Recital in Brooklyn On a Mighty Wurlitzer
description: Two years after extensive water damage silenced its pipes, a vintage Wurlitzer organ that was a permanent fixture at the Brooklyn Paramount Theater can be heard again this weekend.

title: Retail Sales in September Advanced a Moderate 0.5%
description: Retail sales rose a moderate five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government said today. Analysts said the report showed consumer spending was still fairly strong, despite a slowing economy.

title: Lockheed to Use Italian Jet Design
description: The Lockheed Corporation, in the early stages of competing for a $2 billion Air Force training jet program, said it would use an Italian jet design if it won the contract. Lockheed said it had an agreement with Aermacchi S.p.A. of Varese, Italy, to use the MB-339 jet tandem-trainer for the United States Air Force's Primary Aircraft Training System program.

title: Newsweek Agonizes Over Delay in Reporting Mason Remarks
description: Though it has been nearly two weekssince Newsweek magazine reported that four senior members of its staff had been present when Jackie Mason described David N. Dinkins as a ''shvartzer,'' the magazine's handling of the information has continued to be a center of controversy.

title: Ford Seeks 51% Of Saab-Scania
description: The Ford Motor Company wants a 51 percent stake in the car division of Saab-Scania A.B., but the Swedish manufacturer will not relinquish control of the unit, the daily newspaper Svenska Dagbladet said. ''This is not just a business question,'' a source close to the negotiations was quoted as saying. ''There are also other considerations, not least labor-market politics.''

title: H.U.D. Ousts Administrator In New York
description: An investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development has found that its former New York administrator, Geraldine McGann, violated Federal ethical standards in connection with a subsidized housing program in her hometown of Island Park, L.I., but did not use her position to enrich her family or political allies.

title: Facing Scandal, Gandhi Loses Parliament Votes
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, facing his most serious political crisis since coming to office in 1984, lost important votes in Parliament tonight, prompting speculation that he may call snap elections or try to postpone the voting while he rebuilds his political strength.

title: William A. Kottmeyer, Educator, Dies at 79
description: William A. Kottmeyer, an educator and a prolific author of textbooks, died of an aneurysm Wednesday during abdominal surgery at St. Mary's Health Center in Richmond Heights, Mo. He was 79 years old and lived in Town and Country, Mo.

title: Chief of Corrections Retires
description: Richard J. Koehler, the Correction Commissioner of New York City, announced yesterday that he is retiring as commissioner effective Dec. 22. Mayor Edward I. Koch praised Commissioner Koehler, who began as a police foot patrolman in 1967 for changing the Department of Correction ''all for the better in a quantum way.'' The commissioner, who is 44, has not announced his plans for the future.

title: French Concern's Bid For Connaught Stalled
description: The Canadian Government today told Institut Merieux S.A. of France that its takeover bid of $943.5 million (Canadian) for Connaught Biosciences Inc. of Toronto was unacceptable under rules that require foreign buyouts of Canadian companies to be of ''net benefit'' to Canada.

title: The Good Life Has Environmental Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope, Ending Indonesia Visit, Issues Careful Plea on Rights
description: Pope John Paul II wound up a long trek across Indonesia today, telling Roman Catholic bishops to speak out against human rights abuses but trying to reassure the Government that Catholics present no threat.

title: INSIDE
description: F.B.I. Is Given Leeway To Seize Fugitives Abroad

title: Times Square Renewal (Act II), a Farce
description: After a six year intermission, the curtain has gone up on Act II of the long-running show at Times Square called the 42d Street Development Project. The latest revised production hit the boards in August.

title: Dreaded Virus Said to Cause Little Damage to Computers
description: A long-feared electronic virus set to cripple personal computers today created high anxiety but caused very little actual damage.

title: Wall St. Cites Sound Fundamentals
description: Although Wall Street was stunned by the selling wave that swept the stock market in the last hour of trading yesterday, it was not devastated. Some market participants attributed the 190-point, or 6.9 percent, plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average to overspeculation.

title: Corrections
description: A brief review in the Sounds Around Town column of Weekend yesterday, about the Fred Hersch Trio, gave an incorrect address for Town Hall. It is at 123 West 43d Street.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: Will Clark has been labeled racially ''prejudiced'' by Jeffrey Leonard, whom the Giants' first baseman labeled a ''tumor'' when they were teammates. Kevin Mitchell has apologized and agreed to pay what was described as a ''stiff fine'' by Roger Craig, the Giants' manager, for having missed Wednesday's workout. And whenever Dennis Eckersley hurries in from the Athletics' bullpen, he will be under the scrutiny of more cameras than a bank robber.

title: Logic Behind Volvo-Renault Talks
description: Talks between Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden about possible joint efforts are the latest sign of growing concern about increased competition in Europe when trade barriers fall in 1992, the rise of Japanese auto makers as a global force and the soaring cost of research and development.

title: Warsaw Sinfonia
description: Yehudi Menuhin will conduct the Warsaw Sinfonia in Mendelssohn's Overture to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Lutoslawski's ''Funeral Music,'' the Haydn Symphony No. 104 and the Bruch Violin Concerto at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall. Robert McDuffie is to be the soloist in the Bruch. Tickets are $11 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Lawyers Work to Publicize Risks in Household Products
description: A group of lawyers is calling on its members to become whistle-blowers who bring dangerous products to the attention of state and Federal safety officials.

title: Patents; A Cube Game More Difficult Than Rubik's
description: For people who think Rubik's Cube is too easy to solve, two graduate students patented a new cube puzzle this week that makes the original seem as simple as a picture puzzle.

title: U.S. News Owner Sees End of Turmoil
description: The departure of Roger Rosenblatt as editor of U.S. News & World Report, officially announced yesterday, signals the end of five years of turmoil at the top echelon of the weekly magazine, its owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, said yesterday.

title: From Jet Disaster, an Iowa Family Harvests a Reward
description: As she spoke, Janice Sorenson flashed the broad smile she has worn since Wednesday, the day her harvesting combine bumped into the long-sought fan disk suspected of causing the crash of a United Airlines DC-10 at Sioux City in July.

title: Allen on Injured List
description: The Los Angeles Raiders placed their former All-Pro running back Marcus Allen on injured reserve yesterday because of a torn knee ligament, and he will not be eligible to return until late November.(AP)

title: U.S. Plans A Refuge Of 13 Isles In the Ohio
description: An osprey with a fish in its talons languidly flaps by, well above a stream of acrid smoke belching from a power plant - a juxtaposition of industry and nature that is common here where the Ohio River flows around a string of unspoiled islands.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Questioned In the Slaying of a Minister
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with breaking into a church where a minister was found slain, the police said.

title: U.S. Envoy in Seoul Tells of Raid
description: Ambassador Donald Gregg described today how he and his wife listened from their locked bedroom while militant students broke into their residence and caused about $30,000 damage in the living room early this morning.

title: C. Emil Nelson, Leader In Salvation Army, 83
description: Col. C. Emil Nelson, the former national chief secretary of the Salvation Army, died of complications of heart disease Thursday at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Asbury Park, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Asbury Park.

title: Disabled Newborns Deserve to Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Frederick A. Huettner, Executive, 86
description: Frederick A. Huettner, a former president and director of Selchow & Righter, the Long Island company that manufactured Scrabble, Parchesi and Trivial Pursuit before being bought by Coleco Industries, died Thursday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I., after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Brightwaters, L.I.

title: Hidden Cracks Found in Rotor In Trump Crash
description: One of the four main overhead rotors on the helicopter that crashed on Tuesday in central New Jersey, killing three senior Atlantic City casino executives and two crew members, broke in half in flight because of a series of cracks, Federal investigators said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER, 14, 1989
description: Market Turmoil

title: Campaign Trail; Giuliani Turning Up Heat on Dinkins
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani turned up the heat on David N. Dinkins yesterday, both on the air and on the stump.

title: The Ancillary Race: Winning TV Coverage
description: On Thursday night, television news viewers finally saw Rudolph W. Giuliani in a flattering light. Entering a ballroom full of cheering supporters, the Republican mayoral candidate was escorted to a dais by the President of the United States.

title: Suspended Leader of Navajos Vows to Fight Bribe Charges
description: Peter MacDonald, the suspended tribal Navajo chairman charged with taking more than $400,000 in bribes and kickbacks, says he will ''stand up and fight'' the allegations.

title: Board of Estimate Extends Seaport Historic District by One Block
description: The New York City Board of Estimate has voted to extend the South Street Seaport Historic District by one block, reversing a 1977 decision and confounding the development plans of five major banks.

title: Rutgers Finds Curbs on Student Drinking of Little Effect
description: In the last five years, Rutgers University, long regarded as one of the foremost research centers for alcohol abuse, has also become a model for colleges seeking innovative ideas to help reduce drinking among students.

title: Human-Eye View
description: A special look into the ornithology collection of the American Museum of Natural History, at Central Park West and 79th Street, will be offered this weekend as part of the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Whitney Wing. Staff members will demonstrate how an exhibition is mounted, using the guano island case in the Hall of Oceanic Birds. Also open for viewing will be the Audubon Gallery, which includes more than 150 paintings by Audubon, Louis Agassiz Fuertes, Joseph Wolf and Francis Lee Jaques. There will also be guided tours of the Audubon gallery today and tomorrow at 11:30 A.M. Admission to the museum is by contribution. Information: 769-4864.

title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies
description: The Central Intelligence Agency and other Federal groups have begun using satellites to spy on the maze of clandestine airstrips, roads and factories run by the illicit drug industry in South America.

title: Bouncing Noriega Bush Style
description: I am summoned to deepest Washington. The summoner says he represents the most powerful man imaginable. I tell him sure he does and I am the ghost of the late Henry James and am, therefore, repelled by the vulgar social situation in which we find ourselves.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an increase in the Japanese discount rate misidentified the person who said that while the strength of the dollar was a factor in the increase, other factors were equally important. He was Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, not Susumo Saito of the Credit Suisse Investment Advisory Company.

title: Rose Bowl Bid May Be at Stake
description: It is only the second week of competition in the Big Ten Conference, but there have already been suggestions the title may be decided today when Michigan State is the host team in East Lansing, Mich., to Coach Bo Schembechler's Michigan Wolverines.

title: Keeping Pull Cords Out of Tiny Hands
description: Now that cooler weather is here and children are spending more time indoors it is a good time to see that pull cords for window coverings are safely secured.

title: Ana L. Behrens-Pacanins Is Married To Luis Paraud-Carpena, Developer
description: Ana Luisa Behrens-Pacanins, a daughter of Mrs. Reinaldo Herrera of New York and a stepdaughter of Mr. Herrera, was married in New York yesterday to Luis Felipe Paraud-Carpena, the son of Maj. Gen. Fernando Paraud and Mrs. Paraud of Madrid. The Rev. Damian Myett performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: Golden State Foods Exploring Merger
description: The Golden State Foods Corporation, a privately held food processor and distributor that supplies only McDonald's restaurants, retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it explore merger possibilities. Howard Hansen, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the McDonald's Corporation was an unlikely suitor because it had a policy of not selling supplies or equipment to franchisees. A more likely buyer is another of the restaurant company's many large food suppliers, he said. It is possible, however, that McDonald's executives will help negotiate the sale.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Potting Mixtures
description: Whatever happened to the old standard soil recipe (1-1-1) used for potting house plants and growing seedlings?

title: Beatrice G. Kresky, 73, Pediatrician From L. I.
description: Dr. Beatrice Greenwald Kresky, a pediatrician and proponent of prenatal care for pregnant teen-agers, died of cancer Thursday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. She was 73 years old and lived in Rockville Center, L.I.

title: Robinson Honored
description: Gaston's chief managing rival, Frank Robinson, whose Baltimore Orioles went from last place to second place and improved by 33 games, was named manager of the year by The Associated Press yesterday. Robinson received 69 points and Don Zimmer of the Chicago Cubs received 51 in voting by sportswriters and broadcasters. No other manager reached double figures.

title: Richard F. Uhlmann, Grain Dealer, 91
description: Richard F. Uhlmann, a grain dealer who served as president of the Chicago Board of Trade in 1948, died at Highland Park (Ill.) Hospital on Monday after a brief illness. He was 91 years old.

title: End for 'Junk Bond' Takeovers?
description: Institutional investors behaved yesterday as if the takeover craze had ended. Mindful of recent turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market, they grew concerned that corporate acquisitions, which have done much to drive up stock prices in recent years, would grind to a halt because of a lack of credit.

title: Corrections
description: The Campaign Matters column on Oct. 5, about the issue of ethnic slurs in the campaign for New Jersey governor, referred incorrectly to a 1986 Federal indictment of a union that had contributed money to some campaigns of Representative James J. Florio. The indictment accused leaders of roofers Local 30-30B, based in Philadelphia, of having made payments to a number of public officials, including state judges in Pennsylvania. No Federal judges were accused.

title: Group Fails To Finish UAL Deal
description: The group seeking to acquire the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it had failed to complete the financing of its $6.75 billion buyout. But the group said its banks had advised that the deal could be financed ''on revised terms.''

title: Peugeot in Labor Talks
description: The French car maker Peugeot S.A. opened talks today with unions to resolve a six-week-old strike, after workers ended their 19-day occupation of an important foundry.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

title: KEY RATES
Hills, in Japan, Stirs a Baby-Bottle Dispute
description: In her first visit to Japan as the United States special trade representative, Carla A. Hills faced off today against Japan's hard-nosed bureaucrats. They argued about baby bottles.

title: JAY WARD, 69, THE TV CARTOONIST WHO CREATED BULLWINKLE, IS DEAD
description: Jay Ward, the creator of Bullwinkle and other popular television cartoon characters, died of kidney cancer on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old. Mr. Ward, whose innovative work contributed sophistication and wit to television cartoons for more than three decades, was best known for his series about a bumbling, deep-voiced moose - Bullwinkle - and his sprightly companion, Rocky, the flying squirrel. The duo's exaggerated and satirically drawn sidekicks included the Cold War-vintage spies Boris Badenov and Natasha Fatale and the eternally backward Capt. Peter Peachfuzz.

title: Garcia Case in Deliberations
description: The jury in the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee, began its first day of deliberations yesterday by requesting copies of evidence and asking to hear a reading of key testimony against the Garcias. At 5:20 P.M., the jurors sent out a note which said they could go no further, and Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan sent them home. Deliberations are to resume on Monday.

title: Despite Slip in Polls, Thatcher Is Confident at Party Conference
description: Though her Conservative Party's popularity is in a slump and her Government's policies are in a mess, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher showed no self-doubt and brooked none from her followers at a party conference here that ended today.

title: Wall Street Executives Stress Differences, But Traders Point to Troubling Similarities
description: The parallels were almost eerie: a Friday afternoon in October, the 13th no less, and the stock market suddenly goes into a free fall. In less than an hour, the Dow Jones index had declined by nearly 200 points.

title: Corrections
description: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for the sale of 19th- and 20th-century prints at Sotheby's in Tokyo. It took place yesterday; it is not next Friday.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: U.S. Cites Right to Seize Fugitives Abroad
description: Reversing a nine-year-old policy, the Justice Department has advised the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it may legally seize United States fugitives in foreign countries without the consent of foreign governments, Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Dance; Seoul Group Celebrates Nature
description: The seasons of the year flowed gently by on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. The 88 Seoul Art Troupe evoked the passage of time and the beneficence of nature in ''Dance, Voice of the Earth.''

title: U.S. Aid of $7.1 Billion Given In Deals for 4 Savings Units
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation said today that it had sold the assets and deposits of four insolvent savings institutions in transactions requiring $7.1 billion in Government assistance. These were the first large deals since Congress approved a $50 billion taxpayer bailout package in August.

title: Professor Criticized for Exam on Yom Kippur
description: Harry Edwards, a sociology professor with a reputation for bluntly criticizing racism in professional sports, has been accused of being insensitive to Jewish students in an introductory sociology class at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Warner Bros. Sues Sony Over Producers
description: Warner Brothers Inc., the Hollywood studio owned by Time Warner Inc., filed a $1 billion lawsuit today against the Sony Corporation. The suit contends that Sony induced two Hollywood producers, Peter Guber and Jon Peters, to breach their five-year contract with Warner to become co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures, the studio Sony is in the process of buying.

title: Rangers' Streak Ends as Capitals Take Advantage of Miscues
description: The scoring siren went off so often tonight behind John Vanbiesbrouck that by the end of the third period it sounded like one long scream.

title: Lakers Release Dailey
description: The Los Angeles Lakers ran out of patience with Quintin Dailey yesterday and released the veteran guard. Dailey, signed as a free agent on Sept. 12, began training camp by missing a flight to the team's camp in Honolulu and then dropped out of the first practice early. On Thursday, he overslept and missed a practice.(AP)

title: Pretoria Is Said to Transfer Prisoners
description: The Government was reported today to have moved Walter Sisulu and some other political prisoners to jails near their homes amid speculation that they would be released this weekend.

title: Producer Prices Show A Sharp Rise
description: After three straight declines, prices at the producer level surged nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, mainly because of increases for energy and motor vehicles.

title: Patents; A Specialized Antibody For Cancer Treatment
description: Oncogen, a Seattle-based division of the Bristol-Myers SquibbCompany, received a patent this week for a monoclonal antibody that company officials believe could treat lung and breast cancer.

title: In China, an Inescapable Crisis Bears Down
description: LEAD: A wise Chinese just retired from an official post commented to me in Beijing on the rise and fall of the democracy movement: ''The people underestimated old Deng, and old Deng underestimated the people.''

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.95 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

title: Hyman Solniker, Judge, 82
description: Hyman Solniker, a retired New York City Criminal Court judge, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Merab Kostava, 50, a Soviet Rights Figure
description: Merab Kostava, a leading Georgian human rights campaigner and dissident for more than 30 years, was killed today in a car accident, an independent newspaper said. He was 50 years old.

title: BUSH ON ABORTION: HIS VIEWS THROUGH THE YEARS
description: February 1980

title: Community Mental Health Plan Must Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Opera Seminars At the Guggenheim
description: Philip Glass, Frank Corsaro, Maurice Sendak, Christopher Keene, Erie Mills, John Cheek and others will take part in a series of four seminars on ''Opera in the 20th Century,'' presented by the New York City Opera Guild at the Guggenheim Museum on four successive Mondays at 6 P.M.

title: Population Bomb Keeps Ticking
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Chelsea Lifetime: 81 Years of Love, Survival and Art
description: This is a tale of principles, survival, love, art and, in the most recent chapter, rock music videos and a tire commercial. But it is especially about love.

title: Canadiens Top Devils In Overtime
description: Although Coach Jim Schoenfeld made three significant changes tonight, the Devils failed to find the right combination for a third consecutive game. The result was a 4-3 overtime loss to the Montreal Canadiens, the second successive setback for the Devils, who have one victory in four games (1-2-1) this season.

title: Storm May Cancel a City's Halloween
description: Three weeks after a hurricane battered the Carolina coast, this inland city remains so littered with downed magnolias and willow oaks that officials are asking parents to keep children at home on Halloween.

title: U.S. Plan to Use Eagles in Poison Test Is Protested
description: Federal researchers plan to use 15 injured golden eagles in an experiment that could lead to the renewed use of Compound 1080, a highly toxic coyote poison. The plan is meeting strong opposition from supporters of animal rights.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Medical Warnings
description: Nearly any lapse from good health, with a few exceptions like the early stages of malignant tumors, will show up in one of the basic blood tests that can be performed in a routine physical. Such a blood test is diagnostic; it examines proteins that may not be detrimental to health but that indicate imminent health problems. Here are some common materials traced by such tests. Albumin: A protein manufactured by the liver. Changes in level may be linked to liver disease or poor diet. Calcium: A mineral in blood that comes from bones. Loss of bone tissue can increase levels. Kidney disease and lack of vitamin D can lower levels. Cholesterol: A blood fat tied to eating animal fats. High levels are linked to disturbances of fat metabolism. Clotting factors: Low levels indicate bleeding disorders, like hemophilia. Globulin: Similar to albumin, but contains antibodies. Fluctuations in levels are common. Extreme levels can indicate disease. Glucose: High levels could indicate diabetes. Hemoglobin and iron: Low counts indicate anemia. Triglycerides: Blood fats related more to total calories and starch in diet than to fats. High levels can lead to hardening of the arteries. Uric acid: Excessive amounts in the kidneys can cause stones or, in the joints, gout.

title: Turner Broadcasting Considering Publishing
description: The Turner Broadcasting System is considering starting a book publishing operation, possibly with one or more foreign partners. It is also looking into establishing a prize for works of fiction about the environment, according to Turner executives in Atlanta.

title: Patents; New Flexible Magnet Is Called Stronger
description: Using a rare earth metal, a metallurgist has developed a high-energy flexible magnet that he said could easily be shaped into electronic components.

title: Cairo Says Qaddafi to Visit
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, will visit Egypt on Sunday for the first time in 16 years and hold talks with President Hosni Mubarak, Egyptian officials said today. They said Colonel Qaddafi would meet President Mubarak in Mersa Matruh, a resort on the Mediterranean.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arby's 42 largest franchisees formed a group, A. P. Association Inc., to oppose the continued control of the roast-beef sandwich chain by Victor Posner, chairman of DWG Corp., which controls Arby's.

title: Herbert M. Weed, 68, Anaconda Executive
description: Herbert M. Weed, a former vice president of the Anaconda Company, a leading producer of nonferrous metals and uranium, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Denver. He was 68 years old and lived in Cherry Hills Village, a Denver suburb.

title: Centrust Payouts
description: Centrust Bank of Miami said yesterday that it had been ordered to stop paying dividends on its preferred stock because of financial problems including losses in its holdings of ''junk bonds.'' The order to stop paying dividends came from Federal regulators at the Office of Thrift Supervision. Federal and state regulators are considering a proposal by Centrust to sell 63 of its branches for $150 million to the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think this could be the end of the game.'' - Barbara L. Kenworthy, a portfolio manager, referring to the corporate takeover frenzy. [ 33:3. ]

title: Chrysler Price Rise
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it was raising its 1990 passenger car prices an overall 5 percent from comparably equipped 1989 models. It attributed 3 percent of the increase to the installation of driver-side supplementary air bag systems as standard equipment on all of its United States-built cars. Chrysler said the suggested retail base price of its Dodge Omni America four-door hatchback at the low end of its offerings would rise to $6,995, from $6,595 in 1989, while its Chrysler Lebaron convertible GTC would increase to $20,052 from $19,666.

title: Carl Newton, Lawyer, Dies at 91; A Mining Official in Roosevelt Era
description: Carl E. Newton, a New York lawyer for more than half a century who served as Deputy Coal Administrator in Washington during World War II, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Reviews/Music; The American Premiere Of an 1869 Musical Camel
description: The ''Messa per Rossini'' that the New York Philharmonic presented under Helmuth Rilling's baton on Thursday evening is a musical camel, an improbable animal designed by a committee. A collaboration by 13 Italian composers in memory of Rossini, it is a Requiem Mass of gangling proportions instigated by Verdi, who wrote the final section.
