Intended for performance in 1869 on the first anniversary of Rossini's death, the work was abandoned and never heard.

title: Inmates in Jersey City Set Fires in an Uprising
description: Inmates at the Hudson County Jail in Jersey City set fires in their cells last night and confronted guards and firefighters when they arrived to extinguish them, a prison spokesman said.

title: O'Brien Hints He's a Scapegoat
description: Ken O'Brien, distressed at losing his job as the Jets' starting quarterback, conceded today that ''the thought of being traded had crossed my mind.'' But he also said he was willing to wait to see how the situation was resolved.

title: RESUTLS PLUS
description: TENNIS Fernandez Beats Seles: Mary Joe Fernandez outlasted Monica Seles, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6, yesterday to earn a semifinal berth at the International tournament in Filderstadt, West Germany. In other quarterfinal matches, Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina beat Hana Mandlikova of Australia, 6-3, 6-0; Zina Garrison beat Gigi Fernandez, 6-4, 6-2, and Laura Gildermeister of Peru beat Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 2-6, 7-5.(AP) Lendl to Semifinal: Ivan Lendl defeated Thomas Hogstedt of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday and advanced to the semifinals of the Australian indoor championship in Sydney. (AP) Winning Rally in Moscow: Gretchen Magers rallied from a 4-6, 0-3 deficit and won a quarterfinal match yesterday in Moscow in the Soviet Union's first professional tennis tournament. She defeated Laura Golarsa of Italy, 4-6, 7-6, 6-3.(AP) BOXING Breland Retains Title: Mark Breland, showing no ill effects from a stomach infection that almost led him to cancel the bout, defended his World Boxing Association welterweight title yesterday by stopping Mauro Martelli of Italy in the second round of a scheduled 12-round bout in Geneva. The referee, John Coyle of England, halted the fight 1:15 into the second round after Breland floored his opponent. It was Breland's 25th victory, 19 by knockout, in 27 pro fights.(AP) SOCCER Princeton 4, Columbia 3: Andrew Dechet scored on a penalty kick with 2 minutes 37 seconds left in the match to lead the Tigers to an upset victory last night at Princeton, N.J. The teams are tied for first place in the Ivy League at 3-1. Columbia, the 19th-ranked team in the nation, fell to 6-3 over all. Princeton is 6-1.

title: Aristech Shares Climb Sharply
description: The Aristech Chemical Corporation's stock rose today, one day after the company received a $25-a-share offer valued at $817.5 million, but some analysts said it would probably reject the bid from an investment group led by Jon Huntsman, chairman of the closely held Huntsman Chemical of Salt Lake City.

title: Mi Selecto, at 9-1, Captures Meadowlands Cup
description: Mi Selecto led a parade of long shots under the wire tonight in the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup at Meadowlands Race Track, while Blushing John finished a distant seventh as the 3-to-5 favorite.

title: Before There Were Subways, There Was a Subway Series
description: The public has been well informed, by now, that this World Series between the San Francisco Giants and Oakland Athletics, which begins tonight in Oakland, is the first confined to a single metropolitan area since 1956, when the New York Yankees faced the Brooklyn Dodgers. But what about the first one? It took place exactly 100 years ago.

title: Haas & Partners Ends Intertech Bid
description: The Commercial Intertech Corporation, a maker of engineered metal components, said Haas & Partners had advised the company that it does not intend to pursue its efforts to acquire control of Commercial Intertech. The Texas-based Haas group offered to acquire Commercial Intertech late last month for $27.50 a share. At that point, Commercial Intertech said it was not for sale. Analysts said then that they did not expect the deal to be completed because the Haas group said it preferred to pursue a friendly bid.

title: Christian Concern on Syria Delaying Lebanese Accord
description: Christian insistence on guarantees of a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon continued to hold up an agreement among Lebanon's factions today, but Arab officials expressed optimism that the sides would agree on a new charter for their nation.

title: A Bumpy Journey to the Jets
description: Kyle Mackey's father, Dee, caught Joe Namath's tosses in the 1960's. But that was as close to being involved in the Jets' passing game as Kyle ever imagined he would get.

title: Bolar: A Drug Company Under Seige
description: For more than a year, the Food and Drug Administration and the House of Representatives Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations have been reporting evidence of unethical behavior at generic drug companies.

title: Rewriting the Rules of Retailing
description: There is no happier sound to the merchant's ear than that of a constantly ringing cash register.

title: Hong Kong Boat People Fast To Protest Return to Vietnam
description: More than 11,000 Vietnamese boat people in detention centers here staged a hunger strike today to protest repatriation to their homeland, officials said.

title: Nicaraguans at Rebel Camp Are Asked to Disband
description: In their first face-to-face visit with Nicaraguan rebel troops, a special commission of international officials came to this rugged mountain camp today to urge the fighters to accept a recent regional agreement calling for the disbanding of their army.

title: Martha J. Brackenridge Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Bruce Brackenridge of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Martha Jane Brackenridge and Austin Bartholomew Sayre 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sayre Jr. of Westfield, N.J.

title: Supervisor Campaigns Under Way in 17 Towns
description: LEAD: FROM Pelham to Pound Ridge, more than half of the 17 races for town supervisor this year are dominated by Republican incumbents seeking re-election. Democrats, meanwhile, are mounting strong challenges in several contests and are trying to remain in power in Mamaroneck and New Castle, where the incumbent

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: According to President Truman, his successor pushed Castro into the arms of the Soviets. He believes this could have been prevented if only Eisenhower had befriended Castro and showered him with financial assistance.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: 'Proust Project' in New Haven
description: IN ''The Proust Project: Remembrance of Things (Past): Part 1: Combray'' - now there's a title - images and sometimes Proustian lines waft through what is, so far, the writer and director Michael Rush's own vision of things past, present and future.

title: Import What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Recycling at Home, in Your Spare Time
description: EVERYBODY is talking garbage. Conversations on this delicate topic were once limited to direct dealers, but with recycling, it's everyone down to the dump.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Friendly Tavern on the Delaware
description: LEAD: IT is easy to miss the Raubsville Tavern on the Delaware, situated as it is just off Route 611 in Pennsylvania, on a small strip of land in Northampton County between the Delaware River and its canal. It is reached by turning on River Road, which crosses the canal bridge. Unlike many restaurants in this area that ooze charm, the Raubsville

title: Hong Kong Needs Britain's Guarantees
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan J. Israel Is Wed To Daniel R. Scherlis
description: Susan J. Israel and Daniel R. Scherlis, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Scherlis of Baltimore, were married last evening in Chestnut Hill, Mass., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Israel. Rabbi Roland Gittelsohn officiated.

title: One Dies, 5 Hurt as Violent Storms Cross Upstate Counties
description: Violent thunderstorms ripped across a wide swath of upstate New York this evening, bringing winds that reached 85 miles an hour, heavy rain and hail and leaving at least one person dead and five others injured. Power was cut off to thousands of residents.

title: Veronica Schaaf Is Married to Wayne M. Bloom
description: Veronica Louise Schaaf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Perkins Schaaf of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Wayne Michael Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Bloom of Taunton, Mass. Judge Steven M. Honeg of Municipal Court in Upper Saddle River, N.J., officiated at the Central Unitarian Church in Paramus, N.J.

title: Biotech Goes Begging
description: A revived market for initial public offerings has yielded scant benefit for biotechnology companies. Investors perceive biotech as a high-risk business where young companies, lacking revenues and earnings from products, are difficult to evaluate by conventional means.

title: Searching for Ancestors Is Made a Bit Easier
description: It might not have taken Estelle M. Guzik seven years to trace her family tree if there had been a guide to genealogical resources. Now, she has edited one. The guide, Genealogical Resources in the New York Metropolitan Area, was published by the Jewish Genealogical Society and offers information on more than 100 research centers in and around New York, including libraries, archives, government agencies and courts.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: Kids need heroes today more than ever. With temptations like drugs and alcohol it is important for young people to have someone to look up to and admire. Since the world of sports is so appealing to youth, I think it's O.K. for baseball to have showmen. LORRAINE MYERS Bellmore, N.J.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Winthrop, Me.; Main St. Renewal
description: A BUILDING that for decades dominated Main Street in this central Maine city has been moved back 150 feet to make room for a parking lot, dramatically changing the streetscape and making some residents unhappy.

title: CHOOSING SIDES IN NICARAGUA
description: MEMOIRS OF A COUNTERREVOLUTIONARY By Arturo Cruz Jr. 266 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: A GASTRONOME, A MAGICIAN AND A FIRST LADY: DETECTIVES AND THEIR DAY JOBS
description: Homicide cops get a pension, and hard-boiled private eyes don't expect to live long enough to retire. But amateur detectives who hope to survive in their competitive genre find it helps to have a steady day job.

title: Sandra Joy Horbach Wed to S. F. Skoler
description: Sandra Joy Horbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Horbach of Bellevue, Wash., was married in New York last evening to Steven Frederick Skoler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Skoler of White Plains. Rabbi Charles G. Agin officiated at the Pierre.

title: 'Broadway Bound,' Simon's Third 'BB'
description: CONTINUING what has become a Long Island theater tradition, the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is producing the latest Neil Simon play as soon as the rights are released to the regional theaters.

title: Tour Bus Accident Injures 42
description: A tour bus swerved out of control and flipped on its side today on a rain-slickened interstate, injuring all 42 people aboard, officials said. Robert Forbuss, president of Mercy Ambulance, said the 41 passengers and the driver were taken to four hospitals. The worst injury reported was a pelvic fracture. The driver said he lost control when he braked for a car in front of him.

title: Congress Skirts And May Revise Law on Deficit
description: Just as Congress completes one of its most embarrassing failures to meet the requirements of the deficit-reduction law, lawmakers in both parties appear to be focusing seriously on ways to change the statute.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: What baseball needs today is a clean-cut look. Getting rid of the long-haired and bearded image of the players would automatically remove the ''showy'' aspect of the game.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; For Day of Rest, Beef Dish That Almost Cooks Itself
description: Weekends are the only time many people have to prepare dishes that require long, slow cooking. The best kind are those that take very little time to assemble and can be pretty much left unwatched on the stove.

title: In Ethiopia, a P.O.W. at 15
description: LEAD: Mohammed Omar, Abu Michael, and Thebethe Sawra passed their 15th birthdays this past year in captivity.

title: POSTINGS: From Classes to Co-ops; Restoring a Landmarked Public School
description: Those who cherish New York City's architectural treasures have long bemoaned the deterioration of buildings like the former P.S. 9 in Brooklyn, a Renaissance Revival edifice on Vanderbilt Avenue and Sterling Place in Prospect Heights.

title: How to Blend Pros Into the Olympics
description: A nation's Olympic program must have a single standard, regardless of the sport and its importance. It is hard to visualize a highly visible, nationally and internationally recognized superstar with a $2 million-plus income being treated the same as an Olympic performer who may be a substitute on a much less visible or popular sport. But that's the way it is supposed to work.

title: Remembering the Relocation Camps
description: MANY Americans have only recently begun to learn the full story of Japanese-American internment by the United States Government during World War II. Scattered in the county are Japanese-American residents who were among the 110,000 people - the majority American citizens - forced from their West Coast homes into makeshift barracks and confined behind barbed wire for periods up to three years.

title: Gonzalez to Offer Advice To Bush on Latin America
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez says he will argue that Nicaragua's coming elections offer an opportunity to break the current Central American deadlock when he meets President Bush at the White House on Thursday.

title: Stewart Stops Giants in Series Opener
description: This time, the Oakland Athletics were not bitten by a ninth-inning home run. Kirk Gibson did not grab a bat, did not hobble out of the dugout and did not break the A's hearts with one dramatic swing. This time, they held on.

title: Spain's Prosperity Comes a Measure of Pain
description: Streets crowded with new cars and restaurants crowded with new rich, foreign capital pouring in and stock markets taking off, luxury apartments at Fifth Avenue prices and stylish young people in the latest designs.

title: LEARNING FROM HISTORY: What Post-Modernism Means now
description: While the post-modern architecture of the late 1970's and early 80's was based on historical forms, they were often presented in an exaggerated, somewhat humorous manner. ''Today, post-modernism is no longer a cartoon,'' says Mark Simon, a partner of Centerbrook, an Essex, Conn., architectural concern. When the early post-modernists used a column, for example, their version was often overscaled and decorative, sometimes even flattened onto a wall; now, a post-modern architect would be inclined to design a column with more sensible proportions and use it as a structural support. As the decade comes to a close, post-modernists are still borrowing from the past, but in more subtle ways. And their message is clear: The joke is over.

title: As the Charter Vote Nears, New Yorkers Still Argue
description: NEW YORKERS will be asked on Election Day to choose not only a new mayor but also the form of government over which he will preside. A proposal to revise the City Charter - the most sweeping change in the structure of municipal government since the turn of the century - will be on the ballot.

title: Back in Business
description: He may have been forced to resign as basketball coach at the University of Kentucky after it was found that his program was riddled with rules violations, but that doesn't mean that Eddie Sutton is no longer a welcome figure in the world of college basketball.

title: Say 'Be Careful,' Hope They're Safe
description: I DIDN'T know her very well. Christine was another teen-ager who lived in the neighborhood. A 16-year-old girl who was friends with my stepdaughter.

title: Opposition in India Fears Electronic Vote Fraud
description: The leader of India's political opposition, fearing electronic vote fraud in the coming national election, said today that he would oppose the use of computerized voting machines unless their design and programming could be checked by independent experts.

title: Review/Theater Humor and Dark Vision In 2 Portuguese Plays
description: If there ever was a playwright who could find evil in a bright field of wild flowers or corruption in a baby's breath, it was that scourge of Brazil, Nelson Rodrigues. There could hardly be a better introduction to his work than the two plays - ''Family Album'' and ''All Nudity Will Be Punished'' - that the Brazilian director Antunes Filho has combined under the title ''Nelson 2 Rodrigues.''

title: Marxist Thought Finds an Unlikely Godmother
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for Prime Time
description: Ever since a ''Today'' dawned last August with a new female cast member, the show's longtime co-anchor, Jane Pauley, has been rumored variously to be miffed to the point of quitting or just making a mid-career reassessment. For weeks, Ms. Pauley said little to dampen the speculation that she would be moving on after she suddenly found herself sharing the set with Deborah Norville, a 31-year-old, million-dollar-a-year newsreader. Last week, NBC more or less confirmed that Ms. Pauley will leave ''Today'' to become part of a new prime-time news progam next summer. Despite persistent rumors that she felt ill-treated by the hiring of Ms. Norville, Ms. Pauley insisted that the move to a new NBC show after 13 years of ''Today'' was a plus. ''My horizons have expanded,'' she said. ''I'm thinking beyond today.''

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE NO. 10 BUS;
A Route Is Revived to Lure Commuters From Their Cars
description: LEAD: IT'S 6:30 A.M. The rain is pelting the empty sidewalks. The sky is still dark. Yorktown Hall is locked tight. But across Underhill Avenue, a small crowd is beginning to gather.

title: The Prescription for Bed Rest
description: I AM at home, confined to my bed and recovering from an accident that injured two areas of my back. Although the diagnosis revealed nothing broken - just a deep bone bruise and severe muscle sprain - my back disapproves when moving in various undefined directions.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: JUSTICE VS. JUSTICE
description: THE ANTAGONISTS Hugo Black, Felix Frankfurter and Civil Liberties in Modern America. By James F. Simon. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Margaret L. Ford Marries a Lawyer
description: Margaret Lane Ford, a consultant on bibliographies, and John Gillespie Stewart, an associate at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, were married yesterday at the Greenville (Del.) Country Club. The Rev. Robert M. Doss, a Unitarian minister, officiated. The bride, 31 years old and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lane Ford of Wilmington, Del., will keep her name. She graduated from Smith College and received a master's degree in comparative literature from the City University of New York. Her father is a market manager in international sales for Du Pont.

title: Toward Smaller Lawns and Nurseries
description: ON MANY A HOT SUMMER day, the crews of so-called landscaping services can be seen tending lawns on the street where I live.

title: Losing Streak Isn't Any More
description: Fitchburg State ended the nation's longest current college losing streak at 36 games today with a 33-7 victory over Southeastern Massachusetts.

title: POSTINGS: Homes in the Ramapos; 4- to 14-Acre Lots
description: Late in the 18th century, members of the Pierson family acquired a large chunk of what is now Sterlington in Rockland County, N.Y. They used the streams of the Ramapo Mountains to power their forges to make nails and hardwood from the forests to fire their charcoal kilns.

title: 3 Flown to U.S. To Be Charged As Drug Sellers
description: As the latest drug war in Colombia was entering its ninth week, three people sought as low-ranking cocaine traffickers were flown here today from Bogota in a United States marshals' jet to face Federal charges in Florida and Michigan.

title: Bolar: A Drug Company Under Siege
description: FOR more than a year, the Food and Drug Administration and the House of Representatives Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations have been reporting evidence of unethical behavior at generic drug companies.

title: Bush Keeping Chemical Arms Option
description: In an effort to support the Pentagon's program to develop a new chemical bomb, President Bush has decided to retain the option to produce chemical weapons after a treaty to phase out such arms takes effect, Administration officials said today.

title: Miss Brownstein, Lawyer, Marries
description: Nancy Anne Brownstein, an associate at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, and Kevin Patrick Mallery, an associate at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, both New York law firms, were married in Lenox, Mass., yesterday. George Lee, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Cranwell Resort and Hotel.

title: Child's Play in Paris
description: WITH the birth of our son, Nicky, we said goodbye to our yearly trips to France. There would be no more lingering over cups of cafe noir, no more walking along the Seine at 4 A.M., holding hands. Under the heading of what our travel agent calls family vacations, Martin, Nicky and I have danced the Bunny Hop with Roger Rabbit, wrenched our backs on Tilt-a-Whirls, fed smelts to Shamu and been photographed in sepia tones dressed up like Belle Starr and the James gang. One morning Nicky looked up from his bowl of the Real Ghost Busters cereal to announce, ''I know where I want to go next. Matthew said they have a Black Ninja roller coaster at Magic Mountain that goes upside down.''

title: When the Aged Need Care, Their Families Need a Hand
description: A WOMAN in Middlesex County has worked for her company 10 years. Over the last two years, she has spent much of her time caring for her widowed mother, who is partly paralyzed from a stroke. Her mother has become confused, and she fears being left alone in the house they share.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LITTLE ODESSA, by Joseph Koenig. (Ballantine, $3.95.) A Times Square stripper from Brooklyn's Russian emigre community is recruited by the F.B.I. for an investigation that climaxes with a Coney Island roller-coaster ride. This is ''a highly readable, beautifully written book,'' Newgate Callendar said here in 1988. BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Signet/New American Library, $5.95.) Rob Marshall, a wealthy New Jersey suburbanite, arranges to have his wife, Maria, shot to death during a faked robbery. Earlier this year our reviewer, Anne Rice, said this true crime story ''offers suspenseful and engrossing reading, with a courtroom drama that is cathartic as well as gripping. . . . Rob Marshall emerges as a monster by anyone's standards, a deeply flawed and subsequently dangerous individual who was apparently incapable of realizing on any moral level what the murder of his wife really meant.'' Signet has also published a new edition of FATAL VISION ($5.95), Mr. McGinniss's story of Jeffrey MacDonald, the Green Beret physician convicted of killing his pregnant wife and two children in 1970 and blaming drug-crazed hippies for the crime. In a new epilogue the author rebuts a New Yorker article published this year in which Janet Malcolm accused him of tricking Mr. MacDonald into thinking the book would exonerate him. ''Even though the doctor's ulterior motive was clearly to use [ the ] friendship for the purpose of proving his innocence, there are bound to be those readers who feel that Mr. McGinniss has exploited and betrayed a friendship,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times in 1983. ''But 'Fatal Vision' smells of integrity, and that's one of the many things about it that make it irresistible.'' Also available from New American Library is a new edition of GOING TO EXTREMES ($8.95), Mr. McGinniss's 1980 book about Alaska. SOMETHING IN THE AIR, by Emma Lathen. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) The executive vice president of an investment company wonders who killed an outspoken employee of a small airline trying to close a big financial deal. ''I've never been a big mystery fan,'' our reviewer, Wendy Wasserstein, said last year. But Emma Lathen, a pseudonym shared by Mary Jane Latsis, an economist, and Martha Henissart, a lawyer, ''spins an observant tale of financial and criminal intrigue.'' PUZZLE FOR PLAYERS, by Patrick Quentin. (International Polygonics, $5.95.) Preparations for a play called ''Troubled Waters'' are interrupted by a series of mysterious deaths. In 1938, our reviewer, Isaac Anderson, said the ''baffling mystery . . . presents a vivid picture of a play being built in rehearsal and of the problems faced by the author, the producer and the members of the cast.'' Patrick Quentin was a pen name shared by Hugh Callingham Wheeler, who wrote ''Sweeney Todd,'' and Richard Wilson Webb. DEATH TAKES THE STAGE, by Donald Ward. (St. Martin's, $7.95.) This murder mystery takes place in the kinkier strata of Los Angeles's theater community, and the sleuth is a Hollywood agent. ''There are indications that Mr. Ward, to whom nothing seems holy, is kidding around with the private-eye genre,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. ''Have a ball. A fresh new talent has arrived.'' AT DEATH'S DOOR, by Robert Barnard. (Dell, $3.95.) A West End actress arrives at her former lover's home in a small English village to put a stop to a tell-all biography being written by the illegitimate daughter produced by the affair. Last year The Times's John Gross said that ''Mr. Barnard resolves the mystery with practiced ingenuity, rousing suspicions, confirming some of them, deflecting others, making you wonder whether there isn't a second riddle wrapped in the original enigma.'' THE SPY WHO GOT AWAY: The True Story of the Only CIA Agent to Defect to the Soviet Union, by David Wise. (Avon, $4.95.) With the help of the F.B.I., the C.I.A. mishandled an embittered former agent named Edward Lee Howard who fled to Moscow with agency secrets. This account leaves you ''first in helpless laughter - and finally, it has to be said, in helpless rage at the arrogance and apparent incompetence of our homegrown spymasters and counterintelligence wizards,'' Peter Maas said in The Book Review in 1988. GENERAL MURDERS, by Loren D. Estleman. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) Earlier this year our reviewer, Edna Stumpf, said the best of this collection of Amos Walker murder stories is ''The Prettiest Dead Girl in Detroit.'' The author's ''genius seems to reside in his devotion: he slavishly imitates Raymond Chandler and handles the inherent sentimentality of his enterprise with becoming reticence.'' SPRING HARROWING, by Phoebe Atwood Taylor. (Foul Play Press/Countryman, $5.95.) On Cape Cod a man is found clawed to death after his neighbor's two bobcats are set free. ''You will have a mighty good time reading the story, although there will be moments when you may fear that you are going mad,'' Isaac Anderson said in these pages in 1939. Foul Play Press has reissued another mystery featuring the sleuth Asey Mayo, THE DEADLY SUNSHADE ($5.95), published in 1940, in which the victim is found dead beneath her beach umbrella. THE THIRD GENERATION, by Chester Himes. (Thunder's Mouth, $11.95.) The writer who made his mark with ''Cotton Comes to Harlem'' and other novels about crime in far northwest Manhattan called this ''my autobiographical novel.'' In 1954 our reviewer, John Brooks, said the searing story of a black professor whose wife tries to pass for white ''shows how increasingly firm a position he deserves among American novelists.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: Of course. And the showiest of all are the Mets, whose players find it necessary to take a curtain call after every home run hit at Shea. The Met ''sluggers'' could all learn a lesson from Roger Maris, who had to be coaxed out of the dugout at Yankee Stadium to take a bow after his 61st. ROBIN RUBINSTEIN ERIC S. HUTNER New York

title: Karen A. Handel Plans a Wedding
description: Karen A. Handel and Michael S. Baker, graduates of Boston University, plan to be married next month, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morton Handel of West Hartford, Conn., have announced. Mr. Baker is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis K. Baker of Cumberland, R.I.

title: PHILIP MARLOWE IS BACK, AND IN TROUBLE
description: POODLE SPRINGS By Raymond Chandler and Robert B. Parker. 268 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: June Balyk, Banker, Is Wed
description: June Virginia Balyk, a daughter of Edward Joseph Balyk of Union, N.J., and the late Helen Agnes Balyk, was married yesterday to Scott Vincent Martin, the son of Dr. Daniel S. Martin of New York and Bette Finch Martin of Miami. Judge Megdalia Maldonado of Civil Court in New York officiated at the Parc Vendome in New York. The bride, 34 years old, will retain her name. She is an assistant vice president at the Bankers Trust Company. Her husband, 38, is the president of Western Technology Brokers, a New York software sales and marketing firm.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: It's the rare photographer who hasn't been moved by the glow of the setting sun or by rays of sunlight striking a colorful flower arrangement on the kitchen table. In such cases, using flash would only spoil the effect, so the designers of cameras with built-in flash units have provided ways to keep the flash from firing.

title:
GARDENING;
Autumn in Palest Gold to Deepest Sienna
description: LEAD: IT usually begins with the red maples, first appearing at higher altitudes like in the Poconos, often as early as late August. By the time that the last of this species has developed its autumnal brilliance, other species have added yellows, golds, oranges, reds and browns to the display. Depending on the weather, the display may last from three to six weeks before the leaves fall to the ground, providing sustenance for the multitude of funguses, bacteria, earthworms and other creatures that inhabit and improve the soil.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles. Last year, we hired a professional to repaint. He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint. Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun. The painter says this is owing to moisture and that there is a new sealer that will correct this. What is your opinion?

title: WINDY CITY, SUBTLE PRIEST
description: CARDINAL BERNARDIN Easing Conflicts - and Battling for the Soul of American Catholicism. By Eugene Kennedy. 316 pp. Chicago: Bonus Books. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: An illustration on Sept. 24 in The Business World, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about German and Japanese investment in the United States, showed the West German flag upside down. The top stripe should be black, the middle stripe red and the bottom stripe gold.

title: Physics Takes a Step, Leaves a Mess
description: USING particle accelerators to advance through realms of higher and higher energies, scientists hope to reach a place on the far horizon where temperatures are close to those that existed at the beginning of time. From this cosmic vantage point, the universe's perplexing variety of particles and energies would melt together, revealing themselves as splinters of one primordial superforce that shattered just after the Big Bang.

title: Secret Beijing Report Assails Ousted Party Leader
description: A secret Government report has been issued bitterly attacking the ousted Communist Party leader, Zhao Ziyang, for economic mismanagement. It is a new step in the campaign to hold Mr. Zhao responsible for China's economic and political problems.

title: TRADITION WITH A TWIST: Paring It Down
description: As a reaction to the cluttered English country-house style so popular five years ago, a new breed of traditionalists is making news with their pared-down interiors. While firmly rooted in the foundations of good design, their rooms are surprisingly restrained. Sparsely furnished and without a myriad of patterned fabrics and wallpapers, they are at once tailored and elegant. The work of the design team Jeffrey Bilhuber and Tom Scheerer is one example. ''We use tradition as a springboard to create something that is quite new,'' says Bilhuber.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Drug Figures Sent to U.S.

title: 'There Was a Silent Majority Out There'
description: IN his seven years in the Florida State House of Representatives, Robert J. Shelley has been a strong opponent of abortion and has cast votes to restrict it, including one last year to require girls younger than 18 years old to obtain the consent of a parent or a judge before having an abortion.

title: A Trattoria-Pizzeria With a View
description: THOUGH the surroundings at Doc's are minimal - a small frame house with plain pine floors, mismatched chairs painted apple green, framed posters and butcher-paper table covers - the pizzeria has head-on views of scenic Lake Waramaug and classical music as a backdrop to dinner.

title: Drug Cops, Not Drug Soldiers
description: Drug agents, having penetrated the radio network of cocaine middlemen, spread the word that all should report to the jungle clearing at an appointed hour. No one suspected the trap, and when the dealers arrived, local narcotics police and American agents were waiting to make quick arrests. The cops kept violence to a minimum. Though some dealers resisted, there were no deaths or serious injuries. The agents carefully took custody of drugs and weapons for possible use as evidence and, more important, for whatever information they might yield.

title: India's Parliamentary Ways Are Yielding to Other Forces
description: AS the political crisis enveloping Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi deepened last week, with newspapers reporting that efforts to cover up kickbacks from a Swedish arms deal reached higher and higher in his administration, there was one place that the hottest topic in this parliamentary democracy was barely discussed at all. In Parliament.

title: Helping Out
description: As any number of disabled jockeys and exercise riders can attest, riding thoroughbreds is a dangerous occupation fraught with potental injuries requiring expensive rehabilitation programs and equipment. That's why as soon as the ninth race has been run at Santa Anita race track in California today, the track's jockeys will assemble for a softball game.

title: Works in Progress; Once and Future Luxury
description: IT IS ONE OF THOSE HOTELS with a historical roster of famous guests. Edison and Marconi, Enrico Caruso and Sarah Bernhardt, Will Rogers and Mark Twain, Andrew Carnegie and J. P. Morgan, William Jennings Bryan and Oliver Wendell Holmes, not to mention royalty from several nations, 10 American Presidents, Winston Churchill, Nikita Khrushchev and Madame Chiang Kai-shek: all stayed at San Francisco's Palace Hotel (now the Sheraton Palace) between Oct. 2, 1875, when it opened, and last Jan. 9, when it closed for massive renovations.

title: POSTINGS: Greenbelt Addition; 99 Camping Years
description: Because 74 acres near the Todt Hill residential section of Staten Island are now off limits to developers, thousands of needy youngsters for the next 99 years can look forward to going to the 18-acre nondenominational Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds within it.

title: THE WEIRD, THE BAD AND THE SCARY
description: ''Here's your basic convict,'' Sam Cornish said. ''This ghoul here is our own design. Over there is Lucky Lemon Lio. That's for next year. If you need a barbarian ax or some monster hands, they're over against the wall.''

title: On the Trail of History (There Will Be a Quiz)
description: LEAD: EVAN GREEBEL had been a Boy Scout for eight years when he began searching for a project to fulfill the requirements for the Eagle Scout Award, Scouting's highest honor. He found the perfect subject right in his own backyard.

title: Islanders, Ahead by 3, Settle for a Tie
description: After the young Islanders squandered a 3-0 lead in their home opener and settled for a 3-3 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers today, the veterans Bryan Trottier and Don Maloney chose to stress the positive view that comes with experience.

title: Mandarich Hoping to Be Village Hero
description: When Tony Mandarich strapped his helmet to his head and jogged onto the white-lined turf for a third-down play last Sunday, the Green Bay Packer fans at Lambeau Field shouted ''Tony! Tony!'' and clapped in anticipation.

title: Lauren Fields Is Wed To Lawrence M. Talve
description: Lauren Anne Fields, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon J. Fields of New York, was married in New York last evening to Lawrence Mark Talve, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Talve of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Susan Talve, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated at the Plaza.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GILBERT & SULLIVAN

title: Who Are the Refugees, And Who's Going to Pay?
description: IN 1980, when Congress established a comprehensive policy on refugees, there was widespread agreement that the Federal Government should pay for their resettlement because the decision to admit them was made entirely by Federal officials. But that consensus is coming under severe strain as the Federal Government cuts payments for refugees' health, education and welfare expenses.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: I can't think what possessed Margaret Truman, a woman I much admire (''He Didn't Like Ike,'' by Harry S. Truman, Sept. 17). Her article reveals much more about Truman than about Eisenhower. Truman has always been known as a hothead, given to instant reactions, but these papers show him to be bitter and censorious as he played armchair quarterback during his retirement.

title: FICTION
description: BLACK GIRL, WHITE GIRL. By Patricia Moyes. (Holt, $15.95.) In her 18th novel featuring Detective Chief Superintendent Henry Tibbett, the veteran mystery writer Patricia Moyes moves her urban hero from the dreariness of winter in London to the decidedly sunnier island of Tampica, the languid, imaginary Caribbean paradise that also served as the setting for her 1977 novel, ''The Coconut Killings.'' Posing as ''refugees from the English weather'' who are ''rich and stupid, as well as conventional and snobbish,'' Henry and Emmy, his partner in sleuthing as well as marriage, attempt to help their old friend Lucy Pontefract-Deacon, an elderly eccentric who claims her life is being threatened by a Government-sponsored cocaine ring. Meticulous and savvy as ever, Henry soon suspects that some of his own colleagues are involved in certain shipping operations on the island (so ''very conveniently situated'' between South America and the United States) and that his survival depends on trusting no one. In addition to masquerading as a drug-runner himself, he must (horror of horrors) actually lie to Emmy. As for Emmy, she must resort at one point to offering cocaine (the ''white girl'' of the title) as a bribe. In ''Black Girl, White Girl,'' Ms. Moyes handles these indecorous events with her usual decorum; that is, with a minimum of violence and fuss. One of the deftest practitioners of the British procedural detective novel, she somehow manages to make drug dealing seem more like bad manners than bad morals.

title: The Next Wave From Vietnam: A New Disability
description: WHEN Nguyen Van Be, once a colonel in the South Vietnamese army, emerged from 13 years in a re-education camp last year, he wrote to his wife in Washington, wondering how to fit into a world that had left him behind. ''He feels he got lost somewhere,'' says his wife. ''He feels like someone from the jungle.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: EIGHTY-EIGHT STEPS TO SEPTEMBER By Jan Marino. 154 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Miss Powers Wed To A. F. Gallivan
description: Mary Virginia Powers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Powers Jr. of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Francis Gallivan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Xavier Gallivan of Newburgh, N.Y.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $395,000 84 Frame Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 39-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, deck, workshop, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $6,625. Cross River, N.Y. $380,000 Waccabuc Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; 2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen, family room, full basement w/wet bar, 2 decks, 2-car garage, 10.3 acres; taxes $7,326. South Salem, N.Y. $585,000 Bouton Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 56-year-old Cape Cod; library, maid's room, 5-room barn/cottage, 3-car garage; taxes $7,908. Colchester, Conn. $265,000 62 Ventura Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; c/a, greenhouse-style solarium, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. East Haddam, Conn. $142,000 94 Falls Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 200-year-old Cape Cod; log construction in main living area, fieldstone fireplace, 1.2 acres; taxes $1,090. Haddam, Conn. $121,500 54 Old Turnpike Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 57-year-old bungalow; 2-car detached garage, needs work, 0.75 acre; taxes $794. OTHER AREAS Levittown, L.I. $157,000 20 Springtime Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,200. Mineola, L.I. $170,000 119 Wheeler Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $1,700. Springfield, N.J. $315,000 3 Little Brook Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; c/a, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $5,415.

title: Miss Sullivan Becomes Bride
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Mariellen Margaret Sullivan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry F. Sullivan of Chicago and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Noble Olds Carpenter Jr., a son of Mr. Carpenter of Canton, Ohio, and the late Ann L. Carpenter. The Rev. James Carney performed the ceremony.

title: Interned Artists, Devoid of Grievance
description: ''WE had to make friends with the wild creatures in the camp, especially the spiders, mice and rats, because we were outnumbered.''

title:
DINING OUT;
Something a Little Special in Rye Brook
description: LEAD: THE glass cases displaying wild game have been relocated and ecru walls have replaced, to less effect, those of deep forest green. Otherwise the decor remains untouched since Mallards's opening six years ago, this handsome dining room leaving very little room for improvement. Soft lighting, cattails etched magnificently into a mirrored wall, comfortable chairs, illuminated paintings and burnished pillars provide a serene backdrop for gracious dining, and the kitchen often lives up to the expectations these amenities suggest.

title: Boy Scouts Weigh Sale of Several Properties
description: LEAD: THE Westchester-Putnam Council of the Boy Scouts of America is contemplating selling some of its properties, including its headquarters on North Street in White Plains and Camp Siwanoy in Wingdale, in Dutchess County.

title: The Big Race To Drive Jaguar
description: British car maker Jaguar P.L.C. has almost no money, tiny production facilities, few dealers and dwindling sales - but it has something the world automotive giants are itching to get their hands on: a brand name that denotes class.

title: 80-Year-Old Tennis Star Entering Hall of Fame
description: LEAD: EDWARD G. TARANGIOLI, a titan of senior tennis, is being inducted today into the Yonkers Sports Hall of Fame. He ranks No. 1 nationally in singles and doubles in the 80's age bracket and has been in the top flight of veteran United States players for decades.

title: For the Ponies, Paradise Lost
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Design Preview; HIGH POINT: NEW RELIABLES
description: NOSTALGIA WILL BE THE PRE-dominant theme at this fall's International Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C., where showrooms will feature such 19th-century styles as Victorian, Biedermeier and century-old Russian. To see such traditional merchandise is not unusual at High Point, the largest wholesale furniture market in the country. In fact, manufacturers at this twice-yearly show have always relied on easy-to-live-with designs for their bread and butter. But at this fall's show, which opens on Thursday and runs through Oct. 27, many new designs are additions to successful lines introduced last year. Others have been conceived as affordable answers to the rising cost of these popular antiques. ''Russian furniture is so hot right now, and we felt there were serious voids in our Russian line,'' says Todd Sessa, a sales and marketing executive for John Widdicomb. As a result, Widdicomb is introducing such objects as a console, a cocktail table and a demilune door cabinet to its existing collection. Thayer Coggin is also riding on a successful year-old line. Milo Baughman, the company's designer, has created 18 new pieces for a Biedermeier '90 collection. ''They're not authentic,'' the designer says, ''simply in the spirit of the style.''

title: Taxes and Housing Enliven Debates
description: THE race for County Executive entered the homestretch last week with the major-party challengers tangling repeatedly over two issues: the rising taxes needed to balance the county budget and the county's role in providing affordable housing.

title: To Briton, a Play's the Thing, but Who Pays?
description: What do you say to a complete stranger who brazenly accosts you, tells you that his name is Neal Foster and that he wants you to donate your free time to help him raise money? If your name is Jack Lemmon, Dustin Hoffman, Alan Bennett or Dame Judi Dench, you say yes.

Approved 216 to 206, Oct. 11. 2. title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE BARTLETT ARBORETUM IN STAMFORD;
Where Autumn's Spectacle Is the Main Event
description: LEAD: SPRING brings nasty insects that bite. Summer can be hot and humid. Winter can be ferociously cold. But who can find anything bad to say about fall? Cool, crisp and colorful, it is an exhilarating season, especially when experienced from the Bartlett Arboretum in Stamford.

title: NONFICTION
description: ROEMER: Man Against the Mob. By William F. Roemer Jr. (Donald I. Fine, $19.95.) Of his many awards and commendations, the former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent William F. Roemer Jr. writes that ''the best testament'' came from the organized-crime boss Jackie Cerone, who crowned Mr. Roemer ''the nemesis of Chicago organized crime.'' In his autobiography, ''Roemer: Man Against the Mob,'' the author details his unparalleled success from the 1950's through the 1970's at infiltrating Chicago's underworld and prosecuting its members. Mr. Roemer writes that he came to have ''grudging respect'' for such mob figures as the one-time Capone enforcer Anthony (Big Tuna) Accardo and Murray (The Camel) Humphreys. Others, such as Sam Giancana, Mad Sam DeStefano, Felix (Milwaukee Phil) Alderisio and Tony (The Ant) Spilotro earned nothing but Mr. Roemer's contempt. No matter what his feelings, the author stalked them with equal dedication. Mr. Roemer, now a private consultant on organized crime, used wiretaps (before President Lyndon B. Johnson pulled the plug on them in 1965) and, later, informants to gain information on mob figures. Then he would use what he'd learned either ''to prevent their plans from bearing fruit'' or to prosecute them. Throughout it all, Mr. Roemer writes that he loved his role as nemesis and that certain of his adversaries ''gave me great adventure as I tracked them and fought them, and my prayers are with them in spite of them.'' Although the reader may have some problems following the chronology - perhaps inevitably, given the author's episodic style - Mr. Roemer does an admirable job of bluntly recreating the inner workings of Chicago's underworld and the F.B.I.'s methods of fighting them. ''Roemer: Man Against the Mob'' is a revealing, refreshingly sincere memoir that pulls no punches in recalling the triumphs - and, at times, foul-ups - that characterized Mr. Roemer's remarkable career.

title: 'Blaming the Victim' in The War on Waste
description: Assemblyman David C. Kronick states in ''The Trashing of New Jersey'' that the worst crime in America is the trashing of America, particularly New Jersey. He effectively states the problem and in simple, complete form suggests the solution. Finally he appeals to the public, the parents and the schools through education to sweep America clean.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 1 about the New Rochelle Art Association referred incorrectly to the illustrator of a 1923 sign, ''When a Feller Needs a Friend.'' He was Clare Briggs.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: Yes, Truman was a ''take charge'' President. He took charge and dropped two nuclear bombs on Japan, when one probably would have been sufficient. He took charge and started the nuclear-arms race by approving the production of the hydrogen bomb. GARY CASTEEL Knoxville, Tenn.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: Truman was squarely on target. I was a member of the regular Army and a World War II combat medic in the European Theater of Operation, twice wounded and much decorated. I revered George C. Marshall and liked Ike, until the McCarthy incident.

title: Villa Rental
description: To the Editor: The article about rental of villas and castles in Italy (''How to Rent a Private Villa,'' Travel, Oct. 1) did not include our company, Hometours International (1170 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10001; 212-689-0851 or, out of state, 800-367-4668). We also represent Villas Italia. We offer a wide range of accommodations, from very simple apartments in small villages on the Mediterranean Sea, Adriatic Sea, Sicily, Sardinia and Tuscany inland to very large and beautiful villas on the Amalfi Drive and in Positano overlooking the Mediterranean Sea and Forte dei Marmi on the Italian Riviera - castles, villas, farmhouses with swimming pools in the wine region and the moutains of Tuscany.

title: NONFICTION
description: ST. JOSEPH'S CHILDREN: A True Story of Terror and Justice. By Terry Ganey. (Lyle Stuart/Carol Publishing, $17.95.) Every parent's nightmare became reality for a family in St. Joseph, Mo., in 1978. Their 4-year-old son disappeared from a shopping mall and was found murdered hours later. An innocent retarded man went to prison, writes Terry Ganey in ''St. Joseph's Children,'' while the real murderer, Charlie Hatcher, continued his travels, killing whenever the urge grew too strong to resist. Mr. Hatcher, intelligent but poorly educated, had learned from long experience how to manipulate the criminal justice system. In San Francisco he was caught in the act of sodomizing and strangling a 5-year-old boy. Faking a semicatatonic state, he persuaded psychiatrists he should be treated, not punished; then he faked a recovery and all too soon was back on the streets. The insanity ploy continued to protect him in state after state. Whenever he was caught trying to abduct a child, Hatcher would do his routine, be sent to a mental hospital, held a few months, then released. Finally, in 1982, Hatcher returned to St. Joseph, where he found his 16th murder victim. He found her near the same mall. He was caught, but only, Mr. Ganey says, because some part of him was tired of it all and needed to confess. ''St. Joseph's Children'' offers a well-researched recitation of Hatcher's monstrous crimes, but little beyond that. It is as if Mr. Ganey, a reporter for The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, could not bear to look too deeply into his subject. Still, it is a powerfully affecting story, made even more so by the estimation of some authorities that at any one time there are at least 35 serial killers roaming the United States. From the evidence presented here, there is little protection between our children and the urges of these criminals.

title: D. G. Zrike Wed To Miss Hudson
description: Katherine Ann Hudson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher L. Hudson of Germantown, Tenn., was married yesterday to David George Zrike, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Zrike of Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan and the Rev. James P. M. Walsh performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich.

title: Star of TV and Powerboating
description: Don Johnson, the actor, plans to defend his title as a world offshore powerboat champion next week in Atlantic City. But it was not until the start four years ago of the ''Miami Vice'' television series, in which Johnson played the role of Sonny Crockett, that he became acquainted with offshore speedboats.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Your Scallops or Your Life

title:
Fashion Preview;
PARIS
description: LEAD: CONTRASTS AND CONTRADICTIONS. THAT IS HOW PARISIAN ready-to-wear designers, using a bit of Gaulish understatement, describe their new spring 1990 collections, which they begin showing this week. There are no shocks, just slight readjustments of what goes with what and subtle changes in mixes of colors, fabrics and separates.

title: Should a School Athlete Pay to Play?
description: THE new school year has begun; academic study and the interscholastic athletic programs are in full swing. Enthusiasm is high, anticipation of success still undiminished. But a trend has developed in western Connecticut that is disturbing. That is the decision by boards of education to require students who choose to participate in athletic programs to pay for the privilege.

title: WHAT MOMA DONE TOLE HIM
description: JUST LOOKING Essays on Art. By John Updike. Illustrated. 210 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Leah H. Haggerty And Peter Clark Exchange Vows
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., Leah Hilary Haggerty and Peter Stokes Ives Clark were married yesterday by Canon John W. Davis, assisted by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee.

title: A's Show They Have Pitching Edge
description: Before the World Series began, the San Francisco Giants conceded that the Oakland Athletics had the edge in pitching. Nothing changed their minds tonight.

title: Picture of Temptations Painted in Garcia Trial
description: One of the prosecution's last witnesses at the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee, was a Harvard Law School student who worked a few years ago as an intern in the Congressman's South Bronx office.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: Many times I've argued with short-sighted anti-competitive sports advocates about the merits of such activities. How, win or lose, they foster social interaction, camaraderie, team spirit, promote physical and mental conditioning, and create a sense of working toward goals and dreams. Celebration of one's own or his team's performance is normal and happy to see. But what hurts my point time and again is witnessing the finger pointing, in-your-face swaggering that attempts to abase another competitor. Showmanship should offer a flair of talent as entertainment for the fan, or express joy at an accomplishment; it should not try to humiliate or anger another human being. WILLIAM KOZY Bronx

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The world team championships in Perth, Australia, last month were the last with the current format. When the next comparable event will be played in Yokohama, Japan, in 1991, more teams will be involved. The event will again be bolstered by the technology of NEC, the Japanese computer giant, which now sponsors the Bermuda Bowl and the Venice Trophy.

title: Susan D. Ginkel, a Banker, To Wed Christopher H. Lee
description: A November wedding is planned by Susan DeLand Ginkel, a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, and Christopher Hoiles Lee, a vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton, both in New York, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Alfred O. Ginkel of Muskogee, Okla., have announced. Miss Ginkel, 34 years old, graduated cum laude from Bucknell University. Her father is the president of Bacone College in Muskogee.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 17 about the British theatrical producer Cameron Mackintosh incorrectly stated that he was associated with ''Evita.'' The Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim Rice musical was directed by Harold Prince and produced by Robert Stigwood.

title: Review/Rock; Scottish Band Called Texas Makes Its New York Debut
description: There is something slightly incongruous about a rock band from Scotland that calls itself Texas. But that is the name adopted by the young Glasgow-based group that appeared at the Bottom Line on Wednesday evening. Like Deacon Blue, another promising young Scottish band with a growing reputation, Texas puts a Celtic stamp on American rock-and-roll forms, even while trying to sound as American as possible.

title: Repairing Fluorescent Lights
description: FLUORESCENT lights are thrifty. They use less electricity than incandescent lights, and because they also generate less heat, their tubes last longer than incandescent bulbs.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Offices Snuggled Into a Residential Look
description: LEAD: WHEN a Hampton Bays newspaper asked readers what kind of development was under construction at the corner of Montauk Highway and the Hampton Bays Riverhead Road, most thought it was a residential condominium.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: If Truman were alive today, he would have even more reasons not to like Ike. Eisenhower made the decisions to overthrow the Governments of Mossadegh in Iran and Arbenz in Guatemala. As a result, the Shah was replaced by Khomeini and Central America is in turmoil. GEORGE JOCHNOWITZ New York, N.Y.

title: Need for Vocational Training Grows
description: GOOD jobs are going begging. And the shortage of workers needed to fill them is expected to become even more severe in the next decade, because the number of 18-year-olds entering the job market will drop by 8 percent, according to Census Bureau projections.

title: Congress Takes New Interest in the Airline Business
description: THE years since deregulation of the airlines in 1978 have seen cut-rate fares and high-priced mergers, frequent flyer bonuses and aggravating delays, a doubling of flights and a hopscotch system of traveling along hub-and-spoke routes. For better or worse, the change has never come so fast as this year, leading the Secretary of Transporation, Samuel K. Skinner, to state the obvious: ''What we know as the airline industry today will be dramatically different 10 to 20 years from now.''

title: Julia Portale Wed To C. E. Hutchins
description: Julia Diane Portale, a daughter of Emil Portale of Santa Cruz, Calif., and Susan Robertson Pease of Eugene, Ore., was married yesterday to Cameron Edwin Hutchins, the son of Mrs. Dan E. Hutchins of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Hutchins. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Your Scallops or Your Life

title: Looks That Will Sparkle For Holiday Parties
description: For some parties, a ball gown is de rigueur. For others, anything more formal than a shirt and pants would be de trop. Most parties call for something in between, and in between those two extremes lies a wide world of fashion choices.

title: Health Vigilantes
description: To the Editor:

title: A's First Games Designated Crucial
description: For two games, at least, the 86th World Series will be on even terms.

title: A Monumental Capital
description: LEAD: CANBERRA is a 20th-century city surrounded by a spectacular natural setting. It was a tiny village when the new nation of Australia chose it as a capital early in this century. Beset by colonial jealousies, neither Sydney nor Melbourne wanted the other to capture this distinction, so Canberra was carved out midway between the two.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Bach: Lute Suites (BWV 995-97, 1006a) Sharon Isbin, guitar. Virgin Classics VC 7 90717-2; CD and cassette. Sharon Isbin collaborated with the harpsichordist Rosalyn Tureck on the new editions of the four suites heard here, and she plays the music with authority. Immediately striking are the clarity of her articulation and voicing, and her dramatic, high-contrast approach to dynamics and coloration. She plays sarabandes and other slow movements with a soft touch and rhythmic restraint; the fast dances throw off sparks in every direction. Miss Isbin's ornamentation - light initially, florid in repeats - will seem mannered to some, but is often inventive and virtuosic, generally a fine, distinguishing touch. To accommodate this ornamental impulse, she takes all the repeats, making for a generously packed disk (78:47). - Allan Kozinn Schnittke: 'Faust Cantata,' Three Orchestral Works Malmo Symphony Orchestra and Chorus (with soloists, in ''Faust'') conducted by James DePreist (''Faust'') and Leif Segerstam. Bis CD-437; CD only. The Russian composer Alfred Schnittke calls himself a polystylist, so one should probably be ready for anything. Still, it comes as a shock when Mephistopheles bloodies up Faust so violently, accompanied by a grotesque tango. And the tango seems all the more ghoulish, since it follows about 15 minutes of ordinary, faceless avant-garde expressionism. Ultimately Schnittke's livid cantata is hard to take entirely seriously, but it contains wonderfully hair-raising music and is a promising sketch for his proposed Faust opera. The disk also contains three intense orchestral works: ''Ritual,'' Passacaglia and, the best, the wacky Mozartean Nightmare ''(K)ein Sommernachtstraum'' - ''(Not) a Midsummer Night's Dream.'' The performances and sonics are bold and impressive. Great stuff for Halloween. - Mark Swed Bruckner: Symphony No. 8 Vienna Philharmonic conducted by Herbert von Karajan. Deutsche Grammophon 427 611; two CD's only. This comes as consolation to one who missed the performance of the work these artists gave in Carnegie Hall last February. Always an eloquent Brucknerian (a Seventh Symphony is still to come from DG), Karajan managed to summon the needed mystic sense and sonorous haze while sacrificing little in orchestral precision. Here the lapses in ensemble - enough to suggest a live recording, which this is not - count for little against the imposing grandeur of the conception. As Karajan's iron grip on orchestral execution faltered in recent years, it gave way to a new level of soulful intensity. Alongside the Mahler Ninth he recorded with the Berlin Philharmonic in 1982, this will stand as one of the great valedictory statements of his extraordinary final decade. - James R. Oestreich Carter: Vocal Works Christine Schadeberg, soprano; Katherine Ciesinski, mezzo; Jon Garrison, tenor; Patrick Mason, baritone; Jan Opalach, bass; Speculum Musicae. Bridge BCD 9014; CD only. Elliott Carter's vocal works are often thought the most unlovable music of an unlovable, if significant, composer. Carter sets difficult poets - Elisabeth Bishop, John Ashbery and Robert Lowell - and never expects them to fit their multilayered poems within the constraints of single-level melody. Instead, he brings the poetry to life on its own terms. And since life is not easily led or understood, neither is Carter's unpredicatble and exceptional music. Contrived to work the way the brain does, it juggles many conflicting thoughts and feelings at once. Taken together, ''A Mirror on Which to Dwell'' (1976), ''Syringa'' (1978) and ''In Sleep, in Thunder'' (1982) form a triptych on modern love and madness, with Carter's music probing the poets' elusive feelings, dramatizing them and, yes, actually making them more accessible. The scores have been well recorded before, but never have they been presented together or made to sound so vivid and musical. - M. S. POP/JAZZ Elton John: 'Sleeping With the Past' MCA 6321; all three formats. The past to which the title of Mr. John's newest album refers is the American pop-soul music of the late 50's and early 60's that profoundly influenced his style. While not overtly imitating vintage pop-soul hits, Mr. John and his longtime lyrics partner Bernie Taupin pack their latest bunch of songs with allusions to black American gospel music. ''Healing Hands,'' ''Club at the End of the Street'' (which suggests a less frenzied ''Philadelphia Freedom''), the rockabilly-flavored ''Stone's Throw From Hurtin','' and ''Amazes Me,'' an imagined Mississippi idyll, are the most evocative cuts. As usual, the lyrics are vague glosses of stories and don't really add up to anything. But Mr. John's vocal exuberance, buoyed by the light, streamlined arrangements, maintains a pleasant, percolating verve. - Stephen Holden Randy Travis: 'No Holdin' Back' Warner Bros. 25988-2; all three formats. The frozen, almost unreal production of the album belies Mr. Travis's reputation as a new traditionalist in country music. The images - gamblers, singing the blues, an old man who was ''90 years old in 63,'' love and more, tortured, love - all point in the direction of country honky-tonk. But the music, slow and polite, with restrained choral backing, points out that Mr. Travis is retreating from the straightforward music with which he made his reputation. Instead of offering the crisp simplicity of a live performance, ''No Holdin' Back'' has moments of Nashvillian upscale insincerity, all baritone emotionality and rainstorms of mock teardrops. - Peter Watrous The Innocence Mission: 'The Innocence Mission' A & M 5274; all three formats. The quivering angelic voice of Karen Peris, a singer, songwriter and keyboardist who is the center of The Innocence Mission, a rock quartet from Lancaster, Pa., suggests a hybrid of Stevie Nicks and Kate Bush. Her fervent vocal sensitivity complements original folk-rock songs that portray everyday feelings and observations as near-miraculous happenings. Delicate chiming guitar and keyboard textures and circular chantlike melodies underscore lyrics whose subjects range from wondering what kind of person a brother's fiancee will turn out to be (''Curious'') to entranced meditations on the afterlife (''Mercy,'' ''Wonder of Birds''). This debut, produced by the rock bassist Larry Klein, is filled with promise. - S. H. Erskine Hawkins and His Orchestra: 'The Original Tuxedo Junction' RCA 9682-2-RV (recorded 1938-45); all three formats. Adored by the dancers at the Savoy Ballroom, the Erskine Hawkins Orchestra never had much of a following outside the black community. Why the band never crossed over has always been a mystery. It had hits - ''Tuxedo Junction,'' ''After Hours'' - solid arrangements by Sammy Lowe and Bill Johnson and a high-octane Lunceford sound, and starred trumpet soloists like Dud Bascomb and the often overreaching Hawkins. They may have lacked a distinctive style, but they could fill a dance floor, and occasionally, as evidenced here on ''Tippin' In'' and ''Swing Out,'' they made music that lasts. - Richard B. Woodward Hank Thompson: 'Hank Thompson,' 'Livea at the Golden Nugget' Capitol 921242 (recorded 1947-61); all three formats. Stetson (recorded 1961; Sunshine Music Group, 508 Colorado Ave., Stuart, Fla. 34994); LP only. One of the great figures in honky-tonk country music, Mr. Thompson, who is still performing and recording, had his share of country hits - ''Wild Side of Life,'' ''Waiting in the Lobby of Your Heart,'' ''Six Pack to Go'' - most of which are on ''Hank Thompson,'' a 20-song collection. Mr. Thompson liked rhythm and often allowed his records to have a driving drumbeat - ''Rub-a-Dub-Dub'' and ''Wake Up, Irene'' have drum accents unusual for country music of the time - and a hard country feel to them, many of them woven through with Merle Travis's intricate guitar playing. His drifting voice could get tough, and with his band, the Brazos Valley Boys, he tears up a whole set of classic tunes on ''Live at the Golden Nugget,'' the first live album in country music history, and a highly successful one. Loaded with jazz-style improvisation and Mr. Thompson's plain-spoken voice, it's brilliant. - P. W.

title: Maori Tales Told in Wood In Rotorua, New Zealand
description: FOR the Maori (rhymes with ''dowry'') people of New Zealand, woodcarving is the highest form of art, embodying spiritual concepts that can only be brought to it by craftsmen who have been specially trained: tohunga (skilled man-priest-teacher) whakairo (carver).

title: DON'T CALL THE SWAMI 'DAD'
description: LEAD: A BLISS CASE By Michael Aaron Rockland. 176 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: Salvadorans Wonder How To Think About Peace
description: VIOLENCE and suffering have been so central a part of El Salvador's experience that the national anthem reminds the people how ''painful and bloody is your history.'' Ten years ago today, though, a group of young and idealistic military officers launched a coup here ushering in a period of turmoil and destruction that has taxed even this country's remarkable ability to endure.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Michael D. Dellar: Restaurant Consultant
description: LEAD: When Bradley M. Ogden, the acclaimed chef at Campton Place in San Francisco decided to open his own restaurant, he asked Michael D. Dellar to find a location in that city.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; There's No Need to Skip Town to See Fall Colors
description: With the peak of the fall foliage season in the metropolitan region about a week away, leaf peepers who are stuck in New York City do not have to turn green with envy (or red or orange) when friends tell them about their excursions into the country to view the splendors of autumn.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Illinois; Alcohol a Big Issue As 3 Are Charged In Fire at Stadium
description: Three University of Illinois students have been charged with setting a fire last month that destroyed the Astroturf at the university's football stadium.

title: Ms. Sellers Weds A Fellow Lawyer
description: The marriage of Martha E. Sellers and Alan M. Klein, both associates at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, took place yesterday evening at the Harvard Club in New York. Rabbi Burt Siegal and the Rev. John W. Payne, a minister of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), officiated.

title: Wine; GOING FOR THE GOLD
description: SOME YEARS AGO, I SPENT A LOT of time knocking around as a judge at wine competitions. It seemed like the thing to do - a chance to learn something, to taste a lot of wines and see the country. That's pretty much the way it worked out, too.

title: Susan I. Katz Is Wed To Gary W. Nathanson
description: Susan Ivy Katz and Gary William Nathanson were married last evening by Rabbi James Perman at the Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, L.I. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Katz and Dr. and Mrs. Noel Nathanson, all of Great Neck, L.I.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis McEnroe-Connors Matchup: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors will battle for the 33d time in their careers after capturing semifinal matches yesterday in the Toulouse Grand Prix tournament in France. McEnroe, the top-seeded player, breezed past fourth-seeded Horst Skoff of Austria, 6-1, 6-3, after second-seeded Connors rebounded from a first-set loss to beat Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1.

title: Buyers Mull Special Brands For Buyers Like Seniors
description: There are plenty of loaves at the bread aisle at the Food Emporium at 68th Street and Broadway in New York: Wonder Bread, Pepperidge Farm, Arnold, Taystee, Home Pride, Country Hearth, Oatmeal Goodness.

title: Carol E. Snow Weds Thomas S. Crane
description: Carol Ellen Snow, a daughter of Jane Donaldson Snow of Naples, Fla., and the late Robert Bond Snow Jr., was married in Woods Hole, Mass., yesterday to Thomas Smith Crane, a son of Sylvia E. Crane of Princeton, N.J., and Woods Hole, and the late John O. Crane. The Revs. Richard S. Crowell and Robert Mayo, Episcopal priests, officiated at the Church of the Messiah.

title: A Tape Cheers Czech Dissidents
description: A purported tape recording of an address by the Czechoslovak leader before a closed meeting of Communist Party officials is providing amusement for his critics.

title: Great Act
description: As a peripatetic vaudeville team they could be billed as ''The Great One and His Shadow,'' although there is some question about just who is shadowing whom: Wayne Gretzky of the Los Angeles Kings, who has been closing in on the National Hockey League career scoring record of 1,850 points? Or Gordie Howe, the holder of that record, who has been following Gretzky from arena to arena as Gretzky nears the goal?

title: LESSONS FROM THE 80's; CREATING THE LOOK: Tradition With a Twist
description: If there is any one lesson we've learned in this decade, it's how to shop. Indeed, the growing interest in the decorative arts -spawned by an increase in museum shows, books and lectures on the subject, the rising popularity of antiques and crafts shows, and the much publicized boom in the auction market - has heightened consumer awareness of the wide variety of objects that are available. Now, whether it is a rug designed by a world-renowned architect, or an 18th-century Chinese-export por-celain plate, more people than ever before can identify the piece and appreciate what they are buying. At the same time, more antiques dealers and manufacturers are scouring obscure corners of the world looking for goods to tempt their customers, and more celebrated architects and designers are mass-producing their furniture and accessory designs to bring them to the public at affordable prices.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: Wonderful Harry S. Truman. Reading his private writings, I couldn't help smiling. How splendidly refreshing!

title: On the Embryo Front in the Battle of the Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Budget Follies, Cont'd.
description: No scandal in Congress this year is more outrageous than the budget mess. Both houses and both parties have failed in their duty to cut the deficit. President Bush did no better. Putting aside all the hogwash and politicking, it is clear that they're all creating problems, not solving them.

title: On the Embryo Front in the Battle of the Sexes; Collection Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: For Animals, Care Without Cuddling
description: LEAD: AUTUMN is an easy season for Dudley and Jean Seward of Greenwich. Unlike in the spring and summer, the number of injured or orphaned birds and animals that the couple cares for is relatively small - by their standards anyway.

title: David McCall Jr., A Trader, Is Wed To Ms. Stackpole
description: At the Lawrenceville (N.J.) Presbyterian Church, Abigail Florence Stackpole, a foreign rights assistant at Harper & Row Publishers in New York, and David Bruce McCall Jr., a trader at the First Boston Corporation in New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. Carl D. Reimers. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stackpole of Lawrenceville. Her husband is a son of Mrs. C. Paul Cox 3d of Easton, Md., and Mr. McCall of New York. Mrs. McCall, 27 years old, is a graduate of Barnard College. Her father is a counselor at Right Associates, a job-placement firm in Princeton, N.J. Her mother, Willa Stackpole, is an agent for N. T. Callaway Real Estate in Princeton.

title: Standardizing Car Regulations For the Disabled
description: ON Tuesday a committee is scheduled to meet in Washington in an effort to standardize state rules on identifying autos that transport people with mobility handicaps. The committee of 15, convening at the Department of Transportation, includes representatives of the handicapped as well as officials from state and Federal agencies.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: I did not care particularly for Eisenhower and never voted for him, but fair is fair. One must admire, for example, his astonishing farewell speech, by which he became the first at the top to warn against the military-industrial complex. After leaving the White House, he became (with Truman) an honorary co-chairman of the Planned Parenthood Association, at a time when it was no less controversial than it is today. DONALD J. MIDDLEMAN Philadelphia

title: A Word of Counsel On Career Counseling
description: In my 10-year-old practice, Career Counseling Associates, I have continually advised people to avoid signing a contract (most having outrageous fees) for career counseling or ''possible'' employment. Thank you for bringing to print the need to shop carefully for a counselor (''Career Changes Are a Reflection of Changing Times,'' Sept. 3).

title: Hype and High Prices in the 80's
description: ONE DAY A WOMAN walked into Gerald G. Stiebel's art and antiques gallery and told him that she wanted to buy a Rembrandt. ''I was very impressed, even though she didn't look like the type,'' says Stiebel, who is president of Rosenberg & Stiebel, New York dealers of Old Master paintings and drawings and French 18th-century furniture. ''Then she said, 'It doesn't have to be a Rembrandt -it just has to look like one.' ''

title: WHO MADE IT
description: This has been the decade for home design. Decorating became a hot topic, and so did those who do it. Interior designers became celebrities in their own right: Appearing on television and in gossip columns, their faces were often as recognizable as their work. On these pages are 15 of those who made it in the 80's. Will these stars continue to rise? ''OFF-THE-WALL'': Philippe Starck

title: Some Prefer Golf
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Images of an Optimistic, Self-Assured Past
description: Of all the American photographers of the 1920's and 30's who were profoundly influenced by the spirit of modern art, Berenice Abbott remains one of the most underappreciated. She also has been one of the most enduring; now 91, she has lived to see the esthetic principles she adopted more than 60 years ago rise and fall with a regular historical cadence. From the prospect of the 1980's her work seems a relic of an optimistic and self-assured past, but it is a relic that is singularly convincing and inspiring.

title: 29 Reversed Votes on Easing Abortion Curbs
description: Twenty-nine House members voted one way in a vote relaxing restrictions on Federal financing of abortion on Sept. 9, 1988, then voted the opposite way on a virtually identical proposal on Wednesday.

title: Tavern Is a Baseball Fan's Paradise
description: LEAD: PATRONS of Frank's Willow Inn, an East Hartford restaurant and bar, often turn up for cheeseburgers and draft beer. Frank's also serves up plenty of baseball history.

title: At Home Again, William Hurt Takes Stock
description: ''I've been walking the edge for a long time,'' William Hurt says, ''thinking about whether acting is the right thing for me to be doing. Sometimes things happen in my personal life which really make me question whether what I do is right for me. It's not right that my privacy is invaded to the extent that it is.
