I'm a very private man, and I have the right to be. I never said that because I was an actor you can have my privacy, you can steal my soul. You can't.''

title: Milford Does Battle With Drugs
description: FED UP with drug abuse and the crimes associated with it, DeForest Smith, a Milford real estate broker, has declared ''all-out war'' against drugs in his city. He has enlisted the aid of the police department, the schools and the business community, and his efforts have led to a drug-tip hot line that will offer callers cash rewards.

title: Nelson Is on the Air But Prefers a Field
description: Karl Nelson is a man of many talents.

title: Aggie Defense Stuns Houston
description: Texas A&M's defense, geared for speed, slowed Houston's explosive offense and the Aggies pulled off a 17-13 upset today behind the breakaway running of Darren Lewis and Robert Wilson.

title: The Chamber Music Society: Inaugurating a Tradition
description: ''You can believe i'm nervous. Who wouldn't be? I'm starting my tenure here as only the second music director ever for the society, after 20 years of success.'' Fred Sherry is a big man with a broad smile and a shock of prematurely gray hair. He fills the smallish office of the director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center with the nervous, edgy energy proverbially associated with New Yorkers. ''The opening program is something I worked over and thought about late at night: What can I do for the opening piece of the opening concert that will be so fantastic, so irresistible, that nobody couldn't have a good time?''

title: TIMID PROGRAMMING, TEPID TELEVISION
description: If television reflects reality, however hazily, we the people would seem to be mired in growing confusion. While news and ''reality'' shows adopt questionable dramatization devices, entertainment formats drift ever further into inane diversions. Meanwhile, daytime shows like ''Geraldo'' are insisting that the land is being overrun by child molesters and Satanists. And, for the most part, the new season of weekly prime-time series only adds to the blur.

title: Next for Yogi Berra, Master of Words
description: To the Editor:

title: New Air Quality Chief Inherits a Trail of Woes
description: LEAD: CARL PAVETTO, the new director of the Air Quality Control Unit of the State Department of Environmental Protection, has been on the job for little more than a month, but he has already had a year's worth of problems.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles. Last year, we hired a professional to repaint. He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint. Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun. The painter says this is owing to moisture and that there is a new sealer that will correct this. What is your opinion?

title: Amy Daniel Weds Dennis Metnick
description: Amy Alice Daniel and Dennis Metnick were married yesterday by Judge Harvey W. Sherman of Suffolk County Criminal Court at the Young Men's Philanthropic League in New York. The bride, 35 years old, is a daughter of William Moody of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Mimi Feiffer Moody of New York. Her husband, 45, is the son of Mrs. Samuel Metnick of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Metnick.

title: 'Smoke on Mountain,' Gospel Musical
description: IF you haven't been hankering after a bluegrass, Bible Belt gospel sort of musical, circa 1938, ''Smoke on the Mountain'' at the McCarter Theater, through next Sunday, isn't likely to challenge your predispositions.

title: Anne Childs and Charles Collins Wed
description: Anne Carmichael Childs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Coffin Childs of Norfolk, Conn., was married in Norfolk yesterday to Charles H. Collins, a son of Nancy C. Collins of Easton, Md., and the late Francis Howard Collins 2d. The Rev. Bruce Anderson officiated at the Congregational Church of Christ.

title: Chabrol Offers A Cool-Eyed Look At a Stormy Issue
description: Abortion is not the stormy issue in France it is in the United States, which is one reason Claude Chabrol, the French director, has been able to make a movie that deals with it not as a moral dilemma, but as a fact of life. In ''Story of Women,'' abortion is unpleasant, troublesome, even physically dangerous, but for some women it sometimes is the only choice available.

title: No Easy Way Out Of Energy Crisis
description: Governor Cuomo's promise of Canadian electricity for Long Island is as phony as his promise of ''power cheap as Freeport'' and lower taxes. A recent news item indicates that lack of rainfall and high local demand have reduced Hydro-Quebec export capacity.

title: An Anniversary Show Of a Museum's Riches
description: MUSEUMS get critical attention for their temporary shows but not for their permanent collections. Though this is but a symptom of art's show-business condition, the Montclair Museum, for one, is not taking it lying down.

title: 45 Libraries Offer AIDS Programs
description: PUPPET shows and theater are being used to lure children and adults to 45 libraries to learn more about AIDS.

title: Blass's Defeat Marks End of an Era
description: If the price of democracy is eternal vigilance, those eligible to vote in the First Legislative District of Suffolk County were asleep at the wheel on Primary Day, when they allowed well-heeled up-Island hustlers, with designs on the district, to move in with the money and move out with the election. Their winning candidate insists he comes with no strings attached, but, given the circumstances, who could believe that? As Sam Goldwyn used to say, ''In two words: Im Possible!''

title: C. D. Gates Wed To Dr. Bigelow
description: Dr. Natalie Suzanne Bigelow, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bradley Bigelow of New York, was married yesterday to Courtlandt Dixon Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Parker McNair Gates of New York. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli officiated at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Race for Title Narrows to 2
description: With four races left in the Nascar Winston Cup season, it appears that the title will go to either Dale Earnhardt or Rusty Wallace.

title: 10,000 Sheep, Astray at Sea, Head for Europe
description: It has not been the best of times for El Cordero, an Italian-owned freighter carrying 10,000 Australian sheep that has been scorned at ports throughout the Arabian Peninsula.

title: LIVING ELEGANTLY IN A SMALL SPACE: Studio Setting
description: Living in a studio is how I started out in the 1950's, when I was 25 and first came to New York,'' recalls Joseph A. C. Moore. ''So when my friends heard I was moving back into one, they thought I was mad.'' Like other New Yorkers, Moore, an ex-corporate executive turned antiques dealer and decorator, has learned to live elegantly in a small space - perhaps more elegantly than most.

title: HOW TO BECOME A PHANTOM WITHOUT ACTUALLY DYING
description: LEAD: ANTIQUE DUST Ghost Stories. By Robert Westall. 213 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: The Road to Critical Mass
description: The sun had barely risen, and there was still a chill in the desert air; but already cameramen, actors and prop people were scurrying about the dusty set, a small shack and lone 100-foot tower built amid the arid wasteland of northern Durango. As he waited for his crew to prepare the first shot of the day, the director, Roland Joffe, gently balanced a shiny metal hemisphere in each hand and ruminated. ''This is the atom bomb, the energy of the universe,'' he said. ''Here is political power, the ultimate muscle every state has always sought, the ultimate power of life and death.''

title: Contras Said to Sell Arms to Salvador Rebels
description: The rightist Nicaraguan rebels encamped in Honduras are selling their American-supplied arms and ammunition to leftist rebels in El Salvador, diplomats here say.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Office Space For Nonprofits
description: LEAD: A $17.3 million gut renovation of an old warehouse and office building has been completed and the nonprofit organizations for whom the renovation was designed are moving in and custom-fitting their offices.

title: HEARTS AND WRITERS
description: I can't tell you how many times my heart has been jolted by a beautifully written sentence or my life has been affected by the magic of words. Surely, there must be a reason why doctors such as Anton Chekhov and William Carlos Williams were writers, too. Clearly, they realized the power of medicine to shock life back into a stopped heart and the power of language to make that same heart stop, for a few seconds, to feel the power of the written word. EVY SCHIFFMAN Foster City, Calif.

title: VENGEANCE IS HIS, AGAIN
description: THE KILLING MAN By Mickey Spillane. 238 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Correction
description: A theater picture caption in the Arts and Leisure Guide today about the play ''The Ambassadors'' at the South Street Theater misidentifies an actor. He is David Adamson, not Anthony Chisholm.

title: New Issues and Changing Electorate Reshape Virginia Governor's Race
description: Jean Dursee does not think of herself as a pivotal person in this year's nip-and-tuck race for governor.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: FIXING CAPITAL GAINS;
It's Time to Reform Tax Reform
description: LEAD: Just three years after the tax reform revolution set in place a new tax structure designed to endure for decades, the system is in play again.

title: Italian Standards, Regional Specialties
description: ANY evaluation of Roslyn Estates's Classico is a tug-of-war between fine food and slack service. The food is a marvelous mix of exciting regional specialties and well-prepared Italian-American standards.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: FOODS FOR FESTIVALS

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: By all accounts, historians today have Eisenhower in an almost dead heat with Truman in the Presidential ratings. You would never know this from reading Margaret Truman's footnotes. ALAN SCHNEIDER New York, N.Y.

title: Stacy Elise Silk Is Married to Michael Feldman
description: The marriage of Stacy Elise Silk, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Silk of West Hartford, Conn., to Michael Alan Feldman, a son of Dr. Richard N. Feldman of Rocky Hill, Conn., and the late Bonnie Wood Feldman, took place in Hartford last evening. Rabbi Harold Silver officiated at the Hartford Club.

title: HONDURAN ACCUSED IN THEFT OF U.S. AID
description: Senior officers in the Honduran armed forces contend that their commander misappropriated millions of dollars in military aid sent by the United States.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Changing the Elmwood Park Cityscape
description: LEAD: THE view to the north of Elmwood Park from I-80 is of warehouses and factories and the smokestack of the Marcal paper company. But a group of developers plans to compensate with a view to the south of a 14-story, 268-room, all-suite hotel and a 12-story, 300,000-square-foot office building.

title: 'Just Looking'
description: The matching of words to images was known as ekphrasis in ancient times, when the Greeks and Romans practiced it as a genre of literature. It went well beyond the mere description of pictures and statues, such as were given by the geographer and traveler Pausanias, who included accounts of these in the course of describing distant sites. Rather, it was the counterpart of illustration, made to fit to passages of poetry or prose images, with the picture conveying the same effect as the words.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 15, 1989
IN QUOTES
description: ''It's total emotional and psychological chaos. People are dumping everything.'' Eugene Peroni, analyst at Janey Montgomery Scott, on Friday's action.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
For White Plains, 400,000 Sq. Ft. of Offices
description: LEAD: WORKING on the premise that the current soft office market is but a short-term aberration, the Robert Martin Company of Elmsford is joining with the Jack Parker Corporation of Forest Hills to create a 400,000-square-foot office building on a site adjacent to the Metro-North railroad station in White

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Hicksville $212,000 206 College Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300. Levittown $157,000 20 Springtime Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,200. Mineola $170,000 119 Wheeler Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $1,700. Sayville $170,000 285 Sunrise Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old high ranch; dining room, den, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,500. Seaford $164,000 2317 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Westbury $168,500 1068 Mirabelle Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,600. OTHER AREAS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $395,000 84 Frame Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 39-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, deck, playroom, workshop, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $6,625. Colchester, Conn. $265,000 62 Ventura Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; c/a, greenhouse-style solarium, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Wall Township, N.J. $183,500 2129 Butternut Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; patio, living-room fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $1,950.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Philippe Velu: Miniaturist
description: LEAD: Philippe Velu never thought he could earn a living making miniature houses. Although the craft has been popular in the Netherlands and Germany for centuries and has enjoyed a renaissance in the United States and England in the last 20 years, France's love of the little began only about four years ago.

title:
GARDENING;
Autumn in Palest Gold to Deepest Sienna
description: LEAD: IT usually begins with the red maples, first appearing at higher altitudes like in the Poconos, often as early as late August. By the time that the last of this species has developed its autumnal brilliance, other species have added yellows, golds, oranges, reds and browns to the display. Depending on the weather, the display may last from three to six weeks before the leaves fall to the ground, providing sustenance for the multitude of funguses, bacteria, earthworms and other creatures that inhabit and improve the soil.

title: A Levee Near Tijuana Becomes a Flashpoint
description: The recent death of a 14-year-old Mexican boy, run over by a United States Border Patrol jeep, dramatized the chaotic and sometimes violent situation that has developed as more and more illegal aliens try to enter the United States through one narrow section of the California border.

title: A Clear Choice Confronts the Voters In One New Jersey Assembly Contest
description: In a year when Republican control of the New Jersey Assembly could vanish with the loss of only two seats, Democrats are hoping to upset two veteran Republicans in the Sixth District in Camden County. Democrats are banking heavily on differences over abortion to give them a victory in the district, but Republicans, who now hold a 41-to-39 edge in the Assembly, say the race here will turn on other issues.

title: 'TERRIBLE, THE WAY IT WAS IN FAMILIES'
description: THE OTHER SIDE By Mary Gordon. 386 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Where the Tropics Meet the Outback
description: LEAD: NOWHERE does quirky nature meet the charm of Australian Outback life as in the tropical outpost of Cooktown. Seldom in Australia, where I have lived most of my life, have I felt such a sense of history as in Cooktown, or of Australia's links, often unexamined, with a wider world.

title: In a Shift, Towns Begin to Develop Low-Cost Housing
description: RESPONDING to pressure from without and within, surburban communities that long resisted low- or moderate-cost housing are beginning to permit, encourage and even develop hundreds of such units.

title: Trading Places
description: Members of the American Stock Exchange no longer conduct their business al fresco, but they still know which way the wind is blowing. Last week the Amex acted on the longstanding dictum of weapons manufacturers, housing developers and others whose prosperity is tied to national policy: If you want something from Washington, hire somebody from Washington. In a surprise move, the Amex announced that its next chairman would be James R. Jones, who was an aide to Lyndon B. Johnson before being elected in 1972 to the first of seven terms in Congress. Mr. Jones will take over next month, and Amex officials made no bones about why they wanted the former Oklahoma Representative. ''What we needed was Washington experience,'' said one. The Amex, once called the Curb Exchange because it traded stocks outdoors, will be the only leading financial exchange to be headed by a non-businessman.

title: The Abortion-Rights Movement Has Its Day
description: A SERIES of bitter state-by-state battles over abortion has barely begun, but already advocates of abortion rights have proclaimed a watershed. Never before, they argued last week, had political attitudes and behavior shifted so far, so fast, in their favor.

title: Q and A
description: Right to an Apartment

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Cameron Adams to Wed John Soroko
description: Cameron Colket Adams and John Jeming Soroko are planning a November wedding, the prospective bride's parents, David Adams 4th of Bethlehem, Pa., and Mrs. Robert John Connell of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., have announced. Mr. Soroko is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Soroko of Philadelphia.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
DIRTY FIGHTING IN AEROSPACE
description: LEAD: THE FOOL'S RUN By John Camp. 254 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $14.95.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: SOVIET UNION LECTURES

title: CAMPUS LIFE: SUNY-Binghamton; Student Charged With Vandalism Wins a New Post
description: The former president of the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York at Binghamton, who is awaiting trial on charges of painting anti-Semitic slurs at his own organization's headquarters, has been elected to the academic governing board of the university's undergraduate division.

title: Heady Past Bore Giants and A's to Present
description: The Giants and the Athletics are two of the oldest franchises and hallowed names in baseball history, but as San Francisco and Oakland they are 3,000 miles away from their origins and are meeting in a World Series for the first time since thier transcontinental migration.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: The showmanship so prevalent in baseball and other professional sports today is symptomatic of the pervasive influence of television, which has greatly inspired the ''styling'' as well as the myriad of congratulatory gestures at home plate. Fans, reacting to an unfolding soap opera instead of a sporting event, clamor for curtain calls when their heroes save the day. Small wonder that minor league baseball players often refer to the majors as ''the show.'' TERRELL K. HOLMES New York

title: SNAPSHOTS OF HOPE AND HOPELESSNESS
description: It was helpful for Mr. Freedman to characterize some of the injustices engendered by the bureaucracy at 110 Livingston Street, but his gloom and doom portrayal of Seward Park High School missed the mark. It is true that this school has a large non-English-speaking population, a reflection of the community it serves. Teaching these young people to function in the United States is a major business of the school, as it has been for youngsters of every new immigrant group to arrive in New York's Lower East Side. SONNY WHYNMAN Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: Stephen Lesser Weds Ms. Burton
description: Carol Jeanette Burton, a financial consultant for Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets, was married yesterday in Westport, Conn., to Stephen Lesser, an architect at the Wilton, Conn., firm of Robert Faesy Associates. The Rev. Barbara Pescan, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the home of the bridegroom.

title: Review/Music; Trio Doppler From Italy
description: The Trio Doppler - two flutists and one pianist - come from Italy and played for the first time in New York on Thursday night at Weill Recital Hall. Their music was understandably esoteric and understandably of limited quality. The great composers, needless to say, have not expended a great deal of their time on such an unusual and limited combination of instruments.

title:
Food;
SPAIN IN A STEW
description: LEAD: MEALS-IN-A-POT - COCI-dos, potajes, ollas, as they are called in Spain - are probably among the oldest dishes known to man. But despite lightning-swift changes in food and ingredients, these beloved dishes have actually become fashionable in Spain.

title: After Years of Fighting, 2 Democrats Compromise
description: For members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, meetings involving John D. Dingell, Henry A. Waxman and clean air have often been as uncomfortable as listening to parents quarrel at dinner.

title: Borland Seeks Best of Both Worlds
description: Bucking a trend, the Borland International Corporation says it can write a spreadsheet program that has more features than Lotus 1-2-3 Release 3 or Microsoft Excel and can also run nicely on a low-end office personal computer. Borland's program, Quattro Pro, was announced this month, although it will not be ready for sale until the end of the year.

title: MUSIC Carlos Kleiber: Genius Wrapped In an Enigma
description: Carlos Kleiber: Enigma, maverick or genius? Opinions about the most mercurial conductor of his generation range widely: He is unpredictable, unwilling to commit himself to future projects and reticent in dealing with the world at large. Many artists say they hardly ever give interviews; Mr. Kleiber has never been known to give one. But the musical verdict is overwhelming: ''He makes other conductors look like fools,'' said one musician who did not wish to be named for fear of the future of his career under lesser conductors. ''He is a genius, an extraordinary man,'' said the conductor Bernard Haitink. Placido Domingo has called him ''a wizard.''

title: 'The Culture We Deserve'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock's Icons: Hero Today, Homage Tomorrow
description: The concern with roots that has affected (or infected) rock in recent years takes many forms. Some young bands become obsessed with a certain period, style or attitude and become living time capsules, churning out rockabilly or 60's garage-punk or purist psychedelia while resisting the taint of more contemporary influences. Other bands revive the songs of pre-rock pioneers, or work at transmuting roots influences into something they can call their own.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MISS LIZZIE. By Walter Satterthwait. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) In 1893, a Fall River, Mass., jury decided that Lizzie Borden - despite that famous bit of doggerel - did not take an axe and give her parents all those whacks. But once the official verdict was in, whatever happened to Lizzie Borden? This charming period-piece mystery shows us Miss Lizzie some 28 years later, vacationing in a Massachusetts seacoast town and conducting herself with dignity in the face of snubs and stares from those who persist in believing her guilty.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ''PLEASE . . . DON'T KILL ME'': The True Story of the Milo Murder. By William C. Dear and Carlton Stowers. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) When this brutal homicide was solved, the prosecution ultimately obtained 11 convictions, something of a record for a single murder. Written by the private investigator William C.

title: Abortion: Two Bodies Are Involved
description: In the interview with Bishop John McGann, your reporter asked the question: ''What about those who express a belief in a woman's right to abort as part of control over her own body?''

title: Pierce's Hearing, McCarthy's Ghost
description: For the first time since the days of Senator Joseph McCarthy, ''taking the Fifth'' in Congressional investigations is under attack.

title: Paris Talks Seek Attention for Plight of Kurds
description: Kendal Nezan, a soft-spoken refugee from Turkey and chairman of the Kurdish Institute, is dismayed that the world's millions of Kurds and their 1,000-year-old culture have become orphans of history.

title: THE CRUSADES OF DR. ELDERS
description: ON A HOLIDAY MONDAY, THE large, labyrinthine headquarters of the Arkansas Department of Public Health, in Little Rock, is virtually empty. On call in the basement are a pair of communications specialists, whose job it is to dispatch trained personnel in the event of a medical emergency, toxic chemical spill or other threat to the commonweal.

title: A CONSPIRACY TO RULE THE WORLD
description: FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM By Umberto Eco. Translated by William Weaver. 641 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: Stack's, the coin auction house, will offer a rare Higley copper token in its sale of the Gilbert Steinberg collection, which is scheduled for Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the Omni Park Central Hotel, 870 Seventh Avenue, New York City.

title: Review/Dance; Some Graham Stars Create Choreography
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company presented the season's third program of choreography by some of its members on Friday evening; Steve Rooks, Jacqulyn Buglisi and Maxine Sherman were represented.

title: SNAPSHOTS OF HOPE AND HOPELESSNESS
description: Mr. Freedman left a misimpression that the Board of Examiners did not offer an examination for high school social studies instructors for nearly five years. Unfortunately, the Board of Examiners does not have the authority to decide if an examination should be given. That, by law, is the Chancellor's responsibility. JACK BLOOMFIELD Chairman, Board of Examiners City Board of Education Brooklyn

title: Mother Teresa Out of Hospital
description: Mother Teresa has been discharged from a Calcutta hospital after more than a month of treatment for a heart problem, the Press Trust of India said today. The agency quoted hospital officials as saying Mother Teresa, the 79-year-old Nobel Peace Prize winner, had been advised to rest for at least two weeks. There was no report of where she would be staying.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Whale of a Story

title: Louisiana Warden Dismissed Over Security
description: The warden of the Louisiana State Penitentiary has been dismissed because he operated a cockfighting business at the prison and failed to maintain security and to report escapes, the head of the state's corrections department said on Wednesday.

title: CRIME/MYSTERY
description: TROPICAL FREEZE By James W. Hall. 319 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company.

title: A BUILDING THAT SHOULD BE ALLOWED TO FLOUT THE RULES
description: This may be a story about individuals taking on a huge corporation, or it may be a story about preserving the integrity of a celebrated monument, or it may be a story about how the very best buildings should sometimes be allowed to flout all the rules of architecture. In truth, this story is all these things and more. For the turmoil that has surrounded the John Hancock Center for the last year and a half is a saga of architectural politics at its liveliest and most intense, even for this city, where buildings bring out the kind of popular passions that in most towns are reserved for sports teams.

title: Janet Rich Wed To Mark Edwards
description: Janet Wilson Rich and Mark Adrian Edwards, graduates of Harvard University, were married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday at Memorial Church on the Harvard campus. The Rev. Daniel Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Woody Allen Counts the Wages of Sin
description: Movies frequently raise questions about the moral structure of the universe, but rarely do they talk about it. Woody Allen has chosen to talk about it in ''Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' which opened Friday. Whether God exists, whether reality is pitiless, and religious belief merely wishful thinking, whether justice and love can prevail over might or even over daily routine - these are questions explicitly discussed and assumed to bear on at least one life-or-death decision.

title: On Language; Parley in the Foothills
description: THE >SUMMIT USED to be 'way up there, at the top, the peak, the zenith. From the Latin >summus, ''highest,'' the word offered a view that was breathtaking.

title: The World Looks for One Way to Save the Elephants
description: LIKE many Africans, the Zimbabwean farmers in the Nyami Nyami district on the shores of the Zambesi River long regarded the local elephants as a nuisance that trampled crops or as an easy source of meat and ivory.

title: The Mideast, As Seen by James Baker
description: FOR nine months, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been trying to jump-start the Middle East peace process with an approach that forces the parties to the conflict to take the lead and leaves America serving as a catalyst in the background. The next few weeks should determine whether Israelis and Palestinians will latch onto this approach as an original route to change or a novel way to keep things the same.

title: Clemson Shocked By Georgia Tech
description: Jerry Mays scored two touchdowns and Scott Sisson kicked three field goals today as Georgia Tech stunned Clemson, 30-14, possibly dooming the Tigers' hopes of an unprecedented fourth consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference title.

title: House Built by Students Awaits a Buyer and Site
description: IT is apparent that real estate is in a slump when a new two-bedroom house in Ocean County is advertised at $16,000 for four months and does not sell.

title: Airport Buses
description: To the Editor: I recently had occasion to accompany an elderly friend to the Carey Bus Terminal at Park Avenue and 42d Street and was appalled at the lack of basic facilities at what is the only pickup and dropoff station on the East Side of New York, for travelers going to Kennedy International Airport and La Guardia.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TOMORROW'S CRIMES. By Donald E. Westlake. (Mysterious Press, $18.95.) The editorial paterfamilias of the so-called ''Golden Age'' of science fiction in the 1940's and 50's, Analog magazine's John Campbell, maintained that mystery and science fiction could not satisfactorily coexist in a single story.

title: Shakespeare: The Black Hole
description: To the Editor:

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: I always had great respect for President Harry S. Truman. But as one who knew President Dwight D. Eisenhower on a daily basis for 10 years, 8 of them in the White House, I categorically deny that he was ever ''surly'' or ''disagreeable.'' General Eisenhower was a gentleman who never stooped to innuendoes or lies. ANN C. WHITMAN Confidential Secretary to President Eisenhower Washington

title: SHUTTLE PROBLEM SOLVED, NASA SAYS
description: An engine computer to replace the one that developed problems on the space shuttle Atlantis passed its tests today, and the space agency said preparations were being made to launch the shuttle on Tuesday.

title: John F. X. Condon, Announcer For New York Knicks, Dies at 75
description: John F. X. Condon, the resonant voice of Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks basketball team for 42 seasons, died of cancer Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Prospects; Another Black Monday?
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 190.58 points, to 2569.26, on Friday, the largest decline since the Oct. 19, 1987, crash. The market began to fall on news that the big United Airlines buyout deal had fallen through. This 6.91 percent decline in the value of the Dow came just four days after the market hit new highs. Four market watchers assess what might happen next. Charles I. Clough Chief investment strategist, Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Donna Zaccaro Wed to Paul Ullman
description: Donna Anne Zaccaro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Zaccaro of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Paul Arthur Ullman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ullman Jr. of St. Louis. Msgr. Gerald J. Langelier and Rabbi Joseph R. Rosenbloom performed the interfaith ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Reaction Sought on Greenway Proposal
description: COUNTY residents will have a chance this week to comment on the state's ''greenway'' concept, a plan to preserve the Hudson River Valley by creating a chain of interlocking parks, trails and recreation sites from New York City to Albany.

title: Jill Wolfe to Wed Mitchell Roberts
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Wolfe of Plattsburgh, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Kathryn Wolfe, a marketing research project director at Hill, Holliday Advertising in Boston, and Mitchell Jonathan Roberts, a director of marketing and leasing at the General Investment and Development Company, a Boston real-estate concern. Mr. Roberts is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Roberts of Newton Centre, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title: FROM BAKERSFIELD TO BOGOTA
description: THE LAST RUN An American Woman's Years Inside a Colombian Drug Family - and Her Dramatic Escape. By Kay Wolff and Sybil Taylor. 342 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Greene
description: WHEN Fort Greene residents want a night on the town, they can stay close to home. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music and its Majestic Theater, there is everything from ballet to opera to jazz. Sheila's Restaurant offers such musicians as the violinist Noel Pointer, and drama and comedy can be found at the Cecil Alonzo Theater, the Paul Robeson Theater and the Restoration Project Theater Company.

title: No '65 Blackout Looting
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dartmouth; Alcohol Abuse Spurs Suspension Of a Fraternity
description: Dartmouth College officials suspended recognition of one of its 31 fraternities last week following an investigation into alcohol abuse at initiation activities two years ago.

title: Hits Are Nice, but You Can't Win Without Scoring Runs
description: Shawon Dunston is best known as a fine-fielding, hard-throwing shortstop of the Chicago Cubs, but during the recent National League playoff, he stood in the middle of the Cubs' clubhouse and played baseball philosopher, raising a series of interesting questions.

title: DON'T SHARE YOUR AGENT WITH A GHOST
description: NAKED ONCE MORE By Elizabeth Peters. 296 pp. New York: Warner Books. $17.95.

title: ART VIEW
description: Every so often there comes along an exhibition of theater material that, for the enthusiast, is touching, amusing and stimulating beyond all expectation. One such is ''100 Years of Russian Ballet 1830-1930'' at Eduard Nakhamkin Fine Arts, 1055 Madison Avenue, at 80th Street.

title: Not-So-Terrible 2-Year-Olds
description: Adjudicating and Stella Madrid, who won Grade I races half an hour apart two weeks ago at Belmont Park, came right back and did it again yesterday to prove themselves New York's leading 2-year-olds.

title: FICTION
description: FREQUENT FLYER. By Kinky Friedman. (Morrow, $16.95.) Perhaps because a marketing gimmick can be one of the keys to success in writing a series of mysteries, Kinky Friedman is at once the author and the protagonist of his detective novels. In ''Frequent Flyer,'' his fourth whodunit, Mr. Friedman's hero, Kinky, a rock musician turned occasional snooper and constant smart mouth, is once again a sort of urban Indiana Jones, operating out of a lower Manhattan loft where he lives in a perpetual haze of cigar smoke with his cat. In this adventure, he is summoned to the funeral of an old Peace Corps buddy, only to find that the body in the coffin is not his friend but a stranger whom everyone else seems to regard as the legitimate article. As he tries to unravel the mystery, Kinky ventures from Manhattan to Bayonne, N.J., and also back in time to his years as a Peace Corps volunteer in Borneo. Kinky is a forensic Neil Simon, a king of the one-liners who comes up with such gems as the definition of the common Austrian affliction ''Waldheimer's disease,'' which occurs ''when you can't remember that you used to be a Nazi.'' In company with an unlikely pair of sidekicks named Ratso and Rambam, he hunts and is hunted by Nazi villains in a plot that's topped off with a reasonably bloody climax. ''Frequent Flyer,'' which has some fine descriptions of Borneo and its people (as well as of New York City and its people), is a more than passable companion for a short plane trip. But some readers may find that its humor depends far too much on jokes about drugs and booze.

title: SNAPSHOTS OF HOPE AND HOPELESSNESS
description: In the late 1960's, there was a shortage of teachers in New York City. I had a degree in English and had completed the undergraduate education credit requirements, except student teaching, at Hunter College, at night, while working for an insurance company during the day. I was enrolled in the Master of Arts in Teaching program.

title: Will Success Spoil Laurie Anderson?
description: Can a performance artist who arose from the depths of lower Manhattan bohemia retain her artistic self-possession while backstroking through the shark-infested waters of commercial popular music? And can an artist with a radically original but idiosyncratically limited style continue to grow and yet retain the stylistic signatures that distinguished her in the first place?

title: Scholar's Progress, Home to Dorm
description: ''WHEN are we going to start looking at colleges, Mom?''

title: That Last Step When the Tango Turns Deadly
description: In a room that smells of smoke and sweat, a man dressed in a brown shirt, black pants and leather boots drags a woman along the floor by her hair. In another part of the room, a man in a black hat pulled low over his eyes thrusts his knee between a woman's legs, forcing her back to arch and her bare arms to flare out. Against the far wall, a group of unshaven men in high boots finger the knots in their neckerchiefs and watch through half-closed eyes. Across the floor, a young couple lean into each other's bodies as they pass a cigarette back and forth.

title: Eat and Be Wary, Governor
description: Gov. Bill Clements was among several diners who witnessed an armed robbery at a restaurant Thursday night in which one man was shot. The lone robber apparently did not recognize Mr. Clements, who was seatedestors sell their shares, because he was confident that any drop would be temporary. 'Some Shock Value'

title:
FOCUS: Historic-Property Auctions;
National Treasures Fail to Find Bidders
description: LEAD: RICHARD J. THOMAS had an auctioneer's nightmare last month. Five times he was poised to auction historic properties in five cities across the nation - from here to New Haven - in what was billed as the first sale of its kind in the country. Five times the results were the same: no bidders.

title: Words or Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Shore Confronts New Trends in Tourism
description: AS local and state tourism officials and oceanfront communities finish their assessments of last summer and start to plan budgets for next year, the talk is focusing on a trend that has been changing the face of the Jersey Shore in this decade.

title: Bankruptcy: The Facts
description: As an attorney in Garden City whose firm has 14 years of bankruptcy experience, I read, with great interest, the article on Sept. 10 on the rise of personal bankruptcy filings on Long Island. The increase in my business during the past year is consistent with that conclusion. However, there were inaccuracies regarding personal bankruptcy. First, the writer refers to the Bankruptcy Act and Chapters VII, X, XI, and XIII. The Bankruptcy Act and Chapters designated with roman numerals were superseded in 1979 by the Bankruptcy Code. The code provided many changes to the old act, including liberalizing the exemptions for property and money which debtors may keep, after filing of a bankruptcy petition.

title: Into Namibia With Ballots And Pollsters
description: A young campaign organizer just back from the northern region of Kavango burst into the office of the South-West Africa People's Organization here.

title: Lynda K. Jones, Teacher, to Wed
description: The engagement of Lynda Kathryn Jones to Johan Willem Edward Maitland, a son of Caro Maitland of Houston and the late Edward Jan Maitland, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Jones of Larchmont, N.Y. A November wedding is planned.

title: Surf's Up in Australia
description: WHEN the surf is up on Sydney's beaches in the southern summer, paddling a surfboard into the lineup to catch a wave can bring on an inferiority complex of asphyxiating proportions. Or it can inspire even the most mediocre of surfers to feats previously achieved only in the imagination.

title: Will Rice Be the Next Hot Variety?
description: With some of the nutritional myths about the empty calories in white bread dispelled, white bread has staged a mild comeback since the 70's. ''Last year, we had a slight increase in our white bread sales after years of going down,'' said a spokesman for Interstate Bakeries. ''That's significant, because you still build the brand with white bread.''

title: Patricia Hayashi, Lawyer, Weds Michael F. Bartok
description: Patricia C. Hayashi, an associate at the New York office of the Minneapolis law firm of Dorsey & Whitney, was married yesterday evening to Michael F. Bartok, an associate general counsel at Paramount Communications in New York. Rabbi Alfred Lansberg officiated at Temple Emanu-El in Edison, N.J.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lock Haven, Pa.;
Subdivisions Picking Up
description: LEAD: SUBDIVISION activity has picked up in north central Pennsylvania's Clinton County, which has a history of flooding and, recently, of high unemployment.

title: Pitt Finishes Well To Beat Navy, 31-14
description: Alex Van Pelt threw two touchdown passes, including a 19-yarder to Ricky Turner that started a run of 24 consecutive points, and Pittsburgh erased a 7-0 Navy lead today for a 31-14 victory.

title: Susan Shagrin Plans to Wed
description: November wedding plans for Susan H. Shagrin and Daniel J. Pitkowsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Pitkowsky of Berkeley Heights, N.J., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Sandra Zahn-Oreck of Washington and Don M. Shagrin of Los Angeles. Miss Shagrin, 26 years old, is an associate at the New York law firm of Guazzo, Perelson, Rushfield & Guazzo. Mr. Pitkowsky, 26, is a senior management consultant at the Information Consulting Group in New York.

title: Lounge Wear From Your Easy Chair
description: A growing number of women are doubling their leisure comfort - and time - by ordering their at-home uniforms through mail-order catalogues. Since a close fit is the antithesis of lounge wear, these garments are among the most frequently ordered by mail, representatives of the largest mail-order outfitters say.

title: Review/Dance; Another Side of Lucinda Childs
description: Lucinda Childs may have been offering a bit of dance history at the Joyce Theater on Thursday night when she performed ''Carnation,'' a solo she created in 1964 for the ground-breaking experimentalist Judson Dance Theater. But it was vibrant history, and revealed a side of Ms. Childs that we seldom see these days.

title: All (3) Eyes Were On Him
description: Vasya Surin saw the aliens. In a park in Voronezh, 300 miles southeast of Moscow. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said so, in a straight-faced report that conveniently, and perhaps not coincidentally, provided the Soviet public last week with plenty to ponder besides bare food shelves and chaotic politics. Tass said the landing had been confirmed ''scientifically'' and through ''biolocation.'' ''One, two or three creatures similar to humans and a small robot came out'' of the ball-shaped spacecraft, Tass said. Vasya, one of several witnesses to the encounter, told another Soviet publication the aliens were nine feet tall, had a hump where their heads should have been and had three eyes apiece. With psychics and paranormals garnering high ratings on Soviet television, it was just a matter of time, perhaps, before the press would get into the act.

title: East German Anguish
description: LEAD: When a 30-year-old engineer fleeing from Leipzig, East Germany, arrived in the West recently, he needed only a few blunt words to describe his native land: ''It's an economic catastrophe.''

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on page 16 of the Arts and Leisure section today by Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz about the film ''Crimes and Misdemeanors'' renders a word incorrectly in some copies, in a sentence about the High Holy Days. The passage should read: ''Of course I saw the film between Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur, the Jewish New Year time, when we Jews ponder God's judgment and mercy.''

title: NONFICTION
description: SINS OF THE FATHER: The True Story of a Family Running From the Mob. By Nick Taylor. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The ostensible reason why Sal Polisi, a low-level mobster and gambler from New York City, decided to become an informer for Federal authorities was to give his two teen-age sons a chance in life. In reality, Mr. Polisi's motivation seems to have been a desire to avoid a long prison term for drug dealing. Whatever the reason, Nick Taylor, in ''Sins of the Father,'' portrays in careful detail the extraordinary impact on Mr. Polisi's wife and sons when he opted to wear a wire to get evidence against a corrupt state judge. To protect his safety, Mr. Polisi and his family had to enter the Federal Witness Protection Program; using new identities and living in another state, they began again. The Polisi family is shown as it made the transition from the familiar to a world bereft of family, friends, former jobs and schools, even the family dog. At one point Sal Jr., the eldest son, cries out: ''I didn't do anything. I didn't make any mistakes. . . . I didn't and [ his brother ] Joe didn't. And Mom didn't either. Why do we have to go?'' The family comes to understand that they, too, must atone for Sal Polisi's criminal past. While Mr. Taylor, a contributing editor to Conde Nast Traveler, does a fine job in relaying the family's narrative, he is unfortunately weak when it comes to explaining the roles of informants, prosecutors and agents in the Federal court system. We learn virtually nothing of Mr. Polisi's role at the judge's trial. Nor do we know why he winds up as the lead witness in an unrelated case, that of the reputed mob boss John Gotti, a development that takes over the book's final pages. As his nickname, Crazy Sal, suggests, Mr. Polisi is hardly a model of a credible witness. In the end, the corrupt judge is convicted and gets five years, and Mr. Gotti is acquitted. Mr. Polisi resumes his paternal role and gets to star in this book.

title: Nature Survey Turns Up Surprises in Fairfield County
description: THE slimy salamander, a North American variety of salamander that has long been considered to be rare in Connecticut, may not be as uncommon here as once thought, according to a survey of Fairfield County by the Nature Conservancy.

title: Deciding How to Cash In an Annuity
description: For at least a decade, deferred annuities have been popular with investors. Under these contracts, money you pay to an insurance company builds up, free of current income taxes. The taxes are deferred until you reclaim your cash.

title: Six Are Injured in Fire Aboard Delta Airliner
description: A Delta Air Lines airliner loading passengers caught fire here today, injuring six people and leaving a four-foot hole in the fuselage, officials said.

title: Markets to Test Safeguards If Stock Prices Fall Further
description: In the wake of Friday's market plunge, the nation's financial exchanges are bracing for what could be the first test of procedures that would temporarily halt trading if stock prices declined steeply. The plans for such a halt were adopted after the 1987 crash.

title: CLICHES OF THE 80'S
description: Years from now, purveyors of style will easily be able to date rooms decorated in the 1980's. Indeed, in every decade, certain design trends become not simply signatures of their time but veritable cliches. The ubiquitous English country style, for example, ushered in an overabundance of clutter and chintz, while the post-modern interior brought back neo-classical columns and busts. Pictured here are some of this decade's old favorites. Elements of the English country look

title: The Deficit Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Ager Guilty in Rio Grande Raft Killing
description: A 17-year-old youth was sentenced to 30 years in prison today for fatally shooting a rafter on the Rio Grande last year.

title: China Says Taiwan Is 'Buying Hearts' Abroad
description: China has accused Taiwan of using its wealth to buy diplomatic recognition with foreign countries, as a new quarrel further strained relations across the Taiwan Strait.

title:
MUSIC;
Creating a Baroque Ensemble
description: LEAD: A PROVEN local audience for Baroque music, a desire for administrative independence and approaching motherhood were the major factors in the creation of the Baroque Soloists of New Jersey two years ago.

title: Freelance Exchange Part of National Group
description: In reference to the recent articles ''Homeworkers Warned of Fraudulent Schemes'' and ''More On L.I. Are Working at Home'' (Aug. 27) in which myself and my organization, The Long Island Freelance Exchange, were mentioned. I would like to advise you of a few errors and exclusions regarding the organizations services and locations.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Dayton; New Prohibition On Tapped Kegs Stirs Controversy
description: A new policy on alcohol at the University of Dayton prohibits tapped kegs in campus housing and other campus centers and at off-campus activities sponsored by the university unless students get permission from the university.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should the Jets Have Benched O'Brien?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Architecture Eases Into the 90's
description: THE MOST IMPORTANT legacy of the 1980's in architecture may not be a design at all, but a book. It is a slim book, and unlike many other important works, it did not transform the thinking of an age. Rather, it summed up a whole set of impulses, and gave coherence to a time.

title: THE HOMICIDAL MANIAC: A NOVELIST'S BEST FRIEND
description: ''From the evidence coming across our desk, this is the Year of the Serial Killer.''

title: EVIDENCE SPARSE BUT GRISLY
description: THE WOODCHIPPER MURDER By Arthur Herzog. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: Showdown In Florida: Woman Vs. Lizard
description: SOMETIMES, as you concentrate on something, you sense movement out of the corner of your eye. That night, I was sitting quietly in the living room of our condominium in Boca Raton reading a novel. Through the glass doors of the terrace, I could see red streaks in the sky as the sun set.

title: Bones Back Beastly Tale Of Old West
description: A jury of 13 experts who dug up the common grave of five Colorado gold prospectors to find out who killed and ate them has agreed with the verdict handed down more than 100 years ago: Alferd Packer murdered his colleagues while they were marooned in the Rocky Mountains in the vicious winter of 1874.

title: A Squeeze on MarginsAs Grocers Compete In Bread
description: Bob Hocutt moved at a stiff-legged gait through the bustling Winn-Dixie supermarket in the Riverdale section of Atlanta. He pulled up at the voluminous bread aisle and scanned the endless piles of loaves. ''You have to check out the markets a lot in this business,'' said Mr. Hocutt, the vice president of sales for Flowers Industries' Atlanta Baking Company. ''You have bread now that didn't even exist a few months ago. When you have a fresh daily product and all these new varieties, things can get wild.''

title: Tierney Finn, Actress, Weds
description: Tierney Finn, an actress, and Mark Fitzmartin, a television commercial producer for Fernbach Productions in New York, both graduates of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, were married yesterday in Holy Trinity Chapel at N.Y.U. The Rev. Raymond Raferty, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. The bride, 26 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Finn of Belmont, Mass. Mr. Fitzmartin, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Fitzmartin of Freehold, N.J.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Jean Pierre Bretaudeau: Children's Wear Designer
description: LEAD: ''People are always trying to dress children like little adults. But I want to do children's wear for the way they really live,'' said Jean Pierre Bretaudeau, who might be described as a Jean-Paul Gaultier for children. ''They are insolent, provocative and very rough.''

title: Door Opens to New Bishop's Knock
description: When Episcopal Bishop Richard F. Grein ceremonially pounded on the great bronze doors of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, the Episcopal Church in New York was hearing the sound of a new kind of leadership.

title:
GARDENING;
Autumn in Palest Gold to Deepest Sienna
description: LEAD: IT usually begins with the red maples, first appearing at higher altitudes like in the Poconos, often as early as late August. By the time that the last of this species has developed its autumnal brilliance, other species have added yellows, golds, oranges, reds and browns to the display. Depending on the weather, the display may last from three to six weeks before the leaves fall to the ground, providing sustenance for the multitude of funguses, bacteria, earthworms and other creatures that inhabit and improve the soil.

title:
ART;
Tracing Course of French Printmaking
description: LEAD: AS part of its extensive series of programs commemorating the bicentennial of the French Revolution, Hofstra University is presenting a survey exhibition, ''Printmaking in 19th-Century France,'' tracing progress in the graphic arts during a period when new techniques were developed and earlier ones were revitalized.

title:
About Men;
The Recording Angel
description: LEAD: ON LINE AT THE video store the other day, the man ahead of me took a 10-pack of blank tapes from a display rack near the register. ''I go through tons of this stuff shooting my son,'' he said. ''Today he's getting his first haircut. That's almost an hour of tape right there.''

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT: SOUNDINGS;
From an Original Master, Symphonies Writ Small
description: LEAD: Carl Nielsen's symphonies - among our century's finest and most original - may not be as familiar as those of Mahler, Sibelius and Shostakovich, but they are not exactly neglected either. Currently in progress are four complete cycles of the Danish composer's symphonic works (from Herbert Blomstedt on London, Paavo Berglund on RCA, Esa-Pekka Salonen on CBS and Myung-Whun Chung on Bis).

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
MURDER MOST PUZZLING: CAN YOU SOVLE THIS CASE?
description: LEAD: Everybody in the town of Columbo regarded Dizzy McNish not only as slow-witted, but as one of the most incompetent police officers in the state, and yet - He was driving along Route 2 1/2 and thinking of Marcella McNish and all the little McNishes when he spotted a car parked on Weepers Lane, just off the highway.

title: TALKING: Parking Space; Protecting Rights in a Conversion
description: IN New York City, where garage space rents for as much as a small apartment and a single space sells for more than $20,000, it is little wonder that the right to a rent-stabilized parking space, or at least the right to retain a place on a building's waiting list, has become an issue worth fighting for.

title: POSTINGS: Victorian Vice No More; 20 Units for 23d
description: In a city where everything from garment-industry lofts to grim 19th-century tenements has been renovated into fashionable, high-priced apartments, it may come as little surprise that developers have now turned their attention to a onetime bordello. The building, at 140 West 23d Street, between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, in the Chelsea neighborhood, has been renovated into Claret Commons, a condominium with 20 new apartments.

title: THE MAN WHO WALKED IN THE WOODS
description: FROM HIROSHIMA TO GLASNOST At the Center of Decision: A Memoir. By Paul H. Nitze with Ann M. Smith and Steven L. Rearden. Illustrated. 504 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $25.

title: Felicia Pfeiffer Weds
description: The marriage of Felicia Constance Pfeiffer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Pfeiffer Jr. of Glen Rock, N.J., to Michael David Angus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Angus of Woodbridge, Ontario, took place yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Stone Harbor, N.J. The Rev. Eugene Kernan officiated. Mrs. Angus, 30 years old, is a graduate of Wesleyan University. She received an M.B.A. from Dartmouth College, as did her husband, a graduate of Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario. She is a saleswoman at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. Mr. Angus, 32, is a management consultant in London for Bain & Company of Boston.

title: Review/Dance; Christine Dakin in Martha Graham's 'Maze'
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company offered two quite different performances last Sunday afternoon and Tuesday night at City Center (131 West 55th Street), where the troupe is now in the second week of its three-week season.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: OF course, I'd heard of Chief Seattle's discourse on the land - accounted among the most eloquent statements on the environment ever made. It was one of those things you might have read in college - like ''The Prophet'' and ''The Hobbit'' and ''Steppenwolf.''

title: T. E. Lawrence's State of Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Embryo Front in the Battle of the Sexes; No-Fault Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Machines Replace Workers And Turn Out More Loaves
description: Bread has looked like bread for centuries. But the bakeries that make it have changed substantially to speed up production and reduce labor costs.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: There is no better sign of the perpetual invention in chess than the longevity of the Marshall Gambit.

title: October Turns Ugly Once More
description: Stocks had a dizzying plunge on Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping a scary 190.58 points and reviving painful memories of the 1987 stock crash that produced a 508-point plunge on Oct. 19. Friday's heavy selling wiped out all the gains from an early October rally that, just last Monday, had taken the Dow to a new high of 2,791.41. The plunge came when the employee-led group trying to buy UAL said it could not raise all the money it needed. Deals like the UAL buyout have provided much of the market's strength this year. For the week, the Dow lost 216.26 points, to close at 2,569.26. Bond prices surged as investors shifted money out of stocks. The dollar posted steep declines after the market tumbled. *

title: Outfield Assist To Remember
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Victory Is Yet to Come
description: As the new Solidarity-led Government moves into its second month, there is no triumphalism in Poland. Is is as though winning the long struggle to wrest power from the Communist monopoly were a cold bath, an uneasy awakening from the heady if harsh days of confrontation.

title: When It's Over
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SAMURAI EXHIBITION

title: 'Extra' Work Propels Career
description: SHE is seen but not heard as a Hasidic woman with a baby among the pushcarts on the Lower East Side (''Crossing Delancey''), as a mourner attending a funeral, again with a baby, in ''State of Grace,'' and as a neighbor, this time without a baby, watching Roseanne Barr blowing up her own house in ''She Devil.'' (The latter two films have not yet been released.) She is Shellen Lubin, who grew up in Valley Stream, and the baby is her 3 1/2-year-old son, Zachary Lubin-West. While seeking exposure as, simultaneously, actress, cabaret performer, writer, director and vocal coach (''I do everything; it all feeds from the same place,'' she said), Ms. Lubin has made an active avocation of being an ''extra'' in, by her estimation, 15 to 20 films, including 8 in the last six months. Zachary has been in five. An assortment of Ms. Lubin's talent, in cabaret and theater, is currently on display in Manhattan. An act entitled ''A Piece of My Mind,'' in which she sings her own songs, was performed in July and is being revived this month at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street. Remaining performances are tomorrow and next Monday at 8 P.M. And a play, ''Liars,'' by Elliot Myers, which Ms. Lubin directed, opened last night at the Producers Club, 358 West 44th Street. Performances are being given Thursday and Fridays at 8 P.M. and Saturdays at 7 and 10 P.M.

title: Correction
description: A chart last week with an article about vending-machine sales misidentified the source of the data. It was Vending Times, not Vending Today.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: REASONABLE DOUBT. By Steve Vogel. (Contemporary Books, $19.95.) In the waning hours of Nov. 7, 1983, 30-year-old Susan Hendricks and her three children were stabbed to death in their Bloomington, Ill., home. While he professed to have been away on a business trip when the murders occurred, the husband and father, David Hendricks, was suspected by the police almost immediately.

title: HEARTS AND WRITERS
description: I enjoyed Michael Frank's About Men article ''No Longer My Brother's Keeper'' (Sept. 17), but would offer him one comfort. He compares himself, a writer, unfavorably with his brother, a doctor, and wonders ''Can [ writing ] ever accomplish something so essential - so magical - as shocking the life back into a man whose heart has stopped?'' I would argue that this magical shock is precisely the purpose of good writing. DARREBY AMBLER Portland, Me.

title: Army Stops Holy Cross
description: After beating up on Ivy League teams the previous three Saturdays and prolonging its unbeaten stretch this season to five games, Holy Cross stepped up to a higher plateau today and tripped. The Crusaders lost to Army, 45-9, on one of those soft autumn afternoons at Michie Stadium that belong in a painting.

title: Review/Viola; Neubauer, New Soloist, In Recital
description: It was immediately clear back in 1984 why the New York Philharmonic should make Paul Neubauer its youngest section leader ever. Indeed the question had to be how long the Philharmonic could hold on to him, and the answer seems to be five years; the 26-year-old violist has resigned his chair to concentrate on solo and chamber-music playing. His performance Friday night at Weill Recital Hall more than confirmed that he stands to make a contribution in those spheres.

title: How Bad Are Nets? Fitch Finds Out
description: When Bill Fitch became the Nets' coach in August, he knew the team was far from being a contender. Now Fitch is finding out exactly how far away the Nets are.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Christmas cactus, jade plant and any other house plants that are lingering outdoors should be moved in, pronto; frost can be expected any time now and these plants could be ruined. In the garden, continue planting, especially bulbs. Rake leaves or blow them off the lawn and add to compost. Water newly planted shrubs, especially evergreens, and perennials to be sure their roots grow well before the soil freezes. Humus/Compost

title: TRACY ULLMAN MAKES A FACE
description: TRACEY ULLMAN, THE PUCKISH 29-year-old British star of her own Sunday night television variety show, has played girls half her age and matrons twice her age; she's played a psychologist and a postal worker, a bitter Beverly Hills divorcee and a suicidal chorine.

title: 4 Parade With Signs Admitting Their Guilt
description: Four young men who pulled crab traps from the St. Johns River on Memorial Day weekend began paying their debt to society today - by parading on a bridge with signs admitting their acts.

title: Are We Speaking The Same Language?
description: IF I had immigrated to New Jersey from a foreign-speaking country, I would have anticipated the need to learn a new language to make myself understood. But after my moving here from Boston, which is, after all, part of the same country - no border check, no passport - it comes as a shock that I still need an occasional interpreter after nearly 30 years.

title: SNAPSHOTS OF HOPE AND HOPELESSNESS
description: Samuel G. Freedman is right; teachers and administrators do work long hours in buildings that are often crumbling from within and under siege by lawless elements from without (''Snapshots of Hope and Hopelessness,'' Sept. 17).

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Had Your Fill of Football? Here's a Soup to Divert You
description: Not everyone in a household wants to watch football games on Sunday. For those looking for an excuse to wander in and out, nothing beats cooking.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Virgin Islands Hotels Offer Money Back

title: Far-fetched Connections
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet Success for Saviors of A's and Giants
description: Bob Lurie remembers the day 13 years ago when he bought the San Francisco Giants for $8 million because they were more interesting than real estate and because they had their bags packed and were ready to skip town for Toronto. He was cheered as a great civic hero for saving the ball club by the Bay.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Miss Eckert Marries
description: Mary Ellen Pamela Eckert and Kevin L. Potucek, graduates of Wichita State University, were married in New York yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Leroy Matz. The bride, 30 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William G. Eckert of Wichita, Kan. Mr. Potucek, 30, is a son of the late Dorothy Bircher Potucek and the late Joseph Potucek Jr. The bride is a merchandiser for the White Stag division of the Warnaco Company in New York. Her husband is the Northeast regional sales and marketing manager in New York for KDI American Products of Moorpark, Calif.

title: U.S. Softens Position in Trade Talks With Japan
description: Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, ended her first official visit to Japan today by softening an important American position and underscoring a basic shift in American trade policy that may make it more difficult to measure progress in opening Japan's markets.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
THE DETECTIVE WRITES HAIKU
description: LEAD: INSPECTOR IMANISHI INVESTIGATES By Seicho Matsumoto. Translated by Beth Cary. 313 pp. New York: Soho Press. $18.95.

title: On the Receiving End Of the New 'Junk Fax' Law
description: LEAD: THE special of the day at Premier Market in Westport was hot turkey. Frank Tucci, the market's proprietor, put a 22-pound turkey in a convection oven, baked it for two hours, carved it, then had to make a decision he had never faced in all his years in the deli business: To fax or not to fax.

title: NONFICTION
description: RAYMOND CHANDLER'S LOS ANGELES. By Elizabeth Ward and Alain Silver. (Overlook, Cloth, $25; Paper, $19.95.) Perhaps no detective in fiction is so indelibly associated with a city as is Philip Marlowe with Los Angeles. In the variegated communities that make up the West Coast metropolis, Marlowe walked those ''mean streets . . . in search of a hidden truth,'' which his creator, Raymond Chandler, decreed was the proper path of the modern detective hero. The dream factories of Hollywood, the oceanfront playgrounds of Malibu, the seedy corruption of ''Bay City'' (actually Santa Monica) stimulated Chandler's overheated romantic imagination. Los Angeles, a city that has devoted itself to producing illusions, was an ideal backdrop for Chandler's labyrinthine tales of innocence outraged and avenged, described in his feverishly florid metaphors. ''Raymond Chandler's Los Angeles'' gives an illustrated tour of Marlowe's ''neon-lighted slum,'' with more than 100 photographs of some 60 locations described in the seven novels and 23 short stories published in Chandler's lifetime. Elizabeth Ward, a freelance writer, and Alain Silver, a motion-picture producer, have performed ably as literary detectives, tracing the sometimes lightly disguised models (Silver Lake became ''Gray Lake,'' for example). They also include informed, affectionate biographical comments on Chandler and his hard-boiled but softhearted sleuth. ''I don't mind Marlowe being a sentimentalist,'' Chandler said. ''All us tough guys are helpless sentimentalists at heart.''

title: Martha Heintz, Designer, Weds Daniel W. Walsh
description: At the Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N.Y., Martha L. Heintz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Clemens Heintz of Clinton, was married yesterday to Daniel Woodruff Walsh, the son of Allen T. Walsh of Kill Devil Hills, N.C., and the late Mrs. Walsh. The Rev. Gerald Platz, a Presbyterian minister, officiated. Mrs. Walsh, a freelance interior designer, graduated from Skidmore College. Her father is a radiologist. Mr. Walsh, a graduate of the University of Connecticut, is a bond salesman and vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Cranberry Festival's Many Delights
description: LEAD: AT this season when New Jersey is drenched in its annual explosion of leafy color, the pinelands village of Chatsworth emerges with its sea of red cranberries, ripe for harvesting.

title: What Emerson Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Fischer-Dieskau Recitals
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau will give two recitals at Carnegie Hall early next month, one devoted to Schubert and the other to Richard Strauss. The German baritone's first program, on Nov. 3, will offer poems of Goethe set to music by Schubert; the Strauss recital will take place Nov. 5. Hartmut Holl will be the accompanist. Both concerts begin at 8 P.M. Tickets range from $60 to $13 and are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Falcons' Running Defused by the Irish
description: In the rarefied atmosphere of a jammed Falcon Stadium at the United States Air Force Academy tonight, the Notre Dame sophomore nicknamed Rocket explored the reaches of his personal wild blue yonder.

title: John Rex Fuqua Is Wed To Duvall Clark Schultz
description: Duvall Clark Schultz, a daughter of Ruth Duvall Clark of Tarboro, N.C., and Jackson Kermit Schultz of Enterprise, Ala., was married yesterday to John Rex Fuqua, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Fuqua of Atlanta. The Revs. Erric Douglas Remer and Stephen Marsh Price performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Tarboro.

title: CBS Trims 30 Minutes From 'Pat Sajak Show'
description: CBS announced on Friday that ''The Pat Sajak Show'' would be shortened to one hour beginning on Oct. 30. The 90-minute program, which was introduced nine months ago to compete with NBC's ''Tonight'' show with Johnny Carson, is currently broadcast weeknights from 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. In its new format, it will end at 12:30 A.M.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the new television season refers incorrectly in some copies to the network on which the television series ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'' appears. It is ABC, not NBC.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WIDOW'S TRIAL. By John Ehle. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The widow who's on trial in this unusual and imaginatively narrated novel is pregnant, 22-year-old Winnette King Plover, accused of shooting and killing her 31-year-old husband, Lloyd Ernest Plover. Among the book's many ironies is the fact that Lloyd's former wife, Mavis, brought the two together, letting Lloyd know that ''Winnette liked the thought of him.

title: Lynda B. Leaman Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Leaman Jr. of Malvern, Pa., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Lynda B. Leaman, and Kevin A. Macdonald, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Robert M. Macdonald of Hanover, N.H.

title: Elizabeth Simard Marries
description: Elizabeth Kasson Simard and Edward Stillman Richardson were married yesterday at the United Congregational Church of Rowayton, Conn., by the Rev. John S. Livingston. Mrs. Richardson, 25 years old and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simard of Rowayton, graduated from Moravian College. She is a promotion supervisor at Woman's Day magazine in New York. Mr. Richardson, 26, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas de Quartel Richardson of Norwalk, Conn. He is a graduate of Hobart College and a salesman for the Colgate-Palmolive Company in New York.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Sydney
description: Mark Twain on a visit to Australia called Sydney Harbor ''a wonder of the world.'' The vast expanse of water with its coves and inlets extending from North Head to the Parramatta is the heart of Sydney. The city wraps itself around the water's edge and along the promontories, which run like fingers on the hills above the shoreline. Houses cluster along the ridges - colonial sandstone, red brick federation style with terra cotta roofs and multistory apartments - a chronology of the city's history.

title: Stock Traders Expect a Revised UAL Bid With Less Cash
description: Stock traders said yesterday that they expected a revised buyout bid for the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, to be assembled quickly. But they predicted that the buyout group, which includes the company's pilots union and management, might reduce the value of the bid by substituting securities for part of the cash.

title: Residents Try to Reroute a Train Platform
description: NEARLY everyone in this long-established commuter village recognizes the local dependence on the railroad, which has rolled through the center of town since 1844. But now some angry residents say the railroad has gone too far - 170 feet too far.

title: Martinu Can Now Be More Than a Name
description: The name of the Czechoslovak composer Bohuslav Martinu is well known, but probably relatively few American listeners can claim any real familiarity with his highly individualisticmusic, even though he lived in the United States for a dozen years (1941-53) and composed five of his six symphonies for American orchestras. While his music is still more or less in the novelty category in our concert halls, many of his works are available in recorded form, and additional titles are appearing with increasing frequency in anticipation of the centenary of his birth.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, a Posting on Oct. 8 about Deer Crossing at Warwick, a New York residential development, mislocated it and the developer's office. Both are in Orange, not Rockland, County, and near New Milford, an Orange County, not Bergen County, N.J., community.

title: Modern Dance Didn't Always Tell Tales
description: When Martha Graham's superb dancers begin a season on a high, and then proceed to better that exceptionally fine level of execution, it is all too easy to pay more attention to the dancing than the repertory. Nonetheless, this depth of artistry would not be possible without profound works to perform.

title: From Apples and Pears, Elegant Autumn Desserts
description: NOW is the time of year for the widest choice and highest quality of apples and pears. The best apples for cooking are those that are not too sweet but that are firm and juicy, with plenty of flavor. Use hard, crisp McIntosh, semi-sweet Cortlands or tart greening apples. Bartlett and Bosc pears are both good for cooking and their elegant shape always makes an attractive dessert.

title: Confessions of A White House Speechwriter
description: I FIRST SAW HIM AS A FOOT, a highly polished brown cordovan wagging merrily on a hassock. I spied it through the door. It was a beautiful foot, sleek, perfectly shaped. Such casual elegance and clean lines! But not a big foot, not formidable, maybe even a little . . . frail. I imagined cradling it in my arms, protecting it from un-smooth roads.

title: Schoolchildren Ponder Over Where the Garbage Goes
description: JENNIFER PERNEY said she hoped that whatever recycling was, it would help animals survive.

title: Michigan Edges Michigan State
description: Michigan's defense, led by Tripp Welborne, twice held off fourth-quarter Michigan State scoring threats today and the Wolverines beat the Spartans, 10-7.

title: Maryland Steam Ride
description: SITUATED in the Allegheny Mountains where Maryland's panhandle squeezes down to just a skinny neck between Pennsylvania and West Virginia, gritty, red-brick Cumberland is very much a real city, not a preserved-in-amber Colonial Williamsburg. It remains a railroad town, and the moaning air horns of CSX diesels echo off the surrounding mountains night and day.

title: MIAMI MAYHEM
description: SKIN TIGHT By Carl Hiaasen. 319 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Ms. Rose to Wed James H. Marrow
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Rose of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Rose, to Prof. James H. Marrow, the son of Helen C. Marrow of Miami Beach and the late Jerome Marrow of New York. A November wedding is planned.

title: Reviews/Music; Kim and Serkin Begin Series Of Beethoven Violin Sonatas
description: Beethoven's violin sonatas span the years 1797 to 1812, but for all their many merits, they hardly constitute a range of style and expression to equal the composer's string quartets or piano sonatas or symphonies. Still, it is good to hear them periodically as a body of work, and so, quite apart from its virtues of performance, the series begun by Young Uck Kim and Peter Serkin Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y (and continuing there for the next two Wednesdays) is of real value.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
HOUSEWIFE, WATER NYMPH, PRIVATE EYE
description: LEAD: THE NARROWING STREAM By John Mortimer. 186 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Where the Money Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: DARING YET LIVABLE: The Mellowing of Deconstructivism
description: Deconstructivism, the trendy architectural movement that began on the West Coast nearly a decade ago, is still influencing design. But this strident style, known for its hard-edged austerity, is rarely seen in its purist form.
