Rather, architects such as Wayne Berg, a partner of the Manhattan firm of Pasanella + Klein, are experimenting with its principles, but taking a softer, more livable approach.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: How many times have you dialed the telephone, heard a response from the other end, paused, laughed ruefully and said, ''Who is this? I forgot whom I'm calling''? The odds are that it has happened more than once. And more than likely the reverse has also occurred: you've picked up the phone and heard someone else's rueful voice with the same query.

title: Sculpture for Troubled Places
description: A strange symbol of hope has been flowering in some of New York City's most troubled neighborhoods. Sculpture.

title: New Dean Views 'Young' Pace Law School as an Opportunity
description: LEAD: CLASSICAL music from a radio wafted across the room. Unfurled on the floor were matching rugs of Chinese design. Framed photographs of family members stood on sills. The dean of the Pace University School of Law sat in a rocker. Something was curiously wrong with the picture.

title: HE DIN'T LIKE IKE
description: A number of people have asked me what I and my colleagues at the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute thought of the article ''He Didn't Like Ike.''

title: Software Is the Next Target
description: The American software industry finds itself at the crest of what can only be termed a golden age - it accounts for 52 percent of the world's software consumption and holds roughly 70 percent of a $50 billion world market. By the year 2000, the world software market will be worth $1 trillion a year.

title: Lisa R. Bardack Weds Dr. Mitchell S. Nobler
description: Lisa Rachel Bardack, a medical student at New York University, and Dr. Mitchell S. Nobler, a resident in psychiatry at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, were married last evening at Larchmont (N.Y.) Temple. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller officiated.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
description: I've been a big fan of one of baseball's greatest showmen, Rickey Henderson, for many years, and I'd like to explain why. I had the opportunity to watch him for about six hours one day at a baseball card show. Also present were Jim Kaat, Don Mattingly and Pete Rose. It was mobbed, and lines were endless. I watched Rickey smile for each fan, pose willingly for pictures, hold kids on his lap, shake hands and write personalized messages on request. Suffice it to say that Rose and Mattingly were considerably less enthusiastic. If Rickey enjoys himself on and off the field, fine. I hope he continues to enjoy the game and delight the fans. LORETTA K. Karger Woodbridge, N.J.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: If Ike was as bad as Truman says, why did he try to persuade him to be the Democratic candidate for President? THEODORE R. KUPFERMAN New York, N.Y.

title: Copters Lift Boston Commuters Over the Traffic
description: At the height of the rush hour around Boston, a 12-mile drive from the western suburb of Waltham to Logan International Airport in East Boston can take an hour and a half or longer. For passengers who use the Hub Express helicopter commuter service, it takes about eight minutes.

title: Social Events
description: North Star Anniversary

title: Tempting New Offerings in Technology
description: When stock prices crashed two years ago, hot young technology companies suffered some of the steepest declines. The market for initial public offerings, particularly in technology, vanished.

title: Q and A
description: Wimbledon

title: A New 'Thespis,' Old-Favorite 'Boheme'
description: ON the day after Christmas in 1871 a comic opera opened at the Gaiety Theater in London. The reviews were mixed and the piece did not survive long but ''Thespis,'' or ''The Gods Grown Old,'' marked the first association of two men whose names would soon be irrevocably linked, William Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan.

title: Plain or Fancy, The Greeks Said It With Metal
description: Greek metalwork - known more through adaptations made by Romans in antiquity and Europeans in the 18th and 19th centuries than through the originals - is far more remarkable in its vigor than are later manifestations. This can be seen in an exhibition of 38 ancient Greek artifacts, vessels and items of jewelry produced over a period of 600 years, and a companion display of 10 neoclassical urns, candelabra and vases of the 18th and 19th centuries, exhibited at the Michael Ward Gallery, 9 East 93d Street. Both groups of objects remain on view through Dec. 16.

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS SEEM BOGGED DOWN
description: A modest offensive by troops of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, a non-Communist Cambodian rebel faction, appears to have bogged down in northwestern Cambodia, diplomats say.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Colby; A Student Turns Tipster and Loses His Bookstore Job
description: Colby College's bookstore administrators say that a former employee, Jeffrey Winkler, was wrong: Mr. Winkler, class of '89, should never have given information about textbooks sold at the college-owned bookstore to the competing Iron Horse Bookstore.

title: B.P. as a Polluter
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Popularity
description: There were trophies, flowers, hugs and smiles for Pam Shriver in Moscow yesterday, and she didn't even reach the third round. Shriver was given the type of send-off usually reserved for Grand Slam tennis champions as she bade farewell to the Soviet capital.

title: A Beatles Movie Script Goes Onstage Instead
description: ''When i first read 'Up Against It!' I was terrified at the thought of trying to put it on the stage,'' said Kenneth Elliott of the film script Joe Orton wrote for the Beatles in 1967. Misgivings behind him, Mr. Elliott will be directing the first professional stage performances of ''Up Against It!'' in a three-week run at the Public Theater beginning Tuesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we need to import this many people then we should make the decision to let them in the front door instead of through the back door in the middle of the night. What we can't do is say we want a border that's closed to drugs but that is open to people.'' - William T. Veal, deputy chief of the Border Patrol's San Diego sector. [ 30:1. ]

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Englishtown $148,000 27 Tennent Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $1,544. Howell $94,900 83 East Parkway Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 13-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, Florida room, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,548. Jackson $135,000 53 Rhode Island Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; full finished basement, patio, c/a, pool; taxes $2,584. Springfield $315,000 3 Little Brook Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; c/a, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $5,415. South Orange $170,000 204 West Fairview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; screened porch, eat-in kitchen, w/w carpeting; taxes $3,397. Wall Township $183,500 2129 Butternut Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; patio, living-room fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $1,950. OTHER AREAS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $395,000 84 Frame Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 39-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, deck, playroom, workshop, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $6,625. Colchester, Conn. $265,000 62 Ventura Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; c/a, greenhouse-style solarium, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Levittown, L.I. $157,000 20 Springtime Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, 60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $3,200.

title: Poland Says Germans Get Right to Go West
description: East Germany has agreed to allow almost 1,000 of its citizens who have taken refuge in Poland to emigrate to the country of their choice, Poland said today.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;
Profile in Courage, a Day at a Time
description: LEAD: IT seemed as though most of the parts of Janis Henderson's life converged in front of the Mount Sinai Congregational Church at 12:30 P.M. on Sunday, Sept. 17.

title: A Corner of Italy With Ancient Ruins, Grottoes and Vineyards
description: TO PEOPLE who ''see'' Europe by hopping from one major art city to another, northern Italy's Friuli-Venezia Giulia region is nothing but a blurred landscape - flat at first, then mountainous - on the road or rail line from Venice to Vienna. Yet this multiethnic district, about three-fifths the size of Connecticut, is one of the most interesting of the country's 21 regions. Austria borders it on the north, Yugoslavia on the east; its southern boundary is the Adriatic Sea; only to the west is it connected to the rest of Italy. Not surprisingly, a variety of languages and cultures intermingle in this part of the country.

title: Town Fights With Neighbors Over Burning of Tons of Tires
description: In this poor rural town near the Rhode Island border, officials say they have found a solution to their financial woes that would also help clean up much of the Northeast: a power plant that burns 10 million discarded tires a year.

title: An Energy Glut in the Ground Imperils Ecological Hopes
description: FOSSIL fuel reserves, almost always discussed with the modifier ''dwindling'' attached, are now growing rapidly. The conventional wisdom of the 1970's was that the world was running out of oil, coal and natural gas. But in the last three years governments and the companies that do the drilling and mining have found far more than has been extracted.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JOSEPH GIORDANO;
Ethnicity Requires a Personal Journey
description: LEAD: WHILE some question whether Columbus, an Italian explorer, discovered America, few question the mark Italian-Americans have made on this country, particularly in the New York City area.

title: Anne Richmond Weds Stephen Black
description: Anne Moloney Richmond and Stephen F. Black were married yesterday in the former Presidential reception rooms at Union Station in Washington. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Christopher R. Sherrill, an Episcopal minister. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Edwin J. Moloney of Demarest, N.J., and the late Mr. Moloney. Her husband is the son of Zelma Bernstein of Baltimore and Theodore R. Black of New York.

title: Recycling: Family Recipe
description: In response to your ''Recycling Recipe: Easy as Pie'' (Opinion, Oct. 1), may I offer our family's recipe. Composting Kitchen Waste

title: Tailgate 'Terrorists': What About Trucks?
description: Terence Ripmaster, in a recent Opinion page article, and David Hull, in a letter to the New Jersey editor, both wrote about driving ''terrorists'' on the New Jersey Turnpike. To my dismay, neither referred to my ''pet'' terrorizing experiences: tailgating by those behemoth 10, 12 or whatever-wheel trucks.

title: An Industry Coalition Frays
description: THE battle over strengthening the Clean Air Act is placing enormous strain on the industry coalition that has worked together in the 1980's to lobby successfully against stronger air pollution laws.

title: Why Not Add To the Parthenon?
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Honor a Bride-to-Be
description: THE eldest of my three daughters, a 19-year-old with a cheerful outlook, attended her first bridal shower on a recent Sunday. The round trip to Manchester encompassed four hours. She arrived home tired and slightly disappointed.

title: For the Homeless, There Are No Age Barriers
description: LEAD: PETER is a husky boy of 11. Within the last six months, he and his brother have been in four different shelters. The two boys are the youngest of six children; their mother is 44, a diabetic and exhausted. The family is reluctant to speak and is suspicious of strangers. Slinging a plastic sack over his shoulder, Peter's greeting is, ''We're leaving,'' followed by, ''We don't want our friends to know we don't have a place.

title: Tropical Storm Loses Strength in the Gulf
description: Hunreds of workers fled oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico late Friday and early today as Tropical Storm Jerry inched toward Texas and Louisiana, but the storm weakened and showed few signs of regaining strength.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE MOVES TO PROVIDE CASH TO MARKETS
description: Seeking to maintain calm in the nation's financial system, the Federal Reserve Board intends to meet any sudden demands for money that might result from the stock market's sharp plunge Friday, a top official of the nation's central bank said today.

title: A '56 Encounter in East Berlin, Updated
description: I WONDER where they are and what they are thinking now, the two men we shared a table with on May Day in East Berlin in 1959. I looked for them these last weeks in the faces of the young families making their passage from Eastern Europe to the West, but it would be unlikely that I would recognize them on a television screen or in a newspaper photograph after 30 years. And it is unlikely in any case that they would be among those making the trip.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Berkeley; Video Phones, in First Public Test, Link Two Campuses in California
description: Students at two campuses of the University of California, at Berkeley and Los Angeles, have become the test market for a new public video-telephone booth called Phonavision. Its developers claim that it is the world's first video telephone for the general public.

title:
GARDENING;
Autumn in Palest Gold to Deepest Sienna
description: LEAD: IT usually begins with the red maples, first appearing at higher altitudes like in the Poconos, often as early as late August. By the time that the last of this species has developed its autumnal brilliance, other species have added yellows, golds, oranges, reds and browns to the display. Depending on the weather, the display may last from three to six weeks before the leaves fall to the ground, providing sustenance for the multitude of funguses, bacteria, earthworms and other creatures that inhabit and improve the soil.

title: MURDER AT THE SARACEN'S HEAD
description: DEATH AND THE CHASTE APPRENTICE By Robert Barnard. 211 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ARA K. HOVNANIAN;
Building Housing That's Affordable
description: LEAD: THE president of New Jersey's largest home-building company, Ara K. Hovnanian, analyzes the cost of housing in New Jersey and predicts trends. He is a frequent speaker on affordable housing.

title: O BRAVE NEW CHIPS!
description: LEAD: MICROCOSM The Quantum Revolution in Economics and Technology. By George Gilder. 426 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Burke's Solid Play Helps Lift Devils
description: Sylvain Turgeon and Pat Verbeek, two forwards traded for each other, made big early contributions for the Devils and the Whalers in tonight's game at the Civic Center.

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; Will the Wild Bulbs Be Saved?
description: The majority of hardy bulbs that home gardeners are planting this fall can be bought without guilt. Tulip, hyacinth and daffodil bulbs that provide the spring splendor are raised by the billions as a crop, mainly in the Netherlands, and shipped to markets worldwide.

title: 'I'D RATHER PLAY A MAID THAN BE ONE'
description: LEAD: HATTIE The Life of Hattie McDaniel. By Carlton Jackson. Illustrated. 220 pp. Lanham, Md.: Madison Books. $18.95.

title: HOW VIOLENT IS HE? MEMORY FAILS
description: TICKET TO RIDE By Dennis Potter. 202 pp. New York: Vintage Books, Paper, $6.95.

title: Wendy M. E. Alling Wed To John T. Judy, Designer
description: Wendy M. E. Alling and John Thomas Judy, graduates of Carnegie-Mellon University, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., by the Rev. John Croneberger.

title: Penn State Wins A Big Game Big
description: After his team lost to Pitt and was crushed by Florida State in the last two games, the Syracuse head coach, Dick Mac Pherson, said he was glad the Orangemen's game with Penn State was here in the Carrier Dome.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Flights of Fancy, And Warmth, Too
description: You just never know what will pop up on jackets nowadays. A bright young New York designer named Christian Roth has adopted a Warholian approach for his creations, decorating them with giant appliques of clothespins and three-dimensional bottle caps.

title: What About the Book?
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimism Emerging
description: Stock exchange officials are bracing for tomorrow's market opening on Wall Street.

title: Randolph Township Journal Handicapped Driver Keeps the Able-Bodied Honest
description: SITTING in a yellow wheelchair outside Pathmark in the K-Mart Shopping Plaza on Route 10 here, Pat Fletcher was engrossed in conversation. As shopping carts bounced over cracks in the sidewalk and automobiles coasted by, Ms. Fletcher talked above the noise about why she spends so much time at this shopping center.

title: The Home Office of Tomorrow
description: LAST SUMMER, FRANCIS Fukuyama, a deputy director of the U.S. State Department, asserted that history is dead and that class struggle had been quashed by the ideological - and technological - triumph of the West. The idea of an end to progress, though provocative, may have seemed less naive if Fukuyama had limited his analysis to home-office electronics. In this arena, the 1980's was truly a time of sweeping change that brought most components to the brink of maturation.

title: THE REGION: Superintendent Elena J. Scambio; Remaking Jersey City Schools: The State's Agent Digs In
description: A WEEK ago, as Elena J. Scambio, newly installed by the state to overhaul the troubled Jersey City school system, was marching here in the Columbus Day Parade, she noticed that the band from Dickinson High had no uniforms, while a band from nearby Union City was in snappy attire.

title: Casino Technical School Luring Diverse Students
description: LEAD: SUSAN PASQUINI says she has bounced around a lot since graduating from high school in Haddon Heights six years ago. She dropped out of three colleges and worked at several fast-food jobs.

title: Faces and Cries From the AIDS Battleground
description: During one of the interviews conducted for ''Common Threads,'' a documentary about the AIDS Memorial Quilt that will be shown at 10 o'clock tonight on Home Box Office, a gay man named Vito Russo compared himself to a soldier in the Vietnam War. With his lover dead from the disease and himself infected, Mr. Russo said, he understood how it must have felt to stand amid gunfire and shells. And more than that, he went on, he realized that only others on the front could conceive of his terror and rage.

title: FICTION
description: DEAD BY MORNING. By Dorothy Simpson. (Scribners, $16.95.) The ninth mystery in this British writer's Luke Thanet detective series has classic ingredients: a dead body discovered in curious circumstances, lots of suspects and a tight-lipped village guarding its secrets. Two days after his return to the English hamlet where he grew up, the Martindale family's long-absent black sheep, Leo, lies dead in a ditch, the ostensible victim of a hit-and-run accident. The offending vehicle is identified as a van belonging to Longford Hall, once the Martindale family manor, now an elegant hotel run by Leo's sister and her husband. But annoyingly, for Detective-Inspector Thanet's purposes, virtually everyone within a 5-mile radius apparently drove the killer van at some point on the night that Leo died. And all of the drivers had reason to want him dead. Now, not surprisingly, a conspiracy of silence protects a murderer who seems to have done everyone a favor. ''I can't ever remember a case in which we had so many hostile witnesses,'' Thanet muses, but he's determined to find out who did the deed. Was it the deceased's lovely sister, whom Leo would have disinherited? An old family employee, whose life Leo ruined years ago? The insanely jealous husband of Leo's old flame? Red herrings strew the path that leads to the novel's clever ending, which has undeniable shock value. But readers may feel cheated that hints about the final revelations weren't also dropped along the way. In addition, Ms. Simpson has a distracting habit of introducing themes and characters that are unrelated to the plot and then doing nothing with them: the Draconian division chief who makes Thanet's life difficult, for example, or Thanet's problems with his children. But, in sum, ''Dead by Morning'' is an adroitly written mystery, absorbing even if it isn't enthralling.

title: A COURT UPHOLDS DRUG CONVICTIONS
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan last week upheld the 1987 convictions of 15 men in the ''pizza connection'' narcotics trial, but overturned another defendant's guilty verdict on racketeering and conspiracy charges.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: It has taken some years for history to recognize that Mr. Truman stepped into a position for which he was ill prepared but grew well into it. It does his image no good to present the petty-minded picture that Ms. Truman does of her father. I would prefer to believe that he was capable of, and did rise to the demands of, the office admirably. ANNE AUGUST Dorset, Vt.

title: Review/Music; Baroque Bill By 4 Nations Ensemble
description: The Four Nations Ensemble, an early-instruments band directed by the harpsichordist Andrew Appel, describes the boundaries of its repertory as late Renaissance and Viennese Classics. For its Wednesday-evening program at Weill Recital Hall, the group tightened its focus slightly on the middle ground, offering Baroque works from Germany, Italy, England and France.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Jodi L. Picoult, Student, to Wed
description: The engagement of Jodi L. Picoult and Timothy W. van Leer, both graduates of Princeton University, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Myron M. Picoult of Nesconset, L.I. Mr. van Leer is a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Karl van Leer of Lincoln, Mass. The couple plan to wed in November.

title: LESSONS FROM THE 80'S
description: The 1980's have been an extraordinary time for home design. Many trends have come and gone: The English country style swept the nation with cluttered rooms done in chintz and ribbons. Post-modern buildings, boasting pediments and oversize columns, began cropping up in all major cities. Deconstructivism, the hard-edged architectural movement that originated in California, was later immortalized in an exhibition at The Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Now, as the decade comes to an end, there have been many lessons learned, many ideas synthesized. In place of the English style, a new breed of traditionalist is creating more pared-down interiors. Post-modern architects, instead of using historical references in a light-hearted manner, are now taking a more serious look at the past. Even deconstructivism, the most radical style of the decade, is softer and more livable.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: Good for Margaret Truman! Publication of her father's manuscripts constitutes a long-overdue expose of Eisenhower as one of the weakest Presidents, and without moral courage. RICHARD DRESSELHUYS New York, N.Y.

title: Laura Watts Marries
description: Laura Louise Watts, a doctoral candidate in chemistry, and Matthew Dunlap Mitchell, a doctoral candidate in biophysics, both at the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at the University Lutheran Church of the Incarnation in Philadelphia by the Rev. Jeffrey Merkel. The bride, 27 years old, is a graduate of Bryn Mawr College. She is a daughter of Arnold Watts of Princeton, N.J., and Joan Armstrong of Dallas. Mr. Mitchell, 28, is a graduate of Haverford College. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Mitchell of Syracuse.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Transcaucasia - beyond the Caucasus Mountains: few geographical descriptions summon up for Westerners more exotic images of Asia, from Batumi on the Black Sea to Baku on the Caspian Sea, from Iran's northern border through the breadbasket of the Soviet Union in Georgia.

title: The Public-Private Clash Over Beaches
description: AT the southern tip of the village of Longport, on the Jersey Shore, the cross streets begin at 11th Street. South of there, where First through 10th Streets once ran, lies the blue water of Great Egg Inlet, with the Atlantic Ocean beyond.

title: Old Friends Give New Meaning To 'Pas de Deux'
description: Simultaneously, the choreographers Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis were making dances in the same rehearsal studio. While the white-haired Mr. Nikolais played a tape of his own percussive electronic score and directed his cluster of dancers to crouch behind a screen and simulate jack-in-the-box movements, Mr. Louis worked in the corner on fluid, lyrical phrases for another group of dancers, who tried to ignore the loud sounds filling the air.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Charter Revision; Realigning the Powers in Land-Use Control
description: IF New York City voters adopt the proposed Charter revision next month, they will be embracing a land-use regulation system that distributes oversight of the processes of urban change broadly.

title: Sunday Concerts in Church Settings
description: THERE are two good musical reasons for going to church today: a 4 P.M. choral program with organ at Saint Augustine's Catholic Church in Ossining and a 5 P.M. ''Concert in Color'' at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills.

title: Tigers Avenge Loss to Lions
description: Having endured the ignominy last season of being the first team to lose to Columbia over a 5-year span encompassing 48 games, Princeton had a score to settle with the Lions today. And the Tigers got even decisively, beating Columbia, 24-8, before 11,140 at Palmer Stadium.

title: THE LITTLE FLOWER AND HOW HE GREW
description: FIORELLO H. LA GUARDIA AND THE MAKING OF MODERN NEW YORK By Thomas Kessner. Illustrated. 700 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $24.95.

title: Outdoors; Easing Limits on Striped Bass
description: The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has voted to relax restrictions on recreational and commercial fishing for striped bass next year.

title: Vicenza
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your excellent and informative article on Palladio in the Veneto (''A Palladian Journey in Vicenza,'' Travel, Aug. 13). Your readers might want to pack along Caroline Constant's ''Palladio Guide,'' which covers all of his built works. This compact book is an ideal traveling companion for Palladio buffs, and includes maps as well as architectural drawings. ''The Palladio Guide'' is also available in French, German, Spanish and Italian. KEVIN C. LIPPERT New York, N.Y.

title: The Good Old Days of Radio Serials
description: ''HURRY UP, it's almost 5 o'clock. We've got to get home.'' Was it hunger? Was it Mom's command? No, it was the radio serials. Each evening, in 15-minute segments from 5 to 6, the sagas continued: The Lone Ranger galloped over the plain with the faithful Tonto, Superman swooped down to protect Lois Lane from villains, Captain Midnight broke codes with his ring, and Tom Mix just kept roping and riding.

title: Bush to Seek Death Penalty for Drug Chiefs
description: The Bush Administration is preparing to ask Congress to expand use of the death penalty significantly by permitting execution of drug kingpins whether or not they are involved in a killing, Justice Department officials say.

title: Beirut General Warns Christians at Talks
description: The commander of the Christian forces in Lebanon, Gen. Michel Aoun, threatened retribution against Christian Lebanese negotiators today to try to keep them from making concessions to their Muslim counterparts in talks here on ending the 14-year civil war.

title: Driving His Way to Fame
description: If it is no surprise anymore to find, say, a Japanese motor under the hood of an American car, perhaps it is not surprising to find a Honda in America's Automotive Hall of Fame. Last week, Soichiro Honda, whose company was the first to use American workers to build Japanese cars, took his place with the likes of Henry Ford, Walter Chrysler and Alfred Sloane of General Motors in the Automotive Hall of Fame, which opened 50 years ago in Midland, Mich. Like Ford, Mr. Honda, who is 82 years old, was something of an eccentric who got his start as an unskilled tinkerer. The induction ceremony was ''long overdue and well deserved,'' said Donald Richetti, president of the Automotive Hall of Fame. ''When the Japanese first came here, they and the domestic auto makers were at each other's throats,'' he said. ''Now they're all in partnerships.''

title: The New Bed and Breakfast
description: FOR just about as long as they have been around, bed and breakfast inns have been synonymous with modesty in lodging. For a small sum of, say, $25 to $50 a night, even in the early 80's a couple could get the basics: a firm bed, perhaps a shared bath, a hearty meal the next morning and the company of an innkeeper who lived on the premises.

title: K. M. Brooks Jr. Weds Miss Rauscher
description: Megan C. Rauscher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank J. Rauscher Jr. of Weston, Conn., and Kenneth M. Brooks Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of Saratoga, Calif., were married yesterday in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Jeffrey Dugan, an Episcopal priest, at Christ and Holy Trinity Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Selling Delivery Routes to Drivers to Spur Sales
description: Bread, especially white bread, is extremely price-competitive and the rise in private-label brands has made it more so.

title: Marines Are Assigned To Aid Border Patrol
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service says that as many as 50 marines will be deployed along the border with Mexico to help the United States Border Patrol to detect illegal aliens trying to enter the country.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doctors in Stuttgart, West Germany, said that while it was still too early to know for sure, it appeared likely that Adriana Duffy, the Puerto Rican gymnast who broke her neck in a practice accident Thursday night, would remain paralyzed. ... The Los Angeles Raiders released the veteran defensive end Pete Koch yesterday in order to clear a roster spot for the running back Bo Jackson, the Kansas City Royals outfielder, who is expected to play in today's game against the Kansas City Chiefs. (AP)

title: A FAST COMEBACK
description: REIGNING INDIANAPOLIS 500 champion Emerson Fittipaldi is cruising past the farmhouses that dot the Irish Hills of Michigan. It is a lazy Thursday afternoon in August, three days before the running of the Marlboro 500, and the Brazilian driver is making his leisurely way to the lake house he rents for the week of the race. He has one hand on the steering wheel of a big, white Cadillac and one eye on the tree-lined two-lane highway before him. His other hand and much of his attention are devoted to a pair of conversations - one in Portuguese with his father-in-law and the other in English with a reporter. His pace is what might charitably be called sedate; he'd probably have trouble passing one of the tractors that often share this twisty ribbon of blacktop. But that's Fittipaldi's style: The only time he's truly in a hurry is when he's in a race car. Of course, the only time he's truly happy is when he's in a hurry.

title: After 25 Years, Pretoria Frees Sisulu
description: Walter Sisulu, South Africa's second leading jailed black nationalist after Nelson Mandela, was returned to his home today by the police after 25 years in prison.

title: Whose School Is It, Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Build Shops Stirs East Moriches
description: LEAD: WHEN East Moriches voted to zone a 4.9-acre parcel of land for commercial use in 1959, it could not imagine the controversy it would cause 30 years later.

title: Six Rescued After Boat Sinks
description: Six men whose fishing boat had sunk 40 hours earlier were rescued by a Coast Guard cutter about 50 miles northwest of Maui on Friday. The men survived by clinging to a makeshift raft of buoys and nets from their boat, which had sailed from Honolulu on Oct. 3. They suffered only bruises and dehydration, the Coast Guard said. They were identified as Kim H. Kyu, 49 years old, the skipper; Jim Alexander, 22; George Shohswel, 22; Chong S. Yoon, 39; Osa A. Tui, 42, and John Aignua, 39.

title: Why Gorbachev Doesn't Care to Strike Back
description: ACCORDING to the stereotypes Westerners hold dear, Mikhail S. Gorbachev should now be apoplectic over the hemorrhage of Communist power in Europe. Poland falls into the clutches of Solidarity. The Hungarian Communist Party shuns the word Communist, then fractures and quarrels over who gets to keep the bank account. The East Germans yearn westward, chanting the Soviet leader's name as a kind of political mantra. The European principalities of the Soviet Union - most notably Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia - debate whether to choose Sweden or Finland as their role model, as soon as they can rid themselves of the Soviet Army.

title: Dinkins's Money Base Keeps Getting Broader
description: The business establishment in New York City and liberal and black Democrats outside the city have replaced unions and New York City blacks as the main sources of money for David N. Dinkins's campaign for mayor.

title: Wing Biddle Wed To Miss Urstadt, A Bank Executive
description: The wedding of Catherine Cary Urstadt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Urstadt of Bronxville, N.Y., and Willing Legendre Biddle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Biddle of Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The Rev. Frank Goodwin, an English Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/ Concert; All-French Program by Riverside Symphony
description: George Rothman opened the ninth season of his Riverside Symphony Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall with a piquant 20th-century French bill -actually, three pieces composed by Parisians within a span of 28 years.

title: Fall Benefits: Alzheimer's To Tappan Zee
description: A informal but festive opening was held Wednesday evening for the new and enlarged Children's Museum of Manhattan. Bette Korman, the museum's founder and executive director, thought it all up. Laurie Tisch Sussman, chairman of the museum, raised the money, and her family gave and renovated the four-story building at 212 West 83d Street. Later that evening at the Seagram Building, a ball to benefit the Rita Hayworth Alzheimer Association was held under four white tents set on the Park Avenue plaza and over the fountains. Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, who is Miss Hayworth's daughter, was the chairman of the evening. That evening a preview of 26 British paintings collected by the philanthropist Paul Mellon was given at Christie's; proceeds from the evening and from the November sale will go to the Yale Center for British Art. On Tuesday evening, Helen Hayes celebrated her 89th birthday among a crush of celebrities at the Algonquin Hotel. On Thursday evening, in the Grand Salon of the Fifth Avenue mansion of the French Consul General, Ambassador Emmanuel de Margerie pinned the Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur on a New Yorker, Elizabeth Fondaras, for her work on behalf of French-American charities.

title: Uniting Tapestry and Technology
description: CONTEMPORARY tapestries by seven internationally known weavers looks surprisingly at home in a 100-year-old house and a bank in Port Washington. The hues, patterns and textures of woven yarns enliven these plaster and concrete walls, just as the threads of medieval tapestries warmed the stones of ancient castles.

title: Police Recruit Kills Himself
description: A young recruit who worked three years to qualify for the Milwaukee police force shot himself to death at a firing range after failing his final chance at a marksmanship test. The recruit, Daniel Morales, 21 years old, was firing at the third and final target at the Police Training Academy when he turned his .357 revolver to his head and shot himself, a police spokesman said. The police said Mr. Morales's best score on the tests was 203; The minimum required is 210 out of a possible 300.

title: Funeral Home to Offer A New Service
description: LEAD: ''IT'S new, so it's strange,'' James R. Sanders, the owner of Sanders Mortuary in Waterbury, said of his plan for a funeral home with a drive-in window.

title: Senior's 7 Passes Fuel 7 Touchdowns
description: Scott Scesney threw for a school-record seven touchdown passes, four of them to Denis McDermott, as undefeated St. John's overtook the previously unbeaten Merchant Marine Academy, 65-45, yesterday at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I., clinching its first Liberty Conference title.

title: Musician Takes Unusual Path to the Top
description: LEAD: FOR the last few years, Gregory Abbott's life has been a whirlwind. It all started in 1986 when Columbia Records released his debut album, ''Shake You Down,'' and within a year its title single zoomed to the top of the charts. Worldwide sales reached more than a million copies.

title: NEW PLAN OFFERED IN MINERS' STRIKE
description: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said today that she would soon appoint a special mediator in a new effort to end the United Mine Workers' six-month-old strike against the Pittston Coal Group.

title: New York Limits a Key AIDS Test
description: To the dismay of many New York doctors and advocates for people with AIDS, a key laboratory test that can show whether an AIDS virus infection is progressing is all but unavailable in the New York State, although it is readily available elsewhere.

title: Dorsett Mark Is Broken
description: The Texas A&I tailback Johnny Bailey broke Tony Dorsett's 13-year-old National Collegiate Athletic Association career rushing record tonight with a 4-yard carry against Central State. The run gave Bailey 6,085 yards, eclipsing the mark of 6,082 set by Dorsett at Pitt in 1973-76.

title:
DANCE;
Garden State Ballet Salutes the French
description: LEAD: THE Garden State Ballet will offer a balletic salute to the French Bicentennial with four performances at Essex County College in Newark. For Peter Anastos, the company's director and principal choreographer, the program constitutes a showcase of works that celebrate his love of and affinity for French culture.

title: High Spirits at the Summit
description: TO celebrate my birthday, some of my family gathered for the weekend at my son's country house in Vermont. It was a special birthday because it marked the gateway to what we call the golden years. From now on I can claim discounts on trains and buses and in certain stores. I am also eligible for a Medicare card with its reassurance of health care. But, of course, this day brings with it intimations of mortality, with my hopes and fears for the years ahead.

title: Waiting for Word Out in the Bullpen
description: As the starting pitchers in last night's World Series opener, Dave Stewart of the Athletics and Scott Garrelts of the Giants were up on a platform Friday answering questions behind a microphone in the Oakland Coliseum interview area. Their photos and quotes were in all the newspapers. Their video and audio tapes were on television and radio. Then their managers, Tony La Russa and Roger Craig, were asked to identify the starting pitchers for the second game here and also Tuesday night's third game when this Battle of the Bay moves to Candlestick Park in San Francisco.

title: 28 CITIES ASSESSED BY A GALLUP POLL
description: The American public as a whole views New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles as the best large cities in the country, but frequent visitors are most enthusiastic about Seattle, Boston and San Diego in addition to San Francisco and New York, according to a Gallup Poll.

title: Ms. Handy Wed To an Inventor
description: Helene Bredt Handy, a daughter of Ethel M. Woolverton of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Chalmers Handy of Little Compton, R.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Hume Reynolds, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles T. Reynolds of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Shostakovich's Quartets-With Tears
description: LEAD: Bleak, haunted, and imbued with an anguished intensity, the 15 string quartets of Dmitri Shostakovich bare the soul of a composer who suffered under a relentlessly repressive regime. And their harrowing emotional impact never fails to leave an audience profoundly moved.

title: Lotte Andersen and David Meister, Lawyers, Wed
description: Lise Lotte Andersen, an associate at the New York law firm of Rosenman & Colin, and David Meister, an associate at Obermaier, Morvillo & Abramowitz, also a New York law firm, were married last evening at the Loft in New York. Rabbi Robert Lippman officiated.

title: Girls' School
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Seascapes of New England by 19th-Century Painters
description: LEAD: FOR the same reason that Edmund Hillary climbed Everest, New England artists painted the sea in the 19th century: because it was there. The persistence and ubiquity of the sea - in company with the sky - through 45 paintings by 30 artists is the strongest impression one retains from ''Realism and Romanticism in 19th-Century New England Seascapes'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in

title: Court Grants a Delay In an Iran-Contra Trial
description: The Justice Department has obtained a delay of at least another month in the Iran-contra trial of a former intelligence agent, Joseph F. Fernandez.

title: Gay Couple's Move to Adopt Children With AIDS Stirs Debate
description: THE impending adoption of two black boys with AIDS by a gay white male couple has prompted a debate in New Jersey that turns on issues of race, morality and a growing interest among homosexuals to be parents.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner; West 73d, East 73d, and Downtown and Midtown
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Cavaliere

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles. Last year, we hired a professional to repaint. He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint. Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun. The painter says this is owing to moisture and that there is a new sealer that will correct this. What is your opinion?

title: Starting On the Road
description: No one can doubt it any longer:

title: JUILLARD DROPOUT MAKES GOOD
description: MILES The Autobiography. By Miles Davis with Quincy Troupe. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Coalition Is Alive and Well
description: Your article on Oct. 1, 1989, ''Coalition Disbands After Primary,'' may be misleading. Our coalition, the Long Island Committee for Reasonable Government, is alive and well. However, it is apparent that misconceptions exist.

title: L.I. Officials Seek to Insure True Census Count
description: WITH preparations for the 1990 census under way, Long Island officials fear that the Island will be shortchanged in Congressional representation and services, and want to insure that the Island's population is not undercounted.

title: Nuclear Test Treaties, Ready to Ratify
description: U.S.-Soviet differences over verification have long stalled ratification of two treaties to limit the size of underground nuclear explosions. But Moscow proposed a reasonable compromise, leaving each side free to use its own preferred method of monitoring and allowing more on-site visits. President Bush's acceptance of the offer has broken the deadlock. Now it's time for the Senate to ratify the treaties - and thus lay the groundwork for more stringent limits on nuclear testing.

title: A Black Market Arises in the Disposal of Debris
description: LEAD: AN illicit traffic in construction and demolition debris is producing profits for unlicensed operators while testing Long Island's preparation for a state mandate that will close town landfills in December 1990.

title: THE P.I. GOES TO A.A.
description: OUT ON THE CUTTING EDGE By Lawrence Block. 260 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title:
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Day Care Amenity;
Building Workplace Centers to Reduce Turnover
description: LEAD: A TIGHT labor market, the growing number of working women and an increasing demand for child-care services at job sites are prompting developers to incorporate these services in business parks across the country.

title: SEOUL RENEWS BID TO GAIN U.N. SEAT
description: Four decades after its first application for membership in the United Nations, South Korea has begun a major diplomatic effort at the current session of the General Assembly to secure support for its admission.

title: California Grown
description: Fourteen members of the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics were not far from their hometowns when the all-California World Series opened last night.

title: Review/Theater; 'Midsummer Night's Dream'
description: There is, of course, no such thing as a foolproof play, but ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' comes about as close as anything written in the last 400 years. Shakespeare's confection of farce and fantasy can survive virtually any conceit or time warp visited on it and provide a measure of mirth in at least one of the three plots.

title: 'Blaming the Victim' In the War on Waste
description: Assemblyman David C. Kronick's article, ''The Trashing of New Jersey'' (Opinion page, Sept. 17), is another in a series from many sources that improperly accuse New Jerseyites of being addicted to littering and other bad habits related to solid-waste control. It is a cover-up for poor performance by New Jersey politicians who call themselves leaders. It is a repeat of the ''blame the victim'' syndrome.

title: 'I Think We're Middle of the Road'
description: GARY M. YOUNG'S portrait of the state of the arts in Connecticut would excite even the most jaded listener. Last year alone, said Mr. Young, the executive director of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, the nonprofit arts industry generated $354 million. In addition, the arts employed 12,300 people and attracted an audience of more than 8.5 million people.

title: East Germany Tries to Keep Soul-Searching in the Party
description: AFTER swirling through the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary, the Gorbachevian winds of change have turned to huffing and puffing at the formidable bastion of East Germany. They haven't blown the house down, to be sure, but after a remarkable month of mass flight and mass protest, the Communist leadership is feeling the heat.

title:
LIFE STYLE;
A Bit of Pampering, Close at Hand
description: LEAD: Escaping to a health spa to recondition the body and revitalize the spirit used to mean traveling great distances. Today, health spas are proliferating in the New York region as growing numbers of people, who have incorporated health regimens into their daily routines, seek getaways closer to home.

title: Bush's Critics Say He's Crossed the Line, But Public Still Sees Him as Presidential
description: A new buzz word has shoved aside ''ethics'' and ''credibility'' in the endless political chatter that lubricates life in the capital.

title: Bette Davis: The Mortal, The Myth
description: Dorian Gray kept his portrait in the attic where only he could see it. The rest of us aren't as lucky. We walk around wearing ours. In this respect movie stars as fine-tuned and long-lived as Bette Davis are both blessed and damned.

title: Budget Tells Where Priorities Lie
description: IN the next 60 days, Suffolk County will adopt a budget for 1990. An annual budget is the most important statement of public policy that our elected officials develop as part of their public responsibilities. It separates intentions and talk from action. The budget consolidates both fiscal and social policies. It serves as a primary means to hold elected officials accountable to the public.

title: Body-Cavity Searches Barred by U.S. Court
description: A Federal appeals court, calling body-cavity searches ''dehumanizing and humiliating,'' has ruled unconstitutional the Los Angeles police's policy of conducting such a search on anyone arrested on felony charges.

title: Correction
description: A question-and-answer article on Sept. 3 about the selling of medical practices misstated the subject area in which Dr. Madeleine Pelner Cosman earned her doctorate. It was in English and comparative literature, not medical law.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Autumn Jubilee, Second Avenue between 14th and 34th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Law Regulates Tanning Salons
description: AN ordinance enacted by Glen Cove last month - it is the first of its kind on Long Island - regulates the use of tanning devices within the city's jurisdiction.

title: Review/Piano; Russian and French Works By Donna Amato, in Debut
description: For the program of her New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening, Donna Amato chose Russian and French piano works that revel in chromaticism. But her approach was often so heavy - either because she prefers a forceful touch or because she misjudged the volume of sound it takes to fill the intimate hall - that the opportunities the music affords for subtle coloristic interplay were often squandered.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles. Last year, we hired a professional to repaint. He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint. Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun. The painter says this is owing to moisture and that there is a new sealer that will correct this. What is your opinion?

title: 'Oldest Geisha' Sees Loss of Tradition
description: LEAD: KIHARU NAKAMURA, 76 years old, was dressed in a pale golden silk kimono embroidered at the hem with autumn leaves and told an audience at the Cross Cultural Center here that as Japanese society changed, many traditions were disappearing. She fears that the geisha tradition could be among those.

title: State Is Challenged Over AIDS Panels
description: LEAD: A REGULATION by the State Department of Education requiring school boards to appoint members of religious organizations to their AIDS advisory councils has come under attack by the New York State School Boards Association.

title: Drexel's Uncertain Future
description: One night late last month, Frederick H. Joseph strode onto a ballroom stage in the Vista International Hotel in lower Manhattan. Before him, bright light from the ballroom's chandeliers spilled across the oval dining tables as hundreds of top executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. drank wine, savored smoked salmon and medallions of beef and prepared for an evening of dancing.

title: Center Stage for Sets from Bridgeport Firm
description: CHANDELIERS that collapse, a chair that dumps bodies, and a town house interior that folds up are the products of Atlas Scenic Studio Ltd.

title: Lauretta Georgen Becomes a Bride
description: Lauretta Marie Georgen, a daughter of Mrs. W. Donald Georgen of Morristown, N.J., and the late Mr. Georgen, was married yesterday to John Charles Godbout, a son of Mrs. Thomas G. Godbout of Detroit and the late Mr. Godbout. Msgr. John F. Corr and the Rev. Patrick E. Brown officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Can Chicago Save Opera From Itself?
description: Opera in this century resembles the dissolute gentleman in British novels who not only lives off the interest on his inherited fortune but commits the deadly sin of dipping into principal as well. That downward road, devotees of the genre know, is paved with momentary pleasures but leads to the poorhouse. Can opera, the famous profligate, be helped to avoid that sad fate, dear reader? Will Squire Goodfellow or Madame Bountiful step forward in time? Apparently there are those who still believe redemption possible, that the increasing reliance of opera houses on a few 19th-century masterworks can be reversed in time to save the art from terminal poverty.

title: Man Is Arrested in Virginia on Espionage Charges
description: A Tennessee man who said he became involved with the K.G.B. in Moscow after he chanced upon a Soviet ballet troupe on a bus in Bolivia was arrested by Federal agents early today on espionage charges.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Kingsbridge Armory; A Dropped Ceiling In a Moated Bastion?
description: IT could have been in the Guinness Book of World Records, a 300 by 600 feet dropped ceiling, perhaps the world's largest. The only trouble was it was planned for the vast drill shed of the Eighth Coastal Artillery Armory, in the Bronx, completed in 1917 and now a city landmark.

title: THE SHAMUS IS A SLOB
description: PEEPER By Loren D. Estleman. 215 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95.

title: Across the River, 2 Touchdown Artists
description: If you are exiting from the Holland Tunnel in New Jersey, a right turn takes you to Hoboken and a left to Jersey City. In either direction lies one of the top high school running backs in New Jersey.

title: L.I. Teacher Stabbed to Death
description: The body of a 52-year-old high school science teacher was found in his home Friday night, the Nassau County police said today. He had been stabbed to death. The teacher, Edward Slater, had been reported missing by officials of Great Neck North High School on Wednesday.

title: Dune Law
description: To the Editor:

title: DIAMONDS ARE NOW AND FOREVER IN OAKLAND
description: Babe Ruth is at the World Series, and so is Pete Rose, and so is Jackie Robinson, and so is A. Bartlett Giamatti.

title: SNAPSHOTS OF HOPE AND HOPELESSNESS
description: As a sociologist and alumna of Seward Park High School, I was particularly interested in Samuel G. Freedman's article. It led me to take down my copy of the yearbook for my graduating class and look at the snapshots of me and my classmates.

title: Elegant Measures of Time From Colonial Fairfield
description: LEAD: CLOCKS have been popular as ornaments as well as measures of time since the early 1300's, when the mechanical clock was first invented. Before then, sundials, sand glasses, water clocks and candles with graduated marks were indicators of the passage of time. But it is the tall case or grandfather clock, invented in the middle of the 17th century that remains a symbol of status.

title: The Design Story of the Decade
description: ON A RAINY NIGHT in October 1982, over 3,000 people stood in line outside a loft building in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood, hoping to squeeze into an already crammed showroom. The event was Memphis at Midnight, the United States' first look at the bold, colorful, quirky furniture that had been born in Milan the previous year and was taking the world by storm.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: TRADING IN HIGH-TECH;
Confessions of an American in Tokyo
description: LEAD: I am an American who distributes computer products in Japan. I started with $5,000 in 1972 and now have a company with revenues of $80 million a year. We employ 500 people in Japan, where I live. Most of our revenues are from selling American software products that we import.

title: Rivals for The No. 1 Spot
description: To the Editor:

title: Helsinki's Russian Flavors
description: MOST major cities are dotted with restaurants where the locals go when they want something ethnic. London has its Indian restaurants, Tokyo its Italian spaghetti parlors, and in Paris, Vietnamese food gives the extra kick to the French palate. In Helsinki, Russian restaurants provide exotic cuisine for natives when they're looking for a change from the tame and often prosaic Finnish diet.

title: Plant Owners Fighting Plan to Clean Canyon Air
description: The sunsets are sometimes a little redder and the great craggy walls are sometimes a little bluer when the particles of smog drift into the Grand Canyon from industries scattered across the American West and from polluted cities as far away as Los Angeles.

title: Sheila McGovern Weds
description: Sheila Mary McGovern, a daughter of Anne Marie McGovern of Washington and Walter Collins McGovern of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Richard Kendrick 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick 3d of Sewickley, Pa. The Rev. John O'Connor performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in Washington at the Notre Dame Chapel of Trinity College. Mrs. Kendrick, 29 years old, is a sales representative for Metro Magazines in New York. She graduated from Denison University, as did her husband, a vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.

title: In Audio and Video
description: IT HAS BEEN SAID THAT THE field of electronics is emblematic of our age. It reflects the technical imagination of our era and determines our mode of life, just as steam engines did in Victorian times. Radio, recordings and television have become principal shapers of public consciousness, and during the 1980's, technical developments in these media both broadened and intensified their cultural role.

title: Hurricane Batters Galveston, Tex., Leaving 2 Dead
description: Hurricane Jerry roared into the Texas coast tonight, killing at least two people as it tore down power lines, trees, balconies and signs and spun off tornadoes that inflicted scattered damage. It quickly lost its punch over land and was downgraded to a tropical storm.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Untenable is a dirtier word than slaughtered. Slaughtered means you have more innings left to play. Untenable means the game is over.'' -William Silver, a trader on the American Stock Exchange. [ A1:4. ]

title: Century Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iomega Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Laura Preisser Weds Timothy Grozier
description: At the chapel of Our Lady of Good Counsel Academy in White Plains, Laura K. Preisser, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas J. McGoldrick of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late Walter J. Preisser, was married yesterday to Timothy L. Grozier, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Grozier of Sedona, Ariz. The Rev. Vincent G. Potter, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Loiborsoit Journal; The Proud Masai's Fate: Finally, to Be Fenced In?
description: For the first time in his life, Mengoru Aladaru, a 31-year-old Masai tribesman accustomed to wandering the vast, brown and dusty expanses with his cattle, planted and harvested corn this year.

title: Kerkhoff Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New U.S. Prosecutor Ushers In a Low-Key Style
description: Otto G. Obermaier, who is to be sworn in as the new United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York at 4 P.M. today, has something to say: ''I have no message to deliver and I will have no message to deliver. The prosecutor's office speaks in the courtroom.''

title: Dexleigh Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: First Commerce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aspen Air Deal Off
description: Giant Group, the masonry company controlled by the investor Burt Sugarman, ended negotiations to buy Aspen Airways Inc., a regional airline based in Denver. No reason was given for the collapse of the deal last week, but analysts speculated that Mr. Sugarman might not have been able to obtain favorable financing terms.

title: Delchamps Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rights and Wrongs of Blaming Japan
description: Frustration with Japan in the United States and resentment of America in Japan are near the flash point. Many Americans are upset about recent shifts in the global balance of economic power, shifts that seem to threaten American jobs and international influence. Yet to put all the blame on Japanese behavior is to deflect attention from important domestic causes.

title: Papal Trip's Last Stop: An Island Gem
description: Normally, papal trips to third world countries are journeys among strongmen and marches through gut-wrenching poverty. So it was a decided change for Pope John Paul II this weekend when he brought his ministry to this palm-flecked island nation.

title: Florida National Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest 9 months' results were hurt by an extraordinary large loan-loss provision of $57 million, taken in the first quarter, and because of year-to-date other real estate expenses totaling $14.7 million.

title: Jack Henry & Associates reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $970,000. c-Net income The company blamed the loss for fiscal 1989 on a contract dispute with Unisys Corp. and operating losses of business units now subject to a contract for sale.

title: Ancient Eastern Rituals
description: Shomyo, the ritual chanting of the Buddhist sutras, and goma, a Tantric Buddhist fire ritual that originated more than 3,000 years ago in India, were performed at the Asia Society (725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street) on Friday evening by 10 Japanese priests of the Tendai sect. In addition to choral chanting, the music in the majestic 70-minute ceremony, which has never before been seen on tour in the United States, involved gongs, bells, cymbals and the sounds of iron tongs used by a priest to fuel a roaring fire in a brazier at the center of the stage.

title: Maxtor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Pinnacle Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago per share figures were adjusted to reflect 25 percent stock dividend paid December 1988 and 50 percent stock dividend paid June 1989. The company sold 200,000 new common shares in August 1989.

title: Storms Damage New York Towns
description: Tall trees came down and grounded airplanes went up as a series of vigorous thunderstorms whirled through the western half of upstate New York this weekend in a rare display of fall fury. Many towns were making repairs today.

title: Jets Hit the Bottom In Loss to Saints
description: On a day when their coach was trying to find a spark by switching quarterbacks, the Jets seemed to have lost their will. They were routed, 29-14, by the Saints in one of their most dismal performances of the 1980's.

title: Elderly Take Fear of Eviction From Home to Appeals Court
description: Like many of the 520 elderly residents of the Cobble Hill Nursing Home in Brooklyn, Catherine Rizzuto fears she may soon have to find another place to live.

title: Professionals Watching the 'Junk Bond' Market
description: Professional investors say they will be watching the ''junk bond'' market closely this morning. If this $200 billion market of high-yield, high-risk securities continues to suffer sharp selloffs with poor trading liquidity, the stock market is likely to decline further, traders say.

title: Louisville Journal; Keepers of the Flame Stoke Freedom's Fire
description: The descendants of the patriots who fought at places like Bunker Hill and Trenton and Yorktown met here this weekend to check on the fires of freedom.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Goes For a Change Of Direction
description: REVIEWING the most tumultuous period in the 19-year history of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, a leading European advertising executive said, ''Someone has to reinvent that company.''

title: Japan's Banks: A Caution Flag
description: The growing presence of Japanese banks in the United States could invite a backlash, Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, warned last week.

title: Brajdas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Beijing Party Calls for Purge in Capital
description: The Communist Party organization in the capital called today for a purge of its members, and suggested that the party would put more emphasis on ideological loyalty and less on expertise when making personnel decisions.

title: All American Television reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $98,000, or 5 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Abortion Rebuff Chips At a Governor's Image
description: In the early 1980's, when Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida was still Mayor Martinez of Tampa, he was regarded as a man of action, the kind of public official who climbed on the tailgate of a city truck to tell striking sanitation workers to return to their jobs or lose them.

title: Sports World Specials: GOLF; Highest-Priced Ball
description: A claim that an anonymous Connecticut buyer paid an anonymous British seller $11,550 for a single golf ball would seem calculated to raise eyebrows.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis No. 222 Loses to Lendl: Ivan Lendl, ranked No. 1 in the world, outclassed Lars Wahlgren of Sweden, ranked 222d, in straight sets in Sydney yesterday, 6-2, 6-2, 6-1, to win the Australian indoor championship. Wahlgren, 23, had not made it past the first round of any major tournament this year and was playing in his first Grand Prix final. Lendl earned $75,000 for winning, as well as the $800,000 Nabisco Grand Prix bonus pool. Wahlgren earned $37,500, surpassing his total earnings for the rest of the year so far.(AP) Sabatini Defeats Fernandez: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini won the women's international tournament in Filderstadt, West Germany, yesterday with a 7-6, 6-4 triumph over Mary Joe Fernandez.(AP) Mecir Tops Chang: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia beat Michael Chang, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday to retain his title in the Hong Kong Marlboro championship. (AP) Connors Beats McEnroe: Jimmy Connors won his 108th career title yesterday by defeating John McEnroe, 6-3, 6-3, in the final of the Toulouse Grand Prix tournament in France.(AP) Dog Show Pointer Wins 34th: The top-winning pointer in the history of the breed, Ch. Luftnase Albelarm Bee's Knees, yesterday won her 34th top award when she was named best in show at the 28th all-breed competition of the Ramapo Kennel Club in New Jersey. Sailing Australian Takes Columbus Cup: Peter Gilmour beat seven other world-class sailors Saturday to win the Cadillac Columbus Cup match-racing series, 2-1, in Baltimore. Golf His First: George Archer yesterday won his first tournament on the over-age-50 PGA Senior circuit: the Gatlin Brothers Southwest Senior Classic in Abilene, Tex.(AP) Triathlon Two Records Fall: Mark Allen won the Ironman world championship Saturday in Kailua Kona, Hawaii. His time for the 2.4-mile swim, 112-mile bicycle ride and 26.2-mile run was 8 hours 9 minutes 14 seconds, taking 19:23 off the record set in 1986. Paula Newby-Fraser of Zimbabwe repeated as the women's winner with a record 9:00:56 finish. She took five seconds off her 1988 time.(AP) Auto Racing Crash Helps Winner: Geoff Bodine took advantage of a last-lap crash yesterday to win the Holly Farms 400 at North Wilkesboro (N.C.) Speedway.(AP) Victory for Mears: Rick Mears won the Champion Spark Plug 300-kilometer race yesterday in Monterey, Calif., solidifying his second-place finish behind Emerson Fittipaldi in the point standing. Mears won $68,160 and averaged 94.174 miles an hour, breaking the race record of 90.090, set last year. Fittipaldi finished the season as the first $2 million winner in Indy-car history. (AP)

title: Elliott Abrams Remains Reckless on Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Graham, Graduate Student, Is Married to Adam Marc Lindemann
description: Elizabeth Ashley Graham, a daughter of Robert C. Graham Jr. of Stamford, Conn., and the late Christine D. Graham of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday in Stamford to Adam Marc Lindemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Lindemann of Greenwich. Helen Baum, a justice of the peace in Stamford, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's great-uncle and great-aunt Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Altschul, also of New York.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Panama 'Rashomon'
description: Victory finds a hundred fathers but defeat is an orphan, John F. Kennedy reminded us after the failed effort to oust Fidel Castro in 1961 at the Bay of Pigs. Mr. Kennedy assumed the mantle of orphan and took the responsibility for the disaster. But when the President hides, Washington simply starts churning out paternity suits.

title: Jury Spurns Insanity Defense In Ax Killings
description: A jury rejected an insanity defense today in the second phase of the trial of an 18-year-old man convicted of first-degree murder in the ax slayings of his parents and two siblings.

title: In the Mud, on Imported Sod, Golf Is Introduced to Moscow
description: They came from another world, pioneers armed with silvery sticks, and on a greensward at the foot of the Lenin Hills today they performed a ritual as alien as the pointy-headed spacelings reportedly sighted last week in the Russian provinces. They played golf. On nine fairways snuggled ingeniously amid the high-rise tenements and hastily carpeted with squares of imported sod, they introduced the sport of Scottish kings, American presidents and country-club capitalists. Membership Is $20,000

description: An account of the Perfect Swing Trainer in this space last week omitted the company's telephone number. It is (800) 456-8082.

title: As Lebanon Talks Falter, Frustration of Saudi Hosts Grows
description: Saudi Arabia expressed frustration today over the Lebanese peace talks being held here. Its semi-official press said Lebanese politicians appear more interested in preserving their sectarian fiefdoms than in settling the conflict that has torn their country since 1975.

title: Ms. Halkerston Weds Scott Witt
description: The marriage of Merrill-Anne Halkerston and Scott Alan Witt took place yesterday at the Tappan Hill restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cantor David Benedict officiated. The bride is a daughter of Beverly Halkerston of Sydney, Australia, and Keith Halkerston of Henley-on-Thames, England. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Witt of Great Neck, L.I.

description: With no teammates around and thus no pass to consider, Tomas Sandstrom had no option but to shoot. And Wendell Young, the Pittsburgh goalie, was unable to stop the puck.

The company said a portion of both year-ago periods' provision for credit losses reflected a provision made by First Federal before becoming a Southeast subsidiary.

title: Nassau Man Is Electrocuted
description: A 32-year-old man was electrocuted today when he tried to move a live telephone wire from the road near his home in this Rensselaer County town, the police said. The victim, Peter Brewster, was pronounced dead at Albany Memorial Hospital shortly after the 8:30 A.M. incident, said Ray Payne, a County Sheriff's Deputy. He said the downed telephone wire had been wrapped around an electrical wire.

The year-ago periods' results included realized gains and special dividends totaling $1.9 million, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter, and $7.1 million, or 17 cents a share, for the 9 months, from similar gains.

description: The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that it planned to withdraw approval for the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company to sell a generic drug used to treat urinary tract infections and that it wanted the company to withdraw the product from drugstores.

description: Hours after eight of South Africa's most prominent political prisoners returned home from years in confinement, seven of them called today for the release of Nelson Mandela and said they would continue to work for the banned African National Congress.

title: Wall Street Trader Stays Cool During a Weekend of Anxiety
description: William Silver, a quick-witted trader on the American Stock Exchange, is reasonably confident that the performance of the financial markets today will not match the collapse of Monday, Oct. 19, 1987.

description: Upset he was not selected for the 1987 European Ryder Cup team, Christy O'Connor Jr. of Ireland rebounded in Ryder Cup play last month to become something of a folk hero in his own country, particularly in County Galway and County Clare on the West Coast.

title: Review/Music; Brooklyn Hears Factory Sounds From Germany
description: Pohl Musik brought a remarkable instrument to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. The Klangmaschine, invented for the group by Christof Schlager, looks like two ventilator tubes and a large electric fan hooked up to a podium-like control panel; its metallic innards produce enough buzzes, rasps, huffs, clanks, scrapes and siren noises to stand in for a factory.

title: Review/Dance; A Graham-Noguchi Foray Deep Into Greek Myth
description: Martha Graham's ''Cortege of Eagles'' from 1967 was one of her strangest collaborations with the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. The entire work is a startling cinematic flyby of images - both enhanced and obfuscated by geometric forms used as props and masks.

description: Tandem Computers Inc. will introduce a series of computers Monday that it said would provide performance comparable with the International Business Machines Corporation's largest machines at less than half the cost.

description: ALTHOUGH a long-anticipated woodcock hunt turned into something else, I was not distressed. The would-be woodcock venture took shape when Bud Leavitt of Bangor, Me., asked me if I would make a few remarks at a fund-raising dinner in his city for a salmon-conservation group that is opposing a hydroelectric dam on the Penobscot River.

A Canoe and Kayak Curriculum on the Riverside
description: LEAD: KAYAKING and canoeing, the art of making sleek craft go exactly where you want them to go, is not an impossible task if you have proper tutelage. If reputation is any guide, one of the best places to get quality paddling instruction is the Outdoor Center of New England, in Millers Falls, Mass.

title: New Jersey Election Bogs Down in Mud
description: Just after the Presidential and United States Senate elections last year, politicians in both parties here promised they would try to avoid debasing this year's political campaign with mudslinging. But in recent days New Jerseyans have watched their race for governor tumble into what political analysts now say is the most mean-spirited contest in memory.

title: Fernandez Meets Leader Of Principals
description: In a park bench encounter, Joseph A. Fernandez, the incoming Schools Chancellor, met for the first time yesterday with Donald Singer, the head of New York City's principals union, in an effort to gain by persuasion rather than legislation the authority to transfer ineffectual principals.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Rejoin Unesco if It Adopts Changes
description: A panel of distinguished Americans has recommended that the United States rejoin the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization if that body adopts changes it is now considering. The changes were proposed by its new Director General but are being resisted by third-world countries.

title: Campaign Matters; Republican Feud Splits a Party And the Vote
description: It was a Republican dinner, but the state's leading Republican, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, seemed to be about as welcome as rain at a picnic. And he seemed as eager to be there as a wet picnicker.

In 17th- and 18th-century works, and in some light Romantic scores, that can be easy enough, provided the players keep an eye on the concertmaster (and the concertmaster is good with cues).

description: As relations between the White House and Congress grow more combative, President Bush's personal ties to Capitol Hill show signs of strain, and complaints about the Administration's handling of Congress are growing louder, even from members of his own party.

description: The marriage of Nancy E. Gold, a lawyer, and Dr. J. Kirk Fitzhugh, a biologist, took place yesterday in New York at the Top of the Tower lounge in the Beekman Tower hotel. Justice Francis X. Egitto of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated. The bride is the daughter of Alice A. Gold of Bayside, Queens. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Fitzhugh of Dallas.

description: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry is planning measures to increase imports from the United States, starting April 1, a ministry official said last week.

description: The San Francisco Giants encountered fowl play in the fourth inning tonight, but it was two balls that went fair in the same inning that battered them into a 2-0 deficit in the World Series.

description: * Jon Hyde has been appointed an executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson/U.S.A.

title: Entire Town in Ohio Is Evacuated in Gas Leak
description: All 6,500 residents of this city were evacuated late Saturday night when a frozen-pizza plant leaked deadly ammonia gas. The authorities allowed them to return to their homes early today, but people with breathing problems were told to wait.

title: Sports World Specials: HOCKEY; One Growing Presence
description: Considering that girls have been playing ice hockey about as long as boys have, often teaching the game to their younger brothers on the local pond while learning it from their older ones, it is somewhat surprising that women's hockey has only recently begun to emerge as a full-fledged sport.

title: As a Student of Hitting, Will Clark Is Phi Betamax Kappa
description: BEFORE the recent National League playoff games, Will Clark studied videotapes of himself batting against the Cubs' pitchers. Throughout the season, he had checked tapes of every other opposing team's pitchers. Before the World Series opener Saturday night, the Giants' first baseman watched tapes that his parents and relatives in New Orleans had taken of him swinging against Dave Stewart of the Athletics during a two-game spring-training stop there earlier this year.

title: Teen-Ager in Bensonhurst Case Says Threats Sent Her Into Hiding
description: A Brooklyn teen-age girl whose friendships with black and Hispanic men apparently led to the racially motivated killing of a black youth in the Bensonhurst section has said that death threats have prompted her to go into hiding with a round-the-clock police guard.

description: Bridge is a difficult game of chance: you must operate with skill to take full advantage when fortune smiles.

description: Lorenzo White's 12-yard touchdown run with 1 minute 46 seconds left, after Allen Pinkett had run for 60 yards, lifted the Houston Oilers to a 33-28 victory over the Chicago Bears today.

title: African Rebels' Living Encyclopedia: Walter Max Ulyate Sisulu
description: When Walter Max Ulyate Sisulu emerged from his small stucco house in Soweto today after savoring his first few hours of freedom, he told journalists that he had never despaired that he would die in prison, where he spent the last 26 years.

Most classical music stations are profitable, they said, but not profitable enough for takeover artists.

description: BASKETBALL fans in San Antonio have been waiting for David Robinson with festive anticipation, like children waiting for Santa Claus.
