Burris, a son of Mrs. Bernard Abrams of South Orange, N.J., and H. Barry Burris of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman officiated.

title: Market Place; 2 Shifts Since '87, But Just One Helps
description: THE one-time institutional fad of ''portfolio insurance,'' much in evidence when the stock market collapsed two years ago, is almost forgotten. And that factor could help to stem the stock market's slide.

title: Sugar Shortfall Seen

The group said in a report that world sugar consumption for the year that began Sept. 1 is expected to total 109 million tons, which exceeds the projected production of 107 million tons.

title: Question Box
description: A Series a Decade Q, Counting a sports decade as the 10-year span from the zero year to the ninth one, like 1930-39, which major league teams have appeared in the World Series in each decade of the 20th century? A. None, because no team has won a pennant in each such decade. In fact no team has managed to get into the World Series in more than seven of the nine decades since Series play began in 1903. When the San Francisco Giants won the National League pennant last week and managed to squeeze in a Series appearance in the 1980's, it marked the seventh decade in which the Giants, based in New York through 1957, accomplished this. That tied the Giants with the Dodgers and the Yankees as the only teams to win pennants in seven different decades. The Giants missed in the 1940's and the 1970's; the Dodgers, based in Brooklyn through 1957, missed in the first decade and the 1930's; the Yankees did not win a pennant until 1921, missing the first two decades.

title: Talking Business with Callahan of Greiner Engineering; Proposals to Fix Public Works
description: A recent spate of water-main breaks in New York City has provided another sign of the widespread deterioration of the nation's infrastructure, including roads, bridges and airports. Postponing maintenance of the country's public works has produced problems that some experts believe could cost $3.3 trillion to solve. Frank T. Callahan is president and chief executive of Greiner Engineering Inc., an 81-year-old design services company in Irving, Tex., that specializes in transportation and other public works projects. He insists that infrastructure improvements are an investment in the economy and that they should be a priority of government and business. Q. Isn't this a public policy issue for the Government to resolve? Why involve business? A. Clearly, responsibility for building and maintaining the nation's public works systems rests with the Government. However, the decaying condition of this infrastructure can acutely affect economic growth and development. Studies have demonstrated that a significant correlation exists between infrastructure investment and the health of the general economy. In Los Angeles, in 1988, costs of traffic congestion for both business and commuter travelers exceeded $500 million. And by 2005, traffic delays alone will cost the nation an estimated $50 billion a year in lost wages and wasted gasoline. Q. Just how pervasive is this problem? A. In a word, America's infrastructure is crumbling. Of the 2.1 million miles of paved roads, more than 60 percent require some degree of renovation and more than 40 percent of the bridges are structurally deficient or functionally obsolete. At the same time, the current number of highways, bridges and airports is inadequate to cope with the demand. As a result, traffic congestion regularly occurs on 70 percent of urban highways, and airport gridlock has reached epidemic proportions. Q. Why were public works projects postponed to the point of creating this crisis? A. Last year, a Congressionally mandated special commission, the National Council on Public Works Improvement, issued a report that succinctly answers that question: ''Of all public services, infrastructure may be the easiest to take for granted. When it functions best, it is noticed least.'' In fact, that is what happened. In seeking ways to trim expenditures from the budget, the Government reduced the annual increase in infrastructure spending from 4.5 percent in the 1961 to 1970 period to about eight-tenths of a percent between 1981 and 1987. Q. Since fiscal retrenchment remains in force, where will the money come from? A. Not only have budgetary constraints reduced funds available for public works projects, but the effort to shrink the deficit has prompted the Federal Government to withhold about $29 billion in user-paid revenues that are supposed to be reinvested in infrastructure projects like highway redevelopment. Releasing these revenues would be a good first step. However, the only conceivable way to really rebuild America's infrastructure is through a concerted program from all levels of government. Q. What would such a multilevel government commitment involve? A. There are any number of specific ideas being proposed and several bills are currently being debated in Congress. One recommendation calls for the creation of a Federal infrastructure bank to better manage the use of public works funds. Another proposal would make state and local governments responsible for the design and construction of all projects and limit the Federal role to co-financing the projects with the states and localities. Q. Relieving urban traffic congestion would seem to require additional infrastructure building, not just repairing what exists. How can this be accomplished, given urban land-use restrictions and space limitations? A. Our design engineering studies indicate many bottlenecks at interchanges between interstates and secondary traffic arteries. One promising solution is the ''urban interchange,'' a design configuration built within an existing right-of-way to improve traffic flow. In the case of airports, part of the solution requires improved air-traffic control, gate-capacity expansions and landing systems.

title: Man Kills Wife and Children, Then Dies in Burning Home
description: A man shot and killed his estranged wife and their two children today, then set fire to the house and killed himself, the police said.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Society's Debut With Sherry as Its Leader
description: Fred Sherry begins his stewardship at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center with several obstacles placed, perhaps unfairly, in his path. One is the simple idea of change -the uprooting of a very specific and intimate bond that the society has built with its audiences for the past 20 years.

title: 20 Are Wounded in East Jerusalem Rioting
description: Five policemen and 15 Arabs were reported wounded today and at least 40 Palestinian students were arrested in the first riots in East Jerusalem since the spring.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Ogilvy & Mather has focused on elephant poaching, asking consumers not to buy ivory products, in a pro bono campaign for the World Wildlife Fund. The print and television ads emphasize that at the current rate of slaughter, elephants will be extinct in 25 years. The ads are being broadcast in 22 local markets.

title: Charles Schwab reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Upjohn Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Last of 4 Offers Plea In $4.4 Million Theft
description: A 55-year-old Union City man pleaded guilty yesterday to helping plan a $4.4 million armored car robbery last year and to helping commit the robbery with two military cadets.

title: 2 Koreas Move Toward an Accord for Visits
description: South Korea and North Korea tentatively agreed today to allow visits between divided families for only the second time since 1945, but they remained divided on conditions for the exchanges.

title: Qaddafi and Mubarak Seek to Heal Rift
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi drove across 120 miles of desert from Libya to meet President Hosni Mubarak today on his first visit to Egypt in 16 years. He sought to end a longstanding feud with Cairo that ranks among the longest in the Arab world.

title: Excerpts From Baker's Remarks on Soviet Union
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, delivered tonight before the Foreign Policy Association in New York, as provided by the Federal News Service:

title: United Investors Management Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
David Lean, 81, Is at It Again, Working on Brando and Conrad
description: Sir David Lean is working again. The 81-year-old English director of such film classics as ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ''Lawrence of Arabia'' - who makes movies only infrequently nowadays - is casting his next film. And he thinks he has persuaded Marlon Brando to play a brutish South American general.

title: Bay Financial reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included provisions for possible investment losses of $32,360,638 for the latest year and $5,330,606 for the year-earlier period. The company said included in the latest and year-earlier revenues are gains on disposition of investment of $1,523,131 and $4,279,935, respectively.

title: Doctors Debate Value Of Test That Gauges Health of a Newborn
description: LUSTY cries immediately after birth count for a lot in the struggle for a healthy life. Using the strength of an infant's wails, as well as other signs, pediatricians can rapidly assess the status of a newborn in a test that is known throughout the world as the Apgar score.

title: Gretzky's Style Fits The Big Moment
description: Now Wayne Gretzky really is in a world of his own.

title: Brokerages To Clients: Stay Calm
description: Major brokerages as well as smaller money-management firms did their best yesterday to reassure their clients that the stock market would weather the current storm on Wall Street.

title: Airline Takeover Bill Clears a House Panel
description: A bill to forestall airline acquisitions moved ahead on Capitol Hill today, over the objections of the Bush Administration.

description: b-After a loss of $2.2 million for the quarter and income of $3,981,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After income of about $9.6 million, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $23,270,000, or 22 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The 1989 third quarter and 9 months consisted of 13 weeks and 39 weeks, respectively, compared with 14 weeks and 40 weeks for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Viola Deal Completed
description: The Mets completed the Frank Viola trade yesterday, sending Jack Savage, a minor league relief pitcher, to Minnesota. Savage, 25 years old, was 3-2 with six saves for Class AAA Tidewater of the International League last season.(AP)

title: Central Fidelity Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Magazines Plot Invasion Of Salons
description: EVER vigilant in the search for new magazine markets to conquer, two publishers have opened a battle for supremacy in another venue uncrowded by specialty journals: beauty parlors.

description: Share amounts have been restated for the 20 percent stock dividend paid Sept. 15.

title: Reynolds Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
One More Scandal For British Royalty
description: A relative of Queen Elizabeth II who is 24th in line to the throne has created a new royal scandal by publicizing her dispute with her parents over her out-of-wedlock pregnancy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ADT Ltd., said that Laidlaw Transportation Ltd., Burlington, Ontario, Canada, a transportation and waste management company, now holds 253.1 million ADT common shares, representing 29.4 percent of the issued common shares.

title: Bats Found to Adjust Their Squeaks for Motion
description: IT has long been known that bats find their prey by listening for echoes from their high frequency squeaks. Now scientists have found that bats alter the frequency of the squeaks they emit so that the echoes return at the frequency to which the bats are most sensitive.

title: U.S. OFFERS TO AID GORBACHEV'S PLAN TO REVAMP SYSTEM
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said last night that the United States was prepared to provide Moscow with advice and technical assistance to help it restructure the Soviet economy and society.

description: The company said revenues for 1988 are restated to reflect the reclassification of customer pass through expenses to revenue and direct costs.

The losses from discontinued operations represented Yates Industries copper foil unit which the company previously announced is for sale.

title: Comptek Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
This Year, Series 'Travel Day' Means An Easy Hop for Everyone Concerned
description: In less time than it takes most people to travel from home to the airport, the commissioner of baseball changed headquarters today on World Series travel day.

title: Critics Challenge Reliance on DrugsIn Psychiatry
description: THE movement among psychiatrists to rely more and more on using drugs to treat mental disorders is coming under strong attack. Critics contend that scientific studies evaluating the effectiveness of psychiatric drugs have been systematically biased, exaggerating the medications' potency.

title: 100,000 Protest in Leipzig In Largest Rally in Decades
description: More than 100,000 East Germans demanding reforms marched peacefully through the streets of Leipzig tonight. The demonstration, the largest since an uprising in 1953, was reported without condemnation for the first time by the East German press.

title: Morgan Posts a Loss; Other Banks Record Gains
description: As expected, J. P. Morgan & Company announced yesterday that it had reported a loss of $1.82 billion for the third quarter. Meanwhile, the Security Pacific Corporation yesterday reported a 10 percent increase in third-quarter profits; the NCNB Corporation's profits more than doubled, with half its profits coming from its Texas operations, and the First City Bancorporation of Texas reported a 22 percent increase in profits. J.P. Morgan

In London, Simplicity (Mostly) Reigns
description: No sooner had the lights dimmed on the runways in Milan than the fashion action began here.

title: LSB Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Westamerica Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE VOLATILE MARKETS The stock market overcame a shaky opening and roared back on heavy volume to regain about half its losses of Friday. Prices were buoyed both by corporations buying their own shares and by institutions buying shares they considered cheap. [ Page A1. ] Stock prices in Tokyo climbed today, recovering much of their loss of Monday. [ D9. ] Prices rose in the ''junk bond'' market. [ D17. ] Crushing volume in the first hours of trading on the nation's financial exchanges gave the new computer systems their first test in live trading. And industry officials said the systems held up, with only minor problems. [ D1. ] Arbitrage firms might have lost as much as $100 million just on the stock of AMR and UAL. [ D10. ] The much-feared crush of redemptions did not materialize in the mutual funds industry. [ D1. ] Brokerages and money management firms did their best to reassure their clients. [ D7. ] Politicians, economists and business executives are reappraising the economy. [ D7. ] Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply, as dealers unloaded issues when the stock market began to recover. [ D17. ] The dollar finished moderately lower against most major foreign currencies. [ D22. ] Copper futures fell sharply. [ D22. ] COMPANIES Donald J. Trump withdrew his $120-a-share offer for AMR, but some people suggested he would come back with a lower offer, given the sharp drop in AMR stock. [ D1. ] A bill to forestall airline acquisitions moved ahead on Capitol Hill, over the objections of the Bush Administration. [ D8. ] Domestic and international banks have told Citibank that they are willing to lend more than enough money to finance a $6.75 billion leveraged buyout of UAL, a top Citibank official said. [ D1. ] I.B.M.'s profits fell 29.7 percent in the third quarter, at the low end of the range of what the company had anticipated. [ D1. ] Merrill Lynch's profits fell 37.5 percent in the quarter. Paine Webber's net income declined 20 percent; Charles Schwab's earnings rose 70 percent, and Bear Stearns was up 8 percent. [ D6. ] J. P. Morgan reported a loss of $1.82 billion for the third quarter. NCNB's profit more than doubled; Security Pacific was up 10 percent, and First City Bancorporation rose 22 percent. [ D5. ] G.M. has notified workers that it will shut several plants in North America in the next few years. [ D19. ] Farley agreed to sell Cluett, Peabody to a French group for $600 million. [ D4. ] K Mart agreed to acquire Pace Membership Warehouse for $23 a share in cash, or $322 million. [ D4. ] British Aerospace is considering a merger of its missile division with France's Thomson-CSF. [ D4. ] ECONOMY

title: Abitibi-Price Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Kremlin Leader Lashes at Press, Raising Its Fears
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sharply rebuked some of the leading practitioners of glasnost, and accused the liberated press of sowing division and discontent.

title: When in Rome, Montana
description: On a visit to Rome last week, a New York woman felt reassured to realize that her jacket was made in Italy, and so were her slacks, shoes and purse. She thought she'd look as though she belonged. What she saw as she walked outside was a tide of blue denim. The Via dei Condotti looked like an American campus, awash in jeans, jean jackets and institutional T-shirts and sweatshirts, many bearing bold legends in English.

title: There Is Still Life in Roger Craig
description: Extraordinary measures are in order for the San Francisco Giants. Down two games to none to their brothers across the Bay, the Oakland Athletics, in the four-of-seven-game World Series, some business of an ingenious nature must be devised, and hastily. If anyone is capable of helping pluck the Giants from the hot water they find themselves currently and collectively immersed in, it is their manager, the crafty and resourceful, not to say poetic, Roger Craig.

title: Wallach Gets 6 Years for His Wedtech Role
description: E. Robert Wallach, a longtime friend of former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, was sentenced to six years in prison and fined $250,000 yesterday by a Federal district judge who chastised him for selling ''your influence on the back stairs of the White House'' in the Wedtech case.

title: High-Tech Sales Talk By Texas Instruments
description: At 435 pages, Business Week magazine's annual issue on chief executives is already a hefty publication. But 140,000 Business Week subscribers will receive an even bigger copy of the magazine - fattened by what the magazine calls the first talking advertisement.

description: b-Included $250,000 of income from sale of land previously held for investment. c-Net loss

In a Wild Finish, Rams Suffer Their First Loss
description: Frank Reich of the Buffalo Bills threw an 8-yard touchdown pass to Andre Reed with 16 seconds left tonight to cap a wild final three minutes that gave the Bills a 23-20 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Merrill Lynch Net Falls 37.5%, While 3 Rivals Fare Better
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which operates the nation's largest brokerage and investment firm, yesterday reported a 37.5 percent decline in profits for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with the third quarter of last year.

Poland Passes a Bill to Offset Inflation
description: The Polish Parliament enacted legislation today to compensate workers for roaring inflation, but support for the bill was not overwhelming, and some deputies contended that the measure would merely generate further pressure on prices.

description: b-Net loss

title: Associated Banc-Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BellSouth Alters Bid for Lin
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it would revise its bid for Lin Broadcasting, according to papers filed by Lin with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The papers did not disclose the structure of the new bid.

title: Making The Best Of Winter
description: What little humor surrounded closing day at Belmont Park yesterday was of the sort heard among men on their way to the gallows. It won't be so bad, the horseplayers wryly told one another: after just 29 weeks at Aqueduct, a mere 1,566 races, Belmont will be running again.

title: Fresh Look Is Taken at the State of the Economy
description: The decline in the stock market Friday, the rebound today and the nervousness about what it all might mean led politicians, economists and business executives today to reappraise the state of the American economy and the Government's economic policies.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree To Hear Plea On Miranda
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the police must warn drunken-driving suspects of their constitutional rights against self-incrimination before asking them questions aimed at testing their mental functioning.

title: Ohio Edison Co reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected a write-off of $128 million for certain nuclear construction costs.

title: An Arrest Will Free Former Rape Suspect
description: A New Jersey man was wrongly jailed on charges of raping two women at the Penta Hotel in Manhattan last spring and another man has been arrested and charged with the attacks, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: Handholding in Books
description: WORDPERFECT, now in version 5.0, is the most popular word-processing program for I.B.M.-compatible computers. Its 484-page manual and 398-page workbook document such a host of features that new users are bound to be intimidated.

title: Closing by Pauley
description: Pauley Petroleum Inc. said it intends to close its Newhall Refining Company refinery at the end of the year, offer the site for sale and lay off about 70 people. The company said the refinery, in Santa Clarita, Calif., had suffered significant losses in recent years and that the market for its products, including asphalt, fuel oil and jet fuel, was expected to remain weak.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Washington Water Power reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Quotron's Error on Dow Adds to Jitters
description: Quotron Systems Inc., the nation's leading provider of electronic stock quotes, compounded market jitters among its clients yesterday when its computers incorrectly calculated the Dow Jones industrial average and transmitted that information to customers for at least a half-hour.

title: Northeast Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Court to Rule on Bid to Undo Merger
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a major dispute in Federal antitrust law: whether a state or a private party can sue to undo a merger on the ground that the newly combined company poses a threat to competition.

title: General Building Products reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Farace's Wife Free On $250,000 Bail
description: The wife and brother-in-law of Constabile (Gus) Farace, who is the prime suspect in the murder of a Federal drug agent, were freed on $250,000 bail each yesterday on charges of distributing marijuana.

title: Topics of The Times; Disconnected Thoughts
description: While a Federal Communications Commission study confirms that Americans are spending more and more time on the telephone, a telephone workers' strike has put thousands in the Northeast on hold. Unable to get installations and repairs, they tell horror stories about business deals lost, love affairs ruined and hours spent weighted down with quarters, in search of a working pay phone.

title: Is Mr. Bush Serious on Civil Rights?
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh says the Bush Administration is having trouble finding a new civil rights chief for the Justice Department after its first choice, William Lucas, was roughly rejected. Meanwhile the Administration also allows the U. S. Commission on Civil Rights to flounder without a new chairman. The vacancies invite question about whether President Bush is serious about civil rights.

title: MARKET RECOVERS HALF OF ITS LOSSES, LED BY BLUE CHIPS
description: The stock market overcame a shaky opening yesterday and roared back on heavy volume to regain about half the losses recorded in the heavy selling late Friday.

title: Soviet Coach Dismissed
description: The coach of the Soviet national weight lifting team was dismissed yesterday, one month after Hafiz Suleymanov, a world champion in the 123-pound category, defected to Turkey. The Soviet news agency Tass said the executive committee of the Soviet Weight Lifting Federation voted 27-2 tordahl to become a free agent after this season.(AP)

title: National Pizza To Buy Skipper's
description: The National Pizza Company said it had signed an agreement to acquire Skipper's Inc. of Bellevue, Wash. Skipper's operates 216 seafood restaurants in the Western United States and in British Columbia.

title: Home Federal S&L of Upper East Tenn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Careers; Executive Pay Called Too High
description: ''IT is getting worse,'' Peter G. Scotese said recently of the spiraling total pay for top executives. ''I think it is out of control.''

title: Kisio Rests, But Not Easily
description: There were games last season, Kelly Kisio realizes now, that he should never have played in. With one hand cracked in places and his back crying in pain, Kisio pulled on his uniform anyway because he feared he would never be able to shed the guilt if he didn't.

title: DEALS
description: FOOTBALL DALLAS (NFC) - Released Ron Burton, linebacker. Announced Michael Irvin, wide receiver, will undergo knee surgery and miss the remainder of the season. DENVER (AFC) - Appointed Mike Shanahan quarterback coach. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Announced Shawn Patterson, defensive end, will undergo knee surgery and miss the remainder of the season. PHOENIX (NFC) - Placed Randy Kirk, linebacker, on the injured reserve list.

title: In Central Park Rape Testimony, Officer Tells of Murder Statement
description: One of the first youths arrested in the Central Park rape case said minutes after his capture, ''I know who did the murder! I know who did the murder!'' and offered to lead the police to the suspect's home, a police officer testified yesterday.

title: W.W. Williams Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23

title: Worst Fear For Funds Is Averted
description: For the mutual fund industry, the much-feared crush of redemptions did not materialize yesterday.

title: Doctor's Killer Uses Insanity Defense
description: Steven Smith raped, robbed and murdered Dr. Kathryn Hinnant in her office at Bellevue Hospital on Jan. 7, his defense lawyer conceded yesterday as Mr. Smith's trial began. But the lawyer, Marvyn Kornberg, contended that his client was insane at the time and therefore not criminally responsible.

title: Baby's Grieving Parents Sue to Keep Respirator On
description: Deep in their hearts Carlotta and Luis Alvarado know that their new baby will never open his eyes or leave his incubator at Elmhurst General Hospital. Even if his respirator is kept on, they know that his heart will probably stop pumping.

title: Grove Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Talks With Thomson
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said that it was considering a possible merger of its missile division with France's Thomson-CSF to form the largest European contractor for guided-weapons systems.

title: U.S. Energy Official Joining First Chicago
description: Martha O. Hesse, chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission for the last three years, has accepted a top post at the First Chicago Corporation and is to be succeeded by Martin Lewis Allday, a Texas lawyer and longtime friend of President Bush.

title: AMR Bid Withdrawn By Trump
description: Donald J. Trump yesterday withdrew his $120-a-share offer for the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, and said he would review his options.

title: Schools and Police Battle Over Search
description: For weeks, the dismissal of a local high school English teacher for sexual misconduct passed with little notice.

title: Torchmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union Reaches Pact With Gas Company
description: Brooklyn Union Gas and a union representing 2,200 members agreed early yesterday on a contract giving workers a 13.6 percent raise on a three-year contract, averting a strike in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Yeltsin Makes the News Again, but Ruefully
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick Moscow politician who recently toured the United States, told the police late last month that he had been the victim of an assassination attempt, but later recanted his story, according to a bizarre report today by the Soviet Interior Minister.

Bush Signs Order Triggering Outlay Cuts as Deficit Deadline Passes By SUSAN F. RASKY
description: President Bush signed an order today triggering $16.1 billion in automatic spending cuts from an array of domestic and military programs because Congress failed to meet a deadline for adopting its own deficit reduction plan.

title: Accounts
description: * Source Consumer Products, to Christopher Thomas/Muller Jordan Weiss, with a budget of $1 million.

RESULTS PLUS
description: GYMNASTICS Soviet Team in Lead: The Soviet Union, led by Svetlana Boginskaya, took the lead at the halfway point yesterday in the women's competition at the world championships in Stuttgart, West Germany. The United States was a surprise, holding fourth place.(AP) RACING Whiz Along Wins: Whiz Along, ridden by Julie Krone, closed strongly to a one-length victory yesterday in Belmont Park's closing day feature, the $45,000 Cheriepe Handicap for horses 3 years old and up. Born to Shop was unable to withstand the winner's late rush but lasted to be second. Whiz Along, a 4-year-old colt, paid $20.20 for $2 to win.(AP) HOCKEY Capitals 4, Canadiens 3: Dale Hunter scored his second goal of the game 3 minutes 37 seconds into overtime last night to end the regular-season home unbeaten streak of Patrick Roy, the Montreal goalie, at 35 games.(AP)

title: Market Place; Balancing Stocks With the Futures
description: IF one tag on an item says the price is $2 and another says $1.80, it is hard to know what the real price is. But few buyers are willing to pay $2, no matter how much they think it is really worth.

title: Issues for the 5 Boroughs
description: Following are the two questions for the proposed changes in the City Charter that will be on the Nov. 7 ballot:

Christmas Tree Outlook
description: The Agriculture Department is predicting another record season for Christmas tree farmers, despite the preference of many Americans for artificial trees. A record 34.3 million Christmas trees were sold in 1988, and an Agriculture Department report says the market is expected to exceed 35 million this year.

title: People
description: * Rick Carpenter, Jaci Sisson and Mark Monteiro have been named senior vice presidents and creative directors of DDB Needham/Los Angeles.

title: Gold Monkeys Learn How to Live in Wild In Brazilian Preserve
description: IN a flash of orange fur, a golden lion tamarin suddenly appeared, hopping and swinging easily through the green forest foliage. Nine others followed, browsing for fruit and insects, keeping balance with foot-long prehensile tails.

title: Mercury Finance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns; When Drivers Earn Far More Than Secretaries
description: Not long after he became president of Hofstra University in the mid-70's, James M. Shuart decided that a good way to enhance the school's image - and increase its enrollment - would be to have a million-volume library.

title: Thornburgh Accused Of Deliberate Delays
description: The prosecutor in the Iran-contra investigation today accused Attorney General Dick Thornburgh of deliberately sidetracking ''with no legitimate reason'' the criminal case against a former Central Intelligence Agency official.

title: U.S. Suspends Richco Grain
description: The Agriculture Department has suspended a United States grain exporting company from taking part in its export subsidy programs because of reported links with the fugitive trader Marc Rich.

title: Dollar Is Generally Lower In a Nervous Trading Day
description: The dollar finished moderately lower yesterday against most major foreign currencies in what dealers described as extremely nervous trading on both sides of the Atlantic. The dollar managed to recover most of the earlier losses as the stock market began to rebound.

title: Former State Senator Begins a Fraud Trial
description: Former State Senator Richard Schermerhorn went on trial in Federal court yesterday with his lawyer contending that the Government picked on him because of his position.

title: For Hapless Dallas, It's Lonely at the Bottom
description: The Detroit Lions and the Dallas Cowboys entered the sixth week of the season as the National Football League's only teams without a victory and as the brunt of brutal jokes. The Lions were able to escape the doghouse, while the Cowboys were left still pawing at the door.

title: Thomas J. Spenker, 74, Ex-Insurance Chief
description: Thomas J. Spenker, retired president of the J. C. Penney Insurance Companies, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: Car Bomb in Colombia Kills 4 at Newspaper
description: A car bomb exploded today in a northeastern Colombian city and killed four employees of a newspaper that had joined in a condemnation of cocaine traffickers.

The year-ago periods were restated to reflect Oct. 24 stock dividend.

description: Arnold Jacobsen, the retired head surgeon for the Workmen's Benefit Fund of the U.S.A. Inc. in Manhattan, died Saturday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J., after a long illness. He was 91 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Tokyo Closes Higher, But Traders Still Wary
description: Taking their cue from Monday's advance in New York, stock prices here moved up strongly today, recovering much of their losses from the previous session.

description: Bush Readies Veto Of Abortion Financing President Bush is prepared to veto a bill that would expand Federal financing of abortions. Page A16.

Year-ago quarter share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 share split which became effective on May 9, 1989.

title: Prague Reportedly Charges Two Editors With Subversion
description: Two editors of Czechoslovakia's leading independent newspaper have been arrested and charged with subversion, human-rights advocates in Prague say.

title: Coast Distribution reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amid Slowdown, L.I. Weighs Cost Of Boom-Time Pledges
description: As its economy slows and its property taxes soar, Long Island is engaged in a wrenching examination of many of the region's public commitments of the last decade, like environmental protectionism.

title: Beverly Hills's Teachers Strike Over Better Pay and Benefits
description: Teachers struck today for more money and better benefits in the first walkout against the school system of this wealthy community.

title: Nissan Head For U.S. Units
description: The Nissan Motor Company of Japan today named Yoshikazu Hanawa chairman of its two main American subsidiaries, the sales and marketing arm and the manufacturing unit.

title: KEY RATES
Alliant and Intel In Joint Effort
description: The Alliant Computer Systems Corporation, Littleton, Mass., and the Intel Corporation said they had developed a new software standard for use with the Intel i860 microprocessor in computers based on parallel processing. In addition, Intel said it would purchase about $3 million worth of newly issued Alliant common stock, or about 4 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: McGill Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Notre Dame Is Atop Times List
description: With a convincing 41-27 victory over Air Force at Falcon Stadium that stretched its winning streak to 18 games, Notre Dame finally reached No. 1 in The New York Times's computerized rating of the nation's top college football teams.

title: Protein Databases reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kansas Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In East Berlin, Satire Conquers Fear
description: By the late hours of this autumn Sunday, the nondescript suburb of Rummelsburg had taken on the air of a rock and folk festival. That proved only part of it.

title: Cyberoptics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Danilo Kis Dead at 54; Wrote of the Holocaust
description: Danilo Kis, a Yugoslav-born writer and essayist whose works blended fact and fiction to describe the horror of the Holocaust and Stalin's forced-labor camps, died of cancer on Sunday, friends said today. He was 54 years old and had lived in Paris 10 years.

title: 20-Car Pileup Kills 5 at Lyons
description: Five people were killed and 23 seriously injured early today when 20 cars plowed into a burning truck on a highway in southeastern France.

title: National Heritage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a provision for doubtful accounts of $3.1 million. c-Net income

title: Texas Plant Comes Under Scrutiny As Cover-Up of Problems Charged
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today opened a special inspection of the Comanche Peak nuclear power plant in Texas amid charges that some high-ranking commission officials had covered up problems at the $9 billion plant.

title: Scott O'Dell, a Children's Author Of Historical Fiction, Dies at 91
description: Scott O'Dell, who wrote ''Island of the Blue Dolphins'' and 25 other books for children, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 91 years old and lived in Waccabuc, N.Y. His latest book, ''My Name Is Not Angelica,'' is to be published Oct. 30.

title: 'Junk Bonds' End Up After Big Early Drop
description: The ''junk bond'' market closed up, on average one-half point, or $5 for every $1,000 face amount, yesterday. Prices of the high-yield, high-risk bonds fell sharply in the morning, but then bargain-hunting institutional investors bought junk issues of widely known companies like Duracell, Kroger and Safeway.

title: TRW Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Men-Only Golf Course Hours Lead to Harassment Charge
description: A female golfer testified today that a group of men surrounded her with their golf carts to try to block her from playing during male-only hours at a Long Island country club last year.

title: Sales Far Outpace Rise Of 0.3% in Inventories
description: Business sales far outpaced inventory accumulation in August, the Commerce Department said today in a report that suggested unsold goods were not piling up and the economy was in fairly strong shape.

title: Boeing to Resume Bargaining With Strikers
description: Negotiations between the Boeing Company and striking members of the machinists' union will resume on Wednesday, exactly two weeks after the walkout by 57,800 workers began, a Federal mediator said today.

title: Fleet Seeks Buyer
description: The Fleet Aerospace Corporation of Ontario, Canada, said it was actively trying to sell its 88 percent stake in Fleet Aerospace Inc., of Gardena, Calif. Fleet said its decision was part of a strategic restructuring. It said Fleet Aerospace Inc. lost $138,000, on sales of $19.5 million, in the quarter ended June 30.

title: Great Bay Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISI Systems Backs Memotec Deal
description: ISI Systems Inc., a maker of computer software based here, said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by Memotec Data Inc. of Montreal. The company said Memotec would start a $20-a-share tender offer for all ISI shares held by the public within five days. The deal is conditioned on receipt of at least 15 percent of ISI's shares not held by the company's chairman and president, Charles C. Johnston.

title: Franco, 51, Zairian Band Leader And Creator of the Soukous Style
description: Franco, a Zairian guitarist and band leader who was one of Africa's most popular and influential musicians, died on Thursday in a Brussels hospital after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

title: Marcos, Even in Death, Remains a Force in Philippine Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Hughes to Buy Perkin-Elmer Unit
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it had signed an agreement to acquire the Electro-Optics Technology division of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Soviets Give Kin Wallenberg Papers
description: More than 45 years after Raoul Wallenberg disappeared into the Soviet prison system after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, the Soviet authorities gave his family some of his personal belongings: a blue Swedish diplomatic passport embossed with the royal crown, some money and several notebooks.

title: U.N., Under U.S. Pressure, Disavows Envoy's Statement
description: Responding to United States criticism, the United Nations distanced itself today from comments by one of its envoys, who urged Nicaraguan rebels to accept an accord calling for their disbanding and implied that United States policy was anachronistic.

title: Justice Is Cited For Long Delays In Case Rulings
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct has censured Justice Edward J. Greenfield of State Supreme Court in Manhattan for what it said were his ''unreasonable and inexcusable'' delays in deciding court business.

title: Out, Out, Brief Hope
description: The Arab states have stamped out a faint, brief hope that they might take one small step toward real peace in the Middle East.

title: Benjamin Signs With Italian Team
description: Benoit Benjamin spurned a new contract with the Los Angeles Clippers and signed yesterday with the defending Italian league champion Philips Milan.

title: Commerce Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Public Utilities Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1988 write- offs were related to settlement of energy cost rate complaints in Pennsylvania and unrecoverable cleanup costs for the Three Mile Island unit 2 nuclear plant.

title: Devils Reduce Defense Surplus By Trading Kurvers to the Leafs
description: The Devils traded a piece of their present for a bit of the future yesterday when they sent Tom Kurvers to the Maple Leafs for Toronto's first draft choice in 1991.

title: Desjardins Deragon Langlois reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: China Prepares Session Of Central Committee
description: China announced today that a widely expected Central Committee meeting would be held late this month or early next month to discuss the country's economic difficulties and other matters.

title: Boeing and Airbus Get Gulf Air Orders
description: Gulf Air said it plans to borrow $400 million to buy six new 767-300 airliners from the Boeing Company and also buy 12 A320 aircraft from Airbus Industries for a total of $1 billion. A spokesman for the airline said it was inviting bids from offshore banks for the financing.

title: Summit Health Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included after pretax loss of $15.5 million on sale of assets. c-Included after pretax loss of $17 million on sale of assets.

title: Standard Products reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Farley to Sell Some Cluett Operations
description: William F. Farley, who agreed to acquire the big textile maker West Point-Pepperell Inc. early this year for $3 billion, moved a step closer yesterday to completing that deal.

title: For Traders, an Early Start to a Hectic Day
description: As the world watched to see whether Wall Street would replay the stock market debacle of October 1987, brokers and traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange overcame their nervousness yesterday in trading that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average nearly 90 points higher.

title: Some North America Plants May Be Shut Down by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had notified workers in the United States and Canada last week about pending shifts in vehicle production during the next few years that are likely to lead to the closing of several North American plants.

title: Washington at Work; Beset by Critics Hungry for Dynamic Leader, Dogged Mitchell Lashes Back
description: George J. Mitchell was billed as a made-for-television Senate majority leader, a smooth spokesman for a party shut out of the White House and dependent on Congress for its chance at prime time.

title: LEADER FALLS BACK IN BRAZILIAN RACE
description: One month before Brazilians vote for a new President, the race looks increasingly like a tossup.

description: b-After a gain of $315 million, or 53 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes (SFAS No. 96). I.B.M. said the 9-month results in 1988 included a $600 million charge for estimated costs of announced consolidations that was taken in the second quarter.

title: Goldome reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: the company had a gain of $11.5 million in the latest third quarter and 9 months from the sale of a business. The latest 9 months' loss also reflected a charge of $173.6 million taken in the second quartr in connection with a restructuring.

title: Grand Jury Indicts 5 In Mob-Union Case
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted the reported acting boss and four members of the DeCavalcante crime family, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: A practical approach to trading policy recommends ''taking the cash and letting the credit go.'' But there are times at the bridge table when one can earn considerable credit for working out how to take the cash.

Much Fuss, Over What?; For Those Confused, A Few Explanations
description: Has a stock market that falls 190 points one day and rises 88 the next chance it gets simply lost its head?

title: Q&A
description: Birds and Hurricanes Q. What do birds do in a hurricane? A. A number of authorities agree that birds do not get any special storm warnings before a hurricane that allow them to avoid it.

description: b-Net income

title: NCNB Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: NCNB said its earnings included 100 percent of the results of NCNB Texas National Bank since Aug. 1. In addition, the company said, NCNB Texas results are reflected on a consolidated basis retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: Israel Says Officer's Error Let Syrian Fly In
description: An army inquiry completed today found that a Syrian MIG-23 fighter-bomber was able to penetrate Israeli airspace unchallenged last week because of an error by the air defense officer on duty at the time.

title: A Young Noriega Fan Ruffles Her Neighbors
description: A schoolgirl's friendly visits with her Panamanian pen pal, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, have her neighbors and her Congressman shaking their heads. ''If it was my daughter, she wouldn't be going,'' said Virginia Paulson, a Councilwoman here, after the 11-year-old girl, Sarah York, left last week for her second trip to Panama. Sarah's parents declined to discuss the issue.

title: Visit to a Large, Hot Planet: Galileo Heads for Jupiter
description: Scientists hope the Galileo spacecraft's planned explorations of Jupiter, probing deep into the planet's hot, dense hydrogen atmosphere, will yield important clues to primordial conditions in the solar system and also insights about the ''big bang'' that may have created the universe.

title: California Water Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giants Turn to Improvisation to Preserve Victory Over Redskins
description: The Giants' tight ends have prototype size: 6 feet 4 inches and 245 pounds for Mark Bavaro, 6-3 and 240 for Zeke Mowatt, 6-5 and 245 for Howard Cross. Mark Ingram, a wide receiver, is just 5-10 and 188.

title: Telemedia Plans to Start Eating Well Magazine
description: Telemedia Publishing U.S. Inc., the company that acquired New England Monthly magazine earlier this year, announced last week that it would introduce in July a bimonthly magazine on food and health called Eating Well.

title: Taxes Short Of Forecast, Regan Says
description: Revenues from New York State's major taxes were more than $200 million below projections for the first six months of the fiscal year, according to a report issued today. The report renewed debate over whether the state can afford a scheduled $400 million tax cut next year.

title: Birtcher Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Correction
description: An obituary on Oct. 7 about Irving Newman, a former neighborhood aide to three New York City mayors, misstated one aspect of his career.

title: Cornel Wilde, 74, a Performer and Film Producer
description: Cornel Wilde, an athletic actor who was expert in fencing and horsemanship but who won stardom with his portrayal of the tubercular composer Frederic Chopin in the 1945 film ''A Song to Remember'' died of leukemia yesterday in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, three days after his 74th birthday.

description: The company said year-ago third quarter ended Sept. 26, 1988.

title: Congressman Enters Connecticut Primary
description: United States Representative John G. Rowland entered the race for the 1990 Republican gubernatorial nomination today, attacking Gov. William A. O'Neill for the state's constantly changing budget picture and trying to clear up questions about his stance on abortion.

title: Engraph Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Rebels Reject Salvador Government Offer at Talks
description: The Salvadoran Government opened critical talks here today with guerrilla representatives by proposing an end to all hostilities in two days and the demobilization of the rebels in three months.

title: Pretoria May Be Looking to Freed Blacks for Aid
description: In its treatment of the eight political prisoners released on Sunday, the white minority Government appears to be sending signals that it wants the cooperation of the freed men in promoting some form of negotiations with this country's black majority.

title: Guber-Peters Has Profit
description: The Guber-Peters Entertainment Company said yesterday that its net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 was $5.8 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with a loss of $6.9 million a year earlier. Revenue more than doubled, to $10.9 million, compared with $4.6 million a year earlier. The current figures reflect an extraordinary gain of $2.1 million after taxes from the repurchase at a discount of a $9.9 million principal amount of the company's outstanding convertible debentures. Guber-Peters received a takeover offer of $17.50 a share from the Sony Corporation, which has agreed to acquire Columbia Pictures and wants Peter Guber and Jon Peters to run Columbia.

title: Golden West Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split effective Sept. 11, 1989.

title: For Artists and Musicians, Creativity Can Mean Illness and Injury
description: RECENT surveys of musicians and artists have revealed virtual epidemics of occupationally induced ills, from crippled hands that practiced too hard to outright poisoning and severe allergies provoked by the materials used to create artworks.

title: Governors Ignored Poverty's Role in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Comerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Comerica said the third quarter results included a $59 million addition to its loan loss reserve for Latin American loans. It said its loan loss reserve as of Sept. 30 was $195 million, of which $100 million was allocated to Latin American loans.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 The U.S. is ready to help Moscow with advice and technical aid to restructure the Soviet economy and society, Secretary Baker said. Page A1 Excerpts from Baker's speech A14 President Gorbachev rebuked some of the leading practitioners of glasnost in a meeting on Friday. He accused editors of the liberated press of sowing division and discontent. A1 100,000 protest in Leipzig; largest East German rally A12 Poland passes a bill to offset inflation A3 The arrest of Raoul Wallenberg, the diplomat who saved many Jews from the Nazis, was ''a tragic mistake,'' Moscow said. It gave his family some of his personal belongings. A10 Did someone throw Yeltsin in the Moscow river? He denies it A13 The C.I.A. should get greater latitude from Congress and the President in supporting potentially violent efforts to oust foreign dictators, the Director of Central Intelligence said. A1 Salvadoran foes, in talks, seek way out of mire A6 Leader falls back in Brazilian race A7 The leaders of Egypt and Libya met in Colonel Qaddafi's first visit to Egypt in 16 years. He sought to end a long-standing feud with Cairo. A3 20 are wounded in East Jerusalem rioting A5 News analysis: South Africa appears to be sending signals to the men it released Sunday that it wants cooperation in promoting talks with the country's black majority. A6 Oslo journal: Norway tries legalization of skateboards A4 National A16-24 The stock market rebounded on heavy volume as the Dow Jones rose 88.12 points, regaining about half of the losses from Friday. A1 News analysis: Why all the fuss? The stock market fell Friday because of a feeling that the era of heavily leveraged takeovers is over. But the heavy drop was an overreaction. A1 Donald Trump withdrew his offer for the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines. People involved in the bid said Mr. Trump may return with a lower bid. D1 Citibank gains on United bid D1 Boeing talks resume A16 A smoking ban on commercial flights within the continental United States was agreed to by House and Senate negotiators. A1 The risk of a giant waste explosion was created in Washington state in the 1950's, when engineers tried to pack additional radioactive wastes into steel tanks, a study says. A24 Texas A-plant under scrutiny in wake of cover-up charges A24 State faces deadline today on plans to handle toxic waste A19 Talks on financing abortions have broken down between the White House and Congress, White House officials said. President Bush is preparing to veto the measure. A17 Sides in Illinois try to settle suit on abortion standards A17 Automatic spending cuts began on a wide array of domestic and military programs because the Government could not meet a midnight deadline for reducing the deficit. A20 Washington at Work: A Senate chief, George Mitchell, has disappointed Democrats who had hoped he would be more vocal and aggressive. A18 Senate takes up flag amendment A19 Rights of drunken-driving suspects to be warned of self-incrimination when questioned by the police will be considered by the Supreme Court. A21 Marshall uses ''Afro-American'' throughout an opinion A21 Court to rule on merger lawsuits D15 Hurricane Jerry was downgraded to a tropical depression after it hit Texas on Sunday, causing three deaths but minor damage. A22 A school and the police are clashing in Alaska after the police conducted a raid. They were searching for documents related to a teacher accused of sexual misconduct. A16 Wallach get 6 years A22 Neighbors in West use small claims court to combat drugs A16 Regional B1-6 Long Island is re-examining policies it has pursued, like regulating video-display terminals and planning to dismantle Shoreham, because of a slowing economy and soaring taxes. A1 Albany says tax revenues are $200 million under forecasts B1 A new charter will go before voters in New York City on Nov. 7. The two big issus are: Should the Board of Estimate be abolished? Should most of its powers go to the City Council? B1 A master of biting TV campaigns is back on the attack. After producing ads for President Bush's election campaign, Roger Ailes is doing the same for Rudolph Giuliani in New York City and Jim Courter in New Jersey. B1 City begins review of Dinkins's financial reports B2 To keep its baby on a respirator, a couple is taking New York City to court. The baby has no brain activity, and the hospital wants to turn off the life-support mechanism. B1 Steven Smith killed Kathryn Hinnant in her office at Bellevue Hospital on Jan. 7, his defense lawyer conceded at his trial. But the lawyer claimed Mr. Smith was insane, and therefore not criminally responsible. 2 Florida Players Made Ineligible
description: Kyle Morris, the University of Florida quarterback, and Shane Matthews, his backup, have been declared ineligible for the rest of the season for betting on football games, the university said today.

title: Citibank's Progress On UAL Deal
description: Domestic and international banks have told Citibank that they are willing to lend more money than needed to finance a $6.75 billion leveraged buyout of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, a top Citibank official said last night.

description: The states, under pressure of a Federal deadline Tuesday, are submitting plans showing how they propose to dispose of hazardous wastes during the next 20 years.

title: Polar Thinking on the Antarctic
description: LEAD: Environmentalists who, in the name of saving the Antarctic wilderness, have been lobbying in Paris against a new pact on controlling Antarctic minerals could jeopardize the collection of further knowledge needed to understand global climatic change.

title: Compaq Does It Again
description: EVERY once in a while a new computer comes along that leaps ahead of other machines in its class. This time, once again, it comes from the Compaq Computer Corporation. The company yesterday introduced two new notebook computers, the LTE and the LTE/286, which are the first to combine desktop computer performance in a lightweight package that can be slipped into a briefcase. For the consumer, the new Compaqs mean that computing on the road becomes an almost effortless extension of computing in an office.

title: Review/Ice Dancing; Torville And Dean And Russian All-Stars
description: The Russians drink their tea in glasses; the English prefer teacups, although they used to sip from saucers. It comes as no surprise that there are differences in style between the first-class Soviet skaters on one hand and Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean of Britain on the other, who have all teamed up in a fabulous new ice show called ''Torvill and Dean and the Russian All-Stars.''

title: Arbitrage Losses Put At Up to $100 Million
description: Wall Street traders appear to have weathered the worst market slide in two years, although rough Wall Street estimates suggested yesterday that a handful of arbitrage firms might have lost as much as $100 million or more on two airline stocks.

title: I.B.M. Profits, at Low End Of Expectations, Drop 29.7%
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported a 29.7 percent decline in earnings for the third quarter of 1989. The earnings were at the low end of the range that the company indicated it expected in its surprise announcement last month that profits would be sharply lower.

title: Entronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Motorola Unit Sale
description: Motorola Inc. said it would sell its Tegal Corporation subsidiary to a management group led by Elliott Philofsy, Tegal's president. Terms were not disclosed. Tegal, based in Petaluma, Calif., supplies plasma etch and strip systems to the semiconductor industry. Motorola said financing would be provided by Nazem & Company, a New York investment company. A Motorola spokesman said Tegal had annual sales of about $55 million and that the sale would not have a material impact on earnings.

description: In a move against poaching of African elephants for their ivory, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species added the species to their list. Ivory hunters have drastically reduced the number of elephants that survive in the wild.

description: The second stage of the political battle over flag burning came to the floor of the Senate today as lawmakers began debating a constitutional amendment intended to outlaw it.

title: Topics of The Times; Ferries vs. Gridlock
description: Yesterday a new ferry service began shuttling rush hour commuters between New Jersey's rail hub in Hoboken and Battery Park City in lower Manhattan - the first such crossing in 22 years. The new Hoboken ferry is a crucial component of a sound regional strategy to cope with the explosion in trans-Hudson commuter traffic.

title: Governors Ignored Poverty's Role in Education; The Forgotten Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: Guardsman Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Roger Ailes: Master Maker of Fiery Political Darts
description: If you believe Roger Ailes, the Republican media consultant, the Democrats are - there they go again - soft on crime and drugs and maybe a bit crooked, too.

title: Bush Plans to Veto Measure Expanding Aid for Abortion
description: President Bush is preparing to veto a measure that would broaden the circumstances under which Federal money is provided for abortions, White House officials said today. They said efforts to reach a compromise with members of Congress had broken down.

title: C.I.A. Seeks Looser Rules On Killings During Coups
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, called today on the President and Congress to consider giving the Central Intelligence Agency greater latitude in supporting potentially violent efforts to overthrow foreign dictators.

title: Earnings of Japanese
description: The average employee of a Japanese company earned $27,000 last year, but on average, a man earned more than twice as much as a woman, according to a Government study. The average annual income for Japan's 38 million corporate employees, including bonuses, was up by $915, or 3.5 percent, from the previous year, the National Tax Agency said Saturday. The agency said the average woman earned $15,800, less than half the $33,100 of a man. The figures include part-time employees who worked for the entire 12-month period.

title: Teco Energy Co reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a writeoff of assets by a coal mining subsidiary of about $6.3 million.

title: Hospital Stops Using Generic Drugs
description: A hospital in New Haven said today that it had suspended the use of more than 150 different generic drugs, including some frequently used prescription medicines, as a result of allegations of unethical conduct by some generic drug manufactuers.

title: Using Art as a Sword to Defend Brazil's Forests
description: Twisted tree trunks, singed bark, ashen limbs and burned stumps have been on display here in a chic Ipanema art gallery - totemic monuments to the destruction taking place in Brazil's distant Amazon rain forest.

title: Expos Withdraw Offer
description: The Montreal Expos said yesterday they have withdrawn a reported three-year, $9 million contract offer to the star pitcher Mark Langston while keeping the door open for future negotiations. Langston is eligible to file for free agency following the World Series.(AP)

title: Campaign Trail; Dinkins, in High Hopes, Has Scout for City Hall
description: Last week, David N. Dinkins went to Washington to meet the people he'll need to know if he is elected mayor of New York City. Yesterday, he raised that ''if'' almost to ''when'' by naming the head of a team to lead his anticipated transition to City Hall.

'Weak' Hurricane Leaves 3 Dead; Galveston to Weigh Driving Ban
description: Hurricane Jerry was a relatively small, weak storm when it hit shore here Sunday night, and some people decided to take their chances out along the city's sea wall, where 80 mile-an-hour winds whipped the water.

title: Anti-Semitic Ads Investigated
description: The bias unit of the Middlesex County Prosecutor's office has begun an investigation into anonymous anti-Semitic advertisements that appeared Friday in the classified section of the student newspaper at North Brunswick Township High School.

title: By Design; Beware the Bow
description: You would think a bow would solve everything. After all, this pretty, perky toss-and-tie of fabric is supposed to be synonymous with femininity. That is why ties have been used for ages to decorate every possible piece of fashion - accessories, suits, blouses, sweaters, dresses, ball gowns - not to mention the unmentionables underneath.

title: Review/Television; 'Some Girls' and Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: ''Intercom,'' the soberly inclined PBS series, introduces us tonight to a few of the adolescents who give West Virginia one of the nation's highest rates of unplanned teen-age pregnancy. ''Some Girls,'' at 11:30 P.M. on Channel 13, treats its five subjects as individuals rather than as data, helping us to understand why they are likely to have babies before they have husbands.

title: Fighting Fire With Money
description: Two years ago the stock market crashed. Hysterical analysts warned of economic turmoil reminiscent of the 1930's. But no such catastrophe occurred, due in large part to timely intervention by the Federal Reserve Board. Sensibly, the Fed is prepared to step in once more to protect the larger economy of Main Street from the latest debacle on Wall Street.

title: American Business Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said all share earnings were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid June 30.

title: Critic's Notebook; Was She or Wasn't She? A Diary Of Hemingway's (Probable) Muse.
description: Tracking down details about the real person behind a fictional character is a tantalizing game. When disguising an actual person, a novelist has to make personality adjustments for the sake of the story. If the writing is going well, the author stands aside, and with a growing sense of wonder watches as the characters take over, speak for themselves and assume lives of their own.

M. King Hubbert, 86, Geologist; Research Changed Oil Production
description: M. King Hubbert, an award-winning scientist whose work in physics and geology brought radical changes in the petroleum industry, died Wednesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. Dr. Hubbert, who was 86 years old, had been undergoing treatment for a pulmonary embolism.

title: Nobel Fever: The Price Of Rivalry
description: THE Nobel Prize is coveted by scientists as the ultimate key to fame, influence and material success. But some scientists also see it as a growing temptation to squander scientific gifts on petty competition or even, in rare cases, to lie and cheat.

title: Genetics Institute reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chemicals in A-Plant Pose Blast Risk
description: In an effort to squeeze more waste into giant tanks at a nuclear weapons plant in Washington State, engineers in the 1950's added chemicals that created the risk of an explosion, according to a Government study completed five years ago but not made available until now.

description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $592,657 and $757,939 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Patients Under 50 Fare Best With Parkinson's
description: PEOPLE who develop Parkinson's disease when they are 50 years old or younger and begin treatment with the main drug used to fight the disease are less likely to develop severe long-term effects of the illness than those who become afflicted with the disease later in life, researchers have found.

title: Neighbors in West Use Small Claims Court to Combat Drugs
description: In a novel use of Small Claims Courts to fight drug dealers, residents of Berkeley and San Francisco have won substantial judgments against the owners of two buildings that became hubs of drug-related activity.

title: Chess
description: Jonathan Speelman of Britain won the seventh game of his semifinal world championship candidates match with Jan Timman of the Netherlands in London to pull even at 3 1/2-3 1/2. Timman won their second game, and the others were all drawn.

title: Carmen Cavallaro, Pianist, 76
description: Carmen Cavallaro, a pianist who performed the sound track for the movie ''The Eddy Duchin Story'' in 1956, died of cancer on Thursday at Mount Carmel East Hospital here. He was 76 years old and had lived in Columbus for 15 years.

title: Justice Marshall, on 'Afro-American': Yes
description: In the midst of a nationwide debate over how to refer to Americans of African descent, one Supreme Court Justice declared his stand today.

title: Both Sides in Illinois Try to Settle Suit on Abortion Standards
description: Barely seven weeks before the United States Supreme Court is to hear arguments on Illinois's abortion clinic regulations, the two sides in the lawsuit began direct negotiations here today aimed at settling the matter out of court.

title: Kiss Florida Goodbye?
description: LEAD: The countdown to potentially unparalleled disaster has begun. This afternoon, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to launch the space shuttle Atlantis, with its space probe containing 49.25 pounds of lethal plutonium. From the moment the button at the Kennedy Space Center is pushed to the two high-speed, low-level ''flybys'' of

title: Equimark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included special bank shares tax of $640,000 for the quarter and $1,920,000 for the 9 months.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flames 8, Nordiques 8: Calgary tied a National Hockey League record by scoring two goals, both short-handed, in four seconds and also had three goals in a 27-second span in the third period in Quebec to tie Nordiques. With the Flames' Gary Roberts off for roughing in the final minute, Calgary (4-1-2) pulled its goaltender, Mike Vernon, and sent five attackers against the Nordiques. Doug Gilmour scored with a quick shot from the left face-off circle at 19 minutes 45 seconds and then fed Paul Ranheim off the ensuing face-off for the tying goal at 19:49 on a wrist shot from the top of the slot.(AP) Penguins 7, Maple Leafs 5: Randy Gilhen scored with 3 minutes 34 seconds remaining and Mario Lemieux had the 22d three-goal game of his career as Pittsburgh overcame a 3-1 deficit to beat visiting Toronto. Two of Lemieux's goals were into an empty net.(AP) GYMNASTICS Soviet Union Captures Gold Medal: The Soviet Union, helped by a perfect mark from Valentin Mogilny, won the gold medal in the men's team competition yesterday at the world championships in Stuttgart, West Germany. Mogilny got the perfect 10 on the pommel horse as the Soviets took their fifth men's team title in the last six championships, collecting 587.250 points of a possible 600. East Germany won the silver medal and China took the bronze. The United States and Bulgaria tied for eighth.(AP) TENNIS Agassi Advances in Tokyo: Andre Agassi breezed past Wally Masur of Australia, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday while Kevin Curren of the United States was upset, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, by unseeded Eric Jelen of West Germany in the first round of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo. Third-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland defeated Richey Reneberg of the United States, 6-7, 6-3, 6-2. Fifth-seeded Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany beat Patrick McEnroe, 6-4, 6-2; Andres Gomez of Ecuador, seeded sixth, crushed Hidehiko Tanizawa of Japan, 6-0, 6-2.(AP) Tauziat Upsets Maleeva: Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, seeded second, was upset in the first round of the European indoor women's tournament by Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-2, 6-2. Maleeva is ranked seventh in the world, Tauziat 22d. Eva Pfaff of West Germany upset defeated eighth-seeded Belinda Cordwell of New Zealand, 4-6, 7-6, 6-3. Monica Seles of Yugoslavia, seeded fourth, eliminated Emanuela Zardo of Switzerland, 6-1, 6-2.(AP) Gilbert Is Upset: Top-seeded Brad Gilbert, the No. 6 player in the world, was defeated, 6-7, 7-6, 7-6, by Jeremy Banks of Britain in the first round of a Nabisco Grand Prix tournament in Tel Aviv.(AP) Berger Advances: Top-seeded Jay Berger of the United States advanced to the second round of the $285,000 Nabisco Grand Prix tournament in Vienna by eliminating his countryman Jonathan Canter, 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, yesterday. Unseeded Paul Annacone of the United States upset sixth-seeded Jordi Arrese of Spain, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) VOLLEYBALL Japan Defeats U.S.: Japan beat the United States national team, 15-12, 14-16, 15-12, 15-13, yesterday. It was the Japanese team's first victory against the Americans since 1984, ending a streak of 43 losses to the Americans. The victory came in the final game of a three-game series in Japan. (AP)

title: Struggle on Manhattan Roof Ends in Officer's Fatal Fall
description: A young police officer struggling with a robbery suspect on a rooftop in midtown Manhattan died early yesterday after he fell into a shaft between buildings and lay there helplessly for more than 40 minutes before rescuers were able to remove him, the police said.

Walter Farley, 74, A Writer of a Series On a Black Stallion
description: Walter Farley, whose 20 ''Black Stallion'' novels about the friendships between horses and children charmed young readers for nearly 50 years, died of heart failure yesterday at a hospital near his home in Venice, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Venice and on a farm near Earlville, Pa.
