title: Review/Dance; First Impressions of Freud
description: A recorded voice declared, ''First impressions are generally the truest.'' But the production that XXY Dance/Music presented Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater could be cited as evidence against that contention.

title: Just in Time, a Defense Of Fruitcake
description: IT is the gift most people hate to receive. Others call it a bad joke. But these days, as the time to prepare holiday fruitcake draws near, defenders of this centuries-old confection are fighting back, proclaiming that fruitcake has suffered a bad name long enough.

title: Profits Soar at Three Drug Concerns
description: Three big pharmaceutical companies reported yesterday that they had large increases in net income for the third quarter.

title: Hofstra Clerical Workers Return to Offices
description: Clerical workers at Hofstra University returned to work Monday after reaching a contract settlement late Friday evening that ended a six-week strike.

title: A Precedent-Setting Cabernet
description: IN 1974, Stag's Leap Wine Cellars made its first Cask 23, a reserve cabernet sauvignon made only in the best years from outstanding fruit. The wine became a Napa Valley benchmark because of its quality, and has long been a collector's item. The 1985 Cask 23 was released Oct. 1, and its price apparently has acquired near-benchmark status.

title: New York Fears Burden And Quits Waste Plan
description: New York said today that it had withdrawn from a group of Northeastern states working on a regional plan for disposing of toxic wastes because environmental officials here thought New York was being asked to take too much waste.

title: Heritage Loss At $1.6 Million
description: National Heritage Inc., a company that provides long-term nursing care and whose largest investor is the troubled Southmark Corporation, has reported that unaudited results for the fourth quarter ended June 30 showed a loss of $1.6 million on revenues of $22.2 million. National Heritage said on

title: McMahon May Be Out
description: Jim McMahon, the San Diego quarterback, may not play against the Giants Sunday because of injuries he suffered in last Sunday's 17-16 loss to Seattle, Coach Dan Henning said Monday. McMahon is bothered by a sprained ankle and bruised knee, but his most severe injury is a dislocated left shoulder he popped back in place by himself during the Seattle game, Henning said.(AP)

title: UAL's Share Price Drops $24.875, to $198
description: Stock in the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, fell another $24.875 yesterday, to $198, as speculators and option traders sold their shares, uncertainty continued about the financing for a buyout of the airline and the machinists' union renewed its efforts to block such a deal.

title: Cavazos Presses Parental Choice in Public Schools
description: Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos came to a highly praised, innovative school district in East Harlem this week to press the Bush Administration's view that giving parents more say in choosing public schools would be a major step toward improving education.

title: Eastland Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Per share earnings not available; the company went public in July 1988.

title: Probert Gets 3 Months
description: Bob Probert, the former Detroit Red Wing, was sentenced by District Judge Patrick Duggan today to three months in prison and fined $2,000 for smuggling cocaine into the United States from his native Canada.

title: First Tennessee National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Real Estate; New Office Projects for Mitchel Field
description: NOW that some controversies between local officials and developers over leases and development rights at Mitchel Field have been resolved, a new spurt of office building is under way at the former military base in Nassau County.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was an unbelievable thing. The light towers were shaking. I was stunned, stunned.'' - Mike Krukow, a pitcher for the San Francisco Giants, who was warming up for the World Series game when the earthquake hit. [ A1:6. ]

title: Rangers Skate To a Tie In Chicago
description: Their start to the season had been undeniably fast, and the schedule laid out what appeared to be a roadmap to added momentum. But the Rangers lost a step without losing the game last night in a 3-3 tie with the Chicago Blackhawks at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Pop Life
description: Billy Joel at 40

title: So Down on Wall Street
description: I love bad news as much as the next person so long as it's not about me, but there's no bad news I enjoy half as much as bad news from Wall Street.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates declined sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper for the second consecutive week, to their lowest in more than two months. The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.292 percent, down from 8.483 percent. The rate was the lowest since Aug. 1, when it was 8.064 percent. Citicorp also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.986 percent, down from 8.1255 percent and the lowest since Aug. 1, when it was 7.80 percent.

title: Ashton-Tate Reports Loss
description: The Ashton-Tate Company, as expected, reported a loss today, as revenues in its third quarter declined from a year ago.

title: Life Term in Family Ax Slaying
description: A teen-ager has been sentenced to life in prison for killing his parents, brother and sister with an ax at the family's rural home here a year and a half ago. The punishment was imposed Monday on David Brom, now 18 years old, by Judge Ancy Morse of Olmsted County District Court, who said the case was an ''extreme and monumental tragedy'' caused by a ''pathetically sick, depressed mind.'' Mr. Brom, who had pleaded not guilty by reason of mental illness, will not be eligible for parole for 52 1/2 years.

title: Lukens Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chargers Trade Banks And Acquire Nelson
description: Chip Banks, the linebacker who is seeking immediate employment instead of the promise of a future job, was traded yesterday from the San Diego Chargers to the Indianapolis Colts in exchange for unspecified conditional draft picks.

title: Senate Votes, 64 to 35, to Send Money to the Opposition Parties in Nicaraguan
description: In the last gasps of the debate over America's effort to overturn the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua, the Bush Adminstration won Senate approval tonight to send $9 million to assist opposition parties in the election next February and to support international observers.

title: Liquor Barn Sold In $40 Million Deal
description: Liquor Barn, which has been under Federal bankruptcy court protection for nearly a year, has been purchased for $40 million by an investor group. The assets of Liquor Barn Northern California and Liquor Barn Southern California were purchased by LBI Holdings, which plans to operate the 68-outlet chain, the nation's largest liquor retail chain, under the same name with new management. The $40 million cash deal was announced Friday.

title: Du Pont Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $7,900,000, or 25 cents a share for the latest 9 months and $18,000,000, or 57 cents a share for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MCI Profit Jumps 58.7%; GTE's Net Also Rises
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and the GTE Corporation reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings yesterday. Another telephone company, the Southwestern Bell Corporation, said its profits had fallen, mainly because of one-time factors.

title: P.L.O., Irked, Balks at U.S. Peace Plan
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has registered strong objections to the newest United States ideas on Middle East peace, leaving Washington's diplomacy bereft of evident support from either the Israeli Government or Palestinian leaders.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $270,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss of $916,000 from an accounting adjustment due to the adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: Pretoria Eases Stand on Talks With Rebel Group
description: The senior official entrusted with organizing multiracial negotiations on South Africa's future today softened the Government's longstanding refusal to talk to the outlawed African National Congress.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Advertising Fills Deputy Creative Post
description: Grey Advertising yesterday appointed Stephen A. Novick the deputy creative director of its New York office. Mr. Novick, 49 years old, an executive vice president who has been the agency's director of broadcast production for 18 years, will report to Richard M. Karp, Grey's head of creative services.

title: Officer Is Cleared in Shooting
description: A grand jury concluded today that a white Vineland police officer acted properly when he shot and killed a black man whose death sparked two days of rioting and looting by blacks and Hispanics, prosecutors announced.

title: Defeated Hopeful in Delaware Sues Governor on Funds Use
description: The Democrat who lost the race for lieutenant governor in Delaware last year has sued the Republican Governor, Michael N. Castle, accusing him of illegally diverting campaign money to his own choice for the post.

title: Generic Drug Maker Gets Permanent Head
description: Par Pharmaceutical Inc., a generic drug maker that is being investigated by the Government as part of a broad examination of the industry, named Kenneth I. Sawyer yesterday to the posts of president and chief executive. He had been serving in those jobs on an interim basis since last month.

title: Net Rises At Morgan Stanley
description: Largely because of one major deal, the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., the Wall Street investment banking firm, doubled its net income for the third quarter over the corresponding period last year.

Desperate Jets Sign Receiver
description: The Jets, who were down to only two wide receivers who had ever caught a pass in an National Football League game, today signed Phillip Epps, an experienced speedster who had spent his career with Green Bay. The Packers cut Epps before the season.

title: President Picks Hispanic Woman To Become U.S. Surgeon General
description: Dr. Antonia Novello, a pediatrician and an expert on AIDS in children, has been chosen to be the Bush Administration's nominee for Surgeon General of the United States, Administration officials said today.

Shares outstanding are fully diluted, while share earnings are primary.

title: Now Is the Time to Vote for a New Charter for New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Woman From 4 Viewpoints at the Circle Rep
description: The image that lingers from Joe Pintauro's new play, ''Beside Herself,'' is that of four women in white negligees, each representing the same heroine at a different age, as they comb out their hair and prepare for sleep. The setting is a cozy house in the woods on an isolated island; the light is the dim glow of a harvest moon. While there is nothing prurient about the scene, its appeal recalls the calendar art that was yesteryear's soft-core pornography. The idealized women are golden icons intended to be worshiped from a distance by an audience of men.

title: Viacom to Sell a 50% Stake In Showtime TV Service
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 percent stake in Showtime, the nation's second-largest pay television service, to Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, for $225 million.

title: A UAL Rumor Is Proved False
description: The stock of the UAL Corporation traded as low as $194 a share yesterday morning, in part because of a rumor that Kellner, DiLeo & Company, a large arbitrage firm, had sustained heavy losses and was being forced to liquidate a large position in UAL to repay creditors.

title: A $27 Million Loan by Sotheby's Helped Alan Bond to Buy 'Irises'
description: When Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' was sold at auction for $53.9 million in 1987 at Sotheby's in New York, it became the world's most expensive painting. Now, nearly two years later and on the eve of a new auction season, ''Irises'' has become the center of a controversy over how works of art are promoted and sold in today's marketplace.

title: Robert L. Myers, 66, an Industrial Chemist
description: Robert L. Myers, a chemist involved in industrial research and development, died of renal failure and other complications last Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Stock Slide Forces Closing Of a Chicago Options Firm
description: The Fossett Corporation, a medium-sized options trading firm here, is the first firm forced out of business by the plunge in stock prices on Friday.

description: The company said the latest 9 months' net included a gain of $8,406,000, or 15 cents a share, from the sale of its Tangent Systems Corp. unit.

description: From the mean streets of the Bushwick section of Brooklyn to a posh dining room with glittering chandeliers in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani devoted most of yesterday to the issues of drugs and crime.

description: The cable television stock that has emerged as a point of controversy in David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign in New York City dates from 1972, when he invested $5,000 in a fledgling communications company.

description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier and corporate raider, raised his stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 10.62 percent, from 10.43 percent. title: Bush Tells Congress He Will Veto Bill on Abortion
description: Unable to find a strategy that would allow him to modify his position on abortion without alienating his right-to-life constituency, President Bush told Congress tonight that he would veto legislation that would allow Federal financing of abortions for victims of rape and incest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Monday about the special election yesterday for the Fifth Congessional District seat in Mississippi carried misplaced lines and paragraphs in some copies. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: C.F.T.C. Head Argues Against Dual-Trading Ban
description: Wendy L. Gramm, who heads the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, tried to stop Congress today from banning the practice of dual trading, saying instead that her agency would restrict the practice by Thanksgiving.

description: b-Net loss and included pretax charge of $108 million on unrecoverable contract costs and pretax gain on real estate of $12.3 million.

title: Review/Music; Orfeo, a Spanish Early-Music Ensemble
description: We should all begin to brace ourselves for the second coming of Christopher Columbus. The blessed event - the 500th anniversary of Columbus's rather considerable discovery - is still more than two years away, yet the first rumblings of celebration are beginning to be heard.

title: Abortion Opponents Dealt Setback in Illinois
description: In a setback to opponents of abortion, a legislative committee decided today that the Illinois House of Representatives would not consider legislation to restrict abortions at its current two-week special session.

title: Trade Deficit Widened by Import Surge
description: The nation's trade deficit grew sharply in August, to $10.8 billion, as imports surged to a record and exports showed a small decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Reviews/Music; Alessandra Marc Makes Her Met Debut as Aida
description: Alessandra Marc's debut as Aida on Saturday afternoon was one of those events that pose critical questions for the Metropolitan Opera and what might be called the vocal-operatic establishment.

title: Lessons
description: rrGov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey has a theory: Woodrow Wilson left the presidency of Princeton University to run for governor because he was worn out by academic politics.

title: South Korea Offers Plans To Ease U.S. Trade Surplus
description: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea told President Bush today that his nation would take significant steps to curb its trade surplus with the United States by the mid-1990's.

title: Soviets Conditionally Readmitted To World Psychiatric Association
description: The Soviet Union was conditionally readmitted tonight to the World Psychiatric Association after its delegation publicly acknowledged that there had been abuses of psychiatry for political reasons.

title: U.S. Planning for Cuts Of Its Forces in Europe
description: The commander of American and allied forces in Europe, Gen. John R. Galvin, has begun planning to reduce the United States military presence in Western Europe over the next 10 years.

title: Arab-Sicilian Food: Tale of 1,001 Years
description: Many people in this university town know Clifford Wright only as a scholar and an author of thoughtful studies of United States policy in the Middle East. But friends, family and fortunate dinner guests know him as an enthusiastic cook, an engaging host, a tireless researcher of old recipes and an energetic student of a sumptuous cuisine that he calls Arab-Sicilian.

title: WINE TALK
description: SOONER or later it happens to everyone: that moment in the dead of night when you jolt awake and realize to your horror that you have no idea what wine goes with marinated artichoke hearts.

title: Fab Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
Dinkins Explains Carson Cash, in Part
description: Trying to defuse the issue of payments made to Robert (Sonny) Carson, a convicted kidnapper and a civil rights advocate, officials of David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign produced some receipts for the money yesterday but were unable to account fully for $7,100 given to Mr. Carson and an organization he heads.

title: Dow's Next Step? Up or Down; Forecasts as High as 3,100
description: With a single question hanging on the lips of every investor - What now? - the inevitable parade of analysts and economists rushing forth with answers has begun.

title: Washington Talk; Powell To Court: A Caution With Love
description: During his 15 years on the Supreme Court, Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. rarely spoke from the bench. When he did, he phrased his questions gently, his voice barely above a whisper.

title: Michael Carmine, 30, Stage and Film Actor
description: Michael Carmine, an actor, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 30 years old.

title: Alaska to Restrict Tankers Without Approved Cleanup Plans
description: The state of Alaska will bar oil tankers from the port of Valdez next month unless their owners equip them with oil spill cleanup plans approved by the state.

title: Beverly Hills Hires Strike Substitutes
description: Substitute teachers were hired to keep classes open during the first teachers' strike in this city, although discipline problems were reported in some classrooms.

title: BRITAIN MAY FREE 4 CONVICTED IN '75
description: The British Government took steps today that could lead to the release of four people who were convicted in 1975 in the bombing of an English bar, in which five people were killed.

title: Collective Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Book Notes
description: 'Satanic Verses'

title: Report Shows No Evidence Waldheim Mistreated British P.O.W.'s
description: A narrowly focused British Defense Ministry report has found no evidence that Kurt Waldheim interrogated British prisoners of war or was responsible for the harsh treatment or execution of British commandos in Greece in 1943 and 1944, when he was an intelligence officer with the German Army.

title: Affiliated Banc Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Television; Van Cliburn Competition: Both Glossy And Serious
description: In a sense, a circle is completed with tonight's broadcast of ''The Eighth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition: Here to Make Music,'' on Channel 13 at 9 and on Channel 49 at 9:30. Held in Fort Worth from May 27 to June 11, the competition is big, bold and flashy, eagerly inviting press and television coverage. Now, for posterity, it has its very own 90-minute television documentary.

title: A Prosperity Agenda for the 90's
description: The mayoral candidates make a lot of noise about fighting drugs and crime, but they have yet to tell us how to pay for it. With New York's economy deteriorating, we need a mayor who understands the connection between economic growth and social priorities.

title: North Fork Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1988 figures included the results of operations of Southold Savings Bank beginning Aug. 1, 1988.

title: Home Fedl Savings Bank of Ga.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included non-interest income derived from the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock of $298,375.

title: DELUGE OF CALLS DISRUPTS SERVICE
description: Long-distance telephone communication into the San Francisco area was disrupted last night when millions of people across the country tried to reach relatives and friends after hearing of the earthquake that struck there.

title: GTE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Winifred Barnes has joined Wunderman Worldwide as senior vice president and management supervisor.

title: Soviet Gymnasts Take Team Title
description: The Soviet Union, helped by a perfect mark from Valentin Mogilny, swept the gold medal in the men's team competition at the world gymnastics championships today.

title: Bagels Done the Old Way
description: To The Living Section:

title: Site for Series Left in Doubt
description: Hours after tonight's third game of the World Series was called off because of the earthquake, there was confusion as to when, or where, the series might be resumed.

title: Whitman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $5,800,000 and $25,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, reflecting a loss from the sale of operations of $5.3 million in the quarter and $21.3 million in the 9 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $32,400,000, or 30 cents a share, and $44,500,000, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, reflecting gain from sale of operations of $25.5 million for both periods.

title: Gunmen Kill Judge in Colombia
description: A judge was killed in Medellin today in what an anonymous caller said was ''the first retaliation'' for the extradition of accused drug traffickers to the United States.

title: Let Him Eat Cake
description: To The Living Section:

title: Of Citizens, and Poachers
description: A Federal district judge, upholding a law enacted in the nation's early years, has concluded that commercial fishermen living in the United States are poachers if they do not have American citizenship.

title: Market Place; 'Witching Hour' Next Street Focus
description: THE witches of Wall Street are gathering for a minor convention this Friday afternoon. And while forecasting what will happen is perilous at best, the talk among traders is that when all is said and done, the witches will have pushed up prices in major stocks, at least for a period.

title: COMPANY ENDS USE OF APPLE CHEMICAL
description: The only manufacturer of an apple-ripening agent found to cause cancer in laboratory animals has all but ended the chemical's use by halting most overseas sales of it.

title: Federal Express Drops Ads
description: The Federal Express Corporation has canceled much of its prime-time advertising on the ABC television network, after a report by ABC News that was sharply critical of it.

title: Nicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alltel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Court Rejects 5 Challenges to Times Square Plan
description: Five court challenges to the Times Square redevelopment plan were thrown out yesterday, and state officials predicted that construction would begin by early next year.

title: Norwest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corestates Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Pop; After 25 Years, Kinks Retain Their Scale and Informality
description: The Kinks aren't playing at stadiums like their contemporaries, the Who and the Rolling Stones - just middle-sized theaters like the Beacon, where the British band performed on Monday night. And their shows aren't elaborate spectacles, but amiable, scrappy, slightly disheveled concerts that reaffirm the band's perseverance and moxie. Twenty-five years after the Kinks had their first hit single, ''You Really Got Me,'' the Kinks still take rock-and-roll just seriously enough to knock it around.

title: Lilly (Eli) & Co (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Cyril Mathew, Sri Lanka Politician, 77
description: Cyril Mathew, a former Sri Lankan Industries Minister and an ardent crusader for Sinhalese nationalism, died of a heart attack on Monday. He was 77 years old.

title: GORBACHEV SEEKS TO OUST AN EDITOR
description: The editor of the Soviet Union's best-selling newspaper said today that he had been called to Communist Party headquarters and told to resign for publishing a political popularity poll that angered President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Excel Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Havel Donating Prize To Help Fellow Writers
description: Vaclav Havel, the dissident Czechoslovak playwright, has said he will donate a $13,000 literary award to an organization to help banned authors get their work published in the Eastern bloc.

title: Next Inc. Is Offering Improvements in Its Work Station
description: Next Inc., the company founded in 1986 by Steven P. Jobs, the former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., announced two significant developments yesterday. It said that it would add an accelerator to its computer work station to resolve complaints about slow performance and that it would offer a lower-cost version of the work station for use on computer networks.

title: Suburban Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VIOLENT QUAKE HITS NORTHERN CALIFORNIA; HUNDREDS DEAD; DISASTER SCOPE UNCLEAR; HIGHWAY AND BAY BRIDGE'S DECK COLLAPSE
description: A devastating earthquake rocked the San Francisco Bay area at rush hour last night, killing at least 200 people, collapsing a mile-long span of an Interstate highway and wrecking part the Bay Bridge to Oakland.

title: James Rosenwald, 83, a Securities Analyst
description: James B. Rosenwald, a securities analyst who specialized in Japanese insurance companies and banks, died Sunday at his home in Kings Bay Estates, Tobago, West Indies, after a series of strokes. He was 83 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: About New York; Baby Boy's Case: Poignancy In Sea of Flotsam
description: A legal notice in the Sept. 30 issue of The New York Amsterdam News first surprises, then grabs and does not let go. At the top is a picture of a boy in sneakers, smiling slightly and looking very small in a big chair.

title: Goodrich (B.F.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,000,000, or 4 cents a share and $2,300,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,700,000 for the quarter and $9,200,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also included an extraordinary credit of $2,700,000.

title: MCI Communciations Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $10 million from early debt retirement, partially offset by income tax benefits.

title: Olin Corp(S) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included aftertax gain of $6 million from the sale of ammonia and urea businesses which was offset by a $6 million aftertax charge for future environmental expenditures.

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months included an after-tax gain of $77 million from the sale of premises in Japan in the first quarter. The 9 months also included $154 million of cross-border interest payments from Brazil in the first and second quarters, and none in the third, and against none last year; no Argentine cross-border interest payments, compared with $26 million reported in the first three quarters last year. In addition, the 9 months included $55 million after-tax from the sale of the U.S. pension fund management business in last year's third quarter.

title: Jefferson Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for all periods restated to include results of Chesapeake Bank Corp., which merged with Jefferson on Sept. 1.

title: Sunshine Mining's New Silver Supply
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, a silver mining and metal exploration concern, said it would acquire a 45 percent interest in a new silver mine near Libby, Mont., from the privately held Montana Reserves Company for a total of about $90 million. Sunshine will pay about $38 million in cash and assume $32 million of the mine's existing obligations and a 15-year, $20 million note.

title: Warner-Lambert Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Democrat Wins a House Seat in Mississippi
description: State Senator Gene Taylor, a Democrat, won an overwhelming victory over his Republican opponent, Tom Anderson, in a special Congressional election today, giving the Democrats all five House seats from the state for the first time in 17 years.

title: Archer-Daniels-Midland reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjuste for a 5 percent dividend in September.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 East Berlin showed new signs that it is open to change. A Politburo member told workers on Monday that Communists are committed to a dialogue for the ''renewal of socialism.'' Page A9

title: McGraw-Hill Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $8 million, or 16 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting for income taxes. McGraw-Hill said operating results for 1988 and the first half of 1989 were restated to reflect the formation of the joint venture school publishing company with MacMillan on July 1.

title: Mid-America Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $669,000, or 11 cents per share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Gatx Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rise in Babies Hurt by Drugs Is Predicted
description: If current drug abuse patterns continue, 5 percent of all newborn babies in New York City could require admission to intensive-care wards by 1995, state health officials say.

title: Change in Leadership Is Expected in Turkey
description: Turkey seemed headed for new Government leadership today when Prime Minister Turgut Ozal announced that he would run for President in an election that starts in Parliament this week.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an addition of $950 million to reserve against LDC debt, and a gain of $16 million from the sale of an interest in a foreign leasing company. c-Net income and included $142 million in tax benefits and gains from the sale of a building and other non- strategic assets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * The American Diabetes Association has released a print and television campaign by Goldsmith/Jeffrey in New York to enhance public awareness about the disease.

title: Springs Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for year-ago third quarter and 9 months included a one-time restructuring charge of about $11.2 million, or 63 cents a share.

title: Lydia W. Malbin, 91, a Collector of European Art
description: Lydia Winston Malbin, an art collector and patron who assembled a major collection of modern European art, died on Saturday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Music; 'Pictures' by 4 Saxophones
description: Mussorgsky's wonderful ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' are fated to be heard in all sorts of arrangements. Vladimir Horowitz's embellishment of the keyboard original and Ravel's kaleidoscopic orchestration are the best known, but guitarists, organists and orchestrators reckless enough to invite comparison with Ravel and even rock bands have taken their shot at the work. Sunday afternoon a four-saxophone version was played at Weill Recital Hall. For all I know, it may not even have been the first such, but it will do for a while.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Houston
description: LEAD: TEX-MEX has always been the No. 1 ethnic food here, but there is a new kid in town, a South American grill that has won a passionate following among Houstonians who crave big flavors.

title: CBS Not the Real Target of Faked-Film Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: Sim Var, Ex-Cambodian Premier, 85
description: Sim Var, founder of the Cambodian Democratic Party and a former Prime Minister, has died in Paris, according to a statement issued on Saturday. He was 85 years old.

title: Chambers Development reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment of $1,272,000, or 62 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of accounting change on prior periods.

title: INSIDE
description: East German Leaders Show Openness to Change In television and newspapers, East German Communist leaders showed an openness to change for their nation. One predicted some decisions ''very soon, very quickly.'' Page A9. Bush Says He'll Veto Bill on Abortion Funds After efforts at a compromise failed, President Bush told Congress he intended to veto a bill that would allow Federal financing of abortions for victims of rape and incest. Page A20. White House Supports Call For More Leeway in Coups The Administration said it would press Congress to allow more leeway for the C.I.A. to take part in coups.

title: Recognition Deal Reached
description: Recognition Equipment Inc., the troubled data capture systems maker, said today that it had agreed to an arrangement in which its longtime suitor, the Prospect Group, would increase its ownership of the company.

title: East Germany Signals It May Allow Some Change
description: The East German Communist leadership, long regarded as rigidly orthodox, gave new signs today that it is increasingly open to change.

title: Bush Pledges Support; Skinner Is en Route to Site
description: President Bush, pledging to ''do everything we possibly can'' to aid victims of the earthquake that struck San Francisco this evening, activated a Federal disaster team late tonight and sent the Secretary of Transportation to California to assess the damage.

title: Salvador Foes at Peace Talks Say No to Each Other's Ideas
description: The Salvadoran Government and rebels held their second day of talks here today, with the guerrillas calling for a purge of senior officers of the armed forces. The idea was promptly dismissed by the Government.

title: Minnesota Remains Only Unbeaten Team in the N.H.L.
description: The Minnesota North Stars, a team that recently was an embarrassment and affront only to itself, continued their unexpected defiance of all competition this autumn by defeating the Islanders, 6-3, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mr. Jaruzelski Smiles
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who resigned as Communist Party leader to become President of Poland, speaks enthusiastically now about the coalition entrusted with guiding his country through a profound transformation to freedom.

title: Judge and Officer Trade Insults at Murder Trial
description: To the head of the New York court officer's union, Justice James J. Leff of State Supreme Court is a ''psycho'' who should be locked up. To Justice Leff, the union head, Dennis W. Quirk, is a snoop who was ''aptly named.''

title: South Carolina Coast Spared From New Damages
description: Fair weather and a new barrier of sand spared South Carolina's hurricane-scarred beaches from further damage from unusually high tides on Monday.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS (NBA) - Waived Steve Babiarz, guard. Named Bob Salmi video coordinator. PORTLAND (NBA) - Traded Richard Anderson, forward, to the Charlotte Hornets for Robert Reid, guard-forward.

title: Dance Theater of Harlem
description: Dance Theater of Harlem is to perform a three-week season at Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 133d Street, Friday through Nov. 4. The troupe will present revivals of ''Fete Noire,'' by Arthur Mitchell, company director; ''The Beloved,'' by Lester Horton; ''Mirage,'' by Billy Wilson, and Frederic Franklin's staging of the second act of ''Swan Lake,'' with new costumes and sets, as well as works by Bronislava Nijinska and John Butler. Tickets are $17 and $15. Teletron: 947-5850. Information: 690-4100.

title: Help Who?
description: We are prepared to provide technical assistance in certain areas of Soviet economic reform. . . . We want perestroika to succeed. . . . Such words would have been unutterable in official Washington even a few months ago. Such thoughts would have been unimaginable just a few years ago. To Ronald Reagan, the Soviet Union was the evil empire. To Americans generally, the U.S.S.R. remained the implacable enemy.

title: Third Day Without a Verdict In Rep. Garcia's Bribery Trial
description: The jury in the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee, deliberated for its third day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sometimes Lightning Strikes Thrice
description: ''Originality,'' Rosser Reeves, the legendary creative chief of the Ted Bates agency, once said, ''is the most dangerous word in advertising.'' That may explain why New York magazine and Jim Beam bourbon have introduced print advertising campaigns whose themes and graphic styles are virtually identical - and strikingly similar to an ad for HG magazine that made its debut in June.

title: A&W Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEY RATES
Scripps Howard Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rains Force 2d Delay in Launching of Shuttle
description: Thick clouds and showers forced at least a one-day postponement today of the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis, the second delay for the mission to send a spacecraft on its way to Jupiter.

title: Profits Scoreboard
'Apartment Zero' and Its Strange Tenant
description: ''Apartment Zero,'' opening today at the Eighth Street Playhouse, is set in Buenos Aires in 1988 and is about a young man named Adrian LeDuc who is obsessed by movies. He runs a movie theater devoted to old American films. When first met, Adrian is in the projection booth of the Cine York, wiping away a tear as he watches the closing scene of ''A Touch of Evil.''

title: Capital Gains Cut Would Further Roil Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: Aristech Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $23,700,000, or 63 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior year periods.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the New Jersey Weekly last Sunday about the Cranberry Festival in Chatsworth gave an incorrect date for one day of the two-day event. It is scheduled for Saturday and Sunday, not Friday; the rain dates are Oct. 28 and 29, not Oct. 27.

title: Assembly Plant For Subaru-Isuzu
description: Subaru-Isuzu Automotive Inc., formed by two relatively small Japanese auto makers, has formally opened an auto assembly plant. Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., which owns a 51 percent share of the operation, will produce its Subaru Legacy sedans and station wagons here, while Isuzu Motors Ltd., which owns 49 percent, will turn out pickup trucks and sports utility vehicles.

title: Grainger (W.W.) Inc(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $13,800,000 from sales of assets and provision of $11,800,000 from adoption new accounting method for health care benefits.

title: Hubbell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McDonald's Offers McRib Sandwich
description: The McDonald's Corporation is adding McRib, a pork rib sandwich, to its menu, hoping to sell 80 million in a monthlong trial run. The sandwich will feature a four-ounce portion of pork from the front shoulder of the hog and should sell for about $1.79, said David Green, McDonald's vice president of marketing. ''It's premature to decide if McRib will stay on the menu or come back as a specialty item,'' he said.

title: Review/Recital; A Prize-Winning Pianist
description: Adrienne Krausz, a 22-year-old pianist from Hungary, was the winner of the World Piano Competition of Cincinnati this year, and as part of her prize she was presented in her New York debut recital on Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LAMB is the most popular meat in most of the Mediterranean region, including the Middle East and North Africa, so it is no surprise that some of the best lamb recipes come from those regions. It is not always easy to identify a particular dish as being, say, of Moroccan origin as opposed to Tunisian. I call these lamb patties Moroccan style because they include cumin, garlic, black pepper and parsley, flavors I associate with that country.

title: Gerber Seeking Day-Care Buyer
description: The Gerber Products Company said it would try to sell Gerber Children's Centers Inc., its child-care subsidiary that owns and operates 115 centers in 12 states. The centers had revenues of more than $30 million for the year ended last March 31.

title: Chaos and Uncertainty For the Rescue Teams
description: When 500 of the nation's earthquake specialists gathered in Sacramento in August to prepare for a shock like the one that hit Northern California today, they warned that the first hours would be a time of chaos and uncertainty.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Avenue Magazine Starts A Japanese Edition
description: Judy Price is starting a Japanese edition of Avenue magazine, the life- styles publication she founded 15 years ago. Japan Avenue is scheduled to begin publication in April.

title: Arnold Billig, 70; Led Probation Officers
description: Arnold Billig, founder and president of the United Probation Officers Association of the City of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday at a restaurant in Savannah, Ga. He was 70 years old and was en route from his home in Queens to his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: United Savers Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Morgan Stanley Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Both latest periods' results included a pre-tax gain of $56.2 million from the restructuring of Burlington Holdings Inc. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been retroactively adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 common stock split, which became effective Feb. 27, 1989. Revenue represented net revenue.

title: Bank Revamping
description: The Bank of New England Corporation said it would undertake a retructuring program that includes the sale of 53 branches and the consolidation of a number of departments. The result will be the loss of 800 jobs throughout New England, the bank said. The company said it also plans to close loan production offices in Chicago, New York and Philadelphia and to sell $250 million of subordinated debt.

title: ABC Ends Reign by NBC
description: ABC received far less power than expected from Jose Canseco and Will Clark but still put an end to the longest winning streak in television history as it won the weekly Nielsen ratings race. NBC had been first 68 weeks in a row.

title: Innocence Abroad: Memories of '39 Fair
description: In 1939, the French Pavilion opened at the World's Fair in New York, bringing the best in French cooking to the United States. This year marks the 50th anniversary of the fair, and Pierre Franey remembers his days as a young assistant fish cook at the Pavilion.

title: Seidman Assails Regulator In Lincoln Savings Case
description: L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that the Government should have moved three years sooner to take disciplinary action against the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.

title: Incinerator Delay: Impact Is Debated
description: A proposal by David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor, to delay the garbage-burning incinerator planned for the Brooklyn Navy Yard might jeopardize the project seriously or have almost no effect on its already tortured route through governmental bureaucracy.

title: General Housewares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge due to early extinguishment of debt, net of taxes, of $366,000.

title: Housing Group Must Forfeit $700,000
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today it had reversed itself and would order a partnership that includes President Ronald Reagan's former chief campaign lawyer to forfeit nearly $700,000, much of it to be repaid to the Government.

title: EARTHQUAKE IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA
description: This New York Times report on the earthquake in California was reported and written by Dave Anderson, Katherine Bishop, Murray Chass, Joseph Durso, Jane Gross and George Vecsey in San Francisco; Seth Mydans and Richard W. Stevenson in Los Angeles; Allan R. Gold, Andrew Rosenthal and Philip Shenon in Washington; Sandra Blakeslee in Topanga, Calif., and James Barron, Constance L. Hays, John T. McQuiston, Wolfgang Saxon and Craig Wolff in New York. Contributing photographs were G. Paul Burnett and Dave Fornell. Maps and graphics were provided by Arnold Bombay, Al Granberg, Donald Parsons, Jim Perry and Jean Rutter.

title: Broadbeach Sells Its Stake in McGill
description: The private Los Angeles investment firm Broadbeach Associates Inc. has sold all but a small portion of its 7 percent stake in the McGill Manufacturing Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group gave no reason for the sale of the shares. In August, Broadbeach had offered to acquire McGill for $62 a share, or $89.8 million.

title: 63 Killed by Storms in China
description: A series of three typhoons killed 63 people, and injured 712 in Hainan province in the South China Sea, the official New China News Agency said today. Fifteen people were reported missing, the agency said. The typhoons hit the island from Oct. 2 to 13, according to the agency.

title: Review/Opera; More Zeffirelli on the Grand Scale In the Met's New 'Traviata'
description: At one time, Franco Zeffirelli was an opera director of artistic significance. His productions for Maria Callas and for Joan Sutherland in the 1950's showed off their great if dissimilar talents to advantage. His ''Falstaff'' at the old Metropolitan Opera House in 1964 raised staging standards there. For the last couple of decades, however, Mr. Zeffirelli's interest in opera has centered around the superficial and the trivial. As his new Metropolitan production of ''La Traviata'' showed conclusively on Monday evening, he is most charitably thought of nowadays as a fashion designer and interior decorator rather than an opera director.

title: Area of Quake Was Pegged as Risky
description: The earthquake that shook Northern California tonight occurred on a segment of the San Andreas fault that geologists had identified two years ago as one of those most at risk of a major quake in the near future.

title: Adults Play Hard At Nongame Games
description: ADULT Americans are spending their leisure time at home playing games at a pace not seen since the 1950's when television was just emerging as a home-entertainment force. And the games they seem to enjoy playing most are those that play down the competitive element - nongame games, as one expert calls them.

title: Microsoft Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cincinnati Bell reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May. The company said its gains in revenue and earnings are coming from the company's new businesses, especially Cincinnati Bell Information System.

title: Executive Search Finds A New Chief for Zemex
description: The Zemex Corporation, a producer of industrial minerals, metal powders and tin, said yesterday that Gerard E. Wood had been named its new president and chief executive.

title: Victor Norton, 86, Ex-Chairman of Amerace
description: Victor Thane Norton, retired chief executive and chairman of the board of the Amerace Corporation, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at his summer home in Riverside, Conn. He was 86 years old and also lived in Lighthouse Point, Fla.

title: Corning Inc reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 8
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $600,000 and $1,300,000, or 1 cents a share, for the 16 weeks and 40 weeks, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $700,000, or 1 cent a share for the 16 weeks and $2,000,000, or 2 cents a share for the 40 weeks, and the 40 weeks also included a one-time after- tax gains of $20,500,000 from sales of assets and a loss of $83,900,000 from an accounting adjustment. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 17. Extraordinary credit represents tax benefit of carryforward. Accounting adjustment represents the cumulative effect on prior years of change in method of accounting for post-employment medical benefits net of applicable income taxes. The company said certain amounts in the year-ago period have been reclassified for comparative purposes. The company said it acquired all the common stock of G. H. Besselaar Associated in exchange for about 1.5 million Corning common shares in the first quarter this year.

title: Bearings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Urban community colleges have the potential to improve the quality of life substantially in cities and spread equality of opportunity among their residents, but they need more government money and greater coordination of effort, a new report says.

title: Night, Not Despair, Falls Over a Shaken City
description: The night promised renewed dreams. The World Series was back in San Francisco and the only thing that people had on their minds was to hurry home, flash on the television and cherish a rare joy, Then, as if the city had been hurtled into some twilight dimension, San Francisco's quirky charms crumbled, and its people too frightened to show fear.

Year-ago 9 months included charges totaling $5.6 million from restructuring and plant closings.

It is a safe bet that most economists under age 50 barely recognized the name of the latest winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, announced last week in Sweden. Trygve Haavelmo's critical contributions to the infant discipline of econometrics in the 1940's are now ancient history.

description: The next generation of microprocessors is expected to be so powerful that it will make obsolete costly, specialized computers designed for scientific and engineering work.

title: Corrections

It was Mr. Ailes, not President Ronald Reagan, who wrote this passage, referring to what Mr. Ailes calls ''the like factor'': ''I call it the magic bullet because if your audience likes you, they'll forgive you just about everything else you do wrong.

title: White House Backs Call For C.I.A. Role in Coups
description: The White House today endorsed calls for more latitude for the Central Intelligence Agency in supporting potentially violent efforts to overthrow foreign dictators, joining what is likely to become a heated debate on the issue between Congress and the Executive Branch.

description: Ending weeks of speculation, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi called today for general elections to be held next month, two months ahead of schedule.

Unnecessary, or Worse, for Airlines
description: Should the public worry about attempted airline takeovers, like Donald Trump's aborted bid for American Airlines? Such takeovers inevitably saddle new management with huge debt. That, in turn, raises fears that the company will go bankrupt or else skimp on safety.

description: Industrial production slipped by one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the first drop in six months, the Federal Reserve said today in a report that reflected continued weakness in the economy's manufacturing sector.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts

title: A 'Reform' That RICO Doesn't Need
description: An embarrassed Senator Dennis DeConcini recently backed away from a major provision of a bill he is sponsoring to alter RICO, the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations Act. It turns out that the provision would, in the name of ''reforming'' this useful law, have protected one of Mr. DeConcini's prominent constituents.

title: U.S. Economists Are Ready to Advise the Soviets
description: American officials said today that they were prepared to advise the Soviet Union on how to revive its stagnant economy by decontrolling prices, cutting Government subsidies, encouraging private enterprise and permitting the exchange of rubles for gold and foreign currencies.

title: Eastern Air Is Rebuilding At Fast Pace
description: Top executives of Eastern Airlines said yesterday that because a substantial number of striking workers were returning, they expected the airline to emerge from bankruptcy by early next year at 85 to 90 percent of its former size.

title: Leslie Fay Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There were 39 weeks in the latest 9 months, compared with 40 weeks in the year-ago period. The company said that 1988 results reflected a charge equaled to 9 cents a share stemming from the closing of the Summit sportswear operation during the second quarter. These results also reflected the acquisition of the Albert Nipon and Mary Ann Restivo businesses in April 1988 and May 1988, respectively, and the Donna Morgan for non-stop operations in January 1989.

title: First-Rounders Fizzle For Unlucky Clippers
description: The Los Angeles Clippers are probably the most frustrated franchise in the National Basketball Association. Not only have they missed the playoffs for 13 seasons, a league record, but they have been equally unlucky with their first-round draft choices.

title: Danbury, Conn.
description: IT'S ham and eggs and Harley-Davidsons every Sunday morning at the Marcus Dairy Bar, a family restaurant here where up to 800 motorcyclists convene in fair weather to share breakfast and tales of the road.

description: LEAD: The University of Florida football team, which lost its coach last week, lost its starting quarterback Monday because of an admission of gambling.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: James Kirby Jr., Law Professor, Is Dead at 61
description: James C. Kirby Jr., a law professor who taught at five schools and an expert on legal ethics, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Nashville. He was 61 years old. For the last 11 years he had been on the faculty at the University of Tennessee Law School in Knoxville, where he served as acting dean in 1980 and 1981. He retired last July.

title: Harvard Scholar May Get Rare Tenure Bid
description: A Harvard University expert on Vietnamese history says she has been offered tenure, nearly two decades after Harvard made its last such appointment in the history department.

title: New Drug Shows Stunning Success In Organ-Transplant Operations
description: Researchers have discovered a powerful new drug that has had stunning success in preventing rejection of transplanted organs in its earliest tests among more than 100 recipients at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Bridge
description: Suit combinations have a chameleon-like quality: depending on circumstances, there can be half a dozen or more ways to play the same combination. Beginners who learn just one procedure for a given holding are left with a long way to go on the road to expertise.

title: With Eye to '90 Elections, Bush Assails Democrats
description: President Bush, continuing an early round of campaigning for the 1990 Congres=sional elections, assailed Congressional Democrats tonight as political ''chameleons'' who ''cloak their out-of-step ideas in the language of moderation.''

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOMENTUM SHIFTS ON FLAG MEASURE
description: Amid signs that many senators were having sobering second thoughts about potential harm to the Bill of Rights, Democratic leaders said today that they had the votes to defeat a proposed constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning.

The company said in the latest third quarter's income from continuing operations of $156,877,000, or $1.30 a share, included $2.5 million, or 2 cents a share, aftertax provision for shutdown of Gallium Arsenide Wafer manufacturing facilities. Results for 1988 are restated to reflect spinoff of aluminum, plastics and energy businesses during third quarter.

title: Larnaca Journal; Lebanese Go Home, Not Believing in Tomorrow
description: The motor-vessel Baroness left here for Lebanon the other night across a darkened Mediterranean. The cargo included some 300 passengers, many hundreds more suitcases, a man named Anthony Azzi and his new white BMW sedan with its telephone and air-conditioning system.

description: Dr. David Baltimore, the Nobel laureate whose selection as president of Rockefeller University was opposed by many senior faculty members, has accepted the position.

title: EATING WELL
description: ''THE bottom line is that fat tastes good,'' said the chef at the Golden Door spa, as she tested the doneness of a broiling chicken breast with a practiced index finger. ''It's what emulsifies the sauces. It's what fills you up and gives you a feeling of satiety. So to switch from that you are taking a gamble.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about competition for Nobel Prizes misstated the year in which Godfrey N. Hounsfield and Allan M. Cormack won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine. It was 1979.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: GWENYTH CALDWELL had always baked bread in a big way. So it wasn't odd for a friend to give her a copy of Carol Field's seminal cookbook, ''The Italian Baker'' (Harper & Row, 1985). Ms. Field describes various ways of making traditional, rustic-style breads that eschew commercial yeast in favor of a slow-acting starter, or biga, as it is called in

title: Patriots Turn to Grogan
description: Now that the younger Tony Eason and Doug Flutie have failed their opportunities to hold the starting quarterback job with the faltering New England Patriots (2-4), it is the turn of Steve Grogan, a 36-year-old and 14-year-veteran, to take over and attempt to revive the team's dormant offense. Grogan, who in the off season underwent surgery to remove a herniated disk from his neck, said: ''If I'm not producing, there are guys on the bench who can play.''(AP)

title: Miroslaw Dzielski, 47, Polish Political Leader
description: Miroslaw Dzielski, a Polish political leader who espoused entrepreneurship and market-economy principles in his native country, died of bladder cancer on Sunday at the hospital of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 47 years old and lived in Cracow, Poland.

title: Hope in the Elephant Graveyard
description: The African elephant has now been officially classified as an endangered species. That's remarkably good news. No less remarkable is that it took so long to see the obvious.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In its first public offering since 1974, the Tennessee Valley Authority priced a $4 billion offering of notes and bonds yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Broncos Add Shanahan
description: Mike Shanahan, who was dismissed as coach of the Los Angeles Raiders Oct. 3, has rejoined the Denver Broncos as the quarterbacks coach. Coach Dan Reeves, who has been coaching the quarterbacks, said he didn't think he had enough time to devote to them anymore. Before joining the Raiders in 1988, Shanahan was an assistant coach in Denver for four seasons, serving as offensive coordinator. (AP)

title: Dow's Next Step? Up or Down;  Predictions of More Upheavals
description: Some money managers and analysts are reading the same tea leaves as their more hopeful colleagues but divining a decidedly different message: that the stock market is unstable and will head down. These doomsayers argue that the plunge is not an isolated incident, but a signal that the underpinnings of the market have shifted as the economy worsens.

That was why on Monday night in the middle of the Succoth holidays, David N. Dinkins -who has called for a moratorium on incinerators - found himself enveloped in the community's warm, almost crushing embrace.

title: Secondary Stocks Rise; Volume Dips
description: Secondary stocks showed more strength than blue chips yesterday as the market regained stability after last Friday's tumble. The American Stock Exchange composite index was up 2.91 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 378.07, and the Nasdaq composite index, the primary measure of over-the-counter stock movement, rose 3.35 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 463.28.

description: Housing construction, buffeted by rising mortgage rates, fell for a second consecutive month in September, declining to the weakest pace in seven years.

description: FINDING a person skilled at restoring lace and linen is a tough task. ''Young women today don't care to do this,'' said Betty LaCasse, who for most of her 60-plus years has been mending holes in bed linens and re-creating missing lace on wedding veils.

title: Cache Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oklahoma Officers Acquitted Of Conspiring to Kidnap Man
description: A jury in Sherman, Tex., today acquitted two Oklahoma lawmen on charges that they had conspired to kidnap a man they thought was a drug dealer, bring him across state lines and torture him with a curling iron.

title: Grenade Explodes in Bogota, Killing the Man Carrying It
description: A man was killed today when a grenade he was carrying exploded near Colombia's congress building a few hours after the introduction of a guerrilla amnesty bill that excludes pardons for drug traffickers, the police said.

title: More on The Quake
description: THE SCENE GLIMPSES Heroism and Camaraderie

title: Series May Resume Tuesday at Candlestick
description: Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, announced tonight that pending additional structural surveys of Candlestick Park baseball planned to resume the World Series there next Tuesday.

title: Reagan Speculates That Iran May Have Duped U.S. in Arms Deal
description: Former President Ronald Reagan says he wonders now whether the Iran-contra affair that rocked his second term was not ''a setup, a sting operation, by the Iranians.''

title: Review/Television; How the Networks Coped With Scant Information
description: For the first hours after the earthquake Tuesday, all that television viewers could be certain of was that something serious had happened. What it meant for the cities hit and for their people was anything but clear.

title: German Touch at Sony Classical
description: The managing director of CBS Masterworks, the classical music arm of CBS Records, has kept a low profile during the last year as he planned his reorganization of the label.

title: Dow Chemical Net Off 7%; Monsanto's Earnings Up 9%
description: The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that its earnings had fallen 7 percent in the third quarter, primarily because of lower demand for polyethylene, a main ingredient in plastic products.

title: THE CALIFORNIA QUAKE: Earthquake Engineering; Why the Skyscrapers Just Swayed
description: San Francisco's skyscrapers, which over the last generation have given the gentle bayfront city the look of a modern metropolis, came through the earthquake Tuesday with little or no damage, thanks in large part to tough codes for earthquake resistance enacted in California over the last 15 to 20 years.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Cyprus Minerals Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trinova Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,087,000. c-Net income and included a gain from discontinued operations of $196,000 and $1,128,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said that in the latest third quarter, it recorded a provision for restructuring its continuing operations totaling $53 million. The provision reduced the 1989 third quarter and 9-month results by $38.5 million, or $1.13 a share. The restructuring charge included estimated costs for closure or consolidation of facilities, along with termination or relocation of personnel. The third-quarter and 9-month results also included a charge of $5 million net of tax, or 15 cents a share, for writing down the value of a flexible manufacturing system at one of Trinova's production facilities. Year-ago 9-month results included a settlement gain of $2.7 million after tax, or 7 cents a share, from termination of a defined benefit pension plan. The laminated products group business, sold in March 1989, has been reported as discontinued operations.

title: More Research Sought On Cold-Fusion Claim
description: Leading scientists said recent experiments on low-temperature nuclear fusion have produced enough interesting results to justify more research.

title: Valley National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Addendum
description: * The Consumer News and Business Channel will produce six one-hour programs tied to special issues of U.S. News & World Report. The programs, which will begin in April 1990, will be broadcast just before the magazine appears on newsstands.

title: Second Chance for Deer Management Permits
description: Hunters whose early applications for deer management permits in New York were rejected, may try again if they wish.

title: Salvador Peace Talks End Without an Accord
description: The Salvadoran Government and guerrilla commanders ended three days of talks in a convent here today without signing any major agreement.

title: Cuomo Offers Help to Victims
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo offered New York's help today to victims of the earthquake in Northern California. The Governor said the state would supply equipment and other help if it is needed.

title: At Least 18 Dead in Tremor In Rural Area of North China
description: A series of earthquakes rattled northern China late Wednesday and early today, killing at least 18 people and flattening about 8,000 houses in a largely rural area, the authorities said.

title: Measuring the Magnitude
description: For every increase of one on the Richter scale, there is a tenfold increase in ground motions, or seismic waves. The energy released by the earthquake's motion is about 30 times greater for each increase of one on the scale. There is no maximum or minimum on the scale. Even earthquakes of less than -2 are routinely measured.

title: Stanley Works reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Salvador's Armed Forces Accused By a Medical Team From the U.S.
description: The Salvadoran military has conducted a nationwide campaign of killings, harassment and torture against doctors and health-care workers and attacked guerrilla field hospitals in violation of the Geneva convention, a team of American medical specialists says.

title: Her Hints Are Words To Live By
description: ''FORGIVE the dog toys,'' said Heloise, pointing her manicured finger to the rubber skunk, sea anenome, hamburger and ice-cream bar embedded in the grass. The visitor certainly did. After all, this was Heloise. The 38-year-old household-hints writer, who in 1977 inherited her mother's fabled column, ''Hints from Heloise,'' has been called the ''high priestess of housework'' and ''the maven of the mundane.'' And it is here, in the four-bedroom ranch house she built nine years ago with her husband, David, a plumber (thus seven bathrooms), that Heloise mines the precious nuggets of wisdom that have made her a household heroine, the enemy of limp cabbage, ''gunk buildup'' and misbegotten Silly Putty.

title: Pioneer Fedl Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net credit of $8,356,000 representing recapture of unused provision for restructuring loss. c-After a provision of $15,590,000 for restructuring loss and charge for management recognition plan, less the third quarter credit of $8,356,000. d-Net income There were no per share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company converted to stock form of ownership on July 13, 1989.

Shearson Profit Is At $66 Million
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday reported third-quarter earnings of $66 million, or 64 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $3 million for the 1988 quarter. Revenues rose 26.9 percent, to $3.3 billion from $2.6 billion.

title: Snap-On Tools reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Panel Clears Two Officers In Strangling
description: A second grand jury has refused to bring any criminal charges against two white police officers in the 1986 death of a black man in Middletown, N.Y., the special state prosecutor handling the case announced today.

title: 2 Camps Try to Sway Charter Voters
description: Less than three weeks before the Election Day referendum, the campaign over the proposed New York City Charter remains limited to debates before community groups and in the press.

title: Recent Tests Said to Justify More Cold Fusion Research
description: Recent experiments on low-temperature nuclear fusion have produced enough interesting results to justify more research into the phenomenon, leading scientists said today.

Labs in the Bay Area Escape Damage
description: Safeguards incorporated during construction or added later apparently protected three major laboratories in the San Francisco Bay area from serious damage in the earthquake that struck the area on Tuesday.

title: DENG CONCILIATORY OVER CRACKDOWN
description: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, has told an American visitor that Chinese officials made mistakes and bear responsibility for the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in June.

Geologists Track Quake To Predict Future Risk
description: Teams of geologists fanned out into the rugged mountains above Santa Cruz today to piece together the nature and extent of Tuesday's earthquake, map aftershocks and gather data to help determine earthquake risk in nearby areas.

title: Dun & Bradstreet reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago 9 months results included costs of $14.3 million related to the acquisition of IMS International on May 26, 1988. The company also said the revenues in the latest quarter were held down by the impact of its sale of the official airline guides and the strength of the U.S. dollar among world currencies.

title: 'My House, My House,' She Cried
description: The joggers of the Marina district were back out this sunny morning, but this time their lungs were filled with the acrid smoke from the fire.

title: Israeli Leader Rejects a Compromise With Palestinians
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has formally served notice that he is not prepared to compromise with the Palestinians, even if it means his Government falls and Israel enters a sharp conflict with the United States.

title: Bridge
description: Some plays are so routine and obvious that the average player assumes they have no exceptions. But an expert, if concentrating, will sometimes sniff the air and detect one of the rare exceptions to a general guideline.

Garcia Jury Still Deliberates In Extortion and Bribery Trial
description: Deliberations are to continue for the fifth day today in the bribery and extortion trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee.

title: Crippled Airliner Lands Safely
description: After losing electrical power, a jetliner with 104 people aboard made an emergency landing at a small unattended airport early today and ran off the runway, burying its tires in the mud.

title: Noxell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Savings Bank of Alany reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New U.S. Arts Chairman Discusses Role
description: John E. Frohnmayer, the new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said today that judgment rather than the specific language of a bill passed this month by Congress would best help prevent the agency from financing obscene art.

title: Mosbacher Sees a Free-Trade Pact With Mexico
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher predicted today that the United States and Mexico would eventually negotiate a free trade agreement similar to one that went into effect with Canada on Jan. 1, and said the two countries had already discussed the subject informally.

title: UJB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First City to Sell Card Business
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it had agreed in principle to sell its credit card business, First City Bank-Sioux Falls, to the Bank of New York Company for $180 million in cash.

title: Standard Motors Pdts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Dance; Premiere Honors a German Choreographer
description: Susanne Linke's ''Hommage a Dore Hoyer,'' which received its American premiere on Tuesday night in the Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was both powerful in its own right and a poignant tribute to a major figure in modern dance who is largely unknown in America.

title: Korean Surplus Estimate
description: A South Korea trade group predicted today that the country's trade surplus would fall this year to $1.69 billion, in contrast to the Government's forecast of $4 billion and last year's $8.89 billion. Korea Foreign Trade Association officials cited the appreciation of the won by more than 30 percent since 1986, rising labor costs and increases in the prices of overseas raw materials. The association said exports would reach $63.34 billion this year, up from $60.7 billion last year, while imports would total $61.65 billion, up from $51.81 billion.

title: Lebanese Christians Get Arab League Offer
description: The Arab League commission, mediating an end to the Lebanese civil war in talks in Taif, said today that Christian legislators in Parliament should settle for a commitment by the Arab League to obtain a Syrian troop withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: State Street Boston reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: * Brand Fashion Outlet, to Romann & Tannenholz Advertising, with a budget of $2 million.

description: The Cuckoo's Egg Tracking a Spy Through the Maze of Computer Espionage By Clifford Stoll 326 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg Advances to Second Round in Tokyo: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeded first, defeated Glenn Michibata of Canada, 6-1, 6-3, yesterday in the first round of the Seiko Super tournament.(AP) Graf Advances: Steffi Graf, seeded No. 1, breezed into the quarterfinals yesterday at the $250,000 European Indoor tournament with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over Dinky van Rensburg of South Africa. (AP) SOCCER Columbia 3, St. John's 0: Chris Ziadie had a goal and an assist and James Feuerborn recorded six saves for his fourth shutout to lead the Lions (7-3) over the Redmen (9-5-1) at Baker Field. GYMNASTICS 5 Perfect Scores for Soviet Team: The Soviet Union, with five perfect scores, swept the women's team titles at the world championships yesterday in Stuttgart, West Germany, followed by Rumania, China and the United States.(AP)

title: Asian Venture Selects A Banker as Chairman
description: Richard A. Melville, an international banking executive, has signed on with a newly formed financial services and merchant banking company that hopes to establish a global business.

title: Bid for Connaught Extended 10 Days
description: A Swiss-United States group extended its bid of $764 million (Canadian) bid for Connaught Biosciences Inc., as the Canadian vaccine company fought a court battle to let a higher, friendly bid proceed from France's Institut Merieux S.A.

title: More Austerity Seen for China
description: A tough austerity policy this year slowed China's runaway economy, but it will take at least three years to put it back on course, the Government says. The People's Daily quoted

title: Waterzip Is Upset Winner at Aqueduct Opener
description: Waterzip slogged through the soft turf to post an upset victory in the $87,900 Ashley T. Cole Handicap yesterday as Aqueduct Race Track opened on a dark and damp afternoon that reflected the mood of the sparse crowd.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Every year millions of unsuspecting Americans, from children in school to the elderly in nursing homes, work with art materials that could endanger their health. But rarely are they properly protected from the potentially harmful ingredients. Indeed, rarely are they or their instructors even aware of the risks.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-19 Erich Honecker was ousted as the East German Communist Party faced strong demands for change. He led the country for 18 years. His 52-year-old heir apparent, Egon Krenz, was named to replace him. Page A1 Man in the news: Egon Krenz, the new leader of East Germany, was described by several West German officials as a tough, cynical politician, interested mostly in advancing his own career. A8 News analysis: Glasnost's limits were questioned this week when President Gorbachev wished aloud for the removal of an editor who published a survey that cast doubt on the President's popularity. title: Kroc Says Padres Won't Be Moved
description: Joan Kroc, who has announced that the Padres are for sale, gave assurances today that no sale discussions would be conducted with anyone who even intimates the possibility of moving the franchise.

title: Manville's New Chief For Forest Products
description: The Manville Corporation has named Thomas H. Johnson as the president of its Manville Forest Products Corporation, which accounts for 40 percent total company sales.

title: Review/Dance; Vivona Troupe Changes Roles, Sexes and Clothes
description: Diane Vivona's ''How to Fit a Square Peg in a Round Hole and Other Stories,'' performed on Saturday night at Playlab, took a carefree look at modern androgyny. The humor was bright, the cast engaging and the performing accomplished. But it was only in the next-to-last number that the piece became as focused as one might have expected.

title: Bensonhurst Suspect Remains Free on Bail
description: A judge refused yesterday to jail or increase the bail of the man who is accused of being a leader of the whites in the fatal Bensonhurst racial attack.
