description: b-Included a gain of $1,395,000, or 55 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment. The company said 1988 results are restated to reflect cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.

title: Japan Banks Turn Cautious on Lending for U.S. Buyouts
description: Japanese banking officials have become extremely cautious about making loans for American leveraged buyouts.

title: Rejection of Case Against Judge Urged
description: The impeachment trial of a Federal judge on charges arising from a bribery case took an unexpected twist today when a Republican Senator who has been active in the matter urged fellow lawmakers to reject the charges and let the judge remain on the bench.

title: State-O-Maine Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Robert Gersin, 60, Designer, Dies
description: Robert P. Gersin, an award-winning industrial designer, died of cancer Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Damage to Link Across Bay Is More Serious Than Thought
description: State officials said today that the earthquake had caused more damage to the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge than had been thought and that the span could be closed as long as two months.

description: Camilo Jose Cela, regarded as a breaker of literary taboos in the years after the Spanish Civil War, won the Nobel Prize in Literature today.

Cohen and Martin B. Tepper and the Lambert Brussels Capital Corporation, an international investment concern controlled by Belgian and Swiss interests.

title: Judge Mr. de Klerk By His Actions
description: The credibility crisis that faces the new South African administration of state President F. W. de Klerk was pinpointed by Dr. Frank Chikane, general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, when he, I and Dr. Allan Boesak, president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, met Mr. de Klerk last week.

The results also included a reserve related to the restructuring of LJN Toys' international operations. MCA said the above items were partially offset by a gain realized from the sale of the Miller International subsidiary which manufactured and distributed budget-priced audio cassettes in West Germany.

description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $83,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Review/Film; Escape to Fame and Fortune
description: ''The Method'' is an independently produced low-budget romantic drama about Anna, a 40-year-old housewife from Oregon, who finds fame, fortune and her own identity as an actress in San Francisco.

title: Tragedy's Reservoir
description: Similar stories emerge from natural disasters. Voices are heard crying in the wreckage. Someone is saved against all odds. Someone else expires just as the rescuers arrive. The pictures are similar, too. Buildings collapse into playing-card piles. Pavements are crazed with cracks. Flames belch from broken gas mains.

title: Digital Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two Airmen Admit a Plot to Sell Jet Engines
description: Two Air Force security guards have pleaded guilty to stealing three F-16 jet engines and selling them to undercover agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

description: Slow domestic sales and the continued strength of the dollar overseas contributed to a 32.5 percent decline in the Digital Equipment Corporation's earnings for its first quarter ending Sept. 30, the company said yesterday.

description: Workers' earnings rose 3.5 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, failing to keep pace with the rate of inflation in the same period, the Labor Department said today.

title: Brooklyn Handyman Held in Slayings of 2
description: A part-time handyman was charged late Wednesday in the slaying of a Brooklyn mother and her sister-in-law last month while two young children looked on, the police said.

description: Revenue represented total revenue.

description: A white supremacist ''skinhead'' was sentenced to up to 20 years in prison today for helping to beat a black immigrant to death.

description: b-Included $282,000 from the sale or refinancing of shopping centers.

title: Rattling Horns and Green Tomatoes
description: Red sumacs, orange maples, golden aspens, wine-dark ash leaves. This marvelous sunset range of colors is sometimes given voice by flights of geese breezing southward - in wiggling check-marks or military wedges, cheering one another on with halloos, gabbles, baying barks.

title: Bausch & Lomb Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Central Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Art; Intense Personal Visions Of a Fragile Japanese Artist
description: The 1960's are not so long ago, yet the art history of the period already has its gaps. One is being filled by the Center for International Contemporary Art, whose inaugural exhibition is a small retrospective of the work of Yayoi Kusama, a Japanese artist active in New York between 1958 and 1972. Despite its small and overdone interior, the center is getting off to a good start.

title: 10 Side With San Diego
description: Ten of the 24 challengers for the America's Cup have sided with the San Diego Yacht Club in its legal dispute with New Zealand by asking the New York courts not to consider any further appeals.

title: Panama Excuses, and Assassination
description: Two questions about the failed coup in Panama need to be separated promptly to avert undermining a landmark Presidential ban on assassinations. One is why the Administration chose not to support the attempted overthrow of General Noriega on Oct. 3. That is rapidly becoming blurred into a second, much larger question: whether, if there is a risk of assassination, the U.S. should ever involve itself in any coup attempt abroad.

title: Diceon Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: For Shoemaker's Picks, Dial Away
description: Bill Shoemaker, the 58-year-old jockey who is retiring in February after more than 50 paid farewell appearances at tracks around the world, was not offered any mounts in last year's Breeders' Cup races and has no prospects this year.

The film, which has rarely been seen outside of China, shows how modern industry affects the lives of those in a small fishing village.

title: Corrections

title: TV Weekend; A Drama of Day Care With a Satanic Twist
description: On Sunday evening at 9, the television movie on CBS is called ''Do You Know the Muffin Man?'' Set in present-day suburbia, it is about child abuse and Satanism. Also Sunday night at 9, ''Masterpiece Theater'' is beginning a two-part adaptation on Channel 13 of Mary Webb's 1924 novel ''Precious Bane.'' Set in Shropshire in rural England in the first decades of the 19th century, the drama has characters that include a village wizard and a young woman accused of witchcraft. The occult, evidently, is still very much with us, at least as far as television entertainment is concerned.

title: American Cyanamid Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Assassinations: Can't We Learn?
description: It happens I was one of a small company assembled in the big southwest corner office of the west wing of the White House in the early afternoon of Nov. 22, waiting word from Dallas. In the event, no message came; leastwise, none that I recall. Rather, at a point we seemed to come to the same realization. John F. Kennedy was dead. Assassinated.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Blues 3: Joe Murphy's unassisted goal with 1 minute 21 seconds remaining remaining capped Detroit's three-goal third-period rally last night in St. Louis. Murphy picked up a loose puck near the blue line and beat the rookie goaltender Pat Jablonski to the glove side with a 40-foot shot for his second goal of the game as Detroit (4-4-0) won for the first time on the road.(AP) Nordiques 5, Blackhawks 3: Ken McRae scored the game-winner for his first National Hockey League point and Peter Stastny added an empty-net goal for his 1,000th point. (AP) TENNIS Agenor Stops Agassi Again: Ronald Agenor of Haiti continued his mastery over Andre Agassi of the United States yesterday by knocking the second-seeded player out of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo with a 6-0, 6-2 victory in 52 minutes.

title: U.S. Critical on Export
description: Venezuela is subsidizing exports of aluminum sulfate and selling it in the United States at less than fair value, the Commerce Department said today. It said that if the International Trade Commission finds that the shipments have injured the United States industry, countervailing duties would be imposed. Aluminum sulfate is used for water purification and waste water treatment. Venezuelan shipments to the United States last year totaled $634,000.

title: Adlai S. Hardin Dead; Wood Sculptor Was 88
description: Adlai S. Hardin, a sculptor and former advertising executive, died of complications from a stroke on Monday at the Saybrook Convalescent Hospital in Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 88 years old.

description: Four employees at GTE Corporation's headquarters, including a cafeteria worker, have been discovered to have hepatitis, and company officials are recommending that everyone who ate in the cafeteria this month have a gamma globulin shot.

title: Waiting for the Big One
description: ''The big one'' has not yet hit the San Francisco Bay Area, the experts tell us, or southern California. That's small comfort to the thousands bereaved or devastated by a 6.9-magnitude earthquake, but it's a clear warning even to those Americans who live nowhere near the San Andreas Fault.

title: Plan Seen For Another TV Network
description: MCA Inc. and Paramount Communications Inc. are planning a fifth television network to compete with NBC, CBS, ABC and the Fox Broadcasting Company, industry executives said today.

title: Sam Moore, 85, Writer Of Comedy for Radio
description: Sam Moore, a writer for radio in the 1930's and 1940's on such comedy programs as ''The Great Gildersleeve,'' died of a heart attack last Friday while he was on vacation in France. He was 85 years old and lived in Blairstown, N.J.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank of New England Corp., Boston, said it would sell its merchant credit card processing unit to the National Data Corp., Atlanta. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Only 3 Books by Cela Are in Print in the U.S.
description: Only three English-language translations of Camilo Jose Cela's books appear to be in print in the United States. One is a travel book, ''Journey to the Alcarria'' (1948), translated by Frances M. Lopez-Morillas and published by the University of Wisconsin Press.

title: Pop/Jazz; What's New, What's Hot, On the Live Music Scene
description: FOR rock performers, New York City is still the ultimate test.

title: Jannock Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,487,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $426,000. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Executive Board of U.S.O.C. Faces Debate on Reforms
description: With scores of recommendations before it, the United States Olympic Committee's executive board plans to spend the next few days trying to reshape the organization by approving measures it feels would make the U.S.O.C. more efficient in operation and more responsible to the country's elite athletes.

title: Scecorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quipp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Horizon Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months' nets per share earnings were restated to reflect 4-for-3 stock split declared July 25.

title: Fedders Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $887,000, or 6 cents a share, and $4,403,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said this year's third quarter net income was reduced by 13 cents a share due to increased non- cash expenses related to the three acquisitions as depreciation and amortization expense totaled $4,092,000 compared with $158,000 in the year-ago quarter. The company also noted that interest expense in the third quarter amounted to $1,997,000, compared with net interest income of $773,000 in the year-ago third quarter. The extraordinary credit represents utilization of tax loss carryforwards.

title: Alexander & Baldwin reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $18,269,000, or 36 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: INSIDE
description: Optimism About Inflation Helps Bolster Stock Market Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, with much of the increase coming from clothing. The stock market rallied, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 39.55 points, or 1.5 percent. Page D1. Pretoria's Pact With Banks South Africa and the foreign banks to which it owes billions of dollars agreed on easier repayment terms.

title: Bank of Boston reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Questions Arise on the Death Toll In Vehicles on Collapsed Highway
description: Questions arose today about how many bodies and how many cars were trapped in the wreckage of the collapsed freeway here, and about whether the state had done everything it could to insure that it was safe.

title: Bankers Say Refinancing Is Needed to Avert Defaults
description: Bankers affiliated with the South Africa debt agreement said yesterday that the main reason the nation's creditors agreed to refinance $8 billion was that the loans were coming due on July 1 and would have to be rescheduled sooner or later.

title: Fogli in New York Race
description: Laura Fogli of Italy, who has never finished worse than fourth among the women in seven New York City Marathon appearances, has entered the Nov. 5 race. Fogli, 30 years old, has finished second twice, including last year; third three times, and fourth twice.

title: Idle Vandeweghe Returns to New York
description: Kiki Vandeweghe, who reported to the Knicks' training camp two weeks ago with back spasms, returned to New York yesterday while his teammates flew to Detroit for a preseason game tonight against the Pistons at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: Mesa Air Details StatesWest Offer
description: Mesa Airlines Inc. said StatesWest Airlines Inc. was offering $10 a share for Mesa's common stock. The offer, which values the company at $16.5 million, consists of $7 a share in cash plus StatesWest securities with a value of $3 a share.

title: Sage Drilling Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said latest fourth- quarter results included charges of about $502,000 for write-down of assets to be sold, about $398,000 for additional amortization of capitalized oil and gas costs and $945,000 to reduce the carrying value of drilling equipment. Year-ago fourth quarter loss included charges of about $986,000 for write-down of assets to be sold and about $340,000 for additional depreciation on rig equipment.

title: Stock Dinkins Sold for $58,000 He Once Valued at $1 Million
description: David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor of New York, may have a new tax problem to contend with.

title: Capital Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the earnings decline was mainly due to the increase in its administrative and general operating expenses to $4.7 million from $3.1 million.

title: Yeltsin Asserts K.G.B. Men Have Threatened to Kill Him
description: Boris N. Yeltsin asserted today that K.G.B. agents warned him they could kill him at any moment using a remote electronic device that would stop his heart.

title: Dinkins Interview Excerpts About Stock Sale and Taxes
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday at The New York Times with David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor of New York City: Q. How do you explain that you sold the stock to your son for less than you yourself listed with the state? A. You do not mention that repeatedly over the years in the financial disclosure forms filed with the city, that that same stock was listed between, I think, $20,000 and $50,000 or $20,000 and $60,000 or something. . . . The fact is that there is not an attempt here to hide anything or evade anything and you know my income tax returns have been out since 1973. Q. Who told you to put down $1.2 million? A. I don't know. I really don't know. Q. When the sale was made a few years later, did you consult with an accountant or a lawyer? A. None of the above. I just - it was Davey and I, it sounded like a good round number, really.

title: Reality Intrudes on Capital Drug Crusade
description: Six months after the Bush Administration vowed to make the nation's capital a test case in the nationwide effort to combat illegal drugs, local and Federal officials say the city's drug epidemic is as severe as ever.

title: Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Albany International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Film; 'True Love,' as It Is in the Italian Bronx
description: If ''Moonstruck'' had been made by, for and about real people, it might have been a lot like ''True Love,'' Nancy Savoca's exuberant, raucously funny film about a big Italian-American wedding and all its abundant fallout. Ms. Savoca, a Bronx native and a first-time director making a delightful debut, knows her territory and knows much better than to treat it too kindly.

title: United Banks of Colo.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Express reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,900,000, or 3 cents a share for the quarter and $41,100,000, or 10 cents a share for the 9 months. The company said its latest third quarter included a $110 million addition to Amercian Express Bank's credit reserve to protect against deterioration in the market for less developed country loans. The company also said results relating to Fireman's Fund Corp. have been accounted for as discontinued operations. The company's share of Shearson's 1989 third quarter net income was $41 million, after prefered stock dividend requirements, compared to a loss of $7 million a year ago. American Express owns about 68 percent of Shearson's outstanding common shares, or about 60 percent on a fully-diluted basis.

title: American Telephone & TeleFgraph reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reduced by $102 million, or 9 cents a share, and $288 million, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for a change in depreciation method and concurrent changes in estimates of depreciable lives and net salvage for certain telecommunications equipment. Results for the latest third quarter and 9 months reflect the acquisitions of Paradyne Corp. and Eaton Financial Corp. Year-ago third quarter and 9 months results were restated to reflect the consolidation of AT&T Credit Corp.

title: Firstar Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' results included $22,422,000 tax benefit from sale of real estate.

title: Bristol-Myers And Squibb Report Gains
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that the Bristol-Myers Company and the Squibb Corporation each had record sales and earnings in the third quarter. It was the last quarter that the two drug companies remained separate entities before their merger was completed on Oct. 4.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $13,087,000, 19 cents a share for the quarter and $40,134,000, or 59 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: A BROAD PROGRAM OF AID TO POLAND IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to set up a major new program to support democracy, private enterprise and the development of a free-market economy in Poland.

title: Baseball Must Light Its Candles
description: rrNow that electricity is back in much of the Bay Area, life goes on. Fresh caffe latte and good bread are back in the shops while rescue crews sift the ruins of homes and freeways.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review yesterday about coverage of the California earthquake reported incompletely on broadcasts by NBC News and its anchor, Tom Brokaw. This passage was omitted:

title: Equitable Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RPM Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Cabaret; Wallowing in Romance With Andrea Marcovicci
description: Few singers poke fun at themselves more tellingly than Andrea Marcovicci, who returned to the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) on Tuesday evening for her fourth extended engagement.

title: Prices Rose Modestly Last Month
description: Consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in September, cutting the nation's inflation rate so far this year to the same 4.4 percent posted for 1988, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Gamma Biologicals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Standard Register Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Birmingham Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mexico Seizes Nephews of 2 Top Traffickers
description: The national police said today that they had captured nephews of two major Colombian cocaine traffickers and broken up a ring that flew the drug into Mexico and shipped it by boat to Florida.

title: Cleveland Orchestra
description: Ralph Kirshbaum will be the cello soloist in the first New York performance of Peter Maxwell Davies's ''Strathclyde Concerto No. 2'' with the Cleveland Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. The work is the second in a series of 10 concertos commissioned by the Strathclyde Regional Council. The program, which is to be conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi, also includes Weber's ''Invitation to the Dance'' and the Tchaikovsky Fifth Symphony. Tickets are $15 to $30. Information: 874-6770.

title: Chemical Waste Management reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflects 2-for-1 stock split in Oct. 1989.

title: School Backs Down on Issue of Black Player
description: An all-white private school has reversed its decision to cancel a football game against a team with a black player, thus avoiding expulsion from the Mississippi Private School Association.

title: Review/Art; The Recent Sculptures Of Giacomo Manzu
description: This is - in intention, at any rate -the month of Giacomo Manzu in New York. On Monday, Francesco Cossiga, the President of Italy, unveiled in the garden facing the United Nations building a 25-foot-high bronze sculpture by Mr. Manzu that represents a woman holding a child. The gift of the Italian people to the United Nations, it was commissioned in 1987 by the Italian Government. Meanwhile, an exhibition of 23 recent bronzes and 2 large ebony carvings by Mr. Manzu can be seen at Wildenstein & Company. Almost all are recent works.

title: U.S. May Yield on Philippine Bases
description: American officials are prepared to negotiate an entirely new military bases agreement with the Philippine Government that will acknowledge increasing Philippine concerns about sovereignty, Western diplomats say.

title: Minnesota Mining & Mfg.  Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vilified Ball Park Passes Greatest Test
description: Candlestick Park, a 29-year-old stadium that has been vilified since birth, seems to have come through in good shape from its encounter with the biggest earthquake of its life.

title: Soviet Military Transport Plane Crashes Into Caspian, Killing 57
description: A Soviet military transport plane carrying paratroopers to peacekeeping duty in the Caucasus region caught fire and crashed into the Caspian Sea on Wednesday night, killing all 57 people on board, according to reports by the official press agency, Tass, and the Government newspaper, Izvestia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jamaica Tourism Board Parts Ways With Y.&R.
description: Tension between Young & Rubicam and the Jamaica Tourist Board flared yesterday with the agency and the tourist board publicly disagreeing over the release of the news that the two were ending their relationship.

title: Note Cites D'Amato H.U.D. Grant Help
description: A 1985 note to a high-ranking Federal housing official said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was working to obtain a Housing and Urban Development grant for a group headed by a Puerto Rican developer who later became a D'Amato campaign contributor and fund-raiser.

title: Pretoria Official Meets Guerrillas In Namibia for 'Friendly' Talks
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister held what he called friendly and constructive talks today with the South-West Africa People's Organization, the group that has fought South African rule of the territory for 23 years.

title: MPG Investment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Dance; Some Cows, A Goat and (So to Speak) Real Hoofers
description: There was a lot to watch in ''Can We Dance a Landscape?'' For instance, the cows. Then came the goat; then the chickens. The cows appeared first, right when the curtain went up on Wednesday night in the Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. They were nice black-and-white cows. But they were only sculptures, and dancers eventually pushed them offstage.

title: New York State E & G reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Group Seeks New Ways To Pressure South Africa
description: Leaders of the 49-nation Commonwealth searched today for new ways to put pressure on South Africa to move toward political change after discovering this morning that Pretoria had managed to reschedule a large portion of its foreign debt.

title: Ford Will Stop Importing Its German Luxury Sedan
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would discontinue imports of its Scorpio luxury sports sedans from West Germany because of poor sales. The move would end Ford's attempt to attract buyers of European luxury cars to its Lincoln-Mercury dealerships.

title: Hextall to Practice
description: Ron Hextall, a holdout this season, will return to practice today with the Philadelphia Flyers, whose 1-5-1 record has them off to their worst start in 20 years. Team officials declined to comment on the status of their star goaltender's contract dispute.

title: Net Off at Media Concern
description: Park Communications Inc., a diversified media company, said this week that after-tax income in the quarter ended Sept. 30 came to $3.86 million, down 2.3 percent from $3.95 million a year earlier. Earnings per share remained at 19 cents, reflecting the impact of a 3-for-2 stock split. Revenue for the quarter totaled $39.3 million, up from $39.1 million a year earlier. Park Communications consists of 131 newspapers, 10 AM- and 9 FM-radio stations and 7 television stations.

title: Waste Management Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $11,354,000, or 5 cents a share, from an agreement to combine refuse to energy operations with Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.

title: Thomas Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $1,941,000 from sale of a building and property in City of Industry, Calif. c-Included for the quarter $182,000 from the sale of Pouliot Designs, and the 9 months included a gain of $800,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting change reflecting cumulative change in accounting and also $1,576,000 from the sale of minority interests in North American Decorative Products Inc. and the Lennon Wall Paper Co. Lastest and year-ago quarter results included an adjustment for a 5-percent stock dividend paid Jan. 1.

title: Relief Fund Set Up for Victims Across Pacific
description: Feeling suddenly vulnerable to the dangers of earthquakes at home, Japan responded today to the quake in California by setting up an emergency relief fund for victims there.

BOOK FAIR, with face painting, arts and crafts, sports equipment, and new and used books, including best sellers, mysteries, art books and children's books, and refreshments, at the Calhoun School, 433 West End Avenue, at 81st Street. Reservations: 369-8890. CENTRAL PARK ZOO, #10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission: children under 3, free; children 3 to 12, 25 cents; the elderly, 50 cents; others, $1. Information: 861-6030.

title: SOME BUSINESSES AND SCHOOLS OPEN
description: Parts of this exhausted and shaken city returned to a tentative sort of normality today, while in the most stricken neighborhoods the stunned good nature of recent days gave way to impatience, anger and fear.

description: It is rare to find a survey of contemporary art nowadays that does not include at least a few Neo-Romantic landscapes. Not long ago, the Whitney Museum of American Art's branch at the Equitable Center devoted an exhibition to these works and at the moment there are no fewer than three shows that deal in one way or another with this theme.

description: LEAD: If there is one clear lesson from the San Francisco disaster, it is that a lack of information is the most serious problem facing officials immediately after an earthquake.

title: Plan Would Reassign Power on Land Use
description: Since land is to New York City what oil is to Houston, it is not surprising that changes in the regulation of land use proposed by the Charter Revision Commission have divided planners, developers, environmentalists and many others.

title: 16 Reliving The Terror Of a Quake
description: For 16 children now living in this area and receiving medical treatment, the violent earthquake here was the second shock hurled at them by fate in 10 months. They also lived, and suffered, through the earthquake that devastated Armenia last Dec. 7.

title: George Risk, 76, Dies; Electronics Executive
description: George Risk, an inventor who founded electronics companies in Nebraska, died Tuesday in a hospital in Cheyenne, Wyo., after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

The company said the first-quarter fiscal 1990 results included a gain of about $260,000 from the sale of other property and equipment. A $200,000 reduction in the market value of properties held for sale was recorded during the second quarter of fiscal 1990.

title: Economic Scene; Must the Market Dive Again?
description: JUST before the sharp recession of 1937, a Wall Street sage, Richard Dana Skinner, said, ''More zeal and energy, more fanatical hope, and more intense anguish have been expended over the past century in efforts to 'forecast' the stock market than in almost any other single line of human action.'' Sam Goldwyn, the fabulous movie producer, put it more succinctly: ''Never make forecasts, especially about the future.''

title: Now in New York, Spousal Impoverishment Need Not Be Feared
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks Plan Rights March in Chicago
description: It is an unwritten rule of life in Chicago. Black people do not generally venture into the Bridgeport neighborhood after dark. Over the years, that rule has been underscored by more than a few beatings and tire-slashings.

title: Bush Accepts Resignation Of Rights Agency Chairman
description: The White House says President Bush has accepted the resignation of William Barclay Allen, whose tenure as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights was marked by several controversies.

description: A memorial service for Bill Barron, the saxophonist, composer and professor of music at Wesleyan University, is to be held at 7 P.M. on Sunday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.

description: British Airways P.L.C. will not participate in a buyout of the UAL Corporation at this time, its chairman said yesterday.

description: Unemployment in Britain fell to 6 percent in September, its lowest level in nine years, the Government said today. Unemployment figures, adjusted for seasonal factors, showed a larger than expected fall of 50,400 people, to 1.69 million, the Employment Department said.

description: The Amoco Corporation's third-quarter net income tumbled 39.1 percent, to $336 million, or 65 cents a share, from $552 million, or $1.07 a share, in the comparable period in 1988, the giant petroleum company reported yesterday.

title: Photographs of Haiti
description: Recent photographs of Haiti by Maggie Steber are on view in Room 408 of the Union Square Gallery, 32 Union Square East, through Nov. 11. The exhibition focuses on the Caribbean country since the fall of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier. Hours are Fridays from 1 to 7 P.M., Saturdays from noon to 5 P.M., and by appointment. Information: 777-8393.

Aide to Gorbachev Takes Pravda Helm; Brezhnev Man Is Out
description: The chief editor of Pravda, the stodgy and authoritative organ of mainstream Soviet Communism, was removed from his job today and replaced by a close aide to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $11,300,000, or 43 cents a share. The company said the revenue increase was mainly due to continuing strong sales of tape products, particularly the 4400 automated cartridge system.

description: San Franciscans today found new ordeals in the old challenge of commuting.

title: Grace (W.R.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

The company said the income from discontinued operations of $16,636,000, or 20 cents a share, included $6.3 milion of income relating to cash received as partial payment on notes purchased in connection with the sale of Bermans and $10.9 million after-tax gain on the sale of interest in Home Quarters Warehouse Inc. Year-ago 9-month net income of $158,064,000 included $4,854,000, or 6 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment for FAS 96. The latest third quarter and 9-month income from continuing operations of $98,359,000 and $173,264,000, respectively, both included a total pretax gain of $114.4 million on restructuring of natural resource operations, the sale of Grace Equipment Co., the initial public offering of Grace Energy Corp. and the adjustment in the carrying value of certain natural resource assets that are not part of Grace Energy Corp.

title: Vivigen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Allergan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter, latest 9 months and year- earlier 9 months were not available. The company was spun off by SmithKline Beckman Corp. in July. On a pro-forma basis, Allergan posted net income for the third quarter of $29.4 million, up from $25.6 million pro-forma a year earlier. For the 9 months, pro-forma net earnings were $65.3 million, up from $54.3 million pro-forma for the period a year earlier.

title: Panel Backs Nominee For Agricultural Post
description: A divided Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to recommend confirmation of James E. Cason to the Agriculture Department's top environmental position. But opponents said they would continue their fight against the nomination on the Senate floor.

title: Affiliated Bankshares of Coloado Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Kodak Camera
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would introduce a disposable wide-angle-lens camera in the United States. The Kodak Stretch 35 will cost $12.95 and will take 12 color photographs. The company introduced the one-time use camera in Europe and Japan earlier this year. The camera's wide-angle lens will take panoramic photographs.

title: Violin Concert
description: Leonidas Kavakos, a violinist, will play Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 454), Prokofiev's Sonata No. 1 in F minor, and Schumann's Sonata No. 2 in E minor at Washington Irving High School, 16th Street and Irving Place, tomorrow evening at 8. Mr. Kavakos won first prize in the Walter W. Naumburg Violin Competition in 1988. He won first prize at the Niccolo Paganini Competition the same year. Tickets are $3. Information: 586-4680.

title: BankAmerica Profit Rises by 33.7%
description: Continuing its comeback, the BankAmerica Corporation, one of the nation's largest banks, said yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 33.7 percent, to $254 million, or $1.16 a share, from $190 million, or 97 cents a share, in the corresponding 1988 period.

title: Tiffany to Open Philadelphia Store
description: Tiffany & Company said it plans to open a 12,400-square-foot store in Philadelphia in the autumn of 1990. Tiffany's senior vice president, Thomas Andruskevich, told a meeting of financial analysts that the New York-based jewelry retailer would build a stand-alone store on Walnut Street in downtown Philadelphia.

title: Police Dig for More Bodies on Missouri Farm
description: Police officers searching for missing transients have already found the bodies of three unidentified men buried on a farm here, and are continuing to dig.

title: Loral Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $707,000, or 3 cents a share. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5,345,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and $12,790,000, or 51 cents a share, for the 6 months. Results have been restated to reflect the divestiture of two non-defense electronics units on April 27, 1989.

title: Officer Tells of Partner's Slaying in Drug Operation
description: As the family of a slain police officer sat quietly in a Manhattan courtroom, and a dozen off-duty officers glared in stony silence at the three defendants, a narcotics officer testified in harrowing detail yesterday about how his partner was killed in an undercover drug operation on the Upper West Side.

title: Ashland Coal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $728,000 income tax refund and $269,000 after-tax from interest on a related refund. c-Included $2,029,000 benefit from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Peerless Carpet reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said the acquisition of Galaxy Carpet Mills in June was the major reason for the decline in earnings.

title: Review/Film; Med School Madness In 'Gross Anatomy'
description: When Joe Slovak (Matthew Modine) gets the news that he has been accepted for medical school, he stuffs the letter in his pocket, strikes a noncommittal pose and ignores the anxious relatives waiting to find out what the letter says. That's Joe in a nutshell: diffident and jokey, vastly charming but also obnoxiously cavalier. He's someone who wouldn't be caught dead behaving as if he wanted anything badly. So he approaches medical school with a combination of wild-man clownishness, secret apprehension and studied cool.

title: William P. Palmer, 92, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: William P. Palmer, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, died Monday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: With Galileo Deployed, Shuttle Crew Conducts Space Experiments
description: Having completed their primary task, deploying the Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft, astronauts of the space shuttle Atlantis settled down today to a planned four more days of orbiting Earth and conducting an assortment of scientific experiments.

title: World Series Resumption On Course
description: The plan to resume the World Series next Tuesday remains ''on course,'' Commissioner Fay Vincent said today. But he reiterated and emphasized that the status of the Bay Area's recovery from the devastating earthquake remained the No. 1 condition that would determine the ultimate decision.

title: In a Debut, Ranger Stops Penalty Shot
description: For the Rangers last night, the moment could not have been more important. For Mike Richter, the circumstances could not have left him more solitary. Hartford's Kevin Dineen, having been awarded a penalty shot with the Rangers leading Hartford, 4-2, in the second period, stood 90 feet away.

title: Network General reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
About Real Estate; Builder's Plan Cuts Down Payments
description: One factor holding back home ownership in New York City, as in other parts of the country, is the difficulty many would-be buyers have in amassing enough savings for a down payment.

title: Elizabeth Willis, 67, Patron and Composer
description: Elizabeth Firestone Willis, a patron of the arts and a composer, died of heart failure Wednesday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. She was 67 years old and lived in Washington.

title: 2 Yemens Let Animosity Fizzle Into Coziness
description: Two lands called Yemen, long divided, are nudging toward a new coziness reflecting their common sense of nationhood.

Seattle to Examine Bridges and Freeways
description: State engineers said today that they would conduct a study to see if some of the old two-tiered bridges and freeways in Seattle, a city with geography and structures similiar to San Francisco's, should be redesigned to meet stricter standards.

title: Warsaw Pact Offers Plan to Monitor Troop Cuts
description: The Warsaw Pact presented a comprehensive plan in Vienna today for monitoring cuts in conventional forces. It calls for permanent inspectors at key transit points in Europe, Western officials said.

title: Premier Bankshares Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pioneer Set to Acquire Laser Disk Company
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation of Japan, a leader in the laser disk player market, said today that it would pay $200 million for Discovision Associates, a joint venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and MCA Inc. Discovision holds more than 1,400 important patents and patent applications in laser audio and video technology.

title: Relief Agencies Accepting Funds

title: Three Soviet Film Makers Take Their Work on Tour
description: In 1986, the Union of Soviet Film Makers set up a ''conflict commission'' to reconsider the fate of more than 140 films that had been banned or suppressed. Movies that for years had been prevented from being released were distributed, and began to find audiences in the Soviet Union and abroad. Four of the most prominent Soviet directors who have benefited from the political changes in their country - Aleksei Gherman, Aleksandr Sokurov, Kira Muratova and Tengiz Abuladze - are represented in a series of screenings that begin today at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: BankAmerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from tax loss carryforwards of $158 million ($28 million in the third quarter.) c-Included an extraordinary credit of $107 million ($45 million in the third quarter) from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Bankers First Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hasbro Profits Rise
description: The toy company Hasbro Inc. said today that better profit margins and improved performances by its Milton Bradley and Playskool units had helped third-quarter earnings rise 73.1 percent. The company reported earnings of $31.3 million, or 53 cents a share, compared with $18.08 million, or 31 cents a share, in 1988's third quarter. Revenue rose 9.4 percent, to $403 million, in the quarter ended Sept. 30 from $368.4 million in the comparable period last year.

title: Dining Out Guide: Hotel Dining
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Adrienne ** (Oct 6, 1989), Peninsula Hotel, 700 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street (903-3918) - A menu of dazzling cross-cultural cooking is served in Adrienne's luxurious Art Nouveau dining room. An Oriental influence is evident in starters like ravioli filled with leeks and ginger, and pockets of smoked salmon holding herbed vegetables, garnished with crab meat. Braised salmon with watercress-butter sauce; mignonettes of lamb with eggplant ragout and oregano cream sauce, and monkfish and sea bass with tomato-thyme sauce are some recommended entrees. Appetizers at lunch are $10 (with some supplements), $8.50 to $28 at dinner; entrees are $18.50 and $19 at lunch, $19.50 to $35 at dinner. Tasting menu is $55. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Sunday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday; Sunday brunch noon to 3 P.M. Ambassador Grill * (Oct. 3, 1986), 1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (355-3400) - The Ambassador Grill, an urbane restaurant in the United Nations Plaza Hotel, has a menu partly devoted to the cuisine of Gascony. Its subterranean dining room is a strikingly modern setting. Among the appetizers on the current menu are vegetable terrine with tomato coulis, and goat cheese pizza with herbs and tomato sauce. The flavorful duck cassoulet is a recommended entree. There is also grilled veal tenderloin with lime butter; pan-fried sweetbreads with lentils and ginger-cream sauce, and poached salmon in saffron-spiced vegetable broth. Lunch is $23 prix fixe; dinner is $29.50 prix fixe (with some supplements). Lunch: noon to 2 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 10:30 P.M. daily. Saturday brunch: 11 A.M. to 1:45 P.M.; Sunday brunch seatings at 11:30 A.M. and 1:45 P.M. The Edwardian Room * (May 19, 1989), Fifth Avenue at 59th Street in the Plaza Hotel (759-3000) - A noble sentimentality still clings to the dark oak walls of the rejuvenated Edwardian Room, the showcase restaurant of the Plaza. Towering windows over Central Park provide a backdrop to the setting of ornate woodwork and colossal chandeliers. Seasonal appetizers include crayfish in rice paper with coconut sauce, and acorn squash gnocchi with sage sauce. Among entrees from the current menu are veal chop with wild mushrooms; scallops with lemon grass and cucumber angel hair, and roasted lobster with fresh herbs and risotto. Appetizers are $7 to $19.50 at lunch, $7.50 to $19.50 at dinner; main courses are $15 to $29 at lunch, $23 to $34 at dinner. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Saturday; dinner: 5:30 to 10 P.M. Sunday to Thursday, until 10:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Lafayette **** (April 22, 1988), 65 East 56th Street (832-1565) - Lafayette is one of the city's most intoxicating dining rooms, where the chef brilliantly executes the sunny, herb-infused cooking of Mediterranean France. The room is soothing and civilized in decor. The fall menu appetizers include carmelized onion and cheese tart, cream of partridge soup, and Louisiana shrimp poached in orange juice and Sauternes. For main courses, there are breast of pheasant and beet Parmentier with ginger oil; spit-roasted sweetbreads with chestnuts and pomegranate vinaigrette; salmon loin in rice paper, and lobster with seven grains and pumpkin juice. Lunch prix fixe is $37.50; lighter lunch (entree of the day and salad) $23.50. Dinner prix fixe at $65 (''menu Lafayette'' $85). Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Tuesday to Friday; dinner 6 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday. Closed Sunday. Le Regence *** (Jan. 8, 1988), Hotel Plaza Athenee, 37 East 64th Street (606-4647, 606-4648) - This opulent Old World restaurant in the Plaza Athenee is a place for being pampered in the loftiest French style. The cuisine, under the watchful eye of the Rostang family, is light and contemporary. Several seafood entrees excel, like grilled red snapper in soy butter sauce, and black bass in a caviar sauce. Some of the other main courses are guinea hen with bacon and fresh apples; veal chop with either mustard or port wine sauce, and roast breast of duck with candied turnips. Onion tart over greens and salmon-and-scallop tart are good ways to begin. At lunch, appetizers are $7.50 to $23, entrees $14.50 to $26.50. At dinner, $59.50 prix fixe or five-course tasting dinner at $79.50). Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. daily; dinner: 6 to 9:30 P.M. daily. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: Major Earthquakes West of Beijing Kill at Least 29
description: A series of major earthquakes rocked northern China Wednesday night and today, killing at least 29 people and injuring hundreds in largely rural areas west of Beijing, the authorities reported today.

title: A 'Prime' Fund Suspends Sales
description: Officials of the Eaton Vance Prime Rate Reserves Fund said yesterday that they were suspending sales of the popular fund, effective Nov. 1. The firm is taking the unusual step because its portfolio manager has been unable to invest the almost $1.7 billion of shareholder assets as quickly as the money has come in, they said.

Washington Talk; Is Quayle Out of Tune On U.S. Soviet Policy?
description: Vice President Dan Quayle went to California this week. Because he was there when the earthquake struck, he had a golden opportunity to generate some favorable publicity for a change, to show himself capable of reacting to events quickly and effectively.

Former Patient Points to Nurse In Murder Trial
description: The trial of a former nurse accused of injecting his patients with fatal amounts of muscle-paralyzing drugs opened today with a 77-year-old man testifying that he began to choke and struggle immediately after receiving a mysterious late-night injection.

description: AFTER the largest California earthquake in 80 years, one that could cost the insurance companies hundreds of millions, if not billions, Wall Street has responded by bidding up the price of insurance company stocks.

description: A university professor sighed as he described the long self-criticism that he had written painstakingly in a small notebook and then read aloud to a critical audience of colleagues and Communist Party officials at a political meeting.

title: Coastal to Reopen Refinery in Aruba
description: The Coastal Corporation has signed a definitive agreement with the Government of Aruba to reopen a refinery there that the Exxon Corporation closed in February 1985 after 50 years of operation.

description: MANHATTAN'S engaging artifacts fair - the Fall Antiques Show at the Pier - encompasses the North American continent, with special emphasis this year on the great Southwest.

title: Senate Rejects Amendment Outlawing Flag Desecration
description: In a sharp rebuff to President Bush and a clear victory for the Democratic Congressional leadership, the Senate today rejected a proposed constitutional amendment to outlaw desecrating the American flag.

title: Ex-Dinkins Worker Says He Used Campaign Money in Vote Effort
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson said yesterday that he had used $9,500 from the mayoral campaign of David N. Dinkins for a legitimate get-out-the-vote operation on Primary Day.

King School Stages Battle Over Advent Of R.O.T.C.
description: The Manhattan high school named for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is at the center of an emotional dispute over whether a new Air Force Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps program desecrates the name of the slain Nobel Peace Prize laureate.

title: New Currency Studied
description: The Bureau of Engraving and Printing is looking at new designs for currency that would make counterfeiting more difficult. A bureau research panel is studying various designs, but it will need the approval of the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Bank for any change, a spokeswoman said. She declined to say whether there had been an increase recently in counterfeiting cases.

title: Caterpillar Net Tumbles 43.2%
description: Caterpillar Inc.'s third-quarter earnings tumbled 43.2 percent because of a sales slump that has forced the company to place about 325 employees on indefinite layoff, the company said today.

title: Judge Is Calm in Eye of Storm He Helped Create
description: At the center of a long-running storm that has taken Kansas City's school problems to the Supreme Court sits a quiet and reserved Federal judge endowed by background and temperament, associates say, with the patience to weather the winds of controversy.

title: Giants Face Big, Aggressive Chargers
description: A few years ago, the San Diego Chargers were the mad bombers of pro football, with Dan Fouts seemingly passing on every play. The Chargers who play the Giants on Sunday in San Diego are a different breed, a big team on offense and defense that tries to shove the ball down the throat of the opposition in the style of the Washington Redskins.

title: U.S. Officials Look to Policy on East Germany as Next Big Challenge
description: The Bush Administration is reviewing American policy toward East Germany, seeking a balance of encouraging democratization there without also fostering a pell-mell movement toward reunification of Germany that would threaten both Moscow and America's NATO allies.

title: Gillette Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest year's earnings included the benefit of an income tax settlement, all-time peak aluminum prices and a lower effective tax rate. The company also said its Alumax unit's Mt. Holly, S.C., primary aluminum facility was shut down on Sept. 22 by hurricane Hugo and is expected to resume full production within 20 weeks. The third quarter was reduced by $41.7 million as a result of Chevron Corp.'s exercise of its one-time right to receive an additional payment on the 15.2 million shares of Amax common stock that Amax purchased from Chevron in 1988. The quarter also included a gain froma payment related to the proposed Falconbridge acquisition and capitalization of exploration expenditures applicable to the new Hayden Hill gold mine.

title: Argentina and Britain Opening Consular Ties
description: Ending three days of talks here, Argentina and Britain decided today to resume consular ties and direct air and sea links, clearing the path for substantial normalization of relations, according to a joint statement issued today at the end of three days of talks.

The company said the first test market would be Charlotte, N.C., with others to be named the following week. The company said a date for national distribution would depend on the test results.

Canadian Pacific said it had made the bid after it failed to sell its stake in Soo Line, a Minneapolis-based transportation and real estate company that operates the 10th largest rail system in the United States.

title: Catholics, Condoms and AIDS
description: A draft report by a committee of Catholic bishops strongly rejects the use of condoms to retard the spread of the AIDS virus. Every religion has the right to set its own doctrine without interference. But when doctrine affects public health, that's everyone's business.

title: HomeFed Bank
description: The HomeFed Corporation of San Diego said it had converted its Home Federal Savings and Loan subsidiary to a Federal savings bank, and changed its name to the HomeFed Bank. The parent company received approval to make the switch last week from the Office of Thrift Supervision. HomeFed Bank deposits will continue to be insured by the Savings Association Insurance Fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: CBS Cancels a Comedy, Season's First Casualty
description: CBS became the first network to cancel a new series yesterday, dropping ''The People Next Door'' from its Monday night comedy lineup. The network will bring back ''Doctor, Doctor,'' a comedy that had a tryout in the summer.

title: Composer's Orchestra
description: The soprano Martina Arroyo will be the soloist with the American Composer's Orchestra in Samuel Barber's ''Andromache's Farewell'' at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon at 3. Mr. Barber composed the work for Miss Arroyo, who gave it its premiere at a New York Philharmonic concert in 1962. The program, which is to be conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, also includes Steve Reich's ''Tehillim'' and the world premieres of William Albright's ''Chasm: Symphonic Fragment'' and Martin Bresnick's ''Pontoosuc.'' The soloists in the Reich are Pamela Wood Ambush, Rebecca Armstrong and Cheryl Bensman Rowe, sopranos, and Mary Ann Hart, a mezzo-soprano. Tickets are $9 to $23. Information: 247-7800.

title: Justice Delays Iran-Contra Justice
description: Twice this year, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has intruded in Iran-contra criminal cases to appeal decisions on the use of national secrets as evidence. Each time, a Federal Court of Appeals has ruled that the independent counsel on Iran-contra matters, Lawrence Walsh, has the unfettered right to represent the Government in court. How often does Mr. Thornburgh need to hear that before he stops the interloping and seeks an orderly solution to these disputes over secrets?

description: The majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said today that he did not expect the Senate to approve any cut in the capital gains tax this year, and he sharply criticized President Bush for devoting so much effort and attention to achieving it.

description: The Fujimi Tile Company of Nagoya, Japan, has patented a method for making ceramic bricks and tile out of sewage sludge. The process begins by burning the sludge into ash and then mixing the ash with ceramic raw materials, including debris from making conventional tiles, to form a clay that can be molded and baked.

News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-6 Philippine Communist rebels are in a stall, suffering from factionalism, internal purges, declining college recruitment and the capture of some important leaders, diplomats and Philippine officials say. Page 1 East Berlin faces financial trouble exacerbated by the recent of exodus of 50,000 people to the West. The problems include worker shortages and damage to the country's growth potential. 6 50,000 in candlelight March for change in East Germany 6 Moscow is watching East Germany with reserve and skepticism as Egon Krenz comes to power there, Western diplomats say. Some experts feel that Mr. Krenz is destined to be a transitional leader. 6 The prison card of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat arrested by Soviet troops after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, was revealed to his friends and family by Soviet authorities. 3 International pressure on the U.S. to take a more active leadership role in helping Poland and Hungary shed their Communist economic systems is increasing. 6 An appeal for aid to Poland was made by the country's Prime Minister during a visit to the Vatican. He called for Western governments to help his country confront food shortages before winter. 4 London journal: A Polish government still in exile 4 Hungary to disband party militia 3 The disbanding of the contra rebels by an international commission ran into trouble when the United States criticized the commission for remarks that Washington said went beyond the group's mandate. 5 Ex-President Reagan told Japan to open its markets to more imports and take greater responsibility for foreign assistance to the poor countries of the world. He is on a nine-day visit to the country. 3 Homeless in China brave the cold 9 NATIONAL/7-9, 26 A Federal judge was removed from the bench by the Senate. Judge Alcee Hastings was convicted of eight impeachment articles, including one charging that he had conspired to obtain a $150,000 bribe. 1 Business deals by Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, should not be the subject of a formal investigation by the House ethics committee, said an outside counsel who investigated charges against Mr. Gingrich. 1 A cut in the Captial gains tax is not expected to happen this year by the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell. He sharply criticized President Bush for devoting so much effort to achieving it. 7 How to pay for the rebuilding of San Francisco is now a pressing issue under debate by local, state and federal officials. ''We need fast action, we need checks written on the spot,'' Mayor Art Agnos told President Bush. 1 People moving gingerly as they pick up the pieces 8 Quests to learn the fate of homes 8 Hospitals try to help survivors adjust 9 Questions about the highway that collapsed during the quake are being raised. They deal with the weakness of joints supporting parts of the roadway and a state program that may have inadvertently made the failure more serious. 1 Stock prices moved up slightly as traders reacted to encouraging inflation news and to signs that the Federal Reserve may allow interest rates to fall further. 33 A revised buyout plan for UAL, United's parent company, will be submitted by pilots, flight attendants and top executives on Monday, the head of the attendant's union said. 33 Unapproved experimental drugs are being given away to AIDS patients and other people with life-threatening diseases by a growing number of companies under pressure from consumer groups. 33 The astronauts of the space shuttle were told to conserve power in case their mission is extended several days. High winds were forecast for Monday at their landing site. 7 A scholarship fund named for a nun who has long been active in minority education was founded. The nun, Sister Thea Bowman, is confined to a wheelchair by bone cancer. 7 REGIONAL/27-30 Robert Garcia was found guilty of extortion and conspiracy. The proceeding against the Representative and his wife, who was convicted on the same charges, was the last major trial to emerge from the Wedtech scandal. 1 Garcia's downfall ends a political success story 28 David Dinkins said the sale of stock to his son at $58,000 reflected the stock's reasonable market value. The sale is a focus of controversy because Mr. Dinkins has once valued the stock at $1 million. 1 The communications company at the center of the dispute over Mr. Dinkins's stock holdings appears to be a prosperous one, with particularly valuable holdings in radio. 29 Political mentor is also big Dinkins contributor 29 Dinkins attacks, Giuliani pulls negative ads 29 The many changes in government under the proposed charter for New York City include redefinitions of the roles of the Council president and the comptroller, as well as the creation of many committees and boards. 27 Impoverished AIDS sufferers say that the program set up by New York City to help them survive is in disarray. Their complaints include long waiting lists and delayed benefits checks. 27 Many black itinerant farm workers, who have traditionally found fall work in Northern apple orchards, are being replaced by Mexican-born laborers. 27 A 150-year-old sacred tribal mask, on display at a Manhattan antiques show, was identified by an 82-year-old Hopi Indian high priest as stolen from a reservation in Arizona. 27 Brooklyn man admits killing 5-year-old girl 30

title: Intel and Siemens End Biin Venture
description: The Biin Company, a joint venture of the Intel Corporation and Siemens A.G., will be liquidated because no buyer could be found for Biin's manufacturing plant. Intel and Siemens had sought a buyer for Biin's Hillsboro, Ore., plant because the maker of fault-tolerant computers had failed to find a market for its product, a Biin spokesman, Jess Houdret, said. Intel and Siemens formed the Biin joint venture 18 months ago.

title: Chris-Craft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months results both included net of $454 million from the company's disposition of 63 percent of its interest in Warner Communications Inc. The company said the disposition generated cash proceeds of $1.6 billion. About $220 million of the proceeds were used to reduce long term debt, which now totals about $21 million. The company also said it 60 percent- owned unit, BHC Communications Inc., still holds the equivalent of 13.6 million Warner common shares.

title: Review/Music; Praising Nicaragua in Song
description: Agitprop gets a Caribbean lilt in the songs of Luis Enrique Mejia Godoy, one of Nicaragua's leading pop singers and a self-conscious musical ambassador. ''We didn't come to the United States to create problems, or to destabilize your country,'' he said, jokingly, during his first set on Tuesday at SOB's, in Spanish with a translator on stage. Instead, he added, he hoped to promote ''interchange between all the peoples of the world.''

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Formal Wear

The results proved almost too good, soon after in rehearsal. ''I did a battement, hit myself in the head and fell down,'' she said. ''I thought, 'That's my leg!' ''

The number of people crowded into city cells has more than doubled over the last five years, making Rikers Island the world's largest penal colony behind one fence outside of the Soviet Union and South Africa.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blackhawks 4, Jets 2: Dirk Graham's short-handed goal in the third period clinched Chicago's victory last night and handed Winnipeg its fifth loss in seven games.(AP) Sabres 6, Canadians 2: Dave Andreychuk had two goals and an assist and Buffalo erupted for four goals in the third period. Christian Ruuttu added three assists and Pierre Turgeon, Alexandr Mogilny and Rick Vaive had two points each for the Sabres. Jocelyn Lemieux and Shayne Corson scored for Montreal.(AP) Bruins 3, Oilers 0: Andy Moog shut out his former teammates as Edmonton managed only 11 shots against him in Boston's victory. Jarmo Kekalainen, Cam Neely and Bob Carpenter scored for the Bruins as the Oilers broke a team record for fewest shots in a game. They had managed only 12 against the Bruins in a game in 1980(AP) PRO BASKETBALL Nuggets Rout Barcelona: Alex English and Walter Davis combined for 47 points as the Denver Nuggets routed Barcelona of Spain, 137-103, last night in the McDonald's Open in Rome. The European champion, Jugoplastika Split of Yugoslavia, beat the Italian champion, Philips Milano, 102-97, in the second game of the doubleheader. The Yugoslavs will face the Nuggets tomorrow in the championship game.(AP) TENNIS Columbia Senior Gains: Unseeded Jeff Chiang of Columbia won two matches yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the Volvo collegiate championships at the University of Georgia in Athens. Chiang, a senior, will face third-seeded Al Parker of Georgia at noon today. In the first semifinal, top-seeded Jonathan Stark of Stanford, the United States Open junior champion, will play fourth-seeded Stephane Simian of South Carolina. GYMNASTICS Sweep for Soviet Union: Svetlana Boguinskaya of the Soviet Union recorded perfect marks of 10 on her last two events, the floor exercise and the vault, to lead her team to a medal sweep in the women's all-around competition at the world championships yesterday in Stuttgart, West Germany.(AP) CROSS COUNTRY Canisius Runners Win: Canisius, a newcomer to the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, provided the two gold medalists in the championships held in torrential rain at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday. Chris Kane, a sophomore, was the men's winner in 25 minutes 21.52 seconds for five miles. Heather Whalen, also a sophomore, took the women's three-mile run in 19:33.18.

title: Taiwan Draws Investors
description: New securities firms and investors are continuing to enter Taiwan's vibrant stock market, the country's Securities and Exchange Comission said today. The commission said Taiwan, with 20 million people, would have 4 million stock investor accounts by the end of 1989, against 3.7 million now and 700,000 in May 1988. It also predicted that Taiwan would have 250 brokerages by the end of the year, up from 188 at present and a mere 28 in May 1988, when the Government removed restrictions on new brokerage houses. There are 172 listed companies on the exchange.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Saving for College
description: There is now a wider choice of college savings plans than ever before. At least three banks, several states and the Federal Government offer programs that are not subject to the rapid fluctuations of the stock market. These programs have variable rates tied to various indexes. They require minimum deposits of $250 to $1,000, and mature in anywhere from 2 to 25 years. Because you can add money to college certificates of deposit before they mature, they often pay about a half-percentage point more than regular C.D.'s. Rates for regular five-year certificates are averaging 7.90 percent, nationally. Here are the rates for some college C.D.'s that mature in five years. $ Bank Rate College Savings Bank, Princeton, N.J. (Collegesure CD) 8.60 % Amerifederal Savings Bank, Lawrenceville, N.J. (College Savings plan) 8.25 First New York Bank for Business, New York, N.Y. (College CD) 9.00 Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Bid Is Said To Be Near For United
description: The pilots, flight attendants and top executives of United Airlines will submit a revised buyout proposal on Monday to the board of the UAL Corporation, United's parent company, the president of the flight attendants' union at United said yesterday.

title: Knoll Agrees to Sell Its Color Tile Unit
description: Knoll International Holding, a privately held company based in New York, said it had agreed to sell its Color Tile Inc. unit to Investcorp, an international investment bank, and members of the unit's senior management. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: POLAND'S PREMIER, IN ROME, SEEKS AID
description: On his first trip abroad since taking office in August, Poland's Prime Minister made an urgent appeal today to Western governments to help his country deal with shortages of food and other supplies before winter.

title: A Sound Course on the Baltics
description: Nothing threatens the improving American-Soviet relations more than potentially explosive nationalism in the Soviet Union, especially in the Baltic States. If Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia press for independence now, they could undermine Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms or prompt a crackdown. Either outcome would throw East-West rapprochement into reverse. That's something Washington and Moscow needed to discuss. Now they have, with the right results.

description: The San Francisco Giants had a split-squad workout this morning at Candlestick Park so that half of the team could visit an earthquake relief center downtown as a morale-raising measure. The other half of the team will do the same on Saturday.

description: The Hungarian Parliament voted today to disband a militia that was created to protect the Communist Party after the 1956 revolt.

description: LEAD: One vital question has gone unasked about the embarrassing collapse of the Panama coup attempt: Was it another example of an American failure, or near failure, through overcontrol?

title: Roll-Call Vote on Hastings
description: Following is the 69-to-26 roll-call vote by which the Senate today convicted Judge Alcee L. Hastings on Article I of 17 impeachment articles relating to bribery. A two-thirds vote was required for conviction. Article I was the main count against Judge Hastings, and a vote for conviction on any single count was sufficient to remove him from office. Of the 16 other counts, 7 resulted in votes for conviction, 3 in votes for acquittal and 6 in the Senate's decision to waive action. A yes vote was a vote to convict, while a no vote was a vote to acquit. Voting yes were 34 Democrats and 35 Republicans. Voting no were 21 Democrats and 5 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by xxx..

title: Review/Music; An Irish Mix Of Rock Beat And Folk
description: The Waterboys, an Irish group that mixes folk instrumentation and melodies with the raw power of rock, came to the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night and had the audience dancing in the aisles. The show, which was sold out, was another reminder of exactly how popular folk-based rock has become over the last five years.

title: More Than Rivalry at Stake for Alabama and Tennessee
description: A college football team can undergo a radical change in just one year. At this time last season, the Tennessee Volunteers had lost their first five games and went on to drop their sixth by a 28-20 score at home to Alabama, their longtime rival.

title: Kodak in Project On Film Transfer
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and a unit of Britain's Rank Organization P.L.C. are working together to make a high-definition telecine, a machine that transfers film images to video. Rank Cintel Ltd. is the world's largest producer of conventional telecine machines, which cost between $300,000 and $500,000 each. But the new HDTV telecine, using a process that converts film to any of the proposed HDTV standards, is estimated to cost $2 million.

But the only thing that the incumbent, a soft-spoken 69-year-old former accountant named Ryszard Kaczorowski, presides over is a meeting of his cabinet, every two weeks.

Kalin, an arbitrager with a 50,000-share position in the UAL Corporation, glanced over the shoulder of a commuter who was reading a newspaper. ''My heart sank,'' she recalled, when she saw an article saying that British Airways P.L.C. had backed out of the proposed buyout of UAL.

description: Mick Vukota, a fourth-line right wing who had scored a total of three goals in his career, netted three consecutive goals in five minutes for the Islanders tonight as they beat the Washington Capitals, 5-3.

title: Retailing Deals Persist Despite Recent Turmoil
description: Despite predictions that takeovers are on the wane, three significant merger proposals, totaling $1.3 billion, appeared this week in retailing and related fields and more are expected in the weeks ahead.

title: Young and Slangy Mix of the U.S. and Japan
description: ''A Wild Sheep Chase'' by Haruki Murakami is a bold new advance in a category of international fiction that could be called the trans-Pacific novel. Youthful, slangy, political and allegorical, Mr. Murakami is a writer who seems to be aware of every current American novel and popular song. Yet with its urban setting, yuppie characters and subtle feeling of mystery, even menace, his novel is clearly rooted in modern Japan.

title: Minneapolis Museum Director to Retire
description: Martin Friedman, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis for 28 years and a prominent figure in the international art world, will retire in November 1990, soon after his 65th birthday.

title: THE EARTHQUAKE'S TOLL IN 8 COUNTIES
description: ALAMEDA: Thirty bodies recovered from collapsed section of Interstate 880. Maybe 97 to 167 people still missing. Countywide, 320 injuries reported and $1.3 billion damage. No water in city of Alameda, near Oakland. SAN FRANCISCO: Ten deaths; 300 injured. Mayor's office estimates $2 billion in property losses. Most electricity restored except in the Marina district, where 60 buildings were destroyed and a block of apartments burned. Two main state office buildings closed. SAN MATEO: No deaths, 282 injuries, damage estimated at $35 million. Flights into and out of San Francisco International Airport limited because of control tower damage. Thousands of gallons of raw sewage spilled into San Francisco Bay after electricity was lost at a pumping station. SANTA CRUZ: Five deaths reported in city of Santa Cruz; 862 injuries. Damage estimated at $750 million. Twenty downtown buildings must be razed. As many as 10,000 people homeless. Mountain passes closed by landslides and fissures in roads. Two bridges damaged. Eight injuries and an estimated $100 million damage in Watsonville. Major structural damage in Scotts Valley. SANTA CLARA: Five deaths, 900 injuries. Damage estimated at $260 million. SAN BENITO: No deaths. Seventy-five minor injuries. Damage estimated at $100 million. Highway 101 closed by bridge collapse. All water contaminated. MONTEREY: One person dead in fall from water tank in Moss Landing. Six injuries. Damage estimated at $50 million to $100 million. Salinas sustained $3.6 million in damage. In Moterey, state-operated Robert Louis Stevenson house damaged. MARIN: No deaths, minimal damage. Several stores damaged, including glass store in San Rafael where 15 tons of glass were smashed. Roof of a Safeway store in Ignacio partly fell in. (Source: Associated Press)

title: The Wallenberg Fog Persists
description: Despite glasnost, a thick mist still obscures the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swede who rescued tens of thousands of Jews in Nazi-ruled Hungary. It's certainly progress that the Soviet Union now calls Mr. Wallenberg's arrest near Budapest on Jan. 17, 1945, by Red Army authorities ''a tragic mistake that has never been corrected.'' Yet Soviet officials still insist the missing diplomat died of heart failure, at age 35, in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison in 1947. That remains hard to believe.

title: Giuliani Pulls a Negative TV Ad As Dinkins Broadcasts First One
description: In a change of strategy, the mayoral campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani has pulled its negative television advertisement about his Democratic opponent, David N. Dinkins, off the air.

description: The company said year-ago figures are restated for the effects of the accounting change for unbilled revenues.

title: Review/Music; Refining Tempos in the Mahler Fifth
description: Roughly speaking, there are five ways to decide how fast to play a piece of music. The first is to follow the composer's metronome markings. Whether to do so is a thorny question that we are spared in the case of Mahler's Fifth Symphony, which was heard in a tempo-conscious reinterpretation Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. It has no such markings; Mahler preferred to suggest his tempos verbally.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: Control of Arby's By Posner Fought
description: Restaurant franchisees of Arby's Inc., a unit of DWG, said they overwhelmingly opposed continued control of Arby's by Victor Posner, who owns a controlling interest in DWG. The franchisees said they had agreed at a special meeting here to raise $1.5 million to support a new group headed by Leonard Roberts, who was recently dismissed by Mr. Posner from his post as chief executive of Arby's.

description: The Giants' success against the Chargers in San Diego on Sunday may depend on how well the Giants contain Anthony Miller, the Chargers' swift second-year wide receiver.

The Rev. Dawson Trenchard performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Patrick-St. Anthony in Hartford.

title: Reviews/Music; A Bernstein Celebration of Copland
description: For virtually all of Leonard Bernstein's professional career, the works of Aaron Copland have been woven through the texture of his life. The two friends and composing colleagues have been the warp and weft of American music for so long that they seem to make up one long-wearing fabric.

title: Hospitals Try to Help Survivors To Adjust
description: Jane Morgan smiled as comfortably as she could with a broken nose, blackened eyes and a new cast on her left leg.
