title: Concert Programs Changed
description: The New York Philharmonic programs at Avery Fisher Hall from Thursday through Oct. 31 have been altered, the orchestra has announced. On Thursday and Friday evenings at 8, Leonard Bernstein will conduct an all-Tchaikovsky program of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' ''Francesca da Rimini'' and the Symphony No. 4. On Saturday at 8 P.M., Mahler's ''Songs of a Wayfarer'' with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau as soloist will replace ''Romeo and Juliet.'' On Oct. 31 at 7:30 P.M., the Saturday program will be repeated except that the Tchaikovsky tone poem will be ''Romeo and Juliet,'' not ''Francesca da Rimini.''

title: Reviews/Film; Revenge of the Hillbillies
description: ''Next of Kin,'' an appreciably better-than-average revenge drama that opened yesterday at Loew's 84th Street and other theaters, has a taste for novelty. Its heroes are hillbillies, adrift in the big city. Its gangster villains run a vending machine concern. Its final fight to the death takes place in a cemetery, which seems vaguely redundant somehow. The leading character, whose name is Truman, finishes off his machine-gun-wielding enemies with a bow and arrow.

title: Termiflex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company, which reduced its staff by 20 percent on Aug. 11, said the full effect of that reduction will be reflected in expenses for the second quarter ending Dec. 31.

title: Ethics Panel Is Told To Shun Full Inquiry In Gingrich's Case
description: A law firm hired by the House ethics committee to investigate the business dealings of Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, has recommended that the panel conduct no formal investigation, House and other officials said today.

title: Joseph I. Levine, Producer, 63
description: Joseph I. Levine, who produced ''J. B.,'' a play by Archibald MacLeish that won a Pulitzer Prize in 1958, died of stomach cancer Tuesday in the Tarzana Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 63 years old and lived in Sherman Oaks, Calif.

title: Nilsson to Give Master Class
description: Birgit Nilsson is to give a master class in the John C. Borden Auditorium of the Manhattan School of Music (Broadway and 122d Street) on Nov. 12 at 2:30 P.M. Tickets are $25, with the proceeds going to the scholarship fund established in the Swedish soprano's name to help young voice students at the school. Reservations: 749-2802, extension 497 or 498, weekdays from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 2 to 4 P.M.

title: Ojeda Comes Through
description: Bob Ojeda of the Mets visited the Tule River Indian reservation in Porterville, Calif., yesterday to check on progress of a home for displaced Indian children. Ojeda, who lives in nearby Visalia, has helped raise more than $30,000 in two months for the project. ''Sometimes people say things and never produce, but Bobby Ojeda is a man of his word,'' said Joe Carrillo, head of the Tule Indians Youth Council.(AP)

title: Dickerson Can't Run And He Can't Hide
description: It has not been a vintage week for Eric Dickerson. On Sunday, Dickerson, the Indianapolis Colts running back who holds four National Football League rushing records, was held to 35 yards by Denver as the Broncos won, 14-3. The loss not only broke the Colts' winning streak at three games, but it was also the fourth game in a row that Dickerson had not gained 100 yards.

People Moving Gingerly As They Pick Up Pieces

But Gene Holtan and Elizabeth Sanchez lie awake at night in their Tudor house on Beach Hill, listening to the wind pushing on their creaking chimneys and wonder if life will ever really get back to normal.

title: Patents; Synthetic Blood
description: Motivated in part by the danger of transmitting contagious diseases through blood transfusions, as well as by periodic scarcities in supplies, two chemists have patented a synthetic blood. The blood consists of hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying molecule in red blood cells, encapsulated in bubbles that have the consistency of Jell-O. It was invented by two brothers, Bernard and Charles Ecanow, who are president and vice president, respectively, of the Synthetic Blood Corporation in Deerfield, Ill. The bubbles are chemically similar to the membrane that makes up living cells, the inventors said. They protect the hemoglobin from absorbing toxins in the body, but they allow oxygen to pass out and be absorbed by all parts of the body. The brothers received patent 4,874,742.

Miss Devi, an Indian-born dancer who has taught at New York University, specializes in Odissi, which comes from Orissa, a state in eastern India. She made the works she choreographed and performed in this style visually enchanting and spiritually fervent.

Why I Can't Quit the Bay Area

title: Fewer Blacks Migrate to Northern Harvests
description: For many black itinerant farm workers here, the northern end of the migrant stream has always seemed very cold and very far from their homes in the South. But it has also offered them ample consolation: come fall, plenty of work in the apple orchards of upstate New York.

title: World Reaching Out To Boy Who Lost Leg
description: Offers of money, toys and even a new home poured in from many parts of the world today for Julio Berumen, the 6-year-old boy who was rescued from the Interstate 880 wreckage only through amputation of much of his right leg.

title: Nippon Insurance
description: Nippon Life Insurance, Japan's largest life insurer, said it had agreed to buy an 80 percent stake in the Paine Webber Building on Avenue of the Americas in midtown Manhattan for $550 million. The Equitable Life Assurance Society will hold the other 20 percent and continue to manage the 38-story building, a Nippon Life spokesman said. The company has invested in five other buildings in the United States in cooperation with Equitable. It owns 20 buildings outside of Japan, of which 18 are in the United States and one each in Canada and Britain.

title: The No Dealer
description: They say Ronald Reagan has had his phone number unlisted. Apparently it's a case of a thoroughly fed-up Gipper. Too many phone calls in the night from George Bush. Here's a story going around: It's 3:30 in the afternoon. Reagan is sleeping deeply. Phone rings. ''Mister President.'' ''I'm not your Mister President anymore. Who is this anyway?'' ''It's the Vice President, sir.''

title: THE INNER CITY STOCK TRANSFERS
description: May 8, 1972: David N. Dinkins buys 50 shares of class A common stock in Inner City Broadcasting Corp. for $5,000, or $100 per share. 1982 and 1983: Mr. Dinkins acquires 24 more shares at $275 per share. He receives 10 shares as a dividend. May 11, 1983: Mr. Dinkins, in a letter to Governor Cuomo's office, says the asset value of the 84 shares is $1,009,230.60, or $12,014.65 per share. The 84 shares amount to 1.13 percent of the company. Jan. 1, 1986: Mr. Dinkins is sworn in as Borough President and sells his stock, which he says now comes to 588 shares after a split, to his son, David Jr., for $58,000, or $98.64 per share. His son promises to pay for the stock with interest by 1991. Jan. 3, 1986: Inner City Broadcasting offers to buy back a limited number of shares of the company for $93.75 per share. Oct. 8, 1986: New York City's Board of Ethics advises Mr. Dinkins to abstain from voting on any matter involving Inner City. June 30, 1987: A member of Mr. Dinkin's staff votes in his name in favor of an office project in Harlem in which Inner City has an interest. Mr. Dinkins later said his staff was unaware that Inner City was involved. Nov. 17, 1987: Mr. Dinkins abstains from a Board of Estimate vote concerning Inner City's interest in a Queens cable television franchise. June 19, 1989: A member of Mr. Dinkins's staff votes in his name in favor of a matter involving the Queens cable TV franchise. Mr. Dinkins later says the vote was a mistake. Oct. 19, 1989: Mr. Dinkins, in an interview, says he valued the stock at more than $1 million after consulting with an Inner City official. He says he sold it two years later to his son for $58,000, setting the price on his own without consulting others. He says his son has not paid any money so far for the stock. Oct. 20, 1989: Mr. Dinkins, at a news conference, says that the $58,000 sale price reflected the reasonable value of the stock and approximately the same price at which the company was offering to buy back some of the shares. He says he valued the stock at more than $1 million two years before the sale, based on the judgement of company officials about the future of Inner City. Percy E. Sutton, the chairman of Inner City, says at a news conference that the difference between the $58,000 figure and the $1 million figure represented the difference between the market value of the shares and the market value of the entire company if it were broken up and sold.

title: DINKINS DEFENDS HANDLING OF STOCK HE SOLD TO HIS SON
description: With an accountant by his side, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor of New York, fielded questions for almost two hours yesterday in an effort to stanch further controversy over the communications-company stock he sold to his son in 1986.

title: Novacare Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Novacare changed its name from Inspeech Inc. effective yesterday.

title: Review/Film; Two Kinds of Warrior, Two Ways to Die
description: Martin Wragge's World War II action-adventure film ''The Last Warrior'' is not a movie that will advance good relations between the United States and Japan. Set on a small Pacific island during the final year of the war, it chronicles in interminable and fetishistic detail the life-and-death struggle between a young American intelligence officer (Gary Graham), who has been reporting on the movements of a Japanese fleet, and the Japanese military officer (Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa) who captures him.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge players, like drivers, have to be cautious about overtaking. Wasting two honors on one trick can be fatal, but there are times when it must be done. A subtle example is the diagramed deal played a week ago in the North Jersey Open Pairs in Allendale, N.J.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Decline
description: Treasury note and bond prices eased yesterday in lackluster trading. Dealers attributed the dull session to the absence of any significant economic or market news and the usual caution that precedes a week in which a large amount of debt is scheduled for sale.

title: Dispute Over Panel Highlights Difficulty of Disbanding the Contras
description: Days after its first visit to Nicaraguan rebel camps in Honduras, a special international commission established to oversee the dismantling of the rebel army has been plunged into controversy over how far it may go in urging the rebels to disband.

title: Chicago Exchange Head
description: The chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, Karsten Mahlmann, will seek an unprecedented fourth consecutive term as head of the world's largest commodity futures exchange. In a three-page letter mailed to Board of Trade members this week, Mr. Mahlmann said mounting threats to the traditional open-outcry system persuaded him to run for another one-year term.

title: Arrivederci, Milano
description: Benoit Benjamin, the 7-foot center who rejected a contract offer from the Los Angeles Clippers on Monday and flew to Italy to seek a contract with the Philips Milano team, has turned down the team's offer and returned to the United States to renegotiate with the Clippers. (AP)

title: Columbia's Passing Game on Target
description: In recent years, much has gone wrong for Columbia's football team between the time a coach chalks an offensive play on a blackboard and the Lions' attempt to execute it in a game. Somehow, on the field, the plans would splinter as if a stiff wind had blown them off the coach's clipboard.

title: Quests to Learn the Fate Of Homes After Quake
description: Darryl Yee held up the precious computer list - the ''2 A.M. list,'' it was called; there would be a later one - that reported on the condition of the buildings in the Marina district.

title: NONFICTION
description: CARRINGTON: A Life. By Gretchen Gerzina. (Norton, $24.95.) Dora Carrington (1893-1932) was only a peripheral member of the Bloomsbury group, remembered today because of her curious relationship with Lytton Strachey, whom she loved and lived with for nearly 17 years, despite his homosexuality. Carrington was a difficult though charismatic figure. She was a study in contradictions: a loner who could be extremely social, a professed lover of truth who frequently lied, an artist driven to work though depressed by it. With her bohemian life (she lived with both Strachey and her husband, Ralph Partridge) and her outspoken rejection of most traditional women's roles, she seemed, at least from the outside, a symbol of the newly liberated 20th-century woman. But as Gretchen Gerzina makes clear in ''Carrington: A Life,'' there was a disparity between appearances and the actual stuff of Carrington's conflicted inner life. Behind the free-spirited romantic who always had at least two lovers waiting in the wings, the witty raconteur who charmed with her lively illustrations and graceful letters, stood a far more timid soul: a creature mortified by sex and riddled with self-doubt - a woman driven, finally, to suicide after the death of her platonic older lover, Strachey. Among other exaggerated claims, Ms. Gerzina, who teaches English at Vassar College, tends to make far too much of Carrington's importance as a painter, an argument she periodically states, though never convincingly demonstrates. (The truth was that Carrington's art was never as interesting as her romantic entanglements.) And given Ms. Gerzina's obvious familiarity with her subject, it is also unfortunate that she has provided so few psychological insights into the reasons for Carrington's separation of emotional love from the physical. Happily, however, these unanswered questions never seriously detract from Carrington's interest as a character. Even those who vowed never to read another book on Bloomsbury will find themselves drawn in.

title: Ann Getty: Publish and Perish?
description: THE PARTNERSHIP OF Ann Getty and George Weidenfeld -fabulous wealth wed to expansive ambition - should have been the perfect match. He is among Britain's most visible publishers, founder and chairman of Weidenfeld & Nicolson Ltd. She is bankrolled by her husband, Gordon, son of the oil tycoon J. Paul Getty. Together, Weidenfeld and Getty created the Wheatland Corporation (named after her hometown), which would launch Ann Getty's career in publishing and give George Weidenfeld a base of operations in the United States. They started by buying Grove Press, a small, ailing, but prestigious company. Three months later, in June 1985, they announced their most ambitious project:

title: All Skewers Aren't on Plate As Fashionable Meet at Lunch
description: In the flower-filled arena of La Grenouille, the chic restaurant on 52d Street just off Fifth Avenue, the orchids and hydrangeas fairly hummed with suppressed tension. John Fairchild, the chairman and publisher of Women's Wear Daily - and grand poo-bah of the high-fashion putdown - had just taken his customary seat in the corner of the clubby front room.

title: Brisk Victory for Dispersal
description: Dispersal, the lone 3-year-old in a field of seven, contested a fast early pace but still had enough left in the final yards to hold off Sewickley by a long nose and win the $581,000 N.Y.R.A. Mile Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Film Maker Wed To Miss Gunther
description: The marriage of Catherine Lloyd Gunther, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Gunther of San Francisco, to Richard Sazerac Saunders Dallett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Dallett of Taconic, Conn., took place yesterday at Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Philip Devens performed the ceremony. Mrs. Dallett, a painter and sculptor and a textile designer at China Seas, a textile company in New York, graduated from Tufts University and the Boston Museum School. Her father is the executive vice president at Pacific Securities Inc., an investment banking company in San Francisco.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 22, 1989
Don't Mess With Gramm-Rudman
description: Pressure is building to revise Gramm-Rudman, the budget-balancing legislation enacted in 1985 and amended in 1987. Indeed, Congress seems to be on the verge of adopting a pattern of amending the law every two years. This year the argument for revising the targets will have a new and powerful twist: the need to protect people's retirement checks by segregating the Social Security accounts from the rest of the budget for deficit reduction purposes. Although politically appealing, this argument is fundamentally flawed. The right choice is to count Social Security the same way as other outlays and to preserve whatever discipline is left under existing Gramm-Rudman rules.

title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs
description: THE fervor and intensity associated with the war on drugs is a tug on the emotional strings of America. The rhetoric smacks of a call to arms intended to placate the majority, who are worried that crack-cocaine, and the crowd associated with it, will soon be sitting on front lawns and calling to children in suburban classrooms.

title: FRANKENSTEIN SINGSGhouls' Gallery
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Defeated By Canucks 2-1
description: The Vancouver Canucks, on a three-game tour of New York-area rinks, won their second successive game when they beat the Islanders, 2-1, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Karen E. Olsen Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Ellen Olsen was married yesterday to John Michael Pugliese Jr. at the Reformed Church in America in Middletown, N.J., by the Rev. William Coventry, assisted by Robert Nimon, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Olsen Jr. of Middletown. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pugliese of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Allegre Kicking in the Groove
description: Raul Allegre of the Giants is kicking less and enjoying it more. And doing better, too.

title: Army Grinds Out A Tough Victory
description: Army's ground game overshadowed a fierce passing attack for the second successive Saturday as the Cadets beat Lafayette, 34-20, today.

title: How to Brighten a Gloomy Monday
description: MONDAY is not the cheeriest of days, especially when the weather is overcast and gloomy. As a housewife whose children have grown and flown and whose ''girlfriends'' have jobs, so no one to play with, I was bored with housework, television and the telephone.

title: SHUTTLE PREPARES FOR EARLY LANDING
description: Flight controllers prepared today to end the flight of the space shuttle Atlantis one or two orbits ahead of schedule on Monday to avoid high winds predicted for later in the day at the desert landing base in California.

title: Lately the Lens Frames Moral Issues
description: Casual and perfunctory violence, both psychic and physical, are so commonplace on the screen these days that it's truly surprising to find characters expressing regret when they hurt one another. There's a remarkable moment in ''Sea of Love'' when Al Pacino, as a New York police detective on the trail of a serial killer, inflicts unintended injury as he lures and interviews a number of female suspects by pretending to be a lonely bachelor (which in fact he is, but that's another part of the story).

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Deborah Sanders to Wed in March
description: The engagement of Deborah L. Sanders to Eliot Studnitzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Studnitzer of the Bronx, has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Saul L. Sanders of Montville, N.J., and York, Me. A March wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Jets Have Benched O'Brien?
description: It has been several years now that we have watched Ken O'Brien being sacked, injured and otherwise violated. During this time he has always returned to the scene of the sack willingly, and he never complained about lack of pass protection.

title: Melanie Jane Wissemann Wed to Richard S. Essex
description: Melanie Jane Wissemann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Wissemann of Southold, L.I., was married yesterday in Bridgnorth, Shropshire, England, to Richard Scott Essex, a son of Evelyn Holt Essex of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Winfield Scott Essex. The Rev. James Butterworth performed the Anglican ceremony at St. Calixtus Church.

title: Israel Isn't Suicidal
description: LEAD: Israel is once again being treated to a moral and political assault - this time ostensibly because the Israeli Government refuses to negotiate with certain Palestinians on its own proposal for elections in the West Bank and Gaza, and also refuses to accept certain modifications of that proposal recently put forward by President Hosni Mubarak of

title: Hextall Is Back
description: In a variation of the ''you-can't-fire-me-I-quit'' routine, Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia Flyer goalie, has been staging a holdout while under a 12-game suspension for an incident in last season's Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey Sabres 4, Penguins 2: Darren Puppa continued his hot goaltending last night by stopping 38 shots for Buffalo. Puppa raised his season record to 5-1-1 as he and the Sabres held the Penguins scoreless in Pittsburgh on five power plays. The Penguins, who set a National Hockey League record with 119 power-play goals last season, have connected on just 1 of their last 19 chances.(AP) Red Wings 3, Whalers 3: Sylvain Cote scored on a rebound from the slot with 8:39 remaining in regulation time to give Hartford the tie in a home game last night. The Whalers outshot the Red Wings, 31-13. Cote's game-tying goal came after a shot by Scott Young bounced off the goaltender, Glen Hanlon. Cote put the rebound past Hanlon for his third goal of the season. By holding Detroit to just 13 shots, the Whalers matched a club record, set Feb. 29, 1980, against St. Louis, for fewest shots allowed in a game.(AP) Gymnastics 3 Golds for Russians: Russian gymnasts won three gold medals yesterday and Brandy Johnson of the United States won a silver on the vault on the first day of individual event finals at the world gymnastics championships in Stuttgart, West Germany.(AP) Tennis Krickstein Overcomes Edberg: Aaron Krickstein of the United States struggled through two and a half hours of play and two tie breakers yesterday before outlasting top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 2-6, 7-6, 7-6, in the semifinals of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo.(AP) Graf and Novotna Gain: Top-seeded Steffi Graf and fifth-seeded Jana Novotna advanced to the final of the European indoor tournament in Zurich yesterday. Graf eliminated third-seeded Helena Sukova, 6-1, 6-3, and Novotna upset fourth-seeded Monica Seles, 7-6, 6-4.(AP) Connors Wins Another: Jimmy Connors yesterday won his 109th tournament by defeating Gilad Blum of Israel, 2-6, 6-2, 6-1, at a tournament in a suburb of Tel Aviv. (AP) Baseball Japan Series Begins: Hideyuki Awano pitched a seven-hitter to lead the Kintetsu Buffaloes to a 4-3 victory over the Yomiuri Giants in Osaka in the first game of the Japan Series. A former Montreal Expo, Warren Cromartie, the Central League batting champion with a .378 average, singled and doubled.(AP) Soccer Yale 1, Columbia 0: Lars Richters scored on a header with 12 minutes 34 seconds left in the second overtime to lead Yale past Columbia yesterday at Baker Field. With the victory, the Elis (7-3) moved into first place in the Ivy League with a 4-1 record. Volleyball U.S. Team Beats Japan: The United States's national volleyball team beat Japan, 15-13, 15-6, 9-15, 7-15, 15-12, Friday in Los Angeles in the opening match of an exhibition tour. (AP) Cross Country Champion Retains Title: John Trautmann of Georgetown successfully defended his Big East Conference title yesterday, clocking 24 minutes 38 seconds for the five miles at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Obsession
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner; Ethnic Variety Uptown And a Chinatown Spot
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Amsterdam's

title: Expanded ''Dolphins' at East Coast Arts
description: WITH his back arched and his head and toes on the floor, Jerry Tremendous is performing his morning yoga ritual in what is called the dolphin position. Suddenly, he wonders who that woman was, the one who just walked by wearing a familiar-looking wedding ring.

title: Squad's Specialty: Shutouts
description: The Byram Hills High School football team has a reputation for stopping winning streaks. In 1967, the Bobcats snapped Bronxville's streak at 39 games. They snapped Irvington's at 16 in 1979. They stopped Rye's at 23 in 1987.

title: Healing Scars Left by Crises
description: LEAD: ENCOUNTERS with catastrophes - like the collapse at L'Ambiance Plaza in Bridgeport, the earthquakes in the San Francisco area, road accidents and wars - often exact an emotional cost in addition to the physical and financial toll. Disasters give rise to feelings of sorrow, loss, anger, guilt or numbness.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GERONIMO'S PONIES. By Harold Burton Meyers. (Council Oak, Paper, $7.95.) Harold Burton Meyers's debut work of fiction, which won the first National Novella Award, is a beautifully told story of a few weeks in the late 1930's during which young Davey Parker takes a step toward manhood. Mr. Meyers has the enviable ability to set a scene or evoke an emotion with hardly more than a flick of his pen, and his eventful little book is filled with memorable characters.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Cold Spring
description: FOR 93 years, the foundry in Cold Spring - just across the Hudson River from the United States Military Academy at West Point - turned out iron smelted from ore in the nearby hills. Set up with $25,000 allocated by Congress in 1818 and drawing craftsmen from Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England, it made cannon and cannon balls for the Union Army in the Civil War and parts for the first American locomotive.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Jets Have Benched O'Brien?
description: The decision to bench Ken O'Brien for the journeyman Kyle Mackey has deeper implications than the quick-fix remedy for a troubled team. It is this kind of unstable decision making that mirrors the disorganization that is the New York Jets, during the tenure of Joe Walton.

title: Helping Sportsmanship Triumph in Intense Football Rivalry
description: LEAD: ON a recent sparkling fall afternoon in an almost deserted football stadium, a gesture imposed itself, slight and unforgettable.

title: Fighting Addiction: 3 Days in Phoenix House -- A special report.; Struggle and Hope From Ashes of Drugs
description: As though part of an enormous stage set for some brooding morality play, Phoenix House, a drug-treatment center, stands on the edge of a sinister block in the heart of the Morris Heights section of the Bronx. Scrawled across the treatment center's facade in graffiti are the letters C-R-A-C-K.

title: 'Life Goes On' Stretches Reality, Within Reason
description: During a rehearsal the other day inside the family den of the new ABC series ''Life Goes On,'' the actors Kellie Martin and Bill Smitrovich, who play the teen-aged Becca Thacher and her father Drew, ignored the fact that Christopher Burke wasn't on the set. While his dialogue coach stood in for him to feed lines to the other actors, Mr. Burke, who plays Becca's 18-year-old brother Corky, was back in his trailer with his real-life father, learning lines. Like his TV counterpart, Mr. Burke, who is 24, was born with Down's syndrome, a genetic anomoly that causes mental retardation.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Mississippi; 5 Are Disciplined In Racial Prank At Fraternity
description: At the University of Mississippi, where two people were killed in a riot before James H. Meredith enrolled as the first black student 27 years ago this month, a racial incident has provoked strong responses.

title: 'No Exit,' Sartre's Version of Hell
description: ''HELL is other people'' is the standard superficial explanation for the meaning of Jean-Paul Sartre's ''No Exit,'' now at Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre.

title: Elizabeth Greene Weds P. A. Wiley
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Davis Greene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Davis Greene Jr. of Philadelphia, and Peter Alexander Wiley, a son of Welles Wiley of Seattle and the late Cathryn Wiley. The Rev. Peter Sime officiated.

title: Bereavement
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on bereavement fares (Practical Traveler, Sept. 10) was especially timely. I had to attend a funeral on Labor Day. After the news of the death on Saturday evening, I telephoned USAir and requested a bereavement fare for a flight the next morning. The reservations clerk was extremely helpful and said that USAir offered a special fare of $360. However, she suggested I use the Labor Day Weekend fare of $260, if I could take certain flights.

title: Rebecca Moss Wed to Patrick Guyver
description: Rebecca Sarah Moss and Patrick Richard Guyver were married yesterday at St. Gregory-the-Great Church in Stratford-on-Avon, England. The Rev. Placid Sinnott, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Indian News Program Struggles With Censors
description: India's first privately produced news and documentary program, made on videotape for sale and rental, is running into problems with India's film censors as it begins its second year.

title:
WINE;
A Hudson Valley Sampler
description: LEAD: SURPRISINGLY, the shelves of most county retail outlets offer only a token selection of wine made by the 17 nearby Hudson River Valley bonded producers. Inconsistent quality and uncertain availability are the primary reasons cited by shopkeepers for not stocking these wines.

title: Pop Musical Cultures Mined and Mingled
description: Border-crossing has become a 1980's rock ritual. One after another, songwriters become infatuated with some ''exotic'' music, decide to make an album under its influence and collaborate with the top musicians available. At best, star and collaborators inspire one another to synergistic heights. Failing that, the star's fans may have their ears opened, and some might seek out the original sources (which are likely to reach more record stores in the wake of a cross-cultural hit album). The darker possibility is that the star could strip-mine a musical culture, reducing time-etched styles to pop novelties and then move on. Meanwhile, some styles resist assimilation - they just make their would-be borrowers sound clumsy.

title: TRIMMING SCHOOL COSTS: READERS RESPOND; Statistics in Support Of the Indefensible
description: The adage ''Statistics don't lie, statisticians do'' came to mind when I read That Irving Gerber feels comfortable living in ignorance of economic realities is his prerogative. However, selling his ignorance to others is, in his own words, indefensible.

title: DATA BANK: Oct. 22, 1989
Self-Parody as a Part Of the Pop Singer's Art
description: Twenty years ago, an article about Bob Dylan compared his singing to ''hog calling.'' I don't remember the writer or the publication, but the image came back to me recently during a Dylan concert at the Beacon Theater, where the skinny, frizzy-haired rock legend still looked and sounded much like the avenging brat of the mid-1960's. As he sang ''Ballad of a Thin Man,'' the ultimate 60's pop put-down of bourgeois squareness, his abrasive whine still sounded outrageously provocative in its rude insistency.

title: Illinois Edges Michigan State
description: Jeff George threw a 9-yard scoring pass to Mike Bellamy with a little more than a minute to play today to give Illinois a 14-10 Big Ten Conference victory over Michigan State.

title: 'Liaisons Dangereuses' With Its Glossy Veneer
description: PERHAPS for all the wrong reasons, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' has become something of a theatrical epidemic since its Broadway run in a Royal Shakespeare Company production in 1987. Playhouses everywhere appear to be pouncing upon Christopher Hampton's adaptation of the 1782 novel by Choderlos de Laclos.

title: Missed Base Hurt Mathewson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Jets Have Benched O'Brien?
description: Did the Jets make the right move in benching O'Brien?

title: Review/Theater; Vietnam Veterans Ensemble in 'The Ambassador'
description: In his plays, Slawomir Mrozek mixes art and polemics. Sometimes, as in ''Tango'' and ''Emigres,'' his sense of theater is as strong as his political awareness. This is not the case with ''The Ambassador,'' receiving its United States premiere at the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company. With politics taking precedence, the narrative becomes a thin thread on which to hang the author's inquiry into the nature of dissidence and diplomacy during a time of subversion.

title: Bereavement
description: To the Editor: In April 1986 my daughter died suddenly - I was informed in the evening. The first flight to Los Angeles was an American Airlines flight at 9 A.M. I had logged hundreds of thousands of miles on American but was confronted with a bill of over $900 out and back. Even though I asked for some relief, their answer was ''Sorry.'' PATRICIA FOX-SHEINWOLD New York, N.Y.

title: Registering a Clamp on Parking Tickets
description: CITY officials in New Haven, Waterbury and Hartford are taking advantage of a state program to help the five largest municipalities in the state cut down on unpaid parking tickets. Enacted by the General Assembly last spring, the program allows officials at the Motor Vehicle Department to deny vehicle registrations and renewals to drivers with outstanding parking violations.

title: Reviews/Music; Marclay, Hoberman, Sound And Fury
description: Christian Marclay and Perry Hoberman have created a curious mixed-media monster this weekend at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, with the last of four evening performances set for tonight at 8:30.

title: The Pendulum Swings Away From Cynicism
description: In the 1980's art has seemed to suffer from a fin-de-siecle anxiety. The source of that anxiety has been a fundamental skepticism about the possibility of ''making it new.'' Instead of seeming limitless, culture and the world itself have come to be seen as finite, closed systems that have been depleted by overuse. All that is left for artists is to reflect on their own imprisonment in a universe of existing words, forms and images.

title: Not Over Yet
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sag Harbor Gets Ready for 'Sag Harbor'
description: LEAD: SAG HARBOR residents and aficionados are a disparate lot of individualists, but united in unabashed adoration of the centuries-old former whaling port.

title: Nuggets Are Sold
description: They had to accept some outside help and give up their dream of owning a controlling interest, but, as expected, Bertram Lee and Peter Bynoe have resurrected a deal to become the first black owners of a major league franchise, the Denver Nuggets of the National Basketball Association.

title: 'HE IS A DEAR BOY & SO CUTE'
As Expected, Bush Vetoes Bill That Would Pay for Some Abortions
description: As he said he would, President Bush today vetoed a measure that allow the use of Federal money to pay for abortions for poor women made pregnant by rape or incest.

title: Landmarks Appeals Panel Proposed
description: In the ballot on Election Day, New Yorkers will be asked to vote on the proposed city charter in two questions. The first asks whether voters want to approve all the major elements of the proposed new government, including eliminating the Board of Estimate.

title: Bring Back Upper Volta
description: THE PEOPLE OF Chad had good reason to change the name of >Fort-Archambault to >Sarh, and >Fort-Lamy to >Ndjamena: the new names are less warlike, contain no memories of a colonial past and are easier for local residents to pronounce. I will go along with this change in about a year, when I become sure the Chadians mean it and everybody knows where the two cities are.

title: No Luck for Lions In '89 Homecoming
description: Last year, homecoming was especially sweet at Columbia as the Lions ended their record losing streak at 44 games with a victory over Princeton. For homecoming at Wien Stadium this year, the Lions were just hoping to get their first-year coach, Ray Tellier, his first victory at the school and end a losing streak at five games.

title: DARKENING GLOOM IN A STRICKEN CITY
description: Probably no Northern California city was harder hit economically by the earthquake than this picturesque town on the rocky Pacific Coast. Almost all its downtown business district is in ruins, 250 businesses are shut and 2,000 people are out of work.

title: Horning In on the Corner Shoe Repair Store
description: While pounding new heel guards onto a man's ailing loafers, Donald Leafloor wrinkled up his nose and talked about the meaning of shoes. ''People get unbelievably attached to their shoes,'' he said. ''They know that their feet will love them if they put on a good pair. So people have their favorite shoes and they hate to lose them. We save them. Believe me, we save a lot of very sick shoes.''

title: East Berlin Must Move
description: The first reaction to the change of leadership in East Germany was: at last, but what's the difference? Egon Krenz, the new boss of East Berlin, is 52 compared with the ousted Erich Honecker's 77, but that is only a statistical generation change.

title: The Paper Is New, but The News Is Old
description: LEAD: THE Westchester Spy will soon be infiltrating the county. For those who might fear that a notorious double agent is surfacing, rest assured.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
A Heavenly Sweet, The Yemas of Spain
description: LEAD: IN Spain, where yemas are the simplest confections of long-enduring tradition, sweets have for centuries been closely linked with religion. Just consider the names of some of Spain's most heralded pastries and candies: suspiros de monja (nun's sighs); cabello de angel (angel's hair); lengua de obispo (bishop's tongue); orejas de fraile (friar's ears); huesos de santo (saint's bones).

title: GIULIANI MAINTAINS ATTACK ON DINKINS OVER STOCK DEAL
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani entered a critical phase in his Republican-Liberal campaign for mayor of New York City yesterday as he held the feet of his Democratic opponent, David N. Dinkins, to the embers of a stock controversy and launched another attack on Mr. Dinkins's fiscal fitness.

title: 641-Pound Pumpkin Is Titlist
description: LEAD: FROM a tangle of meandering vines that cover the sandy loam on the family vegetable farm in the Jacobstown section here, Robert and Edward Gancarz produce prodigious pumpkins.

title: Milet Andrejevic, 64, Painter and Teacher
description: Milet Andrejevic, an artist and teacher whose work is in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, died of lung cancer Friday night at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: Man Rescued From Rubble of Collapsed Highway
description: Smiling and waving his right hand, a man was pulled alive this morning from the wreckage of the highway overpass that collapsed in Tuesday's earthquake.

title: POSTINGS: Affordable Town Houses; A Push in Putnam
description: In the weak market of the New York suburbs, Joe Cioccolanti thinks he has found a niche. ''There may be a large inventory of unsold homes, but they just aren't affordable,'' said the Putnam County developer, who is offering 75 two-bedroom town-house units in Kent at $129,900 apiece, well below the prices of most new homes in the area.

title: For Sale: 'I Love New York'
description: The Cuomo administration has hired a New York City marketing company to handle franchising of the ''I Love New York'' logo, state officials said today. The company, Hamilton Projects, will be responsible for finding companies that want to use the logo in advertising. Earlier this year the state decided to charge royalties for use of the logo after allowing free use of it for years.

title: Running Out of Space for Nuclear Waste
description: THE problem of what to do with wastes from making nuclear bombs has always been viewed as a long-term issue, posing no immediate threat to life. But events of the last few weeks have demonstrated to the Department of Energy that it can raise more immediate concerns.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Elena Khudiakova: Fashion Designer
description: LEAD: Elena Khudiakova of Moscow has been ''crazy about fashion since childhood, when I made clothes for me and my dolls.''

title: Opposing a Raise For Federal Judges
description: I was intrigued by Federal Judge Harold A. Ackerman's responses to questions concerning the pay increase issue for Federal judges, in a recent New Jersey Q & A. Judge Ackerman's reasons for supporting a raise for the judiciary were at least more substantive than those provided by President Bush and Chief Justice Rehnquist.

title: Sarah E. Swanson Weds P. C. Barry
description: At St. James Episcopal Church in Skaneateles, N.Y., Sarah Elizabeth Swanson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Swanson of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Patrick Charles Barry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Barry of Palmyra, Pa. The Rev. J. Edward Putnam performed the ceremony.

title: Celebrating 'The Artists of Bronxville, 1890-1930'
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of Bronxville may be surprised to learn that their village was once an artists' colony of sorts. Descendants of the painters, sculptors, illustrators, glass and jewelry designers and other talented people who lived there will gather today at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, to celebrate the opening of the show, ''The Artists of Bronxville: 1890-1930.

title: No Headline
description: IN the heart of Moscow, dominating the city, stands the Kremlin, 90 fortressed acres in which Russia's past and present, her ecclesiastical and political legacies join, still a holy place to many Russians, to the world the emblematic center of the Soviet Union.

title: Steven Freeman Weds Ms. Printz
description: Elizabeth A. Printz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Printz of New York and Hillsdale, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday evening to Steven M. Freeman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Freeman of Sergeant Bluffs, Iowa. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Hotel Carlyle.

title: ORDINARY LIFE ALWAYS WENT TOO FAR
description: LEAD: A CARELESS WIDOW And Other Stories. By V. S. Pritchett. 164 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Noriega Might Stay, But the Canal Will Go On
description: UNDER the Panama Canal treaties, a Panamanian is supposed to take over as administrator of the waterway on Jan. 1. But in the last few weeks, the Bush Administration has made clear that that will not happen if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is still ruling Panama. Nevertheless, the canal will continue operating regardless of whether General Noriega retains or surrenders power, American officials say. These officials assert too that the treaties will remain in force, even though there may be problems carrying out some of the provisions.

title: Summer Skiing
description: To the Editor: Summertime skiing in South America (Travel Section, Aug. 20) certainly whetted the appetite of this ardent skier. However, spending $2,000 to $3,000 a couple for a week skiing a South American winter wonderland is a major deterrent, which probably accounts for the paucity of North Americans at their resorts.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
At 21, Are My Best Years Behind Me?
description: LEAD: I recently returned from my junior year abroad, which I spent at the University of London. I was told that this would be the best year of my life and it was.

title: The 'Original' 'Show Boat' Comes to TV, Via New Jersey
description: The only American musical of the 1920's that remains a part of the standard musical theater repertory, the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d ''Show Boat,'' has been revived frequently on Broadway, in the West End, by opera companies and stock and amateur groups, and in the movies.

title: TOUGH TIMES FOR MR. LEVITTOWN
description: Michael Kaufman's article brought back distant memories. From 1950 (my freshman year at Hofstra College) until 1955 (when I received a master's degree in history there), most of my spare waking moments were spent delivering telegrams to many of those 17,311 houses in Levittown, L.I.

title: Classic White Shirt: Still a Fresh Look
description: Diogenes would have been content to find one honest man. Today, many women are content to find one honest white shirt for under $100. Fortunately, there are plenty of sources of quality shirts for less than that, sometimes far less.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope there's someone else left alive. No one is leaving tonight. They don't care how dangerous it is.'' - Jeff Breckenridge, a rescue worker at the Oakland highway overpass. [ 1:3. ]

title: Train to Track Could Use Whip
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stars Lend Scant Luster to News Shows
description: The star reporter, a status once earned by men and women for chasing stories or digging into them, has been replaced on prime-time television by the news-show star, a hybrid like the programs themselves. These glamour-pusses do not do much chasing or digging; sometimes they deign to commit the odd interview, but mainly they are performers, reading lines often written for them in circumstances concocted by their shows' producers.

title: What Should Rise From Catastrophic Law's Ashes; Willing to Pay
description: To the Editor:

J. Raynes) STATEN ISLAND Grasmere $400,000 774 West Fingerboard Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached ranch; dining room, large kitchen, recreation room, fireplace, c/a, 2-car garage, 80- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $3,400 (Broker: Otto Vitale Real Estate) Huguenot $190,000 961 Stafford Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, partially aluminum sided, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: George K. Wonica)

title: THEY LIKE IKE
description: When one former United States President refers to another as a ''chicken-hearted,'' ''weak,'' ''cowering,'' ''dumb son of a bitch'' who ''didn't know anything when he became President and in the years in office he didn't learn anything,'' as Truman says of Eisenhower, the reader has reason to suspect the integrity of what is being written. That sounds more like an embittered old man - embittered, perhaps, because Ike declined when then-President Truman gave him the nod to run on the Democratic ticket, but later walked into the White House, in January 1953, as the first Republican President in 24 years.

title: Leigh Fludd Wed To Peter H. Smith
description: Lisa M. Fludd and Peter H. Smith were married yesterday by Robert J. Walsh Jr., a justice of the peace, at the Silvermine Tavern in Norwalk, Conn. The bride, 24 years old, is the daughter of Victoria S. Jimpson-Fludd of New York and Michael G. Fludd of Teaneck, N.J. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Smith of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Elizabeth Sanford Weds
description: Elizabeth H. Sanford, the assistant circulation director of Life magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Jack R. Horstmeyer, the director of advertising and creative services for Doubleday Book and Music Clubs Inc. in Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Jean Smith officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. Ms. Sanford, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mrs. Laurence H. Sanford Jr. of Princeton and the late Mr. Sanford. Her husband is the son of Mrs. Richard C. Horstmeyer of Garden City and the late Mr. Horstmeyer.

title: Feisty Devils Win, 5-4
description: Feistiness and persistence characterized the play of the Devils tonight against the Canadiens as New Jersey ended an eight-game streak without a victory at the Forum.

title: LOOK DEEP INTO YOUR LIFE
description: ALL NEW PEOPLE By Anne Lamott. 166 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $16.95.

title: Los Angeles Prepares for the Big One
description: The dimly lit parking lot of the Virginia Street Elementary School in downtown Los Angeles was filled with stretchers and simulated cries of pain.

title: Nancy R. Tooker and Richard J. Davis Are Wed
description: Nancy R. Tooker and Richard J. Davis were married yesterday in their New York home by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Managua Puts Cloaks and Daggers on Display
description: After years of secret C.I.A. operations against the Sandinista Government, Nicaraguans lined up this week for a firsthand look inside the spymasters' tool kit.

title: Gutter Cleaning and Repair
description: CLEANING and repairing gutters is best done in the spring and fall, but if you can find time to do this job only once a year, fall gutter maintenance is the more important.

title: Reviews/Music; Century Hopping by the Camerata Bern
description: The Camerata Bern, a Swiss ensemble which at full strength comprises 14 string players and a harpsichordist, hopped back and forth through four centuries of music on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Talking Their Way Out of Trouble
description: THE sign outside the door reads: ''Center for Dispute Resolution. School Mediation Program.'' Behind the closed door and away from the clanging of lockers that signaled the end of classes, four students huddled at a small table in a basement room of Gorton High School here, hammering out a solution to a conflict between two teen-agers.

title: Brokers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: The Elk's Autumn Descent
description: LEAD: AUTUMN is the season of the elk near Jackson, Wyo. Snowstorms sweep across the 8,000-foot plateau of Yellowstone National park in early or middle September and bring summer to an abrupt end. The largest elk herd in the world drops down out of the high, fair-weather meadows and heads for low-lying winter range where the climate is less severe.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Big Books about espionage, flying, adventure or what have you are very much a la mode these days. They tend to run well over 300 pages, many over 400, and whatever their subject they all seem to read alike.

title:
DANCE;
The Princeton Ballet Links Itself to a Star
description: LEAD: USING last year's formula of linking its name to that of a dance celebrity, the Princeton Ballet has invited Fernando Bujones to share the program on Saturday at the State Theater here.

title: Badminton Fans Boast of Feathers and Aerobics
description: On Friday nights, Larry Hudak and his wife, Ginny, join as many as 60 people for a relaxing dinner cooked by friends and a few games of badminton. The action is not in a backyard, though. It is at the Gut 'n Feathers Club, a badminton club in this affluent coastal town known for its sailing and social traditions.

title:
GARDENING;
For Autumnal Color, Maples From Asia
description: LEAD: WHILE two native maples, the sugar maple (Acer saccharum) and the red maple (Acer rubrum), are unexcelled for fall color, the rest of the native maples are either not widely planted in this area or not noted for their exceptional autumn foliage. Some European or Eurasian species turn yellow at best.

title: Alfred Hayes, 79, Retired Chief Of the Reserve Bank of New York
description: Alfred Hayes, who headed the Federal Reserve Bank of New York until 1975 and played a pivotal role in the national and world banking systems for nearly two decades, died yesterday at a nursing home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 79 years old and a longtime resident of New Canaan.

title: Before Buying, School the Ears
description: Before demonstrating a loudspeaker in his showroom, Alan C. Neubauer, one of New York City's more astute audio salesmen, asks his clients, ''When were you last at a live concert?'' He believes that a recent experience of live music helps his customers choose loudspeakers that will give them the most pleasure in the long run. Unless the true sound of music is fresh in the ear, says Mr. Neubauer, customers have no yardstick by which to measure the quality of what they are about to buy and may regret their choice later.

title: Jill M. Goldberg Weds Alan Mann
description: Jill Marla Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Goldberg of Great Neck, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Alan James Mann, the son of Mrs. Robert Horowitz of Newton, Mass. The ceremony was performed at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor Howard M. Stahl.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Danbury, Conn. $150,000 22 Barnum Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old ranch; brick fireplace, walk-out basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,640. Darien, Conn. $1,125,000 64 St. Nicholas Road 8-bedroom, 5-bath, 19-year-old garrison colonial; pool, 3-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $7,431. Portland, Conn. $171,500 48 Prospect Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; extra large rooms, 2-car attached garage, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,910. Armonk, N.Y. $575,000 19 Green Valley Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; family room w/fireplace, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $6,753. Bedford, N.Y. $673,000 Kilborn Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; 2 fireplaces, family room, study, deck, 4 acres; taxes not yet assessed. Rye, N.Y. $538,000 8 Hammond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; family room, 2 flagstone patios, 2-car garage, 0.23 acre; taxes $5,401. OTHER AREAS Belmar, N.J. $105,000 217 19th Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; eat-in-kitchen, screened porch, h/w floors; taxes $1,674. Brick Township, N.J. $114,900 136 Ashwood Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, full basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,406. Sayville, L.I. $160,000 20 Hamilton Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 53-year-old colonial; basement, porch, attic; taxes $3,200.

title: What Should Rise From Catastrophic Law's Ashes
description: To the Editor:

title: Lydia Gray to Wed R. S. Bartholow Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gray Jr. of New York and Haverhill, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lydia Beatriz Gray to R. Stephen Bartholow Jr., the son of Anne Ford and Mr. Bartholow, both of Dallas. A December wedding is planned.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Bivalve Gluttony

title: Vibrant Majolica Handmade in Italy
description: SINCE the early Renaissance, Deruta has produced much of Italy's most exuberant and refined majolica, the handcrafted ceramics developed by Italians in the 14th century. The colorful, lavishly decorated objects were collected by kings and nobles, given as love tokens and prized by museums. ''One of the purest expressions of Italian Renaissance culture,'' noted Laurence Kanter, curator of the Robert Lehman collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Slow Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: More Adventures in Publishing
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Correction
description: The headline of a theater review last Sunday about two plays performed by Repertorio Espanol as ''Nelson 2 Rodrigues'' characterized them incorrectly. They are Brazilian, but were performed largely in Spanish.

title: Scharr's Passing Leads Syracuse Romp
description: The Syracuse team that was supposed to be so intimidating this season finally emerged at Rutgers Stadium today as the Orangemen routed the Scarlet Knights, 49-28.

title: American Modern Isn't at Home in Germany
description: Two new works presented this month in New York - ''Mayday'' by Lucinda Childs and ''Machandel'' by Reinhild Hoffmann - are at such opposite extremes that certain premises about a general cultural consensus can no longer to be taken for granted.

title: Lack of Mass Transit Affects Employment
description: Senator Frank Lautenberg's fine article (''Reducing the Labor Shortage,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 3) on the labor shortage in this state, with emphasis on high unemployment in urban areas, did not address a major reason for this state of affairs: lack of available mass transit.

title: An All-American City Strives To Maintain Racial Diversity
description: IN 1971, Look magazine heralded Bloomfield as an all-American city, for creating a community in which blacks and whites lived together. Now, nearly two decades later, Bloomfield is struggling to maintain its racial diversity.

title: RETURN TO THE KILLING FIELDS
description: Dith Pran and Dr. Haing S. Ngor join with Nien Cheng and Elie Wiesel as having survived three of the darkest, most brutal regimes of the 20th century and then somehow summoned the strength to report to the world the atrocities they experienced (''Return to the Killing Fields,'' Sept. 24). I believe it is the hope of these courageous survivors that their recollections may prevent the world from allowing such acts to take place again.

title: Role of Sectarian Institutions in Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on Oct. 8 about a comeback for fixed-rate mortgages misidentified a lender. It is the Home Mortgage Acceptance Corporation.

title: MEGADEALERS: DOES SIZE MEAN POWER
description: To capitalize on the downturn, some dealers have shifted into an acquisition mode. The DiFeos, for one, now have 35 franchises mainly in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. And the family, which now sells all but 6 of the 40 makes on the market in this country, hopes to buy five more franchises in the next year.

title: Vincent Makes A Rough Climb To the Top Spot
description: Fay Vincent's presence in baseball has been so intertwined with the brief tenure of Bart Giamatti as commissioner that it took an earthquake to give Vincent his own identity.

title: Reviews/Music; Improvising In Two Fashions
description: The opening concert of P.S. 122's Hearings series on Wednesday night had a good concept: the double bill of Irene Schweizer and Maggie Nichols, who have a large following in Europe, and Anthony Coleman and Jim Pugliese showed the differences between European and American improvising styles. It was a nice idea, but unfortunately the performances, except for an occasional burst of energy, sagged.

title: Defining Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Ghoulies and Ghosties With Senses of History
description: Twenty-five years ago, legend has it, Eliza Jumel stood on the balcony of her Washington Heights home and shouted ''Shut up!'' at a group of neighborhood schoolchildren. But Mrs. Jumel had died a century earlier. This is one of the most famous of New York's ghost stories - and there are many. With Halloween approaching, there are three supposedly haunted houses in the metropolitan region for the adventurous to visit.

title: Reviews/Music; Schiff's Central European Assortment
description: Sometimes the art of program-making rightly usurps the normal pleasures that attend concertgoing. Sometimes the very intelligence with which an artist has juxtaposed scores on a program seems so arresting that it takes natural precedence over the individual pieces or their performance, however excellent they may be.

title: Gene Tests Planned to Settle Claims on Girl
description: A couple who claim their daughter was switched with another girl in a hospital maternity ward have promised not to seek custody of the girl in exchange for an agreement on genetic testing to settle the dispute.

title: POSTINGS: Project Conference; Bronx Prospects
description: Anyone interested in learning more about three major Bronx development proposals may attend ''The Bronx Is Up! Accomplishments and Future Projects,'' a half-day conference on Thursday from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. sponsored by the New York City Department of City Planning. The session will be held at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse at 165th Street.

title: Anne Garmey and A. H. Clutz to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Garmey of Boston and Stockbridge, Mass., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter Anne Squires Garmey and Andrew Hunter Clutz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard B. Clutz of Williamstown, Mass.

title: No Abortion Session in Texas
description: In a move that stunned opponents of abortion, Gov. William P. Clements Jr. has decided not to put the issue on the agenda of either of two scheduled special sessions of the State Legislature.

title:
GARDENING;
For Autumnal Color, Maples From Asia
description: LEAD: WHILE two native maples, the sugar maple (Acer saccharum) and the red maple (Acer rubrum), are unexcelled for fall color, the rest of the native maples are either not widely planted in this area or not noted for their exceptional autumn foliage. Some European or Eurasian species turn yellow at best.

title: Indian Cemetery Center of Dispute
description: LEAD: THE simple circles of white stones facing the rising sun were recognized for previous milleniums as Indian grave markers. On the East End, however, they now indicate complex knots of interests.

title: About Cars; Subaru Comes a Long Way
description: It has been six months since my friend Huey Kenniff bought his Subaru Legacy, but he continues to love it. He talks about it all the time, and I have told him he has a good shot at boring me to death.

title: NONFICTION
description: ISTANBUL INTRIGUES. By Barry Rubin. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) Throughout World War II, neutral Turkey remained an oasis attracting refugees, political plotters, deserters, profiteers, assassins, international beauties, journalists and spies. High-stakes intrigue became Turkey's national industry, even as bombers, tanks and death camps were laying waste to much of Europe. Romantic legends of adventure and espionage were born amid the shadows and seedy glitter of wartime Istanbul, and the historic bases of these legends are the subject of ''Istanbul Intrigues.'' A stream of vignettes introduces such leading players as Franz von Papen, Hitler's suavely duplicitous Ambassador to Turkey, and George V. Earle, a brawling former United States Ambassador to Bulgaria. Along the way we meet a host of rival spies from the fledgling American O.S.S., the British M.I.6, the Soviet N.K.V.D. and two bitterly competing Nazi spy organizations, the Abwehr and the Sicherheitsdienst. Players in the narrative include prominent Zionists, a future pope, Zsa Zsa Gabor and Cicero, the renowned Axis spy whose job as valet to the British Ambassador enabled him to steal Allied plans for the invasion of France. Barry Rubin, whose previous books include ''Modern Dictators'' and ''Secrets of State,'' marshals an immense amount of archival material to show that despite their frenetic efforts, the legion of foreign agents working in Turkey accomplished little in changing the course of the war. As history, ''Istanbul Intrigues'' is informative, but as entertainment it is somewhat disappointing. The author tries to cover so much ground that most of the hundreds of fascinating characters in his narrative are spared only a few tantalizing lines. The result is more a catalogue of names than a collection of biographical sketches, and the reader is left hungry for more nourishing fare.

title: I.B.M.'s Urbane New Place in the Sun in Texas
description: The first sign that Solana is not like other suburban office parks is the three 100-foot-tall pylons - one magenta, one purple, one yellow - that stand in the rolling Texas prairie like pieces of a gargantuan building toy left in a thousand-acre backyard. The pylons announce Solana's presence from a mile down the freeway, and they foretell the nature of its architecture, a series of stucco-clad buildings with intense, rich color and a surprisingly urbane presence. Solana, which means ''sunny place'' in Spanish, looks from a distance as if it might be a resort, not a suburban office and retail complex: its buildings are all low, and its 900-acre site is lushly landscaped. But this place is not, in fact, part of the new trend toward making suburban offices so sybaritic that they resemble getaway islands; Solana is quite rigorous in its design, and for all its elaborate landscaping and lively architecture it actually has more of the qualities of a true village than almost any other suburban development of the last few years. This is a place whose design begins to address the critical problems of suburban office parks everywhere: how to deal honestly with the infuriatingly necessary automobile, and how to create a convincing and meaningful sense of place.

title: Mary A. Krieger, Lawyer, to Marry
description: The engagement of Mary Allana Krieger to Dennis Russell O'Brien has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Krieger of Summit, N.J. Mr. O'Brien is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. O'Brien of Elizabeth, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: TRIMMING SCHOOL COSTS: READERS RESPOND; The 'Good Old Days' May Rest in Peace
description: I have spent the last 33 years with the Huntington School District. When I began in 1956, we had one superintendent and an assistant superintendent. There were no therapists or teachers for the blind. We did have three classes for the ''retarded.'' Classes for the learning disabled, emotionally disturbed and handicapped were unknown.

title: Landmarks Hearing
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has schedule a public hearing on whether to designate the Guggenheim Museum a city landmark. The hearing is to be held Dec. 12 at 9:30 A.M. at City Hall.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL

title: THE EARTHQUAKE'S TOLL IN 8 COUNTIES
description: ALAMEDA: Thirty bodies recovered from collapsed section of Interstate 880. Maybe 97 to 167 people still missing. Countywide, 320 injuries reported and $1.3 billion damage. No water in city of Alameda, near Oakland. SAN FRANCISCO: Ten deaths; 300 injured. Mayor's office estimates $2 billion in property losses. Most electricity restored except in the Marina district, where 60 buildings were destroyed and a block of apartments burned. Two main state office buildings closed. SAN MATEO: No deaths, 282 injuries, damage estimated at $35 million. Flights into and out of San Francisco International Airport limited because of control tower damage. Thousands of gallons of raw sewage spilled into San Francisco Bay after electricity was lost at a pumping station. SANTA CRUZ: Five deaths reported in city of Santa Cruz; 862 injuries. Damage estimated at $750 million. Twenty downtown buildings must be razed. As many as 10,000 people homeless. Mountain passes closed by landslides and fissures in roads. Two bridges damaged. Eight injuries and an estimated $100 million damage in Watsonville. Major structural damage in Scotts Valley. SANTA CLARA: Five deaths, 900 injuries. Damage estimated at $260 million. SAN BENITO: No deaths. Seventy-five minor injuries. Damage estimated at $100 million. Highway 101 closed by bridge collapse. All water contaminated. MONTEREY: One person dead in fall from water tank in Moss Landing. Six injuries. Damage estimated at $50 million to $100 million. Salinas sustained $3.6 million in damage. In Moterey, state-operated Robert Louis Stevenson house damaged. MARIN: No deaths, minimal damage. Several stores damaged, including glass store in San Rafael where 15 tons of glass were smashed. Roof of a Safeway store in Ignacio partly fell in. (Source: Associated Press)

title: Bereavement
description: To the Editor: The article on bereavement convinced me that United Airlines is misleading the media about its policy. While the airline obviously told Betsy Wade (as they have told other reporters) that they operate on a ''case by case'' basis, I believe their claim is bogus.

title: Soviet Military Officers Pressing For Changes and a Trade Union
description: Despite fears of possible reprisals from the Soviet Defense Ministry, present and former officers banded together today to press for improved conditions and political changes in the armed forces, including creation of an independent military trade union.

title: FICTION
description: THE DEAD PULL HITTER. By Alison Gordon. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Mystery buffs who also happen to be baseball fans can enjoy both pastimes at once in ''The Dead Pull Hitter,'' an energetic first novel by the Toronto sportswriter Alison Gordon. The lineup of Ms. Gordon's fictional Toronto Titans includes all the archetypes of baseball lore - crafty veterans and insufferable superstars, good-hearted heroes and washed-up sluggers struggling to eke out one more season. With equal measures of cynicism and sympathy, Ms. Gordon also captures the flavor of the game off the field: a hot-shot agent is rumored to have ruined a budding star who dared to break his contract with him; a second-rate catcher turned public relations man wears the look of ''all the baseball dreams that never come true.'' The most acute observer of these goings-on is Ms. Gordon's narrator (and apparent alter ego), Kate Henry, a 40-year-old baseball writer who covers the Titans for The Toronto Planet. She also turns amateur detective when Pedro (Sultan) Sanchez, the team's designated hitter, is found murdered in his apartment the day the team clinches its first division title, and Cy Young Award winner Steve (Stevie the K) Thorson is beaten to death with a baseball bat in the team's locker room the evening after. The reader can guess what happens next: Kate and Staff Sgt. Lloyd Munro, the detective assigned to the case, meet, flirt, compete and eventually work together to nab the murderer. Some of the clues are obvious and there are holes in the plot, but the authentic, often flaky details of daily baseball life still make diverting reading.

title: Brokers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama Derails Tennessee
description: Gary Hollingsworth, who started this season as Alabama's backup quarterback, and Siran Stacy, a tailback who played junior college football last year, ripped Tennessee's defense apart today in a Southeastern Conference battle of previously unbeaten teams.

title: Jan Wurtzburger Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jon A. Wurtzburger of New York and Bedford, N.Y., have made known December wedding plans for their daughter Jan Wurtzburger and Talbot A. Hack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Syria Said to Agree to Relocate Some Beirut Troops
description: Syria has agreed to relocate some of its troops in Beirut, a development that may move Lebanese lawmakers closer to agreeing on a peace plan for their country, people attending the peace conference here said today.

title: Jaunts Keep County's 'Senior Bus' Busy
description: MORE of the county's older residents are getting out and about lately, thanks to a new ''senior bus'' that is being made available 365 days (and nights) a year by the Westchester County Office for the Aging.

title: California Struggles With The Other Side Of Its Dream
description: FROM the beginning, California has been the American symbol of opportunity, freedom, renewal, sunny paradise and human dominion over a land that was as beautiful as it was terrible. Dams and aqueducts brought water into the desert, where vast cities and farms blossomed. Dramatic bridges and mammoth freeways turned small towns into powerful cities. Roads were terraced into steep hillsides and houses were cantilevered along canyon walls.

title: TRIMMING SCHOOL COSTS: READERS RESPOND; Education Costs: Well Worth the Price
description: Re ''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education'' (Opinion, Sept. 24): I am outraged. I am a New York City schoolteacher, born and bred in Merrick.

title: In Bronx, Bitterness On Garcia
description: Few constituents in Robert Garcia's South Bronx district said yesterday that they understood all the facts behind his extortion and conspiracy conviction, but several were certain of two things - Mr. Garcia had let them down and had hurt the prospects of other Hispanic people seeking public office.

title: Confessions of a Seat Strategist
description: AS a fairly frequent traveler, I have to confess I'm confused by the fuss over nonsmoking sections on trains and airplanes. Not that I particularly enjoy sitting next to smokers (I don't). It's just that smoke seems a minor irritation compared with the real issues that divide us.

title: TOUGH TIMES FOR MR. LEVITTOWN
description: My parents' first house was built by the Levitts, in Levittown, L.I. (''Tough Times for Mr. Levittown,'' by Michael T. Kaufman, Sept. 24). I look back on it fondly. It was nicely laid out, had a fireplace and the floors were always warm. The neighborhood was friendly, with lots of kids to play with.

title:
ART;
Stage Designs by Aronson, A Master of Visual Metaphor
description: LEAD: SET designers are rarely stars, but at the Katonah Gallery the name of Boris Aronson is in lights. Mr. Aronson designed his first Broadway set in 1932 (for ''Walk a Little Faster'') and subsequently designed the sets for more than 100 productions, including ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and ''Cabaret.''

title: Hong Kong on Borrowed Time
description: EARLIER THIS MONTH, WHILE CHINA'S LEADERS WERE staging a grandiose celebration of their revolution's 40th birthday, thousands of somber Hong Kong residents gathered for a dreary commemoration of their own. Far from the fireworks display in Beijing, Hong Kongers huddled in a rainstorm near the bronze statue of Queen Victoria, singing patriotic songs and listening to mournful poems dedicated to those who died in Tiananmen Square.

title: SEEDING TIME
description: FALL IS THE SEASON WHEN MOST people's thoughts turn to the harvest.

title: Harvard-Army: An Elucidation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Krenz Gives Bonn Reason To Wait for Reunification
description: ALREADY in his first few days in office, the new East German leader, Egon Krenz, has given West Germany what Communist news agencies like to call a ''resolute rebuff.'' Though he did not directly address reunification - the very term is largely taboo in a state that would vanish in a single Germany - Mr. Krenz haughtily rejected ''tutelage'' from outside. He told church leaders it was important to preserve a separate East Germany, and he told workers that while he hoped to let them travel much more freely abroad, the automatic citizenship offered by West Germany still posed problems.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large kitchen with 25-year-old cabinets covered with a brown matte-finish plastic laminate. We would like to paint these cabinets white. How can we make paint stick to this laminate?

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Williams; Rugby Players Come Under Fire For Beer Practice
description: Beer practice has been a tradition at Williams College ''for longer than anyone can remember,'' says the president of the Williams Rugby Football Club, J. Chapman Petersen.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Television section today carries some listings that have become outdated because of the California earthquake, which occurred after the section had gone to press. Coverage of the World Series, on ABC, is tentatively scheduled to begin on Tuesday night. Updated listings will appear on The Times's daily television page. Changes for today are in the Late Television Listings in this section, on page 39.

title: After Quake, Talks Break Up and Business Is Left Unfinished
description: The last time John Schuerholz was seen in San Francisco, the Kansas City Royals' general manager was standing in a darkened hotel lobby wearing a set of lighted antennae on his head, something like John Belushi used to wear as a Killer Bee on ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Smaller Solar
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Scoring
description: Wayne Gretzky may be gone from the Edmonton Oilers, but last week he gave the still adoring fans of his former team another reason not to forget him. Playing in Edmonton with the visiting Los Angeles Kings, his team since a trade in 1988, the Great Gretzky, as he is known, became the greatest scorer in the history of the National Hockey League. His goal late in the third period broke Gordie Howe's record of 1,850 points scored over 26 seasons. Mr. Gretzky is only 28 years old and set his mark barely into his 11th season. Mr. Howe was the boyhood idol of Mr. Gretzky and the two first met in 1972 when Mr. Gretzky was 11 years old. At the time, Mr. Howe offered some advice to the future No. 99: work on the backhand. Mr. Howe, who was on hand to see his record broken with a backhanded shot, predicted that Mr. Gretzky will reach 3,000 points before he is through. Mr. Gretzky said it was ''only fitting'' that he set the record in Edmonton's Northlands Coliseum, where he played for nine seasons and where a bronze statue of him stands at the entrance. Said a teammate, ''I don't know who writes his script, but it was just perfect.''

title: Review/Music; Vietnamese Pianist in U.S. Debut
description: A pianist of considerable abilities made his American debut at the 92d Street Y Thursday night. Dang Thai Son was the winner of the 1980 Chopin Competition in Warsaw, and has garnered various other honors over the past decade. It was possible to hear something of the consensus-oriented approach we often worry about with competition pianists in his polished, secure, unmannered playing, but there was no mistaking a true and varied command of the instrument and a feeling for musical shapes and pianistic textures that could yet blossom into true interpretative individuality.

title: Claire's Romance With God
description: THE GOLDEN THREAD By Ann Copeland. 274 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: The Serendipitous Appeal of Eurailpass
description: WHEN the Eurailpass was introduced by the railroads of Europe in 1959, Americans of our generation instantly recognized our travel ideal in an affordable ticket offering unlimited access for a set period to all the trains that crisscrossed the Continent. We were young adventurers, about to become children of the 1960's, and we valued the very things that the Eurailpass not only made possible but also celebrated: thrift, spontaneity, simplicity, a sense of camaraderie with other travelers and the opportunity for contact with local people.
