The Eurailpass went with Icelandic Airlines, backpacks, guitar cases, youth hostels, hitchhiking, bed-and-breakfast inns and daily picnics of French bread and cheese and rough red wine. As our ticket - our pass - to the great monuments of Europe, Eurail made possible a hip, democratic version of that classic initiation rite, the grand tour.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Churches as Builders; A Struggle Over Sites in the South Bronx
description: IN the waning days of the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, it is still uncertain whether a housing production program that could bring Nehemiah-style one-family houses to vacant, city-owned land in the South Bronx will ever get started.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Spain and Italy Marry Happily
description: Some of the most popular restaurants in this country carry names likes and Chinois, signaling the combinations of French and Asian foods they serve. So why should anyone raise an eyebrow if an American chef decides to combine the best of an Italian cooking technique with a deservedly popular Spanish recipe?

title: Talks in Paris on Protecting Antarctica Fail
description: After two weeks of negotiations, delegates to an international conference on the Antarctic have been unable to agree on measures to protect the continent's environment, and they say that next year they might consider making it a global nature reserve.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large kitchen with 25-year-old cabinets covered with a brown matte-finish plastic laminate. We would like to paint these cabinets white. How can we make paint stick to this laminate?

title: I.R.A. Gunmen Kill an Officer
description: Gunmen ambushed a police car in South Armagh province, killing an officer and wounding another, the police said today. The Irish Republican Army in South Armagh asserted responsibility for the machine-gun attack in Belleek, about 10 miles north of the border with the Irish Republic. Constable Michael Marshall, 25 years old, died instantly, the police said. His 21-year-old colleague, who was not identified, was seriously wounded in the legs and a shoulder.

title: ''We Think of Adoption as a Triangle''
description: AS the number of healthy American infants available for adoption decreases, infertile couples are increasingly seeking alternatives, said Estelle LaChance, the adoption program coordinator for Catholic Family Services of the Diocese of Bridgeport. These options include adopting infants or children from other countries, those with special needs or older children.

title: A Double Whammy for the Insurers
description: Insurance companies operate in the shadow of the ''big ones.'' These are the brutal storms and earthquakes that strike every so often, crippling cities and forcing insurers to write out bundles of checks. In their planning, insurance company executives expect a big one to occur at worst about once every three to five years.

title: It's Time to Accept the New Russian Image at Face Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Dance; Capucilli and Rooks
description: ''Dark Meadow,'' a 1946 work that the Martha Graham Dance Company presented last Sunday night at the City Center Theater, is both allegorically complex and ambiguous. It shows a woman venturing into some strange, dangerous place. There are mythological motifs borrowed from many cultures, as well as recurrent symbols of sex, martyrdom, death and resurrection. Yet dancegoers are left free to interpret them in whatever way they think appropriate.

title: What Is Fukuyama Saying? And to Whom Is He Saying It?
description: THE YEAR 2000 FAST APPROACHES, and millennial doom is in the air. Global warming, nuclear proliferation, chaos in Eastern Europe. Even the notion of post is over. Post-modernism, post-history, post-culture (to borrow the critic George Steiner's term) - we're beyond that now. "The sun is about to set on the post-industrial era," declares the economist Lester C. Thurow in The New York Times.

title:
ART;
3 Distinct Voices at Awards Show
description: LEAD: THE three artists being honored with awards exhibitions at the Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton take considerable liberties with landscape (Sona Hoefman), figures (Barbara Schwartz) or multidimensional forms (Richard Wands). The presentation is unusual, for each show makes the artist's sources and idea development quite clear.

title: Chicago Schools Try A Radical New Cure
description: EVEN as President Bush's education summit last month called for reforming the nation's school systems, Chicago was well on its way to laying the groundwork for the most radical school restructuring ever attempted in the United States.

title: Pipe Organs
description: To the Editor: As a longtime organist, I share Craig R. Whitney's enthusiasm for experiencing various instruments (''Pursuing Pipe Organs of Note,'' Travel, Aug. 13) and, like him, I am well aware that no two pipe organs sound alike.

title: My 7 Visitors And How They Really Love to Eat
description: MY deck stands in the waddle path of the neighborhood's raccoons. There are seven of them: Rocky, Baby, Sherwood, Scruffy, Prince, Charles and Spot.

title: TALKING: Modulars; Cottages For the Elderly
description: THE option of creating an accessory unit - an apartment in a single-family house or a separate cottage on the house lot - has long been important to many homeowners, especially the elderly and families with limited incomes.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 24 about fall foliage omitted a phone number for Pennsylvania. While the state has no separate phone number for tracking foliage, maps and information about fall activities are available at 800-847-4872.

title: Changes Sought in Teacher Arbitration
description: LEAD: DEMOCRATIC and Republican legislative leaders expect a bipartisan effort in the upcoming General Assembly session to revise Connecticut's teacher arbitration law.

title: Reviews/Music; Gosdin's Songs of Pain
description: Vern Gosdin's voice resonates with country tradition - the conversational, smoke-cured twang of George Jones and Ernest Tubb, holding back pain with quiet dignity. But what brought an admiring cult to the Lone Star on Thursday night for a rare New York performance by Mr. Gosdin was his songs, which are the work of a specialist - or a man obsessed.

title: Karen Griffin, Ad Executive, Weds Clay T. Barnes
description: Karen Elizabeth Griffin, the daughter of Thomas L. Griffin of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Maria Teresa Ermini of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Clay Timothy Barnes, a son of John E. Barnes and Cynde Barnes, both of Logansport, Ind. The Rev. David Heetland, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Alice Millar Chapel at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill.

title: John A. Redmond, Executive, Plans To Be Married to Janalee Salestrom
description: Vem R. Salestrom of Omaha and R. D. Salestrom of Phoenix have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Janalee Salestrom and John Alexander Redmond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Redmond of Washington and Dark Harbor, Me.

title: Elizabeth Douglass Sands Is Married To Talmage Petty, Executive, on L.I.
description: Elizabeth Douglass Sands, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Keating Sands of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Lawrence Talmage Petty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Petty of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Catherine Hilda Sands, a sister of the bride, was the maid of honor. Robert Dean Petty was his brother's best man.

title: Spain's Seldom-Seen Province
description: LEAD: EXTREMADURA is one of the least visited provinces of Spain and, considering its special beauty and excellent hotels, this is hard to understand. It has not been rich since Roman times, when monuments such as the theater at Merida were built, and as a result its treasures - among them the finest Roman ruins in Spain - have survived remarkably well.

title: Brokers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: 2-Point Goal a First
description: Trivia buffs take note: The first 2-point goal in the history of lacrosse was scored yesterday by Greg Kelly, a Johns Hopkins midfielder from Northport, L.I., in a game against Loyola College of Baltimore in a four-team tournament at the University of Maryland Baltimore County branch in Catonsville, Md.

title: Social Events
description: Musical Remembrance

title: Court's Reporter Jailed To Finish a Transcript
description: A court's reporter has been in jail more than two weeks for failing to finish a trial transcript that an appeals court has been waiting for so that it can consider a murder conviction.

title: INDIA WITHOUT NONSENSE
description: ''O new Palms!!! O flowers!! O creatures!! O beasts!! Violent and amazing delight at the wonderful variety of life and dress here. . . . Colours, and costumes, and myriadism of impossible picturesqueness!!!'' So exclaimed Edward Lear in his diary with characteristic enthusiasm in 1873 when he arrived in Bombay for what was to be his last extended journey. Besides offering some of the watercolors Lear made on that last visit to India, IMPOSSIBLE PICTURESQUENESS: Edward Lear's Indian Watercolours, 1873-1875 (Columbia University Press, $65) is also a richly delicate feast of some of Lear's finest and least-known work. The constant sense of delight and whimsy that permeates the journals and notations Lear habitually made when he was drawing makes clear the single vision that links the graphic and written work of the brilliant creator of limericks and nonsense verse. Vidya Dehejia, who teaches art history and archeology at Columbia University, reveals in her selections from the journals, and in her informed remarks thereon, the way in which this worldly sophisticate, who was at home in a variety of settings, remained at heart an Englishman. He thought the sky in Calcutta was reminiscent of Manchester, and Cawnpore was like Sussex. During a monsoon in Poona, it was ''all flat and wet, reminding me of Cambridgeshire.'' The watercolor drawings themselves are light and precise, with features of architectural detail, terrain, flora and fauna more thoroughly rendered than human figures, which Lear tended to treat more abstractly. Allen Staley, a professor of art history at Columbia, titles his perceptive essay ''The Painter of Topographical Poetry.'' This is a perfect characterization. Above all, these are pictures that are intelligent and poetic reports on places as they looked, on a particular day at a particular time, to a worldly, weary self-described ''globular foolish topographer.''

title: Bereavement
description: To The Editor: The article on bereavement fares could not have been more timely for my family. My wife's mother had passed away that morning in Buffalo, and she had already made regular fare reservations to fly there that evening. After reading your article, my wife called back to USAir and was able to change the reservations for herself and our daughter, resulting in a savings of $172. ERIC C. WILLIAMS Pelham, N.Y.

title: Brokers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Facts Daunt Israeli Researcher
description: As Meron Benvenisti sees it, Israelis of both the left and the right refuse to allow the facts to get in the way.

title: Tax Issue Splits Gulotta and Korn
description: AS he tries to become the first Democratic county executive in 20 years, Richard Korn, is seeking to picture the incumbent, Thomas S. Gulotta, as a fiscally irresponsible politician who makes special deals with his developer friends and who deceives the county's taxpaying citizens.

title: For Victims of the Hurricane, Pain and Uncertainty Linger
description: Every morning for almost a month, 75-year-old Harper McNeil has climbed into his rusted 1972 station wagon and driven to the debris-strewn site where Hurricane Hugo obliterated his trailer home Sept. 21.

title: Abstractions by John Golding at Yale Center for British Art
description: AS an art historian, John Golding may know more than is good for him as a painter. He has, nevertheless, kept the two disciplines going for some 30 years, writing about Modernism and Modernists and having frequent exhibitions of his own work. Most of these have been in London and the one now at Yale Center for British Art marks his debut in the United States.

title: A New Leader Carries On An Orchestra's Tradition
description: In the first three decades of the microgroove era, there was no symphonic ensemble more conspicuous in the form of recordings than the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande, which London/Decca seemed to favor for introducing each successive development in the technique of sound recording. The orchestra, founded in 1918 by Ernest Ansermet, achieved international recognition as a direct result of its recording activity, which kept it so busy at its home base in Geneva that there was little time for touring until relatively recently.

title: WHAT'S DOING AROUND: Raleigh
description: LEAD: More than any other, the word campus defines the three-city region known as the Research Triangle.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Murphy
description: The engagement of Mary Elaine Murphy and John Markert Arnold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Arnold of Summit, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Murphy of Trenton. A November wedding is planned.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: Flipping through the November auction catalogue of Bowers and Merena, Inc., the auction house in Wolfeboro, N.H., one is struck by the great number and diversity of coins. They range from New Jersey coppers to counterfeits to medical tokens. But the last entry, an obscure 1744 Austrian token, has politics, religion and sex, three things that mothers say should never be discussed at dinner.

title: Amy Kiernan Marries Griffith E. Lewis
description: The wedding of Anne Madeleine Kiernan and Griffith Eric Lewis took place yesterday at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Albany. The Most Rev. Howard Hubbard, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany, officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Peter DeLacy Kiernan of Albany, Hobe Sound, Fla., and Oyster Harbors, Mass. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Richard Lewis of Albany. Mrs. Lewis, known as Amy, graduated from Connecticut College in 1985. Until recently she was a marketing administrator for Home Box Office in New York. Her father was chairman and chief executive officer of Fleet Norstar Financial Group, a bank holding company with headquarters in Albany and Providence, R.I. Mr. Lewis, a 1985 graduate of Babson College, is the corporate secretary of Breton Industries in Amsterdam, N.Y. The company, owned by his father, designs and manufactures custom fabric covers.

title: Q and A
description: London

title: Margaret Vernon Is Wed
description: The marriage of Margaret Bennett Vernon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack H. Vernon of Weston, Mass., to Dr. James William Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Young of Birmingham, Ala., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Newton Lower Falls, Mass. The Rev. Laurance W. Walton Jr. officiated.

title: Marchers Protest a Charge Of Assault in Hawkins Killing
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton led about 100 black demonstrators through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday, protesting the arraignment Monday of one of the defendants in the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Harbor Bar
description: To the Editor: I was surprised at the omission of the Harbor Bar, a small ice cream bar, on the dessert options among Maine's lobster shacks mentioned in Cynthia Hacinli's warm-spirited article ''No-Frill Lobster on Maine's Coast'' (Travel, Aug. 13). (The ''r's'' are not pronounced by the locals, so it becomes ''Ha-ba Ba.'') While it's not in the same class as the Dove Bar, the Harbor Bar is an institution in most of the lobster shacks, especially in the Mount Desert (pronounced ''dessert'') or Bar Harbor area. DORIS THOMSON Staten Island

title: Sarah B. Thayer Marries a Banker
description: Sarah Bradlee Thayer and Charles LaMar Robinson were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York by the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., who recently retired as Episcopal Bishop of New York. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. David Wetmore Devens of New York and the late Francis Curtis Thayer. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Mebane Robinson of Tryon, N.C.

title: From Japan, Dazzle Aplenty
description: On Wednesday, 61 Japanese performers chosen from among 350 young women all in their 20's and resident at Takarazuka City, an entertainment center 15 minutes from Osaka, arrive at Radio City Music Hall for six appearances. They bring with them nine tons of scenery, including a spanking new built-in-Japan 26-step grand staircase (the one the Rockettes use was deemed too small) and enough costumes for the entire cast to change a half-dozen times during the hour-and-40-minute program.

title: Kathryn Haggerty Weds
description: Kathryn Dianne Haggerty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen C. Haggerty of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Marc Pomerantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pomerantz of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Albert King, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Scottsdale Princess Resort. The bride, 25 years old, graduated magna cum laude from the University of Richmond and received a master's degree in advertising from Northwestern University. She and her husband, 26, are senior marketing consultants at the Chicago office of Arthur Andersen & Company, accountants. He received a bachelor's degree and a master's in advertising from Northwestern.

title: Cruising for Burgers on the Champs Elysees
description: TRAVELS WITH ALICE By Calvin Trillin. 195 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

title: Volunteers Step In As State Support of Aqueduct Drops
description: WHEN it opened on July 4, l842, Manhattan bar owners offered their patrons a free Croton Cocktail, a glass of pure water to celebrate the completion of the country's longest aqueduct and New York City's first water-supply system.

title: Dave Parker Has a Good Suggestion
description: Out of tragedy comes dignity. Dave Parker has used his large vote to persuade the Oakland Athletics to abandon the ritual champagne orgy if they win the World Series.

title: SPEAKING THE PRINCE'S ENGLISH
description: It is fitting that a tenured English professor should agree with a king-to-be's conservative theories of architecture and grammar (''Speaking the Prince's English,'' by Malcolm Bradbury, Sept. 24). After all, it is upon just such time-worn constructions that their livelihoods rely. Both Mr. Bradbury and Prince Charles derive their status from the status quo.

title: A Return to The Past in Austria's Alps
description: NOT many visitors to Salzburg realize that just a short drive south of the city, in Austria's Hohe Tauern national park, a unique project is underway. The Austrian Government has set aside a section of the park - dubbed Tauriska, after the region's ancient Celtic name - for an experiment in small-scale economic development.

title: 'P-Star' Can Spot Inflationary Trends
description: Recent work at the Federal Reserve board, christened P-Star analysis, has stimulated a renewed debate about the relationship between the money supply and inflation. This new work is based on the earlier work of Irving Fisher, which he conducted evidence, and concluded that the P-Star concept is helpful in understanding inflation.

title: THE GUIDE
description: HALLOWEEN OUTING

title: A Jury Awards $1.3 Million To Parents Whose Son Died
description: The parents of a 12-year-old Waterbury boy who died shortly after his release from Yale-New Haven Hospital, where he was being treated for a heart condition, have been awarded more than $1.3 million by a Superior Court jury.

title: Ideological Test for Federal Jobs Worries Doctors
description: As several prominent medical authorities express concern over the Bush Administration's considering ideological issues for those seeking scientific jobs at the Department of Health and Human Services, one of the top appointees in the department has said the Administration should concentrate more on the scientific qualifications of candidates.

title:
ART REVIEW;
Modernist Turned Printmaker
description: LEAD: RALSTON CRAWFORD, who lived from 1906 to 1978 and taught briefly at Hofstra in the 1960's, was one of America's foremost modernist painters, as well as an accomplished photographer and graphic artist. His work as a printmaker is now the focus of an exhibition at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington.

title: Hectic Recovery For Stock Prices
description: Stocks came back after the Friday the 13th plunge of 190 points. Sell orders poured in when the markets opened on Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average had an early 60- point loss but the market turned around within about an hour and the day ended with the Dow up 88 points. Volume on Monday was 416 million shares, the fourth-busiest day ever. The rest of the week saw an 18-point drop on Tuesday but a gain of nearly 40 points on Thursday. The Dow closed out the week at 2,689.14, up 119.88 points, a record. Before the American markets opened Monday, the European markets showed losses, with Frankfurt losing the most, 13 percent. But the Tokyo market fell only 2 percent, helping prevent a recurrence of the worldwide panic seen in the October 1987 crash. So far, the only serious damage appeared to be to some takeover deals, particularly in the airlines. Since Oct. 12, the Dow Jones transportation index has fallen 17 percent. *

title: Patrice Duggan Is Wed
description: Patrice Lee Duggan, a reporter at Forbes magazine in New York, and Gary David Slutsker, a senior editor at Forbes, were married last evening at the Players clubhouse in New York by Rabbi Lawrence Siegel. The bride, 30 years old, will keep her name professionally. She is a daughter of David F. Duggan of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late Marinelle Greene Duggan. A graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, she received a master's degree in economics from Tufts University. The bridegroom, 33, graduated from Middlebury College and received a master's degree from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: INVESTMENT IN TIME

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING? AND TO WHOM IS HE SAYING IT?
description: THE YEAR 2000 FAST APPROACHES, and millennial doom is in the air. Global warming, nuclear proliferation, chaos in Eastern Europe. Even the notion of post is over. Post-modernism, post-history, post-culture (to borrow the critic George Steiner's term) - we're beyond that now. ''The sun is about to set on the post-industrial era,'' declares the economist Lester C. Thurow in The New York Times.

title: 'Yaaba' Comes From Africa To Speak to the World
description: Idrissa Ouedraogo, the film maker from Burkina Faso, West Africa, sat in his room at the Manhattan's Empire Hotel, surrounded by sheets and blankets and a bit bewildered by the pile of items he had to pack into his valise for that day's trip to Japan. The previous night at Alice Tully Hall across the street, Mr. Ouedraogo had charmed the sold-out house with his eight-month-old feature film, ''Yaaba.''

title: Old Shows With New Twists
description: THE show is George and Ira Gershwin's ''Oh, Kay!'' The year is 1926, the setting is a swanky estate in Southampton and the characters include a titled bootlegger (The Duke) and an English heiress (Lady Kay).

title: Annette Radoslovich Weds Peter Francis Corbin
description: Annette Domenica Radoslovich, an assistant vice president with the Bankers Trust Company, and Peter Francis Corbin, an assistant controller and stategic planner with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, both in New York, were married yesterday in Fairview, N.J. The Rev. Edward L. Glynn performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church.

title: Does Ideology Stop at the Laboratory Door? A Debate on Science and the Real World
description: AS we move toward the final decade of the 20th century, perhaps it is natural for some of society's intellectuals to become seized with a sense of millenarianism, declaring that life as we know it is about to end. First it was ''The End of History?'' Francis Fukuyama's essay about the triumph of capitalism and Western liberal democracy, which was published in The National Interest earlier this year. Then Bill McKibben's book, ''The End of Nature,'' declared that humankind has finally dominated the planet, carving its initials so deeply into so many levels of the biosphere that nature itself can no longer be considered separate and pristine.

title: Blacks Should Push For Mayoral Agendas
description: To the Editor:

title: Decoration in a Lavish Style
description: Landscapes, Greek gods or exotic Indian flowers - penned in black on white, white on black or brown on gold - cover virtually every inch of the surfaces of 87 chests, tables, game trays and boxes exhibited at Hyde Park Antiques, 836 Broadway (at 13th Street).

title: Relief Groups Accepting Donations
description: Interaction, a voluntary relief assistance group supported by the Federal Government, has issued the following list of agencies to which money may be sent to assist earthquake victims: American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund, P.O. Box 4691, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163. Telephone: 800-453-9000. Americares Foundation, 51 Locust Avenue, New Canaan, Conn. 06840. Telephone: 203-966-5195. American Jewish World Service, 1290 Avenue of the Americas -11th floor, New York, N.Y. 10104.

title: Ellen J. Savette Marries David Archer
description: Ellen Jeanne Savette and David John Archer were married yesterday at Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Barbara Thrall. The bride is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Savette of New York. Her husband is a son of Mary Archer of Leavenworth, Kan., and the late Dr. William L. Archer.

title: Atlanta Judge Bars Enforcing Of Law Against Assault Guns
description: A local judge has barred the city from enforcing an ordinance that bans the sale of semiautomatic assault weapons.

title: Why the Deficit Is Paralyzing Congress
description: RARELY in peacetime has a single issue dominated politics here the way the budget deficit is doing now.

title: Why Auto Insurance Costs So Much
description: NEW JERSEY drivers, who currently pay the highest automobile insurance premiums in the nation, can expect to see their rates double by the turn of the century, officials say, unless comprehensive, industry-wide changes are immediately undertaken.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Baker Mansion on Park at 93d; Under the Servants' Quarters, a Railroad Siding?
description: IT is certainly a drop in the giant bucket of Manhattan office space - 5,600 square feet at $45 a square foot. But the space is unusual, for it is in one of the grandest houses to survive in Manhattan, the old George F. Baker Jr. residence at the northwest corner of 93d Street and Park Avenue.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Hotel Terminus: The Life and Times of Klaus Barbie 1988. Virgin Vision. $99.95. Laser disk, $99.95. 4 hours 27 minutes. Not rated. A ''vivid, harrowing, minutely detailed'' recollection of France under the German occupation, Max Ophuls's spellbinding film is inexorable in its pursuit of truth, not just about Barbie the ''butcher of Lyons,'' but about the moral climate of his world and of ours today. ''No novelist could possibly set a scene with the inventorying eye of the Ophuls camera,'' and the director, angry and sarcastic, becomes increasingly impatient as the film proceeds to its conclusion with the breathtaking relentlessness of superior fiction. ''It's a fine, serious work by a film maker unlike any other. Great.'' (Vincent Canby) Pet Sematary 1989. Paramount Home Video. No list price. LD, $34.95. 1:43. Closed captioned. R. Based on Stephen King's story, this film, despite some effectively ghoulish (if pointless) moments, fails mostly because it doesn't trust the audience to do any of the work. What the dialogue doesn't carefully explain or predict is explained or predicted by ominous music and special effects. Mary Lambert, of Madonna music-video fame, has little luck in directing the actors; only Fred Gwynne is more than adequate. ''The movie seems to be playing to itself.'' (Canby) Earth Girls Are Easy 1989. Vestron Home Video. $89.98. LD, $24.98. 1:40. CC. PG. Julien Temple's film, inspired by the Jetsons, flying-saucer movies and old Hollywood musicals seen on television, is a joyfully chaotic and wildly uneven work that shows his roots in music videos. Geena Davis is the film's best feature, as a zany manicurist who encounters life-size fur-covered aliens, led by an endearing one played by Jeff Goldblum. The movie can't sustain its lunatic premise and ''often works better as a clever idea than a funny film.'' (Caryn James) Dead Bang 1989. Warner Home Video. $89.95. LD, $24.98. 1:42. CC. R. In Robert Foster's screenplay, which seems not so much written as pasted together from the shredded remains of scripts for old made-for-television movies, Don Johnson stars as a Los Angeles homicide detective who, while investigating the murder of a policeman, uncovers a neo-Nazi political conspiracy. John Frankenheimer has made the movie look better than it should. For all of its camera movement, its chases and its gunfights, it ''gives the impression of just sitting there, waiting - hoping - for a commercial interruption.'' (Canby) A World Apart 1988. Media Home Entertaiment. $89.95. 1:54. CC. PG. This film, the first directed by the Oscar-winning cameraman Chris Menges, won a Special Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival, and for their contributions to it, Barbara Hershey, Jodhi May and Linda Mvusi shared the best-actress award. It presents the story of a white woman in South Africa who, working clandestinely to correct what she sees to be an intolerable political situation, nearly wrecks the emotional life of her adoring daughter. ''It's a beautifully acted, maddening movie that, while expressing all the right sentiments, never goes quite far enough.'' (Canby) The Dark Corner 1946. CBS/Fox Home Video. $59.98. 1:39. CC. Not rated. A private detective is marked as the fall guy in a cleverly contrived murder plot. ''When a talented director and a resourceful company of players meet up with a solid story,'' a contemporary critic wrote, ''then movie-going becomes a particular pleasure.'' The director was Henry Hathaway, and the cast included Lucille Ball in ''one of her happier roles as an acid-tongued secretary,'' along with Mark Stevens, Clifton Webb and William Bendix. A ''sizzling piece of melodrama.''

title: Vikings Aim to Patch Wounds and Discover a Winning Cure
description: The road curves and bends and then suddenly in view is the home of the Minnesota Vikings, named Winter Park, a modern, appealing structure of stone and glass.

title: A Walk Into the Past and Future
description: I WALK every morning, a habit I acquired after the death of my father. He followed his daily schedule of walking until the day he died - I remember him going out even during the bombing of Seoul. I also do it because my doctor told me when I was in for my checkup that my cholesterol level is in the high-risk range.

title: Science Agency Cancels Supercomputer Aid
description: The National Science Foundation has canceled the financing for the John von Neumann National Supercomputer Center in Princeton, N.J., one of five supercomputer centers in the nation.

title: EUDORA WELTY, INQUIRING PHOTOGRAPHER
description: LEAD: Long before she published her first story, Eudora Welty was a photographer. As a young woman during the Depression, she traveled the Deep South, recording rural life as a publicity agent for the Works Progress Administration. She has continued taking pictures all her life, spontaneously and for her own pleasure.

title: A Black Homer Bursting With A Black 'Odyssey'
description: The morning after hurricane Hugo tore through the South, the author Theodore Rosengarten returned to his home in McClellanville, S.C., a small coastal town near Charleston. Miraculously, the house in which the transplanted Northerner lives with his wife, Dale, and their two children was still standing. The rooms, however, were in disastrous disarray. In his study, the storm had blown out the air-conditioner, and books and papers were floating in water. Worse, he discovered in river mud the voluminous tapes on which he had recorded Ned Cobb, an illiterate 85-year-old Southern black sharecropper, whose compelling stories Mr. Rosengarten fashioned into 1974's ''All God's Dangers: The Life and Times of Nate Shaw,'' a pseudonymous oral history that won a National Book Award.

title: ACROSS TEXAS BY NON SEQUITOR
description: LEAD: SOME CAN WHISTLE By Larry McMurtry. 348 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Swiss to Vote On Disarming Their Fortress
description: Absorbed by the grandeur of the Alpine scenery on the train ride southeast from here, few notice the peaks of a different sort - the rows of dragon's teeth, stubby concrete tank traps sewn along the hedgerows to shepherd an invading force toward open ground, where they can be blasted by gun emplacements hidden in the hills.

title: Rooney Out of It
description: With the National Football League owners divided on a choice for a new commissioner, a compromise candidate emerged last week -and promptly shot down his own trial balloon. Asked on Friday to assess his chances of becoming commissioner, Dan Rooney, the 57-year-old president of the Pittsburgh Steelers, replied: ''Slim and none. No, make that none.''

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Earlier this year my husband and I took a tour of Portugal and Spain. We enjoyed Portugal and its people. However, in Seville, we were victims of a purse snatching. We were aware that we should carry nothing of value on the streets, I needed to carry my sunglasses and medication -- and that's all the thieves got. With a world exposition upcoming in Seville and the Olympics in Barcelona I feel that the need to exercise extreme caution in Spain should be stressed. In addition, travel personnel should warn prospective tourists of the problems. ELEANOR S. FONTAINE Vincetown, N.J. The Spanish National Tourist Office replies: Security measures have been stepped up recently. It is true that the big cities have had this kind of problem, but no more so than throughout the rest of Europe.

title: Patients Dance Into the Unconscious
description: IN place of a psychiatrist's couch, there is a piano, an easel or just an open room. In place of lengthy conversations about ego and relationships, patients paint, sing, dance or create a drama about their feelings. This is therapy? For thousands of people in Connecticut it is. Whether frustrated with conventional psychotherapy or simply curious about a different approach, they enlist the help a creative arts therapist who uses dance, drama, art, music or poetry as the basis of psychological treatment.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Prospects; Free Trade With Mexico
description: In comments made before a Senate hearing on the Latin American debt situation, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher predicted that the United States and Mexico would eventually enter into a free-trade agreement similar to the one that went into effect with Canada in January. Four experts comment on the possibility. Rogelio Ramirez de la O General director, Ecanal, an economic analysis and consulting firm in Mexico City.

title:
INVESTING;
A Truck Maker's Transition
description: LEAD: They make more than children's clothes in Oshkosh, Wis. There, the Oshkosh Truck Corporation is managing a transition well enough to make its stock a good value.

title: Smaller Solar
description: To the Editor:

title: Life, and Death, in the Fast Lane
description: From skiing to surfing, California is a state of exhilarating extremes, and perils. Even with respect to risk, Californians cover the spectrum. A law passed by popular ballot in 1986 requires warning labels on any food whose ingredients have a 1-in-100,000 chance of causing cancer. Yet, as Tuesday's tremor hammered home, tens of thousands could be killed in the truly major earthquake that might strike at any time.

title: Jennifer Dicker, Student, Marries
description: Jennifer Gail Dicker and Peter John Rousseau were married last evening at the Hotel Westbury in New York by Rabbi Joel Gore.

title: Settlements
description: The bullhorns, spotlights and canned music make the downtown corner look like a street party. It turns out instead to be a real estate hustle - one that gives blatant, blaring evidence of a cloud over Israel's future.

title: SHE WOULD NOT BE MOVED
description: MARY HEATON VORSE The Life of an American Insurgent. By Dee Garrison. Illustrated. 377 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $27.95.

title: Kohl Disavows Any Land Claims on Poland
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, trying to clear an issue that has cast a shadow on his plans to visit Warsaw next month, said today that West Germany had no territorial claims on Poland.

title: SALVATION THROUGH SOCIOLOGY
description: LEAD: WHOSE KEEPER? Social Science and Moral Obligation. By Alan Wolfe. 371 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: A Network of Female Entrepreneurs
description: A DECADE ago, 12 businesswomen from seven different fields met in a White Plains diner and decided that they needed a trade group.

title: 213 Years Ago, White Plains Was a Battlefield
description: I OFTEN walk along the path bordering the Bronx River, running from the White Plains railroad station to Hartsdale. Along this path, to the west of the Bronx River Parkway, are high bluffs that define the elevation known as Chatterton Hill, or more familiarly, Battle Hill, which marks the site of the Battle of White Plains, fought 213 years ago, on Oct. 28, 1776.

title: Schiller Approved as Director
description: In one of its most contentious sessions in decades, the executive board of the United States Olympic Committee today unanimously approved the appointment of Harvey Schiller to replace Baaron Pittenger as the U.S.O.C. executive director.

title: Comment Sharpens Suffolk Race
description: LEAD: THE outcome of the race for district attorney of Suffolk County between James M. Catterson Jr., a Republican, and Robert C. Gottlieb, a Democrat, seemed to hang last week on a phrase, even a word.

title: What Should Rise From Catastrophic Law's Ashes; The Flaws Exposed
description: To the Editor:

title: CAR MAKERS AND CREDIT UNIONS ENCOURAGE DEALER HONESTY
description: Car dealers once were ranked alongside fast-talking politicians and snake-oil salesmen. But some are trying to create a kinder, gentler image.

title: Jacob Neal: Hair Stylist
description: When Jacob Neal looks at a woman, he sees her not necessarily as she is, but as she could be. He is a hair stylist who specializes in makeovers, which he describes as ''taking a man or woman from one point to another level.''

title: California Quake Seen as Challenging State's Reluctance to Tax and Spend
description: The devastating earthquake here is already having a political aftershock: a re-examination of California's reluctance to tax and spend, enshrined in law by a series of voter initiatives over the last decade that now constitutionally handcuff the state's ability to repair its crumbled highways and bridges.

title: 595 High Earners Avoided Income Tax in '87
description: A handful of the highest-earning Americans are still able to avoid paying Federal income tax despite repeated Congressional efforts to close loopholes.

title: WEDDING CHAOS
description: ONCE UPON A TIME ON THE BANKS By Cathie Pelletier. 368 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Kathleen Collins Weds Navy Flier
description: At St. Dominic Roman Catholic Chapel in Oyster Bay, L.I., Kathleen Ann Collins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Collins of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Comdr. Walter F. Leoffler Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leoffler of Oxnard, Calif. The Rev. Ernest E. Robinson and the Rev. Newton Kerney, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Brattleboro, Vt.;
17 Homes In a Gravel Pit
description: LEAD: WHETSTONE VILLAGE, a cluster of 17 single-family houses on eight acres near the center of this growing town in southeastern Vermont, represents an effort to create new land for ''affordable'' housing from an old gravel pit.

title: Miss McDaniel Plans to Marry
description: Elizabeth Chase McDaniel and Malcolm John Sutherland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., plan to marry in December. Their engagement was made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Chase McDaniel 2d of Haverford, Pa.

title: Storm-Tossed Canvases And Tension in Sculptures
description: AS one of the artists John Myers helped put on the map, Walter Darby Bannard was included in the 1988 show commemorating the late dealer. His was a 1969 Color Field canvas, daintily, almost timidly, executed - very different from the figure the painter cuts in Myers's memoir, ''Tracking the Marvelous.''

title: Nancy L. Tellier to Wed in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tellier of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Nancy Lyn Tellier to P. Murphy van der Velde, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Christiaan D. van der Velde of Norwich, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: A Producer Wed To Miss Proctor
description: V. Elizabeth Proctor, the daughter of Virginia Millane Proctor of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and William Ross Proctor of New York and Sanibel, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Lesure Salguero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Eduardo Salguero of Monte Carlo, Monaco, Madrid and New York. The Rev. Gary Fertig performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: As Profits Slide, a Struggle to Survive
description: These are tough times for the nation's $303 billion a year business of selling automobiles.

title: 'LOVE IS A PUBLICITY STUNT'
description: LOUISE BROOKS By Barry Paris. Illustrated. 609 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: BRIGHT SHARDS AND SOLID POTTERY
description: TIME'S POWER Poems 1985-1988. By Adrienne Rich. 58 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95. TAKE HEART By Molly Peacock. 71 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95. HARP LAKE By John Hollander. Illustrated. 94 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BACK HOME: A Foreign Correspondent Rediscovers America. By Mort Rosenblum. (Morrow, $19.95.) In writing for Americans about Americans, the Paris-based Associated Press reporter Mort Rosenblum has undertaken a thankless chore; to succeed, he must tell us something about ourselves that we do not already believe.

title:
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Historic Districts;
Balancing Profits Against Tight Building Restrictions
description: LEAD: WHEN work started last July on the Pueblo Espanol shopping center in the 117-acre historic district here, the developer, Cesar Gonzmart, thought most of his problems were past.

title: Houston Rolls to A 95-21 Victory
description: Houston became the first team in major college history to gain 1,000 yards in a game and Andre Ware threw six touchdown passes today to set three National Collegiate Athletic Association records as the Cougars beat Southern Methodist, 95-21.

title: DEALERS VOTE FOR THEIR CHOICES
description: The autumnal promise of early evenings and long nights stirs interest in video. Fall is prime time in the stores as many viewers update their equipment.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Roger Rabbit's Straight Man, and Then Some

title: Quiet contest as Gioffre Seeks To Unseat Spano
description: LEAD: IN the race for County Clerk, the Republican, Frederick J. Gioffre, has cast himself as the underdog in his bid to unseat the incumbent Democrat, Andrew J. Spano.

title: CONSUMER RATES

IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: STILL LIFE WITH INSECTS. By Brian Kiteley. (Ticknor & Fields, $15.95.) Brian Kiteley has constructed his brief first novel from a series of vignettes, scenes plucked from 40 years in the life of a man named Elwyn Farmer. These short, evocative moments illuminate a landscape far beyond their own boundaries.

title: The Disorder of Dismantling Apartheid
description: SOUTH AFRICA'S new President, F. W. de Klerk, has been trying to buy time and good will for his promised program of evolutionary changes, but in some ways his efforts are only creating new problems. With each piecemeal gesture toward conciliation, new contradictions have been cropping up in the enforcement of laws that perpetuate white minority rule.

title: A Parting Gift: A Lesson on Embracing Life and Death
description: RUTH, my wife of 43 years, gave me many wondrous gifts: the gifts of love, four sterling children, a full and adventurous life. She surprised me by giving me one more gift at the end.

title: Still Searching
description: The K.G.B. has not backed away from its contention that Raoul Wallenberg died 42 years ago in Lubyanka Prison. But the Russians suddenly are willing to go through the motions of cooperating with people who think otherwise and who are determined to search for Mr. Wallenberg, a Swede who saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from World War II death camps before his arrest by Soviet authorities in 1945. At the K.G.B.'s invitation, Mr. Wallenberg's half-brother and half-sister, Guy Von Dardel and Nina Lagergren, visited Moscow last week to accept recently discovered personal documents - notebooks and identification papers - of Mr. Wallenberg's. But the papers ''do not prove that Raoul is dead,'' said Mrs. Lagergren. Mr. von Dardel said there was evidence that Mr. Wallenberg had been seen as recently as 1980 in the Vladimir Prison near Moscow. The K.G.B. maintains that Mr. Wallenberg died of heart failure at the age of 37, two years after his arrest on unspecified charges. Mr. Von Dardel said the security agency had agreed to let him visit the prison this week to search its archives. ''We feel that he is still alive and that this opportunity will lead us to him eventually,'' he said.

title: Needlework Stories Tell of Chilean Life
description: THE collection of 71 Chilean arpilleras owned by the William Benton Museum of Art of the University of Connecticut is seldom on display at the red-brick institution on the campus in Storrs. The bright primitive wall hangings depicting particular events and the hardships of daily life under the Pinochet regime were acquired two years ago to be used as educational tools. They are lent to schools and colleges in the state and are available for research. ''They cross a lot of academic lines - folk art, history and social studies,'' said Hildegard Cummings, curator of education at the museum and the person instrumental in their acquisition.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''You could posit that Friday's activity was the market's ultimate signal that the day of crazy deals was over.'' Michael D. Madden, senior managing director, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., speaking of the plunge on Oct. 13.

title: 4 Are Acquitted in the Sale of Faulty Pacemakers
description: Four former officials of the Cordis Corporation, a medical equipment manufacturer, have been acquitted of conspiracy and related charges in the sale of hundreds of defective heart pacemakers.

title: Transit Agency Wants to End Airport Express
description: The New York City Transit Authority has recommended that the express subway service between Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport be eliminated, arguing that it is not attracting enough riders.

title: A Passion for Pedaling Country Roads
description: FROM shoreline towns to the Litchfield Hills, Connecticut is booming with bicycles. More and more residents, tired of jarring their joints with high-impact aerobic sports, are storing their jogging shoes, strapping on helmets and taking to the roads by bicycle. Cycling, which its enthusiasts say is fast becoming the No. 1 leisure sport in the state, is growing because of its health benefits, which they say include the gentle toning of the muscles and the replenishing of the mind.

title: Lois Sassone Marries An Insurance Broker
description: Lois Sassone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Sassone of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James B. Lavelle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lavelle of Rye. Msgr. Thomas McMahon officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: NONFICTION
description: TO LIVE LIKE EVERYONE. By Anatoly Marchenko. Translated by Paul Goldberg. (Holt, $19.95.) In 1966, Anatoly Marchenko had a brief respite from what was to become a long career as a political prisoner in the Soviet Union. Before his incarceration in 1958 - he was jailed once in the wake of a workers' brawl and again after a near-escape into Iran - Marchenko had been a young, self-satisfied construction foreman. But when he re-entered the world, he was a man without social identity: neither worker nor intellectual, unemployable yet constantly under threat of arrest. He went from town to town, working what jobs he could without a permit. Eventually he managed to write a book, ''My Testimony,'' about the political labor camps many people thought had been dismantled under Khrushchev. ''To Live Like Everyone,'' Marchenko's third and last book - he died in prison in 1986 - is in part the story of his struggle to write ''My Testimony.'' That effort reached fruition when Western publishers printed the smuggled manuscript in 1967, giving the West one of its first glimpses of post-Stalinist political prisoners and sending its author back to jail. But ''To Live Like Everyone,'' well translated from the Russian by Paul Goldberg, is also a string of anecdotes so cruel, and so ironic, they could have been lifted from an early picaresque novel. Marchenko is a loner in a world of collectivists. By the time he returned to the camps, he had become a near-perfect dissident, yielding nothing and risking everything for the right to be who he was.

title: Eight New Books to Help You Get Going
description: THE publishing of how-to travel books, while still less of an industry than the where-to book business, is certainly burgeoning. Eight new titles merit attention. ''The Official Frequent Flyer Guidebook'' misled me at first; the word official in the title made me think that it was put out by the publishers of the Official Airline Guide, which corporate travel departments use. According to an editor at Bonus Books, the publisher, the book bears the name ''official'' to indicate that it was published with the cooperation of the airlines' frequent-travel programs, allowing use of service marks and trademarks in the text. ''Authorized'' would make more sense, although it may not have sales appeal.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 1 about the television program 'Night Music'' omitted the name of the percussionist Don Alias from the list of musicians in the show's house band. It also misstated the title of the Slim Gaillard song ''Flat Foot Floogie (With the Floy, Floy).''

title: FICTION
description: DEADFALL. By Patti Davis. (Crown, $17.95.) This literary plea for a hands-off policy in Nicaragua is particularly plaintive, coming as it does from the daughter of a President. The actress, songwriter and political activist Patti Davis, Ronald and Nancy Reagan's daughter, took on the American presence in Vietnam in her first novel, ''Home Front,'' which was written with Maureen Strange Foster. This earnest, amiable new novel (her first solo flight) is about a California painter whose life is thrown into turmoil because her film maker husband uncovers some covert operations in Nicaragua. Engaging, aimless Darren Laverty and her husband, Andrew, have an enviable sex life; they always sleep tangled together (''they made love in the silvery light, the wine heavy as syrup in their veins and their bodies still warm from the Jacuzzi''). Then, in Central America, Andrew films scenes of violence that have apparently been prompted by American intervention. Ms. Davis intercuts such crucial developments with more mundane interludes, like Darren adopting a dog, visiting friends and working out at a gym. After a second foray south, Andrew returns with evidence against the covert forces and soon thereafter dies violently, just as Darren discovers she's pregnant. She vows to get to the truth of just why her husband was murdered. Meanwhile Senator Kent Janes, who will attempt an official investigation, soldiers on in a miserably unhappy marriage while the Lavertys' reporter friend, Sean Trudell, continues his own search for evidence. It's only a matter of time before these nice folks get together. Behind the conspiracy are the usual suspects, including a crazed colonel and a family member dear to Darren. ''They got all of us, didn't they?'' Darren concludes. ''We all walked into the same trap from different directions and for different reasons. But we've all ended up wounded.'' In ''Deadfall,'' nobody - not even the author - emerges unscathed from the world of politics.

How long a food is left in a marinade depends on what the final product should be as well as the character of the main ingredient. The following recipes illustrate these points.

description: Chazz Palminteri's one-man play ''A Bronx Tale'' is the theatrical equivalent of sprawling streetwise rock songs like Bruce Springsteen's ''Jungleland'' and Billy Joel's ''Scenes From an Italian Restaurant.'' Performing on a set that impressionistically re-creates the corner of 187th Street and Belmont Avenue in 1960, the New York-born actor and writer spins a vivid true story of his own childhood and adolescence when he was taken under the wing of a neighborhood gangster named Little Johnny.

But ever since Christie Hefner joined upper management of the company her father founded in 1953, she has been battling to turn Playboy Enterprises Inc. from Hugh Hefner's ''personality-driven life-style company,'' as she put it, into an ''international media company for the mass market.''

title: Review/Theater; A Ghost Walks, in 'God's Policemen'
description: At one point in ''God's Policemen,'' two serial killers force a captive salesman to mimic Elvis Presley performing the song ''Don't Be Cruel.'' By then, the song is a plea that might well be taken up by the audience and addressed to the playwright, Richard Lay.

description: I was saddened to see President Truman's diatribe appearing in print on the eve of President Eisenhower's centennial. It is also sad that this sour note comes when both Presidents are rising in the estimation of historians of the 1980's.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Rebuilding Atlantic City's Wasteland
description: LEAD: BEYOND the glittering casinos along Atlantic City's Boardwalk lies the Inlet, an oceanfront neighborhood reduced to a wasteland by decades of abandonment and neglect. Now, with the start of a major home building project there, a new and more hopeful chapter is beginning.

title: The Joffrey Returns, Spotlighting a Virtuoso
description: As a repertory ensemble, the Joffrey Ballet has always avoided the star system and even the term ''principal'' as a means of distinguishing its leading performers. With only 40 dancers, the company is small relative to other major classical ensembles such as American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet, and each performer must be able to handle his or her moment in the limelight when it comes.

Cellist to Play Tchaikovsky Original

description: The vacuum cleaner has kept me busy lately trying to get rid of dust from the bellows of my view camera, which accumulated while on a visit to the Holy Land. That accomplished, it's time to clean the lenses.

title: Conjured by Calder
description: ''The intimate world of Alexander Calder'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is as much fun as any exhibition we can hope to see. But, quite apart from being so much fun, it is also a lesson in life, for Calder had in a high degree the gift of metamorphosis. The first thing we learn from this exhibition is that in the everyday things around him - a clothespin, a cork, a fishbone, a discarded can of this or that - he saw disinherited ingredients that could be put to magical use. We knew that already, in a general way, but never before have we seen so many proofs of it in one place at one time. In his own houses - whether in Roxbury, Conn., or in Sache, near Tours, in France - that gift for metamorphosis ran free and was never in short supply. In this exhibition there is replayed the situation that greeted the visitor. Every last corner of every room, every place, bore his mark. If Robinson Crusoe on his island had had his family with him and decided to re-create the world of domesticity in its every detail, he would have aimed to do what Calder did. But there has only been one A. Calder, and I doubt that R. Crusoe would have been in the same class.

title: Chicago Blacks Hold Bias Protest
description: In a protest against bigotry and police brutality, more than 500 people, most of them blacks, marched without incident today through the city's Bridgeport neighborhood where two 14-year-old black boys were chased and beaten by a gang of whites this summer.

title: After 35 Years, An Old Flame Turns Up
description: LEAD: OLD flames have a way of reappearing years later, bringing back memories that tug at the heart.

title: C. I. Pavelic Wed To Miss Marache
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Eugenie Jebb Marache, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert William Marache Jr. of Greenwich and Nantucket, Mass., to Christopher Ivan Pavelic, the son of Ivan Pavelic of Greenwich and the late Irene Gmur Pavelic. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title:
MIDLAND PARK JOURNAL;
A Bond Issue With No Broker
description: LEAD: IN the small northwest Bergen County borough of Midland Park, where many residents hold blue-collar jobs and almost 40 percent are elderly, the unexpected expenditures of $380,000 for a new fire truck and $200,000 for curb repaving could have translated into an increase of 40 cents for every $100 in assessed value tax for homeowners.

title: When Women Walk Together, A Quiet Bond Is Formed
description: WE women who walk exchange barely perceptible nods and tight smiles as we arrive each morning at the earth-red macadam track that rims our high school. Implicit in our reserve is the acknowledgment that we are determined to respect the yearning for solitude that has spurred each of us to don our sweat suits, lace our sneakers and walk briskly through the milky light of early morning.

title: Still Miffed?
description: Make no mistake, that was not a grudge that Nancy Reagan was holding as she chatted about Donald T. Regan in a recent radio interview. Mrs. Reagan, who was discussing her book, ''My Turn: The Memoirs of Nancy Reagan,'' which is to be published this month, said she ''tried very hard not to be vindictive'' when writing about certain top Presidential aides with whom she was not particularly friendly. But she said that appointing Mr. Regan as White House chief of staff was President Reagan's biggest mistake. She said that although the Iran-contra affair was not necessarily Mr. Regan's doing, ''it did occur on his watch and he should have taken responsiblity.'' Furthermore, she said, Mr. Regan's revelation that she began consulting an astrologer after Mr. Reagan was shot was an ''enormous embarassment.'' Mrs. Reagan said her astrological consultation ''began as a crutch'' to ease her anxieties about her husband's safety. She appeared to have no such worries at week's end as she and Mr. Reagan left for a tour of Japan. The Japanese conglomerate that invited them is to pay the Reagans about $2 million.

title: Nataly Goldstein to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Goldstein of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter Nataly Goldstein to Scott Goldstein, the son of Albert Goldstein of New York and Irene Amsterdam Goldstein of Mineola, L.I. The families are not related. A November wedding is planned. Ms. Goldstein is a placement counselor at the Redford Agency in New York. Her fiance is a transportation executive for the Key Food Transportation Corporation in Brooklyn.

title: SPEAKING THE PRINCE'S ENGLISH
description: I note that Mr. Bradbury has a few unkind implications for the Chomskyites. He could have saved his breath. It is true that they promoted promiscuous permissiveness 15 years ago, but they no longer bedevil language instruction in America.

title: Sports of The Times: World Series; Once 0 for 31, Now He Roots for Canseco
description: Ever since Jose Canseco lined a grand-slam over the center-field fence at Dodger Stadium in last year's World Series opener, he has had 24 consecutive official Series times at bat without a hit. For a slugger of his stature, he's in the worst possible slump at the worst possible time. But when he was told that Marv Owen, a third baseman for the Detroit Tigers more than half a century ago, held the Series record with 31 consecutive hitless times at bat, the Athletics' right fielder smiled. ''Marv can keep it,'' he said with a laugh. Marv will gladly keep it. Marv Owen is 83 years old now, slim and straight with a shock of white hair dropping toward his twinkling eyes. He lives in a senior citizens residence not far from his longtime home here about 40 miles south of Candlestick Park, where the World Series is scheduled to resume Tuesday. And when he was told that Canseco had joked that ''Marv can keep'' the record, he laughed.

title: Protesters Block the Doors Of an Abortion Clinic on L.I.
description: About 150 anti-abortion protesters sealed off the doors of an abortion clinic here today, chaining themselves together to block more than a dozen women from getting in, officials said.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Wisconsin; Student's Death Quickly Followed By Counseling
description: Amid grief over the unexplained death of a freshman early on Oct. 15 at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, students and administrators are lauding the efforts of a crisis-response team in helping dormitory residents cope with the incident.

title: The Amistad Revolt: 'A Tale of Triumph'
description: ONE HUNDRED and fifty years ago, on board the ship Amistad, 53 kidnapped Africans refused to accept the fate of slaves. Instead they rose up, killed the captain and sailed away. Thinking they were headed back to Africa, they became lost at sea and wound up on Long Island. They were eventually brought to New Haven where they stood trial for murder.

title: The Race to Market a 486 Machine
description: Computer companies are beginning to beat their drums, and their chests, over the imminent introduction of computers built around the powerful Intel 80486 microprocessor. Because companies are making promises - about shipping dates, for instance - that they may not be able to keep, customers should be wary of the chest-thumping. Nonetheless the excitement over the new chip is justified. The 80486-based machines will allow businesses to run their existing PC-compatible software applications much faster than before, to develop powerful applications and to manage larger networks of computers with greater speed. ''We believe the 80486 will reset the industry standard for personal computer price-performance,'' said Lee Hoevel, chief architect for the NCR Corporation's work station products division. NCR is among several companies that have already announced they are in the race to sell the first 80486-based systems. For prices expected to be $10,000 to $20,000, the computers are believed to be capable of performing on the same scale as minicomputers costing several times as much.

title: The Crimes and Punishments of Wedtech
description: WITH the extortion conviction last week of Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx and the sentencing of E. Robert Wallach, the Wedtech case is all but over.

title: Saturday a Focus For Fan's Father
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Strong Commissioner, Steady Influence
description: LEAD: This year has been a grim one for baseball: the worst of times. The tragedies piled one upon another.

title: INSIDE
description: Honduran Jetliner Crashes At least 131 people were killed when a Boeing 727 passenger jet with 146 people aboard broke apart in the air and crashed in flames near Tegucigalpa. At least 11 Americans were reported aboard. Page 6. title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Dazzle of Evil

title: TOUGH TIMES FOR MR. LEVITTOWN
description: Your article neglected to mention one significant and controversial aspect of the builder's visions of suburbia: all the inhabitants were white. Mr. Levitt openly refused to sell Levittown houses to black families. In an article that appeared in The Saturday Evening Post in the mid-1950's, he explained his position in the following manner: ''. . . if we sell one house to a Negro family, then 90 to 95 percent of our white customers will not buy into the community. That is their attitude, not ours. We did not create it, and cannot cure it. As a company, our position is simply this: we can solve a housing problem or we can try to solve a racial problem. But we cannot combine the two.''

title: East Berliners March for Democracy
description: Several thousand East Berliners marched hand-in-hand in a single line through the center of the city today in the first demonstration for more democracy in the East German capital since Egon Krenz replaced Erich Honecker as Communist Party leader last Wednesday. The police did not interfere.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CARTOGRAPHIES. By Maya Sonenberg. (University of Pittsburgh, $17.95.) In ''Nature Morte,'' the most successful of the 10 stories in this collection, Maya Sonenberg records a unique event: ''In Paris in 1911, the first cubist baby was born to an unwed mother from Avignon.'' The multi-viewpoint narrative that follows is an ingenious feat of conjuring, reminiscent of the work of Donald Barthelme, bringing to life a boy who in turn evokes the splintered images of Picasso's ''Demoiselles d'Avignon.

title: An Amiable Spot for Italian Standbys
description: MONROE is not widely known for its restaurant choices, so it was a pleasant surprise to discover Cristallini Ristorante, a small place making an effort to serve good Italian food.

title: The Fed's New Tool Just Doesn't Work
description: The research staff of the board of Governors of the Federal Reserve has developed what is described as a new method for forecasting inflation. The announcement of this new construct brought a great deal of publicity. The equation, which is called P-Star, is a throwback to strict monetarism in its most primitive form. However, my analysis of P-Star's results over the last three years shows it to have been a faulty predictor of inflation. A number of sound fundamental reasons suggest this approach is too limited to be used as a tool for successful monetary policy decisions.

title: Nancy Adkins Is Married
description: Nancy Anne Adkins and Joel Allen Shapiro were married last evening at the Lotos Club in New York by Judge Peter K. Leisure of Federal District Court in New York. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John S. Adkins Jr. of Madison, Conn., and the late Mr. Adkins. A graduate of Pratt Institute, she is the printing manager at the Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency in New York and will keep her name professionally. The bridegroom is the son of Sylvia F. Shapiro of Hollywood, Fla., and the late Jack Shapiro. A graduate of Syracuse University, he is the president of Bartmon, Shapiro, Scott & Associates, an insurance and financial services company in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Sarah McNally Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNally of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah McNally to William H. Lynn 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn of Atlanta. A November wedding is planned.

title: Phoenix House Philosophy
description: Residents of Phoenix House recite the center's philosophy at least twice a day.

title: Two of Us Is One Too Many
description: HE WAS A PROWLER on my turf and I hated it. When my husband took early retirement, I came down with a late, hard case of culture shock. It made me crazy.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. CARLO PARRAVANO;
Making Science and Math Enticing
description: LEAD: WHEN the governors of the 50 states got together last month to discuss education, improving the teaching of science and math occupied an important spot on their agenda. Not since the Soviet Union launched Sputnik in 1957 has there been so much concern that American young people are falling far behind others - particularly the

title: The End of Inequality?
description: To the Editor:

title: Punter Becomes Weapon For Jets
description: The Jets may be on to something new in the National Football League: the vertical game.

title: Davis Is Still Angered by Switch
description: Storm Davis, an Oakland Athletics pitcher, was still upset with Tony La Russa, the manager, today, and La Russa was angry with Davis for being angry with him.

title: Now Showing, Survival of the Fittest
description: The buzzword in Hollywood today is ''bulk'' - in studio size and in movies. The strongest studios are committed to making more movies, pictures that are larger in scope and budget, films that can feed a growing worldwide appetite in television, cable and home video.

title: A Stitch, but Not in Time
description: GIVEN THE GRIEVOUS RENTING suffered by the Exxon Valdez when it ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound last March 24, Fred N. Hallett marvels that the ship made it back to port at all. An ex-Navy officer, Hallett is a vice president and spokesman for the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company (NASSCO) in San Diego, which built the Valdez and is now repairing it. ''The crew has been blamed - appropriately so -for running on the reef,'' he says. ''But then to lose a third of the bottom and keep the ship from capsizing was an incredible feat of seamanship.''

title: An Opera Company In Search of Itself
description: Lazarus rose from the dead only once; the New York City Opera has done it again and again during its 45-year history. Depending on how an observer scores on the optimism/pessimism scale, the record of narrow escapes from the grave is either a proof of vitality or evidence of incurable sickness. The company, for all its periodic staggering, has been a survivor in one of art's tougher neighborhoods: popular-priced opera. That, in fact, is one of its main problems today.

title: Home Schooling: Shane Is O.K.
description: I would not enter the fray of this home-schooling discussion except that a child has been unjustly maligned and I would like to speak up for him. We have known Shane, the son of Cindy Soehner (''My Son Is Better Off Learning At Home,'' Opinion, Sept 3), for over a year now and have found him to be a nice quiet boy, easy to have around. He was here at our house for a Halloween party last year.

title: A Potential New Soviet Export Product: Cold-War-Surplus Missiles
description: In an effort to turn swords into plowshares, or ''tanks into tractors,'' as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d put it last week, the Soviet Union is trying to turn its SS-20 missile into a commercial rocket for launching small satellites into space.

title: Nynex Ordered to Reinstate Medical Aid to Striking Workers
description: A Federal District Court Judge late Friday temporarily restrained the Nynex Corporation from withholding medical benefits from striking employees.

title: U.N. Not Story It Once Was to the U.S. Press
description: In the newsroom at the United Nations, there are 34 manual typewriters facing 34 empty chairs. They usually sit untouched in neat rows, a monument to the days when reporters banged out breaking news with a click and a zing instead of rushing to electronic terminals.

title: No Headline
description: At the Wren Chapel at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., Leslie Cornell Bones, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Bones of Richmond, was married yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Jeffrey Donald Maclay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Maclay of Brookfield, Conn. The Rev. Thomas N. Oates, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Hanging On When the Dow Plunges
description: With the stock market on a roller-coaster course again, many people are wondering if they belong in the equity market at all. But most financial experts warn against panic selling should the Dow Jones industrial average experience another precipitous drop, the way it did on Oct. 13, and urge long-term investors to hang on for the ride.

title: Anti-Drug Units Face Formidable Obstacles
description: Colombia's war against the narcotics trade faces fundamental obstacles rooted in the country's geography and the weaknesses in its armed forces as well as the strength of the drug organizations.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Madison Avenue Street Fair, Madison Avenue between 23d and 34th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Because of the East 50's Street

title: More Adventures in Publishing
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Jets Have Benched O'Brien?
description: Absolutely not. If top management approaches the same problem with the same solution yielding the same result year in and year out, changes must take place at the top or changes will take place at the bottom. VLAD RYBAKOV Rego Park, Queens

title: Susan Ann Coleman, A Banker, Is Married
description: Susan Ann Coleman, a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, and Philippe Geneste, a vice president of Merrill Lynch & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Casa Madrona Hotel in Sausalito, Calif. The Rev. William P. Bullard of the Church of Science of the Mind performed the nondenominational service.

title: Illegal Apartments: Let's Face Facts
description: Recently, the Long Island Board of Realtors has encouraged zoning changes to accommodate owner-occupied residences with accessory apartments (''Restricting Illegal Apartments,'' Sept. 24). The support has never been more timely.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: A scrap of blue and red paper sold for $1 million this month. For the arithmetically minded, this bit of paper, the plate block from the sheet of Inverted Jenny airmail stamps, is 2 1/2 inches square. Thus the anonymous broadcast executive who bought the block at a Christie's auction paid the equivalent of $23 million a square foot, or $1 trillion dollars an acre.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DAUGHTERS OF CAPTAIN COOK. By Linda Spalding. (Carol Publishing/Birch Lane, 600 Madison Ave., New York, N.Y. 10022, $15.95.) The meticulous, understated opening chapters of ''Daughters of Captain Cook'' give little indication of what sort of horrifying tale will emerge in Linda Spalding's absorbing, expertly crafted first novel.

title: Dahn Ben-Amotz, Israeli Author, 65
description: Dahn Ben-Amotz, a novelist, playwright and journalist who was a leading figure in Israeli culture for several decades, died of liver cancer on Friday at his home in the Jaffa section of Tel Aviv. He was 65 years old.

title: Mountain Wine Makers Escape Severe Damage
description: Quitting time is 5 P.M. at Roudon Smith Vineyards, a winery in California's Santa Cruz Mountains. On Tuesday, the earthquake hit four minutes later.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large kitchen with 25-year-old cabinets covered with a brown matte-finish plastic laminate. We would like to paint these cabinets white. How can we make paint stick to this laminate?

title: GROUPS OPPOSE BID TO CUT ALIENS' AID
description: Civil libertarians and groups representing the poor and the elderly have expressed concern over a measure passed by the Senate that would bar illegal aliens from receiving Federal benefits, including Social Security and disability payments.

title: NO ONE IS NICE HERE
description: PASSOVER By Foumiko Kometani. 148 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $14.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Broad and Varied Menu in Brewster
description: LEAD: SITUATED in the prettily decorated house last occupied by Victorian Manor, Riverhouse has wisely kept the renovations and appointments of the former tenant largely intact. Beyond the flower-lined walk and entrance, lofty ceilings, grand arches and lace curtains, gentle lighting and comfortable chairs give an aura of luxe to the restaurant's reception rooms, bar and dining areas.

title: A MAN TOO ATTRACTIVE TO MARRY
description: CHARLEY BLAND By Mary Lee Settle. 207 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Change in Certifying Nursery Teachers
description: In the Sept. 3 article discussing Gov. Thomas H. Kean's impact on New Jersey's schools, it is suggested that there may be flaws in his claim to be the ''education Governor.'' An action taken only three days later by the State Board of Education weakens the Governor's claim further.

title: SECRETS OF PAIN AND EUPHORIA
description: LEAD: BRAINSTORMING The Science and Politics of Opiate Research. By Solomon H. Snyder. Illustrated. 208 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep planting, bulbs, shrubs, all evergreens, perennials. Start cleanup by cutting back browning stems of perennials; pull up annuals and add them to the compost. Start raking, if it has not been started, and put tree leaves, grass clippings and twigs on the compost. About Seed

title: WHAT DID HIS WOMAN WANT?
description: LEAD: SILENT PARTNER By Jonathan Kellerman. 404 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95. By Rosemary Herbert

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; To the Rescue of Endangered Plants
description: Pogo, the beloved opossum developed by the late cartoonist, Walt Kelly, once appeared on a poster supporting anti-pollution causes. He was saying ''We have met the enemy, and they is us.''

title: A Ruling In Medical Center's AIDS Case
description: LEAD: AN administrative judge from the State Division of Human Rights has concluded that the County Medical Center illegally discriminated against a pharmacist who has the AIDS virus when it delayed in hiring him, but that the hospital was not wrong in placing restrictions on him once it had given him a job.

title: A Skyscraper-High Office Space Surplus
description: WITH office construction running at high levels at a time when New York City and its suburbs are struggling through an economic downturn, experts say the region is confronting the largest office space surplus in more than a decade.

title: SURVIVAL OF THE LUCKIEST
description: WONDERFUL LIFE The Burgess Shale and the Nature of History. By Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 347 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: Glen Cove Acts to Update Environmental Laws
