description: THE city of Glen Cove has revised its environmental ordinances, many for the first time in 50 years, to keep pace with technological changes.

title: SHORTAGE OF FOOD SEEN FOR AFGHANS
description: United Nations officials are worried that hundreds of thousands of poor and displaced people in Afghanistan's cities may suffer another winter with too little to eat.

title: Foster Parents Testify on Failures in the Child-Welfare System
description: Grieving and angry over the loss of children that they could not help but think of as their own, a group of foster parents came to City Hall Thursday to offer stirring testimony about the ways in which government had failed the youngsters.

title: W. Virginia Routs Cincinnati by 69-3
description: Major Harris threw for two touchdowns and ran for another in just over a half today as West Virginia ended a two-week slump with a 69-3 rout of Cincinnati.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
An East Side Luxury Hotel
description: LEAD: A $25.5 million, 155-room, full-service hotel overlooking Independence Square is nearing completion here about 10 blocks east of City Hall in an area dense with historic sites such as the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FROM JOHANNESBURG

title: A Kosher Cafe Challenges Stereotypes
description: IN years past, kosher restaurants were predictable. The kosher symbol in the window always meant corned beef, pastrami, stuffed derma, potato pancakes and matzoh ball soup: traditional heavy eating.

title: Plane Crashes in Honduras, Killing at Least 131
description: A Honduran jet carrying 146 people broke apart in the air and crashed in flames into a mountain today as it prepared to land, killing at least 131 people, officials said.

title: At a Hospital, a Harsh Lesson on Drugs
description: As the group of 10-year-olds walked into the pediatric ward of the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, , their giggles and horseplay quickly changed into apprehension when they heard a rapid knock-knock sound.

title: Mansion Melodies and Mini-Concerts
description: THE pumpkins reach the Old Ferry Dock in Beacon this afternoon, and then resume their sail to other towns along the Hudson. It is the annual Pumpkin Festival, when huge piles of the gourds are offloaded from the sloop Clearwater each day while its crew is on call for ballad-singing, story-telling and ecological discussions.

title: East Village: Quirky Mix for Rockers, and Bankers
description: Amid the graffiti-splattered walls and the trash-strewn streets of the East Village lies an oasis of fashion: more than a dozen stores selling clothing, accessories and jewelry for men and women are scattered along the crosstown streets of St. Marks Place and Ninth, Eighth, Seventh and First Streets.

title:
INVESTING;
Defense Stocks in a Budget-Cutting Era
description: LEAD: In recent years the stocks of military contractors have stagnated. Many money managers have avoided what they see as a shrinking and troubled industry. As a result, they have overlooked several attractive companies that specialize in advanced electronics.

title: Who Has to Do What As New York Prepares To Pick a New Mayor
description: THE nomination of David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani for mayor of New York City last month also produced two political truisms: that Mr. Giuliani could not win without first deflating Mr. Dinkins, and that this would be Mr. Dinkins's election to lose.

title: Janice T. Hirsch Wed To Michael L. Doniger
description: Janice Turner Hirsch, the daughter of Mrs. Warren Jones Denniston of Norfolk, Va., and the late Gus C. Turner Jr., was married yesterday to Michael Leslie Doniger, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Doniger of Lincolnwood, Ill. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated at the ''21'' Club in New York.

title: Selling Boating Safety Amid Advice
description: LEAD: HENRY E. MARX has found a full-time niche selling boating safety. After almost seven years as owner of Landfall Navigation in Greenwich, Mr. Marx caters to the safety-conscious boater traveling south for the winter, north for next summer or to a far-flung place anytime of year.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 1 about the economist Jeffrey Sachs misidentified the sponsor of his trips to Poland. It is the Stefan Batory Society.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The year's most remarkable contribution to international understanding in the world of bridge took place in Mragowo, Poland, in mid-July. It was the 8th European Junior Bridge Camp. It attracted 174 juniors aged 25 and under. The youngest was a 12-year-old Danish girl.

title: Feminist Version
description: To the Editor:

title: Gazing Into the Economic Crystal Ball
description: THE bad news: The Long Island economy faces trouble. The good news? We should start thinking about making some changes in our regional economy. While the Island has long-term strengths, the time to deal with a future of stress is before a storm.

title: Tigers Start Slow But Pick Up Steam
description: It was an unfamiliar role for an Ivy League football team, but Princeton played like the big shot on the block today and bullied a decidedly weaker Fordham team at Palmer Stadium.

title: Some Say Plan for Lake Erie Park Could Make Matters Worse
description: Despite a decade of evidence that breakwaters ruin shorelines, Pennsylvania recently began building the world's largest breakwater system here to protect one of the nation's most popular parks from the pounding waves of Lake Erie.

title: Fiona Ward Wed To Gregory Clapp
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, Fiona C. Ward was married yesterday to Gregory G. Clapp. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Ward of Riverdale, the Bronx. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Clapp of Birmingham and Harbor Springs, Mich.

title:
GARDENING;
For Autumnal Color, Maples From Asia
description: LEAD: WHILE two native maples, the sugar maple (Acer saccharum) and the red maple (Acer rubrum), are unexcelled for fall color, the rest of the native maples are either not widely planted in this area or not noted for their exceptional autumn foliage. Some European or Eurasian species turn yellow at best.

title: Mr. Dinkins's Self-Inflicted Wounds
description: When he finally got around to answering a complex set of allegations about his personal finances, David Dinkins did it with poise and patience. The New York Democratic mayoral nominee fielded questions for nearly two hours Friday, trying to explain why he sold stock to his son for $58,000 two and a half years after he valued the same stock at more than $1 million.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Stylish Little Place Beside a Lake
description: LEAD: THERE'S a feeling of serendipity when you first come upon the Dove Island Inn. To find such a stylish little lakeside restaurant in what seems to be the middle of nowhere is indeed a surprise.

title: The Realities of 'Friday the 13th'
description: Thank you, Tokyo.

title: An AIDS Bite and a Conviction
description: A man infected with the AIDS virus was convicted of attempted murder on Friday for biting a police officer.

title: William Bullis 2d, Medical Student, Weds Miss Gano
description: Jennifer Lauren Gano and William John Bullis 2d, graduates of Georgetown University in Washington, were married there yesterday in the Dahlgren Chapel by the Rev. James P. M. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Roger Gano of Harrison, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hoover Bullis of Rockville, Md.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Queen of the Jungle: The Look of the Cat
description: One of the most appealing looks of the year is one of the simplest: a two-piece ensemble - black stretch tights and a black one-piece cat suit - that creates a stark, sleek silhouette. The tights and cat suits are blends of synthetic stretch fibers, cotton and wool. They fit snugly, enhancing and seeming to extend the figure.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Braniff Cutback: What to Do With Tickets

title: U.S. Jews Plan Drive to Protect Auschwitz Site
description: Troubled by the decay of buildings and exhibits at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, American Jews are organizing an international campaign to conserve them.

title: 'You Are a Dog'
description: They blindfolded him and handcuffed him with his hands behind his back. Soldiers whispered in his ear, ''You are a dog.'' After putting a cloth in his mouth to keep him from screaming, they burned him with a cigarette on his ear and hand. Then they took him into a bathroom and made him lie on the tile floor.

title: POSTINGS: The Meadowlands; 88,000 Ft. For Trade Shows
description: Convention and trade show organizers and exhibitors who want space in the Meadowlands now are limited to hotel meeting rooms or the stadium in the Brendan T. Byrne Arena in the Sports Complex. But not for long.

title: Report Urging End Of Homosexual Ban Rejected by Military
description: A draft report by a Pentagon research center concludes that the American military should consider ending discriminatory practices against homosexuals and allowing them in the services.

title: To Challenge Top Students, Academies Are Needed
description: AT a time when other states are moving aggressively to provide challenging opportunities for their best and brightest high school students, New Jersey is lagging behind.

title: Executive Is Wed To Julia Talavera
description: Julia Talavera and Robert McKay Pflieger were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Washington by the Rev. John F. Myslinski. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Edwin Flye Stetson 2d of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Rafael F. Talavera. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ely Pflieger of Washington.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The exchange sacrifice is the one offer that players who have sworn off sacrifices will still venture. That's because so much of the time an exchange sacrifice is really more a kind of positional investment than a bludgeon of attack.

title: HOLLYWOOD CONNECTIONS: WHERE THE MOVIES COME FROM
description: Each of the eight major studios has its own strategy to make movies in the 1990's. Here are some of the gambits and people involved. COLUMBIA

title: Pilot in Errant Flight Loses His Right to Fly
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will not allow the pilot who was apparently unconscious while his small plane flew about 1,000 miles down the East Coast and crashed near the Bahamas last July to fly a plane again anytime soon.

title: Glitter at 'Traviata' Opening And a Barbie Doll at U.N.
description: Even the jewels were on a grand scale at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''La Traviata'' Monday. Many eyes were on Lamia Khashoggi, who wore a red dress and enormous diamond bracelets ballooning around her wrists. Far above, boxes were occupied by such as Henry Kravis, Saul Steinberg and Brooke Astor.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: They aren't daydreams because most daydreams are so far-fetched and even ridiculous (which doesn't mean that they aren't wonderful) that there's almost no chance that they could ever come true. But certainly once or twice in each lifetime, there are foolish, impractical things that we could do, and even fleetingly consider doing, but that we back away from, usually because we're afraid of making fools of ourselves or embarrassed for other reasons.

title: 5-Man Giants' Rotation Enters Craig's Strategy
description: They were supposed to have a workout today, but the San Francisco Giants instead spent most of their morning playing cards, signing baseballs and taking batting practice in a cage not far from their clubhouse.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: GWENDOLYN S. KING;
Safeguarding Social Security
description: LEAD: THOUGH an honors student and president of the French Club when she attended Orange (N.J.) High School, Gwendolyn S. King never thought she might one day occupy an office in the West Wing of the White House, or be nominated by President Bush for Commissioner of the Social Security Administration.

title: Story With a Moral, And a Twist From Time
description: I DON'T remember how we got on the subject, but on a recent shopping trip to Mount Kisco I was prompted to tell my wife the story of ''Masha and Sasha.'' It's something I read in a book when I was a very little boy, and it stuck with me ever since. It seemed like such a valuable lesson to learn and to live by. The story of ''Masha and Sasha'': Once upon a time, in a little village, there lived a dry-goods merchant who had two apprentices, Masha and Sasha. After six months, Masha came to the boss and said, ''Boss, I've been here just as long as Sasha, but you pay him two rubles a week more than me. That's just not fair.''

title: Houston Accident Care: Options Are Cut
description: After more than a year of financial chaos, one of the two Houston hospitals offering trauma care closed its doors this month to ambulances carrying the severely injured.

title: Ranger Defense Holds Fort
description: The noise was deafening, the physical attack numbing. For the Rangers, everything was under assault: their net, their lead, their philosophy that common sense and unadorned defense will more often than not prevail.

title: Jewelry Gaining in Crafts
description: IT is easy to spot the jewelry booths at crafts fairs. Customers decked out in new earrings cluster in front of the booths, waiting to admire themselves in a mirror. But the true cognoscenti of handmade jewelry, the insatiable collectors, continue searching the aisles, checking out the booths of crafts people who miniaturize some of their work into jewelry.

title: Independents, Feeling a Pinch, Restyle a Niche
description: These are difficult days for the small independent video store. For one thing, many of the customers who dropped in for rentals and perhaps a purchase or two are now off scouting the miles of cassette bins in huge discount department stores. ''We can't compete with their prices,'' says Jan DeMasse, the proprietor of the Video Place in Exeter, N. H., and a board member of the national Software Dealers Association.

title: Helping Teen-Age Parents in School
description: LEAD: SHEILA PAYTON, 18 years old, is expecting her second child. She knows it will be a boy, and her boyfriend wants to name him Steven 3d.

title: Backup Leads Hofstra
description: Andy Ryan, filling in at quarterback for the injured Rhory Moss, ran 4 yards for a touchdown and completed 9 of 16 passes for 150 yards as Hofstra defeated Merchant Marine Academy, 15-8, yesterday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AS A Surfeit of Similes. By Norton Juster. Illustrated by David Small. Unpaged. New York: William Morrow & Company. $9.95. (Ages 9 and up)

title: Lisa S. Benenson Wed To Joseph Quattrocchi
description: Lisa Sharon Benenson and Joseph A. Quattrocchi were married in New York last evening at the Pierre by Rabbi David M. Posner. Mrs. Quattrocchi is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hartley Benenson of New York. Her husband is a son of Laura P. Quattrocchi of Fort Edward, N.Y., and the late Anthony J. Quattrocchi.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 8 about a videotape produced by the League of Women Voters in Maplewood about New Jersey's garbage crisis misidentified a television network that will show the program. It will be broadcast on Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. on the Cable Television Network of New Jersey, not the New Jersey Network.

title: 'Red Revolution'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Says Trouble Is Past, But Some Supporters Wonder
description: Campaigning amid large and enthusiastic crowds on the streets of four Queens neighborhoods yesterday, David N. Dinkins seemed buoyed by the cheers and said he believed he had put questions about his transfer of stock to his son behind him.

title: Madrid: A New Beat
description: WARNING: Madrid contains a potentially addictive form of night life. Occasional visitors can develop a sudden reluctance to go to bed early. Much of the local population shows symptoms of advanced insomnia. Those young at heart - and with a body willing to follow - are especially vulnerable.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ON a rocky spit at the river's edge just a few miles below the George Washington Bridge, 32 brand new town-house condominiums sit empty and fading, reminders that although the wild, lawless waterfront has drastically changed, part of it, for better or worse, endures.

title: Who Gets the Liver? The Gaffes of Waiters
description: BECAUSE, like more and more Americans, my wife and I love dining out, and love it best where we find the best food and ambiance and service, we seek out the wonderful restaurants in New York City.

title: Challengers for Cup Split by Legal Issue
description: Challengers for the America's Cup have split over the legalities that hamstring the future of the event. Some talk reluctantly of pulling out of the races altogether, while others would like to see the New York legal system resolve the impasse no matter how long it takes.

title: Review/Dance; Nikolais-Louis Troupe In Premiere of 'Act One'
description: Murray Louis has a bright new work in ''Act One,'' which was presented by Nikolais and Louis Dance for the first time in New York on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. It provided an intriguing look at Mr. Louis's strengths and weaknesses.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;
Drivers Bidding on a Dream
description: LEAD: ''I HAVE a quarter, a quarter, a quarter. Do I hear a half, half, half? You're in. You're out. Say hello.

title: Marc A. Zambetti, Sales Director, 27
description: Marc A. Zambetti, a sales director for the Stella D'Oro Biscuit Company, was killed in the collapse of the Nimitz Freeway in Tuesday's earthquake in Oakland. The 27-year-old San Francisco resident was a grandson of the company's founders and the son of its chief executive officer.

title: Treasures of the Czars
description: FOR more than 500 years the treasure of the Kremlin has been one of the great sights of Moscow. In 1485, after the completion of the first stone churches and palaces, the collection had become important enough to erect a special building to house it. By the 16th century, the czar's treasure was so large that when Ivan the Terrible retreated to Novgorod before the Crimean Khan, the treasury contents occupied 450 sleighs.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large kitchen with 25-year-old cabinets covered with a brown matte-finish plastic laminate. We would like to paint these cabinets white. How can we make paint stick to this laminate?

title: Old Hamptons Houses Getting Major Facelifts
description: LEAD: ACROSS the Hamptons, scores of stately, if weathered, old homes are being bought for large sums, then renovated and or rebuilt.

title: THE PRODUCERS
description: IT IS LATE AUGUST, A MONTH BEFORE THE BATTLE BE-tween Warner Bros. and Sony would turn Hollywood on its ear.

title: Freeport Opposing Indoor Marina for 150 Boats
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of Freeport who live in a section of the village laced with canals, together with the village government, are fighting a developer who is erecting a 40-foot-high enclosed building to store 150 boats in the off season.

title: Miss Pond Weds R. G. Hubbard 2d
description: Constance Sue Pond, the president of Charter Service of America, an aircraft charter company in Nashua, N.H., and Robert Glenn Hubbard 2d, a professor of economics and finance at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, were married in Boston yesterday. The Unitarian-Universalist ceremony was performed at the First and Second Church in Boston by the Rev. Dr. Rhys Williams and the Rev. Lawrence X. Peers.

title: How Washington Shifted to Embracing Gorbachev
description: Five months ago the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, dismissed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a ''drugstore cowboy'' - all hat and no cattle, all talk and no delivery.

title: Indian Consumer Group Wins Fight on Medicine
description: An Indian public interest group, charging that pharmaceutical companies are supplying hospitals with contaminated products, won its first battle this week against drug enforcement agencies.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Music on the Light Side Gets Heavy Play Again
description: LEAD: When you have momentarily tired of a steady diet of masterpieces, there is nothing that refreshes the palate better than a tuneful helping of vintage light music.

title: WALL STREET GEARS UP TO BACK A BUYOUT WAVE
description: Auto dealers have long shunned the notion of raising money from outside investors. They don't like ''anyone under the tent but them,'' explained Ezra Mager, an executive vice president at Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney Inc., a New York-based investment banker.

title: Why the Road Turned Rocky for 'Old Gringo'
description: When the movie ''Old Gringo'' was being filmed here early in 1988, it seemed to everyone involved to have all the prerequisites for great artistic and commercial success. In Gregory Peck and Jane Fonda, the film boasted two big names, paired with each other for the first time. The Carlos Fuentes novel on which the script was based offered a story full of passion, both political and erotic, and intelligence. To top things off, there were Mexico's spectacular landscapes and colorful folklore, as well as the innate drama and violence of the Mexican Revolution.

title: A Grown-Ups' Designer Offers Glamour for Girls
description: Victor Costa, the designer whose fame rests partly in making brilliant copies of haute couture and selling them for hundreds rather than thousands of dollars, is now glamorizing little girls' party dresses.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Me.; Competing For the Malls
description: ALTHOUGH plans for regional shopping malls in both Augusta and Waterville have been announced, it is generally acknowledged that only one is likely to be built.

title: Wedding Plans For Amy Wilentz
description: Justice Robert N. Wilentz of Deal, N.J., has announced November wedding plans for his daughter, Amy Wilentz, and Nicholas Goldberg, a son of Richard Goldberg of Wiesbaden, West Germany, and Uli Monaco of New York.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; The Slow Market Benefits Conservation
description: AS developers fret over their stagnant projects, land conservationists are taking advantage of the slow property market to gather parcels while they may.

title: Bereavement
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 9 my father passed away in Maine. We contacted Continental and told them that we had a death in the family. They did not offer any special rate, and I had to pay $320 one way to Maine. The next day your story appeared, so when I returned to Florida I called customer service. They stated that they did not have any special rates for bereavement. WILLIAM L. PAYSON SR. Plant City, Fla.

title: Phoenix Open Increases Purse
description: The Phoenix Open has obtained corporate sponsorship, and the purse for the 1990 golf tournament has increased $200,000 to $900,000.

title: GRIDIRON GREED
description: A PAYROLL TO MEET A Story of Greed, Corruption, and Football at SMU. By David Whitford. Illustrated. 221 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95. THE HUNDRED YARD LIE The Corruption of College Football and What We Can Do to Stop It. By Rick Telander. 223 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Missouri; 'Little Sister' Program Stopped After Assaults
description: Four fraternity-associated sexual assaults, including two last weekend, have prompted the University of Missouri-Columbia temporarily to suspend all ''little sister'' organizations associated with fraternities.

title:
FOCUS: Framingham, Mass.;
Keeping U.S.-Aided Housing Affordable
description: LEAD: IN an experiment that could have national significance, a section of a 20-year-old housing complex here was sold last month by a private developer to a nonprofit corporation specifically designed to own and operate the project.

title: David Duncan: Pillow Designer
description: David Duncan has had a passionate interest in antique textiles for many years.

title: A GENTLEMAN IN THE GALLERY
description: READING RUSSELL Essays 1941-1988. On Ideas, Literature, Art, Theater, Music, Places, and Persons. By John Russell. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $29.95.

title: ANYONE FOR WAR?
description: THE LONG GRAY LINE By Rick Atkinson. Illustrated. 592 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
New Projects Start a Bay Shore Revival
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING years of decline, downtown Bay Shore is emerging as a professional and corporate office center that is attracting new retail activity to Main Street.

title: Carla Edwards Weds Herve Gouraige
description: The marriage of Carla Jean Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Edwards of Jersey City, and Herve Gouraige, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frantz Gouraige of Rowland Heights, Calif., took place yesterday at the Riverside Church in New York. The Revs. Erik Kolbell, a United Church of Christ minister, and Peter D. Ammerman, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Behind Japan's Passion for a Pinball Game, the Unsavory Side of Society
description: It was only noon, but the New Alpha Pachinko Parlor here was already throbbing as dozens of pinball enthusiasts sat mesmerized in front of their machines amid a deafening roar of bells, buzzers, rock music and shouted exhortations over the microphone.

title: GOING PUBLIC
description: CLICK. AT 2:30 P.M. IN RESTAURANTS IN NEW York, a synchronized activity begins. Women open their compacts and swiftly pat noses, cheeks, chins.

title: David Hare Captures His Muse on Stage
description: WHen the British playwright David Hare sat down to write ''The Secret Rapture,'' a strong and striking image came into his head. It was of a youngish woman sitting quietly in the dark beside the bed in which her father lay dead. He wasn't altogether sure what she'd do or where she'd go, but he knew at once who would, who must embody the character in the theater: the actress Blair Brown. ''It wasn't that she was Blair, but she was always going to be played by Blair,'' he says. ''And that realization gave me the extra juice I needed as I was working on the character.''

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Sept. 24 about lodgings in Scotland misstated the scope of the listing. It included the Shetland Islands, not just the Highlands.

title: 'A Little Fright Music' And 'Authentic' Baroque
description: A BUSY chamber music week is not unexpected at this time of year - and we certainly have it - but the symphonic floodgates have opened as well. First is the Fairfield Period Instrument Academy, a professional, chamber-sized ensemble that calls itself ''Connecticut's first 'authentic' instrument orchestra,'' is appearing at 4 this afternoon at St. Paul's-on-the-Green in Norwalk. On the program: Mozart, Bach and Corelli, with John Solum the guest (baroque) flute soloist, and Thomas Crawford conducting (255-1160).

title: Many Issues Neglected In Race for Governor
description: AS it enters its final weeks, the campaign for governor is attracting notice as much for what the candidates are not talking about as for what they are.

title: Ms. Topper Wed To Paul A. Hurty
description: Elizabeth Hale Topper and Paul Anders Hurty were married yesterday by the Rev. Clifford Gain at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Nativity in Marina Del Rey, Calif. The bride, who is 29 years old and is known as Betsy, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Topper of New Providence, N.J. Her husband, 29, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Hurty of Yorba Linda, Calif.

title: Brokers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Building Codes: Designs for Last Quake, Not Next
description: When it opened in 1957, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland was an engineering marvel. The story of how it became a concrete graveyard is the story of California's century of attempts to define what makes a structure withstand an earthquake.

title: Sharyn Kaplan to Marry Vincent Tritto in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Solomon H. Kaplan of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharyn A. Kaplan, to Vincent B. Tritto, the son of Joseph Tritto of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Palme's Widow Criticizes Police
description: The widow of Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden said today that the police and the press ''sabotaged'' the inquiry into her husband's killing and the subsequent trial.

title: Kerry Duffy Wed To Leo P. Wetter
description: Kerry Ann Duffy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malachy J. Duffy of Westbury, L.I., and Leo Peter Wetter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Wetter of Westbury, were married there yesterday at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Timothy McDonnell.

title: THEY LIKE IKE
description: Harry S. Truman is entitled to his opinions, but, buried under the Eisenhower landslides of 1952 and 1956, his attacks look awfully petty (''He Didn't Like Ike,'' by Harry S. Truman, Sept. 17).

title: 2d 'A' in A.A. Important, Too
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reviews/Dance; Role Debut for Dakin In Graham's 'Meadow'
description: Martha Graham has written of the many sources for her ''Dark Meadow,'' among them Roman, Greek and American Indian myths and Jungian theory about the collective unconscious. One might reasonably expect a bit of clutter. And certainly the dance, presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Thursday at City Center, has its share of sculptural Noguchi artifacts, portentous cloaks and leaping entrances and exits for the corps.

title: POSTINGS: Four Levels, With Elevators; Looking Down on Wickers Creek
description: Most builders like to put their projects on level, open ground so potential buyers can visualize barbecues and ball games on the lawn out the back door.

title: Surge in 2d Half Lifts Irish Past Trojans
description: There had been so much talk in recent weeks about Raghib Ismail, Notre Dame's phenomenal sophomore tailback, that Coach Lou Holtz felt obliged to remind the team's fans that the Rocket was simply the latest Notre Damer to step forward and deliver when needed.

title: New &Noteworthy
description: OUT OF THIS WORLD, by Graham Swift. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $7.95.) As Harry Beech, an aerial photographer, flies over the English landscape, his daughter lies on a psychoanalyst's couch in Manhattan. Both try to figure out how their relationship went wrong. ''Not a book the reader is likely to forget, 'Out of This World' deserves to be ranked at the forefront of contemporary literature,'' Linda Gray Sexton said here last year. ADAM, EVE, AND THE SERPENT, by Elaine Pagels. (Vintage, $8.95.) In her examination of Genesis 1-3 the author of ''The Gnostic Gospels'' shows how politics might have helped transform the cryptic Garden of Eden myth from a celebration of freedom to a condemnation of original sin. The book ''has the distinctive qualities so many admired in her work on the Gnostic Gospels,'' Robin Lane Fox said in The Book Review last year. ''It is very clearly written. It has form, moral impetus and direction.'' THE DREAMS OF REASON: The Computer and the Rise of the Sciences of Complexity, by Heinz R. Pagels. (Bantam, $9.95.) Mr. Pagels, who died in a mountaineering accident in Colorado in 1988, writes that like the telescope and the microscope the computer will be a tool that brings on a new scientific age. Last year our reviewer, Brian Hayes, said this ''casual, discursive book . . . contains as much philosophy as science, and it includes a generous measure of informal autobiography and anecdote as well.'' In one section of the book, Mr. Pagels writes, ''I remain an optimist and believe that the liberating capacity of our knowledge, along with a little wisdom, will affirm the power of life over death. I continue to believe that the distant day will come when the order of human affairs is not entirely established by domination.'' AROUND THE DAY IN EIGHTY WORLDS, by Julio Cortazar. Translated by Thomas Christensen. (North Point, $11.95.) The cast of characters in Julio Cortazar's literary game includes Marcel Duchamp, Louis Armstrong and a cat named Theodor W. Adorno. ''With this miscellany that's as challenging as an infinite exercise in connect-the-dots, a color-by-number landscape a la Salvador Dali, the late Argentine fabulist constructs yet another prototype of literature as schoolboy's amusement,'' John Krich said here in 1986. ''Profundity is the grand prize and the winner is the first player to disregard the rules altogether.'' PASSION & CUNNING: Essays on Nationalism, Terrorism and Revolution, by Conor Cruise O'Brien. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) When this collection of writings was published last year our reviewer, Linda Robinson, said the book is ''a service to anyone unfamiliar with his lucid prose. Mr. O'Brien takes on the most intractable conflicts, puncturing fashionable views with pungent comments that sometimes make his fellow liberals uncomfortable.'' PALM LATITUDES, by Kate Braverman. (Penguin, $8.95.) In East Los Angeles, a capital of the steamy, rotting land Kate Braverman calls the Palm Latitudes, Francisca, Gloria and Marta feel doubly alienated because they are female as well as Hispanic. Last year The Times's reviewer, Michiko Kakutani, said the author ''possesses a magical, incantatory voice and the ability to loft ordinary lives into the heightened world of myth, and in using these gifts to recount the tales of these three women she has succeeded in creating a work of hallucinatory, poetic power.'' Penguin has also republished Ms. Braverman's 1979 novel LITHIUM FOR MEDEA ($7.95.), which is set in the Los Angeles of the 60's. THE INVENTION OF MEMORY: A New View of the Brain, by Israel Rosenfield. (Basic, $9.95.) Memories are not fixed images stored in the brain, the author argues, but imaginative reconstructions. In 1988 our reviewer, James W. Lance, said the argument was overdrawn but that the book ''will stimulate interest in one of the most intriguing aspects of brain function.'' THE SWIMMING-POOL LIBRARY, by Alan Hollinghurst. (Vintage, $8.95.) A young, upper-crust British homosexual meets a like-minded older man and together they learn that gay culture cuts through the boundaries of class. ''Like Edmund White, Alan Hollinghurst is a polished poet of homosexual desire,'' Catherine R. Stimpson said here last year. His novel ''tells of impurities with shimmering elegance, of complexities with a camp-fired wit and of truths with a fiction's solid grace.'' BROTHERS: Black and Poor - A True Story of Courage and Survival, by Sylvester Monroe and Peter Goldman, with Vern E. Smith, Terry E. Johnson, Monroe Anderson and Jacques Chenet. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A dozen black men who grew up on Chicago's South Side tell about their successes, but mostly their failures to escape from the ghetto. ''You see men of substance, who they are and how they got to be that way,'' Phyllis Crockett said here last year. ''In 'Brothers' we come to understand why so few make it.'' FATAL LIGHT, by Richard Currey. (Penguin, $6.95.) This story of a young West Virginia man who becomes a medic in Vietnam is ''a spare, elegant novel that manages to summon several layers of images, some quite beautiful, others horrifying,'' Meg Wolitzer said in The Book Review last year. HIS EMINENCE AND HIZZONER: A Candid Exchange, by John O'Connor and Edward I. Koch. (Avon, $4.95.) The Mayor and the Archbishop of New York talk about gay rights, AIDS, abortion and other subjects on which they fundamentally disagree. This is ''a fascinating book,'' Andrew Hacker said in these pages earlier this year. ''They have used this set of alternating essays to present their ideas in some depth.''

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
How Do We Differ? Let Me Count the Ways
description: LEAD: IT is said that, when couples are married a long time, the partners begin to resemble each other. (Which is the real reason people consult cosmetic surgeons after age 40.) But as anyone who has ever wiretapped my phone could tell you, men and women are vastly different.

title: Close Encounters of the Soviet Kind
description: To the Editor:

title: Lauren A. Spina, A Lawyer, Weds
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Glen Cove, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lauren Astrid Spina, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Spina of Bellmore, L.I., and Gray Watson Hampton 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hampton Jr. of Huntington, W.Va. The Rev. Bruce Curry Page officiated.

title: William Lerch Jr. And Susan Torell Wed in Bronxville
description: Susan Allgood Torell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Torell 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., and Pasadena, Calif., was married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Bronxville to William Nelson Lerch Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lerch of Lothian, Md. The Rev. Dr. Richard J. Lichti performed the ceremony.

title: SPEAKING THE PRINCE'S ENGLISH
description: Malcolm Bradbury deplores ''contemporary British media personalities'' who ''wallow in vernacular informality and a heavy regional accent.''

title: Nicole L. Hiegel Becomes the Bride Of J. S. Bomann
description: Nicole Laurance Hiegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hiegel of New York and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to J. Scott Bomann, a son of Donald Bomann Jr. and Mrs. Charles A. Nebauer, both of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Stanislaus Mosley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Thomas More Church in New York.

title: Hospitals Ready for Bitter Battle On Rate Increases
description: THE average patient in a Connecticut hospital in the year ending Sept. 30 incurred a bill of $5,872.37. Under budgets proposed by the state's 34 general hospitals for the current year, that same patient would pay nearly $6,900, an increase of 18.8 percent, and the magnitude of that increase has shocked state officials and the businesses that would pay higher health insurance premiums to support those rates.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: I RAISE MY EYES TO SAY YES. By Ruth Sienkiewicz-Mercer and Steven B. Kaplan. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) Her body has been functionally useless since infancy and she never has been able to talk, but Ruth Sienkiewicz-Mercer, who has cerebral palsy, has written her autobiography. ''I Raise My Eyes to Say Yes'' provides an extraordinary look at being severely disabled in a society that is ill-prepared to cope with the handicapped.

title: N.C. State Stopped By Clemson, 30-10
description: Chris Gardocki kicked three field goals as Clemson defeated previously undefeated North Carolina State by 30-10 today to keep alive its slim hopes of winning an unprecedented fourth consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference title.

title: Stinging Forces
description: It was the British forces under Lord Cornwallis who first learned just how testy the residents of Charlotte, N.C., and surrounding Mecklenburg County could be when provoked.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Hails Unity on Women
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury has endorsed the decision of Episcopal bishops to accommodate sharp differences over the ordination of women.

title: Salina Journal; Rallying Around A Prairie Prophet
description: As if responding to a prophet crying in the wilderness, experts, supporters and others trooped to the Kansas prairie this weekend to give and take advice on agriculture and its environmental problems.

title: UAL Board To Consider Its Next Step
description: Under pressure to respond to a $111.25-a-share plunge in the company's stock last week, the board of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, is to meet today in Chicago to consider several options.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about insurance losses in the California earthquake misidentified one of the big insurers in the San Francisco Bay area.

title: Mapplethorpe Show Opens in Hartford
description: An exhibition of photographs that stirred a national debate over public financing of the arts drew an overflow crowd, including a few protesters, in its first showing since the uproar in Washington.

title: Marc A. Zambetti Sales Director, 27
description: Marc A. Zambetti, a sales director for the Stella D'Oro Biscuit Company, was killed in the collapse of the Nimitz Freeway in Tuesday's earthquake in Oakland. The 27-year-old San Francisco resident was a grandson of the company's founders and the son of its chief executive officer.

title: Maryland Board Approving Sales Of Most Handguns It Considers
description: The state board responsible for deciding which handguns can be sold in Maryland under one of the country's newest and most disputed firearms laws has turned down only a few dozen of almost 700 pistols and revolvers it considered.

title: When the Writers Read, the Readers Listen
description: Fiction readings. Nonfiction readings. Celebrity readings. Amateur readings. Library readings. School readings. Church readings. Synagogue readings. Y readings. Charity readings. Publicity readings. Street readings. Readings? The public reading is enjoying a renaissance in New York City. This fall, the proprietors of venerable series like those at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y, the Writer's Voice at the West Side Y.M.C.A. and the Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery report that their audiences are getting not only larger, but also younger. In addition, the number of offerings at established venues has been augmented by a host of readings in schools, libraries and churches.

title: Books of The Times; From Stephen King, A Writer's Demon
description: The Dark Half By Stephen King 431 pages. Viking. $21.95.

title: Outdoors: A Reel of Diplomacy
description: I WAS sitting in what passes for the Oval Office in this tiny principality high in the Pyrenees talking about fishing with several of Andorra's government officials when Prime Minister Josip Pintat walked into the office.

title: In Paris, Ready-to-Wear Forgoes Understatement
description: Each of the major fashion houses showing spring and summer ready-to-wear this weekend had a distinctive style, so it was quite possible to tell the players without a scorecard. If the clothes were not always memorable, the shows were.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Holly Farms Shifts Tactics In Campaign
description: LEAD: GROWING competition in the refrigerated meat case has driven Holly Farms, the country's largest producer of branded fresh chicken, into taking a more competitive tack in its marketing and advertising, the company says.

title: Diuretics Continue to Be an Effective Therapy for Hypertension
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Piano; Emigre's 10th Anniversary
description: When the pianist Bella Davidovich emigrated from the Soviet Union in 1979, her name was known in the United States, but her playing had been heard only on pirated concert tapes. She made her New York debut at Carnegie Hall that year on Oct. 21, with a Schumann and Chopin recital, and has been heard here many times since then. On Saturday evening, Miss Davidovich returned to Carnegie Hall for the 10th anniversary of her debut, and again offered music by Schumann and Chopin.

title: Sinking Jets Manage 3 Points
description: It got lower today for the Jets.

title: Giuliani and Dinkins See Need for Debates
description: With only two weeks left in the campaign, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani each said yesterday that they should hold at least two debates before Election Day, but they did not agree on a date for even one.

title: El Salvador Striving To Regain Prosperity
description: As El Salvador's civil war enters its second decade, the country's new conservative Government has initiated an audacious liberalization program intended to rebuild a battered economy and alleviate the social injustice, unemployment and stagnation from which leftist insurgents have historically drawn their strength.

title: Tucker Anthony Officer New President of J. Bush
description: The investment management firm of J. Bush & Company has named a new president, William R. Gill Jr. Mr. Gill, 53, comes from Tucker Anthony & R. L. Day Inc., where he was a managing director. The J. Bush of his new firm is Jonathan Bush, 58, President Bush's younger brother and a leading New York Republican.

title: INSIDE
description: H.U.D. Jurisdiction Moved housing secretary has decided to shift control over programs in Puerto Rico from the agency's troubled New York office to Atlanta. Page B1. Concern on Home Abortion In a revival of a technique that flourished in the 1960's, scores of self-help groups are teaching women how to perform abortions. Page B12. Conflict on Panama Reagan aides and Senators agreed in 1988 to shun any coup in which General Noriega might die. Page A10. Gorbachev and the Press The Soviet chief has made it clear that he sees glasnost not as a right but as a tool for change. Page A8.

title: Fear And the First Lady
description: ''Scathing and cruel . . . heartless and dumb . . . vicious and unbelievable'' are the adjectives chosen by Nancy Reagan's autobiographical collaborator to describe my writing about her, long before Nancyphobia became fashionable.

title: Frank A. Saunders, 67, Corporate Executive
description: Frank A. Saunders, a retired vice president of corporate relations and communications at Philip Morris Inc., who helped increase corporate support for the arts, died yesterday of pneumonia in Doctors Hospital after suffering a series of strokes. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan and Nantucket, Mass.

title: Where to Send Donations
description: Interaction, a voluntary relief assistance group supported by the Federal Government, has issued the following list of agencies to which money may be sent to assist earthquake victims: American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund, P.O. Box 4691, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163. Telephone: 800-453-9000. Americares Foundation, 51 Locust Avenue, New Canaan, Conn. 06840. Telephone: 203-966-5195. American Jewish World Service, 1290 Avenue of the Americas -11th floor, New York, N.Y. 10104. Telephone: 212-468-7380. Church World Service, P.O. Box 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Telephone: 212-870-3151. Direct Relief International, 2801-B De La Vina Street, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93105. Telephone: 805-687-3694. Episcopal Church/The Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief, The Episcopal Church Center, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Telephone: 800-334-7626, or in New York City 867-8400. Operation California/USA, 7615 1/2 Melrose Ave., Los Angeles. 90046. Telephone: 213-658-8876. The Salvation Army, San Francisco Earthquake Relief, 132 West 14th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011. Telephone: 212-807-4273. World Relief, P.O. Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. Telephone: 312-665-0235. World Vision, 919 West Huntington Drive, Monrovia, Calif. 91016. Telephone: 818-357-7979. Donations are also being collected by these groups: B'nai B'rith Bay Area Disaster Relief, B'nai B'rith, CVS. 1640 Rhode Island Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Convex Net Climbs 87%
description: Citing demand for its second generation of mini-supercomputers, the Convex Computer Corporation reported last week that its third-quarter earnings had increased 87 percent and its revenues had risen 50 percent.

title: Dangerous for Japan to Leave U.S. Security Fold; The Real Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL Military contractors are turning abroad for parts to build weapons systems, as the Pentagon puts pressure on companies to reduce costs and as foreign suppliers become more adept. The trend is raising fears on dependence, jobs and profits. [ Page A1. ] A plan to phase out many American farm programs if other countries agree to similar cutbacks will be put forward this week by the Bush Administration. But there is much skepticism about the prospects for the plan. [ D9. ] El Salvador's Government has begun an audacious program intended to rebuild a battered economy and alleviate the social injustice, unemployment and stagnation from which leftist insurgents have historically drawn their strength. [ D14. ] Chile is creating an autonomous central bank that the Government says will help preserve the nation's hard-won economic stability, growth and modernization. [ D14. ] THE ECONOMY Steel shipments are falling, reflecting a slowdown in the automobile and construction industries. Several analysts predict that total shipments in the second half of the year will be as much as 15 percent below 1988 levels. [ D1. ] Saving the world from global warming may require sharp reductions in burning fuel, but there was no consensus at a two-day meeting of 40 nuclear industry executives, government officials, energy experts and environmentalists on whether new nuclear reactors are needed. [ D1. ] COMPANIES I.B.M.'s control of the mainframe market is being threatened by far-reaching changes in the industry. Digital Equipment and Tandem are both planning to challenge I.B.M. in its most successful computer market. [ D1. ] UAL's board is to meet today to consider its options, under pressure to respond to the plunge in the company's stock. [ D1. ] R. H. Macy has agreed to make all of its private-label merchandise available to Kintetsu Department Stores of Japan. The one-year contract gives Macy an additional outlet for its large production capacity in East Asia. [ D2. ] Campeau is again facing cutbacks in merchandise shipments as some suppliers to its Federated and Allied department stores have found their trade credit curtailed or canceled. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS McGraw-Hill is willing to customize college textbooks to suit the needs of individual professors, or even individual students, and it says it can make the changes in 48 hours. [ D1. ] Eveready has turned to a marauding rabbit in an advertising campaign intended to startle viewers into paying attention. [ D11. ] China Books and Periodicals has closed its bookstores in New York and San Francisco and will close its Chicago store on Dec. 1, but it is expanding its other book businesses. [ D11. ] Magazine publishers are turning away from premiums as part of their campaigns to build circulation. Magazines. [ D11. ] Holly Farms has dropped Dinah Shore as a spokeswoman and turned to a fast-paced television campaign that puts the focus on health concerns. Advertising. [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Maryland has an innovative plan to try to resolve the thousands of asbestos cases that have swamped court dockets in the state. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ D2. ] What did not happen in the stock market last week may be more important than what did. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] Credit market participants are expected to return to their study of economic data and put the stock market's plunge behind them. Credit Markets. [ D9. ]

title: Deals
description: BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Announced the sale of the team to Bertram Lee and Peter Bynoe. LOS ANGELES (NBA) - Signed Torgeir Bryn, forward. PORTLAND (NBA) - Announced that Rolando Ferreira, center, had left camp. UTAH (NBA) - Waived Rory White and Reggie Turner, forwards. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Recalled Brad Lauer, left wing, from Springfield of the American Hockey League.

title: Nets Waive Jones
description: The Nets waived Charles Jones, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, yesterday to reduce their roster to 16 players. Jones, a four-year National Basketball Association veteran from Louisville, was signed by the Nets on Oct. 4 as a free agent. Jones played 43 games with Washington last season and has also played with Phoenix and Portland.

title: Nancy A. Frumer, Therapist, Weds
description: Nancy Augusta Frumer, a daughter of Mrs. Louis Reshin Frumer of New York and the late Mr. Frumer, was married yesterday to Charles Woodrow Styron Jr., the son of Dr. Styron and Nell Joslin Styron, both of Raleigh, N.C. William Karelis solemnized the marriage at the Dharmadhatu Buddhist Meditation Center in Newton, Mass.

title: Campaign Matters; Crisis After Crisis Lying in Wait For Next Mayor
description: Two weeks from tomorrow, either David N. Dinkins or Rudolph W. Giuliani will be mayor-elect of New York City after spending about $10 million and about 10 months campaigning. It's a wonder that anyone would want the job. The city's 106th mayor will lead New York into the final decade of the millenium, an era which Mayor Edward I. Koch's Commission on the Year 2000 said last year would be characterized by ''New York Ascending.''

title: Review/Theater; Out of the Old South, the Words of a Witness
description: Of all American storytellers, few are more popular than those elderly men and women whose memories reach back into the ashes of the Old South. And few deserve that popularity more than the 84-year-old Alabama cotton farmer whose reminiscences were published in 1974 under the title ''All God's Dangers: The Life of Nate Shaw.''

title: 11,000 Acre Fire Is Put Out
description: A fire that charred nearly 11,000 acres in three counties appeared tamed today under a light rain, but firefighters kept an eye out for flareups. The fire began Wednesday at this Marine base and spread to the San Mateo Canyon wilderness area in the Cleveland National Forest. It charred land in Orange, Riverside and San Diego counties, but no structures were burned. The blaze, which had not advanced since Friday, was declared 65 percent contained today.

title: The Senate Five
description: The House Banking Committee is finally investigating the Government's failure to move promptly against a big, mismanaged California savings and loan association. It has subpoenaed a raft of witnesses, but not five whose role is suspect and may have been crucial: Alan Cranston, Democrat of California Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio John McCain, Republican of Arizona Don Riegle, Democrat of Michigan

title: Washington at Work; Crowe v. Abrams: A Private Feud Over Handling Panama Becomes Public
description: The feud pits a true believer against a four-star admiral; a six-shooter against a 16-inch gun on a battleship.

title: Treating Kin Like Foster Parents Strains a New York Child Agency
description: What was once an obscure decision to start licensing and paying relatives who acted as foster parents to abused and neglected children has become a vast and costly program that is overwhelming New York City's child welfare bureaucracy and causing city and state officials to question its wisdom.

title: Woman Challenges New York State's Anti-Harassment Law
description: Jackie Dietze, who lives in a small town near the Canadian border, does not deny that she was loud, that she swore, that she threatened to beat up a neighbor. But she never raised a hand to anybody, she said, and therefore, she is not a criminal.

title: Prague Autumn
description: Czechoslovakia's cheerless Communist boss, Milos Jakes, lacks charisma but not cunning. He recently told a closed party meeting that the regime erred in jailing the country's best-known dissenter, the playwright Vaclev Havel. It would be far wiser, he said, to pick on lesser-known figures and so avoid an international uproar over human rights. His frank remarks, covertly taped, were broadcast several times by Radio Free Europe.

title: Suddenly Homeless in California, the Prosperous and the Poor Both Suffer; Homes on a Hilltop in Ruins, Families Help One Another
description: With its sculptured gardens and cantilevered decks overlooking wooded canyons, Sandra and Forrest Hill's home high in the Santa Cruz Mountains was the kind of magic place only long years of hard work and personal care could make.

title: U.S. Declines Offers of Help From Foreign Rescue Teams
description: The United States says it has declined with thanks all offers of help from foreign rescue teams to deal with the aftermath of the earthquake in Northern California.

title: After 4 Setbacks, Developers Hire Critic to Design Seaport Building
description: In their fifth attempt to build a large building in the small South Street Seaport Historic District, the developers Paul and Seymour Milstein have taken an unusual tack - hiring as their architect one of the most prominent critics of their fourth attempt.

title: Laura J. Zionts Weds Mark Yellin
description: Laura J. Zionts and Mark C. Yellin were married yesterday by Rabbi Simeon I. Glaser at Temple Beth Israel in West Hartford, Conn. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zionts of Bloomfield, Conn. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Yellin of West Hartford.

title: Nicaraguans Register in Huge Numbers
description: Nicaraguans jammed voter registration stations here today for the fourth consecutive Sunday in what diplomats described as an ''overwhelming'' response to preparations for national elections in February.

title: Amid TV's Ad Clutter, a Rabbit Runs Wild
description: Right from the start, the new commercial for Eveready's Energizer batteries does not look like the run-of-the-mill television ad. The star of the whimsical campaign is a bright pink toy bunny wearing Ray-Ban sunglasses and blue thongs. Banging a big bass drum as it struts around the set, the mechanical rabbit suddenly runs amok and marches out of the sound studio's doors.

title: Review/Dance; Harlem Troupe Challenged By Three Varied Works
description: Dance Theater of Harlem opened its annual season at Davis Hall of the City College of New York on Friday night with three varied works from its repertory. Each challenged the company in a different way.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Shipments Of Steel Declining
description: Reflecting a slowdown in the automobile and construction industries, steel shipments are below their year-ago level. Several analysts predict that total shipments in the second half of the year will be down as much as 15 percent from the comparable period of 1988.

title: War on Cocaine in Peru Is Sputtering
description: In this country where 65 percent of the world's coca crop is grown, the United States and the Government are waging a tiny anti-drug campaign with a handful of men and helicopters.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 22, 1989: MONDAY Atlantic Richfield Co Mercury Svngs & Ln Assn Dana Corp Philadelphia Elec Co Johnson & Johnson Rubbermaid Inc Lubrizol Corp Zurn Inds Inc TUESDAY Ahmanson H F & Co Hexcel Corp Amoco Corp Kennnametal Inc Ball Corp Lawter Intl Inc Bausch & Lomb Inc Newell Co Black Hills Corp Noble Affiliates Inc Cilicorp Inc NUI Corp Con Edison Co NY Rollins Inc Enserch Corp Schering Plough Fedders Corp Smucker Co Fleming Cos SoWestern Pub Svc Gannett Inc Tambrands Inc Glenfield Inc USLife Corp Golden West Financial Wicor Inc WEDNESDAY Amer Bus Prods Inc Ga Minn Pwr & Lt Amer Elec Pwr Natl Med Enterprises AMP Inc NCNB Corp Anheuser Busch Oakwood Homes Corp Baker Hughes Oneida Ltd Bethlehem Steel Parker Hannifin Cigna Corp Phillips Inds Coast Svngs Finl Russell Corp Downey Svngs & Loan Scana Corp Energen Corp Shaw Inds Inc Grainger Inc Textron Inc Hercules Inc TRW Inc Houghton Miflin TW Svcs Inc Inland Stl Inds Union Carbide Jepson Corp Wisconsin Energy Kentucky Utils Wrigley Co Lukens Inc Zero Corp McGraw Hill THURSDAY Amcast Indl Corp Niagara Mohawk Pwr American Gen Corp Olin Corp Amer Home Prods Corp Owens & Minor Anadarko Pete Corp Potomac Elec Pwr Avery Intl Corp PSI Holdings CRS Sirrine Quaker State Delta Air Lines Republic Gypsum Donnelly & Sons RLC Corp Empire Dist Elec Sara Lee Corp Ethyl Corp Sonat Inc Handy & Harman Thiokol Corp Del Iowa Ill G & E Trinova Corp Landmark Bancshares FRIDAY Acme Elec Corp Harris Corp Del Alltel Corp Kysor Indl Corp Armco Inc McDonnell Douglas Broad Inc Mobil Corp Cameron Iron Wks Monsanto Co Coachmen Inds Inc Nashua Corp Dexter Corp Norton Co Entergy Corp PHM Corp Ferro Corp Progressive Cp Ohio First Wachovia Cp Ryder Sys Inc GATX Corp Sizeler Ppty Invs Georgia Pacific Tyler Corp John Harland Co SATURDAY Duke Realty Invs Kollmorgen Cp

title: Severe Injury For 49er
description: Jeff Fuller, the 49ers' free safety and a member of two Super Bowl championship teams, today suffered severe neck damage that threatens his pro football career. Fuller was injured in a head-on collision with John Stephens, the New England Patriots' halfback, on the second play of the game, which the 49ers won, 37-20.

title: Linda S. Courtiss Wed to a Surgeon
description: Linda Sue Courtiss, the owner of Metamorphosis Interior Designs in Boston and Cape Cod, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Laurence M. Rheingold, a plastic surgeon in Hyannis, Mass. Rabbi Samuel Shiel performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carleton Hotel in Boston.

title: Rock-'n'-Roll Managing
description: Charlie Samuels peered into Davey Johnson's office, hoping to capture a full view of what was inside without being conspicuous. There were times, Samuels will admit, when he thought he would look into Johnson's office in the Mets' clubhouse and see another man's belongings. But this was too much.

title: Officer Is Wounded in Queens; 2 Are Held
description: A New York City police officer was shot in the face and seriously wounded early this morning in the St. Albans section of Queens, and two suspects were arrested, the police said.

title: Review/Television; Of 'World Today' and Disasters, a Marriage Is Made
description: The publicity for a new hourlong program on the Cable News Network, which has lately distinguished itself again with its round-the-clock coverage of the San Francisco earthquake, announced that ''The World Today'' would ''change the face of evening news.''

title: Pretoria Sanctions Retained
description: Leaders of the 49-nation Commonwealth moved today to tighten financial pressure on South Africa and said Pretoria would face new reprisals in six months if it failed to deliver on promises to dismantle apartheid. Britain alone dissented.

title: Calangute Journal; India's Tourist Paradise, but Visitors Are Dreaded
description: Pastoral Goa, which was seized by Indian troops in December 1961, now faces a different kind of invasion each year: tourism.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Victory for Krickstein: Aaron Krickstein, posting his third victory of an injury-plagued season, won the Seiko Super tournament yesterday in Tokyo. Krickstein trounced Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 6-2, 6-2, on the indoor surface.(AP) Graf Wins: Steffi Graf of West Germany defeated fifth-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslvakia, 6-1, 7-6, to capture the women's European indoors tournament in Zurich yesterday.(AP) Annacone Triumphs: Paul Annacone of the United States outlasted Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 6-7, 6-4, 6-1, 2-6, 6-3, to win a Grand Prix tournament in Vienna yesterday. (AP) GOLF Casper Wins: Billy Casper, who began the day in a four-way tie for the lead, shot a four-under-par 68 yesterday to win the Transamerica Senior championship in Napa, Calif., by three strokes over Al Geiberger. Casper, who began the day tied for the lead with Geiberger, Dave Hill and Charles Coody, had four birdies in his bogey-free round, which gave him a 54-hole total of 207, nine under par for three trips around the 6,632-yard Silverado Country Club. Geiberger's 71 yesterday left him alone in second at 210.(AP) PRO BASKETBALL Knicks Lose: John Salley scored 19 points last night to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 105-92 victory over the Knicks in an exhibition game at Toledo, Ohio. The Knicks got within 88-86 with 8:22 remaining. The Pistons (4-1) then went on an 8-0 spurt that made it 96-86 with 4:28 to go. Patrick Ewing led the Knicks (2-3) with 20 points.(AP) Nuggets Win Tournament: Fat Lever scored 12 points in the final period and the Denver Nuggets broke open the game in the final three minutes yesterday for a 135-129 victory over Jugoplastika Split of Yugoslavia in the championship game of the McDonald's Open in Rome. The Yugoslavs trailed, 121-120, with three minutes to play, but Lever and his backcourt mate Walter Davis each scored 6 points in the final run to keep the National Basketball Association representative undefeated in three editions of the tournament. In the consolation game, Bob McAdoo scored 36 points to lead Philips Milan to a 136-104 victory over Barcelona of Spain.(AP) AUTO RACING Drought Ends: Mark Martin ended nearly seven years of frustration on Nascar's Winston Cup circuit yesterday, keeping his car under control in a caution-plagued AC Delco 500 in Rockingham, N.C., to take a three-second victory over the points leader, Rusty Wallace. (AP) HOCKEY Jets 5, Oilers 4: Thomas Steen flipped in a rebound with 6 minutes 26 seconds remaining in the third period to give Winnipeg a home-ice victory over Edmonton last night. Paul Fenton, Randy Cunneyworth, Dave Ellett and Dave McIlwain also scored for the Jets, who squandered a 3-1 second-period lead, but rallied from a 4-3 deficit in the third period.(AP) Blackhawks 7, Kings 4: Adam Creighton scored two goals, including one into an empty net, lifting Chicago over the .500 mark for the first time since Nov. 22, 1987. After taking a 6-1 lead with two goals early in the third period, the Blackhawks had to hold tight as the visiting Kings scored three times in a six-minute span later in the final period, with Bernie Nicholls scoring two of the goals. (AP)

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods Sept. Auto Sales Mid-Oct. Wednesday None Thursday G.N.P. 3d Qtr. Friday Personal Income Sept.

title: Man in the News; 'Nobody's Tougher': Buck Alvin Helm
description: Today, the name Buck Alvin Helm is synonymous with hope. ''Lucky Bucky,'' they are already calling the man who was pulled from the wreckage of the Nimitz Freeway on Saturday after being trapped for 89 hours in a sandwich of concrete that has entombed at least 38 people.

title: Dangerous for Japan to Leave U.S. Security Fold
description: To the Editor:

title: Master Patent Overrides 'Stepchild' Patent
description: To the Editor:

title: Township Focuses on Its Prejudices
description: The publication of anti-Semitic personal ads in a high school newspaper has heightened soul-searching among many people in this community as to whether prejudice is a serious problem here.

title: Treasury Selling $10 Billion in 2-Year Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is active, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and continuing with an auction of $10 billion in two-year bills tomorrow.

title: Players Are Back at Work But Series Won't Be the Same
description: All around, there is a certain stillness, as if to laugh or to speak would somehow cause another aftershock where there have already been too many. So as one day passes into the next, the players return to their clubhouses in San Francisco and Oakland, conduct their business and then go home, waiting for the 86th World Series to resume when they know it will never be the same.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange appointed James F. Duffy senior vice president and general counsel.

title: As New Tactic, Do-It-Yourself Abortions Taught
description: Concerned that abortion rights may be curtailed by the courts or legislatures, scores of self-help groups around the country are teaching women how to perform abortions on themselves and each other.

title: Premiums Losing Favor As Circulation Costs Rise
description: A COUPLE of Christmas seasons ago, a magazine executive asked her counterpart at Newsweek to contribute to a fund to buy gifts for the residents of an orphanage in New York.

title: Claire A. Cerni Marries Brian H. Barr
description: Claire A. Cerni, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore A. Cerni of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Brian H. Barr, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary Barr of Orchard Park, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Martin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church.

title: Eagles' 10-7 Victory Doesn't Come Easy
description: With a breeze swirling near both goal posts at Veterans Stadium today, Luis Zendejas and Jeff Jaeger played mind games with the wind, and with each other.

title: New Jersey Rivals Differ On Growth and Ecology
description: Pursuing prosperity and protecting the state from its excesses are common goals of both candidates for governor, but their ideas of how to make New Jersey both economically strong and environmentally clean differ, sometimes substantially.

title: Murderous Mischief on AIDS
description: The language that Jesse Helms insisted on inserting into legislation appropriating money for AIDS prevention could condemn many innocent people to death. Congress needs to take a second look.

title: Despite Pain, Colorado Reaches for No. 1 Spot
description: IN another place, at another time, the young people in gold and black, their index fingers pointed toward the sky, might have been doing little more than perpetuating an American sporting cliche. But on that sad, gray Saturday afternoon at Husky Stadium in Seattle a little more than three weeks ago, in the moments before the football team from the University of Colorado would preserve its still-perfect record, the Buffaloes collectively discovered a way to express their painful feelings.

title: Opera Institute Director
description: William Vendice has been appointed music director of the Opera/ Music Theater Institute of New Jersey. He succeeds Henry Lewis. Mr. Vendice, who started in his new post on Oct. 1, made his Metropolitan Opera debut in 1983 conducting Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia.'' He has been a guest conductor at American and European opera houses.

title: Kintetsu Will Market Macy Brands in Japan
description: R. H. Macy & Company has agreed to make all of its private-label merchandise available to Kintetsu Department Stores of Japan. The one-year contract gives Macy an additional outlet for its large production capacity in East Asia.

title: Pennsylvania Club's Crew Retains Title
description: The Pennsylvania Athletic Club of Philadelphia successfully defended its championship eights title today in the final race of the 25th annual Head of the Charles regatta.

title: U.S. to Offer Plan to Curb Farm Support
description: The United States will put forward in Geneva this week a plan to phase out many American farm programs if other countries agree to similar cutbacks. The offer is part of negotiations to end trade distortion in agriculture by the next century.

title: Question Box
description: The Winning Runs Q. Three World Series come to mind that ended when the winning run was scored in the bottom of the last inning: 1960, when Bill Mazeroski of Pittsburgh hit a leadoff home run off Ralph Terry that beat the Yankees in Game 7; 1953, when Billy Martin of the Yankees singled home Hank Bauer to beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in six games, and 1935, when Goose Goslin of Detroit singled home Mickey Cochrane in the sixth game against the Chicago Cubs. Are there any others? A. There are four other times in which the Series ended with a run crossing the plate, and one of them occurred when the pitcher failed to find the plate. That took place in Game 4 of the 1927 World Series, when the awesome Yankees were leading the Pittsburgh Pirates in games, 3-0, but were tied in runs, 3-3, in the bottom of the ninth inning. With two out, Earl Combs was on third base, Mark Koenig was on second and Tony Lazzeri was at bat when Johnny Miljus, the Pirate pitcher, threw a wild pitch. It allowed Combs to score the run that wrapped up the four-game sweep in rather tame fashion for a Yankee team considered the best in baseball history.

title: Sloppy Giants Hold On
description: Just think how well the Giants might do if they eliminated a few basic errors.

title: Gas-Export Plan by Canada
description: Canada's National Energy Board has ruled that three international oil companies based in Calgary, Alberta, can export a total of 9.2 trillion cubic feet of gas to the United States over 20 years beginning in 1996. But the companies - Esso

title: Reagan Agreed to Prevent Noriega Death
description: The Reagan Administration and the Senate Intelligence Committee agreed in 1988 that American officials should not become involved with Panamanian coup plotters whose efforts could lead to the assassination of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, according to Government officials.

title: Record Loss in Australia
description: The Bond Corporation, the flagship company of the Australian investor Alan Bond, has announced the largest annual loss in Australian history.

title: Bridge
description: One would not expect the administrative head of, say, a major tennis or golf tournament to win a significant title. But that, in bridge terms, was what happened Wednesday in Stamford, Conn.

title: Wall St.'s 2 Camps
description: As traders and Wall Street executives grope for a better understanding of the stock market's recent 190-point plunge, the search for likely villains is dividing Wall Street into two distinctly different camps: the old order and the new order. The old order - Wall

title: Kemp to Cut H.U.D. Region For New York
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has decided to remove Puerto Rico from the jurisdiction of his agency's troubled New York regional office. The move comes as inquiries continue to focus on political favoritism in the management of Federal housing programs in Puerto Rico during the Reagan Administration.

title: Stephanie Seed Weds Geoffrey James
description: The marriage of Stephanie Winslow Seed and Geoffrey Laurence James took place yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in San Francisco. The Rev. Peter Lawson officiated. The bride, 26 years old, is the daughter of Dr. William T. Seed of New York and Barbara B. Seed of West Palm Beach, Fla. Her husband, also 26, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. James Jr. of St. Louis and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Dinkins Pledges to Cut Spending By 1% to Reduce the City's Deficit
description: Acknowledging that New York City faces ''difficult times'' financially, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral candidate, said yesterday that he would be prepared to cut city spending - except for the Police Department - by 1 percent to reduce a looming budget deficit.

title: Campeau Faces New Cutbacks
description: The Campeau Corporation is again facing cutbacks in merchandise shipments as some suppliers to its Federated and Allied department store units have found their trade credit curtailed or canceled.

title: LEBANESE FACTIONS AGREE ON CHARTER TO RESOLVE STRIFE
description: Members of Lebanon's Parliament agreed in Saudi Arabia today on a new constitution that would increase the power of the country's Muslim majority and acknowledge a Syrian role in Lebanese affairs, participants in the talks said.

title: Inner City Media Empire, Born of Politics, Grows to Profit
description: As much as it was conceived as a business, the Inner City Broadcasting Corporation began as a political statement by black entrepreneurs who were critical of how blacks were treated in the mainstream news media. Now the 17-year-old company finds itself at the center of the New York mayoral race.

title: Not in City For Quake, Some Feel Left Out
description: For Margaret Boothroyd, returning home this weekend from the Adirondacks to her family's small apartment on Russian Hill was a little disorienting because everything looked the way it did before she left.

title: Kasparov Beats Chess Computer (for Now)
description: Yesterday Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, played Deep Thought, the world computer chess champion, in a two-game match. He won both games handily, to nobody's surprise, including his own.

title: Review/Music; A Harpist's World
description: Five years ago, the Swiss harpist Andreas Vollenweider became an icon of the New Age musical movement almost overnight with ''Behind the Gardens - Behind the Wall,'' an album of swirling mood music evoking an Alpine fairy-tale world. Since then, Mr. Vollenweider has been struggling to expand the limited vocabulary of a musical style that in the beginning was mostly sylvan strumming and swishing. And at the Beacon Theater, where he performed with a pop-jazz quartet on Friday night, Mr. Vollenweider showed that he has made significant strides in adding color and rhythmic variety to what used to be a pleasant but amorphous blur.

title: Abortion and the Real George Bush
description: In 1980, private citizen George Bush said he opposed Federal funds for abortion except in cases of rape, incest or threats to the mother's life. In 1984, Vice Presidential candidate George Bush couldn't recall having said that; indeed, he said he opposed exceptions. A week ago, President George Bush repeated that opposition but left ''room for flexibility.'' The man who told America to read his lips on taxes seemed to be asking America to read his mind on abortion.

title: Jean Engelmayer Marries Jan Kalicki
description: At the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., Jean Ellen Engelmayer and Jan Henry Kalicki were married yesterday by Rabbi David Posner. The bride, 25 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Engelmayer of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Her husband, 41, is the son of Mireya Jaimes-Freyre de Kalicki of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Prof. Jan Kalicki.

title: Shuttle Mission Trimmed 3 Hours
description: Astronauts on the space shuttle Atlantis were told by Mission Control today to return to Earth Monday morning, three hours early, to avoid the high winds predicted for afternoon at the desert landing base in California.

title: Rangers Are Wary Despite Fast Start
description: Progress, the cynics like to say, is merely the exchange of one nuisance for another nuisance. For the Rangers, progress over the last half-century has been even more illusory, amounting to little more than the substitution of one heartbreak for another.

title: Suddenly Homeless in California, the Prosperous and the Poor Both Suffer; Life in '68 Plymouth for Family of 4
description: When the house at 35 Carr Street shook last Tuesday, then sank a few inches as doors slammed and the front steps flattened and settled, Oscar Ramirez turned to a possession he had been meaning to get rid of: a faded green 1968 Plymouth.

title: Bush Deserves Praise for Restraint on Noriega
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 TRAINS COLLIDE IN OHIO, HURTING 4
description: An Amtrak passenger train struck a 116-car freight train broadside today, injuring four people and throwing a freight car into a residential yard.

title: Doomed Highway May Have Pulsed To the Rhythm of the Deadly Quake
description: The fatal collapse of an elevated highway in the earthquake here Tuesday may have had as much to do with coincidence as it did with the deficiencies of man's handiwork.

title: Series Put Off To Friday
