description: In a joint decision, Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, and Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco announced today that the World Series would not resume until Friday. Disrupted by the devastating earthquake that struck the Bay Area last Tuesday, the Series had been tentatively scheduled to resume Tuesday.

title: A Sideline Campaign
description: Top aides of State Senator John C. Daniels of New Haven are trying to dissuade him from officating at the Boston College-Syracuse game in Syracuse on Nov. 4. And they appear to have a good reason since, on the following Tuesday, Daniels will be on the ballot as the Democratic candidate for Mayor of New Haven.

title: 2 Hired for Justice Dept. Jobs That Were Cut
description: Nine months after Attorney General Dick Thornburgh ousted five career civil servants from the Justice Department's public affairs staff, he has hired two new political appointees to help in relations with news reporters.

title: Losing Coach Calls 95-21 Rout Needless
description: Houston's punishing rout of Southern Methodist University's freshmen-dominated team Saturday, by a score of 95-21, severely tested the longtime friendship of Forrest Gregg and Jack Pardee, two famous Texas football figures who are now middle-aged coaches in the Southwest Conference.

title: Review/Opera; 'Barbiere' in High Volume Is Presented at the Met
description: Some of the wounds suffered by the Metropolitan Opera's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' on Saturday afternoon were self-inflicted, though in at least one case, the Met was an innocent bystander.

title: Chile Plans to Create Strong Central Bank
description: As it prepares to turn over power to elected civilians, the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet is creating an autonomous central bank that it says will help preserve Chile's hard-won economic stability, growth and modernization.

title: A Bookseller Gives Up Its Stores to Focus on Publishing
description: The traditional, if vanishing, role of the book publisher as bookseller has been further eroded by an established company's decision to close its three stores and concentrate on publishing.

title: Redskins Outlast Attack by Testaverde
description: Three quarters of outstanding defense proved to be just enough for the Washington Redskins, who survived a fourth-quarter passing show by Vinny Testaverde today and escaped with a 32-28 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Contra Ambush Kills 18 Nicaraguan Troops
description: A group of contra rebels ambushed two trucks carrying Government soldiers in northern Nicaraguan on Saturday evening, killing 18 of the soldiers and wounding 8, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Fernandez Stirs Anger Over Efforts In Albany
description: State legislators, whose support is likely to be crucial to the new Schools Chancellor, are voicing resentment over his efforts to change laws affecting New York City's public schools.

title: Study Says Medicaid Lags for Poor Children
description: An association representing 100 children's hospitals in the United States and Canada has charged that the health and well-being of millions of American children are endangered because they are excluded from Medicaid coverage.

title: Turkey-Soviet Oil Deal
description: Turkey will buy 2.5 million metric tons of Soviet crude oil a year in a trade pact that may make Moscow one of Ankara's biggest trading partners, a published report said Friday. The Finance Minister, Ekrem Pakdemirli, was quoted by the Anatolian press agency on his return from Moscow as saying the agreement included trade and project credits, talks on railways, border trade and a possible new gas pipeline. The protocol, signed in Moscow this week, aims to raise trade volume to $4 billion a year, the report said. Turkey, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, had in the past bought one million tons of oil from the Soviet Union each year.

title: Facts to Fit Every Fancy: Custom Textbooks Are Here
description: It will not eliminate homework, term papers or studying all night for final exams. But McGraw-Hill Inc., one of the nation's largest book publishers, has developed the ability to customize college textbooks to suit the needs of individual professors -or even individual students - in 48 hours.

title: Media General's Profit
description: Media General Inc. said Friday that its profit had fallen about 63 percent in the latest quarter and attributed the results to weakness in newspaper advertising linage and declines in newsprint sales. Net income dropped to $3.94 million, or 15 cents a share, from $10.78 million, or 38 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue fell nearly 22 percent, to $142.29 million, from $181.82 million.

title: Democrats Take Offensive on Abortion and Flag
description: The Democratic Party has long been on the defensive when it came to the politics of values, but in recent weeks Congressional Democrats have taken the offensive on two emotionally charged issues: desecration of the flag and the Federal financing of abortions.

title: Drug Recall Is Announced
description: The American Home Products Corporation is recalling three generic drugs after Federal regulators found that a subsidiary of the company had mispresented drug data to regulators.

title: Poland's Hard Times Deepen, Dampening Hope for Change
description: Among the Poles who gathered today in Mokotowska street for a plate of soup and some bread was an 83-year old retired schoolteacher named Maria, visibly uncomfortable with the rough-and-tumble atmosphere.

title: The Voices of Namibia
description: In the black township of Katatura, over supper, I listen to a former organizer and current supporter of the South West African People's Organization, which led the fight against South African occupation of Namibia and is now, by all accounts, its largest political party. He tells of his detention and torture by the South Africans 11 years ago.

title: Analysis of a Winner
description: Having won the first two games of the World Series, the Oakland Athletics are obviously in a strong position to win the entire Series, but the team is far from a shoe-in.

title: Game 3 on Friday For World Series
description: The World Series will resume in San Francisco on Friday, three days later than planned. Sports Monday, page C1. Bay Area residents began lining up to apply for Federal earthquake relief.

title: 'Machinal' Is Canceled
description: The Equity Library Theater's production of Sophie Treadwell's 1928 play ''Machinal,'' which was to have opened Nov. 2, has been canceled because of financial problems. The company plans to resume the season with Keith Reddin's ''Big Time'' on Nov. 30. The theater's board will meet in the next two weeks to assess the continuation of the season.

title: Market Place; When the Panic Failed to Happen
description: THE stock market news of last week, as in a famous Sherlock Holmes story where the key clue was that a dog failed to bark, may be more in what did not happen than in what did.

title: This World Series No Longer Credible
description: NOW that the resumption of the World Series has been delayed until at least Friday, baseball has created the unprecedented possibility that one of the Oakland Athletics or one of the San Francisco Giants will emerge as Mr. November.

title: Review/Television; Following the Upsurge And Decline in U.S. Power
description: ''America's Century,'' unusual for television, is essentially a history of an idea. How, asks Lewis H. Lapham, the writer and narrator, has American power manifested itself in the 20th century? Why did it rise so fast in the first half of the century? What accounts for its slow decline during the second half?

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Tips for Cyclists Eager to Compete
description: LEAD: MARION CLIGNET remembers the first time vividly. She was riding a ''30-pound piece of junk'' and wearing tennis shoes. ''I went to the front'' of the race, Clignet recalled about her first bicycling competition. ''Everyone was yelling, 'Marion, draft!' 'Marion, draft!' There I was in my tennis shoes racing against girls in their cleats.

title: State Offices in Los Angeles Closed by Fire
description: A fire in a 21-story building Friday closed Southern California offices of the state's courts and the State Attorney General three days after the earthquake closed similar offices in San Francisco.

title: Californians Fill Churches, Seeking Solace and Life
description: They wore buttons that said ''I'm Alive'' at the Glide Memorial United Methodist Church here today, danced in the aisles and set the old building trembling with exuberant music.

title: Dolphins Hold Off Packers
description: Pete Stoyanovich kicked a 33-yard field goal with 6 seconds to play, giving the Miami Dolphins a 23-20 victory today after Green Bay rallied with two touchdowns in the final six minutes.

title: Bronx Man Dies After Arrest, Apparently of Drug Overdose
description: A 30-year-old Bronx man who was arrested yesterday after firing a gun six times inside his home died, apparently from an overdose of cocaine, an hour later, the police said.

title: China Austerity Cools Economy
description: China's tough austerity policies have cooled off the overheated economy but have made few inroads in solving basic flaws in the system, the Government said last week.

title: Crash Kills Boat Racer
description: A fatality marred the end of racing yesterday in the Trump Castle world powerboat championship in Atlantic City. Kevin Brown, 37 years old, of Rocky River, Ohio, was killed instantly in the flipover and crash of his 32-foot catamaran speedboat. Brown was this year's national champion in the Union Internationale Motonautique II, a class for powerboats of 23 to 40 feet. James Dyke of Bay Village, Ohio, Brown's throttleman, was injured and in stable condition in a hospital in Atlantic City.

title: La Russa Calm but A's Edgy After New Delay
description: Some of them were unhappy that the delay had been extended until Friday night; some of them simply accepted this as a fact they could not alter. But the Oakland Athletics all knew today that their season was going to last longer than expected, like it or not. Many of them did not. ''I think it's getting to be ridiculous,'' Dave Parker said, clearly angry over the second World Series delay resulting from last Tuesday's earthquake. ''Either you play it or you don't play it. If you can't play it here, then take it somewhere else.

title: New York's Schools: A National Test
description: It seems an appropriate, even ironic, coincidence that Joseph A. Fernandez was named New York City Schools Chancellor just as President Bush was gathering the governors for an education summit meeting. Nothing promises to illustrate the practical limits of that conference's rhetoric more than Mr. Fernandez's efforts to reform and improve the largest -and one of the most troubled - municipal school systems in America.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-10 A new Lebanese constitution was agreed to by legislators, participants said. The system would give more power to the country's Muslim majority and acknowledge a Syrian role in its affairs. Page A1 An economic crisis in Poland is demoralizing a country whose hopes were stirred when its first non-Communist Government in more than four decades was elected in September. A1 New analysis: Glasnost was intended as a vehicle for giving the Soviet Union a sense of common purpose. But President Gorbachev has lately criticized the press for confusing it with a right to say anything. A8 Coup attempts in Panama that could lead to the assassination of General Noriega should not be aided by the United States, the Reagan Administration and a Senate intelligence panel agreed in 1988. A10 Washington Talk: A war of words, between a former Assistant Secretary of State and a retired Chairman of the Joints Chiefs of Staff, is fought over the Reagan Administration's policy on Panama. A14 Nicaraguans are registering to vote in ''overwhelming'' numbers, leaving diplomats and local politicians to marvel at the public's apparent deep desire to stand up and be counted after years of turmoil. A3 A tiny anti-drug campaign in Peru, being waged by the Government and the United States, has had small effect on the nation's $1.5 billion coca industry. A3 Calangute journal: A tourist heaven, and hosts dread it A4 Pretoria sanctions retained A10 National A12-17, B10-12 Churches in the San Francisco area were filled by believers and non-believers alike who gave thanks for their lives and sought solace in the embrace of their neighbors. A1 Suddenly homeless, the prosperous and the poor both suffer B11 Residents line up for Federal assistance B11 The earthquake's effect on the highway that collapsed may have been amplified by matching frequencies of the highway and the shaking ground beneath it. B10 Man in the news: ''Lucky Bucky'' B10 Not in city for quake, some feel left out B10 American military purchases abroad are increasing. This has raised concerns about the competitiveness of the nation's weapons technology and the ability to meet military needs in wartime. A1 How to perform abortions is being taught by scores of self-help groups concerned that abortion rights may be curtailed. B12 The health of millions of children is being endangered because they are not eligible for Medicaid coverage, an association of children's hospitals charged. A17 Democrats have made gains in Congressional political battles on two emotionally charged issues: desecration of the flag and abortion financing. A16 News analysis: Wall Street is dividing into an old camp, which blames the recent plunge on a new generation of computer-hungry traders, and a new order that says the system cannot process all the large trades. D1 Steel shipments are falling from the level of a year ago, and total steel industry earnings, which have increased steadily over the last three years, will begin to fall this year, analysts say. D1 I.B.M.'s stronghold, mainframe computers, under siege D1 A Maryland firearms board, under a new and disputed anti-handguns law, has turned down only a few dozen of almost 700 pistols and revolvers it considered. A12 The Cleveland mayoral race features an old guard politician against a former protege in a contest full of name-calling and charges of impropriety. A12 Salina journal: rallying around a prairie prophet A12 Train collision in Ohio injures four A16 Shuttle's mission is trimmed several hours B12 Renewed debate on nuclear power D1 Regional B1-8 A cut in New York City's budget of 1 percent was suggested by David Dinkins. The proposal, intended to reduce a looming deficit, was criticized by Rudolph Giuliani as nothing but a formula that avoids tough choices. A1 Crises await deft hand of next mayor B1 The broadcasting corporation at the center of the Dinkins stock controversy was founded in part as a political statement by black entrepreneurs who were critical of how the mainstream media treated blacks. B1 Candidates for New Jersey governor differ, sometimes strongly, on their ideas for making the state economically strong and environmentally clean. B1 A foster parent program by New York City, which pays relatives who act as parental substitutes for abused children, is overwhelming the child welfare system, officials say. A1 H.U.D. will shift Puerto Rico from the jurisdiction of the agency's New York office, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has decided. Inquiries are focusing on favoritism in H.U.D.'s Puerto Rico programs in the Reagan years. B1 The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, handily defeated the world computer chess champion. But some experts believe that era of the human chess grandmaster is ending. A1 Legislators voice resentment over new Schools Chancellor B1 After 4 setbacks, developers hire critic to design building B2 New York Court of Appeals considering anti-harassment law B3 North Brunswick focuses on the problem of prejudice B3

title: Margie Abrams Wed To William John Otto
description: Margie Abrams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Abrams of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to William John Otto, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Otto of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Nathan Kapner officiated at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, L.I.

title: Faith L. Diamond Weds an Actuary
description: At the Princeton (N.J.) Marriott, Faith L. Diamond, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Diamond of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Martin Sacks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sacks of Dresher, Pa. Rabbi Helene Ferris officiated. Mrs. Diamond-Sacks, who graduated with distinction from the University of Virginia and received a master's of management degree from Northwestern University, is a product manager for the Rorer Corporation, a pharmaceuticals company in Fort Washington, Pa. Her father is the vice president of consumer products for the New York textiles concern of Glenoit Mills.

title: Gorbachev and the Wayward Press
description: As the Soviet press has become a daily riot of sensationalism, from U.F.O.'s to sacrilegious critiques of the Bolshevik Revolution, Westerners and even many Soviet readers have come to mistake glasnost for freedom of the press.

title: Baseball, Like Life Itself, Endures With Prudence
description: CITING Winston Churchill, the commissioner of baseball has spoken for the reaffirmation of life. Baseball will resume when the engineers and the police say it is practical.

title: FOREIGN ROLE RISES IN MILITARY GOODS
description: The nation's military contractors are increasingly turning abroad for parts and components to build weapons systems, as the Pentagon puts pressure on them to reduce costs and foreign suppliers become more adept.

title: Renewed Debate on Nuclear Power
description: Saving the world from global warming may require sharp reductions in burning fuel, but there was no consensus at a two-day meeting here of 40 nuclear industry executives, government officials, energy experts and environmentalists on whether new nuclear reactors are needed.

title: Preparing to Operate, Polymerix Fills Post
description: Polymerix Inc., a company that has not yet manufactured its product, has named Gary J. Schantz president and chief operating officer as it moves toward an operational stage.

title: False Unity Shunned By Interfaith Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Cup Outlook Is No Clearer
description: A busy weekend of prep races failed to winnow many candidates or crown any strong new favorites for the Breeders' Cup races at Gulfstream Park Nov. 4. When preliminary entries are taken today, the fields for five of the seven cup races are likely to be large and lacking a strong favorite.

title: Business and the Law; A Plan to Speed Asbestos Cases
description: INNOVATIVE plans are quietly being drawn up in Maryland to resolve thousands of asbestos cases that have swamped that state's dockets.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: I.B.M.'s Stronghold Under Siege
description: For the first time in decades, the International Business Machine Corporation's undisputed control of the market for mainframe computers is being threatened by far-reaching changes in the industry.

title: Historian to Run in Hungary As the Opposition Candidate
description: Hungary's leading opposition group today announced its candidate for President in the multi-party elections to be held next June.

title: J. Donald Gartland, Coin Dealer, Dies at 45
description: J. Donald Gartland 3d, a coin dealer who specialized in commemorative Olympic issues, died of cancer Thursday in Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 45 years old and lived in Ocean City, N.J.

title: Cleveland Mayoral Race Marked by a Bitter Feud
description: A bitter feud between the old guard and a new generation of politicians is under way as Cleveland's most powerful black official campaigns for the Mayor's office against a onetime protege.

title: Brussels Computer Snag
description: The Brussels stock exchange computer, which went out of operation early last week, will resume operating on Tuesday, the exchange's chairman, Jean Peterbroeck, said. Belgian stockbrokers have had to resort to open outcry trading this week, using their old tools of blackboard and chalk, while the software is fixed to handle heavier volumes. Mr. Peterbroeck said the computer broke down at the start of last week's trading because of a flood of orders in the Petrofina oil group, a large Belgian company. The system's failure forced the exchange to close during the turmoil on world stock markets on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've been shaken, we've been jolted, but we're saying yes to life. And it's important for us to be shaken - rich, poor and middle class. This quake shook us all, and now we have a common problem and need common solutions.'' -the Rev. Cecil Williams of San Francisco. [ A1:1. ]

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Off the Charts: An Aid to Top Tennis
description: LEAD: COACH Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears offered his view on the subject just the other day. ''Statistics are for idiots,'' he growled.

title: Beer Ad Curb Faces Fight
description: The National Association of Broadcasters has asked television and radio stations to fight any move by the National College Athletic Association to curb beer advertising during its annual basketball tournament.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Prudential Finalists
description: LEAD: Backer Spielvogel Bates dodged a bullet on Friday, surviving another round of cuts on Friday in the competition for the giant Prudential Insurance Company advertising account. BSB, the incumbent agency, joined Grey Advertising; Scali, McCabe, Sloves; and Lowe Marschalk as finalists for the account, which is worth more than $60 million.

title: Traders Look to 3d-Quarter G.N.P.
description: After nervously tracking developments in the stock market after the market's plunge on Oct. 13, the focus of most credit market participants is likely to return to a more familiar determinant of fixed-income prices and interest rates: developments in the real economy.

title: Jody Kresch, Lawyer, Weds Ross Silverman
description: Jody E. Kresch, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Kresch of Searingtown, L.I., was married yesterday to Ross O. Silverman, a son of Irwin Silverman and Inez Silverman, both of Toledo, Ohio. Rabbi Paula Winnig officiated at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Residents Begin Lining Up For U.S. Disaster Aid
description: Residents of the Bay Area began lining up today to apply for Federal assistance to help them recover from Tuesday's devastating earthquake.

title: Safer Baseball For Children
description: New baseballs and softballs, designed to reduce the potential for head injuries, are the first to meet national safety standards. The balls meet standards approved last July by the National Operating Committee on Standards for Athletic Equipment.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Unpredictable On View in Sao Paulo
description: The Sao Paulo Bienal is not like other major international exhibitions. It does not have the glamour of the Venice Biennale. It does not attempt to be a state of the art show, like the Carnegie International in Pittsburgh. Nor does it pretend to be a state of the world show, like ''Documenta,'' in Kassel, West Germany.

title: Herbert Hastings Foster Jr., Lawyer, 76
description: Herbert Hastings Foster Jr., a former general counsel for the J. P. Stevens textile company, died Friday in the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Block Island, R.I., and Captiva, Fla.

title: U.S. Committee Adopts Drug Plan
description: The executive board of the United States Olympic Committee today approved an aggressive out-of-competition drug-testing program, which includes oversight by an independent auditor and the hiring of an officer to investigate drug-related accusations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Strategies That Sell Everywhere
description: FIRST, American makers of consumer goods became multinational companies, says Hamish Maxwell, chairman and chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies. These companies had ''many national strategies, different products and different marketing approaches from country to country.''

title: Children Still Being Sold Vehicles
description: Dealers are still selling all-terrain vehicles for use by children despite an agreement between the Federal Government and the manufacturers to curtail such sales, a consumer group charged today.

title: Banks of Iowa reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Corning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Board's Trading Data
description: Computer-driven program trading accounted for 13.8 percent of the average daily New York Stock Exchange trading volume in September, the exchange said yesterday. The percentage is sharply higher that the 10.3 percent of average trading in August by the exchange's member firms.

title: How to Embarrass Americans
description: The plain truth is that it is getting a little embarrassing for an American to talk to foreigners.

title: Judge Hastings, Fairly Judged
description: Impeachments by the House and trials in the Senate are so cumbersome and distasteful that Alcee Hastings of Florida is only the sixth Federal judge to be removed in this manner. But in convicting and removing Judge Hastings, despite his acquittal of similar charges at a criminal trial, Congress acted responsibly, even judiciously. It vindicated the Constitution's admittedly inefficent method for purging those who dishonor their offices.

title: Hartford Steam Boiler Inspecion & Insur Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TW Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After $60 million of merger-related expenses associated with the proposed merger of TW Services with a subsidiary of TW Holdings, Inc., an affiliate of Coniston Partners. c-Net income

title: Jan Bell Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,027,000, or 7 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Review/Dance; Royal Winnipeg's 'Anne of Green Gables'
description: The Royal Winnipeg Ballet is a survivor. Repeatedly defying adversity, it continues to prosper on the Canadian prairie, and it is now celebrating its 50th anniversary. It was in a festive mood on Sunday afternoon at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx. But what made the onstage merriment possible was a tradition of courage and determination.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Vast East German Protest
description: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through Leipzig in the biggest demonstration since protests began last month. Page A14.

title: China Whispers of Plots and Man Called Yang
description: When people here lower their voices and speak frankly about politics, their suspicions and hostilities frequently focus on a sprightly 82-year-old man whose most important hour may not yet have arrived.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Sunday with an article about fashion industry reaction to the book ''Chic Savages'' misidentified the woman in the lower picture. She was the designer Mary McFadden, not Anna Wintour, who was pictured above.

title: Betty B. Linker, County Commissioner, 67
description: Betty B. Linker, vice chairman of the commissioners of Montgomery County, Pa., died of breast cancer Saturday at Chestnut Hill Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 67 years old and lived in Flourtown, Pa.

title: Manville's Trust for Asbestos Victims Runs Low
description: The trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos has almost run out of money. As a result, tens of thousands of people with asbestosis, lung cancer and other often fatal diseases who ask the trust for money this year will have to wait 25 years before being compensated, the trust estimates.

title: Ampco-Pittssburgh Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $788,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,222,000, or 13 cents a share, for the months, and extraordinary tax credits of $680,000, or 7 cents a share and $2,600,000, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $20,112,000 for the quarter and $21,834,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results are restated to reflect continuing operations.

title: Philadelphia Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
John Archer Gifford, New York Lawyer, 88
description: John Archer Gifford, a lawyer, died Sunday at Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan and Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Amerada Hess reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months included a charge of $30,000,000 for estimated expenses necessary to sustain refining and marketing operations as a result of hurrican Hugo. The company also foreign currency exchange transactions resulted in gains of $19,900,000 and $3,000,000 in latest quarter and 9 months. In the corresponding periods of 1988, foreign currency exchange adjustments resulted in losses of $3,300,000 and $9,700,000, respectively.

title: Chinese Mushrooms Barred
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was blocking indefinitely all shipments of canned and pickled mushrooms from China after a number of food poisonings were associated with earlier shipments.

title: Review/Music; Dohnanyi Civilizes the Wilder Symphonic Beasts
description: The Cleveland Orchestra did its best over the weekend to civilize some of the wilder beasts of the symphonic repertory. Christoph von Dohnanyi's regime as music director has brought a measured humanism to this naturally elegant ensemble. Thus it was fascinating at Carnegie Hall on Friday night to hear logical discourse applied to the illogical passions of Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique.'' On Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Dohnanyi's swift tempos cleansed Tchaikovsky's E-minor Symphony of every lugubrious tendency.

title: The Chancellor's Handcuffs
description: Even though Joseph Fernandez will not take office formally until January as New York City's schools chancellor, he is off to a promising start. His initiative deserves more energetic support than it's getting from Albany.

title: West German Rightist Party Does Well in Municipal Vote
description: Candidates of the far right won six Stuttgart city council seats and received more than 10 percent of the vote in several other municipal elections in the southern state of Baden-Wurttemberg, officials said today.

title: Wood Banned 4 Games
description: Randy Wood, the Islander left wing, was suspended by the National Hockey League for four games for deliberately attempting to injure Curt Giles, a Minnesota defenseman, with his stick in a game at Nassau Coliseum last Tuesday.

title: ADMITS BREAKING ARMS PACT
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told the Soviet legislature today that the nine-year Soviet military role in Afghanistan had violated Soviet law and international norms of behavior.

title: Panel Considers Immunity for H.U.D. Figure
description: A House panel has opened immunity discussions with a principal figure in the Congressional investigations of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in hopes of obtaining his testimony about political favoritism at the department, people familiar with the talks said today.

title: Giamatti Service Is Rescheduled
description: The delay to the World Series caused by the earthquake here has also caused the memorial service for baseball's late commissioner, A. Bartlett Giamatti, to be pushed back.

title: Even New York City School Principals Deserve Due Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn Central Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains from the disposal of foreign subsidiaries of $68 million, or 96 cents a share. c-Included gains of $15.1 million, or 21 cents a share, and $19 million, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of equity securities and certain discontinued operations.

title: Cresmont Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Giants' Clark Rated Best Big-League Player
description: Will Clark, the San Francisco Giants' first baseman, who was named the best player in the National League playoff earlier this month, gained the No. 1 ranking among all major league players today.

title: Augat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax restructuring charge of $2,500,000. c-Net loss and included pre-tax restructuring charge of $39 million for both the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago sales for the quarter included $7.6 million in sales by businesses that have been sold or closed.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Central Illinois Public Service Co reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
U.S. MOVES TO LIMIT RACKETEERING LAW IN BUSINESS CASES
description: In moves that could significantly limit the use of criminal racketeering charges against white-collar defendants, the Justice Department has revised rules governing the use of the racketeering law by Federal prosecutors.

title: A 30-Year Feud Divides Experts On Meteorology
description: REID A. BRYSON and Verner E. Suomi of the University of Wisconsin at Madison started their careers as best friends, colleagues who helped each other build homes on adjacent lots and who together ran the university's meteorology department, making it one of the best in the nation.

title: Time Warner Reports Loss For Quarter
description: Reflecting the costs of its recent merger, Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $176 million in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, compared with a profit for Time Inc. alone of $81 million, or $1.42 a share, a year earlier.

title: Accord on Quebec's Status Meets Indifference
description: No issue in Canadian politics has roused greater passions than the future of Quebec.

title: Race Is Getting Closer, Mayoral Candidates Agree
description: David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani remained apart yesterday on holding debates, but agreed that the New York City mayoral race had grown considerably closer.

title: Article 773689 -- No Title
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation yesterday announced a loss of $1.42 billion in the third quarter, because of a previously announced $1.6 billion increase in its provision for losses on loans to third world countries.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Acounts
description: * Sunshine Biscuits Inc., to Waring & LaRosa, with a budget of $10 million.

title: Giuliani Says Dinkins Lacks 'Respect for Law'
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, brimming with confidence born of encouraging poll numbers, used the Liberal Party's annual dinner last night to drive home the points he believes are tightening the mayoral race - that David N. Dinkins lacks toughness, decisiveness, and respect for the law.

title: Occidental Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $42 million, or 15 cents a share, and $29 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The net extraordinary gain of $42 million, or 15 cents a share, resulted primarily from the Federal income tax benefit realized for the application of a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains. c-Included extraordinary losses of $3 million and $11 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; loss of quarter was due to early retirement of debt. Results for 1989 included an aftertax net gain of $54 million from the sale of various oil and gas properties, including Occidental's interest in the Hartzog Draw unit, located in Wyoming, and an aftertax charge of $22 million from the restructuring of domestic oil and gas operations. Results for 1989 and 1988 were depressed by the inclusion of extraordinary losses of $3 million resulting from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Susquehanna Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Maize-Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After nonrecurring charges of $3,523,000.

title: Two Giants Receivers Dodge Major Injuries
description: Mark Bavaro is all right. So is Zeke Mowatt. And therefore, so are the Giants.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Japan's Maneuvering For a Big Global Voice
description: Japan, the world's biggest creditor and provider of financial assistance, is quietly building its influence in global finance institutions long dominated by the United States and Western Europe. Having gained the appointment of a Japanese official to the top ranks of the World Bank, Japan is moving to promote a candidate to run the International Monetary Fund when the term of its managing director expires in January 1992.

title: Koch Swears In Police Commissioner
description: Richard J. Condon was sworn in yesterday as New York City's 35th Police Commissioner a few minutes after Mayor Edward I. Koch promised that he would not cut the hiring of police officers to balance the municipal budget.

title: The California Quake; Rains Halt Quake Cleanup; Rescued Driver Is Stronger
description: Chill rains and gale-force winds halted rescue efforts today at a flattened highway overpass in Oakland and threatened new destruction in the hard-hit hills to the south.

title: Revamping Is Planned By Qintex
description: Qintex Australia Ltd., whose $1.5 billion agreement to buy the MGM/ UA Communications Company collapsed two weeks ago when it was unable to produce a $50 million letter of credit, announced a reorganization plan today and an accelerated program of asset sales.

title: Wadi Dahr Journal; Give Up Desert Ways? Not Queen of Sheba's Land
description: The old is very old here, and the new is very new. Sometimes, the collision is painful.

title: Bankers Trust N.Y.  Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1.6 billion from a special provision for credit losses for both periods. c-Net income

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
East Rock Team Finds A 'Stable' Opportunity
description: LEAD: Friday's proposal by East Rock Partners L. P. for a $40-a-share, or $97 million, buyout of A. P. Green Industries represents a team effort, according to East Rock's two limited partners, John D. Kuhns and Robert W. MacDonald.

title: Pain, as a Matter of Policy
description: LEAD: My mother-in-law used to speak of people as having ''a good death.'' It seemed inconceivable to me, at the time, that any death could be good. Now I know what she meant. My father had a bad death. It was the kind of death more and more of us will experience unless changes are made in insurance health care policies.

title: AMC Entertainment Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Sept 28
description: b-Included pre-tax gains from disposition of assets of $2,977,000 for the quarter, and $10,496,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Antarctic Accord Must Protect Environment; Support Gore Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmer and Rights Lawyer Among Victims of Jet Crash
description: A Wisconsin farmer returning from a volunteer mission to Nicaragua and a lawyer working for a human rights group were among the 12 Americans killed when a Boeing 727 jet crashed in Honduras on Saturday.

title: Communications Satellite CorpN) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax settlement of $2.2 million, or 12 cents a share, on a primary basis.

title: Allegheny Ludlum reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Careers; Arboretum Directors Are Sought
description: MORE than $150 million is being spent to build arboretums and conservatories, and job opportunties are sure to follow, said Anne L. Crammond, executive director of the Atlanta Botanical Garden.

title: The California Quake; Earthquake Casualties
description: Following is a list of the dead who have been identified in the Northern California earthquake on Oct. 17, as reported by the coroner's office in each county or the county's Office of Emergency Services. The names are followed by the victims' age and hometown when known. Alameda County ASFOUR, Ramzi, 51, Novato. BEAUREGARD-SUND, Raymonde, 42, Alameda. BERUMEN, Petra, no age, Richmond. BRONK, John H., 38, hometown unknown. BROWN, James H. 3d, 20, Oakland. BUTLER, Walter, 63, Richmond. CASTILLO, Joshua, 4, Oakland. CERVANTES, Miguel, 34, Vallejo. CHAU, Hoa, 30, San Pablo. CHENOWETH, Albert, 43, San Leandro. CLARK, Samuel, 56, Clayton. DAVIS, Alexander, 59, El Cerrito. EDSTROM, Joy, 45, Alameda. FORTUNE, Tarran, 28, Richmond. HOLMES, Ray, 40, Mill Valley. HUANG, Zhi, 31, Oakland. HURTADO, Rosalpina, no age, Hayward. IRVIN, Sherman, 45, Alameda. JOHNSTON, Kirk, 35, San Rafael. KAHN, Anis, 23, San Francisco. LAURITZ, John, 51, San Francisco. LEE, Lanna, 43, Alameda. LEVANITIS, John, 23, San Leandro. MARSDEN, Donna, 36, Alameda. MAXWELL, Melissa, 32, Burlingame. McKENNA, Gerald, 42, Santa Rosa. McKEOWN, Mary, 32, Berkeley. MOSS, Timothy, 40, San Francisco. OROZCO, Yolanda, no age, Richmond. PHU, Vinh, 32, Oakland. RICHARD, Michelle, 19, Hayward. RUBI, Juan, 28, San Francisco. SINGH, Margaret, 21, Oakland. TREIGUTS, Fricis, 77, Cupertino. Santa Cruz County DeBENEDETTI, Dale, 27, Watsonville. McCORMICK, Sean, 21, Santa Cruz. ORTIZ, Robin, 22, Santa Cruz. TREIMAN, Catherine, 75, Scotts Valley. WEST, Gary Philip, 41, Napa. San Francisco County ANDERSON, John J., 29, Boulder Creek. CHOI, Jeffrey, 50, San Francisco. DICKINSON, Scott, 3 1/2 months, San Francisco.
