title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Investors bid up the prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday as the stock market weakened.

title: Trial Opens in Shooting That Led to Miami Riots
description: The trial of a Miami police officer who killed a black motorcyclist, touching off three days of racial violence, opened today with the defense demanding that the case be moved as demonstrators clashed outside the courthouse.

title: Melba Till Allen, Ex-Alabama Official, 56
description: Melba Till Allen, a former Alabama state auditor and state treasurer who was convicted of using her office for personal gain, died of cancer Friday at Baptist Medical Center in Montgomery. She was 56 years old and lived in Marbury, Ala.

title: TV, World Cup Soccer And the American Way
description: LEAD: When the Federation Internationale de Football Association (FIFA) awarded the rights to stage the 1994 World Cup to the United States last year, sending the tournament outside Europe or Latin America for the first time, the pioneering decision was accompanied by apprehension as well as excitement.

title: McDonald's Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: System-wide sales for the latest periods totaled $4,587,692,000 for the quarter and $12,862,156,000 for the 9 months, compared with $4,197,349,000 and $11,925,455,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively. The share earnings were restated for 2-for-1 common stock split declared in May.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bowne & Co., a communications company, named Catherine Godbille vice president of its Bowne International unit and director of Bowne Translation Services.

title: Tapes of School Officials: Ante Becomes 'Little Higher'
description: These are excerpts from conversations taped by Colman Genn, superintendent of School District 27 in Queens, with James C. Sullivan, the school board treasurer, Samuel Granirer, board vice president, and William Sampol, a former Republican state legislative aide seeking a $42,000-a-year district job, and others over a course of seven months. The opening excerpts are from a conversation that generally revolved around Mr. Sullivan's and Mr. Granirer's complaints that Mr. Genn had hired too many black assistant principals and not enough of the people they wanted. Feb. 6, 1989

title: Puzzling Pattern of the Quake May Hurt Ability to Predict
description: The California earthquake has presented scientists with a puzzle, one that has left some of them wondering whether probability estimates of future quakes are too low.

title: Medical Schools Open Doors to Minority Teen-Agers
description: In the life of Melanie Rodriguez, there are few cheers for being a 16-year-old mother, a high school student and an aspiring physician.

title: Israelis Say Cache of Letters Shows P.L.O. Terrorist Plan
description: Israeli authorities operating in the Gaza Strip say they recently discovered a cache of detailed, secret documents showing that the Palestine Liberation Organization is hiring local killers to assassinate other Palestinians and carry out ''military activity'' against Israelis.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Corp. agreed to exchange its 50 percent interest in a British onshore oilfield with Ultramar P.L.C. in return for Ultramar's stakes in two North Sea exploration blocks.

title: Namibia Rebel Leader: A Focus of Hope and Fear <
description: The most famous face in this land belongs to an avuncular Namibian with a white beard and ingratiating smile. The portrait of Sam Nujoma, the leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization, beams from political posters, on the cotton print skirts worn by admiring women and in right-wing graffiti superimposed with a rifle target.

title: Nixon to Visit China
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon will visit China around the end of the month, meeting with Chinese leaders and reporting to President Bush on his return, a spokesman said today. The White House said Mr. Bush looked forward to the report.

title: Santa Fe Talking To Pension Fund
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said its Santa Fe Pacific Realty Corporation unit is negotiating with the California Public Employees Retirement System to issue the pension fund stock representing a 20 percent stake in the unit. Before the transaction is complete, the realty company would issue debt that, when combined with the money it will receive from the pension fund, will enable it to pay back more than $500 million of debt owed to the parent company.

title: Bemis Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HBO & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
8 Top Pretoria Rebels Meet to Plan Strategy
description: Eight African National Congress leaders, including seven freed from prison this month, held a strategy meeting today, unhindered by the police even though their movement remains outlawed.

title: New Hungary Marks '56 Uprising: 'Gorby!' and 'Russians Out!' Mix
description: Hungary today marked the 33d anniversary of the violent uprising against Soviet rule in 1956 by peacefully scrapping the ''socialist people's'' label and proclaiming itself a republic.

title: USG Corp(M) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax gains in the first quarter of $16.3 million on an insurance settlement and in the second quarter of $11.2 million on the sale of construction metal business which was only applicable to net income and not earnings per share. c-Included a charge of $2.7 million.

title: Massbank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Massbank said, contributing to its profit decline in the latest third quarter was a $250,000 pre-tax loss on investments in a real estate venture.

title: Our Towns; The Gas Line That Moves With the Winds
description: rrFifty-six-year-old Andrew Mills, a farmer and backhoe operator who owns 20 acres just off Highway 55 in this pastoral Dutchess County community, thinks of himself as community minded. But he figures at this point that he has done more than his share.

title: The California Quake; Children Live With Fear in Area of Disasters
description: The lights were back on and children returned to class today at Lexington Elementary School near the summit of the Santa Cruz Mountains and just a few miles from the epicenter of the earthquake last Tuesday. For children who lost their homes, who saw neighbors injured or who have spent nights sleeping in a strange place, today was a day of sharing their own stories.

title: An Editor's Cry From Gorbachev's Doghouse
description: Vladislav A. Starkov was supposed to be in Canada today, promoting the wonders of life under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But late Saturday night, a Communist Party underling phoned him at home to tell him his trip was ''not recommended.''

title: The California Quake; Bay Area's Commuters Find a New Way to Go: Mass Transit
description: After surprisingly smooth traveling on the first full workday after last week's devastating earthquake, local transit and city officials wondered if the long weeks without the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and one of its key feeder highways, the Nimitz Freeway, would substantially alter the travel habits of local residents.

title: Fischer-Dieskau Is Ill
description: The baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau has canceled his performances with the New York Philharmonic on Saturday and next Tuesday. saying he is suffering from the flu. He was to have sung Mahler's ''Songs of a Wayfarer.'' Instead, the orchestra will present an all-Tchaikovsky program, including ''Romeo and Juliet,'' ''Francesca da Rimini'' and the Fourth Symphony, with Leonard Bernstein conducting. Mr. Fischer-Dieskau's recitals on Nov. 3 and 5 at Carnegie Hall are still scheduled.

title: First Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lone Star Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,564,000 related to the extinguishment of debt.

title: Savings Outflow In August
description: The savings industry lost billions of dollars in deposits in August as the tough new capital requirements set by the savings and loan rescue forced executives to shrink the size of their institutions, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

title: Lake Shore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hershey Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7,105,000, or 8 cents a share and $16,063,000, or 18 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, both from a Friendly Ice Cream Corp. restaurant unit, sold Sept. 2, 1988 and an extraordinary gain from sale of Friendly of $53,380,000, or 59 cents a share for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Union Carbide Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a previously reported non-recurring gain of 5 cents a share representing the net effect of an aftertax gain of 44 cents a share from the sale of Carbide's urethane polyols and propylene glycols businesses and an aftertax loss of 39 cents a share resulting from a writedown of the corporation's polysilicon business. Figures for 1988 have been restated for reclassification of foreign currency gains/losses on debt incurred by international affiliates operating in hyperinflationary countries in Latin America, from other income to interest expense. Results for 1988 included a $10 million charge for impairment of assets related to an enhanced oil recovery project and included a $20 million gain from the sale of securities by Canadian affiliates.

title: Review/Music; Old and New Works Offered By Composers Orchestra
description: The American Composers Orchestra serves the important double function of giving premieres of newly composed orchestral works, and offering second looks at older ones. In the first concert of the orchestra's season, on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Dennis Russell Davies led the ensemble in new works by Martin Bresnick and William Albright, a neglected score by Samuel Barber and a recent piece by Steve Reich.

title: Galileo Sent on Way, Atlantis Returns Early
description: Darting back to Earth between two storms, the space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here this morning after sending the Galileo spacecraft on a six-year journey to Jupiter.

title: Freeway Survivor's Time Was Running Out
description: BUCK Helm, the burly 57-year-old longshoreman plucked alive from the earthquake rubble last Saturday, was rescued just in time. His doctors now say that he was on the verge of cardiac arrest, and experts expressed doubt that he would have survived another day trapped in his Chevrolet Sprint under the rubble that was once Interstate 880 in Oakland.

title: Fourth Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In a First, U.S. to Sell Two Picture Postcards
description: The United States Postal Service has decided to start selling picture postcards, but it will limit sales to cards bearing photographs of the White House and the Jefferson Memorial and they will be available only in Washington.

title: Patterns
description: Stripping Down to Basics

title: British Aerospace Strike
description: Britain's main engineering unions said today that they would ask 7,000 workers to go on strike next week at two British Aerospace plants and a Rolls-Royce factory to support a shorter workweek. The Confederation of Engineering and Shipbuilding Unions had conducted a poll of workers in seven factories to measure support for a strike on the issue of cutting the workweek to 35 hours, from 39.

title: Jane Bronson Philips, Professor, 69
description: Jane Bronson Philips, an associate professor of English at Pace University, died of cancer Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 69 years old and lived in Briarcliff, N.Y.

title: Reagan Given Top Award By Japanese
description: Ronald Reagan was hailed, honored and generally treated like a head of state today while Japanese leaders fondly recalled his Presidency as a time of fewer frictions over trade and other issues.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Baltimore Stadium Bonds
description: To finance the construction of a new stadium for the Baltimore Orioles baseball team, the Maryland Stadium Authority is offering $137.55 million in tax-exempt sports facilities lease revenue bonds through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The maxmimum yield is 7.60 percent for bonds due in 2019.

title: Safeco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months included realized gains from the sale of investments of $6,332,000 and $24,104,000, respectively. Results for the year-ago quarter and 9 months included $2,718,000 and $23,563,000, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
People's Bank-Bridgeport reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months' per share figure was unavailable; the company converted to a stock form of ownership in July 1988.

title: Atlantic Richfield reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 9 months revenues included sales of Lyondell Petrochemical Co. of $1.2 billion and $3.6 billion, respectively. The first 9 months of 1989 net income included a $634 million after-tax gain from ARCO's sale of a majority interest in Lyondell in January 1989. This gain was partially offset by $345 million after-tax charges. Results of the firs 9 months were also reduced by about $26 million after tax as a result of increased Alaskan severance taxes which were levied retroactively to Jan. 1.

title: New York Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $114,000 reflecting a penalty on the prepayment of F.L.H.B. advances. The prior year per share net is not directly comparable as the company went public on Feb. 4, 1988.

title: Ramada Alters Buyout Terms
description: After failing to raise $230 million in ''junk bond'' financing for a plan to divide the company, Ramada Inc. altered the terms of its deal. Under the new arrangement, Ramada investors will receive up to $1 for each share of stock instead of up to $7. Investors in the company, which is planning to sell its hotel business to concentrate on gaming, will also receive one share of stock in the new Ramada company, to be called the Aztar Corporation, instead of one-half share for every Ramada share under the original plan. New World Hotels Ltd., the

title: Branford Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
United Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Capital Cities Profit Up 29% In Quarter
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday reported a 29 percent increase in its third-quarter net income, based largely on significantly stronger revenues for its broadcasting division, led by the ABC television network.

title: Finnish Ship Manufacturer Planning Bankruptcy Filing
description: Wartsila Marine Industries, the Finnish shipbuilder that once built 30 percent of the world's cruise ships and more than half of the icebreakers, said today that it would file for bankruptcy protection.

title: Gasoline Prices Drop
description: The average price of gasoline nationwide dipped about a half-cent a gallon at the pumps in the last two weeks. The Lundberg Survey of 12,000 gas stations showed the average retail price of all grades of gasoline, including taxes, at 109.12 cents a gallon on Friday, down 0.53 cent from Oct. 6, Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. According to the survey, self-service prices for a gallon were: regular unleaded, 97.74 cents; premium unleaded, 114.87 cents; regular leaded, 96.62 cents. At full-service pumps, prices for regular unleaded were: 127.26 cents a gallon; premium unleaded, 139.92 cents, and regular leaded, 126.01 cents.

title: Rationing 'Dallas' in Europe
description: Western Europe, the font of Western culture, now seeks to protect itself against foreign cultural subversion. In an absurd effort to regulate public taste, the 12-nation European Community has put restrictions on foreign television shows. Though the lid may have little practical effect, Washington is filing formal charges under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which sets the global rules for exporting and importing. Its point is valid: The proposed quota for imported entertainment is protectionism.

title: The California Quake; Where to Send Donations
description: Interaction, a voluntary relief assistance group supported by the Federal Government, has issued the following list of agencies to which money may be sent to assist earthquake victims: American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund, P.O. Box 4691, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163. Telephone: 800-453-9000. Americares Foundation, 161 Cherry St., New Canaan, Conn. 06840. Telephone: 203-966-5195. American Jewish World Service, 1290 Avenue of the Americas -11th floor, New York, N.Y. 10104. Telephone: 212-468-7380. Church World Service, P.O. Box 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Telephone: 212-870-3151. Direct Relief International, 2801-B De La Vina Street, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93105. Telephone: 805-687-3694. Episcopal Church/The Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief, The Episcopal Church Center, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Telephone: 800-334-7626, or in New York City 867-8400. Operation California/USA, 7615 1/2 Melrose Ave., Los Angeles. 90046. Telephone: 213-658-8876. The Salvation Army, San Francisco Earthquake Relief, 132 West 14th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011. Telephone: 212-807-4273. World Relief, P.O. Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. Telephone: 312-665-0235. World Vision, 919 West Huntington Drive, Monrovia, Calif. 91016. Telephone: 818-357-7979. Donations are also being collected by these groups: B'nai B'rith Bay Area Disaster Relief, B'nai B'rith, CVS. 1640 Rhode Island Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Walton Gives a 2d Opinion
description: As if the Sunday results weren't bad enough, the Jets' bad news continued today.

title: West Newton Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected an increase in the provision for possible loan losses to $2 million for the quarter, from $100,000 a year ago, and joint venture losses of $450,000. c-Net income

title: SEARCH IS STOPPED FOR PARTS OF JET
description: After failing to find a part crucial to investigators, searchers have stopped looking for engine pieces from a jetliner that crashed in July, Some 90 volunteers with metal detectors turned up engine fragments over the weekend when they examined stubble from corn and soybean, but a flange from the engine remained missing.

title: The Welfare War Between the States
description: Much has been written about the wars waged between states to attract new jobs. A similar war is being waged in welfare reform. Some states keep welfare benefits low so that some of their residents will move to more socially responsible states.

title: Detective Tells Of Confession In Jogger Rape
description: One of the teen-agers indicted in the Central Park rape case confessed only after his father suggested that the boy's mother leave a police interrogation so that she would not feel ''embarrassed by the nature of the crime,'' a detective testified yesterday.

title: Reputed Organized-Crime Figure Agrees to Fine in Teamsters Case
description: A reputed organized-crime figure who had high-level ties to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is to pay the Government $250,000 in a civil settlement that will also permanently bar him from all labor union activities, the United States Attorney's office in New York announced yesterday.

title: Downey to Be Co-host Of Talk Show on CNBC
description: The Consumer News and Business Channel has announced that it will present a new daily television talk show with Morton Downey Jr. as co-host, starting Dec. 4.

title: Net Off at Exxon and Phillips; Occidental and ARCO Gain
description: Big oil companies reported mixed third-quarter earnings yesterday, with the Exxon Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Company down, while the Occidental Petroleum Company, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Amerada Hess Corporation reported gains. Ashland Oil Inc. reported a loss for the quarter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We violated the norms of proper behavior. We went against general human values.

title: Rangers Thwart Power Play to Beat Canucks
description: If he has any genius, Roger Neilson, the Rangers' coach, would like people to believe he acquired it strictly by coincidence. Neilson chalks up each successful strategy to accident. So it was natural when he said his showing of a videotape on Vancouver's five-on-three power play yesterday morning to the Rangers was simply an afterthought.

title: Big Leap for Texas After a 2d Upset
description: The Texas Longhorns, lifted by a 24-20 upset of previously undefeated Arkansas, gained an impressive 10 positions yesterday in The New York Times's computer ranking of leading college football teams.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Moscow admitted violations in Afghanistan. The invasion broke Soviet law and international norms of behavior, Foreign Minister Shevardnadze told the Soviet legislature. Page A1

title: Allegheny Power System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iran Offers Trade on Hostages, but U.S. Is Cautious
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said today that Teheran would help the Bush Administration obtain the freedom of American hostages if Washington helped solve the case of three Iranians kidnapped in Lebanon or returned Iranian assets frozen in the United States since 1979.

title: Congress Moves on Ethics, but Stalls on Campaign Spending
description: In response to attacks this year on lawmakers' personal and professional behavior, Congress has developed several measures to tighten ethical standards but has made little progress on restricting campaign spending.

title: Newport News Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected an additional loan-loss provision of $987,000 and a loss of $265,000 on securities transactions. c-Net income

title: Liz Claiborne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nicaragua Coup in 30's Had U.S. Blessing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paribas Makes Offer For Navigation Mixte
description: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, the French investment banking group, said today that it would try to acquire two-thirds of Navigation Mixte, a holding company with interests in insurance and banking.

title: American Television & Comunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charges of $3.3 million related to damage caused by hurricane Hugo in its Charlotte, N.C., division. c-Affected by a one-time pretax charge of $19.9 million for the reorganization and relocation of ATC's executive offices.

title: David Victor Dies; Produced 'Kildare' And Other TV Series
description: David Victor, a producer of numerous television series including ''Dr. Kildare'' and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.,'' died after a heart attack on Oct. 18 while he and his wife, Florence, were vacationing in Williamsburg, Va. He was 79 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Attorney Is Said to Be Investigating Con Edison in Steam Blast
description: Con Edison is under investigation by the United States Attorney's office in connection with the explosion of an asbestos-lined steam pipe in Gramercy Park, a top Federal environmental official told a Congressional hearing in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Ashland Oil Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $77,697,000 and $72,384,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from settlement of dispute with National Iranian Oil Co.; additional reserves for cost overruns in Riley Consolidated, and charge relating to sale of technology unit; the year charge also included charge for arbitration award and gain from Carbon Black sale. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary charge of $24,800,000 which included charge for Riley reserves and settlement of lawsuits for the quarter and the year included an extraordinary gain of $12,293,000, or 22 cents a share, which included Riley reserves, lawsuit settlements and a gain of $40.2 million from an accounting change.

title: School Superintendent in Queens Tells of Costly Patronage Scheme
description: A Queens schools superintendent who secretly tape-recorded conversations with school board members testified yesterday that dozens of unnecessary jobs in his district were awarded to friends and supporters of those board members at an annual cost of almost $1 million.

title: Advo-System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Mahorn Italy Bound?
description: Rick Mahorn, the latest National Basketball Association player to be courted by the Italian basketball league, is expected to arrive in Italy today to negotiate a deal with Glaxo Verona.

title: The California Quake; A Crippling Blow for Oakland's Poor
description: When Jeanette Blackmon moved into her single room at the Oaks Hotel on 15th Street five weeks ago, she thought she had finally arrived.

title: Hong Kong-Beijing Immigrant Rift Ends
description: A diplomatic dispute between Hong Kong and China was resolved today when officials here announced that Beijing had agreed to resume accepting the return of Chinese illegal immigrants who have crossed into the colony.

title: Let the Dollar Drift
description: One reason the financial markets are jittery is the increasing tension between the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve over the value of the dollar. The Treasury wants to push the dollar down and thus push exports up. The Federal Reserve resists.

title: NFS Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lubrizol Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected charge of $14 million from writedown of investments for the both periods; the 9 months also reflected gain of $7 million, or 18 cents a share, from sale of investments, and a gain of $8,751,000, or 22 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: D.E.A. Agents Kill Suspect In Rockefeller Center Arrest
description: A drug suspect was shot and killed and a Federal drug agent was slightly injured last night when an undercover operation involving four pounds of cocaine went sour at Rockefeller Center in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Guarantees of Free Speech Aren't Unlimited
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; A New York Rousseau Is a Hit in Leningrad
description: The sensation of the loan show that marks the 225th anniversary of the foundation of the Hermitage in Leningrad is beyond a doubt ''The Sleeping Gypsy'' by the Douanier Rousseau. Long familiar to every visitor to the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, where it normally hangs, it is now the Leningraders' favorite enigma. Not only do they crowd in to see it, but they also form an orderly line - 10, 11, 12 deep - so that each in turn can look at it intently and without interference from others.

title: Defense Implies Witness Killed Student at Pratt
description: A defense lawyer told a jury yesterday that his client had not fatally shot a Pratt Institute art student during a street robbery last year and suggested that the prosecution's key witness was actually the murderer.

title: Coal Mine Strike in Siberia
description: As many as 20,000 Siberian coal miners defied an official ban and mounted a protest strike today, raising the prospect of more industrial unrest before of the harsh Russian winter. Tass said pit workers in the city of Mezhdurechensk, who began a wave of strikes that paralyzed the Soviet coal industry in July, stopped work again for two hours to protest the failure to implement pledges made to them by management.

title: First Michigan Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UAL Tries To Keep Itself Intact
description: The board of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, announced yesterday that it would seek to keep the company independent while it examines financial and strategic alternatives.

title: A 6-Foot-3, Blue-Eyed Taiwanese-American Is China's Top Rocker
description: Dressed in a sequined jacket and white slacks, a slender blue-eyed, black-haired singer swivels his hips around the stage under the light of a flickering strobe as a crowd of 15,000 Chinese youngsters, officials and even grandparents watch the spectacle in fascination.

title: Eastern Quakes: Real Risk, Few Precautions
description: AN EARTHQUAKE as powerful as the one that struck northern California last week could occur almost anywhere along the East Coast, experts say. And if it did, it would probably cause far more destruction than the West Coast quake.

title: Mississippians Seek Inquiry to Determine If Tritium Is Leaking
description: On the 25th anniversary of the first underground nuclear test in a salt dome here, some Mississippians are seeking a study to determine if radioactive material is leaking from the site.

title: 'Attack' Politics, Rife in '88 Election, Comes Into Its Own for Lesser Stakes
description: From the streets of New York to the Central Valley of California, American political campaigns have degenerated into nasty, name-calling affairs in which debate about the ''issues'' is often little more than a shouting match over which candidate is the bigger liar.

title: Pictures Come to Life in Minutes
description: IMPEL is so much fun it's almost a shame that it's useful too. With Impel you can create animated presentations for your computer screen.

title: Helms Says Reds Overlook Him for Job
description: Tommy Helms says the Cincinnati Reds' management has passed him over and is only identifying him as a managerial candidate as a courtesy while the Reds seek someone else.

title: Giuliani Calls for Road and Bridge Repairs
description: Standing in front of the Williamsburg Bridge, which had to be closed for about two weeks last year because of poor maintainance, Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday announced his plans for improving the city's infrastructure if he is elected mayor.

title: 2 Norway Banks Agree to Merger
description: Two of Norway's biggest banks, Den Norske Creditbank and Bergen Bank A.S., agreed to merge effective Jan. 1. In the merger, two D.N.C. shares will be worth one Bergen Bank share. Trading in the stock of both banks was suspended before the terms were announced, with D.N.C. shares quoted at 99.5 kroner, about $14.4, and Bergen Bank shares at 168 kroner, about $24.39.

title: Meritor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $5,510,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,236,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from early extinguishment of debt; the 9 months also included a pre-tax gain on divestiture of operations of $27,757,000 and a pre-tax loss from sales of investments and loans of $13,575,000. c-Included a pre-tax gain of $7,017,000 on divestiture of operations and a pre-tax gain of $12,950,000 from the sales of investments and loans. Meritor said the latest quarter results also included a pre-tax gain of $8.4 million from the settlement of pension plan obligations.

title: CFS Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DiMaggio, A Neighbor, The Quake
description: rrJoe DiMaggio is her neighbor. She has lived for about 10 years just a few doors down the block from the old Yankee ballplayer in the Marina District here, the lovely, snug area that took so terrible a jolt from last week's earthquake.

title: For Storage, New Disks Gain Ground On Floppies
description: CD-ROM, which stands for Compact Disk Read Only Memory, is the nerdy cousin of the audio compact disk's that are replacing conventional phonograph albums. While a single five-inch audio CD can hold an hour's worth of Beethoven or The Austin Lounge Lizards, an identical computer CD-ROM disk can hold 550 to 600 megabytes of data, the equivalent storage capacity of hundreds of floppy diskettes.

title: Tandy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INSIDE
description: Factory Blast in Texas Up to 22 workers were missing and one was dead in explosions at a plastics plant near Houston that injured more than 100 people. Page A18. Tokyo's Financial Influence Japan, the world's biggest creditor and provider of financial assistance, is taking a larger role in global finance institutions. Page D1. Shuttle Returns Early The space shuttle landed three hours early after sending a probe toward Jupiter. Science Times, page C7. Asbestos Fund in Jeopardy The trust set up by the Manville Corporation to pay victims of asbestos is almost out of money. Page A18.

title: Ogilvy Group's Chairman Resigns
description: A little more than a year after becoming chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, the world's seventh-largest advertising agency, Kenneth Roman resigned yesterday. His departure after 26 years at the company comes just five months after he lost a takeover battle to the WPP Group, the London-based marketing and communications company that also owns J. Walter Thompson.

title: Market Place; Behind the Surge In Rally's Stock
description: RALLY'S Inc. has a goal of providing fast food faster than McDonald's. But its new speed record has nothing to do with hamburgers.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: San Antonio's $575 million tax-exempt bond issue to refinance debt previously sold when interest rates were higher was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The maximum yield on the electric and gas system revenue refunding bonds is 7.30 percent for bonds due in 2009.

title: The California Quake; NBC News Tells of Errors and Obstacles to Early Coverage of Quake
description: Executives of NBC News said yesterday that errors in news judgment, transmission problems and a lack of experienced technical personnel had contributed to the division's failure last week to provide competitive coverage in the first 90 minutes after the earthquake struck San Francisco.

title: Baker Sees in Gorbachev a New Chance for Peace
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of change could provide the United States and the Soviet Union with the ''clearest opportunity to reduce the risk of war since the dawn of the nuclear age.''

title: As Plankton Fares, So Does a Reef Fish
description: Without the tiny plants, the larvae die.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about do-it-yourself abortions referred incompletely to the author of the book ''When Birth Control Fails.'' It is by Suzann Gage, who teaches at Holistic Health for Women, a clinic in Los Angeles.

title: Dinkins Forum In Jewish Center Becomes Nasty
description: A forum between David N. Dinkins and Jewish civic and religious leaders in Queens - intended to reassure the audience about the Democratic mayoral nominee's support for Jewish causes - turned nasty yesterday when some attacked him for his friendship with the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Coliseum Sale Not Expected By Deadline
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch indicated yesterday that he did not believe a legal challenge to the Columbus Circle redevelopment plan would be resolved in time to lessen budget cuts and fee increases expected soon.

title:
ON HORSE RACING;
Grade I's: Pro Tour Of Sorts
description: LEAD: rrThe upper echelon of thoroughbred racing marked a brief pause yesterday, a hiatus between the season behind and the championship day ahead.

title: Cummins Engine Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss

title: Ewan MacColl Dies; Folk Singer Was 74
description: Ewan MacColl, who led the folk music revival in Britain and wrote the Grammy Award-winning ballad ''The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face,'' died on Sunday in a London hospital after heart surgery. He was 74 years old.

title: Detroit Edison reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for year-ago 9 months reflect a $344.1 million write-off for disallowed plant.

title: Eliot Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The bank said the loss in the latest third quarter was primarily the result of loan-loss provisions and a $652,000 writedown of investment securities.

title: Deluxe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Attack' Politics Is Rife
description: A wave of ''attack'' ads has buried hopes that last year's Presidential race would produce a backlash against negative politics. Page A24.

title: The Chanel Jacket: An Icon Adorned
description: After the costumes and theatrics of the first days of the spring and summer ready-to-wear showings, the clothes have begun to demand some serious attention. Well, maybe not all the clothes, but certainly the decorative elements.

title: Prime Planning 2,500 Layoffs
description: Prime Computer Inc. said today that it would lay off 2,500 employees, or about 20 percent of its employees.

title: Time Warner Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results for 1989 included a significant increase in interest expense due to the purchase of 100 million shares of Warner Communications common stock, as well as the purchase price amortization associated with the Warner Communications acquisition, and also reflected Time Warner's 59.3-percent ownership of Warner Communications Inc. from Aug. 1 and the use of the purchase method of accounting. The company said its operating results included the operating results of Warner Communications for the two months ended Sept. 30, after deducting the minority interest's 40.7-percent share. Interest expense for the three and 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1989 included $216 million from the amortization of fees incurred to obtain the short-term financing of the offer. Depreciation and amortization expense included $40 million from the amortization of the excess of the cost to acquire the 59.3-percent common stock interest in Warner Communications over the net assets acaquired, based on an estimated average life of about 30 years. The valuation and other studies necessary for a final determination of the allocation of excess cost are not complete; accordingly, the basis for amortization is subject to adjustment. Historical earnings and loss per share are based upon average common shares outstanding during the period after eliminating Time Warner's 59.3-percent interest from July 24, 1989 in the Time Warner exchange shares owned by Warner Communications.

title: Pacific Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included the impact of the Diablo Canyon rate case settlement, which reduced aftertax earnings by $576,000,000, or $1.38 a share. Share earnings have been affected by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Allied-Signal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 9 months included net-after tax provisions of $118 million and $125 million, respectively, for streamlining and restructuring as well as environmental expenditures for shutdown facilities. Year-ago quarter and 9 months both also included an after-tax gain of $36 million, or 24 cents a share, on the sale of the company's investment in Akebono Brake Industry Co. and an after-tax gain of $81 million, or 54 cents a share, from the sale of the automotive electronics unit and the formation of a joint venture between Allied-Signal and Union Carbide Corp.

title: G.M. and Fuji Out
description: The General Motors Corporation and Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan have decided to withdraw from a planned car-making joint venture with a Chinese company in northern China, officials at both companies said. Fuji said it had decided to drop the project because of a lack of components and worry about political instability. A G.M. spokesman, Ron Theis, said in Detroit that the deal ''did not appear to be viable.''

title: Spend Taxes for Quality of Life, Not Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Salt in the Sea Q.Why is the ocean salty? A.Rocks that erode on the continents contain salt, which is brought by the rivers to the ocean, said Harmon Craig, professor of geochemistry and oceanography at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California at San Diego.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about experimental drugs given away by pharmaceutical companies misidentified a lawyer and consultant to the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund. He is Jay C. Lipner.

title: Solidarity Struggles - With Democracy
description: It's a thrill to watch former political prisoners and underground Solidarity activists sitting in the august chamber of Poland's new Parliament, debating budget bills and tax legislation. This is the Communist world's most dramatic revolution so far. It is also sobering to see how difficult the construction of a democratic system of government is proving to be, mechanically and psychologically.

title: NBB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Magazine Executives Celebrate Their Industry's Revival
description: The publishers and editors of America's magazines have gathered at this resort community on Florida's southwest coast this week to celebrate their industry's renewed prosperity. The Annual Magazine Conference comes at a time when circulation is rising, new titles are proliferating and advertising revenue share -coaxed away from television - is increasing.

title: Pinnacle in Talks
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation declined to confirm rumors that it was nearing an agreement with Federal regulators on the sale of its loss-ridden Merabank subsidiary. Analysts said that if a sale is not arranged by Dec. 7, strict new capital rules could require Pinnacle West to inject some $300 million to $400 million into Merabank. Pinnacle West's stock was off $1.625 today, to $9.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its decline of 15.1 percent was the largest of the day.

title: Gilbert J. Sinnott, 82, Insurance Executive
description: Gilbert J. Sinnott, a retired insurance executive, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Go Ahead, Sleep In
description: For people seeking an excuse to sleep the extra hour in the morning, a new study may provide just the answer.

title: Suits Accuse White Supremacists in a Bias Death
description: Two major civil rights organizations have filed suit in Federal court in Portland, Ore., charging that a California white supremacist group called the White Aryan Resistance incited two Oregon ''skinheads'' to beat an Ethiopian immigrant to death in Portland last November.

title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs
description: Federal efforts to seize the property of a Vermont man who was caught growing marijuana in his vegetable garden have aroused the ire of neighbors here.

title: 2 Forms of Skin Cancer Increase
description: Two deadly forms of skin cancer are increasing at alarming rates in the United States, apparently because people are spending more time in the sun, researchers have found.

title: L.I. Man Buries Body in Parents' Backyard
description: A man who panicked when a friend died in his car buried the friend in his parents' backyard here, then agonized for a week before telling his mother about it, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Exxon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from Valdez provision of $880,000,000.

title: American Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months per share earnings unavailable as the company went public on Jan. 26.

title: Net Rises 14% At McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation today reported a 14 percent increase in its third-quarter earnings, attributed largely to strong sales overseas and the success of domestic promotional programs.

title: Lebanese Militia Leaders Fault Proposed Charter
description: Lebanon's Muslim and Christian militia commanders today sharply criticized a new national charter for governing the country, a day after it was adopted by 62 Lebanese legislators in Saudi Arabia.

title: Search for Commissioner: Act III
description: The National Football League's owners hope that all of the dialogue, the rhetoric and the infighting are behind them now and that they can indeed elect a new commissioner in meetings scheduled to begin here Tuesday.

title: 300,000 Reported to March in Largest East German Protest
description: Hundreds of thousands of East Germans marched peacefully through Leipzig tonight, demanding democratic changes, including legalization of opposition movements, independent labor unions and separation of powers between the Communist Party and the state.

title: Inco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $11.6 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $45.3 million, or 43 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from the use of prior years' tax losses. c-After extraordinary credits of $12.9 million, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $27.8 million, or 26 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from the use of prior years' tax losses.

title: Courter and Florio Contrast Most Over Social Issues
description: The two candidates running for governor of New Jersey appear in starkest contrast when they speak about social questions facing the state, like how to fight crime, drugs and AIDS, and whether government should place new restrictions on abortions.

title: President of Reebok Resigns to Rejoin Firm
description: After less then three years in the job, C. Joseph Labonte has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Reebok International Ltd., the athletic-shoe company said yesterday.

title: Plastics Plant Explodes; Many Missing
description: Huge explosions at a petrochemical complex on the Houston Ship Channel today injured more than 100 workers, sent debris flying for miles and started a fire that burned out of control for hours.

title: Teamster Leader Found Slain In Local Office in New Jersey
description: An official of teamsters Local 478 was found shot to death today at the local headquarters in Union, officials said. A co-worker found the official, Harry Serio, 68 years old, was found at 8 A.M., an assistant Union County prosecutor, David J. Hancock, said.

title: Problems Loom in Effort to Control Use of Chemicals for Illicit Drugs
description: FRUSTRATED by the failure to stop the flood of drugs into the country, leaders of America's battle against drugs are seeking to restrict supplies of key ingredients and processing chemicals required to make illegal substances. But many experts believe the effort is doomed to failure by the seemingly endless alternative methods of synthesizing drugs that technically skilled criminals have devised.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 12 about Tass's reaction to the world attention given its report of extraterrestrial creatures in a Soviet city misidentified the chairman of the astronomy department at Cornell University. He is Yervant Terzian.

title: Books of The Times; Vargas Llosa on the Role of Fiction and Its Making
description: The Storyteller By Mario Vargas Llosa Translated by Helen Lane. 246 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Dana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
5 Ejected for Fighting As Devils Stop Leafs
description: The officials worked harder than the players tonight, filling up the penalty boxes at Maple Leaf Gardens in an ugly hockey game that resulted in five ejections, including those of the starting goaltenders.

title: Ford Grantor Trust Certificates Priced
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company yesterday priced the largest issue of any pass-through securities to date, with the sale of $2.575 billion in asset-backed certificates issued through Ford Credit 1989-A Grantor Trust. The asset-backed securities, which are due in 1994, are secured by automobile loans sold to the trust by Ford Motor Credit, which will continue to service the loans.

title: MGM Grand Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $1,806,000, or 9 cents a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $356,000 from a tax change. d-After an extraordinary tax credit of $66,000. The latest 9 months' income before extraordinary item included a pre-tax gain of $26,482,000 from the sale of hotel-casino assets.

title: Killings And Control
description: Should the C.I.A. be allowed greater latitude in overthrowing foreign governments, even when such an attempt might lead to the death of that government's leader?

title: DSC Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $324,000 for the quarter and $801,000 for the 9 months.

title: Ameribanc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $189,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $607,000, or 28 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Baseball Fans Are Mixed on Restart of World Series
description: Baseball fans expressed mixed reactions today on the propriety and practicality of resuming the World Series on Friday. But they generally seemed to agree that the slogan ''The Battle of the Bay'' had lost its ring of cheer since the earthquake struck northern California six days ago.

title: Robinson Faces Knicks
description: David Robinson, the center the National Basketball Association has been waiting for, will be the big attraction at 7:30 tonight as the San Antonio Spurs oppose the Knicks in a preseason game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Even New York City School Principals Deserve Due Process; Risks of Transfer
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; AIDS Quilt and the Stories Behind Its Symbols
description: As of this past summer, the number of deaths among Americans with AIDS rose to more than 59,000, higher than the total fatalities in the Vietnam War. Yet the vast majority of people with AIDS remain virtually invisible on prime-time television. There is one obvious reason. The groups most affected so far, male homosexuals and drug users, are considered by many to be social outsiders. Compassion is clearly at a premium. A not-so-benign neglect has been the general rule.

title: Quayle and Kean Buoy Courter
description: Reminding their audience of uphill fights of their own, Vice President Dan Quayle and Gov. Thomas H. Kean today encouraged the Republican candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter, to strive for a come-from-behind victory on Nov. 7.

title: CVB Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Keystone Consolidated reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits from tax loss carryforwards of $780,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,165,000, or 86 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $187,000 for the quarter and $423,000 for the 9 months.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $5,897,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and the 9 months is after an extraordinary charge of $348,000. The company said extraordinary charges represent premium on early retirement of debt.

title: Panel Changes Dietary Standards for Calcium
description: AFTER a delay of four years, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences has updated the recommended dietary allowances of vitamins and minerals, making two changes that could affect what Americans choose to eat.

title: Wall St. Journal To Raise Rates
description: The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that it would raise national advertising rates 4 percent next year. The increase is smaller than the 6.5 percent of 1989 because the cost of newsprint and postage has not risen this year, said Roger May, a spokesman for The Journal. ''We wanted to share that with our customers,'' he said. Regional advertising rates will increase 5.5 percent in The Journal's four regional editions, while they will jump 7.5 percent for local advertising, which is available in 15 local markets.

title: Michael Cecere, 45, Labor Law Specialist
description: Michael S. Cecere, a lawyer who specialized in employment litigation, died of cancer of the colon Thursday at Hackensack Medical Center in Hackensack, N.J. He was 45 years old and lived in Tenafly.

title: Utilities Admit the Potential Silencing of Workers
description: At least three electric utilities have told Federal regulators of secret labor settlements with workers at nuclear power plants that might be interpreted as buying their silence, Government records indicate.

title: British TV on Eve of Competitive Era
description: On the eve of legislation to change the face of British television by 1992, viewers, critics and broadcasters are debating whether more commercial competition will lead to lower standards on the air.

title: Texas Congressman Stricken
description: Representative Jack Brooks, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, underwent hospital tests today after suffering abdominal pains during a flight from Texas to Washington, his office announced. Mr. Brooks, a 66-year-old Texas Democrat, was being treated at Bethesda Naval Hospital to determine the cause of the pain, his office said in a brief statement. He is expected to be hospitalized for several days for observation, his office said.

title: Irma A. Bloomingdale, 101, a Civic Leader
description: Irma Asiel Bloomingdale, who was active in philanthropic and civic causes in Westchester County for many decades, died Friday at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 101 years old.

title: Chess
description: In the two semifinal world championship candidates matches, which ended Oct. 17 in London, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union defeated his countryman Artur Yusupov and Jan Timman of the Netherlands defeated Jonathan Speelman of Britain. Karpov and Timman will meet in the final in London in March to determine the next challenger for the titleholder, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union.

title: Crane Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,788,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and $13,297,000, or 39 cents a share, for the 9 months. Year-ago income from discontinued operations represents the distibution of Medusa Corp. to shareholders in October 1988. The company said 1988 share data are restated for a 50 percent stock distribution in September 1989.

title: Stock Documents From Inner City Could Bolster Dinkins's Assertions
description: New details were released yesterday that could support David N. Dinkins's contention that he properly valued stock sold to his son for $58,000 in 1986, even though in 1983 he had put its market value at more than $1 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Leo Burnett U.S.A. has created a pro bono ad campaign to heighten awareness of Alzheimer's disease. It will run in November, which is National Alzheimer's Month.

title: Arbitragers Face Big Losses on UAL
description: Arbitragers have paper losses of as much as $1 billion on their holdings of stock of the UAL Corporation, and some of the biggest losses are at conservative firms that generally do not buy into a takeover target until an agreement is reached with its board.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Asher-Gould Receives Suzuki Motor Account
description: Seeking to recover from the turmoil that followed a Consumer Reports finding last year that the Suzuki Samurai was unsafe, the American Suzuki Motor Corporation awarded its advertising account on Friday to Asher/Gould, a medium-sized Los Angeles agency.

title: Tony Manero, Golf Champion, 84
description: Tony Manero, the 1936 United States Open golf champion and a member of the 1937 United States Ryder Cup team, died of heart failure Sunday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Browns Crush Bears
description: Bernie Kosar's passing and a fired-up Browns' defense led Cleveland to a 27-7 victory over Chicago tonight, leaving the Bears with a three-game losing streak for the first time in eight years.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
People
description: LEAD: * Shelly Lazarus has been named U.S. president and chief operating officer of Ogilvy & Mather Direct.

title: Stocks Drop Broadly; Dow Off 26.23 Points
description: Stocks dropped broadly yesterday, as investors focused on a faltering economy, weakening corporate profits and a stagnant dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 26.23 points, or about 1 percent, to 2,662.91.

title: Bridge
description: Four team events concluded the Regional Championships in Stamford, Conn. Sunday. The winners were: Knockout Flight A, Ruth Stober of Great Neck, L.I., Bob Goldman of Dallas, Glenn Lublin of Silver Spring, Md., Howard Piltch of Andover, Mass., and Dave Leopold of East Weymouth, Mass.; Flight B, William Wood of South Salem, N.Y., Kay Barnett of Southport, Conn., Mary Keirns of Brewster, N.Y., and Jay Force of Stamford, Conn.; Swiss Teams, Flight A, Alex Ornstein of Roslyn Heights, L.I., Glenn Milgrim of Whitestone, Queens, Ken Jacobs of Manhattan, and Simon Erlich of Forest Hills, Queens; Flight B, Jade Barrett of Reading, Mass., R. Michelle Green of Somerville, Mass., and Barbra Arnold and Marcello Gambacorta, both of White Plains.

title: S.&P. Adds Harland
description: Shares of the John H. Harland Company, a printer of bank checks, will be added to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index at the close of trading Wednesday, replacing American Medical International, which is being acquired by the IMA Holdings Corporation, S.&P. said yesterday.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included after-tax writedown of about $179 million from a rate settlement agreement.

title: New Indignities for Refugees in Japan
description: Before a small group of Vietnamese were resettled in eastern Tokyo recently, the Japanese authorities had to assure nearby residents that the refugee centers would have showers. The neighbors were worried that the refugees might mingle with them in the local public baths.

title: Review/Theater; A Musical Inspired By a Trio Of Movies
description: ''Slay It With Music'' is the latest and far from the cleverest in a seemingly endless torrent of camp musicals inspired by old movies. Although shows of this sort usually send up vintage genre films, ''Slay It With Music,'' dares to set its satirical sights a bit higher by compresssing plot elements from ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?,'' ''Sunset Boulevard'' and ''The Bad Seed.'' The result is a lighthearted mishmash of a show lacking in drive and focus.

title: U.S. Hails Lebanon Accord and Urges Support
description: The Bush Administration today hailed the Lebanese peace accord as an ''extraordinary opportunity'' for ending the country's 14-year-old civil war and urged all parties to support it even though it acknowledged a Syrian role in Lebanese affairs.

title: Suburban Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Capital Cities/ABC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
U.S. OFFICIALS HAIL NEW SOVIET STANCE
description: American officials and specialists outside Government welcomed Moscow's admission today that its Krasnoyarsk radar station was a violation of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Washington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bickering Splits Westchester's Legislature
description: As Election Day draws near, any vestiges of civility have slipped out under the giant wood panel doors of the chambers here of the Westchester County Legislature, where every seat is up for grabs.

title: Israel Crausman, 90, Architect in New York
description: Israel L. Crausman, an architect and engineer, died of heart disease on Sunday at his home in Spring Valley, N.Y. He was 90 years old. Mr. Crausman was born in Bessarabia, now part of the Soviet Union, and came here with his family at the age of 13. He graduated from Cooper Union six years later with architectural and engineering degrees.

title: Glenmore Distilleries Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Business and Health; The Turnaround Of the H.M.O.'s
description: MOST health maintenance organizations did well this year, recovering from two years of heavy losses. Industry experts said most of the prepaid health plans should remain profitable at least through 1990, when the cycle may turn down again.

title: Antarctic Accord Must Protect Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Kimball International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Phillips Petroleum Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cincinnati Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included realized capital gains of $700,000, or 5 cents a share for the quarter and $6,000,000, or 37 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Included realized capital gains of $400,000, or 3 cents a share and $4,700,000, or 29 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: By Design; The Little Black Suit
description: The little black suit is this fall's surprise success story. While all the fashion oracles were predicting a preponderance of brown, the return of gray and camel, or the ascension of red, women were out finding and buying their new fall suits - in solid black.

title: The California Quake; House Panel Votes $2.85 Billion in Quake Relief
description: The House Appropriations Committee approved a $2.85 billion aid package today to help earthquake recovery efforts in the San Francisco Bay Area. The legislation would provide low-interest loans and grants to rebuild homes, businesses and highways in the devastated area.

title: Eaton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $100,000 and $5,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $600,000, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and $1,500,000, or 4 cents a share for the 9 months, and the 9-month also included an extraordinary charge of $17,700,000. The company said the extraordinary item in the year-ago 9-month reflects its payment of award in a lawsuit in the 1988 second quarter.

title: Plans for a Mayoral Debate Finally Appear to Be Firming
description: After three weeks of politicking and posturing, David N. Dinkins and Henry F. Hewes agreed yesterday to three debates. Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed to three debates, but two of them without Mr. Hewes and Ronald S. Lauder, who is in Europe and is not sure what he will do.

title: Nationwide Health reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net gains of $708,000 on the sales of assets.

title: Tony Manero, Golf Champion, 84
description: Tony Manero, the 1936 United States Open golf champion and a member of the 1937 United States Ryder Cup team, died of heart failure Sunday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Treasury Issues Continue Up
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to climb and yields decline yesterday as more investors moved from the stock to the fixed-income market. Dealers attributed the latest ''stocks for bonds'' move to a sharp selloff in equities that pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down at one point by as much as 85 points.

title: Illinois Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $34,012,000, or 49 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. The latest 9 months reflected a $346 million writeoff.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 President Bush spoke of Germany,predicting major changes in its status in the next decade and playing down European fears about the possibility of reunification. Page A1 East Germany elected Egon Krenz President, although there were votes against him in the usually deferential Parliament. He urged an end to the current protests. A15 Words fly on Marx-Engels-Platz: ''We want democracy'' A14 Freedom can cause headaches, Hungarians have found. As they near democracy, Hungarians are coping with soaring prices and squabbling politicians. A11 Shevardnadze in Poland for talks A12 Soviet legislature votes to abolosh official seats A13 North Korea's nuclear capability, including the possibility that it may be trying to develop nuclear weapons, is causing worry in Washington. Secretary Baker has characterized the problem as ominous. A9 Seoul agrees to buy 120 U.S. fighters A3 Cambodia vexes Singapore chief A3 China says Hong Kong apoligized in dispute A5 Lebanon's Parliament is to meet in Beirut in two weeks, elect a new President and begin changes to end its civil war, Saudi Arabia said. A6 Israel accepts U.S. plan on talks, with a catch A7 Crying ''sellout,'' Beirut Christians rally against accord A6 Behind the failed coup in Panama and subsequent debate over it lies a history of secret Bush and Reagan Administration plans that went awry or were resisted by Congress. A10 Amnesty International issues report on illegal state killings A8 National A16-29 The diaries of President Reagan may be used by John Poindexter's defense, but the papers of President Bush when he was Vice President may not be used, a judge ruled. A1 Sweeping restrictions on abortion were approved by the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. The move may allow Supreme Court to reconsider a landmark ruling. A1 Jim Bakker got 45 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. At the sentencing, the Federal judge called the television evangelist the mastermind of a ''massive fraud.'' A1 All the bodies from Highway 880 in Oakland have most likely been recovered, the police said, though 56 cars remain on the earthquake-damaged road. A1 House approves aid package for quake and storm victims A28 U.S. relief agency seeks relief from criticism A29 How bad was the UAL deal? Outside of initiating panics in the stock and bond market, the deal seems to have damaged the credibility of everyone in its path. A1 Dow ends 3.69 lower in a wild day D1 ''Degradable'' plastic products and the marketing campaign behind them could be causing more environmental problems than they are solving. A1 Exxon sues Valdez over cleanup A23 Twenty-four people may have died and little hope was held of finding survivors in the wreckage of a petrochemical complex ruined by an explosion on Monday. A18 Reverberations for industries but not for U.S. households A18 Lawmakers are expected to clash over Federal spending priorities as Congress begins a budget conference. Their aim is to shave a modest sum from the Federal deficit. A20 A White House counterattack began, seeking to divert attention to the Federal budget and away from emotional and politically troublesome issues like abortion. A20 Commutes from inner-city to suburb are increasingly popular around the country, serving low-income residents who need jobs and suburban employers short of workers. A16 How Mississippi clung to segregation in a speech A19 Poll shows homosexuals gain more acceptance A24 Regional B1-6 A school board was suspended by Chancellor Mecklowitz for making appointments in School District 27 based on ''political agendas.'' A1 Mayor Koch unveiled spending cuts, fee increases and other measures to close a $530 million budget deficit this year and reduce an even larger deficit expected next year. B1 Social-service trims proposed B2 David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani are adjusting their strategies to a tightening mayoral campaign. Polls put Mr. Giuliani within striking distance of an upset. B1 In Midwood, the big issue is still Jackson B1 Three Cabinet members to make appearances for Giuliani B3 stimating the value of Inner City stock B3 Will New Jersey taxes go up? Both candidates for governor say they do not plan to raise taxes, but neither can explain exactly how he would get pay for new programs. B1 On Jersey shore, a crucial race B4 To prevent begging in the subways and to keep people from lying down on trains, the New York City Transit Authority is to begin enforcing new rules of conduct today. B5 Lack of witnesses in killing of concertgoer puzzles officials B6

title: Deficit Reduction: A Love Story; I Want A Divorce
description: After four years in a shotgun marriage called Gramm-Rudman-Holl ings, I'm filing for divorce on grounds of infidelity and irreconcilable differences.

title: Greyhound Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $10,750,000, or 28 cents a share. The company said the accounting adjustment represents cumulative effect to Jan. 1, 1988 of initial application of SFAS No. 96 -Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: San Diego Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Old National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Regional Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nunn Reinstated
description: The Phoenix Cardinals announced yesterday that the defensive end Freddie Joe Nunn has been reinstated by the N.F.L. after serving a 30-day suspension for substance abuse. The 27-year-old Nunn, who was second in the league last season with 14 quarterback sacks, was suspended and placed on the team's nonfootball illness list without pay on Sept. 26, reportedly for cocaine abuse.

title: Car Sales Are Down 19 Percent
description: Sales of United States-built cars plunged 19 percent in mid-October and sales of domestic light trucks dropped 22.8 percent as auto makers continued to feel the effects of earlier aggressive discounting.

title: The California Quake; Victims of Quake in Bay Area
description: Following is a list of the dead who have been identified in the Oct. 17 earthquake, reported by the coroner's office in each county or the county's office of emergency services. The list includes deaths from traumatic injuries only, not from heart attacks, except in the case of Santa Clara County, where the count from the emergency agencies is at odds with that of the coroner. Two counties - Marin to the north of San Francisco and San Benito to the south - reported no deaths. Alameda County ASFOUR, Ramzi, 51, Novato. BEAUREGARD-SUND, Raymonde, 42, Alameda.
