description: THE working title of Leland and Crystal Payton's book in progress - a look at a wide range of wacky, witty and just plain ugly lamps made in the 1950's - was ''Outrageous Lamps.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about negative political campaigns misidentified a Democratic consultant. He is Robert Squier.

title: Bush, Citing 'Threat,' Reaffirms Need to Keep Nicaragua Embargo
description: President Bush told Congress today that he would continue the American trade embargo against Nicaragua because the Central American country represented ''an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States.''

title: Bridge
description: An imaginative bid on the diagramed deal helped the winners of the Flight A Regional Swiss Team Championship in Stamford, Conn., Sunday. Glenn Milgrim of Whitestone, Queens, overcalled one heart with one spade and heard his partner respond two clubs. This suggested moderate values with at least six clubs and a misfit in spades.

title: Sara Lee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3,000 Meet as East Germans Find Their Voices
description: A few hundred paces from the seat of leadership of the Government and the Communist Party, about 3,000 opponents of the regime met tonight to voice their critical views, which have not changed since Egon Krenz replaced Erich Honecker as party leader one week ago.

title: Review/Dance; Meditations on Misfits
description: Strength expressed weakness and weakness revealed unexpected strength on Monday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Chris Kaufman - a dancer of remarkable authority - offered a program of solos about social misfits. Yet some of her unfortunates proved quietly defiant.

title: Alaska Spill Jolts Chevron, Too
description: Public outrage over the 11 million gallons of crude oil that the Exxon Valdez spilled into Alaska's Prince William Sound in March has lashed the industry in many ways. But perhaps no company, Exxon included, has been jolted as badly as the Chevron Corporation.

title: Long-Distance Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Rule of Law?
description: The United States Government has just made amends, of a kind, for an act of lawless cruelty. It has agreed to pay $170,000 to the widow of William Albertson, a leading Communist Party figure who was a victim of J. Edgar Hoover's paranoid rage.

title: 42 Are Hurt in Melee In Pennsylvania Prison
description: At least 42 people were hurt today in a prison disturbance that was touched off by an inmate's assault on a prison employee, officials said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Asher/Gould Sees Suzuki Opportunities
description: ASHER/GOULD, a medium-size Los Angeles ad agency, has had a fair amount of experience with clients whose public image is less than stellar. Among its biggest accounts is the American Savings and Loan Association; until the completion of a Federal bailout plan at the end of last year, it was the nation's largest insolvent savings institution.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: FOR many adults, telling their parents that they are getting a divorce brings about feelings and concerns they may not have felt for years. Will their parents reject them? Can they still live up to their parents' expectations? They worry about how their parents will react and they vividly recall what happened during times of crisis when they were younger.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the race in the 10th Assembly District in New Jersey misidentified the town where John A. Peterson Jr. is mayor.

title: Talking Deals; Generosity Leads To a Bank Merger
description: WHEN the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico contemplated the takeover of the BanPonce Corporation earlier this year, it was confronted with the problem of how to reach a friendly agreement with a competitor that said it wanted to remain independent.

title: Scana Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Workshops on Making Holiday Decorations
description: A variety of workshops are being offered in November, some for the family and some looking ahead to the holidays. Here are a few:

title: Khmer Rouge Reported to Seize a District Capital
description: Western diplomats said today that the Khmer Rouge appeared to have taken a district capital in northwest Cambodia that the Phnom Penh Government had vowed to hold.

title: GM Acceptance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: General Motors Acceptance Corp. is a wholly owned subsidary of General Motors.

title: Profits Scoreboard
S.E.C. Acts To Smooth Trading
description: In an effort to smooth the big swings that have plagued the stock market because of computerized trading techniques, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday approved for trading a new financial instrument that would allow investors to buy and sell a ''basket'' of 500 stocks in a single order on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The California Quake; Aftershocks Damaging Frail Psyches
description: The aftershocks keep rumbling through the cities and mountains in the San Francisco Bay area, sparing roads and buildings but rattling spirits.

title: Libraries Can Counteract Adult Illiteracy, but They Need Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan to Ban Marshmallows
description: University of Michigan officials have announced plans to add marshmallows to the list of objects banned from Michigan Stadium during Wolverine football games. Now banned are umbrellas, coolers, chairbacks, backpacks and alcoholic beverages.

title: Merieux Bid Gains
description: Institut Merieux S.A. agreed to spend about $42.5 million to pay for biotechnology research in Canada, clearing an obstacle in its friendly bid of $942 million (Canadian) for the vaccine maker Connaught Biosciences Inc. The agreement was reached with Connaught's founder, the University of Toronto, which had been opposing the bid on the ground that a foreign takeover would mean a loss of research spending and jobs in Canada. Merieux said that if it won control of Connaught it would spend $12.75 million on vaccine and immunological research in Canada in the next 10 years, of which the University of Toronto would get $7.65 million. It also promised to spend up to $34 million to build a Toronto biotechnology research center employing 125 people.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to a possible cash distribution to shareholders of Property Capital Trust of Boston. The distribution was called off after the company did not receive what it considered an acceptable offer for the properties it planned to liquidate.

title: Japanese Retailer May Buy A Stake in Bloomingdale's
description: At least one large Japanese department store group has expressed interest in participating in a $1 billion global buyout of Bloomingdale's, the New York-based department store chain, people involved in planning the buyout said today.

title: Golf; Complaining All the Way To the Bank
description: The $5.5 million Nabisco Championship, which concludes the official money competitions on the PGA Tour, has such a big purse that it has drawn criticism from the golfers who have qualified for the tournament, although not one of the 30 competitors has turned his back on it.

title: Scramble Gives Oilers A Goal And a Tie
description: The Rangers, up a goal and down a man, had just survived Edmonton's attack with the extra player in the waning minutes of the third period. But the puck, sliding elusively in front of Bob Froese's goal, was still loose as the power play ended.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Martinair Holland, a commercial airline, to Kaufman & Maraffi for its North American advertising, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Knicks' Tucker Returns
description: Trent Tucker, who suffered a bruised back in the Knicks' exhibition game against the Detroit Pistons last Sunday and sat out the 104-99 loss to the San Antonio Spurs Tuesday night, returned to practice yesterday. Tucker, the Knicks' best 3-point shooter, is expected to play tonight against the Minnesota Timberwolves at the New Haven Coliseum.

title: LPL Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest 9 months' figures included a gain of $14,478,000, or $1.90 a share, from the sale of its Times Microwave Systems unit. Share earnings reflected a 3-for-2 stock split, which was effective in August 1989.

title: The California Quake; Hunt for Victims in Freeway Is Called Too Risky for Now
description: The Oakland police said today that it was too dangerous to continue the search for bodies amid the wreckage of the Nimitz Freeway until the shaky structure was demolished.

title: Qaddafi Says He Sponsored And Now Forsakes Terrorists
description: A Cairo weekly magazine reports that the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said he sponsored terrorists but stopped when he discovered that the terrorists were working for themselves and not for all Arabs.

title: Statement May Cast Doubt On Allegation Against Pierce
description: The Inspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has submitted a statement to lawyers for former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. that could cast doubt on a key accusation of favoritism leveled against Mr. Pierce.

title: Houghton Mifflin Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said 1988 results have been restated to reflect a change in method of accounting for book returns.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day on Friday for W. R. Grace & Company misstated its latest third-quarter net income. It was $97,891,000. The Profits Scoreboard chart with the listing also misstated the percentage increase in income from the same quarter last year, when the company earned $50,537,000. With the income rounded, the increase is 93.9 percent.

title: The Two Faces Of Saint Laurent
description: Yves Saint Laurent had a wonderful op portunity to tie up all the disparate threads of the spring and summer fashion openings today, and he muffed it. His was the last of 60 scheduled and innumerable unscheduled showings that have ranked high in theatrics and low in content over the past nine days.

title: Design As Usual From Italy
description: ALTHOUGH modern design has permeated Italian life for decades, it takes a display like the one at the Italian Trade Center (499 Park Avenue, at 59th Street) to really make the point.

title: Review/Opera; A Safe Bet and a Risk in Philadelphia
description: The Opera Company of Philadelphia, a troupe of modest means but lofty ambitions, has made its reputation over the last 14 years by balancing safe bets with calculated risks. It has presented works that have never been staged here, and a few that are rarely staged anywhere. And although its productions are hardly the gilded spectaculars one sees at the Met, the company has had seven of them telecast nationally.

title: Oryx Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment of $85,000,000. c-Net loss Year-ago 9 months included pretax provision of $395 million for writedown of assets and other matters.

title: Tecumseh Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1989 results included its French unit, L'Unite Hermetique, and its Italian unit, Tecnamotor S.P.A., on a fully consolidated basis as a result of the completion of the acquisition of those companies on Dec. 30, 1988 and July 25, 1989, respectively. First and second quarter results have been restated to reflect the consolidation of Tecnamotor as of the beginning of the year. Prior to this year, partial ownership in these companies had been accounted for on the equity basis.

title: Electronic Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
America West Air reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $2,080,000 and $6,802,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included extraordinary credits of $1,577,000 for the quarter and $5,021,000 for the 9 months. The company said the gains in the latest quarter and 9 months are from tax credits. The gains in the year- earlier quarter and 9 months are from the retirement of debentures.

title: Tyco Toys reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mays (J.W.) Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included net of $36,972, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $4,908,480 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary charge relating to utilization of a tax loss carryover of $670,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $4,465,000, or $2.04 a share, for the year, representing utilization of a tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,272,866 for the quarter and $3,135,279 for the year; the quarter also included an extraordinary charge relating to utilization of a tax loss carryover of $449,000. Revenue in the latest periods included gains on sale of fixed assets of $1,713,198 for the quarter and $21,739,991 for the year, compared with $492,284 for the year-ago quarter and year. Results have been restated to reflect discontinuance of retail operations.

title: Rebels Step Up Killings in Peru to Disrupt Election
description: A leftist rebel group is mounting the biggest terror campaign in its history in an effort to disrupt Peru's municipal and presidential elections.

title: Israeli Restraint Allows Uprising to Drag On; 'Tell Jacob's House'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Jazz; A Pianist Comes Into His Own
description: It is a common experience for those listening to jazz groups led by the saxophonist Lou Donaldson to become suddenly riveted by a pianist who emerges from the ensemble to turn it in volatile, joyful directions. The pianist is Herman Foster, who spends much of his time in groups led by Mr. Donaldson and others, and as accompanist to a variety of singers. Through Sunday, Foster fans can get a large serving of his work at the Fortune Garden Pavilion, 209 East 49th Street, where he is in the spotlight as leader of a duo with the bassist Harvie Swartz.

title: How to House the Mentally Ill
description: Here's a way for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, lately known for scandal, to gain some positive notice and give some real relief to the nation's cities: Create a new housing voucher for the homeless mentally ill.

title: HEALTH: Diagnostics; Test Unmasks a Parasitic Disease
description: By using a highly specific new test, a New York internist has found that many people believed to be suffering from irritable bowel syndrome actually have the common intestinal parasitic disease giardiasis.

title: Baines Gets New Pact
description: Harold Baines, a .288 career hitter for his 10 seasons, has agreed to a new contract with the Texas Rangers that extends through the 1992 season. The Rangers acquired Baines, a 30-year-old designated hitter, on July 29 in a five-player deal with the Chicago White Sox. He had been signed through 1990 with an option for 1991. In 146 games this season, Baines batted .309, with 16 home runs and 72 runs batted in. (AP)

title: Both Giuliani And Dinkins Claim to See Dual Standard
description: It began with Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican mayoral candidate, complaining that his Democratic opponent, David N. Dinkins, was getting off easy. Then, after a week of public grilling about his personal finances, Mr. Dinkins began asking why his opponent was not being subjected to the same scrutiny. ''All we want,'' said Bill Lynch, Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, ''is a level playing field.''

title: Analyzig Success Stories of Products
description: THE perfect screwdriver isn't everybody's Holy Grail. Not everybody puts the Dustbuster, the Taurus and the Walkman on a pedestal. And how many remember when ''Made in Japan'' was an esthetic epithet?

title: Union Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fly-Fishing Connoisseurs to Gather for Seminars
description: As the fly-fishing season for trout draws to a close for most Easterners - there is a small band of fanatics who will be dodging ice floes on the no-kill sections of the Beaverkill in the Catskills all winter - members of the Theodore Gordon Flyfishers of Manhattan have set up the first half of their annual arts of angling seminars.

title: Motorola Joins I.B.M. Effort On Semiconductor Research
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that the Motorola Corporation had become the first company to participate in its effort to develop a crucial new X-ray technology for the manufacture of semiconductors as part of its drive to maintain the nation's leadership in making the most advanced computer chips.

title: Bill Considered to Suspend Program Trades Sometimes
description: Representative Edward J. Markey, chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the financial markets, said today that he was considering legislation to give Federal regulators the power to suspend program trading in times of market stress.

title: Tyson Ill; Title Bout Off Till '90
description: The world heavyweight championship fight scheduled for Nov. 18 between Mike Tyson and Donovan (Razor) Ruddock has been postponed until at least early next year because Tyson has a condition similar to pneumonia, Garry Stevenson, the promoter, said tonight.

title: 'The Straw' by O'Neill Is to Open a Season
description: A production of ''The Straw'' by Eugene O'Neill is to open the season of the new Salamander Repertory Theater on Nov. 3 at the Walker Street Theater, Walker Street, south of Canal Street.

title: Yields Down For Week
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday, reflecting anticipation of lower interest rates and a ''flight to quality'' by stock market investors.

title: Soviet Miners Strike in Defiance of Ban
description: In a powerful challenge to the new Soviet ban on strikes in energy and other crucial industries, thousands of coal miners in the Arctic Circle walked off their jobs today, demanding political and economic changes.

title: John A. McLaughlin, A Microbiologist, 65
description: John A. McLaughlin, chairman emeritus of the biology department at Fordham University, died Tuesday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I., after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived in Oakdale, L.I.

title: Power Plays Work for Winnipeg
description: Three power-play goals, including Dave Ellett's tie-breaker in the third period, eased the Winnepeg Jets to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Neighbors With a History
description: Until 1917, Finland was an autonomous territory of czarist Russia, and it did not proclaim its independence until the Russian Revolution shook the lands under czarist rule.

title: Rio Journal; Cariocas Live for Carnival, but Live With Crime
description: One day, radios flash the latest Brazilian record: a $2.5 million ransom paid for a kidnapped Sao Paulo businessman.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Maxicare Accord
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said it had reached agreement with its court-appointed creditors' committees on terms of the company's restructuring in Federal Bankruptcy Court. The health maintenance organization company said creditors and shareholders would receive no less than $78.8 million in cash, 10-year 13.5 percent notes with a face value of $67 million, and common stock and warrants. The securities are expected to be tradable.

title: Armor All Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marion Harper Jr., 73, a Leader In the Advertising Industry, Dies
description: Marion Harper Jr., a leader in the advertising industry, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday, at his home in Oklahoma City. He was 73 years old.

title: Yugoslav Communists Back Multiparty Plan
description: The governing Communist Party has for the first time indicated that it may allow a multiparty democracy.

title: Acuson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brother International Corp., Somerville, N.J., an office products manufacturer, appointed Dean F. Shulman vice president for sales and marketing of its consumer products division.

title: Senators See Delay in Capital Gains Tax Cut
description: Senate Democrats who generally favor reducing capital gains taxes warned President Bush today that his only realistic hope of achieving a lower rate was to include it in a broader budget compromise, one that might have to wait until next year.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Irma A. Bloomingdale listed some of her survivors incorrectly. Joseph and Lewis Bloomingdale, both of Scarsdale, N.Y., are her sons, not her brothers. In addition to her daughters Laura Goeldlin and Beatrice Steinhaus, survivors include a third daughter, Elinor B. Preis of Rancho Bernardo, Calif.

title: Newell Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lawter International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Utility Gets Two Sweetened Offers
description: Two Connecticut utilities sweetened their offers yesterday for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire in filings with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manchester, N.H.

title: Mine Safety Appliances reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Moscow has no right to interfere in the affairs of its Eastern European neighbors, President Gorbachev said. He held up neutral Finland as a model of stability in stormy Europe. Page A1

title: Businessland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sara Lee Profit Increases 24.1%
description: The Sara Lee Corporation reported record first-quarter earnings today, showing a 24.1 percent increase over the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Credit to Erie Museum
description: To The Home Section:

title: Results Plus
description: SOCCER Sweden and Belgium in Finals: Sweden, Belgium and South Korea clinched spots yesterday in the 1990 World Cup finals, bringing to 11 the number of nations that have qualified for the 24-team tournament in Italy. Sweden and South Korea both scored 2-0 victories away from home. Belgium clinched a spot by struggling to a 1-1 tie at home against Luxembourg. A penalty kick by Peter Larsson in the 35th minute and a goal by Johnny Ekstrom in the 60th minute led Sweden to its victory at Poland, making the Swedes champions of Europe's qualifying Group 2 and shutting Poland out of the finals. England is the group's other qualifier.

title: When Sports Equipment Is Ailing
description: HIS tools: nylon thread, leather laces, cowhide, cotton and horsehair. His task: fixing the glove ''that makes the catch.''

title: Practice Puts Life Into Athletics
description: It was just batting practice, not much more, but the element of excitement seemed to make the Oakland Athletics' unexpected visit seem like more.

title: The California Quake; CONGRESS ADOPTS DISASTER AID BILL
description: After a day of frantic legislative activity, Congress approved and sent to President Bush a $4.15 billion disaster aid package to finance earthquake recovery efforts in Northern California and help the victims of Hurricane Hugo.

title: Boy Is Saved by Umbilical Blood of Sister
description: Medical researchers in France and the United States have replaced the blood-producing cells of a 5-year-old boy seriously ill with anemia by using frozen blood saved from the umbilical cord of his newborn sister.

title: The California Quake; From Homes to Hospitals, Dimension of Loss Emerges
description: As the dust continues to settle, public officials and the insurance industry are beginning to get a clearer picture of the vast toll of the earthquake that struck Northern California last week.

title: Review/Ballet; Fan Dances, Charlestons And Other Flapper Fare
description: Inviting a spiffily dressed audience to check its collective intellect in the cloak room, the Joffrey Ballet opened a new season on Tuesday night with a recycled piece of entertaining fluff.

title: Amid the Shouts, Dinkins Remains Calm
description: As two electric guitars and a clarinet struck up ''New York, New York,'' David N. Dinkins strolled into the rococo ballroom of Antun's restaurant in Queens Village the other night for a fund-raiser sponsored by the Queens Democratic organization. Representative Thomas J. Manton, the county leader, made the introduction.

title: Grace Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are on a pro forma basis. Grace Energy's initial public offering took place in August 1989, and all amounts have been adjusted to reflect the company's operations as if its offering had been completed on Jan. 1, 1988. The year-ago 9 months' net excludes income of $13,311,000 from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes. The share earnings were reflected following the completion of initial public offering.

title: Campaign Matters; Where's the Fat? Only the Auditor Knows for Sure
description: Ask Representative James J. Florio how he would get a handle on New Jersey's $12 billion budget as governor and he will say that the state needs to conduct a comprehensive audit of how it spends its money.

title: Del E. Webb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,858,000, or 63 cents, and $2,964,000, or 32 cents, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Jordan Vote Stirs Fervor Where Fiat Is the Rule
description: Six months ago, many of the young men of this town were throwing rocks at the police in what they called their version of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied lands across the Jordan River.

title: Joslyn Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Armco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $3,100,000, or 4 cents a share and $6,700,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and also included in the 9 months is a gain of $37,400,000 from an accounting adjustment. The company said the year-ago quarter income of $32,900,000 before the extraordinary credit included a charge of $5 million for litigation settlements, adjustments to reinsurance recoverables, asset valuation and runoff expenses of AFSG insurance companies that Armco intends to sell and that continue underwriting activities. The latest 9 months income of $149,500,000 before the extraordinary credit included a charge of $45 million in connection with runoff expenses of AFSG insurance companies that Armco intends to sell that continue underwriting activities. Year-ago 9 months included $20 million of related charges.

title: Norfolk Southern reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kansas City Southern Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $14.8 million, or $1.44 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Sysco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split on Oct. 17. Results included operations of foodservice businesses acquired from Staley Continental Inc., effective Aug. 1, 1988.

title: Turner to Make Films
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. says it has formed a unit to make movies and distribute them to theaters. Gerry Hogan, president of the new division, said this week that the new branch would be called Turner Pictures and would go into operation immediately. Its first two releases will be ''The Secret Life of Ian Fleming,'' a dramatization about the former British spy who wrote the James Bond novels, and ''Treasure Island,'' starring Charlton Heston.

title: Compaq Profits Up 50.4%
description: Continuing its dazzling performance in the personal computer industry, the Compaq Computer Corporation today posted a 50.4 percent increase in net income on a 36 percent rise in sales for the third quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 16 about the appearance of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato on WNBC-TV's ''News Forum'' program misidentified the author of a memorandum about his requests for Federal financing for housing rehabilitation in Puerto Rico.

title: Baby of Slain Mother Is Near Death
description: Doctors were struggling today to save a premature baby delivered by Caesarean section before the mother died of a gunshot wound. The father was also shot after the couple were abducted as they left a birthing class Monday night, and he was reported in critical condition.

title: Amdahl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split and the acquisition of Key Computer Laboratories Inc.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know the Frank Sinatra song, 'I Did It My Way'? Hungary and Poland are doing it their way.'' - Gennadi I. Gerasimov, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman. [ A1:3. ]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Coke Revives Popular Song and Slogan
description: COCA-COLA hopes that by early next year millions of Americans will be humming ''I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing'' -all over again.

title: Economic Scene; The Changes Forced by Deficits
description: THE White House and Congress still pay lip service to the importance of getting rid of the budget deficit. But virtually nobody believes that the Government will come close to balancing its budget in the foreseeable future. This means that with the budget deficit subtracting from the already low national savings rate, the United States has been compelled to sell assets to foreigners to maintain its existing level of consumption and investment.

title: RJR Nabisco Bonds Tumble on Asset Rumor
description: Prices of RJR Nabisco's ''junk bonds'' tumbled yesterday on unconfirmed rumors that a proposed deal by the company to sell its Del Monte division was in trouble. Bonds of distressed companies like Federated Stores and Southland also fell sharply, dealers said. Some Federated bonds were quoted as low as 12 cents on the dollar.

title: McDonnell Douglas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $6 million, net of income taxes, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 16 cents for the 9 months, in earnings from discontinued operations in the information systems; the 9 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $179,000,000, or $4.68 a share, from adoption of a new accounting standard for income taxes. c-Included losses from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, of $4 million and $15 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 1988 amounts have been restated for the adoption of FAS No. 94, consolidation of all majority-owned subsidiaries. Operating results of discontinued operations have been reclassified from amounts previously reported. The company said the principal factors accounting for lower earnings in the third quarter of 1989 compared with the third quarter of 1988 were higher interest expense, an operating loss in the transport aircraft segment, and decreased earnings from the combat aircraft and the missiles, space and electronic systems segments. Operating losses in the transport aircraft segment were $3 million on revenues of $1,283,000,000 in this year's third quarter compared with operating earnings of $15 million on revenues of $1,294,000,000 in 1988's third quarter. Results for the quarter included a pretax gain of $25 million, or 40 cents per share, after tax, from an insurance payment related to the loss of a leased aircraft.

title: Japan Internees Voted Funds
description: The House of Representatives voted today to begin making $1.2 billion in reparations next year to Japanese-Americans who were confined to internment camps during World War II.

title: Campbell Keeping Busy
description: John Campbell, the leading driver with a dozen victories, nine second-place finishes and more than $4.5 million in profits through the first five years of Breeders Crown events, will have a full card tonight at Pompano Harness Track in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ames Department Stores, Rocky Hill, Conn., reopened 254 former Zayre stores under the Ames name.

title: AIDS Led to Dismissal, Choreographer Says
description: Michael Shawn recently left the AIDS unit of Roosevelt Hospital, where he learned that along with everything else, he now had liver cancer. Still, this visit was easier than his last, 15 months ago. That time, he lost his dream job as choreographer for a Broadway show called ''Legs Diamond.''

title: Ubu Rep's New Play
description: ''Your Handsome Captain,'' a play by the Guadeloupian writer Simone Schwartz-Bart, will open at the Ubu Repertory Theater, 15 West 28th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. The play, a love story about a Haitian couple forced by economic necessity to live in different countries, will be performed in English. The free-jazz composer Henry Threadgill has written the score. Tickets are $15 and $12; information: 679-7562.

title: Dining Out Guide: Contemporary American
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. An American Place ** (April 14, 1989), 2 Park Avenue, entrance on 32d Street (684-2122) -The menu covers the American map at this restaurant where the chef stresses native-grown provender. The appetizer list has baked oysters and sea urchins in chive-butter sauce and grilled-vegetable terrine with baked goat cheese. Entrees include charred Black Angus steak (marinated in beer and fresh thyme) with carmelized onions and grilled breast of free-range chicken with whipped potatoes and wild mushrooms. At lunch, appetizers are $5.75 to $11, main courses $14.50 to $24; at dinner, appetizers are $6.50 to $12.50, main courses $22 to $29. Lunch: 11:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 10 P.M. Monday to Saturday. Arcadia ** (April 8, 1988), 21 East 62d Street (223-2900) - Inventive American menus are offered at Arcadia, where the cooking is consistently refined and alluring. Among recommended starters are grilled leeks in puff pastry and and corn cakes with creme fraiche and caviar. The fall menu includes entrees of roasted quail with molasses; chimney-smoked lobster and roast chicken with savoy cabbage and small kasha knishes. Papaya and peach-honey shortcake is one of the desserts. At lunch, appetizers are $7.50 to $14.50, main courses $16 to $24.50; dinner is prix fixe at $55. Lunch: noon to 2 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 10 P.M. Monday to Saturday. Gotham Bar and Grill *** (Sept. 29, 1989), 12 East 12th Street (620-4020) - Gotham Bar and Grill remains one of the most dynamic restaurants downtown. A high point among appetizers is the seafood salad. Entrees include roasted squab with vegetable ravioli and mustard-coated rack of lamb with garlic flan. There is warm chocolate cake with brandied cherry ice cream for dessert. At lunch, appetizers are $8.25 to $11, entrees $11.50 to $18; at dinner, appetizers are $8.25 to $14, entrees $25 to $29. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Thursday, to 11:15 P.M. Friday and Saturday; 5:30 to 9:45 P.M. Sunday. Jane's Bar and Grill ** (June 2, 1989), 208 East 60th Street (935-3481) - Jane's is an attractively designed dining spot with a succinct but varied menu. The chef offers light dishes using sauces based on vegetable purees and olive oil; typical of his style are the vegetable tart and lobster-filled cannelloni. Entrees include grilled steak with tomato chutney, roast squab with cepe-flavored risotto, and red snapper with artichokes and leeks in a tomato-infused oil. At lunch, appetizers are $6 to $9, entrees $12 to $15; at dinner, appetizers are $6 to $10.50, entrees $16 to $28. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 11 P.M. Monday to Saturday (supper menu Friday and Saturday, 11 to 11:45 P.M.), 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Sofi ** (May 22, 1987), 102 Fifth Avenue, near 15th Street (463-8888) - A deep, loftlike dining room with elegantly laid tables is the setting for Sofi's light cuisine, bolstered by aggressively seasoned stocks and vegetable purees. Starters include sauteed chanterelles with potato crisps and smoked quail salad. Among the entrees are pan-roasted salmon with a mustard-rhubarb crust and grilled, marinated chicken breast with pomegranate sauce and sweet potato gratin. At lunch, appetizers are $6.50 to $8.50, entrees $15 to $23; at dinner, appetizers are $6.50 to $9, entrees $17 to $27. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 11 P.M. Monday to Saturday.

No terms were disclosed, but some estimates say each player will receive $11 million.

title: Review/Art; New From David Reed, A Modern Traditionalist
description: David Reed's latest show at the Max Protetch Gallery includes seven works, all completed during the past year, that recapitulate what have been abiding themes with this painter. Mr. Reed prefers long, narrow canvases that look like unfurled scrolls. These are hung either lengthwise or vertically and they feature abstract images closely resembling enlarged photographs of swirling brushstrokes. The artist juxtaposes several such images in a single painting, making each canvas into a kind of montage of painterly occurrences.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blackhawks 5, Canadiens 3: Steve Thomas scored twice last night in Chicago as the Blackhawks defeated Montreal for the first time in 13 games, moving into first place in the Norris Division. The team last beat Montreal on Jan. 2, 1985, and was 0-7-5 since. Jacques Cloutier stopped 14 shots before Guy Carbonneau put in a 10-footer with 3:13 remaining in the middle period. But by then, Chicago had four goals, and held firm.(AP) Blues 4, North Stars 1: Paul MacLean had two goals in a home game as St. Louis managed to avoid collapsing in the third period. Minnesota fell out of its first-place tie with Chicago in the Norris Division. Brett Hull got his league-leading 10th goal of the season at 16:05 of the third period with a slap shot from the point. St. Louis had been outscored, 10-1, in the third period of its previous three games, losing the lead in two.(AP) Penguins 3, Red Wings 3: Phil Bourque's controversial power-play goal with one second remaining in regulation time lifted Pittsburgh to a tie in Detroit. With time expiring, Mario Lemieux backhanded a pass in front of the Detroit net, and Bourque jabbed a shot past the goaltender, Tim Cheveldae, from close range. The green light signifying the end of the period came on before the red goal light, but after a five-minute delay, Referee Dave Newell ruled that the puck had entered the net before time expired.(AP) Bruins 4, Nordiques 2: Bob Sweeney and Andy Brickley scored power-play goals in a game in Boston. In his National Hockey League debut, the Russian goalie Sergei Mylnikov had 31 saves for Quebec.(AP) RUGBY California Beats Dartmouth: California-Berkeley, a leader in intercollegiate rugby, defeated Dartmouth, 41-12, yesterday in Hanover, N.H., at the start of its first Eastern trip. BOXING Soviet Fighters Win: The first Soviet pros to fight outside their country both won their bouts Wednesday in London. Viktor Egorov, a middleweight, stopped Mastapha Cole of Cincinnati midway through the fifth round of their six-round bout. Andrei Oreshkin, a heavyweight, defeated Carl Gaffney of Britain in 71 seconds. (AP) TENNIS Lendl and Mecir Triumph: Ivan Lendl and Miloslav Mecir reached the quarterfinals of the European Community championship yesterday in Antwerp, Belgium. Lendl beat Andrei Chesnokov, 7-5, 0-6, 6-2. Mecir beat Aaron Krickstein, 5-7, 7-6, 6-0.(AP) BASEBALL Grand Slam in Japan: Tatsunori Hara's grand slam broke open a close game as the Yomiuri Giants beat the Kintetsu Buffaloes, 6-1, yesterday in Game 5 of the Japan Series.(AP) HORSE SHOW Victory for U.S.: Flawless riding led the United States equestrian team to victory at the Capital Center in Landover, Md., last night in the Bank of Montreal Nations' Cup at the 31st Washington International Horse Show. The four-rider squad had no faults in the two-round competition, easily outdistancing teams from Britain, the Netherlands and Canada. Jeff Welles of Newtown, Conn., Anne Kursinski of Flemington, N.J., and Beezie Patton of Hartland, Wis., turned in perfect rides in the first round. Joan Scharffenberger of Rolling Hills, Calif., scored four faults, a score that was dropped. Britain was second with 20 faults.

title: Review/Ballet; Joffrey Revival of the 1932 'Cotillon'
description: The Joffrey Ballet performance of ''Cotillon'' on Wednesday at City Center (131 West 55th Street) did not look much like period descriptions of this 1932 ballet by Balanchine. Long lost and remembered with great pleasure by those who saw the original, ''Cotillon'' was an instance of Balanchine's gift for using what he had, in this case the technique and poignant sophistication of Tamara Toumanova, who at 13 was one of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's ''baby ballerinas'' and for whom Balanchine created the role of the Young Girl. The ballet also caught the particular flavor of its time in its portrait of youthful gaiety haunted by an uncertain future.

title: U.S. Divided From Allies on Easing Export Bans
description: As a meeting of high-level trade officials ended today, the United States remained divided from most of its allies over proposals to relax controls on shipping machine tools and other high-technology goods to Eastern Europe.

title: Bush Administration Is Divided Over Move to Halt Global Warming
description: The Bush Administration is facing increasing pressure from other nations, Congress and environmental groups to take more aggressive action on the problem of global warming. But members of the Administration are divided on what course to follow.

These gains, net of income tax effects, increased share earnings by 17 cents in the latest quarter compared with 7 cents in the year-earlier quarter.
