title: 50 Waste Disposal Plans Help and Hinder Project
description: Federal efforts to assure safe disposal of hazardous waste over the next 20 years have yielded a hodgepodge of plans from the 50 states and the District of Columbia that have both reinforced regional cooperation and hardened barriers to it.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker; Getting to Know A Quirky Island Off Manhattan
description: ROOSEVELT ISLAND confounds almost every expectation of what life in New York is all about. A cross between a quiet, waterside village and a high-rise, 1960's version of Futureworld, this cigar-shaped island in the East River is perhaps the city's strangest piece of real estate. It has one street, one church, four restaurants, a handful of shops, lots of open space, magnificent vistas of Manhattan, two chronic-care hospitals, a small lighthouse and eerie, fenced-off ruins dating from the island's Dickensian days as a dumping ground for criminals, the insane, incurable patients and others deemed social misfits.

title: Ford Motor Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fort Wayne National reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Kinder Essington, Mel Foster and Roy Field have been named senior vice presidents of J. Walter Thompson/Detroit.

title: Regulatory Victory for A.T.&T
description: In a big victory for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that the company could continue to offer customized networks for large business customers.

title: Connecticut Offers Mortgage Bonds
description: The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority is offering $132.8 million in housing mortgage finance program bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Review/Art; Ashley Bickerton's Pleas to Rescue a Threatened Earth
description: Ashley Bickerton's ''Landscapes and Seascapes'' may be this season's conversation piece at the Sonnabend Gallery. With its leathery and black futuristic surfaces and its catalogue of ecological problems, the show is like a heavy-metal band asking its audience to join hands and pray for the whales. Or like Darth Vader visiting the Great Barrier Reef and returning as an ecological missionary. Or like ''Alien'' as a morality tale about saving the stars.

title: Allied Bankshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stocks Fall As Dow Drops 39.55
description: Stocks finished broadly lower yesterday on moderate volume as the market continued a week of turbulent activity.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The passage of severe anti-abortion laws in the Pennsylvania Legislature may well have looked to President Bush like a single point of light on a darkening horizon.

title: British Cabinet in a Flurry; Treasurer and Rival Both Out
description: One of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's longest-serving ministers, Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson, angrily resigned tonight in a dispute over who was in charge of British economic policy - the Chancellor or Mrs. Thatcher's economic adviser at 10 Downing Street.

title: An Avenging Convoy Stalks Contractors
description: After massing its forces like a small army going into battle, the New York City Transportation Department made a dramatic foray yesterday morning against construction contractors who were blocking the streets and sidewalks of mid-Manhattan with their building materials and delivery vehicles.

title: Disputed Antibiotic Recalled
description: Because of new evidence of irregularities in testing, a major manufacturer of generic drugs has agreed to recall completely an antibiotic that it had previously withdrawn from the market only partly, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: It's Comedy! From Skit To Song To Satire
description: ''IT is the duty of the humor of any given nation in time of high crisis to attack the catastrophe that faces it in such a manner as to cause the people to laugh at it in such a way that they cannot die before they are killed.''

title: Otter Tail Power reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $9,146,000 for the quarter and income of $77,457,000, or 59 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $736,000 for the quarter and income of $28,903,000, or 21 cents a share, for the 9 months. The latest periods' income from continuing operations included realized investment gains of $9,681,000 for the quarter and $19,827,000 for the 9 months, compared with realized investment gains of $11,070,000 and $23,883,000 for year-ago periods, respectively.

title: No to 2 Royals' Options
description: The Kansas City Royals announced yesterday that they would not pick up the options for next year on the contracts of Willie Wilson, their longtime center fielder, and the pitcher Floyd Bannister. General Manager John Schuerholz, however, said he was interested in negotiating new contracts for both players. Bannister and Wilson could declare themselves free agents at the end of the World Series.

title: Fannie Mae Prices Real Estate Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $500 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Fred E. Katzner, Executive, 88
description: Fred E. Katzner, a former president of the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home in Forest Hills. He was 88 years old. Mr. Katzner was president of the Comfy Manufacturing Company, which made slipcovers, until he retired in 1965. He was also a former chairman of the Jewish center's executive board.

title: Law firm, in pursuit of Haitian property, finds the chase can be tedious and frustrating.
description: International law can be full of glamour, panache, money and, particularly when human rights are involved, satisfaction. But it can have its frustrations, too. Consider the recent experience of New York's Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

title: Exxon Will Move Its Headquarters To Texas
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would move its corporate headquarters and 300 employees from the Exxon Building in Manhattan to a 132-acre office park near Dallas.

title: U.S. Checking Reports of Pressure at H.U.D.
description: Federal prosecutors and Congressional staff members are investigating assertions that two former regional administrators in the New York office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development pressured housing workers to approve projects with ties to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Tagliabue Is Elected N.F.L. Commissioner
description: Under the glare of camera lights, after a marathon of public and private meetings, of civil discussion and heated debate, Paul Tagliabue wiped sweat from his brow and pledged to be a leader for all. The promise came after Tagliabue, a Washington-based lawyer, was elected today as the National Football League's seventh commissioner.

title: KEY RATES
Eagle Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Medicare and Social Security Aren't Welfare; Benefits Will Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Champion Parts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $510,000, or 14 cents a share from a cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income and the 9 months included an extraordinary gain of $99,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said the extraordinary gain of $99,000 is the result of the repurchase of $4.5 million of debentures at a discount from face value.

title: MTM Enterprises
description: Arthur L. Price, the president and chief executive of MTM Enterprises Inc., the Hollywood production company, resigned today, 15 months after MTM was acquired for $320 million by Television South P.L.C., a British broadcasting and entertainment company. MTM, which Mr. Price co-founded with Mary Tyler Moore and Grant Tinker in 1969, has been one of the most successful independent television production houses in Hollywood. The company was responsible for ''Hill Street Blues,'' ''St. Elsewhere'' and a number of other series.

title: Review/Music; Shostakovich and Dvorak By Philharmonia Virtuosi
description: Richard Kapp's 15-year-old Philharmonia Virtuosi chamber orchestra is one of those curious New York institutions that reminds one what a mixture of big-town and small-town our metropolis really is.

title: Union Texas Petroleum HoldFings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $58.6 million gain from an insurance settlement.

title: First Interstate Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $29.9 million, or 64 cents a share, from the utilization of tax loss carryforwards, and a gain of $16,105,000, or 35 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change to mark- to-market accounting for swap transactions. c-After a charge from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $23.4 million. d-Net loss The company said its loss for the third quarter was attributable to a $350 million loan loss provision recorded by its First Interstate Bank of Arizonia, primarily related to its real estate construction and commmercial mortgage portfolio.

title: Homestake Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,021,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $17,275,000, or 18 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,564,000 for the quarter and $2,255,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months was also after a gain of $3,125,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Constitution Bancorp of New England reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cardinal Distribution reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $4,745,000, or 68 cents a share, from discontinued operations which reflects sale of and net earnings from Cardinal's discontinued wholesale food operations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Colleagues Remember Founder of Interpublic
description: Colleagues of Marion Harper Jr. remembered the advertising executive yesterday as a larger-than-life figure, whose blueprint for a diverse marketing-communications firm presaged industry giants like Saatchi & Saatchi and the WPP Group.

title: Leggett & Platt reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Diner's Journal
description: Le Pistou

title: Roosevelt Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
25 Bulgarian Ecologists Detained
description: The Bulgarian police detained at least 25 environmentalists today, beating and kicking them as they campaigned against a hydroelectric project, Westerners in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, said.

title: Taiwan Flight Crashes; 54 Deaths Are Feared
description: A China Airlines Boeing 737 crashed into a mountain today minutes after takeoff from the eastern city of Hualien, and airline officials said all 54 people on board were feared dead.

title: Airborne Freight Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net gain of $1,013,000, or 14 cents a share, from aircraft sales.

title: 10 Get Awards for Writers
description: Ten writers, including established novelists, a playwright and authors who have not yet written a book, have each been named recipients of $25,000 Whiting Writers' Awards. The awards program, now in its fifth year, is the largest privately financed program offering individual support exclusively for writers.

title: Interest Reported In Hershey Oil
description: The Transamerica Corporation said undisclosed third parties had got in touch with it about purchasing its 26.4 percent stake in the Hershey Oil Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Transamerica said it had held preliminary discussions with one group and might hold further talks.

title: Producers and Warner File Court Papers
description: Lawyers for Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the production team the Sony Corporation wants to hire to run its newly acquired Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., argued in papers filed in Los Angeles Superior Court yesterday that both their contractual agreement with Warner Communications Inc. and verbal commitments from its top management permit the pair to join Columbia Pictures.

title: DPL Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Citizens Savings (Ithaca) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FirstFed Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Avnet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
What the New West Germans Can Expect
description: To the Editor:

title: FLS Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are not available; the company's common stock is all privately held. Florida Steel Corp. became a unit of FLS Holdings in 1988. In connection with the acquisition, a new basis of accounting was adopted Sept. 1, 1988. Year-ago results reflected a combination of results before that date, on the previous accounting method, and after that date, according to the new method.

title: Savings and Loan Executives Accused of Tapping Phones
description: State and Federal regulators today accused senior officials of a California savings and loan of using wiretaps, political pressure and inducements to regulators to avoid any action against the institution.

title: Reviews/Film; Good Woolens vs. Motorcycle Garb
description: ''It used to be that adoption was about a child needing a home,'' one character in ''Immediate Family'' says. ''Now it's about a couple needing a child.''

title: Bach and Berio
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to perform Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 3 and the Cantata No. 169, as well as Luciano Berio's ''Chemins IV'' for oboe and strings and Aaron Copland's Nonet, at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8. The program will be repeated tomorrow at 2 P.M. and on Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets: $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Gorbachev Plans to Destroy His A-Armed Subs in Baltic
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced plans today to destroy four Soviet nuclear-missile submarines based in the Baltic Sea, as a step toward ridding the region of nuclear weapons.

title: British Airman, Child Die in West Germany
description: Two gunmen killed a British serviceman and his year-old child near a Royal Air Force base today, officials reported.

title: SOVIET URGES END OF MILITARY PACTS
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze struck a familiar refrain of Soviet European policy today by calling for a phasing out of Eastern and Western military alliances. He spoke as the foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact began a two-day meeting here.

title: John Hancock Investors Tr reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Assets represented net assets.

title: Terex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest periods included for the first time the Fruehauf truck-trailer business, acquired by Terex earlier this year.

title: William F. Poten, 79, A Retired Ship Broker
description: William F. Poten, a retired ship broker in Manhattan who specialized in chartering oil tankers, died Tuesday at his home in St. Simons Island, Ga., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Retail Shift In U.S. Seen
description: The chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., told a retailing meeting yesterday that half of the existing retailers in the United States ''won't be in business 10 years from now.''

title: Number of Untaxed Companies Is Said to Decline
description: Many large and profitable companies that once managed to pay little or no Federal income tax have been pushed back onto the tax rolls by the 1986 overhaul of the tax code, Citizens for Tax Justice said today, citing its own survey.

title: Sweden's Social Democrats Veer Toward Free Market and Lower Taxes
description: The governing Social Democrats, who have made Sweden a generous welfare state and the world's most highly taxed nation, have reached a crossroads and are taking a distinct turn toward the free market.

title: Benj. Franklin Fedl Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $4,540,000 for the quarter and $8,722,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $1,204,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,208,000, or 42 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Charles Pedersen, 85, Nobel Winner in Chemistry
description: Charles J. Pedersen, who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1987 for wide-ranging research that included the creation of artificial molecules that can mimic vital chemical reactions of the processes of life, died yesterday at his home in Salem, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Castle (A.M.) Co.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1989.

title: Conferees Near Accord On '90 Arms Programs
description: A Congressional conference has narrowed differences between Senate and House versions of the 1990 military programs bill, including the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.

title: Braniff Adviser
description: Braniff Inc. the financially troubled airline, said it had hired Merrill Lynch to explore the possible sale of the airline. In late September, Braniff filed for protecion from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. It was the airline's second such filing in seven years.

title: Singapore's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Donnelley (R.R.) & Sons (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest period' nets included a gain of $3.4 million, or 4 cents a share, primarily from the sale of certain land. The year-ago periods' nets included a one-time benefit of $5.6 million, or 7 cents a share, from the purchase of certain tax benefits under the Alaskan Native Claim Settlement Act.

title: Ryland Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jets Will Send Walker Deep, But Can O'Brien Reach Him?
description: There are games during a season when one team seems so superior that a minor miracle, and a healthy quarterback, are needed by the underdog.

title: Erie Journal; A Mayor For Whom The Office Equals Life
description: A City Hall parking space with a sign saying ''Erie's first six-term Mayor'' has been empty for more than six months, and secretaries are packing up political souvenirs in the Mayor's pink office, a few blocks from Lake Erie here in the northwest corner of the state.

title: First Federal Savings (CharFlotte) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Empire of America Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included charges of $83,710,000 for the third quarter and a $71,261,000 charge for the 9 months, reflecting the planned sale of corporate real estate and the portfolios of fixed-rate mortgage-backed securities and bonds.

title: Aquino Reaffirms Her Pledge to Not Run for a Second Term
description: With her approval rating slipping in the opinion polls and criticism of her administration rising, President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines is saying more unequivocally than ever that she will keep her pledge not to run again in 1992.

title: Canada Packers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: He Walks the Line

title: Control Data Set To Sell Division
description: The Control Data Corporation has agreed to sell its 1,000-employee United States computer maintenance business to the Bell Atlantic Corporation of Philadelphia for an undisclosed price. The business involves maintenance services for computers not made by Control Data, which is retaining service operations for its own products.

title: Seles Qualifies
description: Monica Seles, the 15-year-old Yugoslav who went from No. 86 to No. 7 in the world ranking in 1988-89, has qualified for the $1 million Virginia Slims championships Nov. 13-19 at Madison Square Garden. She brings to nine the number who have qualified for the 16-player field. (AP)

title: Review/Art; Subtleties of Yoruba Art Over the Centuries in Africa
description: ''Yoruba: Nine Centuries of Af-rican Art and Thought,'' the latest exhibition at the Center for African Art, is a show that proves that less can be more. Using only about 100 objects, the exhibition takes the viewer on an extended journey through the various kingdoms and city-states that have waxed and waned in West Africa since the end of the first millennium.

title: Quantum Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included for the 9 months income from discontinued operations of $133,300,000, or $5.36 a share, from the discontinued oleochemicals operations. Both periods were adversely affected by an estimated $22 million for costs associated with the fires at the Morris, Ill. chemical complex in June and September, and a charge of $19.7 million, or 79 cents per share (including $8.5 million, or 34 cents a share, of non-recurring debt issuance expense) attributable to the company's share of the loss incurred by QFB partners in connection with the newly-formed petrolane propane joint venture. c-Included income from discontinued operations from the discontinued oleochemicals operations of $5,100,000, or 20 cents a share, and $16,700,000, or 62 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net income

title: Economic Growth in 3d Quarter Maintained Pace of Early 1989
description: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, Commerce Department reported today.

title: Daily Flights to Be Offered at Stewart Airport
description: In a deal that State Economic Development Commissioner Vincent Tese said was worked out with ''smoke and mirrors and no money,'' American Airlines reversed its position and announced today it would begin daily passenger service from Stewart International Airport to connecting hubs at Chicago and Raleigh/Durham, N.C.

title: Giants to Start Tough Part Of Schedule
description: In the first seven weeks of the National Football League season, the Giants have rolled up a 6-1 record and lead their division.

title: Correction
description: The caption of a picture by The Associated Press in SportsMonday this week about preparations for the World Series misidentified a San Francisco Giants pitcher. He was Jeff Brantley, not Don Robinson.

title: On Stage
description: Feiffer in the Spring?

title: Bell Savings Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago results included a one- time pre-tax profit of $940,000 from sale of the company's investment in the stock of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: Avon Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3.3 million for the quarter and $25.6 million for the 9 months, and included extraordinary losses of $425 million for the quarter and $520 million for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $20 million, or 31 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: China Announces Nixon Visit
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry announced today that former President Richard M. Nixon would arrive this weekend as a guest of the Government. The Chinese have regarded Mr. Nixon as a friend since he reopened relations by visiting as President in 1972.

title: First Executive Stake Is Increased
description: An investment group that includes the Bass family of Fort Worth has raised its stake in the First Executive Corporation to 8.8 percent from 6.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it might seek talks with the Los Angeles life insurance company's management and big shareholders.

title: Curtiss-Wright Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $4,256,000, or 85 cents a share and $5,103,000, or $1.02 a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $1,021,000, or 21 cents a share for the quarter and $1,460,000, or 29 cents a share for the 9 months. The company said extraordinary credits reflect utilization of capital loss carryforwards generated in late 1985. The company also said it realized an after-tax gain of about $10,200,000, or $2.04 a share, in the third quarter from the sale of 1,013,500 common shares of International Minerals & Chemical Corp. back to the company. This gain included extraordinary credits of $3,470,000, or 70 cents a share. The 1988 third quarter earnings included a gain of $1,973,000, or 39 cents a share, from two separate real estate transactions.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Paul John Tagliabue; Family Man, Sports Fan, N.F.L. Chief
description: As someone who grew up rooting for the Brooklyn Dodgers and dreaming of playing for the Boston Celtics, Paul J. Tagliabue would not, at first glance, appear to be a natural choice to become commissioner of the National Football League.

title: Bill to Allow Death Penalty For Terrorists Passes Senate
description: The Senate today approved capital punishment for the murder of Americans overseas by terrorists, brushing aside a move to change the maximum penalty under the bill to life in prison.

title: Howell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $3,792,000, or 79 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $7,279,000 for the quarter and $8,407,000 for the 9 months.

title: Rexene Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After deducting pretax non-recurring charges of $3 million associated with the issuance of the increasing rate notes in July; $4.2 million of previously unamortized financing fees and related expenses on bank debt; severance costs related to the recent organizational consolidations of $1.5 million; and a pre-tax non-cash charge for compensation expense of $3.3 million relating to the vesting of certain employee stock options. Nine- months also included a charge of $67,267,000 from settlement of lawsuit and charge of $9,192,000 from redemption of notes. c-Net income

title: Boston Edison Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $5.5 million, or 14 cents a share, from an eminent domain taking of certain company property.

title: Tultex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Premark International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from the cumulative effect of change in method of accounting of $15,900,000 which reflects the inclusion of a $15.0 million, or 44 cents a share, tax benefit due to the sale of the Dartco facility. Latest quarter comprises 13 weeks; 9-month period, 39 weeks.

title: Conservatism: The Agony of Victory
description: LEAD: The conservative cause to which I've devoted the last 25 years of my life is said to be cracking up, burning out or, at the very least, running out of steam. And it's conservatives who are saying so. But I wouldn't bet the family farm on the demise of conservatism.

title: Lockheed Division To Reduce Jobs
description: The Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, will cut several hundred jobs in the next two months as part of the company''s cost control program, a spokesman said.

title: Crown Central Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Business Digest
description: Economy

title: Herman Roth
description: Herman Roth, a retired district manager for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the father of Philip Roth, the novelist, died of a brain tumor on Wednesday at St. Elizabeth Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Elizabeth.

title: A TOP EAST GERMAN MEETS 2 LEADERS OF THE OPPOSITION
description: In a another first in East Germany's three-week experiment with tolerance and openness, a member of the ruling East German Politburo met today with leaders of New Forum, a month-old opposition movement that the Government originally branded as hostile to the state.

title: CALIFORNIA CHIDES BUSH ON PESTICIDES
description: California environmentalists today voiced strong opposition to President Bush's proposals to increase Federal control over pesticide use, contending that they would threaten the health of consumers while pre-empting stricter state guidelines.

title: Trading Begins in Stock 'Baskets'
description: Trading in stock ''baskets'' began yesterday in New York and Chicago, marred by a computer problem in New York that led to two basket trades being canceled. The new product, approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, allows investors to buy or sell all the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in one trade.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, the telecommunications company, named C. Hyde Tucker president and chief executive of Bell Atlantic International.

title: Vista Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from an extraordinary item of $2,748,000 and $2,380,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The extraordinary loss of the quarter was a charge to relocate research and development operations. c-Included a loss from an extraordinary item of $7,831,000 and $9,337,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The quarter charge included a $2.6 million, or 15 cents a share gain, and a $10.5 million, or 63 cents a share, charge. The 9-month charge included a $1.5 million, or 8 cents a share, gain and a $10.8 million, or 62 cents a share, charge.

title: Portland General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said lower earnings resulted primarily from increased power and maintenance costs associated with outages at the Trojan Nuclear plant, operated by its principal subsidiary, Portland General Electric Co.

title: 36 Arrested During Protest Over Squatters
description: At least 36 people were arrested yesterday and early this morning during protests over the eviction of about 20 squatters from an abandoned school building in the East Village, the police said. Four police officers and three protesters suffered minor injuries, officials said.

title: Profits Fall, Revenues Up at UAL
description: The UAL Corporation said yesterday that its revenues in the third quarter rose 7.1 percent from the corresponding period last year, but earnings fell 72.4 percent. Even excluding a large one-time gain last year, profits dropped 38 percent.

title: Dissidents Trying To Control Rally's
description: A group of dissident directors led by Burt Sugarman, the Hollywood producer, filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to acquire more than 50 percent of the outstanding shares of Rally Inc., a Louisville, Ky., restaurant chain that went public last month.

title: Anchor Savings Bank FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary income of $2.6 million representing the tax effect from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results reflected the operations of Richmond Hill Savings Bank, which was merged with and into North Side on Oct. 31, 1988.

title: Heritage Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Brunswick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $79.2 million for the writeoff of certain assets for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also included charges of $6.1 milllion, after taxes, for costs associated with production cut-back and reductions in for in the company's marine segment. c-Net income and the 9 months included an after-tax gain of $10.6 million from the sale of filtration technology business and the writeoff of certain assets.

title: UAL Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $393,006,000 on the sale of Covia partnership interest for both periods, and the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $548,935,000, or $17.09 a share.

title: Celebrity Opinions Always Have an Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $801,000, or 10 cents a share, from early retirement of debentures. c-Net income and the 9 months was after an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $251,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Monarch Machine Tool Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Indecent Broadcasts Lead to F.C.C. Fines On 4 Radio Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission fined four radio stations today, saying they had broadcast indecent material in the daytime.

title: Presidential Airways In Bankruptcy Filing
description: Presidential Airways Inc. filed today for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Utilicorp United reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago per-share figures are adjusted to reflect a stock split.

title: National Sanitary Supply reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $830,000, or 14 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment due to the cumulative effect of two accounting changes.

title: Rivals in Nassau Offer Differing Visions of County
description: As Richard Korn travels through Nassau County, campaigning for its highest office, he says he sees a place where people who came to pursue the American dream are being driven out by rising taxes.

title: TV Weekend; 'Show Boat' Skirts Nuances To Concentrate on the Fun
description: Looking for a great old Broadway musical, the kind whose songs keep you humming for days? Tonight at 9, make yourself comfortable and settle in for the three-hour ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13. It's ''Show Boat,'' with music by Jerome Kern and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who also adapted the book from a novel by Edna Ferber.

title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing
description: Federal drug agents arrested 119 people today and raided retail stores in 46 states that sell specialized horticultural equipment that investigators say is used for growing marijuana indoors.

title: 3 to Sing
description: Peter Stampfel, Jimmy Dale Gilmore and David Halley, three singers and songwriters, are to perform tonight at 10 at Gonzalez y Gonzalez, 625 Broadway, at Houston Street (473-8787). There is no cover charge but there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Pan Am Is Adding New Miami Flights
description: Pan American World Airways plans to add to its winter schedule more than 60 flights a week from Miami.

title: Flaw in Chip Made by Intel Is Discovered
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that design flaws had been discovered in its top-of-the-line microprocessor chip but that the errors would be corrected quickly and would not hurt its ability to ship ''tens of thousands'' of the chip before the end of the year.

title: U.N. Refugee Chief Quits Over His Use of Funds
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has resigned in a scandal over allegations that he misused agency money to pay for entertainment and first-class air travel for himself and his wife, officials said today.

title: Security Pacific In Deal for La Jolla
description: The Security Pacific Corporation signed a letter of intent to acquire the La Jolla Bancorp in a deal worth about $111 million. Security Pacific said it would pay $15 in Security Pacific stock for each share of La Jolla, whose stock jumped $3 a share, to $13, on the American Stock Exchange. Its 30 percent gain was the best of the day.

title: Richard K. Parsell, 89, Ex-Patent Attorney
description: Richard Kendrick Parsell, a retired patent attorney, died Oct. 14 at Church Homes, a retirement community in Hartford. He was 89 years old and until two years ago, lived in Manhasset, L.I., and in Center Harbor, N.H.

title: Imperial Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $11,013,000, or 77 cents a share, for the quarter and $13,812,000, or 96 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income and after extraordinary gains of $1,199,000, or 8 cents a share, and $2,854,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Some year-ago results restated to reflect a change in lease accounting. Total net earnings for 1988. The extraordinary gains represented the repurchase of subordinated debt issues.

title: Hammond Takes a Two-Shot Lead
description: The race for the biggest purse in golf began today at the Harbour Town Golf Links and the hottest golfer on the PGA Tour, Donnie Hammond, shot a six-under-par 65. This gave the 32-year-old Hammond a two-shot lead over Greg Norman and Mark O'Meara.

title: Citytrust Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Citytrust said it recorded certain non-recurring expenses of $2.1 million related to staff reductions in the latest quarter, offset by the realization of a $2.3 million one-time gain.

title: Tandem Computers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1989 results included the financial results of Ungermann-Bass Inc. The 1988 figures included Ungermann-Bass Inc., from March 18, 1988, the date of acquisition.

title: Interlake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time pre-tax expenses of $20.3 million related to a financial restructuring. c-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will show the world that we have a can-do spirit in San Francisco that is alive and well. Our ability to successfully put on this World Series will show the rest of the country that San Francisco is back.'' - Mayor Art Agnos. [ A1:4. ]

title: Church & Dwight reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Imperial Chemical Industries Plc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary items. Results for all periods have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.63 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Sept. 30, 1989. Four I.C.I. one-pound ordinary shares are represented by each American Depositary Receipt (ADR).

title: Bigger Shortfall Now Faced By Cuomo for Next Budget
description: New York State will enter the next fiscal year with a budget shortfall that could be twice what the Cuomo administration had originally forecast, adminstration officials say.

title: Governor Joins Dinkins Attack Against Rival
description: New York State's leading Democrats shifted the focus of the mayor's race to ideology yesterday, with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo accusing Rudolph W. Giuliani of producing ''a whole lot of smoke'' to obscure Republican positions on urban issues.

title: Restaurants
description: Sparks Steakhouse

title: 2d Sailor on Carrier Convicted of Espionage
description: For the second time in five weeks, a sailor stationed aboard the aircraft carrier Midway has been convicted of espionage.

title: President's Gains Tax Maneuver
description: In an effort to regain momentum in its battle to cut capital gains taxes, the Bush Administration today announced extraordinary Government borrowing measures to insure that next month's Social Security checks would not be delayed by the political fight.

title: Delta Air Pact In Singapore
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. announced a linkup with Singapore Airlines in a deal worth $360 million in which the companies would buy a stake in each other and develop joint marketing programs.

title: At the Movies
description: Filming 'The Bear'

title: 2 Officers Wounded In Newark Shooting During Drug Check
description: Two Essex County police officers were shot and seriously wounded while checking a car during a drug stakeout in Newark's Central Ward last night, the police said.

title: Rulings on Job Bias: Chilling Effect on Lawsuits
description: When the Supreme Court issued a series of rulings last June cutting back the scope of Federal laws restricting employment discrimination, civil rights lawyers feared - and many employers hoped - that the balance in civil rights lawsuits had tilted dramatically in favor of defendants.

title: N.A.M., in Shift, Picks Economist as President
description: Jerry J. Jasinowski became president of the National Association of Manufacturers this week, setting a sort of precedent. Normally the association recruits an executive of a manufacturing company to be president. Mr. Jasinowski is the first economist named to the group's top job, and he has never even worked in the private sector, except for odd jobs while in college.

title: MARTIAL LAW'S END IS SEEN IN CHINA
description: China's top leaders decided in principle last week to revoke martial law, which now applies to most of Beijing, but the exact date has not been set, according to a Communist Party official.

title: Baseball Makes a Donation
description: With officials of four affected communities at his side, Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, announced today that major league baseball would contribute a minimum of $1.4 million to the Northern California Earthquake Relief Fund.

title: Japan's Output Declines
description: Japan's industrial production in September fell 2 percent from the previous month, but growth should resume in October, the Government said today. September's fall was the first since July, and despite the drop production was still 3.9 percent higher than a year earlier. The ministry also said September sales at Japan's leading department stores and supermarkets grew 9.4 percent from a year earlier.

title: Drug Result May Idle Valenzuela At Breeders'
description: Pat Valenzuela, who won this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness aboard Sunday Silence, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by the Santa Anita Park stewards for testing positive for cocaine use.

title: Pierce Again to Refuse to Testify; He Asks Delay in Hearing Today
description: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. informed a House subcommittee today that he would once again cite his Fifth Amendment right to silence by refusing to testify Friday about allegations of political favoritism and mismanagement in Federal housing programs.

title: Novel Wins Awards
description: ''The Remains of the Day'' by Kazuo Ishiguro won the Booker Prize yesterday for the best novel published in Britain this year. The alternately humorous and sad novel, which concerns an English butler who ponders his life during a vacation to the country in 1956, was published in the United States this month by Alfred A. Knopf ($18.95). Mr. Ishiguro, the author of two previous novels, was born in Japan and moved to England with his parents in 1960 when he was 5 years old.

title: Experts Advise Ending Age Limit for the Pill
description: Experts advising the Food and Drug Administration recommended today that it no longer put an upper age limit on the use of birth control pills by healthy women who do not smoke.

title: Tenace Named a Coach
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have signed Gene Tenace as batting coach, the job held until last May 15 by Cito Gaston, who then replaced Jimy Williams as the Blue Jays' manager.

title: For Want of a Trestle . . .
description: Here's how to reduce New York City's traffic congestion and air pollution dramatically, and save many millions yearly: Build a railroad trestle in the Bronx. When will the State Legislature understand the importance of this plan?

title: INSIDE
description: Giuliani and Dinkins: Differ Little on the Issues All the heat in the New York City mayoral race has been over personal matters. On the issues, the candidates offer similar solutions to the problems facing the city. Page B1. Baltic Arms Cut Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said his country would scrap four nuclear-missile submarines based in the Baltic Sea. Page A10. N.F.L. Picks Commissioner Seven months after Pete Rozelle announced his resignation, Paul J. Tagliabue, a league counsel for 20 years, was chosen to succeed him. Page B15.

title: Southdown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,698,000, or 22 cents a share, and $10,027,000, or 60 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,242,000, or 39 cents a share, and $10, 930,000, or 82 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 9 months also included an accounting adjustment of $19,600,000, or $1.47 a share, resulting from SFAS No. 96, adopted Jan. 1, 1988. Results for periods of 1988 also included $2.9 million in the quarter and $4.1 million in the 9 months, respectively, from settlement of natural-gas contract disputes.

title: Goodbye Rubles, Hello Baubles: Russians Rush to Get Rid of Cash
description: The people standing three deep in line today in front of the jewelry store on the Arbat pedestrian mall did not need the official announcement on Wednesday that the exchange rate for the ruble would be slashed to know the waning value of their currency.

title: Review/Theater; Bad Sister vs. Good Sister In Hare's 'Secret Rapture'
description: In the one moving scene in David Hare's new play, ''The Secret Rapture'' - the last - the audience is suddenly overwhelmed by pity for a young woman it has hated all night long. The woman is Marion French, a Tory junior cabinet minister whose faith in dog-eat-dog capitalism is so unshakable and whose contempt for her adversaries is so patronizing that she makes Margaret Thatcher seem like Mary Poppins. But Marion has been shaken now. The home of her recently deceased father, a provincial bookseller, is being dismantled. Someone she loves has been murdered in a crime of passion. And so Frances Conroy, the actress who plays Marion in a progression of starchy yuppie business suits, cracks apart, her once stony face streaked by tears.

title: Meridian National reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: EAB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Works and Process
description: The French choreographer Maguy Marin and her company are to perform excerpts from her new work ''Hey, What's All This to Me?'' tonight and tomorrow as part of the Works and Process series at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street. The work includes popular songs inspired by political and social crises from the French Revolution to the Spanish Civil War. A discussion with Miss Marin will be part of the evening. The program begins at 8 P.M.; tickets are $10, or $9 for students. Information: 360-3503.

title: Former Helmsley Employee Admits Guilt in State Tax Case
description: Harry and Leona Helmsley's former business manager pleaded guilty yesterday to state tax-fraud charges after incriminating the Helmsleys in the state's case against them.

title: And What Did The Cat Know?
description: After any earthquake the San Francisco Zoo routinely checks to see if any of its 1,000 or so animals acted strangely before the shock.

title: Sterling Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The losses in the latest periods included a non-recurring provision of $3.2 million for taxes.

title: Tribe Rejects Sale of Right To Spearfish in Wisconsin
description: Members of the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa tribe have rejected an offer of $35.6 million to give up their right to spearfishing on Wisconsin's 250 lakes.

title: Canada Would Extradite Suspect
description: The Canadian Government said today that it had ordered the extradition of Charles Ng, a 28-year-old former United States marine who could be sentenced to death in California if he is convicted in one of the state's worst mass-murder cases.

title: Leo Stillman, 85, Dies; An Art Deco Architect
description: Leo Stillman, a retired architect who was noted for his Art Deco designs in the 1930's and for later innovations in the use of poured concrete in apartment house construction, died of a stroke on Oct. 18 at the Ocala (Fla.) Geriatric Center. He was 85 years old.

title: Ex-New York Senator Guilty of Tax Evasion
description: Former State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn of Newburgh was found guilty today of tax evasion, obstruction of justice and lying on a bank loan application.

title: Fairfield County Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest quarter earnings were negatively affected by it increased loan loss provision, as well as by a loss of $183,436 related to the sale of a real estate joint venture project and a $106,000 writedown of the value of other real estate owned through foreclosure.

title: Ruddick Corp. reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
General Motors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected effects of accounting change effective Jan. 1, 1988, that increased earnings by $218.1 million, or 35 cents per G.M. common share.

title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters
description: An office building above a hamburger franchise is a far cry from the stately courtrooms of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. But this is the immediate reality for the court, improvising like dozens of other institutions since last week's earthquake.

title: Helix Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Medicare and Social Security Aren't Welfare; Share the Load
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Lemmon As a Codger In 'Dad'
description: Any movie titled ''Dad,'' with Jack Lemmon playing a lovable old codger of 78, would seem to be something to be avoided by everyone except charter members of the Jack Lemmon Fan Clubs of America. It sounds pretty sticky.

title: A Meteor in Thatcher's Political Constellation
description: The spectacular leap of John Major to the top ranks of British Government might be thought of by some as belying the adage that nice guys finish last.

title: How to Be Crazy in New York
description: New York Jews who vote against David Dinkins just because they do not like Jesse Jackson are doing a disservice not only to the candidate but to the city, Jews, blacks, Israel - yes, and maybe to Jesse Jackson, too.

title: Despite Good Intentions, Political Ads on TV Still Accentuate the Negative
description: Time again for hand-wringing over negative political advertising on television. In the New York City mayoral contest, ads for Rudolph W. Giuliani charge David N. Dinkins with a habit of not coming clean on his financial delinquencies until caught. Just as Mr. Giuliani begins to accentuate the positive, the Dinkins camp takes to charging him with flip-flopping on issues.

title: Top CRS Sirrine Officer Adds Post of Chairman
description: LEAD: CRS Sirrine Inc. an engineering services company in Houston, said yesterday that its president and chief executive of seven years, Bruce W. Wilkinson, had been named chairman of the company as well.

title: After a Record 11-Day Delay, World Series Ready to Resume
description: Lest anyone forget, Dennis Eckersley pitched the ball, Matt Williams hit it, Tony Phillips fielded it and Mark McGwire caught it for the last out of the second game of the World Series.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BIG APPLE CIRCUS TIME

title: Zero Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split last month.

title: Some Haunting Places
description: The annual Greenwich Village Halloween Parade takes place on Tuesday, beginning at 7 P.M. on West Street; the parade heads east on Houston Street, north on Avenue of the Americas to 14th Street, and east on 14th Street to Union Square. Here is a sampling of Halloween events this weekend. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Today HALLOWEEN CRUISE, aboard the Andrew Fletcher, leaving from the South Street Seaport Museum, Pier 16 and the East River. Music, costume contest. Today, 6:30 P.M. Admission, $20. Information: 669-9405. HALLOWEEN IN RICHMONDTOWN, Richmondtown Restoration, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I. Parade, costume contest. Today, 4 to 5 P.M. Admission, $2 ($4.50 for children). Reservations: (718) 351-1617. Tomorrow ''HALLOWEEN HAPPENINGS,'' South Street Seaport Museum, 165 John Street. Activities for children, including mask making, poetry writing and hat designing. Tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M. Information: 669-9489. PUMPKIN SAIL, Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, Pier 45, Christopher and West Streets. Music, storytelling, environmental displays. Tomorrow, noon to 5 P.M. Information: 691-6265. HALLOWEEN FAIR,Little Red School House, 196 Bleecker Street. Games, prizes, food. Tomorrow, 2 to 6 P.M. Admission, $1; part of the proceeds benefit Unicef. Information: 477-5316. HARVEST FESTIVAL, East 11th Street between Second and Third Avenues; sponsored by the Family Resource Center. Music, rides, food. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date, Sunday. Information: 677-6602. PUMPKIN-CARVING CONTEST, Union Square Greenmarket, Union Square and 16th Street; sponsored by the Council on the Environment of New York City. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Entrants should bring their own carving tools. Information: 533-0669. HALLOWEEN PARTY, Jack and Jill School, St. George's Church, 209 East 16th Street. Games, entertainment. Tomorrow, 1:30 to 3:30 P.M. Admission, $3. Information: 475-0855. ''HALLOWEEN HAPPENING''CONCERT, Avery Fisher Hall; sponsored by the Little Orchestra Society. Program: Stravinsky's ''Firebird Suite''; the march from Prokofiev's ''Love for Three Oranges''; Halloween section of ''Holiday Music'' by Morton Gould, and the ''Creaky Door Overture'' by Stefan Kozinski. Tomorrow, at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Tickets, $25 to $12. Information: 874-6770.. HALLOWEEN FIESTA, McBurney Y.M.C.A., 215 West 23d Street: sponsored by the Mexican Center of New York. Performance by the Ballet Folklorico Mexicano of New York; costume contest. Tomorrow, 8 P.M. Admission, $10. Information: 989-6545. HALLOWEEN WALK, through the Ramble in Central Park, beginning at Belvedere Castle, 81st Street in mid-park. Tomorrow, 3 P.M. Information: 772-0210. HALLOWEEN FUNHOUSE, Brownstone School, 128 West 80th Street. Face painting, trick-or-treat preparations. Tomorrow, noon to 4 P.M. Admission, $2.50 for children; adults, free. Information: 874-1375. MASQUERADE PARTY, Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, W. T. Davis Center, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Pumpkin painting, leaf rubbing, film. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to noon for those ages 3 to 5; 2 to 4 P.M. for those 6 to 10 years old. Admission, $7 for children (one adult accompanying a 3-to-5-year-old, free.) Registration required: (718) 727-1135. Sunday FALL FEST, Brooklyn Friends School, Pearl Street between Adams and Jay Streets in the downtown section of Brooklyn. Sunday, noon to 4. Pumpkin painting, mask making, food. Information: (718) 852-1029. FALL HARVEST,Open Eye, 270 West 89th Street. Apple bobbing, costume making, pumpkin painting, games, storytelling. Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission, $5. Information: 769-4142. CARNIVAL AND HAUNTED HOUSE, Cathedral of the Incarnation, 50 Cathedral Avenue, Garden City, L.I. Sunday, 1 to 4 P.M. Admission, $2. Information: (516) 746-2955. HALLOWEEN FESTIVAL, Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, L.I. Magic shows, face painting, rides, food. Sunday, 1 to 4 P.M. Admission, $3. Information: (516) 922-9200.

title: Fight to Survive
description: Rod Douglas spent his 25th birthday in intensive care in a London hospital yesterday after surgery to remove a blood clot close to his brain, one day after he lost a British middleweight title fight to Herol Graham of Britain. (AP)

title: Ford Motor Co. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Hydraulic Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10:30 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M., 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
