title: Imasco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Milton Roy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Michigan Bill on Consent for Abortion Gains
description: The Michigan Senate has approved a bill that would require girls 17 or younger to obtain a parent's consent for an abortion.

title: Galoob (Lewis) Toys (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Agrees to Notify Congress on Covert Actions
description: President Bush has agreed to give Congress notice within days of nearly all covert operations, but has insisted on retaining the right to withhold such information in rare instances, Administration officials and legislators said tonight.

title: Adobe Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $569,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $390,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $121,000, or 1 cent a share, and $4,685,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter net was reduced by an $11,114,000 writeoff of international exploration costs and a $2,421,000 loss on disposition of unprofitable gas gathering and processing facilities. The extraordinary charge in the latest quarter is from reversal of tax-loss carryforwards; extraordinary items in the year-ago quarter and in the 9 months in both years are gains from tax-loss carryforwards. There were no share earnings in the year-ago periods because preferred dividends affected them.

title: New York Post to End Its Sunday Paper
description: After eight months of steady losses, The New York Post plans to stop publishing on Sundays, the newspaper's publisher and owner, Peter S. Kalikow, announced yesterday. The last Sunday issue will appear on Nov. 26.

title: Take Me Out to the Ball Game
description: Barring, the gods willing, anything unforseen, other than your conventional and not so treacherous, in retrospect, pelting rainstorm, Game 3 of the longest, shakiest, most harrowing and most memorable World Series in history will be played tonight in Candlestick Park in San Francisco. It is 10 days and some 27 minutes after they had tried to play it the first time.

title: Chrysler Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Chrysler Financial is a wholly owned subsidiary of Chrysler Corp.

title: Colombia Police Bus Bombed
description: A bomb today destroyed a bus filled with police officers in Medellin, killing at least 4 policemen and injuring 40, a radio station reported. The station, RCN, said without identifying the source of its report that 66 pounds of dynamite exploded beneath the bus in Belo Horizonte, a suburb of Medellin, the base for the most powerful drug cartel in Colombia.

title: Harris Bankcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: West Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect accounting changes. Nine-month year-ago results included a 6-cents-a-share charge for retirement program.

title: Weldwood of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said lower sales reflected the merger of the distribution businesses of Weldwood and Canfor Corp. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pierce Balks Again in H.U.D. Inquiry
description: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. invoked the Fifth Amendment again today in refusing to answer lawmakers' questions about political favoritism in Federal housing programs, prompting new calls for appointment of a special prosecutor.

title: Jones Intercable reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a charge of about $2 million on the redemption of $35 million of debentures.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Inv reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leiner (P.) Nutritional Prodcts Corp.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Texas Utilities Co. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
For Ortega, a Pose With Bush
description: The heads of state of the Western Hemisphere had gathered to talk about the large issues: democracy and the environment and the North-South axis. But in the end, the main focus of attention was a small, symbolic event: Would the American President and the Nicaraguan President meet and shake hands? Would they smile at each other, or slug each other?

title: Kansas Power & Light Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Compucom Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patents; New Method Of Finding Tumors
description: Capitalizing on the ''leakiness'' of dead cancer cells, two doctors at the University of Southern California Medical Center have patented a new technique for detecting and possibly treating tumors.

title: KEY RATES
Culbro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income spun off from discontinued operations of $1,039,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,750,000, or 87 cents a share, for the 9 months. First Financial Caribbean Corp., the company's consumer finance business, was spun off in a tax free distribution to Culbro shareholders on Dec. 16, 1988. The 1988 results have been restated to include this business as a distributed operation. The company said the latest quarter's income from continuing operations included nonrecurring shutdown and restructuring reserves totaling about $4 million, reflecting managment's recent decisions to realign several operations. The year-ago period's results reflected the effect of a temporary labor interruption and the loss of business from a major customer at the company's plastics business and start-up expenses of the labeling systems unit.

title: St. Luke's Orchestra
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's will play American works at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 6 to open its fifth season at Carnegie Hall and to celebrate American Music Week. On the program will be John Adams's ''Fearful Symmetries,'' conducted by the composer; Charles Wuorinen's ''Five: Concerto for Amplified Cello and Orchestra,'' which Mr. Wuorinen will conduct with Fred Sherry as the soloist; Copland's ''Music for the Theater,'' and Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' with Jeffrey Kahane the pianist. Tickets, at $35 to $10, are available at the box office or by calling Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Now What's All This Fuss About Fast Food?
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Nets 108, Bucks 100: Dennis Hopson had 19 points and seven other Nets reached double figures last night in an exhibition game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Sam Bowie had 8 blocked shots, 11 points and 5 rebounds for the Nets. Randy Breuer led Milwaukee with 22 points.

title: Vacu-Dry Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $21,000, or 1 cent a share, and $18,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest and year-ago quarter, respectively.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday about the Women in Comedy festival of the Manhattan Punch Line Theater misidentified the performer in the foreground. She was Patricia Scanlon, not Nancy Mura.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1989
description: Markets

title: Officer Kills Brooklyn Man After He Attacks With Knife
description: A police officer shot and killed a Brooklyn man last night after the man charged at officers with a butcher knife at his grocery, the police said.

title: Mortgage Rate Declines
description: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 9.82 percent in the week ended today, from 9.92 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said.

title: DINKINS IS SEEKING TO WIDEN APPEAL
description: In an effort to assure voters that his administration will be broad-based, David N. Dinkins has told associates that he will appoint Victor L. Kovner, a longtime ally and a politically active Manhattan lawyer, as his corporation counsel if he is elected mayor of New York City.

title: U.S. Won't Challenge Los Angeles Hiring Plan
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has decided that it will not challenge the efforts of Los Angeles to help coordinate the hiring of day laborers, at least for now.

title: E. C. Fraze, 76; Devised Pull Tab
description: Ermal Cleon Fraze, an engineer who invented the pull-tab opener that is used on aluminum beer and soda cans, died of a brain tumor Thursday at Kettering Memorial Hospital in Dayton, Ohio. He was 76 years old and lived in Dayton.

title: China Loosens Free-Enterprise Rules
description: In an unexpected departure from their harsh line against private enterprises, the authorities announced new regulations today that would encourage unemployed people to establish private and collective enterprises in the capital.

title: Red Lion Inns L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said that of the $1.4 million increase in net income, $400,000 can be attributed to the absence of accrued incentive management fees which reached their contractual maximum accrual in 1988.

title: COSTA RICA GAINS LOAN AGREEMENT
description: After years of negotiations, Costa Rica and its commercial bankers agreed yesterday on a proposal to reduce the country's foreign debt substantially and provide new incentives for bankers to take part.

title: Ciba-Corning Deal
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. said it had agreed to buy Corning Inc.'s share of the Ciba-Corning Diagnostics Corporation, a joint venture in which each company had owned half. Terms were not disclosed. Ciba-Corning, based in Medfield, Mass., provides diagnostic systems and related products. It has 2,500 employees and had 1988 sales of about $300 million.

title: Geriatric & Medical Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $3.3 million, or 34 cents a share, from utilization of a net operating loss carryforward. c-Net loss The company said its earnings or income before item of $4,735,000, or 50 cents a share, included $10,118,000 of after-tax income, principally from the sale of two long-term care facilities, and a charge of about $400,000 for the estimated recovery of certain pre- opening costs.

title: A Midwestern Radio Host Wears Keillor's Shoes
description: Given 20 words to describe how he spent his summer vacation, the eager caller from Minneapolis began, ''I went to Thailand, China, Japan, Russia, Poland, East Germany . . .''

title: Jerusalem, Despite Strife, Works as a City
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch's New Admirer: Giuliani on the Stump
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican mayoral candidate, spent the summer vilifying Mayor Edward I. Koch, saying that he had responded to corruption in his administration with ''his eyes closed, his ears clogged and his mouth open.''

title: CB Pak Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $52,910,000, or $2.56 a share, for the quarter and $81,121,000, or $3.92 a share, for the 9 months. The company said the gain in the third quarter consisted of $48.8 million from the sale of Twinpak Inc. and $4.1 million from other favorable adjustments. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Iran Ends Flooding of Iraqi Truce Line
description: The Iranian Army has stopped flooding a section of its cease-fire line with Iraq on the eve of a new mediation effort by the United Nations and the Red Cross, diplomatic officials said today.

title: School for Patronage
description: ''I'm a political leader - that's why I'm here. . . . I make sure my people [ get jobs ] .''

title: National Presto Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Mate at Helm of Grounded Ship Is Arrested
description: A freighter that ran aground on a protected coral reef has been refloated and the Coast Guard has filed charges against the vessel's captain and mate.

title: Agra Industries reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $63,118,000, or $4.33 a share, for the latest year and $1,651,000, or 12 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. The company said the extraordinary credits were largely from a gain on sale of Cybermedix subsidiary. The latest loss before extraordinary items of $6,318,000 included $7,183,000 pre-tax writedown of investment in California recycling operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Farr Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Gypsum Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter included a gain of $10.6 million from the repurchase of debentures, while the year- ago period included a $76.9 million provision for loss on the sale of American Olean Tile Co. In addition to the latest quarter's $10.6 million gain, the latest 9 months included a gain of $782,000 from the repurchase of debentures. The year- ago 9 months included, in addition, to the third quarter's $76.9 million charge, gains of $38.8 million from the sale of Lafarge Coppee common stock and $5.1 million from the repurchase of debentures.

title: First Mississippi reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quixote Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Charter Proposal for New York: Little Debate Despite the Stakes
description: With Election Day little more than a week away, the proposed new charter for New York City, which would represent the most significant overhaul of municipal government in nearly a century, has failed to generate a broad public debate.

title: Ionics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Free Soviet Press Depends on Attitude, Not Law
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGN STOP: Harlem; Dinkins Bid Rekindles Community Hope
description: Harlem has been both dream and nightmare.

title: INSIDE
description: Pierce Refuses to Testify

title: Anadarko Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $2.2 million after-tax interest expense for redeeming notes. c-Included $9.1 million non-recurring after-tax gain. d-Included after-tax gains totaling $12.9 million in the quarter and $8.6 million in the 9 months for settlement of a lawsuit and termination of a discounted sales arrangement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about the rescue of a 6-year-old boy, Julio Berumen, after the California earthquake misstated the circumstances of his removal from a car. Rescuers were impeded by the body of a family friend, later identified as Yolanda Orozco, not by the body of the boy's mother, Petra Berumen.

title: Your Money; Making Best Use Of Benefit Plans
description: Most companies offer employees choices within their benefit plans, and give them an opportunity at this time of year to revise their choices for the coming year. By reviewing their needs and options, employees can significantly increase their financial security.

title: A Case of Cultural Misperception
description: Whenever Kazuo Ishiguro goes on the road to promote his books, he has to spend much of his time explaining himself.

title: Jackson's Half Brother Is Indicted In Hiring of Killers and Skimming
description: A Federal grand jury today charged Noah Robinson, half brother of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, with skimming receipts from Wendy's restaurants he owns and hiring a street gang to kill a man who uncovered the scheme.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $282,000, or 1 cent a share, and $16,254,000, or 51 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $289,000 and $22,687,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $3,353,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: National Healthcorp L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: 3 GUILTY IN CASE TIED TO COLOMBIAN
description: A Federal jury here has convicted three men and acquitted two others of charges that they conspired with Carlos Lehder Rivas, one of the world's leading drug traffickers, to smuggle cocaine into the United States and distribute it.

title: Aetna Life & Casualty reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included realized capital gains of $48 million, or 43 cents a share, of which $27 million resulted from the sale of Federated Investors Inc., and included $15 million from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards for the quarter, and the 9 months included realized capital gains of $81.1 million, or 72 cents a share, and third quarter tax credits. c-Included realized capital gains of $45 million, or 40 cents a share, and $32.4 million, or 29 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said 1988 results were restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Johanna Roth Is Wed To George Comstock
description: Johanna Deborah Roth, a third-year student at the New York Law School, and George Foster Comstock, a civil engineer in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Larchmont, N.Y., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Roth. Rabbi Robert Rothman officiated.

title: Energen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $60,000 and $474,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on disposal of $2,061,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After income from discontinued operations $50,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $34,000 for the year.

title: Personal Income Up 0.3% in Month
description: Americans' personal income, dealt a blow by Hurricane Hugo, rose a lackluster three-tenths of 1 percent in September as consumer spending posted its weakest advance in a year.

title: Mayoral Candidates Walk Away From Koch's Idea for a Tax Rise
description: In the New York City mayoral primaries, the incumbent, Edward I. Koch, was alone among the six candidates in endorsing a tax increase - a proposal to pay for more police officers.

title: Student Is Slain On Packed IRT After Argument
description: A 19-year-old student at Julia Richman High School in Manhattan was shot and killed by another student on a subway train yesterday afternoon after an argument that started in the school cafeteria, the police said.

title: Canron Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $543,000 and $908,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary charge of $2,395,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,730,000 for the quarter and $2,232,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sun Energy Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $199,000,000 loss from changing the accounting method used to capitalize interest costs. c-Net loss

title: Dinkins and Bradley Fill Air, Not Baskets
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani occasionally needles David N. Dinkins about spending too much time on the tennis court, but it became clear yesterday that Mr. Dinkins should stay on clay and off the hardwood.

title: John D. Brundage, 70; Led Heart Association
description: John Denton Brundage, a retired insurance executive and former chairman of the American Heart Association, died of liver failure yesterday at his home in Winnetka, Ill. He was 70 years old.

title: So Cool, So Tense, So What?
description: What I like about David Dinkins is his refusal to let tax laws get him down. I envy that. I've often thought I could get my chin up off the floor and feel good again about being alive if I weren't so dumb about taxes.

title: The Big Oil Spill From Home Mechanics
description: Only the biggest oil spills get much attention, but the smallest ones add up. The amount of oil dumped by do-it-yourself auto mechanics every two and a half weeks is roughly equivalent to the amount spilled by the Exxon Valdez, experts say.

title: Russ Togs Stake
description: A Hong Kong investment concern controlled by the New Zealand financier Sir Ronald Brierley has acquired an 8.06 percent stake in Russ Togs Inc. and says it is seeking clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to acquire up to 25 percent of the New York apparel manufacturer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd. said its 591,700 Russ Togs shares had been purchased for investment purposes only for an average price of $11.69 each. Shares of Russ Togs rose 37.5 cents today, to $12.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the company a market value of $91.75 million. =

title: Loyola Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge
description: Few bridge players ever achieve a 75% score in a duplicate game and fewer still ever celebrate a 65th wedding anniversary. The parlay, both events on one day, is almost certainly singular. It occurred October 11 at the Riverdale Yacht Club, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, and the record-setter was Reginald Johnson, 89 years old.

title: Hills Urges Japanese To Act to Lift Imports
description: Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, called on Japan today to take a series of sweeping domestic actions, including the slapping down of companies that fix prices and the restructuring of retail distribution, to avoid new trade sanctions from Washington.

title: Fansteel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Progressive Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months included a net realized gain on security sales of $5.7 million and $11.2 million, respectively, compared to $300,000 and $1.7 million for the comparable year-ago periods, respectively.

title: WAR-POWERS CURB ON KREMLIN SEEN
description: A top adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet President could not order military intervention in another country unless he first consulted closely with the new Soviet Parliament.

title: 800 Numbers Off Map For Foreign Customers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lumex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bill Prices Fall on Debt-Ceiling Fears
description: Treasury bill prices plunged and discount rates soared yesterday as the annual Congressional wrangle over raising the debt ceiling unsettled the government securities market.

title: Crane Gets 8.9% Of Milton Roy
description: The Crane Company, a New York-based engineering products concern, has acquired an 8.9 percent stake in the Milton Roy Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Crane said it had acquired the shares to obtain ''a significant equity interest'' in Milton Roy, and left open the possiblility of seeking control of the gas-monitoring equipment concern based in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy
description: Even in the glow of Indian summer, Luella Wilson rarely goes outdoors anymore. She does not like to sit in the warm sunshine on her front porch because she fears that the neighbors will look at a tiny 91-year-old woman and see a criminal.

title: Tambrands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest-quarter results included a one-time charge of $5 million related to the sale of its Spanish joint venture.

title: La Quinta Motor Inns Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patents; A New Seat to Improve A Baby's Comfort
description: Arguing that ordinary infant seats are uncomfortable and sometimes unhealthy, two pediatricians have patented a new seat that replicates the position some parents call the ''football hold.''

title: Buckeye Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $819,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $983,000, or 37 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after extraordinary credits of $201,000, or 8 cents a share, and $967,000, or 37 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said in the year-ago 9 months, the extraordinary items included a gain of $1,663,000 from a tax benefit and a charge of $696,000 related to early retirement of Federal Home Loan Bank advances. The company also said the latest quarter and 9 months net figures included a gain of $586,000 from settlement of its defined benefit pension obligation and a charge of $650,000 to reduce the carrying value of a corporate debt security.

title: Case Against LaRouche Groups Is Dismissed
description: A Federal judge has dismissed bankruptcy proceedings that the Government brought against three organizations associated with Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. Judge Martin V. B. Bostetter Jr. of the Federal Bankruptcy Court ruled that the Government had acted in bad faith in filing the involuntary bankruptcy petitions against Caucus Distributors Inc., Campaigner Publications Inc. and Fusion Energy Foundation Inc.

title: Review/Recital; The Issue Of Crescendo For a Pianist
description: Peter Orth, who played Hoiby, Chopin, Brahms and Ravel on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, is a pianist capable of communicating real musical ideas. This puts him ahead of most young instrumentalists, even if some aspects of his musical and technical approach are not fully persuasive.

title: Goody Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Included non-recurring gain on the August 1988 sale of the assets of the company's Southeastern Box Co. subsidiary of $904,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: Police Seal Building After a Protest by Squatters
description: After a night of violent clashes between squatters and the police, city workers began sealing the windows and doors of an East Village school building yesterday morning where about 20 homeless people had been living.

title: Peace Corps Triumphs
description: Peace Corps, the queen of harness racing, and John Campbell, the king of Breeders Crown drivers, shined in the rain tonight at Pompano Park. The pair, who teamed to win the Breeders Crown 2-year-old Filly Trot last year, scored an impressive victory in the 3-year-old Filly Trot.

title: When Relatives Take Children In
description: Three years ago New York City set up a sensible-sounding program called ''kinship foster care,'' in which relatives received foster care stipends for taking in children in danger of abuse or neglect by their parents. Now city officials wonder if they have created a monster. The well-intentioned program needs careful reassessment.

title: NOW Goes to Court to Deter Blocking of Abortion Clinics
description: The National Organization for Women went to court today in an attempt to stop the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue from blocking abortion clinics.

title: Foremost Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $666,000. The company said year-ago 9 months net from continuing operations included a gain of $5,360,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago quarter results included a charge of $15 million related to its discontinued private credit insurance program.

title: Witness List Includes Gators
description: Five current or former University of Florida athletes, including the basketball team's center, Dwayne Schintzius, are among the possible witnesses in the upcoming trial of 11 men facing drug charges, a newspaper reported today.

title: New Tactic For Giuliani: Praise Koch As a Leader
description: As Election Day draws closer, Rudolph W. Giuliani is turning kinder toward the man he once vilified and wants to succeed, Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Praxis Biologics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Third-quarter revenue increase, which was almost all generated by the company's Hibtiter pediatric vaccine, was offset by continued investment in research, costs associated with producing and selling Hibtiter and expenses of about $900,000 related to the proposed merger with American Cyanamid Co.

title: Review/Dance; Affectionate Tributes From a Ballet Collector
description: Robert Joffrey was frequently described as a collector of ballets, intent on putting together a repertory for his company that included as many genres and contemporary classics as possible. The Joffrey Ballet's program on Thursday evening at City Center suggested that Gerald Arpino, the company's artisic director since Mr. Joffrey's death last year, is a spirited fan at heart. The three ballets representing Mr. Arpino, co-founder of the Joffrey and its longtime resident choreographer, were all affectionate tributes - one to a great ballerina, another to an admired performance and the third to American vaudeville.

title: President Vetoes Second Measure To Relax U.S. Limts on Abortion
description: President Bush vetoed a budget measure for the District of Columbia today because it would expand the District's use of Federal and local funds to pay for abortions.

title: Wyse Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Burritt Interfinancial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Martin Lawrence Ltd. Editions Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metropolitan Fedl S & L reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Is It Oslo, Oschlo, Ozlo, Osslo
description: LEAD: A man holds up a bank, but before making his getaway, he apologizes to the teller and hands over a box of chocolate to assuage her stress. A waiter inordinately delays taking orders because, he complains to one customer, he's been on his feet the better part of an hour. The Government wants to crack down on drunk driving, but considers shortening the hours of rapid transit service.

title: Northwest Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflected preferred and preference stock requirements.

title: Eva Crossman-Hecht; Ballet Pianist Was 59
description: Eva Crossman-Hecht, a pianist with the Frankfurt Ballet and a composer of music for several ballets, died on Oct. 16 in Frankfurt after a long illness. She was 59 years old.

title: Patents; Device Distinguishes 'Killer' Bee From Others
description: Engineers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee obtained a patent this week on a device that distinguishes African ''killer'' bees from ordinary European bees by measuring the buzzing of their wings.

title: Masco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for both 1988 and 1989 have been restated due to pooling of interests with Universal Furniture Ltd., acquired in May 1989.

title: Dofasco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $46,300,000. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Michael Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Unisys Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Result for latest quarter and 9 months included the effect of previously announced restructuring actions, an unusual tax impact and other charges. The company said that as a result of the previously announced restructuring, about $230 million reflects costs related to a planned work force reduction of about 8,000 people and consolidation of manufacturing capacity and facilities; about $150 million principally reflected costs accrued for the defense business to cover estimated losses on certain fixed price contracts and certain contingent litigation liabilities.

title: Budget Deficit Drops Slightly
description: The Federal budget deficit declined slightly, to $152.1 billion, in the fiscal year 1989, mostly because the Government spent only half as much as expected in August and September on the savings and loan bailouts, the Government announced today.

title: Macy (R.H.) & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $7,885,000 and a gain of $17,243,000, or $10.34 a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-After an extraordinary charge of $53,994,000. The loss in the year-ago fourth quarter reflected expenses incurred by an unsuccessful bid for Federated Department Stores Inc., as well as the restructuring of some of its department store operations.

title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case
description: A couple in the town of Washington will be allowed to keep their farm despite their admission that marijuana was grown there.

title: USLico Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Television; Soviet Afghan Reporting
description: Sunday's edition of ''60 Minutes,'' on CBS at 7 P.M., or whenever the Jets game ends, is smack on the news. As Soviet officials have, startlingly, begun apologizing for their invasion of Afghanistan, Harry Reasoner introduces us to Artyom Borovik, the first Soviet reporter to send home candid dispatches about some of the 120,000 Soviet troops who fought there. Up to then, the Soviet people had been told virtually nothing about a war in which 15,000 of their own men and a million Afghans had died.

title: Unless Liberalization Takes Hold in East, Bonn Fears a Swelling Tide of Emigres
description: As change sweeps across Eastern Europe into East Germany, officials in West Germany are growing anxious about the possible consequences. Their preoccupation is not reunification, which might be possible if the transformation in the East succeeds, but a flood of emigres if the changes fail.

title: Review/Jazz; A Salute to Mel Lewis
description: The American Jazz Orchestra's tribute to its regular drummer, the band leader Mel Lewis, at Cooper Union on Thursday night opened and closed with deserved standing ovations. Mr. Lewis, who has been sick recently and looked a bit thinner, played his typically generous and large-hearted way, using his immense drum sound, loose yet controlled, to help swing the 17-piece band. And while the three-hour concert could have been shortened a bit, the music, with few exceptions, had a real ebullience.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a friend, I tell you that Americans are not as patient as the Japanese. We don't want a Japanese tea party. Yet fairness is a real issue when it comes to trade between the U.S. and Japan.'' - Former President Ronald Reagan. [ 31:3. ]

title: Teck Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-earlier results have been restated to reflect the award to Teck and Corona Corp. of the ownership of the Page-Williams Gold Mine near Hemlo, Ont. Teck owns 50 percent of the mine, and it said its financial results have been restated to include the mine's operations from Jan. 1, 1986. Third-quarter earnings were hurt by the strike at Highland Valley Copper, which began July 6 and ended Oct. 20. Higher 9-month earnings were due to higher base metals prices and greater gold production from the David Bell Mine. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: British Cabinet Shift: Will Policies Change?
description: The shock of the resignation Thursday evening of Nigel Lawson, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, roiled the financial markets here today.

title: Dataproducts Sought by DPC
description: DPC Acquisition Partners began an unsolicited $10-a-share cash tender offer for all the shares of the Dataproducts Corporation that it does not already control, in a transaction that would value the company at more than $200 million. DPC Acquisition is controlled by Crescott Inc., a New York investment firm that already controls 7.5 percent of Dataproducts' 21 million shares outstanding. Dataproducts, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., is a maker of computer printers. In its tender offer documents, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, DPC said it would liquidate the company if it gained control.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Octoberfest, 42d Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas will be closed tomorrow from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Fallout From Testimony Worries Queens District
description: Like most educators and parents in School District 27 in Queens this week, Toby Sohn, a special-education teacher, was mesmerized by her superintendent's testimony before the Gill Commission - tales of racial and religious bias in hiring, unnecessary jobs and a plot by some school board members to run the schools as patronage mills.

title: George Webby, 59, Maronite Church Leader
description: Msgr. George J. Webby, Vicar General of the Maronite Church in the United States, died of a heart attack Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 59 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Darwin Klingman, 45, Computer Authority
description: Darwin Klingman, a professor at the University of Texas who was an authority on mathematical models and computer applications in policy and decision-making, died of a brain tumor yesterday at St. David's Hospital in Austin, Tex. He was 45 years old and lived in Austin.

title: Noble Drilling Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Soviet Official Explains Ruble Devaluation
description: Slashing the value of the ruble this week was a small step toward making the Soviet currency freely convertible but a big step toward cutting back the country's flourishing black market, a Soviet state bank official said today.

title: In Beijing, the 'First Terror' Fades As the Crackdown Seems to Ease
description: He is still jittery, still afraid that every policeman can peer into his heart and see the fervor with which he supported the democracy movement, but the young university teacher has given up life as a fugitive. After spending months visiting friends and relatives in other cities, he sent his wife back to scout around and recently returned himself.

title: Danaher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,309,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $4,991,000, or 21 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said the extraordinary credits due to utilization of tax loss carryforwards, net of losses on early retirement of debt. Year-ago results are restated to reflect Master Shield Inc. as a discontinued operation. 1988 results include $483,000, or 2 cents a share, of income for the quarter and $628,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Article 017289 -- No Title
description: The Unisys Corporation said today that it had a net loss of $648.2 million in the third quarter, caused in part by the expenses of reducing its work force and taking other actions intended to enhance its competitiveness. In the 1988 third quarter the computer company had earned $151 million, or 77 cents a share.

title: Midtown Masters Series
description: A recital by the pianist Ursula Oppens will open the Midtown Masters series on Nov. 20 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. On the program is the world premiere of ''Two Canons for Ursula,'' a piece by Conlon Nancarrow that was commissioned by Composers Forum; there will also be works by Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky and Schubert. Tickets are $12 and $15. Information: 840-2824.

title: Craig's 'Killer Bees' Fall Short
description: The Giants were neither denying reality nor moping around tonight as they unwound in their clubhouse for what might be the next-to-last-time this year.

title: IPL Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hako Minuteman reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tritium Puzzle Halts Shipment
description: The Energy Department has again suspended all commercial shipments of tritium, the radioactive gas used in nuclear warheads, after failing to find missing quantities of it.

title: General Binding reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings included 6 cents a share gain after recovery of prior years' state taxes and provision for related federal and state income taxes. The year-ago periods' share earnings have been restated for the 3-for-2 stock split in August 1989.

title: World Series Reopens With Tribute to Dead
description: At 5:04 P.M. today, in a solemn baseball stadium where 10 days ago to the minute they feared for their lives, a crowd of 62,000 World Series fans stood silent to mourn those who died in the earthquake here.

title: Boston Agonizes Over Street Violence
description: The slaying of a pregnant woman abducted outside a hospital here has focused national attention on a recent spate of street violence in a city seldom preoccupied with crime.

title: Nicolet Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $959,000 for the quarter and $1,652,000 for the 6 months.

title: Chili's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A's Overwhelm Giants As Series Resumes
description: Eleven days after it was halted by the great earthquake, the 86th World Series was resumed tonight with a mixed mood of solemnity and cheer, and with a barrage of five home runs by the Oakland Athletics that thrust them within one game of completing a sweep over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Ambase Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $18,000,000 due to insurance losses arising from hurricane Hugo for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Aydin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Hispanic' Is No More Racist Than 'Asian'; First Rainbow Coalition
description: To the Editor:

title: Bay State Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
I.R.A. Says It Regrets Killing
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that its gunmen killed a Royal Air Force corporal and his 6-month-old daughter in West Germany, and it expressed ''profound regret'' for killing the child. Cpl. Maheshkumar Islania, 34 years old, died when two gunmen opened fire at his car in a snack-bar parking lot outside the British air base at Wildenrath.

title: Prime Motors Inns Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Weirton Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $12,595,000 related to early extinguishment of debt associated with recent refinancing activities for both periods, and the 9 months also included a pretax charge of $35.5 million for the 1984 ESOP. c-Net loss and included a pretax charge of $19.3 million related to a contribution to the company's 1984 employee stock ownership plan. d-Included a pretax charge of $57.9 million related to the 1984 ESOP. The company's third-quarter operating income was $19.9 million, compared with $20 million in the year-ago quarter. For the 9 months, the company's operating income was $67.8 million, compared with $70 million in the year-ago 9 months.

title: East Germans Declare Amnesty for Those Who Fled
description: East Germany announced an amnesty today for all citizens who have fled or tried to flee the country, as well as for most of those arrested in the recent wave of anti-Government demonstrations.

title: Green Tells Reds He's Bowing Out
description: Two months ago, Dallas Green was dismissed as manager of the Yankees by George Steinbrenner, the owner. Last week, he announced that he had been offered the job of managing the Cincinnati Reds by Marge Schott, the owner. Yesterday, he withdrew his name from consideration for the job for what the Reds called personal and business considerations.

title: Potash Corp. of Saskatchean reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is owned by the Province of Saskatchewan, which has filed a preliminary prospectus for a public offering of about 37 percent of the company.

title: United Westburne reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Eunice Taylor Vanderhoef, Horticulturist, 91
description: Eunice Taylor Vanderhoef, a horticulturist in Connecticut, died Wednesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: South Africa March Banned
description: A magistrate today prohibited without explanation a protest march by the nation's black labor federation. But the Congress of South African Trade Unions threatened to proceed with the march on Saturday in Vereeniging. The Government has recently permitted marches by unions and other anti-apartheid groups. It has given its permission for a rally near Johannesburg on Sunday to be attended by freed African National Congress leaders.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Halloween Safety
description: Tuesday is Halloween, a time for ghosts and goblins and little children. With a little planning and some common sense, adults can make Halloween festivities safe. Here are some tips. In the Street: Plan trick-or-treat routes in advance, picking well-lit streets. Choose costumes in light colors so drivers can see them. Have the children carry lighted flashlights. Use makeup rather than face masks to provide better vision. Treats: Keep treats in the bag until children get home. Cut and examine all fruit. Throw away all unwrapped candy. Remember that some hospitals X-ray Halloween candy free. Fire Safety: Make sure costumes are fire-resistant. Keep candle-lit pumpkins out of children's reach, not on porches or doorsteps. Make sure smoke alarms work. Sources: Automobile Club of New York, Consumer Product Safety Commission

description: Killing and pillaging. Pillaging and killing. The life of a Viking warrior is not an easy one, especially for strapping Erik (Tim Robbins) who is all thumbs when it comes to the obligatory rape.

description: In another move aimed at thwarting a proposed takeover of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation by McCaw Cellular Communications, Lin and the BellSouth Corporation yesterday sweetened their offer to shareholders for the merger of their cellular telephone properties.

description: Every week, Jews read successive passages of the Torah, the Five Books of Moses. In a year's time, they are finished. It is time to start over.

description: On the bus that carried the Oakland Athletics across the bay and into another grand moment in the 86th World Series, Dave Henderson allowed himself a few moments to dream.

title: Reviews/Music; A Night of Tchaikovsky by Bernstein
description: Leonard Bernstein seemed in an uncharacteristically muted mood Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, but given the overwrought emotionality of his New York Philharmonic program, perhaps that was just as well.

description: Ending a four-month inquiry, a Nairobi court ruled today that there was foul play in the death of a British photographer at the Masai Mara Game Reserve last year.

description: John T. Burnell, a former union official who held posts in labor-management relations under Mayor Abraham D. Beame, died Thursday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 79 years old and lived in Flushing.

Junior-Books Publisher Leaving Harper & Row
description: Harper & Row announced Wednesday that Elizabeth Gordon, the senior vice president and publisher of its junior books, was leaving the company but would remain as a consultant through the end of the year. No replacement has been named for Ms. Gordon, who has been publisher since 1982.

title: Employers Casualty Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Included in the latest quarter and 9 months results were investment gains of $371,087 and $897,822, respectively, and the year-earlier quarter and 9 months included an investment loss of $291,701 and an investment gain of $353,780, respectively. The company said its results reflect storm losses totaling $10,500,000 this year compared to $3,700,000 in 1988. Included in the losses are $400,000 for hurricane Hugo and $10,100,000 for storms and flooding in Texas. Hurricane Jerry, which hit Galveston in October, is estimated to cost about $200,000. The company also said it incurred a $5,300,000 loss under the reinsurance treaty under which it reinsured 50 percent of Texas Employers' Insurance Association results. That treaty was cancelled Sept. 1.

title: Tarpley Misses Practice
description: Dallas Mavericks officials are not overly concerned that the forward Roy Tarpley, a two-time offender of the National Basketball Association's anti-drug policy, did not attend practice yesterday and remained unaccounted for, a team spokesman said. Tarpley was suspended from the team last January for drug violations and returned to the roster in April after undergoing treatment for drug abuse.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, part of an article yesterday about Michael Shawn, a choreographer who says he was dismissed because he tested positive for the AIDS virus, was overprinted in some copies by a misplaced section from another article.

title: Nicaraguans Begin Sweep Against Contra Stronghold
description: Heavy fighting broke out today in this rugged mountain region as Government troops began what appeared to be a coordinated combat operation against several hundred rebels encamped here.

title: Going Below the Surface of La Guardia as Legend
description: Fiorello H. La Guardia And the Making of Modern New York By Thomas Kessner Illustrated. 700 pages. McGraw-Hill. $24.95.

Sunday Silence's Rider Is Suspended
description: Pat Valenzuela was suspended for 60 days by the Santa Anita Park stewards yesterday for testing positive for cocaine last Friday, and Chris McCarron will ride Sunday Silence in the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic on Nov. 4.

title: Orkem Agrees to Buy Bostik
description: The French state-owned chemicals group Orkem S.A. said today that it would pay $345 million to buy the Bostik adhesives business from the Black & Decker Corporation.

title: Aquino Ban on Marcos Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court today narrowly upheld President Corazon C. Aquino's right to ban the return to the Philippines of the body of her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Rangers Tie the Islanders On Horava's First Goal
description: Miloslav Horava had difficulty finding the proper words to describe his game-tying goal. Roger Neilson, a man with a gift for a turn of phrase, hit a dead end when asked simply to supply an adjective. Horava and Neilson had company, because the goal also left the opposition and the 16,485 fans at Madison Square Garden speechless.

title: As the City Falters, the Candidates Fiddle
description: LEAD: The Washington disease has spread to New York City. The primary symptom is electioneering without content, by slogans rather than substance, and the foremost victims are the two principal contestants for the mayor's office: Democrat David Dinkins and Republican-Liberal Rudolph Giuliani.

title: ORTEGA DECLARES HE WILL ABANDON NICARAGUAN TRUCE
description: As leaders of the Western Hemisphere gathered for a meeting here, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said today that he would end a 19-month-old cease-fire with the Nicaraguan rebels and order the Nicaraguan Army to resume military operations next week.

description: Sherman Walt, a former principal bassoonist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, died on Thursday evening at Beth Israel Hospital in Brookline, Mass., a few hours after he was struck by an automobile. He was 66 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

As someone who first came to Washington in the early 60's, when the city was dominated by the Democrats, this speculation bears an uncanny resemblance to what was then being said about the moribund Republican Party.

'Hispanic' Is No More Racist Than 'Asian'

title: Hidden Billions in the Budget
description: It's no secret that Federal spending is still growing, despite all the fuss about the budget deficit. But it's well concealed that ''tax expenditures'' are growing even faster, adding to the deficit just like spending. They warrant scrutiny that they don't get now.

description: Outside the main post office here, the noise and the bustle recall the stock market on a busy day. As customers come and go, on foot or in cars, with letters or checks in hand, they are immediately set upon by dealers waving wallets or pocket calculators, elbowing each other aside as they shout the latest exchange rates.

title: Mahorn Traded to 76ers
description: Rick Mahorn, who refused to report to the Minnesota Timberwolves this fall after they made him their first selection in the expansion draft last June, was traded to the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday for a first-round pick in the 1990 college draft and second-round choices in 1991 and 1992. The trade is conditional on Mahorn's reporting to Philadelphia.

title: Two Are Seized In the Shooting Of Two Officers
description: Two men were arrested early today, and two more were being sought in the shooting on Thursday of two Essex County police officers. Officials speculated that the shooting was related to a turf war over drugs.

title: British Shift Puts Spotlight On an Obscure U.S. Journal
description: The resignation of Nigel Lawson as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer has lifted an obscure American economic journal into the limelight.

title: Center-Left Coalition Is Set for Netherlands
description: Queen Beatrix asked Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers today to form the Netherlands' first center-left coalition government in seven years. The move, seven weeks after parliamentary elections, means the new govenment could be completed in a few days.

title: New Date for Bout
description: Mike Tyson will fight Donovan (Razor) Ruddock on Jan. 5 in Edmonton, Alberta, unless Tyson's promoter, Don King, says no, according to Ed Bean, the Edmonton businessman paying $3.5 million to stage the fight. The fight had been scheduled for Nov. 18, but was postponed this week because Tyson is ill with a virus causing pain in his chest.

title: Tanker, After Being Barred, Docks in Alaska
description: A tanker that has been anchored in Cook Inlet for lack of a state-approved contingency plan for cleaning up any oil spill began unloading oil Friday night after the ship's owner agreed temporarily to adopt the cleanup plan of another company.

title: Prague Seizes Dissidents On Eve of Anniversary
description: In an effort to thwart or blunt unauthorized demonstrations on Saturday, the police today rounded up some of the country's major dissidents, including Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's most prominent writer and a founder of the Charter 77 human rights group.

title: Computer Advances Assist Drug-Money Investigations
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that recent advances in computer technology were helping uncover illegal schemes to conceal narcotics profits and transfer them offshore.

title: Reagan Warns Japanese on Trade
description: In a tougher warning on trade than he issued as President, Ronald Reagan said today that Americans did not think their products had fair access to Japan and that trade barriers must be lowered to avoid rising anger in the United States.

title: Florida State the Favorite? Miami Disagrees.
description: The Miami Hurricanes, after winning 48 of their last 49 regular-season games and four in a row over Florida State at the Seminoles' Doak Campbell Stadium, were a bit miffed this week to learn they were likely to be slight underdogs today when they make another visit to Tallahassee.

title: Too Soon Darkness
description: In Australia, with summer coming on, they'll be setting their clocks forward one hour this weekend - the start of daylight time Down Under. Up here in the Northern Hemisphere, it's back to darkness in the afternoon. Too soon.

title: Potomac Electric Power Co. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
6 Women on Broadway Are Stuck With Pins
description: At least six women walking along Broadway on the Upper West Side were stuck from behind with needles or pins by young women who then ran away, the police said yesterday.

title: Strickland to Sit Out
description: Rod Strickland, who has started all seven preseason games thus far, while Mark Jackson works his way back into playing shape, sat out yesterday's Knick practice with a swollen left knee. Strickland suffered the injury Thursday night in the Knicks' 103-100 overtime victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves at the New Haven Coliseum. He is listed as doubtful for tonight's game against the Cleveland Cavaliers in Pittsburgh.

title: Changes at Units Planned by Boeing
description: The Boeing Company announced plans for a revamping of its military and space exploration businesses to cut losses on military projects and reduce general overhead costs on its Government work. Paul Binder, a company spokesman, said the changes were largely a matter of redrawing flow charts and executive assignments.

title: A 66 Puts Kite Ahead by 4 at Hilton Head
description: Winds came off the Atlantic Ocean strong enough to be to Tom Kite's liking today: 25 to 30 miles an hour, and swirling through the big trees lining the Harbour Town Golf Links.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,241,000, or 4 cents a share. c-Included extraordinary credits of $2,803,000, or 5 cents a share, and $2,341,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: b-Net income

title: Patents; Quigg, Leaving Office, Cites Patent Speed-Up
description: The Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, Donald J. Quigg, who will step down Tuesday, is claiming at least one victory for efficiency: The average time needed to process a patent application is now 18 months, down from almost two years when he took office in 1985.

title: Great Amer Management reports earnings for Year to July 31
Opera by Rameau
description: A concert version of Jean Philippe Rameau's opera ''Hippolyte et Aricie'' is to be presented by the Concert Royal Baroque Orchestra on Nov. 29 and 30 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The performance is part of the Original Instruments series. Tickets are $20. Information: 362-8719.

title: Liggett Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giants' Pitching Mistakes Are Athletics' Homers
description: If the 11-day hiatus between World Series games produced any changes in the fortunes of the teams, those changes favored the Oakland Athletics.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-6 Nicaragua will break a cease-fire with Nicaraguan rebels and resume offensive military operations next week, President Ortega said. Reports indicate that the offensive has already begun. Page 1 Fighting broke out in Nicaragua as Government troops began what appeared to be a coordinated combat operation against several hundred contras in a mountain region. 5 For Ortega, a pose with Bush 5 San Salvador journal: Where dollars talk, unfettered by war 4 East Berlin announced an amnesty for all citizens who have fled or tried to flee the country, as well as for most of those arrested in the recent wave of anti-Government protests. 1 News analysis: East Germany is causing anxiety in Bonn. West Germans worry that if the East German Government fails to change, Bonn will be flooded with refugees. 1 Curb seen on Kremlin war powers 6 Prague arrests dissidents 6 A feel of terror in China has subsided, but in its place is a consuming dread that the next few years will be painful, economically and politically. 1 China departed from its hard line against private enterprises by announcing new regulations that would encourage unemployed people to establish private and collective enterprises in the capital. 3 President Reagan warned Japan that it faces American ire unless it changes its trading practices. He said it risks a possible boycott of its products unless it corrects some environmentally dangerous policies. 31 Japan must take sweeping actions, including the slapping down of companies that fix prices and the restructuring of retail distribution, to avoid new U.S. trade sanctions, the U.S. trade representative said. 32 Philippine bans return of Ferdinand Marcos's body 3 Iran has eased tensions with Iraq by stopping its flooding of a section of the cease-fire line at Basra. The move also ends a yearlong dispute between Teheran and the United Nations. 3 Where is Britain's economy headed? That was on the minds of many financial analysts the day after the replacement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer. 31 National 8-10, 26 Some 50,000 sports fans stood silent in Candlestick Park to mourn the earthquake's dead. Then they joined in singing ''San Francisco,'' the 1936 movie anthem to the city's revival after the 1906 disaster. 1 Samuel Pierce refused to testify before Congress again about political favoritism in Federal housing programs, prompting new calls for appointment of a special prosecutor. 9 President Bush vetoed a budget bill for the District of Columbia because it allowed Federal and local financing of abortions. Lawmakers are not sure if they will try to override. 8 The police stormed a state prison in Camp Hill, Pa., rescuing five prison employees who had been taken hostage by inmates and regaining control of the 52-acre complex. 9 A spate of street violence in Boston has attracted national attention after the slaying of a pregnant woman abducted outside a hospital. Eight people in the city have died in bloody shootings in the last two months. 8 Alaska has refused to allow a tanker carrying more than 14 million gallons of North Slope crude oil to dock without a state-approved contingency plan for cleaning up an oil spill. 26 A nuclear weapons program chief has been appointed on an acting basis. The Bush nominee for the job faces obstacles in Congress. 9 Tritium puzzle halts shipment 9 A 91-year-old woman is being sued for $950,000 in Vermont because she lent her grandnephew money to buy a car. The youth, who did not have a driver's license, was involved in a car crash that maimed a passenger. 8 A jury has convicted three men and acquitted two others on charges that they conspired with a leading drug trafficker to smuggle and distribute cocaine in the United States. 8 Jackson's half brother indicted in hiring of killers 10 Federal officials do not challenge hiring program in West 10 Two investment houses end index arbitrage 31 Regional 27-30 Little debate over the new charter proposed for New York City has been generated so far, with little more than a week left until election day. Each side is accusing the other of distorting the issues. 1 David Dinkins named Victor Kovner to be corporation counsel in a Dinkins administration. The announcement was apparently aimed at assuring voters that a Dinkins administration would be broad based. 1 Harlem is swelling with pride as one of their own, David Dinkins, approaches Election Day. Among the neigborhood's residents, questions about Mr. Dinkins's finances dealings hold little resonance. 27 Rudolph Giuliani has a new strategy regarding Mayor Koch. He is positioning himself closer to Mr. Koch in the hope of winning over former Koch supporters, who polls show are growing wary of David Dinkins. 27 Mayoral candidates are not embracing idea of new taxes 27 A Queens school district is angry about a superintendent's tale of a plot to run schools as patronage mills, at an annual cost of $1 million. Many wonder how much was wasted. 27 To reduce the toxic exhaust on buses and comply with 1991 Federal air standards, the New York City Transit Authority said it will install breadbox-sized trap oxidizers. 29 A 19-year-old student was killed by another student on a northbound subway train below the Upper East Side after an argument that started in the school cafeteria, the police said. 29 Building sealed after protest by squatters 29 Two held and two sought in shooting of two officers 30 Three New York mothers face charges of child mistreatment 30

title: Review/Film; A Mix of Gore and Freud
description: Horace Pinker (Mitch Pileggi), the raging mass murderer who cuts a splattery swath in Wes Craven's ''Shocker,'' is a television repairman with an unusual relationship to the world of video. Toward the end of a movie that begins as a conventional horror film and grows steadily weirder, he dives in and out of television screens that transport him to and from various otherworldly realms.

title: Alfred C. Bruce, 88, An Ex-Civil Engineer
description: Alfred C. Bruce, a retired civil engineer and business executive, died of heart disease Thursday at a nursing home in East Haven, Conn. He was 88 years old and had lived for many years in Southport, Conn.

title: College Football; FIRST LOSS FOR MIAMI
description: Miami, rated No. 2 in the news service polls and No. 4 in The New York Times computer ranking, suffered its first loss of the season last night when it fell to Florida State, 24-10, at Tallahassee, Fla.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Separate Officals For TV Replays
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A CORRECTION
description: A Northeast Notebook item on Oct. 15 about redevelopment in Winthrop, Me., misidentified the former variety store that was moved. It was Wilson's, not Grant's.

title: Tagliabue Has Only Begun to Rebound
description: At the National Football League's annual meeting in the spring of 1986, the 28 club owners were confronted with a decision that would determine their future as well as the future of pro football: to go to trial over the United States Football League's antitrust suit or to settle it out of court. During the discussion, one of the owners turned to one of the N.F.L.'s attorneys.

title: Sony Discussing Contribution to Reagan's Library
description: Representatives of Ronald Reagan were discussing a possible contribution to Mr. Reagan's presidential library with the Sony Corporation at the same time that the former President was defending the giant electronics company's proposed takeover of Columbia Pictures, a Reagan spokesman said today.

title: BRAWLING OVER HARRODS
description: Harrods is my corner shop. Nearly daily dashes there to get everything from milk to air tickets have given me a ground-floor view of the changes resulting from the dramas reported in your article. When I moved to Knightsbridge five years ago, Harrods was a musty old dowager. Nothing lured me to shop past the items on my list.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Whalers 1, Bruins 0: Mike Liut posted his second successive shutout and the 22d of his National Hockey League career last night in Boston as Hartford edged the Bruins on Scott Young's third-period goal. Liut, first among active goaltenders in shutouts, made 28 saves to win a goaltending duel with Boston's Reggie Lemelin, who had to make only 17. Lemelin lost his shutout bid when the Bruins' defense faltered briefly in the tight-checking game.(AP) Horse Racing State-Breds Run: Just Cuz and Sir Richard Lewis won their respective divisions of the New York Stallion Stakes for 2-year-old New York-breds at Aqueduct yesterday. Just Cuz led throughout in taking the first division, for fillies. She finished three-quarters of a length ahead of It's Windy. Chestnut St. Rose was another head back. Just Cuz, with Jerry Bailey up, paid $15.80 for $2 to win.

title: DIGGING THEIR OWN CORPORATE GRAVESP
description: CORPORATE MAKEOVER The Reshaping of the American Economy. By Harvey H. Segal. 269 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Is East Europe Too Amazing for the West?
description: AS one astounding development succeeds another in what used to be known as the Soviet bloc, it is no longer visionary to think of the possibility of a new Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals by the end of the century. The extent of change in the East became even clearer last week, but so did the implication that the Western countries may soon have to rethink some fundamental assumptions of the old postwar order if they want to help shape the new one.

title: Tomorrow, Sleeping Late
description: IF Jane Pauley was miffed, as some reports had it, when Deborah Norville showed up on the ''Today'' show last August, it was all hugs Friday morning when they passed the baton. NBC said that Ms. Pauley (at right) would be leaving the show after 13 years to begin work on a weekly prime-time news program and on a special in which she will be interviewing people ''who have undergone significant personal and professional change and examining how they have faced these crossroads.'' Here was part of their exchange on Friday's show:

title: A Place for Developing Artistry in Glass
description: IN the brilliant light of their red-hot furnaces, silhouetted glassmakers take on a primeval aspect. Ritual-like blowing and twisting of a long pipe turns the molten glass at the tip into a glowing sphere. The blowpipe is passed from hand to hand and back to the ''glory hole,'' where the glass is reheated and reworked, again and again.

title: CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: WHEN THE TRUSTEES OF ROCKEFELLER University in New York City appointed Nobel Laureate David Baltimore as president earlier this month, it plunged the school's distinguished scientific faculty into turmoil. More than a third of Rockefeller's full professors took the extraordinary step of coming out against the appointment in the press. Baltimore found himself on an unlikely and humbling mission, going from lab to lab in the lush enclave to hear concerns about his role in what has become a scientific scandal.

title:
In the Heartland, Points of Light;
Providing Mentors As Role Models
description: LEAD: In 1987, Procter & Gamble joined with a local Cincinnati school, Woodward High, to establish Project Aspire, a program that matches students with volunteer ''mentors'' drawn from the company's ranks.

title: James Freney to Wed Caroline Neville
description: Mrs. William Frederick Thayer of Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I., and Warwick Fay Neville of Pinehurst, N.C., and Palm Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Livingston Neville to James Raymond Freney. He is the son of Susann Ferguson Freney of Bryn Mawr, Pa. A January wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A citronella candle dripped melted wax onto the pressure-treated pine on our outside deck. We have tried removing this stain, but so far nothing has worked. Any suggestions?

title: No Suits Filed By Sound Coalition
description: As an organization committed to the protection of the Sound, the Long Island Sound Task Force welcomed the article ''Deep Splits Mar a Cause'' (Sept. 24). We want to clarify a statement in the accompanying article, ''The Watch From the Shore: A Who's Who for Long Island Sound,'' that the Connecticut Coastal Coalition, of which the task force is a member, has taken legal action against municipalities.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: WHAT THEY STILL DON'T TEACH YOU AT HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL. By Mark H. McCormack. (Bantam, $18.95.) The sports agent and entrepreneur Mark McCormack, the author of the best seller ''What They Don't Teach You at Harvard Business School,'' now gives us a new collection of managerial tips, with chapters on selling, negotiating, managing, getting ahead, getting organized, communicating, entrepreneuring and doing business on the road.

title: Sandra B. Wilson Weds
description: Sandra B. Wilson and Theodore R. Walser were married in New York yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Charles Amstein. Mrs. Walser, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Benjamin of Remsenburg, L.I., graduated from the State University of New York at Cortland. She is the accessories fashion director in New York for the Neiman-Marcus stores. Mr. Walser, a graduate of Yale University, is a son of Mrs. Kenneth E. Walser of Washington and the late Mr. Walser. He is a vice president and senior manager of Lloyds Bank in New York. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did her husband's.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Florida's Messy Marvels
description: LEAD: STONE crabs are to Florida what lobsters are to New England: one of the region's most cherished specialties. When stone crab is listed on a menu, more often than not the Floridian or savvy visitor will overlook other temptations, including local ''spiny'' (clawless) lobster, to order a platterful.

title: Bavaro Likely To Miss Game
description: Mark Bavaro did some running on his sprained left knee today, but the Giants' tight end remained doubtful for Monday night's game against the Minnesota Vikings in Giants Stadium.

title: Colleen Gunning Is Married
description: Colleen Marie Gunning, a critical-care nurse at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., and Dr. Thomas Arthur Beckett, an obstetrician-gynecologist at the Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital and at St. Barnabas, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family in Florham Park, N.J. The Rev. Martin Glynn officiated. Mrs. Beckett, 27 years old, is a daughter of Joan M. Gunning of Mendham, N.J., and Wendel M. Gunning of Morristown. Dr. Beckett, 31, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Beckett of Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Nancy Porter and James Bokern Wed
description: Nancy Chase Porter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Porter of Virginia Beach, Va., was married there yesterday to James Scott Bokern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Bokern of Town and Country, Mo. Dr. J. Scottie Griffin performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title:
AMERICAN CONTEMPORARY;
Mail Order Trims Settings That Deliver
description: LEAD: ENTERTAINING AT HOME REQUIRES tableware - and time. For the host or hostess who is short of either, catalogue shopping can be a convenient solution.

title: THE NOUVEAU TYCOONS
description: THE NEW CROWD The Changing of the Jewish Guard on Wall Street. By Judith Ramsey Ehrlich and Barry J. Rehfeld. Illustrated. 444 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: Now, the People's Army Has Fewer Friends, More Power
description: CHINA'S favorite hat used to be the army cap. As recently as this spring, young boys wore them everywhere and doting parents beamed their approval.

title: In Purchase, a Movable Musical Feast
description: A VALUABLE but at times neglected possession of the State University of New York will take center stage at the Performing Arts Center of the campus here in the coming weeks.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; A Peaceful Training Ground for Army Officers
description: Seen from across the river in the waning color of mid-autumn, the forbidding institution carved into the rising banks of the Hudson unquestionably has a serious purpose. Form probably never clung closer to function.

title: Once a Wunderkind, Now Robert 'Long Ago'?
description: It is fitting that the survey of Robert Longo's career at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art is starting its three-city tour in the capital of American popular culture, the home town of movies and television.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: THE DECISION MAKERS: The Men and the Million-Dollar Moves Behind Today's Great Corporate Success Stories. By Robert Heller. (Truman Talley/Dutton, $22.50.) One day in 1957, Akio Morita, the co-founder and chairman of the Sony Corporation, turned down a purchase order for 100,000 new transistor radios from the Bulova Corporation because Bulova would sell them only if the radios carried the Bulova brand name. Mr. Morita refused because he believed building Sony's brand image was more important than a huge sale. Looking back, Mr. Morita says that decision was the best he ever made. That tale appeared two years ago in Mr. Morita's autobiography, ''Made in Japan: Akio Morita and Sony,'' but Robert Heller retells it in ''The Decision Makers'' because he wants to make a point. ''The history of any great entrepreneurial business consists of milestone decisions,'' he writes. The editor of the British business publication Management Today, Mr. Heller finds many lessons for managers and would-be managers in the dozens of anecdotes and abbreviated case studies he collects here. He relies mainly on accounts from major business publications in the United States and Europe, and on popular books of recent vintage. There is nary a whiff of fresh reporting. Factual errors are annoying, but they are infrequent and mostly minor. Mr. Heller likes lists and bromides. He is full of advice and authority distilled from briefly sketched turning points of well-known companies - Chrysler, Ford, I.B.M., Jaguar and Compaq Computer, among others. ''The Decision Makers'' covers familiar ground effervescently and stirs up the scent of the diverse and daring maneuvers in business competition. But Mr. Heller reaches too high. His claim to deliver a guide to effective executive decisions is suspect from the start. By the end, the blend of pedantry, limited scope and superficial detail has turned mind-numbing.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HALLOWEEN CONCERT

title: Five Killed and One Missing as Bridge Falls Into an Arkansas River
description: A pedestrian bridge with as many as 50 people on it collapsed today, killing at least five people and injuring 18, after the crowd rocked the span back and forth, the authorities said.

title: Listings Try to Help Save Old Buildings
description: SOMEBODY somewhere must want to buy a dismantled 18th-century tavern, move an early 19th-century Greek Revival house or help solve the problems of a 1933 International Style prefabricated home. That is the idea that led the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation to start its Historic Properties Exchange.

title: M. S. Farkas Wed To Miss Goldberg
description: Jessica Ann Goldberg, a daughter of Richard Goldberg of Palm Springs, Calif., and the late Marcia Goldberg of Chicago and New York, was married in New York last evening to Matthew Scott Farkas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Farkas of New York. Rabbi Thomas Weiner and Cantor Richard Botton performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Fare With Interesting Specials
description: LEAD: JUST as good hosts should sleep in their guest beds before inviting anyone else to sleep in them, so should restaurant owners dine at all the tables in their restaurants before opening to the public. The year-old Sabitini's, which is opposite the United Methodist Church in Caldwell, is a good illustration of why this should be done.

title: Off the Record
description: THE STATEMENT was never made on the record, off the record, in any way,'' insisted Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley. He had been reported by The Washington Times to have told a group of foreign journalists that ''the President is like a mad dog after a bone on this capital gains cut.''

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: WORKING TOGETHER: Entrepreneurial Couples. By Frank Barnett and Sharan Barnett. (Ten Speed Press, Paper, $9.95.) In a country and an era that zealously guards individual space, time alone and independence, Frank and Sharan Barnett, husband and wife, founders and partners in their own advertising firm, celebrate entrepreneuring with one's best friend - one's spouse.

title: Review/Music; Jolly Boys' Caribbean Stylings
description: Thursday night at the Knitting Factory, the only palm trees in sight were printed on the singers' shirts. But the four Jolly Boys, who are graying, brought with them the casual atmosphere of the Jamaican resort beach at Port Antonio, where they serenade tourists and residents under the Caribbean sun.
