title: Sometimes, a Negative Isn't Positive
description: A QUICK scan of the political landscape last week suggested one lesson future candidates may draw from the campaigns of 1989: hit hard, hit fast, hit nasty.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: Of course the Series should have been called off. Could it be that the money involved in the games is too large to forfeit even in the face of a major disaster? ALFRED W. MUNSON Stroudsburg, Pa.

title: Say 'Ah'
description: THE ELASMOSAUR WAS A GIANT sea reptile with fierce-looking jaws, flippers and an athletic neck that accounted for more than half its length. Dating from the Cretaceous Period, some 66 million to 144 million years ago, it belonged to a family of creatures known as plesiosaurs, of which paleontologists say they are often reminded when they hear descriptions from those who claim to have sighted the Loch Ness monster, the possibly apocryphal Scottish water dragon.

title: TALKING: Inspections; Flawed Reports on Homes
description: THE problem could be a roof that starts to leak within days of the buyer's moving in, or termite damage found to have pulverized a beam in a dark corner of the basement.

title: LATE-NIGHT COOL
description: Arsenio Hall should not be angered by Johnny Carson's attempt to control guest appearances (''Late-Night Cool,'' by Michael Norman, Oct. 1). After Mr. Hall has ruled the late-night talk circuit for nearly 30 years, he may use the power that comes with that territory to impede rising young competitors. It is not personal and it is not racism. It's show business. EDWARD F. KUNIN Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Review/Music; Chico Freeman
description: Chico Freeman, the hard-toned tenor saxophonist, brought a brawling quintet to Carlos 1 on Tuesday night. And though the group was unrehearsed and played too long, it still put on a rocking show, driven by the percussion of the drummer Steve Berrios and the conga playing of Jerry Gonzales. The idea was to merge Afro-Latin rhythms with Afro-American ones, an old and noble concept; in this case it worked.

title: Panamanian's Tale: '87 Plan for a Coup
description: Eduardo Herrera Hassan, a former colonel in the Panamanian Army, learned firsthand about the problems of plotting a coup that complies with the Presidential rules restricting covert operations by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: New Deans At Adelphi
description: I would like to correct a misconception in the article ''Colleges Strive to Keep Students on L.I.'' (Sept. 23).

title: Peace at Last, on Paper at Least, for Lebanon
description: AFTER 14 years of civil war, Muslims and Christians in Lebanon have drawn up a new charter for sharing power that recognizes the dominant weight of the country's Muslim population and the country's Arab identity. The deal struck last week holds a promise of an end to a murderous conflict, but it is still hard to say that peace in Lebanon is at hand.

title: Villanova Wins in Italy
description: Kirk Schulz passed for two touchdowns and led two third-quarter drives that helped Villanova to a 28-25 victory over Rhode Island today as the Yankee Conference opponents played in the first college football game in Italy.

title: Watch for Labels On Wooden Bats
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: THE CHARISMATIC LEADER: Behind the Mystique of Exceptional Leadership. By Jay A. Conger. (Jossey-Bass, $20.95.) What is charisma and how does it work in business? In ''The Charismatic Leader,'' Jay A. Conger, an assistant professor of organizational behavior at McGill University in Montreal, sets out to get ''behind the mystique of exceptional leadership.

description: LEAD: ACTING on one of the most controversial issues to face it in years, the state's Board of Higher Education has directed two potential competitors in nursing education to collaborate to offer a joint degree.

description: The Oakland Athletics won the World Series last night with a 9-6 victory over the San Francisco Giants, to complete a four-game sweep that had been interrupted for 11 days by the earthquake of Oct. 17.

title: DATABANK: Oct. 29, 1989
Selling a House Becomes a Family's Passion Through the Seasons
description: HOW did our predicament begin? Simply enough. The two children were now teen-agers. The small vacation cottage we owned was four-and-a-half traffic-filled hours away, and the resistance to making the weekend and summer trips was monumental. What should we do?

description: DANA PARKER has been doing odd jobs at the Boston Post Road Stage Company - sorting nuts and bolts, cleaning up and ushering - since the theater started five years ago.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: MANAGING FOR RESULTS;
Set a Goal and Reach It Step by Step
description: LEAD: Ideas are for action, Aristotle said. But the trek from idea to action is never easy. This is especially true when it comes to putting ideas into place that will change an organization's stategic direction.

title: U.S. Legislators Press Beirut General on Pact
description: Two American lawmakers tried today to persuade the Lebanese Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, to accept an Arab League-sponsored peace plan. They also urged kidnappers holding Western hostages to free the men.

title: Amy Edelmann Plans a Wedding
description: Amy Maureen Edelmann and William Paul Donohue Jr. plan to marry in December. The future bride's parents, Maureen Edelmann of Montville, N.J., and West Tisbury, Mass., and Dr. Robert B. Edelmann of Mendham, N.J., have made known her engagement to Mr. Donohue, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donohue of Manhasset, L.I.

description: RUDE AWAKENING The Rise, Fall, and Struggle for Recovery of General Motors. By Maryann Keller. 275 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

description: Laurinda Payson Middleton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bentivoglio Middleton of New York and Greve, Italy, was married yesterday to Frank Graf Oswald 3d, a son of Mr. Oswald of New York and Audrey C. Oswald of Newport, R.I. The Rev. Cal Larson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Middleton Place Gardens in Charleston, S.C., public gardens that were once owned by the bride's family.

title: Who Buys . . . Navy Times? Dirt Rider?
description: UNDER the influence of bookstore chains and mass-circulation newspapers and magazines, the American reading public continues to blend into a single, more or less uniform market. But a recent survey of magazine circulation by the advertising agency Young & Rubicam's San Francisco office shows that beneath the layers of homogenization, American cities retain their distinctive flavors.

title: Rhones, California Style
description: YOU DON'T HAVE TO BE A WINE EXPERT to recognize such names as cabernet, chardonnay and pinot noir. Of course, they're the names of the grapes that go into California's most famous wines. But don't get too comfortable; things are changing out on the West Coast. Are you ready for syrah, mourvedre, grenache, cinsault and viognier? Not exactly household words, even in wine-loving households, but these are some of the grapes from which California's most exciting new wines are made.

title: Sylvia Helm, Editor, Weds D. D. Armstrong
description: Sylvia Marie Helm, the executive editor of Computers in Banking magazine, and Daniel Dobyns Armstrong, a director of the Globecon Group, a bank consulting concern, both in New York, were married in New York yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. John Backe, a Lutheran minister. The bride, 38 years old, will retain her name. She is the daughter of Marie Helm of Chicago and the late Kenneth Helm. She is a graduate of the University of Chicago. Mr. Armstrong, 36, is a graduate of George Washington University and earned an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. He is a son of John Milton Armstrong of Annapolis, Md., and the late Susan Armstrong.

title: Financing Repairs in Co-ops and Condos

The elevator won't pass inspection and the broken and buckled sidewalk outside, which everyone thought belonged to the city, turns out to be the building owners' responsibility.

title: Oil vs. Fish? No, a Way To Have Both

title: 'Upheaval in the Quiet Zone'
description: To the Editor:

In the biggest player turnover in league history, 128 players, more than one-third of the league, will be wearing new uniforms after an off season of stocking the two expansion teams, free agency, trades and the influx of rookies.

title: ROLL OVER, WAGNER

For the last few years, I have been scoring films using computers and synthesizers. So I read your article on Stewart Copeland with great interest. Copeland is a first-rate drummer. He deserves a place in a musical hall of fame, like a great ball player. But to quote him on serialists is as far-fetched as quoting Yogi Berra on Sartre.

description: LEFTOVERS, I HAVE found, can often be a headstart on the way to a new adventure. I welcome them as dividends, and the microwave oven is particularly good at transforming them into savory new dishes.

Yet he is little more than a name in the United States.

title:
BOOK & BUSINESS;
THE 60-YEAR CYCLE (DON'T LOOK NOW!)
description: LEAD: REGULAR ECONOMIC CYCLES Money, Inflation, Regulation and Depressions. By Ravi Batra. Foreword by Lester C. Thurow. 192 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press.

For decades, books on New England legends have labeled it everything from ''Connecticut's favorite ghost town'' to ''the village of the damned.''

description: For the next few weeks, Kamal Bahadur Singh and thousands of people like him in farming villages and towns in a rural pocket of India called Amethi will number among the most important people in Indian politics.

title: The Influential and Joyous Legacy of Zaire's Franco
description: The nation of Zaire went into mourning, by presidential decree, for four days after the death on Oct. 12 of L'Okanga La Ndju Pene Luambo Makiadi, the Zairian bandleader and guitarist more simply known as Franco, who died at the age of 51. During the mourning period, Franco's music was heard continuously on the radio - probably without much repetition, since he had recorded at least 100 albums since 1956, when he helped to start O. K. Jazz, one of Africa's most influential bands.

description: WITH the opening of the county's bow-hunting season for deer this week, state officials are considering a plan to allow a limited shotgun season in January on private land of 10 acres or more.

title: Measures Intensify to Ease The Strain on Sewers
description: LEAD: OVER the next few years, many otherwise law-abiding homeowners may learn that the connections that drain rainwater from their property are illegal and are contributing to the overloading of the county's sewage-treatment plants during wet weather. These ''lawbreakers'' will, quite literally, be smoked out.

title: Michele Pincus Weds James Frederick Eller
description: Michele Amy Pincus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Pincus of New York, was married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., to James Frederick Eller, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Milton Eller of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Arnold Marans officiated.

description: WHEN it comes to international taxation, businessman and bankers here and abroad look to Walter H. and Dorothy B. Diamond. From their office here, the husband-and-wife team provide a constant stream of data on the changing world of finance and trade.

description: BREATHES THERE A SOUL WHO doesn't hate cleaning up after a party?

description: To the Editor:

title: In Paris Shows, Couture Meets Its Marketers
description: LIKE glittering nymphs of the post-industrial age, the models sauntered down runways last week, showing the first styles of the 1990's. But on their backs hung more than clothes. Dangling from their coat-hanger shoulders were the fortunes of a luxury-goods industry that is France's second largest exporter after defense.

title: An Absurdist Drama in a Drawing Room
description: WHAT are our best friends for? Suppose they arrive at our door, frightened - no, terrified - in the middle of the night. Of course, we must take them in; mustn't we? But what if they then say they're staying - and take over the room of a family member?

title: Mocking the Utopian Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Ultimatum for Eason
description: The New England Patriots have won only two of their first seven games, and Pat Sullivan, the general manager, thinks he may have hit on a formula to improve things, if not on the playing field, then at least on the balance sheet.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Luxurious Grande Dame in Lewisboro
description: LEAD: RENE CHARDAIN'S restaurant certainly has pride of place among the grandes dames of the northern county. Although the lighting, somewhat brash, could be more enhancing, the details of both situation and building manage to be impressive. A dramatic serpentine driveway, broad lawns and generous entrance lead to public rooms of unstinting proportions with carefully worked neoclassic moldings, marble fireplaces and pretty paintings.

title: Japan Is Divided On Foreign Workers
description: IN a country known for its wariness of outsiders, this bustling port has long been particularly welcoming to foreigners, with its English-language signs and the colorful Chinatown tucked into its narrow streets. But as Japan slips deeper into its most severe labor shortage in 15 years, even Yokohama has become a front in the Government's losing battle to preserve the nation's cherished homogeneity and keep out a growing influx of illegal foreign workers.

title: A Big Change Looms in 'Cafeteria Plans'
description: As the end of the year approaches, some employees must decide how much, if anything, they will set aside for 1990 in their ''flexible spending accounts'' for health care - an employee benefit that lets them pay for uninsured medical expenses with pre-tax dollars.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: Only if a portion of revenues from the gate, the concessions, the salaries and the media is donated to relief, should the Series go on. STEPHEN R. TOBER Portsmouth, N.H.

title: NOBODY'S PERFECT
description: THE SUN ALSO SETS The Limits to Japan's Economic Power. By Bill Emmott. 292 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: Court Rejects Plea for Abortion Before Jail
description: A county judge has refused a woman's request to postpone her 60-day jail sentence so she can have an abortion first.

title: Leading a Path to Nature and Its Restful Ways
description: JEAN VERTEFEUILLE introduces people to the sight of blue herons, the feel of canoe paddles and the sound of silence.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: WHEN GIANTS LEARN TO DANCE: Mastering the Challenges of Strategy, Management, and Careers in the 1990s. By Rosabeth Moss Kanter. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) This could have been a deadly academic treatment, full of charts and graphs, footnotes and tables. Instead, Rosabeth Moss Kanter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, has written a relaxed, readable account of the hows and whys of change in American corporations. In tomorrow's corporate Olympics, the prizes will go to the businesses and managers who have met the challenge of ''the ultimate corporate balancing act'': organizational and structural changes that will require, simultaneously, cutting back and growing, doing more with less. It is a complex world, Ms. Kanter says, and Americans are up against tough competition. Business is in transition because the world economy is changing, and the author peppers her pages with examples. While older corporations, like Eastman Kodak, learn to update their approaches, newer ones, like Apple Computer, are evolving from entrepreneurial start-ups to more mature, settled organizations. Change is the key: becoming lean without becoming mean, restructuring for maximum ''entrepreneurial thrust,'' developing and using synergies. (Once an upstart buzzword, ''synergy'' is now an accepted academic term meaning a ''whole that multiplies the value of the parts.'') Synergies involve getting more for less; hence the streamlining, bureaucracy-cutting, decentralizing that are necessary in today's postentrepreneurial corporate world. For all the change, however, and the uncharted waters ahead, Ms. Kanter makes it clear that people are the dominant factor and the most important resource in a successful business. The demands on them are multiple and conflicting; restructuring can disempower them, but they are the key to success or failure.

title: Margaret Graham Is Wed in Darien
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., Margaret Eileen Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Graham of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Joseph Arrix Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arrix of New Canaan. The Rev. Edward J. Howley performed the ceremony.

title: Koch's Stand on China Enrages Ambassador
description: In the battle over Tiananmen Square - the one at 42d Street and 12th Avenue - the exchanges between the People's Republic of China and the City of New York are turning increasingly hostile.

title: In Nuclear Cleanup, Costs Grow and Promise Fades
description: Engineers arrived here in 1982 to begin cleaning up a factory that once processed nuclear waste. Their task was to employ a pioneering technology: remove hundreds of thousands of gallons of radioactive liquids and sludge from an aging storage tank and make the radioactive materials safe from spills or leaks by mixing them with cement or glass.

title: POSTINGS: Near Booth Memorial; Medical Offices
description: A few years ago, administrators at Booth Memorial Medical Center, on Booth Memorial Avenue at 141st Street in Flushing, Queens, were searching for a way to take better advantage of properties the center owned on the other side of the avenue and was using for offices and staff housing. They turned for assistance to W. J. Barney, a construction and development company that specializes in medical projects.

title: Review/Music; Laussade, Pianist, In Recital
description: Elyane Laussade, a pianist with a powerful, polished technique and many an original interpretive notion, made her New York recital debut on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Her program covered ample ground, all of it well within the standard repertory, and she addressed each work with an impeccable sense of style.

title: RUTHLESS OPTIMISM
description: CIRCUS OF AMBITION The Culture of Wealth and Power in the Eighties. By John Taylor. 240 pp. New York: Warner Books. $19.95.

title: Robert Halsband, 75, English Scholar, Dies
description: Robert Halsband, an authority on 18th-century English literature and a teacher and writer, died of pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old. Professor Halsband wrote a dozen books on the literary figures of the 1700's and their works. Among his books are ''The Life of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu,'' ''The Complete Letters of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu'' and ''The Rape of the Lock and Its Illustrations, 1714-1896.'' All were published by Oxford University Press.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Old Warehouses In New Roles
description: LEAD: A FORMER riverfront warehouse center here is gradually being transformed into a haven for young professional service firms that are buying and renting space in rehabilitated historic buildings.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Lifestyle; No Idle Hands as Daylight Time Ends
description: Hedy Bagatelle has fond memories of growing up in a two-clock family: an electric wall clock in the kitchen and a wind-up clock in the bedroom (moved into the living room whenever she was practicing piano).

title: Campus Life: Boston U.; Police Investigate False ID's Issued By Student Ring
description: A student ring that produced illegal driver's licenses for use by underage students to obtain alcohol and enter adult clubs has been uncovered by officials at Boston University and Boston College.

title: LATE-NIGHT COOL
description: So Paramount believes that Johnny Carson's audience is ''skewed to older men.'' Well, maybe yes, maybe no. Frankly, this 61-year-old WASP finds Mr. Carson and his fill-in buddy Jay Leno consummate bores. (Is it foreordained that they do a Dan Quayle or Exxon joke every night?) Arsenio Hall, on the other hand, is alive, upbeat. His show moves along swiftly, with great fun and joy.

title: On the Ancient Nile, a Modern Voyage
description: PERHAPS, when you think of Egypt, you imagine yourself on a boat, gliding smoothly along the wide green Nile as people have done for thousands of years. Beyond the bulrushes and palm trees that line the shore are small mud-brick villages, each with its own mosque and minaret, flanked by wide fields of black earth being plowed by bullocks. Perhaps you imagine that the pace is very slow: the majestic progress of your boat, the quiet sliding current of the water, the people and oxen on the rich soil, and the vast reaches of time you encounter with each new visit to a temple on shore.

title: Review/Dance; Death-Life Celebration By Muteki-Sha Troupe
description: Natsu Nakajima has an indisputable sense of theater. Her eye for visual effect extends to the smallest details of costuming and lighting. But though her latest work, presented on Friday night at the La Mama Annex by Miss Nakajima's Muteki-Sha Dance Company, obviously thrilled much of the audience, to this observer it looked surprisingly shallow.

title: Boeing and Strikers to Talk
description: The Boeing Company and the machinists' union have agreed to hold contract talks for only the second time since 58,000 workers struck the aircraft manufacturer Oct. 4 over wages and work schedules. The announcement was made Friday by a Federal mediator, Doug Hammond, who said the two sides would meet separately with mediators Sunday and direct talks would be held Monday. The strike has slowed production of aircraft at a time when orders for commercial jetliners are piling up.

title:
AMERICAN CONTEMPORARY;
A Meal of Mushrooms
description: LEAD: SILKY, SAUCER-SIZED FRESH PORCINI in Italy and fragrant pine mushrooms, or matsutake, in Japan often serve as entrees, virtually unadorned. In the menu suggested here, dense roasted portobello caps play a similar role, although in this meal, courses are neither entrees nor accompaniments but a progression of dishes of satisfying proportions - even for meat eaters.

title: Play Group With Fetching Charges
description: LEAD: LIKE most play groups, the dozen or so people who meet every morning at East Rock Park in New Haven do so with two goals in mind: to give their young charges some exercise and social interaction with their peers, and to compare notes on developmental issues, effective discipline and toilet-training techniques.

title: Touch Tones
description: IN THE 18TH CENTURY, VELVET was velvet, silk was silk, lace was lace and men were men - no matter how elaborately they adorned themselves in luxurious trimmings. A hundred years later, the finery of French court dressing had given way to the simplicity of the English squire, whose coarse tweeds and woolens set the tone for a new definition of masculine attire. ''The choices for men became narrower,'' says Claudia Brush Kidwell, costume curator for the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History and its current exhibition, ''Men and Women: A History of Costume, Gender and Power.'' Whereas decoration had once been the mark of male status and individuality, it grew to be associated with more-feminine flourishes. In time, says Kidwell, ''conformity to a very specific ideal became the standard. Men strove to dress in an acceptable manner, and what was acceptable was more codified, more uniform.''

title: Beatrice Daniels, I.B.M. Manager, Marries Banker
description: Beatrice Jean Daniels, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Daniels of White Plains, was married yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y., to Michael Louis Zion, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benson Zion of Havertown, Pa. Justice Thomas A. Facelle of State Supreme Court in White Plains officiated.

title:
FOCUS: Nashua, N.H.;
Fabricating Rentals in an Old Mill Town
description: LEAD: SINCE the completion last January of the conversion of a 160-year-old mill here that is on the National Register of Historic Places, all but a handful of its 143 apartments have been rented and this city considers the success of the project, called Clocktower Place, a major step in revitalizing its downtown.

title: The N.F.L.'s Painful Profit Crunch
description: It is a curious enterprise: an intercity alliance of 28 monopolies, blessed by Congress and invariably ruled by fabulously rich capitalists, bound up in its own form of socialism. Yet the National Football League is as much a part of everyday American life as apple pie, Coca-Cola and Disney World.

title: A Soprano Who Feels She Can Say No
description: ''I really consider myself in semi-retirement now,'' says the soprano June Anderson. It is an odd comment for a 36-year-old singer who is about to make her debut as Gilda on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera in a new production of ''Rigoletto,'' with Leo Nucci and Luciano Pavarotti and designed by Zack Brown and staged by Otto Schenk. However, stories emanating from Europe have prepared one for such unorthodox comments by a singer who has quickly been building a reputation not only for her voice, but for her frank and often controversial remarks and behavior.

title: Patricia Collins Weds
description: Patricia Jean Collins, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Kelly Collins of Lee, Mass., was married yesterday to Kevin Gerard Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bradley Taylor Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Revs. Francis X. Murphy, Eugene O'Brien and Phillip O'Shea performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Lenox, Mass. Mrs. Taylor, a graphic design manager for the American Express Travel Related Services Company in New York, graduated from Wheaton College. Mr. Taylor, a graduate of Holy Cross College, is a project manager at the Tishman Construction Corporation in New York.

title: Individualism That Promises Fun
description: THE Jersey City Museum's ''Two Arks, a Palace, Some Robots and Mr. Freedom's Fabulous Fifty Acres'' will be fun for most of its viewers. Dominating the show is a wolf-sized dog made entirely out of automobile engine parts, by William Clark. Titled ''Junkyard Dog,'' but looking infinitely meaner than the real thing, the creature stands with its jaws ajar to reveal huge white-painted fangs.

title: Miss Goldstein Weds A. R. Edelstein
description: The marriage of Karen Ellen Goldstein and Anthony Robert Edelstein, both graduates of the University of Pennsylvania, took place last evening at the Columbia University Faculty House in New York. Cantor Lisa Hest performed the ceremony. The bride, who received an M.B.A. degree from New York University, is a direct-mail manager at Citicorp in New York. She is a daughter of Marilyn Goldstein of Port Washington, L.I., a columnist for Newsday in Melville, L.I., and of Capt. Robert J. Goldstein of Cliffside Park, N.J., a retired United Airlines pilot.

title: Jets Just Lack What It Takes
description: The bare-bones statistics give a bleak picture of the Jets, and hint at perhaps an even worse future.

title: Beijing Welcomes 'Old Friend' Nixon, Hoping for Thaw With U.S.
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon arrived today for a visit of about six days in which he will meet with top Chinese leaders, and although it is billed as an unofficial fact-finding trip, both the United States and China seem to hope that it will help smooth relations.

title: Rita M. Jakeway Becomes a Bride
description: Rita Mary Jakeway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Jakeway Jr. of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Skinner Bigelow 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bigelow 3d of Landgrove, Vt. The Rev. Patrick Walsh performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Li Edelkoort: Trend Forecaster
description: LEAD: According to Li Edelkoort's calendar, it is now the winter of 1991-92. Concern for the environment is the primary fashion influence, and people are wearing rustic, natural fabrics that look hand-knit or primitive woven tweeds that Ms. Edelkoort defines as Ec-Coco: half ecology and half Coco Chanel.

title: One Goal, Two Styles in New York City: Catered Party
description: I USED TO STAY UP LATE AND DO A LOT OF the cooking myself - I love to cook,'' Mavis Taintor admitted before her guests arrived for a Wednesday night cocktail party she and her husband, Zebulon, gave in their Upper East Side brownstone. But, she said, ''I work at a very demanding job, and I have three children, and that's where I put my energy.''

title: A Late Kick Pulls Yale Ahead
description: A 27-yard field goal with 10 seconds to play gave Yale a 23-22 victory over Penn today. Ed Perks booted the line-drive kick that just cleared the crossbar as the Elis captured the Ivy League contest.

title: 9 Remain in Hospitals After Rioting at Prison
description: Nine of the 133 people injured in rioting at the state prison here this week remained in hospitals today. Two guards and three inmates were released.

title: Asharoken, Long Losing Sand, Getting Aid in Erosion Fight
description: LEAD: FOR the last 20 years, the once-abundant beach at Asharoken on Long Island Sound has sustained severe sand loss. Now the residents of this remote North Shore community, with about 70 houses on the Sound, are receiving help from the United States Army Corps of Engineers in their fight against erosion.

title: Murder Trial Offers DNA Test
description: THE use of DNA as evidence in identifying crime suspects will come under scrutiny tomorrow, when a hearing begins in Nassau County Court in Mineola to determine its admissibility in a murder trial.

title: In Newtown, Going to the Movies Is Still a Bargain
description: LEAD: IMAGINE walking into an elegant 560-seat movie theater with a balcony, upholstered seats and pillars framing the screen. Throw in ''Gone With the Wind,'' a 50-cent candy bar and a $2 ticket.

title: Spotlight On Artists From Asia
description: FOR several years Asia has been providing an astounding number of remarkable young musicians. The opening of cultural doors and a strong sense of discipline are often credited, and the number of musicians of Asian heritage in the United States is increasing.

title: POSTINGS: 51 Low-Cost Houses; 2-Families
description: More than two years after New York City began the nation's largest low- and moderate-income housing program, construction is moving at full throttle. In one recent initiative, work is nearing completion on El Rosario, a complex of 51 two-family homes in a blighted industrial section of the East Williamsburg neighborhood in Brooklyn.

title: A Footnote On Sketching Trips
description: The Society of Illustrators notes your recent article on the exhibition at the New Rochelle Arts Association [ ''Graphic Art's Glory Days in New Rochelle,'' Oct. 1 ] . Many of the society's members will be represented.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
Cruise Ships Decked to the Nines
description: LEAD: A GROWING fleet of new luxury cruise ships is making it possible for anyone who has the wherewithal to indulge in the sybaritic pleasures that were once exclusive to private yachts or to those who occupied elegant suites on trans-Atlantic liners.

title: Anne D. Campion Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of Our Savior in Brookline, Mass., Anne D. Campion, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander T. Daignault of Boston, was married yesterday to Curtis Hartman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Hartman of Aurora, Ohio. The Rev. William A. Spurrier 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Japan Moves Toward Modest Aid for Poland
description: Prodded by the United States and other Western democracies, Japan is moving cautiously toward approving a modest program of aid for Poland. It would be the first time that Tokyo has provided economic assistance to a nation in the Eastern bloc.

title: Baseball Adds To Quake Aid
description: Baseball's $1.4 million contribution to the Northern California Earthquake Relief Fund breaks down this way: $50,000 from each of 24 clubs and $100,000 each from the two Bay Area teams, the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: Yes, yes, yes. Call the Series off. Schedule the remaining games one week before the opening of the 1990 season. JOSEPH A. KRYPEL Wolcott, Vt.

title: SOME FOLKS ARE MORE REAL THAN OTHERS
description: LEAD: THE EXAMINED LIFE Philosophical Meditations. By Robert Nozick. 308 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: THE PEST CAN'T THEM DOWN
description: GARMENTS THE LIVING WEAR By James Purdy. 152 pp. San Francisco: City Lights Books. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: Mediation Can Aid Children in Divorce
description: Janice Cohn and Gary Skoloff are certainly on the right track (''Children Can Survive a Divorce,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 24) when they say that non-adversarial settings afford parents an opportunity to constructively consider the needs of their children instead of fighting over them in a courtroom.

title: CRACK AND RACIAL TENSIONS
description: ''Taking advantage of lax gun laws in Texas, Florida and Virginia,'' writes Michael Massing in his article, the dealers ''have stockpiled Uzis and AR-15 assault rifles.'' If this is true, it gives the lie to those who piously maintain that people, not guns, kill, and that, therefore, gun-control laws do not work. MANFRED WEIDHORN New York, N.Y.

title: Of Wigs And Wigmakers
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Upheaval in the Quiet Zone'
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. KING'S BEST FRIEND
description: AND THE WALLS CAME TUMBLING DOWN An Autobiography. By Ralph David Abernathy. Illustrated. 638 pp. New York: Harper & Row.

title: Dan Wickenden, Author and Editor, Dies at 76
description: Dan Wickenden, an author and retired senior editor at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the book publisher, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 76 years old.

title: Grovey Powers Arkansas Past Houston
description: The Arkansas quarterback, Quinn Grovey, accounted for 335 yards in total offense, third-best in school history, and had five touchdowns tonight as the 13th-ranked Razorbacks remained in the Southwest Conference race with a 45-39 victory over 12th-ranked Houston.

title: Diver Battles Illinois Over 2 Lake Michigan Wrecks
description: A salvage expert who discovered two 19th century steamers at the bottom of Lake Michigan is battling the state for control of the wrecks.

title: Allison Day Married to John B. Lanni
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Allison Balken Day, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney D. Day 3d of New York and Bryn Mawr, was married yesterday to John Bryenton Lanni, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Lanni of York, Me. The Rev. Mark H. Andrus officiated.

title: Don't Waste Time Planning - Act
description: American managers should reject the barrage of criticism they receive for focusing so much on short-term results. Instead, they should concentrate on doing a much better job on those short-term results. Traditionally, our greatest strength is the ''let's do it,'' ''let's try it'' attitude. This American penchant for quick successes and quick rewards dovetails with the pressure for results that most American managers face. Why fight that reality when we can take advantage of it? Concentration on short-term goals need not be at the expense of long-term perspective. In fact, imaginative, longer range planning is best created while working toward immediate results.

title: Sound Coalition Filed No Suits
description: As an organization committed to the protection of the Sound, the Long Island Sound Task Force welcomed the article ''The Sea That Unites Also Divides'' (Sept. 24). We want to clarify a statement in the accompanying article, ''The Watch From the Shore: A Who's Who for Long Island Sound,'' that the Connecticut Coastal Coalition, of which the task force is a member, has taken legal action against municipalities.

title: In Bach, Enlightenment Without Illumination
description: The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment is the latest of London's recombinant early-instrument groups, peopled with musicians familiar to anyone who has scanned the rosters of the English Concert, the Academy of Ancient Music and other ensembles. As with most such groups, the roster expands and contracts as the music requires.

title: Tending the Greenbelt Trail
description: I CALLED my friend Joan the other day. ''I think it's time we hit the trail again,'' I said. She agreed. We're not planing to pack our bags annd skip town. Instead, we'll pack a lunch, grab our pruning shears and a supply of garbage bags and head for Massapequa State Park.

title: ELECTION PLANNED BY AFGHAN REBELS
description: A visiting delegation of the Afghan rebels' government in exile in Pakistan has announced plans to hold some form of election in Afghanistan before Feb. 15.

title: It Can Happen There
description: Suppose the people of some small American town decided to protest Federal Government policy by withholding their taxes. The Government responded by sending in the Army.

title: Supersecrecy of a Capital Drug Trial Is Extended to the Jurors
description: The courtroom where Rayful Edmond 3d and 10 others are on trial has become a testing ground for new and troubling legal issues that arise in the prosecution of suspected drug lords who are feared in the communities from which juries are drawn.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Homemade Corn Bread Ready-Mix
description: The nostalgia food faction has not only returned regional American foods to their rightful place in the regions from which they come, it has also introduced the rest of the country to some of these wonderful old dishes that have been loved for generations for good reason.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FROM RUSSIA, WITH ART

title: Art Meets Life for a Vietnamese Actress
description: It's probably fair to say that just about nothing in Kieu Chinh's life has turned out as she expected. Ms. Chinh did not anticipate leaving her native Hanoi when she was 14. Certainly she could not have imagined that she would become, in the late 1960's, South Vietnam's most famous female movie star and television talk show hostess, voted, in 1972, the most popular actress of Asia at the Asian Film Festival. She didn't know that she would come to Los Angeles in 1975 after the fall of Saigon and have to start over again as a bit player who was once a big star. She had no particular reason to think that, after 15 years of what can only be described as obscure struggling in the back lots of Hollywood, a real career would begin again to take shape.

title: Tearing at the Deep Roots of Protectionism
description: AS the Bush Administration sought in Geneva last week to push the world toward a freer agricultural economy, it was facing opposition not only from Europe but from some important farm interests at home. The problem is that the United

title: Was English At Shortstop?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A New Frontier At the Bottom of the Sea
description: LEAD: WITH its black lights, fluorescent color and bizarre shapes, the Maritime Center in Norwalk's new exhibition, ''Underwater Exploration,'' on view through April, is as festive as a circus. Adding to its impact is the opening of two new films in their Imax Theater: ''The Great Barrier Reef,'' an adventure in an empire of coral reefs, islands and sheltered seas, and ''We Are Born of Stars,'' a three-dimensional journey through the solar system into a D

title: Blood Donations And Cholesterol Tests
description: The article ''A Night for Singles at a Blood Center'' (Sept. 24) was an excellent illustration of how far a little imagination can go in attracting new blood donors.

title: Further Delay Urged for New Mexico Nuclear Waste Dump
description: An already delayed underground nuclear-waste dump in New Mexico, which the Energy Department now hopes to open by 1992 to end a crisis in plutonium disposal, should be delayed two or three more years to insure proper safety testing, a panel of advisers has told the department.

title: BRAWLING OVER HARRODS
description: When my brothers and I bought Europe's biggest department-store company, House of Fraser, including Harrods, we paid cash (''Brawling Over Harrods,'' by Steve Lohr, Oct. 8). We paid $:4 ($4.28) a share. It was a good price, and the shareholders were happy to accept our money. They went their way rejoicing. The biggest shareholder of all, Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland made a $:70 million ($74.9 million) profit, and, to the best of my belief, he has never come round to Knightsbridge offering me that money back.

title: Corrections
description: A television review of ABC's ''The Final Days'' in the Arts and Leisure section today misattributes a remark quoted in the second paragraph.

title: INSIDE
description: Making Nuclear Site Safe

title: What's Keeping Us From Building New Cities; Princeton and Irvine
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonnie Margolin, Teacher, Is Wed
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue, Bonnie Lee Margolin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Margolin of Great Neck, was married yesterday to Dr. Simon Cheirif, a son of Rachel Cheirif-Kuriansky of Mexico City, and the late Benito Cheirif. Rabbis Dale Polakoff and Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: Xavier Rousseau: Jewelry Designer
description: Xavier Rousseau might be described as an updater. For 12 years, he was involved in Les Must de Cartier, including the development of the Santos watch (which he still wears), leathers, crystal, silver, china and scarves.

title: Magazine to Print Lost Stevenson Story
description: An unpublished and nearly forgotten story by Robert Louis Stevenson will appear in the fall issue of the Georgia Review, the University of Georgia's literary magazine announced today.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Grand Central Viaduct; An $8 Million Revival for a Midtown Masterpiece
description: IT'S one of those things one doesn't really notice, fading as it does into the familiar background of midtown. But the 1919 Park Avenue viaduct, running between 40th and 42d Streets, will begin to stand out again next year as an $8 million restoration by the Grand Central Partnership re-establishes the structure - including the roadway hugging the terminal - as a central focus for the Grand Central area.

title: What's Keeping Us From Building New Cities; Part of the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: CAN ELENI'S HUSBAND BE FORGIVEN?
description: A PLACE FOR US By Nicholas Gage. Illustrated. 419 pp. Boston: A Marc Jaffe Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER
description: THE DARK HALF By Stephen King. 431 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayville $230,000 22 Highland View Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, h/w floors, deck, patio; taxes $2,500. Glen Cove $200,000 16 Tulane Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Hicksville $148,000 3 Jordan Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,500. Islip $96,000 100 Wilson Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. Levittown $134,500 88 Cord Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, unfinished attic, carport; taxes $2,800. Sea Cliff $365,000 127 17th Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 96-year-old Victorian; sun room, fireplace, stained-glass windows, widow's walk; taxes $1,600. OTHER AREAS Stamford, Conn. $305,000 210 Rockrimmon Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; pond, h/w floors, 1 acre; taxes $3,638. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $328,000 Hunter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, screened porch, 1-car garage; taxes $5,656. Lakewood, N.J. $105,000 75 Columbus Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old ranch; patio, dining room, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $1,381.

title: Japan's Emperor Of Film
description: WE THAT IS TO SAY, A GROUP OF Japanese journalists and I - were waiting for Akira Kurosawa. It was February, the week of Emperor Hirohito's funeral, and the director was to hold a press conference about his new film, ''Akira Kurosawa's Dreams,'' shot in various locations around Japan. It is to be released next spring.

title: Teen-Age Dateland: Risky Country
description: TEEN-AGERS, since time began, have always been ''cooler'' than their parents. They know, on an experiential level, tons more about drugs, danger, depression, music, fashion and what's playing in the movies. They take risks, accept challenges, try out new behavior.

title: NO CHANGE IS SEEN AT SPANISH HELM
description: In the fifth general election since democracy returned here in 1975, Spaniards go to the polls on Sunday fully expecting that Felipe Gonzalez will be returned as Prime Minister but less happy with that prospect than they have been in the past.

title: A Love Affair With Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Real Senior

title: No Suits Filed By Sound Coalition
description: As an organization committed to the protection of the Sound, the Long Island Sound Task Force welcomed the article ''The Sea That Unites Also Divides'' (Sept. 24). We want to clarify a statement in the accompanying article, ''The Watch From the Shore: A Who's Who for Long Island Sound,'' that the Connecticut Coastal Coalition, of which the task force is a member, has taken legal action against municipalities.

title: Outdoors; Help for the Atlantic Salmon
description: One of the world's most highly regarded game and food fishes, the beleaguered Atlantic salmon is also a symbol of pure, free-flowing rivers.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If the Congress of the United States stops financing the counterrevolutionaries, then we will unilaterally declare a truce.'' - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [ 1:5. ]

title: ON THE TRAIL OF THE PARANORMAL
description: WHAT does someone do when he hears footsteps or muffled conversation and no one is there? Perhaps he has been touched by an unseen hand or knows of a room where an icy chill exists the year round. Many people have called in A. J. Rauber of North Brunswick, a self-described investigator of paranormal activity.

title: Burger King's Big Comeback Bid
description: The Burger King Corporation is at a point of reckoning.

title: Paul Dwyer WedsMary Sue Howley
description: Mary Sue Howley, a Daughter of Mrs. Peter D. Howley of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Howley, was married there yesterday to Paul Gerard Dwyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Dwyer of New York. The Rev. Edward F. Maloney officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: ECONOMICS: READING YOUR WAY OUT OF CHAOS
description: Economics has long accommodated dozens of schools of thought. But in the last decade or so, it has become more like physics or chemistry, disciplines so broad and so complicated that, within the field, one group of specialists barely speaks the same language as the Ph.D.'s across the hall. And so much of what is published seems more to proselytize for an ideology than to make sense of the chaotic world inhabited by economists. It's no wonder that a single economic development can be interpreted as a godsend or a disaster, depending on the interpreter's frame of reference.

title: About Men; Goodbye Thoreau, Hello Astaire
description: THAT'S GOOD CLOTH,''

title: Finding Strength In Compassion
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jazz and Mavericks Set To Challenge Lakers
description: The following Western Conference preview was prepared and written by Cliff Brown. Midwest Division

title: Clashes With Police at Gay Conference at Yale
description: A man was arrested Friday night after putting up sexually explicit posters at Yale University, leading to a confrontation between the police and hundreds of people attending a conference on homosexual issues.

title: LONELY AT THE TOP
description: ARMAND HAMMER The Untold Story. By Steve Weinberg. Illustrated. 501 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: A New Mayor, Just in Time For the Hard Time After the Boom
description: A FEW months ago Felix G. Rohatyn caused a stir when he told the City Club that he believed New York may be heading for a period even more painful than the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.

title:
ART;
Displaying Works Of Black Pioneers
description: LEAD: DURING the 1920's, America's first black opera star began to assemble a collection of historical and contemporary art representing the contributions of African-Americans to visual expression.

title: 13 Are Wounded in Gunfight At Flatbush Birthday Party
description: Thirteen people were wounded in a gunfight at dawn yesterday at an all-night birthday party in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Harvard; Two Fraternities Set Up Operations Near a Campus
description: The Dean of Students says Harvard University does not have a fraternity program. Two such groups, however, exist off campus.

title: When the Villain is Colonialism: Two Shows Explore Oppression
description: ''Evil Empires'' at the Longwood Arts Gallery, and ''Consciousness Raising Art'' at the Bronx River Arts Center and Gallery, are separate but equal. Both shows are about oppression but the first treats the subject generally while the second addresses one of its aspects, apartheid.

title: Up From Africa, Down From the Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: DAMAGE CONTROL DIDN'T WORK
description: THE FALL OF THE HOUSE OF HUTTON By Donna Sammons Carpenter and John Feloni. 322 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95. SUDDEN DEATH The Rise and Fall of E. F. Hutton. By Mark Stevens. 298 pp. New York: NAL Books/New American Library. $19.95.

title: Milwaukeeans Seek to Stem Rising Violence
description: Earlier this month the city broke its record of 95 homicides in a year, set in 1987. This year, one of drive-by shootings, drug-running and nightly gunfire, is being called the year of 100 murders.

title: The Road From Pulpit to Prison
description: Jim Bakker, the television evangelist, apparently had no intention of waiting for the afterlife to get his taste of the good life. With his PTL ministry bringing in $100 million a year at its peak, the boyish Mr. Bakker indulged in expensive homes, cars and companionship, mostly with his ministry's money. Mr. Bakker, meet Judge Robert Potter. In sentencing Mr. Bakker last week to 45 years in prison and a $500,000 fine for fraud and conspiracy, Judge Potter severely tongue-lashed the erstwhile cleric. ''Those of us who do have religion are sick of being saps for money-grubbing preachers and priests,'' said Judge Potter. The main charges against Mr. Bakker -he was accused of selling his followers more vacations at his Heritage USA Christian resort than he could provide - emerged in investigations that began after Jessica Hahn, a former church secretary, said in 1987 that she had been paid $265,000 to keep quiet about a sexual encounter with him. While the verdict is being appealed, Mr. Bakker will be sitting in a Federal prison in Minnesota. He will be eligible for parole in 10 years.

title: Economic Miracle
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas; Gambling Den Off Campus Shut, Austin Police Say
description: When vice squad officers raided a suspected gambling den near the University of Texas, the ring was said to be handling $100,000 a weekend in sports bets.

title: Changing Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Gershwin: 'Porgy and Bess' Cynthia Haymon, Harolyn Blackwell, Cynthia Clarey, sopranos; Damon Evans, tenor; Willard White, Gregg Baker, baritones; Glyndebourne Opera Chorus, London Symphony conducted by Simon Rattle. Angel 49568; three CD's and cassettes. Those who have long and justly championed ''Porgy'' as a great opera may find its recent accession to the mainstream a mixed vindication. ''Porgy'' has made the Met at last; Glyndebourne has treated it as a masterpiece; the present recording (stemming from Glyndebourne) is the third full-score, major-label effort. It makes a stronger case than did this year's lugubrious Met revival, but the work sounds more dated and less sure-footed than we had hoped. As song succeeds song and ensemble climax succeeds ensemble climax, one begins to feel as earlier producers did: This needs cutting. It also needs a brisker stride; Simon Rattle's love of the score is apparent in the lush textures, but also in indulgent tempos. There is polish and care in the singing and playing and much spirit in quick numbers. And some of the voices are beautiful. But the whole feels overinflated. - Will Crutchfield Gubaidulina: 'Offertorium,' 'Hommage a T. S. Eliot' Gidon Kremer, violin; Boston Symphony conducted by Charles Dutoit (''Offertorium''); Christine Whittlesey, soprano (''Hommage''). Deutsche Grammophon 427 336; CD only. No less admirable than Gidon Kremer's superb artistry are the varied uses to which it is put. Mr. Kremer has performed tremendous service on behalf of living composers, notably the Russians Alfred Schnittke and Sofia Gubaidulina. He has played ''Offertorium'' (1980), Miss Gubaidulina's deconstruction of the ''royal'' theme from Bach's ''Musical Offering,'' with several American orchestras, and it's good, finally, to have a representative account on record. The coupling with the Eliot ''Hommage'' (1987), for soprano and instrumental octet, makes for a well-filled disk (69:05) of challenging and rewarding contemporary music. Like the violinist, this inventive composer merits close attention. - James R. Oestreich Grieg: 'Peer Gynt' Excerpts Barbara Hendricks, soprano; Oslo Philharmonic Chorus and Orchestra conducted by Esa-Pekka Salonen. CBS Masterworks 44528; CD and cassette. ''I am sure my music has a taste of codfish in it,'' said Edvard Grieg once, and it's certainly true of this most consciously Nordic of his scores. (He tended in his later years to regard it as a youthful indiscretion.) Esa-Pekka Salonen, who has moved from strength to strength in the Scandinavian repertoire, leads a fresh, idiomatic performance of these well-chosen excerpts (all the major numbers, and several less familiar ones), and Barbara Hendricks sings the ballads with her usual mastery and charm. - Barrymore L. Scherer Schuman: Violin Concerto; Bernstein: Serenade Robert McDuffie, violin; St. Louis Symphony conducted by Leonard Slatkin. Angel CDC 7 49464-2; CD only. Americans haven't, for some reason, produced many great violin concertos. Only the Barber has become well known, but William Schuman's strong-fisted, deeply felt concerto and Leonard Bernstein's oddly seductive pseudo-symphonic poem about love and Plato for solo violin, strings, harp and percussion, both first performed in the early 50's, are candidates for wider renown. And Robert McDuffie, an ardent young violinist from Georgia with technique to burn, may just be the soloist they have been waiting for. His impassioned but utterly solid readings generate maximum excitement in the fast sections and make splendid rhapsodies out of the lyric moments and cadenzas. Leonard Slatkin and his band underscore with their usual lapel-grabbing vivacity. - Mark Swed Oliveros-Dempster-Panaiotis: 'Deep Listening' Pauline Oliveros, accordion; Stuart Dempster, trombone; Panaiotis, vocals. New Albion NA-022; CD only. In October 1988, the composer-accordionist Pauline Oliveros, the composer-trombonist Stuart Dempster and the composer-vocalist Panaiotis descended into an abandoned underground water cistern in Washington State to use the enormously resonant acoustical space as an environment for group improvisation. The result is ''Deep Listening,'' an astonishing aural experience. Capitalizing on a 45-second reverberation time, the performers build up long, eerie drones that echo long after they have moved on to new material; slowly the drones and melodic arabesques coalesce into luminous clouds of sound, by turns meditative, ritualistic or enraptured. ''Deep Listening'' asks only that listeners relinquish Western notions of directionality and climax; those who do will be richly rewarded. - K. Robert Schwarz POP/JAZZ Peter Stampfel and the Bottle Caps: 'The People's Republic of Rock 'n' Roll' Homestead HMS 133; all three formats. An insouciant combination of oddball folk and wry rock, this is the former Holy Modal Rounder Peter Stampfel's second album with his band, the Bottle Caps. Mr. Stampfel uses punk yowls, surf music and reggae as specialized tools of eccentric expression, not sales pitches. His frail, amiably cracked voice in tandem with his capering fiddle work helps banish archness from smart jokes like the satire of Top-40 uplift ''When Things Come True,'' and ''Bridge and Tunnel Girls,'' a cheeky Manhattan reply to the Beach Boys' ''California Girls.'' Any savvy listener should be tickled by some of the fancies here. - Milo Miles Billy Joel: 'Storm Front' Columbia 44366; all three formats. Mr. Joel's first studio album in three years is his bounciest record since ''Glass Houses'' in 1980. Produced by Mick Jones (the lead guitarist for Foreigner) instead of Mr. Joel's regular partner Phil Ramone, it has a muddier English art-rock flavor than his other records. Its catchiest cut is the almost-rap song ''We Didn't Start the Fire,'' in which the 40-year-old singer lists 40 years of news headlines. Its strongest ballad, ''Leningrad,'' is a personal vignette about the easing of cold-war tensions, and ''The Downeaster 'Alexa' '' sympathizes with Long Island fishermen whose grounds are being depleted. Although the album lacks the consistency of Mr. Joel's most ambitious record, ''The Nylon Curtain,'' it still has plenty of verve and personality. - Stephen Holden Poi Dog Pondering: 'Poi Dog Pondering' Columbia 45335; all three formats. Late-1980's pessimism hasn't reached Poi Dog Pondering, a band that keeps on the sunny side. It's nominally a rock group (from Hawaii by way of Athens, Ga.), but one that also pulls out trumpet or accordion or tin whistle as needed, in songs that smile through daily ups and downs, from the pleasures of toast and jelly to the uncertainties of romance. The group updates hippie eclecticism with touches of 1980's world-beat; for all their dexterity, the songs sound like impromptu sing-alongs. ''Poi Dog Pondering,'' the band's first major-label album, simply combines its two independently released EPs, preserving their homespun charm. - Jon Pareles Shelly Hirsch and David Weinstein: 'Haiku Lingo' Review Records 139; LP only (available from Lunch for Your Ears, 25 Prince St., New York, N. Y. 10012). Few groups can meander as wildly as Ms. Hirsch and Mr. Weinstein do and still sustain a listener's interest. Ms. Hirsch, an extraordinary vocalist and a major figure on the downtown scene, chatters and talks and sings and mimics different languages, interacting with Mr. Weinstein's keyboards and electronics. Techno-pop gets a parody; she'll mumble through an ostensibly serious section of a piece, European classical music is reduced to a rubble, and all musical genres are used for their references, not their forms. Through everything runs Ms. Hirsch's personality, enormously inventive, scathingly satiric and virtuosic. - Peter Watrous 'Paul Motian on Broadway,' Vol. 1 JMT 834430-2; all three formats. This is Bill Frisell's year. After a sensational solo album, the guitarist walks away with this date, designed to highlight the drummer Paul Motian. To songs by Kern, Gershwin, Porter and Arlen, Mr. Frisell adds a country twang, his ghostly, reverbed chords sounding intimate and far away, as though picked up from a radio signal long ago. Mr. Motian's penchant for slow tempos and open textures creates a discreet but subdued atmosphere, as though no one should speak out. But on ''Someone to Watch Over Me'' his expert brush work, joined to Charlie Hayden's bass and Joe Lovano's quiet saxophone, sets off one of Mr. Frisell's best solos on record. - Richard B. Woodward

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: TERRENCE M. HINES;
Seeing is Believing? Not Really
description: LEAD: THIS is the season for ghosts and witches and haunted houses. If it's just for fun, there's nothing wrong with ''believing,'' said Terence M. Hines, the Pace University associate psychology professor who wrote the book ''Pseudoscience and the Paranormal'' (Prometheus Books, 1988). But he believes there are many con artists out there ready to take advantage of people who truly believe in ghosts, extrasensory perception, U.F.O.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hanover, N.H.;
Housing Boom For the Elderly
description: LEAD: THE growth in the over-65 population is fueling a boom in retirement housing throughout the state. One of the most ambitious continuing-care projects is being developed by the nonprofit Kendal Corporation of Kennett Square, Pa., operated by the Society of Friends.

title: STREET FIGHTING FEMINIST
description: LETTERS FROM A WAR ZONE Writings 1976-1989. By Andrea Dworkin. 337 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Where to Get More Details
description: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).

title: Seeking Tolerance in the Wake of Bias Crime
description: CRIMES committed against people because of their religious, racial or ethnic background are dramatically lower in the county so far this year compared with the same period last year, county police statistics indicate.

title: Correction
description: A list last Sunday of people prosecuted in theWedtech case misstated the job of a Postal Service employee. The employee, Jerrydoe E. Smith, was a contract specialist in the Postal Operations Procurement Division, not a postal inspector.

title: NEW ORLEANS KITCHEN SESSION
description: When Leonard Salvato, an architect based in New Orleans, began to think about building a house, he turned for inspiration to memories of his childhood home. Mr. Salvato grew up in the San Francisco Bay area where, he said, his large and gregarious Spanish and Italian family treated cooking as a team sport and meals as spontaneous, guess-who's-coming-to-dinner sorts of affairs. ''It was a great place to hang out,'' he recalled. ''It was constant open house, with friends and relatives dropping in, and always lots of good, simple food.'' An environment for that kind of relaxed entertaining was what he hoped to create in his new home.

title:
SERGEANTSVILLE JOURNAL;
An Entire Town Joins In to Stage Annual House Tour
description: LEAD: THANKSGIVING in the country conjures images of the nation's Colonial heritage. It is a time to reap the bounty of the autumn harvest from cornfields, apple orchards and pumpkin patches. It is a time for snuggling before fireplaces, dining in romantic inns and enjoying the crisp winds that fan through century-old maples.

title: Real Estate Signs Unsettling Greenwich
description: LEAD: PROLIFERATING ''For Sale'' signs in front of houses have become the target of individuals and groups who say they are a blight and must be controlled.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Trenton State Rally Produces 31-31 Tie
description: Darin Roberts, a quarterback, scored on a 7-yard run as time ran out, and Scott Osborne kicked the extra point, enabling Trenton State to gain a 31-31 tie with Montclair State yesterday.

title: Community Control Goes Awry in a City School Board
description: LAST week a panel investigating corruption in New York City public schools heard startling tapes made by a Queens school superintendent talking with members of his local board. But just as important as what was said was what was not said.

title: Angolan Resists U.S. Effort on Peace Talks
description: Angola will not soften its attitude to rebels because of pressure from Washington, the Angolan President, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, said today.

title: Walker Happy as A Viking
description: Herschel Walker is coming home.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: The 19th century brought curious items to numismatics, coins called struck copies. They filled a need for reproductions of some American Colonial coins and different die makers created pieces that were faithful copies of the originals. These copies were openly advertised and sold to collectors and museums.

title: Experts Examine A Rare Ailment
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, 5-year-old Lucas Moustaka of Setauket was getting ready for bed when his brother noticed a lump the size of a golf ball on the side of his neck.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Real Swan Lake

title: When the Sun Set on the Nixon Presidency
description: In a pivotal scene in ABC's ''Final Days,'' Richard M. Nixon becomes a character out of Samuel Beckett. It is early May 1974. The Watergate scandal has reached a boiling point, and Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski has taken legal action to wrest more White House tapes from the President. Retreating to his home in San Clemente, Calif., Mr. Nixon begins listening to the tapes again.

title: Drug Evictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Jams
description: To the Editor: If what you're looking for on your vacation is a massive, chronic traffic jam, I've just the place for you: State Highway 16 going through Conway and North Conway, New Hampshire both northbound and southbound.

title: Long Talks Bring Child Rights Charter to U.N.
description: After 10 years of negotiations, the first comprehensive Convention on the Rights of the Child is expected before the General Assembly for approval next month.

title: Where Are the Innovators Of Today?
description: ''For young artists to follow in the footsteps of titans is not a particularly happy lot,'' Walter Terry wrote in 1971 in his history ''The Dance in America.'' ''Thus it is with a new generation of modern dancers, with those who came after Graham, Humphrey and their fellow pioneers and who were forced not only to follow but also to attempt to rival the continuing creativeness and, in some instances, the performing magnitude of the master. The titans had made the break with the past, evolved new principles, battled convention, won the rebellion. What was left to be done?''

title: Unclogging a Pop-Up Drain
description: POP-UP drains, the kind operated by raising a vertical rod in the center of the faucet, are common on bathroom sinks. Although convenient to use, these drains clog easily because the opening in the bottom of the sink cannot be screened. Also, the plug mechanism frequently slips out of adjustment.

title: Hemond Rewarded
description: The Baltimore Orioles yesterday extended the contract of Roland Hemond, the team's general manager, and gave him the added title of executive vice president. In 1988, Hemond's first season as general manager, the Orioles had a 54-107 record. Fortunately for Hemond, he had a two-year contract, and this year the team finished at 87-75, coming within a hair of the American League East pennant. The 32 1/2-game improvement was the second-best year-to-year gain in major league history, outdone only by the 1945-46 Boston Red Sox.

title: N.F.L. Picks, In Overtime
description: If the teams of the National Football League took as long to select a play as their team owners took to pick a commissioner, sportscasters would be talking about the seven-month instead of the two-minute drill. Last week, after three meetings in three cities and 11 ballots, the owners chose Paul J. Tagliabue (above), a Washington lawyer, as the league's seventh commissioner. He succeeds Pete Rozelle, who announced his retirement last March after 30 years. The delay was caused by objections from newer team owners who felt that the league's longstanding owners, who constituted the original search committee, were trying to rush the selection of Jim Finks, the president of the New Orleans Saints. Mr. Tagliabue, who is 48 years old, is no walk-on, having worked on N.F.L. legal matters for 20 years. Noting that he had worked with all the league's teams, he said, ''I hope now that we can talk about the games and competition instead of the old guard and the new guard.''

title: Nancy Demmon Wed To George Fowlkes Jr.
description: At the Menlo Park (Calif.) Presbyterian Church, Nancy Bailey Demmon and George Allen Fowlkes Jr. were married yesterday in a ceremony performed by the Rev. James Larkin. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Demmon of Atherton, Calif., and Mr. and Mrs. Fowlkes of New York.

title: Gun-Related Slayings In Young Are Studied
description: About 1 in 10 people who die before the age of 20 is killed with a gun, the Government's National Center for Health Statistics says.

title: THE CASE OF THE HOPELESS CASE
description: A STRANGER IN THE KINGDOM By Howard Frank Mosher. 421 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: U.S. Resolution on Armenians Angers Turks
description: The Turkish editorial cartoon may not have been a model of subtlety, but it made its point clearly.

title: Miss McPhillips Weds M. H. Allen
description: Maureen McPhillips and Dr. Michael Hall Allen were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. John F. McDermott performed the ceremony.

title: Prospects; Mr. Blumenthal's Troubles
description: Last year W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman of Unisys Inc., announced a strategy for the $10 billion company that he said would double its size by the mid-1990's. But the strategy is not working. The company's substantial debt has been downgraded, its inventories have increased and it has been reducing staff. On Friday it announced a huge third-quarter loss of $648.7 million. Four industry experts assess the nation's third-largest computer maker. Stephen P. Cohen Vice president and director of research, Soundview Financial Group Inc., Stamford, Conn.

title: Death and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukrainian Catholics Move Into the Open
description: For more than 40 years, Ukrainian Catholics have worshiped in secret gatherings held in the dense forests of the western Ukraine or behind drawn shades in the homes of believers.

title: POSTINGS: At Home, Off Course; 20 Condos
description: Howard Loewentheil, head of LFM Development Corporation of New Rochelle, N.Y., was so pleased with Fairway Greens - the Mamaroneck condominium project overlooking a golf course that he completed last year, with 50 of 54 units sold - that he decided to do a similar one in his home base.

title: THE FREEWAY DEAD: Portraits From Oakland - A special report.; 11 WHOSE LIVES ENDED AS QUAKE CRUSHED I-880
description: They were brought together by chance, by fate, by an act of God, some might say: 23 men, 15 women and a little boy. Strangers caught together in a terrifying moment as the earth's mantle shrugged, blithely shattering a fragile man-made structure, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland.

title: Couple Die in Fall From Train
description: An elderly California couple were killed in a fall from a moving Amtrak train today, the authorities said. Investigators were trying to determine the events that led to the deaths of Arthur Kohfeld, 87 years old, and his wife, Dorthea, 76, of Reedley, Calif., near Middle Point in northwest Ohio, the Van Wert County Sheriff's Department said. The Kohfelds were traveling on the overnight Broadway Limited from Chicago to New York when the incident happened at 1:30 A.M., the authorities said.

title: Musical Misers and Big Spenders
description: What ineluctable force impels one type of musician to work as tirelessly and prolifically as Schubert, while other, differently driven, artists jealously hoard their talents like Alberich guarding the Rheingold? Listening to Carlos Kleiber conduct ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan Opera the other evening, all the while trying not to blame him for being involved in the overdressed and underthought Franco Zeffirelli production, I diverted myself by speculating about that mystery.

title: Fashion; In New Sweaters, No Motif Goes Unknitted
description: Autumn is sweater season. Even mild October weather calls for something more than shirt sleeves. Soft knits are a nice change from tailored jackets, and will slip comfortably under coats when winter's chilly blasts move in.

title: Paper Says Lockerbie Bomb Possibly Originated in Malta
description: The police have found evidence that the bomb on Pan American Flight 103 that killed 270 people was planted in Malta, The Sunday Times of London reported.

title: The Social Cost Of Low Wages
description: The article dealing with the homeless problem in New Jersey was very timely (''State Grapples With Homelessness,'' Sept. 17). The reference made to the low wages and high cost of rent facing the poor in our state has been confirmed by many private agencies involved in aiding the homeless.

title: THE RISKS WEE TOO GOOD TO PASS UP
description: OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY The Inside Story of the S&L Mess. By Paul Zane Pilzer with Robert Deitz. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95. INSIDE JOB The Looting of America's Savings and Loans. By Stephen Pizzo, Mary Fricker and Paul Muolo. 443 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill. $19.95. THE S&L INSURANCE MESS How Did It Happen? By Edward J. Kane. 181 pp. Washington: The Urban Institute Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: Verdict Upheld In Assault Case Over Mercury
description: A New York State appeals court has reinstated the convictions of the owners of a Brooklyn thermometer factory who were found guilty by a jury of ''assault by a dangerous instrument'' for exposing workers to unsafe levels of mercury fumes.

title: Rangers Trounce Unhappy Islanders
description: The Rangers preserved their grasp on first place in the National Hockey League with a vengeance tonight at Nassau Coliseum as they crushed the Islanders, 4-1.

title: The Computer Buff's Bookshelf
description: Those executives who pay attention to computers (and of course all executives should) are more likely to worry about grand issues like productivity and small ones like how to make their personal printers handle envelopes than whether the K.G.B. has penetrated their companies. In a fresh crop of books, they will find lessons on all these matters.

title: Votes in Congress; Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: SENATE

title:
In the Heartland, Points of Light;
Advertising the Importance of School
description: LEAD: Just a few years ago, students in Pennsylvania's Monongahela Valley could count on following a generation-old tradition of working in the area's steel mills. But the decline in the steel industry, once the backbone of the greater Pittsburgh area's economy, has changed all that. The area's economy has become more diverse and largely information-based, and the chance for students to go on from school to work in the mills no longer exists.

title: Groucho: The Curmudgeon on Stage
description: A LEGEND creates problems for his or her subsequent biographers. Recreating a personality who, while living, was larger and more dramatic than life can reduce biographical sketches into pale imitations of the original.

title: INSIDE THE INTIFADA
description: AT MIDDAY THE WORD spreads among the young men of Husan: Gather at the usual place just after dark. And a little before 8 P.M., about 15 youths assemble at the prearranged spot. Their faces are covered by ski masks or checkered kaffiyehs, and each in turn utters the password, an Arabic letter difficult for Hebrew-speakers to pronounce. Satisfied that no strangers had infiltrated the group, they set off down the narrow streets and dirt alleys of this small West Bank village just south of Bethlehem, heading for the highway. In minutes, the settlers' bus will roll past, escorted by two jeeps full of soldiers.

title: Pastimes: Gardening; Tree Planting at Home Helps a National Effort
description: Home gardeners who have learned of the environmental threats posed by the greenhouse effect may not realize they can play a role in combating it.

title: Study Sees More U.S. Plea Bargains
description: The Federal prosecutor for the Southern District of New York brought more criminal cases per 100,000 people than United States Attorneys in 10 other districts, a study has found.

title: POLICE IN PRAGUE MOVE TO BREAK UP BIG PROTEST MARCH
description: Czechoslovakia's hard-line Government used heavily armed policemen today in an effort to crush protests by thousands of Czechoslovaks who marched in the capital calling for freedom and an end to Communism.

title: Lifestyle; Matchbooks With X-Rated Message Are Adding to Some Smokers' Woes
description: In what is fast becoming a smokeless society, the classier accoutrements of cigarette consumption have lost their allure. Ashtrays of crystal and marble, however handsome, have been banished from the coffee tables of reformed smokers who equate them with spittoons. Monogrammed silver cases and lighters, like the one Fred used to ignite Ginger's cigarette, now seem as quaint as snuff boxes.

title: As Ideology Dies, Analogies Rise
description: While much is utterly unpredictable - Mikhail Gorbachev's staying power, the limits of Soviet tolerance in the Baltic and Eastern Europe, China after Deng Xiaoping, the consequences of the European Community's move toward complete economic integration in 1992 - two international developments seem to have achieved a degree of probability approaching certainty.

title: Rueful Ruminations on Love in 'Bus Stop'
description: IF ''Bus Stop'' is to work with an all-black cast - and why can't it? - the American Stage Company is offering no clue as to just how it can.

title:
MUSIC;
A Special Homecoming For Pianist at Princeton
description: LEAD: A RECITAL by the pianist Robert Taub on Saturday night in Princeton will be more than a homecoming for Mr. Taub, a Princeton University graduate and a Metuchen native who is now a resident of New York City.

title: The Opium War
description: The argument about legalizing drugs has become passionate, for good reason. There is a certain intellectual appeal to the logic that suppression provokes the enormity of crime, corruption and irresistible riches that make enforcement so ineffective and so costly.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A citronella candle dripped melted wax onto the pressure-treated pine on our outside deck. We have tried removing this stain, but so far nothing has worked. Any suggestions?

title: Some Links to the Past in East Norwich
