description: IT was 1907 and Oyster Bay's Teddy Roosevelt was President. Nearby in East Norwich, a restaurant called Rothmann's opened its doors. After 63 years of ownership by the Rothmann family, followed by 19 years when it was known as Burt Bachrach's, the restaurant has been lovingly restored to its early 20th-century mellow elegance.

title: POSTINGS: On Donated Land; Affordable Homes in South Norwalk
description: With a 1.6-acre site donated by the City of Norwalk, below-market-rate mortgages from the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority and the sponsorship of a nonprofit housing agency, construction has begun on Ben Franklin Gardens, a 39-unit condominium project in the South Norwalk neighborhood. Completion is scheduled for April, and its one- and three-bedroom apartments will be priced to be affordable to people earning $25,000 to $35,000 a year.

title: Joanne Waller Is Married
description: Joanne Karen Waller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Waller of New York, was married at the Stanhope Hotel in New York yesterday to Robert Thomas Maddox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Maddox of Sayville, L.I. The Rev. Bernard Poppe, an Episcopal priest, officiated. The bride, 30 years old, as is her husband, graduated from the Spence School and Brown University. She is a product manager at Citibank. Mr. Maddox, who graduated from Columbia University, where he and his wife received M.B.A. degrees, is a bond trader at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. Her father is the owner of Maurice Weir Designs, an interior design concern in New York. Mr. Maddox's father is a retired chef.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Love may strike in the middle of a crowded room, but inspiration not too often. Or at least inspiration in its dictionary definition, as ''stimulus to creative thought.'' (Forget the alternative and more esoteric definition of ''divine influence''; that's a whole other thing.) Then again, inspiration doesn't strike that often anywhere. Occasionally, something flashes through the mind while walking or jogging or puffing away on an exercycle, although the thoughts generally inspired by physical-fitness machines might better be left unborn. Sometimes creative ideas will flicker as a bus or subway jolts along or a plane cuts through the clouds. But basically, these activities or places are not particularly conducive to first-class thoughts, the kind that may not prompt a cry of ''Eureka, I've got it,'' but are nevertheless pretty good. Where does inspiration strike? Obviously, in isolated instances, anywhere at any time. But the one place that seems to ignite the creative process in an amazing number of people is the shower. This may be because the shower is, in a sense, something of a refuge. The only sound is usually that of running water, and for most people it's one of the few places the telephone doesn't intrude.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Pastimes; Chess
description: Gary Kasparov was annoyed by remarks from commentators about a terrible blunder that his opponent Anatoly Karpov made in the 11th game of their second title match, the one that won him the world championship.

title: Review/Music; Composers' Diverse Appropriations
description: The only artist-member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to participate in Friday's program at Alice Tully Hall was Fred Sherry, the cellist and new artistic director. This might lead some to assume that Mr. Sherry's purge of the old membership is now complete. In fact, he has some old and new fellow members, even if none were engaged for this program, the last repeat of which takes place this afternoon at 5.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: FUNNY BUSINESS: An Outsider's Year in Japan. By Gary J. Katzenstein. (Soho Press, $17.95.) Gary J. Katzenstein went to Japan with his eyes and heart open. His innocence did not last. A computer specialist, Mr. Katzenstein went to work for Sony as part of a yearlong fellowship. Expecting to bear witness to the dazzling efficiency of a leading Japanese corporation, he instead found an office filled with grim workers whose greatest virtue was endurance. ''Funny Business'' is best when Mr. Katzenstein describes the lot of the Japanese around him, and the lot of the foreigner trying to fit in. Though his language skills are limited, he is expected to attend meetings just to show that he is part of the team. His training sessions are conducted in Japanese. Despite his best efforts, Mr. Katzenstein remains the outsider - a status that no foreigner in Japan can ever expect to escape. However, the book loses its way when an increasingly frustrated and embittered Mr. Katzenstein ventures outside the office and begins explaining why Japan is the way it is. He mars his story with inaccuracies, generalizations and declarations that he characterizes as an insider's answer to an all-too-generous depiction of Japanese business practices by the American press. Unfortunately, he tells us little that is new, and one wishes that despite the considerable obstacles he faced in finding a place at Sony, he had told us more about the workplace and spent less time making declarations about subjects he was less able to judge.

title: A Tyson Setback
description: By the time he gets around to fighting Razor Ruddock, the Canadian heavyweight, Mike Tyson, the youngest man to win the world heavyweight title, may be the world's oldest heavyweight champion. The bout, which has already been postponed once, from Nov. 18, because of a Tyson illness, has had to be postponed again. This time there is no available makeup date.

title: More Boats Being Kept On Racks
description: MORE Connecticut boats are being kept year round in warehouses instead of on the water, as rack storage buildings, or boat valet operations, are constructed along the coast.

title:
INVESTING;
Spotting the Most Promising Spinoffs
description: LEAD: Spinoffs are the orphans of Wall Street. The parent company's stockholders dump them, financiers shun them and the press publishes little about them. But these spinoffs can sometimes be good deals. ''If you are the recipient of one of these things, whatever you do, don't just automatically sell it out,'' said Charles W.

title: School Costs: The Real Villain Is Property Taxes
description: ANOTHER school year has now begun, but this one will be different from recent years. Tax revolt hysteria swept Long Island last spring, leaving in its wake defeated school budgets, divided communities and disillusioned students and teachers.

title: WARMING UP TO NEW ENGLAND WINTERS
description: CALAIS, VT., IS A PLACE WHERE the general store closes at 7 P.M., and the night life goes downhill from there. This quiet country town of 1,500 is precisely what Cornelia Capwell Denker, a textile and graphic-arts designer, and her husband, Goeffrey Poister, a musician, writer and film maker, were looking for when they moved there nine years ago. Having rejected city life, with its lure of lucrative jobs and the amenities of apartment living, in favor of the challenges of freelancing and the charms of an 1810 clapboard Cape, the couple soon discovered tht rural winters, though beautiful, can also be long. So to stave off cabin fever, they entertain often. And they do it on a budget.

title: Dinner in the 80's
description: For five years i was a hostess in remission. It began when I moved into a typical New York City apartment and came into full bloom while I was a restaurant critic. First I had no room to entertain at home; then I had an excuse not to.

title: Preparing to Celebrate the High Holiday of Candy
description: THOUGH I admit that little trick-or-treaters are adorable in their witches' hats, trailing sheets and monstrous faces, I think the holiday should be outlawed. The reason is candy.

title: The Growing Legal Battle Over Employee Waivers
description: Robert C. Patterson was 55 years old when the Xerox Corporation offered him a tough choice. He could volunteer for the company's early retirement program and be eligible for 15 months' pay with benefits. Or he could take his chances and possibly be discharged in an upcoming staff reduction. If that happened, Xerox would give him 12 months' pay, but no benefits.

title: Stacy Aaron Engaged
description: December wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Philip I. Aaron of Roslyn Estates, L.I., for their daughter Stacy Ann Aaron and Barry Richard Carus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Carus of Merrick, L.I. Ms. Aaron, 26 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Boston University and is a promotion manager for Act III Publishing in New York. Mr. Carus, also 26, is an associate at the New York law firm of Reid & Priest. He graduated from George Washington University and the Hofstra University Law School.

title: FEELING THE HOT BREATH OF CIVILIZATION
description: THE STORYTELLER By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen Lane. 246 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: When Disaster Is Predictable, A Failure to Communicate
description: THE first days after a catastrophe bring shock, grief and anger, followed by finger-pointing at the technical experts. Invariably, politicians ask scientists and engineers, ''Why didn't you tell us this could happen?'' To which the specialists usually answer, ''We did.''

title: U.S. Medical Workers Seized in Mozambique
description: Government soldiers seized six members of an American medical team and two South African colleagues and held them at a military compound in northern Mozambique, United States officials said today.

title: Connecticut Q&A: J. Williams Burns; 'A Road in Good Condition Is a Safer Road'
description: AS State Transportation Commissioner, J. Williams Burns oversees 5,500 miles of highway and 3,600 bridges. He supervises 4,700 employees and is responsible for an operating budget of $400 million. He also oversees the state's airports, harbors, piers, buses and trains.

title: New Look for Cheerleading
description: LEAD: ''THERE'S no ribbing,'' said Robert M. Fontanella, a rugged-looking, personable Valhalla High School junior, as he caught his breath on the auditorium floor of the County Center.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
The Flowering of the Interchange 8A Area
description: LEAD: DESPITE a sluggish industrial real estate marketplace, business parks continue to sprout amid the cow pastures and corn fields around Interchange 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Does One's Color Really Matter?
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Homeless Projects At the Crossroads
description: Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo arrived in the county determined to build transitional housing for the homeless in Mount Vernon, White Plains and Greenburgh.

title: Medicare Fee for Doctor Bills Rising to $29 a Month in '90
description: The insurance premium that the nation's 33 million Medicare beneficiaries pay to cover doctor bills will rise to $29 a month in 1990, the Department of Health and Human Services said this weekend. The 1989 rate is $27.90 a month. Congress has decreed that 25 percent of the cost of Medicare's program that pays physician fees be covered by premiums paid by beneficiaries. The other 75 percent is financed from general tax revenue. The premium is calculated annually from the costs of the program and the $1.10 increase is in line with what had been estimated previously.

title: Rising to the Occasion: Simple Souffles
description: FOR DINING ROOM DRAMA, NOTHING compares with a souffle. Its golden dome, towering tremulously above the edges of the dish, creates a stunning impression, suggesting that either daredevil or genius has been at work in the kitchen.

title: For-Profit Tactics Take Hold Despite Deep Resistance
description: Despite considerable resistance to the concept, a growing number of nonprofit groups are thriving by using marketing research principles to refine their services and target their message. Those nonprofits that can afford it have begun to rely on M.B.A.'s, consulting firms, advertising agencies, lobbyists and media specialists to guide their leaders, who traditionally have had little business experience.

title: Neither Seats Nor Turbo Nor Sun Roof Nor Warranty
description: ALPHONSE SAGNELLI of Stamford has a tougher time moving inventory than most used-car salesmen. His obstacle in achieving a healthy bottom line is that his Jeeps and vans, although modestly priced, have several peculiar features.

title: Carolyn Murray, Lawyer, Marries
description: Carolyn Anne Murray and David Christopher Scalera were married yesterday at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J., by the Rev. Michael J. Kreder. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Norbert Paul Murray of Bloomfield and the late Mr. Murray. Mr. Scalera's parents are Judge and Mrs. Nicholas Scalera of Florham Park, N.J.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: Yes, they are ''just'' baseball games. Yes, death, destruction and despair have tragically gripped the Bay Area. But invariably the process of life must continue. The process of healing must begin. The World Series should not be called off, assuming roads are commutable, sufficient police are available and the edifices holding 60,000 people are certifiably safe.

title:
INVESTING;
Household's Triple Spinoff
description: LEAD: Shareholders who thought Household International Inc. was just a finance company may have been surprised this spring to learn that it also made bathroom fixtures, ice machines and turbochargers for gasoline engines.

title: Bird Is Back, but Celtics Have Age-Old Problem
description: The Eastern Conference preview was prepared and written by Sam Goldaper. Atlantic Division

title: Terreri's Play Lifts Devils Past Chicago
description: The coach's harsh words about their lackadaisical play at home must have finally reached the Devils' ears, because they finally played a solid game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: No Time to Shop
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Recalls 'Conspiracy of Goodness'
description: LEAD: >HILE the song ''Never Going to Dance Again'' weaves through the background, Rudy Appel of Woodbury and Jack Lewin of Woodmere sit in J. Sprat's, a restaurant in Westbury, drinking wine and glancing through wartime photographs.

title: Mimi Nicolaides Weds Peter Mahoney
description: At the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington, Margaret Rose Nicolaides, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Homer Nicolaides of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Peter Edward Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mahoney 3d of Baton Rouge, La. Msgr. J. Joshua Mundell performed the ceremony.

title: What's Keeping Us From Building New Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Terry Duke Wed To John Marsh 3d
description: Terry Trippe Duke and John Bigelow Marsh 3d were married yesterday by the Rev. John Thursby at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Robert P. DeVecchi of New York and the late William H. Duke of Southport, Conn. Her husband is a son of Helen H. Marsh of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Mr. Marsh Jr. of Old Lyme.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: BERLANT CARNIVAL AND ENTERTAINMENT;
All Dressed Up With Somewhere to Go
description: LEAD: JOHN JULIANO is going to be the Headless Horseman for Halloween. He is really excited, he said, because the costume is ''pretty gross.'' It begins innocuously enough with a cloak collar a la Sherlock Holmes, then progresses to a bloody stump of a neck that totally covers the real head of the wearer, who sees through slits in the rubber.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 15 about Cumberland, Md., misstated the phone number for the C.&O. Canal Visitors Center. It is (301) 722-8226.

title: A's Win Series In Four Straight
description: The Oakland Athletics completed a four-game sweep of the San Francisco Giants tonight and brought a resounding end to the first Battle of the Bay Area and to the first World Series ever interrupted for 11 days by an earthquake.

title: For a Bit of a Gamble, Meet Them in St. Louis
description: In South Africa in 1959 one would hardly have expected to find the American musical thriving, much less splashing in the rain that Louis Burke and Joan Brickhill concocted for their revival of Gershwin's ''Lady Be Good'' that year. Yet musicals and dramas with such special effects as Borzois, chariots, 45-foot sequined cloaks, shipwrecks and flying Ariels became the trademarks of this married couple who eventually mounted more than 80 productions in their native country. Doing triple and even quadruple duty as directors, choreographers, designers and actors, they were known as ''the King and Queen of South African theater'' before Mr. Burke abdicated to immigrate to America in 1984.

title: Reviews/Music; A Concert In Honor Of Ascap
description: The first Meet the Moderns concert of the season, on Tuesday evening at Cooper Union, had a full agenda. It was the start of the 10th season of the series, but the anniversary took a back seat this time. Instead, Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic celebrated the 75th annivesary of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, a performing-rights organization that licenses performances and distributes royalties to its 45,000 members.

title: GENDER AND THE G.N.P.
description: IF WOMEN COUNTED A New Feminist Economics. By Marilyn Waring. Introduction by Gloria Steinem. 386 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THERE is a lesson for writers in search of subjects in ''Sabotage at Black Tom: Imperial Germany's Secret War in America, 1914-1917,'' by Jules Witcover.

title: Tanker, After Being Barred, Docks in Alaska
description: A tanker that has been anchored in Cook Inlet for lack of a state-approved contingency plan for cleaning up any oil spill received permission today to unload after the ship's owner agreed temporarily to adopt the cleanup plan of another company.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
3 Congregate-Care Centers for 'Well Elderly'
description: LEAD: AS Westchester's population ages, its older residents face increasing difficulty in maintaining their homes and life styles. But many do not want to pull up stakes and head to retirement communities in other states.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: 'Forced March' Sees the Holocaust Through a Victim
description: Amid the growing number of films dealing with the Holocaust, some of the most effective have been those that bracket the horrors of World War II with the flashbacks of a central character. From ''The Pawnbroker'' to ''Sophie's Choice,'' there seems to be something more ''real'' about avowedly subjective recollections, as opposed to reconstructions that purport to show the past in an objective way.

title: How a Artist's Vision Became Ours
description: Most of us see Italian landscapes for the first time over somebody else's shoulders - the valley of the Arno, for example, behind Pollaiuolo's martyred St. Sebastian, or the lakes of Mantua through the back windows in Mantegna's strange ''Death of the Virgin.'' After a time it seems natural to want to move the all-important central figures for a while and to walk into the picture, in particular the part that they necessarily hide from you.

title: A Case for Boys' Manners
description: WE had heard there were more wolves in Russia than any other country, but one afternoon we wondered if they all had gathered in our backyard. They arrived one by one and immediately canvased the yard for a new toy to attack. They were not very gracious in delivering their presents to the birthday boy, nor did they remember to wish him a happy birthday.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: 1929: The Year of the Great Crash. By William K. Klingaman. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) Can a stock market crash throw the nation into another Great Depression? William K. Klingaman's lively book ''1929'' will inspire readers to think more deeply about this question. Mr. Klingaman looks at the 11 months leading to the 1929 stock market catastrophe and the relationship of the crash to the Great Depression.

title: For Mayor: David Dinkins
description: What a disappointing campaign: voters have heard almost as much about Jackie Mason and Jesse Jackson as about David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani. So far, the two candidates haven't even managed to debate each other.

title: Reaction Is Mixed On Court Security
description: TOUGH new security measures in use at the Hudson County Administration Building in Jersey City are drawing mixed reactions from county employees, lawyers and visitors to the busy nine-story structure that contains the courtrooms and offices of 21 State Superior Court judges.

title: East German Catholic Bishop Adds to the Cry
description: A pastoral letter demanding far-reaching democratization was read last Sunday to Roman Catholics in all churches of East Germany's leading diocese, Dresden-Meissen.

title: Wright Bridge for Bay Would Have Held Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable TV: 40 Channels, Nothing to Watch
description: WHEN the cable television installers first appeared in our neighborhood, we greeted the army of line workers and sales representatives with open arms and open checkbooks.

title: In Bolivian Drug War, a Question of Will
description: Bolivia has certain advantages over its neighbors when it comes to waging war against narcotics traffickers. Unlike Peru and Colombia, there is no insurgency in Bolivia to interfere with antinarcotics operations. Also, the drug lords in Bolivia have none of the organization, sophistication or equipment of the Colombian drug cartels that allow them to challenge the Government openly.

title: Ms. Seretean Wed To Glenn I. Levin
description: Tracy Lynn Seretean, the daughter of Farol Seretean of Washington and Martin B. Seretean of Boca Raton, Fla., was married in New York last evening to Glenn I. Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Levin of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated at the Pierre.

title: Tracy L. Kelley Married
description: Tracy Lynne Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Kelley of Carneys Point, N.J., was married there yesterday at Trinity Lutheran Church to Edward Kelly Nalbandian, the son of Pat Kelly Nalbandian of Westport, Conn., and Edward J. Nalbandian of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Shenton performed the ceremony. The bride, a magna cum laude graduate of Rutgers University, is an international market support representative at the International Business Machines Information Network in Tampa, Fla., where her husband is the executive assistant to the general manager. The bridegroom graduated with honors from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: First Things First
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Rules on Stabilization

title: Auto Insurance: Wide Changes Are Sought
description: AS automobile insurance rates rise and the Joint Underwriting Association sinks deeper into debt, New Jersey officials and insurance industry experts agree that the current system is ripe for sweeping changes.

title: One Goal, Two Styles in New York City: Family Lunch
description: TO INCLUDE THEIR YOUNG SON AS MUCH as possible in their lives, Martine and Jean-Michel Bergougnoux entertain en famille -for lunch usually, and in ways that allow Edouard, now 4, to take a small but active role. In New York just three years, they like to share the personal, low-key pleasures of French home cooking with new American friends. ''I think they enjoy having French food,'' Mrs. Bergougnoux said with a wide smile.

title: Victories Sought
description: Ulster County Community College in Pound Ridge, N.Y., is looking for a new basketball coach.

title: Fashion; For Dancing Downtown, Buckets and Bags
description: What evening bag goes with combat boots?

title: Doing More With Less: Companies Donate Volunteers
description: After a surge early in the decade, the growth of corporate philanthropy has stalled. Corporate contributions, adjusted for inflation, have fallen by 7 percent since 1985, to $4.8 billion in 1988. By comparison, individuals donated $86.7 billion, up 15 percent for the same period. The most recent culprits for the decline in corporate giving: the rise of cash-draining mergers, the stock market crash in 1987, increased foreign competition and a reduced tax incentive.

title: Teamwork
description: To the Editor:

title: Sludge Sites For Nassau
description: The article ''Towns Resist Selection as Sites for Sewage'' (Oct. 1) failed to mention that Nassau County's preferred resolution of this matter would be the processing of sludge off Long Island in a joint venture currently under consideration with Westchester County.

title: Colorado Pounds Oklahoma by 20-3
description: The tailback J. J. Flannigan and the quarterback Darian Hagan each rushed for more than 100 yards and Colorado's defense stifled Oklahoma today to give the Buffaloes a 20-3 victory, their first over the Sooners in 12 years.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden Joan Lee Faust
description: For This Week: Leaves are falling; keep after them with rakes or power blowers; add them to compost. Mow the lawn one more time and set the blade to cut low, about one-inch; this short cut will endure until spring and spur rapid start up of the grass. Finish bulb and shrub planting; tree planting continues well into early winter.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''They are so determined to win the capital gains cut that they are resorting to extraordinary financing. This is unprecedented, and it will cost the Treasury an extra $20 million to do it.'' Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, on the Administration's borrowing plan.

title: Hatsy Brown and Scott Vallar Marry
description: The marriage of Harriette Anne Brown, a daughter of Lieut. Gen. and Mrs. Frederic J. Brown 3d of McLean, Va., to Scott William Vallar, the son of Meryl Vallar and William H. Vallar Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at the Chapel of the Centurion at the Fort Monroe Army post in Hampton, Va. The Rev. David P. Thomas, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Lions Losing Hope
description: The season began with the optimism a new coach brings. Injuries to the top two running backs soured the atmosphere, but after four losses in four games, the Columbia football program still had hope for a successful season.

title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers
description: LEAD: TUCKED among the rural landscape of Hunterdon County could be one of the answers to substance abuse that the Federal Government is seeking.

title: The Evolution of a Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Katherine Conkling, a Painter, Marries
description: The marriage of Katherine Anne Conkling, the daughter of Rowena Conkling and Robert H. Conkling, both of Cambridge, Mass., to Dewey McDonald Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Thompson of New Canaan, Conn., and Westport, Mass., took place yesterday. The Rev. Dean Thornburgh, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Marsh Chapel at Boston University.

title: New York Mayoral Race Focuses On Voters' Sense of Party Loyalty
description: Whether to resist or respond to party loyalty is emerging as a dominant question in the final 10 days of New York City's mayoral campaign, with David N. Dinkins wrapping himself in the mantle of prominent Democrats and Rudolph W. Giuliani, his Republican-Liberal rival, by necessity appealing for Democratic and independent votes by invoking John F. Kennedy's maxim that sometimes party loyalty demands too much.

title: Old and New Guard Aim to Narrow Gap
description: Paul Tagliabue stood at a lectern at a hotel in Cleveland three days ago and was scrutinized from his first answer to his last. He had just been voted commissioner of the National Football League after a seven-month search. The league's 28 owners had named a man from within, one they considered their own.

title: Appointments Worry Environmentalists
description: President Bush won applause when he chose William K. Reilly, a career conservationist, as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. But since then the President's choices for top environmental jobs have raised questions among some preservation groups and lawmakers about Mr. Bush's commitment to protecting the environment.

title: Thomas H. Yorke Wed To Jeannette V. Jardine
description: The marriage of Jeannette Vreeland Jardine and Thomas Hosford Yorke took place yesterday at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J. The Rev. George A. Willis performed the ceremony.

title: Pamela Flood to Marry Dr. Glauco Radoslovich
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Flood of New York and Chappaqua, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Pamela Dru Flood to Dr. Glauco Radoslovich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton Radoslovich of Cliffside Park, N.J. A December wedding is planned.

title: Numbers, Too, Were Against the Giants
description: If the World Series was supposed to become part of the healing process after the earthquake here, it didn't offer much healing to the San Francisco Giants in the third game. They knew the numbers all too well: 16 teams in the previous 85 years of the Series had lost the first three games, and none recovered.

title: Conference on Black Theology Unites Scholars and Pastors
description: Black theology, a distinctive understanding of Christianity based on the religious experience of African Americans, was forged in the days of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X and the Vietnam War, but its proponents believe it is no less relevant in the days of President Bush, televangelism, Spike Lee and the crack epidemic.

title: Hello, Central. Get Me Stereo
description: A well-appointed home once had its music room, usually containing one or two grand pianos. (A second piano was handy for playing duo-piano arrangements of symphonic scores, which used to be a popular pastime in musical households.) Later, as domestic space got tight, the music room contained a hi-fi system and maybe no piano at all. But odd things are happening to the music room now. The latest trend is to make (almost) every room a music room by piping stereo throughout the house.

title: Bentsen Exhorts Democrats To Embrace Family Values
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today that the Democrats lost the Presidential election ''because too many young people aren't sure they can trust us to govern this nation.''

title: Off-Track Behind the Iron Curtain
description: THE danger may not rival murder on the Orient Express, but an overnight train in Europe still can have its perils - at least if you're behind the Iron Curtain and as unwary a traveler as I am.

title: Seeing 'Intolerance' Is Hard Work
description: ''I don't think I ever want to see 'Potemkin' again.''

title: Q and A
description: France

title: A Large Helping Of Gunter Wand In Four Big Sets
description: Like an errant delivery truck that mistakenly dumps a ton of coal on your lawn, the good people at BMG/RCA Records have seen fit to release 24 compact disks of Germanic music conducted in a Germanic fashion by Gunter Wand. The disks, assembled in four boxed sets, consist of the complete symphonies of Beethoven (60090-2-RC, 6 disks), Schubert (60096-2-RG, 5 disks), Brahms (60085-2-RG, 3 disks) and Bruckner (60075-2-RG, 10 disks).

title: 23 Yachts Set Sail In Race's 2d Leg
description: Twenty-three sleek monohull yachts from 13 countries set sail today on the rugged second leg of the 33,000-mile Whitbread Round the World Race.

title: Offsetting a Loss of Federal Support
description: The conservative agenda of the Reagan era has forced many nonprofit groups to become much more sophisticated in the way they do business.

title: Tigre Rebels to Begin Talks With Ethiopia
description: Rebels from a northern Ethiopian province said today that they would begin peace talks with the Ethiopian Government next week in Rome in an effort to end 14 years of civil war.

title: Terrace Solarium
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Exactly A Campaign Swing
description: Who would have thought that a tree-planting ceremony of the American Forestry Association at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington would make compelling television news? Certainly not Senator John Glenn (below), the Ohio Democrat and former astronaut, who was being interviewed on other matters of the day at the ceremony by a television correspondent. Suddenly, a well-dressed man walked up and punched the Senator in the jaw. Television viewers could hear the man, Michael Breen, 31 years old, of Washington muttering about earthquakes. A startled Mr. Glenn rubbed a sore jaw and said, ''I haven't been hit like that in 30 years.'' Mr. Breen, charged with assaulting a member of Congress, a felony, was ordered held for psychiatric evaluation. His lawyer, Barry Stiller, declined to discuss the case but described his client as ''just a very nice young man who I think is a little confused.''

title: That Old Question for a Candidate
description: AS I was listening to a syndicated news show, a male correspondent was concluding an interview with a candidate for state senator.

title: Bakker Will Serve Sentence As Worker at Medical Center
description: Jim Bakker, the television evangelist who on Tuesday began a 45-year sentence for fraud and conspiracy, will be moved from a prison in Alabama to the Federal Medical Center here, the Bureau of Prisons announced Friday. It gave no reason for the transfer.

title: Fond Memories Of Secretariat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: REVISITING OCT. 13;
Fear of a Crash Caused the Crash
description: LEAD: Those who try to make sense of the Friday Oct. 13 stock market drop have relied often on what may be called the ''last-straw'' theory of stock prices: a sequence of bad news events has no effect on the market until a last-straw news event becomes too much to bear. The market drops precipitously.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $500,000 22 West Orchard Road 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 34-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, screened porch, den, family room, rec room, 1.04 acres; taxes $7,481. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $328,000 Hunter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, screened porch, 1-car garage; taxes $5,656. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $780,000 Heerdt Farm Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, family room, screened porch, deck, 2.8 acres; taxes not yet assessed. New Britain, Conn. $121,000 269 Pleasant Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; family room in basement, sliding doors from kitchen to new deck; taxes $1580. Ridgefield, Conn. $700,000 44 Old Branchville Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; custom stone exterior, interior masonry finishes, 4.8 acres; taxes $6,137. Stamford, Conn. $305,000 210 Rockrimmon Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; pond on property, hardwood floors, 1 acre; taxes $3,638. OTHER AREAS Hicksville, L.I. $148,000 3 Jordan Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,500. Islip, L.I. $96,000 100 Wilson Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. Lakewood, N.J. $105,000 75 Columbus Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old ranch; patio, dining room, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,381.

title: Social Events
description: For the Homeless Oct. 29 - George Plimpton will be the host. Ashford and Simpson will provide the music, Fran Lebowitz the humor and Calvin Trillin some enlightenment on the world in general at a party at Christ Church United Methodist, 60th Street at Park Avenue. The festivities, starting at 5:30 P.M. with performances, wine and snacks, will benefit the East Side Community Center's program for the homeless. Tickets, $50, at the door. Uptown Jazz Oct. 29 - The Ron Carter Quintet will be holding forth at a benefit for the the Bloomingdale House of Music, the 25-year-old community music school at which 1,000 students, young and old alike, take lessons at little or no cost. The evening at Birdland, Broadway at 105th Street, will begin at 7:30 P.M., and the quintet will play at 8:30 P.M. and 9:45 P.M. Tickets, $40 including a buffet, $25 without, at the door. Briefly Noted: Oct. 29 - Midori, the violinist, will perform, and Beverly Sills will be the toastmaster at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria, a benefit for the American Committee for the Weitzmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel. Tickets, $1,000, from 212-752-1300. Oct. 30 - The Lawyers Alliance for Citymeals-on-Wheels is holding a Halloween party with dancing, a buffet and drinks at Bridgewaters at the South Street Seaport from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M. Tickets, $65, from 212-577-1758. Oct. 30 - Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jersusalem and Johanan Bein, Israel's delegate to the United Nations, are scheduled to be on hand for the American Friends of the Israel Museum dinner-dance at the New York State Theater. Black tie; cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets, $1,000, from 212-683-5190. Oct. 30 - Madre seeks to link women and children in the United States with their counterparts in Central America and the Caribbean in educational, cultural and humanitarian endeavors. The writer Alice Walker and the actress Susan Sarandon will be honored at a dinner-dance at the Columns, 584 Broadway (Houston Street), starting with cocktails at 6:45 P.M. Tickets, $150, from 212-627-0444. Oct. 30 - Champagne at Cartier from 6 P.M. to 8 P.M. will benefit the junior and young rider programs of the American Horse Shows Association. Tickets, $125, from 212-972-2472. Oct. 30 - The Parkinson's Disease Foundation will be the beneficiary of a tribute to Howard Dietz at the Pierre. Cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by dinner, dancing and tributes to the late lyricist. Black tie. Tickets, $350, from 212-944-5700. Oct. 31 - Diplomats will be out in force at the 35th Ambassadors Ball at the Plaza, a benefit for the Hospitality Committee for United Nations Delegations. Black tie; cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets, $300, from 212-963-8753. Oct. 31 - Pet cats will be the theme of a benefit for the Humane Society of New York from 6 P.M. to 8 P.M. at the Hoya Crystal Gallery, 450 Park Avenue (57th Street). Wine and hors d'oeuvres will be served. Tickets, $30, from 212-752-4842. Oct. 31 - The American Craft Museum will hold its annual benefit auction and dinner-dance at the Puck Building, Lafayette and Houston Streets, starting with cocktails at 5:30 P.M. Silent and live auctions will offer 164 items by contemporary American craftsmen. Tickets, $300, from 212-956-3535. Oct. 31 - The Ubu Repertory Theater, a showcase for French drama, will stage the United States premiere, in English, of Simone Schwartz-Bart's ''Your Handsome Captain'' at 15 West 28th Street. The performance will be followed by a Caribbean-style buffet and an auction of Haitian lithographs and other items. Tickets, $100, from 212-679-7540. Oct 31 - The Boys Clubs of America will honor William C. Ferguson, the chief executive officer of Nynex, at the Marriott Marquis, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Dinner, dancing and entertainment by Roberta Peters will follow. Tickets, $500, from 212-997-0100. Nov. 1 - The United Nations Children's Fund will benefit from a 6 P.M. reception for Julio Iglesias at the Russian Tea Room, followed by the singer's 8 P.M. concert at Carnegie Hall. Tickets, $250, from 212-686-5522, or $25, $30 and $50 for the concert alone, from 212-247-7800. Nov. 1 - Founded by Jean Kennedy Smith, Very Special Arts, an educational affiliate of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, provides opportunities in the arts for those with mental or physical disabilities. A 7 P.M. screening of ''My Left Foot,'' followed by dinner at the Sign of the Dove, 1110 Third Avenue (65th Street), will benefit the organization. Tickets, $125, from 212-983-2965. Nov. 2 - Mothers for More Halfway Houses provides follow-up assistance to people 18 to 35 years old who have been released from mental institutions. The group is holding a benefit from 6 P.M. to 8 P.M. at the River Club, 447 East 52d Street, with an open bar, hors d'oeuvres, music, a fashion show and auction. Tickets, $125 or $75 for those under 40, from 212-288-6567. Nov. 4 - The National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, will hold its 91st Anniversary Benefit Ball from 6:30 P.M. to 11 P.M. Cocktails, dinner, dancing and awards will be included at the benefit for the club's restoration and scholarship funds. Black tie. Tickets, $250, from 212-475-3424. A Man for All Media Nov. 5 - Before television there was radio and before that vaudeville, and in each medium, along with movies and nightclubs, George Burns has been a star. The comic will be honored by a score of show business personalities at a benefit at the Plaza for the Museum of Broadcasting, which provides a visual and audio history of radio and television at 1 East 53d Street. The black-tie evening will start with cocktails at 6 P.M., followed by dinner and the tribute. Tickets, $400, from 212-888-2526.

title: Youths Take on Drug Abuse in Video
description: LEAD: ''PARENTS JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND'' is a rap video by Jazzy Jeff and the Fresh Prints that is telecast on MTV. And 30 students from the Bridgeport region have produced a 30-minute anti-drug video using that theme.

title: G.E. to Test Alternative Method of PCB Disposal
description: A small model of the Hudson River will be constructed in Ann Arbor, Mich., in the next few months to test laboratory findings that naturally occurring bacteria can be accelerated to destroy PCB's on the river bottom, the General Electric Company announced this week.

title: French Designer-Decorators in the Style of Luxe
description: The Paris School of Art Deco design was even more varied than shows of the last 25 years have shown. While some designers found inspiration in ancient Egypt or in early-20th-century European modern, others, such as Ernest Boiceau and Andre Arbus, devised furnishings firmly rooted in the French classics of the late 18th and early 19th centuries.

title: Reviews/Music; Celia Cruz Takes Cuba to Harlem
description: The Celia Cruz Celebrates Harlem show at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem on Oct. 21 caught fire during the second half and stayed lighted. Backed by Mario Bauza's orchestra and egged on by the insistent choppy drumming of Tito Puente, Miss Cruz brought the packed house to its feet.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: Would not the skills of those workers repairing damage done to Candlestick Park be put to better use helping the people of the Bay Area restore their shattered homes? Could not the services of the scores of police officers assigned to the remaining Series games be better used in performing other, more critical duties? JOHN P. WIRTZ New York

title: Review/Theater; Brains vs. Beaut In Family Melodrama
description: ''Everyone needs a place to dance and sing,'' observes a character at the end of Kim Merrill's play ''Beauty Marks.'' The pronouncement is one of many mawkishly sentimental observations that punctuate a drama so aswirl in tearful memories, accusations and reconciliations that it has the feel of a high-pitched soap opera.

title: Ms. Chowenhill Plans to Marry
description: Rona Anne Chowenhill's engagement to Clarke Edward Thrasher 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thrasher Jr. of East Aurora, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. C. Frampton Chowenhill of Chappaqua, N.Y. A December wedding is planned.

title: Faulty Metal in a Part Is Blamed for Iowa Jet Crash
description: Government investigators have concluded that a manufacturing flaw caused the crack in an engine fan assembly that brought about the crash of the United Airlines jet over Iowa last July.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; Week of Civility Tries to Confront Campus Prejudice
description: Civility Week, which ended here Friday, marked the third anniversary of a racially motivated riot at the University of Massachusetts in 1986. The university-sponsored observance, intended to promote racial and cultural harmony, was heralded by posters and the distribution of ribbons of different colors, symbolizing various races. It included about 80 events, like films, lectures and workshops, that highlighted the university's efforts to study racial and cultural tension on campus.

title: A Lesson in Pain and Loss Comes at the Death of a Hamster
description: IT was clear and cold, the kind of night that feels right for putting on a mask and going door-to-door to ask for Halloween treats. Instead, the whole family processed solemnly outside. I ran ahead to cut a late-blooming rose from the garden. My daughter Liza came next, holding a tiny white box gingerly in front of her, with her brother shining a flashlight to show the way. My husband was already outside with the spade, digging a deep cavity under the towering andromeda in our front yard.

title: Condemned to Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Streets Inspire a Novelist
description: WHEN Alice McDermott was in college, she took writing courses so she could ''coast.'' But her teacher said: ''I've got bad news for you. You're a writer.'' In Elmont, L.I., where she had grown up, writing was not ''something people did or even thought about,'' said Ms. McDermott, now 35 years old. ''I thought all writers were dead.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. A citronella candle dripped melted wax onto the pressure-treated pine on our outside deck. We have tried removing this stain, but so far nothing has worked. Any suggestions?

title: Animal Films? The Secret Is a Bankable 'Dog'
description: It's been said, by Woody Allen, I think, that if you do comedy, you don't sit at the grown-ups' table. If you do animals, you may not even get into the house - and with reason.

title: Review/Music; Walter Hilse, on Organ, With Hockets
description: Walter Hilse is one of our more venturesome organists, and his recital Wednesday night on the Holtkamp instrument at the Park Avenue Christian Church offered 7 of the 12 sections that make up Dave Soldier's ''Hockets and Inventions.'' The performance was billed as a world premiere, even though it was incomplete; Mr. Hilse has recorded the entire work with this same organ for release on a compact disk of Mr. Soldier's music.

title: Jim Bakker's Startling Sentence
description: ''Those of us who do have a religion are sick of being saps for money-grubbing preachers and priests.'' That's how U.S. District Judge Robert Potter prefaced his startling 45-year prison sentence for Jim Bakker, the TV preacher who turned out to be a confidence man.

title: The Rite-of-Passage Cruise
description: UNTIL last summer, no one had ever trapped me into an all-you-can-eat, nightly-entertainment-provided, package-deal vacation. Then my daughter Elizabeth, who was 18 in May, said she wanted to go on a cruise after high school graduation. To her, a cruise seemed romantic, adult and a good way to get a suntan. To my husband, who had stayed home during most of our family's outdoor adventures, a ship sounded like a good place to read ''War and Peace.'' Skeptical as I was about the rewards of this kind of vacation, I tagged along, unwilling to miss any of the final summer at home of my third and last child.

title: Review/Dance; West German Company Makes American Debut
description: By importing attractions from West Germany in recent seasons, the Next Wave Festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music has revealed that contemporary German dance is not only esthetically stimulating and controversial but also remarkably varied. This autumn, New Yorkers have been able to admire the extravagant fantasies of Reinhild Hoffmann and the emotional eloquence of Susanne Linke. On Tuesday night, Tanztheater Christine Brunel made its American debut in the Academy's Lepercq Space, offering a program of spare, calculated choreography.

title: Nancy J. Lavin Wed in Boston
description: The marriage of Nancy Jane Lavin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Carson Lavin of Needham, Mass., to Daniel Austin Scheerer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Durand Scheerer Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J., took place yesterday at Trinity Church in Boston. The Rev. Margaret Gunness, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Yanks Withou Two Nuisances
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Wolverines Roll Past the Hoosiers
description: Tony Boles scored three touchdowns, including a 91-yard scoring run, overshadowing Anthony Thompson's record-tying 59th regular-season touchdown for Indiana, as Michigan routed the Hoosiers, 38-10, today.

title: DIFFERENT FROM YOU AND ME: EIGHT INVESTORS
description: THE NEW MONEY MASTERS Winning Investment Strategies of Soros, Lynch, Steinhardt, Rogers, Neff, Wanger, Michaelis, Carret. By John Train. 385 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/ Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: ONE STEP AHEAD IN CHINA: Guangdong Under Reform. By Ezra F. Vogel. (Harvard University, $29.95.) In 1987 Ezra F. Vogel, the Clarence Dillon Professor of International Relations at Harvard University, spent seven months in Guangdong Province in southeastern China, at the request of the provincial government, to assess the results of economic and social reform.

title: Japan's Leader Peeks Out of Scandal's Shadow
description: In less than three months in office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has performed calisthenics on National Fitness Day, given speeches endorsing the cause of consumers and generally tried to project an image of renewal and stability in the Government.

title: Human Race, 2; Computer, 0 (for Now)
description: To hear Gary Kasparov tell it, he could have beaten the vaunted computer chess program, Deep Thought, with one lobe tied behind him. Mr. Kasparov (above, right), the world chess champion, took on Deep Thought in a $10,000 grudge match last week in New York City and handily whipped the computer two straight games. Deep Thought, which can scan 720,000 positions a second, had been hailed as a breakthrough in computer chess after it recently beat several grandmasters, but Mr. Kasparov was having none of it. ''I can't visualize living with the knowledge that a computer is stronger than the human mind,'' he said. ''I had to challenge Deep Thought for this match to protect the human race.'' Mr. Kasparov explained that he conquered Deep Thought with psychology. ''If you know a computer well, you can anticipate its moves,'' he said. The only thing that puzzled him as he played against the computer, he said, was that ''there was no opposition.'' Well, maybe, said the five scientists who created Deep Thought, but wait till the next decade. By 1995, they said, they will have completed a program with a thousand times Deep Thought's strength.

title:
GARDENING;
A Diversity of Cultivars of Apples
description: LEAD: NOT too many people realize that the apple was once considered the national fruit, and cider the national drink. Today's produce markets are so filled with exotic fruit unheard of in earlier times. Despite the competition, though, apple production has exceeded 200 million boxes annually in most recent years.

title:
GARDENING;
A Diversity of Cultivars of Apples
description: LEAD: NOT too many people realize that the apple was once considered the national fruit, and cider the national drink. Today's produce markets are so filled with exotic fruit unheard of in earlier times. Despite the competition, though, apple production has exceeded 200 million boxes annually in most recent years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's change, an article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the play ''The Talented Tenth'' at the Manhattan Theater Club gives an outdated schedule. The opening has been delayed, and a new date has not been set.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Thirteen years ago Norman Snyder, a New York photographer, decided that what the world needed was a compendium of all things photographic. The result was ''The Photography Catalog,'' a book modeled none too subtly on ''The Whole Earth Catalog.'' Like ''The Whole Earth Catalog,'' which was a combination of counter-culture wisdom and consumer titillation, ''The Photography Catalog'' adopted a chatty, anecdotal tone, but still managed to dispense valuable information.

title: Exxon Faults Wildlife Group's Criticism of Oil Spill
description: Exxon has resigned from the National Wildlife Federation's corporate advisory board and has called the federation unfair in its criticism of the Alaska oil spill last March.

title: CRACK AND RACIAL TENSIONS
description: Thank you for showing me just how easy it is to produce and smoke crack. Your simple, step-by-step instructions make an excellent primer for any first-time crack user. The ''recipe'' and how-to-smoke instructions were great. The only thing missing was a map of the neighborhoods where crack is bought most easily. CATHY CARR New York, N.Y.

title: What Poison Politics Has Done to America
description: FROM the tavern on the corner to the Capitol on the hill, there is a feeling that something has gone badly wrong in political discourse. People have complained for years that campaigns do not grapple with issues of government. But more and more, it seems that government has become enmeshed in the issues created for campaigns.

title: A Honeymoon for One
description: I SLATHER cold cream all over my face, and carry a bowl of mushy mocha-fudge ice cream to my night table.

title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race
description: THE last two times out, Denis Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, ran for re-election unopposed. This time, he is being challenged more by his own record as a staunch antiabortionist than anything else.

title: What Lies Behind The Strange Smile On the 'Mona Lisa'
description: As his two children run about his small apartment, dodging his easel and smearing their fingers across his palette, Song Bin paints ''Mona Lisas'' - more than 100 of them so far.

title: MR. LONELYHEARTS
description: I FIRST MET EPPIE LEDERER (alias Ann Landers) in July 1981. She had just given a speech at a real estate convention and, as a reporter for The Orlando Sentinel, I approached her for an interview. I was star-struck and somewhat fawning. She was 63 years old and a legend; I was 22 and not yet jaded about celebrityhood. But I'd done my homework. I knew all about the contest Eppie won to get her job, and I'd researched her rivalry with her twin sister, Popo (Dear Abby). I'd even studied how after her divorce she became more liberal about life styles.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: TOTAL CUSTOMER SERVICE: The Ultimate Weapon. By William H. Davidow and Bro Uttal. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) Customer service may seem a mundane topic in an era of spectacular financial gymnastics and swashbuckling corporate raiders. But the authors of this engrossing, tightly written book argue that while most companies in the United States give lip service to customer service, few really invest the money or effort to do it well.

title: Lauren B. Abrams Marries
description: Lauren B. Abrams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Abrams of Ridgewood, N.J., was married last evening to Daniel L. Krieger, a son of Laura Poster of White Plains and the late Jesse Krieger. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated at the Preakness Hills Country Club in Wayne, N.J. Mrs. Krieger, 28 years old, is the director of sales and marketing at Morgans Hotel in New York. Her husband, 34, is a vice president in the New York office of the Fort Lee (N.J.) Marketing Corporation.

title: Soviets Lack More Than Market Savvy
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A Hotel Closes, But B.V.I.'s Say They're Ready

title: NEW INVESTIGATION URGED IN I.R.A. CASE
description: After deciding to free four people who were apparently wrongly convicted of terrorist bombings in 1975, the British Government is under growing pressure to reopen the case of six men who were convicted of murdering 21 people in the bombings of two Birmingham pubs in 1974.

title: Governors Change, but Not Their Favorite Tennis Partner
description: LEAD: TAPPING his tennis racquet on top of the net a few days before stepping down from office, Gov. Brendan T. Byrne squinted at the morning sun pouring through a skylight. Still in his warm-up suit, he leaned toward his successor, Thomas H. Kean, and introduced Edward Meara 3d by saying: ''About the only thing constant in the Governor's office is that you get to play tennis with Ed.

title: An April Bridal For Jennifer Ash
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clarke B. Ash of Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Ash, to Dr. Albert Joseph Rudick Jr., a son of Eleanore Rudick of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Rudick. An April wedding is planned.

title: Heidi Schallenberg, a Lawyer, Marries
description: Heidi Elisabeth Schallenberg, a lawyer in New York, and Philip Sweeney, an official of the Environmental Protection Agency, were married yesterday at the First Reformed Church in Fishkill, N.Y., by the Rev. Richard N. Ryley, a United Methodist minister.

title: Best vs. Best, Not East vs. West
description: In the next few days, newspaper and magazine stories will herald the anticipated clash of thoroughbred racing's titans -Easy Goer and Sunday Silence - in the sixth edition of the Breeders' Cup Saturday at Gulfstream Park near Miami.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ASPIRING QUARTET

title: Loophole for an Earthquake
description: Where did Congress suddenly find $3.5 billion for earthquake disaster relief? In a loophole. If the quake had hit last month, as Hurricane Hugo did, money to aid its victims would have had to come from cutting other programs. But, as luck would have it, the deadline for trimming this year's budget deficit has passed now, and with it this year's spending ceiling.

title: CRACK AND RACIAL TENSIONS
description: At a time when racial tensions in New York City are at a peak, with violent racial attacks occurring in the streets and a racially charged mayoral campaign occupying the press, Michael Massing's article ''Crack's Destructive Sprint Across America'' (Oct. 1) has, regrettably, added to racial misunderstanding.

title: Sailor Takes His Fun Seriously
description: LEAD: AS chairman of Thomson Industries of Port Washington, a manufacturer of ball bearings, John Thomson spends much time on his 50-foot sailboat Infinity. But leisure for Mr. Thomson, whose company has 1,200 employees, is not sunset cruising.

title: The Land of the Lemurs
description: ''WHEN will we see lemurs?'' we asked on our arrival after dark at Berenty, a reserve in the south of Madagascar. We had come to the capital of Madagascar, Antananarivo, only the night before and that morning had taken a plane to Fort Dauphin, then drove all afternoon through a variety of ecological niches including the spiny desert, where the cactuslike plants of a unique-to-Madagascar family serrate the horizon.

title: Historic Neighborhood Getting New Life
description: LEAD: THE ambivalence of a neighborhood in transition is apparent at Hudson and Pearl Streets, where a boarded-up, graffiti-marred, three-story building sits across from a neatly restored yellow brick row house surrounded by a wrought iron fence.

title: CONFRONTING THE SOVIET UNION'S ECONOMICE MORASS
description: In a speech in New York on Oct. 16, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said that perestroika's success in the Soviet Union is in the long-term interest of the United States. Mr. Baker offered to send American technical and economic experts to the Soviet Union to help with the reforms.

title: THE PLAYERS' MAIN MAN
description: ONE DAY IN THE middle of the baseball season, nine Houston Astros, in New York for a series against the Mets, spent an afternoon in midtown Manhattan. For 90 minutes they sat around a conference table on the 26th floor of a Third Avenue office tower, listening to Don Fehr, a man more important to their careers than any manager, umpire or opposing pitcher. By many accounts, in fact, it is Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, the players' union, who controls the future of the sport, and his message that afternoon was grim: there is a coming labor war in baseball.

title: DROPPING IN ON A DRAGON
description: THE FOUR LITTLE DRAGONS By Brian Kelly and Mark London. 432 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Point Guard Takes Over N.B.A.'s Show
description: As a youngster growing up in Lansing, Mich., Magic Johnson often dribbled the night away at the local basketball court, pretending to be one of his idols. One night he would pretend to be Dave Bing. The next night, he might be Oscar Robertson or Walt Frazier.

title: Ortega Now Says End to Rebel Aid Can Save Truce
description: Modifying a position he stated on Friday, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said today that he would adhere to a cease-fire with the contras if the United States halted its assistance to the rebels as a fighting force.

title: Ballet School Faces Loss of Studios
description: LEAD: FOR the second time in three years, the School of the Princeton Ballet is faced with the possible loss of its studios in Princeton Township, just a few blocks from the center of Princeton.

title: Battered Wife Freed in Killing of Husband
description: A woman who ended 17 years of terror and abuse by hiring a gunman to kill her husband was freed from prison Friday after she was granted clemency by Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington.

title: For Some Free Agents, Not Filing Becomes New Strategy
description: In 1981, a negotiating battle over professional compensation for lost free agents (the owners wanted it, the players didn't) produced a 50-day players' strike. Four years later, the issue had become so unimportant or the owners had so soured on the idea that professional compensation was quietly dropped from the collective-bargaining agreement.

title: Some Colleges Still Go All Out on Halloween
description: Halloween on most college campuses on Tuesday will be filled with revelry and high-camp costumes. Students also plan other activities like trick or treating for disadvantaged children.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: ORGAN RECITAL

title: Roll Over Basho: Who Japan Is Reading, and Why
description: Japanese writers are very aware of what we're doing on this side of the Pacific and very well informed about American fiction, about American culture," says the novelist Jay McInerney. "Yet we're terribly ignorant in this country of Japanese fiction, Japanese culture. It is, I think, far more accessible than we might imagine."

title: In Chicago, A New Romanticism
description: This city's celebrated passion for skyscrapers has been as evident as ever recently. First there was the announcement last June by Lee Miglin and J. Paul Beitler, a pair of local developers, that they planned to put up a 125-story, 1,914-foot tower on a tight corner site downtown, a building that would be the tallest skyscraper in the world, eclipsing its neighbor, the Sears Tower, by more than 400 feet. Several other towers, not record breakers but plenty big anyway, have been announced this year, too. And in the months just before and after Mr. Miglin and Mr. Beitler unveiled their project, several of the tall buildings Chicagoans have been eagerly awaiting for years have come to completion.

title: A Cold War Over Coffee
description: In the soothing confines of the Kerckhoff coffee house on the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles, where students like to while away hours prattling on about exams and fractures in their love life, the coffee industry feels it may be looking at its future.

title: Natasha Cowger Becomes a Bride
description: Natasha Catiche Cowger, a daughter of Kathryn H. Cowger of London and Robert E. Cowger of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday in New York to John Richard Bergreen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris H. Bergreen of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y. Justice Felice K. Shea of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Capone Connection; Transforming a Onetime Chicago Mob Headquarters
description: A $2.6 million Federal urban development action grant awarded to this city last month has provided the last link in the financing of a $28.6 million project to transform the historic Lexington Hotel, where Al Capone had his headquarters, and a neighboring building into a 258-suite hotel with 32,000 square feet of retail space.

title: Slaloming Through European Ski Brochures
description: THIS is the season when skiers read color brochures the way gardeners read seed catalogues in January. And for those Americans who want to ski in Europe, comparing ski packages there is just as arcane an art as deciding which tulip bulb will fare the best.

title: 5 More Dead in Texas Blast
description: Rescue workwers recovered five bodies overnight from what is left of the Phillips Petroleum plastics plant, destroyed by explosions Monday. Twelve bodies have now been found, said a Phillips spokesman, Jere Smith.

title: Vivian Makram, An Auditor, Weds
description: Vivian Makram, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Makram of Cairo, was married yesterday in New York to Michael Ward, a son of John J. Ward Jr. of Chicago and the late Mrs. Ward. The Rev. Gilbert J. Gentile performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church, where the bridegroom is the music director.

title: Army Defeats Rutgers
description: Army, which has thrived on adversity this season, rallied in the second half today to beat Rutgers, 35-14, as Mike Mayweather scored three touchdowns for the third game in a row.

title: Playwrights Tread The Welcome Mat In Hollywood
description: Like many other established playwrights, Marsha Norman is finding she is very welcome these days in Hollywood. ''There are lots of opportunities there now for playwrights, and people are usually willing to trust our judgment,'' she says. The ubiquitous Ms. Norman, author of ''Getting Out'' and '' 'Night, Mother,'' should know. On Thursday evening at 9, her play ''Third and Oak: The Pool Hall,'' starring James Earl Jones and Mario Van Peebles, kicks off American Playwrights Theater, a series of four one-acts on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network. Recently, she finished a television film for the ABC network about the homeless, and she's currently working on a movie idea for Madonna.

title: Ladle Label
description: What's in a nickname? For Vinnie (Microwave) Johnson, the No. 3 guard on the champion Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association, apparently a lucrative endorsement contract. Johnson scored so many points so fast after coming off the bench and entering a game three years ago that an awed opponent, Danny Ainge of the Boston Celtics, gave him the ''microwave'' label.

title: Tobacco Chewing: Concern Heightens
description: LEAD: A RECENT study shows that about one in three high school athletes in Hudson and Bergen Counties has tried chewing tobacco, despite warnings by experts that the practice has been linked to oral cancer and tooth loss.

title: Susan Ann Belfiglio Weds George Grimbilas Jr.
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susan Ann Belfiglio, the daughter of Ronald Belfiglio of New York and Susan Belfiglio of White Plains, to George Grimbilas Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grimbilas of New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony. Mrs. Grimbilas, 26 years old, graduated cum laude from Princeton University and received an M.B.A. from Columbia University. She is a management consultant in New York for the Boston Consulting Group. Her father is a vice president of Citibank. Her mother is the legal administrator for the New York law firm of Corbin, Silverman & Sanseverino.

title: 11th-Hour Syracuse Victory
description: John Biskup, who missed his fourth extra-point attempt of the season, kicked a 24-yard field goal with four seconds left today to lift Syracuse to a comeback triumph over East Carolina, 18-16.

title: The 'Subway to Nowhere' Now Goes Somewhere
description: Twenty years after its conception, a new subway-line extension - dubbed the subway to nowhere by its critics -made a ceremonial maiden run yesterday, rumbling under the East River from Manhattan to Roosevelt Island and into Queens. Regular service was to start today on the $868 million line, the first subway to the island.

title: How Safe Are Cruise Ships?
description: THE National Transportation Safety Board has conducted a broad investigation into the cruise business, and it is not happy.

title:
GARDENING;
A Diversity of Cultivars of Apples
description: LEAD: NOT too many people realize that the apple was once considered the national fruit, and cider the national drink. Today's produce markets are so filled with exotic fruit unheard of in earlier times. Despite the competition, though, apple production has exceeded 200 million boxes annually in most recent years.

title: Halloween: Big Business and Big Trouble
description: AS certainly as suburban doorbells chime when the sun goes down each Oct. 31, cash registers everywhere will relentlessly ring in the weeks preceding Halloween. Candy corn is steady at 99 cents a pound. A decent Batman costume will go as high as $20. Child-sized candy bars are piled up at the entrances and exits and checkout counters of grocery stores. School is back in session. Halloween is coming; it's in the air.

title: Housing On Aquifier Opposed
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER seeking permission to construct 21 houses on 16 acres in Westhampton has run into opposition from a homeowners' association and environmental groups. They say that such housing density should not be allowed over a sensitive water-recharge area.

title: Abused Children: Do Judges Know Best?
description: The article ''Grandparents Raising Children of Crack'' (Sept. 17) focused attention on the recurrent problem of what to do with children of abusive parents.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: A delivery experiment that failed yielded stamps and postal stationery that are inexpensive but hard to find, a combination that attracts hobbyists. The experiment - several experiments, actually - involved the delivery of mail by pneumatic tubes, which used vacuums to pull mail from one city station to another.

title: Julia Horn to Wed James L. Bosland
description: Mr. and Mrs. William B. Horn of Minneapolis have made known the engagement of their daughter Julia Laramee Horn to James Lockwood Bosland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Bosland of Short Hills, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Waterfront Transformation
description: LEAD: HOUSING projects along the eastern edge of Baltimore's waterfront are transforming an area that formerly was as a section of warehouses, industrial plants and vacant lots.

title: Miss Lee Weds Kraighton Stack
description: Alexandra Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Lee of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Kraighton Stack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian Stack of Albany and Glass Lake, N.Y. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: 50 Years of Batman at the Cartoon Museum
description: LEAD: BATMAN is spreading his cloak at the Museum of Cartoon Art on Comly Avenue in Rye Brook, in an exhibition of art and artifacts spanning the 50 years since the character's creation.

title: Susan L. Brinkley Wed in Baltimore
description: Susan Lynn Brinkley and John Francis Means, both 1988 graduates of the College of William and Mary, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Baltimore. The Rev. William N. McKeachie officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James Wellons Brinkley of Baltimore and Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Means of Alexandria, Va.

title: THE SELLING OF DNA
description: GENE DREAMS Wall Street, Academia, and the Rise of Biotechnology. By Robert Teitelman. 237 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: No. 1 Irish Trounce Panthers
description: Smarting over criticism of their manners and defending their top-ranked status, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame thrashed Pittsburgh, 45-7, today to extend their winning streak to 20 games over two seasons.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The new play-by-play announcer for Yankee games on the Madison Square Garden network is DeWayne Staats, who has been announcing Cubs games for five seasons. . . . Mark Breland, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, will defend his title for the third time, against Fujio Ozaki of Japan in Tokyo on Dec. 10. . . . Art Boileau of Canada and Zoya Ivanova of the Soviet Union, winners of the 1989 Los Angeles Marathon, have entered next Sunday's New York City Marathon.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: ''Relatively new?'' My wife and I did a month's auto tour of the Soviet Union, camping in our own car, 20 years ago. Judging from your story of Aug. 27, the only thing that has changed since then is that the gasoline hoses have nozzles. In 1969, the hoses just ended, and sometimes the fuel was supplied in jerry cans, not pumped.

title: A'S OTHER HENDERSON IS SPOTLIGHT
description: When the World Series picked itself up and began again Friday, it almost seemed as if the Oakland Athletics had been standing there impatiently, tapping their feet and folding their arms and waiting to play again.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: After the quake, the bars and the liquor stores reopened so people could drink. The movie theaters played on so people could laugh and cry in front of the screens. People went to work.

title: New York's Mayoral Rivals Support School Innovations
description: The next mayor of New York City wants to be held accountable for the successes and failures of the school system and is committed to sweeping changes in how the schools operate.

title: An Out-of-the-Way Place in Darien
description: BACKSTREET in Darien couldn't be more appropriately named. In a modest clapboard shopping complex, facing a municipal parking lot on a short, inconspicuous street off Route 1, just a block from the railroad overpass, the tiny restaurant requires directions to find. Backstreet has the easygoing atmosphere of a neighborhood drop-in place, with only about 50 seats. The menu contributes to a light-hearted spirit. At lunch there are salads, omelets, hamburgers and hot and cold sandwiches as well as an ample number of hearty and diverse entrees. Dinner crosses the map culinarily, from New England (with littleneck clams casino or clams on the half-shell) to Louisiana (Cajun popcorn and blackened fish of the day) and on to trendy California (warm chicken and watercress salad in raspberry vinaigrette, baked brie with fresh fruit). Detours to England (fish and chips), France (confit of duck, fillet of sole Francaise) and Italy (veal saltimbocca, scampi, chicken Milano) occur en route.

title:
AMERICAN CONTEMPORARY;
How to Tell A Fine Old Wine
description: LEAD: ''In spite of all that has been written about wines, the confusion in the minds of some lay drinkers is just as foggy as it was - in the case of some minds, even foggier. The main trouble, I think, is that the average wine connoisseur has suddenly become rather more the writing man than the sipping man without possessing that fine precision in expository composition that comes only from long years of writing, rewriting, cutting down and, most especially, throwing away.

title: Miss Gallagher To Wed in May
description: Jayne H. Gallagher of New York and Washington has made known the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Jayne Gallagher, to William Michael McManus Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McManus of Rockville Centre, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE OTHER SIDE OF ORIGINALITY
description: STOLEN WORDS Forays Into the Origins and Ravages of Plagiarism. By Thomas Mallon. 300 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Old Lyme
description: LEAD: WHEN town officials banned car dealerships and restaurant drive-through windows this summer, they did so to preserve a rural landscape that made this coastal community the home of artists of the American Impressionist movement in the early years of the century - among them, Henry Ward Ranger, Childe Hassam and Guy

title: FASHION: On the Street; Bending Tradition Just a Bit
description: After many years atop the illustrious domes of statesmen and politicians, the homburg is becoming a fashionable addition to the downtown look. So, thanks to brisk business at thrift shops and antique-clothing markets, are vintage snap-brim fedoras and that flat-topped favorite of 50's hipsters, the porkpie.

title: MARKET MADNESS
description: MANIAS, PANICS, AND CRASHES A History of Financial Crises. Revised Edition. By Charles P. Kindleberger. 302 pp. New York: Basic Books. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $12.95.

title: Mediation Can Aid Children in Divorce
description: The current divorce numbers do not change anything about the past - but the past is past.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
In a Sluggish Market, Property Auctions Gain
description: LEAD: AT a three-hour auction late last month, Dr. Simon Levy made the winning $158,000 bid on a seventh-floor, one-bedroom penthouse duplex at the Ocean Club in Long Beach. The unit, with slate floors, a whirlpool bath, a terrace overlooking the ocean and views of Manhattan, was one of 52 condominiums in the building that went on the block and were sold that day.

title: Trekking In Thailand's Hill Country
description: THE open-air truck noisly careered around the mountain, up steep, rocky hills and down the bumpy tree-lined roads. The 12 of us, sandwiched elbow-to-elbow in the back, alternately smiled, winced and strained our necks trying to catch a glipmse of a waterfall that graced the northern Thai landscape. It was 2 o'clock in the afternoon. The hot February sun (ever-present, even in this, the cool season) beat down on our backs as we swallowed great mouthfuls of dust.

title: Cooked Anchovies: A Different Taste
description: ANCHOVIES taste quite different when they are cooked. In the Piedmont region of Italy, raw vegetables are served with a classic hot dip made with anchovies, garlic and olive oil that is called bagna cauda. It is usually cooked in an earthenware pot brought to the table and kept warm over a spirit lamp.

title: Browsing Through Columbia's Jazz Reissue Bins
description: When long-playing records came on the market 40 years ago and began supplanting the 78-rpm disks that had been dominant for much of the preceding half-century, a colorful byproduct of the record business disappeared along with the 10- and 12-inch shellac platters.

title: Nancy B. Meyers Weds
description: Nancy B. Meyers and Scott L. Gottlieb, who both graduated from Woodmere (L.I.) Academy in 1982 and cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania in 1986, were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal officiated.
