The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Meyers of Belle Harbor, Queens, is the senior account executive at Omni Development and Marketing Ltd. in New York. Her husband, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Gottlieb of Lawrence, L.I., is a fourth-year student at Cornell University Medical College. Mr. and Mrs. Gottlieb are both 25 years old.

title: Woody as Rabbi
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama Still Undefeated After 7 Games
description: Someone threw a rock through Coach Bill Curry's office window after Alabama's disappointing 22-12 homecoming loss to Mississippi last year. This year someone might throw a parade for him.

title: Soviets Report Economic Decline Since July
description: The Soviet economy has worsened since July as strikes and ethnic conflicts cut into production, the Government reported today.

title: The Heyday of the Three-Martini Lunch
description: WE CALLED THEM SILVER BULLETS - they were six-ounce martinis made up of six ounces of gin, a drop of vermouth and a thin strip of lemon peel floating on the top, surrounded by a handful of silvery slivers of ice. ''Straight up'' was the way most people drank in the 1960's; ordering ''on the rocks'' was seen as a sign of weakness, as was the substitution of vodka. Olives displaced too much gin, and the only people who drank Gibsons were the effete heads of publishing companies. The town's bartenders took pride in picking up their cocktail shakers the minute they heard the voices of their favorite customers booming ''Hello, Dino.'' It was a simpler time - maitre d's names were limited to Dino or Gino in Italian restaurants and Pierre or Claude in French restaurants. By the time you made your way to the bar, your martini awaited you, drops of moisture icing the glass. You reached for it, took a first sip and said out loud, to no one in particular, ''Ah, that feels like jumping into a cool freshwater pond on a hot day.'' Another business lunch of the 60's was under way.

title: The Ivy League Isn't 'Half-Baked'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; Southwestern, French and Indian
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in the Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Arizona 206

title: 7 Guards Accused of Assault On Patrons at Meadowlands
description: Seven security guards at the Meadowlands sports complex in East Rutherford, N.J., have been arrested on charges of assaulting rock concert patrons there, the Bergen County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: HOW TO SUCCED IN BUSINESS? HERE'S THE SECRET....
description: I've just read - that is, tried to read - more than a dozen books about how to succeed in business. I now know what's wrong with most businesses: the businessmen are all home writing books about how to succeed.

title: Leila Penniman, Designer, Weds
description: Leila Thompson Penniman and Glenn Ridgely Hardy were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill, Pa., by the Rev. Charles Carter.

title: OVERPAID AND GUILT-RIDDEN
description: LIAR'S POKER Rising Through the Wreckage on Wall Street. By Michael Lewis. 249 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: Another Quarter Of Economic Growth
description: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, the Commerce Department reported. The overall advance matched that of the April-June period. Economists found reason to cheer in the report's indication of lower third-quarter inflation, even though that was mostly a reflection of falling energy prices. The data also showed no growth in exports and a 15.1 percent increase in imports. *

title: Evening Hours; Benefits for the Arts, Children and AIDS
description: Cartier's resembled the Mad Hatter's tea party Thursday night when nearly 100 young dancers age 8 to 14, all looking like Alice in Wonderland, gathered for a celebration. The young dancers, all members of the School of American Ballet, are to perform in this year's ''Nutcracker'' at Lincoln Center.

title: One Struggle Over, Attention Turns to Guilt
description: One afternoon two years ago, when Richard Wesley was feeling especially frustrated in his effort to write a play about what W. E. B. Du Bois had called ''the talented tenth'' of black America, he drove from his suburban New Jersey home to visit cousins in Harlem. Heading across 145th Street, he noticed a car wash and decided to pull in. And as he did, a skinny young man with a bucket and squeegee in hand and a sheath of rags draped across his shoulder offered to do the job for a few dollars less.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Jackson $130,500 3 Dina Place 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old contemporary; c/a, 1-car garage, den, pool; taxes $2,198. Lakewood $105,000 75 Columbus Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old ranch; patio, dining room, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,381. Millburn $239,000 28 East Manchester Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,378. Orange $115,000 221 High Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; den, 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,855. Short Hills $490,000 28 Tioga Pass 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; fireplace in living room, 2-car garage, patio; taxes $6,426. Wall $130,000 1016 Atlantic Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old ranch; sun porch, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,170. OTHER AREAS Stamford, Conn. $305,000 210 Rockrimmon Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; pond on property, hardwood floors, 1 acre; taxes $3,638. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $328,000 Hunter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, screened porch, 1-car garage; taxes $5,656. Islip, L.I. $96,000 100 Wilson Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400.

title: One Coach Had to Lose; Bellport Won
description: Joe Cipp and Sal Ciampi are high school football coaches who spend an average of 40 hours a week preparing for game days. They push themselves as hard as their players, and while Ciampi has attempted to retire, Cipp has just been contemplating it. Being so similar in nature, it's no coincidence they are considered two of the best coaches on Long Island.

title: Low Tax Rceipts Vex County Officials
description: LEAD: CONVINCED that Long Island has been shortchanged by the state on sales-tax returns, Nassau and Suffolk County officials predicted last week that an audit by Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller, would increase the counties' shares.

title: Frank F. Blaisdell, Mayor, 76
description: Frank F. Blaisdell, a former mayor of Middletown Township in New Jersey and longtime business and community leader in Red Bank, N.J., died at his home Thursday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Liberal Causes Cash In On a Rash of Conservatism
description: While most nonprofit groups struggle to maintain their services, several liberal advocacy groups have had to deal with a different problem: how to manage phenomenal growth.

title: Medicaid Rules Revised Against Hospital Fraud
description: The agency that administers the Medicaid program in New York City has issued stringent new guidelines to prevent what workers at several hospitals have said was pervasive fraud by the hospitals against the health insurance program for the poor.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: To: The Students Who Released Those Balloons

title: A Journal In Search of Folklore
description: LEAD: CAN you recall the words of a strange song that your grandparents used to sing? Do you know a version of a familiar story that is different from the widely accepted version?

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Nassau
description: The Bahamian capital, Nassau, spared the destruction that Hurricane Hugo wreaked on the neighboring Caribbean, is in the midst of its biggest construction boom ever. Casinos are being renovated and expanded and new development is evident all over the island. A flourishing economy is apparent in a multitude of new city buses, shopping malls and services.

title: Review/Music; Gary Thomas's Rhythms
description: Jazz is, as usual, translating aspects of popular music for its own purposes. The process could be heard full blown in a set the tenor saxophonist Gary Thomas played at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. Using funk and go-go beats, Mr. Thomas and his rhythm section, aided and abetted by a drum machine, a computer or two and a rack of other electronic tools, turned in a show that had all the furor of a funk band and all the polish of a space-age pop show.

title: New York
description: LIKE MOST AMERICAN DESIGNERS, DONNA KARAN HAS BEEN WORK-ing round the clock on her spring collection. Late one recent night came a moment of truth. The gorgeous fabric spun of sheer linen and glossed with golden metal threads had been months in the making in Italy. Now it had finally arrived. It draped like a dream, but when it met the sewing machine - screeeeech! -the metal refused to move with the linen to make smooth seams. There went the plans for a good part of Karan's new collection. But when Donna wants something, she finds a way. And so with ingenuity and different fabrics, she has accomplished what she set out to - spring clothes that sparkle plenty.

title: Virginia Campaign Watched As Test on Abortion Rights
description: L. Douglas Wilder has built his campaign for governor of Virginia around his support for abortion rights to an extent that no major candidate for high office has ever dared before.

title: Susan Kohnken Is Married
description: Susan J. Kohnken, an assistant Suffolk County district attorney in Riverhead, L.I., and Joseph R. Onorato, an assistant Nassau County district attorney in Mineola, L.I., were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., by the Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. Mrs. Onorato, 35 years old, is a daughter of George J. Kohnken of Barefoot Bay, Fla., and the late Mary Jane Kohnken. A graduate of Fordham University, as is her husband, she received a J. D. degree from the Brooklyn Law School. Mr. Onorato, 40, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Onorato, received a law degree from Hofstra University. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Police Abuse Is Down, But Concern Has Risen
description: THE police and citizens here have had many violent clashes over the years, but the city had never held hearings on police brutality until last month, when a group of black politicians asserted that brutality was increasing.

title: Six Candidates Seek Ears, Not Votes
description: The Libertarian Party candidate for mayor of New York City runs his one-man campaign organization out of his midtown Manhattan stockbroker's office, where he writes his own literature - ''I'm anti-big government'' - photocopies it and mails it out.

title: Trading Places
description: The new players for each team, and how they were acquired (r-rookie; t-trade; fa-free agent; e-expansion draft): Atlanta Hawks: Roy Marble (r), Aleksandr Volkov (r), Haywoode Workman (r) Boston Celtics: Michael Smith (r), John Bagley (t) Charlotte Hornets: Stuart Gray (t), J.R. title: Karen Barbanel Weds
description: Karen S. Barbanel, a senior enforcement attorney at the New York Stock Exchange, was married last evening to Warren A. Estis, a partner in the New York law firm of Rosenberg & Estis. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sidney W. Barbanel of Manhasset, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Estis of West Palm Beach, Fla. The bridegroom's first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Business Lunch: A Personal Approach
description: IN WASHINGTON, GEORGETTE MOSBACHER IS known primarily as the wife of a Cabinet member and as a glamorous addition to the capital's party circuit.

title: SO MUCH MORE THAN VIRGINIA'S HUSBAND
description: LETTERS OF LEONARD WOOLF Edited by Frederic Spotts. Illustrated. 616 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch; An Old-Timer, a Newer Standby
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Gage & Tollner

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A DROP OF HONEYAn Armenian Tale. By Djemma Bider. Illustrated by Armen Kojoyian. Unpaged. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Movement for a Historic Graveyard
description: LEAD: THE ghost of Hartford's past can rest more easily now that restoration of the city's Ancient Burying Ground is near completion.

title:
BOOK & BUSINESS;
THE LANGUAGE OF MONEY
description: LEAD: THE GLOBAL BANKERS By Roy C. Smith. 405 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: TOUGH CHOICES: The Decision-Making Styles of America's Top 50 CEOs. By Warren J. Pelton, Sonja Sackmann and Robert Boguslaw. (Dow Jones-Irwin, $24.95.) The authors have set themselves the slippery task of writing a book about how to recognize and deal with business situations ''not treatable with standard textbook solutions'' - which they call Type 2 situations.

title: Why Not an Aperitif
description: AN APERITIF IS BOTH A DRINK and an occasion, a point in time when the day's labors are suspended and the fun part begins. An aperitif smoothes the rumples, cleanses the palate and wakes up the stomach. In Europe, its role in the ritual of hospitality is so central that over the years a whole class of specially concocted drinks has evolved based on secret, almost alchemical formulas.

title: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS
description: LEAD: RUST TO RICHES: The Coming of the Second Industrial Revolution. By John Rutledge and Deborah Allen. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) Now that best-selling doomsday scenarios are passe, John Rutledge and Deborah Allen argue in ''Rust to Riches'' that the business cycle theory is almost obsolete and that future recessions, whenever they come, will be ''less frequent, less severe, and less pervasive than we have seen in the past.

title: LATE-NIGHT COOL
description: Michael Norman does well to praise Arsenio Hall for his deserved success on late-night television. But to portray him as a maverick slights the fresh format of ''Late Night With David Letterman,'' a show that preceded Mr. Hall's by roughly six years.

title: Bacon's the One
description: To the Editor:

title: Marion Bartle, Investment Manager, Weds John N. Packs in Massachusetts
description: The marriage of Marion Stuart Bartle, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Bartle of Lee, Mass., and New York, to John Nicholas Packs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Packs of Endicott, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans, the rector of St. Paul's, and the Rev. Stamatios Ganiaris, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Limit on Soliciting a Day's Work
description: Just 30 miles south of Los Angeles, which has just begun a program helping day laborers find jobs, Costa Mesa is taking the opposite approach to the growing number of illegal aliens who gather on street corners seeking work.

title: 'Garments the Living Wear'
description: In ''Garments the Living Wear,'' the wit and sauce of a James Purdy drawing room extravaganza collide with the supernatural hyperbole of one of his trademark riffs on the Southern gospel tradition. The consequence is a transvestite-transsexual comedy of gay mannerism that is as reminiscent of Joan Crawford and Bette Davis in ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'' as it is of Wilde, Sheridan, the Book of Revelation and down-home Pentecostal awakenings. Once again, Mr. Purdy - who is the author of more than a dozen novels as well as poetry, stories and plays - has produced fiction that could easily pass (at least in part) as the writings of a richly inspired prophet who's been disqualified from the realm of the sacred texts on the grounds of explicit sex and especially rowdy humor.

title: The Smugness Of Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Schwartz Weds Tony Eprile
description: Judith Dora Schwartz and Tony Eprile, who are writers, were married last evening at the French Culinary Institute in New York. Rabbi Bruce Dollin officiated. The bride, 28 years old, will keep her name. She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Schwartz of Schenectady, N.Y. She is a graduate of Brown University and the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. The bride's father is a physician.

title: Miami Undone By Turnovers
description: Undone by six turnovers, two of them coming 1 yard from a touchdown, the University of Miami hopes for a perfect season came apart tonight with a 24-10 loss to Florida State.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Driving in the Soviet Union is indeed the best way to experience the joys and frustrations of that country. I was sorry to see, however, that there was no mention of the group trips run by Pioneer Travel Service of Cambridge, Mass. Pioneer has operated camping and driving trips to the Soviet Union for 23 years. The trips include group leaders and extensive handbooks that allow travelers to avoid pitfalls. This guidance encourages them to exercise independence, which most travelers to the Soviet Union fear, and to experience things that no ordinary tour (and few individual travelers) would experience.

title: The New Business Lunch: Offbeat Restaurants
description: DICK BYRNE, AN EXECUTIVE vice president of a New York advertising agency, is a veteran of more long, bibulous business lunches than he cares to recall. Only 10 years ago, these affairs were routinely held at such Establishment bastions as La Cote Basque, The Four Seasons and Christ Cella. On a recent occasion, however, when clients came in from out of town, Mr. Byrne took them to a whimsical Chinese restaurant with a barnyard motif called Pig Heaven.

title: Tempting Offer in Irvington, but How Should Village Respond?
description: THE village made famous by such l9th-century residents as John Jacob Astor 3d, Louis Comfort Tiffany and its namesake, Washington Irving, has gained a new claim to fame. In the last 10 years, this sleepy Hudson River community has become the fastest-growing village in the county, increasing an average 12.1 percent each year in population.

title: Exchange Program of Jobs Worldwide
description: WHEN 23-year-old Debra Commey of Accra, Ghana, was an accounting student at the University of Ghana, she never dreamed that she would work for the International Business Machines Corporation. But now she is in the accounting section of I.B.M.'s Latin American division in North Tarrytown.

title: Reviews/Music; Half of X Equals Cervenka
description: X, the standard-bearers for Los Angeles punk-rock in the early 1980's, revolved around the songwriting partnership and marriage of John Doe and Exene Cervenka. Both relationships have broken up, and with her current album, ''Old Wives' Tales,'' and the band she brought to the Lone Star Roadhouse on Tuesday night, Ms. Cervenka is untangling the separate strands that went into X's music.

title: Margaret Enloe, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Margaret Anne Enloe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Enloe of Ardsley, N.Y., was married yesterday in Fogelsville, Pa., to Steven Rand McIntyre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William McIntyre of La Porte, Tex. Judge James T. Giles of Federal District Court in Philadelphia officiated at the home of the bride's uncle, Charles Dent.

title: Long Island Sound: Problems and Solutions
description: I am writing in regard to your article ''L.I. Sound: Deep Splits Mar a Cause'' (Sept. 24) and your accompanying description of Long Island Sound advocacy organizations.

title: Dr. Patricia A. White Weds
description: At St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Ossining, N.Y., Dr. Patricia Anne White, an assistant professor of medicine at the New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y., and Daniel Kevin Flatley, a vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Michael Connolly officiated. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. White of Babylon, L.I., graduated from St. John's University and the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center. Mr. Flatley, a graduate of the University of Notre Dame who has a law degree from Georgetown University and an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Flatley of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Effort to Repair an Old Project Lifts Tenants' Spirits (and Paintbrushes)
description: Parishioners from middle-class churches in the Chicago area have been spending their weekends since July fixing abandoned apartments in a rundown public housing project where even the police are reluctant to venture after dark.

title: Shortage of Officials Hurts Soccer
description: LEAD: AS the assigning commissioner of the Southern Connecticut Soccer Officials Association, Jack Mullady is accustomed to spending much of his time on the telephone insuring that two officials will show up for each game played by the nearly 30 high schools in his territory. Lately the telephone line to Mr.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE PLACE IN FLOWERS WHERE POLLEN RESTS, by Paul West. (Collier/Macmillan, $9.95.) After a descent into some of the worst white America has to offer - the Los Angeles pornography industry and the war in Vietnam - a young Hopi Indian returns to the center of his earth in the Arizona mesas. Last year our reviewer, Thomas R. Edwards, called this ''a rich, often astonishing meditation upon how a particular human culture can represent a source of 'otherness' - the imagination itself - that persists even in a world that other modes of thought and desire have made almost uninhabitable.'' A BRIGHT SHINING LIE: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam, by Neil Sheehan. (Vintage, $12.95.) John Paul Vann was the one officer the correspondents covering the Vietnam War felt they could trust. But in the end he, like the war itself, turned out to be a carefully crafted deception. ''Immensely long, enormously ambitious, told with an emotion that bursts through its pages, this is an impressive achievement,'' Ronald Steel said in The Book Review last year. ''If there is one book that captures the Vietnam War in the sheer Homeric scale of its passion and folly, this book is it.'' It won both a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award. BELIEVE THEM, by Mary Robison. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) In one of these short stories, a retarded girl and her siblings briefly take control of the house while their parents are away. Last year our reviewer, Larry McCaffery, complimented Mary Robison on ''her fascination with the grotesque and darkly comic, her characterizations of quirky people possessing odd tics of speech and behavior - in short, her intuitive feel for the surrealistic dimensions of American life that lie barely concealed under the ordinary.'' GUMSHOE: Reflections in a Private Eye, by Josiah Thompson. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) In this memoir, a Kierkegaard scholar tells how he suffered an existential crisis and changed his life by becoming a private eye. ''Surveillance reminds him of the closing section of Sartre's 'Being and Nothingness,' '' The Times's John Gross said last year. ''References to Merleau-Ponty and Heidegger are all in a day's work.'' STORIES IN AN ALMOST CLASSICAL MODE, by Harold Brodkey. (Vintage, $12.95.) In some very long stories with very long sentences, Harold Brodkey writes about the relentlessness of suffering. ''The prose, then, is a prose of painful abundance,'' Frank Kermode said here last year. ''He recollects in a sort of poetic fury, nothing is too strained or too bizarre.'' ''WHAT DO YOU CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'': Further Adventures of a Curious Character, by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Bantam, $9.95.) Last year our reviewer, James Gleick, said this sequel to ''Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman'' shows that the physicist was ''not just a bongo-playing, skirt-chasing, joke-telling prankster, but a man, always earnest and sometimes troubled, who thought more deeply than most about the power and the limitations of science.'' The book includes Feynman's experiences as a member of the commission investigating the Challenger explosion. MASCARA, by Ariel Dorfman. (Penguin, $7.95.) A man without a face uses photography to steal the visages of others. This novel is ''an ominous fairy tale, a literary horror story, a post-modern version of Jekyll and Hyde,'' Robert Atwan said here last year. ''But the book is also a parable of human identity and paranoia engendered by authoritarian politics.'' UNDER A CRUEL STAR: A Life in Prague, 1941-1968, by Heda Margolius Kovaly. Translated by Franci Epstein and Helen Epstein with the author. (Penguin, $8.95.) A Czechoslovak Jew tells how she escaped from Auschwitz, only to suffer later under Stalin's crushing of the Prague Spring. ''Mrs. Kovaly experienced the two supreme horrors of what Hannah Arendt called this terrible century,'' Anthony Lewis said in The Times in 1986. ''But her book is not just a personal memoir of inhumanity. In telling her story - simply, without self-pity - she illuminates some general truths of human behavior.'' HOT SIBERIAN, by Gerald A. Browne. (Avon, $4.95.) In this thriller about an international diamond caper involving the Soviet Union, ''the plot gets more and more complicated, the pace wilder and wilder,'' Newgate Callendar said here earlier this year. ''The beautifully written 'Hot Siberian' will keep you entranced.'' THE BODY IN TIME, by Kenneth Jon Rose. (Wiley, $10.95.) Ticking in rhythms as brief as milliseconds, as long as years, the human body is a carefully synchronized machine, as the biologist Kenneth Jon Rose explains in this book. Last year our reviewer, Iris Poliski, said its fascinating text was studded with arresting bits of information ''like garlic slivers plugged into a roast.'' AN AMERICAN MEMORY, by Eric Larsen. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) A young man is driven toward madness as he tries to understand his childhood on a remote Minnesota farm with an austere Lutheran father. '' 'An American Memory' is as much a prose poem as a novel,'' Dinitia Smith said here last year. Eric Larsen has written it ''in language as sparse and wind-riven as the Midwest of his imagination.'' ECHOES OF REVOLT: The Masses, 1911-1917, edited by William L. O'Neill. (Elephant/Ivan R. Dee, $18.95.) In its day a little magazine called The Masses was considered so radical that in 1917 the United States Post Office refused to allow it in the mails. In 1966 our reviewer, Peter Lyon, said that capturing its spirit in this anthology of writing, cover art and cartoons called for ''a kind of psychic taxidermy.'' It is ''a splendid achievement, and we are all the luckier to have this bonny reminder of the good old, golden days of American radicalism.''

title: The Muted Beauty of November
description: NOVEMBER is a beautiful month. October gets all the attention because every hill and valley and suburban street is ablaze with autumn color, but November has its own charm.

title: Among War's Toll in Mozambique: Empty Stomachs
description: The refugees - hungry, barefoot and nearly naked - straggle in daily from the bush, fleeing a guerrilla war that they do not comprehend and looking for relief from a Government that has little to give.

title:
GARDENING;
A Diversity of Cultivars of Apples
description: LEAD: NOT too many people realize that the apple was once considered the national fruit, and cider the national drink. Today's produce markets are so filled with exotic fruit unheard of in earlier times. Despite the competition, though, apple production has exceeded 200 million boxes annually in most recent years.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Michigan; Marshmallows Are Added To List of Missiles
description: The University of Michigan athletics department is taking action against marshmallows and students in wolverine costumes. After receiving complaints from fans, the school has added marshmallows to the list of items prohibited in the 101,701-seat Michigan Stadium.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: Tournament bridge players have a major problem that tournament chess players solved more than a century ago: slow play. The chess clock, with its associated time limits and forfeitures for exceeding them, cannot conveniently be applied in bridge events although there have been attempts.

title: Under Full Sail From Monte Carlo To Italy's Coast
description: IT was a cool, windy night when we pulled away from the pier in Monte Carlo and headed out to an almost frighteningly black vacuum of sea and sky. The blizzard of lights from the resort's densely packed apartment buildings was growing dimmer and dimmer when we noticed, off in the darkness, an odd, towerlike object lighted up like a Christmas tree.

title: Dancing to a Revolutionary Beat
description: Maguy Marin, considered one of France's most audacious young choreographers, has always gone her own way, and never the same way twice. In her latest work, ''Hey, What's All This to Me!?'' (''Eh, Qu'est Ce Que Ca M'Fait a Moi!?''), an abrasive rock musical about the French Revolution, Miss Marin shows that the glut of bicentennial reverence has not slowed her down. It's a riotous show, performed by her company - 12 dancers, 8 musicians, 2 singers, and Miss Marin herself, who belts out an incendiary tango or two.

title: DELIGHTFUL CROCODILES
description: THE MEDICI AESOP Spencer Ms. 50. Translated by Bernard McTigue. Introduction by Everett Fahy. Illustrated. 175 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $45.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Octoberfest, 42d Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas will be closed today from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: The Details: Tips From Seasoned Hosts
description: MOST SUCCESSFUL HOSTS ARE KNOWN BY A PARTICULAR approach that makes their parties work - for themselves as well as for their guests. Whether it is the design of a kitchen enabling guests to join in the cooking or a flair for creating quirky centerpieces, there are certain details that set these hosts apart and make their gatherings memorable. Some of these ideas - culled from those who gave the parties on the preceding pages - are given here. And a bonus: An expert reveals the secrets of a versatile culinary classic. DESIGNING A KITCHEN FOR GUEST COOKS

title: From the Grass Roots, Group Helps Disabled
description: LEAD: WHEN a mother receiving welfare benefits called the Disability Helpline in New Haven about finding a pediatric bed for her autistic mentally retarded 4-year-old, Lori Hanna approached Medicaid and then the State Department of Mental Retardation, both of which said they could not help.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
description: When you get knocked down, you have two choices: you get up or you stay down. Play ball. MATT JACKSON Brooklyn

title: Mansions Sprouting in a Tiny Florida Town
description: LEAD: THIS little town 10 minutes south of Palm Beach has developed more slowly than many of its oceanfront counterparts. But skyrocketing land values - one home appreciated $4 million in just seven years - and prime lots that front both the Atlantic Ocean and the Intracoastal Waterway have sparked a building boom in this town of fewer than 400 residents.

title: Nicaraguans Bracing for a Return To a War They Hoped Was Over
description: Pessimism and apprehension descended here today as Nicaraguans and foreign officials learned that Sandinista leaders might end their 19-month cease-fire with contra rebel forces.

title: Exxon Valdez Trial to Be Held in Anchorage
description: The trial of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood, skipper of the Exxon Valdez, will be held in Anchorage despite claims by the defense that it will be hard to field an impartial jury here.

title: Jan C. Grossman Engaged to Marry
description: The engagement of Jan Carol Grossman to Joshua Morton Rubins, a son of Eve Rubins of Baldwin, L.I., and the late Dr. Irving Rubins, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Grossman of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: Warhorses On The Campaign Trail
description: A FEW weeks before the last election of the 1980's, John S. DaVanzo is campaigning as if it were still the 50's.

title: In Peekskill, Fodor Resumes His Concerts
description: ''I HAVEN'T had a drink or drug since this thing happened,'' said Eugene Fodor, the celebrated violinist, who was recently placed on three years' probation after his arrest last July for possession of cocaine and other charges. ''I'm thinking with a clearer mind and I've never felt better in my life. I'm also establishing friendships with people who share the common goal of a lifetime of sobriety, and that is really exciting.''

title: William Warmus: Curator of Glass
description: Both his father, a glass blower at the Corning Glass Works, and his wife's grandfather, a Norwegian glass blower, may have had something to do with William Warmus's interest in contemporary glass.

title: Northeast Forests, Too, Get Congress's Interest
description: CONGRESSIONAL debate over the future of American forests has almost always concentrated on the vast timber-growing areas of the Pacific Northwest and Alaska. But slowly, the future of another heavily forested region, the Northeast, has begun to stir concern on Capitol Hill.

title: Basic Education At Nassau Community
description: ''In the article ''Colleges Increase Remedial Efforts for Marginal Students'' (Oct. 1), you did not mentioning the Basic Education Program at Nassau Community College.

title: Jessye Norman's Mediterranean Specialty
description: WHEN JESSYE NORMAN speaks of food, the conversation may turn to Gustav Mahler - not as surprising as it may seem, given her renown as an interpreter of his music. In fact, the Austrian composer led her, in a manner of speaking, to discover one of her favorite dishes, a Corsican specialty, her variation of which is given here.

title: Baseball Comes Back With a Flop in the Dirt
description: Some people will say baseball came back with the cathartic ceremony on Friday night, 12 saviors from the earthquake throwing out 12 first pitches: ''Real heroes,'' as Dave Stewart would call them.

title: Don't Play Games With Water Quality
description: After this year's spring rains, New Yorkers put aside worries about the quantity of their water supply and started debating its quality. For 150 years, the city's supply has been coming from what was sparsely settled countryside.

title: Software Services of America reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Capital Ties Murder Record
description: The District of Columbia matched its year-old record for homicides today with five killings in a seven-hour period that pushed this year's total to 369 killings. Three of the weekend killings were linked to drugs, as are most of the slayings in the nation's capital. The police said at the end of 1988 that homicides took 372 lives that year, but three victims of police shootings were subtracted from the total Sunday.

title: Almost Close to Home
description: There's no reason to expect a basketball team founded in Chicago and headquartered in Hollywood to have any players from New York, except for one thing. The team is the Harlem Globetrotters.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Head of Y.&R.; To Be Relieved
description: LEAD: The president of Young & Rubicam New York has asked to be relieved of his duties temporarily, three weeks after being indicted on charges that he and other agency executives bribed Jamaican Government officials to obtain Jamaica's tourism advertising account.

title: Commuter Plane Crashes in Hawaii Valley, Killing All 20 Aboard
description: A commuter plane with 20 people aboard, including members of a high school volleyball team, crashed into a remote vally on Molokai late Saturday. There were no survivors.

title: Unifi Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Included a credit of $1,852,844 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Michelle Maggal Is Wed
description: Michelle Judith Maggal, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Moshe M. Maggal of Las Vegas, Nev., and Arnold Steven Weinstein, a son of Bella Weinstein of White Plains and the late Milton Weinstein, were married yesterday at the Ballroom at 24 Fifth Avenue in New York. The bride's father officiated. Mrs. Weinstein, 32 years old, attended Hebrew University in Jerusalem and graduated from San Diego State University. She is the manager of office automation operations at the United Nations. The bridegroom, 31, a graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, is a systems analyst at the Loral Corporation, an electronics manufacturer in Yonkers.

title: Early Signs Appear In Maine's Upset
description: A pass thrown by the Maine quarterback, Mike Buck, was intercepted early in the game Saturday in Newark, Del. Right then it may have occurred to some of the Black Bears that this game could be different.

title: Freeport-McMoran Copper Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brenda W. Kunofsky,An Executive, Marries
description: At Congregation B'nai Jacob in Waterbury, Conn., Brenda Wynne Kunofsky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kunofksy of Waterbury, was married yesterday to Keith Ronald Herrmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Herrmann of San Leandro, Calif., by Rabbi Michael Menitoff.

title: Books of The Times; Judge (Not Justice) Bork on His Defeat
description: The Tempting of America The Political Seduction of the Law By Robert H. Bork 432 pages. The Free Press/Macmillan. $22.50.

title: Sports of The Times; A's Outrun a Bad Memory
description: THIS World Series, which will always be remembered for the big bang smack in the middle of it, ended with a bang-bang play, as they say in baseball.

title: Advance Ross Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest 9-month share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS:Advertising;
'Jump' Stays, Slogan Shifts For Toyota
description: LEAD: MOST television viewers are quite familiar with the ''Toyota jump,'' the leap of enthusiasm performed by Toyota owners at the end of commercials for the Japanese cars and trucks.

title: Turbo Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,494,000, or 1 cent a share, and $1,928,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,873,000, or 2 cents a share, and $4,960,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CGC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Nuclear Plant Remains Shut
description: A problem with a cooling system at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear-power plant will keep the plant from reopening on schedule, plant officials said today. The plant was shut down almost two weeks ago when a malfunction was discovered in its electronic system. It was being brought back on line late last week when a problem with the cooling system was discovered, said Robert Burtch, a spokesman for Niagara Mohawk, a co-owner of the plant.

title: Franklin Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Art; Poetry and Showmanship of Frederic Church
description: When Mark Twain encountered Frederic Edwin Church's enormous landscape painting ''The Heart of the Andes'' during its national tour in 1860, the usually skeptical Missourian turned rhapsodic. ''Your third visit will find your brain gasping and straining with futile efforts to take all the wonder in,'' he wrote to his brother, preparing him for the painting's miles-deep vista, its profusely and accurately detailed forest, distant waterfall, rolling plain and crowning mass of lofty yet gentle mountain peaks.

title: RS Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Koss Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $59,000, or 2 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $53,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year- ago period.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Top East Germans heard complaints for almost five hours on the steps of City Hall East Berlin. ''You are finished,'' one man told the East Berlin Communist Party chief. ''Give us free elections.'' Page A1

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Wells, Rich, Greene Lures Creative Partner
description: LEAD: Wells, Rich, Greene has lured one of the brightest lights in the Boston advertising business to its Image Group. On Friday, Cheryl Heller, the chairman and creative director of Heller/Breene in Boston, was named executive vice president and creative partner for the group.

title: 4 Rising Stars Behind Magazine Success Stories
description: While graying and grayed executives still dominated the American Magazine Conference here in late October, the thirtysomething generation is increasingly taking over the magazines.

title: Dole Suggests Increase In Federal Gasoline Tax
description: In a move that could generate bipartisan momentum for a Federal tax increase, Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, said today that he would support an increase in the gasoline tax.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd. named William J. Russo senior vice president of public affairs and advertising.

title: Grubb & Ellis reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Thursday referred incorrectly to a sale of three subsidiaries by the Parker Hannifin Corporation. The company is selling its three automotive aftermarket units; it will retain its automotive connectors and cliff impact metal-forming divisions.

title: In Many Town Halls, Professionals Rule
description: Town halls around the New York metropolitan region, once the province of public-spirited amateurs, have been inundated in the last decade by lawyers and consultants. Article, page B3.

title: Outdoors: It's Time For Deer Hunters To Be Zeroing In
description: THIS is the time to make sure that your deer rifle shoots where you aim it, a process called zeroing in.

title: INSIDE
description: Spanish Prime Minister Wins a Third Term The Socialist party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez claimed a majority of one seat in Spain's general elections, winning 176 seats in the 350-seat Parliament and assuring Mr. Gonzalez of a third term. Page A3. Ortega's Miscalculation The Nicaraguan President brought a political bombshell to a meeting of Western Hemisphere leaders. But it appears to have exploded in his own hands. News analysis, page A8. Dole Backs Fuel Tax Rise Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, became the first top Republican to say he would support an increase in the gasoline tax. Page A15. Defense in Bensonhurst The young white men accused in the death of a black teen-ager prepare to argue that the slaying was just a tragic mistake. Page B1 Thatcher Steadfast Britain's Prime Minister will support a single European currency - if other nations abandon a ''higgledy-piggledy set of rules.'' Page D1. Be Prepared, and Cool Using images and language of pop culture, the Boy Scouts is trying to change its image. Page D12.

title: Marquest Medical Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1988 results were restated.

title: Robert Van Fossan, 63, Chairman Of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance
description: Robert V. Van Fossan, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company and a longtime New Jersey civic leader, died of cancer yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Mendham, N.J.

title: Focus Is on Raising the Debt Limit
description: For much of the 1980's, official Washington has chosen a dubious milestone - a necessary increase in the nation's debt ceiling - as the appropriate moment to call a political scrimmage.

title: 2 Hard Years For the Contras
description: Aug. 7, 1987The Presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica agree to prohibit the use of their territories for insurgencies and commit themselves to greater democracy and dialogue with guerrilla forces.

title: Economic Calendar

No More Room For Amateurs In Town Halls
description: Small-town government, once the province of public-spirited part-time amateurs and sleepy local issues, has been surrounded in the last decade by lawyers, consultants, planners, environmental regulators and real-estate developers who have closed in on town halls and changed them forever.

title: Ex-Officer Sees Gains If He Wins Sharon Steel
description: Walter Sieckman, who has twice left executive positions with the Sharon Steel Corporation, says he cannot seem to stay away from the company, the nation's 17th-largest steel producer.

title: Bills Put Brake on Marino To Win
description: This was supposed to be an afternoon where the tougher and vengeful Miami Dolphins staked their claim in the American Conference East race while proving they were a playoff-caliber team. The matchup against the Buffalo Bills would give Miami's defense a chance to show that its recent successes were not a fluke.

title: Khmer Rouge Report Gains On Highway to a Major City
description: The Khmer Rouge said today that their guerrillas were advancing in an attempt to capture a main route from a western Cambodian outpost at Pailin to the city of Battambang.

title: 93-Day and 184-Day Bills to Be Auctioned
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to today's amended bill auction. Instead of the regular three-month and six-month maturities, the Treasury will auction 93-day and 184-day bills.

title: Seira Greenwald Weds Elihu Davison
description: Cheryl Joy Greenwald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Leonard Greenwald of Pittsburgh and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Elihu David Davison, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sol Davison of Washington. Rabbi Eli Leiter performed the ceremony at the Women's Club of Glen Ridge, N.J.

Macchiarola, who has the unusual perspective of an academic, a former New York City Schools Chancellor and a losing candidate for city comptroller. ''They promise $2 worth of services for the $1 we have.''

description: A skittish ''junk bond'' market forced buyers of the CNW Corporation to make significant last-minute changes in the financing of their $1.6 billion buyout of the railroad company, officials involved in the plan said.

description: The Orchestre de la Suisse Romande will never, and perhaps should never, escape its long identification with Ernest Ansermet, who founded the ensemble in 1918 and conducted it for 50 years.

description: To the Editor:

title: TRAINING JET CRASH KILLS 5 ON CARRIER
description: Five people were killed and at least two were critically injured yesterday afternoon when a Navy jet trainer crash-landed on the deck of the aircraft carrier Lexington in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The leading role of the party will remain. This is not open to discussion. This dialogue will take place within these confines. The leading role of the Communist Party is the only alternative to decaying capitalist society. But the leading role must be a genuine consensus between the party and the broad masses.'' -Gunter Schabowski, the East Berlin party leader. [ A6:1. ]

description: As the college football season moved within a month of the Saturday evening when deals are made and invitations to bowl games are officially extended, the possibilities involving a game for an unofficial national championship became clearer this weekend.

title: Jets Stumble Again But It's Predictable
description: It was predictable, if not disastrous.

title: Would-Be Robber Loses Gun And Is Shot By Storekeeper
description: A Queens shopkeeper turned a would-be robber's shotgun on him yesterday but injured four passers-by in the process, the police said.

title: Premier Canadian Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Socialists Win Majority in Spanish Vote
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain secured a third term in office early today after a cliffhanger general election Sunday in which his Socialist Workers Party came within one seat of losing its majority in Parliament.

title: U.S. Aid Sought for Electronics
description: In a report that will be delivered to the President this week, a national advisory committee on semiconductors will recommend that the Government establish a multibillion-dollar venture capital operation intended to resurrect the American consumer electronics industry.

title: The Day After, Prague Is Under Police Guard
description: Tension remained high in Prague today as hundreds of armed policemen patrolled the city streets, with many more massed at important intersections, ready to crush any resumption of the rallies that filled the center of the city on Saturday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: To End the Race Well, Start Well
description: IF you are among the 23,000 runners entered in the 20th New York City marathon Sunday, the most important factor in how well you run and how much you enjoy it will be your pace during the first few miles.

title: Defendants to Argue Hawkins Killing Was Not Racial
description: Two months after the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager, Yusuf K. Hawkins, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the seven white defendants are preparing to argue in court that the crime was not racially motivated. Most defendants also plan to assert that they were not at the scene of the shooting or were unaware that the man accused of pulling the trigger, Joseph Fama, had a gun.

title: Flexsteel Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $551,581, or 8 cents a share, in nontaxable life insurance proceeds.

description: b-Net loss

title: Government Spreading Net To Break Market Free Falls
description: Prodded by the likelihood of periodic plunges in stock market prices, the Federal Government, like it or not, is becoming committed to emergency measures to limit the damage from these frightening episodes.

title: Review/Music; New Cast in Met 'Boheme'
description: Saturday's matinee of ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera was an exercise in free enterprise. A number of new singers entered the cast, and most of them - evidently hoping to make the best impression - sought out their own little islands of distinctiveness on stage.

title: Thatcher Skeptical on Europe Money Ties
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed skepticism today about whether other European Community countries would fulfill Britain's conditions for tying the pound more closely to their currencies, an essential prerequisite for full European economic union.

title: Kite Wins Playoff And Record Purse
description: Just four months after he lost the United States Open title in what he said was his biggest personal disappointment in golf, Tom Kite won the richest purse in golf history today when he beat Payne Stewart on the second playoff hole for a total of $625,000 and some other important rewards.

title: American Film Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: 2 Earthquakes Strike Algeria; 19 Are Dead and 100 Hurt
description: Two earthquakes about 15 minutes apart struck northern Algeria on Sunday night, killing at least 19 people and injuring about 100, the Interior Ministry reported today. Most of the deaths were in the Tipasa region west of Algiers and in Churchell, on the Mediterranean coast west of the capital.

title: A Knee Strengthener Doubles as Fitness Aid
description: A sports medicine device designed to rehabilitate athletes with knee injuries is also being targeted for use in fitness training. It is being recommended for runners, skiers, swimmers, cyclists, as well as tennis, baseball and football players.

title: Violent Crime and Theft On Rise For the Second Year, U.S. Reports
description: Violent crime and personal theft rose 3.1 percent in 1988, the second straight year of increases for these offenses, the Justice Department reported today.

title: A's Look Gingerly To '90 and Beyond
description: When there was nothing left but an empty clubhouse and the memory of players hugging joyously on the infield grass, one question still hung in the air like a pop fly in the afternoon sun.

description: New York City's Jewish voters are the most sharply divided of the city's major ethnic and racial groups, so divided that many campaign strategists say they could swing this year's mayoral election.

title: Florida's Still There After Galileo Launch

title: 70,000 HAIL REBELS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The largest political rally in the history of the African National Congress was held today with the acquiescence of the white minority Government, which declared the organization illegal 29 years ago.

description: When President Daniel Ortega Saavedra set out Friday morning for a presidential summit meeting in Costa Rica, he carried with him a carefully constructed political bombshell: a decision to renew combat operations against American-backed rebels.

description: Oaklanders had waited years for this moment, to beat San Francisco in the World Series, to show the world they had something better than their snooty neighbor across the bay.

title: Article 472289 -- No Title
description: The Unisys Corporation reported a third-quarter loss of $648.2 million on Friday, reflecting a reorganization and losses on military contracts. The computer maker earned $151 million, or 77 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1988.

title: BULGARIAN LEADER TALKS OF CHANGE
description: Bulgaria's hard-line Communist leadership said today that it would increase efforts to carry out political and economic change.

title: Girl, 13, Collapses and Dies At Connecticut School Dance
description: The state medical examiner's office was conducting an autopsy today on the body of a 13-year-old Branford girl who collapsed and died during a school dance.

title: 2 Stars on Fast but Separate Tracks
description: FOR nearly a decade, they have traveled the globe as Norway's foremost distance runners. Between them, Ingrid Kristiansen and Grete Waitz have won scores of races, running several world records on the track and world bests on the roads.

title: Kenneth Handelman Weds Lisa Loeb
description: Lisa Renee Loeb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Loeb of Rye, N.Y., and Stockbridge, Mass., was married in Rye yesterday at the Community Synagogue to Kenneth Benjamin Handelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Handelman of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Gary Mazo and Cantor Meredith Stone.

title: Carol K. Demitz Is Married
description: Carol Keyes Demitz, a financial executive and lawyer in New York, and Dr. Curtis Fred Brewer, a professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University, were married yesterday at their home in New York by Justice Myriam J. Altman of State Supreme Court. The bride, who will keep her name, is a vice president and the assistant general counsel at Fiduciary Trust Company International, an investment management company. She is a daughter of Mrs. Roberts S. Demitz of St. Louis and the late Col. Demitz, U.S.A., retired. The bridegroom, the son of Mrs. Curtis Fred Brewer of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Brewer, is a professor of molecular pharmacology, microbiology and immunology at Albert Einstein.

title: Reviews/Music; Time Traveling and Agoraphobia in Tippett Opera
description: Despite the honored place that Sir Michael Tippett holds in English musical culture and the ceaseless exertions on his behalf by admiring critics, his operas have not traveled well. The first and best of them, the 37-year-old ''Midsummer Marriage,'' has had San Francisco Opera exposure and still arouses some interest among opera enthusiasts in this country. The later works - ''King Priam,'' ''The Knot Garden'' and ''The Ice Break'' - remain largely a British secret.

title: Finnigan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income and included an accounting adjustment of $316,000, or 6 cents a share, for FASB No. 96.

description: For almost five hours, the local Communist Party chief, the Mayor, the police chief and a host of other prominent East Berlin officials stood on the steps of City Hall today listening to things that a scant three weeks earlier would have been tantamount to treason.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Patrolling Mean Streets To Bestow a Blessing
description: Sgt. Gerald F. Weigand is driving his cruiser up one block and down another, crisscrossing Police District 3 on a foggy Friday night in South Philadelphia. He is drinking soda, chain-smoking Marlboros, scanning the streets.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Florio Promises a Prime-Time Victory
description: Casting off the caution with which he usually discusses his chance of victory, Representative James J. Florio today predicted that he would be declared the next governor of New Jersey by 8:22 on election night.

description: With its narrow, tightly clustered houses, its weather-beaten 15th-century belfry and its ancient dock lined with fishing boats, Honfleur is the type of place for which the phrase ''picture postcard town'' might have been invented.

description: The president of the Rockefeller Foundation has called for a new American philanthropic strategy to help alleviate poverty in the third world and protect the imperiled global environment.

title: Corrections

The program was managed then by three officials, including Deborah Gore Dean, not by her alone.

title: David Savage, 60, a Specialist in Mail Ads
description: David Savage, an expert in direct-response advertising and a managing director of Krupp/Taylor USA, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding, died of a heart attack on Friday in his Manhattan office. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Vying for Uncle Sam's Phone Dollars
description: With the first part of the Federal Government's new telephone system officially on line, the three big long-distance carriers and smaller companies are scrambling to sell the Government additional services that could increase their revenues by billions of dollars.

title: Review/Cabaret; Songs by Laurie Beechman
description: In the comic centerpiece of her new cabaret act, the Broadway singer Laurie Beechman offers a witty twist on the preening ''Little Me'' genre of show-business autobiography.

title: At Troubled Bridgeport U., Fear Is Growing
description: Catalogs for the University of Bridgeport carry on their cover a collage of college life: students playing saxophones, peering into microscopes, tapping computer keyboards.

description: b-Loss caused by hurricane Hugo claims, which reduced net income by $1,218,000. c-Net income

description: Meems Coffey and Sholom Ellenberg were married yesterday at Congregation Emunath Israel in New York by Rabbi Meyer Leifer.

title: Nixon Meets With Chinese on Student Policy
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon met with Education Minister Li Tieying today for what the Chinese described as ''frank and sincere'' talks on China's policy toward its students in the aftermath of the crushing of the student-led democracy movement.

title: Air India Tries a New Look For International Travelers
description: Falling behind its regional competitors in Asia's burgeoning air travel market, Air India is shedding its ethnic image for a sleeker, made-in-America look.

title: Question Box
description: Series Surprises Q. No team has ever reached the World Series with a losing record during the regular season, but has there ever been a Series in which both teams had losing records the year before they won their pennants? A. Never before baseball's first expansion in 1961, only once before the league championship series format was set up in 1969 and only once more since then. And both times it happened, the Minnesota Twins were involved. When the Dodgers played the Twins in the 1965 World Series, the matchup paired a Los Angeles team that had finished sixth in a 10-team league in 1964 with an 80-82 record against a Minnesota team that was seventh in the American League in 1964 with a 79-83 mark. The Dodgers won the Series in seven games.

title: Beirut Distrusts the Promise of Peace
description: Disillusioned by the failure of numerous cease-fires and peace agreements during Lebanon's long civil conflict, many Beirut residents are skeptical that the accord reached in Saudi Arabia last week can bring calm.

title: Health Images Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Investigators Look for Clues In Fatal Collapse of Bridge
description: An investigation began today to determine what caused a popular historic footbridge to collapse Saturday afternoon, spilling up to 40 people into the Little Red River, killing 5 and injuring 18.

title: Audrey Feinberg, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Audrey Sue Feinberg and David Andrew Kaplan, 1981 graduates of the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday in Bozman, Md., at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Alan William Kaplan. Rabbi Joy Levitt officiated.

title: From Pipes to Pennant
description: To hear some of his colleagues tell it, Paul Tagliabue, the new commissioner of the National Football League, is an oxymoronic sort, a brilliant plodder who combines a devotion to hard work with an imaginative flair.

title: Publishers Worry After Fiction Sales Weaken
description: Summer is usually the slowest season for hardcover books, but last summer's stagnant market has publishers wondering what happened.

title: On Moscow: The President Is Missing
description: There is an iron law of bureaucratic politics in Washington: Until a President takes a firm public position on an issue, even his closest aides will push and pull in different directions. And there's an obvious corollary: Without a united administration, coherent action is impossible.

title: Life Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; Mysticism And Fervor: Nusrat Khan And Group
description: Sitting Buddha-like on stage, pouring out thrusting and intricate vocal lines, the Pakistani singer and star Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan rattled the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. And though the music Mr. Khan sings usually requires an audience that understands his religious fervor, Mr. Khan still managed to communicate a real intensity.

title: 'Final Days' for the First Amendment?
description: Last week, I had the strange experience of seeing myself on television when I previewed ABC-TV's docudrama version of ''The Final Days,'' Bob Woodward's and Carl Bernstein's book about the Watergate scandal. I was portrayed by an actor named Ed Flanders. My wife fell out of her chair laughing. I did not think it was particularly funny.

title: Market Place; Index Arbitrage Debate Renewed
description: RARELY do Wall Street firms rush to be the first to curb a business that makes a lot of money. But last week, reacting to huge swings in the stock market and increasing pressure from customers, a number of firms announced that they would curtail or eliminate their business in index arbitrage, the best-known form of program trading.

description: b-Net income

Government by Litmus Test
description: Louis Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said yesterday that the abortion litmus test will no longer be applied to top scientific positions like the directorship of the National Institutes of Health. Dr. Sullivan says the White House now shares his views. That would be a welcome step away from the Administration's heedless politicization of this critical technical post.

description: Government investigators have concluded that a manufacturing flaw caused the crack in an engine fan assembly that brought about the crash of the United Airlines jet in Iowa in July.

title: Ideological Tests Ruled Out In Filling U.S. Science Jobs
description: Candidates for top scientific jobs in the Department of Health and Human Services will not have to pass an ideological ''litmus test'' test on abortion or other political questions, Secretary Louis W. Sullivan said today.

description: Although business leaders can no longer anoint mayors as they did decades ago, the campaign now under way shows that good business is still good politics in Houston.

description: R. H. Macy & Company said in a financial filing on Friday that it had a net loss of $43.1 million in its fourth quarter ended July 29, compared with a loss of $106 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Review/Television; 'Barging Through Europe,' a 3-Part Series
description: As a series, WNET's ''Travels'' is based on a promising idea: take trips to places, familiar or a bit exotic, with travelers who will put their own personal spin on the experience. Travelogues in living color have long been one of television's stronger suits. But ''Travels'' is not content to let the cameras do most of the work. The show and its host, John Heminway, insist on inflating the experiences, sometimes to the point of absurdity.

title: One Europe, but Many Airlines
description: Eager to increase competition in the airline industry, European Community officials have decided that change is not coming fast enough and that it is time for tougher deregulation measures. But they face a huge fight from many governments and airlines.

title: Rangers' Victory Clouded
description: The fear of an injury that has hovered over the Rangers like a dark cloud because of their lack of depth became reality Saturday night.

title: Miss Mayer Weds David Freedman
description: Nancy Bertha Mayer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Mayer of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday to David Freedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Freedman of Fall River, Mass. Rabbi Barton Shallat officiated at Temple Beth El, assisted by Cantor Leon Perlman.

title: Would Unions' Backing Cost Dinkins as Mayor?
description: If David N. Dinkins is elected mayor of New York City next week, his pledge to share the goals of the many municipal unions that were instrumental in his nomination and his longstanding commitment to help uplift the poor will be tested almost immediately.

title: Irish 'Peace Trains' Halted by Bomb Threat
description: Two ''peace trains'' that were formed to protest Irish Republican Army bomb attacks on the Dublin-Belfast rail link have been halted by a bomb threat.

title: Adtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

description: The marriage of Leslie Iris Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Brown of South Orange, N.J., to Samuel Bernard Goldberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. G. Marshal Goldberg of Palm Beach, Fla., and Marblehead, Mass., took place yesterday at the Grand Summit Hotel in Summit, N.J. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro officiated.

title: Charter Plan Is Angrily Debated
description: Often interrupting and trying to outshout each other, six Democrats yesterday strongly disagreed on the proposed New York City Charter that residents will vote on next week.

title: Trick Plays Give Browns the Edge
description: Stopped cold by Houston's defense in the first half, the Cleveland Browns resorted to trickery in the second half today, using gadget plays on three of their four touchdown drives and beating the Oilers, 28-17.

title: Jeff Diamond Is Wed To Tracey L. Hoffman
description: Tracey L. Hoffman, a telecommunications analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, and Jeff D. Diamond, an investment manager with the Prudential Capital Corporation in Newark were married yesterday at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gary Creditor officiated.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rise To '89 High
description: Bolstered by higher capital spending in a number of industries, machine tool orders climbed 33.4 percent in September from the previous month, reaching the highest monthly total this year.

title: Astec Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Continue Contra Aid Until the Elections, Senate Chiefs Agree
description: Spurning a call by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua to redirect American aid to dismantling the contras, Congressional leaders vowed today to continue assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels until the elections scheduled there next February.

title: Bridge
description: The House of Representatives administered a severe defeat to the Senate Thursday night, but it was not in conference. It was at the card tables in the Capitol Hill Club in Washington, where they met in their first annual bridge match, which was organized by the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Business Technology page on Oct. 18 about new computer chips referred incorrectly to products of the MIPS Company. The company's R4000 chip has not yet been announced; MIPS executives said the company had not backed away from a design strategy known as ''superscalar execution,'' which lets a computer execute more than one instruction in a tick of the quartz crystal clock that governs the chip's speed.

title: Wall Street Futures
description: Wall Street has lost the confidence of the small investor for good reason: the marketplace that should be the self-policed source of capital from every investor has become a high-tech casino for the tax-favored institutional gamblers.

title: James Florio for New Jersey
description: For the most part, Tom Kean's eight years as Governor have been good ones for New Jersey. The economy has been robust, job growth strong and the state has shucked its image as a backwater to New York City and Philadelphia.

title: Trade View Of U.S. Dim
description: In a pessimistic assessment of trade prospects, the Bush Administration said Friday that it was unclear that the trade deficit could be shrunk further and warned that it might grow next year.

title: Dash Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Four New Trophies For a Top Headhunter
description: Gerard R. Roche, who is regarded as a top executive headhunter, has four new trophies to display.

title: Gentleman Farmers Baffle Ukrainians
description: The tour was billed as an opportunity for a group of Ukrainian diplomats to inspect a few American family farms. But it did not take long today for Victor A. Krizhanovsky to realize that this beautiful town tucked away in the northwest corner of Connecticut is not a typical farming community.

title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons
description: Once confined to a class session or two reciting horror stories and statistics, drug education in America is undergoing radical changes as the crack epidemic touches the lives of younger children across the country.

title: Frank Paxton Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Abortion Consent Law Creates Support System; Who Is a Minor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Series May Hold A Hint of Future
description: It took 15 days to finish because it was interupted by an earthquake, and nobody poured champagne or ran wild when it was finished. But the 86th World Series went into the record books today as the second-most one-sided Series in history, and it left the Oakland Athletics with a growing image as the team most likely to continue to succeed in the 1990's.
