description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $6,395,000, or 33 cents a share.

title: Abortion Consent Law Creates Support System; Biology and Maturity
description: To the Editor:

title: Archive Exhibit Reveals That Civic Strife Is Nothing New
description: A startling documentary portrait of little old New York - with its brutal race relations, resentful taxpayers, dreadful prisons, filthy streets and miserable workers - has gone on view along the marble-lined corridors of the Municipal Archives.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Volvic still water, a unit of the Perrier Group, to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners. Budget has not been set.

title: 33 Are Headed For Re-Election To City Council
description: Thirty-three members of the New York City Council are expected to win re-election on Nov. 7 in a display of the power of incumbency in a city largely dominated by Democrats.

title: Ford Increases Jaguar Holding
description: The Ford Motor Company has raised its stake in Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury car maker, to 13.2 percent, Jaguar said Friday. Ford, which had held 12.4 percent of Jaguar, now owns 24.2 million ordinary Jaguar shares. In a filing last week with the

title: How Percy Helped the Elderly of Wilmette, Ill.
description: To the Editor:

title: Manitowoc Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New TV Ad's Pitch: It's 'Cool' to Be a Boy Scout
description: Standing in a shadowy, littered alley, the young spokesman in a new commercial is clad in a black leather jacket and tight Levis. It is the look usually used to sell jeans or MTV. But what he is pushing is the Boy Scouts.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. PLEDGING CONFERENCE FOR DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Washington at Work; Making a President's Planes, Trains (and Diplomatic Matters) Run on Time
description: There are plenty of ways to get a job from a new President. One way is to grow up with him and play cheerleader for him in the souks of Morocco.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Jonathan G. Sherman, 82, Dies; A Former Episcopal Bishop of L.I.
description: Jonathan Goodhue Sherman, the retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, died of heart failure on Friday at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford. He was 82 years old and lived in Simsbury, Conn.

title: Review/Dance; Tulsa Ballet's 'Coppelia'
description: The Tulsa Ballet Theater has a good many fans among New York dancegoers. And the Tulsa production of ''Coppelia,'' performed on Saturday night at Colden Center at Queens College, promised to be of special interest. The fact that Roman Jasinski and Moscelyne Larkin, founders of the Tulsa company, could draw on their years with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo for their staging of ''Coppelia,'' suggests a link to the Ballet Russe version danced so notably by Alexandra Danilova.

title: Heartland Express Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nose to Nose, Down to a Final Race
description: HORSE races are games of necks and noses, with seven-digit purses and ancient trophies won or lost on the bob of a head. But when it comes to year-end titles and lasting reputations, the sport usually is far more forgiving than its photo-finish cameras.

title: Miss Zimmerman Is Wed in Florida
description: Caryn Lisa Zimmerman and William Michael Zoffer, both lawyers in Washington, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Shalom in Clearwater, Fla., by Rabbi Kenneth Bromberg.

title: Ultimate in Whirling
description: Running, diving, catching and striving constantly to move downfield toward an opponent's end zone. The game is not football, but Ultimate Frisbee.

title: B. Altman Has Losses Of $4 Million a Month
description: B. Altman & Company's seven department stores have together lost $4 million a month since September and expect the drain to continue through the end of the year, the chain's parent company, the L. J. Hooker Corporation, has said.

title: Debate in London on Excavating Where the Globe May Have Been
description: To the unschooled eye, the newly excavated site near the Southwark Bridge here looks like an ordinary dirt field with crumbling chalk-and-brick foundations. But after two months of digging, archeologists say they are almost certain this is the site of the Globe Theater, where William Shakespeare was an actor and shareholder and where most of his plays were first performed.

title: Riesenberg Rises To Giant Occasion
description: In Super Bowl XXI, the Giants' offensive tackles were Brad Benson and Karl Nelson. They also had William Roberts, a former No. 1 draft choice, at tackle. In 1987, the first two players they drafted were Eric Moore and Jumbo Elliott, both tackles.

title: Net Off 15.5% At Kellogg
description: The Kellogg Company said Friday that its net income for the third quarter fell 15.5 percent.

title: I Have No Secret Agenda
description: During the past several weeks the leadership of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, has visited the U.S., Britain, France and several African nations with the purpose of reviving the Angolan peace process that began last June in Gbadolite, Zaire.

title: CPAC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Student Shot on L.I. Campus
description: A 21-year-old student at the SUNY campus in Old Westbury, L.I., was shot and seriously wounded early yesterday during a melee between students following a campus Halloween party, Nassau County police said. The student, Joseph Thompson, of 202 West 138th Street, Manhattan, was struck by three bullets fired from a 9-millimeter pistol by an unknown person, the police said. Mr. Thompson, a sophomore, was taken to North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset where he was in serious but stable condition last night. The police said they did not know of a motive for the shooting; there have been no arrests.

title: Turbulent Weather in Britain
description: Winds gusting to hurricane force swept parts of Britain over the weekend, killing six people, sinking a Pakistani freighter and driving a Nigerian fishing trawler onto the rocks. The London Weather Center said gusts up to 100 miles an hour were recorded at the Portland Bill lighthouse on the south coast.

title: Universal Health Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Desk Reference From the Public Library
description: The weight of authority, in the case of The New York Public Library Desk Reference, is 4 pounds 8 ounces, and since its 836 pages are not likely to be adapted to portable pocket-size service, the consumer may well have to buy a desk to put it on.

title: RIVALS FOR MAYOR AIM FINAL DRIVES AT CRUCIAL BLOCS
description: David N. Dinkins began the final full week of his New York City mayoral campaign yesterday by playing to his weakness, while Rudolph W. Giuliani, his rival, sought to capitalize on it.

title: Brush Fire Near Los Angeles Blackens Thousands of Acres
description: A wind-whipped blaze roared through brush and canyon country overlooking the Pacific Ocean today, charring 4,000 acres, destroying one home and forcing more than 2,000 campers to flee, officials said.

title: Air Travel Sets Record in 1988
description: Airlines carried a record number of passengers last year, increasing worldwide profits to $1.6 billion, the International Air Transport Association said in a report made available today.

title: Small Town Is Shaken By a Child's Abduction
description: Frightened and puzzled, the children of this small town have been asking their parents, again and again, ''Why?'' There are no good answers. One week ago, an 11-year-old boy, Jacob Wetterling, was abducted by a man with a gun. Searchers here have been unable to find any trace of the boy.

title: Cash America Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; Jules Feiffer Presents the Playwright as Father
description: Anthony Rose, the playwright and title character in Jules Feiffer's dark comedy at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, is a refugee from the treacherous domestic battles fought in such former Feiffer works as ''Grown-Ups'' and ''Little Murders.'' In ''Anthony Rose,'' Mr. Feiffer has shifted the battleground on which his characters fight for their identities from the Upper West Side of Manhattan to a rehearsal hall in Kansas City. Long a man of the theater, Mr. Feiffer knows that cast members can forge bonds as tight - and as damaging - as any family.

title: Ipco CorpN) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $659,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,147,000 for year-ago period.

title: Lawson Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
East German's Art Gets a Brooklyn Home
description: When Gerd Sonntag, an artist from East Berlin, came here to show his work at the new Castillo Cultural Center in Greenwich Village, he didn't expect to wind up with an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. But when his paintings go on view there tomorrow, he will be the first East German artist to have a one-person show in a major American art institution.

title: Fatal Car Accident Shuts Bridge in Queens
description: The North Channel Bridge, which connects the Rockaways peninsula with the mainland of Queens, was closed for five hours yesterday morning after a fatal car accident left oil contaminated with a toxic chemical on the road, the police said.

title: Give Us Biomedical Research, Not Bombs
description: To the Editor:

title: Himont Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
By Design; Larger-Than-Life Jewelry
description: Clank, clank! Clink, clink! You can hear them even before you see them. And then, of course, you cannot miss them, for the newest accessories are not only noisy, they are blockbuster in scale.

title: Friend Turned Foe of Gandhi Is Gaining in Self-Assurance
description: Vishwanath Pratap Singh stood on the veranda of his home here and described the disenchantment that he felt for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, whom he had served as Finance and Defense Minister and whom he hopes to unseat in national elections three weeks away.

title: Witches, Without Warts
description: LEAD: You see them in school windows, on candy racks in drugstores, dangling from front porches, leering out from Halloween greeting cards: witches.

title: Ortega Seems to Retreat Further From War Threat
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra is apparently stepping back still further from his announcement that his Government will break its cease-fire with rebels.

title: Foster Wheeler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included income of about $3 million, or 9 cents a share, from a pension plan settlement for latest period, while the year-ago 9 months included a gain of about $5.5 million, or 16 cents a share, on the sale of Conergics Corp.

title: Review/Television; America's 'Great Adventure,' World War I
description: ''The Great War: 1918,'' tonight's episode of the estimable history series ''The American Experience,'' at 9 o'clock on Channel 49 and at 10 on Channel 13, gets its power from the newsreels of trench fighting in the last grim year of World War I. The straightforward if undistinguished narration, written by the producer Tom Weidlinger and read by Eric Sevareid, tells how the ebullience of the ill-trained young Americans marching to join the Allies in 1917 was transformed by the shock of combat. It was here, as Mr. Sevareid says, in a comment you may have heard before, that ''the 19th and 20th centuries parted ways forever.''

title: Poland Devalues Zloty
description: Poland devalued the zloty today by 12.6 percent, continuing its drive to narrow a huge gap between the free-market and official rates for the currency. The central bank set the new rate at 2,400 zloties to the United States dollar, compared with 2,098 on Friday, according to figures published by the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita.

title: Topics of The Times; Going Bats in Gotham
description: We know of an 8-year-old girl who is turning herself into a medieval princess. Her little brother, who likes bows and arrows, will be Robin Hood. We know of a penguin, too, and expect the usual number of ghosts. But the star of Gotham City's Halloween will be the guy with the pointed ears and the big cape who hangs upside down when he sleeps. Batman.

title: U.S. Birth Level Nears 4 Million Mark
description: The number of babies born in the United States every year is edging toward four million, a level not reached since the baby boom in the 1950's. Until recently, demographers thought that level would be out of reach until well into the 21st century.

title: Despite Scorn, Team in Utah Still Seeks Cold-Fusion Clues
description: THE euphoria and wild claims about a ''cold fusion'' power source are long gone. So is the gold-rush fever over the hope of turning a table-top apparatus into a font of nearly limitless energy and profit. It's even hard to find the T-shirts and bumper stickers that entrepreneurs once peddled around town to celebrate the finding.

title: Dominion Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Mayoral Candidates' Basic Speeches: Laments Followed by Proposals; Giuliani: Problems of Crime Pervade Life in the City
description: The New York City mayoral candidates give dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. More often they use a ''basic speech'' that varies little from one occasion to the next. These are the basic speeches of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, and David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate:

title: Change in Accounting Rules Backed
description: In a decision that is likely to upset some state and local government officials, the Financial Accounting Foundation voted 12 to 2 yesterday to require government-owned utilities, hospitals, colleges and universities to base their accounting decisions on standards set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, not its sister organization, the Governmental Accounting Standards Board.

title: Amstrong World Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time pre-tax gain of $5.9 million, or 8 cents a share, from sale of real estate. Share earnings figures reflect additional preferred dividends paid to the ESOP.

title: Bellevue Jury Rejects Plea Of Insanity
description: A Manhattan jury, rejecting the insanity defense of Steven Smith, convicted the 24-year-old homeless man yesterday of robbing, raping and murdering Dr. Kathryn Hinnant in her office in Bellevue Hospital on Jan. 7.

title: Passing Game Is Giving Packers High Hopes
description: At the midpoint of the scramble for Super Bowl XXIV, 20 of the National Football League's 28 teams have records at or above .500, television ratings are steady and attendance is at near record levels: 913,996 people were at games this week, the second highest total in history.

title: Court Review Set in LTV Pension Case
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a case that could affect the solvency of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the troubled Federal agency that Congress set up 15 years ago to guarantee the security of employee pensions.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE 10 A.M. PLEDGING CONFERENCE FOR DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES - 10 A.M.

title: Spinal Surgery
description: A University of Mississippi player remained in critical condition in Memphis after five hours of spinal surgery yesterday, and doctors said it was unlikely he would regain the use of his arms and his legs.

title: Gerald Sussman, 56, Humorist and Author
description: Gerald Sussman, a humorist and advertising copywriter, died early Sunday in Alford, Mass., after a bronchial asthmatic attack while visiting friends. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jackson Sees a Daily 'Crucifixion' of Dinkins
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose relationship with David N. Dinkins has become an issue in New York City's mayoral race for some Jewish voters, said yesterday that the Democratic candidate was ''facing a kind of protracted crucifixion every day'' about the nature of his association with Mr. Jackson.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said its Erisco unit had bought data bases and other assets of Managed Health Care Services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Sales Dip Deflates Hyundai Bubble
description: Just three years after engineering one of the most successful imported-car introductions in the United States, the Hyundai Group has hit a rough patch.

title: Communication Center Names New Chairman
description: Burton B. Staniar, chairman and chief executive officer of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company (Group W), has been named chairman of the Center for Communication.

title: Reviews/Dance; Festive Vivaldi, With Room In the Spotlight for All
description: Gerald Arpino's ''Viva Vivaldi'' sailed back into the Joffrey Ballet repertory over the weekend. And the company's performance of the ballet on Sunday afternoon at City Center (131 West 55th Street) suggested why this has become a signature work for the Joffrey and for Mr. Arpino. Although ''Viva Vivaldi'' ends curiously, with a section led by two male soloists instead of the grand summary one might expect of a festive pure-dance piece of this sort, the ballet has moments in the spotlight for nearly everyone in the cast. And the dancers seized them eagerly.

title: Joseph Beruh, 65, Dies; A Theatrical Producer
description: Joseph Beruh, a theatrical producer whose shows included ''Godspell,'' ''The Magic Show'' and ''American Buffalo,'' died in his sleep on Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Program Offers a Million Printing Possibilities
description: BANNERMANIA may turn you into a banner maniac. With it, you can create a huge number of banners, posters, or bumper stickers and print them out on your printer, color or monochrome, dot-matrix or laser.

title: CS First Boston's Debt Downgraded
description: Moody's Investor Service yesterday downgraded the long-term debt of CS First Boston from A2 to A3, citing the risks inherent in its merchant banking business. The rating service also downgraded the debt of Financiere Credit Suisse First Boston, the company's Swiss subsidiary. All told, the downgrading will affect about $550 million of the Wall Street firm's debt.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Itel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said interest expense related to its purchase late in 1988 of minority equity positions in Santa Fe Pacific Corp. and American President Cos. Ltd. adversely affected latest third quarter share earnings by about 35 cents. Without this interest expense, the latest quarter and 9-month share earnings after cash taxes would have been about 65 cents and $1.78, respectively.

title: Black Town Suffers for Its Fidelity to South Africa
description: A harsh retribution has been visited upon the people of Nkqokqweni. They have been beaten, detained, deported and have seen their homes bulldozed to rubble, all because they believe that they belong to South Africa.

title: Knicks Put Aside the Pressing Matter
description: Watch for the press. Look out for the trap.

title: Review/Opera; Handel's 'Caesar,' Updated Into Musical Comedy
description: Because Handel's Italian operas were written in a Baroque form that was already outmoded in his lifetime, companies feel justified in bending them into shapes that the modern-day operagoer may easily recognize. Typically, the scores are drastically cut and/or their numbers shifted around in hopes of sharpening dramatic points.

title: PATTERNS
description: The Tired Look

title: Times Settles Legal Dispute With Independent Dealers
description: After seven years of litigation, The New York Times and most independent dealers who deliver The Times to homes in the New York area announced a settlement yesterday of their dispute.

title: Gag That Man!
description: Some of those people in Washington really have their nerve.

title: ANOTHER BIG RALLY IN EAST GERMANY
description: Chanting demands for everything from free elections to the ouster of the secret police, more than 300,000 East Germans marched around Leipzig's old center in what has become the major weekly ritual of the growing popular movement for change.

title: The Mayoral Candidates' Basic Speeches: Laments Followed by Proposals; Dinkins: I Intend to be Toughest Mayor on Crime This City Has Ever Seen
description: The New York City mayoral candidates give dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. More often they use a ''basic speech'' that varies little from one occasion to the next. These are the basic speeches of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, and David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg Advances: Second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden advanced easily in the first round of the Paris Open yesterday by beating Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-3. Also advancing easily was Aaron Krickstein of the United States, seeded sixth, who beat Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, 6-1, 6-3. And Martin Jaite came from behind to defeat Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 2-6, 6-4, 7-6.(AP) Maleeva Rallies and Wins: The defending champion, top-seeded Katerina Maleeva, rallied to defeat unseeded Tami Whitlinger of Neenah, Wis., 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, last night in the first round of the Virginia Slims of Indianapolis tournament. Fifth-seeded Amy Frazier of Rochester, Mich., defeated Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3. Sixth-seeded Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union defeated Gisele Miro of Brazil, 6-4, 6-0.(AP) SOCCER Colombia to World Cup: Colombia played to a 0-0 tie with Israel yesterday in Ramat Gan, Israel, to clinch a berth in the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy. (AP) HORSE RACING Banquo Wins by a Head: Golf Cart Stable's Banquo led from the start under Jose Martinez Jr. to win by a head yesterday in the $33,000 On Watch purse for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Farewell Wave was second in the field of six, 2 1/4 lengths ahead of Jonathan's Gold. The victory was the fourth in 11 career starts for Banquo, who went seven furlongs on a fast track in 1:22 4/5 to earn $19,800. Banquo returned $13.40 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: For a Schoolmaster-Spy, Strain of Heroism Shows
description: In the glare of media scrutiny, Colman Genn has conveyed the confidence and toughness that might be expected from a former street gang member. He gambled his reputation to save some New York City schools, and he appears to have won the bet.

title: Investor Group Makes Offer To Buy Detroit Free Press
description: A group of Michigan investors yesterday proposed to buy The Detroit Free Press for $68 million, just as the owner of the money-losing daily newspaper, Knight-Ridder Inc., was asking the Supreme Court for permission to merge the newspaper's business operations with those of its rival, The Detroit News.

title: Chrysler Is Said To Plan Cuts
description: Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, was quoted as saying the company expects to close at least one assembly plant, to delay products and to lay off some white-collar workers because of the slumping domestic auto industry. The report in the trade paper

title: Rediscovering the Lost Crops of the Incas
description: HALF a millennium ago in the Andes, on the eve of the Spanish conquest, the Incas created an agricultural wonderland. On irrigated mountainside terraces along the spine of South America, they cultivated an estimated 70 species of crops, almost as many as the farmers of Europe and Asia combined.

title: Suwalki Journal; In Poland's Hopeless Hog Picture, a Hopeful Spot
description: In this land of limited meat and scarce though cherished kielbasa, few things would seem to offer a better growth opportunity than pigs. And yet in the last three years stocks of hogs, Poland's principal livestock, fell from 22 million to fewer than 14 million.

title: All Quiet in the Jets' Offense and Their Locker Room
description: Isn't anyone on the Jets upset with a 1-7 record?

title: Whirlpool Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $5,100,000 and $14,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said results of the latest periods included all of the revenues of Whirlpool International B.V. and 53 percent of the net earnings in line with the corporation's ownership position.

title: Houston Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stake Is Acquired In Durham Corp.
description: An investment group led by Financial Securities Fund, a Nashville investment partnership, and Bailey Financial Group, a Rocky Mount, N.C., investment concern, has acquired a 5.6 percent stake in the Durham Corporation. The group also said it might seek control of the Raleigh, N.C., holding company, which has interests in insurance and broadcasting.

title: TV Networks May Approve A Pool for Election Exit Polls
description: The three major broadcast networks and the Cable News Network are expected to approve this week a plan to conduct joint exit polls and pool the information during national elections, beginning next year. ABC News and CBS News, both of which want to control the pool, have offered competing plans, network news executives said yesterday.

title: Quotron Is Set To Lay Off 400
description: Quotron Systems Inc., the nation's leading provider or electronic stock quotes, said it would lay off 400 workers. The company blamed the continued problems in the securities industry since the October 1987 stock market crash for the cutbacks.

title: NL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share, from tax- loss carryforwards. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3.1 million, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $5.9 million, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months, and extraordinary gains from tax-loss carryforwards of $900,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $8.5 million, or 13 cents a share, for the 9 months. The latest periods also included gains from the sale of business units of $25 million for the quarter and $33.5 million for the 9 months.

title: Mabel Hampton, Gay Rights Advocate, 87
description: Mabel Hampton, an advocate in the gay rights movement, died of pneumonia Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Street Cleanup Would Boost New York Morale
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerusalem Sentences A Palestinian to Life In Deaths of 16 Jews
description: An Israeli court sentenced a Palestinian today to 16 consecutive life terms plus 480 years in jail for killing 16 Jews when he wrenched the steering wheel of a bus away from its driver last July and sent the vehicle plunging over a cliff.

title: Bush Shuns Dole Suggestion On Raising the Gasoline Tax
description: The White House today rejected a suggestion by Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, that the Federal gasoline tax be increased to build roads and bridges.

title: Poll Finds Californians Support a Quake Tax
description: A majority of Californians support a temporary increase in the sales tax to finance earthquake recovery efforts in the San Francisco Bay Area, according to a newspaper poll published today.

title: Glum Over Polls? Not I, Courter Says
description: The streets tell a story different from the polls, Representative Jim Courter says, and that is what keeps him campaigning at a hectic pace, still optimistic that he can be New Jersey's next governor.

title: Neil H. G. Green, 66, An Executive of Nestle
description: Neil Harold George Green, senior vice president of finance and treasurer of Nestle Holdings Inc., died on Sunday at his home in Jackson, Miss. The cause of death was not released. He was 66 years old.

title: U.N. Funds Sought by President Again Facing Cuts in Congress
description: Against President Bush's wishes, Congress is planning to withhold money owed the United Nations this year for the fifth year running.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Women Raise Voices For the Right to an Abortion
description: While President Bush and his advisers reiterate their commitment to the anti-abortion movement, some of the most influential women in their party have publicly broken ranks and are arguing the case for abortion rights.

title: Sonics Release Gaze
description: Andrew Gaze, the 6-foot-7-inch forward from Australia who last spring helped Seton Hall reach the championship game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, where it lost to Michigan, has been released by the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association. Gaze was expected to become the 12th man on the Sonics' roster, but a 6-10 center-forward, Scott Meents, who played at Illinois in 1986, got the roster spot.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Polls Skew Strategies Of Mayoral Candidates Although both the Democratic and Republican nominees in New York expect a 60 percent voter turnout on Election Day, neither is willing to predict who will turn out, because of uncertainties in several polls. Page B1. Broad DES Liability Stands The Supreme Court declined to review a New York ruling that made all manufacturers of the pregnancy drug potentially liable. Page D23. A Village vs. South Africa Residents of a village were beaten and detained and homes there were demolished over its resistance to joining a tribal homeland. Page A6.

title: Bridge
description: The members of Congress who played last Thursday in the first match between the Senate and the House of Representatives are now looking forward to their next match. They are to play Feb. 23 in London against the British Parliament, and will be seeking to avenge two previous defeats. A match scheduled in Nashville, Tenn., last November had to be canceled because Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher summoned Parliament unexpectedly.

title: Rosario P. San Filippo, 90, Retired Surgeon
description: Dr. Rosario P. San Filippo, the retired director of surgery at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Friday at the medical center. He was 90 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Gilbert in Masters
description: Brad Gilbert, ranked fifth in the world and the winner of five tournaments in 1989, is the fourth player to qualify for the eight-player Masters Championships, Nov. 28-Dec. 3 at the Garden. Gilbert, who is in fourth place in the Nabisco Grand Prix standing, joins Ivan Lendl, Boris Becker, and Stefan Edberg. (AP)

title: KEY RATES
Rangers Have Depth Misperception
description: The notion had surfaced even before the season began: The Rangers, decent but not deep in talent, were a couple of critical injuries away from serious trouble.

title: Japanese Buy New York Cachet With Deal for Rockefeller Center
description: The Rockefeller Group, the owner of Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, said yesterday that it had sold control of the company to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo, one of the world's biggest real estate developers.

title: Thomas Noyes, 67, Broadway Producer and Newspaperman
description: Thomas Ewing Noyes, a Broadway producer who later became a reporter and an editorial writer and a radio commentator, died of heart disease on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 67 years old.

title: Three for the City Council
description: Only 3 of the New York City Council's 35 members face more than token opposition in the election next Tuesday. That's what often happens in heavily Democratic New York; winning the primary is almost always tantamount to election. The proposed revision of the City Charter, which would expand the Council and give it some real power, might change that. But for now, here are our recommendations in the three contests.

title: Father Thomas Oddo, Catholic Educator, 45
description: The Rev. Thomas Oddo, president of the University of Portland and a trustee at three other Roman Catholic institutions, was killed Sunday in an auto accident. He was 45 years old.

title: Hungry Deer Called Threat To Fire Island's Ecosystem
description: The Sunken Forest, a bramble of holly, pine and sassafras nestled behind the dunes of this Fire Island community, is an unusual ecosystem that some biologists believe is threatened with extinction.

title: Gateway to Volumes
description: THOUSANDS of software titles are available for Compact Disk Read Only Memory, or CD-ROM. Most of them are notable primarily for cramming vast amounts of arcane material onto a single 4.7-inch platter. Although most CD-ROM applications are specialized, there are an increasing number of general interest CD-ROM titles that, for the right users, might justify the purchase of CD-ROM paraphernalia.. CD-ROM is still relatively expensive. Computer CD's must be played on a CD-ROM drive, which is more complex and thus more expensive than a CD audio player. In addition, a hard disk drive is usually required, along with at least 256 kilobytes of main memory. Many applications require more memory. Here are brief descriptions of some CD-ROM titles that we have found to be particularly useful.

title: Palmy, Balmy Site for Breeders'
description: The smell of suntan lotion sweetens the salt air in the ocean breezes. Hot and blinding sunlight bounces from the blue water to the shell-pink stucco of the beachfront hotels. The breaking waves muffle the rustle of swaying palm fronds. Just like the travel brochures promise.

title: Sotheby's to Break Up a Robert Sketchbook
description: A decision by Sotheby's in London to break up one of two surviving sketchbooks by Hubert Robert, a leading French artist of the 18th century, has provoked criticism among some historians of French art and has prompted the resignation of a consultant to the auction house.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Federal Savings Bank, Jacksonville, Fla., named Norman J. Harrison chief executive.

title: Japanese Buy New York Cachet With Deal for Rockefeller Center
description: The Rockefeller Group, the owner of Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, said yesterday that it had sold control of the company to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo, one of the world's biggest real estate developers.

title: New Talks Are Held In City Opera Strike
description: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra met informally last night, with a formal bargaining session set for this morning, in an attempt to resolve their six-week labor dispute.

title: Fire Kills 60-Year-Old Woman
description: A 60-year-old woman who apparently had been smoking in bed was killed today when her bedroom became engulfed in flames, the authorities said. The woman, Nancy Sterback, was dead when firefighters arrived to put out the 4:30 A.M. fire. About 20 years ago, another person died in a fire in the same room, Chief David Russell said.

title: NEW EVIDENCE SEEN IN PAN AM ATTACK
description: Investigators in Europe have uncovered evidence and testimony linking a radical Palestinian faction to the December 1988 bombing of a Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland, United States Government officials said today.

title: Creditors and Eastern Seen Near Accord
description: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines are close to backing management's ambitious plan to rebuild the bankrupt carrier, two people involved in the creditors' meetings said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Soviet price increases were called for on cigarettes, beer and food delicacies. Officials said prices will be set by the market on some other products next year. Page A1

title: Ancient Spider
description: A fossil recently discovered near Gilboa, N.Y., indicates that spiders may have spun webs as long as 385 million years ago.

title: From Blass and Herrera, Wearable Styles
description: Scarcely skipping a beat, the spring and summer fashion openings picked up yesterday in New York, just a few days after the Paris shows faded into memory. Many audience members, as well as the trends, were the same on both sides of the Atlantic as the week opened: the jacket continues as key to spring dressing, fringe appears everywhere, bright colors are set off by neutral black, navy, white and beige, and hemlines frequently dip.

title: Merrill Ends Index Arbitrage
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest retail brokerage, said yesterday that it would abandon its business in index arbitrage, the best-known form of program trading.

title: Drillers Seek Rich Energy Source At Site of Ancient Volcanic Blast
description: IN the hope of verifying the existence of a vast reservoir of useful, nonpolluting energy, scientists are drilling into a dome of California rock where one of the most violent volcanic explosions in earth's history occurred.

title: Tracking a New Drug From the Soil in Japan To Organ Transplants
description: IN the unending quest for new pharmaceuticals, many companies have sent employees to the remotest areas of the globe to collect samples of soil and other natural products. From these forays have come many drugs now used to treat infections, heart disease, arthritis, cancer and other ailments.

title: On TV, Fiction Blurs Fact
description: The urge to dramatize news events is leading television down two dangerous paths. One is the familiar docudrama, a blend of drama and documentary like ABC's ''The Final Days,'' shown Sunday. The other is the re-enactment or simulation of news events on news programs. The minimum remedy - a foghorn-blast warning to viewers that fact and fiction are being blended - may make docudramas palatable. But nothing can excuse simulated news.

title: Secret Heart of 'The Wizard of Oz' Unlocked
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Asked to Oust Wall
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee has asked President Bush to dismiss M. Danny Wall, the nation's top Federal regulator of savings and loan associations, because of Mr. Wall's handling of the failure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.

title: Nalco Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pastels at the Plaza, Cowgirls in the Park
description: Starting the week on an upbeat note, Rebecca Moses presented a thoroughly professional and well-coordinated show that stressed monochromatic outfits in soft, romantic colors. Her palette was pale, ranging from ivory to peach and sea greens.

title: Unocal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included for the quarter a gain of $6 million from the sale of exploratory lands and a $14 million gain related to deferred income taxes; the 9 months included a gain of $53 million related to natural gas contract settlements and a gain of $27 million from the sale of surplus properties in Southern California. c-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $456,000,000, or $3.91 a share. Nine-month income before the accounting adjustment included a $341 million charge related to asset writedowns. Year-ago quarter results included a gain of $32 million related to a refund for overpayment of windfall profit tax; a $13 million gain from settlement of pension oligations; and a charge of $16 million from writedown of the portion of the company's Beaumont, Texas, refinery. The company said $7 million of the gain from gas contract settlements was recorded in the latest quarter.

title: 2 More Concert Guards Held
description: Two Burns International Security guards at the Meadowlands Sports Complex were arrested today, bringing to nine the number of guards charged with assaulting patrons at a series of Grateful Dead rock concerts Oct. 11, 14 and 15. Seven guards were arrested Friday night on charges of aggravated assault. Authorities said publicity surrounding the unsolved beating death Oct. 14 of Adam Katz, a 19-year-old concertgoer who was found lying on a roadway near the arena while the concert was under way, caused patrons to report abuse by security guards.

title: Bally's Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge related to early retirement of debt of $8,411,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-Included a gain of $5.1 million, or 17 cents a share, from the sale of securities. The company said the latest 9-month income of $38,043,000 (before the extraordinary charge) included a gain of $33.9 million, or $1.26 a share, from the sale of a unit, partially offset by charges of $8.4 million related to relocation and other expenses.

title: Genetic Links May Help Save Rhinos From Extinction
description: IN a discovery that could be crucial to the survival of the black rhinoceros, scientists have found that different subspecies of the endangered animal are so genetically similar that they can interbreed.

title: Johnson Controls Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ex-Head of MCA Unit Talks to Time Warner
description: Irving Azoff, the former chairman of the MCA Music Entertainment Group, is expected to join Time Warner Inc. as head of his own record label in a joint venture arrangement, several industry executives said yesterday. which is the umbrella company for the record label, music publishing and amphi theatre operation.

title: Pedro Vargas, a Mexican Singer And Film Performer, Is Dead at 85
description: Pedro Vargas, who was known as ''the tenor of the Americas'' during a career that lasted more than 60 years, died of heart failure today at his home here. He was 85 years old. His eldest son, Pedro Jr., said he died in his sleep, and that he had been suffering for several years from diabetes and heart problems.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Village Halloween Parade, Broadway between 14th and 23d Streets will be closed tonight from 6 to 11, as will Fifth Avenue between 14th and 23d Streets. The Avenue of the Americas will be closed between Houston and 14th Streets from 5 P.M. to 11 P.M.

title: First Financial Management Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dodge City Journal; Soviets Find Friendship In a Historic Cow Town
description: When a Soviet delegation led by a top adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union expressed the desire to meet ''real Americans,'' Senator Bob Dole arranged to give them a taste of the Old West mixed with some Western-style democracy.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Product-Liability Ruling Left Standing by Justices
description: The Supreme Court today let stand one of the most far-reaching product-liability rulings ever issued by an American court.

title: Nearly Complete Tyrannosaur Skeleton Found
description: THE most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex ever found has been uncovered in the badlands of eastern Montana. Paleontologists expect the fossilized bones to give them a much clearer picture of the anatomy of the fierce-looking carnivore that, in the popular imagination at least, epitomizes the great dinosaurs.

title: MANY ARE LEAVING PRISON HIT BY RIOTS
description: Federal prison officials have agreed to accept as many as 800 state prison inmates in Pennsylvania to relieve crowding caused by the destruction of cellblocks in rioting last week at the Camp Hill prison, state and Federal officials said today.

title: Europe Routes By American
description: American Airlines said today that it would expand its European schedules by 30 percent and add destinations in Europe and the South Pacific.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no business address in the world that has the same cachet as Rockefeller Center.

title: Dow Posts Narrow Rise in Slow Trading
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, settling down after a week in which the Dow Jones industrial average lost more than 90 points.

title: Uncertainty on Poll Results Clouds Strategy in Race for Mayor
description: Both the Democratic and Republican candidates for mayor are less confident about the results of public-opinion polls than in previous New York City elections, an uncertainty that could affect their strategy and skew their vote-pulling operations on Election Day.

title: John Beckman Is Dead; Designer of Sets Was 91
description: John Beckman, who designed the sets for ''Casablanca'' and other films and for the television series ''Designing Women,'' died in his sleep on Wednesday. He was 91 years old and lived in Sherman Oaks, Calif.

title: 53d St. Group Tries to Help Homeless Closest to Home
description: Many civic associations take on projects that produce quick, visible results, like increased police protection, cleaner streets or new trees.

title: Doctors Are Baffled By Rates For Cancer
description: In the United States, the death rate from colon and rectal cancer is highest along an arc from Maine to Iowa, say Government researchers, who are puzzled by the finding.

title: BUSH SENDING TEAM TO ADVISE POLAND
description: President Bush announced today that he would send a delegation led by three Cabinet officers to Poland next month to help decide how to spend a package of American aid that is now stalled in Congress.

title: Murray Levy, Manufacturer, 77
description: Murray Levy, a clothing manufacturer and philanthropist, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Foolish, and Thuggish, in Nicaragua
description: The only positive thing to be said about the assault on peace by Nicaragua's President, Daniel Ortega, is the universal storm of outrage it instantly provoked. That storm may, as soon as today, force him to back down from his re-declaration of war against the contras. But even if he does, his bellicosity threatens the Nicaraguan election campaign just under way. Only if supporters of the peace initiative maintain their present outrage can they maintain hope for continued advance.

title: Chinese Seeking to Avoid Reduction of Debt Rating
description: Chinese state bankers said today that there was no reason for China's international credit rating to be diminished and expressed confidence over the country's ability to repay its mounting debts. According to the latest official figures, China's debts totaled $40 billion at the end of 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Nigel Lawson as Chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain misidentified the editor of the magazine American Economist. He is Michael Szenberg.

title: Q&A
description: Dropping a Penny Q. What would happen if you dropped a penny from the top of the Empire State Building? Would it make a difference if the penny fell flat or on edge? A.If the coin fell straight down on edge, it could build up its velocity to 150 miles an hour, said Anatol Roshko, who is Theodore van Karman Professor of Aeronautics at the California Institute of Technology, Pasadena.

title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker
description: The long history of migrant labor in America's orchards and fields has been a chronicle of debt, dependency and fear. Now the discovery of a written record of degradation and servitude among sweet potato pickers at a farm near here has demonstrated anew how little the lives of migrant workers have changed.

title: F.D.A. IS PREPARING NEW RULES TO CURB FOOD LABEL CLAIMS
description: The Food and Drug Administration is preparing new rules to help stop the unchecked growth of health claims that have begun to appear on cereals, juices, food supplements and other products, Administration officials said today.

title: Market Place; Individuals Stay Unafraid of Stocks
description: SMALL investors, far from being scared by market volatility, seem to see it as an opportunity this year. Some mutual fund managers said yesterday that there was a net flow of cash into funds in October, when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 190 points in a single day.

title: Protesters March to K.G.B. Headquarters
description: Hundreds of demonstrators encircled the notorious headquarters of the K.G.B. tonight in candle-lit protest, saying that new political freedoms have been too limited to guard against the revival of state terrorism.

title: Bush's Acid Test
description: President Bush's much-ballyhooed clean air proposals took a beating in a House committee but he still can push his innovative acid-rain program through Congress - if he throws the full weight of his Administration and his own prestige behind it.

title: Beneficial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pilot of Crashed Jet Was Flying Too Low In Carrier Approach
description: A Navy pilot attempting his first landing at sea was flying too low before his training jet crashed on the aircraft carrier Lexington, killing him and four others, the ship's captain said today.

title: Shuttle Crew Completes a Practice Launching
description: A team of five astronauts successfully concluded a practice countdown today for a November launching of the space shuttle Discovery on a secret military mission.

title: El Paso Natural Gas Appoints a New Chief
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company, a leading natural gas transmission concern, has named William A. Wise as chief executive.

title: Piniella and Quinn Meet About Reds Job
description: Lou Piniella, the former Yankee outfielder and manager, said last night that he had met earlier in the day in Ohio with Bob Quinn, the Cincinnati general manager, about the Reds' managerial vacancy. ''The Reds have permission to talk to me, and I met with Quinn today,'' Piniella said after returing to his Allendale, N.J. home, ''All I can say is I'm one of their candidates.''

title: Dollar Takes Its Cue From Stocks
description: Something different is happening in the foreign exchange market. In a reversal of the recent pattern, the dollar is being led around by the stock market.

title: Mitsubishi Estate a Force In Japanese Real Estate
description: When the brokers and investment bankers representing the Rockefeller Group went looking for a buyer with the cachet to match that of their prestigious client, they did not have to look far.

title: Short of Cash, Kremlin Weighs A Soviet Version of the Sin Tax
description: Venturing into the dangerous political terrain of consumer prices, the Soviet Finance Minister called today for an immediate increase in the prices of cigarettes, beer and delicacies.

title: Careers; Panel Weighs Methods on Family Leave
description: THE issue of parental leave, now more broadly described as family leave, is high on the agenda of women's groups, unions and some state legislators.

title: Miller to Market Non-Alcohol Beer
description: In another sign of sluggish sales for the beer industry, the Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee said it plans to sell a beer-flavored alcohol-free beverage. The nation's No. 2 brewer, after the Anheuser-Busch Companies, said it would begin selling the drink, Miller Sharp's, on Jan. 1.

title: Two Plead Not Guilty In Shooting of Officers
description: Two brothers pleaded not guilty today to the attempted murder of two Essex County police officers who wandered into what authorities said was a drug-related shootout.

title: Peru Plans Silver Stockpile
description: In a move that could restrict world silver supplies, Peru said Sunday that it would stockpile silver to help local mining companies through economic doldrums. The Government's Central

title: Chess
description: On Oct. 22, the world champion, Gary Kasparov, showed his overpowering machine-eating style against the computer Deep Thought. Thursday night the 26-year-old Soviet star showed his man-eating style against 15-year-old Gata Kamsky, who defected to the United States in March from the Soviet Union.

title: The Spanish Victory: A Mandate for the Socialists
description: After a tightly fought election in which business executives and bankers sided openly with the governing Socialist Party, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has won a mandate to continue modernizing Spain's economy in preparation for the creation of a single European market after 1992.

title: Giants Toughen Up in 2d Half and Jolt Vikings
description: For almost the first 34 minutes of the game tonight, the Minnesota Vikings outclassed the Giants in every department. Then, in the third quarter, the Giants' defense and kickoff team exploded with three big plays, and the Giants rolled to a 24-14 victory. It did not come cheaply. Phil Simms, the Giants' starting quarterback, lasted only six plays before he was sacked by Al Noga and knocked out of the game with a sprained right ankle. The injury did not appear serious, and Simms was able to drive his car home.

title: Human Rights Group Is Active in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Beathard Is the Man Jets Need
description: If the Jets lose in New England next Sunday for a 1-8 record, they will have sunk to the depths of the worst start in their 30-year history. But even if they somehow were to avert that embarrassment, it's time for the Jets' owner, Leon Hess, to acknowledge that three heads are not better than one.

title: Move Gives Trusts More Flexibility
description: The history of the Rockefeller family is the history of the word ''trust.''

title: Cambodians Flee New Terror: Quake
description: When the ground began to heave on Oct. 17, many Cambodian refugees here did not know it was an earthquake.

title: Reports of Needle Attacks on West Side Rise to 23
description: Sixteen additional women have reported that a group of teen-age girls struck them from behind with a needle or pin on walks last week on the Upper West Side, the police said yesterday.

title: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers awaited reports on economic activity in October.

title: Books of The Times; Pleasures and Hazards of Familial Love
description: Ordinary Love & Good Will By Jane Smiley 197 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Environmentalists Favor Revised City Charter
description: To the Editor:

title: As Oratory Fades, Obstacles to Chemical Arms Pact Multiply
description: One month after President Bush proposed from a United Nations podium that the United States and Soviet Union begin to slash their stockpiles of poison gas, his initiative has run into political and technological obstacles.

title: One Top Soviet Editor Backs Another's Ouster
description: The new editor of Pravda today defended President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to oust the editor of Argumenty i Fakty, the country's most popular paper, saying that any editor who is a Communist must answer to the party even if his publication is ostensibly independent.

title: Y.&R. Ordered To Pay Midler
description: A Federal court jury today ordered Young & Rubicam Inc. to pay $400,000 to Bette Midler for using an imitation of the singer's voice in a commercial for the Ford Motor Company.

title: Yugoslav Police Break Up Protest in Trial of Albanians
description: Using tear gas and clubs, the police today dispersed 1,000 demonstrators of Albanian descent who were protesting the trial of the former Communist Party chief of Kosovo, a southern Yugoslav province troubled for years by ethnic violence.

title: Boeing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated for 1989 3-for-2 stock split.

title: The Trident Boondoggle
description: A common-sense pillar of U.S. strategic policy over the years has been that our nuclear weapons planning and arms control goals should be consistent. In that respect, the Trident submarine program is a bafflement. By pursuing it full bore, we are ignoring our goals for a strategic arms agreement and committing to buying billion-dollar submarines that we may be forced to dismantle in a few years.

title: Printers Plan To Combine
description: Quebecor Inc. of Montreal and the Maxwell Communication Corporation of Britain said today that they would merge their printing businesses in Canada and the United States to form North America's second-largest printer.

title: Dangerous Delusions: When Fans Are a Threat
description: INTENSE public attention on the lives of the famous is leading an increasing number of mentally disordered people to place celebrities at the center of delusions that can lead to harassment and occasionally to violence, psychiatrists say.

title: Reviews/Dance; On the Thread of Memory, A String of Fanciful Dances
description: For the final premiere of their season, Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis have jointly choreographed a single work, ''Segue.''

title: Kemper Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $6.4 million due to reinsurance costs from hurricane Hugo. c-After income of $77,820,000, or $1.49 a share, from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $6,189,000 for the quarter and income of $4,429,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: On Front Line of Drug War, U.S.-Built Base Lags in Peru
description: The sandbagged bunkers and lookout towers of this American-built base rise in the heart of a broad valley with the greatest concentration of coca plants in the world, roamed by heavily armed drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas.

title: Critic's Notebook; Thomas Jefferson, From Statesman to Tchotchke
description: Monticello is one of the great works of American architecture, and one of the nation's most revered historical shrines. Thomas Jefferson's home in Charlottesville is also a place in which you can buy earrings, glassware, key rings, jigsaw puzzles, T-shirts, plates, pillows, mugs, scarfs, bookends, neckties, cuff links, wastebaskets, candlesticks, silverware, place mats, cassette tapes, tote bags and cookie molds.

title: Treasury Offers Proposals Aimed at Drug Laundering
description: The Treasury Department yesterday disclosed the range of the new guidelines it is reviewing to regulate the electronic transfer of vast sums of money among banks around the world.

title: Kean's Popularity Is Little Help to Courter
description: The popularity of New Jersey's best-known Republican, Gov. Thomas H. Kean, has been of little help this fall to his own party and its candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter.

title: New Whooping Cough Vaccine Under Study
description: An Italian scientist says he has discovered a new vaccine for whooping cough that does not have the side effects of the vaccine now used.

title: Nora Levin, Historian, 73
description: Nora Levin, founder of the Holocaust Oral History Archive at Gratz College and author of ''The Holocaust: The Destruction of European Jewry, 1933-1945,'' died of cancer on Thursday at American Oncological Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 73 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Flag Burning Brings Out the Worst in Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Evert Opts Out
description: Despite her five victories without a defeat in the recent Federation Cup in Japan, Chris Evert has decided not to compete in the $1 million Virginia Slims Championships at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 13-19. She qualified for the season-ending tournament, as she has every year since the event's inception in 1983.

title: Cross & Trecker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring charge of $25 million taken in the third quarter and related essentially to a major restructuring program. Also included the realization of a foreign translation gain of $3.6 million, or 29 cents a share, resulting from the sale of Cross & Trecker's equity in a Japanese joint venture for both the quarter and year. c-Included a restructuring charge of $2.1 million for both the quarter and year.

title: Secret Heart of 'The Wizard of Oz' Unlocked; Kansas, Be Proud
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Mitsubishi Estate bought 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, which owns Rockefeller Center, the Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, for $846 million in cash. [ Page A1. ] The Rockefeller Group quickly turned to Mitsubishi Estate when it sought a prestigious buyer. [ D7. ] Four generations totaling 88 people derive the benefits of the trusts that control one of the world's legendary fortunes. [ D7. ] Eastern Airlines' unsecured creditors are close to backing management's ambitious plan to rebuild the bankrupt carrier. That support for management comes despite the considerable risks that the creditors' advisers found in the management plan. [ D1. ] Hyundai has hit a rough patch, just three years after its successful introduction of its subcompact car in the U.S. [ D1. ] Revco, the pharmacy chain, received a $925 million buyout offer 10 days ago from the Bass Group and Acadia Partners. [ D4. ] Lee Iacocca says Chrysler expects to close at least one assembly plant, to delay products and to lay off some white-collar workers, according to Automotive News. [ D5. ] The New York Times and most independent dealers who deliver it in the New York area settled their dispute. [ D21. ] An investor group proposed to buy The Detroit Free Press from Knight-Ridder for $68 million. [ D20. ] MARKETS Merrill Lynch will abandon its business in index arbitrage, the best-known form of program trading. The nation's largest retail brokerage firm is but the latest Wall Street house to react to a recent wave of bitter opposition to the practice. [ D1. ] Something different is happening in the foreign exchange market. In a reversal of the recent pattern, the dollar is being led around by the stock market. [ D1. ] The dollar was mixed against the leading foreign currencies, while the pound advanced for the first time since last week's political upheaval in London. Gold prices slipped after rising overseas. [ D18. ] Stocks stabilized after a bad week, ending narrowly mixed, as the Dow industrials gained 6.76, to 2,603.48. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading. [ D17. ] Copper futures prices fell sharply on the New York Commodity Exchange, extending the market's two-week-old slide. [ D18. ] THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court agreed to review a case that could affect the solvency of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the troubled Federal agency that Congress set up 15 years ago to guarantee the security of employee pensions. The case involves a pension agreement between LTV and the steelworkers' union. [ D1. ] The Treasury disclosed guidelines on money transfers that it is reviewing in its effort to monitor the flow of cash among world banks, part of its attempt to crack down on drug financing. [ D1. ] The S.E.C. has put tight limits on John S. R. Shad's contacts with the agency, which he used to head. Mr. Shad is now chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert. [ D2. ] The Financial Accounting Foundation voted to require government-owned utilities, hospitals, colleges and universities to base their accounting decisions on standards set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board and not from the Governmental Accounting Standards Board. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Another huge merger of accounting firms is unlikely, says Larry D. Horner of KPMG Peat Marwick. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Far from being scared by market volatility, small investors seem to see it as an opportunity. Some mutual fund managers say there was a net flow of cash into funds in October. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D10. ] Hasbro has planned a $6 million campaign for its toy cars, called Record Breakers. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Margaret L. Alsina
description: Margaret Lowenthal Alsina, a retired language teacher at the Allendale Columbia School in Rochester, died of a heart attack on Oct. 21 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. She was 66 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: Topics of The Times; Public Service, New and Old
description: Young lawyers and law graduates who choose careers in public service can expect to earn only a fraction of the wages of those who serve private clients. Some law schools and law firms have begun to recognize the need to address the growing pay gap through such measures as student loan forgiveness programs. A welcome addition to this trend is the Harvard Law School's new Judge Irving R. Kaufman Public Service Fellowship program.

title: Nynex's Debt Under Review
description: The debt rating of the Nynex Corporation and related entities has been placed under review for possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday. The review affects about $7.7 billion in outstanding debt.

title: Weisfield's Is Sold
description: Ratners Group P.L.C. agreed to acquire the American specialty jewelry retailer Weisfield's Inc. for $50 a share, or $55 million. Weisfield's operates 87 stores in nine states. Weisfield's stock jumped $14, to $53, in over-the-counter trading. Its 35.9 percent increase was the best of the day.

title: Justice Dept. Approves Timing of Vote on New York Charter
description: The Justice Department yesterday gave its approval to the timing of the referendum next week on the revised New York City Charter. But the department also said it was unlikely that the agency would complete its review of the substance of the proposal by Election Day.

title: American Family Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenues reflect adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement 97, in which realized investment gains before taxes are included in revenues.

title: Talking Business with Horner of KPMG Peat Marwick; Merger Outlook For Accountants
description: With merger activity in the accounting profession subsiding, KPMG Peat Marwick remains the world leader with roughly $4.3 billion in revenues for its 1989 fiscal year. Larry D. Horner, KPMG's 55-year-old chairman, was the first to take the plunge almost three years ago when the firm he headed, Peat Marwick Mitchell, paired off with Dutch-based KMG Main Hurdman to expand its reach overseas. In an interview earlier this month, he reflected on the upheaval of the last few months. Q. Will there be more mergers ahead? A. It'll partly be dictated by the success of the current ones. Coopers & Lybrand has no interest in mergers, and we certainly have no interest in a mega-merger. That leaves Price Waterhouse and Arthur Andersen. I doubt that you'll see another mega-merger. Q. Of the two deals on the table - Ernst & Whinney's merger with Arthur Young, and the Deloitte Haskins & Sells-Touche Ross merger - which will be tougher to pull off? A. Neither one is going to be easy. I would guess Ernst and Young have an easier time. They seem to be further down the road internationally. Q. As you know, Deloitte's British and Dutch affiliates have rejected the merger. How serious a threat is this to the merger ? A. If you follow the basic premise that you go into these mergers to develop a greater global presence and then you begin to lose operations outside of the U.S., you begin to undermine the strategy. I think we have done a better job. We had $2.5 billion in combined revenues starting out in our merger. I think we lost less than $50 million of that. Q. The Securities and Exchange Commission restricts accounting firms from entering into joint ventures or subcontracting with audit clients. Are the restrictions justified, and if not, how would you amend them? A. Independence is very important in audits, but I tend to think its impact on consulting activity has been overplayed. I don't know of any instances where such relationships have led to a bad audit. Therefore loosening the rules would make a great deal of sense. Probably, a materiality test is the way to do it. In the case of the largest accounting firms, if the joint venture were worth several hundred million dollars, it could be material. If it were only worth $25 million, it might not be material. Q. Does it concern you that McKinsey & Company is close to buying the Information Consulting Group, the boutique founded by defectors from Andersen Consulting? A. If they really did it and did it well, it would make them a very strong competitor in information technology. I look at it as a possibly even greater competitor than Andersen. Q. Britain is considering allowing accounting firms to sell up to a 25 percent stake to outsiders. Would KPMG be interested in raising outside funds if the proposal goes forward? A. KPMG was against that. We had not felt it appropriate to have outside shareholders. Our fear is it's hard to control. You begin to get outside shareholders who are not accountants, and that can raise independence issues. Let's say an investment bank ends up owning you that does all sorts of underwriting. The conflicts can become severe. Q. The S.E.C. put sanctions on Peat Marwick in the 1970's because of some bad audits. What do you do today differently as a result, and how do you explain the recent lapses you have had on the audit side of your practice? A. Those weren't Peat Marwick lapses. Wedtech came from Main Hurdman. Sahlen came from Main Hurdman. Crazy Eddie came from Main Hurdman. Regina was ours. I don't think we have any more problems than our competitors. Statistically, you will always get a certain number that go up in smoke. To some extent it reflects the litigious environment in which we work and the complexity of the business environment. Q. What do you see as your firm's competitive advantages? A. Our global capabilities really are unmatched. Frankly, I'm glad we are the biggest, but that could change tomorrow morning. Price Waterhouse and Andersen could come together again. And obviously our competition must think that we have a competitive advantage or they wouldn't be attempting to merge.

title: 4 Are Held in Burning Of 3 Flags to Test Law
description: Four people shouting ''Burn, baby, burn'' set fire today to three American flags on the steps of the Capitol in an attempt to test the constitutionality of a new Federal law banning flag desecration.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Exercised the option on the contract of Tom Foley, infielder, for 1990. TORONTO (AL) - Exercised the option on the contract of George Bell, outfielder, for 1990. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Elected August A. Busch 3d chairman of the board, Fred L. Kuhlmann president and chief executive officer, and Mark Sauer executive vice-president and chief operating officer. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Waived Fennis Dembo, forward. KNICKS (NBA) - Waived Tony Karasek, guard. SEATTLE (NBA) - Waived Andrew Gaze, guard-forward, and Mike Champion, forward. FOOTBALL PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Released Luis Zendejas, place-kicker. Signed Steve DeLine, place-kicker. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE -Fined Troy Mallette, Rangers center, $500 for his actions during a fight in a game on Oct. 28. DETROIT (NHL) - Recalled Rob Schena, defenseman, from Phoenix of the International Hockey League. MONTREAL (NHL) - Recalled Ed Cristofoli, left wing, from Sherbrooke of the American Hockey League. QUEBEC (NHL) - Suspended Jeff Brown, defenseman.

title: Israel Spira, 99, Leader of Bluzhov Hasidim
description: Rabbi Israel Spira, who as the Grand Rabbi of Bluzhov was the spiritual leader of a Hasidic branch in Brooklyn and Israel, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 99 years old and lived in Brooklyn's Borough Park section, where his synagogue was situated.

title: Kateb Yacine, Novelist And Poet, Is Dead at 60
description: Kateb Yacine, a leading Algerian novelist, poet and playwright, died of leukemia on Saturday in Grenoble, France. He was 60 years old.

title: Hercules Analyzes Unit
description: Hercules Inc. said today that it was assessing the future of the Aircraft and Electronic Products part of its Hercules Aerospace Company as part of its shift in strategic direction. Hercules said it engaged the First Boston Corporation to analyze the business and help determine the best course of action. No timetable was given for completing the evaluation. The unit makes advanced systems, subsystems and components for commercial and military planes and electronic warfare systems for military use. It has annual revenues of about $275 million and employs more than 3,500 workers.

title: A's Earn Record $117,580.29 Shares
description: None of the eligible members of the champion Oakland Athletics were among the 18 first-day filers for free agency yesterday, but they became wealthier anyway, gaining a record winning share from the World Series.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about a piano recital by Norman Krieger at Alice Tully Hall misidentified a composer on the program. He is Lowell Liebermann.

title: Pactel's Damage Is Over $40 Million
description: Pacific Telesis Group, one of the nation's seven regional telephone companies, said that the Oct. 17 earthquake in nothern California had caused $40 million to $50 million in damage to its buildings and network facilities. Pactel, based in San Francisco, said most of the damage would be covered by a $150 million earthquake insurance policy that it carries. The policy has a $10 million deductible.

title: Shun 'Backwater of Oppression,' Nixon Tells China
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon urged China today not to sink into a ''backwater of oppression and stagnation'' and called on both the United States and China to strive for cooperation to overcome the present bitterness in their relationship.

title: Atoms Bound Together by Light
description: RESEARCHERS at Harvard University and the Rowland Institute, a private research center in Cambridge, Mass., have discovered a way light can bind matter into molecules. The scientists formed the ''optical molecules'' by using a previously unknown interaction detected accidentally while conducting other experiments.

title: Drexel Head Limited On S.E.C. Dealings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subjected John S.R. Shad, its former chairman and now the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, to tight limits on his dealings with the agency.

title: Our Towns; A Cancer Scare Adds to Sparkle Of Bottled Water
description: The A.&P. on Lincoln Avenue in Glen Rock is just across the highway from the town of Hawthorne, and it is where most of the people in Hawthorne do their grocery shopping. Bill Halliwell has worked at the A.&P. for eight years, and he has seen the demand for bottled water skyrocket.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Revco D.S. Inc., the bankrupt pharmacy chain, received a $925 million buyout offer 10 days ago from the Robert M. Bass Group and Acadia Partners.

title: New York to Drop Ban On Private AIDS Tests
description: New York, the only state to prohibit testing for the AIDS virus by commercial laboratories, said today that it would lift the ban.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Oct. 14 about the nation's 10 largest guard companies misidentified the fifth-largest. It is American Protective Services Inc.

title: U.S.-Soviet Citizen Forum: Fewer Rifts Now
description: Soviet and American citizens celebrated the improvement in relations between their two nations today as they met here for their fifth annual exercise in people-to-people diplomacy. But the occasion was marred by American concern about a Soviet editor who was not allowed to attend.

title: 6 Detained Americans Freed by Mozambique
description: Six American members of a missionary medical team seized by soldiers last week were released today, United States officials said.

title: Toy Cars Are Getting A Big Push
description: THERE'S a commotion down in Al Carosi's basement. It's coming from Derek, who is 13 years old, and Brendan, 9. As their father, Mr. Carosi wants them to pipe down. But as the senior vice president for marketing at Hasbro Inc., the nation's largest toymaker, Mr. Carosi is glad to hear it.

title: Washington Talk; Above the Dirt Arena, Bush Keeps the Score
description: People close to the President know from the 1988 campaign, if not before, that when the occasion merits he has a taste for what he likes to call red-meat lines. And at times in recent weeks, they have urged him to leave the cozy bipartisanship with which he has draped the Oval Office and indulge.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Gets TV Guide Account
description: Wieden & Kennedy, a small agency in Portland, Ore., with a lofty creative reputation, yesterday won the trade advertising account of TV Guide. The account had been at N. W. Ayer for 26 years, but the magazine and agency parted company last week because, in the words of Joseph W. Cece, the president of TV Guide, ''We were not on the same wavelength.''

title: Louise S. Hay, Professor, 54
description: Louise Schmir Hay, chairman of the mathematics department at the University of Illinois at Chicago, died of cancer Saturday at West Suburban Hospital in Oak Park, Ill. She was 54 years old and lived in Oak Park.

title: John M. Ketteringham, 49, Executive, Dies
description: John M. Ketteringham, an executive with Arthur D. Little Inc., died of cancer Friday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 49 years old.

title: Enron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $24.1 million from the sale of Mobil Corp. stock for the quarter, and an extraordinary credit of $200,000 associated with the retirement of debt for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-Included an after-tax gain of $9.7 million from the sale of Mobil Corp. stock for the quarter, and extraordinary losses of $3.2 million for the quarter and $18.5 million for the 9 months, both associated with the retirement of debt.

title: White House to Limit Job Screening
description: The Bush Administration will not use anti-abortion views as a test for screening job candidates except for people being considered for the Government's top health policy jobs, the White House said today.

title: Times Are Tough For U.S. Runners
description: Another marathon came and went over the weekend, this one in Chicago, and it has still been more than five years since an American has finished a race of that distance under 2 hours 10 minutes.
